column2: Moliere's masterpiece, "The Misanthrope," in a new translation by Elsie Elizabeth Duncan-Jones, opened for the short season at the Ambassadors tonight. She made no effort to temper Moliere's satire to present-day susceptibilities, but the critics found no sense of chill in Celimene's jilting of Alceste.

Emil Spaiser, 39, applied to Police Sergeant Daniel Ahearn for a warrant to help him get a night's sleep. "I bunk with my brother, Otto," Spaiser said. "He takes up threequarters of the bed. I nudged him to move over this morning and he gave me a larruping."

The Ontario Court of Appeals upheld today a Supreme Court ruling that the $500,000 "baby derby" clause in Charles Vance Millar's will was valid. It also upheld the decision of Justice W. E. Middleton that illegitimate children could not be counted as entrants.

Mrs. Willard Henry Johnstone and her daughter, Miss Mary D. Sage, gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 812 Park Avenue, for members of the junior committee and the floor committee who are working toward the success of the "Night in Bagdad Dinner Dance" to be held March 4 at the Ambassador for the benefit of the relief fund of the Red Cross.

With New York's traffic moving smoothly under the first real test of the new Traffic Code, Mayor La Guardia summoned thirty business leaders and city officials to a conference at City Hall yesterday in an effort to cope with parking and other remaining traffic problems.

The Provincial Government received its second rebuff in a week today when Justice W. C. Ives of the Alberta Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional its legislation cutting interest on Provincial bonds, savings certificates and guaranteed securities.
General Motors and United Automobile Workers of America representatives pressed toward agreement on seniority problems tonight.

The home of Edgar Allan Poe was advertised for sale today by the Sheriff to satisfy an $8,000 mortgage. The three-story brick building where Poe lived from 1842 to 1844 and where he wrote several of his best known works, was restored in 1933 by Richard Gimbel and turned over to the Poe Society.

The New York Americans' hopes of gaining a playoff berth in the international division, National Hockey League, became almost invisible tonight when they were overhauled and defeated, 5-2, by the Bruins before a crowd of 10,000 at the Boston Garden.
The possibility of James J. Braddock having his world's heavyweight title declared vacated loomed yesterday as developments in the involved situation surrounding the title experienced a lull.

the Rev. John M. Chmielinski, dean of the Polish priests of the Catholic Church in this country, died today at the priest's home of the Church of our Lady of Czestochova here. He was 70 years old and had been ill for several, years.

Charles F. Glore, president of the Chicago Corporation, was re-elected a director with other members of the board today at a meeting of stockholders which was marked by a running fire of criticism of the management.

For what was said to be the first time in this State, an employer went on trial yesterday in the Queens County Court on a charge of being equally guilty with his employee in a motor vehicle fatality in which it was alleged the vehicle was defective.

Leases of space to firms in the clothing and allied trades formed a major part of the commercial rentals reported by brokers in Manhattan yesterday. Many concerns contracted for quarters on Broadway. The list follows:
Rose Bampton will make her first appearance this season in the role of Laura in "La Gioconda" at the Metropolitan Opera House. Miss Bampton replaces Anna Kaskas, who is ill.

Dealings in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday were strongly influenced by the weakness in stock prices. Although high-grade issues were steady, speculative bonds, especially those carrying conversion or option privileges, were hard hit.

The 3,000-meter steeplechase event which has been something of a walkover for Joe McCluskey for almost six years, promises to be one of the features of the national A. A. U. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

The grand jury today presented Harry Cohen, American Federation of Labor organizer in the recent taxicab drivers' strike here, on a bench warrant charge of inciting riot and disorder laid against him by Judge Eugene O'Dunne.

The benefit hockey match between the New York Rangers and Toronto Maple Leafs, played last night at Madison Square Garden, was followed by an "after-the-game party" in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

Henry M. Rynehart, a realty operator with offices at 215 Montague Street, Brooklyn, and a prominent figure in Masonic and club circles, died on Monday at his home, 3,702 Avenue J, in his sixtyfourth year. Mr. Rynehart was the founder of the Midwood Masonic Temple and the first Master of Midwood Lodge F. and A. M.

The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld an order of Governor Fred P. Cone revoking suspension of Mayor ?? E. Armstrong and other city officials of Daytona Beach who were ousted by his predecessor, Dave, Sholtz. .

Representative Raymond J. Cannon of Wisconsin, who tried to unionize baseball players seventeen years ago, is considering another attempt. He said today he might introduce legislation which would have the effect of unionization.

A tale of alleged terrorism was told today by a member of the United Automobile Workers to the La Follette committee investigating labor espionage and two organizers for the union declared they had been forced to leave the Fisher body plant in Baltimore by hostile nonunion workers. The plant reopened today.

With the metropolitan basketball championship at stake, Manhattan and Long Island University quintets will clash in Madison Square Garden tonight in the feature of the eleventh college double-header while DePaul University of Chicago, Olympic tryout finalist a year ago, meets St. John's in the other game.

The preliminary report of the Federal Water Service Corporation and its subsidiaries, exclusive of the. Southern Natural Gas Company, for 1936 shows a net income after all charges of $1,034,039, compared with a net of $491,494 in 1935, a gain of approximately 110 per cent.
Mr. and Mrs. Rowland Hazar gave a dinner last night in th Trianon Room of the Ambassadc for Mr. and Mrs. W. Hallam Tuc of Brussels, Belgium, who are visi ing in this country.

Manhattan's junior varsity and freshman basketball teams were successful in a double-header at the Manhattan gymnasium last night. The jayvees defeated the Good Shepherd A. C. of Kingsbridge, 32 to 23, while the cubs beat Newark Prep, 47 to 31.

ABBOT--On Tuesday, Feb. 23, Alice Balch, daughter of the late Abiel and Alice Abbot, at her residence, 134 Tysen St., New Brighton, S. I. Services private. BARDES-Feb. 22, at her home, 32 Watkins Place, New Rochelle N. Y., Berthe, mother of Charles and Peter and Mrs. Caroline Meyer, and sister of Leon Mundel. Services at the Geo. T. Davis Memoral, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle, Wednesday, 9 P. M.

After several months of inactivity, the special grand jury in the Samuel Drukman murder case unexpectedly handed up perjury indictments yesterday against William W. Kleinman, the former Kings County Assistant District Attorney, and Louis Luckman, a nephew of one of the convicted murderers of Drukman.

Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old-age pensions advocate and founder of the Townsend plan, went on trial before a jury in Federal District Court here today on charges of contempt of the House of Representatives.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Feb. 17, shows increases for the week of $34,000,000 in total loans and investments, $52,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $85,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $90,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, and a decrease of $51,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

An increase of 10 per cent in all hourly rates of pay at the Edgewater, N. J., plant of the Aluminum Company of America was announced yesterday at the same time that word came from the general offices in Pittsburgh of plant extensions that ultimately may represent an outlay of $1,000,000 .
John M. Barringer, City Manager of this recent General Motors strike center, was removed from office tonight by a 5-to-3 vote of the City Commissin.
Two favorites turned in inferior showings today in the National Field Trials, the world series of bird dogdom, apparently leaving claim to the championship wide open.

Abutting business buildings, at 242-250 West Fifty-fifth Street and 247-259 West Fifty-fourth Street, the former of twelve stories and the latter of eight stories in height, were sold in a block yesterday at auction by Thomas F. Burchill. The action was brought by the Bank for Savings, to satisfy a judgment of about $800,721, and taxes and other liens of $18,000, against the Nonkwah Realty Corporation.

Dr. John Bain (Jock) Sutherland scoffed tonight at reports that he would resign as head football coach at the University of Pittsburgh. "There are a lot of persons," he said in an interview, "that seem to know more about the situation than I do.

Aurel Toma, 119, prominent European bantamweight, registered an impressive ten-round victory over Henry Hook, 122, of Indianapolis in the feature bout at the Broadway Arena before 2,000 spectators last night.

Stockholders of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois at their annual meeting today approved a plan to issue under a first lien and refunding mortgage a new series of bonds not to exceed $80,000,000.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. appeared in a reminiscent mood last night in telling of the many changes of the last forty years at an anniversary dinner of the Men's Class of the Riverside Church.

The Walgreen Company of Chicago filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 100,000 shares of $100 par value 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock with common stock purchase warrants attached and 100,000 shares of nopar-value common stock to be received for issuance upon exercise of the warrants.

Fred C. Moffatt, president of the New York Curb Exchange, will sail this afternoon on the French liner Champlain for a cruise in the Mediterranean, accompanied by Mrs. Moffatt. From Marseilles Mr. Moffatt expects to motor to Paris and the World War battlefields, where he served with the Army Signal Corps.

The committee on student organizations at Columbia University has been empowered by the university council to demand a prospectus from every campus organization not falling within the scope of King's Crown, regular supervisory body of extra-curricular activities, and to grant privileges accordingly, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of Columbia, disclosed yesterday.

Larry Kelley, Yale all-American football star, disclosed tonight he had definitely turned down all offers to become a professional to accept a teaching position at the Peddie School, Hightstown, N. J. Kelley told the minute men of St. James

Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN-George Sturerhof, 17th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 3, 1908. Transfers and Assignments CAPTAIN-Duncan Cameron, 47th Preclnct to 48th Precinct.

Benjamin Delvalle Fidanque, an importer and exporter in this city since 1901, died last night at his home, 285 Central Park West, at the age of 74. Mr. Fidanque, who was born in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, was descended from Spanish Jews who fled to Holland from the Inquisition in the sixteenth century.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Capt. Ralph A. Dutton, Sig.-Res., 1,636 W. Colvin St., Syracuse, N. Y., Corps Area Service Command, is ordered to active duty, March 16. He will proceed to the Signal Corps School, Fort Monmouth, N. J., for the purpose of pursuing the course for National Guard and Reserve officers.

Frank. V. Kelly, Brooklyn Democratic leader, admitted yesterday that the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland, a suretY Concerpn,'had offered him the post of resident vice president. He refused to-discuss the offer but said that he might make an announcement in' a few ays.

Governor Hoffman accepted today gn invitation extended by the Northern New Jersey Council of the Committee for Industrial Organization to debate the sit-down strike, but Julius Emspak, chairman of the council, who had suggested the debate, declared tonight that the Governor's definition of the question amounted to a refusal to debate.

The 127th annual report of the New York Bible Society, out yesterday, showed that 899,528 whole Bibles, testaments and single books of the Scriptures have been issued by this agency either as gifts or by sale to those who could afford to pay. In New York City they were in eighty-three different languages.

On an unheralded visit today to his friends, the Count and countess Paul Muenster, the Duke of Windsor poked about old Muenster Castle, deep in the Karawanken Mountains, and played golf by the Woerthersee.

An army of 3,000 Ethiopians who had planned to attack Addis Ababa, former capital of Ethiopia, during the confusion following the expected assassination of Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, the Italian Viceroy, was virtually annihilated Saturday, it was revealed today.

United States road engineers began the construction of three bridges today. The bridges will be on the Pan-American Highway linking the United States and Panama. The cost will be paid partly by the American Government and partly by Nicaragua.

Despite the fewer business days, occasioned by the observance of Lincoln's Birthday, commercial and industrial business failures in the United States in the week ended Feb. 18, numbering 203, advanced to the highest level since May 14, 1936, when the total was 206, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Colonel and Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim gave a dinner tonight for a company of twenty in their home on Woodland Drive.
In this South Georgia community on the banks of the Ogeechee River, Henry Ford will carry to fruition his dream of an ideal industrial community surrounded by farms. able to sustain it.

The question whether brawn or brains is the more important- attribute of a fireman seemed pretty well decided in favor of brawn at the end of a hearing called yesterday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to sound out public opinion on the issue.
A sit-down strike, affecting an estimated 600 pressmen, curtailed printing operations at the Crowell Publishing Company plant here today. The company employs 4,000.

The untimely death of the efficient and overworked chairman of the House Committee on Appropriations, Representative Buchanan of Texas, and the succession of Representative Taylor of Colorado, bring into notice the fact that the Democratic leadership in Congress is gradually becoming desectionalized.
The steady rise of the Seine River menaced the environs of Paris tonight and danger of the Winter's second flood siege grew acute elsewhere in the nation.

The American Lunbermen's Mutual Casualty Company of Illinois reported yesterday earnings in 1936 of $5,248,372, a gain of $1,244,934 over 1935. Assets rose $4,018,905, to $26,630,204. Premium income reached a new high record, $22,219,615, against $20,343,475 for 1935.

Mrs. Annie Gray Sheridan, member of an old Brooklyn family, died on Monday at her home, 294 Adelphi Street. Her age was 91. She was the daughter of the late Edward Gray. She was the widow of Theodore W. Sheridan, who operated a bookbindery machine company in Manhattan, which was founded by his father in 1835.

Charge by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association that employment had been refused its members on ships of the Black Diamond Line because of their participation in the recent marine strike in Atlantic and Gulf ports were heard yesterday by the Labor Relations Board, 45 Bnoadway.

While not holding out hopes for an early peace in Spain, Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos declared in the Senate today that the chances for a settlement now were immensely larger than they had been, since all the outside powers had stopped blowing on the fire.

Captain Royal G. Cornish, master of the American Export cargo-passenger steamship Executive, docked in Jersey City, died suddenly yesterday, probably of a heart attack. at Broad Street Hospital here shortly after being taken ill in a taxicab. His age was 54.
The government will be questioned on the possibility of the Dominions' contributing to the Civil List, which provides for the upkeep of 01 the Royal Family.

The Metropolitan Water District of Los Angeles, Calif., has invited bids, to be opened on March 19, on $29,132,000 of bonds. The bonds, on which the bidders are to name the rate of interest at not to exceed 5 per cent, will mature serially from 1952 to 1987.
Riker Co., Inc., negotiated the lease of the Castleholm Restaurant, Inc., in the Pare Vendome Apartments, 340 West 57th St.
Automobile accidents, deaths and injuries again increased last week as compared with the corresponding period of 1936, it was announced yesterday by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.

The funeral of Miss Helen P. McCormick, social worker and lawyer, who died Sunday in the Brooklyn Hospital, will be held this morning. The cortege will proceed from the Big Sisters House, 338 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, the shelter maintained by the Catholic Big Sisters, which she founded, to Queen of All Saints Church, Lafayette and Vanderbilt Avenues, where a requiem mass will be sung at 10 o'clock, with the Most Rev. Raymond A.

A high official of the National Coffee Department said today that the Santos coffee market, in which there was much speculation recently, was moving toward a normal condition. He said that the Federal Government and that of the State of Sao Paulo held the same point of view and both were doing their utmost to find a solution to the situation and end the crisis.

The Congregation of Rites today admitted the cause for beatification and canonization of Vitale Justine Grandin, first Bishop of Edmonton, who died in 1902. Bishop Grandin was a pioneer missionary of the Canadian Northwest. In 1854, as Father Grandin, he was sent to Lake Athabasca,
Assurances that the House will approve his program to reform the judiciary were transmitted to President Roosevelt today by a group of House leaders who called to discuss the legislative situation.

Nearly 1,000 officials of the highway departments of eleven States and the District of Columbia and engineers engaged in the construction of roads attended the opening yesterday of the thirteenth annual convention of the Association of Highway Officials in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Liu Lu-yin, for a long time chief of the Kuomintang's publicity department, was arrested in the International-Settlement today and charged with plotting two political assassinations, those of Tang Yu-jen, Vice Minister for Foreign Affairs,
Marie Tempest, in one of the longest parts in her brilliant career, dominates the stage in "Retreat From Folly," which opened at the Queens Theatre tonight after a successful provincial tour.
Army's hockey team defeated Middlebury College today, 3 to 0. Hines scored for Army, unassisted, in the last minute of the first period, and the cadets added two more goals in the third.

The Senate line-up on President Roosevelt's proposal to add six members to the Supreme Court, if justices past 70 years of age do not retire, was unofficially put as follows today as the result of actual commitments, private advices of some Senators and the known or indicated leanings of others:
Motions by various defendants to dismiss a stockholder's accounting suit brought by Bella Gallup against

Another advance in cotton prices in Liverpool influenced fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and a steady demand for contracts pushed the list to the highest levels of the last three weeks.
President Roosevelt recommended to Congress the creation of a provisional Columbia River Authority to dispose of Bonneville power;

Cooperation of business men, engineers and architects in an effort to curb the growing competition of government agencies with private enterprise in the building industry was urged by R. H. Shreve of Shreve, Lamb Harmon and member of the board of design for

Miss Ruth Karin Justinius, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Wilhelm Justinius of this city, has chosen April 17 as the date for her wedding to Gunnard F. Wellner, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. F. Wellner, also of Bridgeport.

The posthumous award of a gold medal to A. W. Erickson, late chairman of the board of McCann-Erickson, Inc., for distinguished services to advertising," was announced last night at the 1936 Annual Advertising Awards Dinner held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Among those due today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa from Channel ports are the Countess Wachtmeister, H. Kenaston Twitchell, Mrs. Sosthenes Behn, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm, Colonel and Mrs. William H. Wynne Finch, and Edger Eyre, vice president of the Grace Steamship Lines.

The Treasury reported today that 76 per cent of the soldiers' bonus bonds have been redeemed in cash. As of Feb. 20, the Treasury said, $1,799,155,200 of adjusted service bonds have been issued and $81,801,289 paid veterans in checks for odd amounts.

Mrs. Mary E. F. Quinn Meighan, former secretary of the old New York Daily News and the widow of William J. C. Meighan, once city editor of The New York Herald, died on Tuesday of a heart ailment at her home, 327 West Fiftysixth Street. She had been ill several months. Her age was 75.
The Negro Melody Singers, under the direction of Juanita Hall, will give the first in a series of popularpriced concerts tonight at the WPA Theatre of Music.
The Dunkirk plant of the American Locomotive Company had new orders today for three complete oil refineries and two mammoth tunnel shields.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old-age pension advocate, was convicted today of contempt of the House of Representatives.
Pope Pius, still a very sick man, lay for several hours in the sunshine of his Vatican loggia today, too weak to receive the new Minister to the Vatican from El Salvador, Raoul Contreras.

Shareholders of the Blaw-Knox Company have been notified that their annual meeting on March 17 would consider approval of the company's new incentive-payment plan, according to a report to the New York Stock Exchange.

Henry Wineburgh of 784 Park Avenue, president of the United Advertising Corporation of Texas, with offices at 500 Fifth Avenue, died Tuesday in Phoenix, Ariz., according to an announcement made here last night.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,295,950 barrels daily, a new high record, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represented a gain of 9,900 barrels over the average of 3,286,050 in the previous week, the former high record.

Dr. and Mrs. William H. Hinkel of Tamaqua have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabelle Hinkel, to William Otis Johnson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Otis Johnson of Alexander City. Ala.

Importers here yesterday feared a revival in part of the supposedly dead NIRA as a result of a decision by the first division of the United States Customs Court, holding that special "fees" assessed under the Recovery Act against cotton rugs from Japan, are still in force and collectible.
A memorial concert in tribute to ossip Gabrilowitsch, pianist and conductor, was presented at Carnegie Hall last night before a large and responsive audience. The concert was sponsored by Mailamm.

Not long ago the "Big Four" railroad brotherhoods and the switchmen's union, representing a total membership of about 300,000 men, voted to ask for a 20 per cent wage increase. Now sixteen railway unions, representing a membership of about 800,000 "nonoperating" workers, have decided to ask for an increase of 20 cents an hour.

The Boston Bruins will furnish the opposition for Red Dutton's New York Americans at Madison d Square Garden tonight. The Spangled sextet, practically out the running for a play-off position in the. post-season race, nevertheless is unwilling to call it quits until the last slim mathematical chance in their favor is dissolved.

A plea that married school teachers are entitled to work for a living "without the penalty of economic death for motherhood" was put before the Supreme Court today in a petition begging the justices -to reconsider their refusal on Feb. 1 to review the case of Catharine Ulrich Kabatt against the Board of Education of Elmira, N. Y.
By another sweeping list of 900 promotions and 1,800 transfers, the present high command has strengthened its control of army adminlsration.

Recommendation that Congress enact the revised Guffey-Vinson Coal Bill to regulate the $1,000,000,000 bituminous industry was made today in a majority report of the House Ways and Means Committee. Unless the measure is passed, the report stated, the industry will return to "chaotic conditions."

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was only fair to slow. The lamb market was mostly 50c lower, with spots off $1. Other classes showed little change. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be about steady, veal weak, lamb lower.

On March 6 Australians will vote on two proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Constitution which, having passed Parliament, must be approved by popular referendum. Voting is compulsory, and those not voting are liable to fines.

Having clinched the Section 2 Brooklyn P. S. A. L. championship and taking things rather easily until the play-offs, the Abraham Lincoln quintet suffered its first setback in ten tournament engagements in losing to Erasmus Hall, 34--22, at Erasmus yesterday.
League for Political Education, the Town Hall. "My. Country and My People," Dr. Lin Yutang, 11 A. M.; "What Does Society Owe Youth?" Dr. Lyman Bryson and six young men and women, 8:45 P. M.
A Republican descendant of Alexander Hamilton today made a spectacular entry into the Assembly fight over ratification of the Federal child labor amendment.

Further pressure was brought to bear on most classes of bonds yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The heavy tone predominated in the face of a further drying up of trading interest as total transactions dwindled to $12,012,800, compared to $13,189,200 on Tuesday.

A bill to increase the daily license fee of the racing associations of New York State from $25 to $5,000 was introduced today by Assemblyman Harold P. Herman, Nassau Republican. Mr. Herman, an advocate of parimutuel betting, declared that the State would get as much as $1,000,000 a year by such an increase.
The Yale basketball team trounced Providence, 50-37, before 1,200 persons tonight at the Payne Whitney gymnasium for its fifth straight triumph.

The city's new sanitation 'patrol squad, exercising police powers in issuing summonses and making arrests, was inspected on duty yesterday by William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation, and found to be an effective force in educating offenders against municipal cleanliness.

The Commonwealth was balked today by Justice Maxey of the State Supreme Court in its efforts to send Stacey Gunderman, a State trooper, to the electric chair as- being responsible for the alleged "third degree" death of Frank C. Monaghan, Uniontown hotel keeper, in the Bertillon room of the Fayette County Court House last September.
William Freisenbruch defeated his younger brother Everett in the Princess Hotel tennis tournament semi-finals today, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4. In another match Colin Smith beat E. Lombard, 6-0, 6-2.

The National Socialist party celebrated its seventeenth anniversary here today. The party's birth hour, according to orthodox National Socialist doctrines, was the first public mass meeting under the swastika staged in the Munich Hofbrau Haus festival hall, Feb. 24, 1920.

The Atlantic Refining Company last year had a net income of $7,347,858, the largest since 1929, according to the annual statement sent to stockholders today. Physical operations for 1936 were at the highest level in the company's history, the report states. Earnings a common share were $2.59, compared with $1.49 on a net income of $3,970,598 in 1935.

Engagement of $5,676,000 gold abroad for shipment here, including, $1,697,000 in Canada and $3,979,000 in England, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank noted the arrival of $6,000,100 gold from England.
The Board of Assessors submitted its report for 1936 to Mayor La Guardia yesterday, showing that it had reduced claims against the city by $1,032,111.

A revolutionary new wind tunnel and first details of new four-engined stratosphere planes capable of flying at altitudes of 35,000 feet were described last night at the an.nual alumni dinner of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel before several hundred M. I. T. graduates, including many leaders in aviation.

An apparent deadlock existed tonight in the strike of employes of the Electric Boat Company who are- affiliated with the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, a Committee for Industrial Organization group.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 23: COLONELS Barrows, F. M., Field Artillery, three months' leave, account sickness, March 1.

Captain Jack came back to the wars yesterday. This wire foxterrier, best in show at Bloomingdale's pet dog show last year, returned to competition to take terrier honors and thus become eligible to defend his championship on Saturday.

Louis P. Griswold entertained with a dinner last night at the Meadowbrook Restaurant for Miss Margaret Smith Salvage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Salvage of Glen Head, L. I., and James Potter Polk, whose marriage will take place on April 19.

A superb performance by Philip T. Moore of the Columbia University Club, which brought about the defeat of Harry F. Wolf, national titleholder, in the deciding match. sent the Columbia team into a firstplace tie with the New York Athletic Club as the regular Class A schedule of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association was completed yesterday.
Harvey W. Seig, president of Harvey W. Seig Co., securities brokers, pleaded guilty yesterday to mail fraud and conspiracy.
Machinegun outposts were strengthened tonight at Dessye, Ethiopia, to guard against further anti-Italian outbreaks. Executions of Ethiopians found with arms continued in Addis Ababa.

Members of the New York Circle of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, of which Mrs. James E. Dougherty is regent, have arranged a card party and fashion revue for the afternoon of March 6 at Sherry's.

The Honduran Minister here today released to the local press a denial of the report of clashes between government forces and rebels in Honduras yesterday, although a telegram from Tegucigalpa, signed by President Tibureio Carias's private secretary, Jose Albia, admitted a skirmish with General Umana near Progreso.

Higher operating, labor and raw material costs, as well as increased taxation, will have to be figured by food manufacturers in the colt make-up of their finished products from now on, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., told members of the Texas Wholesale Grocers Association here today.

Collective bargaining between the "striking" employers in the wholesale dry goods trade and their employes' union was resumed yesterday, after the employers had withdrawn their insistence on an unconditional right to discharge or transfer workers.

Professor Kiyozumi Ninomiya announced tonight that he could guarantee to produce a female chicken from any hen's egg. He has had 100 per cent success in this line by injecting female hormones into eggs, he said. An injection costs about 2 sen (slightly more than half a cent) per egg.
Carl M. Dann Jr. of Orlando won the second annual invitation golf tournament of the Mountain Lake Club today, defeating Claude Harmon, also of Orlando, by 4 and 3 in the eighteen-hole final.

A prediction that Sixth Avenue, with the elevated structure removed, will be the greatest thoroughfare of the city was made yesterday by speakers at an informal reception under the auspices of the Sixth Avenue Association at the new showrooms of Nathan StrausDuParquet, Inc., to celebrate "the rebirth of Sixth Avenue."

President Roosevelt recommended to Congress today the creation of a provisional authority to operate the Bonneville hydroelectric project and approved a progress report of his National Power Policy Committee which urged that preference in distribution of electric energy be given to public an rural cooperative interests.

For fifty years, Jeremiah Cooper, 83, said today, he has been exercising his voting franchise, but not until a naturalization hearing yesterday did he learn that he had been casting his ballot illegally.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh took off in their black and orange low-wing monoplane at 9:15 A. M. today (11:15 P. M., Wednesday) on another leg of their sight-seeing tour. Their next destination was not disclosed.

Rene Revillon of Paris, for many years identified with the interests of the Revillon Freres, Cartier and Jaeger S. A., died on Tuesday in the French Hospital after a short illness at the age of 48. He had been in New York on a business visit since December.
Broome St., 520-528, and Thompson St., 51-55; 2-story Tunnel garage, 120x100: Manhattan. Savings Institution against Tunnel Garage; Inc.; due, $119,736, taxes, , $4,443; to plaintiff for $60,000.

Plans of the House Foreign Affairs Committee to report a neutrality bill today were upset by Representative Hamilton Fish of New York, ranking Republican member, who presented an amendment in substitution for the section of the McReynolds bill dealing with restrictions on exports to belligerents other than arms, ammunition and implements of war.

By order of the Superior Court, ten bakery workers went off the pie standard tonight. Superior Judge Emmett Wilson issued a temporary injunction and the pie-makers walked peacefully out of the Brownie Pie Shop, bringing to an end their sit-down strike in which they demanded a 25 per cent wage increase.

Because of the unusual power given to trade associations there, Japan is probably the only country in the world with which a group of American business men could negotiate such an agreement as that recently signed to curb Japanese shipments of cotton goods to the United States, Dr. Claudius T.

Paul Stassevitch conducted his orchestra last night at Town Hall in the third and final program of a series which. brought numerous interesting works to performance this season, some of them novelties and others worthy compositions infrequently given a hearing.

Colgate came from behind tonight to gain a 38-35 basketball victory over an Alfred team that had won seven straight games. Schachter of Alfred led the scoring with 11 points, Dieffenbach of Colgate had 9 and his team-mates, Clinton and Lenhart, got 8 each.

William S. Keeler, for many years sole proprietor of a restaurant bearing that name, died at his home today after a brief illness. Mr. Keeler's restaurant in State Street was the eating place of Governors and legislators who have come to Albany in the last half century.

In Wall Street circles the suggestion of the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that the Exchanges of the country pass rules requiring their trading members to be fully margined at all times during the trading day was looked upon as merely a move to eliminate another of the abuses possible--but

With the final session of the international horse show scheduled for tomorrow the general impression among experts here is that the American military team will gain further honors in competition against the horsemen of Cuba, Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador and Chile.

Minister of Education Bernhard Rust has called a halt to the German student's traditional tendency to wander from university to university. By a decree issued today every student En must spend at least three semesters at one university and then obtain the rector's permission if he wants to transfer to another.

The Chrysler Corporation agreed tonight to confor on collective bargaining with the United Automobile Workers of America, as union representatives negotiating strike issues with Genneral Motors reached tentative agreements on three more of their demands.
Two members of the House of Representativex tried to settle their political differences with their fists in Japan's costly new Diet Building today.

Professor Edward S. Robinson, head of the Department of General Studies in the Yale Graduate School, was knocked down this noon by a bicycle ridden by John E. Lantz, a Yale Divinity School student, and critically injured.

Prices of Pennsylvania grade crude oil advanced 10 cents a barrel today. The South Penn Oil Company announced these new prices: In National Transit Lines, Bradford field, $2.67; Southwest Pennsylvania Lines, $2.42; Eureka Pipe Lines, $2.37, and Buckeye Pipe Lines, $2.22.
Strikers entered the second-week of their sit-down siege at the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation today with no prospects in sight for a settlement of the dispute over union recognition.

A 148-pound broadbill swordfish was caught at Bimini by trolling last midnight by Frederick B. Alexander Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. As far as is known, it was the first broadbill caught in Bahamian waters and the first caught by blind trolling.

Tom Iannicelli of Short Hills, top seeded, came through his secondround test with a three-game victory over Joe Weiner as the quarter-final bracket in the New York State professional squash racquets championship was filled at the Downtown A. C. last night. The score was 15-5, 15-12, 15-12.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the Federal District Court signed an order today forecasting the appointment of a new trustee for the New York, New Haven Hartford, the Old Colony, and the Hartford, Connecticut Western Railroads, all undergoing reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
Pensioned On police surgeon's certificate: SERGEANT-John Raftery, 7th Precinct, at $1,728 per annum. Appointed June 13, 1917.

The Prosecutor General of Electoral Justice, MacDowell da Costa, ruled today that the recent election of Cardozo de Mello Netto as Governor of Sao Paulo was unconstitutional. Sao Paulo had elected by popular vote Armando Salles de Oliveira, who resigned the Governorship to qualify himself for the Presidential race.

Continuation for another year of the moratorium on mortgage foreclosures where interest, taxes and assessments had been paid was urged today by spokesmen for real estate and financial groups at a public hearing before the Assembly Committee on Mortgages and Real Estate.
The full parts bench of the State Supreme Court today held that a "no-smoking" ruleat Tabor Academy of Duxbury "cannot be found unreasonable.
Investment buying of apartment houses in scattered sections formed the bulk of realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

Mrs. Franc C. Briggs of 14 East Sixtieth Street, who died at St. Petersburg, Fla., Feb. 6, left most of her estate to charity. This was learned yesterday when her will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court. Her estate was formally valued at "more than $50,000."
Legislation will be introduced immediately by the Quebec Government for creation of a hydroelectric power commission with authority to set up power development plants.

President Roosevelt's collection of ship models was augmented today by a true model of the Hudson River packet sloop "Experiment" which was presented to him by the New York Rod and Gun Editors Association as an award in recognition of the "outstanding accomplishments of his administration in behalf of conservation."

Persons interested in the many philanthropic enterprises of the Maryknoll Sisters in Maryknoll, N. Y., have taken over the performance of "The Eternal Road" the night of April 17 at the Manhattan Opera House to raise funds for the work of the order.
The decoration of an Officer of the National Order of Honor and Merit of the Republic of Haiti has been received by the Navy Department to be conferred upon Captain Montgomery A. Stuart,
Many parties tonight preceded the "fiesta" which the board of directors of the Passaic Y. W. C. A. gave as its Winter entertainment.

The millionaire industrialist Conde Matarazzo, who died recently in Sao Paulo, left a sum estimated at $40,000,000 to be distributed among children of several charitable institutions and to create a fund to operate an orphanage established by him.

A $50,000 policy to insure Gladys Swarthout, Metropolitan Opera soprano, against the possibility of missing a broadcast has been obtained from Lloyd's of London by the sponsors of the program on which the singer appears Wednesdays at 10:30 P. M.,

Demand for store space was manifested by a number of leases for this type of commercial space reported by brokers yesterday. Chain-store expansion accounted for several of the contracts closed. The list follows:

Gerard Av. (9-2488); n. w. cor. of McClellan St., 129x115; Benjamin Levin to Bensid Realty Corp., 1,845 Andrews Av.; mtg., $153,600. Prospect Av. (10-2691); s. e. cor. of 166th St., 100xl5; Edith Herz to Harlem Savings Bank.
Valentine Av.. 2,084; 3-story frame tenement, 18.11x92.11 by irreg.; D. Emil Klein. executor, against Ellen White; due. $9,886; taxes, , $200; to plaintiff for $6,000.
One of the culinary arts usually associated with a camper's life was demonstrated yesterday at the National Sportsmen's Show. No rugged sportsmen took part in the contest.
James Reed. John LaPagne, In 65 W. 46th St.; Mrs. Helen Donow, in 59-63 E. 56th St.; Dr. Wm. Hall Holden, In 104 E. 81t St.; Fanny Stegman, in 63 W. 46th St.; Butler Baldwin, Inc.; broker.

W. E. Coyle and Conway Hoffman, the Montclair Athletic Club stars who- are defending their laurels in the men's sixth annual doubles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, were successful in reaching the semifinal round at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Not more than twenty-five Senators and hardly more than a hundred members of the House are listed by Administration checkers as fundamentally favorable to the President's program; therefore, the remaining number needed to pass it in both branches must be gathered on the basis of loyalty to the President or to the party.

WSHINGTON, Feb. 24.-Just as a snowstorm whirled around the classic temple of the Supreme Court today, workmen clambered in the branches of a venerable elm at the northwest corner of the building. They lopped off limb after limb.

Indianapolis, Ind., has awarded a new issue of $600,000 of short-term school notes to a banking group composed of the Union Trust Company, the Fletcher Trust Company, American National Bank, Indiana National Bank and the Merchants National Bank, all of Indianapolis, on a 1 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $80. The notes will become due and payable on May 28, 1937.
Counsel for the Borden Company, whose license to deal in milk in New York State was ordered revoked by Peter G. Ten Eyck, Agriculture Commissioner, obtained a stay of execution of the order today.

The House passed today and sent to the White House a bill to continue until June 30, 1939, authority for the Federal Reserve Banks to use direct obligations of the United States as collateral security for Federal Reserve notes.

A. J. McCarthy, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, was re-elected for his third term as chairman of the New York Shipping Association at a meeting yesterday afternoon at 80 Broad Street. Christian J. Beck, freight traffic manager of the Hapag Lloyd Line, was elected vice chairman, and Joseph Mayper secretary and treasurer.

In one respect the new House version of the "neutrality" resolution differs slightly from the Senate version, which received the approval of the Committee on Foreign Relations several days ago. It would give the President somewhat broader discretionary powers at one point.

The former estate of Dr. Harold B. Adams in Matthiessen Park, Irvington-on-Hudson, has been sold for occupancy to a client of George Howe, Inc., brokers in the deal. The Bank of the Manhattan Company, as trustee, was the seller. The estate contains a large stone and stucco house of English design on about three acres of landscaped land.

The appointment of Edward A. Richmond as master of the United States liner American Traveler was announced yesterday. He was chief officer of the flagship Manhattan, and this will be his first command, effective with the departure of the ship for Liverpool on Saturday.

Rochester came back into the dog show circuit today after a hiatus of eight years, the recently formed Genesee Valley Kennel Club opening its first exhibition in the State Armory, to continue through tomorrow evening.
Senator Patrick Burns, Alberta rancher and meat packer, died here today. His age was 80.
After five days of bewildering activity, the Giants essayed to play their first exhibition game of the year today and forthwith provided a perfect climax to Cuba's national holiday.
Police by written notice ordered sit-down strikers out of the Douglas Aircraft Corporation plant late today, and said that force would be used to remove them if "the powers that be" so desired.

The attack of maritime workers of Atlantic and Pacific ports on the Federal requirement that seamen tarry continuous discharge books will be transferred from the Federal courts to Congress, it was announced yesterday in San Francisco.
Harry Rowe Shelley, organist, last night appeared in a recital at the auditorium of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, 632 West 156th Street.

Dr. and Mrs. R. E. Tuthill of Clinton Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty G. Tuthill, to Raymond Hutchinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Hutchinson Sr. of Bristol, Conn.

Tribute to the memory of Miss Helen P. McCormick was paid yesterday morning by public officials, politicians, welfare workers and church dignitaries at a mass celebrated in the Queen of All Saints Roman Catholic Church, Lafayette and Vanderbilt Avenues, Brooklyn.

Golfers of the New York Athletico Club who have been competing in their seventh annual Winter tournaments found too many other activities to take part in today to enter a large field in the best-ball four-ball match. Eight pairs turned in scores.

With her eyes filled with tears, the widow of Ottorino Respighi, celebrated opera composer who was known in New York almost as well as in Italy, took the bows to a first night audience tonight in the Scala at the premiere of her husband's posthumous opera "Lucretia."

Americans were urged to look to "the glorious pioneer spirit, the intrepid courage and steadfast fidelity to high ideals" of their forebears for guidance and inspiration in meeting the complex problems of the present by speakers yesterday at a Colonial Willamsburg Restoration Conference.

Quoting Samuel Johnson to the effect that charges of plagiarism were the most serious a man of letters could face and should not be made lightly, Federal Judge John M. Woolsey yesterday dismissed an injunction and accounting suit which Edna Buckler of 140-40 Beech Street, Flushing, had brought against Sidney Kingsley, author of "Dead End," and others.

Although no trace of a pistol was found, Robert Brown, 32- years old, of 316 Eighty-ninth Street, in the Bay Ridge district of Brooklyn, a clerk employed in the Wall Street district, was found dead of a shot wound near the heart in his home shortly before 1 o'clock this morning.

In more northeastern sections of the belt considerable heaving was reported during the week, and more snow is needed to furnish protection. Elsewhere in most central and eastern sections, Winter grains progressed slowly, but favorably and are now green and looking good in many States. In the northern great plains, greens are mostly well protected by an ample cover, and where uncovered look good.

Stock Exchange Stocks improved and closed irregularly higher, copper and steel shares strong; turnover, 2,078,080 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds lower, foreign issues were mixed; transactions, $12,012,800.
The American premiere of "Garrick," opera in three acts, libretto by Robert Simon, music by Albert Stoessel, took place last night in the theatre of the Juilliard School of Music on Claremont Avenue.

The Women's National Committee for "Hands Off the Supreme Court," sponsored by the Women Investors in America, Inc., formed about two weeks ago to oppose attempts to increase the number of Justices on the Supreme Court, carried its message to the people yesterday for "united action and vigorous protest."
Groups of motorists and advocates of parking meters, particularly for New York City, clashed today in the final stage of a public hearing on proposed motor vehicle legislation.

Although only four horses went postward for the Grade A Handicap that topped today's Hialeah Park card, a thrilling contest developed in the onemile test. Mrs. Emil Denemark's Higher Cloud, the only starter not named for the $50,000 Widener

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Kliegl of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Beatrice Kliegl, to Lieutenant James Francis Byrne, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Patrick J. Byrne of Lowell, Mass., and the late Mr. Byrne.

The fourteenth annual luncheon bridge party of the Catholic Young Women's Club will be given this afternoon in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton to raise money for the maintenance fund. Mrs. Paul T. Kammerer Jr. is chairman of the committee arranging the benefit.
James Truslow Adams, noted historian, today accepted membership on the National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government, it was announced today by Frank E. Gannett, chairman of the committee.

Frederick A. Watson, manager of the Forest Hills Inn at Forest Hills, L. I., died suddenly at the hotel yesterday of a heart attack. He was 40 years old and began his hotel career twenty years ago as a bellboy with the Knott Hotels.

The first important test flights from the Foynes transatlantic air base at the mouth of the Shannon River will begin tomorrow. Engineers, radio men and meteorological experts are preparing for the arrival of the Imperial Airways flying boat

The Columbia varsity fencing team remained undefeated by conquering Princeton, 15-12, while the Tiger freshmen beat the Columbia yearlings, 17% to 9%, in the university gymnasium tonight. It was Prince ton's first loss in three varsity matches and the third successive victory for the freshmen.

Edward F. Hutton, former chairman of the General Foods Corporation, has resigned as a director of the company, it was announced yesterday. In relinquishing his connection with the General Foods Corporation and certain other organizations,

The fact that the Irish Free State will take no part in the coronation ceremonies for King George VI to be held in London next May was made explicit in the Dail Eireann (Parliament) today by President Eamon de Valera. Replying to a question by the Labor leader William Norton regarding the coronation oath, he said:

Scoring a 3-to-2 victory over New Jersey and winning on a default from New York, Westchester captured the Group B women's squash racquets team championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club courts.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 12 per cent for the week ended Feb. 20, in comparison with a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase is unchanged from that reported for the previous week. For the four weeks ended on Feb. 20 the gain was 13 per cent.

Representative Cannon, Democrat, of Wisconsin, demanded today that the House investigate the American Bar Association. He charged the association was a "band of rapacious corporation-controlled lawyears" that had "impeded the government."
The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Pennsylvania Railroad to issue $52,670,700 in fifteen-year 3 1/4 per cent convertible debenture bonds to be sold at par and interest.

Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, widow of the New York utility magnate, is preparing to give her showplace here, Innisfada, to the Society of Jesus, it was learned tonight. The Jesuit order will use it as a house of studies where young men will be trained for the priesthood.

While New York and New Jersey detectives held a council of war last night on methods to be followed in their joint efforts to solve the mystery surrounding the murder of Norman Redwood, subway construction workers' union organizer, the slain man's widow gave Prosecutor John J. Breslin of Bergen County what he described as "information of vital importance to the State."
The manager told an amazed audience: "Please step outside the theatre for a few minutes while men blow open the office safe."

Mr. and Mrs. Nelson I. Asiel of 15 East Sixty-third Street announced yesterday the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris R. Asiel, to Bruce A. Gimbel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of the Chieftains. Port Chester.

DUBLIN, Feb. 24-President Eamon de Valera, using the closure power, had the Spanish non-intervention bill making it illegal for Irish Free State citizens to go to Spain as volunteers passed through all the remaining stages of the Dail Eireann tonight.

Picturing himself as the volunteer banker for a large number of relatives and friends, for whom he wrote checks in exchange for cash or to whom he extended small loans, Irving Epstein, secretary treasurer of Local 302 of the Cafeteria Workers Union, completed yesterday his fourth day on the witness stand in the restaurant racket trial.

Inland Investors, Inc.-For 1936: Net asset value was $27.11 a share on Dec. 31, against $21.95 the year before. Marketable securities, carried at $1,394,789, had a year end market value of $2,686,514, compared with a book value of $1,330,138 and market value of $2,144,398 at the end of 1935.
Electric power production increased last week when a slight decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to 106.6 from 105.5 (corrected). It was 99.9 for the week ended Feb. 22, 1936.

A three-story business building will replace the nine-story Lawyers Building at 164 Market Street, Newark, which has been leased by the trustees of the First Presbyterian Church to. the Market and Nutria Corporation.

Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the world champion Yankees, asserting that "somebody has to take a stand on this salary business, and I'm taking it," said today his star first baseman, Lou Gehrig, would be paid $31,000 for next season's work--"or nothing."

Building plans filed yesterday in Manhattan included specifications for a one-story office and trucking station in the Chelsea section to cost $75,000 and alterations to the Empire Building at 71 Broadway at a cost of $350,000.
Officials of Landers, Frary Clark Company announced today a 5 per cent wage increase for all workers effective March 1, with time and one-half for all over fortyfive hours in one week.
Two high French officials who had been stormbound in the Alps since Monday escaped today on skis. They were Pierre Cot, Air Minister, and Leo La Grange, Under Secretary for Sports.

A full program has been planned for the Eastern savings conference to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria on March 11 and 12 under the auspices of the savings division of the American Bankers Association, according to the schedule of speakers issued yesterday by the association.
Lady Hildyard, wife of Sir Reginald J. T. Hildyard, Governor of Bermuda, is arriving tomorrow on the Monarch of Bermuda and will be at the Plaza.
One of the most interesting places in town and in the whole United States is beyond a doubt Teachers College. This is the good-sized normal
Paced by Wally Sonstrom, who scored 19 points, the Wesleyan Cardinals defeated the Williams five, 41-30, tonight. The count was tied at 5-5, 10-10 and 12-12 during the first period.
M. C. Robichau, who spent his last years in poverty, was found today to have possessed $46,827. Robichau died two weeks ago.

Australia's favorable trade balance with its principal customers in 1936 aggregated [Pound]24,540,000, an increase of about [Pound]2,500,000 over 1935. Exports totaled [Pound]113,607,000, a rise of [Pound]12,000,000, while imports, aggregating ??89,066,000, were up [Pound]9,523,000.
Governor Lehman welcomed the members of the New York State Association of Towns and tonight attended the annual dinner of the Association of Civil Service Employes.

Thirty-two hundred WPA employes in this city will be dismissed and more than 16,000 others will receive pay cuts under the terms of an order received from Washington yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Work Progress Administrator.

The 1937 budget for this city, with gross appropriations of $3,343,350, an increase of $181,639 over 1936, was adopted by the City Commission today. For the first time in years there were no protests offered at the public hearing that preceded approval of the budget by the commission.

The Chase National Bank, as successor fiscal agent, has notified holders of State of New South Wales, Australia, 5 per cent bonds, due on April 1, 1958, that $290,000 of these bonds have been drawn by lot for redemption on April 1 at par.

Judge and Mrs. Charles W. Appleton entertained tonight with a dinner at the Boca Raton Club in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Owen D. Young, whose marriage took place on Feb. 20 in St. Augustine and who arrived at Whitehall today.

The New York University swimming team easily defeated Manhattan College, 43 to, 26, yesterday in the Park Central Hotel pool. This was the final meet of the season for the Violet and enabled the squad to finish with five victories in six starts.

It was a happy if obvious choice on the part of the Rod and Gun Editors Association to select President ROOSEVELT as the recipient of its first annual award to the man who had done the most for conservation during the past year. This is indeed sure ground.

The development of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., in connection with the Securities and Exchange Commission was described today to the Bond Club of New Jersey by Ralph T. Crane, vice president of Brown Harriman Co. and former president of the Investment Bankers Association. Mr. Crane spoke at a luncheon of the club at the Newark Athletic Club.

An alleged change of testimony of the complaining witness in General Sessions yesterday resulted in a directed verdict of acquittal for Edward J. O'Connor, 38 years old, had a recently disbarred lawyer, on an indictment charging he obtained $600 from the complainant as a "job-fixer."

Turpentine firm, 401/2c; sales, 139 barrels; receipts, 83 barrels; no shipments; stock, 26,257 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 171; receipts, 591; shipments, 85; stock, 60,435. Quote: B, $8.50; D, $8.85; E, $9.25; F, G, H, $9.85; I, K, M, $9.90; N, $10; WG, $10.25; WW, X, $12.

Heavy rain and thawing snow and ice in Western Germany are causing the Rhine and its tributaries to rise alarmingly. At Coblenz the Rhine rose further today and the wharves of the Cologne-Duesseldorf Steamship Company were abandoned. Cellars and storehouses along the banks were inundated.

Triumphs by 38-28 as Sheie Leads Scorers With 12 Points The Wagner College quintet turned back the Webb Institute team, 38 to 28, in the St. Nicholas of Tolentine gymnasium last night. The victors, led by Sheie with 12 points, were in the van by 27-15 at the close of the first half.
As you know, the Bonneville project is nearing completion and I am informed by the War De partment that the first electric power will probably be available for public distribution late this year.

An accumulation of overnight selling orders, partly as the result of calls for additional margin, gave the grain markets on the Board of Trade here a somewhat easy start today, but there was no material pressure thereafter and the liquidating movement appeared to have temporarily run its course.

The explosion of a Spanish anti-aircraft shell squarely on the quarterdeck of the British battleship Royal Oak injured four officers and a seaman and tonight aroused some concern lest other such "incidents" mar a six-power neutrality patrol of the Iberian peninsula.

Some Nantucket residents want to secede from Massachusetts and rejoin New York, of which the island was a part in- Colonial days, unless they get lower electricity rates, State Representative William T. Swain of Nantucket declared today.
The Upsala College women's basketball team subdued the New York Village University sextet tonight, 8--, in a moose, game featured by the close defensive play of both teams.
Mrs. Marie Gorenslo Morrix, retired actress, widow of Richard Paynter Morrix, died here today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Daniel H. Littleton.

The election of six undergraduate members of the class of 1941 to posts in the freshman class at the City College was announced yesterday- by Bernard Wolpin, chairman of the Student Council Committee on Elections. They are:

Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., holder of the New York State title, was defeated in the first match round of the South Atlantic championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today. Her conqueror was the New Jersey State titleholder, Mrs. William Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong, who won by 3 and 2.

After indicating they intended to withstand a siege, forty-seven sit-down strikers unexpectedly gave up possession of the Century Wall Paper plant late today to twenty-five city policemen and Sheriff's deputies.
The Duke of Kent arrived here this morning from Munich. Contrary to expectations his wife did not accompany him, remaining in Munich with her sister.

Germany's Foreign Exchange Control Bureau today decreed sweeping restrictions on foreign trade transactions through compensation deals or the use of "aski" or discounted marks, which have been employed as a form of subsidy.
Offerings of hogs exceeded trade requirements and prices declined 15 to 25 cents with the day's average off 20 cents at $9.85, the lowest since Jan. 30. While a load of hogs sold at $10.15 early,

The Congress [Independence] party is still sweeping the polls in South India. The final results of the elections for the Madras Legislative Council show that twenty-seven of its thirty-one candidates have been successful, giving the party an absolute majority in the upper house with forty-six seats.
Cuba today celebrated the forty-second anniversary of the beginning of her last War of Independence by presenting

The Teachers Guild, in its current bulletin, made public yesterday its opposition to the re-election of Dr. Joseph M. Sheehan, Associate Superintendent of Schools, for a new term of six years beginning April 7.

Life on the farm, away from "things that go on in cities," was championed yesterday by a youthful editor of a national farm magazine who was chosen from hundreds of candidates to represent the country's young farmers in a radio discussion tonight on "What Shall America Do for Youth?"

The Prudential Insurance Company submitted the high bid of 100.353 for $13,800,000 of 2 1/4 per cent equipment trust certificates due in from one to fifteen years auctioned by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway yesterday.

The undefeated Peddie School team of Hightstown, N. J., gained its sixth victory in as many Eastern Private Schools Basketball League starts and its thirteenth in a row this season by turning back Poly Prep, 29-12, on the losers' court in Brooklyn yesterday.
A 10 per cent increase in wages affecting 6,500 hourly rated workers in the Pittsburgh district has been granted to 20,000 workers by the Aluminum Company of America.

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Feb. 23 unless specified: Antares, at San Clemente Island. Babbitt, at Balboa. Charleston, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to Ponta del Gada, Feb. 24. Chaumont, San Francisco to San Pedro. Cummings, at Callao.
Not Great Britain but the United States must make concessions if there is to be an Anglo-American trade agreement, Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, indicated in a speech today.

The Rev. Dr. Robert Laird of Toronto, treasurer of the United Church of Canada, was nominated yesterday in the face of considerable opposition by the Western, or American, section for president of the Alliance of Reformed Churches Throughout the World Holding the Presbyterian System. The alliance has a membership of 60,700,000.

The Kings County American Legion adopted a resolution at its headquarters in Brooklyn last night urging the removal of Mrs. Johanna Lindlof from the Board of Education because of pacifist remarks attributed to her at graduation exercises of the Thomas Jefferson High School on Jan. 28.

The business building at the southwest corner of Fulton Street and Gallatin Place, in the heart of the Brooklyn shopping district, has been sold by the French estate to a Manhattan merchant. It was sold for $665,000 through Paul Fisher and Leo Hess, brokers.
The heavy fighting that began yesterday afternoon on the Jamara River front, southeast of Madrid, continued day today. There hasbeen no harder or more sanguinary fighting since the war started.
PARADISE: AN HISTORICAL ROMANCE, by Esther Forbes. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50.) A romance of the early days of the Massachusetts Bay Colony.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in an interview yesterday told of her literary work and aspirations in that direction, and her impressions of life with its varying type of experiences as reflected in her autobiography. "This Is My Story."
The St. Francis College basket- S ball team was forced to extend itself in the final minutes to defeat, the fighting St. Peter's College five of Jersey City, 33-30, on the winner's court last night.

Trustees. of the United Hospital Fund voted an initial distribution yesterday totaling $564,000 to member hospitals for charitable service, for the needy ill of New York City. The funds were allotted on a basis of each hospital's free service.

There was to have been an opening tonight, but not any longer. After cutting the script of "Now You've Done It" a bit, Mr. Pemberton decided his players could stand a few days' extra study, and so the whole thing has gone over until Monday night. Still at Henry Miller's Theatre. The defection of Mrs. Chase's comedy leaves the WPA in complete command of the week: "Power" last Tuesday and "The Sun and I" tomorrow.

A commission of Catholics left this town in the State of Veracruz today for Mexico, D. F., to discuss with the Finance Minister the question of turning the churches officially back to the care of local groups.

WASHINGTON, Feb.24-Secretary Roper, in answer to questions at his press interview today, prophesied that the sit-down strike situation would be solved by the courts. He regards the matter as one of property, and had this to say:
The $500,000 breach of promise suit brought by Peggy Garcia, former hat check girl, against David Rubinoff, violinist, was discontinued yesterday in Supreme Court on application of her own counsel.

The Committee for Industrial Organization has already lined up 150,000 to 165,000 of the country's 500,000 steel workers eligible for union member.ship and expects to have a majority- about April, according to Clinton S. Golden; regional director here for the steel workers' organizing committee of the C. I. O.

Joseph Fishbach, who was graduated from De Witt Clinton High School a few weeks ago, eliminated Leonard Hartman,. the defending champion, in the semi-finals of the metropolitan indoor tennis singles championship at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York, at a special meeting last night, adopted the majority report of its committee on Federal legislation, condemning as "indefensible" President Roosevelt's proposal for reforming the Supreme Court.

Seeking a six-year term as Surrogate of Westchester County instead of the ten-month term he would have if appointed by Governor Lehman, William J. Sheils renewed today his fight to be declared winner of last November's election.

Secretaries Swanson and Roper today voiced the belief that it might be necessary for the government to open the $25,000,000 armor-plate factory built at South Charleston, W. Va., during the World War unless there were an end soon to the deadlock resulting from refusal of steel producers to bid on Federal orders because of the Walsh-Healey act.

The seven sons of former United States Senator Hiram Bingham and their mother, Mrs. Alfreda Mitchell Bingham, are the chief beneficiaries under the will of Mrs. Bingham's mother, Mrs. Annio O. Mitchell, admitted to probate here today by Judge S. Victor Prince.
Among those in the receiving line at the Committee of One Hundred clubhouse, on Michigan Avenue, for the committee's annual ladies' day reception tomorrow will be George Ade, Harvey S. Firestone,

Chancellor John G. Bowman of the m University of Pittsburgh said to- m, night the reported Sutherland-Harrison breach in the university's deapartment of athletics "is closed" until "more facts come directly to the athletic council."
Theodore C. Baker, 46-year-old business man of Brookline, Mass., was notified yesterday in Venice, Fla., that he had become the first "millionth passenger" to be carried by a regular airline.

The principal features of the current business recovery in Canada are the marked buoyancy of external trade and the expansion of mining of base metals and gold, according to a summary issued here yesterday by the Bank of Montreal.

Miss Polly Luke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Luke of Braemar, Tarrytown, N. Y., will be married to John Calvin Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Graham of 1,070 Park Avenue, this city, on the evening of March 18 at the home of her parents.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Feb. 20:
The veteran Sports Peerless failed to live up to his previous performances today and dropped from the ranks of leading contenders in the national field trials.

The engineer who prepared the detailed steel plans for the building at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, which collapsed last June 19, killing eighteen persons, testified during cross-examination yesterday afternoon that he had made no provision for templates beneath two of the four girders which supported the tower of the structure.

The basic hour and wage standards established for labor under the NRA are being maintained generally in the consumer goods industries, it was indicated at a meeting of members of the Consumer Goods Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, at which George A. Sloan,
THE NEW YORK TIMES acknowledges receipt of the following contributions:

A group headed by Nathan Wil son has purchased the six-story apartment at 37-15 Eighty-first Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. The building contains fifty-nine apartments, occupies a plot 120 by 100 feet, and is said to be fully rented and producing $38,500 annually.

The Princeton Triangle Club, one of the two undergraduate dramatic organizations of the university, has elected William J. Watson, a junior from Trenton, N. J., as president for the coming year, it was announced today.
Can a horse that wheezes like a windbroken thoroughbred win the world's richest horse race? This question is to the fore at Santa Anita Park today following

Three large German Protestant Church bodies threatened tonight to boycott the church elections in April unless Nazi authorities accede to five conditions. The conditions, met by the Confeusional Synod, the Lutheran State churches of Bavaria, Wuerttemberg and Hanover, and the non-Nazi ,church committees, follow:

At a hearing before the Assembly Ways and Means Committee this afternoon Harold Riegelman, chairman of the State-wide slum clearance committee, accused Governor Lehman by implication of attempting to obstruct slum clearance financing by putting forward his own proposal to bond the State for $60,000,000 for permanent public improvements.

Work at the two plants of the Illinois Watch Case Company ceased today after 600 of the 900 employes, affiliated with the jewelry workers' union, struck to enforce demands for union recognition and minimum wages.

Fiscal authorities heard with considerable interest tonight that the British had acted to check exports of money from Great Britain. The advices were that the British Government had asked insurance and investment companies to discontinue capital exports to this country.

Moving further to curb speculation in stocks, either "on or off" the market, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had submitted to the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange a suggestion that "trading by members of

Members of the European team won four out of five matches pus against United States rivals last night as the first half of play in the international table tennis competition was completed in the grand ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker. The event will be concluded tonight.
The list of seeded players was reduced to six as the field moved into the third round of the Class B metropolitan squash racquets championship at the Harvard Club last night.

Formally ending the sit-down strike at the Electric Storage Battery Company's plants here, representatives of the company and the Battery Workers Union, Local 18,551, signed today a contract calling for a wage increase of five cents an hour and a week's vacation with for all employes.
Rate increases in mail pay for American Airlines, Inc., totaling about $186,400 annually, were recommended today by examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Personal Credit Plan. Inc., of 39 Broadway, Manhattan, purchased from the 2836 Realty Corporation, Julius Vinik president. the store and office building at 2,836-38 Boulevard, Journal Square, Jersey City. The building, which was completed last Fall, is a three-story brick structure on a site 50 by 65 feet.

THE dossier on Paffaire Thil-Brouillard has been forwarded from the Left Bank direct to this observer by Operative X-37 of the Deuxieme Arrondissement. The "coup bas" (out et non!) landed by Lou Brouillard on the Rive Gauche under the roof of the Palais des Sports so upset the habitants of the Grenelle district that
Howard Bergman rallied to triumph over Anthony La Via in the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline billiards tournament at the Capitol Health Center last night. The final count was 200 to 126.

President Jorge Ubico as supreme chief of the Order of the Quetzal has awarded the Grand Cross of the Quetzal to King Victor Emmanuel of Italy, President Albert Lebrun of France, President Lin Sen of the Chinese Nationalist Government, Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy and Presidents Maxmiliafio Martinez of El Salvador, Tiburcio Carias Andino of Honduras,

Anti-Semitic student demonstrations occurred at Budapest and Pecs universities today. Nationalist students drove Jewish ones from classrooms and buildings and interrupted many professors' lectures. In Pecs organized street demonstations were dispersed by the police, while in Budapest students smashed- windows of the main synagogue.

Showing the way by a 15-11 count at the. intermission, the Hunter College basketball team defeated the Brooklyn College women, 28-15, on the winners' court yesterday. Miss Margaret Dunning, with seven field goals and a foul for fifteen points, led the Hunter attack.
Two demonstrators were shot and killed and six, including two women, were wounded tonight in a clash with the police near the mine where 267 coal miners were entrenched on strike.

Championship polo, starting on March 20, will give to- New York City, in the armory rings of Squadron A in Manhattan and Squadron C, Brooklyn, a climax to the most successful of recent indoor seasons.

An advance in price of base metals on the foreign markets caused a shortage of offerings of domestic copper yesterday. All American interests now have conformed to the price of 15 cents a pound, domestic fabricators advancing their prices yesterday in conformity with the quotation.

The results of the balloting among booksellers who have lately voted on outstanding books of 1936 will be announced today by Christopher Morley at a luncheon to be held by the American Booksellers Association at the Hotel Astor.

Internal revenue collections in the first seven months of the 1937 fiscal year amounted to $2,071,883,792, an increase of $362,117,443 over the corresponding period last year. For January receipts were $207,483,011, an increase of $23,717,973 over January, 1936.

The importance of the work entrusted to the commission of Chilean industrial, commercial and technical experts which sails Friday for a six-month study of markets in the Far East is now being revealed with publication of its Program.

Warning that diphtheria is unusually prevalent in the city, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, said yesterday in his weekly survey that "more immunizations are necessary if we are to keep this disease in check." Every child under the age of 6 years who has not been immunized should receive the protective treatment at once, he said.

Judge Owen W. Bohan of General Sessions quashed yesterday the second-degree manslaughter indictment returned early in January against William Hoffman, 44 years old, an unemployed printer, in the death of five persons on the night of Dec. 18 in the rooming-house fire at 273 West Seventy-third Street. The court acted on the motion of Hoffman's'lawyer, Edward T. Tighe of the Voluntary Defenders of the Legal Aid Society.

For reasons obvious to any newspaper reader, the forthcoming ruling of the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the Wagner act is awaited with more interest and excitement than any decision since the court finally passed on the legal tender legislation.

Selden Hannah of the Montreal Red Birds, 1936 combined champion of Canada; Ottar.and Magnus Satre, famous brother combination from Salisbury, Conn.; Olav Aasen, Staten Island S. C., and Hans Strand and Carl Holmstrom of Bear Mountain are among the leading ski jumpers who will participate

Manhattan Estate, more than $10,000. To Georgina Don, secretary, 130 E. 57th St., $10,000; Mrs. Charles D. Vasselais, 1,641 Amella St., New Orleans, La.. $5,000; Charles A. Jeanselme, godchild, Laval, France; Signa Charbonet. godchild. La Cerba, Honduras, C. A.;

The following film programs, which will be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization-composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

Albert F. Reilly, a manufacturers' agent in Detroit, testified before the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he had never given any one authority to trade in his account at W. E. Hutton Co.

A defense of "genuine and sincere" foes of repeal and disclosure that "some of the more intelligent leaders of both the drys and wets are taking definite steps toward meeting on a common ground to talk things over,"
