Three of the first ten ranking players of the country and four members of the second ten are included among the sixty-four contenders who were drawn yesterday for competition in the national indoor tennis championships.
Through his attorney, Alexander Meyer pleaded guilty today to the murder of Helen Moyer, 16year-old high school student, and was ordered held without bail for court.
Sir Guy Standing, distinguished English motion picture actor, fell dead today while chatting with an attendant in the garage where he kept his automobile. His age was 63.

Expenditure of more than $20,000,000 for equipment in 1937 was announced today by the Canadian Pacific Railway. The building program includes fifty locomotives, thirty passenger and express cars and 3,600 freight cars. Contracts have been let for the equipment.

The second shipment in the government's movement of $300,000,000 gold from the mint here to the Denver Mint is on its way to Colorado today under heavy guard. The shipment of 200 gold bricks, taken from the mint here, was valued by Superintendent Peter Haggerty at $7,500,000.

Victorious in twenty-seven plants in their demand for an immediate 15 per cent pay increase, leaders of striking New England shoe workers tonight sought to bring seven more firms into line before extending the walkout.
Pompoon, winner of the Belmont Futurity and pre-race favorite to capture the Kentucky Derby, will complete his training for the Blue Grass classic in Columbia, S. C.
MANHATTAN Gross assets, $16,423; net, $14.819. To Doris Abbott, daughter, residue. Chief assets, mortgages. notes, cash and insurance, $10,576. Bloomberg Bloomberg, attorneys, 580 5th Av.
ABBOT--On Tuesday, Feb. 23, Alice Balch, daughter of the late Abiel and Alice Abbot, at her residence, 134 Tysen St., New Brighton, S. I. Services private.

The stock market here was bright and more confident today and prices had a better tendency in most sections. Gilt-edge issues continued to show strength after weeks of unsteadiness. Foreign bonds were quiet.

Victor Ghezzi, professional from Deal, N. J., took par apart today to post a 67, five under regulation figures, and lead a field of ninetytwo amateur and professional golfers through the first round of the $3,000 St. Petersburg open championship.
Lou Gehrig was summoned to the Coast today to make tests for the role of Tarzan In a series on the Edgar Rice Burroughs character to be made by Sol Lesser.

Miss Lillian Charlotte Kessler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Kessler of Irvington, N. J., was married to Franklin E. Quinn of this city here yesterday morning in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

The annual report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and affiliated companies for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $37,398,870. The computa tion was made after providing for Federal income taxes, depreciation,

The twelfth annual production of the benefit performance for the support of the medical, dental and eye, ear, nose and throat clinics maintained throughout the school year by the Kiwanis Club was held here tonight in the Paramount Theatre. Arthur Hammerstein and Sam H. Harris, New York producers, directed the show, assisted by C. W. Carroll, chairman of the Kiwanis committee.

The novels "Arrowsmith," by Sinclair Lewis, and "Les Miserables," by Victor Hugo, are among a group of books to be taken out of general circulation and reserved for senior reading only at the John Adams High School, Ozone Park. Queens, it was announced yesterday by William A. Clarke, principal.

A new step to stabilize the millinery industry, eliminate unfair competition and combat the growth of contracting in the trade was announced yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission. The plan features the confining of purchases by manufacturers of blocks and dies to producers who have registered with the commission.

Reminiscent of one of 0. Henry's metropolitan sketches but with a denouement much more mundane, Yvan Nob's "Christian" was given last evening by the French Theatre of New York at the Barbizon-Plaza before a large and brilliant audience-the first of nine performances which will close the second season of Mr. de Vestel's players here.
The first conviction in Queens on the charge of dangerous driving under the new traffic code was obtained yesterday in the Queens Traffic Court, Jamaica.

Mrs. Carey Read Bullivant, member of a family prominent in Lexington, Mass., was found dead at 10 A. M. yesterday in the threeroom apartment and terrace she had subleased a month and a half ago at 20 East Thirteenth Street.

As probably the most active proponent of the Dickstein bill "to protect the artistic and earning opportunities in the United States for American actors, vocal musicians, operatic singers, solo instrumentalists and orchestral conductors, and for other purposes," I believe I am qualified to take issue with your editorial "Keeping Genius Out."

The Board of Education has approved the following appointments and transfers of teachers and others in various branches of the school system: APPOINTMENTS High Schools BENJAMIN FRANKLIN-Harold Mager. HAAREN-Thomas M. Murphy, David M. Van Ornum. Grant H. Carpenter.

Local 306 of the Motion Pictures Operators Union won yesterday a twelve-hour stay-in strike of fiftyfour operators in twelve movie houses of the Bell Theatre Company; mostly on the East Side. Joseph D. Basson, president of the local, and Benjamin Sherman, president of the company, agreed to a two and one-half year contract, according to a joint announcement last night.
Phil Sanders claimed a limited championship as a pinochle player today as the result of victory in a game atop a 125-foot chimney.

The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company of Springfield, Mass., reported sales of new insurance of $141,410,115 in 1936, an increase of 7 per cent from 1935. Total insurance in force on Dec. 31 was $1,874,060,619, a gain of $22,615,000 in the year.
DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 24.-Dr. Harris Fenton Brownlee, for nearly half a century a leading physician in this community, died this morning at his home. His age was 70.

The world's production of tin in 1936 was 171,888 tons, compared to 140,652 in 1935, an increase of 22.2 per cent, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council. Last year's output was the largest since 1929.

Long Island University settled the little matter of the metropolitan basketball championship in Madison Square Garden last night and did it in mighty convincing style. The Blackbirds, riding along on high, throttled the title hopes of Manhattan and won, 41 to 20.

Heats were drawn yesterday for the 600-meter run, 1,000-meter run, 1,000-meter sprint relay and 1,600meter relay, four of the championships which will be decided at the national A. A. U. meet at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.
Mrs. Ida Russell Kiernan, wife of Frank Kiernan, head of the advertising agency bearing his name, died on Tuesday at her home, 9 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, after a short illness.

Military activity on the southern Spanish front was negligible today, the surgents holding an advanced position along the coast a short distance from Almeria, while continuing cleaning-up operations in the mountainous region inland.

Behind a cheerful and prosperous front, changes of far-reaching importance are taking place in Belgium. The sharp reorientation of external and internal policy now in process tends to strengthen Belgian nationalism while at the same time

Returns of the first twelve railroads to report for January showed that the end of the emergency freight surcharges last year failed to halt the rise in revenues that has been under way for many months.

Leaders on both sides of the fight over President Roosevelt's program to reformthe judiciary started out in earnest today to pin down votes. Further defections, actual and potential, in the Democratic ranks led opponents of the plan to believe that they had some chance to stop it in the Senate.

Senator Borah, entering the debate today on extending for three years the President's authority to negotiate reciprocal trade agreements, declared that while he had no objection to the principle of reclprocity, he was convinced that it was not working in the interests of agriculture in the agreements in effect.
Banks figured as the sellers in several Bronx real estate deals reported closed yesterday. Apartment houses in various parts of the borough changed ownership.

The promotion of industrial uses of cotton will receive prominent attention in the organized campaign which the Cotton-Textile Institute is now preparing, C. K. Everett, head of the new uses section of the institute, said here yesterday.

State officials and nationally prominent persons were among those who attended funeral services yesterday for Mrs. Maud O'Farrell Swartz, secretary of the New York State Department of Labor. Mrs. Swartz died early Monday in the New York Hospital after a brief illness. She was 58 years old.
Max Adelbert Baer, former world's heavyweight champion, appeared before the State Athletic Commission meeting yesterday, as per request, to petition for renewal of his license as a boxer here.

Estimating that 200,000 soft coal miners never again would be employed full time in the mines, the American Friends Service Committee announced here today plans for an experimental rehabilitation project in the bituminous region of Southwestern Pennsylvania.

Deaths Announeed Fireman 3d grade George H. Smith of H. L. 115, died Feb. 22. Funeral will take place from the Funeral Parlors of Thomas M. Quinn, 162-14 Sanford Av., Flushing, at 10 A. M., Thursday, Feb. 25. Interment at St. Mary's Cemetery, North Hempstead Turnpike and Black Stump Road, Flushing.

Judge Lester W. Patterson in the Bronx County Court yesterday suspended sentence on Rose Lucks, 25 years old, of 1,584 Jesup Avenue, the Bronx, on her plea of guilty to manslaughter in the second degree in connection with the death of her newborn son on May 2, 1936.

A contribution of $100 by Postmaster General Farley helped to increase the American Red Cross flood relief fund to $1,971,059 in the last half week, it was announced yesterday by General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Chapter.

Mrs. Louise Baldwin Rich, wife of Edward N. Rich, lawyer, died here tonight of a heart attack at their home, 1,006 North Charles Street, at the age of 72. In addition to her husband, she left three sons, Johns B., Edward N. Jr. and Woodward Rich;

Quinlan Leland have placed with the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Co. a first-mortgage loan of $205,000 at 4 1/2 per cent on the business building at 34-38 S. 4th Av., Mount Vernon. The building is leaked to Genung Campbell, Inc.

Most people are out of date on nutrition and malnutrition- my own wife is," Viscount Astor, husband of the American-born Member of Parliament, said in an interview here today. He is presiding at a private meeting of representatives of national committees on nutrition of eleven countries, including the United States, under the auspices of the League of Nations.

Secretary Swanson said today that "finish" had been recorded in the case of James Lee Johnson, Negro student, and 134 other midshipmen dismissed from the Naval Academy recently for delinquency in studies and for other causes.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Leave of absence for 1 month and 9 days, effective on or about March 1, to terminate not later than April 10, is granted 1st Lt. Frazer W. Rodman, Ord.-Res.

George R. Daley, 49 years old, died today far from the battlefields of France where he won a round dozen medals for gallantry. He succumbed to injuries received when a bomb exploded on a motion-picture war set at Universal Studios in North Hollywood.

Funeral services for Rollo Ogden, editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be conducted this morning at 10 o'clock in the Frank E. Campbell funeral establishment at Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street The New York Philharmonic String Quartet will participate. Thereafter the body will be taken to the Ferncliff Crematory at Woodlands, Westchester County.
While fire axes crashed above them and streams of water played on the roof members of the staff of the University of Pennsylvania

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of 48,884 shares of Collins Aikman Corporation convertible 5 per cent cumulative preferred, $100 par value, and 81,474 additional shares of common stock, no par value, and 1,818,182 shares of Tide Water Associated Oil Company common stock, $10 par value.
THE beginning of the new historical novel by Esther Forbes, "Paradise" (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50), drags a little. The writing seems strained, the characters artificial.

Without expressing his own personal views on the merits of the proposed legislation, Governor Lehman today transmitted to the Legislature the housing bill of Mayor La Guardia, dealing with the emergency relative to the old type of tenement house on which violations have been filed.

Germany's fundamental dilemma, which dates from almost the beginning of the Nazi regime, is brought into sharp relief by the "successful" flotation on Tuesday of another 500,000,000mark loan "for the purpose of contin"uing the tasks assumed by the Reich "Government."
The GaumontBritish Picture Corporation has tentatively decided to close its f300,000 ($1,467,000) studios at Shepherd's Bush, London, as part of a drastio reorganization plan, it was learned today.
A billion-dollar four-year, low-rent housing and slum-clearance bill was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Wagner of New York and in the House by Representative Steagall of Alabama:
Sweeping through the eight matches, a sturdy New York Athletic Club wrestling team vanquished Columbia University, 30 to 0, in the Winged Foot gymnasium last night.

" For our own self-proteotion, we must all dedicate ourselves to the cause of true conservation. Much progress has been made during the past four years, but the full signiflcanoe of conservation as related to our national welfare is not yet clear to all our people."
The rise of Gunnar Barlund in the heavyweight ranks was checked last night when Nathan Manz of New Haven defeated the fighting Finn in their ten-ound bout at the Hippodrome.
Caricature is rampant this week at the A. C. A. Gallery, 52 West Eighth Street, where members of the American Artists Congress are holding, until March 6, an exhibition called "Framed and Hung."

Differences of opinion between Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, and several of his faculty members and many alumni flared at two sessions today in connection with the convention of the department of superintendence of the National Education Association.

The National Hockey League's 'board of governors ironed out details of the annual play-offs, reported increased attendance, accepted a new trophy from President Frank Calder, and discussed the complicated affairs of the New York Americans in a four-hour session yesterday, The Associated Press reports.

Mrs. Elizabeth Palmer, widow of Captain Clinton Palmer, died at the Greenwich Municipal Hospital last night. She was born in New York on March 22, 1853, but had lived here seventy years. Her husband was captain of a number of Long Island Sound vessels.

Lady Katherine Cairns, the last English squash racquets player to arrive for the international WolfeNoel team matches on Saturday, provided most of the interest in the annual Junior League invitation competition yesterday.
Syracuse turned back an aggressive Cornell basketball team tonight, 51 to 44, withstanding a spirited second-half rally by the visitors.

50th St., n. e., 155 ft. ?w. of Park Av., 45x100.5; 35-37 E. 50th St, Corp., Benson Woodland, president, to Joseph L. Gavigan, 89 Wynsum Av., Merrick, L. I.; prior mtg., $93,800; 10 years, 5 per cent, $5,000.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct ten concerts at the head of the NBC Orchestra, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, revealed at a press conference yesterday. Mr. Toscanini will arrive some time in December and the concerts will be held weekly.

By a vote of 41 to 15, the New. Jersey Assem-. bly adopted tonight a resolution for a constitutional amendment to permit pari-mutuel betting 'at. race tracks. It was sent to-the Senate, where it was. referred to committee.
Frederick A. Scheffler, one of the organizers of-the Edison Pioneers and a resident here thirty-six years, died today at his home after a fiveweeks' illness following an operation.
Joseph's College, for the third time in basketball history, defeated Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 37-36, before a crowd of 10,683 wildly cheering fans.

A vast undertaking in which a forest of 10,000 trees will be transplanted to the bare plains of the World's Fair site in Flushing within the next two years was started yesterday by the fair corporation with the opening of bids for the first 500 trees.

David A. Croll, Minister of Welfare, who helped bring the Dionne quintuplets virtually a million-dollar fortune in two years, moved in the Ontario Legislature today to turn over his-job as special guardian, or business manager, to new hands. The change will take effect April 30.

Leaders of industry should be guided by the same factors in the establishment of favorable industrial relations as in the field of research, Roderic Olzendam, director of the social security bureau of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, declared yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry, held at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Jumping 178,026 shares over the figure for Dec. 31, the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange at the opening of business on Jan. 29 was 1,314,840 shares, according to a report made public yesterday.

Assertions that the American girl was the greatest "strip tease" artist of them all, and that "stripping" was a typically American art, were made before the House Immigration Committee today by Herbert and Morton Minsky.

Leading by 34-22, with only five minutes to go, the Seth Low quintet was forced to stave off a desperate Brooklyn College rally to win, 36--34, in the opener of a twin bill at the Union Temple in Brooklyn last night.

Mayor La Guardia requested the Board of Education yesterday to assign the Parental School buildings in Queens to the Sinking Fund Commission so that the property might be transferred to the Board of Higher Education in line with the Mayor's plan for a new city college.
13th St., 544-46 E.. 35.3x70; also 18th St.. 508 E., 25x75; Esther A. Levin to Samuel Levin, 650 W. 173d St. (50c) (deed dated Nov. 18, 1924).

Oyster shucking, which may- become as prominent nationally as corn husking if its sponsors have their way will be the feature competition today at the National Sportsmen's Show at the Grand Central Palace.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Feb. 13 amounted to 286,158,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, an increase of 42,000 barrels from the previous week and comprising an increase of 92,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude, but a decline of 50,000 barrels in stocks of foreign crude.

Calling attention to the fact that army fliers flew eight times as many hours in 1936 as were flown in 1922, while total accidents last year amounted to one-sixth the rate in 1922, Secretary Woodring, in a letter to Air Corps officers and Corps Area commanders,

Bank clearings for the five-day week ended on Wednesday increased 11.4 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago. The total for the twenty-two leading cities throughout the United States, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,591,156,000, against $5,018,780,000.

The following candidates for promotion to the rank of lieutenant in this department shall be directed to report to the Municipal Civil Service Commission at Room 1401, Municipal Building, Manhattan, at time and date specified for medical examination.

The funeral of Rollo Ogden, editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was a simple ceremony, in accordance with his wish. It was conducted yesterday morning in the Campbell funeral establishment and the body was taken thereafter to the Ferncliff Crematory in Westchester.

Governor George H. Earle received several scratches last midnight when his car, Which he -was driving, skidded off the Montgomery Pike near here during a snowstorm. The car shot over a slight embankment and plowed into a snowbank, narrowly missing a tenfoot drop into a creek.

Directors of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share on the common stock. On Jan. 26 a dividend of 10 cents was paid. During 1936, dividend payments aggregated $1 a share.

The sale of the Champlain Transportation Company, an affiliate of the Delaware Hudson Railroad Company, to Horace W. Corbin of Burlington, Vt., was announced yesterday. Mr. Corbin, who has operated ferries on Lake Champlain several years, thus became the sole operator of steamboats on the lake.

Dr. Richard Hoope Cunningham, neurologist, physiologist, engineer and pioneer in the construction of X-ray equipment, died on Wednesday at the Presbyterian Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 71. He had been chief of clinic in the neurological department of the Vanderbilt Clinic, chief engineer of the Splitdorf Company and consultant for a number of firms making radio equipment.

The market for high-grade bonds, particularly United States Government obligations, was quick to respond to the official announcement by Secretary Morgenthau that the Treasury will restrict its midMarch financing to the refunding
Howard Chivers of Dartmouth College defeated his brother, Warren, an Olympic skier, today In the Langlauf, opening event of the three-day Intercollegiate Ski Union championships.

Isadore Rauch, 39 years old, a roofer of 94-45 166th Street, Jamaica, Queens, and Louis Washington, 27, a Negro chauffeur of 10633 150th Street, Jamaica, Queens, were found guilty yesterday of second-degree manslaughter by a jury in the Queens County Court in Long Island City before County Judge Charles S. Colden.

Denial that a new commercial treaty was being drawn up between Cuba and Japan came today from Dr. Miguel Angel de la Campa, Assistant Secretary of State. Mr. de la Campa explained that the only change contemplated in the trade relations of the two countries was the granting to Japan of a minimum tariff rate during the present year.

Halibut fishermen, preparing for the opening of the annual fishing season the middle of March, said today that they would receive more than four times as much for halibut livers as they did five years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times Professor Corwin of Princeton, in an article which appeared in THE TIMES on Feb. 14, defends President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court as a measure which may be "necessary in the present situation to readjust the balance between the departments and to effect an application of the Constitution, which is demanded by conditions and which has been sanctioned by the people."

Mildred King Hyde, one of the ten children of Mrs. Mary (Mother) King, whose midnight lunches to Chicago newspaper men laid the foundations for the later fortunes of her family, died today in her home at 854 Castlewood Terrace. She was 57 years old.

After hearing that all of the alleged victims of a swindle were more than 78 years old, the Federal grand jury returned a six-count indictment yesterday, the first ever obtained under the Securities Act of 1933, against Lyman Hess and Sidney Horwitt as operators of a stock fraud scheme.

The claim of Mrs. B. S. Copping, wife of a naval lieutenant, that she was criminally attacked on the morning of Feb. 15 by "a six-foot white man" cannot be substantiated, the Honolulu Police Department announced today. A formal statement said:
Arturo Godoy, 93 3/4, Chile, knocked out Art Sykes, 187, New York, in the third round at the Star Casino last night.

After six weeks of careful preparation, eighty members of the junior class at Columbia College, who have served either as heads or members of nine committees, are ready to lead 300 other members of their class tonight in staging the annual Columbia Junior Promenade in the Oval Room and ballroom of the Ritz Carlton Hotel, Madison Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.
Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 75.3 from 69.3. It was 70.1 for the week ended Feb. 22, 1936.
A pair of lightweights who have yet to meet defeat in this country will clash over the championship route of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The annual statement of the General Foods Corporation and subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, shows net earnings of $14,240,957 after all charges, expenses and provision for taxes. This is equal to $2.71 each on the 5,251,440 shares of common stock outstanding at the end of the year.

Miss Margaret Zolnay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Julian Zolnay of 137 East Nineteenth Street, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents to John Churchill Newcomb of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Danforth Newcomb of Wayetree Hall, Greenwood, Va., and Louisville, Ky. The ceremony was performed by Magistrate Overton Harris, formerly of Louisville, a friend of the two families.
Four properties in Bergen Country, N. J., have been sold for the Fidelity Liquidating Trust by Joseph P. Day, Inc.
Restaurants, food shops and building construction and supply firms figured prominently in the reports from brokers of commercial space leased yesterday. The list follows:

A new plan of government for Westchester County, less drastic in its reforms than three others proposed since 1925, but offering modernization through installation of a county executive and realignments of departments,

George C. Stebbins of Catskill, noted as a' hymn writer, and for many years a singer at revival meetings all over the country and abroad, will celebrate his ninetyfirst birthday tomorrow. He will attend a service in his honor at the Methodist Church Sunday, when some of his bestknown hymns will be sung.

Two indictments charging firstdegree robbery were returned by the grana jury yesterday in General Sessions against Norma Parker, 21 years old, whose right name is Nellie Gutowski, in two of the five hold-ups she is alleged to have

Charles G. Hurd. 32 years old, a Yale man and member of a wellknown New York family, has been missing since Feb. 18, following a night-club visit-and an automobile accident, the Missing Persons Bureau disclosed yesterday.

Three of the leading men's clothing chains announced yesterday that they were advancing the price of their lines from $2 to $2.75 on Monday. The Richman Brothers Company, Cleveland; Crawford Clothes, Philadelphia, with stores here, and Howard Clothes, Brooklyn, are increasing their prices.
Contrary to reports from official Vatican sources which continue to state that the Pope is gaining in health and strength every day, it is understood he was not as well today as during last week.

Enno Greeff, textile executive, died yesterday at his home, 1,212 Fifth Avenue. In 1931 the concern of Greeff Co. of 79 Madison Avenue was acquired by the Commercial Trust Company and merged with Morton H. Meinhard Co., Inc.,

Seventeen miners, most of them staggering and bloody, escaped from a strike-locked coal mine tonight with grisly tales of fighting below between self-appointed pickets, armed with hatchets, axes and picks, and other miners who wanted to quit a stay-down hunger strike.
Under the lead of gilt-edge issues, the stock market reflected further all-round recovery today. Foreign bonds were mostly steady and little changed.

The five-story apartment house at 2,361 Valentine Avenue, near 184th Street, in the Bronx, has been sold by David S. Meister to an investor through J. S. Frant, broker. The house, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, accommodates twenty families.

The sight of swirling snowflakes yesterday brought considerable joy to the hitherto gloomy legions of skiers in the metropolitan area, who immediately visualized a weekend of good running over snowcovered hills and trails in the "Northlands." And sure enough the patient snow-famished outdoor enthusiasts will have something to be thankful for, as the best twoday period of skiing this Winter is promised for tomorrow and Sunday.

A check to the amount of 1,000,000 francs has been remitted by the Valencia government to the Belgian Government as indemnity for the murder of Baron Jacques de Borchgrave, Secretary of the Belgian Legation in Madrid, says a dispatch from Brussels to the Lokalanzeiger.

Artur Rodzinski, the fifth and last of the conductors to be heard this season with the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, appeared yesterday evening at the head of that body in Carnegie Hall, and was enthusiastically welcomed on this his first concert in New York this Winter.

Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended on Feb. 24 were down $3,577,481 from the previous period, according to the statement of the bank issued today. At the same time deposits by chartered banks showed an increase of $4,127,922.

Six small apartment buildings in Long Island City have been purchased by Norman-Lila Estates, Inc., operators, from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank. The three-story houses, each on a plot 20 by 100 feet, are at 47-32, 47-38 and 47-44 Forty-fifth Street and 46-05, 46-13 and 46-15 Forty-eighth Avenue. Each accommodates six families.

Holding that more than half of the highway accidents occur after sunset, while only a fifth of motor traffic is abroad at night, Dudley M. Diggs, special representative of the General Electric Company, told a group of highway officials yesterday that lighted highways reduced the night accident rate below that of daytime travel.
Fire Commissioner John J. McEligott announced yesterday that he would promote seventy-seven men of his department this morning and that 287 men would be appointed as probationary firemen.

Lord Brownlow, who a few days ago hit back at the Archbishop of Canterbury and others who, he believed, had criticized him for his friendship with former King Edward and Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, returned today to Austria to visit the former monarch at Enzesfeld Castle.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, issued a statement yesterday reminding employers that Federal social security tax returns on Form SS-1 for January are due Sunday.

The ratio of gold reserve to note circulation and deposit liabilities was 55.36 per cent, against 55.31 a week ago and 71.17 .a year ago. The legal minimum is 35 per cent. The highest figure, 80.87 per cent, was renorted on Dec 20 1934.

The formal opening yesterday of the Port Richmond-Tower Hill viaduct, said to be the largest grade crossing elimination unit in the United States, marked the completion of the last link of the $6,000,000 grade crossing elimination program on Staten Island. This viaduct,
The hubbub and excitement of yesterday's opening of the exhibition schedule having subsided, Colonel Bill Terry, with characteristic patience, set to work today mending his fences.
Grimly holding on to the slim play-off chance that mathematical possibility affords them, the New York Americans did something last night that they had been unable to do all season.
SOMETIING OF MYSELF FOR MY FRIENDS KNOWN AND UNKNOWN, the autobiography of Rudyard Kipling. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50.) The story of himself that Kipling sat down to write at 70.

The navy would have to spend three years and $4,000,000 to get the South Charleston, W. Va., naval ordnance plant in shape to turn out finished products, in the opinion of Rear Admiral Harold R. Stark, chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, Navy Department.

Retail credit collections last month showed an increase of 0.17 per cent, according to the index of twenty local "key" stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The average was 50.76, compared with 50.59 for January, 1936.
General Motors Corporation officials informed union representatives today that the automobile industry was not "ready for" the thirty-hour work week.

Receipts of hogs declined precipitously as the result of the sharply lower prices in the last few days, and, with a better demand, quotations at the yards today were steady to as much as 15 cents higher.

Plans for a new nine-and-one-halfmile parkway connecting Wantagh State Parkway with the present terminus of Northern State Parkway in Nassau County were announced yesterday by -the Long Island State Park Commission. The new road will give New York City's 1939 World's Fair visitors a direct parkway connection with Jones Reach State Park.

Carroll J. Waddell, an investment broker, died of pneumonia last midnight at Pennsylvania Hospital here. He was 55 years old. Well known in investment banking circles in New York, Philadelphia and other cities,

President Roosevelt discussed his proposals for reorganization of the Federal judiciary with officials of the Department of Justice and members of Congress. The Senate passed the bill to extend authority for the negotiation of reciprocal trade treaties.

The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 24, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,466,000,000, a decrease of $16,000,000 compared with the preceding week and with the corresponding week in 1936.

The 112th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design will open with a private view and reception on March 12 at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Galleries, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, according to an announcement yesterday.

ABRAMS-Morris, dearly beloved husband of the late Emily, and devoted father of Esther Kutz, Lillian Hess, Albert, Marion Ross, Evelyn and Julian. Funeral from Millheiser's Memorial Chapel, 1,460 Lexington Av., Sunday, Feb. 28, at 2 P. M. Kindly omit flowers.
The Soviet Central Executive Committee today appointed Vice Premier Valery Ivanovitch Mezhlauk as Commissar of Heavy Industry, succeeding Gregory K. Ordjonikidze, who died Feb. 18.
Within a few days a leading producer will announce a price advance affecting nearly all steel products and ranging from $2 to $6 a ton, declared the Iron Age summary issued yesterday.

Secretary Woodring told Representative Edward W. Curley of New York City today the army engineers were ready to make a new survey of the proposed Bronx Kills improvement as soon as Congress authorized it. Mr. Curley has introduced a bill to authorize the survey.
Judge Merrill E. Otis meted out prison and jail sentences today to seven men convicted of vote theft conspiracy in the government's drive on election irregularities here last November.

Senators Byrd and La Follette joined today in a demand that consideration of President Roosevelt's departmental reorganization program be "brought into the open." Their action was made known as a joint Congressional committee took up the reorganization proposals.

Four ruffians raided today the Japan Rescue Mission, an establishment in Osaka specializing in rescue of inmates of licensed quarters, seeking two Japanese girls who had escaped from a licensed house.

An appeal to American industry to clean its ranks of "selfish chiselers" and to get behind "constructive" legislation intended for the national good was made yesterday by Ernest G. Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce,
The Harvard varsity quintet routed a fighting Tufts College team tonight, 41-25. Harvard's seconds opened the fray, but after the Jumbos had jumped into a lead, the Crimson regulars were sent in.
Indications are that the night session of the Legislature on Monday is to be a crucial one in the contention over the ratification of the Federal child labor amendment.

The Labor Relations Board ended yesterday a three-day hearing on the complaint of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association against the Black Diamond Line charging discrimination against its members in employing engineers on its ships.
There was a lull in the fighting on the Jarama front today, while both sides rested for further attacks.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-Patrick J. McGreevey, from 64th Precinct to 1st Division, assignment changed from desk duty to duty as supervisor of plain clothes patrolmen. Michael A. O'Neill, from 10th Division to 64th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.

Turpentine firm, 41c; sales, 3 barrels; receipts. 42 barrels; shipments, 40 barrels; stock, 26,259 barrels. Resin steady; no sales; receipts, 594; shipments, 2,171; stock, 58,858. Quote: B. $8.50; D, $8.85; E, $9.25; F, G, H, $9.85; I, K, M, $9.90; N, $10; WG, $10.25; WW, X, $12.

Printed with the type and press used by Benjamin Franklin, and on paper made in the Franklin Institute Museum, an all-Philadelphia invitation to President Roosevelt to attend the annual Boy Scout pageant in Convention Hall here next week was sent to the White House today.
The meeting called yesterday to permit stockholders of the Grand Union Company to vote on a plan of recapitalization was adjourned to March 4 because of lack of a quorum.

The entire furnishings at Inisfada, the Manhasset estate that Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady is giving to the Society of Jesus, will be sold there at public auction under the management of the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., during the week of May 10, it was announced last night.

The need for protecting buildings against earthquakes was emphasized yesterday by Jacob J. Creskoff, consulting engineer of Philadelphia, in an address at the annual. convention of the American Concrete Institute, which is in session this week at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The defense in the restaurant racket trial intends to prove that Abe Borson,- an official of Local 302 of the Cafeteria Workers' Union, was murdered on Armistice Day, 1933, by gangsters hired by employers to stop his unionization activities, Louis Waldman, one of the defense counsel, declared in court yesterday.

At the present moment the problem of Austria calls itself to the attention of European diplomacy. Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg has advanced the date for his visit to Rome by a fortnight to discuss immediately with his protector, Premier Benito Mussolini, the situation created after the visit to Vienna of Baron Constantine von Neurath, German Foreign Minister.

The two-story house at 95 Ocean Avenue, South Beach, S. I., has been sold by the Staten Island Savings Bank to Mary Argenati; a two-story dwelling on Margaret Street, Great Kills, was purchased by Roswell C. Coles for occupancy; two building lots on Locust Avenue,

A tract for five twin-engined Sikorsky S-43 type amphibian airplanes, and for spare parts equivalent to one more complete amphibian, was of the awarded by the War Department to today to the Sikorsky division of the United Aircraft Corporation.

The Internal Revenue Bureau has gone to prison in quest of income taxes from Alesandro de Nicola, formerly of Waterbury and Bridgeport, Conn. The Board of Tax Appeals disclosed today that the bureau had assessed deficiencies of $2,068 and $2,562 respectively for 1934 and 1935 against de Nicola.
The annual Ladies Day reception of the Committee of One Hundred today was attended by several hundred in the clubhouse. It is the one day of the year on which women are invited to the club.

Customers' men of W. E. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange charged with manipulation, were placed on the stand today by Jacob Gruber, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, in an effort to show that the firm rigged the market in Atlas Tack late in 1935 and in 1936.

Christopher Gray, 17, a cadet on the British cruiser Frobisher, was so ill today when the ship entered this port to put him in a hospital that the commander declined to fire the salute that formality dictates.

Merle Vandenbush, ex-convict and bank robber, dubbed "Public Rat No. 1" by J. Edgar Hoover, Federal investigation chief, and two other men were captured at Armonk, N. Y., yesterday afternoon exactly twenty-two minutes after Vandenbush and one of his companions had robbed the Northern Westchester Bank of Katonah, N. Y., five miles away, of more than $17,600.

Assemblyman Bernard J. Moran announced yesterday at a meeting of the United Retail Liquor Dealers Association of Kings County in the Hotel St. George that he intended to introduce a bill at the present session of the Legislature providing for the sale of package goods at bar and grills when the package stores are closed.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Feb. 24: MAJOR GENERAL Birnie, U., Jr., Chief of Field Artillery, one day leave, Feb. 25. BRIGADIER GENERAL Brant, G. C. (Colonel), Air Corps, Barksdale Field, La., to Command Second Wing, General Headquarters Air Force, Langley Field, Hampton, Va.
Farrar Rinehart report that "The Sisters," by Myron Brinig, has taken a sudden spurt in sales and is averaging between 2,000 and 3,000 copies daily.
89th St., 316-320 W., 62x100.8, also 170 W. 81st St.. 60.9x102.2; Crown Equities, Inc., Abraham Weinstein, president, to Merit Factors Corp., 41 E. 57th St.; demand. 6 per cent: S28.000.
Overhanging gray skies let loose a heavy snowstorm that looked like a blizzard yesterday, but by nightfall almost the last flake had fallen and the total counted up to little more than half an inch.
The Kansas House adopted the child labor amendment to the Federal Constitution today, bringing to twenty-eight the number of States to approve. The vote was 64 to 52.
Sixty sit-down strikers were routed by two police officers today from the clothing factory of H. Daroff Sons.
The Count of Covadonga, eldest son of the former King of Spain, who returned here Tuesday from the United States, is ill at the home of Dr. Blas Rocafort, it was learned this afternoon.

Robert J. Aitchison, president of the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation in North Chicago, where a sit-down strike has been in progress since Feb. 17, late tonight rejected Governor Horner's proposals for settlement of the strike.

Investigators for the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, which, under the chairmanship of Senator Burton K. Wheeler, is delving into the financial transactions surrounding the creation of the Van Sweringen railway empire, took under scrutiny yesterday a deal
Miss Gynell Soom, a 20-year-old church worker, told officers today a story of kidnapping, a wild ride, escape and then the suicide of her 'abductor, a.rejected suitor.
The general level of wholesale prices reached a new high since June, 1930, in the week ended on Feb. 20, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Determined to retain the open shop, the steel industry is planning wage increases and the strengthening of its employee representation plan in order to counteract the organization drive of John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization and to prevent or minimize the threatened steel strike.

A special meeting of stockholders of the National Gypsum Company has been called for March 23 to vote on a plan of recapitalization eliminating the present Class A and Class B stocks, and substituting a $1-par value common stock.
Mrs. Sarah H. Hatch, widow of C. Everett Hatch and a prominent figure for years in social organizations of Beacon, died yesterday in Highland Hospital as the result of falling and fracturing a hip.

Bad weather and deep mud prevailed at Santa Anita today and the expectation is that it will affect the going on Saturday when the world's richest race, the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap, will be run.

Wealthy and powerful cattle barons of the vast 'pampas urged hundreds of policemen into a great hunt tonight for 2-year-old Eugenio Pereyra Iraola, who is believed to have been kidnapped from his parents' estancia.

Ernest G. Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, and Mrs. Draper, have arrived at the Ambassador from Washington. The Hon. Charles Winn of London, who has been visiting Charles A. Munn in Palm Beach, is returning to the Savoy-Plaza tomorrow. Count and Countess Giuseppe Cippico have left the WaldorfAstoria for Nassau.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day industrial high schools, in the subjects inlicated, be issued, as of Feb. 24, 1937, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore:

The North American Company regis tered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a holding company. Officials of the SEC said that was a major break in utility opposition to the Holding Company Act.

All five borough Democratic organizations joined officially yesterday in an attack on the constitutionality of the proportional representation method of electing City Councilmen as provided-in the new charter at a hearing on a taxpayers' suit before Justice Lloyd Church in Manhattan Supreme Court.

Governor Horner tonight commuted the death sentences of Mrs. Mildred Bolton and Mrs. Minnie Mitchell to 199 years each in prison. Both women, convicted of murder, were to have died soon after midnight in electric chairs, Mrs. Bolton in the Cook County Jail and Mrs. Mitchell in the prison at Chester.
Plans were filed yesterday for new buildings in Queens to cost about $9,000,000. The bulk of the projects consisted of small dwellings and tenement houses.
A greyhound which could have graced any show ring with distinction went to the top in a field of more than three hundred sporting and non-sporting dogs at Bloomingdale's Pet Show yesterday.

Directors of the New York, Ontario Western Railroad took action yesterday to postpone for six months the semi-annual interest due on March 1 on its $20,000,000 of first 4 per cent bonds of 1992. The indenture provides a period of six months in which the default may be "cured."

President Eamon de Valera, announcing the terms of a new trade pact with Great Britain for the present year in the Dail Eireann tonight, disclosed that it contained no changes in Britain's penal tariffs on the Free State's cattle and pigs.

The second Federal Theatre Project opening of the week takes place this evening up at the Adelphi Theatre. The name is "The Sun and I," and it is Barrie and Leona Stavis's light treatment of the biblical story of Joseph and his brothers. David Enton,

Miss Gertrude C. Buttenwieser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Buttenwieser, was married to J. Warner Prins, son of Mrs. Maurits Prins of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, and the late Mr. Prins, yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 885 Park Avenue. Dr.
Governor Lehman signed today six bills sponsored by Assemblyman Harry Reoux, Republican, and designed to coordinate State law with provisions of the National Bankruptcy Act.

Gregory W. O'Keefe, Supervising Customs Agent for the New York district, was appointed today as Assistant Collector of Customs at the Port of New York, according to an announcement by Secretary Morgenthau.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 23: COMMANDERS Traynor, F. P., Washington, D. C., to command the Altair. Wheeler, C. J., the West Virginia, to Command the Bridge.

The longrange Empire flying boat Cambria will begin tomorrow a series of radio tests at Rynanna on the Shannon estuary, Ireland, where it has now been decided to establish the eastern terminus of the North Atlantic air service.

While representatives or WPA employes' and unemployed organizations were protesting yesterday against the dismissals and pay cuts ordered by Federal authorities for workers on WPA rolls, word came from Washington that a 10 per cent exemption from the dismissal order had been granted to New York City.

Ras Desta Demtu, son-in-law of the Negus, his prospective representative at the coronation of King George VI and the last Ethiopian Ras to raise the flag of revolt against Italy, was captured yesterday after a brief skirmish in the impassable Guraghie Mountains and put to death by a native band commanded by Italian officers.
Members of the New York A. C. who remained here longer than they originally planned to stay carried on today in the impromptu series of golf matches arranged by the committee.

Young Joseph Fishback, seeded No. 6, won the metropolitan indoor tennis singles championship yesterday by recording a straight-set victory over John Nogrady, ranked second, in the final at the 102nd Engineers Armory. The scores were 6-4. 6-2. 6-3.

The United States Army horse show team scored a sweeping victory at today's closing meeting of the international horse show, which has been drawing the attention of the Chilean public for more than ten days with the unusually brilliant exhibitions of the teams from the United States, Cuba. Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador and Chile.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Evelyn Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Miller of Oxford, N. J., to Lawrence A. Maginnis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Maginnis of this place, took place tonight at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

The results of voting on preferred books of the year by the 600 members of the American Booksellers Association were announced by Christopher Morley at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor. The association annually makes five awards.

Mr. DE VALERA'S statement in the Dail Wednesday that the Free State will not be represented at the coronation of GEORGE VI was expected. It is consistent with his old hopes and policies and with some of his more recent measures. Up to the abdication of EDWARD VIII the King had been one of the Estates of the Free State Parliament.
Word was received here today of the death from heart disease in Clearwater, Fla., last night of Charles B. Collingwood, former Ingham County circuit judge. He was 76 years old.

Appointment of a committee of seven Aldermen to investigate the shortage of police in the city was foreshadowed yesterday following a hearing of the Aldermanic rules committee on a resolution introduced by Alderman John Cashmore, Brooklyn Democrat.

The conclusion of financial observers who have studied the week's grist of dispatches relating to navy steel requirements and the WalshHealey act is that the entire problem can be disposed of in five minutes at this time if the Department of Labor overcomes its unwillingness to use its power to waive certain conditions stipulated in the act. It is not unlikely,
General liquidation developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today and prices dropped to new low levels for the movement with rye weakest.
Sir Ofori Atta, native ruler of one of Britain's African Gold Coast States, put justice above fatherly affection today when he had two of his sons jailed for stealing one of his golden crowns.

IT seems only reasonable to approach a booklength poem like Selden Rodman's."Lawrence: The Last Crusade" (Viking, $2.50) with two questions in mind. First, how effective a booklength poem is it? Second, how completely satisfying can any book-length poem, in the Year of Our Lord 1937, aspire to be?

Mr. and Mrs. Blon Huntington Hooker of 620 Park Avenue and Chelmsford, Greenwich, Conn., announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adelaide Ferry Hooker, to John Phillips Marquand, author, son of Philip Marquand of Curzon's Mill, Newburyport, Mass., and the late Mrs. Margaret Fuller Marauand.

The board of directors of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company at a meeting in Philadelphia yesterday decided not to pay the interest instalment aggregating $874,440, due on March 1, on the twenty-year convertible 6 per cent debentures of the company.

The State Milk Control Law .was characterized yesterday as unenforceable before a bipartisan legislative committee which opened a two-day public hearing in the State Building, 80 Center Street, on the question of abandoning, continuing or amending the act.

Wadsworth Terrace, 57-63, 116x100; Freybell Realty Co., Nellie K. Kline, president, to 57-63 Wadsworth Terrace, Inc.. 176 Broadway; one-half interest ($1). 107th St., 10 W., 25x100.11; Joseph Brown to Rubin Solove, 415 Central Park West.

Cimarosa's 145-year-old opera buffa, Il Matrimonio Segreto," had its first performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It was done in an English translation by Reginald Gatty and Albert Stoessel, with new recitatives by Mr. Stoessel, and it had an English title, "The Clandestine Marriage."

Immediate action to speed up the movement of merchandise through this port was pledged by government officials in Washington yesterday following an appeal telephoned by represent ves of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc.,

Without increasing taxation in any form and with many downward revisions of the tariff schedule, Finance Minister Charles Dunning today budgeted for an over-all deficit of $35,000,000 for the fiscal year 1937-38.

Pope Pius today named Bishop Martinez, now first Coadjutor Bishop at Morelia, Mexico, to be Archbishop at Mexico, D. F. Prelates said the nomination of Bishop Martinez was a "normal procedure" as the office was vacant through the death of Archbishop Pascual Diaz.
Jessie James, 183, Hollywood, Calif., threw Bill Raburn, 180, Oklahoma, in 22:29 of the main match of the weekly wrestling show at the New York Hippodrome last night before 3,000 persons.
Milton Shubert, theatrical producer, returned on the Rex yesterday after passing two months in England, France and Italy seeking new material for New York production.

Harry Newbold Earl, retired railroad engineer, died at his home here on Tuesday after a long illness. His age was 80. Mr. Earl for more than half a century was with the West Jersey Seashore Railroad, now a part of the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore lines.

The death of Arthur O. Minnich, assistant to the president of International Utilities Corporation of 120 Broadway, in an automobile accident on Wednesday near Baquendang, Chile, was reported here yesterday by Embury Palmer of 170 East Seventy-ninth Street, a friend of the family. Mr. Minnich was touring South America studying investments for his concern. He left Miami Feb. 14, arriving at Antofagasta, Chile, last Tuesday by airplane.

Men and women were permitted to skate in pairs today for the first time in Japanese history, provided they were professionals. The practice, hitherto strictly forbidden, was legalized by the police in view of the Olympic Games to be held in Japan in 1940.
Issuance of equipment-trust certificates at low rates of interest was authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission today for the following roads in the amounts named:

Support of the pending city ordinance which would end sales here of bootleg coal from abandoned anthracite mines in Pennsylvania was expressed yesterday by three New York unions in a memorandum addressed to the Board of Aldermen.

Charles Brower, a trader, studied faded papers today pertaining to the voyage of the British ship Enterprise in search of the Sir John Franklin expedition eighty-seven years ago. An Eskimo said he found the can on a beach 300 miles east of Point Barrow.

TODAY-New England: Cloudy, probably occasional rain, little change in temperature, probably changing to snow and colder with return to freezing over north and central portions; occasional rain, little change in temperatures over south. New York State: Occasional rain, changing to snow and colder, with return to freezing over north and central portions; occasional rain, little change in temperatures over south. Pennsylvania:Cloudy, probably occasional rain and little change
Associated Industries of New York, Inc., through its directors and advisory council, went on record tbday in opposition to President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposals.
Two former national amateur squash tennis champions turned back the clock in the veterans' national tournament at the Yale Club last night to gain the final round with remarkable exhibitions.

An increase of almost $55,000,000 in personal property valuations has brought the net total assessments of this city this year to $961,796,474, a new high record, according to figures made public today by A. F. Minisi, Director of Revenue and Finance. The net is $44,094,252 higher than in 1936.

The third of a series of shipments which will transfer the store of gold from the United States Assay Office, Old Slip and South Street, to the Federal vaults at Fort Knox, Ky., was started. on its way last night with elaborate police protection.

The price of lead was advanced one-half cent a pound yesterday by leading sellers. The new prices are 7 cents a pound here and 6.85 cents at St. Louis. This is the highest level since 1929, when the price touched 8 cents. In 1932 lead sold at 21/2 cents a pound.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 24 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, avowed foe of John L. Lewis's C. I. O., accepted the challenge of the New Jersey Federation of Labor yesterday to lend an active hand in the investigation into the murder of Norman Redwood, business manager of the sandhogs' union which was fighting Samuel Rosoff, New York City subway contractor and rival unions bent on its absorption.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, James G. McDonald, Mrs. Felix M. Warburg and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman spoke over three national radio networks yesterday in a celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

Miss Mary Pearsall Field entertained with a luncheon yesterday at the Plaza for Mrs. Lewis Gawtry, Mrs. Richard Trimble, Mrs. Harry Harkness Flagler, Mrs. Mbrris W. Kellogg, Mrs. J. Sergeant Cram, Mrs. Henry Wilmerding Payne and Miss EmilY Trevor.
With some of the holdout problems yet to be solved, the first detachment of the Yankees will move southward tomorrow to begin training at St. Petersburg,

Ignatz Rensing, a veteran of the Civil War, died today at his home here at the age of 93. He was the last surviving member of Ellsworth Post, Grand Army of the Republic. For years he led Memorial Day parades in Hudson County.

The Petengill "long and short" haul bill was reported favorably today by the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee by a vote of 15 to 8. It seeks to-permit railroads to compete upon more favorable terms with truck and waterway lines.

The first consolidated opposition to the Quezon administration since the dissolution of the Democrata party in 1932 was revealed today in an announcement that a message was being sent to President Roosevelt urging him to veto the National Assembly Act granting "extensive" tariff powers to the Commonwealth President.

Miss Patty Berg, 19-year-old Minneapolis schoolgirl, suffered her second defeat in match play this season by losing to Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco, 1936 Western titleholder, in the quarterfinals of the South Atlantic championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.

The campaign by a large number of. Members of Parliament to halt the spread of "yellow journalism" in Britain met further success today when the powerful Newspaper Proprietors Association, representing the majority of national daily and Sunday newspapers, notified the government it "strongly condemned methods of news gathering which may cause unnecessary distress to private persons."
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh hopped off from Bombay at 7:30 o'clock this morning in their monoplane, with Calcutta believed to be their destination.

The Bonneville recommendations of the National Power Policy Committee, which were endorsed yesterday by President Roosevelt and introduced in the House by Representative Martin F. Smith, Democrat, of Washington, are not the last word on the government's power policy, Secretary Ickes, chairman of the committee, said at his press conference today.

In the fierce fighting on the Jarama front, which for nearly three weeks has caused many casualties on both sides, an American hospital unit sent here from New York by the Friends of Spanish Democracy has been doing most important work in caring for Loyalist wounded.

With her bows badly battered by a Spanish sub-sea mine and two holds flooded, the 10,600-ton British Union Castle liner Llandovery Castle, with 300 persons aboard, was standing off Port Vendres on the French Mediterranean coast tonight awaiting assistance from Marseilles.

170th St. (11-2966), n. w. cor. of Charlotte St., 100x37; Lizzie Ticotsky to Leonat Holding Corp., 570 7th Av.; mtg., $25,000. Dwight PI. (18-5411), e. s., 250 ft. n. of Griswold Av., 75x100; Jacob A. Guttenberg, referee, to Edward E. Bashford, trustee, 41 Clarke St. Pleasantville. Y.

Terms, made public today, of the new three-year trade agreement which Great Britain and Canada have substituted for the five-year agreement made here in 1932 indicate that Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King's government has given Britain additional preferences worth about $6,000,000 a year to obtain substantially the same concessions from Britain as before.

Rochester Central Power Company 5 per cent debentures, Series A, due in 1953; Northwestern Power Company, Ltd., 6 per cent first-mortgage bonds, due in 1960, and American Electric Power Company convertible gold debentures, Series A, 6 per cent, due in 1957, have been removed from unlisted trading by the New York Curb Exchange.

Albert Plesman, general manager of the Royal Dutch Air Lines and director of the Royal Netherlands Indian Airways, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to discuss with Americans the proposed completion of the airways link between Batavia, Dutch East Indies, and Manila.

Justifying their top ranking, the four high-seeded players in the New York State professional squash racquets championship, led by Tom Iannicelli of Short Hills, came through their quarter-final tests at the Downtown Athletic Club last night to gain places in the semifinal round.

The Will Rogers Memorial Hospital, tribute of the motion picture industry to the memory of the cowboy humorist, newspaper philosopher and motion picture star, came into official existence yesterday when the deed to the former N. V. A. Sanatorium at Saranae Lake, N. Y., was presented to Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and treasurer of the Will Rogers Memorial Commission.
The Baltimore Orioles won an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game from the New York Rovers tonight, 4 to 3, and went into a second-place tie with Atlantic City.
The nation learned to its amazement tonight that British factories were already turning out gas masks at a rate of 100,000 daily to defend the civil population against the horrors of another war.
Kelvinator interests were placed in complete control of the board of directors of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Baltimore.

A joint committee of American and Japanese cotton mill executives, created to facilitate an agreement on exports from Japan, not covered in the recent treaty signed between groups representing both countries, will begin to function not later than April 1, it was revealed last night by Dr. Claudius

A. A. Silverberg, through Tlshman Realty Construction Co., in 885 Park Av.; Mrs. Harry T. Payson, in 929 Park Av.; Ernest V. Knowlton, through Fred F. French Co., in 1,140 FIfth Av.; Douglas L. Elllman Co., broker.

Supreme Court Justice Steinbrink in Brooklyn heard arguments and reserved decision yesterday in a proceeding to determine whether Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, should reimburse investors in mortgage certificates issued through the Lehrenkrauss Mortgage and Title Guarantee Company.

In response to a further rise in prices for cotton in Liverpool, quotations on the Cotton Exchange here-advanced yesterday to about the level reached on Feb. 1 and ended with a gain of 4 to a loss of 6 points.

A request that the Piper bill, requiring business corporations to prepare and keep available for inspection by stockholders monthly operating statements and balance sheets, be recommended for a public hearing, was sent to members of the Assembly yesterday by the Merchants Association.

Governor Lehman signed today six bills designed to synchronize the State Stock Corporation Law with the National Bankruptcy Act. He went to New York City to attend a testimonial dinner tonight to Charles Poletti, his counsel.
Blackbirder, under perfect handling by Charlie Stevenson, made a show of four rivals in the featured Lake City Handicap of a mile and a furlong today at Hialeah Park.

Edward Irwin, veteran actor, died here today. He was 70 years old. Mr. Irwin had spent fifty of his seventy years in the theatre, both as actor and playwright, and had served in leading roles under many of the celebrated managers of the last half-century.

Former Judge Alfred J. Talley was elected for a fourth term as president of the Catholic Club night at the organization's annual meeting in the club rooms in the Waldorf-Astoria. Others elected were T. Louis A. Britt, vice president; Michael S. McPhillips, secretary; Thomas F. Hanley, treasurer.

The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company has subscribed to $100,000 of New York World Fair 4 per cent debentures, it was announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the bond sales committee. In announcing this subscription,

Marcus Samuel, a Conservative Member of Parliament, in a letter in The Times of London this morning, says he is informed on authority "which I believe to be unimpeachable" that the Spanish Republican Government's gold shipped to London for safekeeping "has been handed over in London in the names of individuals to the Moscow Narodny Bank and not to the branch of the Spanish-Government-ownedand-controlled Bank of Spain in London."

Karl Eilers, president of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, announced yesterday that more than 250,000 New Yorkers were now enrolled in the threecents-a-day plan for hospital care. Enrollments have tripled since last May when the plan started its second year, he said.
The Music Room of the Everglades Club was the setting tonight for the first of three concerts by the Stradivarius Quartet, arranged by Mrs. Grover Loening, Lytle Hull and Hugh Dillman.

James Monroe High School's five, city co-champion with Jefferson last season, closed its 1936-37 schedule in the upper Manhattan-Bronx Division of the P. S. A. L. by beating Morris High, 30-20, on the winners' court yesterday.

After the meeting of directors of the Equitable Office Building Corporation yesterday it was said that no action had been taken on a common dividend. The Manufacturers Trust Company is depositary under the readjustment plan covering $5,500,000 New York Dry Dock Company 5 per cent serial gold notes.
Under the title "Instructive Example," the official press bureau here compares the recent automobile strikes in the United States with working conditions in the Third Reich.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., has leased the four-acre plant at Rhawn St. and the Pennsylvania Railroad, Philadelphia, formerly occupied by the Harmon Bleachery, consisting of a one-story building, 320 by 162 feet, and including a railroad siding. Cross Brown Co. was the broker.
Elmer E. Hann, court crier at the Hauptmann trial, died at his home here last night at the age of 73. He was court crier for eighteen years and custodian of county buildings forty years.

Sir Bhupendra Nath Mitra, a leader in Indian affairs since 1910, died here today of a heart attack. After his graduation from Presidency College at Calcutta, Sir Bhupendra entered the British Government service as a clerk in 1896.

A hearing on the application of the National Gas and Electric Corporation of New York City, a registered holding company, and two of its subsidiaries, the Industrial Gas Company and the Gas Producing Company of Ohio, for approval of acquisitions of securities and business interests, was announced today for March 16 by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Representative William B. Barry of New York City asked Congress today to establish a hospital for veterans in Queens County, N. Y. In a statement accompanying his bill, Mr. Barry said that thousands of disabled veterans in Queens.

J. J. McCarthy, pioneer of the motion picture industry and lately a member of the Will Hays organization, died. at his home here this morning. He was 58 years old. Joseph Jefferson McCarthy was one of Will H. Hays's principal aides in the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc.

Covered by machine guns and surrounded by a heavily armed cordon of 350 law enforcement officers, 343 sit-down strikers in the Douglas Aircraft plant here submitted to arrest without resistance tonight and were locked up in the Los Angeles County jail, ending their three-day occupancy of the plant.

Stocks closed irregularly lower, low-priced mining shares up; turnover, 2,227,230 shares. United States Government issues higher, corporate bonds irregular, Polish obligations lower; transactions, $13,753,400.

Consistent year-round advertising was advocated here yesterday by H. B. LeQuatte, head of the agency of that name and also president of the Advertising Club of New York, who declared that the practice of curtailing copy in certain seasons was unwise.

Sudden deportation orders for ten Germans accused of anti-Soviet activity led tonight to German Embassy predictions that thirty-four Germans still held in Russian jails would soon be called to trial on espionage and sabotage charges.

The two title characters of "George and Margaret," which got off to a good start at Wyndham's Theatre tonight are bores whose visit the family dreads. They are talked about throughout the entire play, but their appearance is only announced when the final curtain falls.

W. D. Hackney, whose name was once familiar throughout the South as the builder of the Hackney farm wagon, died today, the victim of a motor truck injury. The 79-year-old retired manufacturer wax knocked down on a street here ten days ago and suffered a fractured skull.

Humphrey Pearson, successful scenario writer, was found shot to death in his desert cottage here early today under mysterious circumstances. His wife, still hysterical and incoherent, was under police guard tonight at the Riverside County Hospital, although no charge had been placed against her.
Ralph Guldahl, former automobile salesman from St. Louis, led the field at the half-way mark today in the $3,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament with a subpar card of 139 for 36 holes.

Are the Wets gaining or the Drys? Gaining, that is, formally and legally. There are shifts here and there, but the balance remains undisturbed. All of us should be glad to see Kansas true to herself again. She is naturally contrary and Dry. Arkansas put prohibition into her Constitution in 1912.

With but four dissenting voices, school administrators of the nation went on record here today as favoring enactment of a universal Draft Law to be applied to all the resources of the country in time of war.

Alfred Hitchcock's latest venture in melodrama for the Gaumont British Studios, "The Woman Alone," begins an engagement this morning at the Roxy. Adapted from Joseph Conrad's novel "The Secret Agent" (the author's title was discarded because the studio previously had made a Peter Lorre film under the same name), "The Woman Alone" is played by Sylvia Sidney, Oscar Homolka, John Loder, Desmond Tester and Joyce Barbour.

A first edition of Lord Byron's "Don Juan" in uncut state went to Barnet J. Beyer for $290 last night at the Rains Galleries at an auction of the library of the late George Francis Richardson of Lowell, Mass., and other properties. The first. session brought a total of $2.885.

Extra-game matches featured last night's play as the second round was completed in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B championship at the Harvard Club. Ten of the eleven encounters contested included at least one extra session.

More than 1,600 men and -women attended a dinner and dance last night of the-Queens County Demo-cratic Executive Committee in theCommodore Hotel in celebration of the Democratic victory in their county last November.

The first postage stamps bearing the image of King George VI probably will be issued within a month, and preparations for the coronation issue, showing the heads of the new King and Queen already are under way, it was revealed today.
Governor Cross jumped to his feet today during a conference with three labor delegates, pointed his finger at them and said with great determination:

Sky Lad, which has the habit of win?ning every other start, kept up that pace today when he got up in time to take a photo finish decision in the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature for platers at the Fair Grounds.

A House Judiciary Subcommittee, headed by Representative John E. Miller, Arkansas Democrat, today completed consideration of the Miller-Tydings bill to enable States to legalize minimum price agreements for goods bearing a trade-mark or brand where they are sold in intrastate commerce.

The highest Winter egg production on record in New York State, with a consequent drop in market prices, was Attributed today to unseasonably mild temperatures. The State Department of Agriculture and Markets declared that a report of 43.8 production was the highest recorded for Feb. 1 since collection of data was begun in 1924.

Showing in brilliant form under the careful handling of Leonard Brumby, Champion Wolvey Noel of Clairedale, splendid Sealyham terrier bitch owned by the Clairedale Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. W. O. Penny of Riverhead, L. I., tonight was named as best in show at the first annual exhibition of the Genesee Valley Kennel Club.
George F. Rand, president of the Marine Midland Corporation of Buffalo, announced today that four banks in Elmira and adjacent communities plan to affiliate with his corporation.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices delined 0.6 point to 139.4 in the week ended on Tuesday. There was a conspicuous advance of non-ferrous metals, but the grains declined sharply.

Peggy Garcia, former hat-check girl whose $500,000 breach of promise suit against David Rubinoff, violinist, was dismissed Wednesday in Supreme Court, was arrested last night with her husband, Michael La Rocca, whom she married last September. Both were charged with bigamy.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading continued only fair to slow. Some good grades steer cuts were lower, strictly choice and prime steady. Veal continued downward price trend. Lamb sold mostly steady, fresh pork cuts steady to slightly lower. Kosher business was confined largely to lamb at about steady prices.

About $800,000,000 in maturing securities will be refunded by the Treasury on March 15, but there will be no issues for the purpose of obtaining "new money" or cash, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

MANHATTAN AAROE, PETRA (Feb. 6). Estate, not more than $5,000. To Johannes Andersen, uncle. executor, 1,120 Park Av., residue. BLUM, ANNA (Feb. 17). Estate, more than $10,000. To Henrietta Blum, mother, 230 W. 79th St., tangible personal property and life estate in residue, with right to any or all of principal of trust; five contingent bequests; M. M. Blum, brother, executor, 230 W. 79th St., remainder in residue.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Gage Crofut, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Crofut of Cleveland, to William Augustus Whift tlesey. Jr., 'son of Mr. and Mrs, William A. Whittlesey.of this city; lis to take place at the First Congregational Church, Pittsfield, Sat. urday. April 3.

Governor Lehman will submit his supplementary budget bill to the Legislature tomorrow proposing additional expenditures. of about $5,000,000, including $4,000,000 for financing the requirements of the Social Security Act.

Frederic Hedge Kennard, associate in ornithology at the Museum of Comparative Zoology of Harvard University, died yesterday at Phillips House. His age was 71. Mr. Kennard, who lived in Newton Center, was born in Brookline,

Gene Letourneau, the fishin'est fellow in Maine, came down from Waterville the other day to see the National Sportsmen's Show. Between portages at Grand Central Palace, Gene, who does a nifty job of outdoor writing for a chain of New England newspapers (when he isn't fishing), took time out to jot down his impressions. Here they are:
By now it is plain that the bombs thrown at Marshal GRAZIANI and other high Italian officers at Addis Ababa were

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Feb. 24 were announced today: Bradbury, Lt. Cmdr. H. G., Coast Guard Academy, to the Modoc, as commanding officer, about June 1. Prall, Cmdr. W. M., the Tahoe, to San Francisco Division, as assistant to division engineer.
A bill which would provide a mechanism to settle maritime labor disputes was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Guffey.

The New York Telephone Company, controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, issued yesterday its annual report, showing for 1936 a net income of $34,485,325 applicable to the common stock after payment of preferred dividends.

Frederick J. Perry of Great Britain will return to Madison Square Garden next month to play William Tilden. Announcement was made yesterday at the 21 Club by Francis T. Hunter and S. Howard Voshell that the two former world amateur tennis champions have been signed for a series of five matches.

Despite the intervention of the Washington's Birthday holiday, the report of awards for engineering construction for the current week reached the highest total for the year and more than double the total for the same week of last year, according to The Engineering NewsRecord.

A onetime bicycle manufacturer who was without previous experience in high finance related today how he had pyramided an original investment of $2,072,000 into securities valued at $680,000,000 in 1929.

Reports for January issued by the railroads yesterday showed that in general railroads unaffected by floods or strikes increased their revenues last month despite the loss of the. emergency freight surcharges which expired on Dec. 31.

Mr. ALFRED N. PHILLIPS Jr., successor of that accomplished veteran, Mr. SCHUYLER MERRITT, as Representative in Congress of the Fourth Connecticut District, describes himself in the Congressional Directory as " a publisher." He is the author of H. R. 4952, " a bill for the furtherance of the freedom of the press."

The Port of New York Authority protested yesterday to Senator Copeland against the proposal to merge the America-France and American Hampton Roads-Yankee steamship lines on the ground that proposed service would be detrimental to the Port of New York and harmful to the interests of American shippers generally.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Lt. Col. Frank V. Schneider, Infantry, having been detailed for duty with the Organized Reserves, Second Corps Area, with station at New York City, N. Y., is assigned, effective upon completion of his present tour of foreign service, to duty as assistant to the District Senior Instructor, Metropolitan District, Southern New York Reserve Area.

Preparations are being undertaken by the civil governor and other authorities of Malaga, recently captured by the Rebels, for the immediate repair of the extensive material damage and to insure adequate provisioning of the city.
