The annual statement of the New York Life Insurance Company, published today, shows the company's insurance and annuity reserve to have been more than $1,957,000,000 on Dec. 31 last.

Settlement of the strikes on the Sixth Avenue subway and the Wards Island sewage disposal plant project was announced last night by the Board of Transportation after a day of conferences with contractors and spokesmen for labor organizations.

The New York Athletic Club quintet accounted for its tenth victory in eleven Eastern Athletic Club League games by routing the University Club of Stamford, Conn., 47 to 31, on the winners' court last night.

Senator WAGNER'S new Housing Bill is by all odds the most promising plan that has yet been offered to Congress for the solution of one of our great problems. It has two admirable purposes. One is to stimulate an important industry which has lagged behind the general movement toward recovery.

A guarded plea for a broad interpretation of the Constitution was made last night by Governor Lehman, speaking at a testimonial dinner for Charles Poletti, counsel to the Governor, at the Hotel Astor.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total gold holdings reached a new low for 1937.

Uncovered by a gardener's hoe, the burial plot of W. S. Downs, Louisiana statesman who contended in the Senate with Henry Clay, was restored to public view today. Historians had sought the grave for years.

At a meeting of Radical Socialist Deputies on the eve of Pierre-Etienne Flandin's interpellation on Premier Leon Blum's policy, no voice was raised to urge that the party bolt the Popular Front during tomorrow's discussion.

Three mahogany tables, usually highly polished for the use of lawyears in the Bronx County Court, assumed yesterday the disheveled appearance of tables in a contractor's shanty while for five hours five attorneys questioned an engineer on the differences between his steel plans and those drawn by an architect for the apartment house at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, which collapsed last June killing eighteen men.
While floods are abating in Central Germany, the Rhine is still rising. At Coblenz it was nearly twenty-three feet above normal this afternoon and still mounting.
The House Foreign Affairs Committee, by a vote of 15 to 3, reported favorably the revised McReynolds Neutrality Resolution, the text of which was printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Wednesday.

Currier Ives prints from the collection of Mrs. Frances H. Reilly of New Haven, Conn., and others brought $7,244 last night at auction at the Plaza Art Galleries. A rare large folio print, "Winter in the Country-Getting Ice," went to J. Rothschild for $800.
A group of minority stockholders sued today the Inland Steel Company for $1,086,665 in Federal court, alleging fraud in connection with the sale of the Inland Steamship Company.
Foren days St. John's has remained blockaded port as huge Arctic loes spread along the coast and Penetrated every inlet, pressed in y continuing easterly winds.

Frank Iannicelli, younger brother of Tom, the world open champion, gained an easy victory over Andy K. Marckwald of Short Hills as play in the annual National Class B squash tennis championship opened at the Cresecent A. C. courts yesterday.

" Paris dress designers this Spring are thinking in terms of the sales opportunity offered by the coronation, rather than of the American market," Tobe, style expert and merchandising counsel, informed a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

An antilynching bill which its authors, Senator Wagner of New York and Senator Van Nuys of Indiana, declared was not an assault on States' rights but an attack upon mob rule, was introduced in the Senate today.
The Yale swimming team tonight defeated Franklin and Marshall, 48 to 27, for its 161st consecutive dual meet triumph and created three new team relay records.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, defended today the necessity for a long-range social security program, asserting that one of his greatest problems was to get "responsible citizens" to think about the scope and cost of the work to be done.

The Toronto Maple Leafs advanced to within 3 points of second place in the international group of the National Hockey League tonight by upsetting the pace-setting Montreal Canadiens, 3-1, before a crowd of 8,000.

A plea to the governments of the world to follow the example set by the twenty-one American republics at the Buenos Aires conference last Summer was made last night by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in an address before the Council on Foreign Relations at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

After listening to two witnesses, the grand jury yesterday refused to indict Everiste Girouarde, 29 years old, a dog fancier of 95 Lexington Avenue, for the alleged theft of Supreme Midget, a prize Pomeranian, from the Westminster Kennel Club's show in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 10.

Edwin C. Mott, for sixty years a lawyer, first in Manhattan and then in Yonkers, died last night in his home here. His age was 81. He was a former president of the Yonkers Museum of Science and Arts, located in Trevor Park.

The Maritime Commission has accepted the bid of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of $0.2575 per gross ton for the dry docking of fifty-four ships in the commission's laid-up fleet in the James River. It is estimated that this work, which is to begin at once, will cost about $105,700, or an average per ship of $507.40.

Alexander Jay Bruen, greatgrandson of John Jay, died yesterday at his home, 19 East Eightythird Street, at the age of 81. He practiced law here from 1880 until his retirement about ten years ago. Mr. Bruen was born in Newport, R. I.,

The Commercial Credit Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for March 30 to consider an increase in the authorized preferred stock to $50,000,000 par value, of which $12,230,200 of 41/4 per cent convertible preferred stock is to be considered a part and constitute one series.

Waddill Catchings, private banker and former president of the Goldman Sachs Trading Company, is being sted by his divorced wife, Mrs. Helen Werner Catchings, for $1,000,000 alleged to be due under a 1930 separation agreement, it was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $4,260,000 of refunding, welfare and PWA project bonds of Syracuse, N. Y., on a bid of 100.0599 for 2.20s. The bonds,

David Mannes will continue the series of free symphony concerts under his direction on Saturday night, March 6, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Four concerts on Saturday nights will be given through March.

Monroe Goldwater, counsel for the trustees of the Warner-Quinlan Company, which' is in reorganization proceedings, reported to Federal Judge Hulbert that all parties were working harmoniously toward evolving a reorganization plan which contemplates the sale of more than 200 gasoline stations of the company to the Cities Service Company.

While the "educators" in America are discussing the "social order," word comes. from England that a "revolution" in her schools is being planned and that in a few months London, and later the whole country, will be able to understand "what the revolution means." The "revolutionary campaign"

Forty-two jumpers were named today as prob able starters in the renewal of th? Grand National Steeplechase at Ain tree March 19. The list included the favorite Royal Mail, and Miss Dorothy Paget's Golden Miller, a forme winner of the classic.

Among the interesting political developments of the controversy over the President's Supreme Court plan is not only the refusal of members of the Senate Progressive group to support. the proposal but the counter-plans offered by some of them.

Into the midst of President Roosevelt's struggle with a determined group of Senators over his sweeping proposals for reform of the Federal judiciary, Senator Borah today tossed a proposed constitutional amendment to re-define the "due process" clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

Mrs. Ethel Stockton, who served on the jury which convicted Bruno Richard Hauptmann in the Lindbergh kidnapping case, journeyed from Hunterdon County, N. J.. to Nassau County during the snowstorm tonight to speak in favor of the proposed law to permit women to serve on juries in New York State.

Anton Torgersen, a retired sea captain and veteran of the World War, died yesterday at Staten Island Hospital, New Brighton, after a long illness. He was 60 years old and resided at 556 Davis Avenue, St. George, S. I.

State Trooper Stacey Gunderman was convicted of second degree murder tonight by a jury of Western Pennsylvania mountain folk, who decided that he had maliciously beaten to death Frank C. Monaghan, Uniontown hotel keeper, in the Bertillon room of the Fayette County jail Sept. 12.

What Have You, Frank M. Gould's American-owned candidate for the Grand National at Aintree, March 19, received his first competitive test over the British jumps today, but wound up last in a field of seven in the three miles of the Newbury Steeplechase.
Switzerland today produced the only startling surprise of the world's amateur hockey championship by extending the undefeated English team to two overtime periods before England won, 2-0.

An unidentified gunman who pressed a pistol against a jewelry salesman's ribs as the salesman entered his automobile near a busy Bronx intersection at 5 P. M. yesterday, was particular that the driver obey the new traffic regulations.

The Police Department, after a survey by First Deputy Commissioner Fowler and Deputy Chief Inspector O'Leary, relaxed yesterday the ban on turns on red light for six traffic intersections in Manhattan.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "World - Wide Political Current Events," Mrs. Henry R. Caraway. Meeting of the Women's Committee of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, Hotel McAlpin, 11 A. M. "Woman's Contribution to Better Human Relations," Mrs. Her. bert H. Lehman, Mrs. Harper Sibley, Dean Georgiana. McEntee.

The Police Department, after a survey by First Deputy Commissioner Fowler and Deputy Chief Inspector O'Leary, relaxed yesterday the ban on turns on red light for six traffic intersections in Manhattan.

Waddill Catchings, private banker and former president of the Goldman Sachs Trading Company, is being sted by his divorced wife, Mrs. Helen Werner Catchings, for $1,000,000 alleged to be due under a 1930 separation agreement, it was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday.

David Mannes will continue the series of free symphony concerts under his direction on Saturday night, March 6, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Four concerts on Saturday nights will be given through March.

Monroe Goldwater, counsel for the trustees of the Warner-Quinlan Company, which' is in reorganization proceedings, reported to Federal Judge Hulbert that all parties were working harmoniously toward evolving a reorganization plan which contemplates the sale of more than 200 gasoline stations of the company to the Cities Service Company.

Forty-two jumpers were named today as prob able starters in the renewal of th? Grand National Steeplechase at Ain tree March 19. The list included the favorite Royal Mail, and Miss Dorothy Paget's Golden Miller, a forme winner of the classic.

THESE are what might be called second-hand footnotes. They were jotted down while the athletes were competing in the New York A. C. games last week. But what they did last week may have some bearing on what they will do this week, and the A. A. U. indoor championships are hard at hand. Consequently and without further introductory remarks:
The European table tennis team captured three of five matches from American representatives in the grand ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker last night and annexed the series, 7 to 3.
Herbert G. Summers of Boston died here last night. He was 55 years old.

The first meeting of the committee appointed by the Retail Store Executives Association to make a study of employee relations in stores in the metropolitan area will be held here next Monday or Tuesday, it was stated yesterday by T. W.

The steel industry began today a series of increases in prices of steel which is expected to be followed by another advance in wages and the establishment of the $5 day for common labor in steel plants.
The joint' resolution extending until June 12,. 1940, the power of the President to enter into foreign trade agreements was passed by the Senate this afternoon by a vote of 58 to 24.

Nathan E. Percy, 34 years old, of 124 West Ninety-third Street, jumped or fell to his death yesterday morning from his sixth-floor apartment. He was a member of the law firm of Timen Percy, 36 West Forty-fourth Street. Police listed his death as suicide, pending further investigation.

Officials of the New York Curb Exchange expect that the special committee organized to deal with the rules to govern "daylight trading" that were suggested onWednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission will take favorable action at its meeting today.

Arriving here tonight to address members and friends of Local 118, United Automobile Workers of America, Homer Martin, international president of the union, found that officials of the local had been unable to hire a hall for the meeting.

The letter addressed to Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, by the government's Reich Church Commission for the administration of the Protestant Church, which recently resigned, has now become available.

Petitions Filed--By HYMAN BECKER, laundry driver, 152 Mansion St., Poughkeepsie--Liabilities $26,638, assets $25,000. MORRIS COWEN, ladies' tailor, 1,455 Sheridan Av.--Liabilities $1,107, assets $225 exclusive of insurance.
Division St., 118-20, three 5-story tenements and stores, 63.9x61.7 by irreg.; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co. against Kley Realty Corp.; due, $49,709; taxes, , $9,162; to plaintiff for $50,000.
Baroness Wijk, daughter of S. S. Kresge, and Charles Murphy of Detroit were married here today by the Rev. Archibald Alexander at Marylebone Presbyterian Church.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $95,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $8,633,000,000, according to the weekly condition statement of the banks, published yesterday.

Shareholders of Safeway Stores, Inc., when they meet on March 17, will be asked to approve a refinancing plan under which $10,000,000 of bank loans and $8,399,700 of 7 per cent preferred stock will be retired and an employment contract made with Lingan A. Warren,
In a surprise vote the Senate today defeated the bill passed by the Chamber of Deputies according the government full powers to modify tariff rates and to combat dumping.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Rye, N. Y., yesterday kept the United States in the running in the seventh annual Junior League invitation squash racquets tournament and today at noon will be put to the final test against her English adversary.

The House of Representatives remained in session all last night hearing. the Controller General's charges of graft against War Minister Plinio Mendoza Niera, who served as Controller General in the Olaya administration and for part of the present administration.
The five-story apartment house containing 108 rooms at 711 West 180th Street was resold yesterday by the Highboro Realty Corporation to an investor represented by J. Karp, attorney. The flat,

Ambassador William C. Bullitt's Washington's Birthday speech in Paris has inspired a belated but sarcastic editorial in the Frankfurter Zeitung. While the newspaper admits "the undoubted political zeal

To facilitate an early agreement on the reorganization plan for the Munson Steamship Line and subsidiary corporations, the debenture holders reorganization committee, composed of Cornelius A. Sullivan, chairman; David C. Ross and William J. MacGuire, said yesterday, in a letter to holders of the 6 1/2 per
William P. Crowell, State Director of WPA operations, has revealed that his relief agency has taken over the "Quoddy" village.
Henry Ford said today he preferred newspapers to history books in modern education and not too many games during school hours.
Marjorie Mears, president of the New York Newspaper Women's Club, announced yesterday that sixty entries had been received in the prize contest being conducted by the club.

Organization of building councils in communities throughout the country to raise practices in the building industry to higher levels, has begun under the sponsorship of sixty-eight chapters of the American Institute of Architects.

Viscount Halifax, Lord Privy Seal, speaking at a League of Nations Union meeting at Southampton last night, said the British Government believed that peace might be immensely strengthened by a system of regional pacts.

Annoyed at what he termed a "tempest in a teapot," William A. Clarke, principal of John Adams High School, Queens, explained last night the circumstances which led to the removal of "Arrowsmith" and "Les Miserables" from general circulation in the school library.

Approximately $275,000 has been allocated for relief work among the Jews of Poland during the first three months of this year, Dr. Bernhard Kahn, D. J. Schweitzer and Nathan Katz of the American Joint Distribution Committee declared today on their return from a survey trip in Poland that at no time since their work began there have they seen more appalling misery or a greater feeling of despair among the Jews.
Hitting top form in the last eight minutes, the Roxbury School basketball team subdued the Columbia freshmen, 35-28, yesterday in the Lions' gymnasium. The half-time score was- 14-all.
Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of traffic, announced yesterday. two additional exceptions to the ban on turns on red lights.
The Hun School hockey team scored its eighth victory out of nine starts

A rapidly spreading fire in Brooklyn's main shopping district menaced one of the borough's largest department stores, caused slight injury to five firemen, severely damaged a building at 482 Fulton Street and tied up important Brooklyn traffic arteries for more than an hour yesterday morning.

A committee to represent $8,549,000 of Philippine Railway 4 per cent bonds due on July 1 was elected at a meeting yesterday called by the Bankers Trust. Company, trustee for the issue, and held in its office at 16 Wall Street.
A "stay-in" to prevent a "sitdown"-something new in labor disputes-was under way here tonight with about 300 employes of the Eagle Ottawa Leather Company participating.

Russia withdrew from the naval patrol on the Spanish coasts at today's meeting of the non-intervention subcommittee. She did this after having previously objected to the zone allotted her, which was in the Bay of Biscay, but her formal withdrawal came only after the committee had unanimously agreed that any noninterventionist power wishing to participate in the sea control scheme should have the right to do so.

Miss Gertrude Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Friedman of 1,424 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, and Benjamin Schaffer, New York attorney, were married by Mayor La Guardia yesterday morning in his offices at City Hall.

A barrage of nauseating and tear gas fired by deputy sheriffs and police equipped with guns, hand-grenades and an improvised battle tower ended at daybreak this morning the nine-day sit-down strike in the Fansteel Mettallurgical Corporation's plants at North Chicago.

The Linen Thread Co. Inc., of Paterson bought from the Belgrove Realty Co. as a site for a factory a plot 371 by 177 feet on the north side of Belgrove Drive, between Passaic and Clarke Avs., Kearny. The Osborne Drilling Corp sold to the Sprague Henwood, Inc., of Scranton, Pa., a one-story frame storage building on the southwest corner of Adams and 15th Sts., Hoboker.

Mediocre races ruled the national field trials today with championship bird dog form still to be displayed over the rolling Hobart Ames plantation. Age told on 6-year-old Air Circus, a pointer from the kennels of Miss C. S. Phelps of Cleveland.
Florida will decide its 3-year-old turf championship tomorrow when an even dozen colts face the barrier in the $20,000 added Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah Park.

A matter of $2,500 yesterday separated Colonel Jacob Ruppert and Lefty Gomez when the Yankees' owner and his southpaw pitching ace conferred for the third time. The Yankee vanguard leaves today for St. Petersburg, Fla. Gomez has been successful in hiking his promised stipend for this year up to $12,500. On that figure.
In the face of recurrent rumors of the danger threatening Czechoslovakia from attack by Germany, reassuring views were expressed to the writer today by the Czechoslovak Foreign Minister,
Fred Smith's Wildfire won the Duke of Kent's Cup race at Montagu Park today in record time before a record crowd. This was the feature of the racing season here.

Two Cornell men reached the singles semi-finals in Cornell's invitation indoor tennis tournament tonight. One of them, William Simpson, up set Raymond Antignat of Columbia, seeded No. 2, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4.

Ruling that he could pass only upon .the legal and not upon the moral aspects of the case, Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck refused today to declare void mortgages amounting to $251,000 on Westchester real estate owned by Joseph Marcadante of Larchmont.

Tom Iannicelli of Short Hills, world open squash tennis champion, and Dan Martella of the Wilmington, Del., Country Club, first and second seeded entrants, respectively, gained the right to meet for the title in the inaugural New York State professional squash racquets championship at the Downtown Athletic Club last night.
The strike at the Electric Boat Company plant ended its fourth day tonight, the deadlock between the company and officials of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers unbroken.
John Semer Farnsworth, former naval officer, was sentenced by Justice James M. Proctor in United States District Court today to serve from four to twelve years in prison for peace-time espionage.

Mr. and Mrs. John T. Terry Jr. of 340 East Seventy-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Josephine Taylor Terry, to William Hude Neilson Brune, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy J. Brune of North Stonington, Conn.

It is understood that the Italian civil airlines have obtained a five-year contract for running a service from Buenos Aires to Uruguay, Paraguay, Chile, Bolivia and Patagonia on the expiration of the present contract between the Argentine Government and a French company.

Retail trade continued quite active here during the week, although the comparative showing with a year ago varied rather widely among department stores. Some establishments launched heavy promotions, while others did not stage the special events they did a year ago and consequently had large figures "to beat."

Dr. Louis I. Dublin of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has leased his residence at 22 West St., Mamaroneck, Westchester, to George Anscomb, through Peter C. Doern Jr., broker. G. Schnell, in 554 South Tenth St.; M. Bross, in 515 South 17th St.; Eli Simon.

The approximate status or tne municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for saving banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Appointment of a number of new executives was announced yesterday by Arnold, Constable Co. Miss Dorothy Murdock Cox on Monday will become stylist for the store. She has resigned her post in a similar capacity with Frederick Loeser Co., Inc.

The volume of fabricated structural steel booked in January was down seasonally compared to recent months, amounting to 130,651 tons, the American Institute of Steel Construction reports, but this was "comfortably" in excess of the figure for last year, which was 120,364 tons.

The increase in cotton mill activity last week was less than seasonal and the adjusted index fell back 1 point. The figure now is 137.4 as against 138.4 (revised) for the preceding week. For the week ended Feb. 22, 1936, the index stood at 109.5.
Two copies of the first folio of the plays of Shakespeare as well as copies of later folios were sold last night at auction at the Rains Galleries.

Thanks to a remarkable victory gained by its No. 5 man, A. F. Douglas, the Bronxville Field Club yesterday won the Class C team championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, defeating the Harvard Club, Group 1 winners, by 3 to 2.

Two women were among the thirty-three recipients today of the 1936 Charles A. Coffin Foundation awards, the highest honors given by the General Electric Company. The remaining prizes were divided among fifteen factory men, twelve engineers, two commercial men and two of the office force.

Professor William H. Kilpatrick, whose enforced retirement at the age of 65 from Teachers College, Columbia University, under an automatic rule, brought protests this week from schoolmen all over the country, was hailed today as the prophet of "a distinctive type of education suited to a democracy" by 5,000 educators at the national convention of the Progressive Education Association here.
The directors of Armour Co., packers, announce that they had ordered the retirement on June 1 of $27,813,000 of real estate first mortgage 4 1/2% per cent bonds due in 1939.

Covering of March obligations carried prices into new high ground for the year on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, with the list 3 to 12 points higher. Under aggressive buying for both foreign and domestic account, the spot month widened its premium to 105 points t over December of the 1937 crop, while steadily increasing the difference over both May and July.
Wheat made a tame start and a relatively strong finish today on the Board of Trade, with closing trades in futures V4 to 1% cents a bushel higher than yesterday, the latter on May.

With promotions of Spring merchandise giving impetus to the widening consumer-buying trend, retail sales this week surged ahead with renewed vigor, the volume for the country being estimated at 14 to 22 per cent higher than the total in the. corresponding period last year, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Under the spur of Governor Lehman, the Senate Labor and Industry Committee today reported the FischelSteingut Minimum-Wage Bill. A t floor vote is expected next week.

Somewhere in a government warehouse lie 150 copies of a volume described as the most authoritative work on present-day China, lost to American readers unless the Customs Service not only relaxes its rules but also is able to locate them.

Premier Leon Blum was subjected to a severe attack in the Chamber of Deputies today, with former Premier PierreEtienne Flandin as a battleship, Paul Reynaud as a light cruiser and others playing the parts of destroyers and even submarines.

183d St. (11-3197), n. e. cor. Grand Av., 100x100; Isidore Fruman to Grand Av. Associates Corp., 149 B'way; mtg., $110,000. Webster Av. (12-3357), e. s., 1,093 ft. n. of Burke AV.. 250x64; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp., trustee, to Cornelius J. Smyth. trustee. 1.192 Park Av.

Mrs. George Laurie Osgood Jr. of this city, formerly of Newton, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Catherine Farley Osgood, to Thomas Henry Foster Jr., son of Mrs. Thomas H. Foster of Bennington, Vt. and the late Mr. Foster.

As twentytwo Detroit industrial plants were affected by sit-down strikes, Governor Frank Murphy entered the labor situation here today. He sent to the city George A. Krogstad, State Labor Commissioner, who opened an office in the Transportation Building.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 20 amounted to 714,884 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Effingham Lawrence Hunter of Flushing, Queens, and Litchfield, Conn., of the engagement of Mrs. Hunter's laughter, Miss Natalie Gillet Adenaw, to John Brantley Mulford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Brantley Mulford of Philadelphia and Penrith Farm, Lodi, N. Y.

The entire political situation in the Legislature was thrown into confusion tonight by the death in Syracuse of Assemblyman Richard B. Smith, Onondaga Republican. The Republicans, through his death, no longer possess the constitutional majority of seventy-six votes needed to pass a bill and a deadlock may result.

Australia had scored 530 runs for the loss of five wickets at tea time today in the fifth and deciding test cricket match with England. The Australians will carry on after the interval in an effort to build an even larger first innings score.

A building loan of $180,000 has been placed by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., on the apartment house under construction on the northeast corner of 174th Street and Grand Concourse, the Bronx, with the General Realty Utilities Corp.

The Morris Plan Industrial Bank of New York has been authorized by the State Banking Department to change the location of its business from 33 West Forty-second Street, New York City, to 60 East Forty-second Street.
A day of desperate fighting that lasted until long after midnight tightened yesterday the circle being drawn about Oviedo by government forces.

Chairman Walsh of the Naval Affairs Committee indicated in the Senate today that the controversy between the government and the steel makers over the forty-hour-week clause in the Walsh-Healey act, of which he was co-author, was nearing solution as a result of negotiations.

Report that Gaumont British Pictures, Ltd., will close its studios at Shepherds Bush near London and curtail its production elsewhere were confirmed today in a statement issued by the company early this morning after a conference lasting twelve hours.

One statement attributed to WALTER RUNCIMAN, President of the British Board of Trade, in his address the other day to the National Liberal Club is puzzling. As proof of England's "open door" policy in trade, he cited her imports last year of [Pound]849,000,000--"an "amount probably unequaled, he sug"gested, by any country in the history "of civilization." In actual value,

As a result of the Moreland Act investigation ordered by Governor Lehman into alleged frauds in the State Motor Fuel Tax Bureau, an increase in the personnel of the bureau has been recommended, two more employes have been suspended and other steps have been taken to guard against future frauds, it was disclosed today.

Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, testified at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing here yesterday that the bondholders' protective committee for Kreuger Toll secured debentures which bear his name voted last Autumn to itself and its attorneys remuneration aggregating $290,000. This sum,

Monday's dispatches from THE TIMES'S European financial correspondents expressed doubt as to whether any action would be taken here to " penalize" foreign investments in our markets, with a view to stopping the flow of foreign capital into our securities. But they agreed that,

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 929,000 bales, against 920,000 a week ago, 906,000 two weeks ago, 906,000 three weeks ago and 745,000 a year ago; of which American 410,000 bales, against 415,000 a week ago, 399,000 two weeks ago, 396,000 three weeks ago and 399.000 a year ago.

The condition of most Mexicans is better under the regime of President Lazaro Cardenas than ever before, Ambassador Josephus Daniels informed the American Winter Seminar, meeting in the United States Embassy today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The opposition to the Federal child labor amendment on the part of the Catholic hierarchy has been brought. out this year openly. I have-talked with many of my Roman Catholic friends, including members of the clergy, and find differences of opinion as to the desirability of the amendment.

Frank S. Dodd, former president of the Newark Tax Board, died today at his home here, after a week's illness. He was 73 years old, was born here, and had been a seafood merchant for more than forty years.
The Norfolk Western Railway has increased from 1,000 to 2,000 each orders for hopper cars recently placed with the Virginia Bridge Company and the Bethlehem Steel Company.

99th St., 306 W., 59.6x100.11; 306 W. 99th St. Corp., Mildred M. Schwab, president, to New York Savings Bank; purchase money $102,000. Same property, same to Ernest MacLead, 3,495 Broadway; prior mtg. $102.000: $2.000.

Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed irregularly higher; turnover, 1,775,190 shares. United States Government bonds slightly lower. corporate issues irregular, Polish loans continued weak; transactions, $12,222,400.
John W. Hutchinson, an attorney, who had been active in Republican. politics, died on Thursday in his apartment at the Hotel Roosevelt of a heart ailment. He was 66 years of age.

The Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets defeated the New York Rovers in the final minutes of an overtime Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight, 3-2. The Jackets held a 2-0 lead in the second period, but Wareing, assisted by McKay, cut it to 2-1 in that frame. Then Collings,
Dr. Carlos Brenes Jarquin, former President of Nicaragua, who has been appointed Minister to Washington, left Managua today for his new post.

President Roosevelt asked Congress today to enact legislation abolishing the dual system of measurement of vessels using the Panama Canal, and substituting therefore Panama Canal Rules of Measurement as presceribed by the President. These rules would provide for a reduction in tolls in some cases.

Valentine AV., 2,335 (11-3151): Joseph Altman to Union Dime Savings Bank; extends mtge. to Feb. 1, 1942, at 5 per cent.$79,000 Boynton Av. (14-3741). e. s., 134 ft. s. of Westchester Av., 150x100 ft.; M. G. Enterprises, Inc., to State Mortgage Commission, installments, at 4 to 4 1/2 per cent,

After reaching their highest levels in thirty years, the Rhine, Moselle, Main and Neckar began to fall slowly this afternoon. In some areas inhabitants returning to take stock of the damage reported it was considerable.

Anthony La Via of New York scored a major upset as he beat Joseph R. Johann, the defending champion, in the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline billiard tournament at the Capitol Health Center last night. The score was 200173.
Mrs. W. Freisenbruch surprised tennis followers today by defeating Miss Gladys Hutchings, Bermuda's No. 1 woman player, 6-3, 6-3, in the final of the Princess Hotel tourney.

Pale and unshaven, Luis Carlos Prestes appeared today before the Supreme Military Tribunal for trial as an army deserter. Refusing to accept counsel appointed by the tribunal, he said he would defend himself, but declared that after a year in jail he was not conversant with the recent changes effected in military jurisprudence.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, and Representative W. D. McFarlane, Texas Democrat, criticized the "power trust" and the Supreme Court tonight at the opening of a three-day conference on the social control of power called by the League for Industrial Democracy.

By JOSEPH P. DAY, INC. 106th St., 161-163 E., two 4-story tenements and stores, 56.6x100.11: Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Harlex Realty Corp.; due, $35,724; taxes. , $165; to plaintiff for $1,000. Rivington St., 262, 5-story tenement and store, 25.2x100; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Rose Scherer; due. $23,442: taxes, , $2,000: to plaintiff for $1,000.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 24: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Brooks, W. A.. Washington, D. C., to Navy Yard, Mare Island, Calif. Lassiter, H. C., Navy Yard, Philadelphia, Pa., to Fleet Air Base, Pearl Harbor, T. H. Mathas, S. M., Charleston. W. Va., to home, relieved from all active duty.

Following hard on Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's recent announcement that Great Britain would push ahead in the immediate future toward pacification of Europe with regional pact in the West as the first objective,

Unless unforeseen contingencies arise, it is likely that within a fortnight the protracted conferences between railroad managements and employes for a voluntary system of retirement pay will be completed and will be announced by President Roosevelt, it was disclosed today after a visit of spokesmen for both sides to the President.

Standard Distributors, Inc., 114 East Thirty-second Street, New York, and Louis H. Geller, president, were named respondents in a Federal Trade Commission complaint today, which charges "unfair competition through providing retailers with means of conducting lotteries in sales of radios, food beaters and mixers, and through misrepresentation of certain products and facilities furnished these merchants," the commission announced today.

Since the start of the year, quite a few national advertisers have either stopped or curtailed their advertising in newspapers and magazines, whose rate increases they have regarded as unreasonable, according to declarations yesterday by executives of these companies.
The Teachers Retirement Board voted yesterday to restrict future contributions to its fund to amounts which would produce not more than half the teacher's average salary upon retirement.

Captain Bernard William St. Denis Thomson, for twenty-one years sports editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died suddenly last night at St. Luke's Hospital. He was taken ill Wednesday morning, a few hours after completing his duties at THE TIMES.

A biazing tropical sun, tempered, however, by a cooling breeze off the Gulf, saw Colonel Bill Terry drive his Giants today through their longest and most satisfactory workout since this Cuban expedition got under way.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman enjoined the Emergency Relief Bureau last night from putting into effect the provisions of the so-called Lyons Residence Law by singling out for dismissal, in staff curtailments, those who fail to meet its requirements.

Vacant plots and houses changed hands yesterday in deals announced in Queens communities. Irving O'Melia sold to Thesa Ernstberger a plot 200 by 220 feet on the north side of Sixty-second Drive, between Ninety-seventh Place and Ninety-seventh Street.

128th St., 57 E., 18.9x99.11: Sadie Mergash, referee, to Emma G. Thompson, 128 Pinehurst Av.; foreclosure ($1). Madison Av., n. e. cor. 31st St.; Gertrude C. Rourke to Sarah Backer. 29 E. 64th St.: mtg. $825,000; three-fourths interest (50c). Same property; same to Myra A. Blum, 1,112 Park Av., et al., administratrix of Emanuel Arnstein; mtg. $825,000: one-fourth interest (50c).

The New York Athletic Club's golfers who have been spending the past week here played their last scheduled best-ball handicap tourney today. The party will return to New York tomorrow. Perfect weather conditions prevailed.

Executors of. an estate should not be punished for following the wishes of the sole beneficiary, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court ruled yesterday by a three-totwo vote in reversing a decision of Surrogate James A. Delehanty, which imposed a surcharge of $195, 000 on the Brooklyn Trust Company and Charles H. George as executors of the will of Claude C. Pinney, formerly a member of the New York Stock Exchange.

Pedro Montanez, the whirlwind from Puerto Rico, is knocking at the door of the world lightweight championship as the result of his decisive triumph over Enrico Venturi, holder of the European 135pound title, in their fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., of New York City filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a notification of registration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1936 as a holding company.
A clash between strikers and strike-breakers in Manhattan and strikes called in three additional buildings in the Bronx marked the progress of the building strike yesterday.

Pensioned--On Their Own Application PATROLMEN-Edward P. Fream, 88th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 19, 1907. Joseph J. Doelger, Traffic Precinct L. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 5, 1912.

Sixteen lots at Elberon, N. J., have been sold to Samuel Slotkin, who intends to use them as a paddock for his horses. The Siwanoy Development Company was the seller. David S. Meyer, Inc., con?? the sale.

Edward P. Field Jr. of the Princeton Club, seeded No. 1, conquered John S. Davidson, Yale Club, 15-4 15-4, in the outstanding secondround match of the national Class C squash tennis championship at the Crescent Athletic Club in Brooklyn yesterday.

A General Sessions jury, after deliberating six hours on the evidence, reported at 6 o'clock last night their inability to arrive at a verdict in the second-degree manslaughter indictment against Patrolman William F. Glendenning of the Charles Street station in the killing of the driver of a horse and truck on the Queensborough Bridge in the early morning of Aug. 21 last. The jurors,
Ruth Slenczynski, the 12-year-old girl from Sacramento, Calif., who has been hailed as a piano prodigy since she was 6, bowed off the stage at Queen's Hall promptly at 10 o'clock tonight.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at dinner in the White House tonight honoring Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr., wife of the Secretary of the Treasury and a longtime friend of the Roosevelts. Additional guests were invited for a musical after dinner.

The text of the Cuban-British trade agreement signed Feb. 19 and made public today reveals that Cuba has granted certain tariff concessions and exemptions from nationalistic labor laws and promised to refrain from promulgating more restrictive insurance legislation affecting British companies.
Catholics of the State of Veracruz sent today a telegram to President Lazaro Cardenas asking that he dictate a solution of the church problem in the State.

Peggy Garcia, former night club hat-check girl, whose $500,000 breach of promise suit against David Rubinoff, the violinist, was dismissed in the Supreme Court Wednesday, and Michael La Rocca, 30 years old, a granite salesman, whom she married last September in the Municipal Building, were indicted yesterday on bigamy charges. Both were under arrest.
Miss Doris Muriel Harrison, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. F. M. Harrison of Drexel Hill, was married this evening to Dr. Charles A. Steiner, son of Mrs. Lou Steiner of Altoona and of the late Mr. Steiner.
General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano announced today in a broadcast from- Seville, Spain, that the Insurgent gunboat Canovas del Castillo had fired on and captured the Netherland steamer Ramboy.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission contended today that some transactions in the stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation through W. E. Hutton Co. were made without the buyers putting up any capital.
Building plans filed yesterday included an eleven-story and penthouse apartment at 108-112 East Eighty-seventh Street to cost $500,000. It will have 133 rooms in apartments of four and six rooms.
The Dowager Countess of Leicester, widow of the second Earl, died here today. She was 85 years old and had been in failing health for some time.

The engagement of Miss Rachel Marjorie Hixson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Warren Hixson of this place, to Dr. Richard H. Wilhelm of Princeton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Richard Wilhelm of Richmond Hill, Queens, has been announced by her parents.

By THOMAS J. LUNNEY Bradford Av., 1,243, 24x100.7, parcel 1; also Bradford Av., 1,245, 24x100.7, parcel 2; also Bradford Av., 1,247, 24x100.7, parcel 3; New York Protestant Episcopal Public School against Prospect Investing Co.; due on parcel 1 $15,649, taxes $1.445; on parcel 2 $15,510, taxes, , $1,488; on parcel 3 $15,556, taxes, , $1,391; three parcels sold to plaintiff for $1,000 each.

J. P. Morgan Co. and the National City Bank of New York, as fiscal agents for the Government of the Argentine Nation 6 per cent bonds, due 1959, and Public Working bonds due 1960, announced yesterday that they have drawn for retirement, at par and accrued interest, on April 1, out of sinking fund money, $306,500 and $165,500 of such bonds, respectively.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany has promised to respect Swiss neutrality, Giuseppe Motta, president of the Swiss Federal Council, announced today.
Newark Academy came from behind in the second half to conquer the Morristown School five, 26-23, on its home court today. Morristown opened up well, holding the lead, 18-12, at half-time.

Appointments The following ununiformed firemen, having completed their probationary period of three months satisfactorily, are appointed as firemen, fourth grade, with compensation each at the rate of $2,000 per' annum.
The Spring song of the Dodgers as they open another training season will not be marred by discord, on early indications. There is harmony among the holdouts.

Archibald Keightley Nicholson, artist in stained glass, whose windows adorn many of England's cathedrals, including Lincoln, Wells, Worcester, Chester, Norwich and Carlisle, died in London at the age of 65.

The Central Theatre, which only last night was showing subsequentrun pictures, joins the rank of Broadway first-run houses this morning with Universal's "Girl Overboard," featuring Gloria Stuart, Sidney Blackmer, Walter Pidgeon and Hobart,Cavanaugh.

Tonight's solitary closing, barring the unpremeditated which sometimes happens in this business, is "An Enemy of the People," the Ibsen play which Mr. Hampden revived for two weeks only and now is keeping his word.

Women who think, by virtue of their non-commitment to the status quo and their freedom to think, constitute the most progressive force in the world today, in the opinion of Mrs. Harper Sibley, wife of the president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

A new auction record for the 24cent airmail stamp of the 1918 issue, with the center inverted, was made yesterday when an unused specimen sold for $3,200 at the offering of United States stamps in the rooms of Nicholas Sanabria, 17 East Forty-second Street. It was purchased by Spencer Anderson, a Nassau Street stamp dealer, for a client.
Arthur W. Straus, retired Chicago and New York investment banker, died this morning in his Winter home at Miami Beach, Fla., of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.
Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, issued an order today forbidding criticism of Chancellor Adolf Hitler for calling church elections at this time.

Eighteen thoroughbreds, two of them fillies, were named today for the world's richest race, the Santa Anita Handicap, which will gross $136,800 if all go to the post tomorrow in the mile-and-a-quarter test.

THE NEW YORE TIMES has received the following communication from Representative Alfred N. Phillips of Connecticut: To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 12. 1937. you carry a short account of the proceedings in the United States House of Representatives on Feb. 11, 1937.

The value of non-alcoholic beverages produced in the United States during 1935, not including production of fruit and vegetable juices, was $160,843,680, an increase of 40.3 per cent over the $114,616,439 produced in 1933, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippines, and his daughters, the Misses Aurora and Zeneida Quezon, who had been at the Ambassador, left yesterday for Washington. They expect to return here on March 8.

Attorneys for power companies opposing the $37,000,000 Santee-Cooper hydro- electric project obtained from Judge J. Lyles Glenn in Federal Court today permission to question the validity of the Federal license under which the South Carolina Public Service Authority proposes to construct the development with Federal funds.
President Roosevelt received a report on the Philippines today from President Manuel Quezon of the island Commonwealth at luncheon in Mr. Roosevelt's office.
People on the island of Nantucket are talking secession.

State and national officials Joined today in tribute to Representative James P. Buchanan, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, at funeral services here. Mr. Buchanan died of heart disease in Washington on Monday.

While the Canadian public was reacting favorably today to the new AngloCanadian trade treaty announced yesterday, government officials were saying that one of its most important features was the manner in which it left the door open for an extension of the Dominion's recent trade treaty with the United States.
More than 400 judges, attorneys and friends attended the funeral of Surrogate George A. Slater of Westchester County this afternoon at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Kahn of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Kahn, to Leonard J. Marx of New York, son of Mrs. Solomon Hoffman of Allentown and the late Emil Marx of Sioux City, Iowa.
New York University's four-year undefeated record on its home court withstood its most serious threat of the season last night when the Violet's quintet turned back Villanova, 37 to 23.

Turpentlne firm, 42 cents; sales, 10 barrels; receipts, 84 barrels: shipments, 1,327 barrels; stock, 25,006 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 304; receipts. 162; shipments. 104: stock, 58.916. Quote: B; $8.25; D, $8.65; E, $8.95; F, G., H, I, $9.50; K, X, $9.65; N, $9.75; WW. X. $11.50.

Yale tonight defeated Cornell, 5 1/2 to 2 1/2, in their annual boxing match before a throng that included many junior promenade visitors. Captain Dick Galland's knockout of Peyser early in the second round, and Fred Siemer's one-round score over Charley Wallace in the unlimited event featured the action.

Per Wendelbo, managing director of the Norsk Telegram Bureau (Norwegian news agency), died today. He was 70 years old. Mr. Wendelbo was the author of several novels and long-time president of the Association of Norwegian Newspaper Men.

State Senator John J. McNaboe, speaking at a meeting of the New York Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution last night at the Hotel Plaza, charged that he had found Mayor La Guardia's name among the list of subscribers to the stock of the Russian-American Industrial Corporation, which aided Soviet industry.

Champion Jockel va Burgund, upstanding black and tan Doberman pinscher owned by Owen A. West of Lake Forest, III., and handled by James Sullivan, early this morning was awarded the piece of plate representing the bestin-show award at the exhibition of the Niagara Falls Kennel Club in the State Armory.

Mr. and Mrs. William Lafayette Burton 2d gave a reception yesterday at their home, 129 East Sixtyninth Street, for Countess Margaret Seherr-Thoss of Austria, who is visiting relatives and friends here.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Foundation Company has been called for March 23 to consider a proposal to change the authorized and outstanding no-par common stock into $1 par common stock and to increase the number of authorized shares to 500,000, against 100,000 now, to provide for present and future financing of the company.

The Rev. John E. Barlow, Professor of Philosophy at Xavier University, died at Good Samaritan Hospital here today after a short illness. He suffered a paralytic stroke while lecturing before a class in logic last Wednesday afternoon. His age was 66.
With nine performances of YVAN NOE's "Christian," the French Theatre of New York under the direction of GUY DE VESTEL is bringing its second season to a close at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre.

With thirty-three guests from business and government ranks, thirtyone professors and eighty-one students attended the second annual Harvard-Yale-Princeton twoday conference on public affairs opened here this afternoon.
Alabama asked the Supreme Court today to pass upon the State Unemployment Insurance Law, which is said to be much like the New York law upheld some time ago by- a 4-to-4 division of the justices.
The Diamond State Telephone Company's directors have approved an appropriation of $200,600 for new conStruction and replacement in March.
Hog receipts continue small and below trade requirements. This situation has precipitated somewhat keen competition for the limited supply, and prices as a result advanced 10 to 15 cents.
The Lawrenceville School polo team defeated the Yale freshmen in the 112th Armory by a score of 15 to 4 1/2 today. The victors jumped to an early lead and never were pressed.
Rosita Diaz, Spanish film star, who formerly acted in several Hollywood movie productions, was executed as a spy by Spanish Insurgents a month ago, it was learned here today.

Parents were warned against prolonging the nursery period of their children, and of the dangers resulting from adolescent "Peter Pans," at the twelfth annual conference of the Secondary Education Board, which opened yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Commodore.

For the Old Vienna gala dinner dance of tomorrow night at the Surf Club the lounge and dining room will be decorated to represent a ballroom of Schoenbrun, beautiful palace of the Hapsburgs. The orchestra will be dressed as a Viennese Hussar band.

Judge Henry S. Waldman of the Juvenile Court here fined two boys a total of $15 today for turning in three false fire alarms in Linden, N. J., last month, and told them they would have to earn the money themselves to pay the fines.

Horace Gregory will edit and H. W. Norton will publish a series of volumes entitled "New Letters in America." Volumes will appear twice each year-the first next September-and will be made up of a selection of unpublished verse and prose "revealing the character of the present decade, its consciousness of the society in which it lives and its awareness of new but not necessarily experimental forms of writing."

A persistent and widely credited report that President Roosevelt might tour the country personally for support of his judiciary reform program was heard here today as he announced that he had reserved radio time for the night of March 9 for another of his "fireside chats."

A luncheon was given yesterday at the Ritz Tower for Miss Cornelia Otis Skinner and Miss Fanny Bradshaw by Mrs. Alma Clayburgh. The other guests were Mrs. Arthur Impey, Mrs. Chester Griswold Burden, Mrs. David Franklin Houston and Miss Joyce Carey.
Honors were evenly divided between the United States and Canada at the end of the first day's competition in the North American figure skating championships.

Miss Mary Adele Halsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. W. Halsey of this place, has chosen March 19 for her wedding to William Waverly Bell of Montclair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waverly James Bell of Bacon's Castle, Surry County, Va.

Three top- ranking professional golfers, Ralph Guldahl, Harry Cooper and Horton Smith, all of Chicago, tied today for first place in the St. Petersburg open tournament with seventy-two-hole scores of 284. They will meet in an eighteen-hole play-off Monday afternoon.

Maurice Evans, a "dark horse," drove his team of huskies to a thrilling victory here today in the first running of the grueling fifteen-mile Arctic Dog Derby after passing the favorite in a nip-and-tuck stretch drive.

Although gross revenues reported by railroads yesterday for January in general showed increases despite the termination of the emergency freight surcharges on Dec. 31, in several cases lower net operating income was reported. Gross revenue of the first thirty-two companies to report showed an advance of 12.1 per cent, but their net aggregate income rose only 5.9 per cent.

Governor Lehman will hold an informal conference tomorrow, at his home, 820 Park Avenue, with the Governors of six other States, to discuss general relief problems which their States have in common with New York.

I. Nicholas Gordon, the attorney who successfully defended former Magistrate George F. Ewald against charges that he bought his place on the bench, was disbarred yesterday by unanimous decision of the Appellate Division.

While high grade bonds generally lost the buoyancy yesterday that had marked the group on Thursday, the market for secondary railroad loans was disturbed by the announcement by two carriers that decision had been reached to defer the March 1 interest on their obligations.

Many visiting clergymen will occupy pulpits in the city tomorrow, the third Sunday in Lent. The sermons will be on Lenten themes. The visitors will include an Archbishop, several Bishops and deans. Several of the guest preachers will be from Canada and--others will be from Great Britain.

Two QUAKER SISTERS: ELIZABETH BUFFUM CHACE AND LUCY BUFFUM LOVELL, collected and arranged by Malcolm R. Lovell. (Liveright, $2.50.) A portrait of two sisters who lived in the early nineteenth century drawn from their writings.

The directors of the Moscow Narodny Bank tonight issued a categorical denial of the charge by Marcus Samuel, Conservative Member of Parliament, published in The Times of London, that the Spanish Government's gold shipped from Spain to London for safekeeping had been handed over in the names of individuals to that bank and not to the branch of the government-owned and controlled Bank of Spain in London.
The 1936 tax collections of Jacksonville, Fla., were 101.74 per cent of budget anticipations, according to a report by F. M. Valz, commissioner of finance, and J. E. Pace, auditor.

Coffee, Brazil's principal export, broke 15 per cent in price today, as the Santos Coffee Exchange reopened, after a brokers' strike had precipitated a fortnight's shutdown. Ten thousand spectators were on hand as the bidding started.
A strong attack in the final five minutes enabled Columbia's basketball team to defeat Dartmouth, 45-43, last night in the Lions' gymnasium in an Eastern Intercollegiate League encounter.
The Columbia University swimming team vanquished City College, 47 to 22, in the C. C. N; Y. pool last night.
Beggars and blind, dumb, paralyzed or "recognized indigent" persons will have a hard time buying a drink in Mexico after today.

Space for the manufacture of garments, millinery and businesses of an allied nature was the major demand revealed by the contracts for commercial space reported closed by brokers yesterday. A number of printing firms also were reported to have taken new quarters. The detailed list follows:

CHAMPIONSHIP DIVISION Semi-Final Round-Miss Kathryn Hemphill, Columbia, S. C., defeated Mrs. William Hockenjos, Lake Hopatcong, N. J., 2 and 1; Miss Marjon Miley, Lexington, Ky., defeated Miss Dorothy Traung, San Francisco, 3 and 2.
Eighty geisha [female entertainers] walked out in Osaka yesterday because the geisha quarters' management refused to recognize the union they had formed.

The directors of the National Leather Company have recommended to stockholders the discontinuance and liquidation of the business, abandonment of its corporate enterprise and distribution of the assets, in accordance with a proposal made by holders of more than 99 per cent of the preferred shares.
Governor Lehman submitted to the Legislature today his supplemental budget totaling $4,453,958, of which $3,425,000 is to be used to finance the costs of the recently passed Social Security Act.

Officials of the C. I. T. Safety Foundation made public yesterday the names of the newspaper men receiving the foundation's cash awards for 1936 for work in connection with traffic safety. The awards will be presented at a dinner next Wednesday evening at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Shareholders of the McCall Corporation will meet here on March 16 to approve absorption of the McCall Company and the New Publishing Company and to vote on renewal of employment contracts with officials, according to a notice filed with the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff of the Cuban Army, asserted today that he was not seeking a Presidential nomination, and he reiterated his desire that a Constituent Assembly be called to provide a new Constitution.

The blue-ribbon event of the indoor track and field season, the national A. A. U. championships, will be staged in Madison Square Garden tonight when the top-ranking performers from five countries battle for sixteen titles in a meet that promises to supply the high spot of the campaign.
Dugald Stewart Walker, internationally famous artist, lecturer and author, died at a hospital here tonight. He was 48 years old.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The tone in the wool market is better, in consequence of the improvement in the foreign markets, both in fine and cross-bred wools, which has resulted in the advance in fine tops in Bradford of a penny a pound for the week.

Bishop John Taylor Smith, chaplain to Queen Victoria and for twenty-four and one-half years Chaplain General of the British Army, including the period of the World War, will be the chief speaker at a six-day local celebration of the centennial of the birth of Dwight L. Moody.
The Rutgers University crew schedule was announced today by Director of Athletics George E. Little as follows:

Miss Evelyn Soule Wurzburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Wurzburg of Bronxville, N. Y., was married here yesterday afternon in the Church of the Resurrection to John Hampton Barnes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hampton Barnes of Devon, Pa., by the rector, the Rev. Gordon Wadhams.

Formation of the Citizens Housing Council to coordinate ideas looking to the solution of slum clearance problems and low-cost housing was announced yesterday by Harold S. Buttenheim, editor of The American City, at a meeting in the City Club.
The legislative committee investigating milk control was urged yesterday to recommend the abandonment of the State Milk Control Law and its price-fixing features
Kabo, a 4-year-old filly owned by Mrs. C. C. Winters, came through with her third victory in six 1937 starts when she won the feature six-furlong dash at the Fair Grounds today.

Since both branches of Congress have now approved a resolution continuing for three more years the Government's power to negotiate reciprocal trade agreements, Secretary HULL is assured that he may go ahead with the splendid work that he has begun.

The five remaining seeded players In the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class B singles championship in progress at the Harvard Club entered the quarterfinals last night, but most of them were carried to one or two extra games by their opponents.

By drawing the third and last game of the supplementary match, made necessary to decide the tie for first place in the tournament proper, Isaac I. Kashdan, New York State titleholder, yesterday won the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club from Albert C. Simonson, the runner-up.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, addressing an international meeting of the New York State Federation of Business and Professional Women last night, discarded her prepared address to call on the women of the State to interest themselves in ratification of the Child Labor Amendment, now before the New York State Legislature.

Stockholders of Spiegel, Inc., at a meeting in Chicago, authorized yesterday the sale of 150,000 shares of new cumulative preferred stock, of which 100,000 shares will be offeared by a group headed by Brown Harriman Co. and Goldman, Sachs Co. when a registration statement filed with the SEC becomes effective.

Tightening of restrictions in regard to reports dealing with gross sales and the cost of goods sold under the Securities Act of 1933 for the protection of investors in connection with issuance of securities, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Estate, less than $10,000. To Tillie Davis, sister, 221 W. 82d St., $1,000; Felice A. Dworetzky, daughter, 20 W. 84th St., and Daniel Auslander, son, executor, 37 Riverside Dr., one-half residue each. Solon B. Lilienstein, 1,130 Park Av., executor.
Eastern District High and Thomas Jefferson High kept up the close fight for the Section 1, Brooklyn P. S. A. L. basketball honors by turning in triumphs yesterday.

The Experimental Theatre at Vassar, which has an enviable repstation for encouraging the less formal muses, this evening put on Ernst Toller's "No More Peace." It was in the nature of an American premiere, although Herr Toller's play, with attendant lyrics by Britain's violent young W. H. Auden, was seen a bit back in a subscription theatre in London.

The Greenwich Glee Club gave its annual concert at the Greenwich Country Club tonight. Miss Jane Wyeth, young American harpist, assisted. Russell Locke of the Greenwich Country Day School is director of the club and Dale Bar tholomew accompanist.

Three hundred Columbia College students and their guests participated last night in the chief event on the collegiate social calendar, the annual Columbia junior promenade, held in the Oval Room and ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, Madison Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.

Captain Ernst Lehmann, commander of the dirigible Hindenburg, announces in a publication appearing here that Germany' will have a fleet of four Zeppelins by 1940 operating regularly to North and South America.
William G. Skelly, president of the Skelly 0il Company, has been elected president and a director of the Pacifie Western Oil Corporation to succeed H. P. Grimm, resigned.

The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reports for 1936 a net income of $10,656,515 after texes, depreciation, interest, , equivalent to $53.28 a share on the 200,000 shares of 6 1/2 per cent preferred stock of $100-par value.
More than 300 couples are expected to attend the Hunter College annual senior hop, to be held tonight at the Savoy-Plaza, Fiftyninth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Nineteen games have been listed for the New York University baseball team, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon. Contests for Ohio Field have been arranged with Holy Cross, Georgetown and L. I. U., in addition to home-and-home series with City College, Manhattan, St. John's and Fordham.

A breed or two may have been overlooked, but four distinct strains were recognized in Dewey, the winning dog of most-breeds at Bloomingdale's pet dog show yesterday. Canine oddities were the order of the day, as the exhibition was given over to mixed breeds.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, chief subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, announced tonight that it would defer until March 5 its quotations for steel for delivery in the second quarter of the year.
Picking at random from the old felt hat in which the events of the following week are always filed, this column hereunder lists an impartial schedule of next week's activity:
Bert Acosta was arrested and jailed here today, the second time within a week, for failure to answer a nonsupport charge filed by his wife, Mrs. Helen Acosta of Rockville Center.

Under the prevailing conditions of working hours, productivity and population increase, maintenance of a permanent body of five or six million unemployed would be impossible, unless the volume of production and trade, as well as the standard of living, were to be held practically stationary hereafter, according to a study made public yes- t terday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

New $1 par capital stock of the Ferro Enamel Corporation has been admitted to listing on the Curb Exchange and the old common stock, for which it was exchanged on a share for share basis, has been suspended from dealings, it was announced yesterday.

Joseph T. Fosse, 38 years old, of 114 West Sixty-first Street, a first grade fireman attached to Engine Company 40, 142 West Sixty-third Street, died last night at the fire house after returning from a small fire at 137 West Sixtieth Street. Fosse, who had been a fireman for nine years, was assisting in the arrangement of hose lines when he collapsed.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey reserved decision yesterday afternoon after hearing extended argument by counsel for a group of Pacific Coast seamen and Shipping Commissioner John J. Daly on the legality of continuous discharge books as a requisite of seamen leaving this port on American merchant ships.

Ross (Bull) McKenney, Maine's gift to the art of moose calling, leaned wearily against a slightly dented pine tree at Grand Central Palace yesterday. Ross can take a five-mile portage up in the Allagash in his stride and never draw an extra breath, but when we saw him he was definitely wan, not to. say tuckered out.

The German Government has informed the Turkish Government that it views unfavorably certain clauses of the Dardanelles Straits convention signed at Montreux, Switzerland, particularly those relating to the freedom of passage for Soviet battleships from the Black Sea to the Mediterranean.

Using profits built up since repeal by the Ferris Wheel bar at the American Women's Association clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, Mrs. W. K. Vanderbilt, chairman of the house committee, has renovated the club's art gallery, which houses many fine works. The new gallery, which was opened Wednesday, is regarded as one of the finest in the city.

Because he dared to sue a commander of Storm Troops and Chancellor Adolf Hitler's publishing house for issuing a book libeling his ancestry, Dr. Herman von Wehner, son of a former Bavarian Culture Minister, has been suspended from a high government post and proceedings for disbarment have been demanded against the lawyer who dared handle the case.

A program devoted to the school concerts of the Musicians Emeragency Fund will be given at its next luncheon, on Tuesday at the Hotel St. Regis. Officials of the Board of Education will discuss the concerts. Albert Stoessel, composer, is the recipient of the David Bispham Memorial Medal from the American Opera Society of Chicago.

For her piano recital at Town Hall last night Henriette Michelson arranged an elaborate and exacting program well devised to exhibit many facets of her art. Its chief number was the Brahms "Variations on a Theme by Paganini," a work demanding such endurance on the part of its performer that women players rarely attempt it on the concert platform. In fact,

The Count of Covadonga, former heir to the vacant Spanish throne, who has been ill for the last few days at the home of Dr. Blas Rocafort, was resting easily tonight following an operation performed on an external hip tumor this morning, according to a bulletin issued by the three attending physicians.

The first move in the new discussions on steel labor wages has been the opening of negotiations between employes and officers of the National Steel Corporation. Employes of the eighteen Carnegie-Illinois plants have virtually completed organization work preliminary to the presentation of their demands.

Classifying Japan as a "have not," Eiji Amau, Foreign Office spokesman, said today that, in the Tokyo Government's opinion, the best solution of the problems of colonies and raw materials was extension of free trade and access to raw materials in all colonial territories throughout the world.

Two bricklayers testified yesterday that the bricks which backed up the wall of the Bronx apartment house which collapsed last June 19, killing eighteen persons, were 50 per cent second hand and that the mortar was of poor quality. .

Colonel Frank B. Keech, Wall Street broker, will be arraigned before Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief here tomorrow afternoon on charges of arson in connection with a $200,000 fire which destroyed the Keech mansion in Tuxedo Park five years ago, District Attorney Henry Hirschberg announced this afternoon.

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission, was criticized sharply in a letter from Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, on the ground that he had misquoted the Federal official and for "choosing the public as a forum" for discussing the New York rate situation.

Because of alleged untrue statements and omission of material information, the Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered a hearing on March 11 in regard to the "offering sheet" filed on Feb. 11 by the James W. Tait Company, Inc., of New York.
John B. Elmendorf, agent for the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died yesterday at the New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 71 years old and lived at the Murray Hill Hotel.
Rafael Lopez De Onate blamed his inability to support his wife on his father-in-law, Senator McAdoo, in an answer today to Mrs. Ellen Gibbs McAdoo's divorce suit.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Feb. 15, issued today, showed that the gold reserve's ratio to notes in circulation had declined from 137.04 per cent on Jan. 31 to 136.26 per cent on Feb. 15, 1937.

While divers were examining today a fifteen-foot hole made by a Spanish mine yesterday in the British steamer Llandovery Castle, the British and French Navies started an intensive search for-other loose mines off the French and Spanish coasts.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court reserved decision today on the question whether the proposed reorganization plan of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway, submitted by bondholders committee, had been properly filed and was properly before the court.

The prohibition of the right-hand turn on red was put into effect chiefly to protect the pedestrian. It does protect him, but just how much? The answer to this depends on another question: In how many ways is it possible for a pedestrian to get hit, assuming that both he and the car that hits him are obeying the light signals?

An exhibition of Indian textiles from the collection of the Maharani of Baroda was opened yesterday at the Jacques Seligmann Gallery, 3 East Fifty-first Street. Included in the exhibition are a number of rare seventeenth and eighteenth century velvets and brocades.

Jake Magin, who some years ago was a well-known bicycle rider, was found dead tonight in the cellar of his home at 1,693 Van Ness Terrace, Union Township, when members of his family returned after visiting friends in the neighborhood, according to the report to the police.

Joseph Migliore of 1,810 Lexington Avenue, accused by Federal agents of being a source of counterfeit $5 notes which have been passed here at the rate of $1,000 a week, was held in bail of $25,000 yesterday by Isaac Platt, United States Commissioner.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh took off from Calcutta in his speedy monoplane at 7 o'clock this morning (9 P. M. Eastern standard time) for a 700-mile flight to Nagpur, where Mrs. Lindbergh was awaiting him.

The Woodmere Academy five captured the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools basketball championship by gaining a 1918 triumph over the Barnard School for Boys in a play-off on the Lincoln School court yesterday.

Mrs. Ortrud Barbara Leichsenring Busch of Berlin and Theodore H. Thiesing, New York attorney, were married yesterday morning by Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black in his chambers at the New York County Court House.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading showed some improvement in the morning. Most classes were cleaning up go well with choice steer hinds and ribs slightlv higher.
Professor Edward S. Robinson, 44, Yale University psychologist, died today in New Haven Hospital of injuries suffered when he was struck by a bicyclist.
Optimism continued to dominate the stock markets, which were quiet today for the end of the account.

MANHATTAN ARMSTRONG, HELEN S. (April 19, 1935). Gross assets, $77,790; net, $58,728. To Mary S. Harkness, Charlotte R. Stillman, sisters; Eleanor M. Kearney, not related, $5,000 each; Helen Armstrong Husted and Elizabeth S. K. Newell, daughters, life estates in one-half residue each; five grandchildren share remainders in residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $66,593. Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt Mosle, attorneys, 63 Wall St.

The Quakers have done so many good things in the way of relief and reconstruction since 1917, when the American Friends Service Committee was organized, that one is ready to look with favor upon any new social project of their undertaking. First,

William Weaver Christman of Delanson, farmer-poet. who received the John Burroughs Memorial Medal for his volume of nature poetry, "Wild Pasture Pine," in 1934, died today at his home after a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

Registering triumphs in their final matches yesterday, the Harvard Club and the New York Athletic Club finished in a tie for first place in the Metropolitan League Class C squash tennis team championship. Each squad closed its campaign with sixteen victories and two defeats.

The restaurant building known as Anna's Rest on East Post Road, Mamaroneck, was purchased by John and Anna Greiner, the present occupants. The property consists of a roadstand, grill, bar and restaurant. It had been leased by the Greiners several years ago and they have occupied it since. Peter C. Doern Jr. negotiated the sale.

The desire of the French Government -to continue and strengthen its collaboration with -the United States in the fields of liberal trade policies and' currency stabilization was expressed today by Georges Bonnet in presenting to President Roosevelt his credentials as Ambassador of France.

Norman Redwood, murdered business agent of a tunnel workers' union, is pictured as a self-sacrificing friend of labor in a letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES from a former sandhog who became an author.

Igor Stravinsky will present three of his ballet compositions at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 27 and 28. The featured performance will be the world premiere of his latest work, "The Card Party," which was commissioned by and written for the American Ballet Ensemble.

Financial provisions for the Duke of Windsor are likely to be settled on a cash payment of [Pound]125,000 and t an annuity of [Pound]20,000, The Daily Express said today. It is probable, the paper declared, that King George will make himself responsible for the annuity and that other members of the royal family will privately be responsible for the capital payment.

An inquest tomorrow is expected by investigating officers to prove that Humphrey Pearson, Hollywood film writer, paid with his life for his boast that he would "beat this Hollywood writing racket." Accidental shooting is expected to be the verdict.

The Republic of Argentina's export trade balance for January reached 173,180,739 pesos ($57,700,000 at the official rate of exchange), compared with 103,289,094 pesos ($34,400,000) in December and 40,602,103 pesos ($13,500,000) in January, 1936, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.
The primeval forests of Brooklyn (Jamaica Bay meadows), yielded up another specimen of rare avifauna last night in the form of a fighting wall-eyed goshawk. Or perhaps it is a sparrow or pigeon hawk.
These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Paragraph 9, Special Orders 43. Feb. 23. 1937, relating to 1st Lt. Joseph Hudes, Med.-Res., is revoked.
