David MacLevy, tall, white-haired, pallid and blind, brought a touch of melodrama into the restaurant racket trial yesterday when he testified that Louis Beitcher, gangster who pleaded guilty and testified for the State, had-confided to him that he was out to save his own skin at the expense of the other defendants.
Pope Pius, using crutches and assisted by attendants, took a brief walk today. He enjoyed an hour in the sunshine and his condition was reported satisfactory.
The picture magazine Look was banned officially today from circulating in Germany "until further notice." The announcement gave no reason for the order.
Temple University easily defeated Pittsburgh tonight at the Arena, 45-34, to take first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Conference, forcing the Panthers into second position.

Harvard tonight ruled a strong favorite over Yale for the opening tomorrow night of their annual hockey series, the only major sport in which the Crimson leads the Elis. The game will be played before 2,400 Yale junior promenade guests in the New Haven Arena.

Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Allen Locke of Boston and Williamstown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Gilmor Locke, to Dr. John Hillyer Boyd of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. T. Hillyer Boyd of Toronto.

William Earle Truesdell, for many years a well-known amateur golfer, died on Wednesday at Pinehurst, N. C., after three years of illness. He was in his eighty-second year and maintained a Summer home at Huntington, L. I.

Mayor Clarence E. F. Hetrick and members of the City Council engaged in refinancing the city's S10,000,000 defaulted debt adopted here today an amended refunding plan providing for a shorter maturity and payment of about $658,000 in defaulted interest. The plan,

Mrs. Susan S. Ellsworth of West Hartford gave a dinner at the Pettibone Tavern here tonight at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Osler Ellsworth, to Ralph Tichenor Reeve of Bloomfield, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edgar Reeve of Westfield. N. J.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, national chairman of the Emergency Peace Campaign, has called a conference of religious workers for Thursday. The conference, which will begin at 10 A. M. and close with a public meeting in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, of which Dr. Fosdick is pastor, will be part of the "No Foreign War Crusade" which is being led by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd.

The building containing eighteen apartments and two stores at 144 Forsyth Street was bought by M. Weissblum from 144 Forsyth Street, Inc., Samuel Bernstein, president. James Felt Co. were the brokers in the deal. The property is 25 by 100 feet and overlooks the ChrystieForsyth Playground.

The procedure to be followed by the "platform commission" of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in putting into effect the general principles of the voluntary platform covering wage, hour, advertising and venders' relations were discussed yesterday by the executive committee of the commission at a meeting here.

After pleading guilty to a sixcount indictment charging a stock fraud against aged investors, Lyman Hess, attorney, was sentenced yesterday to serve two and a half years in prison and his associate, Sidney Horwitt, to four and one-half years.

The 1937 National Sportsmen's Show at the Grand Central Palace, opening at 11 A. M. today and continuing for twelve hours in the final program of its ten-day run, already has attracted more persons than the 1936 venture, according to Sheldon H. Fairbanks, president of Campbell-Fairbanks, Inc., the sponsoring organization.

The St. Joseph Lead Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1936 a profit of $3,409,632 after interest and depreciation but before abandoned leases, depletion and Federal income taxes, compared with a profit of $933,746 in 1935.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: If the Braddock-Louis fight is staged in Chicago in June it certainly will place the United States in a peculiar light in the eyes of the rest of the world,

J. L. Houghteling of this city, an investment banker, was named today by Federal Judge William H. Holly to make an investigation of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation which is undergoing reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

The joint legislative committee named to investigate the guaranteed-mortgage situation expects to recommend the establishment of a mortgage bank to be privately operated but licensed by the State, which will have for its purpose the refinancing of mortgages, Senator Lazarus Joseph, chairman of the committee, said yesterday after the conclusion of a public hearing at the Bar Association, 42 West Fortyfourth Street.

Two days in Paris and the listening American feels at home. The French air is filled with echoes of long-familiar sounds. After nine months of the Blum government France reverberates with exactly the same arguments that excited the United States about the second year of the Roosevelt administration.

School Art League lecture, the American Museum of Natural History, 10:30 A. M. "To Peru on a Poster Prize," Henry J. Seahbury. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Our Undiscovered Resources," David Seabury.

Army Air Corps officials decided today that there was not a suitable air field in Washington-the potential center of military aviation in time of national emergency-on which they could risk their prize possession, the four-engined Boeing bomber, a veritable flying fortress.

William Matthews of 327 West Twenty-eighth Street was appointed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as a Municipal Court justice to fill the vacancy caused by the promotion of Justice Frank A. Carlin to the City Court. Justice Matthews must run for election to the court at the next general election.

The list of the Italian liner Rex, due to sail today for Mediterranean ports, includes: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gauvert, Colonel and Mrs. E. J. Sampson, Miss Candace C. Stimson, Mrs. Parton Swift, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Tuck and Mr. and Mrs. Nicola Raffalovich.
A bill providing for compulsory inspection of automobiles at State-operated testing stations was introduced today by Senator Berg.

Employers were warned today by the Social Security Board against distributing unauthorized questionnaires purporting to be required by the board and intended to disclose union affiliation, religion or other personal affairs of employes.

Fear for resi the safety of twenty-eight men Bn aboard the missing Boston fishing schooner Gossoon'grew tonight as three Coast Guard vessels plowed the seas east of Boston without finding a trace of her.

The Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute quintet downed Cooper Union, 35-25, at Odd Fellows Hall in Brooklyn last night. The winners held a 16-15 lead at the half. Ed Denzer and Hank Johnson, making twelve and eleven markers respectively,. starred for the Brooklynites.

Ernest B. Lush, a former pitcher for the New York Giants and St. Louis Cardinals and of several minor league teams, died today at his home in Detroit, according to a telegram received here by relatives.

Verdi's "Aida" received its fourth presentation of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It was heard by a large and appreciative audience. All the members of the cast had appeared in the work at previous performances this Winter, except Lawrence Tibbett, who was warmly acclaimed as Amonasro.

Stockholders of the American Republics Corporation at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday authorized the directors in their discretion to sell all or part of the unissued $10-par value common capital stock at a price not less than par.

Mrs. Helen Reilly of 334 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, mother of Edward J. Reilly, Brooklyn attorney who was counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, obtained a Supreme Court order yesterday designating her as committee of the person and property of her son, who is a patient in the Psychiatric Institute and Hospital, 722 West 168th Street.
John Joseph Foley, a lawyer and inheritance tax appraiser for the State Tax Department for the last twenty years, died Thursday night of heart disease in Beekman Street Hospital. His age was 48.

The Manufacturers Trust Company held yesterday its first drawing of its preferred shares in accordance with the retirement provisions of the stock. A total of 7,075 shares was drawn for redemption on March 31 at $53 a share and accumulated dividends from Jan. 16 to the redemption date.
The House of Representatives killed today a move to put a picture of Franklin D. Roosevelt in the place of honor on the chamber wall occupied by Woodrow Wilson's likeness.

The War Deapartment released the following order today, dated Feb. 25: COLONELS Turtle, L., C.A.C., 1 month and 5 days' extension of leave. Gillespie, A. G., Ordnance Dept., Rock Island Arsenal, Ill., to office of Chief of Ordnance, Washington, D. C., about June 30.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $5,238,000, with fifty municipalities represented. The total compares with a revised figure of $16,807,393 for the current week, and 1937 average of $39,062,472.

The Brown hockey team defeated Boston University, 6-1, tonight. Brown took a 3-0 lead in the opening ten minutes on brilliant passing by the first forward line. The second line took up the scoring in the second period.

The Petersburg (Va.) High School quintet suffered its second setback in as many nights when it dropped a 46-31 decision to Lawrence High before 700 persons tonight. Vladimar Medvedeff and Ed McDonnell paced the attack for the winners, who led at the half; 26-16.
A mother and her new-born baby lived today because a son, ill with influenza, walked six miles through a mountain blizzard to summon help.

The first practical use of television on a large scale in connection with a public spectacle is to take place this Spring, when views of the coronation procession will be broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

Strong opposition to the renomination of Mayor La Guardia on the Republican ticket has been expressed by members of that party in letters to and conversations with the county leaders, it was learned yesterday.

Controller Frank J. Taylor disclosed yesterday that the city's bankers would raise no objection to the city's plan to cut the interest penalty on delinquent taxes from 10 per cent, the rate fixed under the bankers' agreement, to 7 per cent.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association will approve the passage of the Tydings-Miller Resale Price Maintenance Bill, now under consideration by Congress, if the measure is amended as suggested by Irving C. Fox, counsel for the association, at the recent hearing of the House Judiciary Committee, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director.

The Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company, one of the largest producers of anthracite in Pennsylvania, asked the United States District Court today for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Lieut. Commander Paul W. F. Huschke, 42, shot and killed himself in his quarters aboard the U. S. S. Holland here today. He was executive officer of the Holland, having been transferred to that post from command of the U. S. S. Waters two weeks ago.

On the eve of their international team match for the Wolfe-Noel Trophy with the United States, the British women's squash racquets players saw their lead-off representative turned back yesterday in the final of the seventh annual invitation tournament of the Junior League.

THOSE who enjoyed the extracts from Kipling's autobiography serialized in this paper some time ago will probably want the complete work, now published by Doubleday, Doran: "Something of Myself" ($2.50).

Fines of $500 each were imposed by Justices Brady, McDonald and Renaud in Special Sessions yesterday on William Faehndrich, Inc., cheese importers at 13 Harrison Street; the head of the firm, William Faehndrich of 610 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, and his son, Rudolph, of 1,819 Avenue L, Brooklyn.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott warned fifty-three new fire lieutenants yesterday against having a feeling of superiority because of their promotions. "You fellows, perhaps, feel as I felt and as many others felt on being promoted from firemen to lieutenants," he said.

President Roosevelt lunched with President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth and later introduced him at a Cabinet meeting; indicated at his press conference that he favored the Guffey Coal Bill and the Wagner Housing Bill;

Stockholders of the American Republics Corporation at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday authorized the directors in their discretion to sell all or part of the unissued $10-par value common capital stock at a price not less than par.

Mrs. Helen Reilly of 334 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, mother of Edward J. Reilly, Brooklyn attorney who was counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, obtained a Supreme Court order yesterday designating her as committee of the person and property of her son, who is a patient in the Psychiatric Institute and Hospital, 722 West 168th Street.

Movements vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 25, unless specified: San Clemente Island to San Diego: Antares, Wyoming. San Diego to Wilson Cove: Brant, Feb. 26; Rail. Arctic, Pearl Harbor Yard to Samoa. Clark, Boston yard to Rockland, Feb. 26 Drayton, at Rockland.

The volume of new bond financing this week declined to $18,615,000, representing only three borrower classifications, and was the smallest total since the week ended on Nov. 6, last year, when only $450,000 in new loans was placed. This week compares with new offerings of $28,929,000 last week, and a total of $87,770,072 a year ago.

Layoffs added 1,001,000 to the total of unemployed in January, according to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who said today that "this is the first time since January, 1936, that there has been any significant increase in unemployment."

Dr. Joseph Lehrs, a German Jew, was shot dead this morning by Arabs at Beisan, Northern Palestine. He was the last Jewish resident of that district, which, since the release from prison several weeks ago of Farid Fakhridin, notorious agitator, has again become the scene of disorders.

The annual report of the Radio Corporation of America, issued yesterday, shows that its net profit for 1936 was $6,155,937, an increase of 20 per cent over the net of $5,126,872 in 1935. After allowing for all preferred dividends paid or accrued in the year, there remained $2,845,285 applicable to the common stock, or 20 1/2 cents a share.

More than $1,000,000 yearly in pay increases is provided in an agreement reached today between the National Cash Register Company and its employee representation unit. About 6,800 workers here are affected.
A story of hunger-crazed men swinging pick-axes in a battle alongnarrow, murky tunnels at the bottom of a mine shaft was pieced together tonight from the accounts of terrified survivors.
A job is a property right and may be defended by a sit-down strike, Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, said at a mass meeting here tonight.

Friction between union and nonunion workers resulted in the closing of two General Motors plants today, but a national officer of the United Automobile Workers of America ordered the striking unionists to return to work.

Merle Vandenbush, the Department of Justice's "Public Rat No. 1," and two men trapped with him by village police in Armonk, N. Y., Thursday afternoon less than half an hour after the $17,600 hold-up of the Northern Westchester Bank of Katonah, N. Y., were indicted for first-degree robbery yesterday by the Westchester County grand jury at White Plains.

Deliveries of rayon woven cloths during January declined somewhat in comparison with December, with the combined index based on reports to the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., and the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc., dropping to 170 from 178.
Power Memorial Academy's powerful quintet clinched the Manhattan-Richmond C. H; S. A. A. championship yesterday by downing La Salle Academy, 25-17, on the losers' floor.

The total volume of round-lot sales on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Jan. 30 amounted to 13,108,170 shares, compared with 17,166,510 the week before, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Of publicity items directed to a city desk, only about 15 per cent find their way into the paper, John A. Bogart, assistant Sunday editor of The New York Herald Tribune, yesterday told the Advertising and Marketing Forum of the Advertising Club of New York.

The State Athletic' Commission yesterday approved a boxer's license for Max Baer, former heavyweight champion, and a manager's ticket for his pilot, Ancil Hoffman. What is more, the solons acted unanimously, Commissioner Bill Brown, with an explanation that lacked none of his initial opposition, voting approval of the move, which endorses a scheduled bout between Baer and Bob Pastor in Madison Square Garden on March 19.

The Rev. Dr. Caspar Wistar Hodge, Professor of Systematic Theology at Princeton Theological Seminary for the last sixteen years, died today at Princeton Hospital after a week's illness of pneumonia. He was 66 years old.

Because of disagreement over the probable cost of developing North Beach Airport in Queens as a transoceanic terminal, members of the Sinking Fund Commission voted yesterday to defer action on the project until March 10.

Patrolman Thomas Kane, 34 years old, of 34-34 Thirty-second Street, Astoria, and the West Sixty-eighth Street station, was arrested at 7 o'clock last night on a charge of disorderly conduct. Howard Kase,

Deciding a question never before determined by a court in this country, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn cleared-Joseph A. Solovei, former defense counsel in the Samuel Drukman murder case, yesterday of all charges of misconduct cited against him by the Drukman special grand jury.
A proposal to legalize labor troubles out of existence in Minnesota rested in committee today while plans were under way for hearing probably next week.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
This being WPA week along Broadway, the Federal Theatre staged "The Sun and I" at the Adelphi last evening with considerable scenic elegance and many crashes of learned music from the orchestra pit.

President Roosevelt has approved the promotion of three commanders to the rank of captain, the selection of twenty lieutenants commanders for advancement to the rank of commanders, and the assignment of four lieutenant commanders to the retention list, the Navy Department announced today. All the officers designated are in the Naval Medical Corps.

LATE yesterday afternoon the stylish-stout secr etary-treasurer of the A. A. U., Mr. Daniel J. Ferris, was in a mild dither over the fact that he didn't know whether or not Galloping Glenn Cunningham was going to start in the 1,500-meter event on the national indoor championship program at the Garden this evening.

Air travel across the Atlantic at such speeds that one could dine in New York, breakfast in London and dine again in New York is foreshadowed by the specifications of the two new stratosphere transport planes which Pan American Airways has in course of engineering development at the plant of the Boeing Airplane Company at Seattle.

Total sales of reporting wholesale firms in this area during January averaged 10.7 per cent higher than last year, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission sought today to prove that a $15,000,000 tail wagged a $2,500,000,000 dog in the utilities industry. They contended that the feat was the result of the operations of Harrison Williams, who was described as the master of the mammoth canine.

Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., winner of the qualifying medal, and Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., tournament victor in 1935, reached the title round of the South Atlantic championship today at the Ormond Beach Golf Club, each taking a hard-fought match.
A list of thirty-eight securities registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 was made public today by the Securities Exchange Commission. Among the issues registered were the following:

The State of New Jersey dropped yesterday, for the present, its attempt to force Samuel Rosoff, the subway builder, to go there for questioning as a material witness in the murder of Norman Redwood, sandhog union leader. John J. Breslin, Bergen County prosecutor, said emphatically, however, that eventually Rosoff would be forced by "due process of law" to answer questions in Hackensack.
Ward's Automotive Reports today estimated that this week's output of the motor-car factories would be 115,360 units, which it describes as the highest level for any February week since 1929.
The Earl of Sefton, Viscount Richard Adare, Captain the Hon. Lionel Montagu and Captain the Hon. Charles Winn were hosts tonight for a dinner and dance at the Everglades Club.

Under a blunt warning to "get out or be indicted," 200 sit-down strikers deserted the Northrop Aircraft plant today, while 343 others were arraigned on felony charges for their three-day occupation of the huge Douglas airplane factory.

The removal of Miss Charlotte E. Carr as executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau was demanded by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens in letters addressed yesterday to Mayor La Guardia and members of the Board of Estimate.
Gregory Mangin of Newark, national indoor tennis champion, will start the defense of his title today in the tournament opening at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

A $300,000 check, reported to have been found in the street in the New York financial district today, was turned over to the Secaucus police tonight. The check was drawn on the Chase National Bank by Brown Brothers, Harriman Co., 59 Wall Street, and is made payable to the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company, "to the ac count of the Anglo-French Banking Corporation, Ltd., London."
Appointment of the executive committee and chairmen of the principal committees of the National Association of Real Estate Boards for 1937 are announced by Paul E.Stark, president, as follows:

City College's boxing team met with a surprising 4 1/2-3 1/2 setback last night at the hands of the Penn sylvania State Teachers College in the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium. The Beavers had been undefeated in their last three years of competi tion. Two defaults on the part of City aided the Pennsylvanians ingaining the victory.
GUERRILLA warfare is probably the hardest and strangest sort of fighting takes the most courage brings out the most personality in those who can stand it. Thephrase has an ill-omened ring

MARCH seldom has been a month productive of new broadcasts; in fact the ides of March was consid ered for a long time as the end of the radio season. St. Patrick's Day melodies were taken as the signal that Spring was ready for its dance and the Winter-time radio performers took the cue and quite generally signed-off untilLabor Day.

Several card parties for the bene fit of philanthropic organizations will be held in the near future. A feature of the bridge next Friday afternoon in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of the Humane Society of New York will be an exhibition of por traits of members of the benefit committee photographed with theirdogs for the occasion.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader and former nominee for President, charged the Republican party with responsibility for ratification or de feat of the proposed child labor amendment in this State and urged its immediate ratification by the Assembly, in a statement issued yesterday on behalf of the Socialistparty.
President Alfonso Lopez reappoint ed Alberto Lleras Camargo as Min ister of Government today and filled the other posts left vacant as a re sult of the recent mass resignationof the Cabinet.

Some jobs at this season of the year keep the gardener guessing as to whether he should do them now or later. The task of pruning such shrubs and trees as require cutting back while they are still dormant need, however, give rise to no doubtin this respect.

Dr. John Letcher Patterson, chancellor emeritus of the University of Louis ville and first dean of its School of Arts and Sciences, died of a cerebral hemorrhage early todayat his home here. His age was 76.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Morris Guards of this resort will Celebrate their fiftieth anni versary on March 12, 13 and 14. Representatives of historic mili tary units in the original Thirteen States will participate in the festivi ties. These units, oldest of which is the Ancient and Honorable Artil lery of Boston, founded in 1638, are all members of the CentennialLegion.

Sam Rosoff, the subway contrac tor, and. Joseph Fay, would-be czar of the New York City building trades unions, were accused jointly of plotting the murder of Norman Redwood in a signed statement is sued last night by John J. Breslin Jr., Prosecutor of Bergen County, N. J.

Henry Titus Folsom, president of the H. D. Folsom Arms Com pany, a wholesale sporting goods concern of New York, died last night at his home in Llewellyn Park after a long illness. He was77 years old.

TOKYO.-The diagnosis of world unrest which declares that Japan, Italy and Germany are unsatisfied powers, the have-nots in the family of nations-is it accurate analysis, or propaganda, or loose thinking? In calling themselves "have nots," Japanese officials have never said that Japan is unsatisfied in the sense Germans mean when they de mand colonies. The attitude is ex plained by a few easily accessiblestatistics.

The Mon treal Canadiens edged nearer to clinching first place in the National Hockey League's international group by rallying to score a 3-2 vic tory in an overtime battle with the New York Americans in a listless game that speeded up somewhat inthe closing stages.

Under the largest volume of busi ness for a short session this season, prices on the Cotton Exchange con tinued yesterday the uninterrupted upward movement that began on Tuesday and ended with net gainsof 6 to 9 points.
Dr. Seelye W. Little, authority on ness man, who gave up h nephritis and cancer, died of heart stable business shortly a disease today at his home here at turn of the century to engathe age of 68.

Facing a barrage of questions in tended to discredit his testimony against Jacob J. Lesser, an attor ney who once sought a Federal judgeship, and ten others charged with bankruptcy fraud, Harry Wind, an ex-convict, vehemently denied yesterday that he had planned to "shake down" Lesserfor $10,000.

Francis Leo Oley, shackled to a deputy Fed eral marshal, left late today for New York to face a charge of com plicity in the John J. O'Connell Jr. kidnapping. On the special railroad car with Oley were his wife, Ge nevieve, and several other Federal prisoners.
Bids probably will be asked next month upon the construction of two new $50,000,000 battleships which Secretary Swanson named the North Carolina and the Washington today.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Bax of Rockville Center, L. I., for merly of Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edythe Corinne Bax, to Harold Von Lehe Seifert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Seifert of Brooklyn. The announcement was made at a supper party given atthe Plaza here last night.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, who demanded the removal of Miss Charlotte E. Carr as director of the Emergency Relief Bureau after a confidential investigation had disclosed alleged abuses in the system, replied to Miss Carr's published denials yes terday by challenging her to join him in an application to the Board of Aldermen for a complete investigation.

A resolution by Representative John Chichester, prominent Birmingham real estate man, requiring that lob byists wear uniforms and specifying a particular uniform for each group brightened this final week of the Alabama Legislature's special session.

A fresh turn was given to the re sale price maintenance situation in this State last week with the intro duction of a new bill by Senator A. Spencer Feld which approaches the question from the trade-mark registration standpoint.

To the Drama Editor: With my blood still pounding from the magnificence of Marlowe's "Dr. Faustus" as presented by Orson Welles and his WPA associates, I hasten to urge that the same treatment be accorded Marlowe's other great heroic tragedy, "Tamburlaine."

Older experience in recovery from a prolonged world depression has almost invariably marked out two industries on which the new demand primarily converged. One has been breadstuffs. In that industry, reduction of the world's agricultural acreage, due to preceding accumulation of unsold sup plies with the much lower prices which resulted, has coincided with the in creased consumption of better times and has usually created what wascalled world deficiency.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. James Henry Andrew of 163 Hancock Street, Brooklyn of the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Isabel Wallace Andrew to John Moffett Beery, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Milton Beery, alsoof Brooklyn.

A bridge tea will be given on Saturday at the Park Lane under the auspices of the New York unit of the Women's Overseas Service League for the benefit of disabled and unemployed women who servedin France during the World War.

The West Sixty-third Street Com munity House, formerly known as the Riverside Day Nursery, will be the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show on Thursday at the Versailles.. Sponsored. by the Crime Prevention Bureau, the community house, through its classes and rec reational direction, serves as a vo cational school and social centerfor young persons.

The charitable work of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals will be materially aided by a pro gram of three one-act plays to be presented by the Lakeview Players (formerly the Junior Branch Play ers) on the night of March 11 and the afternoon of March 13 at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventythird Street.

Navigation on the Seine at Paris and at suburbs below the capital was suspended today by the flood which was rapidly mounting tonight. The level at the Austerlitz Bridge this morn ing reached the danger mark atnoon.

Colonel Frank B. Keech, Wall Street broker, was free on $50,000 bail following his arraignment here today before Supreme Court Jus tice Graham Witschief on indict ments charging second and third degree arson and wilful destructionof insured Property.

Playing with characteristic dash in a snowstorm and a wind that at times assumed gale-like proportions, Ireland triumphed, 11-4, over Scotland in an interna tional rugby match at Lansdowne Road today. Erin's representatives won by a goal and two tries to adropped picked goal.

DUDE ranches in the North-west and up-State New York are busy these days, and cowboys who during the Summer led guests on horseback over piney mountain paths are showing their versatility by breaking trail for ski and snow-shoe expeditions.

Amend ment of the Motor Vehicle and Traffic Law making it a jail offense for any unfit person to operate a motor car has been suggested to Assemblyman Elisha T. Barrett by Edgar F. Hazelton, County Attor ney, who would eliminate the sec tion referring to driving while in toxicated, make unfitness punish able by a mandatory jail sentence of thirty days and make a secondoffense a felony.

A mass meeting of strikers laid plans today for a systematic picket patrol at the Fansteel Metallurgi cal Corporation plants, scene of two fights. Paul Glaser of Gary, Ind., attor ney of the Committee for Indus trial Organization, said conferees in the closed session had been in formed of their "legal rights" and had elected to start picketing "in force" at the company's NorthChicago property tomorrow.

Building permits issued in Newark, N. J., during the month of January indicate that the volume of new construction in that city for the present year will be materially greater than the 1936 record. The January permits represented an estimated cost value of $718,020, an increase of more than $580,000 over the January record of 1936 whichwas $136,937.

Winning six of the eight bouts, Yale's varsity wrestling team de feated Columbia, 20-8, yesterday in the Morningside Heights gymna sium. With only a 1-point advan tage and three contests to go, theElis took all of the remaining bouts.

Introducing the budget for 1937-38, the Yugoslav Finance Minister, Dushan Letitza, gave a glowing pic ture of national prosperity. Last year Yugoslavia had a budget sur plus of $10,000,000, owing to the increased yield in taxes, exports ex ceeding imports by $7,000,000 andforeign trade increasing 10 per cent.

Various philanthropic and educa tional projects furthered by the New York Society for Ethical Cul ture will be aided by a recital by Lotte Lehmann of the Metropolitan Opera Company next Sunday after noon at the Town Hall. Already there has been a large subscriptionfor the benefit.

Two paintings by Corot, American landscapes and other paintings, comprising property of the estate of Frank D. Frazier of New York; selections from the collection of the Lotos Club and paintings from other sources will be offered at auction at the American Art Asso ciation Anderson Galleries on Thurday evening.
More than three hundred couples attended the annual senior ball of Hunter College last night at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. Among theguests of honor were Dr. Eugene

American manufacturers in more than a score of industries experi encing keen competition from Japa nese manufacturers focused their attention this week upon the "gentlemen's agreement" nego tiated by cotton textile interests here with Japanese cotton clothproducers.

Led by Emauel Jarmulnick and Seymour Schneidman, who scored 9 points each, the City College bas ketball team had an easy time win ning its tenth victory of the season, defeating the American University of Washington, 51 to 19, last nighton its home court.

Rights to buy $52,670,700 of new convertible. 3 1/4 per cent debentures dated April 1 and due in 1952, to be issued by the Pennsylvania Rail road, will be admitted tomorrow to dealings on the New York Stock Exchange.

Presi dent Roosevelt's unswerving in sistence upon enactment of his plan for reform of the Federal judi ciary-his plan for remaking the Supreme Court with more "liberal timber"-and the argument he has advanced that he must have action this session in order to pave the way for new New Deal measures have naturally brought up the ques tion as to what other legislativeproposals he has in mind.

The New York State Economic Council, through Merwin K. Hart, president, announces the results of a survey made by Miss Sara H. Birchall, special field representative, during a two-week trip through South Carolina to investgate "alleged cases of child labor."

Five years ago San Francisco adopted a new charter, created a Municipal Public Utilities Commission and hired E. G. Cahill, a successful mining engineer and building con tractor, as manager of utilities. Mr. Cahill, interested in the job because his own trade of building was then at a standstill, name into office prejudiced against politiciansand public ownership.

AN avalanche of letters to the editor has rolled into newspaper offices since President Roosevelt an nounced his.plan to reorganize the Supreme Court. Characteristically the writers have registered their emotions They have been indignant, sympathetic: in many cases they have applied pure rea son to their arguments. Their letters have reflected widespread interest in a momentous question.

One seeded player dropped out and the other three survived yes terday as the Eastern Squash Rac quets Association's Group 1 cham pionship tournament got under way with an entry of twenty-four at theNew York A. C.
The Far Eastern situation today is not un satisfactory from the Soviet point of view, although it is quite likely that no Soviet speaker or writer would admit that this is true.

"One more German statesman's visit and the last shred of the Austro-German agreement will have vanished." A responsible leader of the Aus trian Pronounced Nationals quoted this as the verdict of a German diplomat on Foreign Minister von Neurath's visit to Vienna. The feel ing among extremist Nazis and their Pronounced National friends is nearer despair than at any time since the failure of the July, 1934,putsch.

Though Winter sports at the Naval Academy are approaching their end with the coming of March, a program of consider able interest will be presented next week. Wednesday, Rutgers will have its swimming and water polo teams at Annapolis, while Harvard will send its swimmers and Dartmouth its gymnasts,Saturday.

Philadelphia.Athletic pitchers' were wild as their 1937 camp exhibition season opened today and the Amer ican Leaguers were humbled by the Necaxa Club, Mexican semi-pros, 3-2. Fred Archer, fourth Athletic hurler to see service, sent the win ning run home from second basewith a wild pitch.

A NEW phenomenon is developing today in opera. That is the virtuoso stage director. He is the man who plans scene and action, whose interpretations of classic and modern masterpieces are breathlesslyawaited by the eager throng.
SKIING, whose progress in this country in the past two years has been noteworthy, always supplies thrilling moments toits devotees and spectators.

Miss Alice Graeme, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Wright Graeme of 430 East Fifty-first Street, New York, was married here today to Baron Serge Alexander Korff, son of Baroness Serge Alexander Korff of Washing ton and a grandson of Admiral W. K. van Reypen. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Albert J. McCartney at Miss Graeme's homein Georgetown.

THE annual grain race, in recent times the longest and most hazardous sailing-ship contest, is now under way. The Finnish bark Killoran has squared away for the run of 14,000 nautical miles from South Austra lia to England, and soon all the en trants, two regular barks and eightthat have four masts, will set sail.
T. O. M. Sop with's Endeavour II is being rap idly pushed to completion at the Gosport yards in order to get the vessel to Rhode Island early inMay, it was revealed today.
EL PASO, Texas. President Cardenas of Mexico, uti lizing the wide powers given him under the "Six-Year Plan," has set aside for education a sum equal to about $14,000,000 in American money.

Since the settlement of the General Motors strike and evacuation of the Fisher Body plants the sit-down strike technique has extended from coast to coast. During the week attention was centered on the sit-down strike called by local lodge 66 of the Amalgamated Association of Iron,Steel and Tin Workers

Mrs. Eugene W. Goodwillie and Miss Lorraine Condit will have the leading roles on Saturday morning and afternoon when the Montclair Junior League will present two per formances of "The Patchwork Girl of Oz" at Mount Hebron Auditorium here.

Dartmouth College retained the Intercollegiate Ski Union cham pionship ahd the Dartmouth Cup today with a perfect score of 500 points in the annual three-day com petition in the Laurentian Hills. It was the first time in the meet's history that a college team won tophonors in all five events.

Mrs. Reeves W. Hart of Stamford has announced the engagement of her sister, Miss Catherine Page Under wood, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence F. Underwood, to Richard B. Edwards, son of Charles H. Edwards of Greenwich and thelate Mrs. Edwards.

The marriage of Miss Ethel William to Claude McClure, both of Philadel phia, took place-this morning in the parsonage of the Washington Street Baptist Church here. The Rev. Marple M. Lewis, pastor and brother-in-law of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony, whichwas followed by a reception.

Commodity futures continued in mixed trends in light trading in the local markets yesterday. Cocoa, rubber, hide, sugar and cottonseed oil futures gained, while coffee, copper and lead futures -declined. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, cotton and lard were higher, butrye, oats and Straits tin were lower.

Felicitations on his "successful handling of the sit-down strike" in his factory were telegraphed to Robert J. Aitchison, president of the Fansteel Metallurgical Com pany, yesterday by Ralph M. Eas ley, chairman of the executive coun cil of the National Civic Federa tion. Mr. Easley's telegram follows:

TOMORROW in St. Louis the second annual North Amer ican Wildlife Conferencewill get under way, to continue through Thursday. Sponsored by the American Wildlife Institute of Washington and other organiza tions, the conference will bring to gether well over 1,000 leaders of the conservation movement from the forty-eight States, Canada and Mexico.

The Moscow Zoo, one of the largest and most frequented in the world, has solved the problem of its excess animal and bird population by distributing young pets to chil dren on a lottery basis. The scheme has proved ex tremely embarrassing to parentsof many children

No New Jersey industry will gain exemption from the Committee for Industrial Organization drive mere ly by raising wages and improving working conditions, Homer Martin, C. I. O. organizer of the General Motors sit-down strike at Flint,Mich., said yesterday.
THE annual migration to the homeland of hundreds of thousands of Americans and other foreign residents of theworld's remote outposts has begun.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Thomas Lamdin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. N. Gist Lamdin of Kew Gardens, Queens, to Lloyd H. Hall, son of Mrs. Frank W. Hall of Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn.,took place here yesterday afternoon

Children who do not want to play the piano or violin are wasting their time if parents force them to prac tice, Roy D. Welch, Professor of Music at Princeton University, said yesterday at the final sessions of the twelfth annual conference of the Secondary Education Board,meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

There no longer is any chance :hat Congress will pass a measure :o limit trade for the sake of Neutrality, Stephen Raushenbush, Secretary of the Senate Munitions committee , declared yesterday. He asserted that the nation "has not ret decided whether it wants peaceor war."
Following an annual custom, Freeport officials and some of the old time residents of the village enjoyed today clam chowder and clam pie made from recipes invented duringColonial times.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, serving as temporary chairman of the Joint Committee on Low Priced Housing which represents the Board of Aldermen and Board of Estimate, announces that the committee will hold a public hearing at 2 o'clockon March 8 in City Hall.
Mrs. Miriam Finn Scott will ad dress the Parents Association of P. S. 165, Manhattan, on "Adoles cence-its Needs and How to MeetIt," tomorrow at 8:30 P. M.
Some one has said that man lives not by bread alone, but by catchwords; and apparently school superintendents

The nearness to completion of the $40, 000,000 Bonneville Dam, forty-two miles east of Portland, has given rise to the most important power questions in the history of the Pa cific Northwest, a region contain ing two-fifths of the nation's potential hydroelectric energy.

KINGSTON, Jamaica. IN this island, to which last season 49,800 visitors were attracted, of whom 6,192 stayed, the others spending no more than a day or a day and a night, a youthful hawker of imported bead necklaces was heard to observe to acompetitor in the trade:

The new 1937 model farm plan, as it appears to the farmer so far, is a good deal like the advance prospectuses of the new cars-interesting, but call ing for demonstration and detailed explanation before judgment ispassed.

AFTER several years in which every comedy had to be compounded of wry jests and caustic gibes the theatre seems to have glided into a world of forbearing humors and pleasant characters. "Seems" is the proper word: there is no program in the theatre at any time and very seldom a recognizable trend; and there is always "The Women" to remind us that fashionable calumnycan be fabricated to order.

Playing par golf on the first nine holes to establish her winning mar gin, Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Co lumbia, S. C., 1936 titleholder of the Carolinas, became South Atlantic champion today by defeating Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., in the final, 2 and 1, at the OrmondBeach Golf Club.

The National Real Estate Founda tion, conceived by the National As sociation of Real Estate Boards as a medium for the collection and dis semination of data on all phases of the industry, rapidly is assumingtangible form.

A delegation of children ranging in age from 9 to 15, representing the 4,000 members of the junior sec tion of the International Workers Order, picketed the home of Herbert Brownell, Republican As semblyman, at 47 West TwelfthStreet, yesterday morning.

A blazing first period in which they galloped at a terrific pace from the opening throw-in to the bell, brought the New York Athletic Club victory over the Squadron A team last night in the feature match at the loser's armory, 13 to 9 1/2.

The best performance the writer has heard this season from Lily Pons was given by her yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House when she sang as Lucy of Lammermoor in Donizetti's composition.

Those who knew him in his youth and those who followed him into African fastnesses joined today in tribute to Martin Johnson, explorer, killed in an airplane crash. More than 2,000 persons were present at the funeral services in MunicipalAuditorium.

The dean's honor lists at the Col lege of Mount St. Vincent, River dale, were announced yesterday. Those who have attained general honors have an average of 90 per cent in all their subjects and no grade below 70 per cent. Those who have secured departmental honors have an average of 95 per cent in all subjects in any one department. The names follow:
As a prelude to more vigorous pro tests this week, including picketing, against reductions in WPA rolls, three groups of WPA workers met yesterday to organize opposition toforthcoming layoffs.

For the first time perhaps in his tory the poor downtrodden school ma'am was last week a major ob ject of concern to a convention of school administrators.. At least four leading educators told the De partment of Superintendence at its New Orleans meeting that theymust begin to treat her as an equal.

Encountering unexpectedly stiff opposition in the second half after having things all its own way in the opening period, Long Island Uni versity wound up its local basket ball campaign in salutory fashion by defeating Brooklyn College, 32 to 24, before 2,500 at the Hippodrome last night.

SOON to be added to the historical buildings in Greenfield Village, Mich., are two structures significant in the history of aviation. One is that which housed the bicycle shop of Orville and the late Wilbur Wright, where they conducted their early experiments

Mrs. James B. Greeley of 187 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, will be chairman of the first of a series of social events sponsored by the Brooklyn Young Women's Christian Association in connection with aSpring membership campaign.

A VOLUMINOUS document entitled "Air Mail Docket 14" was made public within the last week by the Interstate Commerce Commission. It con tained a report by two examiners of the commission on the petition of American Airlines for a revision of air mail rates.

Miss Alberta Irene Darby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Lewis Darby of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Simpson Grace Methodist Episcopal Church to Edward Lewis New, son of Mr. and Mrs. George New, also of Jer sey City, by the pastor, the Rev.Wilbert Westcott.

STOWE, Vt.--This village of 500 persons, recovering from a Washington's Birthday influx of 1,500 out-of-State skiers who taxed housing, restaurant and transportation facilities, settled down to entertain over this week-end a throng of skiers more nearly adjusted to its facilities.

Correctly spelling such words as "asofetida," "hieroglyphic" and "perihelion," six Hunter College students captured honors for their Alma Mater yesterday afternoon by remaining standing against a soli tary New York University male when the gong called a finish to the second intercollegiate spelling bee broadcast over the NBC nation-'wide network.
MEMBERS of New York's roller-skating fraternity are now turning with renewed zest to a period of indoor roller skating that threatens to rival in popularity its more spaciousbrother of the outdoors.

Mrs. William M. K. Olcott of Great Neck and Quogue, L. I., has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Oenia Janith Payne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James George Payne of this city, to George Goodnow Bradley, son of Mrs. J. E. Bradley of Bloomfield,Conn.

Verdi's "La Traviata" will be per formed on Friday night at the Ven ice Theatre by the Opera League. Albert Diechler, managing director of the company, promises "to pre sent the traditional- Italian opera in a new, modern and American manner."

A bridge will be held under the joint auspices of the junior auxiliary and welfare committee of the Orphan Asylum Society of the City of Brooklyn on the afternoon of April 9, at the society's building, Brooklyn, Kingston and Atlantic Avenues.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls de feated the New York Rovers, 2-0, in a hard-fought Eastern Amateur Hockey League battle before 6,500 persons in the Auditorium tonight. The most startling safari in the history of amateur hockey arrivedhere just before the contest,

Miss Geraldine Farrar, the soprano, reached the eve of her fif ty-fifth birthday tonight. Her sing ing voice, she said, would play no part in-her anniversary celebration tomorrow. She has sung little since her retirement from the concertstage in 1932.

The formal Spring reopening of the Sert Room of the Waldorf-As toria will take place on March 27 when a supper dance will be given for the benefit of the Opportunity Shop, a permanent activity of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

New York City's new traffic code, one week old today, has already yielded two important lessons. The first is that city drivers, given suf ficient advance notice, can con form even to drastic changes in op rating rules with a minimum of confusion.

The annual Mi-Careme bridge in aid of the Jesuit Seminaries will be givenn under the auspices of the Loyola School for Boys on March 9 at the Ambassador Hotel. The Rev. Coleman Nevils is rector of the school, located at Park Avenue andEighty-third Street.
J. H. Matthews, executive secre tary of the Middle Atlantic Fish eries Association, in a letter to this column, explains his organization's attitude on questions of commercial fishing regulations.

Operators, builders and brokers in New Jersey are unanimous in predicting increased activity in the months immediately ahead. Charles H. Reis reported that he sold nine ty-six homes last year, the majority being in his Lylewood Hills community in Tenafly, Bergen County.
Preliminaries to the organization of 200,000 California agricultural work ers into a single union began to day under the auspices of the Amer ican and State Federations of Labor.

The Wagner-Steagall Low-Rent Housing Bill, introduced last week in both houses of Congress, repre sents the best and most considered thought on the solution of what is probably the most important socialproblem in this country.

Dividends declared in February amounted to $363,175,368, compared with $266,699,645 in January and $277,964,942 in February, 1936. A feature of the announcements was the ordering of "interim" or"irregular" disbursements.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Hannah Elizabeth Chelius, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Chelius of Bayonne, N. J., to Charles Ferdi nand Stark Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Stark of Maplewood, N. J.

LONDON. THE British broadcaster takes his mission as educationist very seriously and, no doubt, some recent ventures have been made with the main object of keeping British musicians informed about the activities of their Continental brethren. Italy is far away;

The same arguments which are advanced in the United State against large scale slum clearance and public low-cost housing have been soundly refuted by eighteen years of experience in England Captain Richard L. Reiss, member of the London Housing Authority declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Grand Street Boys Association in the clubhouse at 101West Fifty-fifth Street.

A quick dash in front of a closely approaching train to save the life of an apparently intoxicated man may bring coveted medals for heroism to a Long Island Rail road fireman, it was revealed here today. The case came to the at tention of J. A. Appleton, general manager of the railroad, when witnesses reported it this morning.

The Mount St. Michael quintet vanquished De La Salle Institute, 21 to 20, in an Interborough C. H. S. A. A. clash that featured the scholastic basketball quintuple header on the Hippodrome courtyesterday.

The Republican Assembly leadership decided today to defer action on controversial measures until-after election of a successor to Assemblyman Richard B. Smith, Onondag. Republican, whose death yesterday deprived the party of a working majority.

Luiz de Toledo Piza Sobrinho, president of the National Coffee Department, resigned today. The government probably will appoint Jayme Guedes, also of the department, as temporary head. The change has been rumored for two weeks, or ever since the Santos coffee bourse was the scene of uncontrolled speculation.
After fifty years of active service in the New York City school sys tem, Benjamin Veit, Assistant Su perintendent of Schools, will retire this August when he reaches hisseventieth birthday.

The Williams College hockey team won a hard but evenly contested battle tonight, defeating Hamilton Col lege, 2-1. Jay and Young scored for Williams in the first period, while Vicary tallied for Hamilton in the second. Harris, Williams goalie, had 34 saves, Laux of Hamilton 25.

In celebration of the seventy-sec ond birthday of Sir Wilfred T. Gren fell today, the crew of the Grenfell Juniors, from 7 to 13 years old and numbering more than 300, held a party on board the Monarch of Bermuda yesterday morning, before the liner sailed for Bermuda. The Grenfell Juniors are part of the Grenfell Association of America and help in Sir Wilfred's work among the children of Labradorand Northern Newfoundland.
Two books 300 years old, writ ten by Captain John Smith, were added to the Vassar College library this week as the gift of Rebecca Lawrence Lowrie '13.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Sisson of this place have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Florence T. Sisson, to George F. Richards, son of Mrs. F. St. John Richards, also of Cranford, and thelate Mr. Richards.

THE legend of Lawrence of Arabia, destined perhaps for many a poet's pen, is re told here in an easily read, con versationally narrative blank verse. In three parts it pictures Lawrence's pre-war archaeologi cal experiences, some incidents and items from the Arab cam paign and a summary account of Lawrence's life after the Treatyof Versailles as Private Shaw.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Howard Dudley of Hanover, N. H., gave a reunion luncheon yesterday in the Grill Room of the Ambassador for the girls of Interlaken Camp, of which they are directors. Receiving with the host and hostess were their daughter, Miss Constance Dudley; their son, Andrew Dudley, and Miss Vera Milner of Atlanta,Ga.

Lehigh University's wrestling squad lost its first meet of the season to night, bowing to Penn State before a crowd of more than 6,000. The score was 20 to 8. The Lions took six of the eight bouts. Each team won one contest on a fall. Richard Bishop, Lehigh's in tercollegiate champion, threwLuther Single in 8:21 and Captain Joe O'Dowd earned State's fall when hetossed Myron Sterngold in 6:03.
Twelve freshmen at the College of St. Elizabeth, here, have at tained a scholastic rating in the highest tenth of their class, it was announced today by Sister HelenCecilia, registrar.

TO Jonathan Starbuck, watching the wagon-trains encamped about the fron tier town of Independence, Mo., in the year 1846, it seemed as if all America were headed Westward A likely lad of 15. son and grandson of pioneers. could hardly fail to be stirred byPierre Leroux's rousing words:

Dick Neal, outboard motor boat racer from Kansas City, today hung up his second world record in as many days at the Lakeland regatta, guiding his Class B craft over a five-mile course at 48.309 miles an hour. He traveled almosta mile an hour faster
The Methodist Episcopal Church, South, reports gains in contributions and membership during 1986 as compared with 1935.

COLLTECTORS of antique fabrics-and many interior decorators as well-place great value on old painted and printed cottons from India. These are important because of their inherent beauty and the extent to which they have, from the seventeenth century on, influenced European design and decoration.
The Maritime Commission postponed to day "until further notice" the opening of bids for the charter of four government-owned steamship lines. The bid opening had beenscheduled for Monday.

Mr. and Mrs. William P. Willetts of Homewood, Rosyln, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Newhall Willetts, to Lieut. Walter D. Coleman, U. S .N., son of Dr. and Mrs. W. W. Coleman of Lincoln, III.

The Amherst basketball team piled up an early lead to defeat Wesleyan, 47-30, in Pratt Cage tonight. Be fore a capacity crowd of 2,500, the Jeffs rolled up a 14-0 lead in the first seven minutes. At half-timethey were ahead, 28 to 12.
Mrs. Raymond Rothstein of New York has announced the engage ment of her daughter, Miss May Rothstein, to Roy Reider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Reider ofDobbs Ferry, N. Y.

The wheat market showed a relatively firm undertone today. The beneficial effect of snow on the coming crop in Kansas and Oklahoma was off set by evidence of a close adjust ment to supply the world over. Price movements on the Board of Trade held within a range of 1/2 to 1 cent a bushel. Closing trades wereat net gains of 1/4 cent.

VIENNA. IT is only a little over a year since Max Lorenz, down from Berlin to "guest" as Tannhaeuser, left Vienna in a huff, vowing by all that is holy that he never would return because, forsooth, one of the newspapers had written five and a half lines more about MariaMueller than about him.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Johnson of Blythewood Farms, Pittsfield, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Helen John son, to Donald L. Retallick, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Retallick,also of Pittsfield.

A REALLOCATION of broad casting stations is in prospect, Anning S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, reported at a recent Senate hearing. He assured the committee that applications for super-transmitters are to be acted upon most discreetly to protect regional stations throughout the country.
Yale Uni versity and the City of St. Louis came in today for official censure from the Progressive Education As sociation at the final session of itsnational convention here.

Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, speaking today at a round-table dis cussion in connection with the Harvard-Yale-Princeton conference on Public affairs, predicted that the managers of public utilities would be subjected to greater control by public regulatory bodies, and warned the utilities that it was "safer and more profitable" for them to cooperate with such regulatory agencies.

THESE are days when those European peoples who are still free to think and to speak have to reflect upon fundamentals. Even when they are unable to make head or tall of daily events they can ask themselves where "bedrock" lies and whether their feet are firmly planted on it. Quite a number ofBritons are now doing this;

PARIS. TWO plays recently have been produced in Paris-one written by a man of 60 and the other by a man of 30--which appropriately may be considered together because the contrasts which can be drawn between them Illustrate so many things about the theatre. Further, each play is typical of the generation to which its author belongs--one might almost say that each play is typical of its period,

A jury that deliberated twenty hours in a murder case and stood eleven to one for conviction re ported yesterday afternoon to Judge John J. Freschi in the Court of General Sessions that it was unable to reach a verdict, and was discharged.
-Taking a 20-to-3 advantage in the first fifteen minutes, the Williams College basketball team halted Massachusetts Institute of Technology tonight, 46 to 24.

Coopera tion at Goucher College has been carried out to a noteworthy extent in its cooperative house project. Four years ago, a committee was selected to work on the project which was to offer scholarships tonineteen worth undergraduates.

A na tion-wide movement to combat prejudice against the employment of men and women who have reached middle age, the so-called past 40 group, was launched here today with the announcement that papers had been filed for the incorporation of the American Citizens'League.

Five days hence it will have been just four years since the first inaugura tion of Franklin D. Roosevelt as President of the United States. The only commemoration of the occasion, even semi-officially, willbe the "Victory Dinners"

I MET Knud Rasmussen for the first time in 1924. He had just returned from his Fifth Thule Expedition, named by him and Peter Freuchen after the Latin name for an island, probably one of the Shetland group, which in ancient times was regarded as "farthest north"-hence the familiar expression, "Ultima Thule."

Dr. Ran dolph Winslow, Professor Emeritus of Surgery, University of Maryland School of Medicine, died at his home here today at the age of 84. He was born in Hertford, N. C., son of Dr. Caleb Winslow and Mrs.Jane Paxson Parry Winslow.

The Desmond-Mailler and Buck ley-Reoux bills to provide optional forms of county government outside New York City were approved yes terday by the committee on legisla tion of the Citizens Union. Both bills were passed last year by the Senate and were recommended this year by Governor Lehman in hisopening message to the Legislature.

A white and orange setter from the C. A. Chestlick kennels at Buffalo, N. Y., ran into sleet and snow in the midst of a capable per formance in the national field trials today. The weather, which caused Missis sippi Jack Hawk's trainer to reguest his withdrawal
Governor Benson asked the State Attorney General today to define his author ity with reference to taking over the strike-bound Northern States Power Company's plants in Minneapolis.

There are several more big musical shows in preparation for Coronation audi ences. Having abandoned the idea of a Gracie Fields musical comedy, Charles B. Cochran now is working on the new Franz Lehar operetta, "Paganini," wherein Evelyn Laye is returning to the London stage after an absence of nearly four years. A. P. Herbert and Reg inald Arkell are responsible for theadaptation.

Miss Dorothy Lilienthal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Lilienthal of this city, has chosen March 13 for her marriage to George F. Dollar, son of Mrs. L. Stephen Dollar of West Philadelphia and the late Mr.Dollar.
A foundation to aid economic re search, which he will personally endow and which will carry his name, has been established by Al fred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation.
Repaving of the Queensboro Bridge will be continued tomor row, weather permitting, officialsannounced today.
The New York Life Underwriters Association has announced that George S. Van Schaick, vice presi dent of the New York Life Insur ance Company and former Superintendent of Insurance of New York

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lydia Fur bush, daughter of Mrs. William H. Eades of Downingtown, Pa., and Philadelphia, and of Dr. C. Lincoln Furbush of this city and Philadel phia, to Lancelot Falcon Sims Jr.of New York.

United States naval planes from the base at Coco Solo, C. Z., began arriving at Caribbean ports today to start the most extensive air manoeuvres ever scheduled in this region. Operating under orders from Rear Admiral Ernest J. King at St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, approx imately fifty planes started eastward from the United States naval

Premier William Aberhart of Al berta will tell the public over the radio tomorrow afternoon that he will not be able to put the social credit dividend system into opera tion within the eighteen months' time limit he had promised. He will also offer to resign and call an other election if the electors who supported him at the last provincialelection desire him to do so.

An organization designed to cooperate with builders and other interests in the financing and sale of medium-priced houses in metropolitan home communities has been formed by George Serper, a builder of several years' experience in the Brooklyn area.

Nearly 900 dogs were benched today for the opening sessions of the thir teenth annual two-day all-breed ex hibition of the Kennel Club of Buf falo. The remodeled Broadway Auditorium offered unusual oppor tunities for spectators to get a close-range view of some of thegreatest dogs in the country.

The House of Commons gained one of its ablest recruits in years tonight when Sir Arthur Salter, internationally known economist, won a three-cor nered by-election fight for one of the two Oxford University seats. Sir Arthur, running as an inde pendent, triumphed over Sir Farquhar Buzzard,

General prospects favor a con tinued high rate of industrial ac tivity over the next six to eighteen months, with commodity prices holding firm in all lines of trade, the business survey committee of the National Association of Pur chasing Agents reported yesterday in its current survey of nationalbusiness conditions. The committee.

After ten eventful and record-breaking days, during which 277,000 outdoor-minded city folk and their suburban neighbors were attracted to the Grand Central Palace, the 1937 National Sportsmen's Show ended last night.
The engagement of Miss Josephine Hill to Lieutenant Beverly Carter, U. S. N., has been announced here by her parents, Lieut. Commander Patrick Hill, U. S. N., and Mrs.Hill of Washington, D. C.

Mrs. Nancy Watson Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald R. Watson of Mayfair House and Fallowfield, Smithtown, L. I., was married to Maurice A. Gilmartin Jr. of 71 East Seventy-seventh Street, son of M. A. Gilmartin of Garden City, L. I., yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Christ Church, Park Avenue andSixtieth Street.

"It Doesn't Happen Here," the annual Junior Show of Barnard Col lege, will take place on March 12 and 13. The plot concerns a contest held at the college for the best skit on college life. Writers who com pete include Eugene O'Neill, H. G. Wells, Lewis Carroll, H. B. Warnerand William Randolph Hearst.
Colonel John W. Tinker, superin tendent of the Vermont Soldiers' Home here, died late today in a Burlington hospital after a majoroperation. His age was 62.
The realty investment group headed by Norman K. Winston, which started its purchases of New York properties in March, 1933, announced yesterday the purchase oftwo more large structures.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Naomi Brittle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur P. Brittle of this place, to August Theodore Bahr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Bahr of EastOrange. formerly of New York.

Syracuse basketball team solved Penn State's zone defense tonight and won by 39 to 26 before 2,200 spectators. Syracuse had a 23-to-13 lead at half-time. State cut the margin to six points midway in the second half, but Syracuse put on a closingspurt to stay out of danger.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It becomes increasingly clear that the President has failed, by proposing re forms of the Federal judiciary, to cam ouflage the real motive for his attack on the Supreme Court.

The speech of 450 Smith Col lege freshmen will be tested at the college during the first week of March. Tests in speech are a col lege requirement at Smith, and each entering student receives an examination during her first year-students of advanced standing in the Fall. and freshmen at the beginning of the second semester.

Posse College's team of champion swimmers and former title-holders easily defeated the New York University mermaids, 37 to 16, in the Women's Swimming Association pool yesterday. Of the six events the winners took five.

OUR world of today is as different from the world of one hundred years ago as was that from the world of the great Rameses Not only on account of the inventions which have made commonplace events of journeying once al most impossible and enabledone man's voice to be heard

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 24 aggregated $8,935,000,000, or 1 per cent above the total reported for the preced ing week and 16 per cent above the total for the corresponding week oflast year.

Top honors in the field of 1,185 dogs benched during the five days of Bloomingdale's pet dog show went to Bummey, an upstanding Old English sheepdog owned by Miss Mona Saphir of Manhattan. The judging for best in show yes terday concluded the most success ful exhibition of the six conductedfor pet dogs.

The marriage of Miss Mildred Evelyn Piggins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Piggins of this town, to Lawrence B. Weir, son of Mrs. M. C. Weir of Kansas City, Mo., took place this afternoon in the Church of the Holy Commun ion, South Orange, where the bride's parents were married twenty-five years ago.
Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were fewer than for the preceding comparative periods in February.
Dr. Eugene L. Maguire, senior surgeon at the Somerville Hospital and secretary of the medical board there, died yesterday at his home in Somer ville, where he was born fifty-eightyears ago.

Opposition to the McReynolds Neutrality Bill on the ground that it represents a "distinct blow to democracy" is contained in a statement signed by fifty representatives of civic, fraternal, trade union and religious organizations, made public by the New York City Division of the American LeagueAgainst War and Fascism.

Dis patches from Beirut reported today the seaport town of Latakia was under a curfew rule and the sur rounding region was experiencing strikes, following a clash yesterday between French troops and Syrian Nationalist Iron Shirts in whicheleven were killed.
A 109 foot three-masted schooner is be ing overhauled and refitted here for a two-year voyage in the north polar regions, carrying a group of scientists who will study meteorological conditions.

STUNNED by a comprehensive survey of radio communities in which the various stations have been judged and rated according to showmanship, local broadcasters in more than one city have hastened to scrutinize their formulas.

FOR some time now, ever since the literary maturity of James Farrell, it has seemed as if photographic realism has accomplished everything of which it is capable, both good and bad. Our ears, jangled by the cacophony of gutter, tenement and pool parlor, and our eyes, smarting before portraits of human futility and incompetency, were not a little ready tocry halt.

Enrollment of 5,130 young men for the Citizens' Military Training Camps this Summer in New York, New Jersey and Delaware will begin tomorrow. Application blanks are available at the office of the Military Training Camps Association, 7 West Ninety-sixth Street.

The Williams College faculty has taken another step toward liberalization of the curriculum by altering graduation requirements so that seniors, beginning next year, will have four courses in stead of five. This action, an nounced by Dr. Theodore Clarke Smith, dean of the faculty, follows a series of wide curricular changes instituted during the last three years and leading to the introduction of a degree with honors.

High waters in the lower Missis sippi River today moved on toward a stormy Gulf of Mexico, with the flood situation still under control. Army engineers have become more confident daily that the levees would hold as the flood crestpoured on to the Gulf.

Mayor La Guardia, in a letter sent yesterday to J. L. Kilpatrick, presi dent of the New- York Telephone Company, asked that the practice of making an additional charge for handset telephones be discontinuedafter Jan. 1, 1938.

IF you have ever so much as thought of going abroad, any where, here at last is a travel book that is a must. And if that seems high praise, let the re viewer state at once that, in pro portion to this book's deserts, it is a very mild statement. Among all the books which offer advice to the would-be traveler, this one steps immediately-and modestlywithal-to a place by itself.

IT is a matter worthy of passing inquiry whether, if a search were to be instituted here-abouts for a genuinely first-rate male dancer in the ranks of the contemporary ballet, it would not prove to be the lowly world of the revue that demanded prime attention.

Rudy Marshall, Harlem middle weight, gained an eight-round decision over Danny Lyons, Buffalo, N. Y., in the feature bout at the Rockland Palace last night before 2,500 spectators. Marshall weighed 155 3/4 pounds and Lyons 164 3/4.

Storage of sixteen bales of Japa nese straw hat braid and a few bales of Scotch wool constituted the sum total of business done by New York City's free port in the first month of its operation,officials admitted yesterday.

A mys terious S O S message tonight wor ried the Coast Guard. An amateur radio operator reported receiving a message, which said: "Taking water fast. Fisher." Neither the Coast Guard nor the amateur was able to contact thesender again.

Further gains in distribution and manufacturing activity were regis tered throughout the country last week, with retail sales continuing to show marked improvement over the figures for the corresponding period last year as the demand forSpring merchandise broadened.

The military sub-committee of the House Appropriations Commit tee reviewed the corps at the mili tary academy today during an in section in connection with a pro posal to purchase additional landfor the academy.

Driving an ambulance across wartorn fields or preparing bandages in a dressing station not too remote from the battle lines gave an illusion of romance-at least in anticipation-to girls of less than a generation ago who responded to an impulse to be of service in theWorld War.

The procedure undertaken by lo cal credit associations in the flood areas to aid in rehabilitation of business there and to extend credit was reported here yesterday to the National Association of Credit Men and outlined in a release sent outby that organization.

The men's glee club of Duke Uni versity will give a concert tomor row night in the Garden of the Am bassador for members of the New York Alumni Association, of which Frank Warner is president, andtheir guests.

Miss Marian Newfield, daughter of Albert Newfield of Stamford, will be married to Bernard John Grad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Grad of Newark, N. J., on March 12 at the Tumblebrook Country Club Rabbi Abraham J. Feldman willperform the ceremony.

Degrees and certificates will be awarded to 532 students of City Col lege who completed the four-year course of study and were graduated as of Feb. 1, 1937, at the annual commencement exercises in June, according to an announcement by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president.
Guy New all, British stage and screen actor, died yesterday at his Hampsteadhome. His age was 51.

Drew University will be host Tuesday to the second Winter session of- the northern section-of the New Jersey High School Principals Association, Dean Frank G. Lankard of Brothers College has announced.

In a pamphlet entitled Realism in Housing, the tenement house committee of the Charity Organization Society presents a four-point program for the "achievement of healthful and decent living conditions in existing tenement houses."

Charlton Athletic and Ar senal maintained their positions as leader and runner-up over the week-end in the race for the English Football League champion ship. With two months of play remaining, the Athletic has 41 points, the rival Londoners beingtwo points behind.
A non-profit system of voluntary health insurance will be begun in a few weeks in To ronto, Norfolk County and Windsor under the supervision of the Ontario Medical Association.

A committee of twenty-five per sons who will press a campaign for more recreation centers, rezoning plans and better housing for the West Side will be named during the coming week. The committee, to be composed of members of four of the West Side Councils of Social Agencies, was decided on yesterday afternoon at the West Side Joint Recreation Conference and Lunch eon, at which about 200 recreational organizations were represented.

A magic putter manipulated by Frank Strafaci of Brooklyn sent the 1935 national public links cham pion and his southpaw partner, Frank Crum of Williamson, W. Va., into the final of the .Miami Biltmore amateur invitation four ball golf tournament today. They vanquished T. E. Price of Miami and Sam Anderson of Chicago, 7 and 6, in the thirty-six-hole semifinal round today.
An effort to arouse public sentiment against ratification by the Senate of the commercial treaty signed by Cuba and Great Britain Feb. 19 was made today by members of theHouse of Representatives.
"When I retire to private life 'on Jan. 20, 1941," the President this week has been saying -to his friends, "I do not want to leave the country in the condition Buchanan left it toLincoln.

Many dinners will be given before the sec ond annual "Esquire Night" of the Junior Assembly of Yonkers, which will be held on March 7 at the Park Hill Community Club here. Former Supreme Court Justice William L. Bleakley, father of Miss Margaret Bleakley, a member of the assem bly, will be among the guests ofhonor.

For the first time- since the estab lishment of the Yugoslav dictator ship in 1929, the seemingly solid Croat bloc showed signs today of a bitter internal feud The occasion was the observance of the forty first anniversary of the death of theCroat patriot Starcevitch.

For the first time in four months the end of the week coincided with the month-end, in so far as the markets were concerned. The inde cisive movement of stocks was re flected by THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty issues, which closedthe week at 137.22.

Many of her American friends and executives of the Y. W. C. A. will honor Miss Maude Royden, distinguished woman preacher from England, at a dinner. Wednesday night at the headquarters of the National Board, 600 Lexington Avenue.
Andrew R. Brodbeck, member of Congress during the World War and former Sheriff of York County, died at his home here today after a long illness.His age was 76.
