During the final half of the year 1936 the number of savings, build ing and loan associations with as sets exceeding $10,000,000 was in creased by four members. This is the first time, reports H. F. Cel larius, secretary of the United States Building and Loan League, that an increase has been madesince the latter half of 1930.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday, according to The Associated Press, that it ex pected a satisfactory conclusion to negotiations for a wage increase"within the next few days."

Members of the board of trustees of the New Jersey State Federa tion of Women's Clubs, of which Mrs. Alfred Robie Driscoll is presi dent, at the February meeting at New Brunswick voted opposition to President Roosevelt's plan to in crease the number of members ofthe Supreme Court.

Leading throughout the game, St. Lawrence University's five spiked a desperate Colgate rally in the last few minutes of play and went on to win, 35-27, tonight. The visitors led at half-time, 17-13. Hugh Purcell paced St. Lawrence, which bowed to the Red Raiders on its own court earlier in the season.Purcell made 11 points.
Penn sylvania captured its ninth straight Eastern Intercollegiate League vic tory tonight, defeating the tail-end Cornell team, 40-24, at the Palestraand clinching the championship..

A cargo-passenger ship which has been reconstructed under safety regulations of the Department of Commerce and is now 99 per cent unburnable, has been turned over to the owners by the Maryland Dry dock Company, it was announced yesterday.

Peggy Garcia, the former night club hat-check girl whose $500,000 breach of promise suit against Dave Rubinoff, violinist, resulted in her indictment on a charge of bigamy, was unable to obtain yesterday the $2,500 bail necessary for her release from the Woman's House of Deten tion, Sixth Avenue and TenthStreet.

BECAUSE of the devastation of the flood, the twentieth bien nial convention and American Musical Festival of the National Federation of Music Clubs will be held in Indianapolis, April 23-29, instead of in Louisville.

Trench newspapers, posters and other pictorial and literary material relating to the World War collected by Mrs. Frederick Elliott Lewis, as well as first editions, library sets, autograph letters and manuscripts belonging to William Ryle and other owners, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., onThursday afternoon.

Plans for the ninth meeting of the Southern Conference for Music Education, which will be held in Columbia, S. C., next Wednesday to Saturday, have been announced by Miss Grace Van Dyke More, head of the Department of Public School Music at the Woman's College of the University of North Carolina,who is president of the conference.
Erwin Shepard Spink, teacher and headmaster in various private schools before his retirement in 1933, died at his Winter home heretoday. His age was 72.
The West chester County Children's Associa tion will be the beneficiary of a fig ure skating carnival ?? be held next Sunday night at the Playland Camino here.

Following a sharp rise in November and December, industrial activity declined in January, according to today's announcement of the Federal Reserve Board. The distribution of commodities to customers declinedmore than seasonally in January.

Andres Segovia, the distinguished Spanish guitarist, played last night with his characteristic and inimitable art in the Town Hall. His program would have been of interest, competently performed, in itself, but it could be said that any music played by a Segovia would begiven fascination.
Vincent T. Connolly, newspaper man, died this morning at his home here of a heart attack. He was in his seventieth year. Born in Brooklyn, he attendedschools in Jersey City.

The baseball spotlight swung defi nitely and finally to the sunny South yesterday. The vanguard of the Yankees, last remaining link here between an October World Series and the opening of Spring training, headed for the warm cli mate and preparation for anotherchampionship campaign.

The Nassau Lit, undergraduate literary publication at Princeton University, passed the ninety- fifth anniversary of its founding this month, the second longest span of any college publication in the country. It is antedated only by the Yale Literary Magazine, which wasfounded six years earlier.

The law is cracking down on drunken drivers, said the Motor Vehicle Commission er, John A. Harnett, today as he disclosed that there had been a sharp increase in license revoca tions and suspensions for drivingwhile intoxicated during the month.

Under the joint directions of Dr. Andred Francis Jackson, J. J. Gould and Mary Ryan O'Brien, the Play ers Club of Swarthmore will pre sent "The Cradle Song," by Gregorio and Maria Martinez Sierra, for five nights, beginning next Tuesday in the club's theatre here. Thish is the same play of convent life presented with such success a few years ago by Eva Le Gallienne and her civicrepertory company.
Scoring a vic tory by one foot in the varsity mile relay final, Dartmouth won the quadrangular track championship from Harvard, Yale and Cornell be fore 4,000 spectators at the BostonGarden tonight.
Members of the Auxiliary of St. Angela Hall have arranged a card party and fashion show for St. Patrick's Day at the Biltmore for the benefit of the scholarship fundof the organization.

James Duross, Knight of St. Greg ory and patron of letters, has found ed for Marymount College, here, a gold medal to be awarded at the commencement exercises for the best essay on "The Encyclicals ofthe Popes," it was announced today.

Dr. Walter Damrosch and Mrs. August Belmont will address the Music Education Conference of the New York University School of Education in the auditorium, 41 West Fourth Street, next Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Ernest G. Hesser, chairman of theDepartment of Music Education.

LAKELAND, Fla. VISITORS who flock to Florida each year during the cold months usually are given the general label of tourists, but it is possible and proper to divide them into at least three distinct groups. Indeed, that is precisely what Floridians have an increasingtendency to do.

Health conditions and nursing needs of an actual but anonymous mountain county will come under professional scrutiny at an all-day forum called for Wednesday at the Hotel Roosevelt by the New York branch of the Southern Women'sEducational Alliance.
The first Philadelphia performance of Puccini's opera, "Madame Butter fly," in several seasons will be given at the Academy of Music on March 17 by the Civic Grand Opera Company of Philadelphia.

New York University's School of Education has established a new scholarship fund in memory of Lowell Mason, pioneer American hymnologist, publisher and "father" of public school music, it was an nounced yesterday by Dean John W. Withers. The original contri bution to the fund was made by Wanamaker's through the Men's Glee Club of the music educationdepartment.

William F. Bleakley, the Repub lican candidate for Governor in the last election, and William Cronin, County Democratic Chairman, have expressed unqualified approval of the major features of the proposed Westchester County Charter, filed Thursday with the Board of Supervisors.

James M. Curley, until Jan. 7, "His Excel lency, the Governor of Massa chusetts," will try this autumn to become for the fourth time "His Honor, the Mayor of Boston." On the day he walked out of of fice down the State House steps, he joined the bride he had marriedthat morning for a wedding tour.

Modern educators, in stressing the teaching technique of imparting large quantities of knowledge to their students, have utterly failed to develop independent minds, Dean Joseph W. Barker of the Columbia Engineering School pointed out to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, presi dent of Columbia University, in his annual report, made public yesterday.

When the curtain went up last night at the Forrest Theatre in West Forty-ninth Street for an other performance of "Tobacco Road," Maude Odell, veteran actress, who played the part of Sis ter Bessie Rice, itinerant psalm singing preacher, failed for the first time since the show opened more than three years ago to respond toher cue.

Committees in New York and Westchester have undertaken ar rangements for the annual benefit at Arnold Constable Co. here to aid the Children's Village, the school for maladjusted boys and girls at Dobbs Ferry. The bene ficiary will receive a percentage of the sales made on March 16 and 17at the store.
The marriage of Miss Sarah Porter Hunsaker to David Swope, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Swope of Ossining, N. Y., took place this afternoon at King's Chapel here.
The body of I. T. Clement Dissinger, 39, a college professor, was found in a Northumberland County swamp to day. Police Chief Michael Surgent said he believed the teacher committed suicide.

THE coronation of George VI of England and its dominions beyond the seas is two months away, but plans for the event on the air are almost complete, according to the British Broadcasting Corporation in its official journal,The Radio-Times.

Subjects of Mr. JOHN L. LEWIS be lieve that they have the "right" to seize and occupy an employer's prop erty; also, if need arises, the "right" to commit malicious mischief on the seized premises and therefrom violently to resist the officers of the law seekingto carry out the orders of the courts.

Harold F. Swenson of Plainfield, N. J., has been appointed editor of the Manhattan College Quarterly, the recently revived literary maga zine of the Riverdale institution. His selection and those of the other new members of the editorial staff were announced yesterday by Brother Augustine Philip, head of the School of English Literature, and faculty moderator of the Quarterly.

The annual Gilbert and Sullivan operetta presentation at the College of William and Mary will be offered next Thursday and Friday evenings in the Phi Beta Kappa Memorial Hall. This year's production, "The Gondoliers," is under the super vision of George M. Small, head of the Music Department of the col lege, assisted by Frederick Eids ness of Alexandria, Va., a graduate student at the college.

The Congress shall have power to limit, regulate and prohibit the labor of persons under 18 years of age. This is the wording of the child labor amendment, and some persons appear to have become sincerely alarmed by the extent of the powers that they believe it grants.

Chiseled gold pendants, set with rubies or sapphires, are being worn in draped evening turbans suggesting the head. dress of a Rajah. Several smart Parisiennes appeared in them at the recent opera gala, the occasion being the re-openingof the freshly decorated house.
The capital of the Virgin Islands will henceforth be known as Charlotte Amalie, the Interior Department announced today, the new namereplacing that of St. Thomas.

SEVERAL papers on sculpture appear in Vol. V, Part 2 of the Metropolitan Museum Studies, an important, schol arly periodical published semi-annually by the museum. Valen tin Mueller contributes an essay on "The Beginnings of Monumental Sculpture in Greece,"

In celebration of its ninetieth an niversary, the Twelfth Regiment, N. Y. N. G., now known as the 212th Coast Artillery, whose armory is a familiar landmark at West Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue, will give a dinner April 14,at the Hotel McAlpin.

Running skillfully over one of the most difficult cross-country courses ever laid out in the United States, the versatile Sverre Kolte rud resumed his winning ways in American skiing by annexing the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's langlauf championship today.

To most newspaper readers the name of Rollo Ogden was unknown. He never appeared in public, never signed articles, never sought self-advertisement. But in his chosen field-that of editorialwriter-he was recognized as a master.

Mr. and Mrs. George B. Coe of Stam ford announce the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison W. Coe, to Theodore K. Hess of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank N. Hess of Waterbury, at a tea this after noon at the home of Mrs. EthanPendleton in Waterbury.
TO few persons, and certainly to very few writers, has it been given to live with the zest that was vouch safed Rudyard Kipling. And this zest for living animates every page
Mr. and Mrs. Peter Hoffman will ob serve their sixty-fifth wedding an niversary tomorrow at a familygathering at their home here.

Three men were arrested on charges of burglary last night after a bed-ridden invalid, whose long years of idle gazing from a propped pillow had made him intimately aware of whatever fell within his view, noticed something wrong andsent word to the police.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Cangin of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Josephine Lillian Cangin, to Dr. Constantine Monteleone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartolo Monteleone, alsoof Brooklyn.

THROUGH the week at hand the Museum of Modern Art will continue to show its seventeen recent acquisitions, which, along with the examples of modern English architecture and the posters by E. McKnight Kauffer, went on view Feb. 10.

Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Ambassa dor, flew back to Berlin tonight to make a speech in Leipzig Monday and then report to Chancellor Adolf Hitler on the events of the past fewweeks in Great Britain.

A fantasy of the Orient based on "The Thousand and One Nights" of Arabian legend will be presented as a feature of the special dinner dance to be given on Thursday night in the Garden of the Ambas sador as a means to augment theflood relief fund of the Red Cross.
A reception to mark founder's day at the Chapin Home for the Aged and Infirm will be held Wednesday afternoon at the headquarters of the home, 165th Street and ChapinParkway, Jamaica, Queens.

The Targum, Rutgers Univer sity undergraduate semi-weekly newspaper, announced today elec tion of its editor in chief and busi ness manager. Elections were con ducted by the Targum council, governing body for the publication, following the recommendations of the past editor and business manager.
The varsity five of Peddle School kept its record clear by defeating Blair Academy today for the second time this season, 40-34. It was Peddle's fourteenth straight victory.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in a telegram to State Assembly leaders, has renewed his attack on the Child Labor Amendment, now awaiting ratification by the Assembly, and has urged the leaders to defeat the measure as "one more of the radical proposals to undermine our social and political order."
A field trip to the Boyce Thompson Institute at Yonkers will be made tomorrow afternoon by the members of the Flushing Garden Club.... At Wednesday afternoon's meeting of the Great Neck Garden Club,

Delegates from more than forty colleges will attend the Middle At lantic Regional Conference of the National Student Federation of America, which will be held at the New Jersey College for WomenApril 16, 17 and 18.

Record increases in every branch of its operations made 1936 a ban ner year in the history of Eastern Air Lines, according to figures re leased yesterday by Captain E. V.Rickenbacker, general manager.

Rallying superbly after dropping the first game, William E. Coyle and Conway Hoffmann of the Mont clair Athletic Club triumphed in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets As sociation doubles championship final at the Heights Casino in Brooklynyesterday to retain the title.
PLANS now being made for New York's 1939 World's Fair foreshadow the issuance of a series of stamps commemorating this event.

Ernest Greasley fled into hiding today to escape 300 ad miring laundry girls who have called him "Clark Gable" and struck because he was to be trans ferred as foreman to another plant. Only his 24-year-old wife was at home to greet the girls when they went to tell him they had agreedto go back to work.
W. D. (Don) Curtis, baseball scout, who discovered the famous brothers, Jerome (Dizzy) and Paul Dean, diedhere yesterday at the age of 57.

Four little sisters learning to swim at Gales Ferry three decades ago churned up more than the wa ter as they splashed and flound ered. They brought into being a national program of recreation for their companions which has bur geoned, through the years, Into the Camp Fire group of more than 250, 000 girls, intent this week on ob serving the silver anniversary oftheir organization.

The matter of the Italian and German Ministers' participation in the funeral of two members of the Fascist Iron Guard, who were killed while fighting with the Spanish Rebels, is not settled. There is no precedent for the refusal of coun tries to recall Ministers from a cap ital where they are declared to beunwelcome.

Society of the Four Arts, and Mrs. Dillman, chairman of the social committee, were-hosts today at the invitation preview tea of the Retro spective Exhibition of Flower Paint ings, including canvases from the fifteenth century to today, at thesalon.

Sharply rising commodity levels, higher wages and the prospects of Federal legislation on hours and wages will force Fall prices to the highest levels since 1929, with that year's marks exceeded in many cases, according to opinions ex pressed by business men here yesterday.

THE banquet season is at its height in New York. Toast-masters have reached top form, after-dinner speakers are bringing out new stories-funny or not, as the case may be-and chefs are putting their staffs of cooks over the hurdles. striving always to produce theperfect feast.

Interest in the steady progress of women in archaeological research was sharpened last Fall through the appointment of Dr. Hetty Goldman of New York as a full professor at the Institute for AdvancedStudy at Princeton.

WALTER MILLIS views the European scene with out alarm. Great Britain, France and the U.S.S.R. do not want war although they have the means, while Germany and Italy, aggressively militant, lack raw materials and money. The British have Lombard Street, which endows their placiditywith vigor.
A rousing finish gave Lafayette a 30 to-27 triumph over Lehigh, its traditional rival, tonight.
The Rockville Center Building and Industrial Exposition will be held in Rockville Center, L. I., from May 25 to June 2. Louis W.Capone is executive director.

Mrs. Margaret F. Lugsdin of 80 Park Road, Scarsdale, N. Y., will receive a life interest in a $200,000 trust fund, in which nine New York City charities will share equally upon her death, under the terms of the will of Miss Louise H. Tiffany of Scarsdale, filed in Surrogate's Court here today.

AMES, Iowa.-Temporary silos built hurriedly when the drought threatened saved the farmers of this State an estimated 1,026,600 tons of feed during 1936, accord ing to figures compiled by the Iowa State College. Following plans suggested by the, university extension service,Iowa farmers built 18,598 silos.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Adolph A. Hageman of this city and Babylon, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emelia Theresa Hageman, to Frederic John Schroeder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic CharlesSchroeder of Norwood, NW J.
Mrs. Irene Peacock of Tenth Street gave a large tea this afternoon at the Garden City Hotel.
THE Philadelphia Orchestra, un der Eugene Ormandy, will give the eighth concert of its New York season Tuesday night, March 9, with Lawrence Tibbett, baritone, as soloist.

The 122-acre property at Pleasant Plains, Dutchess County, N. Y., formerly conducted as Camp Carle ton by the Brooklyn and Queens Young Men's Christian Associa tions, has been sold by those organ izations to William J. Williamson of Long Island City. Homer W. Guernsey of Poughkeepsie acted asbroker.

IT is seven years since Lord Balfour died and, in these breathless days, seven years test a memory. If Balfour still fascinates, it is not because he was among the pre-war Prime Ministers but because, here and now, his personality presents aproblem.

Machine-gun fire terrorized busy neighborhoods of Philadelphia and Camden, N. J., this afternoon as a squad of this city's police exchanged shots with a gang suspected of a $6,954 payroll robbery at Plymouth Meeting yesterday and of a series of other recent hold-upsin the suburban area.

Miss Doris Osborne Frantz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Frantz of Davenport Neck, has completed plans for her marriage to Robert Winslow Carrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Carrickof Larchmont.
A plan to strike first in defense against enemy fliers was disclosed today as the general scheme of Japanese aircombat.

After a laboratory course of five periods devoted, to discussion of "The Dress You Buy," with authorities of the industrial world explaining the conditions under which the clothes women wear are produced, members of the League of Women Voters have decided to invite the public to listen in on thefinal meeting.

Nine-year-old Barbara Ann Wahl of the Havemeyer School won the championship in the annual junior riding competition for Greenwich schools held at the Round Hill Club stables today. Miss Wahl competed with twenty other riders who had taken first and second places inhorsemanship classes in the show.

Sir James Grigg, finance member of the government of India, presented his third budget to the Legislative Assembly today, admitted it was a "story of disap pointment," and announced the army would have to do with lessmoney.

President Roosevelt's proposal to increase the number of Supreme Court justices will be the subject of a debate between the College of New Rochelle and Manhattan College Monday night in Chidwick Auditorium here, it was announced today by John Lane, New Rochelledebating coach.

MEXICO, half romantic, half myste rious, never fails to baffle the American visitor, who finds it both easy and pleasant to suc cumb to what John Dewey describes as the "incredible paradoxes of that land. Yet bafflement is unnecessary, for there are facts, however cold and impersonal, which can be found.

Directors of Paramount Pictures, Inc., acted yesterday to clear up all preferred dividend arrears by declaring a back dividend of 60 cents and a quarterly dividend of 15 cents on the second-preferredstock.

The Red Cross said today that the task of repairing damaged homes and restoring refugees of the Ohio and Mississippi River flood to the position of self-sustaining citizenswould take at least four months.

The Rev. John J. Donlan, since 1926 rector of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, Court and Con gress Streets, Brooklyn, died sud denly Friday of a heart attack on board the liner Manhattan, on which he sailed from this port onWednesday for a visit in Rome.

Last-minute ballots from tax-paying radio own ers poured in tonight in the Popu lar Front's battle for control of French Government broadcasting. The deadline for returning the mailed-in ballots to elect members of regional councils of radio man agement was tonight. The counting of the votes of 3,000,000 radio own ers who have paid the fifty-franc annual tax on receiving sets wasto start tomorrow.

The Holland-America Line an nounced yesterday that work on the company's new transatlantic liner New Amsterdam was pro gressing rapidly and that 14,550 tons of materials already had been used in her construction. The 88,000-ton vessel will be launched in April and will make her maiden voyage from Rotterdam to New York in April,1938.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Dolan of 145 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Adelaide Dolan, to Franklin PerryHatfield of Kansas City.

Miss Dorothy Wolverton of New York, daughter of C. Parker Wolverton of Northumberland, Pa., and Richard Eugene Devereaux, also of New York, son of Captain and Mrs. C. W. Devereaux of Jacksonville, Fla., were married in Plymouth Congregational Church at noon today.

A total of $42,000 has been given in the current year by Smith Col lege alumnae toward building the new Alumnae House to be started this Spring, Mrs. R. Keith Kane of New York, chairman of the alum nae fund, announced today at the last meeting of the 1937 AlumnaeCouncil.

The killing of Ras Desta Demtu, the last great Ethiopian chieftain remaining in rebellion, encourages the Italians in their efforts to subdue Ethiopia preparatory to its exploitation. The feat came within a week of the bomb throwing at Addis Ababa which wounded the Viceroy, Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, and drew atten tion to the military and economic problems facing the Italians in thenew colony.

Uncle Robert, sponsor of enter tainments for children, announced yesterday that the 100-piece band from - the James Monroe High School, 172d Street and Boynton Avenue, the Bronx, augmented by 150 picked musicians from other New York City high schools, would furnish the music for his tenth an nual Parents Day program, to be held on the Mall in Central Parknext May 9.

Development in the schools of courageous non-conformists who may be troublesome but know how to be critical of propaganda, would be an effective means of preventing war, Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assis tant Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday at a luncheon on "Education for Peace," given by the Public Education Association atthe Hotel Commodore.

MIAMI BEACH. "BOOM" is a dangerous word in this incredible land of the sun-wor shipers. It is forbidden in polite conversation. Natives go white around the gills when you utter it; even waitresses and manicurists warn youagainst using it.

IN reply to recent accusations in the British House of Commons that political emphasis was given in speeches and news put on the air by the British Broadcasting Corporation, Postmaster General Major G. C. Tryon denied politicalbias in the programs.

Displaying a smooth passing at tack, the Manhattanville College girls' basketball team routed the College of William and Mary of Virginia, 47 to 15, on the victors' court yesterday. The triumph was the second for the New Yorkers inas many starts.

Stung by the mass of unfavorable comment printed in the world press about the strong action Italy has taken to re-establish order in Ethiopia, well-informed Italian circles have been driven to admit that the at tempt to kill Marshal Rudolfo Graziani, the Viceroy, on Feb. 19 was part of a "big uprisingfomented by Ras Desta Demtu."
Two long-term leases signed this week complete the rental of all the stores on the east side of South Ocean Avenue in the business block nearMontauk Highway.
The fight over organization of the steel industry is being waged with in creasing vigor on all fronts. Here in the capital of steel the struggleis at white heat.

Miss Berta Mitlacher of Vienna and Baron Jean du Boisberranger of Paris, secretary of the French Legation at Bogota, Colombia, were married this morning by the Rev. Joseph Nelligan in the old Catholic Cathedral here. A nuptial massfollowed the ceremony.
Elmer F. Andrews, State Indus trial Commissioner has prohibitedunrestricted industrial homework

The United States Supreme Court was today declared responsible for tan gling the national power problem into "a maze of inconsistencies," the charge being made in an ad dress by James J. Bonright, vice chairman of the New York State Power Authority, at a three-day conference by the League for In dustrial Democracy on the socialcontrol of power.

ONE of the most potent forces in the renaissance of fine printing in the United States has been the influence exerted by the Ameri can Institute of Graphic Arts through its annual show of the"Fifty Books of the Year."

NOW YOU'VE DONE IT-Monday evenving at Henry Miller's The atre. Being a comedy by Mrs. Mary Coyle Chase, dealing with the antics of a political campaign and having among the mem bers of its cast John Alexander, -Evelyn Varden, Margaret Perry, Barbara Robbins, Ruth Gates, Mary Howes, Jane Bancroft and George Lessey.

Seven hundred million pieces of mail containing "free" bulletins, the speeches of Senators and Representatives, and vast quantities of official correspondence, were distributed last year by the administrative legislative and executivebranches of government.

Delays in the review of tax as sessments by certiorari may be at tributed primarily to the accumula tion of such proceedings instituted in recent years, according to Law rence J. Rittenband, aide to O. S. Cox, Assistant Corporation Counsel in charge of the tax division of theCorporation Counsel's office.

THE awarding board of the Goncourt novel prize did not always make so felici tous a choice as this year. Mr. Van der Meersch has uncon testably won the rank of one of the first French novelists of to day with his last work, "I'Em preinte du Dieu" (Albin Michel.256 pp., 15 fr.).

There is an easier feeling regarding the inter national outlook from one end of Europe to the other among those who know anything about it. Espe cially is this the case in England, where optimism is a habit of mind and an improved national position justifies optimism more than inmost countries.

A hunch that a fugitive with an Italian name and enough money for his passage would be on his way to Italy enabled detectives yester day to arrest a man whom they charged with being wanted forgrand larceny in California.

The United Peace Chest campaign, which was opened here on Wednesday by the Emergency Peace Campaign, the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, the Committee on Militarism in Education and the National Council for the Prevention of War, has received contributions of $43,000 to date, itwas announced today.

Witnesses at a hearing held here yesterday by the Securities and Ex change Commission testified that Lee, Higginson Co. had been in duced to buy, at par, $24,000 of Kreuger Toll secured debentures in order to extinguish alleged rescis sion rights that no longer existed and that the Bainbridge Colby bond holders' protective committee had failed to mention the deal in regis tering its deposit certificates withthe commission.

THIS is a thriller among au tobiographies with most of the good qualities of a dime novel. Serge Zolo is only 29 years old, but if his ac count of himself is to be accepted as written he has already had more adventures than any onesince Buffalo Bill.

IT seems almost incredible, but at one time Elkanah Settle was a formidable rival of Dryden, a highly successful playwright, and the darling of the younger set at Cambridge. With the production of "Cambyses" in 1666 he was embarked on what promised tobe a brilliant career.

Two grants by the Rockefeller Foundation for zoological and chemical studies at Mount Holyoke College were announced yesterday by Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of the college, and then cited by her to refute a belief that women's colleges were inactive in scientificresearch.

Adequate financing for Spring and Summer residential building operations was assured when Presi dent Roosevelt signed the amend ment to the National Housing Act extending the expiration of the gov ernment guarantee of debentures issued to mortgagees in cases of de fault from July 1, 1937, to April 1, 1939, according to Thomas G. Grace,State F. H. A. director.
After straying for a while from the moorings erected for her by Adolf Hitler's book "Mein Kampf" and getting into such exciting but, in results, rather disappointing adventures

"American and other overseas visitors for the coronation now need fear no dif ficulty in finding accommodation at reasonable -rates in London," says Hugh W. K. Wontner, secretary of the newly formed coronation ac commodation committee, set up with the authority of the British Government to act as a clearing house to coordinate accommodationfor the coronation period. Mr.

A collection of some 1,500 books about Napoleon assembled over period of thirteen years by John H. Regan, ship news reporter for the New York City News Associa tion, will be put on private sale here this month. Because of in health, Mr. Regan is on sick leaveat his old home in Texas.
William Nesbeth, one of the fu gitives wanted for the Sioux Falls dynamite blast killing on New Year's Day, is under arrest in Okla homa City, it was revealed here today.

The Bank of the Manhattan Com pany, as trustee, is prepared to pay interest, due on Jan. 10, 1935, on 1,088 Park Avenue, Inc., first mort gage 6 per cent bonds. It also will deliver definitive bonds of the State of New York Emergency Unemploy ment Relief 1 1/2 per cent issue dated Sept. 10, 1936, in exchange for temporary receipts.

Funeral services for Captain Ber nard William St. Denis Thomson, who was sports editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES for twenty-one years, will be held tomorrow at 2:30 P. M. at the Universal Chapel, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street. Captain Thomson died suddenly at St. Luke's Hospital Friday evening following a brief attack of pneumonia.
THIS teacup title is decep tively belittling. The book features a magnificent storm, a really big blow, powerful enough to keep a reader's hair standing on end.

Kid Chocolate, former world featherweight champion, out punched Jimmy Lancaster of Wil mington, Del., to gain the decision in the feature six-round bout at the Ridgewood Grove last night before3,000 persons.

When Burleigh Grimes assembles his first squad of pitchers, catchers and rookies on Clearwater Field at 10:30 Monday morning a number of Dodgers are going to discover that: "life is real, life is earnest." The militant manager may not be able to carry that poetic analogy further and make their baseball lives sublime, but he will make hisathletes hustle-"or else."
The Chinese jade, Georgian silver, English and American furniture, Oriental rugs and other objects sold yesterday afternoon at the Amer ican Art Association Anderson Galleries realized $23,707.50.

Comparative quiet, broken only by the gunfire of Spain's deadlocked civil war, lay over Europe last week. It was, however, no more than a surface calm. Britain revealed to a startled populace, and for the consideration of nations abroad, the swift progress ofher gigantic rearmament.

An application for a writ of certiorari designed to obtain a separate trial for 18-year-old Donald Wightman, who with Gladys MacKnight, 17, is charged with the murder of the latter's mother, will be heard before a full branch of the Supreme Courtin Trenton on March 24.

WHEN the Federal Gov ernment recently of fered to give Hoffman and Swinburne Islands to the City of New York not a few people asked where these islets might be found and for what purposes they had been used. Hoffman and Swinburne are man-made islands and they lie at the entrance of the Narrows, west of the main ship channel, amile off the Staten Island shore.

Trailing by three points at the half, Harvard's basketball team came back with a rush in the second period to take the measure of the Yale quintet, 33 to 29, in the feature event of a busy program for Eli athletes today. A crowd of 2,100, many of them here for the Junior Prom, watched the Eastern Intercellegiate League contest.

C. S. Bancroft's Skeeter, outsider in the betting at $27.20 for $2, raced to a driving two-length vic tory in the New Orleans Handicap, feature event on the Fair Grounds program today. Ably ridden by F. Ritz, the 3 year-old held closely to the pace most of the way and then passed Honey Cloud and Virginia J. in thestretch.

IN more than half the cities and towns covered in a nation-wide survey sponsored by the Fidelity and Casualty Company, civic leaders, after studying their local traffic problems, think that unfamiliarity with regulations is frequently responsible for offenses by visiting drivers.

JOHN STEINBECK is no mere virtuoso in the art of story telling; but he is one. Whether he writes about the ami able outcasts of 'Tortilla Plat" or about the grim strikers of In "Dubious Battle," he tells astory.

The Rev. Otho S. Thornberry, Presbyterian minister, died at the Bethesda Hos pital today. He retired two years ago. Formerly he was pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Newport, Ky., for fourteen years.

Tear gas and stench bombs were exploded last night in the orches tras of six motion picture theatres on Broadway in the upper west side, apparently in a renewal of labor troubles which have caused a series of bombings and other dis turbances in movie auditoriums inthe last three years.

Helena Rubinstein, Inc., Class A stock, no par value, and new com mon stock, no par value, have been admitted to listing by the New York Curb Exchange. Both stocks were issued under the plan of Oct. 29,1936.
The final events in the week-end Junior Promenade festivities at Yale took place this afternoon and evening, consisting of dances given by the Sheffield societies and theuniversity fraternities.

Dr. and Mrs. Rachnil Kornblith of 82 Bainbridge Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Rebecca Helene Kornblith, to Dr. David Gurin, son of Mr. and Mrs. JosephGurin of Great Neck, L. I.

Harvard's 300-yard medley relay team tonight set a new national intercollegiate swimming record and Greg Jameson, 200-yard breast stroke star, swam within almost three seconds of the world record as the Crimson mermen swampedPenn, 57 to 18.

MIAMI, Fla.-Books will be accepted as tickets at the annual book, tea and garden party to be held on Thursday afternoon at the Coconut Grove estate of Commodore Albert H. Swetland and Raymond H. Swetland, both of Cleveland, Ohio. The party is sponsored by the American Merchant Marine Associ ation, which supplies sailors of the American marine service withbooks for reading at sea.

Edward P. Field Jr. of the Prince ton Club, No. 1, and Edward L. Kilroe of the Columbia Club, No. 5, moved into the quarter-final round of the National Squash Tennis As sociation's Class B championship at the Crescent A. C., Brooklyn, yesterday.
Does a shortage of skilled labor impend in the nation? Over this question disagreement has arisen. Employers of labor, Chambers of Commerceand manufacturers' associations

TOURISTS' eyes are turning to Hawaiian beaches and the South Seas following settlement of the shipping strike on the Western Coast. The steamship companies which maintain passenger service from San Francisco and Los Angeles to South Pacific islands, New Zealand and Australia report heavy bookings tovarious objectives.

Lawrenceville's basketball team downed Horace Mann today by 28 to 21. The game, which was marked by many fouls, was played at a fast pace. The victors led by 19-8 at the half and kept the lead throughout. Bartlett of the Law rentians was high scorer of theday with 10 points.

With all but one of its components higher, THE NEW YORK TIMES week ly index of business activity for the week ended Feb. 20 advanced to 104.8 from 102.4 (revised). It was 91.3 for the week ended Feb. 22,1936.

The list of patrons and patron esses for the eighth annual Spring card party of the Brooklyn Asso ciation for Improving the Condition of the Poor, to be held on March 13 at the Hotel St. George, was made known yesterday by the chairman, Miss Madeleine W. Smith.

This is the title which a local paper of Brantford, Canada, has given to that city of 30,000 inhabitants. The toxoid treatment for the prevention of diph theria was introduced fifteen years ago, through the "foresight and enterprise " of the medical health officer. This is the story as related by The Toronto Globe:

A model of a slum tenement flat, set up in the stately nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 110th Street and Amsterdam Ave nue, will be an exhibit at a mass meeting tonight at 8 o'clock to demand city slum clearance.

Hunter College is giving new Im petus to potential leaders of the stage this term with an enlarged scope of curricular and extra-cur ricular dramatic activities. The newly formed dramatics com mittee, which replaces the old elec tive dramatics board, is a volunteer group whose purpose is to stimulate dramatic activity in all phases ofcollege life.

Navy teams bowed in three closely contested varsity engagements to day, dropping a 41-34 decision to Dartmouth in an Eastern Intercol legiate Swimming League meet which was a highlight of the pro gram. Nebraska University's pow erful wrestlers subdued the Annap olis grapplers, 16-14, while Temple won from the Middies in gymnasticcompetition, 28-26.

Army's poloists rode to their thirty first consecutive triumph in the feature contest of a busy afternoon of sports at the academy today, turning back Princeton, 13-9. The Cadet boxers vanquished Western Maryland rivals, the varsity win ning by 7 1/2--1/2, while the plebesbeat the visiting freshmen, 7-1.

AT a regional dealers' meeting held by Studebaker here last week under the sponsorship of M. E. Hewins, sound body structure, careful paint jobs and, above all, economy of operation of the 1937 Presidents and Dictatorswere stressed.

AUGUSTA, Ga.-The Ball of All Nations to be given by the Bachelors' Club of Augusta at the Bon Air Hotel on Thurs day night and varied entertainment for national and State officials of two women's organizations compose the social program here this week. The Bachelors' Club ball will be one of the outstanding social events of the season, with 500 guests expected,attired in costumes of all nations.

Ernest Hemingway, author, sailed yesterday on the French liner Paris on his way to Spain as a news paper correspondent. With him was Sidney Franklin, the Brooklyn matador who said he had no in terest in Spanish politics but wasgoing to Spain to fight bulls.

Students of five colleges here will take part in a symposium on the topic "The Church and the Worker" this afternoon in Keating Hall, on the campus of Fordham College. The event is one of a series to be held by the Intercolle giate Sodality, composed of stu dents of Georgian Court College, College of Notre Dame, College of St. Elizabeth, Fordham College and Fordham College, Manhattan Division.

A national small-homes forum, sponsored by more than fifty na tional associations of building sup ply dealers, electrical manufactur ers and home supply organizations in cooperation with the Federal Housing Administration to spur home construction, will be held inthe Hotel Roosevelt tomorrow.

Henry W. Morganthaler, Cincinnati capitalist and tax expert, is dead at Miami, Fla., according to word received here today. His age was 87. Mr. Morganthaler was appointed tax inquisitor of Hamilton County in 1875 when that position was cre ated by the State Legislature to re quire individuals and business firms to list stocks and other taxable se curities for taxation in that capacity.

Two officers of the Army Reserve Air Corps were killed today in the crash of an army training monoplane in which they were taking blind flying prac tice. Witnesses said that the ship went out of control at an altitude of about 500 feet several minutes after it took off from the City Air port and spun into a vacant fieldnear by.
Court action to determine the constitutionality of compulsory flag-saluting in public schools is being pressed in eight States by Jehovah's Witnesses, a religioussect.

New Yorkers are literally eating their way out of one of the greatest oversupplies of poultry and poultry products that have occurred in the industry. Consumption of poultry-it is estimated-has expanded 25 per cent since heavy stocks began to force the price downward last Fall; appetite for eggs has increased around 40 per cent since retail costs fell off in the middle of January.

The Columbus Council Knights of Columbus basketball team of Brook lyn defeated the University Club of Stamford at the State Armory to night, 38 to 26, in an Eastern Ath letic Club League game. Universityled. 15-10 at the half.

At the request of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., the Maritime Com mission yesterday announced an extension to March 17 of the time in which objections to a report urg ing limitation on the period mer chandise can be stored free of charge on local steamship piersmay be filed.
Germany launched another de stroyer today in solemn exercises during which the crew was remind ed that "men, not ships, do thefighting."

The Spring Dolphin Dance, one in a series of subscription enter tainments for girls who will be introduced to society in the next three years, will be held in the ball room of the Pierre on the night of March 31 instead of on Easter Eve,March 27, as originally planned.

TWO large orders of rolling stock from Vic toria, B. C., are William John Peden, called Torchy, and James Douglas Peden, called Doug. They are brothers over the handlebars as well as under the skin, and are teamed together in the six-day bike race that is due to start around the wooden saucer in Madison Square Gardenthis evening.

Free dom approached today for most of the 186 sit-down strikers still held after the arrest of 345 at the Doug las Aircraft Corporation Thursday night as Judge Emmet Wilson con tinued his individual investigations of the prisoners and prepared to release them on their own recog nizance. He has released 267 todate.

President Roosevelt was the guest of honor tonight at the annual dinner of the White House Correspondents Association at the Mayflower Hotel. About 700 members and guests attended the dinner. As entertainment, there appeared several radio stars provided by the Columbia Broadcasting Company and a news-reel satirizing the Roosevelt administration.

Chancery Court officials opened the way today for a test of the validity of a Tennessee constitutional pro vision prohibiting whites and Ne groes from attending school to gether. They set March 22 for a hearing before Chancellor Lois Bejach of a Negro's application for a man damus writ to force his admittance to the University of Tennessee'sCollege of Pharmacy here.

LONDON. AS the coronation approaches the tempo of London fashions is quickening. The salons of many of the great English dress houses are displaying the rich fuchsia-red velvet of the peeresses' robes in large quantities.

A nationally planned, internationally instituted examination into the economic status of the American business girl-butterfly or bread-winner?-will submerge all other interests in the National Federation of Business and Professional Women for the immediate future.

Some 1,200 employes of the WPA Women's and Provisional Division will start courses tomorrow to qual ify as first-aid workers, following more than 2,000 of the Division of Operations who recently com pleted the course and passed the standard American Red Cross test, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell,local WPA Administrator..

The New York Society, Descend ants of the Signers of the Declara tion of Independence, will hold its annual dinner on Saturday at Sherry's. Kenneth Chorley of Colo nial Williamsburg, Inc., will be the speaker. Major Samuel Bryan Scott of Philadelphia and Walter Godley of Wallingford, Pa., respectively first vice president general and secretary general of the national society, and other officers are expected to attend.

A motorist, who was so unnerved at striking and fatally injuring a pedestrian he had to get a cup of coffee to "straighten" himself out, was arrested yesterday morning. He described himself as Charles E. Tucker, 31 years old, of 409 West146th Street.

A higher percentage of resources of building and loan associations are in mortgage loans today than at the present time one year ago, according to balance sheets of sev eral hundred representative asso ciations surveyed by the United States Building and Loan League. It was also shown that the per centage of real estate owned by theassociations has decreased.
IT Is likely that the series of sixteen concerts devoted to Beethoven and Brahms that were undertaken this year by the New Friends of Music will not bethe last.

Flying missiles felled three strikers, one a woman, today, in the first vio lence of a score of unrelated labor disputes that have developed in De troit industrial plants since theGeneral Motors strikes were settled.

MANISTEE, Mich. -Red foxes, whose glowing coats furnished Michigan's finest pelts in the big trapping years, will be protected here if the State Legislature this Winter passes a bill recommended by the Michigan Conservation Deapartment.
United States Senator-elect Wil liam H. Smathers, in a statement today, came out strongly in sup port of President Roosevelt's pro posal to revise the United StatesSupreme Court.

The market for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. turned dull yesterday. Prices moved within a restricted range on a small trading volume, total transactions amount ing to $6,808,200, compared with sales of $9,096,400 on the preceding Saturday.
Mrs. Leslie R. Palmer of 178 East Seventieth Street had returned to her yesterday a platinum wrist watch valued at $2,500, lost four years ago and regarded by her asgone forever.

Proposed State legislation which would permit the formation in New York of privately owned but State regulated mortgage banks is gaining public favor, according to Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman of the Mortgage Commission of the Stateof New York.
News has just reached this port from Japan that four new "super freight ers" are being built for KawasakiRisen Kaisha.

"American students of the theatre body of honest acting technique and must acquire a vast and reliable a traditional standard of excellence in personal performance which will apply to all plays, no matter how good or bad the sets, lighting andother physical aspects may be."

Week-end transactions on the Boerse today were light. Certain heavy indus trials, such as Stahlwerke, which had gone up at a lively rate the last few days, suffered a slight setback. Rheinstahl made a fractional gain, while I. G. Farben lost 1/4 point and Daimler 1. Continental Rubber wasfirm, as also was German Linoleum.
Miss Mary Elizabeth Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Magill Patterson of Wayne, was married this afternoon to John Burnhaus Yerkes, son of Mr. and Mrs. MiltonR. Yerkes of Bryn Mawr.

Prominent men and women are among the subscribers to the program of monologues to be presented by Miss Cornelia Otis Skinner on Tuesday night at the Cosmopolitan Club for the benefit of the Shakespeare Fortnight Hostelry in Stratford-on-Avon, England.

A collection of World War posters, which has never before been shown publicly, will be placed on exhibi tion in the Tapestry Room of the Sherry-Netherland, beginning Fri day, as a benefit for the blind musi cians of the Cape Cod Institute ofMusic.

New York State led the country in January in the amount of malt liquors, mostly beer, produced, with 604,009 barrels, according to the Bureau of Internal Revenue. The country produced 3,657,062 barrels of fermented malt liquors in the month, an increase of 8,382over the previous month.
THE growing enthusiasm for sled-dog driving as an amateur sport in New England is shown in the appearance of half a dozen or more new teams in the racingfield this year.

The yacht Nourmahal, with Vincent Astor, the owner, and guests aboard sailed today for the Galapagos Is lands via Cocos Island on a fishing and collection trip. Mr. Astor said he had arranged for a quick transit through the Panama Canal on his return to save the live fish in special tanks aboard the yacht.
RETIREMENT AGE: "The retire ment age at Yale's earlier than that of the United States Supreme Court. Thereis one comfort which I have been able
A dinner dance and moving picture entertainment given by the Winter sports committee of the Greenwich Country Club tonight was attendedby 250 members and guests.

All air lines in the United States have been directed to put radio direction finders on all planes used in inter state commerce, the Bureau of Air Commerce announced today. In ad dition to the "homing device." as it is sometimes called, airline op erators have been ordered to equip all planes with an "approved radio antenna system," shielded against static, caused by rain, fog, snowand dust.

The improvements made in hardy perennials during the last few years rave been so marked that many gardeners are seeking out and planting the newer things, even though this may necessitate elimi nating some of the outmoded formsfrom beds and borders.
A measure of immortality, for what it is worth, was offered today to the man, woman or child who can invent an acceptable simple American word for "hors d'oeuvres."
The flying fingers of Reuel Small, which have recorded countless words of Congressional debate,were still today.

Alarmed by threatened mass vi olence over the Veracruz church State issue, government officials to day clamped a censorship on news from the district. Catholics, who recently reopened their churches forcibly in "peaceful rebellion" against anti-church laws, openly armed themselves against any attempt by the anti-religious Confederation of Workers of Mex ico [C. T. M.] to stage a demonstration tomorrow.

Walter Simmons, 41, asked for his release from the Woodbourne prison today on the ground that he is obliged to work without pay. Simmons applied to Justice Sydney F. Foster of the SupremeCourt for a writ of habeas corpus.

Louis Green, 85 years old, a re tired real estate broker, of 65 West Ninety-fifth Street was injured yes terday morning when he walked in front of a truck in Columbus Ave nue, near Ninety-fifth Street, and died at 12:30 P. M. in Reconstruction Hospital.

Miss Lillian D. Wald, leader in social work, will receive the city's certificate for distinguished and exceptional public service on March 10, her seventieth birthday, Mayor La Guardia announced Yesterday. The certificate will be awarded either at ceremonies in Miss Wald's honor which are to be held March 10 at the headquarters of the Visiting Nurses Service, 99 Park Avenue, or at Miss Wald's home in Westport, Conn.

In celebration of its ten years of service to the city of Honolulu the Honolulu Academy of Arts has purchased from the Dalzell Hatfield Galleries and the Lilienfeld Gal leries of New York a painting, "Girl With Doll," by one of the founders of the modern movement in art, Paul Cezanne. It was on April 8, 1927, that the academy first opened its doors and invited the community to enjoy its collectionsand activities.

PLAYING "Hamlet" anywhere eight times a week is a pretty arduous business In a strange country one has the additional responsibility that in every audience there are many hun dreds of people who may have heard one's name, and perhaps enough of one's work to make them curious to see it, and who will be judging one severely against the future on the single performancewhich they happen to attend.

A series of fortnightly discussions on political and social issues, remi niscent of the New England Town Meeting, will be started on March 15 at Teachers College by the Stu dent Council. The symposiums will continue for the rest of the Springsemester.

The Italian liner Rex sailed at noon yesterday for Mediterranean ports with a large passenger list. She was the last Italian vessel to leave from Pier 59, North River, at the foot of West Eighteenth Street, which is leased by the International Mercantile MarineCompany from the city.
A formal grand march, led by Colonel Bernard W. Kearney, na tional commander-in-chief of. the Veterans of Foreign Wars, and Mrs. Gladys Mooney of Detroit, national president of the V. F. W.

THE still hush which has shrouded Billy Rose, sometime rhymester, windmill tilter and lightning defier, the past three months was shattered last week with the deafening announcement that the pocket Barnum had lashed himself to an outboard motor and was about to taketo the rolling deep.

Beatrice G. Rosahn and Abraham Goldfeld are the authors of a com prehensive book entitled Housing Management, published last week by Covici-Friede. Mrs. Rosahn is secretary of the American Society of Women Housing Managers and Mr. Goldfeld is manager of the Lavanburg Homes, on the lowerEast Side.
Members of the Greater New York and Long Island Chapter of the Alumnae Association of the College of New Rochelle have arranged their annual bridge party and teafor next Saturday afternoon
Hackley School captured the Tri angular League basketball crown yesterday by subduing Riverdale,38-23, at the Riverdale court.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Patty Mac Robert, daughter of Mrs. Mona G. MacRobert of Larchmont, N. Y., and Dr. Russell G. MacRobert of 3 East Seventy-sixth Street, New York, to M. Clay Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Clay Adams, alsoof Larchmont.
Three weeks of argument pro and con over the President's proposals for the reorganization of the Fed eral judiciary have brought the opposing viewpoints into sharp relief.

THE casual ecole de Paris manner which characterized canvases by Biala in her first American show, two or three years ago, has almost completely disappeared, if her present exhibition of paintings and drawings at Georgette Passedoit's Gallery maybe taken as evidence.

Discussing the expectant benefits of the new city law exempting from taxes the value of alterations and improvements on old buildings made before Oct. 1 of this year, Benjamin Driesler Jr., Brooklyn architect, points out that in many cases renovation and modernization of older properties will be a sound er real estate policy than demolition and new construction.

Manhattan and Brooklyn are ex periencing a scarcity of desirable industrial space, especially with re spect to large units and ground floor locations with railroad sidings and adequate freight facilities, ac cording to I. Jerome Riker, headof the realty firm of Riker Co.
Mrs. Thomas F. Casey, chairman of the board of directors of the Im maculate Conception Day Nursery, will give a tea at her home, 157 Sul livan Place, Brooklyn, next Sunday,

IN a recent edition The Burlington Free Press commented editorially at some length on the work that is being done by the WPA in Vermont under the State directorship of Pierre Zwick. "Those who attended the exhibition at the Fleming Museum last year of the work done by Vermonters employed in the Federal Art Project got a new conception

Louis Ginsberg, 26 years old, of 1,067 Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, who was accused by his estranged wife, Fay, of having gone to France with the intention of joining the Spanish Loyalists, was returned here yesterday from Havre, France, on board the liner President Harding and locked up in Raymond Street jail on a charge of abandonment.

Louisville's direct flood death toll was fixed today at the "almost un believable" total of 90 by Dr. Hugh R. Leavell, Director of Health. He listed the fatalities as follows: drowning, 6; exposure, 10; burned or killed in explosions, 15; asphyxi ation, 2; pneumonia, 28; heart disease, 28, and bacillary disease, 1.

EVER since the S. S. Titanic plunged to eternity in 1912, and Operator Harold Cottam of the rescue ship Carpathia picked up the S O S by a lucky twist of fate, radio engineers have sought to de sign an automatic distress alarm that would screech for help withoutthe necessity of an operator.

ROBED in black, seated behind a long, black walnut desk--"bench" to us--the "nine old men" who constitute the Supreme Court of the United States hand down decisions momentous in the evolution of the nation. The President would force out Butler(70). Sutherland (74), Hughes (74).

Van Henry Plass, aged 26, was arraigned in City Court today on an abduction charge as the aftermath of a double wedding ceremony involving two brides in their 'teens. Judge Corbally granted a plea for time to engage counsel and remanded Plass to jail in lieu of bail untilMonday.

OSLO'S short-wave station on 9.53 inegacycles is seldom heard clearly in America be cause this station operates at nearly the same hours and on approximately the same wave as W2XAF, Schenectady. On a recent morning, however, Norway's signal, coming down over the Hebrides
A 50 per cent increase in unit sales of electric ranges this year, compared with 1936, was forecast here yesterday by electrical manufacturers specializing in such equipment.

Presi dent Roosevelt's wish to see estab lished "meeting places for the dis cussion of public questions, in the cities, hamlets and on the farms throughout the length and breadth of the land," expressed at the time of founding of the Washington Town Hall in 1934 and reiterated in substance in his recent message to the annual convention of the De partment of Superintendence of the National Education Association, seems well on the way towardrealization.

The six-day bicycle race makes another visit to Madison Square Garden, starting tonight. For a full week the Eighth Avenue arena will resound to the cheers of the cycling fan as the leading riders of many nations compete in the grind that will go on without any scheduled interruption until 11o'clock on Saturday night.

IT was in 1926 that Esther Forbes published her first novel. "O Genteel Lady!" It was an exquisite book--one whose memory still lingers after a decade-and it has had two suc cessors nearly as good, "A Mir ror for Witches" and "Miss Mar vel." All three of these stories.however, were on a minor scale;

A vigorous campaign directed at enlisting the farmers of the country in support of President Roosevelt's program to reform the judiciary was understood to be in preparation in administration circles today.

Mr. and Mrs. Leon.Grant Godley of 45 Gramercy Park North, this city, and Out of Bounds, Skytop, Pa., have announced from Winter Park, Fla., the marriage of their daughter, Miss Barbara Godley, to A. Dean Swift Jr.,

THE drink which Dr. Johnson prescribed for heroes--it is known as cognac in French-will celebrate the 300th anniversary of its birth this year, probably in June, in the quaint, partly medieval French city bearingthe same name.
Some important dividend meet ings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distribu tions ordered by the directorsfollow:

A sum estimated at $665,000,000 should be spent every year for the next thirty years by the farmers in the United States for the repair, replacement and modernization of their homes and farm buildings, declares William C. Bober, head of the statistical department of theJohns-Manville Company.

The annual supper dance under the auspices of the Almoners for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital will be held on April 23 at Sherry's. A tea will be given on Tuesday by Mrs. Vincent O'Shea at her home, 145 West Eighty-eighth Street, for membersof the committee.
The Harvard Observatory re ported tonight that it had located and photographed a new comet dis covered earlier today by a mannamed Wilks at Cracow, Poland.

The proposed Westchester County Charter filed last week is the only new charter being recommended currently by a responsible group. Voters will doubtless have no other charter submitted to them in the near future.

Murder in labor ranks figured on two metropolitan fronts last week. (1) New Jersey and New York police tried to find in labor feuds explanation for the shooting of Norman Redwood, business manager of Local 102 of the Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America, in thedriveway of his Teaneck, N. J., home.

The prevailing basis employed by individuals of making income tax returns is that of cash receipts and disbursements. This basis differs from the "accrual" method mainly in that income has been actually brought to possession by the re ceipt of cash or its equivalent, and that deductions from income have been actually disbursed, all withinthe taxable year.

Mrs. Benjamin R. Schenck of 155 East Ninety-first Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lella Marion Schenck, to Stuart T. Parson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart H. Parson of Bronxville, N. Y.

Defending the Securities and Ex change Commission against its critics, James M. Landis, the chair man, told members of the Swarth more Club of Philadelphia tonight that an "inadequate" judiciary wasresponsible for its creation.

The Sheriff's office reopened the case tonight after a coroner's jury had reported it was unable to de termine the circumstances under which the screen writer, Humphrey Pearson, was shot to death in his Palm Springs home Wednesdaynight.

Opened by a meeting with Dartmouth, the debate season at Skidmore is definitely under way, to culminate in a tour by the varsity team, one of the features which makes debating a popular extracurricular activity at Skidmore.
The Andover track team, running true to pre-meet predictions, won the fourth annual indoor meet from Exeter by 51 to 30 today and ended a perfect season. Three new meetrecords were set.

Engagement of $6,207,000 gold abroad for shipment here, including $6,085,000 in England and $122,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank announced that $2,396,900 gold had been received from England yesterday and that $697,600, also from England, hadcome in late on Friday.

The annual supper dance of the Junior American Ort, an auxiliary of the American Ort Federation, will be held next Saturday at the Savoy-Plaza. Dr. Harold H. Keyserving is chairman of the entertainment, which will aid the economic rehabilitation and training of the Jews of Eastern and Central Europe.

The Dartmouth basketball team remained in a tie for second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race by holding off a gallant second-half rally by Princeton to triumph, 35-34, tonight. Trailing, 22-14, at the half, the Tigers came back in the second period to take a 34-33 lead near the close.

A curious side-discovery about carrier pigeons which, it is claimed, will be important in time of war, has just been reported by a professor of physiology, N. A. Rojansky, and his colleague, Dr. Orloff.

The Misses Nancy and Anita Easley are among the young wo men headed by Miss Katherine V. Marsters who will sell flowers and cigarettes at the performance of "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse" on Thursday night at the Hudson Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the New York City Visiting Committee of theState Charities Aid Association.

The increase of 16 2-3 per cent in the legal reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Re serve System, which will become effective tomorrow, is expected by bankers to be received without a "ripple" of disturbance in themoney market.

A renaissance has occurred in the musical activities of colleges and universities in this country, accord ing to Dr. J. Lawrence Erb, Profes sor of Music at Connecticut College, who says that the old "Bull Dog on the Bank" type of song no longer characterizes the college glee club, nor do the music departments of the institutions of higher learning concentrate their attention upon the development of music curricula whose end and aim is primarilyprofessional.

Thirty four colleges and universities, rep resenting thirty-six nations, have accepted the invitation of Cornell University to attend the annual as sembly of the Model League of Nations to be held here April 22-24.

SYDNEY, Australia.-Train-raid ing in force is taking place in vari ous Australian States and police are troubled to devise a plan to check a racket which threatens to become expensive for the State-owned railroads.

A change is taking place in the shoe industry which is of first im portance to the woman whose feet are not slender, shapely and strong, whose arches need support, and whose difficulties make it neces sary.- for her to wear shoes builtfirst and foremost for comfort.

Urging passage by the Legislature of a bill to provide State aid for kindergartens, the New York League of Women Voters cites fig ures of the State Education De partment on the cost of keeping children in the first grade of schools which do not have kindergartens.

More than 100 girls, most of them 18 to 20 years old, started the first "five and ten" sit-down strike here today, had luncheon "the the. house" and considered their demands. One Is a demand for a general pay in crease of 10 cents an hour. There were defections, however, in the ranks of the strikers. Some of them refused to forego meeting "boy friends" and deserted theirposts with the connivance of stock

Members of the Junior Board of Madison House and of the Younger People's Committee are taking an active interest in the sale of tickets for the annual Madison House Ball, to be held March 20 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Already an encouraging subscription has beenreported.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marjorie Anne Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Allen of this place, to Frederick Gordon Stevens, son of Mrs. Albert Clark Stevens of Hackensack, formerly of EastOrange, and the late Mr. Stevens.

The fate of Seattle's Municipal Street Railway, laboring under a debt of $10,073,000 and running behind more than $600,000 a year, will be decided at the polls Tuesday, March 9, when the voters pass upon a refinancing and modernizing program sub mitted by a group of New York financiers and transportation experts.
IT all begins when Robin Bishop finds a coat lying on the beach with a suicide notepinned to it.

THE airplane in the British Empire, as everywhere else in the world, is steadily speeding up mail deliveries. From Australia, Southern Rhodesia and Egypt, for example, an ordinary postal card sent by air will travel a thousand miles daily, reaching London in twelve, eight and twodays, respectively.
To meet what are considered the needs of the Jewish people, a community program on "Marriage and the Home" will be established in this city and- also in other largecenters of Jewish population.

Having surmounted the handi caps of floods, strikes and unsatis factory weather conditions, retail trade is confidently entering the last month of the first quarter with the expectation that the gain in dollar sales for the three months will average close to 15 per centover last year.
THE third volume of this "History of Jewish Liter ature From the Close of the Bible to Our Own Days" covers the period from the middle of the seventeenth centuryto the year 1880.

After one of the hardest-fought matches in the history of the event, the United States women's squash racquets team yesterday triumphed over their British rivals in the an nual matches played at the Junior League Club. The final count was3 to 2.

Complete plans for construction of the Battery-Hamilton Avenue ve hicular tunnel, to link lower Man hattan and Brooklyn, were received yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and copies were transmitted immediate ly to the members of the Board ofEstimate for study.

Frequently educational leaders have urged formation of a strong organization of teachers to speak in the name of the teaching profes sion. Professor Jesse H. Newlon of Teachers College, at the Depart ment of Superintendence meeting in New Orleans several days ago, stressed the importance of suchunited action.

Four unmasked men held up the West Side branch of the Lorain Street National Bank today and escaped with $20,000. Joseph Varga, a motorist, told po lice that two of the robbers com mandeered his automobile a few minutes before the robbery, forced him to pick up two companions,then drive them to the bank.

Kept in the field for two days while Australia com piled a huge first-inning total of 593 runs for nine wickets, England faces an almost insurmountable task in the fifth and rubber match of the current cricket test series. Led by Don Bradman, their cap tain, the Australians wielded mighty bats against all the English bowlershad to offer.

Hilaire Belloc, visiting Professor of History, and the Rev. Jaime Cas tiello, Professor of Psychology in the Fordham University Graduate School, will speak at a symposium on the Spanish crisis, to be held on March 19 in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Fordham Uni-versity Alumnae Association.
Striking geisha girls, to whom a sit-down strike is not new, settled down to an almost military regimen todayin a mountain top temple.

The marriage of Miss Rhoda Hermine Wuensch, daughter of Mrs. Everett Raymond of Palmer Hill, to Robert E. Phillip, son of Mrs. Walter Blauvelt and the late James Phillip, will take place on April 10 in the First Presbyterian Church, Stamford.

Before a capacity crowd of 10,000. Torcheen, 4-year-old chestnut geld ing, scored a surprise victory in the $1,000 Au Revoir Handicap at Alamo Downs today, beating Dreel by a neck over the six-and-a-half furlong route. Amazing was third. The winner, ridden by Melvin Calvert, covered the distance in1:18 3-5.
A foul shot by Pat Gleason in the final minutes of play enabled the St. Francis College basketball team to defeat Cortland State Teachers College, 39--38, on the victor's courtlast night.

According to reports reaching here from Saarbruecken, Saar Pfalz, less than ten miles away, there have been demonstrations in Frankenholz against the substitu tion of portraits of Chancellor Hitler for the crucifix in a placeof honor in local school rooms.
Baby Eugenio Peyrera Iraola was found dead today, five years almost to the day after Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was kidnapped fromNew Jersey's Sourland hills.

AS a step toward applying the new theory of all-weather flying, Jack Frye, president of the Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., last week an nounced the purchase of six Boeing monoplanes to carry thirty-two pas sengers each and equipped to fly atmean altitudes up to 35,000 feet.

A TRIP through an automobile factory presents a faacinating sight. In long, low buildings which sprawl over acres like the Midwestern cities they dominate, huge quantities of raw materials are fed into the jaws of a me chanical monster, and by the magical metamorphosis of modern technology transformed into thousands of shiny newcars every day and night.

First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler listed yesterday thir ty-two additional intersections at which stanchions would be placed indicating that turns might be made on red lights, contrary to the general provision of the new trafficcode.

The after noon party to be held by the King and Queen at Buckingham Palace will take place on March 16 instead of on March 24, as originally planned. Their residence at the palace is undergoing many alterations, and it was not until this week

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, announced yesterday that three women stu dents in the College of Medicine had been elected to class offices for the current semester. There are forty-four women students registered in the college.

With the bench-show dogs start ing the long Midwestern circuit this week, bird-dog folk along the Atlantic seaboard are preparing their charges for the opening of the Spring field-trial season, which is just around the corner. Moremeetings have been arranged

SHE was the youngest girl in a large family of brothers and sisters, whose home was at Chadwick Manor, on the edge of the Lickey Hills--an old house then in the depths of the country and since then presented. I believe, by Mr.Cadbury to the city of Birmingham.
Charles Rubien, brother of Fred erick W. Rubien, secretary of the American Olympic Committee, died last night in the Polyclinic Hospital. He was 71 years old.

American history, and particular ly the history of New York City, will be dramatized by the New York Historical Society through unusual ly comprehensive exhibits of its treasures when the additions to the society's building at 170 CentralPark West are completed next year.

Captain Thomas F. Gates, who retired three years ago after fifty eight years' sea service, forty-five of them in command, arrived yes terday on the President Harding of the United States Lines to spend i two weeks here visiting friends. Hewas 75 years old in January.

Extra postage charges for air mail have been abolished by the French Minister of Posts and Tel egraphs in the belief that mail service by air is a normal twen tieth-century service, "just as it was normal for the train mail service to replace the old mailcoaches."

The application for a certificate of reasonable doubt by A. Henry Ross, the Brooklyn attorney who was sentenced to three to eight years in State prison for trying to extort money from Alfred E. Smith Jr., was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy. If the certificate had been granted it might have released him under bail pending the outcome of his appeal. Justice Levy, in dismissing the application, said:

The engagement of Miss Florence Touro, daughter of Mrs. Harris C. Touro of this city, formerly of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Mr. Touro, to R. Robert Eisner, son of Barnett Eisner of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Eisner, has been announced by her mother.
The Very Rev. Thomas F. Conlon, national director of the Holy Name Societies, has been honored by Pope Pius XI, who conferred upon him the cross Pro Ecclesia etPontifice.

For the tenth successive year, Mrs. Samuel Spiegel of New York will preside at the annual convention of the Women's League of the United Synagogues of America, opening today at the Hotel Schenley, Pittsburgh, where delegates from 288 sisterhoods are gatheredfor a three-day session.

There can be no real solution of the special problems which face Negroes in industry and labor with out a solution of the problem for the entire population, Eugene Kinckle Jones, executive secretary of the National Urban League, told 100 social workers and educators yesterday at a luncheon meeting which concluded a two-day confer ence called by the New York UrbanLeague, 204 West 136th Street.

The School of Medicine, founded a cen tury ago and forerunner of the University of Louisville of today, will be the starting point of the university's centennial observance, according to plans being prepared by the executive committee, headed by Yancy Altsheler, chairman, and Dr. Raymond A. Kent, president ofthe university.
The hard-punching fighters of the University of Maryland tonight won the Southern Conference box ing championship, outscoring DukeUniversity, 19 to 16.

A NEW type of roadside sign is appearing on the Florida land-scape, particularly in the citrus belt. "All the Orange Juice You Can Drink for 10 Cents," "Taste the Rare Tropical Fruits," "Camp Here and Pick Your OwnFruit." So run the invitations.

After devel opments this week on Capitol Hill, which have attracted nation-wide attention to the battle in this State over ratification of the Fed eral Child Labor Amendment, con tention has shifted for the nonce from the legislative forum to a realm where the eyes of the un initiated do not generally penetrate.

THE dominant feature of these verses by Virginia Moore is their note of high seriousness. This is not to say that the poems which go to make up the contents of "Homer's Golden Chain" are didactic, or even moralistic. Nevertheless, each piece is purposeful; Miss Moore has no wish to reform the world: but she seems profoundly desirous of aiding it spirituallyand intellectually.
Rosita Moreno, film actress, received a cablegram today signed "Rosita" in answer to one she sent when her friend, Rosita Diaz, was reported to have been shot as a spyby Spanish Rebel troops.

Fingerprints of a man who said he was Carl Longo, arrested in Mansfield, Ohio, on a charge of illegal possession of liquor, tallied with those of Anthony Calabrese, 31 years old, wanted since 1931 in Westchester County for first-degree murder, Walter A. Ferris, 'DistrictAttorney, said today.
