Sit-in" workers who com pleted their second all-night vigil to prevent possible attempts by other workers to stage a sit-down strike in the Eagle-Ottawa Leather Com pany plant here, resumed work to day and prepared to continue theiroccupancy over the week-end.
Major Gen. Charles R. Reynolds, Surgeon General of the Army, and Mrs. Reynolds have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Hebe Louise Reynolds, to Marshall Beverly.

Eight of ten women summoned to receive the honors of the Women's National Press Club for achieve ment during 1936 are New Yorkers. They are among those leaving to day for Washington to attend the annual stunt party of the news paper women of the capital at theWillard Hotel tomorrow night.
Judge
Fifty American students who visit the Paris exhibi tion this year will find at their disposal 1,000 francs each to permit them to extend their visit to Alsaceand Lorraine.
ONE approaches this novel by Compton Mackenzie with something like awe, ff only for the size of the task it initiates. This book which is itself half the size of"Gone With the Wind"

Depart mental clubs at Brown University this year are proving to be excep tionally valuable in bringing aca demic and social life closer together. At the same time they are serving as definite aids in the university's educational and extra-curricularprograms, faculty advisers of the clubs reported today.

WASHINGTON. THE latest phase of the Ameri can Red Cross's national pro gram to help victims of motor accidents is the inauguration of a fleet cordon of mobile units to pa trol the country's arterial high ways. In various States fifteen State highway and public utility trucking groups already are coop rating with the local Red Crosschapters.

Although its three performances are set some weeks ahead, the an nual International Skating Carnival to be held on March 27, 29 and 31 at Madison Square Garden has re ceived a large advance subscription from many persons of prominence who comprise a large committee ofpatrons and patronesses.

ELABORATE programs have been arranged for the 1937 May festival of the University of Michigan, to be held at Ann Arbor, Mich., May 12-15, which will celebrate the centennial of thefounding of that institution.

One of the most important devel opment deals closed for some time in the Scarsdale section of West chester County has just been made by the Long Island developers, Levitt Sons. The tract, which they have purchased from the own ers of the well known Fox Meadows development in Scarsdale, has. a frontage of about 1,000 feet on theBronx River Parkway.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and Fannie Hurst, novelist, will speak on the menace of Nazism to democracy at the fourth annual luncheon of the women's division of the American Jewish Congress, to be held Wednesday at the HotelAstor. Proceeds of the afternoon.

The gyropilot, the "automatic human," which flies big airplanes while the pilot devotes his time to observation, navigation, radio and instrument control, has reached its peak of efficiency in the 1937 type just installed in United Air Lines' new fleet of transports, companyofficials said yesterday.
Union College observed its 142d birthday anniversary today with full aca demic ceremony in celebrating its first Founders' Day convocation inthe Memorial Chapel.
GUATEMALA is not a little Mexico. It is not at all like Mexico. It is not just another picturesque Latin American country for tourists totravel to. It is not just another

LONDON'S rejection of Mme. Leontovich's Cleopatra and Fraeulein Bergner's Boy Da vid was so decisive that Miss Ann Harding may, perhaps, have felt that her accent would imperil her representation of Mr. Shaw's Candida. If she had any such mis giving, they were unfounded. Mme. Leontovich was rejected, not because she was foreign, but be cause she brought the verse of a great classical part to incomprehensible ruin.

Captain Richard L. Reiss, a member of the London County Council's Housing Commission, who has been in this country since Jan. 20 lectur ing under the auspices of the National Housing Conference, said in an interview yesterday that he had found housing conditions in the United States "definitely worse"than he had expected.

Professor Irving Fisher of Yale Un iversity, finance and economics au thority, said today, in queitly cele brating his seventieth birthday at his Prospect Hill home, that he was fitter in every way to continue his active work than when he was graduated from Yale, forty-nineyears ago.

The continued popularity of the chapel choir and other musical organiza tions at St. Lawrence University warrants the expectation that music will enter into most phases of university and extra-curricular campus life, according to H. Well ington Stewart, chapel organist and director of the university'sMusic Department.

The en gagement of Miss Gabriella Kirk Leavitt, daughter of Rufus E. Leavitt of this place, formerly of Short Hills, and the late Mrs. Gabriella Martin Leavitt, to Walter Stokes Libby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Libby, also of Summit, will be announced at a party to be given at the Leavitt home tomorrow afternoon.

A "re-evaluation" of the prob lem of leisure time will be at tempted in a series of eight semi nars on "Recreation and Adult Education," beginning tomorrow at Teachers College, Columbia University. Dr. Wilbur C. Hal lenbeck, Assistant Professor of Education, is in charge of thediscussion series.
Governor Leh man announced today the appoint ment of William J. Sheils of New Rochelle as surrogate of West chester County to fill the vacancy caused by the death of SurrogateGeorge A. Slater.

Collector of the Port Harry M. During and other customs offi cials of Washington and New York bade farewell yesterday to Henry C. Stuart, assistant collector of the port, who retired at the end of the week after forty-six years of serv ice. Shortly before noon a large oil portrait of Mr. Stuart was unveiled in the collector's office and was ac cepted by Commissioner of Customs James H. Moyle in behalf of theservice.

With the filing of plans last week for sixty-five apartment houses each to be six stories in height, at Forest Hills, L. I., a striking ob ject lesson was presented of the influence upon new building opera tions of the extension of the munic ipal subway recently opened toForest Hills and Kew Gardens.

While the nation debated and dis cussed President Roosevelt's controver sial Supreme Court proposal last week, labor relations loomed as a more imme diate issue for the country to solve. Sit-down strikes, spurred by the recent one in General Motors, closed industries in many centers.

A Yorkville transaction was announced yesterday by Frederick Zittell Sons, brokers, who sold for the 62 East Eighty-seventh Street Corporation to an investor the five-story apartment house at that address. The building occupies a lot 25.6 by 100.8 feet and contains ten suites.

WASHINGTON. ANDREW MELLON'S gift to the Federal Government of his collection of paintings, together with a building he will erect to house them, means that Washington will soon be able to boast of a gallery which in the quality of the pictures will rank in importance with the Louvre in Paris. the Uffizi Gallery in Florence, the Prado in Madridand the National Gallery in London.

A Supreme Court decision today took from the Eagle Oil Company, a sub sidiary of Royal Dutch Shell, two of its largest fields and ordered them back into the national re serves. The, court held defective the com pany's title to its 3,875-acre La Con cepcion field and its 2,163-acre San Antonio Coauchapa field near Minatitlan, State of Veracruz.
Valencia, like Madrid, began to guard her food supplies today. The municipal council fixed dailyquotas for bread.

While political ly important, yesterday's debate in the Chamber of Deputies, when Premier Leon Blum held his Left Popular Front together against a combined Center and Right attack, was utterly devoid of any constructive quality.

Al though a contradictory New Eng land Winter has deprived Wheaton students of their usual snow sports, the mild months have increased their enjoyment of the new arbore tum, the latest addition to thecampus.

Pedro Montanez's next opponent in a bout here will be Jimmy McLarnin, Coast welterweight, if plans outlined yesterday by James J. Johnston, boxing director at Madison Square Garden, ma terialize. A counter-proposal which developed yesterday is a possible meeting between the Puerto Rican and Barney Ross, world welterweight champion.
The 12 to 14 per cent price rise which two New York clothing chains will put into effect tomorrow will be watched with considerable interest by both manufacturers and other retailers here.

Chinese and Indian universities are making increasing use of mod ern chemical technics to raise the standard of living in the Far.East, Dr. Joseph B. Niederl, Professor of Chemistry at New York Univer sity's Washington Square College, said yesterday following his returnfrom a world tour.
George C. Gunn, former owner and editor of The Burling ton Daily Enterprise, died of cor onary thrombosis at his home here yesterday at the age of 69 after ashort illness.

TO the seasonal valedictories, add that of Alex Yokel. He still has his offices, still has a schedule (not so big as it was, though), but of Broadway plans he has none- for the current semester. "Tom Cat" remains to be written. as play by John Tain tor Foote, author of the short storyof that name.

Instead of the usual admission fee, guests have been requested to bring packages of useful articles suitable for resale to the card party and tea for the Kips Bay Boys Club on Tuesday at the headquar ters of the organization, 301 EastFifty-second Street.

All WPA arts projects in New York City will be administered from Washington beginning Monday, Ad ministrator Harry L. Hopkins an nounced today. The order regularizes a de facto condition, it was explained by a WPA official, and makes virtually no material change in the NewYork set-up.
Mohandas K. Gandhi literally walked back onto India's political stage today in what was considered a crucial moment in the nation'srelations with Great Britain.

On Friday, Feb. 19, Norman Redwood, labor union leader, was killed in cold blood as he drove into the driveway of his residence in Teaneck, N. J. An investiga tion of one week discloses-the following facts:

Announcement has been made by Mrs. William van Doorn Jr. of Upper Montclair of the engagement of her sister, Miss Blanche Morrison Opp, to Daniel L. J. de Viaming of Amsterdam,the-Netherlands, and New York.

A well-earned victory by D. E. Jackson Jr. of the Harvard -Club over the second seeded player, B. B. Adams of the University Club, featured the quarter-finals yester day in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B singles championship tourney atthe Harvard Club.
Wives in Alabama who may have punched their husbands' noses with impunity in the past may find divorce suits on their hands in thefuture.

The opening on Tuesday of a re tail store at 35 West Eighth Street by the Richard W. Kaase Company of New York, manufacturers of bakery products and candies, will mark the entry of an old Clevelandconcern into the New York field.

Away to a substantial early lead and playing well together all the way, the first division riders closed their regular Metropolitan Indoor Polo League schedule with a 13-to-4 victory over the 112th Field Artil lery at Squadron C armory in Brooklyn last night.

Unable to for get the victories of the American Negroes in last year's Olympics, the Hitler Elite Guard has launched another attack on Harlem and United States Negroes generally. The Black Corps, the guard's offi cial organ, carries a display of Harlem night club photographs, notably those of the so-called Lindy Hop.

FOR the first time since the cinema assumed its present stature, an important picture is being made with the advance knowledge that it will be banned in virtually all foreign countries with the exception of the British Empire.

CONVERTED by means or records, of which he had every complete set available, a devotee of opera who lives some 200 miles from the Metropolitan journeyed to New York for hisfirst taste of the real thing.

Preliminary estimates indicate that the Class I railroads of this country had an aggregate net oper ating income of about $38,000,000 in January, against $35,764,000 in January, 1936, and that gross revenues were about $333,000,000,against $299,098,000.

The same old center of Madrid was shelled this afternoon for the first time since Jan., 25. It was not a very heavy shelling--eight shells, of which only three did any particular dam age-but, like the night aerial bombardment of Feb. 17, it signal izes the end of any illusions about Madrid's being spared the continu ance of whatever horrors can beheaped upon it.
Harold J. Mahon, president of the First National Bank for the last fourteen years, died of a heart attack at hishome here today.
The Insurgent government an nounced today a ban on all films written, acted or. directed by a proscribed list of Hollywoodcelebrities.

The Young Republican Club of Canarsie made public yesterday copies of a resolution urging ratification of the proposed Federal child labor amendment, which it had sent to legislative and party leaders inthe State.

The Gamma Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa at City College has elected sixteen new members to its rolls. Students elected from the class of February, '37, are: Meyer Barash, Victor Brudney, Lawrence Cran berg, Nathan Katz, George Lavosand Joseph Pechman.
Savage scored its tenth victory in thirteen starts this season by halt ing the St. Peter's College quintet 36-27, at the Savage court yester day. The victors led by 25-21 atthe intermission.
Three hundred fifty missing poison tipped Indian arrowheads for which police of Colon have been search ing frantically for two days were in safe custody again tonight andthe city breathed easier.

Marking an innovation at Bryn Mawr College, a course in play pro duction is being introduced this semester, correlating student ac tivities and academic work. It is actually an extracurricular course sponsored by the college "to co operate with both extracurricular dramatic groups on the campus and the regularly accredited courses in playwriting and drama."
THIS would have been a dull and cheerless week on Broadway except for Alfred Hitchcock of London and Charles C. Moskowitz of Loew's.

Dart mouth topped Princeton, 7--6, in a sensational hockey game in the Baker Rink tonight as 2,000 looked on. The result was in doubt until the final period, which saw the most hectic hockey of the evening. In the final three minutes Dartmouth scored three times and Princetononce.

In a move to transplant across the At lantic the current British enthu siasm for the new poetic dramas of T. S. Eliot, Archibald MacLeish and their modern school, Harvard stu dents, with the backing of some of the best-known figures in the uni versity's English Department, have started this country's first "little theatre" group devoted exclusively to producing the modern verseplays.

Before the year is out, the Na tional Youth Administration hopes to have fifty educational camps for unemployed young women, capable of accommodating 15,000 girls on a revolving plan. Eighteen such camps are already open in fifteen States. But their purpose and the work that goes on in them should not be confused with that of the men's camps of the Civilian Con servation Corps, according to Miss Dorothea de Schweinitz, their director.
VINCENT returns in endless repercussion. Both the WPA exhibition and the concurrent affair at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee sponsor their souvenirs.

Competition in the P. S. A. L. round-robin fencing tournament was resumed yesterday after a lapse of a year, with fourteen of the fifteen schools entered seeing action at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium in sevenmatches.

ARATHER uneven month has closed in retail trade, but in the aggregate merchants believed that the January gain over last year had been main tained with perhaps a slightly higher margin on the up side. Weather conditions, floods and strikes hampered sales, and yet volume held its increase.

Because considerable uncertainty has developed among New York Stock Exchange houses regarding the interpretation of the rule con trolling "free riding" that will take effect tomorrow, the committee on business conduct has handed down an interpretation, with instructions for reporting operations in marginaccounts.

Miss Cecile Marie Deurer, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey T Deurer of Maplewood, will be mar ried to Edward John Iverson, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. N. Iverson of Irvington, on April 15 in the First Methodist Protestant Church, Clin ton Avenue, Newark. The pastor, the Rev. John N. Link, will offi ciate. A reception will follow atthe Deurer home.
THE Ninth Infantry, United States Army, is wondering what to do about fifty-seven silver cups which go with its regimented trophy, the twentygallon Liscum punch bowl.

Rollo Ogden died last week. Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES since 1922, and, for twenty-nine years earlier, edi tor of The New York Evening Post, he carried forward the tradition of great newspaper writing from the days of Bryant, Greeley, Raymond, Godkin and Miller into the present. Until a week before his death at 81, his voice stillguided THE TIMES editorial page;

The two year controversy between Governor George H. Earle and the University of Pittsburgh over the trustee-elec tion method of the institution has ended in a compromise. The uni versity is now assured continuance of its biennial State appropriationof $1,118,000.

A hundred couples attended the sophomore dance of Barnard Col lege which was held at the Casa Italiana in Columbia University last evening. Miss Helen Costello was chairman. Her assistants included the Misses Elizabeth Otis, refresh ments; Jane Bell and Ruth Cum mings, floor committee; Jean Alli son, programs, and Jean Morris,advertising.

With a warning that "the nation that de stroys its soil destroys itself," President Roosevelt today sent to the Governors of all States a model law .which would vest broad pow ers in proposed local agencies to compel farmers to abide by ap proved farming methods and im pose fines for violations of prescribed rules.

DISCOVERY of the earliest known original representation of a map of the world In the Plimpton Library at Columbia Uni versity directs attention to the romantic growth of cartography and to the picturesque handiwork of the early mapmakers, now eagerly sought by collectors.

It was announced at a joint meeting of the Rhine-Danube Association and the Bavarian Planning Commission here today that Rhine steamers would be able to reach Nuremberg in 1943. Governor Franz von Epp of Ba varia attended the meeting, as did a representative of theAustrian Government.
The students' concert given last night at Carnegie Hall by the Phil harmonic-Symphony Orchestra, un der the direction of Artur Rodzin ski, attracted a large and enthusiastic assemblage.

WHEN an actor is announced as giving his first performance in New York, even the most indulgent are somewhat inclined to expect a gifted amateur showing a kind of promise but not really skilled enough for the stern standards of Broadway. New Yorkers, in their cheerful insularity,

As always hap pens when, under political pressure, many innovations have been im posed on a country, France is suf fering from what can perhaps be best described as economic growing pains. Last Summer's social legis lation has disturbed the balance ofthe whole system.

COLOSSAL PICTURE: Of all forms of painting, the panorama is the most grandiose, and of all the world's pano ramas the Soviet Union - which seeks to excel capitalist nations in art as well as industry - intends to have the biggest. A staff of Moscow painters is completing a panorama in four sec tions, one of them 160 yards long and 22 yards high.
WASHINGTON. WHEN President Roosevelt's judi ciary reform program was dropped upon the already bleed ing heads of the new Congress the first reaction of Senator BennettChamp Clark was:

The White Plains Choral Society, under the direction of Caroline Bee son Fry, and the White Plains Symphony Orchestra, Louis Greene conducting, will give a concert here Friday evening in Eastview JuniorHigh School.
Colonel and Mrs. Robert H. Montgomery of Greenwich, Conn., were among those entertaining at the "Old Vienna" ball at the Surf Club tonight.

SURPRISED to hear the sound portion of London's television broadcasts from Alexandra Palace, New York radio men at Radio Central, Riverhead, L. I., attribute the "freak" ultra-short wave reception to the sunspots nowrampant on the face of Old Sol.

Gas par Bacon Jr., son of Gaspar Bacon, former Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts and of Mrs. Bacon of Boston will play the lead in "Come Across" this season's offer ing by the Harvard Hasty Pudding Club, at the Bellevue-Stratford onApril 7.

The year 1936 was marked by gratifying nation-wide progress in achieving the principal objectives of the Federal Housing Administra tion, reports an official of that body. He points out that during the present year an enlarged vol ume of home financing probably will be demanded, and the manner in which this demand is met will be of lasting significance to the American people.

Spencer Borden, sailing Red Rover, led Walter Moore Jr. in Joanna by 1:29 today in winning the first race for the Royal Yacht Squadron Cup in the Royal Nassau Sailing Club series. Other competitors and their orderof finish were: Nelson Odman's

The quota tions of all foreign securities were wiped off the boards of German Stock Exchanges today when the Foreign Exchange Control Office decreed that such securities could be bought and sold only with its permission unless they were sold to the Reichsbank or its agentbanks.
A suggestion that farmers' coopera tives eventually might take over the administration's proposed crop insurance system aroused interest today at a Senate Agriculture Subcommittee hearing.

The first edition of the interna tional electrotechnical vocabulary, a work which has been more than thirty years in the making by an international committee of electri cal experts, will be published in the near future, it was announced by the American Standards Association, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

A WPA worker assigned for two years as a deputy collector of the Internal Revenue Bureau was held in $500 bail for the grand jury yes terday on a charge of extorting $300 from a sugar broker. The suspect, William Levine, 36 years old, of 1,521 Undercliff Avenue, the Bronx, denied the charge before UnitedStates Commissioner Isaac Platt.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. German of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Elizabeth German, to Frank Edwin Kuhn of Jackson Heights, Queens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Kuhn, alsoof Buffalo.

Dinner of the Gourmet Society, Meadowbrook Restaurant, 52 East Fifty-fifth Street, 1:30 P. M. Ad dress by Ford Madox Ford. Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eighty-second Street and Fifth Ave nue. "Flemish and Italian Devo tional Painting (Survey of Collec tions)," Roberta M. Fansler, 2 P. M.; "Digging Into the Past; the Daily Life of the Egyptians," motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.;
The fourth annual convention of the Mortgage Conference of New York, composed of savings banks and other mortgage lending insti tutions in this area, will be held onMarch 8 in the Hotel Commodore.

Felix M. Warburg, in accepting an honorary chairmanship of the Greater New York United Palestine Appeal, urged yesterday public sup port of the local campaign for $1, 700,000 for the settlement in Pales tine of Jews of Germany, Poland and other lands. He expressed his "sense of rejoic ing over the possibility of securing the larger funds which are becom ing necessary for Palestine Colonization and resettlement."

Net income of the American Home Products Corporation and subsidiaries amounted to $2,825,261 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed profits, according to the annualreport, issued yesterday.

A fast-skating Northwood Prep hockey team defeated Lawrenceville School today in Baker Rink, 4-2. Stan Wright, Northwood spare, opened the scoring in the first frame with a solo dash down the ice in 4:30. Shep Wilson retaliated for Lawrenceville in 9:02 of the second period and Goff and Dickson scored again for Northwood in 10:20 and11:33, respectively.

After fourteen months the most compre hensive study of the effects of changing industrial technology on the volume of employment is ap proaching completion, according to the WPA Administrator, Harry L. Hopkins. The first report is expected within two months.

Collapse of negotiations today up set plans for prompt reopening of two General Motors plants, which were closed by a union dispute arising from the management's suspension of an employee "until hecould act like a man."

This department and a host of his yachting friends are dipping their colors this week-end in a me morial salute to Captain. Bernard Thomson, sports editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who died Friday. Known and respected in many a yacht club and yacht anchorage as a devotee of pleasure boating, he Goes West on his last cruise withflag-hoists saluting him.

Mrs. Alma Clayburgh entertained with a dinner last night in the Per sian Room of the Plaza for Miss Ariel Bryce, who is leaving today for California with-her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Cooper Bryce, andMiss Barbara Wall.

FESTIVE and carefree is the look, these days, of the A. C. A. Gallery, down in Eighth Street. A new sly little ?? embellishes the quiet smile of Herman Baron, proprietor of thegallery, as he surveys the scene.

The West Orange team of Frank R. Kelly and Carl Schweinler won both of today's titles in the third annual Eastern two-man skeet championships at the Loantaka Skeet Club. The 410-gauge honors went to them in the morning when Kelly broke 86 and Schweinler one fewer for a team score of 171. Strong northwest winds brought the scores down.

Strong opposition to the proposed increase of the State gasoline tax from 3 cents to 4 cents a gallon, is expected to develop at hearings on the proposal to be held Wednes day before an Assembly committeeat Albany.

Discussing the residential growth in the present metropolitan area of New York City and its transitions during the past century, Dr. Homer Hoyt, FHA housing economist, states that in this section there are sectors which have acquired certain characteristics and which have definite appeal to people ofthe various income groups.

SPEED, as a cause of automobile accidents, has been stressed from two angles of approach within the past few days. In its report to the general committee of the Accident Prevention Conference, a subcommittee on causes and remedies, of which Labert St. Clair is director, held high speed responsible for most motorcar accidents.
With only twenty-two business days in February, trading on the New York Stock Exchange was ap proximately at the same rate as in January. Sales for the month, ascompiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Edward N. Nockels, secretary of the Chicago Federation of Labor and manager of labor's radio station, WCFL, dropped dead today in a Loop restaurant. He was 67 years old. He had planned to go to Washing ton tomorrow to carry on his fight for higher power and an additionalwave length for the station.

The State Liquor Authority an nounced yesterday the cancellation of six liquor and beer licenses for violations of the State Liquor Law. Among the licenses cancelled was one issued to the Yacht Club Cater ing, Inc., 38 West Fifty-second Street. The license was cancelled, according to the announcement, because the licensee "permitted per sons not mentioned on said license to avail themselves of the license, failed to keep adequate books andrecords."
Frederic L. Johnson, former Newark District Court judge and Essex County freeholder, died at his home here today after an illness of ayear. He was 59 years old.

DETROIT. CAR divisions of General Motore have snapped back into volume production with astonishing rapidity following the strike settlement. It was no secret that the corporation's assemblies would be limited by the. number of bodies that could be built by the Fisher plants, body manufacture forming the bottleneck controllingthe corporation's output.

Under the auspices of the New York City Colony of New England Women a card party will be held Thursday afternoon at the Woman's Club House on the sixth floor of the South Building of John Wanamaker's.

Girls at the University of Ver mont are learning their dance steps all over again-on roller skates. With one of the number playing popular tunes at the piano, they are practicing the waltz and tap dance at the new Southwick Memorial Union for women, which was opened this Fall and is now used as a women's gymnasium and social center.

The first issue of Amerasia, a monthly magazine described as a "review of America and the Far East," was published yesterday. The magazine has as its main pur pose the providing of a "forum for the expression and clarification of ideas concerning America's participation in Far Eastern affairs."

Premier Milan Hodza has just declared the agreement between the Czechoslovak Government and three German parties was only the first step toward a general im provement in the German situa tion. He offered to cooperate with Konrad Heinlein's Sudeten German party in exchange for its adherence to democracy and abandonment oftotalitarian slogans.

President Anastasio Somoza an nounced today that an American financial expert would be employed to study Nicaragua's economic conditions. Two groups of econo mists in Nicaragua are debating the present inflation and proposed de flation with attempts to stabilizethe currency.

Issuance last night of Fleets, the government's official catalogue of the navies owned by the British Common wealth and other countries, fails to solve the mystery of Russia's sub marines, which some experts nere declared recently had been heavilyincreased.

Real estate bond prices since Jan. 1 have advanced an average of 2.9 per cent, according to- a survey by Eli T. Watson Co., Inc. Higher rentals and improved busi ness conditions were reflected in the higher prices listed in the in dex, which is based on a study of250 issues.
The Rev. Charles Edwin Perkins, for many years rector of Protestant Episco pal churches in Baltimore, Colorado and Utah, died at his home hereyesterday at the age of 63.
The eight race program at Santa Anita today accounted for a total izator handle of $1,539,879. It was a record in the three-year history of the track. The handi cap coaxed $396,553, also a record.

Lewis H. Losee has been elected president of the Security Title and Guaranty Company, 350 Fifth Ave nue, succeeding Daniel J. Lyons. The new president has been a mem ber of the board of directors since joining the Security company abouttwo years ago.

DES MOINES, Iowa. THEATRE history took a for ward lunge when Katharine Cornell in "The Barretts of Wimpole Street" shattered world's records of the largest house in history for the number of per sons attending and the money in the box-office. And it wasn't on Broadway. It was out in the"sticks," Des Moines, Iowa.

The engagement of Miss Marjorie Ethel Conklin, daughter of Mrs. John Percy Conklin of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Conklin, to Willis Mott Moore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Mott Moore also of Brooklyn, has been announced byher mother.

The Right Rev. Archimandrite Bohdan, formerly of Prague, will be consecrated as Bishop of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of America today at 10:30 A. M. in Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street. His jurisdiction will embrace Ukrainian churches in the United States andcanada.

Miss Bernice Rentner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Rentner of 55 Central Park West and Larchmont Manor, N. Y., whose engagement to Arthur Jablow, son of George Jablow, also of this city,and the late Mrs. Jablow,

The Swarthmore College women's varsity basketball team overcame the University of Pennsylvania by 25-13 today. In spite of Penn's rally in the last quarter, during which it tallied 8 points, it was un able to overcome. Swarthmore's big lead. Miss Margaret Leeper, Swarth more forward, was the high scorerof the game with 15 points.

The first International Labor Office conference to be held in this coun try since the United States entered the I. L. O. in 1934 will be the Tri partite Preparatory Textile Confer ence, which will be called to orderin this city on April 2.

The West Side Association of Commerce has chosen the following members as chairmen of its various committees for 1937: H. W. McGraw, executive; Frank W. Kridel, convention and new business; Frank W. Kridel, publication; Alfred Rheinstein, engineering; R. K. Christenberry, industrial; C. H.Thompson, finance;

Joe Rodriguez's goal in the sec ond overtime period gave the Iona Prep quintet a 14-12 victory over Fordham Prep at the Fordham gymnasium yesterday in the decid ing contest for the Bronx-West chester C. H. S. A. A. champion ship. Both squads had five vic tories and two defeats before theclash.

George H. Peck, Bridgeport busi ness man, who gave up his livery stable business shortly after the turn of the century to engage in the automobile business, died at his home here last night. He was 79 years old.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Dorothy Elizabeth MacVicker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. MacVicker of this place, to John C. Gillies of New ark, son of Charles Gillies of Edinburgh Scotland.

It was learned here tonight that Egon Berger Waldenegg, the Austrian Minister to Rome, yesterday called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, the-Italian Foreign Minister, seeking information re garding the attitude of the newspa per Giornale d'Italia as expressed in a recent anti-legitimist article byVirginio Goyda.

IT is a poor theatrical season which fails to turn up at least one Cinderella-using the term, of course, in its broadest generic sense. Usually it is some young actor or actress who comes glittering forth from obscurity to garner a scrap-book full of praise. Or, again, it may be some new play-wright with a witty or wrathful pen who sets the critics and publicto turning handsprings.

Astute use of the corner drop shot helped Dan Martella of the Wil mington C. C. turn back Tom lanni celli of Short Hills and win the New York State professional squash rac quets championship yesterday at the Downtown A. C. The scoreswere 12-15, 15-12, 17-15, 15-12.

A proposal that the discount rate in the dress industry be changed from 8 per cent to 5 per cent in order to defray the cost of the new tax imposts, including the social security levy, will be made to all organizations in the dress industry this week by Morris Kolchin, execu tive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., he announcedyesterday.
Reduced buying activity was noted in the wholesale market last week, as retail stocks are generally heavy, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORKTIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

The most puzzling crime Berlin has experi enced in many months was com mitted last night by a 28-year-old New Yorker, John Joseph Hughes Jr., who gave his address as 140 East Forty-sixth Street and claimed to be an insurance broker. He shot and killed 82-year-old Oskar Hoff mann, a passer-by whom he hadencountered in the street.

Westchester County authorities declared yesterday that they would take advantage of a recent law to bring Merle Vandenbush to trial within a week for the Katonah, N. Y., bank robbery for which he was indicted with two others Friday.
Miners in increasing numbers fol lowed air trails today to the mouth of the Kuskokwim River, scene of Alaska's newest gold and platinum strikes.

The St. Francis Prep sextet, led by Eddie Maher, who scored three goals, downed the La Salle M. A., 5 to 0, yesterday at the Brooklyn Ice Palace to clinch second place in the Private School HockeyLeague.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-From the point of view of sports, so cial and cultural activities, March is coming in like a lion, and it will go out the same way if half of the events plannedhere for this month take place.

BY undeclared mutual agree ment motion- picture script writers regard newspaper men as queer fellows, and newspaper men have their own no tions of what goes on in Hollywood. The fact that many newspaper men become script writers and vice versa does not seem to have much to do with the case.
Seven hundred children at a special matinee staged a "sit-down strike" at a theatre here today in protest against a short program and what they called poor "shorts."
After a slight setback yesterday Pope Pius has again improved considera bly and his condition is officiallydescribed as satisfactory.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Pressman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Alfred Pressman of 336 Central Park West, to Nelson Mintz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Herbert Mintz, also of this city and Morristown, N. J., has beenannounced by her parents.

THE Metropolitan, in its eleventh week of opera, will present the season's first performance of "Goetter daemmerung," the second of "Nor ma" and a new Violetta in "La Tra viata"--Bidu Sayao, the Brazilian soprano.
A farm woman's labor over a period of thirty years is worth more than $50,000, Miss Julia Newton of the Farm Credit Administration told Indiana farmwomen in convention here.

The gov ernment called on German churches tonight to share part of their lands with the landless and spoke of the "necessity of compulsory measures" if they failed to do so voluntarily. Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, appealed to the Evangelical churches and German Bishops to co operate wholeheartedly in the gov ernment's task of finding land forsmall settlers.

The Manhattan Chess Club, three time winner of. the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League, suffered its first reverse of the sea son yesterday when J. Balint of the Bronx-International Chess. Club de feated A. S. Denker in an ad journed game, giving the Bronx Internationals a winning total of5 1/2-4 1/2.

BELGRADE. DESPITE the sweeping changes which the World War has brought about in the Balkan lands, that pic turesque figure of the Middle Ages, the Balkan bandit, persists throughout Yuguslavia. Bulgaria and Albania He has been forced to change his tactics and his arms, but in the main he is still something of a Robin Hood inhis way.
Chairmen for the Spring Fiesta, sponsored by the Junior Committee of the Little Italy Neighborhood Association, to be held on May 7, at The Towers, Brooklyn, have beenchosen.

IF it weren't for Louis Bromfield, J. Edgar Hoover and a fellow named Edgar Bromberg who starred in the Columbia varsity show of 1926 or thereabouts, J. Edward Bromberg's enjoyment of his well earned recognition in the theatre and the cinema mightbe unalloyed.
The arrangements committee for the Starlight Roof Dinner Dances is planning to hold the third of this series of subscription dances on March 18 in the Starlight Roof ofthe Waldorf-Astoria.

Rowland B. Haines of the :Co lumbia University Club, former na tional title-holder and second rank ing player at the present time, won the veterans' national squash tennis championship yesterday when: he defeated another former national title-holder, Thomas R. Coward ofthe Yale Club.

There would seem to be a moral of sorts behind the illness and sud den return home of Miss Susan Noel, the former squash racquets champion who came over here to lead the English team in its defense of the Wolfe-Noel International Trophy at the Junior League Clubyesterday.
TO one who has passed many pleasant and rewarding hours among the essays of the earlier Maeterlinck, the pres ent volume comes with a distinctsense of shock.
The nation-wide wave of labor difficul ties seemed destined today to sweep in on the hotels and restaurants of Atlantic City, the resort's greatestindustry.

APITHY and entertaining discussion of chiaroscuro wood-cuts by Winslow Ames, director of the Lyman Allen Museum, is a feature of the February number of Parnassus. In the same issue, Hans Tietze and E. Tietze-Conrat deal with the Venetian drawings in the Albertina (Vienna) Collection. Under the title of "Four Vital Sculptors,"

A marked increase has been no ticed since the first of the year in refinancing home prop ties in New Jersey, reports Thomas E. Colleton, State FHA director. The refi nancing of existing mortgages, he states, represents about 60 per cent of the whole FHA business, against 40 per cent of new home construc tion loans, also carrying FHA insurance.

MIAMI BEACH, FLA. TAXES days to lose your suspicion of palm trees, too-blue skies, green and cobalt water breaking snow-white on golden sand. You wonder at first if the palms may not be so many props set up on suggestion of go-getter publicity men; whether the hibiscus, flame vine, other luxuriant flora, may not be a plant. Natives remind you, though, that "Florida" means "State of Flowers."

Miss Frances Becker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude M. Becker of Fourth Street, has chosen April 14 for the date of her marriage to Joseph A. Keenan Jr. of Brooklyn and Washington, D. C. The cere mony will take place in the morn ing at St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Garden City. A small reception for members of the immediate families will follow at the Cherry ValleyClub.

IN a recent message to the Boy Scouts President Roosevelt remarked that he liked to think that the many thousands of men-some young, others entering middle-age-who are no longer active in the organization have, nevertheless, found it true that "once aBoy Scout, always a Boy Scout."

Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace will be the principal speaker at a national consumer conference opening for a two-day session at 2 P. M. Saturday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, under direction of the Consumers Emergency Council.

Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin, speaking last night in defense of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposal, declared that the country's great need is for a Supreme Court that will itself obey the Constitution and notamend it by judicial decree.

President Roosevelt has asked Congress to pass a law affecting the membership of the Supreme Court of the United States. His recommendation has let loose the floodwaters of propaganda dammed up since the recent election.

Announce ment has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Alexander Fyfe Mac Gregor of this city of the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Nancy MacGregor, to Frank Laughton Getman Jr. of New York, son of Mrs. Frank L. Getman of Fairport,N. Y., and the late Mr. Getman.

MOST screen people specialize in private lives which are different from the roles they have to play. The villain tends a suburban rose garden; the femme fatale loves children and has the vicar on alternate Thursday for tea. But Errol Flynn, the swashbuckling romantic, succeeds in being different by quaintlyremaining the same.

Miss Elizabeth Elmore White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton Taylor White of Noroton, was mar ried this morning to Phillip Van Sicklen Kleinert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph B. Kleinert of Shippan. The Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham, pastor of St. John's Episcopal Church, Stamford, performed the ceremony at the home of herparents.

IN Malaga, a year and a half ago. I saw Belmonte fight He had come out of one of his various retirements; the corrida was in honor of a Moroc can chieftain who was the guest of army officers and the government then in power.
Roy Barton White, twelve rooms, furnished, in 620 Park Av.; C. Mendez, in 125 E. 50th St.; Lucille Spafford, in 717 Madison Av.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.

Rescued as they were writing farewell messages after eight foodless days, two passengers of the Brisbane-Sydney airliner, which disappeared Feb, 19, were found today beside its burned wreckage in the MacPherson Range of Queensland.

A "cat burglar" who made his way up a fire-escape unobserved during the dinner hour stole jewelry valued at between $5,000 and $7,000 from the home of Allen Wardwell at 127 East Eightieth Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues, it became known last night.

In this machine age, methods have become an end in themselves rather than a means to an end, dedared the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons is yesterday morning in his sermon at All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

President Roosevelt's recommendation for reform of the Federal judiciary was debated yesterday over station WOR by two Democrats, Senator Walter F. George of Georgia and Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black of New York.

If this is a world of phobias and ferocity, with the members of one nation casting vicious looks at the members of other nations, it is because too many cooks are preparing too much food badly, Ford Madox Ford said yesterday.

Shipments of gold from England were the feature of imports of the metal at the port of New York in February. While the month's total of gold imports from all sources was smaller than in the preceding month, it was substantially larger than in February, 1936.

Passengers riding on a B. M. T. express speeding south from Thirtyfourth to Fourteenth Streets yesterday were unaware that tragedy inside the motorman's cab required a supreme effort of mind to control a failing body and stop the train safely.

Government forces operating on the Andalusian front north of Motril are stated to have cut off a detachment of German troops that attempted to drive a wedge southward toward Ca4el de Ferro, on the coast about nine miles east of Motril, to isolate government troops facing Motril from their main body on the coast road toward Almeria.

Dr. Tyler Dennett, president of Williams College, in his address before the students, faculty and alumni of Union College in the Memorial Chapel this morning, asserted that the liberal arts college helps to resolve the disorders of the present-day political, economic and social life.

Mrs. Anna Sands O'Shea, who worked for woman suffrage from her sixteenth year until the vote was granted, died yesterday in her apartment at 76-66 Austin Street, Forest Hills, Queens, at the age of 84. A daughter, Mrs. W. A. Redding, with whom she lived, and a son, Ambrose L. O'Shea of Kew Gardens. survive.

Two metropolitan A. A. U. junior championships featured the swimming meet held yesterday in the Park Central Hotel pool and in both of them standard-bearers of the St. George Dragon Club of Brooklyn captured the premier honors.

Patrick H. McQuade, believed to have been the oldest school principal in the State up to last June, when he retired from the Albany school system, where he had served for seventyone years, died tonight at the age of 92.

About 150 persons attended a memorial service-yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral Club, 85 Sixth Avenue,, Brooklyn, for the Right Rev. Mgr. David J. Hickey, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, who died on Feb. 2.
Word has just come from France that plans are afoot for the erection of a statue of Pere MARQUETTE in Laon, where he was born, son of an old and honorable family of that city, 300 years ago.
The Rev. Dr. William Pendleton Chipman of this city, retired minister and well-known writer of boys' books, died today after a brief illness. His age was 82.

Police were searching today for two burglars who last night broke into the home of Lawrence Donahue at 62 Cliff Avenue and fled in fright when Mrs. Donahue went to a telephone and summoned the police.

Despite satisfactory deliveries by farmers, the wheat situation has not improved. Mills are refusing to supply bakers or dealers with first-grade flour unless the second-grade commodity is simultaneously bought. Retailers,

A prediction that five years from now none of the present dictators will be in power was made yesterday morning by the Rev. Charles Francis Potter before the First Humanist Society at the Steinway Building, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Walter Melville, famous as "King of Melodrama" and for the joint managership with his brother, Frederick, of the Lyceum Theatre in London, which they made the home of stage thrillers for the past twenty-eight years, died tonight at Hove, Sussex, at the age of 62.
Mrs. Carrie E. Saben prepared tonight to begin spending $200 in new $1 bills, under a test of the Townsend plan.

The Union Settlement, which furthers extensive health, educational and recreational programs for adults and children in a crowded district of the city, will be the beneficiary of a supper dance on March 15 in the Empire Room of the.Waldorf-Astoria. Miss Ellen S.
Horace Francis Carpenter, mineralogist and conchologist, and one of the oldest living alumni of Brown University, died here today. He was in his ninety-fifth year.

Oxygen, administered by a police emergency crew from the West Thirtieth Street station, gave life to a twin baby girl born last night to Mrs. Frances Plotero, 32 years old, at her home, 325 West Twentysixth Street.

Australia's first stay-in strike started in the New South Wales coal fields today. Following a dispute over the introduction of an electric coaldriller, in consequence of which the men were required to fill two more skips on each shift, thirty men went underground in the North Wallarah colliery declaring they would not return till their demands were met.
More than 100 Jews of German origin stood silent for two minutes yesterday afternoon in memory of Jews who have died as the result of Nazi persecution.
In hobor of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Robert, guests of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hopkins gave a dinner tonight at the Everglades Club.

Under the sponsorship of the Danish Consul General, George Bech, the film of Eskimo life made by the late Knud Rasmussen in 1933 on his last journey into the North will have its American premiere tonight at 8:45 o'clock at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse under the title, "The Wedding of Palo."

Mrs. Susan White Harkrader, mother of Charles J. Harkrader, publisher of The Johnson City (Tenn.) Press, The Chronicle, The Bristol Herald Courier and The News Bulletin, and of Rhea Harkrader, a business executive of Nashville, died here tonight at the age of 83.

Sir James Haldane Lockhart, expert on Chinese affairs, died here today at the age of 78. He had spent forty years as a British official in the Far East, the last half of that period engaged in the development of the British naval outpost at Weihaiwei.
In a tense atmosphere Berks County began preparations today for a general strike of 15,000 hosiery workers scheduled to begin tomorrow.

Three men who were arrested Saturday night on charges of burglary after they had been observed by a bedridden invalid were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Felony Court. They will. have hearings tomorrow.

The restaurant racket case against eight defendants being tried before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury will enter its seventh week when testimony is resumed at 10 o'clock this morning. The eight defendants are charged with conspiracy and extor tion in the restaurant industry.

In its annual report of operations for 1936, to be made public today, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company shows a net income of $174,826,414, equal to $9.35 each on the 18,865,093 shares of common stock outstanding at the end of the year.

Richard E. Handlen, trainer of William du Pont Jr.'s Rosemont, winner of the big Santa Anita Handicap, said tonight "Rosy's" feet are "a little sore" after yesterday's great performance, and he would not be entered in next Saturday's $10,000 added San Juan Capistrano, closing feature of Santa Anita's racing season.

Harrington Mann, British artist, who was known particularly for his portraits of children, died early yesterday at the Leroy Sanitarium, 40 East Sixty-first Street, of pneumonia at the age of 72. Mr. Mann, who had been ill only three days, had been living at 36 Central Park South.

" Now You've Done It," scheduled to have its postponed premiere this evening at Henry Miller's Theatre, was again set back when John Alexander, who had the leading male role, underwent an appendicitis operation yesterday morning at Polyclinic Hospital.

Miss Maria Cerra of the Salle d'Armes Vince, ranked No. 6 nationally, staged an impressive performance in winning the third of a series of four competitions for the Santelli Trophy on the strips of the Salle Santelli yesterday.
The Catalan people love freedom and democracy. They have always fought for their rights, and so they will fight against a Fascist dictatorship.
Louis Richardson, a rancher, faces trial for manslaughter because his wife left their home after a family quarrel, walked out into a blinding blizzard and froze to death in sub zero weather.

The Penn A. C. quintet won its eleventh straight game in the Eastern Athletic Club League, beating the New York A. C. today, 40-22, before a crowd of 1,800. It was also the twentieth in a row for the Pennacs this season.

A subscription dance, to be known as the Spring Supper Dance, has been arranged by Mrs. George Eustis Corcoran and will be held on April 14 at the Plaza. The invitation list will include debutantes of this and the last two or three seasons and young married couples.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 85 per cent of capacity, up 1 point in the week. The average in January was 81.42 per cent, affected slightly by the flood. While production is 15 per cent under rated capacity, it is close to practical capacity.
Mr. THOMPSON in his book column last Saturday spoke out vigorously but quite justly on RUDYARD KIPLING'S racial and national
With the sound of a pistol shot fired by Glenn Cunningham, fifteen teams sped away from the mark to start the sixty-second six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden last night.

BACH-Eva, widow of Herman. Funeral from residence, 291 Lefferts Av., Brooklyn, at 3:30 P. M., today BENEDICT--At Daytona, Fla., Feb. 28, 1937, Florence, daughter of the late James Lawrence and Christina Benedict. Notice of funeral later.
Dr. Wilber M. Dailey, for twentyfive years personal dentist to President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, died on Saturday evening at his home, 19 East Sixty-ninth Street. He was 68 years old.
Although he signed a law legalizing gambling, President Juan Demostenes Arosemena announces that he is opposed to it and that it will be the ruination of the country.

Conditions for the big ocean race of the coming Summer, that from New London, Conn., down the coast and up Chesapeake Bay to Gibson Island, Md., were announced yesterday. It will be a thrash of 475 miles, the start at Sarah Ledge, off the mouth of the Thames River, and the finish off Baltimore light.

American political campaigns are praise-meetings compared with those in many British constituencies. Abusive interruptions, punching heads, breaking up meetings by continual hullabaloo, are ordinary incidents among our so phlegmatic British brothers.

Disturbed by the mounting cost of relief to State and local governments and faced with the prospect of increased costs through curtailment of the Federal government's WPA program, six Governors, sent a telegram to President Roosevelt yesterday, asking for a conference on the relief situation at his earliest convenience.

Alvin S. Rosenson, chairman of the executive committee of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, reporting yesterday for Nathan S. Jonas, president, at the thirty-fifth annual meeting of the hospital, said maintenance costs last year incurred a deficit of $350,000, while the dispensary exceeded its budget by $70,000.

The work of missionaries in the Philippine Islands was described yesterday by Deaconess Kate Sibley Shaw, on furlough after twelve years in the Philippines. She spoke before the congregation of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

The competition for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club was exceptionally close and interesting yesterday. J. Nida and M. Hickey finished on even terms in the regular shoot with cards of 93. They set the pace in a field of nineteen gunners.
Figures showing that the great majority of convicts paroled from New York State penal institutions "go straight" have been compiled by State parole authorities.

The Madrigal Singers, under the direction of Lehman Engel, assisted by Suzanne Bloch, flutist, gave a program of early English music yesterday afternoon in the Theatre of Music. There were compositions by Pilkington, Farnaby, Vautor, Philips, Ravenscrift, Morley, Gibbons and others, and a final group of folksongs.

The Rev. James A. Smith, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Babylon, called upon his congregation today to protest to Assemblyman Elisha T. Barret against adoption by the Legislature of the Federal child labor amendment.
A. A. Young's Countess Ann, showing courage in a stirring stretch drive, captured the mile-and-a-sixteenth Martin Behrman Memorial Purse, feature of the program at the Fair Grounds today.

In an effort to form an usocia tion of parents of students of the three city colleges, Albert W. clur man, chairman of a provisional committee, has called the first meeting for tomorrow evening at the City College House Plan Center. 292 Convent Avenue.
The annual report of the steel trust (Vereinigte Stahlwerke) produced a good impression.

The government's policy regarding the export of British capital has been subject to many rumors recently. No special action, however, has been taken to check purchases of United States or Canadian securities and no fresh prohibition has been imposed in other directions.

The complementary roles of- science and religion, each in its distinct way. a guide to truth, were explained by the. Most Rev.. Dr. John Andrew Richardson, Archbishop of Fredericton, N. B., in his sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, where the will conduct midday service this week.

The British Board of Trade, in its annual estimate of Great Britain's overseas balance of visible and invisible foreign trade shows, for 1936, a net deficit of [Pound]19,000,000, compared with a net credit of [Pound]33,000,000 in 1985.

When Harvard's oldest living graduate reaches the age of 98 and goes to his office as usual, it's news, and reporters waited at the office of Henry Munroe Rogers, Harvard, '62, yesterday, to interview him. When the veteran attorney confronted them, however, he good naturedly brushed them aside.
The first tests carried out by the Imperial Airways flying boat Cambria from the Free State's, transatlantic air base on the River Shannon at Foynes have proved successful.
The Rustian Army, the government asserted today, is the healthiest in the world.
An orchestral program featuring two works by American composers, with both composers present as performers, was given last night in the Theatre of Music, on Fiftyfourth Street.
With ritual and pageantry unchanged through the ages, the Rev. Archimandrite Bohdan was consecrated yesterday as Bishop of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church in America.

In behalf of the President's Supreme Court plan it has been said by Mr. CUMMINGS and by others that speed is the essence of the matter. This point of view was amplified yesterday in Mr. KROCK'S summary of the President's own position.

Albert K. Root of 277 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Barbara Root, to Walter S. Hollister, also of this city, son of Mrs. R. D. Freeman of South Orange, N. J., and the late William Hollister.

A resolution regarded as a direct criticism of the willingness of Chairman Arthur E. Morgan of the Tennessee Valley Authority to cooperate in the power-pooling plan of private utility companies, was adopted today at the closing session of the three-day conference on the social control of power, called by the League for Industrial Democracy.
The Lenten sewing class of the Fresh Air Association of St. John the Divine will hold its third meeting tomorrow morning at the home of Mrs. Robert S. Brewster, 100 East Seventieth Street.

Mike McTigue, 42 years old, of 338 East 142d Street, the Bronx, former light heavyweight champion, was transferred last night from Fordham Hospital to the psycopathic ward -at Bellevue, suffering from alcoholism.
Everything except a husband is provided for girls of Georgian Court College who major in home economics.

Joe Bree, Tuckahoe (N. Y.) veteran, carried off the tri-State indoor senior men's speed-skating championship tonight by defeating Dick Werner of Haledon, N. J., in a half-mile skate-off after the pair had tied, each with total of 60 points apiece, at Playland Casino.

The action of the cash corn market here last week was disappointing both to holders and to speculative interests. The latter have been cut down while the cash demand remains good, and liberal quantities of corn are going to outside markets.

The preliminary adjusted index figure for retail sales of new passenger automobiles declined sharply from 175 in December and 151 in November to 128.5 in January, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce has reported.

Demolition of old East River piers between Grand and Fourteenth Streets will start this week, to be followed by the construction of an extended bulkhead and a thirtyfive-acre park on new ground, with a spacious promenade, recreation fields and landscaping between the new drive and the river.

Alderman Charles E. Keegan, Bronx Democrat, will introduce a bill in the Aldermanic branch of the Municipal Assembly today which, if adopted, would add 200 policemen to the patrol force without increasing the Police Departmeant's budget.

With the technical work completed, a report on window display research, conducted under the sponsorship of the Advertising Research Foundation, will be presented to the committees in the immediate future.
Except for continued activity in commercial paper transactions, the money market was featureless in February. Call and time loan rates were unchanged for the ninth consecutive month.

Neutrality was denounced yesterday by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in the annual report of its Division of Intercourse and Education, made public by Nicholas Murray Butler as director.

Dan D. Coyle, a Princeton junior from Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., has been elected president of the University Press Club for the coming year, it was announced tonight by Robert G. Barnes, '37, of Philadelphia, the retiring president.

Floods and the labor disturbances in the automotive industry were largely responsible for the decline in industrial activity in January, according to the regular monthly survey released by the National Industrial Conference Board. The recession, the report continued, cannot be considered as any important interruption in the upward trend of the recovery cycle.

More than a thousand persons, gathered last night in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, saw and heard of the evils of the city's slums, as religious leaders of various denominations, headed by Bishop Manning, opened a drive for the replacement of century-old dwellings through government housing subsidies.

Mrs. William Garland Heeks, who heads the executive committee for the Bassinet dinner dance to be held April 2 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, has enlisted the aid of several young women in the arrangements for the event.

Frank M. Ransbottom, banker and pottery manufacturer, died today of pneumonia. His age was 63. He was a member of the board of directors of the Federal Home Loan Bank for Ohio at Cincinnati, Past Grand Master of Ohio Masonry and a thirty third-degree Mason.

To what extent Italy shall expand her army, navy and air force in the light of Great Britain's vast rearmament program will be considered tomorrow night by the nation's leaders when the Fascist Grand Council meets with Premier Benito Mussolini presiding.

The allegation that President Roosevelt, in his plan to change the Supreme Court, is proposing the indirect "destruction" of the Constitution is made by Senator Borah of Idaho in an article published today.
The Chicago Black Hawks upset the New York Rangers, 4-3, in a furiously played National Hockey League battle tonight to keep the New Yorkers from taking second place in the American group.

Taking advantage of the world-wide armament race, which is creating world-wide hunger for all kinds of goods, Germany is preparing to embark on a new export drive the principal object of which) will be to sell "for cash instead of for kind," in order to buy urgently needed raw materials.

Eastman ha Kodak Company will announce to- po morrow an increase in wages which ev will add $1,500,000 to its payroll annually. The company will also dis- ob tribute to 23,987 employes $2,112,555 in wage dividends for the year. The wage increase will be effective March 15.
Because of the unfriendly attitude taken by the French Government toward his cause, General Francisco Franco has forbidden the export of iron pyrites from Spain to France.

Information that Ben Leider, formerly a New York newspaper man, was killed Feb. 19 while serving as an aviator with the Loyalist forces near Valencia, Spain, has been received by relatives here, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Morris Leider, a brother, who lives at 101 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. Dr.
Canisius College of Buffalo today won the Little Three championship title, defeating the Niagara quintet, 41-34. It was Niagara's third home defeat in fifty-five games.

The marriage of Miss Janet E. Goldsmith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton M. Goldsmith, to Arthur H. Bernstein, son of Mrs. Jacob Bernstein of New York and the late Mr. Bernstein, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 935 Park Avenue.
Miss Etta Redell of this city gave a dinner yesterday at the Hotel Taft for her mother, Mrs. Betsey Redell, who celebrated her eighteth birthday. More than sixty relatives and friends were present.

Samuel Roeoff, builder of subways and tunnels, issued a statement last night denying that he had any band in the murder of Norman Redwood and branding accusations to the contrary as "damnably outrageous."

" Blessed are they who hear the word of God and keep it," was offered as the divine prescription for happiness by the Rev. Dr. Walton H. Greever, secretary of the United Lutheran Church of America, in his sermon yesterday at the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue at Seventy-third Street.
Gene Sarazen of Brookfield Center, Conn., swept down the homestretch to win the Florida West Coast open golf tournament and $700 first prize money today. His 72-hole score was 141-72-73-286.

The combined averages of prices of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES and based upon fifty representative issues, declined slightly last month, from 138.11 on Feb. 1 to 137.22 on Feb. 27.

If Jesus were to walk the streets of New York, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, the-pastor, said yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street, He still would see many of the characters He knew in Jerusalem, but He also would see evidence that His teachings had not been in vain.

Social security identification cards, bearing employes' permanent numbers, and issued under the old age benefits program, need not be carried at all times, the Social Security Board said today in response to inquiries.

There is now pending in Albany a measure to enable the Tenement House Department of this city to compel the repair and alteration of old tenements. The measure was originally proposed by the New York City Housing Authority and has the endorsement of the Mayor.

Reaching the highest total since the Securities and Exchange Commission began compiling figures in October, 1934, the dollar value of sales on all registered exchanges rose in January to $2,972,598,078, an increase of 11.1 per cent over December and a gain of 3.1 per cent over January, 1936, it was announced today.

The British Home and Mediterranean Fleets, engaged in maneuvers in the Western Mediterranean, have been ordered to continue the annual Spring exercises in the less dangerous Atlantic, says The Sunday Graphic.

Philip H. Steckler has been appointed manager of the Savoy-Plaza office of Harriman Keech. A. L. Stamm Co. announce the formation of an investment department under the supervision of Lester S. Miller.
The International Mercantile Marine Company has adopted a plan whereby junior officers will be put in command of ships for brief periods while awaiting promotion to permanent posts.
The F. ers W. Woolworth Company threatened today to close all of its forty stores in the Detroit area if 100 salesgirls remain in its downtown unit on a "sit-down" strike.
The Exchange has received notice from the Commercial Credit Company of a proposed increase in authorized preferred stock from $25,000,000 to $50,000,000, issuable in series.

David M. Milton has resigned as president and a director of the Cnsolidated Funds Corporation, according to a letter which he has sent the stockholders. It is proposed to elect Ellery C. Huntington Jr., now vice president, to the pres idency.

Two countries, Germany and Switzerland, have just published their new corporation laws. The new corporation law of either country is a new codification and replaces totally the former laws on stock corporations.

Konrad Henlein, Nazi leader, charged in a speech this afternoon at Aussig that the Czechs were attempting to separate the German minority. He made his expected contribution to the German press campaign against the Czechs by accusing them of tolerating Bolshevist propaganda.
Pope Plus postponed several audiences today until Tuesday because of fatigue from working late last night, but prelates said his condition continued to improve gradually.
An exhibition of sporting prints and paintings will open with a private view this afternoon and to the public tomorrow in Gallery D6 at the Metropolitan Museum.

Dr. Robert E. Speer, who will retire this Summer as secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church, was honored yesterday by the congregation of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

With six inches of fine, hard ice covering its surface Greenwood Lake today was thronged with Winter sports enthusiasts, who engaged in about every conceivable pastime that a frozen stretch could offer. Fully 4,000 persons were there, mostly in the southern end of the lake, which is in New Jersey.
Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Levey gave a dinner dance last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their marriage.
Patrolman Philip Korber had a split second to decide yesterday whether a fire or a man buried alive deserved police attention the most. The buried man won.
Miss Maud Eustis Paine, prominent socially in New York, and Lieutenant Marvin Evenson of Sioux City, Iowa, naval aviator attached to the U. S. S. Lexington, were married here yesterday.

The Anchor liner Cameronia arrived'late yesterday from Glasgow, via Belfast and Molille, with 115 passengers in her cabins and her holds filled to the hatches with Scotch whisky. The ship made a quick trip.

The conservation movement, which for many years has been sponsored largely by sportsmen's and allied wildlife clubs, enters upon a broader and more comprehensive phase tomorrow with the opening of the second North American Wildlife Conference here.

Organization of steel workers in a vertical, industrial union (the type now being pushed by John L. Lewis and the Committee for Industrial Organization) is urged in "The Economics of the Iron and Steel Industry," a report to be published today, based on a research investigation conducted by the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Senator A. Harry Moore's announced opposition to President Roosevelt' Supreme Court reorganization program and the declaration of Sneator elect William H. Smathers that he would support it was interpreted today by the Young Republicans of New Jersey as an effort of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic leader, to straddle the issue.
Still seeking in vain the elusive combination that wins a ball game, the Giants went toppling down to defeat today for the third consecutive time before a team of agile and acrobatic Cubans.
The Duke of Kent left here for Munich tonight. He was accompanied to the station only by the Duke of Windsor and the latter's two equerries.

A plan to establish large strictly residential districts in the Corlears Hook section of the East Side was presented last night by the East Side Chamber of Commerce to Borough President Samuel Levy, who said he would support the plan in the Board of Estimate.

Strikers at the Perennial Dye and Print Works of West Warwick today received promises of the complete support of the Committee for Industrial Organization and the Rhode Island branch of the American Federation of Labor at a mass meeting attended by about 1,000 persons.

Two-year-old Eugenio Pereyra Iraola was buried in Recoleta Cemetery here today while the police at Mar del Plata centered their investigation on a hobo, Jose Gancedo, their chief suspect in the kidnap-killing.

Representatives of most of the principal railroads of the country reached an agreement tonight with officials of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen to employ firemen, or helpers, on Diesel-electric, steam-electric and other internal-combustion. locomotives hauling streamlined or .main-line through passenger trains. The agreement is effective March 15.

169TH ST. (11-2933), n. s., 167 ft. e. of Franklin Av.. 37x138; Isaac Stern to Muval Realty Corp., 46 St. Nicholas Av.; mtg., $35,000. Arnow Av. (16-4550), n. s., 116 ft. w. of Matthews Av., 33x100; John D. Dwyer, referee, to Daniel J. Dowdney, trustee, 320 Riverside Dr.

Frank R. Kelly, captain of the American skeet team, and Carl Schweinler, both of West Orange, made a clean sweep of the third annual Eastern open two-man skeet championships when they annexed the all-bore title at the Loantaka Skeet Club today.
Hundreds of soldiers newly arrived from Japan moved into Peiping today, but the Japanese command here and in Tientsin denied that its forces in North China were being increased.
Viennese were paying nearly twice the former prices for canned sardines today because of a customs officer's bright idea.
Ten persons were badly hurt and a gendarme was wounded today at a meeting of the Nazi Zbor organization.
How small-sum borrowers paid more than 693 per cent interest on a $5 loan was described here tonight by investigators into the loan business.
Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw will give a dinner at her home on Wednesday for Lord Davies of London, who is returning from Florida that day and will be at the Plaza.

Opposition to Secretary Wallace's "evernormal granary" proposal and a warning that any successful crop insurance program must be divorced from it are voiced in a final study of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration by the Brookings Institution.
Eugene L. Vidal, director of the Bureau of Air Commerce for the last four years, announced this afternoon that he was resigning and that his resignation would take effect at once.

The finest array of international ski talent to appear in this country since the 1932 Olympic Games at Lake Placid participated today in the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's annual jumping championships.

At the moment France has little attention to spare for external affairs. Outside events that would ordinarily be of vital concern are almost forgotten while hopes and fears concentrate on internal difficulties growing out of the country's steadily worsening financial position.
Ten Germans, nine men and one woman, arrested by the G. P. U. last November for anti-Soviet activities, were expelled from Russia last night. Four were sent from Moscow and the rest from Leningrad.
Mr. and Mrs. Theodore CStreibert of 1 Grace Court, Brooklyn, gave an informal reception yesterday at their home and a buffet supper later at the Heights Casino.

A vesper service yesterday afternoon at the Church on the Hill, 168th Street and Thirty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, commemorated the tenth anniversary of the founding of the church. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, executive secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, declared that "the world is too strong to be met by a divided church."

Rabbi Morris Lichtenstein, founder and leader of the Society of Jewish Science, which is celebrating its fifteenth anniversary, said yesterday at the Science Center, 150 West Eighty-fifth Street, that Jewish science is not a new religion but a revival of the ancient faith of Israel, with emphasis on the efficacy of prayer.

The Bourse's tendency was suddenly reversed this week. The rise in French securities, which had been going on for several weeks, finally extending into the government bond list, unexpectedly was checked, and, following profit-taking, the prices were heavily slackened.

British imports of gold in January amounted to [Pound]11,814,416 and exports to [Pound]17,038,613. Of the imports, [Pound]2,656,042 came from South Africa, [Pound]5,320,948 from France, [Pound]1,138,358 from Russia, [Pound]897,893 from India, [Pound]506,212 from Australia, [Pound]420,537 from Southern Rhodesia, [Pound]245,376 from Holland, [Pound]58,465 from Switzerland, [Pound]87,798 from Belgium, [Pound]25,250 from Germany and the rest from other countries.
A peculiar shipping officers' strike of Fascist inspiration has broken out on vessels of the Nippon Yusen Kaisha, Japan's largest shipping company.

Felony cases should be handled by the same prosecutor from their inception in the magistrates' courts until their disposal in General Ses sions, Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. says in the current number of The Panel, the official publication of the Grand July Association of New York County.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be congratulated upon its determined opposition to any violation of the sanctity of private property, its expression of the view apparently not held by the labor organizers that our President owes allegiance to no individual and to no special group, its reproval of John L. Lewis for disregarding entirely the injunctive order requiring evacuation by the sit-downers.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--By JACK B. FOX, teacher, 853 7th Av.-Liabilities $9,488, assets $217. PHILIP GLICKMAN, unemployed, 739 Coster St.-Liabilities $19,841, assets $6,075. HYMAN PARIS, builder, 885 Beck St., Bronx--Liabilities $103,489. assets. $50.

Cotton prices registered a substantial advance last week, especially the quotations for spot cotton and near-by deliveries in the futures markets. On the New York Cotton Exchange, old-crop deliveries made advances of 25 to 47 points and new-crop positions advanced 16 to 18 points. The upward movement was led by the March delivery.
