The Roosevelt Administration, through its policy of encouraging increasing organization of labor, is "poisoning the well springs of American freedom," said Professor Harry Gideonse, of the University of Chicago's executive department, in an address before the Chicago Forum today.
Last week's continued slow recession in the market for stocks and bonds was a movement familiar enough after so unusually prolonged and vigorous a forward movement as that of the two past years.

Erratic action of the world's wheat markets last week, especially that on the Board of Trade here, caused much uncertainty as to the ability of interests on either side to maintain their position for any length of time under existing conditions.
The condition of Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, Viceroy of Ethiopia, has become alarming, according to a news dispatch from Jibuti, French Somaliland, to the Havas Agency in Paris.
Stuart Logan, private investment banker of Chicago, and his eldest daughter, Mrs. Phoebe Logan Terbell, have been named defendants in a $150,000 suit charging alienation of affections.

France's wholesale price index advanced further to 516 as of Feb. 20, compared with 514 and 515, respectively, for Feb. 13 and 6. For the first time since last Summer, the index for native products declined slightly from 541 to 538, while that for imported products advanced from 467 to 476.
The foreign exchange market has been more subdued this week and the stabilization fund apparently has not been obliged to operate on any large scale to satisfy foreign exchange requirements.

A youth who fired a blank cartridge pistol on a dare last night caused confusion in the audience of the Dyckman Theatre, at 552 West 207th Street. About half the 1,200 persons in the movie house ran to the street, but none was injured in the rush.

Frank Parker of Spring Lake, N U., the second ranking tennis player of the country, faces the prospect of a real test of his ability on board courts this afternoon when play is resumed in the men's national indoor championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

SOME weeks ago Herr Doktor Al Schacht, the noted baseball starch and protein menumaker, gave his eye-witness version of the famous collision between Ty Cobb and Billy Evans on a warm day in the Washington ball park.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, was 82.3 on Feb. 24, compared with 81.5 a fortnight before, 81 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The tax research staff of the Twentieth Century Fund reported yesterday that a reduction in the Federal debt of from $1,800,000,000 to $3,500,000,000 will be possible in a single year under the present revenue system "if taxable incomes return to the levels reported for the extremely prosperous year of 1928."

Robert Easton Irwin, veteran theatrical press agent and company manager, died yesterday morning his residence, 155 East Thirtyfourth Street, of cardiac asthma, from which he had long been a sufferer. He was 67 years old. Two sons, Godfrey and Robert, and a sister, Elizabeth Irwin, survive.

President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court is an "impeachment" by indirection of the justices over 70, the Rev. Dr. Edmund A. Walsh, S. J., dean of the Georgetown University School of Foreign Affairs, declared today.

Retirement, .effective today, of two officers of the Consolidated Edison Company, was announced yesterday. They are Joseph F. Becker, vice president in charge of electric sales, and Malcolm M. Graham, assistant treasurer of the company.

Those who believe that man is too small in comparison with the immeasurable universe to receive the attention of God should remember that the infinitesimal electron is said by scientists to be the basis of the cosmos, the Very Rev. Dr. E. Frank Salmon, dean of Christ Church Cathedral, Ottawa, Canada, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the past three weeks:

Of the many Democratic victory dinners to be held Thursday evening throughout the country, in approximately 1,200 communities, the one with the oddest setting will be that which will be held jointly by supporters of President Roosevelt in Thurston and Mason Counties, State of Washington, which lie on opposite sides of an inlet of Puget Sound.

An interesting and unusual program was offered last night by the Durieux Chamber Music Ensemble, conducted by William Durieux, at the second of its three concerts of the season at the MacDowell Club. Louise Stallings, mezzo-soprano, was the assisting artist.

Howard Hughes, American high-speed transcontinental flier, and Jean Batten, New Zealand girl who made a record-breaking solo flight from England to New Zealand, were declared winners of the Harmon international trophies today as the outstanding aviators of 1936.
Steneh bombs temporarily halted today but failed to break up a meeting launching a drive by the Committee for Industrial Organization to enlist more than 7,500 carpet workers in four plants here.

Johns Hopkins University announced today that to avoid the evils of commercialism in collegiate sports it would abolish all paid admissions and "neither pay guarantees to visiting teams nor * * * accept guarantees when its teams play away from home."

The American Smelting and Refining Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net income of $17,131,036, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $6.85 a share on the common stock, compared with $13,768,153, or $5.01 a share, earned in 1935.

Nan O'Reilly, golf editor-of The New York Evening Journal, who was the wife of Silas M. Newton of Essex House, 130 Central Park South, died at midnight Saturday in the Doctors Hospital, after a two days' illness, of an intestinal ailment complicated by a weak heart. She was 41 years old.

Miss Margaret Schieffelin Pardee and Miss Margaret MacKenzie Treadway head a group of debutantes of this season who will act as manikins in the fashion revue entitled "A Century's Looking Glass in Fashion," to be given during the luncheon hour March 30 in the Louis Sherry Room at Sher ry's for the benefit of the West Side Thrift Shop.

The most elaborate offerings of last night's opera concert at the Metropolitan were the second act of "The Barber of Seville," given in its entirety in costume, and the character ballet, "The Bat," danced by the American Ballet Ensemble. Besides the Rossini excerpt mentioned, the "scenes intimes" included a duet from the third act of "Lohengrin."

Louis Adamic has returned from a two months' stay in Guatemala, bringing with him the nearly completed script of a new book of nonfiction entitled "The House in Antigua," This is the story of a 300year-old Spanish colonial dwelling in which he lived while in Guatemala.
Stocks irregularly lower on week in less active trading; turnover, 9,953,220 shares. United States Government bonds irregular, Polish loans weak, corporate issues steady; transactions, $57,986,000.

The twentieth anniversary of the clergymen's pension system of the Protestant Episcopal Church was celebrated in Episcopal churches throughout the nation yesterday. The system, as now administered, became effective twenty years ago last midnight.

On the eve of Senate consideration of the Pittman permanent neutrality resolution, drastic amendment of this and the House resolution sponsored by Representative Sam D. McReynolds of Tennessee was demanded by the National Council for Prevention of War. The council,

The total bill during the next five years for British rearmament, including the annual upkeep of the army, the navy and the air force, may reach [Pound]3,000,000,000 or more if the international situation gets worse, according to the estimates of some observers here.

John Marchiando, organizer for the United Rubber Workers of America, a unit of John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization, announced today that a majority of employes of the Thermoid Rubber Company here have enrolled and that a conference with company officials will be asked this week.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has developed tires made of rayon cords, instead of the traditional cotton fabrics, for bus and truck operations, according to an announcement by P. W. Litchfield, president.
The Hamburg of the Hamburg American Line sailed at 6:45 P. M. yesterday for the Channel ports. She was to have departed at midnight Saturday, but had been delayed by storms on the voyage here.

While the Municipal Art Society heartily endorses the pending Wagner Housing Bill and proposed changes in the State Multiple Dwellings Law, it feels that other steps must be taken to eradicate the city's slums.

Dr. Frank Conrad, assistant chief engineer of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, East Pittsburgh, Pa., is the winner of the 1936 Lamme Medal of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, it was announced yesterday.

Appointment of four new members of the Mayor's Committee on City Planning was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. They are Charles G. Meyer, Mrs. William P. Earle Jr., and Professor Joseph D. McGoldrick, all former members of the Charter Revision Commission, and Stanley M. Isaacs, president of the United Neighborhood Houses.

This week's return of the Bank of France shows the bill portfolio at 9,139,000,000 francs, against 9,100,000,000 on Feb. 12, which exceeds the figure of the previous month by about 1,000,000,000 francs.

An unforeseen result of the Social Security Act may be that middle-class families of moderate means will be unable to keep a maid, Ruth E. Finley writes in the current issue of The Woman Republican, publication of the Women's Division of the Republican State Committee, under the title:

A bad-tempered steer that broke loose near Newtown, Pa., yesterday morning and then swam the Delaware River to New Jersey was killed this afternoon at Irven Heights, near here, as it charged a State trooper, who was one of five policemen who were gunning for the animal.
The German wholesale price index for Feb. 17 stood at 105.5 against 105.6 on Feb. 10.

Donald Douglas, president of the Douglas Aircraft Corporation, announced tonight that its plant at Santa Monica would reopen tomorrow morning, but that employes under indictment for participation in a sit-down strike, which caused its closing last Tuesday, were barred from re-employment.
Ragnhild Hveger, Danish swimmer, claimed two new women's world swimming records today. She swam 880 yards in 11:16.1 and 1,000 meters in 14:12.4 in an international competition.

For the first time this Winter, operas by Puccini will be offered at the Metropolitan during the twelfth week of its season. That composer's "Madama Butterfly" will be staged next Monday night and his "La Boheme" on the following Friday night. Franca Somigli,

Madison Av., n. e. cor. 86th St., 100.8x62.2; Seymour Mark, referee, to McComb Estates Corp., 7 Hanover St.; mortgage, $611,000; foreclosure ($50). Same property; McComb Estates Corp. to Church Business Corp., 150 5th Av.; mortgage, $611,000 ($155).

Shorts and speculators were good buyers of lard here on weak spots last week, absorbing the offerings of near-by, and distant futures as well as considerable cash lard. Evening-up of the trade yesterday brought a fair recovery. It is estimated that

Reopening of the wage provisions in existing agreements affecting some 50,000 building service employes appeared probable yesterday as a result of action by Ben Golden, industrial arbitrator, in the agreement between Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes Union and the Midtown and Penn Zone Realty Owners Associations.

Jacob Allen Metzger, with the legal office of the State Department since 1914, died today at his home here. He was 57 years old. As assistant to the legal adviser of the State Department, Mr. Metzger at his death was agent for the United States in the pending arbitration with Canada with respect to the Trail Smelter in British Columbia.

At the first independent convention of the Women's League of the United Synagogue ever to be held, 200 delegates today heard their president, Mrs. Samuel Spiegel of New York City plead for "social security" for all rabbis in the United States.
Joe McCarthy, manager of the world champion Yankees, arrived tonight with five of his squad from the North to open the 1937 training campaign of the Ruppert Rifles at Hpggins Field tomorrow.

Renewing his attack on the antireligious policies of the Nazi Government, but disavowing any animus against the German people, the Rev. John S. Kennedy declared in his sermon yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue between Fifty-ninth and Sixtieth Streets, that he always would denounce the "despiritualization of youth."

The first foreigner to have entered the Communist areas of Northern Shensi province since the Sian rebellion arrived in Nanking yesterday and gave the writer his impression of conditions behind the government lines in Communist territory. Harry Dunham,

Mrs. Edson Akin Starks of this city and Red Bank, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Wallace Knott, to Walter Edward Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Jones of Canton, Ohio.

Last night's decision of the Mexican Supreme Court declaring void two leases held by the Mexican Eagle Oil Company, a subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell, is held here to set a precedent for future cases.

The Kimberley Dynamiters ranked tonight as world kings of amateur hockey. The squad that won the Allan Cup last Spring concluded its undefeated march through the world amateur championship last night with a 2-1 victory in overtime over Switzerland.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Bogert and their daughter, Eleanor, 15 years old, climbed down a ladder to safety early this morning after fire had trapped them on the second floor of their home at 568 Fairmount Avenue.

Old Mory of the Montauk Club, chef to one of Brooklyn's oldest and proudest institutions for thirty years, made his debut last night as a guest of the house committee and sampled some of the dishes through which he has given satisfaction for three decades. The club is at Eighth Avenue and Lincoln Place.

Mrs. Grace Holt Reed, widow of Ralph D. Reed of Manchester, N. H., and sister of President Hamilton Holt of Rollins College, died, in her sixty-third year, in an Orlando (Fla.) hospital early this morning of a heart ailment.

Meyer Adelman, C. I. O. leader sought since Friday was arrested in a Kenosha hotel tonight on a warrant charging unlawful conspiracy. Police Captain Frank Schneeberger said that Mr.-Adelman was arrested by Kenosha police on an Illinois warrant.
Everybody's Thrift Shop will hold its annual election of officers Wednesday morning at the home of Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Captain Harold Dale Hinckley, United States Coast Guard, retired, died of a sudden heart attack today. His age was 59. He retired in 1934 after thirty-seven years in all branches of the service, including the superintendency of the Coast Guard Academy at New London, Conn.

Deborah Vivien Freeman-Mitford, 17 years old, the youngest daughter of Lord and Lady Redesdale. has run away to Spain in an attempt to marry her 18-year-old cousin, Esmond Romilly, a nephew of Winston Churchill.

At a special meeting yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt, the labor committee of the Progressive City Committee demanded that minimum wage legislation be broadened to include every category of wage-earners.

Dr. Thomas M. Ballet, dean emeritus of the School of Pedagogy of New York University, will observe his eighty-fifth birthday today. There will be no celebration, just a gathering of friends for dinner, because, Dr. Balliet explained, "I'm not old enough to make a fuss over."

The annual report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for 1936 represents a new accounting procedure for the Bell System, undertaken to meet the requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Imperturbable as ever, scarcely looking to the right or left as she was paraded up and down the ring, Champion Wolvey Noel of Clairedale stood stock still tonight as George S. Thomas pronounced her best in the thirteenth annual exhibition of the Kennel Club of Buffalo.

Decisive action on the Federal Child Labor Amendment is possible in the Legislature this week. The Kleinfeld resolution for ratification, which has passed the Senate, is due to be reported out of the Assembly Judiciary Committee Tuesday and friends and foes of the resolution are gathering their forces for a showdown. The vote, however, may go over to next week.

Eight persons, trapped in the two upper floor apartments by a smoky fire in a stationery. store on the ground floor of a brick building at 56 Warburton Avenue, were carried down ladders by firemen at 7:30 this morning. Patrolman William Bell was felled by the smoke, but was revived and remained on duty.

The heavy clouds that have hung over the security markets here since the announcement of the government's big defense plans finally are dispersing, and the rather shattering blow that was dealt to confidence is losing its influence slowly.

The New York Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, yesterday defeated the Scots Americans of Newark, 2 to 1, at Starlight Park and qualified for the Eastern final in the annual Challence Cup competition of the United States Football Association.

Three works by Brahms made up the program put forward at Town Hall yesterday afternoon by the New Friends of Music. The most important of the offerings was the great quintet in G, Op. 111, which many authorities place first among the master's ensemble compositions.
The Athletics won their first exhibition game of the season today, coming from behind with a fourrun drive in the seventh to score a 14-11 victory over the Comintra semi-pro team.

Loans of $117,000 and $105,000 have been placed through Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., with the Investors Syndicate Title Guaranty Co. on the two apartment houses being erected by Jacob Janos at the southwest corner of Maran PL and Cruger Av., the Bronx.

Plans were filed on Saturday in the Brooklyn Building Department for forty one-family brick homes on Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets by I. Kallich, architect. The aggregate cost will be $180,000. Bay Ridge Homes, Inc., S. Berman, president, 4,915 Seventeenth Avenue. is the owner.

The top price for hogs here last week was $10.50 a hundredweight, paid on Monday. In the previous week the best price was $10.40, while a year ago $10.60 was top. The average for the week was $10.05, against $10.10 the previous week and $10.05 a year ago.
Glenn A. Valentine's underthe-house lion hunt ended abruptly today with the Albuquerque machinist in full retreat, and Peaches, five-foot yearling cougar, still complete master of the situation.

Carl Gallub, 56 years old, of 109-58 153d Street, Jamaica, Queens, a mechanic employed by the Long Island Railroad, and his wife, Pauline, 43, were arrested and booked at the Jamaica police station at about 11:30 o'clock last night on a charge of felonious assault. Detective Charles Wrage,

ARTHUR JAMES BALFOUR, 1848-1930, by his niece, Blanche E. C. Dugdale. (Putnam. two volumes, $10.) A full-length study of the first Earl of Balfour. LUCIFER IN PND LABE, by Samuel Rogers. (Little, Brown, $2.50.)

The restrictive regulations that the Roosevelt administration has placed upon Wall Street have driven so much business to London that stock brokers here jokingly describe Throgmorton Street, where United States securities are largely handled, as "the New York exchange."

Although Great Britain's steel industry is producing at its full capacity and at the highest level in its history, an unprecedented volume of unfilled orders is being carried over. Demands for steel continues to run much ahead of supply, which can be increased only as productive capacity is enlarged and this is a slow process.

Further tributes to Captain Bernard W. St. D. Thomson, whose death from pneumonia Friday night ended his twenty-one years as sports editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES. were paid yesterday by leaders in sports and journalism. Some of the tributes follow:

Mrs. Emma Avery Pendleton, who had not missed the Sunday morning service at All Souls Universalist Church, Brooklyn, in fiftyseven years, died yesterday in the Peck Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. A son, Frank A. Pendleton of Brooklyn, and a daughter, Mrs. Enid P. Hyde of Stonington, Conn., survive. Mrs.

Renting a room with their last $3, two women, one about 60 years old and the other about 25, apparently mother and daughter, ended their lives by gas poisoning yesterday morning in a rooming house at 404 West Twenty-third Street.

Three hundred Catholics fortified themselves in a church in this town in the State of Veracruz and continued prayers despite anti-Catholic demonstrations ordered by the C. T. M., or Mexican Labor Federation, throughout the State today.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

The greatest tribute an audience can pay an artist was earned by Eugene List, 18-year-old pianist, at his recital in Town Hall yesterday. Instead of rushing to the exits after the final number of the program, the entire gathering remained seated, too deeply impressed to depart until the extraordinarily talented youth had concluded the last of his encores.

Mrs. Fenton. Taylor has arranged a Spring fashion show to be known as "Mother Marries Off Her Debutante," which will be held today at the New York Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, under the auspices of the arts and interests committee, of which Mrs. Jarvis Cromwell is chairman.

The dance committee of the Eden Valley Social Club of 618 Broadway, Manhattan, was arrested this afternoon and each was fined $10 here for chopping down five white pines and one hemlock about twenty-five feet from the pavement of the Bronx River Parkway Extension.

Major General Dennis E. Nolan, retired, director of State participation for the World's Fair of 1939, predicted yesterday that participation by States in the fair will far exceed that of any previous exposition. The largest foreign participation is also expected.

Dr. John Wyckoff, dean of the New York University College of Medicine, announced yesterday that ninety-three of the 144 members of the senior class had already been appointed to interneships in thirtythree hospitals.

The Public Works Administration since it was set up in 1933 has put into circulation more than $3,500,000,000 in recovery dollars and has created more than 7,000,000,000 man-hours of labor, the administration reported today.

Housing properties in Manhattan and the Bronx formed the bulk of the real estate turnover reported over the week-end in the city. Multi-family buildings in the Yorkville area of Manhattan proved attractive to investors.

Yarnall, Stetser, Malone Co. will start operations today as an investment banking house in Philadelphia. Officers are J. V. Yarnall, president; F. B. Stetser, vice president, and A. J. Malone, secretary and treasurer.

The Anti-Nazi department of the American League Against War and Fascism last night was sponsor of a mass meeting in the Yorkville Casino at 210 East Eighty-sixth Street to commemorate the fourth anniversary of the Reichstag fire trial. About 700 persons attended,
Reflecting a slackening in refunding operations, offerings of new stocks and bonds in February showed a decline from January. Both classes of securities, however, were larger than in February, 1936.

Order and reorder activity in the wholesale apparel market here was heavy last week. Dresses moved well in all price groups, with the bulk of business going to costume ensembles and sheer street dresses. Deliveries tightened in the coat and suit market.

Bishop H. H. Font of Indianapolis predicted today at the annual convention of the Anti-Saloon League of America that prohibition would return, "probably in a shorter time than we are prone to realize."
Professor Alfred Remy, linguist and musician, a resident of Bronxville for many years, died Friday night at the Lenox Hill Hospital, after a long illness. His age was 66.

When detectives of the West 152d Street station arrested three men late last night at the Convent Field Club, 1,984 Amsterdam Avenue, on a charge of assault brought by a young married woman a score of others, incensed at the arrests, attacked the policemen, knocking one of them unconscious.

The floods of March, 1936, caused the Pennsylvania Railroad a loss of $7,641,858, it was announced yesterday. This was the chief cause for a reduction of $11,801,314 in the company's profit-and-loss surplus in 1936 from $184,532,669 to $172,731,355.

The stock market here this week was dull and irregular, with declines predominating. Contrasted to slight advances in banks, shipping construction and non-ferrous metal shares and substantial gains in rubber and linoleum stocks were reactions in steel, coal, chemical, electrical, textile and potash stocks. Temporary bull.

In order to insure priority for State orders, the Steel Supervision Board has directed producers of steel to return to customers all orders for semi-finished products and rolled materials which cannot be filled before April 30.

In two particulars the program given by Artur Rodzinski with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon differed from that of last Thursday and Friday. The first 'was the opening with Weber's poetical overture to "Oberon."
The process begun last year of cutting down State farms for the benefit of collectives received fresh impetus today.

Harry Moles, 17 years old, a painter's helper of 53-52 Seventythird Street, Elmhurst, Queens, who was arrested in a stolen automobile yesterday after radio policemen had pursued the car for half a mile, admitted later, according to the police, that he had received a suspended sentence in Queens County Court last Friday after pleading guilty to an automobile theft.

Hope for continued peace in the Pacific was expressed by representatives of the United States and Japanese Governments yesterday at a memorial service to George Washington and Commodore Matthew Calbraith Perry in St. Mark's Church in-the-Bouwerie, 234 East Eleventh Street. Eighteen relatives of Commodore Perry attended the services.

The Long Island University A. A. quintet and City College's varsity were among the victors in the quartet of first-round games that inaugurated the Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball championship at the Hippodrome yesterday.

Walter Le Jeune Hayward of 160-09 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, Queens, night supervisor of the Press Wireless station at Little Neck, L. I., died Saturday in the Flushing Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 30.
The Brooklyn Hispanos defeated the Irish-Americans by 1--0 in the Eastern semi-final round of the National Challenge Cup competition at Clark's Field today.

A $50,000 fire early today swept four stores on Main Street. The blaze started in the Betty Shop, a women's dress store, and spread to the adjoining electrical appliance store of A. Guldi Son before being discovered by Village Patrolman Ross Smith.

One hundred and seven contracts involving $4,979,309 were awarded by thirteen government agencies under the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Feb. 25, the Department of Labor announced today. Contracts let by the navy accounted for about two-fifths of the dollar volume.
Representative Henry E. Stubbs (Dem., Calif.) died today after a three-month illness. He was 55 years old. He was serving his third term in Congress, to which he was first elected in 1932.

The Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners has published another appeal for contributions to pay the cost of an appeal to the United States Supreme Court by Pedro Albizu Campos, president of the Nationalist party, and others whose sentences for sedition were recently confirmed by the Circuit Court of Appeals.

Recovering quickly from the shock of its defeat by the Bronx-Internationals in the second round, the Manhattan Chess Club, championship defender in the Metropolitan Chess League, came back strong at the expense of the West Side group in the third round yesterday, winning by the one-sided score of 9 1/2--1/2.
Charles D. McAvoy, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, died of a heart, attack today in St. Francis Hospital, Miami Beach, Fla. He was in his fifty-ninth year.
Representatives of 4,100 coal miners decided tonight to call a general strike tomorrow in protest against the dismissal of 146 miners who staged a two-day "suicide strike" underground this week.

Subscriptions for $100,000 by Armour Co. and $77,000 by the Commodore Hotel were included in a list of purchases of New York World's Fair 4 per cent debentures announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the exposition's bond sales committee.

Australia's first innings was cormpleted today shortly after resumption of play in the fifth and deciding test cricket match with England. The Australians added 11 runs to their Saturday score for a total of 604.
The text' of the radio address made tonight by Senator Copeland, attacking the President's Supreme Court plan, which was telephoned from here to station WFBL at Syracuse, follows:

Ninety-eight American writers, in a joint statement issued yesterday said the neutrality policy of the United States should not prevent condemnation by private citizens of the "military faction which with its foreign allies is making war on the legally and democratically elected republican government of Spain."

Ben Howe, chairman of the City Fusion party, announced yesterday the selection of Dr. Moses Benmosche as New York County Chairman. Dr. Benmosche will succeed Beverly Myles, who has resigned the chairmanship but will continue as a member of the city advisory committee.
Consolidated Trimming Corp., in 332 E. 28th St.; Robert E. Johnson, accounting, In 250 W. 57th St.; Robert Thomas Pollock, in 570 Lexington Av.; Cushman Wakefield. Inc.. broker.

Because of a serious oversight by whoever is held responsible for the dissemination of Florida sunshine and warm breezes, tomorrow's opening workout of the new Dodgers is threatened by a freeze out or washout-or both.

Ninety-eight American writers, in a joint statement issued yesterday said the neutrality policy of the United States should not prevent condemnation by private citizens of the "military faction which with its foreign allies is making war on the legally and democratically elected republican government of Spain."

Ben Howe, chairman of the City Fusion party, announced yesterday the selection of Dr. Moses Benmosche as New York County Chairman. Dr. Benmosche will succeed Beverly Myles, who has resigned the chairmanship but will continue as a member of the city advisory committee.

Scripps-Howard units of the American Newspaper Guild were advised yesterday by the ScrippsHoward Guild Advisory Committee to give the Scripps-Howard management until March 12 "to make up its mind" on questions of tradeunion principle involved in pending negotiations for a guild contract.

A delegation of Queens residents will confer with representatives of Mayor La Guardia within a week on the administration of relief as a result of charges made last week by Borough President Harvey that the local relief bureau is contaminated by Communistic influences.
The fate of the Aberhart government was entrusted today to the men and women of Alberta who elected it, the first Social Credit Administration in the world, in 1935.

Giving up petty things for Lent is merely ministering to self-love and a smug feeling of righteousness, Dr. Charles T. Cook of London, editor of The Christian, said yesterday in a sermon at the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

After a week of fighting for the possession of Oviedo, in Northern Spain, government forces strongly entrenched themselves today on the outer circle of the city and are now preparing for an assault on the Northern Railway Station on the northwestern side, which is the key to entry to the inner part of the city by the broad avenue, Calle de Uruia.

Legislation to increase the legal responsibility of labor unions if the Wagner Labor Relations Act is to remain on the statute -.books. was urged by the industrial committee of the Merchants Association in a report made public yesterday.

As the struggle over the President's court reorganization proposals moves into its fourth week there are no signs that either side is making appreciable gains over the position of a week ago or that a compromise is considered either by the President or his opponents.

Rose Bampton, who has recently elected to sing as a soprano rather than a mezzo, gave a song recital last night in Town Hall. The results, in this writer's estimation, fully justified her course. That there may be places in the voice to make even, in order to complete the readjustment of the registers, was at some moments indicated.

Francis J. Littig, Democratio leader of the fourth zone in the First Assembly District, Queens, was sworn in yesterday as Acting Postmaster of Long Island City, Queens, at the Postoffice, Twentyfirst Street and Forty-Sixth Avenue. He was sworn in by Postal Inspector John Criss. Induction ceremonies will take place at the postoffice at 10 A. M. today,

A conflict- between two kinds of intolerance--divine truth and force--will divide the world of the future, because the present world craves the intolerant and can choose only those philosophies, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University warned yesterday in a Lenten sermon in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Although the German proposal regarding the Straits Convention is not freely discussed in Turkish official circles, the general feeling seems to be that it is a blunder of German diplomacy.
The New York Council on Economics asked the New York City Civil Service Commission to remove age barriers in civil service positions in which youth is non-essential.
Paul E. McGowan has been appointed sales manager in charge of the new district office opened recently by the General Foods Corporation in Jacksonville, Fla.

It has been realized only during the last decade that there is any way to restore fish other than replanting them, says the technical committee of the General Wildlife Federation, in discussing a program for fish research.

The Rev. Father V. Ducattillon, assistant prior of the Dominican Convent in Paris, said yesterday in a Lenten sermon at the French Church of St, Vincent do Paul,Twenty-third Street west of Sixth Avenue, that the true Christian does not stifle his intelligence in order to believe.
President Frank Aydelotte of Swarthmore College announced today the award of the five open scholarships and the alumnae scholarship award for women students of the class of 1941.

Weakness on the New York Stock Exchange in some recent sessions probably was due chiefly to the fear that the Federal Government might take steps to penalize foreign security purchases, but French financial circles feel that such purchases are difficult to curb.

Automobile fatalities throughout the country met an all-time high for January with 3,050 riders and pedestrians killed, the National Safety Council announced today. The month's death toll was 20 per cent more than in January, 1936, and exceeded by 200 the previous high established in January, 1934.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,849,519,000. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

Recent liberal buying of rye for cash and future delivery was said to have been fairly satisfied here last week for the time being at least. May rye finished at $1.05 1/4 a bushel, a net decline of 3 3/4 cents from the previous week. July lost 2 3/4 cents, closing at 98 cents, while the September declined 1 cent, with the close at 88 3/4 cents.

The establishment of a comprehensive rapid transit system linking communities of Northern New Jersey with midtown Manhattan and Staten Island is recommended by the Port of New York Authority in a report to be submitted today to Governor Harold G. Hoffman and the New Jersey Legislature. The Initial cost is estimated at $187,500, 000.

The newspaper La Razon publishes today a report that former War Minister Plinio Mendoza Mira and former Minister of Agriculture Guillermo London Mejia are planning a country-wide campaign for the nomination of Dario Echandia, former Government Minister, for the Presidency.
Frank Campbell came close to a perfect score in Class B and Mrs. Helen Hill fared only a shade less well in Class X in the weekly dinghy regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club today.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Long Island University and Fordham shared honors as the outstanding college basketball teams in the metropolitan district as the result of outstanding performances last week. The Blackbirds trounced Manhattan on Wednesday and subdued Brooklyn College on Saturday, although extended somewhat in the second half, while the Rams scored a fine victory over Manhattan on Saturday.

Patrolmen were stationed in front of thirty-eight motion-picture theatres in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday as police pressed the investigation of the tear-gas barrage on the upper West Side Saturday night which injured about thirty persons.

Building fund subscriptions that total $11,250 have been received by the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, which will cooperate with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in the development of Tanglewood as a festival center.

In his report of the year's medical relief work, Dr. H. Jackson Davis, assistant director of the local health administration of the State Department of Health, reported that continuance of adequate medical relief had enabled thousands of needy persons to return to private employment.

Ghe government today-the fifth anniversary-of the founding of Manchukuo as an "independent" State-promulgated a law governing the imperial succession. It makes Pu Chieh, Japanesetrained younger brother of Emperor Kang Teh, heir presumptive to "the orchid throne."

If Carl Merner had hopes of sneaking in very quietly with his Columbia track team and then stalking off with the Intercollegiate A.A A.A. championship when the college classic is staged in Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday, he had better revise his plans. The Lion coach tipped his hand in the National A. A. U. championships last Saturday.

FROM the memoirs of dead or aged Englishmen who were at Eton with Arthur James Balfour in the early Eighteen Sixties, one learns that he was known to one schoolboy set as "Clara" and to another as "Miss Nancy." After his uncle,
Flying Officer David Llewellyn abandoned his attempt today to fly from England to Capetown and return in four days, after a forced landing in the Nubian desert.
The text of Samuel Rosoff's statement last night, denouncing charges against him in the Redwood murder case, follows:

The 100th anniversary of the birth of Dwight L. Moody, worldfamous American evangelist and founder of Christian schools, was commemorated yesterday afternoon at a mass meeting attended by nearly 4,000 men and women in Mecca Temple, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Dr. Walter S. Reed, for thirtyseven years a practicing physician, and former Mayor of this city and former member of the New Jersey State Assembly, died today at the home of Commissioner William L. Ousterman, Hastings Place, Monmouth Beach, where he had been ill for the last month.

The American Writing Paper Company, Inc., following confirmation of its plan of, reorganization under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act, will give today to holders of its first-mortgage 6 per cent bonds and certificates of deposit therefor, prior privilege to subscribe for $200,000 of general-mortgage bonds and 40,000 shares of common stock of the American Writing Paper Corporation, the successor company.
The City College varsity baseball team will play twenty games this Spring, according to the schedule released yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.

The fifteenth anniversary of the ministry of the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street, was celebrated at the church yesterday morning.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller profoundly stirred Protestant Berlin today when he publicly announced in two churches that the secretary of the National Confessional Synod, the Rev. Mr. Wiesler, had been discovered hanging in his cell at Sachsenhausen concentration camp.

Further evidence of Austria's resentment against Italy because of her hostile attitude over the Hapsburg question-which incidentally gave Germany the only satisfaction she got out of Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath's recent visit-was furnished by today's Reichspost in a small paragraph.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Mexico the Mysterious," James C. Sawders. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "The New York State Debt and Taxes," George R. Fearon, Mrs. George A. Wyeth.

Leonard Romagna, sailing Jenny, and Everett Morris, at the helm of Dampants, tied for first place today in the Class D races that featured the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's sailing dinghy regatta. Each scored 28 points.

Turpentine steady, 42c; no sales; receipts 72 barrels; shipments, 669 barrels; stock, 24,409 barrels. Resin steady; no sales; receipts 504; shipments, 2,559; stock. 56.861. Quote: B, $8.25; D, $8.65; E, $8.95; F, G, H, I, $9.50; K, M, $9.65; N. $9.75; WG, $9.80; WW, X, $11.50.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence V. Price of Montclair, N. J., of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss-Jeanne Price, to A. Richardson Goodlatte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Goodlatte of Upper Montclair, formerly of Passaic. The wedding will take place April 15.

Miss Cecilia Colledge, British and European titleholder, held the lead tonight at the end of the first stage of the women's world figure skating championship. Miss Audrey Peppe of New York ranked last in the field of twelve.

Fern Rodolph, 20-year-old stenographer, tonight ended a lone, one-day sit-down strike, apparently without winning the $10 weekly pay rise she demanded. Miss Rodolph, blonde graduate of a business college, spent the day on the floor of her employer's office. She insisted she should have the wage increase, because she had "more responsibilities than other girls.

Supplemental tax proceeding in which the income on trust of $5,066.752 for the benefit of the widow, Annie K. Belding, was held taxable. Appraisers figured probable income at $2,036,587 and fixed tax at $78.000. Principal of trust passes to the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children on death of widow. Gifford. Woody, Carter Hays, attorneys, 1 Wall St.

By turning back the Harvard Club, 3-2, last night in a play-off match at the Columbia University Club, the New York A. C. team captured the Class C championship of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.
The Board of Aldermen adopted a resolution yesterday setting the basic tax rate on real estate for 1937 at $2.64 for $100 of assessed valuation, a drop of one point from the 1936 rate.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Feb. 24, shows increases for the week of $86,000,000 in total loans and investments, $34,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $18,000,000 in time deposits, and decreases of. $41,000,000 in government deposits, $65,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, $115,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $42,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Testimony yesterday in the Securities and Exchange Commission hearing in the case of Charles C. Wright and nine other respondents charged with having manipulated stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Company, Ltd.,
The Brooklyn Chapter of Hadassah raised $19,000 yesterday for health institutions in Palestine at the twenty-fifth anniversary luncheon held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Lord Aberconway, chairman of John Brown, Ltd., Glasgow shipbuilding company; the Hon. Joan Eyres Monsell, daughter of the former First Lord of the Admiralty; Mrs. Belloc Lowndes, English novelist, and Max Schmeling, heavyweight fighter, are among the passengers due tonight from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

Twenty-five battery candidates for the Princeton baseball team, seventeen pitchers and eight catchers, reported to Coach Bill Clarke in the University Field cage today and spent forty-five minutes limbering up in the first practice.

The discontinuance of the processing tax on sugar and benefit payments to the producers of cane and beet sugars has created problems that make necessary the re-enactment of a sugar quota system embodying the principles of the Jones-Costigan act,

The American Labor party, which has officially praised President Roosevelt's court reorganization program as "essential to economic, social and political progress," began yesterday a campaign in this city to obtain at least 150,000 signatures on a petition urging Congress to support the project.

Jesse G. Morgan, New York real estate broker who was widely known as a real estate management director, died today of pneumonia at Mountainside Hospital. Mr. Morgan lived in Upper Montclair. His age was 55.

Spurred on by a new vision of the importance of conservation to the security, health and happiness of the American people, 1,200 delegates to the North American Wildlife Conference today tackled the job of welding a nation-wide organization to arouse public opinion behind the campaign to save and restore natural resources.
Lara Keys, famous for his habit of stopping in the stretch, changed his tactics today and came from behind to win the mile and a sixteenth feature for $1,500 players at the Fair Grounds.
The House and Senate adjourned today out of respect to the late Representative Henry E. Stubbs of California, who died in Walter Reed Hospital here yesterday after a long illness.
H. S. Gans, attorney for the first-mortgage bondholders' protective committee, explained today the major provisions of its plan to reorganize the New York, Westchester Boston Railway.
Bit by bit the groundwork of the five-year plan sponsored by Ducks Unlimited is taking shape. The huge task of organizing committees of duck hunters in every State is progressing steadily.

Profiteering in the Japanese munitions industry was alleged in the budget sub-committee of the House of Representatives yesterday when Ichiro Kono of the Seiyukai (chief minority party) declared Japan was

A mortgage holder's proposal to make the Philadelphia home of Edgar Allan Poe a rooming house was blocked at a Sheriff's sale today by Richard Gimbel, president of the Richard Gimbel Foundation for Literary Research.
President Roosevelt's fondness for salt fish was not proof against finding it on the luncheon table before him four days in succession, Mrs. Roosevelt told her press conference this morning.

H. Lloyd Thomas's Royal Mail continued to rule the favorite at 10 to 1 today in the latest call-over of odds for the Grand National Steeplechase or March 19. J. B. Snow's Delachance, at 15 to 1, was best regarded among American-owned entrants figuring in the day's betting.

Rookie Sylvanus Apps, Connie Smythe's candidate for the Calder Cup, is making a brilliant race for another National Hockey League honor-the league's scoring leadership-and he's just one point away from it now.

The fine riding of the French team of Emile Ignat and Emile Diot featured the going at Madison Square Garden last night as the thirteen teams remaining in the sixday bicycle race entered their second stretch of twenty-four hours.
Dr. Knud Rasmussen, the Danish explorer, has left behind him as vivid a chapter on the life of the Greenland Eskimo as one may hope to find. "The Wedding of Palo,"
Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin today "welcomed" the collaboration of the United States in reducing tariff barriers, but refused to commit his government to active steps in this direction.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt grasped time by the forelock and celebrated last night the coming of age of John Roosevelt, who will be 21 on March 16.

Samuel L. Deitsch of Deitsch Weraba Coppola was re-elected president of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., at a meeting of the board of governors of the organization at the Hotel New Yorker last night.
The Rev. Dr. Edward Miller Jefferys announced today his resignation as rector of historic St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Gerald L. K. Smith, preacher-organizer in Huey Long's Louisiana dictatorship, formally launched his latest movement, the "Committee of 1,000,000," at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. The committee is an anti-Communist organization, so called because, as Mr. Smith said, "a million" of his friends wanted him to form it.

On an increase of about $2,275,000 in consolidated gross earnings in 1936, compared with 1935, the New England Power Association and subsidiaries will show an improvement of nearly $950,000, or approximately 20 per cent, in consolidated net earnings before dividends of the association,

Samuel Heller, an importer or precious stones, died Sunday in St. Francis Hospital, Miami Beach, Fla., according to an announcement made here last night. Mr. Heller, who resided in White Plains, N. Y., came here from Moscow in 1888.

The time for deposit of bonds of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad, a subsidiary of the Erie Railroad, has been extended to March 31. Under the plan proposed by the management the maturity of the first mortgage 5s, due Jan. 1, 1937, and of the second mortgage 4 1/2s, due Feb. 1,

Automotive advertising in newspapers, magazines, radio and outdoor, should reach a seven-year peak this month, as the entire industry is swinging into larger production schedules, according to comment here yesterday.

The Italian flag went up and the British standard came down in an "incident" here today. The British Minister ordered his country's flag taken down after the Italian banner had been hoisted on the chief flagpole at the Hotel Costa Rica.

Eugene J. Finnegan, Assistant District Attorney, requested Bernard M. Sandler, lawyer, yesterday to appear before him today for questioning in his investigation of the recent $500,000 breach of promise suit by Peggy Garcia, former night club hat-check girl, against Dave Rubinoff, violinist. Supreme Court Justice Cotillo dismissed the suit last week.
Mr. and Mrs. Martin Grois of this city today observed the fifty-first anniversary of their marriage. They have a daughter, seven sons and fourteen grandchildren.
George J. Shand Jr., former Manhattan College all-around athlete, died early yesterday of pneumonia in St. Elizabeth's Hospital, 689 Fort Washington Avenue, at the age of 28.

Mayor La Guardia renewed his effort to get a $45,000,000 "yardstick power plant" for New York City yesterday after conferring on the plan with Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission.

A group of 150 lots on Goodrich Avenue and Uniondale Road, East Hempstead, L. I., ve been purchased for building by East Hempstead Homesteads, Charles J. Rorech, president. Construction of thirty quarter-acre homesteads has been started with four of the new houses already contracted for, according to Mr. Rorech.
Senator ROBINSON has a particularly hard row to hoe at present. Any diversion from argument to rhetoric to which he treats himself in the Senate should be looked -upon with indulgence.

Owners of the Brook Manufacturing Company installed "comforts of home" in their plant for fifty employes, mostly women, who remained inside over the week-end to avoid possible clashes with workers who were on strike.

The Prudential Life Insurance Company obtained yesterday the award of two issues of railroad equipment-trust certificates, aggregating $6,030,000. For the issue of $3,780,000 of Duluth, Missabe Northern 2 1/2 per cent equipment,

Of the 65,723 prisoners received in State and Federal prisons and reformatories during 1935, the highest ratio was for persons 30 years old, the number gradually declining in the higher age groups, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

Edward O. Shakespeare Jr., an architect, died at his home in Wynnewood last night after a short illness. He was 37 years old. The son of Dr. Edward Oran Shakespeare, who conducted world-wide research in connection with efforts to eliminate yellow fever and cholera, he was educated at St. Luke's School, Cornell University and the University of Pennsylvania.

Mrs. Richard A. Peabody gave a luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Mrs. Benjamin Ward Appleton, Mrs. Arthur Ryle, Mrs. Charles Coster, Mrs. Frank W. Doubleday, Mrs. Henry Wolcott Warner, Mrs. Albert Tilt and Mrs. Robert A. Sands.
Most people here do not expect any immediate retirements of Supreme Court justices now that the Sumners-McCarran Retirement Bill has become law.
After miners had been below ground for thirty-eight hours three of the wives of the men settled the stay-in strike in the North Wallarah colliery on compromise terms.

Ellis Jungman, 53 years old, of 2,125 Ellis Avenue, the Bronx, chairman of the Municipal Board of Examining Plumbers when it was abolished by Mayor La Guardia in 1934 on revelations of grafting, escaped with a $500 fine in General Sessions yesterday on a perjury indictment. He had pleaded guilty.
Votes of most of the 18,500 voting stockholders of the MissouriKansas Pipe Line Company in the election of directors were recorded in Chancery Court today by Albert W. Massey, special master.

Truson, the 300-pound orang-utan Martin Johnson captured in Borneo, died Sunday morning in the Bronx Zoo, less than twenty-four hours after funeral services for the explorer were held in the municipal auditorium at Chanute, Kan.

Defying the frigid weather, Manager Burleigh Grimes of the Dodgers this morning marshaled nearly thirty well-blanketed athletes on Brooklyn Field and gave them two hours of brisk exercise for their first workout.

The names of Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo and Dean and Mrs. Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College head the list of seventy-six patrons and patronesses of the annual college musical revue, the Varsity Show. Justice Cardozo received his Bachelor of Arts degree from Columbia in 1889.

Union labor, fighting for a new code of wages and working conditions, took more than 1,000 workers from Western Ontario furniture factories today and drove into unorganized shops with the intention of doubling the number on strike.
Representative Alfred F. Beiter of New York introduced a bill in the House today to force solvent "racketeers" to pay for their food and lodging while in prison.
Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott received congratulations yesterday from Mayor La Guardia as he celebrated his fifth year as fire chief and commissioner.

With an accompaniment of fisticuffs, the Republican Club of the Ninth Assembly District went on record last night as favoring the renomination of Mayor La Guardia on the Republican ticket. The vote was 30 to 10. It was said to be the first regular Republican district organization in the city to endorse the Mayor.

A reduction in the initial payroll tax to be paid by the railroads under the existing railway pension law from 3.5 per cent to 2.5 per cent is contemplated in a tentative agreement between the managements and labor received by railroad officials here yesterday.

While some objections were being raised tonight as the comprehensive rapid transit plan linking communities of Northern New Jersey with mid-town Manhattan and Staten Island was brought before the Legislature, all concerned agreed that the plan was a definite step toward much needed transit unity.

The Federal Trade Commission and counsel for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, a chainstore grocery concern, locked legal horns here today in a test case of the Robinson-Patman Chain Store Act, passed at the last session of Congress.

Two industrial concerns whose plants are held by sit-down striking members of the United Automobile Workers of America asked for injunctions today against the strikers, terming them "former" employes.

AT the finish of the 1,500-meter run in the A. A. U. indoor championships the other evening it seemed to this observer, hanging breathless over the wall just above the finish line, that Luigi Beccali was an irate Italian. And not without reason. The slim, close-coupled, blackhaired former Olympic champion from the Land of Mussolini took quite a banging-around in the stretch.

Disapproval of President Roosevelt's plan to enlarge the Supreme Court has been voiced by members of the Connecticut State Bar Association in a ratio of 9 to 1. The voting is not yet over, but the total to date is 366 against the proposal and only 39 for it. There were three favoring votes with qualifications and two doubtful votes.

Two Camp Fire girls from Reading, Pa., were honored here yesterday for making one of the winning recreational surveys of their home city. They were guests at a founders' luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria, celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the organization.

Bones of a Revolutionary War soldier, who was honored as an unidentified hero in 1922 by President Warren G. Harding, General John J. Pershing and Governors of forty-eight States, were rattled today by political parties as a forerunner of the March 16 village election.

Amid colorful scenes and to the strains of the Italian royal march, Roberto Cantalupo, the first Ambassador accredited to the government of Insurgent Spain, today presented his credentials to Franco, whom he styled "Generalissimo and head of the government of the Spanish State."

President Roosevelt sent to Congress a message recommending legislation to replace the Costigan-Jones Sugar Act, which expires at the end of this year; agreed to confer with the Governors' group on relief, and signed the SumnersMcCarran bill extending retirement privileges to Supreme Court Justices.

Members of the State Legislature, led by Speaker Oswald D. Peck, and city and county political leaders attended the funeral this afternoon of Assemblyman Richard B. Smith. The services were conducted at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, the Rev. Franklin B. Bennett officiating. Burial was in Oakwood Cemetery.

The engagement of $3,388,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $1,700,000 in Canada and $1,688,000 in England, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the amount taken in England, $588,000 was obtained yesterday and the remainder at an earlier date.

A state of siege at the White House, with an embattled First Lady maintaining a "sit-down strike" to obtain union hours for the arduous duties of Presidents' wives, provided a major theme for the annual frolic of the Women's National Press Club at the Hotel Willard tonight.

Finishing the second nine with a sub-par 34, Mrs. Lillian K. Zech of Chicago and Powell Crichton Jr. of Bronxville, 17 years old, captured low gross honors in the fourball mixed foursome golf competition on St. Augustine links today. They went out in thirty-nine strokes for a 73.

Letters to editors of London newspapers point out there is no such thing as the pound sterling. They recall that Bank of England notes read: "Bank of England promise to pay the bearer on demand the sum of one pound."
Germany's determined campaign against waste has started statisticians thinking about how much material is irretrievably lost without even being noticed.
The Oxford crew equaled a forty-year-old record today when it rowed from the finish post at Mortlake to Chiswick Steps in 6 minutes 33 seconds.

Mrs. Julia Bakalar was back in her husband's radio repair shop at 326 East Second Street, Brooklyn, last night after a sit-down strike by her husband in which he refused to return home until she resumed helping him at the shop.

The Maritime Association announced yesterday that six labor, trade and transportation groups had filed briefs with the International Joint Commission expressing their opposition to the proposal to construct a waterway from Montreal to Lake Champlain, southward through the Champlain Canal to the Hudson River and thence to tidewater at the Port of New York.

After deliberations of more than eight hours a General Sessions jury was unable to agree on a verdict in the trial of Dr. Leon Luria, 44 years old, of 901 Fiftieth Street, Brooklyn, on a charge of participating in a fake accident claim. Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. dismissed the jury about 11:30 P. M.
Miss Virginia P. Phelps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dexter Stillman Phelps Jr. of this place will be married on March 19, to Richard F. Berry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Berry of Hartford.

The right of New York State to levy an income tax upon rents from land outside the State, and upon interest on bonds secured by mortgaged real estate also outside the State was upheld by the Supreme Court today in a seven-to-two opinion. Justices Butler and McReynolds dissented.

Joint Annual Meeting and Luncheon Conference of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association and the Association of Tuberculosis Clinics of New York City, Hotel Pennsylvania. Luncheon meeting at 12:30 P. M.

Striking clerks, most of them girls, occupied two F. W. Woolworth five-and-tencent stores here tonight and a union official said there was a possibility that strikes might be called in Woolworth stores in other cities.
With 2,100 workers answering the call, the threatened general strike in the full-fashioned hosiery industry began here today.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 27: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Richard, G. J., Engrs., and Van Volkenburgh, R. H., C. A. C., relieved from detail as members of the General Staff Corps, Washington, D. C., June 30, and ordered to Naval War College, Newport, R. I., as students in the 1937-38 senior course.

A hearing by the National Labor Relations Board on a Committee for Industrial Organization union's charge that the Condenser Corporation of America and a subsidiary, the Cornell-Dubilier Company, had discriminated against its employes was temporarily halted today by Federal Court orders signed by Judge Guy L. Fake.

Announcement of the Treasury financing on March 15, involving about $800,000,000, probably will be made on Thursday, Secretary Morgenthau said today. The Treasury on March 15 will pay off in cash $300,000,000 in short-term bills out of current revenues,
Twenty-six member colleges have nominated a total of 463 entries for the sixteenth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday.

A nine-room dwelling at 47 AberEoyle Road, New Rochelle, was sold by Herbert Homes, Inc., to John W. Tolley Jr. through R. M. Norris, broker, who also sold in the same community ten lots on the north side of Interlaken Avenue for Freda Schrieber to a builder for improvement with dwellings.
The Seth Low College quintet defeated the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy five on the latter's court last night, 54-36.
Government sources tonight reported their militiamen had entered a suburb of Insurgent-held Toledo and defeated its defenders in a battle.

Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, has accepted the invitation of Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper to rejoin the Business Advisory Council, it was disclosed here yesterday.
The National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters effective yesterday dropped the "fire exclusion" in the standard mercantile safe burglary policy throughout the United States.
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh late today paid a surprise visit to the Parliament of Religions. The celebrated flying couple remained throughout the sitting.

With six members of the British Wolfe-Noel Cup team gracing the draw, play in the women's New York State singles and national doubles squash racquets championship tourneys got under way simultaneously on- the Sleepy Hollow Country Club courts today.

127th St., 362 W., s. s., 25x99.11; also 8th Av., 2,549, w. s., 24.11x85; also property in Bronx County; Espico Realty Corp., Mortimer B. Litt, president., to Helen Walton. 234 W. 48th St.; installments, 6 per cent: $15,000.
Leases of commercial space reported by brokers yesterday inIncluded several to novelty, metal products and dress firms. The list follows:

The premise of most plans in Washington for new labor legislation is the assumption that employment has lagged behind industrial production in the recovery movement. This statement has been made so many times that there is a tendency to regard it as axiomatic.

Lazard Freres Co., Inc., and the First National Bank of Dallas obtained the award of a new issue of $450,000 of City of Dallas, Texas, street bonds on their bid of 97.562 for 2 1/2s. The bonds, which will be dated April 1, 1937, and mature on April 1, 1938 to 1967, inclusive,
Mrs. Sarah McWilliam Miller, wife of Henry F. Miller, a lawyer, died on Sunday at their home, 14 East Ninetieth Street, from a heart attack suffered on Saturday. Her age was 76.

President Roosevelt will send to Congress tomorrow a special message transmitting, without recommendations, a report from a committee appointed to study in retrospect the invalidated National Industrial Recovery Act.
The Turkish Government faces a new problem in enforcing a law effective today forbidding the age-old trade of hamal, or human beast of burden.

The annual report of Jersey City for 1936, released today by Mayor Frank Hague and Arthur Potterton, director of Revenue and Finance, shows cash collections during the year of $27,541,781, or $826,495 greater than disbursements of $26,715,286. As of Dec. 31, last, the city's free cash surplus was $1,309,995, according to the report.

For a manager whose team of National League champions has just taken three successive beatings from Cuban squads Colonel Bill Terry appeared to be in a singularly optimistic frame of mind today as his Giants began their second week of intensive training here.
In the United States Court of Claims the following proceedings were had today: K-22-A. Roy Knabenshue, petition dismissed; judgment in favor of the United States. Opinion by Chief Justice Booth.

A Tass news agency dispatch from Vladivostok, published here today, is accepted as confirmation of the evidence of Japanese espionage given at the "Trotskyist" conspiracy trial in January. The dispatch states:
Charley Gomer, Baltimore lightweight, had an easy time last night hammering his way to victory over Gino Salvatore of Chicago in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace.

A concert of music by J. S. Bach and the most famous of his sons, Carl Philipp Emanuel, Wilhelm Friedemann and Johann Christian, was given yesterday evening in Town Hall for the concluding program of the Bennington College series.
55th St., 327 W., n. s., 18.9x100.5: Cornelius F. Collins Jr., referee, to Bank of New York and Trust Co., et al., executor, Theo. H. Benedict: foreclosure ($25).

With the approach of the championship weeks of the indoor polo season, which start in New York on March 20, the handicap committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America has made some interesting changes in the ratings as a result of the annual pre-championship meeting.

Federal Judge James Wilson temporarily approved today an amended plan of reorganization for the Cosden Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries. The proposal was submitted by the Cosden management under terms of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. He set a final approval hearing for March 27.

Eugene Vidal, director of the Bureau of Air Commerce, who announced his resignation yesterday, has been succeeded by Professor Frederick D. Fagg Jr., formerly of the faculty of the Law School of Northwestern University.

Two dead men were blamed yesterday for the connection between the gangsters of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and Local 302 of the Cafeteria Workers Union. The charge was made at the restaurant racket trial in the testimony of John J. Williams, defendant official of the union.

George Francis Barrett, former chief justice of the Cook County Circuit Court, died today in the Henrotin Hospital from a cerebral hemorrhage suffered a short time earlier in his law office. His age was 57.

His mind apparently deranged by a recent illness, Byron C. Dozier, 63 years old, a watchman for the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, shot and seriously wounded William J. DeBevois, 51, superintendent of watchmen, yesterday in the railroad's office at Pier 22, North River, foot of Jay Street, and then committed suicide.

The transaction recently concluded between the Gaumont British Picture Corporation and C. M. Woolf still requires the assent of the Law Debenture Corporation as trustee for Gaumont British debenture holders to make it legal.

The Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston reported yesterday for 1936 a net income of $5,170,907 after taxes, depreciation, interest and other charges. This was equivalent to $8.38 a common share on the number of shares outstanding at the end of the year.

Beating back the strong bid of Luigi Beccali of. Italy, Don Lash of Indiana raced to victory in the mile and a half invitation test that featured the annual Seton Hall Games at the Newark Armory tonight before a capacity crowd of 4,000.

Dr. Cesare Frugoni, the medical expert Premier Mussolini sent to Addis Ababa to treat Marshal, Rodolfo Graziani, reported today the Ethiopian Viceroy was recovering rapidly from the flesh wound received when natives attempted to assassinate him with hand grenades.

A letter from Secretary Perkins approving in principle the Ellenbogen bill for a "little NRA" in the textile industry was made public today by Representative Kent Keller, chairman of the House Labor subcommittee, who said the measure would be changed to conform to some revisions suggested by the Labor Deapartment Secretary.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was dull with prices moving narrowly. Whether traders remained on the sidelines to await the effect, if any, of the higher reserve requirements, some which were effective yesterday, or merely lacked sufficient incentive to make fresh commitments, the fact stood out that the market generally lacked trading interest.

Seven railroad and terminal companies operating about 700 miles of lines which spread through Illinois, with their apex at St. Louis, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to consolidate.

Two John Doe indictments were filed yesterday with Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora as a result of the two-year investigation made by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey into a racket reputedly costing the garment industry about $2,000,000 a year. Additional indictments are expected in the near future.

Robert H. Barclay, in 45 Christopher St.; Murray Coates, Milton Rosen, Edward Flatow. in 2 Horatio St.; Hal Michelman, John Sharp Hays, Emmons B. Stone, Agnes V. Owen, in 150 West 79th St., through Bing Bing, Inc.
John Grimshaw Wilkinson, blind botanist, on whom Leeds University conferred an honorary degree of Master of Science for his investigations of botanical flora, died today at Leeds at the age of 81.

The United States Consulate here was reopened today, with Robert D. Longyear, consul at Marseilles, France, temporarily in charge. The consulate has been closed for five months, Consul George Graves having been transferred to Vigo. Mr. Longyear will remain until the appointment of a successor.

Strength in Liverpool and other foreign grain markets was reflected in higher wheat prices yesterday in North America. While trade was light on the Board of Trade here there was no pressure of consequence and persistent scattered local and commission house buying kept prices on the upgrade most of the day with the close at net gains of 1 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel.
Saddler, 4-year-old pointer owned by Dr. H. U. Butts of Salem, Mass., gave the gallery of the national field trials a laugh today by forsaking the bird hunt to chase and kill a young pig.
Baroness Clemens von Ketteler of Villa Gameraia, in Florence, Italy, who has been passing several weeks at Stone Ashley, Tucson, Ariz., is expected next Monday at the Pierre.

The Swedish liquidators of the Kreuger Toll Company soon will recommend a dividend of 23 per cent to creditors whose claims have been allowed in the Swedish bankruptcy, according to Edward S. Greenbaum, American trustee in bankruptcy for Kreuger Toll.

Although Pope Pius will make his first public appearance after his long illness on Easter Sunday, either participating in a religious ceremony in the Sistine Chapel or blessing the crowds from a balcony of St. Peter's, he proposes to resume his normal activities as head of the Catholic Church even before then.

President Roosevelt agreed today to confer on relief with the six Governors who wired to him yesterday asking such a conference and stating that States and their local units could not bear the relief load which would be imposed on them by the contemplated cuts in employment by the Works Progress Administration.

Mayor La Guardia added 613 men to the Police Department yesterday morning, only a few hours before the Board of Aldermen voted to appoint seven of its members as a committee to investigate the shortage of police in the city.

President Pehr Evind Svinhufvud relinquished his office today to Kyosti Kallio, the nation's first farmer President. In his inaugural address Mr. Kallio emphasized his intention to continue Finland's peace policy in accordance with League of Nations principles.
Sightless employes of the Pennsylvania Association for the Blind started a sit-down strike today with demands for increased wages and improved working conditions.
Operations in the steel industry this week are scheduled at 85.8 per cent of capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, the highest level since the early weeks of October, 1929,
Lighthorse Harry Cooper, veteran Chicago professional and leading money winner of the Winter campaign, captured the St. Petersburg open golf tournament today after a three-way play-off.
Somebody got the goat of M. Mindick Co., meat dealers, today and also of most everybody in the office of the Master of the Brighton District High School.

The British Government launched tonight a new attack against the so-called depressed areas, where old established industries have died and hundreds of thousands of unemployed and their families have been living for years in misery.
William Taylor, inventor of many processes for improvement of photographic lenses and adviser to George Eastman when the latter founded his Kodak Company, died today at the wheel of his automobile.

BANNERMAN-Dr. Walter Bruce, brother of Frank and David, in his sixtieth year, on Feb. 27, at his home in East Bridgewater, Mass. BARBER--At Ridgewood, N. J., March 1, 1937, Emery Gardner, beloved husband of Sara Woodruff, aged 58 years. Notice of funeral hereafter.

Turning in identical cards, Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley of London, England, and F. L. Shea of Quincy, Mass., tied for the medal in the qualifying round for the Palm Beach golf championship at the Palm Beach Country Club today. The pacemakers posted 39, 36-75.
The Netherlands Labor party congress, concluded here today, resolved by 1,509 to 328 votes to modify its views regarding armaments.

" Storm Over Patsy," the new offering of the Theatre Guild, opened here tonight before a not very large but enthusiastic audience. Sara Allgood, Roger Livesey, Claudia Morgan and Ian McLean starred in an absurd farce built around a mongrel dog and a political campaign.

The money market was little affected last month by the announcement on Jan. 31 of an increase in reserve requirements of member banks to become effective on March 1, and May 1, says the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review, published yesterday.

The pamphlet report of the Amerex Holding Corporation for 1936, independently audited, which was issued yesterday, showed a net income of $722,766, which was equal to 98 cents a share on the 740,000 shares of capital stock outstanding.
Plans filed for new buildings yesterday included a $400,000 apartment house for eighty-eight families and two units to house sixty families and costing $200,000 each, in Long Island City.

Arthur Schnabel gave his first piano recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. It was a benefit for the scholarship fund of the Walden School. Since a near capacity audience was in the auditorium, the fund realized a tidy sum.

Miss Margaret Marie Ferry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Ferry of Brooklyn, will be married to Nicholas J. Healy 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Healy Jr. of New York, on the morning of March 29 in the Church of St. Francis of Assisi, Brooklyn.

The New York Telephone Company began defense yesterday against a suit brought before a sixman jury in the Municipal Court at 8 Reade Street to collect $3.85 in alleged overcharges on a series of long-distance telephone calls made last September.

The Ohio Encaustic Tiling Company, a subsidiary of the American Encaustic Tiling Company, has arranged to sell its property in Zanesville, Ohio, for $150,000 to the Shawnee Pottery Company of that city. The latter company, a new concern, proposes to make pottery products but not floor or wall tile.
Two hold-up men robbed three employes of the Public Theatre, Second Avenue and Fourth Street, of a $2,100 payroll Sunday night, it was revealed yesterday.
Governor Lehman sent to the Senate tonight the nomination of William J. Sheils of New Rochelle as Surrogate of Westchester County to fill the vacancy caused by the death of George A. Slater.

In honor of Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring was host this afternoon to about one hundred high ranking Army and Navy officers, members of the Senate and House, and trade experts from the State and Commerce Departments, at a reception at the Mayflower Hotel.
Investors figured as the buyers several of the scattered realty transactions reported yesterday for Manhattan and the Bronx. Most of the Manhattan deals involved East Side property.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading in veal improved and prices turned slightly upward for the first time In several weeks. Demand for other classes was good to slow. Prices were inclined to strengthen on most classes. Kosher veal opened strong to $1 higher than last Friday and other kosher meats steady.
