A funeral service for Captain Bernard W. St. D. Thomson, who edited the sports pages of THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1915 until his death from pneumonia on Friday, was held yesterday afternoon at the Universal Chapel, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today:

Germany's "will to world trade" was emphasized by Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador to London, and Bernhard Koehler, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's economic adviser, in speeches delivered in Leipzig tonight at a mass meeting of Germany's political and economic leaders.

American interests in Cuba will receive the same exemption under the nationalistic labor laws now in force as was granted to British companies in the new Anglo-Cuban commercial treaty signed Feb. 19. Assurance of this was given in a communication dated Feb. 22 and addressed to United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffrey by General Rafael Montalvo,
All the pressure of Japan's military establishment in North China is now being applied to promote the speedy industrialization of the region under Japanese auspices.

Dr. Simon Tannenbaum, medical director of Sydenham Hospital, Manhattan Avenue and 123d Street, died yesterday of a heart attack in his penthouse residence on the roof of the hospital. He had been able to attend to his duties although suffering from coronary sclerosis for the last two years. His age was 64.

Two workmen were severely injured about 3 P. M. yesterday when one fell fifty feet and landed on the other as they were working on the Marine Park Bridge under construction by the Park Department to connect Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, and Riis Park, Rockaway Peninsula, Queens. The men were John Anderson, 36 years old, of 2,408 Clarendon Road, Brooklyn, and John Quevedo, 22, of 1,001 St. Nicholas Avenue, Manhattan.
Justice Cardozo, whose gift of expression makes his opinions interesting reading, went back to Theodore Roosevelt for a phrase today.
With the induction today of Jayme Fernandes Guedes as president of the National Coffee Department, it is felt in coffee circles that the situation is on its way to normal.

Exactly five years after the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. the Assembly of the New Jersey Legislature voted unanimously tonight for a bill appropriating $25,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the person or persons responsible for the crime.

Net income of the Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries last year amounted to $20,398,078 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the preliminary report for 1936, issued yesterday. Net income in 1935 was $15,804,256.
State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced yesterday the appointment of Sol I. Smithline, 31 years old, of 200 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, as an Assistant Attorney General. Mr. Smithline,

Near the same area-twenty miles south of Cape Creu-where the British steamer Llandovery Castle struck a mine last week, the French cargo ship Marie Therese le Borgne hit a mine yesterday morning and ,was badly damaged. With her bow heavily sunk she managed to reach the Spanish port of Palamos. None of the crew was injured.

The marriage of Seward Webb Pulitzer, son of Ralph Pulitzer of New York, former publisher, and Mrs. Cyril Hamlin Jones of Milton, Mass., to Mrs. Jane Martin of Rockville, Md., took place this afternoon in the chambers of County Judge Richard P. Robbins in West Palm Beach.
By a vote of 50 to 4, the Board of Aldermen adopted yesterday a new taxicab ordinance restricting the number of taxicab licenses that may be issued to the number now outstanding.
That the Gadsden treaty of 1853 between Mexico and the United States has been annulled officially was announced tonight by the Mexican Government. The reason given is that the treaty is obsolete,

A jury of honor, composed of four parliamentarians presided over by the President or the Council of State, today settled a personal controversy between Alessandro Lessona, Minister of Colonies, and Marshal Emilio de Bono, who was commander-in-chief in East Africa during the first part of the Ethiopian campaign.

After months of prospecting and drilling in the southeastern part of Illinois, the Pure Oil Company on Sunday brought in a substantial-sized oil well in Clay County, three and a half miles southeast of Clay City officials announced today.
The former James C. Clark residence and forty acres at Far Hills, N. J., have been purchased by Leonard J. Buck of Great Neck, L. I., through Mrs. Leslie Hyde, broker.

Walnut Av. (10-2591). n. w. cor. of 139th St., 200x225: Harlem Metal Corp. to consolidated Edison Co. of New York, Inc., 4 Irving Pl.; five years, 5 per cent; $34,500. Aqueduct Av., W. (11-3214), w. s., 248 ft. s. of 192d St., 75x101; Shatz Shatz Holding Corp. to Adca Realty Corp., 140 Park Row, Installments, 5 1/2 per cent; $18,500.
The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria will steam into port some time today immediately to become the focal point in a strange pugilistic situation.
Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission sought today to prove that one company controlled by Harrison Williams, public utilities man, stimulated the stock of another he dominates.

England had scored 101 runs for the loss of three wickets at tea time today in its second innings of the fifth and deciding test cricket match with Australia. The English batsmen were faced with the task of running up 365 runs to prevent Australia winning by an innings and taking the world championship.

Carl K. Withers, State Commissioner of Banking, filed suit in the Court of Chancery today for repayment by twenty-two former directors of the defunct Mechanics Trust Company of Bavonne of approximately $2,200,

Preliminary plans are being prepared for a great anti-Communist International exhibition in Berlin this Summer. It is intended to form part of the intensive National Socialist anti-Bolshevist campaign and to further the proposed official anti-Communist International to be formed with headquarters here.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are March 1. unless specified: At San Diego: Chaumont, Trever, Feb. 27, Neches, Feb. 28. At Mare Island Yard, Feb. 28: Dorsey, Elliott, Koka. At Culebra: Owl, Feb. 28; Wright. Balch, Guantanamo Bay to Newport.

Charges that organized propaganda is being used throughout the country to sway opinion on President Roosevelt's court reorganization proposals were hurled in the Senate today by principals on both sides, while the President was signing the Sumners--McCarran Bill for voluntary retirement of Supreme Court Justices, which many hope may produce a solution of the whole controversy.

Offering to the public of $4,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures of the Celotex Corporation, carrying common stock purchase warrants, will be made today by Distributors Group, Inc., at a price of 101 1/2 and accrued interest.

A subpoena calling for the production of records before the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with an investigation is not reviewable, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday, sustaining Federal Judge Julian W. Mack,

About fifty of the writers employed on the WPA Federal Writers Project here have resigned to take jobs in private industry or to work on fellowships and scholarships, a survey recently completed shows.

Thomas Searle, a Republican leader here for many years, died suddenly last night in St. Petersburg, Fla., following a heart attack. He had been visiting his brother, Charles, when stricken. He was born in England sixty-eight years ago.
Pompoon, Brooklyn and Reaping Reward are among the leading 3year-olds named for the 1937 Kentucky Derby, Colonel M. J. Winn announced tonight.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted the following securities to listing: Duro-Test Corporation common stock, $1 par value; Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., new common stock, $2 par value, issued in exchange for old no par value common on basis of three shares of new common for each share of old;

Emery Gardiner Barber, a retired director of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, who had been associated with the Standard Oil interests for thirty-seven years, died here today at his home, 231 West End Avenue, after a sixmonths illness. He was born in Brooklyn 57 years ago.

Mrs. Nancy Traylor Swift, daughter of the late Melvin Traylor, president of the First National Bank here, was married today to Marcy T. Weeks, a bank clerk, in the marriage court in the County Building a few minutes after they had obtained a license.

Plans to form a 100 per cent governmentowned petroleum company "to increase Mexican petroleum activities" were officially announced this evening after stockholders had voted to dissolve the Petro-Mex government-controlled company, of which 49 per cent of the stock was privately owned.
The New Jersey Bankers Association will hold its annual convention here in the Hotel Traymore, May 20 to 22, with a golf tournament on the opening day,

Recommendations for uniform traffic-control lights throughout the State, plus the removal of safety pedestals, stanchions and other unlighted impediments to through traffic, were made yesterday in the first annual report of the State Traffic Commission, headed by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
Three hundred miners, employes of the Jamison Coal Company, went on a sit-down strike 300 feet below the earth's surface today.

The World-Telegram management, in a notice to its staff posted on the office bulletin board yesterday, announced its readiness "to negotiate a contract with its editorial employes in which the New York Guild is given full reognition as their accepted bargaining agent."

The Senate adjourned abruptly at 10:10 o'clock tonight until next Monday night immediately after members of the Democratic minority had served petitions on the chairmen of two Republican-controlled committees in an effort to force release of the Relief Financing Bill and the resolution for a constitutional amendment to legalize pari-mutuel betting at race tracks.
The Lehigh freshman basketball team defeated Hun School of Princeton, N. J., rather handily today, 42-29. The cubs went out to an 11-1 lead in the opening period and from then on were never headed.

An injunction limiting strike pickets around the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation plant in North Chicago to about ten was issued today by Circuit Judge Ralph J. Dady. The court also prohibited mass meetings of the strikers anywhere in Lake County.

A request by Representative Emanuel Celler that the Senate Judiciary Committee review "new developments" in connection with the Tydings-Miller Resale Price Maintenance Bill has been granted by Senator Ashurst, chairman of the committee, and the hearing will be held on Thursday morning,

Joseph Rappaport, murderer of Max Dent, a government informer, died in the electric chair early today after a struggle for a repreive which had its climax when a lie detector was carried into the death cell and scientists, lawyers, jailers and witnesses stared at tiny needles tracing on a slowly moving paper ribbon what proved to be mute lines of doom.
Talk of another Pacific Coast maritime strike punctuated a Congressional hearing today on proposed repeal of the law requiring seamen to carry continuous discharge books.

The name of the man who told Mrs. Norman Redwood that Samuel Rosoff, Joseph Fay and "the Big Six" ordered her husband's execution by gunmen is known to the authorities, it was asserted yesterday by John J. Breslin Jr., Prosecutor of Bergen County.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Words and phrases are used by demagogues to confuse their dupes, and there is no more confusing or harmful use of words than the phrase "the working class."
Mr. and Mrs. Ellsworth C. Warner gave a tea and cocktail party today at Villa Bellaria for a company of 150. Yellow roses adorned the tea table.

Divergent views of the problem presented by the city's slums were outlined by religious and social leaders yesterday at the Church Conference on Slum Clearance, held in the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The border control that became effective ten days ago is being rigorously enforced by -the French on this section of the Franco-Spanish border, even though enforcement costs them money through loss of business.
Manager Frankie Frisch, although he is 39 years old, was perhaps the "fittest" man in the Cardinal baseball training camp, which opened today.

The present trend in advertising agency organization is toward specialization and departmentalization, according to John B. Hunter, vice president of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., who addressed the class in advertising sponsored by the Advertising Women of New York at The Time last night.

A plan of recapitalization for the Struthers Wells-Titusville Corporation of Warren, Pa., was approved by stockholders at a meeting in Baltimore yesterday. It provides for the issuance of five shares of $1.25 dividend cumulative convertible preferred stock and one common share for each share of 7 per cent $100 par, preferred, on which arrears are $36.75 a share.
GREY OF FALLODON, by George Macaulay Trevelyan. (Houghton Mifflin, $3.75.) A long-awaited biography.
Mayor La Guardia conferred yesterday at City Hall with Assemblyman Stephen A. Jarema on the latter's bill authorizing the use of State parks as Summer camps for underprivileged children.

Samuel Cochran Jr. of the Squash Club and J. W. Taylor of the Montclair A. C. reached the final round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's eighth annual Class B championship tournament yesterday on the Harvard Club courts.

The American Bureau of Metal Statistics reports that world zinc production in January amounted to 137,776 short tons, compared with 144,951 in December, and 133,061 in January, 1936. The monthly average in 1936 was 135,706 short tons. Owing to the absence of information from Italy and Spain, the bureau is unable to report monthly totals of world production of refined lead.

New Deal won another victory today when the Supreme Court by a five-to-four decision held that the Congressional emergency joint resolution of June, 1933, abrogating payments in gold reached out to cover rental contracts specifically based on settlements in gold bullion.

Eugene s J. McCarthy, superintendent for the Walton Shoe Company, operators of six Chelsea factories, announced tonight that 1,400 employes who went on strike during the day with a demand for a 15 per cent pay increase had agreed to accept a 10 per cent increase. They will return to work in the morning, he said.

Denouncing the "negative dictatorship" of "two or three elderly Supreme Court judges," Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, said in a radio address tonight that the lives and fortunes of millions of Americans depended on adoption of President Roosevelt's judiciary reform program.

Five bricklayers occupied the witness stand in the Bronx County Court yesterday and for five hours told of men erecting walls at a pace so fast that the customary precautions were often omitted. The house on which they labored, 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx, collapsed last June 19, killing eighteen men.

Seventy-five $1,000 Liberty bonds, which the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer posted as security for bail when income tax indictments were pending against him, were held yesterday by the United States Circuit Court to be the property of Joseph L. Jacob

Teachers in West New York, N. J., lost their fight today against a reduction of salaries in the depression, the Supreme Court ruling unanimously in a case brought by Jay B. Phelps and Lucy Askam. The decision was written by Justice Roberts.

Gina Cigna, the Italian dramatic soprano, made her final appearance of the season in the title role of "Norma" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. She was permitted to depart only after an ovation at the end of the opera wherein she was recalled repeatedly.
YESTERDAY was March 1. Here are some notes on books published since Nov. 1 that this reviewer remembers with especial satisfaction. The order of listing is haphazard.

Governor Lehman urged upon the Legislature tonight several major changes in the State Unemployment Insurance Law, one of which would bring under the terms of the act all employes, whether manual or nonmanual workers, and no matter what wages or salaries they were getting, in an establishment employing four or more persons.

Argentina's sensational kidnapping case was solved tonight, the police said, when a dull-eyed tramp confessed having kidnapped and killed Baby Eugenio Pereyra Iraolo. The police announced that Jose Gancedo Gonzalez had admitted the crime after five days of questioning.
Dr. Francisco R. De Goenaga, dean of Puerto Rico's medical fraternity, died today after almost sixty years of practice. His age was 82.

FORD MADOX FORD, the British novelist, is of the opinion that the present ferocity of the world is the result of badly prepared food. When people have bad cooking they have indigestion, and when they have indigestion they cannot be amiable with their fellows, and want everybody belonging to a race other than their own to be stood against a wall and shot.
A. L. Stamm Co. have opened an investment department under the management of Lester S. Miller. The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed co-transfer

With consumer interest now beginning to be shown in Spring apparel and accessories, re-orders placed in the wholesale markets here yesterday indicated this week will show a substantial increase in activity.

Increase in passenger and freight traffic since low fares were put into effect led officials of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company to re-establish the personnel of the Hartford Division, abolished two years ago, it was announced tonight.
Yesterday was the hundredth birthday anniversary of an American newspaper man who at one time wrote editorial pieces for

In tile race of growing opposition among members of his own party in the Legislature to ratification of the Child Labor Amendment to the Federal Constitution, Governor Lehman announced today that he was prepared to go to the front for a measure which he had strongly advocated on the stump as a candidate for re-election last Autumn.
There will be no performances of "Tonight at 8:30" this week. Noel Coward is reported suffering from laryngitis and he is pretty indispensable in the nine short plays which make up the show.

Fireman 1st Grade Joseph T. Fosse of Engine 40, died Feb. 26, in the discharge of duty while operating at fire at 137 W. 60th St., Manhattan. Funeral will take place from 39-43 W. 60th St., Manhattan.

Willis J. Ballinger, who has acted as chief of special studies for the Securities and Exchange Commission, left the commission officially today with the expiration of the office that he held. The commission's decision to abolish his office was announced on Feb. 4. A spokesman for it explained tonight that he had been asked to remain some time and had asked him to suggest a possible field for his work.

Semi-finals in the fourteenth annual Golden Gloves warfare, bringing together some of the outstanding amateur boxers in the East, attracted a capacity turnout of 6,500 persons to the Hippodrome last night. Gladiators from five States furnished the action.

A "Serenade," dedicated to Mayor La Guardia, "the friend of musicians," has been composed by Arcady Dubensky, violinist of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Dubensky, who has composed in various forms, wrote this work at the suggestion of his colleagues in the orchestra.

A reorganization plan for Price Brothers Co., involving reduction of the bankrupt newsprint concern's capital from $60,000,000 to $30,000,000, was ratified today at meetings of the preferred and common shareholders.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee and the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation today opened what was regarded here as a new era in capital-labor relations in the United States when spokesmen' for both sides conferred officially for the first time on a proposed contract between the Amalgamated Association of Iron,
John Hughes, New York insurance man, who killed an 82-year-old German passer-by last Friday, has been placed in the hands of the prosecuting authorities under a general charge of homicide.

John A. Reddan, for the last seventeen years State Budget Commissioner and prior to that a Trenton reporter and legislative correspondent, died today at his home on Lake Boulevard, Hillside Lakes, at the age of 53. His health had been impaired for several months, but he continued his duties until two weeks ago, completing work on the current budget.

Estate more than $20,000. To Margaret Berghorn, widow, executrix, 2,330 First Av., household, personal effects and onethird residue; Elsa Berghorn, daughter, 2,330 First Av.; George Berghorn. same address, son; William Berghorn, son, 485 Central Park West, and Louis Berghorn Jr., son, executor, 2.314 First Av., equal interests in two-thirds residue.

Gene Gisburne's scant touch victory in the anchor leg of the 400-yard relay enabled Pennsylvania to defeat Dartmouth in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet at Hutchinson Pool today, 39-36.

President DENNETT of Williams College, speaking at the Founders Day Convocation of Union College, made a telling defense of the liberal arts college. Professor WILLIAM JAMES used to say that a college education enabled one to know a good man when one saw him.

The new Polish Government party, "Camp of National Unity," came into being tonight at a meeting of the party's first group, consisting of more than 400 representatives of various middle-class organizations of 150 Polish cities.

In as stunning a reversal of form as the tournament has witnessed in years, Gregory Mangin of Newark was eliminated in the second round of the national indoor tennis championship last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

The first of a series of shipments of Channel Island cattle to American importers is due in this port today with the arrival of the United States liner American Shipper. The ship is carrying eighty-nine head of Jersey cattle which were taken aboard when she made a special stop at Plymouth and took the consignment from a boat that ferried from Jersey to shipside.
Frank Sexton, husky California grappler, wrestled to a draw with Paul Jones of Texas in the feature match, scheduled to a finish, at the New York Coliseum last night.

Benefiting from the increased demand and higher prices for copper, lead and zinc during 1936, the American Metal Company, Ltd., showed a net income of $1,731,599 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, United States and foreign income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings.

The Long Island University baseball team will play thirty games this season, it was announced yesterday by Clair F. Bee, director of Athletics. The Blackbirds will have two home diamonds, one at Manhattan Beach and the other at Dexter Park.

James C. Burger, vice president of the Denver National Bank and a former Imperial Potentate of the Shriners of North America, died today at the home of his brother in Santa Barbara, Calif. Mr. Burger, at the time of his death, was Imperial Treasurer of the Shriners' organization.
John J. Keough, 32, of 39 Charles Street, Brooklyn, was convicted of first-degree murder by a jury before County Judge Fitzgerald in Brooklyn yesterday.
A centenary exhibition of lithographs by Theodore Fantin-Latour has just been opened in Room 316 (third floor) of the New York Public Library.

The eleventh annual Eastern bridge championship tournament opened yesterday at the Hotel Commodore. During the afternoon sixteen pairs started play for the Liberman Cup, open only to players who have not won a first or second place in a major tournament.

Business failures in the United States totaled 166 for the five-day week ended Feb. 25, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. figure compares with 203 for the preceding week and with 188 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Two 16-year-old boys, accused of starting a fire in a locker room at Bushwick High School, where they are pupils in Grade 8A, were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon and were booked at the Wilson Avenue police station on a charge of arson.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today under date of Feb. 26: COMMANDER Shirley, M. J., detached from Norfolk Navy Yard, Portsmouth, Va., on April 30; to home, relieved from all active duty.

A building loan of $125,000 has been placed with the Investors Syndicate Title and Guaranty Co. by Jacob Emil Leitner. Inc., for Philip Krumholz on the apartment building being constructed at the northwest corner of Park Terrace West and West 215th St.
For the first time in the memory of the oldest attaches of General Sessions, a Negro was sworn in yesterday as a member of one of the New York County grand juries.

Victor Rothschild, nephew of Lord Rothschild and heir presumptive to the title, has decided to disperse the family's famous art collection housed at 148 Piccadilly, a mansion built by Baron Lionel Nathan de Rothschild, who started the collection.
The following probationary patrolmen, having completed their course of training in the Recruits Training School, Police Academy, are transferred to precincts indicated:

Business failures in the United States totaled 166 for the five-day week ended Feb. 25, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. figure compares with 203 for the preceding week and with 188 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Two 16-year-old boys, accused of starting a fire in a locker room at Bushwick High School, where they are pupils in Grade 8A, were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon and were booked at the Wilson Avenue police station on a charge of arson.

Genie Palatine, sturdy 4-year-old filly owned by the amazingly succesful Chicagoan Mrs. Emil Denemark, added another feature triumph to the remarkable list of her owner in the Marianna Purse at Hialeah Park today.

You loved him! I do not deny that's true, And yet you never will get me to think It was exactly playing fair for you To give the cup to him and make him drink. You couldn't have him so you didn't weigh The consequences-not a single one;
Receipts of hogs failed to equal trade expectations today and prices were steady to 5 cents higher than on Friday. The top was up 5 cents at $10.30 a hundredweight,

Leslie MacMitchell, the 16-yearold George Washington High boy who shattered the national interscholastic standard for the mile at the fourth annual championships in Madison Square Garden last Saturday, was voted the outstanding athlete in the meet, according to an announcement yesterday.

First enforcement of New York City's new traffic code last week coincided with a marked decrease in fatal accidents, statistics compiled in the office of First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler revealed yesterday.

The Amateur Athletic Union yesterday provoked an argument with the Eastern Hockey League by declaring the Baltimore Orioles ineligible and breaking off its agreement with the Canadian Amateur Hockey Association regarding the transfer of players -between the two countries.

Mayor Albert B. Schultz of Hewlett Bay Park was elected president of the Community Chest of the Rockaway Branch Villages at the annual meeting of the directors of the charity in their offices here tonight. Milton S. Harrison was re-elected first vice president; Sylvan Joseph, treasurer; Edgar J. Treacy, secretary.

Mayor La Guardia and members of the RFC Mortgage Company reached a preliminary agreement at City Hall yesterday which offers a method of financing alterations to multiple dwellings to bring them into compliance with the Multiple Dwellings Law.
Tomorrow night will be amateur night for the Committee of One-Hundred, with talent selected from among the committee members.

Brooklyn College began the defense of its Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball crown in successful fashion by downing the Grace Lutheran Church A. A. quintet, 39-31, in the second game of a tournament double-header at the Union Temple court in Brooklyn last night.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions BURGEO STEAMSHIP CO., INC., owning and operating coastwise steamer, 29 Broadway-Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Laws. Liabilities about $47,000 plus disputed claims; assets one steamship valued at $100,000. SCHARF BROS. CO., INC., candy makers, 609 W. 51st St.-Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Laws. Liabilities $94,437 exclusive of stockholders claims; assets $148,541.

The persuasive eloquence of Joe McCarthy, manager of the world champion Yankees, today brought two of the Ruppert hold-outs into the fold. Bill Dickey, the catcher from the Ozarks, remains the lone recalcitrant on the citrus front.

The Rev. James P. Sandefur, 22, filed suit today for a divorce. against his wife, June, 19, charging that she made faces while he preached at the Primitive Baptist Church, and that she went to sleep during services.
Quiet and orderly, several hundred pickets looked on today as the Douglas Aircraft factory resumed operations which were halted last week because of a sit-down strike.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Nicholas T. Rogers of New York City was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: 180--Holyoke Water Power Co., petr., V. American Writing Paper Co., Inc. Writ of cert to the First Circuit Court of Appeals.
Intermediate Half-Mile Middle Atlantic Championship-Won by Ambrose McKee, Martinson's S. C.; Joseph Dodds, Paterson S. C., second; Raymond Noble, New York S. C.. third. Time-1:31.3.

Kurt Ruhrseitz, an assistant conductor with the Metropolitan Opera Company, died yesterday in Dresden, Germany, according to a cable dispatch from his widow received by a friend here. He was 35 years old. A few weeks ago he suffered a nervous breakdown and ten days ago sailed for Germany. His parents also survive.

Inquiries for garage properties in many parts of the city are increasing, according to the State Mortgage Commiission, which reports that prospective buyers apparently foresee an increased demand for automobile storage space if more stringent regulations against all-night parking are enforced.
156th St. (9-2458), n. w. cor. of Sheridan Av., 100x152; Menlo Building Co. to Antmar Relaty Co., Inc., 3,510 White Plains Av.; mtg.,

With a police guard stationed "until further notice" at SpringerCocalis theatres in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, a contract was signed yesterday morning renewing the employment of members of the Empire State MotionPicture Operators Union in thirtytwo theatres of the chain.

Maurice W. Metzler Jr. of the City A. C., seeded third, went the limit in his second successive match as he downed Hollister Moore of the Bayside Tennis Club, 17-18, 15-8, 12-15, 15-7, 15-6, in a second round match of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group 1 championship at the New York A. C. yesterday.
Leicester Fisher handed Jerome Strauss his first setback in the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline billiard tournament at the Capitol Health Center last night. The score was 200 to 169.

Governor Lehman called a special election to fill the vacancy in the Third Assembly District in Onondaga caused by the death of Richard B. Smith. The Governor also made it known that he would bend his utmost efforts to bring about a favorable vote in the Assembly on ratification of the Child Labor Amendment.

Gregory O'Keefe was sworn in at the Custom House at 10:30 A. M. yesterday as Assistant Collector of the Port of New York to succeed Henry C. Stuart, who retired on Saturday after forty-six years of service.

Four hundred and seventy Princeton sophomores had joined the seventeen upperclass eating clubs of the university at noon today when the official signing-up period, which commenced Saturday morning after two weeks of club calling, ended.

The Princeton freshman hockey team defeated the Northwood School skaters today, the Tiger Cubs overcoming a two-goal deficit to triumph, 4-2, in Baker Rink. It was Northwood's second defeat in eleven games.

Gabriel Jose Fajardo died of pneumonia today at his home here. Mr. Fajardo was born in Cuba seventy years ago. A graduate of the University of Havana, Mr. Fajardo had been an importer and exporter of drugs, operating his own business in New York City for the last thirty-five years.
The Federal Department of Justice announced today that it had rejected the appeal of Carlo Aprato, coeditor of the Journal des Nations, against its withdrawal of his permit to live in Switzerland.

There will be no dismissals of WPA employes before July 1 beyond the 3,000 ordered recently by Federal WPA authorities if plans discussed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, are approved by the Board of Estimate.

To keep up with the march of events is the great difficulty facing the press today, Neil MacNeil, assistant night managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared last night in an address on the function of the city editor at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

A petition that would have asked President Roosevelt to withdraw the Supreme Court issue from public controversy in the interest of internal peace of mind and to ward off "fratricidal strife" in the face of world unrest, was ruled out of order as being outside of the ecclesiastical field at a session yesterday morning of the Brooklyn-Nassau Presbytery.

While terms of those steel wage settlements effected yesterday were not known in market hours here, the multiplicity of negotiation and the known frame of mind of the managements of leading steel companies stiffened prices of steel stocks in the securities markets.

The Erasmus Hall High School quintet, which had previously clinched the runner-up position in Section 2 of the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. concluded its regular league schedule yesterday by routing Manual Training High, 52 to 36, at the Prospect Park Y. M. C. A.

With all General Motors divisions increasing output last week as conditions approached normal, automobile production spurted forward against a downward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index advanced to 128.5 from 108.8. It was 72.8 for the week ended Feb. 29, 1936.

A picture of the factories and ports of the United States suffering aerial bombardment from the aircraft of a desperate belligerent in the next world war if this country attempted to preserve its neutrality through the Pittman resolution now under consideration, was painted for the Senate today by Senator William E. Borah of Idaho.
The Reichsbank's statement as of March 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

President Roosevelt said today he was unaware that the suggestion in his message to Congress yesterday for an excise tax of 0.75 cents a pound on sugar would be a violation of the reciprocal trade agreement between Cuba and the United States.

The wise counsels of elder statesmen have prevailed among the Republicans, and, since Chairman Hamilton's impulsive speech urging the party as such to oppose the President's Supreme Court program, Republicans have been careful to divest themselves, as much as possible, of partisan labels when entering the controversy.

The first stage of the Spanish Government's offensive on Oviedo has miscarried, in the opinion of impartial observers who have arrived here from both warring sides, and the reason is held to be dissension within the ranks of the Loyalists.

Freddie Steele of Tacoma, Wash., middleweight boxing champion, scored a technical knockout over Paul Pirrone of Cleveland after 1 minute and 57 seconds of the first round in their scheduled ten-round non-title bout tonight. Steele weighed 158 and Pirrone 162.
Hosiery workers enlisted employes of four more mills in their sit-down strike today, bringing the number of knitters affected to 4,700.

Australia retained world cricket laurels today, subduing England by an innings and 200 runs in the final encounter of the five-game series. Staging a great recovery after losing the first two tests, the Aussles won three successive matches to triumph.
The indications are for fair and slightly colder weather today. Tomorrow will be mostly cloudy and warmer, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

For a Princeton graduate to capture the Metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship is becoming almost a tradition here. Yesterday, for the seventh time in the eight-year history of the event, an alumnus of Old Nassau was victorious when Sam Cochran Jr. gained the verdict over John W. Taylor after four hard-fought and well-played games.

A truce temporarily ended today a strike of 400 students at Delaware Academy, who returned quietly to their classes after it was learned that the Village School Board had called a meeting for Wednesday night to consider the proposed dismissal of Principal H. Benton Arthur, which caused the students yesterday to refuse to sit in classes.

With William R. White, former Deputy Sheriff in Kings County, scheduled to go on trial on Friday in Kings County Court on an indictment containing eight counts, Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, made public yesterday an investigation of the office showing fifteen embezzlements which he attributed to White.

A further broadening of the powers of Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd to enable him to prosecute any evidences of perjury uncovered during his inquiry into the various phases of the Samuel Drukman murder case was authorized yesterday by Governor Lehman in Albany.

A field of fifty-four sprinters from twenty colleges has been named for the 60-yard dash in the sixteenth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships, which will be held in Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Executive Secretary James A. Taylor.

Richard C. Osborne, veteran jockey of Brooklyn, died this afternoon in the Leon Levi Hospital. He had been here for a week and was to have ridden Heart Break, Bill Jolly's entry in yesterday's third race at Oaklawn Park.

Chang Soo Lee, on trial in the Westchester County Court for attempted murder, feared as early as last July that his employer, Mrs. Ida L. Churchill, would leave her fortune to Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves, and he promptly set out to poison them, it was charged today by the State.

Patrolman George J. Schuchman of the West Forty-seventh Street station is alive today probably because a bullet fired at him by a fleeing bandit hit his nightstick, which he happened to be holding in front of his heart.
An all-time record for February was established last month by the port of Philadelphia in' vessel movements and gross registered ship tonnage, Mayor S. Davis Wilson said today.

The complexion of the $50,000 Widener Challenge Cup race, to be run Saturday, changed sharply today at Hialeah Park with the announcement that the future-book favorite, Roman Soldier, would not go to the post.

In strongly worded language, County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn challenged yesterday the legality of the proceedings whereby a convict in Auburn prison had been brought to this city and kept in the West Side jail for several weeks while he was questioned by assistants of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.

Japan is not altering her building program on account of the huge British construction plan and does not consider that British and American naval policies inaugurate a new armament race, Rear Admiral Noritake Toyoda, Vice Minister of the Navy, today told the budget subcommittee of the House of Representatives in the course of interpellations on naval questions.
Game little Sulu, running like a champion but unable to find birds, tumbled from the throne today in the national field trials, leaving the way open for a new titleholder.

James Cromwell and his wife, the former Miss Doris Duke, departed on the Hawaii Clipper at noon today on the way to Alameda and New York. They later expect to go to London to attend the coronation ceremonies for King George VI. Mr. and Mrs. Cromwell will return here in August.
Significant political developments are impending now that the National Congress (independence) party has won majorities in six of India's eleven provinces.

Southern Woman's Educational Alliance Forum Conference on Nursing Service in Rural Areas, Hotel Roosevelt, 10 A. M. Afternoon session, 2:30. Jewish Board of Guardians Conference for Jewish Prison Chaplains begins at 10 A. M. at 228 East Nineteenth Street. Afternoon session at 2:30 at Hotel Woodstock. Dinner session at 8.
Huge cakes of ice rumbled over Niagara Falls tonight, crashing into the gorge and jamming into high "mountains" in what rivermen called the largest ice movement since 1908.

Republican leaders expressed yesterday the opinion that the vote of 30 to 10 by which the Republican Club of the Ninth Manhattan Assembly District endorsed Mayor La Guardia for renomination represented just about the ratio by which members of the party organizations throughout the city would support the Mayor.

Max Schmeling, conqueror of Joe Louis and the No. 1 challenger for the world heavyweight title, arrived in New York last night on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria not in the least disturbed by the fact that Champion James J. Braddock had signed to fight Louis in Chicago June 22.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had picked the old Chisholm Mansion at College Point, Queens, as his Summer City Hall for July and August of this year.

A trim, compactly built young man celebrated his twenty-eighth birthday in the Giants' swank training camp today, and even had something more momentous happened than just a routine three-hour workout at the ball park the item would still have to be regarded as the day's outstanding piece of news.

Because the Literary Guild has made "American Dream," by Michael Foster, its July selection, the publication of the novel has been postponed from March 24 to some time in June, Morrow, the publishers, announce. The author is a newspaper man in Seattle.

Publicly financed construction work increased 37 per cent in January over December, while privately financed construction of the same period gained 11 per cent, the F. W. Dodge Corporation informed Public Works Administrator Ickes today.
Lieut. Commander Donald B. MacMillan, explorer, will leave Boston June 19 on his sixteenth Arctic expedition with a party of about thirty scientists and college students.

Lawrence La Brie, in 225 E. 57th St.; Henry M. Patridge, in 3 E. 76th St.; Mrs. Marian P. Collins. in 71 Park Av.; Harry Bishop, through Riker Realty Corp., in 15 E. 55th St.; Mrs. Edith Mann Simonds, In 1,028 Park Av.; Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., broker.

Blind for sixty of his sixty-two years. Joseph Backlund looked today upon a strange world in which he must learn to associate objects with names. An expert mechanic, he has known a gasoline engine by touch for so long that sight of it leaves him a hit nuzzled.

Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, and Mrs. MacCracken have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joy MacCracken, to David Paul Dawson of New York, son of the late Colonel William Campbell Dawson of Louisville, Ky., and Mrs. Dawson, who resides in Charlottesville, Va.

Offering will be made today of 200,000 shares of Class A non-voting common stock of $1 par value of the Mar-Tex Oil Company of Houston, Texas, at $3.50 a share, by L. S. Carter Co., Inc., and Gillet Co., Inc. Stockholders have the right to subscribe for two shares of this stock for each three shares of common or Class A common stock now held at $3 a share.

The second series of wool auctions opened here today and offerings totaled 6,311 bales, of which 4,989 were sold. The offerings did not consist of any outstanding selections, although all grades of crossbreds were sold, the home trade being the principal purchasers.

Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd, noted woman golfer and a resident of Whitehall, Haverford, was married this afternoon at 5 o'clock to Edward L. Howe, Princeton, N. J., banker, at the home of Mrs. Frederick Richardson in suburban St. Davids.

Joseph R. Johann, defending champion, last night defeated Leicester Fisher for his second victory in three starts in the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline billiard tournament at the Capitol Health Center. The score was 200 to 131.

The newspaper Pravda, organ of the Communist party, voices alarm today about a religious revival of somewhat unusual character in the eastern section of Ivanovsk Province, which is the chief textile region of the Soviet Union and is about 250 miles northeast of Moscow.

Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in the Federal court in Brooklyn imposed a suspended sentence yesterday on Carmine Ancona, 37 years old, of 66 Bay Eighth Street, Bath Beach, who pleaded guilty to sending an extortion letter to his wife, Mrs. Anna Ancona, last Feb. 6. The letter said Ancona had been kidnapped and his abductors demanded $5,000 for his release.

Third-grade Detective James Boyle of the Liberty Avenue Station, Brooklyn, was on duty Monday when Mayor La Guardia told 613 rookies at City Hall: "If a crook tries to pull a gun on you, be fast on the draw and pull the trigger first."

A heating contractor, a carpentry contractor and a carpentry foreman testified yesterday afternoon in the Bronx County Court that they had committed three violations of the Building Code while they worked on the apartment building at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South which collapsed last June 19, killing eighteen men.

Great Britain has not discharged her duties or fulfilled her pledges with respect to Palestine, but instead has placed artificial barriers to immigration there, obstructed the purchase of land by Jews and failed to give adequate assistance in reconstruction work, according to a statement issued yesterday by the American Labor Delegation to Palestine.

Police Commissioner Valentine hurried yesterday (over a distance that was every bit of five feet) to watch some of his men raid a store opposite police headquarters where they say they broke up a race-horse betting place.

It is estimated that no other man spoke to so many people directly as did DWIGHT L. MOODY, in whose memory services are being held this year and week in all parts of Christendom. For nearly thirty years he preached to multitudes-often to more than were gathered on the shores of the Lake of Galilee. But he was never an "ordained " minister.

A six-story apartment on East Seventy-fourth Street, Manhattan, to cost $150,000, and a six-story house for forty-one families, on Bay Parkway, Brooklyn. to cost $100,000, were among the building projects for which plans were filed yesterday.

Fifteen army planes left Albrook Field today on the first leg of a 4,000-mile flight to Lima, Peru, and return. The squadron is commanded by Major George H. Beverly and consists of three observation and twelve pursuit planes. Thirteen awition officers are making the flight.
The police examined a witness today who swore that John Hughes of New York and the 82-year-old German he killed last Friday had collided on the street.
By ROBERT FISHEL Riverside Drive, 51-52, 15-story apartments, 50.9x122.2; New York Life Insurance Co. against Ragaz Holding Co.; due, $439,541; to plaintiff for $200,000.

Unheralded and unsung on their arrival in this country to participate in the current six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden, the team of Roger Deneef and Gerard Loncke of Belgium served notice last night that they are a partnership worthy of consideration for top honors in the grind.
French military and naval bases in the Eastern Mediterranean were urgently recommended today by General Maxime Weygand in an address to a Franco-Syrian group.

A 1937 budget specifying a municipal tax rate of $4.44 for each $100 of assessed real estate valuation was adopted by the Camden City Commission today subject to the approval of Walter R. Darby, State Auditor of Municipal Accounts.
More than 200 miners emerged today from the Jamison pit to end the first sit-down strike in bituminous history.

The monthly index number of average commodity prices, the first to be published for February, was given out yesterday by Dun's Review. The Dun average indicates an advance of 1 per cent during February, as against a decline of 1% per cent in January.

The mysterious killing in 1935 of a relative of President Buchanan, which has been a political issue in Philadelphia ever since, was solved here yesterday by Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney, when he obtained a confession from Frederick Thomas, 27 years old, a Negro waiter. George F. Buchanan, 63, owner of a Philadelphia printing establishment, was the victim.
Appleton Gregory, Albany lawyer, died last night after several days of illness with the grip. He was 51 year old, a son of the late County Judge Clifford D. Gregory.

The second important remake to be announced within a week came today from RKO, where plans are being made for a 1937 version of "Rio Rita," one of the earliest and most successful musicals of the sound era. A few days ago the studio placed "Irene" on schedule.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company and Goldman, Sachs Co. jointly won yesterday the award of a new issue of $400,000 of work relief bonds of Monroe County, N. Y., on a bid of 100.282 for the securities as 2.10s.

Word was received here today of the death yesterday of William Maxson Stillman of this city at a hospital in Naples, Italy. Mr. Stillman was dean of the Plainfield Bar Association and third oldest member of the Union County Bar Association. His age was 81 and death was due to pneumonia.

Provision for cigars and cigarettes for inmates of the Home of Old Israel, 70 Jefferson Street, Manhattan, was made in the will of Louis Singer, filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn. A trust fund of $3,000 was set up, the income from which will be used for that purpose.

A national exhibition of newspaper typography, open to all daily English-language newspapers in the United States, was announced today by H. A. Batten, president of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., under whose auspices the exhibition will be held here.

The Federal Trade Commission has been asked to investigate the pending Tydings-Miller Price Maintenance Bill and State laws legalizing resale "price-fixing," it was announced yesterday by Representative Emanuel Celler, ranking Democratic member of the House Judiciary Committee.

Almon G. Rasquin, Collector of Internal Revenue in Brooklyn, said yesterday that only one-quarter of the more than 100,000 employers of one or more persons subject to social security tax in the First Collection District of New York, which includes all of Long Island and Staten Island, had filed returns for January.

Starting somewhat earlier than in previous seasons, the Fordham football squad yesterday reported to Coach Jim Crowley for the opening of Spring practice on Fordham Field. Fifty-five players were on hand for the drill, which lasted about an hour.

The defense at the restaurant racket trial received a setback yesterday when a witness, called to testify to the proper conduct of two union officials, finished by admitting that he had been victimized in a $1,500 shakedown.

After the opening of bids yesterday for the extension of the West Side highway from Spring to Cedar Streets, Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan said the bid of Poirier McLane was $86,609 lower than the estimate of his engineers.

Members of the younger set, headed by Miss Katherine V. Marsters, are assisting Princess Dorothy Caracciolo and her aides in the sale of tickets for the performance of "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse" tomorrow night at the Hudson Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the work of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

Eric Seelig, 160, European boxer, gained the decision over Jimmy Belmont, 158 3/4, of Pittsburgh in the main event of ten rounds at the Broadway Arena last night.- A crowd of 2,500 persons saw the victor outpunch his rival' at close quarters. Belmont made it a close battle all the way.
The demands of rearmament are becoming so insatiable that the giant iron and steel industry of this country-the third greatest producer in the world-is no longer able to cope with them unaided.
George T. Eaton, retired educator who served on the faculty of Phillips Andover Academy for a half century, died today at the Massachusetts Memorial Hospital.

Charged with attempting to commit arson in Bushwick High School, Woodbine Street and Irving Avenue, Brooklyn, on Monday morning, Arthur Hock, 16 years old, of 82 Wyckoff Avenue, and Anthony Liotta, 16, of 106 Central Avenue, both Brooklyn, were held in $1,000 bail each for the Grand Jury by Magistrate Mason in Adolescent Court, Brooklyn. yesterday.

The provision in the new Copeland bill for amending the Pure Food and Drugs Act which invests the Food and Drug Division of the Department of Agriculture with power to control misleading adverrising was sharply criticized last night by Henry Ward Beer, president of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Sharply criticizing the Ivee act of 1934, requiring teachers' oaths, as "not only unnecessary, but actually harmful to the best interests of the teaching profession," twenty-four heads of colleges and universities in this State have signed a petition to the Legislature asking that the act be repealed.
In the Supreme Court of the United States Olin R. Moyle of Brooklyn, N. Y., and Emanuel A. Stern of New York City were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

The New York Stock Exchange has already taken steps to revise, where necessary, its rules involving the listing of railroad holding companies, Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange, told the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today.

Carl M. Loeb Co. will underwrite jointly with B. H. Roth Co. all rights to be offered to stockholders under the amended plan of reorganization for the Cosden Oil Corporation, which was approved tentatively by Federal Judge Wilson in Fort Worth, Texas, on Monday.

Sixteen faculty members at Teachers College, Columbia University, will get promotions effective July 1, it was announced yesterday by Dean William F. Russell, who said the board of trustees had voted to elevate seven associate professors to the rank of full professor and to move five assistant professors to the rank of associate professor.

The Rev. Dr. Warren Hugh Wilson, for almost thirty years in charge of rural church work in the Presbyterian Church and a leader in the efforts of Protestant groups to revive the rural churches, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He failed to rally from a mastoid operation performed on Monday. He was 69 years old.

Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, member of the Democratic National Committee for the District of Columbia, made public today a reply to a letter written by Amos R. E. Pinchot, New York lawyer, attacking President Roosevelt's program for reorganization of the Supreme Court. Mr. Pinchot's letter was sent about two weeks ago to members of Congress and many others of prominence here, expressing fear of a dictatorship.
The famed battlefield where once "the embattled farmers stood and fired the shot heard 'round the world" won't be bathed in the glare of floodlights at night this Summer.

From the "have" side, the problem of raw materials, according to figures the League of Nations published today, boils down virtually to four democracies-the British Commonwealth. the United States, France and The Netherlands.

Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson has just ordered a number of new dresses from Molyneux. She chose them from a replica of the Paris collection now being shown at the Cannes branch of the establishment, for she has not left Cannes since she arrived there.

Thomas Jefferson, co-holder of the city championship, captured the Section 1 title in the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. by halting Eastern District, 31 to 26, after a three-minute overtime period before a capacity crowd in the winner's gymnasium yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia presented cash prizes last night to the captains of the seven winning teams in the Fifth Avenue Coach Company's safety contest at a dinner given for the men by the company at the New York Athletic Club, Fifty-ninth Street at Seventh Avenue.

Bond prices were erratic yesterday despite a large volume of trading and the more active issues for the most part showed only fractional changes. Transactions amounted to $13,610,600, compared with $11,49,400 on the day before.

Conqueror of Gregory Mangin, the defending titleholder, on Monday, Ray Palmer Jr. of New York passed out of the National indoor tennis championship yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Along with him, J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, sixth in the seeded list, made his exit and Frank Parker and Walter Senior survived only after protracted struggles.
Patrolman George Johnstone, attached to the police emergency squad, was found dead with a bullet wound in his head about 11 o'clock tonight in an apartment at 134 Court Street.

With Princeton's record of twelve straight wrestling victories for the last two years hanging in the balance, Charlie Toll, captain-elect of the football team, threw Myron Sterngold tonight in 3:08 to give the Nassau grapplers a 19-13 triumph over Lehigh.
Gilbert Miller, accompanied by Mrs. Miller, heads the theatrical group sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

August A. (Gus) Gennerich, bodyguard to President Roosevelt, left an estate valued at $8,500, it was revealed today in United States District Court when a request was made to remove his will to Dutchess County, N. Y., for probate.

Long-distance operators throughout the United States deduct five seconds from their calculations of the time consumed by telephone calls, even though the timing is done with calculagraphs, the purpose of the rule being to protect the consumer from any error, it was brought out yesterday in the suit to collect $3.85 from the New York Telephone Company for alleged overcharges on thirty-one long-distance calls.
THEATRE, by W. Somerset Maugham. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50.) A novel about an actress. WOMEN ARE BORN TO LISTEN, by Norah C. James. (Macaulay, $2.) A woman plays out the feminine role.

With a characteristic sprint finish, Columbia closed strongly in the second half to beat Yale, 41 to 37, at the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night as the Lions replaced the losers in fourth place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League.

Since the Social Security Act has focused popular attention on oldage security, life insurance companies are expected to tie in their advertising with this theme and stress annuities in their copy, according to comment here yesterday.

President Roosevelt presented the Harmon International Trophy today to Howard Hughes, movie producer and speed flier. The trophy is given annually by the Ligue Internationale des Aviateurs, which designated Mr. Hughes the world's outstanding aviator in 1936.

Last Monday, March 1, the first of the two increases in bank reserve requirements decreed by the Federal Reserve Board on Jan. 28 went into effect. It raised the requirement 16 2-3 per cent above the percentage previously in force.

News of the adoption of the forty-hour work week by the leading steel companies was received with pleasure by government officials today, particularly Secretary Perkins and Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy.
The report that Great Britain is planning a fleet of twenty-five capital ships and a heavy increase in other naval craft by 1942 was received in Washington with keen interest tonight.
A proposed new retirement system for the railroad workers of the nation absorbed the attention today of government fiscal and pension officials.
Following is the text of the Securities and Exchange Commission's announcement today informing American investors of the conditions under which the new $69,000,000 German bond issue is offered;

The signing of the agreement between the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and the Steel Workers Organization Committee today is expected to have an important repercussion in the relationship between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.

A bill to create a system of mortgage banks, privately owned but under the supervision of the State Superintendent of Banks, was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Lazarus Joseph, chairman of the joint committee on guaranteed mortgages.

Crude oil production in the United States last week rose slightly to a new high record, averaging 3,296,100 barrels daily, compared to 3,295,950 barrels the week before and with a daily average output of 3,274,700 barrels for the four weeks ended Feb. 27, the American Petroleum Institute reports.

Skirmishes between counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission and for Charles C. Wright over the admissibility of evidence occupied most of the hearing yesterday in the proceedings against Mr. Wright and nine other respondents, charged with manipulating the stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd.

Armed men guarded iron mines of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company today against a strike, while the company promised a quick answer to employe demands for a general wage increase and a forty-hour week.
Every man's heart, irrespective of party, will go out to the President who was served salt fish for lunch four times

Union demands for a national minimum hourly wage in General Motors automotive plants proved the stumbling block today to a final agreement between conferees of the corporation and the United Automobile Workers, who sought settlement of recent strike differences by tonight.

The Chase National Bank, as special agent, is notifying holders of State of Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil) consolidated municipal loan fortyyear 7 per cent bonds due 1967 that, pursuant to decree, funds have been received for payment of coupons due Dec. 1, 1936, at the rate of 25 per cent of their face value.

77th St., 103 W., n s, 35x100.6; 103 West 77th Street Corp., Sylvan Bien, president, to Central Savings Bank; p.m., demand, int. per bond; $42,000. Same property; same to same, building loan, demand, int. per bond; $11,000. 145th St., s s, 200 ft e of 7th Av, 150x 99.11; Cardinal Motors, Inc., A. Merdinger, president, to Mutual Life Insurance Co., p.m. due, , as bond ; 50,000.

Poly Prep scored its initial victory in nine Eastern Private Schools Basketball League starts yesterday by defeating Trinity, 31 to 16, on the victors' court. Robert Maslow set the pace for Poly, which led at the half, 14 to 6, by registering 12 points.

The Wabash Railway, which the Pennsylvania Railroad controls through a $63,041,500 investment and which was started on the road out of receivership on Monday by an order granted in a Federal court in St. Louis, was one of the first railways to enter receivership

At a meeting of directors of the Bankers Trust Company yesterday, the following changes were approved: C. C. Gardner resigned as treasurer and was appointed assistant vice president. Julius Paul, formerly assistant vice president, was appointed treasurer. W. W.

Preliminary to negotiations for a new wage contract, the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers yesterday addressed a letter. to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union asserting that the high labor standards prevailing in the industry have put it at a serious disadvantage in competition with other branches of the needle trades, and asking that the negotiations be based upon a factual study of conditions.
Bermuda's last relic of slavery, which was abolished here on Aug. 1, 1834, disappeared last night when Mrs. Jane Johnson, a Negro known as Aunt Jane, died at 106 in the Poor House.

Things were so quiet in the Yankee camp today that the signing of a new infielder became the outstanding event. Ellsworth (Babe) Dahlgren, first baseman purchased from the Red Sox, has returned his Yankee contract properly attested.

An important heavyweight meeting between Negro rivals will hold the fistic spotlight at the Hippodrome tonight when Leroy Haynes of Philadelphia and Eddie Blunt of this city enter the ring for their scheduled ten-round battle.

Officials of the Board of Education and musicians lauded the cultural influence of concerts in the public schools of Greater New York at a luncheon meeting of the Musicians Emergency Fund yesterday afternoon at the Hotel St. Regis.

While German quarters watched with a certain grim amusement how the British lion jumped again at the mention of colonies by Joachim von Ribbentrop, the Reich's Ambassador to London, in a speech at the Leipzig Fair last night, chief interest centered here today on Italy's military and economic armament announced by the Fascist Grand Council.

Ruling that a strike, even though called at the height of the employer's busy season, did not legally constitute duress, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo reversed yesterday the findings of a referee who had recommended that the settlement that ended the strike be voided.

Alarmed over a rising tuberculosis death rate, public health officials called on the city yesterday to provide "quickly and liberally" for adequate care of the tubercular and warned against a change in municipal administration that might delay the hospital expansion program.

The residence at 77 Jerome Avenue, Wykagyl Park, New Rochelle, has been purchased by Hamilton McInnes from the New Rochelle Trust Company, trustee. The property was listed at $38,000. James F. Gilkinson negotiated the deal.

A story that stock of Harrison Williams's American Cities Power and Light Company rose 250 per cent while its chief asset was advancing only 25 per cent engaged the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

Four thousand Waterbury employes and almost 1,000 workers in the Cleveland branch of the Chase Brass and Copper Company will receive a 5-cent increase in hourly wages and a 7 per cent rise in piecework rates, effective March 5, it was announced today.

At a hearing yesterday in the reorganization proceedings of the Consolidated Textile Corporation, Peter B. Olney Jr., Federal court referee, announced he had received an offer of $100,000 for the corporation's mill in Henderson, Ky., from L. A. Parker and associates.
C. C. N. Y., Brooklyn College and-Union Temple were victorious in the Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball competition at the Hippodrome last night and advanced to the semi-final round.

One of the smallest of the old New York brownstone residences figured in a sale reported yesterday. It is the tiny dwelling formerly owned by the Harper estate at 143 East Sixty-third Street, on a plot 12.2 by 100.5 feet.

The steel-making capacity of the steel industry at the end of 1936 was 69,244,694 gross tons annually, compared with 69,428,989 tons the year before and with the peak of 69,734,701 tons at the end of 1934.

Urging prompt ratification of the child labor amendment, passage of neutrality legislation to prohibit the use of American armed forces outside continental and territorial United States and endorsing President Roosevelt's, "good neighbor" policy in Pan-American relations, the Women's League of the United Synagogues closed its convention here today by adopting five resolutions.

Abandoning the earlier Republican strategy of letting the Democrats fight out the issue of Supreme Court reorganization among themselves, Senator Vandenberg tonight denounced the President's proposals and expressed favor for the WheelerBone amendment, under which Congress might enact some laws over adverse decisions of the court.

The patience of a Nassau County detective in continuing to question a "hold-up victim" for several hours after hearing details of an assault and robbery in a Glen Head (L. I.) gasoline station early last night led to the admission today that the story of the robbery had been concocted by the victim so he might obtain money to buy an engagement ring for a girl.

Joseph Fay, union labor boss, who was named by John J. Breslin Jr. with Samuel Rosoff, the subway builder, as a conspirator in the murder of Norman Redwood, was accused by the Bergen County, N. J., official yesterday of trying to "chisel in" on contracts the murdered leader of a sandhogs' union had negotiated for labor on World's Fair building.

A fleet of twenty-five capital ships by 1942, with seventy or more cruisers and hundreds of smaller craft, and an air armada totaling, reserves included, at least 5,300 planes by 1939, are predicted here on the eve of the presentation to Parliament tomorrow of the naval estimates for the next fiscal year.

Davidson Av. (11-3200), e. s., 150 ft. s. of 190th St.. 62x100; Dadson Holding Co., Inc., to Ambon Realty Corp., 423 W. 126th St.; mtge., $70,000. Hull Av. (12-3346). n. s., 279 ft. e. of 205th St., 125x100; Knockanower Realty Corp. to Truko Realty Corp., 11 W. 42d St.; mtge., $112,000.

A virtual blockade of the Massachusetts-Rhode Island border by representatives of 2,400 striking truck drivers of this State was broken up tonight by local and State police who dispersed picket lines on three main highways, after hundreds of laden trucks had been turned back at Pawtucket and Woonsocket.
President Roosevelt offered newspaper men today a substitute for the term "must" which they have attached in the past to legislation that the administration wanted passed.
Donald Sweet, a 290-pound Ithaca College freshman from Hoosick Falls, is staging a sit-down strike in protest against Kappa Gamma Psi's initiation paddling.

Support of the United States Sesquicentennial Commission by bar associations while President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court is pending was opposed yesterday in a letter by Robert C. Morris, member of the law firm of Morris, Plante Saxe.

After pointing out that 80 per cent of the city's population did not get proper dental care, Mayor La Guardia said last night that some way must be found to provide dental care for those of the lower-wage brackets.

Acting on a twenty-two-page recommendation, one of the longest in the history of General Sessions, made by Irving Mendelson, Assistant District Attorney, Judge Bohan quashed yesterday the $7,500 bail on which Harry Sherman, former official of the motion picture operators' union, was at liberty on a grand larceny indictment.

In the Court of Claims of the United States the following proceedings were had today: Submissions: Cong. 17540-Yorkville Cotton Oil Co. Plaintiff's motion to substitute party plaintiff filed Feb. 23 is ordered withdrawn on request of counsel for plaintiff. Order entered in open court this date.
Niceto Alcala Zamora, who earned a million and a half pesetas a year as President of Spain, said tonight that he was trying to eke out a living as a newspaper man in Paris.
A gas-proof baby carriage was publicly displayed in London today and will soon be made commercially available to protect infants unable to wear masks.

The Niagara Falls Power Company today flatly refused to obey an order of the New York State Water Power and Control Commission that it give up threefourths of the water that it diverts from the Niagara River.

Franklin Pierce Adams, known to New Yorkers for more than a quarter of a century as F. P. A., announced yesterday that he had severed his relations with The New Herald Tribune, in which he has conducted "The Conning Tower," a paragraph column, since 1931.

President Roosevelt's proposal to increase the personnel of the Supreme Court will be considered by the State Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street, at a meeting tomorrow at noon, it was announced yesterday.

Gino Garibaldi, 216, St. Louis, threw the veteran Rudy Dusek, 218, Omaha, last night in the feature bout of the weekly wrestling show at St. Nicholas Palace. Using a double arm lock, the Italian won in 31 minutes 22 seconds.

There is reason to be lieve the Italian reprisals in Addi?? Ababa, capital of Ethiopia, afte?? the attempt on the life of Mar, shal Rodolfo Graziani, the Viceroy were carried out with a savagery almost beyond description.
Melvin C. Eaton, former New York Republican Chairman, made an indirect plea today to Senator Copeland, Democrat, of New York to help defeat President Roosevelt's plan to reorganize the judiciary.

The Brazilian Government, through the National Coffee Department, will reappear tomorrow at Santos to defend the prices of coffee, intervening in the market at times, it was stated tonight by Arthur SouzaCosta. Minister of Finance.

DAVIS, SARAH E. (Oct. 17, 1936). Gross assets, $50,030; net, $48,799. To William H. Davis, Edith D. Haldimand and John W. Davis, children, one-third residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $46,505. William Henry Davis, attorney, 21 Shawnee Rd. Scarsdale.

Brig. Gen. John Deane Charles Hoskins, retired army officer, died of heart disease last night at his home in Germantown. His age was 91. General Hoskins had been retired since 1908, after forty-four years in the service. He was one of the oldest graduates of West Point.
The Chase National Bank has been appointed transfer agent for the stock of the Holophane Company, Inc., and registrar for the no-par common stock of the United Electric Coal Companies.
Jules Bender broke his 108 consecutive game playing streak tonight as the Long Island University quintet routed Catholic University, 64-37, at the Brookland gymnasium.
Declaring it is going to be hard work right from scratch this year, Manager Frankie Frisch put his crew of Cardinals through two strenuous workouts today.

Anna Grossman, pianist, who gave a recital last night in the Town Hall, showed a good deal of technical proficiency when she played Bach (Toccata in E Minor and Fifth English Suite) and Beethoven (Sonata opus 101) but little interpretive understanding.
Mr. and Mrs. C. Gorham H. Godwin gave a tea yesterday at their home, 969 Park Avenue, to celebrate the second anniversary of their marriage.

" The Corps Drives On," by Yea! Furlough, dramatic organization of the New York Military Academy at Cornwall-on-Hudson, N. Y., will be presented twice this week-end on the annual midwinter hop program.

Possibility of a general steel strike this Spring was scrapped today when the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, the United States Steel Corporation's major subsidiary, signed an agreement with the Steel Workers' organizing committee on behalf of its members who are employes of the corporation.

Turpentine firm, 41c; sales, 45 barrels; receipts, 34 barrels; shipments, 79 barrels; stock, 24,364 barrels. Resin quiet, no sales, receipts 272, shipments 205, stock 56,928. Quote: B, $8,25; D, $8.65; E, $8.95; F, G. H I, $9 50 K, M, $9.65; N, $9.75;

Upsets marked the battle for berths in the semi-final rounds of the New York State singles and the national doubles squash racquets championships for women on the courts of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

The Rev. James P. Opie, an Episcopal minister, announced tonight he had officiated Friday night at the marriage of Mrs. Helen Boughton-Leigh, captain of the 1935 American women's Olympic ski team, to Malcolm E. McAlpin of New York.
Former President Pehr Evind Svinhufvud, who immediately after relinquishing office left for his estate at Kotkaniemi, was acclaimed by crowds throughout his journey.
Dr. Glenn Frank, deposed president of the University of Wisconsin, tonight called President Roosevelt a "leader drunk with power and determined to rule the roost or know the reason why."
Three bandits surprised a gathering of bookmakers going over the "morning line" of racing odds in a restaurant today and robbed them of at least $10,000.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 27: REAR ADMIRAL Craven, T. T., detached as Commandant, 13th Naval District, about May 8, and ordered home, relieved from all active duty.
Miss Cecilia Colledge, brilliant young English skater, today added the figure skating title of the world to her British and European title.
Britain and Japan have virtually completed an agreement, official sources said today, providing for gradual surrender by Britons of their last extra-territorial rights in Japan.

Madison Square Garden, through its legal staff, yesterday started actions against Max Baer; his manager, Ancil Hoffman, and Sydney Hull, matchmaker for. Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley of England, and the last-named as the result of Baer's expressed refusal to keep an engagement to fight Bob Pastor at the Garden, March 19.

New York's Senate confirmed unanimously today the appointment of William J. Sheils, New Rochelle Democrat, as Westchester County surrogate to succeed the late George A. Slater. Governor Lehman transmitted the nomination last night. Meanwhile, the Assembly adjourned out of respect for Surrogate Slater, who died last Tuesday.

The first international conference on trade barriers and economic cooperation since the breakdown of the, World Economie Conference in London in 1933 will be opened by Premier Hezdryk Coliin here tomorrow.

Governor Lehman issued an amendatoryy order today designed to insure the right of Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd to press perjury indictments growing out of the trial in the Drukman case in Brooklyn.

It appears improbable tonight that the scheme for the control of imports of war materials into Spain can come into effective operation next week-end as planned, although the points in dispute have been generally settled.

Although the stock market here was somewhat irregular today, prices in general were firm. Gilt-edge issues were strong for the most part, but in the foreign bond section German securities were weak. International issues were buoyant and United States Steel and International Nickel shares spurted ahead.

The award of honorary scrolls by the Columbia Graduate School Alumni Association to five leading figures in the fields of letters, botany, education and biology was announced yesterday by Charles J. Hoffman, corresponding secretary of the organization.
Baldur von Schirach, Hitler Youth leader, in an open letter to "German parents and German youth," urges all boys and girls who have completed their tenth year "to enter Hitler's service."
The Fascist Grand Council voted early today, after a long night session, to throw all Italy's resources into creating a war machine capable of defending Italy against any adversary.
Anthony Pelleteri's The Shooter won the $1,200 added Stanford Purse, feature race at Santa Anita Park today, finishing two and a half lengths ahead of Golden Era over the six-furlong route.

Former Governor Stanley C. Wilson's $7,500 compromise offer on a $137,000 claim of the closed National Bank of Orange County was rejected in United States District Court today by Judge Harland B. Howe as being "too little" from "one of the foremost members of the bar."
Sit-down strikes by thousands of workers closed two major parts plants in the nation's automobile capital yesterday, but one of the strikes was settled early today.
