Exports of gold bullion in January amounted to 145,658 ounces valued at $5,901,069, compared with 294,593 ounces valued at $10,327,000 in January, 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Urgent representations made by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht and his colleagues in the Reichsbank and the Ministry of Economics have induced the German Government to reduce the allotment of imported raw materials for armament and "Ersatz" [substitute] production.

Mrs. Blanche Adele Spellman Pick, 34 years old, daughter of Benjamin F. Spellman, lawyer, was killed instantly at 8 o'clock last night in a fall from her bedroom window on the eleventh floor of 51. Fifth Avenue to the sidewalk of Twelfth Street near the corner of the avenue.

The possibility of liquidation of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad, now in the process of reorganization, was indicated in a memorandum of decision filed late today in Federal District Court by Judge Carroll C. Hincks.

The significance of the wage increases announced during the last two days by many of the large steel companies cannot be appreciated fully without some understanding of the background of this action. The steel industry is now employing more men than it has ever before employed.

Net earnings of the J. C. Penney Company last year amounted to $18,712,488 after all charges, including taxes. This was equivalent to $7.36 each on the 2,543,984 shares of common stock outstanding, including the recently registered 75,000 shares for issue to employes.
Colonel and Mrs. Arthur O'Brien of this city, who have been living at The Highlands, Seattle, Wash., for a year, are at the Pierre for a week before going to Washington, D. C.

Spokesmen of steamship lines operating from this port have admitted to Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Director of the Regional Labor Board, that they are making possession of union cards showing membership in the International Seamen's Union an essential to obtraining employment on their ships.

At a meeting on Monday of the protective committee for Woodward Iron Company 5 per cent first and consolidated bonds due in 1952 it was decided to issue no new fixed interest bonds on account of interest on existing first-lien collateral notes.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday were well above the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 1,107, as against 637 in the previous week and 861 in the same period last year.

When the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation opens its books for third-quarter business on Friday, it is virtually certain that buyers will find prices possibly $3 to $6 a ton higher than for the first quarter. Late in November prices were advanced $2 to $4 a ton, reflecting the wage increases put into effect a few days before.

In a few words dropped in the middle of a speech at a luncheon in honor of the retiring British Ambassador, Sir George Russell Clerk, Premier Leon Blum today reiterated what he had said on two separate occasions in the last week; that is, that the government, despite all rumors to the contrary, would continue to adhere to the free money policy laid down in the Anglo-French-American declaration of last September.

The Anti-Saloon League of America will invoke the drama in its fight to pledge 10,000,000 youths to total abstinence. "Safety vs. Disaster," the chosen vehicle, will have its premiere tomorrow at the league's convention.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, through its commodore, Van S. Merle-Smith, notified owners and designers of six-meter yachts yesterday that the races for the Seawanhaka Cup and the Scandinavian Gold Cup as well as the trials leading up to them would be sailed with boats rigged under the new rules adopted by the International Yacht Racing Union.
Professor John M. Clark, economist member of the President's committee which reported on the NRA, was asked yesterday at Columbia University if he thought the country needed a new NRA.

Attorneys for the Federal Trade Commission charged today that discounts paid to the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company by a Cambridge packing concern were "actually" rebates given to the chain-store grocery concern in violation of the Robinson-Patman act.
The Chicago Daily News filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 55,000 shares of $100 par value 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

Charles L. Reierson, general sales manager of the Gilbert Bennett Manufacturing Company and former president of the Remington Arms Company, died today at his home here. He was 64 years old. He had been ill for nearly a year.

THE sad news from Clearwater, Fla., is that Manager Burleigh Grimes of the Brooklyn ball club is deadly serious about his men and his work. Being naturally strong of arm and hand, he plans to throttle anything that looks like a lighter vein in the make-up of his more or less agile athletes.

An interim dividend of 75 cents a share was declared by the American Enka Corporation. This compares with a quarterly of 25 cents a share paid on Dec. 15, when an extra of $.50 also was disbursed. O. L. Alexander, chairman, said that directors had decided to discontinue paying regular dividends and would declare interim dividends as deemed advisable.

The countries of the Western Hemisphere can solve their future problems through the spirit of cooperation expressed at the recent Pan American Congress at Buenos Aires, Dr. Augusto S. Boyd, Minister from Panama to the United States, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Pan America Society at India House, 1 Hanover Square.
Thieves stole about 100,000 stamps, rare and otherwise, valued at $20,000, from the eighth floor premises of Globus Co., 268 Fourth Avenue, early yesterday or late Monday night.

Two men pointed revolvers at Miss Ruth Felzblum, bookkeeper of the Eastern Yarn Mills, Inc., as she entered the hallway of the company's building at 205 West Nineteenth Street about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon and took from her an envelope containing $757, the company's payroll.
Governor Lehman announced his support today of a movement for a special commission to study cultural, health and living conditions of urban Negroes with a view toward improvement.
Martha Graham gave her third recital of the season at the Guild Theatre last night, thereby departing from the time-honored schedule which has relegated dance recitals to Sunday.

Broadway's A. H. Woods now seems to be the West Coast's. From Los Angeles yesterday came word that he has leased the Belasco Theatre there, beginning May 1, and that he will launch a program of new plays and revivals of New York hits. Sam H. Harris and William A. Brady are expected to supply him with some of the scripts.
Adolph Sieroty, founder and vice president of Eastern-Columbia chain of Southern California personal furnishings stores, died yesterday at Palm Springs of a heart attack. He was 60 years old.
Two railroads applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to sell equipment bonds totaling more than $8,500,000 to buy new rolling stock and locomotives.

THE striking thing about W. Somerset Maugham is that it appears to be almost as difficult for him to write a stupid book as it is for other authors to write a clever one. Mr. Maugham has nodded, as have all Homers from the beginning of history, but the bulk of his literary output is of surpassing quality. "Of Human Bondage,"

The Hartford Public High School relay team broke the Connecticut interscholastic record for 200 yards tonight as a feature of the fifth Yale swimming carnival, setting a mark of 1:40. The previous record, also held by Hartford, was 1:41.

The defending champions in the Eastern bridge tournament teamof-four event for the Curt H. Reisinger trophy were eliminated yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Commodore in a session in which four teams qualified for the knockout rounds that start today. The defenders who failed to qualify were Fred D. Kaplan, Morrie Elis, Irving Epstein, Lou Jaeger and Charles Vogelhofer.

President Roosevelt sent to Congress the report of his special committee for study of the NRA, conferred on the financing of his housing program, presented the Harmon Aviation Trophy to Howard Hughes and received a group interested in continuing the CCC at full strength.

Mr. and Mrs. George A. Dixon of this city and Paris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vivian Dixon, to T. Dennie Boardman of Boston, son of Mrs. Lawrence Waterbury of Palm Beach, Fla., and of Reginald Boardman of Boston.
Appointed Patrolmen on Probation The following are appointed patrolmen on probation in this department at $2,000 per annum, effective March 1:

Kay Francis, Joe E. Brown and Leslie Howard were listed by Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., as those of its employes and officers who received the highest remuneration during the fiscal year most recently ended.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Katherine Handley, daughter of Mrs. Tom Satterthwaite Handley of Esthwaite, Spring Lake, Mich., and Grand Rapids, Mich., to Jerome Beaudrias, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. J. Beaudrias of Yonkers, N.Y.

The retention by the alumni of British universities of the right to elect their own representatives to Parliament, admittedly an anachronism, is often useful as a means of enabling men of exceptional talents but no formal political affiliations to enter political life.

Melchor G. Ferrer of New York has won the first prize of $50 in the annual Theatre Intime contest for the best play written by a Princeton undergraduate, Thomas H. Smithies of Chicago, president of the Intime, announced today.
Nine more men were added today to the list of more than a score convicted of Black Legion terrorism since the murder of a WPA worker exposed the secret society last May.

President Roosevelt sent to Congress today the report of his special committee to study the National Industrial Recovery act and its administration and with the report a message saying that it "will point the way to the solution of many vexing problems of legislation and administration in one of the most vital subjects of national concern."

W. C. Pitfield Co., Ltd., Canadian security dealers, entered this market yesterday, announcing the formation of W. C. Pitfield Co., Inc., a New York corporation. Ward C. Pitfield, president of the parent company, is chairman of the New York firm. A. D. Hunt will direct the new company as president at 30 Broad Street.

The body of James C. Stevens, 60 years old, a New York insurance broker, who lived at 10 Vincent Place, Montclair, was found about 10 o'clock tonight in the ocean about 500 feet north of the First Avenue Fishing Pier.
Steel ingot production Increased last week when a slight decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to 115.8. It was 113.9 for the previous week, and 73.0 for the week ended Feb. 29, 1936.

Sugar is a Government-regulated industry, and has been one for generations. This fact must be kept in mind in considering the President's latest proposals. They-would not be a new Government " interference " with the industry, but merely a new form of such interference. For years domestic sugar production,

First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler, in charge of traffic, announced yesterday further changes in the new traffic code, which will permit southbound motorists on Riverside Drive to make left turns on red lights at the following intersections:

John Gielgud has returned from a New York appearance in "Hamlet," which broke John Barrymore's and Edwin Booth's records, enthusiastic over receptions there and on an Eastern tour, but complaining bitterly of "candid camera friends" among theatregoers.

The death of Assemblyman Richard B. Smith of Onondaga, depriving the Republicans of their majority and placing both parties in the Assembly in a position where they cannot pass any bill without cooperation, has stopped legislative wheels at dead center, but it was learned tonight that the proposal for a recess until after the special election April 1 to fill the vacant seat had not met with approval among the leaders.

Operas will come and go, but the "Ring" cycle will remain secure in the repertory for more years than a man who lives today can predicate. And for the majority of operagoers it is probable that "Goetterdaemmerung," the climax of the cycle, will stand as one of the summits of human inspiration in the field of the music-drama.

The Eastern Amateur Hockey League replied to the National A. A. U. yesterday in regard to the latter's action on Monday of ruling the Baltimore Orioles ineligible. The answer was framed in a single sentence and was voiced by Tom Lockhart, an official of the circuit and manager of the New York Rovers.
The Fischel Minimum Wage Bill, advocated by Governor Lehman's administration, is due for passage in the Senate tomorrow.
Lieut. Gen. Luigi Montanari, who served as a surgeon in three wars for Italian independence, in 1859, 1860 and 1867, died today at the age of 104.

Under the lead of the March delivery, prices on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to advance. The upward movement has been in progress for seven successive sessions. The gains were 3 to 16 points.

AMBERG, MAX W. (Feb. 20). Estate, more than $10,000. To Irma H. Amberg, widow, executrix, 1,112 Park Av., residue. DE VITO, GAETANO (Jan. 25). Estate, $2,500. To Frank De Vito, brother, executor, 3,246 White Plains Av., Bronx, residue.
President Lazaro Cardenas made himself the dictator of the petroleum industry in Mexico today by an executive decree.
Midtown properties figured in several of the Manhattan realty deals announced yesterday. It was one of the busiest days in several months with respect to sales in this borough.

Improving conditions in railway equipment manufacturing were disclosed in the annual report of the American Locomotive Company, issued yesterday. The company reported a net profit in 1936 for the first time since 1930.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

Whether the Legislature has the right to abolish so-called heart-balm actions, and whether the Act of 1935 which sought to accomplish this is unconstitutional, as the courts below have held, was put before the Court of Appeals today in the case of Lawrence Hanfgarn of Floral Park against George Mark of Elmont, Nassau County.

Mrs. Charles Evans Hughes Jr., wife of the son of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, was reported to be "doing nicely" tonight at the Atlantic City Hospital, where she underwent an appendicitis operation earlier in the day.
Acton Griscom will serve as cnairman of the men's committee in the fund-raising campaign of the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra.

Daniel P. Guiney, a patrolman formerly attached to the Butler Street precinct in Brooklyn, must be reinstated to the police force, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn held yesterday, in overruling an order of Police Commissioner Valentine dismissing him.

Louis Dups, formerly with the Mutual Life Insurance Co., has joined Wm. A. White Sons. The five-story brick buildings at 121-123125 Newark Av., Jersey City, which were damaged by fire, are to be rebuilt by B. Carlin for the John Mullins Furniture Co. A. Davis Is the architect.
Mrs. Laura Letzer, descendant of two prominent Maryland families, died at her home here yesterday at the age of 71. Her husband, William Clark Sweeten, died in 1893. Mrs.

Centering in Ohio, earth tremors this morning shook five States from the Canadian border to Kentucky, interrupting business and causing slight property damage. While in some communities there were as many as five distinct shocks, no injuries were reported.

Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta, addressing the Senate and Chamber foreign relations committees at a joint session today, said the report of a coming break in the Little Entente [Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia] was false, adding that its solidarity would be demonstrated again by President Eduard Benes on his forthcoming visit to Belgrade, Yugoslavia.

Edith Mason, grand-opera star, arrived here this afternoon and declared she came here for her health. Asked if she intended seeking a divorce from Georgio Polacco, she replied: "I am here for my health, and that is all."

Charles Pellman, son of Mrs. Jennie Pellman of 22 West Fifty-fourth Street, this city, is a member of the cast of Fred Ballard's "Ladies of the Jury," a comedy, to be presented Friday in the Little Theatre at Ithaca College by students of the Department of English and Drama.
President Getulio Vargas sent to Congress today a message asking another ninety-day extension of the state of war [a form of martial law]. The present state of war expires March 17.

The new Federal Constitution for that vast subcontinent loosely called India has just had its first trial in the initial provincial elections concluded last week. The returns which have been coming in for a fortnight, though still incomplete, indicate that the Congress party, which is opposed to the new Constitution in its entirety and

The 150 copies of the jubilee issue of the China Press that got tangled up in governmental red tape last Friday were finally banished from the United States yesterday, with all their encyclopaedic reports on present-day China, because of a literal interpretation of the Tariff Act of 1935.

G. K. Chesterton, who was so very fond of paradox, would have received a real treat on March 1 when the Carnegie Endowment for Peace advocated an international policy certain to lead to war. The subtle, delicate sophistries of the pre-World War days disported themselves in every line of the warring peace report.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 1: COLONELS Metcalfe, R. F., Med. Corps, appointed as assistant to the Surgeon General, with rank of Brigadier General.

Deliveries of airplanes, airplane engines and parts in January increased 62 per cent over those of the corresponding month of 1936, a report of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America revealed yesterday.

Eight months of the 1937 fiscal year endd several days ago with the government's deficit nearly $400,000,000 less than in the same period of the preceding year, it was revealed by today's Treasury announcement of P the daily statement for Feb. 27.

President Roosevelt started active work on the Wagner-Steagall bill for alum clearance and low-cost housing today, bringing together a group of the proponents of the measure and the administration fiscal authorities who will be responsible for raising the necessary money.

The Pamana Pacific liner California arrived yesterday from the West Coast for the first time since the beginning of the general shipping strike last Fall. She left New York in October and was tied up at San Pedro, Calif., from Oct. 31.

The renewal by Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany's demand for restoration of her colonies was answered inferentially by Foreign Minister Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today in a debate on British foreign policy.

The Indiana House of Representatives passed today the Senate bill which its opponents said would mean the ousting of Dr. William A. Wirt as superintendent of schools at Gary. Dr. Wirt gained attention two years ago by testifying before a Congressional committee that he believed President Roosevelt was "the Kerensky of the American revolution."

Leading stocks strong; steel motor, rail and copper shares up 1 to 6 1/2 points; turnover, 2,294,970 shares. United States Government issues lower, corporation and foreign bonds narrow and mixed; transactions, $13,610,600.
C. Blackburn Miller, president of the Salt Water Anglers of America, has made public the contents of a letter just received from President Roosevelt pertaining to the study of marine fishes.

William A. Brady of New York, theatrical producer, petitioned the United States Circuit Court today to allow him to appeal from the decree of District Judge Oliver B. Dickinson which confirmed the reorganization plan of Baldwin Locomotive Works under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act.

The City Affairs Committee, through Frederick L. Guggenheimer, its executive director, made public yesterday a letter to the Public Service Commission asking that hearings be held on the subject of the charges by the telephone company for telephone hand-sets.

Felix Lenorcy, Acting French Financial Attache in London, who arranged a ??40,000,000 loan with British banks a few days ago, left hastily for Paris today, bearing a most important message from the British Treasury.

The eighth and last performance of the season of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" will be given a special non-subscription matinee on Wednesday, March 10, at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday. There will be no advance in the price of seats for this performance.

An intimation that the Board of Trade, which is in charge of tariff matters in Australia, will recommend changes in the tariff set-up there was given by David M. Dow, official Secretary for Australia in the United States, at a luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Mr.
For his concerts on Thursday night and Friday afternoon, Artur Rodzinski, guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, has rearranged the order of the program. It now reads:

A 5 cents an hour wage increase was announced today for all employes of the picketed Douglas Aircraft plant, scene of a sitdown strike last week which ended with the felony indictment of nearly 350 workmen.

Following is a summary of the report on the National Recovery Administration by the President's Comittee on Industrial Analysis. The summary was made at the White House by condensing the conclusions presented by the committee in Chapter XX of its report, under the heading "General Estimate of Accomplishment."

The death of Joan Morvan, 4 years old, at her home at 115-41 Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica, Monday afternoon was caused by peritonitis resuiting from an attack, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Howard W. Neail, senior assistant medical examiner in Queens.

Workhouse terms were imposed by Magistrate Aurelio in Tombs Court yesterday on three leaders of the thirty-three WPA workers who staged a three-day sit-down strike outside the WPA offices at 40 Varick Street before their arrest on Feb. 14.
Representative Elmer H. Wene of the Second Congressional District denied today he had contributed to a fund to buy votes in the November election.

Prominent Britons in the act of denouncing Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his regime from public platforms are being photographed by Nazi agents and their pictures and speeches are being published in Germany' in the form of magazines, which are subsequently distributed to the speakers' homes with anonymous letters threatening their lives.

Purchase of six autogiros and the customary complement of spare parts from the Kellett Autogiro Corporation of Philadelphia was announced today by the War Department. The total cost was $238,482.18, or $39,747.03 for each machine and spare parts.

Young Jack Gibbons, 172, St. Paul, outpunched and outboxed Mickey Misko, 170, Saginaw, Mich., to win a clear decision in a ten-round bout at the Arena Gardens tonight. In the eight-round semi-final George Nichols, 166, Buffalo, N. Y., outpointed Stanley Evans, 173, Detroit.

With 2,000 births reported in the city for the week ended Saturday, Feb. 27, the total births for the first eight weeks of the year were 16,049, or more than in the corresponding period in 1936, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday. The birth rate for the week was 14 per 1,000 population, as compared with 12.5 for the corresponding week in 1936.

Crime has a most inviting appearance in "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse," which was acted at the Hudson last evening. From now on it is going to be hard for theatregoers to go straight and keep inside the law. For Sir Cedric Hardwicke, who impersonates the chief felon in Barre Lyndon's play,

Boards of directors of Republic Steel Corporation and the Gulf States Steel Company approved today a contract providing for the sale to Republic of all properties and assets of Gulf in consideration of the issuance to Gulf of Republic common stock.

An ice jam, which recently blocked St. John's for twelve days, did much damage at the government fisheries laboratories at Bay Bulls. Total collapse of the main building was averted only when the government rushed workmen to the structure yesterday.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was fair on steer hinds and ribs with prices strong to slightly higher. Some steer cuts were sharply higher. Other classes moved only fair to slow at unchanged prices. Kosher meats opened steady with Monday's close.

With concessions from Equity and the Stagehands and Musicians Unions, "The Eternal Road" is about to become the first regular attraction to take advantage of the law permitting Sunday performances in the New York theatres.

Manufacturers of ladies' garments, millinery, handbags, and similar lines were among the firms contracting for business space yesterday, according to brokers' reports. Chain organizations took two stores for new units. The list follows:
Premium writings in 1936 of the American Mutual Liability Insurance Company were more than 25 per cent larger than a year earlier, according to Charles E. Hodges, president.
The police held Jesus Eduardo Sanchez today on a charge that he had set off a bomb filled with nails which exploded in the bar of the Royal Hotel yesterday.
Five Westchester pianists have been chosen to compete in a final audition for a place on the 1937 May Westchester Music Festival program as a result of the preliminary auditions.

Two lawyers were forced to resign from the bar yesterday by Bernard C. Botein, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the new Accident Fraud Bureau. Mr. Botein later laid a trap through which an itinerant "runner" for lawyers was arrested by two of the prosecutor's detectives as he was allegedly soliciting accident cases in a ward in Bellevue Hospital.

The residuary estate of James Neilson is bequeathed to the truetees of Rutgers College, according to the will probated here today. Mr. Neilson, who was the oldest Rutgers alumnus, died here Feb. 19 at the age of 92. Although no announcement was made as to the value of the estate, it was estimated at more than $500,000.

Repeating her performance of a year ago, Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis carried off medal honors today in the qualifying round for the women's Florida East Coast championship on St. Augustine links with a score of 42, 34-76.

The old Chisholm mansion at College Point, picked by Mayor La Guardia as the city's 1937 Summer City Hall, is a mere hour and ten minutes from Times Square by subway and bus under favorable conditions.

Harry H. Charles, president of the Charles Advertising Service, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street and former president of the New York Advertising Club, died yesterday of pneumonia at his residence, 355 Riverside Drive, at the age of 72.

Irish Johnny Clinton, West Side welterweight, won a close decision from Lew Raymond of Baltimore in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 9,000 noisily dissented from the verdict.
Ulmer C. Russ, senior member of U. C. Russ Company, printing establishment, 226 William Street, New York, died at his home here last night after suffering a stroke four days ago.

Alfredo Salmaggi and his company will present "Rigoletto" on Friday night at the Hippodrome. On Saturday afternoon "The Barber of Seville" will be offered, and in the evening "Tosca" will be the production.

Anton Grohar's tavern patrons stood him up by sitting down. They sat down, Anton grumbled today, in a strike against ten-cent beer, and while they sat they played cards, ate free pretzels and peanuts and called for water.

County Judge James F. Brearton assigned Charles S. Meehan, Troy lawyer, today as counsel for William Franco, and ordered Franco's trial for .the murder of Michael Kane, taxicab driver, six years ago. Franco, arrested in Brooklyn last December, told the court that he was financially unable to engage counsel. Previouslv Michael I.

Senators Copeland and Robinson took exception today to published reports that Senate criticism of the Bureau of Air Commerce had been aimed at Colonel J. Carroll Cone, assistant director, along with Rex Martin, assistant director, who was relieved of that post by Secretary Roper yesterday in his reorganization of the bureau.
Britain turned to Northern Ireland tonight to help recruit her territrial army, the defense force of the British Isles.

Operators and investors were active yesterday in Bronx deals, which included the sale of several apartments and industrial property. A syndicate purchased the two five-story apartments at 2,541-2,547 Aqueduct Avenue from the Adca Realty Company.

Death Announced Fireman 1st Grade Patrick J. Galligan of H. and L. 113 died Feb. 28. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 1,086 Ocean Av., Brooklyn, at 8:45 A. M. Thursday, March 4. Interment at Old Calvary Cemetery.

The annual Army Day parade will be held on Fifth Avenue, from Ninetieth Street to Sixty-third Street, on Saturday, April 10, it was announced yesterday by the Military Order of the World War, which arranges this event in connection with the nation-wide observance of Army Day. The Fifth Avenue Association is cooperating.

The foundation for the peaceful settlement of the threatened labor dispute in the steel industry was laid at a series of man-to-man talks held in this city last week between Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, and John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, it was learned i?? Wall Street yesterday.
An Anglo-Saxon alliance, backed by the armed forces of the United States and Great Britain, would constitute the best guarantee of world peace, said Viscount Craigavon,

Warren Sidney Chapman of 48 Pulaski Street, injured four years ago while playing football, is dead after a long fight during which many blood transfusions were resorted to. He was 15 years old. The boy, a pupil at Demarest School, suffered a bone injury. His school principal, Lloyd V. Krueger, aided the transfusions.

The receipt of an order from the Queens-Nassau Transit Lines, Inc., for fifty-five forty-one-passenger omnibuses by the American Car and Foundry Motors Company was announced yesterday by Charles J. Hardy, president of the manufacturing company.

Agreeing with officials of the Westchester Lighting Company that a woman's viewpoint would be valuable in the management of a public utility, stockholders of the concern at their annual meeting this afternoon elected Mrs. Kenneth B. Norton of Bronxville a director.

Hans Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, is publicly accused in an open letter by the Confessional Church leader, Dr. Otto Dibelius, retired leader of the Evangelical Union, of attacking and deriding fundamental doctrines of the Christian faith.

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding the Second Corps Area, with headquarters at Governors Island, sailed yesterday at noon on the Army transport Chateau Thierry from the Army Base, Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, for San Juan, Porto Rico, on his annual inspection of army units there.

Frank Iannicelli of the New York Athletic Club, second seeded, was eliminated by Charles Fechheimer of the City A. C. in a quarter-final round match of the national Class B squash tennis championship at the Crescent Athletic Club, Brooklyn, yesterday, 17--15, 6--15, 17--15.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are March 2 unless specified: At Culebra: Lapwing, Teal, March 1. At Honolulu, March 1: Lark, Tanager. Bridge, at San Francisco, March 2. Cassin, Philadelphia yard to Lewes, Del. Erie, Tompkinsville to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk.

The last place Chicago Black Hawks nursed their mathematical chances for one of the National Hockey League's play-off berths tonight by outskating the Boston Bruins for a 4-2 triumph before 10,000 at the Boston Garden.

77th St., 103 W., n. s., 35x100.6; Central Savings Bank to 103 W. 77th St. Corp., 415 Lexington Av. ($45). 97th St., 106 E., s. s., 25x100.11; Guy H. Mulligan to Frederick W. Robinson, Shrewsbury, N. J. 48th St., 147 W., n. a., 20x100.5; Browntop Realty Corp., Alfred H. Kilt president, to Amalia Malone, 119 Grove St,; mtg. $30,000 ($15.50).

The Oxford crew smashed a forty-year-old record today when it rowed from Chiswick Steps to Putney Bridge in 11 minutes 9 seconds while working out for the annual boat race on the Thames with Cambridge, March 24.
A suit threatened by Raymond W. Moore of the New York Athletic Club over the will of his wife, Mrs. Edna Tweedy Moore, heiress to the Bradey lumber millions, has been settled out of court.
The Merchants Association of New York disclosed yesterday that it had asked legislative leaders to support measures enabling New York City to make a practical test of the parking meter.

The Assembly Judiciary Committee voted late this afternoon to report the Kleinfeld Resolution to ratify the Child Labor Amendment to the Federal Constitution without a recommendation for favorable action by the Assembly. The resolution has already been adopted by the Senate. where the Democrats are in control.

After delays and disputes extending over more than two years, the registration statement covering an issue of $69,000,000 of 3 per cent dollar bonds that are to be issued by Germany to American holders of German bonds in lieu of past-due interest became effective today.
The captains of 275 vessels icebound for three months in the New York State Barge Canal were cheered today by the prospect of getting under way on or about March 25.

Stanley Galowin of the City Athletic Club, Albert E. Watt of Jackson Heights and Elisha Leo Jr. of Block Hall gained the semi-final round of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association, Group 1, championship yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.

The preliminary report of the Illinois Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for 19386 shows a net income of $2,199,048 after interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization, subsidiary preferred dividends and surtax on undistributed profits.

In a bruising three-round struggle, Allie Stolz of Paterson, the New Jersey State flyweight champion, carried off the decision over Bobby Carroll of Trenton to gain an open final berth in the fourteenth annual Golden Gloves tournament as the second section of semi-finals was completed at the Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night.

ARVINTZ-Sarah, wife of the late Aron, devoted mother of Abraham A., Nathan A. and Robert A. Arvintz and Rose Rosenthal. Services today 11 A. M., Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1,283 Coney Island Av., Brooklyn. BAER-Bernard, beloved husband of Annie, devoted father of Jacob, Louis, Mitchel, Philip, Sadie Shapiro, Stella Lippman, Mabel Levine and Fay Simmons. Services Thursday, March 4, 11:30 A. M., Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Av.

The text of the agreement between the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee announced today was as follows: This agreement, dated March 2, 1937, between CarnegieIllinois Steel Corporation and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee on behalf of the members of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers of North America employed by the corporation:
The Oratorio Society of New York, directed by Albert Stoessel, presented its eleventh complete performance of Bach's apocalyptic B minor Mass at Carnegie Hall last night.

A Naval Supply Bill carrying $526,555,428 for the fiscal year 1938, or $1,547,104 less than. the record peace-time appropriation for the current year, was favorably reported by the House Appropriations Committee today.

Miss Lizzie, either second or third in her three previous races, got into the winner's column today, when she carried A. J. Stallings's silks to victory over seven other $2,000 players in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

An all-day conference on alum clearance and low-rent housing to be held on March 9 at City Hall by the National Public Housing Conference will be opened by Mayor La Guardia. Jonah J. Goldstein, chairman of the New York Committee on Public Housing, will preside.
President Roosevelt got out a big blue chart of the Gulf of Mexico today and mapped a tarpon fishing trip for himself for late April.

A vote of practically 100 per cent in favor of a strike is expected by union officials in the poll now being taken of the 86,000 members of the standard railroad unions over their wage restoration dispute with the two Canadian railways.

Fred Frankhouse signed his contract and Tony Malinosky, new shortstop from Louisville, agreed to terms, leaving only Van Lingle Mungo and Buddy Hassett in camp to defend the holdout fort, Business Manager John Gorman disclosed today.

Miss Vera Felicity Story, daughter of Mrs. Julian Story of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Story, noted portrait painter, was married this afternoon to Henry Latrobe Roosevelt Jr., son of Mrs. Henry Latrobe Roosevelt of Washington, D. C., and the late Mr. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy.
Yesterday's attempt at Jassy University to murder Professor Trajan Ratu has aroused the country to the danger threatening it from Fascist terrorists.

A general strengthening of the Commodity Exchange Act to provide more intensive regulation of the grain trade and reinforcement of antitrust laws to prevent further concentration of corporate power in a relatively few concerns was recommended to Congress today in a report by the Federal Trade Commission.

Continued relatively small receipts of hogs and a better movement of fresh pork brought all interests into the market as buyers of hogs today and sales generally were 5 to 10 cents higher than yesterday.

The first court of honor of army officers, sitting according to regulations recently promulgated by the Schuschnigg government, met last week to try a former chief of staff of the Socialist Republican Defense Corps, General Theodore Koerner, and two other former Imperial General Staff officers who joined the Socialist party and supported the Defense Corps-Generals Schneller and Mayer.
Representatives of the nation's outdoor organizations drove on today toward the-goal of obtaining restoration of threatened natural resources through an aroused public opinion.
Lord and Lady Swinfen of London have returned to the WaldorfAstoria after a tour of the South. They will sail on Wednesday on the Queen Mary.
Six men, all but one Bronx residents, were slightly hurt yesterday afternoon in a collision between two street cars at Atlantic Avenue and Court Street, Brooklyn.
The Fascist Grand Council early today approved a sweeping seven-point program for increasing the population of Italy.
Syracuse's "S-men" gained their twelfth victory of the basketball season tonight by downing Niagara, 46 to 33.

IT must be that touch of Spring in the air. Though it may be temporary, the dignified Metropolitan Museum of Art has kicked up its architectural heels to the extent of including a sports section. The official billing is: "A Special Exhibition. Sporting Prints and Paintings." Second floor, turn left.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $705,869,461 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on March 1, was $45.56, compared with $45.30 at the beginning of February.

The establishment of a mixed Franco-Tunisian legislative committee to alleviate unrest in Tunis was advocated by Pierre Vienot, Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, upon his return today from an inspection trip of the French protectorate.
Senator Norris of Nebraska "guessed" today that he would have to draw up a constitutional amendment to change the weather.

It is too early to say whether or not Germany has already pushed its combined armament and self-containment program to its farthest possible limits, but the increasing difficulties which that program involves seem now to have come to a head. The signs are both financial and physical.
The Canadian Government held 105,458 ounces of gold for the Treasury and 176,218 ounces in the Dominion mint on Jan. 31, Charles Dunning, Finance Minister, reported today in the House of Commons.

The Senate adopted today the Pittman neutrality resolution laying down a course of conduct for the President in the event of war abroad in order to keep this country from becoming involved. The vote was 63 to 6.
England and the Spanish Inquisition provide the background for the Erich Pommer-London Films production of A. E. W. Mason's "Fire Over England," opening today at the Radio City Music Hall.
Favorable results were reported yesterday by two steel companies which announced their annual figures for 1936.

H. D. Shuldiner Co, have is sued an analysis of first mortgage fee. 6 per cent bonds of the Majestic Apartments, together with a summary of the reorganization plan. The Guaranty Trust Company, as depository
Homewood Flirtatious, 1935 national champion, showed exceptional form but failed to exhibit a "nose for birds" todaY in the national field trials.
A good demand for tenement houses in the Yorkville section was indicated in realty transactions reported yesterday in Manhattan. Some of the properties will be modernized.

A new high mark for construction activity in the Borough of Queens was set in February with the filing of plans for work estimated to cost more than $16,000,000, according to a report made yesterday to Borough President Harvey by Acting Commissioner of Buildings Clifton A. Ripperberger.

The Santos coffee market opened today with a representative of the National Coffee Department in attendance. Futures in the amount of 7,500 bags were traded on the Bourse in the morning and 30,500 bags at both the morning and the afternoon sessions. Prices fluctuated between 136.8 and 138.6 milreis a ba.

Sixteen colleges have named teams for the mile relay championship in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field meet which will be held a week from Saturday at Madison Square Garden. This is the largest entry in the history of the games and is perhaps the best balanced, with no outstanding favorite.
The Pittsburgh Steamship Company, a subsidiary of United States Steel Corporation, announced today that it will build -four 600-foot Great Lakes freighters to carry iron ore.

The Jones Beach Surf Fishing Club of Freeport, L. I., has requested the Conservation Department to conduct a survey of the lakes, ponds and streams of Nassau County in order to determine which of these is best for stocking game fish.

The New York Association for the Blind spent $472,863 in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, according to its thirtieth annual report, made public yesterday. This represented an excess of expenses over income of $76.684.

Evidence intended to show conditions in restaurants before and after unionization, held by the defense attorneys in the restaurant racket trial to be of vital importance to their case, was ruled out yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

Two Bob and White Cockade, both candidates for the $50,000 Widener Challenge Cup to be run Saturday, raced to a nose finish at Hialeah this afternoon after more than a dozen other candidates had been on the track in morning workouts.

The marriage of Mrs. Anita Bradshaw Nichols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Bradshaw of Morristown, N. J., to John Livingston Hopkins of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Linton Cook Hopkins of Atlanta, Ga., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church.
Lieutenant Franklin M. Kreml of the Evanston (Ill.) Police Department received a check for $5,000 last night from the C. I. T. Safety Foundation for outstanding work in traffic safety during 1936.

Miss Peggy Reynolds, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry C. Reynolds of this place, has set April 2 as the date for her marriage to Robert Roew Hertzler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver H. Hertzler of Lancaster, Pa. The wedding will take place in Blanchard Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church here.

In a message to all General Motors employes yesterday, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, stated the position of the company arising from the settlement of the recent automobile strike, emphasizing the principles of labor relations to be followed by the company under the settlement.
The Bishop of London, assailing "miserable propaganda for birth control," asserted today that a larger population would solve the problem of railroad deficit.

Albert E. Watt of the Jackson Heights Squash Club, second seeded entrant, staged a brilliant rally to defeat his clubmate, Andrew McKenna, in the semi-finals of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group I championship tourney at the New York A. C. last night.

Joseph R. Johann, defending champion, went into second place in the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline billiard tournament by defeating Samuel Swenarton, 200103, in twenty-nine innings at the Capitol Health Center last night.

Thomas J. Newton of 15 Brewster Terrace, New Rochelle, treasurer and a director of F. R. Tripler Co., men's furnishers, Forty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, died Tuesday night in the Medical Arts Sanitarium, 57 West Fifty-seventh Street, at the age of 66.
Poisons were kept in the White Plains home of Mrs. Ida L. Churchill with her knowledge and consent, Chang Soo Lee testified today as the first defense witness at his trial for attempted murder.

Adams, McEntee Co., Inc., obtained the award yesterday of a new issue of $520,000 of public welfare, public works, public building and bridge bonds of Niagara Falls, N. Y., on a bid of 100.58 for 2s. The bonds will be dated March 1,
William B. Smith, for years prominent in Baltimore political and legal circles, a former member of City councils and the State Legislature, lied last night at his home here at the age of 59.
Frank P. Headley, a former actor and newspaper advertising man, died in St. Joseph's Hospital here today in his seventy-first year. He retired several years ago because of ill health.

Captain Thomas E. Halls, veteran secret service agent credited with thwarting a plot to steal the body of Abraham Lincoln from its tomb many years ago, died today after a long illness. His age was 92, He was retired from the service in 1929.
Electric power production declined less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index advanced to 109.7, a new all-time high figure, from 106.6. It was 98.2 for the week ended Feb. 29, 1936.

In the U. S. Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: PATENTS 3765--Kellogg Co. v. General Mills, Inc., Dismissed upon motion of aplt. 3762--Ex part Union Oil Co. of Calif. Argued.
Sunshine and balmy breezes, in marked contrast to the Maine and Vermont brand of weather that prevailed for several days, made today's workout, the Dodgers' third, pleasurable.
The President and Mrs. Roosevelt were guests of honor tonight at the annual dinner given for them by the Cabinet.
Police closed the newspaper Cziennik Popularny permanently and arrested the fourteen members of its staff today on the charge that the publication was a Communist organ. After searching the

Prime Minister Mackenzie King will on Friday pay his second visit to President Roosevelt since his election to office a year and a half ago. He will do so on the President's invitation extended in a letter written in Mr. Roosevelt's own hand, dated Feb. 19.
Reaction of the Merchants Association to bills pending in the Legislature affecting real estate was made public yesterday.

James Rowland Angell, retiring president of Yale University, has just sent the Yale University Press the last pages of his manuscript, "American Education." The book is to be published early in May. It will contain a selection of Dr. Angell's addresses and articles of the last fifteen years.
Mrs. Jeanette Trader, accused of slaying her estranged husband, Clarence J. Trader, owner of an electric light plant, died at Peninsula General Hospital today, following an operation yesterday.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated March 2: BRIGADIER GENERAL Pratt, H. C., 3 days' leave, March 12. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Wall, J. F., Cavalry, 3 months' and 8 days' leave, March 22.

Jacqueline Salomons, French violinist, gave a recital in the Town Hall last night, which was attended by a sizable and responsive gathering. Miss Salomons made her debut in the same auditorium six years ago and has been heard here frequently since. Her program at this

A national plan for regulating the distribution of electricity in Britain aimed at unification of systems and voltages and establishment of uniform charges was announced in the House of Commons today by Leslie Hore-Belisha, Minister of Transport.

The Senate has unanimously approved a resolution calling on President Federico Laredo Bru to inform that body whether- there exists friction between the United States and Cuban Governments resulting from the recent signing of the Cuban-British trade treaty.

The following film programs, which will be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:
An old-line American Federation of Labor craft union announced through its representative tonight the launching of a New Jersey organization campaign along industrial lines with C. I. 0. approval.

John T. Rogers, a Post-Dispatch reporter for twenty years, died suddenly last night while calling on family friends. Although not feeling well for a week, Mr. Rogers had been at The Post-Dispatch office daily. He was 55 years old.

Tobe of the Tobe Fashion Service and Julia Coburn, who has just resigned as fashion editor of the Ladies Home Journal, will found a "School for Fashion Careers," to open next September, it was announced here yesterday.

Objection to making the North Beach Airport in New York a terminus for the Pan-American Airways and other air transportation lines was expressed today by Representative O'Toole, New York Democrat, in a letter to Mayor La Guardia. Mr. O'Toole called the proposal "a foolish expenditure of funds."
The engagement of $11,628,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by local commercial banks.

The compositions of David Stanley Smith, dean of the Yale University School of Music, filled the program of the Composers' ForumLaboratory last night at the WPA Theatre of Music, 254 West Fiftyfourth Street.

The Oxford crew, considered the strongest Dark Blue eight in years, today broke another rowing record, the second in as many days. The Oxonians rowed from Barnes Bridge to Chiswick Steps in 3 minutes 34 seconds, beating their own 1933 record by 12 seconds.

Michael Krupsky, 19 years old, was denounced by Judge Bohan as a menace to society as he sentenced him yesterday in General Sessions to twenty years to life imprisonment on his guilty plea to seconddegree murder in the shooting of Fred Dunn, 29, ex-convict, last Jan. 2 in an apartment at 11 West Sixtyfifth Street.

Assistant District Attorney George A. Tilzer of the Bronx began an investigation yesterday into the death at 1:30 A.. M. of a 15-months-old boy who had been boarded out by the New York Foundling Hospital.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, tonight discounted recognition of rival unions by steel companies, and declared that the federation would continue its fight to become sole bargaining agent between workers and employers, despite wage increases and shorter working hours granted.

The Turkish Foreign Office appears desirous of minimizing the importance of the German demarche on the Montreux convention. It does not, in fact, admit any official action has been taken by Germany in this connection.

Notwithstanding a gain in pig iron output in February on a daily basis, there are increasing signs of a shortage of iron. Production last month, according to The Iron Age, was 2,994,883 gross tons compared with 3,211,500 tons in January, but the daily rate was 3.2 per cent higher than in January - 106,960 tons against 103,597 tons.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art asked Justice Julius Miller in Supreme Court yesterday to rule that it was a charitable institution and therefore exempt from the New York City sales tax. Controller Frank J. Taylor has held that it is an educational institution and must pay the tax on paintings and other objects of art that it buys and sells.

AMERICAN CITY: A RANK AND FILE HISTORY, by Charles Rumford Walker. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) A study of social change. ANGRY DUST; AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF NIKOLAI GUBSKY. (Oxford, $3.50.) An unusual autobiography.

Howard Magnussen, 26 years old, of 96 Columbia Avenue, Huntington Station, L. I., confessed yesterday, according to the police in Queens, that last Sunday he criminally assaulted Joan Morvan, 4 years old, thereby causing her death from peritonitis on Monday at her home at 115-41 Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Curtis Merrill, daughter of Mrs. Philip H. James of Portland, Me., to William Juhring Broadhurst, son of Mrs. William C. Broadhurst of 1,148 Fifth Avenue, this city.

Secondary and convertible railroad bonds and convertible industrial issues held the center of interest in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Spectacular gains were scored in both sections in response to the strength in the junior securities on the Stock Exchange as well as to the psychological effect of the recent developments in the capitallabor field.

Professor Albert Einstein has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the American Committee Appeal for the Jews in Poland, 225 West Thirty-fourth Street, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Winter, national chairman.

State Senator Aubrey Weaver announced today that about May 15 the Viscose Corporation of Virginia would start construction on the 323 acres that it recently purchased here, of the first unit of a rayon-yarn manufacturing mill.

An apparent collapse of the company's employee representative system marked the start today of negotiations between Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America, with a corresponding strengthening of the position of the union.

Thanks to the prowess of Harry F. Wolf, who has been national champion in squash tennis for the last seven years, the New York Athletic Club yesterday annexed the metropolitan Class A team title by defeating the Columbia Club, 3 to 2, in the play-off match at the Harvard Club.
A son was born on Monday to Mr. and Mrs. Francis Vernon Lloyd Jr. of St. Paul's School, this place. Mrs.

An American petroleum company opereating oil fields in the Bahrein Islands (Persian Gulf) is making extensive plans to enter the Indian market, according to a report from Vice Consul D. B. Anderson, at Bombay, to the Commerce Department. It is reported locally that

A final vote on the Fischel Minimum-Wage Bill in the Senate was delayed until next week because eight Democrats were absent from their seats today. John J. Dunnigan, Democratic leader, had planned to put the measure, favored by Governor Lehman's administration, through the Senate at today's session.
Within the next day or two the 250 members of the City Gardens Club will receive a letter asking them to count the trees on the streets on which they live.
Awards of fellowships to Vassar College students and alumnae and elections to Phi Beta Kappa were announced today in college assembly.
The joint wage conference of soft coal operators and miners of the Appalachian area, meeting at the Hotel Biltmore, adjourned yesterday until next Tuesday. John L.
Ralph A. Light, vice president of the United States Metallic Packing Company, died last night, two hours after being stricken on a squash court of the Philadelphia Country Club. He was 44 years old.
William E. Borah rounded out thirty years of Senate service today, a longer period than any other living member of that body.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced amendment of Rule 566 under the Securities Act of 1933. The rule as amended now reads: "Rule 566. Incorporation by reference of contested material.

The Sun-Telegraph says today that it has learned that Mrs. Myron C. Taylor, wife of the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, unintentionally helped open the way for the negotiations which ended in the corporation's recognition of John L. Lewis's steel union.

George H. Alderton, a buyer for Arnold Constable Co. until his retirement fifteen years ago, died today at his home, 340 Mamaroneck Avenue, at the age of 71. He had been with the company thirty years, and as buyer for the interior decorating department traveled extensively in this country and Europe.

When the six-man jury hearing the suit for $3.85 for alleged overcharges against the New York Telphone Company failed to agree after deliberating two hours yesterday, Municipal Court Justice Daniel V. Sullivan ordered them to leave a written verdict to be presented at the opening of court today.

Mayor La Guardia will break ground at one and possibly two new Harlem public school sites tomorrow at 3 P. M., according to an announcement yesterday by James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education.
Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw entertained with a dinner last night at her home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street, for Lord Davies, later taking her guests to the opera.

George T. Dunlap Jr., 1933 national amateur champion, whose consistently fine play has been a feature of the Tin Whistle and other competitions here during the Winter, was in rare fettle today for the opening round of the thirty-third annual best-ball match play Spring tournament.

The stock market here today was irregular and dull except that the international group made a new high record. British funds became firm after. a dull opening but fell back later in the day. In the foreign section, German and Japanese securities were off.

Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company Series A preference stock, $100 par value, is to be admitted to the list today. The Monsanto Chemical Company has notified the Exchange of a proposal to create 275,000 shares of no par value preferred and to increase the authorized common from 1,250,000 to 1,725,000 shares.
The indications are for cloudy and warmer weather today and for rain and colder tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.
Rene Seligman entertained today with a cocktail party at his villa for Nicolas de Molas of London and Paris, his guest.

Friends of Gabriele d'Annunzio denied today that he was seriously ill, although the poet, in a letter to Achille Starace, secretary general of the Fascist party, had said: "I am now old and ill and my end is near."

Manhattan's swimming team closed its dual-meet season with a 41-to-28 victory over the University of Delaware at the Hotel Park Central pool yesterday. The Jaspers captured first places in six of the eight events, including the 400-yard relay. It was the Green's third triumph in seven meets.

Three of the six members of the Republic of Colombia Bondholders' Committee, named to represent the interest of holders of $152,851,000 in defaulted Colombian bonds, are directly or indirectly connected with the Standard Oil Company of New

In a Camden Chancery Court room, crowded by more than 200 spectators, many of whom were women who knitted busily as they listened, the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America today renewed its effort to obtain actual control of the property of the Collingswood Presbyterian Church, now held by secessionists.

The Commnwealth Edison Company will offer four shares of new $25par stock for each share of 6 per cent and 7 per cent preferred stock of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois under the unification plan awaiting the Illinois Commerce Commission's approval, it was disclosed today.
Miss Patty Berg, 19-year-old Minneapolis star and medalist, resumed her winning march today in the first round of match play in the Florida East Coast women's championship on the St. Augustine Links.
Governor Davey granted a full pardon tonight to T. F. Cannon, apprehended recently in Pittsburgh more than fifteen years after he escaped from the London Prison Farm.

Offering will be made today by means of a prospectus of 25,000 shares of $2.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock of no-par value of the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation of Baltimore by W. E. Hutton Co. The stock will be priced at $51 a share, plus accrued dividends.

What the police believed to be a fortune in jewels, the extent of which they declined to estimate, was found in a chamols bag hanging from a gold chain about the neck of Mrs. Lillian Langford, who died of a heart attack last night at her home, 46 Hamilton Terrace. She was 64 years old.

Building projects submitted yesterday in the city included plans for a small dwelling in the Greenwich Village section and a $100,000 alteration in Madison Avenue. Architects also filed for numerous houses in Brooklyn and Queens. Details of the plans follow:

Bernard H. Sandler, trial lawyer for Peggy Garcia in her recently dismissed $500,000 breach of promise suit against Dave Rubinoff, violinist, denied yesterday the statement last Monday of Assistant District Attorney Finnegan that he had been called for questioning in the prosecutor's investigation of the suit. Mr. Finnegan admitted that

Herbert Morrison, who is held to be one of the brainiest of Britain's Laborites, will lead his battalions to the polls tomorrow in an effort to retain control of the London County Council, which labor won three years ago after a surprise victory over the Municipal Reform party or Conservatives.

Anders Jordahl and his wife, Mary D. Jordahl, of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., filed today with the Board of Tax Appeals denials of the Internal Revenue Bureau's claims that they owe about $700,000 in income taxes, penalties and interest.

Hogs were in fair demand today, with prices steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. The top moved up 5 cents to $10.45, while the day's average was up 5 cents at $10.25. Most sales were at $10.05 to $10.40. Light lights were quoted at $9.30 to $10.15; light weights, $9.85 to $10.45; medium weights, $10.15 to $10.45; heavy weights, $10.10 to $10.40; packing sows, $9.35 to $10, and pigs, $7.85 to $9.75.

The Penn A. C. defeated the Brooklyn Y. M. C. A. five tonight, 52-21, to clinch its second straight Eastern athletic club title. McMichael, with 14 points, and Thomas with 16 paced the clubmen to their twenty-first consecutive victory of the year.

The Princeton basketball team, destined for sixth place in the Eastern Intercollegiate circuit, gave Pennsylvania, the new champion, a finish fight before 1,500 fans in the university gymnasium tonight before succumbing to the superior ability of the visitors. 34-27.

What started out to be a rout for Long Island University developed into one of the hardest games for the Blackbirds as they downed George Washington University, 28-24, tonight. A new record for the local team's home games was

Mrs. Elizabeth Van C. Lyman Harrower of New York was married to Frederick Frelinghuysen of Mill House, Elberon, N. J., at the Beacon Street House of the bride's parents, Mr, and Mrs. Ronald T. Lyman, today.

Frederick Jagel. American tenor, who for the last ten years has been a prominent member of the Metropolitan Opera Association, in an interview yesterday condemned the prevailing opinion that Wagnerian roles are more difficult for singers than those of the French and Italian repertoires. Mr. Jagel has appeared in thirty roles.
In the Supreme Court of the United States, Michael M. Platzman, and Benjamin A. Wilder, of New York City were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

Three hundred non-union workmen, many of them armed with iron rods, drove seventy-eight sit-down strikers from the Holmes Foundry today after two hours of hand-tohand fighting. Eight men required hospital treatment.

CHARLES RUMFORD WALKER slices into the immediate past of the new American labor movement, cuts out a segment and dissects it, in "American City: A Rank and File History" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50). John L. Lewis is mentioned only once. Mr. Walker's main

For the second time in as many years the constitutionality of the FrazierLemke Farm Mortgage Moratorium Law was debated before the Supreme Court today, the test being on a new statute passed by Congress after the court unanimously killed the original proposal in May, 1935.

Turpentine firm, 42c; sales, 4 barrels; receipts, 41 barrels; shipments, 25 barrels; stock, 24,380 barrels. Resin, quiet; no sales; receipts, 303; shipments, 16; stock 57,215. Quote--B, $8.25; D, $8.65; E. $8.95; F, G, H, 1, $9.50; K, M, $9.65; N, $9.75; WG, $9.80; WW, X, $11.50.

The long-heralded negotiations for a new FrancoGerman trade agreement, which according to plans ascribed to Premier Blum of France are to form a possible overture for a larger European settlement, opened at the Foreign Office here this afternoon.

Robert M. Temple, an inventor and manufacturer of bakery machinery, died on Monday in Misericordia Hospital. He was 65 years old. Mr. Temple in 1931 received the John Scott bronze medal for inventing a dough-mixing and kneading machine.

Under the heaviest trading of the year cotton prices rose for the eighth consecutive session and established the highest records made on the Cotton Exchange since August, 1934. March continued to lead the upward movement, with so urgent a demand from mills that the March-July spread widened to three-quarters of a cent and the list ended with net gains of 21 to 31 points.

An 8-year-old boy was drowned in the Hudson River off West 155th Street at about 6 P. M. yesterday, and an 11-year-old companion and a 21-year-old youth were numbed by the near-freezing water in an effort to rescue him.
From this battered and now cosmopolitan town, which the Insurgents have often claimed but in which they have never set foot, the impression of impregnability is strong.
Those Sunday performances of "The Eternal Road," to which Equity and the Stagehands' and Musicians' Unions gave their consent, will begin on March 21 and they will be matinees. Top price,

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Regional Director of the Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday that complaint had been filed by the board against the Grace Line alleging. improper treatment of its seagoing personnel in relation to union matters, and that a hearing had-been set for Tuesday morning at - the government building, 45 Broadway.

A defiant message came to The News Chronicle tonight from Esmond Romilly, 18-year-old Communist nephew of Winston Churchill, who took Lord Redesdale's daughter, Jessica, his fiancee, to Bilbao as his secretary.

The final accounting in the estate of William Wrigley Jr., chewing gum manufacturer and owner of the Chicago Cubs baseball team, was approved today by Probate Judge John F. O'Connell. Mr. Wrigley died Jan. 26, 1932, at the age of 70.

A huge, streamlined locomotive without protruding smokestack or other common externals of ordinary engines came into Boston's South Station today and was delivered to the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

The collection of delinquent taxes was accelerated today by a demonstation by 2,000 local school pupils. The youngsters, dismissed two hours earlier on orders of school officials, paraded this afternoon through the main streets with such placards as, "Why be a sit-down striker? Pay your taxes," and "All good Americans pay taxes."
Upsetting his Princeton Club rival, Thomas D. Flynn yesterday advanced to the final round of the national Class B squash tennis championship.

The legislative committee obtaining data for a report on the attitude of farmers toward the Milk Control Board, held its next to the last hearing here today. Independent producers, members of the Dairymen's League and Sheffield producers, contributed to the symposium.
These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name:

J. P. Morgan Co. lost $1,294,284 net as a result of financing operations involving the Van Sweringen railway system. In the underwriting of bond issues and stocks the firm made a net profit of $6,957,933 while partners in the firm made $1,368,972.
Yesterday's reports by brokers of commercial leasing activity included a number of contracts for store space, as well as upper-floor space for men's clothing concerns. The list follows:

Miss Madeline Dalton, former Intercollegiate champion from Hunter College and now a pupil at the Salle D'Armes Vince, gave a convincing display to win the Mildred Dick Fish competition at the Fencers Club last night. Miss Barbara Cochrane of the Salle Santelli finished in third place.

Francis I. Ketcham, founder and former president of the Bushwick National Bank in Brooklyn, died yesterday after a long illness at a nursing home in Hempstead, L. I. Mr. Ketcham had not been active in banking for several years and lived in retirement here at his home. He was in his sixtieth year.

In a move believed here to mark the resumption of regular publication of its statement, after a lapse of sixteen months, the Bank of Italy issued yesterday a report of its condition as of Feb. 20, showing an increase in the lire amount of gold holdings and a decrease in note circulation, compared with the last available figures, those for Dec. 31, 1935.

Cooperative farming with Federal aid was advocated yesterday by J. R. Butler, president of the Southern Tenant Farmers Union, as the only solution for the plight of 3,000,000 "poor and overexploited" sharecroppers in the cotton belt.

Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Crane of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Crane, to Carl Johan Michaelsen of this city, son of Mrs. Sophus Michaelsen of Charlotten-lund, Denmark, and the late Mr. Michaelsen.

Dr. Hugo H. Schaefer, Associate Professor of Chemistry since 1927 at the Columbia University College of Pharmacy and director of its chemical laboratory, will become dean of the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy of. Long Island University on July 1, it was announced yesterday. He will succeed Dr. William C. Anderson, the retiring dean.

Petitions asking repeal of the 50 per cent increase in water rates and a reduction of the interest penalty on arrears of taxes from 10 to 7 per cent were given yesterday to Mayor La Guardia, Aldermanic President William F. Brunner and the Board of Estimate by a committee representing sixty-one organizations.
MANHATTAN Estate, $10,000. To Irving C. Green, grandson, 194 Greene Av., Brooklyn, one-third residue; Edwin Cary, son, executor, 210 E. 68th St.. remainder.
2d Av., n. w. cor. 52d St., 25.4x99.11; Mellit Realty Corp., Gussie Lemken, president, to Phaeton Realty Corp., 129 Woodmere Blvd., Woodmere, L. I.; mtg., $8,800 (50 cents).
The government has written off an average of 25 per cent of the cost of the first twelve rural communities completed by the Resettlement Administration and turned over to local administration.
The estate of Senator James Couzens of Michigan was valued at $31,000,000 in an inventory filed with the Wayne Probate Court today by Clarence E. Wilcox, attorney.

Dr. Solomon Lowenstein, executive vice president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York, received yesterday, on his sixtieth birthday, congratulations paying tribute to his community service and leadership in the fields of private and public social welfare work, extending over nearly forty years. Among the tributes was a message from Governor Lehman.

Mayor La Guardia urged last night that the proposed site of a Bronx airport, 300 acres of land at the Boston Post Road and the Hutchinson River Parkway, be drained and graded for temporary development as a trailer camp.

The constitutionality of legislative acts which provided for the diversion of water of the Niagara River by the Niagara Falls Power Company is to be tested in the courts, following a formal notice from the State. Water Power and Control Commission to the power company to "desist from

The trustees of the Gunnery School announced today that the Rev. Tertius Van Dyke had accepted the post of headmaster of the school for the coming year. Mr. Van Dyke has been headmaster pro tem this year.

President Roosevelt received several callers, was host at a formal luncheon for President Quezon of the Philippines, and devoted the afternoon to preparation of his speech to be delivered tomorrow night at the Democratic Victory Dinner.

The New York State Athletic Commission, after disposing of various matters at its weekly meeting yesterday, turned its attention to the current feud with James J. Johnston, director of boxing at Madison Sauare Garden.

The titanic scale of British rearmament was emphasized once more today by new naval estimates calling for the construction of more than 238,000 tons of fighting craft and the greatest peacetime expenditure in a single year in the history of the Empire.
The New England Council of the Committee for Industrial Organization, seeking to bring shoe workers under its banner, announced plans today for the formation of a new shoe union.

In districts where steel wage rates have been lower than in the central area, it is probable that increases will be granted that will preserve the geographical wage differentials that have existed, acccording to Iron Age.
Government troops have stormed and captured some outlying parts of Toledo near the Alcazar, according to unofficial reports published in Madrid tonight.

There may be some statistical comfort in the fact that motor vehicle travel, measured by gasoline consumption, increased by 11 per cent in 1936 and the deaths for which motor vehicles were responsible by only 4 per cent. Only 4 per cent! But they will do. They run up the total of automobile

The Finish naval training frigate Suomen Joutsen, silver-colored fullrigged ship with the lines of a racer, slipped into the harbor yesterday afternoon carrying 184 officers, cadets and crew, who are about half way on a training cruise that started on Nov. 2 at Helsingfors.

Led by steel shares, which advanced 1 to nearly 7 points on the overnight news of agreement reached by Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and the C. I. O. union in its plants, the stock market moved sharply higher yesterday in a buying movement that embraced nearly all sections of the list.
An airplane with its pilot and a passenger crashed about 5 o'clock this evening in the center of this community, one of the largest in Suffolk County. Both men were instantly killed.

Penn State defeated Georgetown in basketball tonight, 34 to 24, and maintained its third place standing in the Eastern Conference. The Lions took an early lead when Reichenbach scored five baskets in the first half. The period ended with Penn State ahead, 23 to 13.
After Navy's swimmers had lost to Rutgers, 50-25, today, the Annapolis water poloists turned in a victory over the Scarlet representatives by an 18-11 score.

Fifty infield and outfield candidates turned out for the initial practice of the Brooklyn College varsity baseball squad at the Lawrence gymnasium yesterday. Coach Arthur Musicant announced that indoor drills would be held until next Thursday, when the squad would move outdoors.

The possibility of a union strike against foreign oil companies appeared today as members of the Syndicate of Petroleum Workers issued a statement that after fifty-two days of discussions regarding wages and conditions of work the negotiations to effect a labor settlement were going badly. Declaring that only fourteen points of differences had

Commenting on the 1937 year book of the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association, which was made public at the recent convention of the department in New Orleans, local public school officials took exception yesterday to opinions expressed in the book on democracy, other political and social orders and religion.

Judge Thomas Brown in Circuit Court appointed today Samuel Pesin, a lawyer, as auditor to determine how much money, if any, is due the Pan-American Securities Corporation of New York from the Friedrich Krupp Holding Company, which represents steel and munitions interests in Germany.

Rights to subscribe to $52,670,700 of Pennsylvania Railroad 3 1/4 per cent convertible debentures have been exempted from the provision of the New York Stock Exchange's constitution that forbids trading by members outside the Exchange in securities listed on the Exchange, it was announced yesterday.
Pine Bluff golfers agreed today that two holes in one scored by members of the same fivesome at the Pine Bluff Country Club is "one for the book." Frank J.

Rutgers University's basketball team defeated Lehigh, 64 to 27, tonight in its final home appearance for the season. The victory gave the Scarlet a clean sweep in Middle Three competition with Lehigh and Lafayette.

Mayor La Guardia used a broad smile yesterday to convey his reaction to the improved working conditions for steel employes, arranged by negotiation between the Committee for Industrial Organization and the steeL interests.

Lord Aberdare, 52-year-old British peer, started auspiciously today in his quest of the American amateur court tennis championship by overwhelming G. H. (Pete) Bostwick of New York, 6-0, 6-0, 6-0, in a quarter-final round match at the Racquet Club.

The International Labor Office issued today a report on the world's textiles industry in preparation for the international conference on the textile industry at Washington April 2. This conference, which the United States proposed, represents, the report says, an experiment because it is the first attempt to review the general situation of a world-wide industry in order to explore the possibility of improving its social standards.

Determined that his Giants shall not take another trimming when the fourth exhibition game of this Havana training campaign is staged tomorrow, Colonel Bill Terry put his players through a complex series of manoeuvres today that at least taxed their endurance if it did nothing else.

Shareholders of the PennsylvaniaDixie Cement Company have been asked to vote on April 20 on a proposal for reclassification of the company's preferred stock. The directors recommend that the present $100 par value preferred shares be converted into "Series A convertible $7 cumulative preferred stock,"

Gram markets made today a poor response to the general strength in stocks and commodities.
