There was a rush of buying of wheat early in the session on the Board of Trade, prices rising 7/8 to 11/3 cents a bushel, the latter on May, which touched $1.35, or only 3 1/2 cents under the highest level of the season.

The annual report of the Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., and subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $12,837,813, which, after interest, amortization, depreciation, Federal income taxes and preferred dividends, equals $2.45 a share on the common stock outstanding on Dec. 31.
Reports of trading in Bronx properties yesterday included sales of multi-family buildings in the central part of the borough.
The Eastern Amateur Hockey League moved swiftly yesterday to strengthen its position against the National A. A. U. and by the close of the day had consummated an international alliance with Canada.
The moment has come in French politics when daring leadership must become reconciled with prudence and unity, Camille Chautemps said in a speech to young Radical Socialist party members here tonight.
France has been holding radio elections this week which have caused almost as much excitement as a Parliamen tary poll. In fact, the campaign

The bank accounts and sources of income of all the labor leaders mentioned in connection with the murder of Norman Redwood are to t be investigated by John J. Breslin Jr., Prosecutor of Bergen County, it became known yesterday.

The Federal Government's hearings here on alleged violations of the Robinson-Patman chain-store act ended today after Warrington Harris, sales manager of the Phillips Sales Company, had been questioned.

The unbeaten Peddie School quintet of Hightstown, N. J., gained assurance of at least a tie for the Eastern Private Schools League championship by virtue of a 40-to-32 triumph over the Horace Mann School for Boys on the latter's court yesterday.

A sea story almost as good as fiction is being acted out by real-life characters on the Red Star liner Westernland, it was learned yesterday when the liner docked in Hoboken after passage from AntwerD.

In an indictment of "evils" of the present social order, the Philadelphia Methodist Episcopal Conference, opening its annual meeting today, condemned war, "injustices of capitalism" and racial and religious discrimination.
Robert J. Marks and Mrs. Adelaide Neuwirth won the Liberman Cup yesterday in the eleventh annual Eastern bridge championship tournament at the Hotel Commodore. They had been consistent

Detailed conversations have begun between Manuel Quezon, President of the Commonwealth Government of the Philippines, and United States Government officials looking to the preparation of groundwork for the trade conference which will be held between the two governments under the terms of the Independence Act to determine their economic relationships after full independence has been achieved in 1946.
Newspapers announced tonight that Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg would shortly visit Budapest and Rome, but persons close to him denied he would go to Rome.

Adoption of a new organization plan for the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York, in which the posts of president and vice presidents have been eliminated and the direction of the association placed in the hands of an executive committee of five merchants, was announced here yesterday, following the annual meeting of the group on Tuesday night at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

Don Bradman today received a cable from the King congratulating the Australian cricket team on its great victory in the five-game test series. The Commonwealth scored over England on home soil for the first time since 1935.

A belief that President Roosevelt may make a strong statement in support of his proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court when he speaks tomorrow night at 10:30 o'clock at the Democratic Victory Dinner became general here tonight following a White House conference between the executive and members of his Congressional high command.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Feb. 27 Charles C. Burlingham offers a sincere, dispassionate argument to prove there is no basis for fear that the proposed child labor amendment might affect education. The grounds for objection to the measure are vastly broader than that, but how well does Mr. Burlingham sustain his point even on the narrow grounds he chooses? I quote him:
The Amherst basketball team defeated Williams, 30-26, in Pratt cage tonight. The game was close and hard fought, the score being tied, 13-13, at half-time.

Changes in equity holdings of stocks were relatively light in January, as indicated by reports received between Feb. 1 and 10, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced in its monthly report today.

Aroused over what they consider the lack of practical value for their children in modern elementary school educational methods, a group of taxpayers were circulating a petition here tonight demanding that grade school teachers place greater emphasis on instruction in the "three R's."

Directors of the Lehman Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 75 cents and a special dividend of $4.25 a share. The extra payment was declared in view of the provisions of the Revenue Act of 1936 imposing a tax on undistributed profits.

An ice jam dried up part of the American Falls early today, but by midafternoon the flow was increasing. For an hour or two before noon tourists saw a gap in the middle of the American Falls, caused by ice barriers farther upstream. These deflected most of the water in the Niagara River toward the Canadian Horseshoe Falls.

How much further the activity of steel companies may go, with the present rate of operations at about 86 per cent of capacity, represents pretty much of a problem in view of the increasing shortage of pig iron. There are 175 blast furnaces

William Stone Gnichtel, a Newark attorney who was formerly a legal adviser to D. Frederick Burnett, State Beverage Commissioner, died today in Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a long illness. He was 32 years old.

Visiting British squash racquets players, who failed in the defense of the Wolfe-Noel Cup and could not get further than the quarter-final round of the United States singles championship tourney recently, are assured of titles in the women's New York State singles and national doubles competitions as a result of their semi-final triumphs at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

Mayor La Guardia gave encouragement yesterday to the backers of a plan for a building at the World's Fair that would be dedicated to religious freedom and would depict the struggles made for that cause through the centuries. He said he was sure the fair authorities would display a "responsive attitude" to such a plan.

Three show horses owned by Elizabeth Arden, cosmetic manufacturer, of New York, who is Mrs. Elizabeth Lewis in private life, were killed by smoke during a small fire in one part of Stable 3 at Belmont Park about 8:45 tonight.
Reciprocity features of the Alien Actors Bill of Representative Dickstein, chairman of the -Immigration Committee, were endorsed today by American artists at a hearing before the committee.

Sheriff J. Mason Smith of Albemarle County announced on arriving here early today with Dr. R. G. Miller of Charlottesville that the dentist had signed a confession of the chloroform slaying of Cleo Sprouse, 18, whose body was found Tuesday on the edge of the University of Virginia campus.

Wagner's "Lohengrin' received its fourth performance of the current season last night as the Metropolitan Opera House before a near-capacity assemblage. The production was marked by two changes in the cast.

Georges Bonnet, the new French Ambassador, told newspaper men tonight in his first formal interview here that his chief aim was to improve Franco-American trade relations when the existing trade agreement expires in two months.

Continuing his purchases in the blocks just north of Rockefeller Center, Sumner Gerard, through his Aeonitt Realty Corporation, yesterday acquired the five-story altered dwelling at 55 West Fiftythird Street, near the corner of Sixth Avenue.
The striking Osaka geisha (girl dancers and entertainers) are still at the Gyokuzo Buddhist temple, and their hosts, the priests, have offered to mediate with their employers..

The report of the special committee appointed by the President to study the results achieved by NRA during its brief span of life is plainly written in a spirit of great friendliness, but at more than one important point it holds up a warning hand.

Jewish farmers in the United States shared in the general agricultural improvement last year, Dr. Gabriel Davidson, general manager of the Jewish Agricultural Society, 301 East Fourteenth Street, said in his annual report, made public yesterday.

Miss Rose Schneiderman, president of the New York Women's Trade Union League and a former member of the NRA Labor Advisory Board, was appointed secretary of the State Department of Labor yesterday by Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.

Maurice Leon, who served last year as a member of the Westchester County Commission on Government, said today that if the county charter proposed by a committee of the Board of Supervisors became a law, jobholders would be increased and tax burdens would be "greater than ever."

For his work in aiding poverty-stricken and homeless Philadelphians, George W. Wilkins, executive director of the Galilee Mission, tonight was introduced to an applauding audience at the Academy of Music as the sixteenth recipient of the Philadelphia award, founded by the late Edward W. Bok.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has no corner on the large-scale production market as Columbia Pictures proved last night when it presented its film of James Hilton's "Lost Horizon" at the Globe. There,

State Department officials said today that though President Roosevelt's proposal to place an excise tax of three-fourths of a cent a pound on sugar would necessitate revision of the Cuban-American reciprocal trade agreement, no steps could be taken toward revision until the exact amount of the tax is determined by Congress.

Cheering with what amounted almost to religious fervor, 1,000 outdoor enthusiasts from all parts of the country saw a dream of many years come true today as the nation's conservationists united to fight the battle for preservation of the country's natural resources.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue issued a warning yesterday that only ten days remain in which to file the Federal income tax, the final day being March 15. The collectors in the various districts and their deputies are prepared to furnish free information and assistance.

Members of the Municipal Housing Authority sent a resolution yesterday to all members of the New York contingent in Congress, endorsing the Wagner-Steagall housing bill introduced in Congress last week by Senator Robert F. Wagner and Representative Henry B. Steagall.

One of the two prosecutors in charge of the Bronx building collapse case, for which six men are on trial for second-degree manslaughter in the Bronx County Court, took the stand yesterday in a successful battle with the defense counsel to have two photographs of sections of a brick wall of the building at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South submitted as evidence.

Executors of the estate of Cyrus H. K. Curtis, who have already paid more than $8,000,000 of estate and inheritance taxes on the publisher's fortune, sought today to block the government from collecting an additional $1,000,000 of income taxes.

Mrs F. A. Harris's Breezing Along and Mrs. F. C. Dunn's Sir Ten, coupled in the wagering, ran one, two in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today. Taking the lead at the stretch turn, the consistent Breezing Along closed strongly to finish a length in front of Sir Ten, which came from far back to beat Mrs. B. Franzheim's Compensatory out of runner-up honors.

John E. Phipps, in 67 Park Av.; Henry M. Legler, in 27 E. 79th St.; Potter, Hamilton Co, broker. Pierpont M. Hamilton, in 2 Beekman Pl., Frederick P. Delafield, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. in 1,060 Park Av.; Robert G. Donaldson, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. 155 E.
Governor Lehman will go on the air Friday evening in an appeal to the people to bring pressure to bear on their Assemblymen to vote for ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment.
New modifications to the recently adopted motor traffic code were announced yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler. Left turns now will be

Emergency Peace Campaign Conference of Religious Workers to discuss "What Can Church and Synagogue Do to Prevent War?" Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive. Sessions 10 A. M., 12:30 P. M., 2:30 P. M., 8 P. M.

The riddled ranks of the favored array called a halt to the epidemic of unexpected casualties in the men's national indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday after Miss Florence Le Boutillier, second in the women's seeded list, had been eliminated by a newcomer to metropolitan courts.

Contrary to the national trend, business activity in New England in January showed a general increase compared to the previous month, and reached the highest point since November, 1929, according to the New England Council's index of business.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Cutler of Yonkers, N. Y., and Kensington, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Lucille Cutler, to Gordon Francis Biehn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Biehn of Bronxville. N. Y.

Bills to put in the Conservation Commission the power to fix detailed regulations for hunting and fishing became the subject of sharp dispute today at a joint public hearing on conservation measures pending in the Legislature.
Close associates of John L. Lewis said tonight that the agreement he won from the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation was only the beginning of his industrial unionization campaign.

Tentative dates and other details of the championships which start on March 20.were discussed yesterday by the tournament committee of the Indoor Polo Association in a meeting presided over by Elbridge T. Gerry. The dates, which are
Major Frederick A. Smith, who for many years was connected with the Quartermaster Department of the United States Army, died here today at his home of a bronchial condition. He was 66 years old.

Commissioner of Accounts BLANSHARD has made a supplementary report to Mayor LA GUARDIA on conditions past and present in the Sheriff's office of Kings County. Embezzlements are alleged to have occurred in the past. This was before the time of Mr. PETER MCGUINNESS, the present Sheriff, and no censure or criticism of him or his predecessors is made by the commissioner.

The Whitney Museum of American Art has decided to extend the current exhibition of New York Realists for one week, through March 12. This exhibition, which occupies all of the gallery space in the museum, consists of paintings and drawings produced from 1900 to 1914 by Robert Henri, George Luks, John Sloan, William Glackens, Ernest Lawson, George Bellows, Everett Shinn and Guy Pene du Bois. Most of the paintings

For the third consecutive term, G. Arthur Callahan was appointed yesterday president of the New York Curb Exchange Securities Clearing Corporation. James A. Corcoran was appointed second vice president to fill a vacancy. Other officers were reappointed.
For the second consecutive year, General Motors was the largest user of newspaper advertising in the country in 1936, according to Printers' Ink, out today.

Returning from flood conferences in Washington and Pittsburgh, Colonel R. G. Powell, United States District Engineer, listed today estimates involved in flood control plans for fifty communities along the Ohio River.
The State Department announced today that it was refusing permission for any Americans to go to Spain and was so informing all inquirers.

During the two and one-half years from July 1, 1934, to Dec. 31, 1936, the fixed indebtedness of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation and subsidiaries was reduced by $4,216,356, including the payment of $1,125,209 of the company's secured 6 per cent notes, according to the report of the Irving Trust Company, as trustee, submitted yesterday to the United States District Court.
Lawrenceville's polo team took a hard-fought game from the Princeton varsity trio, 16 to 10, in the 112th Field Artillery arena today.

The Supreme Court reserved decision today after hearing argument on a suit brought by Edwin L. Watters to have set aside a resolution adopted by the governing body of Bayonne authorizing construction of a $5,000,000 ship-to-rail terminal.
An apartment house site, industrial plots and one-family dwellings figured in sales on Long Island reported yesterday.
Sit-down strikers in Goof's Tavern bemoaned the fact tonight that the generosity of their friends was likely to defeat the purpose of their squatting.

The Rev. Francis J. Haas, Federal conciliator, announced today that the strike of Northern States Power Company electrical workers had been settled at a conference of company and union representatives.

KINGS DALE, HARRY H. (Nov. 17, 1935). Gross assets, $30,375; net, $18,791. To sister, Nettle D. Bodger; grandson, Harry H. Dale. $5.000 each: Jeane Popkin, $2,000: Maria Kumm, $7,249. Chief assets, real estate, $6,200; mortgages. notes, cash and insurance, $23,360; miscellaneous property, $762. Harry Ahrends, attorney, 16 Court St.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Steer hinds and ribs were in good demand and prices were mostly 50c higher to the wholesale trade. Lamb carcasses were in very moderate supply and this market was also advanced about 50c. Other classes of traefa meats were mostly steady and demand only fair to slow. Kosher meats opened steady with Tuesday's close.

A joint telegram of congratulations from officials of the social action department of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, the industrial division of the Federal Council of the Church of Christ in America and the social justice commission, Central Conference of American Rabbis, addressed to Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation at Pittsburgh, was made public yesterday.

Completing twenty-three years in the Board of Elections, S. Howard Cohen, president of the board, said yesterday that during his tenure the Democratic vote for Governor in the city had increased by more than 1,000,000, while the Republican vote had gone up by less than 200,000.
The Assembly Rules Committee voted today to recommend passage of a resolution granting a full pardon to Tom Mooney, who is serving a life sentence for the 1916 Preparedness Day bombing.
The Daughters of the Cincinnati, of which Mrs. Gustavus T. Kirby is president, will hold its March meeting and tea this afternoon at Sherry's. Miss Emily Gilbert will speak on early English houses.

How modern steam and electric locomotives are constructed will be learned by 125 young men interested in building model railway equipment when members and guests of the Westchester Model Club, Inc., of New Rochelle, N. Y., visit the erecting shops of the Baldwin Locomotive Works and the Pennsylvania Railroad on Sunday.

The second day of the strike of 2,000 Rhode Island truck drivers came to a violent close with the burning of a truck at the Pawtucket-Massachusetts State line. Governor Robert E. Quinn and State Police officials meanwhile watched developments in the textile city, awaiting the word needed before State police can interfere.
Naotake Sato, Ambassador to France, was named Foreign Minister in the new Cabinet of Premier Senjuro Hayashi today.
James C. Dooley, veteran Democratic politician and lawyer died yesterday at the Columbus Hospital. He was 86 years old.
Secretary Roper proposed today that business join with labor and agriculture to develop a "coordinated" attack on problems of wages, hours, child labor and production control.
Mrs. Nellie Brooke Stull of Elyria, Ohio, national president of the Widows and Widowers Club, says the widows of her organization would be called upon to go on a "sitdown" strike April 1.

Dr. William B. Gibson, 85 years old, a practicing physician in Huntington for about sixty years and Suffolk County coroner for many years, was arraigned this afternoon before Justice of the Peace John C. Toaz at the Town Hall on a charge of performing an illegal operation on Mrs. Anna Sodomora of East Meadow, Nassau County.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas for the five days ended Feb. 27 increased 7 per cent over a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.

Princeton defeated Columbia, 38 to 37, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet in the latter's pool last night. Victory went to the Tigers when Referee Ben De Young ruled out the Lions' victory in the 400-yard relay, claiming that Jack Thompson, anchor man, started before Alston Jennings, third man, touched the board.
Colonel George Colin Campbell, Controller and Auditor-General of New Zealand since 1922, died today. He was 78 years old.

The Rockefeller Plaza ice skating rink will be the scene tomorrow night of a skating party to be given under the auspices of the Radcliffe Club of New York for the benefit of that organization's scholarship fund.
Pay rises were announced today for 7,000 employes of the Scovill Manufacturing Company, including the Oakville and Waterville divisions.
Dr. Aldo Castellani, Italian authority on tropical diseases, is arriving today from Rome on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.

Transfer and Assignment SERGEANT-John Casey, from Emergency Service Squad 5 to 22d Pct. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Daniel J. Hannon, from 14th Pct. to 18th Division, duty in D. A. Office. N. Y. County. for 1 day.
The conference Of Oslo powers called to discuss commercial relations between the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxemburg, Norway, Sweden and Finland was opened today by Premier Hendryk Colijn.
Dr. Morris Meyerovitz, a member of the Chicago Plan Commission and a former member of the Illinois State Board of Health, died suddenly today of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

Blair Academy's 400-yard free style relay team today broke the world interscholastic record by 6 3/10 seconds in a dual swimming meet against Rutgers Prep. Blair also scored its thirtieth consecutive dual meet victory in easy fashion, winning, 49 to 25, by sweeping all eight first places.

A more progressive and socialized penal system, with more coordinated prison staffs, was urged yesterday at a conference of prison chaplains under the sponsorship of the Jewish Board of Guardians in the Hotel Woodstock.

If there is dishonesty in the office of Peter J. McGuinness, Kings County Sheriff, he wants it ferreted out, he said yesterday in commenting on a report from the office of Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, disclosing embezzlements in the last few years. The Sheriff,

A. J., Hain, managing editor of the magazine Steel, estimated tonight that between 30,000 and 40,000 "new jobs" will be created in the nation's steel industry as a result of revised working schedules.

The conclusion that Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, has no "legal proof" that electric rates in New York compare unfavorably with those elsewhere was drawn yesterday by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, in a letter to the Federal official.

Mrs. Agnes Thayer Probst, business executive, an early leader of the women's suffrage movement and a church musician, died at her home here last night. She was 86 years old. She had been active in the old Political Equality Club and worked in close association for a number of years with Susan B. Anthony.

Representatives of the General Electric Company and the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, will meet here March 15 to discuss collective bargaining on the basis of demands presented by the union.

In recent speeches defending the application of the Maverick bill to the Supreme Court, both Senator Bulkley of Ohio and Governor La Follette of Wisconsin have emphasized the point that the Constitution does not specifically assign to the court the power to nullify acts of Congress.
The right of Governor Lehman to appoint a brigadier general of the line in the New York National Guard was upheld today by the Appellate Division, Third Department.

Hamilton Academicals sprang a surprise on Heart of Midlothian, powerful Scottish League team, in a third-round Scottish football cup match today, winning a close tussle on their own ground, 2-1. The contest, originally scheduled for last Saturday, was postponed on account of snow.

Modern applied science, by creating substitutes for raw materials needed by the so-called "have not" nations, will thereby eliminate the primary cause of war, provided the world "can for a short while keep the supernationalistic maniacs from cutting the jugular vein of civilization," according to Professor C. C. Furnas of Yale University. Dr.
In the annual Bermuda women's golf championship at Riddells Bay today Mrs. Harry Curtis of Bermuda provided a first-round upset by defeating Mrs. Eric Phillips of Toronto, 2 up.

At the annual meeting of the Union Oil Company of California, R. D. Matthews, executive vice president, told stockholders the net profit for the first quarter of this year probably would approximate, after all charges, $2,100,000, equal to about 45 cents each on 4,666,270 shares of capital stock outstanding.
San Francisco extended a welcome today to Cardinal Dougherty, Archbishop of Philadelphia and Papal Legate, returning to America from the Eucharistic Congress in Manila.

The revolutionary symphony is being written. A call for news reporters to assemble yesterday at the Mayflower Hotel gave rise at first to the impression that it was already here. They were assured, however, that it certainly was on the way.
Adultery will be punished in Germany as a common crime against the State with imprisonment or up to ten years' penal servitude, according to a semi-official announcement in the press today.
The second in a series of popular concerts will be presented tonight at the WPA Theatre of Music. The newly established WPA MusicArt Center in Harlem will be officially opened on March 10.

Gangsterism seems to have reared its ugly head even in Soviet Russia. At any rate, there is the case of a boy of 15 named Vladimir Lintin, whose father did not like his mother much any more and would not bother about Vladimir. So Vladya,
Two more deserters from the ranks of holdouts and the matter of weights were the high spots in the third day of training for the world champion Yankees today.
Governor Lehman announced that he would speak by radio Friday night to urge Assembly approval of the resolution to ratify the child labor amendment.

Nine locomotives, costing approximately $1,500,000, have been ordered by the Spokane, Portland Seattle Railway Company for delivery this Summer, it was announced today at the general offices of the Great Northern and the Northern Pacific Railways, which jointly own the Spokane road.

Supervisor Robert C. O'Grady of Nassau County was exonerated of criminal negligence today in a hearing on the death of Mrs. Edna Grier, Negro, who was injured fatally by Mr. O'Grady's automobile here March 19.

Confronted with popular resentment against what opponents of the plan described as "packing the court," its defenders have sought to invoke precedent. Did not President LINCOLN and President GRANT adopt the same recourse in the Sixties?

The sixteenth annual meeting and election of officers of Everybody's Thrift Shop, a permanent organization maintained for the benefit of various charitable enterprises, took place yesterday morning at the home of Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street.
The Hackley hockey team defeated Riverdale today in a Triangular League game at the Bear Mountain Rink, 5 to 0. Joe Scott tallied three goals for the winners and Dick Peyser and Ed Going one each.

A 40-hour work week, with time and a half for overtime, will be put into effect by all factories in this highly industrialized city, Frank J. Damon, president of the Union Hardware Company, announced tonight. Mr. Damon, who

Eddie Blunt, Negro heavyweight from Corona, L. I., who until recently was better known as a sparring partner than a main-bout performer, came through with another startling victory last night at the Hippodrome. He was declared the victor when Leroy Haynes of Philadelphia was disqualified.
A topic of never-failing interest is meals. And when meals are tied up with the position of woman and new social horizons for

Harrison Williams told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he had a clear conscience concerning stocks sold to one of his investment trusts by another of his companies which sponsored it. He was testifying in the commission's investigation to determine whether legislation is needed to regulate investment trasts.

Holding its rival without a field goal in the first half, Seward Park downed Benjamin Franklin, 20-15, at the James Monroe High School gymnasium yesterday to capture the lower Manhattan division P. S. A. L. basketball title with a record of ten triumphs in as many league starts.
Husky Lou Gehrig, a first-base fugitive from the New York Yankees, became a rookie movie actor tonight with a one-picture film contract "signed, sealed and delivered."

Hans Arthur Thilo, the first of ten German engineers expelled from Russia to reach Warsaw, obtained a temporary British passport today because he feared he might be thrown into a concentration camp if he returned to Germany.
At a town meeting held here yesterday President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court was unanimously condemned.
William Samuel Johnson of 238 East Forty-ninth Street, author and lawyer, died Tuesday afternoon in St. Luke's Hospital of a cardiac weakness, after a short illness. He was 77 years old.
Members of the Berlin Jockey Club were guests at Hialeah Park, Miami, this afternoon of Joseph E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club.

The Anti-Saloon League of America closed its national convention today after adopting an uncompromising policy of fighting alcoholic beverages and placing responsibility for a vigorous new campaign in the hands of a committee of seven.
Miss Lois Krieger of East Orange, N. J., succeeded Miss Marianna McNees of Harrisburgh, Pa., as editor-in-chief of The Mount Holyoke News at Mount Holyoke College today. Other members of the

The engagement of Miss Arley Pistor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. E. J. Pistor of this place, to Olin Henry Timm, son of Mrs. Henry Timm of Dixon, Calif., and the late Mr. Timm, has been announced by her parents.

Gina Cigna, dramatic soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria on her way to Milan to sing at La Scala. Later she will go to London to appear at Covent Garden on May 8 in "Aida" with Giovanni Martinelli during the coronation celebrations.

New York City probably will turn the operation of the so-called free port at Stapleton, S. I., over to a private concern, which will pay the city a percentage of gross receipts, it was indicated yesterday.

As a result of the progress made by the unions in the steel industry yesterday, the local cotton goods trade foresaw another 10 per cent wage rise for workers in cotton mills and the general enforcement of a forty-hour week. The feeling was that the industry would have to follow the example provided by the steel mills.
A poem has been introduced in a suit against the administrators and heirs of an estate to show the intention of a decedent to make a property bequest. The suit was brought
Canadian Railway Union members were represented tonight as overwhelmingly in favor of demanding restoration of the 10 per cent wage cuts.
The Corn Products Refining Company had a net income of $11,490,647 in 1936 after taxes, depreciation and provision for contingencies, according to the pamphlet report, made public today.
Joseph Conte, a 16-year-old public school student, presented a portrait of Mayor La Guardia to the Mayor at City Hall yesterday.

William J. Bingham, athletic director at Harvard, announced officially today that arrangements have been completed whereby the Harvard and Yale combined track and field teams will have another international intercollegiate meet with Oxford and Cambridge Universities this summer.

Mexico, which perhaps has given as much material aid to the Spanish Loyalists as any nation helping them, will continue to send whatever war materials she has available, despite the European embargo. A declaration to this effect...
State Police Sergeant John F. Lockhart, who recently proved that spontaneous ??ombustion caused the fire that destroyed the steamer Benjamin B. Odell, died in a hospital here today at the age of 43.

Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., wielding a charmed putter, led the field around the first eighteen holes of the seventy-two-hole $3,000 Hollywood open golf tournament today. Both his outgoing 34 and his incoming 32 were two under par. His 66 was one stroke better

Showing no signs of weariness as they passed the half-way mark, the teams remaining in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden continued to thrill the fans with their speedy and daring riding last night.

A blanket plea of not guilty, subject to Judge Patrick T. Stone's ruling on pending motions and demurrers, was made in Federal court today by fifty-seven of the sixty-seven individual defendants to two government indictments charging violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in the oil industry. The ten others will appear later.

Notice Battalion Chiefs, when investigating the characters of Ununiformed Firemen, shall make personal investigations. The practice of having the men concerned procure copies of court and police records shall be discontinued.

Federal power to regulate use of the mails entered yesterday the Securities and Exchange Commission's proceeding against Charles C. Wright and other respondents charged with having manipulated the stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd.

Plans to complete organization of the nation's steel workers were made today at a special meeting of forty subregional organizers of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, addressed by Chairman Philip Murray.

The Walker Vehicle Company division of Yale Towne Manufacturing Company has leased from the estate of Frank H. Clement the one-story building to be erected on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 530-2 West Thirty-Fifth Street.

The Walker Vehicle Company division of Yale Towne Manufacturing Company has leased from the estate of Frank H. Clement the one-story building to be erected on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 530-2 West Thirty-Fifth Street.

Church circles considered possible measures of retribution tonight if the Nazi regime fulfills its threat to expropriate church lands for resettlement. The Catholic Church was reported in authoritative sources to be prepared to denounce its concordat with the German Government.

Fighters who thrilled crowds in what now seems the dim and distant past of boxing took their bows and heard the cheers again tonight at the second annual dinner given to the Veteran Boxers' Association by Leon Rains, former Philadelphia promoter.

William O. Clark and Elmer Fingar, Chief Clerk and Deputy Chief Clerk, respectively, to the Westchester County Surrogate's Court under the late Surrogate Slater, were reappointed for indefinite terms today by Surrogate William J. Shells.

Roderick Stephens, coordinator of the Retail Solid Fuel Industry, sent a statement yesterday to the Board of Aldermen backing the proposed ordinance which would impose stringent regulation on retail coal dealers, designed to end the use of stolen coal and eliminate shortweighting practices.

A new two-year contract has been offered to Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, by the board of directors, it became known last night. With this proposal the board signified its belief that the Metropolitan is on the road back to security.

Three Negro children were burned to death in a frame house here occupied by John Dumpson, unemployed, at 90 Harbor Road, this afternoon when jelly boiled over on a cook stove while the mother, Mrs. Jessie Dumpson, was at a near-by store.

Using modern advertising principles, the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Parish, is attracting Lenten worshipers to Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, by exhibiting a diorama of Christ in Gethsemane which was installed yesterday. The exhibit will be shown until Easter Week.

The team of Waldemar K. Von Zedtwitz, S. Garton Churchill, Charles Lochridge and A. M. Barnes took of a lead of 2,520 points yesterday at the halfway mark of the eighty-board final for the Eastern team-of-four bridge championship being played at the Hotel Commodore.

Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio entertained tonight with a dinner at their villa for Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Blair, Viscount and Viscountess Adare, Mr. and Mrs. Sirney J. Legendre, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Kittredge Jr., the Duchess of Sutherland, Thomas C. Eastman and George Carey of New York, their house guest.

American Museum of Natural History. Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West, 10:30 A. M. "Mexico Today." Gladys L. Pratt. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Facing Two Ways," Baroness Shidzue Ishimoto. Luncheon of the Pan American Socity in honor of Dr. Rafael Belaunde, Peruvian Minister to Mexico. India House, 12:30 P. M.
Norman Lewis, New York University senior, last night captured the national junior epee championship, his second national title in a week, in the east building gymnasium of Washington Square College.

Dispatches from Calcutta reveal that when Colonel LINDBERGH, a prominent guest at the meeting of the Parliament of Religions, heard himself compared by an Indian poetess to "Buddha, GA"LILEO and other spiritual figures of " the world," he blushed furiously.

Stan Lectanski, 168, of the West Side, suffered a concussion of the brain and a possible fractured skull when he was knocked out in 52 seconds of the first session of his scheduled six-round bout with Cuban Luis, 170, of Havana, before 3,000 persons at the Star Casino last night.

Contracts for store and floor space in the midtown section featured the business leases reported yesterday. The list follows: Arthur Brown, artists' supplies, in 67-73 W. 44th St.; Joseph Moskowitz, dresses, store, in 480-84 8th Av.; Isadore Lite,

Miss Katharine Faville, associate dean of the Frances Payne Bolton School of Nursing of Western University, has been appointed director of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, it was announced here yesterday. She will begin her new duties in the early Fall, succeeding Miss Marguerite Wales, who resigned last Summer.

Niagara's great ice jam began breaking up today. The water flow over the American falls, which were partly dry yesterday, increased nearly to normal, and holes appeared in the ice sheet in the Lower Gorge. This sheet has been estimated by rivermen to be forty to sixty feet thick.
Exports rose 12 per cent in January over January of last year, and imports increased 28 per cent, the Department of Commerce announced today. Exports,
When Mr. BORAH matriculated on March 4, 1907, he was one of a class of ten whose rank was thirty-six in the order of length of service. Three freshmen came in a few months later.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 2: CAPTAINS. Lassing, W. H., Naval Operations, to Headquarters, 11th Naval District, San Diego, Calif.. in April. Hughes, W. N., Navy Dept., Washington, D. C., to Navy Yard, Pearl Harbor, T. H., in April.

Miss Patty Berg, the Minneapolis star and medalist, was extended to the very last putt to win her quarter-final match from Miss Helen Dettweiler of Washington, D. C., in the women's Florida East Coast championship on the St. Augustine links today.
Viscount and Viscountess Mandeville of Brampton Park, Huntington, England, accompanied by Alexander de Couriss of London, are at the Waldorf-Astoria on their way to Australia.

The presence of a small detached part of Finland in our harbor invites a word of greeting to the little land it represents. The silver-colored fullrigged ship which bears the Finnish name for swan-not the "Swan of Tuonela," whose ferry song, composed by the great SIBELIUS, has been heard around the world, but the silver bird of the free Finland.

Premier Leon Blum likens the course of his government to that of a rider in an obstacle race. The fences become higher and the ditches harder to jump as the face goes on, but each hazard taken increases the chance of winning.

Democratic members of the Legislature showed concern today over Governor Lehman's decision to make a radio appeal to the people in favor of immediate ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System amounted on Wednesday to $1,310,000,000, a decline of $790,000,000 from the figure of $2,100,000,000, reported for the previous week, according to the weekly Federal Reserve statements issued yesterday.

The wheat market on the Board of Trade here showed today considerable resistance to pressure in the face of private estimates suggesting a Winter wheat crop of 629,000,000 bushels, a total which has been exceeded materially only four times in the history of the country.
An agreement to facilitate emigretion of wealthy Polish Jews to Palestine was signed today by the Jewish Emigration Agency and the Polish Government.

The campaign of organized labor in behalf of President Roosevelt's proposed judiciary reforms is already under way, according to a statement made today by Labor's Nonpartisan League, with a "substantial majority" of national and international unions and nineteen State federations already in the movement.
Walter J. Kenlon, eldest son of John Kenlon, former New York fire chief, and Mrs. Kenlon, died today at his home here of a heart attack. He was 47 years old.

A field of at least a dozen, and probably fifteen, is the outlook for the $50,000 Widener Challenge Cup, mile and a quarter test, which will be the richest race in Florida's history when it is run on Saturday.

The joint legislative committee investigating conditions in the milk industry will recommend that price-fixing features of the present Milk Control Law be allowed to lapse on March 31, it was indicated today as the committee conducted its final public hearing here.
Announcement of the engagement of Miss Margaret Tompkins to Lieutenant Clarence Herbert was made today at a cocktail party in the Hotel Viking.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, received the gold medal of the Hundredd Year Association at its ninth annual dinner last night at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. The medal is awarded annually to the person considered to have made "the outstanding contribution to the welfare of the city in the preceding year."
Turpentine firm, 41 1/2c; sales, 15 barrels; receipts, 13 barrels; shipments, 120 barrels; stock, 24,273 barrels Resin quiet; no sales; receipts, 622; shipments, 476: stock. 57,361.

An unidentified man hurled white pepper into the eyes of Mrs. Bernard Vinissky, the former Jenny Dolly of the Dolly sisters, in her apartment on Lake Shore Drive this afternoon. She was temporarily blinded.

Maurice G. Lavis, who had been in the employ of Park Tilford for fifty-three years, died Tuesday night at his home, 506 East Eightyeighth Street, at the age of 73. Mr. Lavis started in the service of Park Tilford on May 19, 1884, as a packer, in the Broadway and Twenty-first Street store.
White House sources said today that Mrs. Roosevelt would begin in mid-April a thirteen-week series of talks on a commercial radio program. Her compensation,

The Merchants Association announced yesterday its endorsement of a proposal to amend the Federal Motor Carrier Act so that restrictions applying to the railroads with respect to long and short haul freight would be imposed upon common carriers by motor vehicle.

Damaging admissions made by Chang Soo Lee during examination by the police and District Attorney after his arrest last Oct. 14, were the result of "words being put into my mouth," the Korean testified today at his trial for attempted murder.

The Monarch Machine Tool Company of Sidney, Ohio, has arranged with F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., and Hawley, Huller Co., Cleveland, for the underwriting of an offering to the public of common stock, the proceeds of which will reimburse the company for additions to its manufacturing facilities and provide additional working capital, it was announced yesterday by Wendell E. Whipp, president of the company.

The collection of $20,000 from the Kaplan Elias Dress Company of 463 Seventh Avenue, in settlement of union claims for underpayments to workers and other violations of collective agreements, and the organization of a violation prevention bureau by the union were announced yesterday by the Joint Board of the Dressmakers Union, 218 West Fortieth Street.

Erich Pommer's rich production of "Fire Over England," which came to the Music Hall yesterday, has all the solid virtues of the better English pictures. It is dignified, sound, carefully filmed, extremely well played and reasonably faithful to the events it sought to re-enact. It has, too,

Prosecutor W. O. Fife said tonight that Albemarle County authorities were not satisfied with a written confession by Dr. Richard G. Miller of the chloroform death of 18-year-old Cleo Sprouse and that he regarded the affair as "plain out and out murder."
Announcement has been made of the birth of a daughter to Mr. and Mrs. M. Roy Jackson of Kirkwood Farm, near Edgemont.

Mrs. Anna Baum, wife of Charles B. Baum, one of the labor union officials on trial in the restaurant racket case, testified yesterday that her husband was in a hospital at a time when another witness had placed him as a participant in a $500 "shakedown" strike.

A wave of price advances affecting scores of major and minor items of factory equipment as well as raw materials is looked for by industrial purchasing agents in the wake of the steel industry's announcement yesterday of a $8 to $8 a ton price advance effective April 1.
Luise Rainer received the award of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences tonight for the best performance by an actress in 1936 for her work in "The Great Ziegfeld."

Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France gained the remaining bracket in the semi-finals of the women's national indoor tennis championships yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

With competition confined chiefly to Class B, the fifth annual metropolitan badminton championships began yesterday on the courts of the 165th Regiment Armory in Manhattan. Play in the record field of 233 entrants, comprising nine divisions, will not begin in earnest until today, when three of the five Class A sections start.

Conflicting testimony as to whether the joint Child-Owen Committee, which has been named to bring about an adjudication of from $152,000,000 to $165,000,000 in Colombian bonds in default with the American public was actually protective to these investors was placed before the Securities and Exchange Commission today.
United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies returned today from a 1,250mile industrial survey of the Ukraine, where, he said, he was deeply impressed by a dozen great plants. He visited Kharkoy,

About 700 Democrats attended the local Victory Dinner of the Democratic National Committee, held last night at the Hotel Commodore. It was in the nature of a party, as there were no speakers other than Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan, who introduced President Roosevelt, and the President, speaking over the radio from Washington.
Martha Graham's second recital of the week at the Guild Theatre last night found her again at the top of her form and her excellent dance group in equally fine fettle.

Joseph Hocking, novelist, died today at St. Ives, Cornwall, at the age of 76. Like his elder brother, Silas, who died in 1935, he was the author of many novels of a simple, old-fashioned type describing the middleclass life of his day.

Alfredo Salmaggi and his company will offer Verdi's "Rigoletto" tonight at the Hippodrome. A matinee performance of "The Barber of Seville" will be given tomorrow and in the evening "Tosca" will be the production.

METZ, France, March 4.-More than 300 miners from the Saar who work just over the border In France were arrested in the frontier towns of Lauterbach, Gross-Rossein, Wadgassen and Gleislautern today in connection with a new currency decree of the German Finance Ministry.

In France, where already seven of every ten francs in taxes goes to pay for past and future wars the question raised by the Italian rearmament program is where Premier Benito Mussolini is going to get the money to pay for it.
A sharp spurt in advertising expenditures and the revision of marketing plans were predicted here yesterday as the aftermath of the wage increases now being put through in many industries.

Extension of the sugar marketing quota system established in 1934, with a new tax of 75 cents a hundred pounds, as recommended by the President and embodied in a bill introduced on Tuesday by Senator O'Mahoney, was attacked today by spokesmen for producers of Hawaii, Puerto Rico, Cuba and the Philippines.

The Yale baseball schedule will be increased to twenty-nine games this season and Yale will play the Army for the first time on Yale Field. The Blue also play Indiana University at home June 17. Regardless of the outcome of the first two games of the annual series, Yale will meet Harvard at New London between the morning and evening races of the annual regatta June 25.

The charge of using "imaginary" figures, "picked out of thin air," in an effort to discredit their $436,000,000 transit unification plan was hurled against John J. Curtin, special counsel for the Transit Commission, yesterday by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr., sponsors for the unity project.

Miss Florence J. Fields, daughter of Mrs. William J. Fields of this place and the late Dr. Fields of New York, was married to Richard Winston Siver, son of Mrs. Annabelle Ross of New Brunswick, yesterday in the Old Tennent (N. J.) Church by the Rev. Harold B. Ingalls, chaplain of Northfield Seminary.

Advancement in aeronautical design will make it possible by 1939 to operate transport planes throughout the year without a single fatality, according to E. R. Breech, chairman of the board of North American Aviation.

Tomorrow is "motner-in-law day in Texas, by proclamation of Governor Allred. In the four years since Gene Howe, editor, initiated the event here in penance for a printed reference to his wife's mother as "the standing army," its observance has spread to State-wide proportions.

Germany's Jewish population has been reduced by 90,000 in the four years of the Hitler regime, leaving a total of 409,000 professing Jews in the Reich, according to the annual report of the Jewish Central Committee for Aid and Reconstruction issued today.
IS GABRIELE D'ANNUNZIO at work on a new poem or is he perfecting what the tabloid headlines might call a new Death Bath?

A run-off race to declare a national bird dog champion appeared probable tonight with only two casts remaining and mediocrity ruling today's three races. Trial judges ordered Tip's Manitoba Jake, owned by Mrs. Glenna Collet Vare of Philadelphia, and Shanghai Express,

More than 1,300 Democratio leaders, headed by President Roosevelt, met here tonight to celebrate the November victory by eating a $5 dinner for which they paid $100 per plate. The extra $95 went toward paying off the party's deficit of about $430,000.

Arrangements were made today for the annual Yale-Harvard regatta on the Thames above New London, June 25. Rowing officials of the two universities conferred with representatives of the New York, New Haven Hartford and Central Vermont Railroads.

Mrs. Marie Dorsey Smith of The Towers, Brooklyn, will be married next Wednesday to Horatio King Gray, son of Mrs. Percy R. Gray, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Gray. Mrs. Smith is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Dorsey of Brooklyn.

The list of "guest stars" who have been invited to play in the fourth Augusta national tournament, now grown famous because it is the only competition during the year that attracts Bobby Jones, champion of champions, was announced yesterday by Clifford Roberts, chairman of the event. The dates are April 1-4.

Five girls were overcome yesterday afternoon when the wind forced fumes from an exhaust pipe attached to a boiler in the factory of Paramount Robes, 119 West Twenty-fourth Street, back into the building where about fifty employes were at work.

Ap hearing before the Supreme Court which two years ago unanimously rejected the original Frazier Lemke Farm Mortgage Mora, torium Law, Representative William Lemke today defended the substitute passed by Congress after the first plan was held unconstitutional.
Superior Judge A. Demidov, charged with burning down his courthouse to destroy damaging records, was shot today after having been condemned by the very court over which he once presided.

Plans for the expenditure of $42,000,000 for new construction and improvements during 1937 were announced yesterday by the Cities Service Company. Of the total, $24,000,000 will be for petroleum subsidiaries, and the remainder, $18,000,000, for public utility subsidiaries. In 1936 the company appropriated $29,600,000 for construction and improvements.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh blushed with embarrassment today when an Indian poet compared his accomplishments with those of Buddha, Galileo and "other spiritual figures of the world."
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The advance of $3 to $8 a ton in steel prices announced for all United States Steel subsidiaries for secondquarter business means that the average price level for finished steel has been restored to about the level prevailing in 1926.
Alberto de Stefani, former Minister of Finance, is leaving for Nanking at the request of the Chinese Government to act as its financial adviser, it was announced today.
Concern over the idleness among the 2,413 prisoners at Sing Sing prison was expressed in a report based on the latest inspection by the State Commission of Correction, made public today.

Robert de Graff, president of Blue Ribbon Books, Inc., which specializes in non-fiction reprints, announced yesterday the purchase of the stock and good-will of the A. L. Burt Company, a publishing organization founded in 1883. Harry P. Burt, head of the company, is retiring.

Hughes Av (11-3068). w s, 101 ft., n of 178th St, 150x180; Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. to Jerlan Realty Corp., 1,450 Broadway; mtg. $185,000. Brook Av, 1,498 (11-2895); Bloomah J. Levine to Belle Salomon, 2940 Grand Concourse; mtg. $17,650.

MANHATTAN Estate, more than $10,000. To Right Rev. Mgr. Charles A. Mackel, St. Patrick's Church, Elizabeth, N. J., $1,000; Nellie Nulligan, niece, life estate in $2,000, remainder interest to New York Foundling Hospital; Margaret Connolly, sister, 207 Chapel St., New Haven, Conn., $2,000 and specific real estate in trust; Ethel T. Brehn, niece,

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended March 4 were announced today: Vogel, Brig. Gen. C. B., appointed adjutant and inspector of the Marine Corps, with rank of brigadier general from March 1. Smith, Lt. Col. W. D., Shanghai, China, to Marine Barracks, navy yard, New York, N. Y., reporting June 1.

Mrs. Louisa Wardner Evarts Scudder, widow of Dr. Charles Davies Scudder, died yesterday of heart disease at her home, 26 Gramercy Park, at the age of 76. Mrs. Scudder was the daugher of William M. Evarts, Secretary of State under President Hayes.
President Roosevelt will go South for a vacation at Warm Springs, Ga., one day later than he had planned, leaving here on March 11, the White House announced today.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens, after a conference with Suffolk County officials, gave permission yesterday to have the body of Joan Morvan, 4-year-old victim of an assault for which Howard Magnussen of Huntington Station, L. I., is being held in Suffolk County, given to the child's mother, Mrs. Dorothy Morvan, for burial in Huntington.

Data showing the benefits derived from the increasing, number of conventions held in this city were issued yesterday by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, based on information received from Harris, Kerr, Forster Co., accountants.

WASHINGTON, March 4.-A statement that Secretary Perkins, through her administration of the Walsh-Healey Government Contract Act, was responsible for the navy's inability to obtain copper and steel for its treaty fleet program, was made in the House today by Chairman Vinson of the Naval Affairs Committee.

The three exhibitions now on view at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will close Sunday evening. They are the Modern English Architecture, posters by E. McKnight Kauffer and new acquisitions in painting and sculpture.

Willett St., 66, 24.9x100; Anna Pesaty to Morris Wald, 2,352 64th St., Bklyn.; prior mtg., $13,300: 6 per cent, $1.000. Washington St., 293, 20.1x82.2; Sylvia Wahl to Joseph P. Sauer, Hotel Martinique, Bway and 32d St.; purchase money; prior mortgage $15,000, due March 1, 1942 5 per cent, $5,500.

Amelia Earhart has taken her flying laboratory up for a test and found the monoplane she will use in her flight around the 'world, starting within two weeks, "in perfect shape." Before the test hop she rigged a box kite for emergencies,

The Middle Atlantic Division of the Amateur Athletic Union, after a meeting last night with the National A. A. U. executive committee, agreed to withdraw sanction for the Hershey A. C. track meet at Hershey, Pa., March 12-13, as a result of the controversy between the A. A. U. and the Eastern Amateur Hockey League.

The monthly statement of the Bank for International Settlements, issued today, shows that its funds totaled 627,917,967 Swiss francs on Feb. 28, a drop of about 18,000,000 in the month. Virtually all the decline was in deposits made by central banks for their own accounts. the remainder being in gold bar sight deposits.

Italy raids and seizes Ethiopia because it simply must have an outlet for its "excess" population. Thereupon MUSSOLINI issues decrees designed to make the Italian population still more excessive by subsidizing large families.

Magistrate Aurelio in Felony Court discharged yesterday two men as suspects in one of the many holdups that led to the killing of Fred Dunn, ex-convict, by Michael Krupsky, 19 years old, after the hold-up of Barney's clothing store.
Mrs. James A. Naismith, wife of the inventor of the game of basketball and a player on the first girls' team, died of heart disease today at the age of 67.

Amid reports of a forthcoming complete change in the government's monetary and financial policy, including definite low-level stabilization of the franc and re-establishment of free circulation of gold, Premier Leon Blum's Cabinet will hold an exceptional meeting tomorrow.
Trends of commodity prices were mixed last week, and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices was unchanged at 139.5 on Tuesday, the figure for the previous week having been revised.

J. A. Lopez, a former New York physician, as chairman of the Roosevelt victory dinners here tonight, said that the attendance at San Juan, Ponce and Mayaguez was the largest of any public dinners held in the island.

A dinner dance entitled "A Night in Bagdad"-arranged to augment the Red Cross flood relief fundtook place last night in the Garden of the Ambassador. It was featured by an oriental pageant based on "The Thousand and One Nights" and directed by Mr. and Mrs. Constantin R. Goodlet.

After advancing for eight consecutive trading days, near-month options on the Cotton Exchange reacted yesterday for the first time in a rise of more than $6 a tale and closed 3 points off to 8 points up.

Bright children need only half the school day to master their work, and under existing conditions waste the rest of their time in the classroom, Professor Leta S. Hollingworth of Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday in making public her report of the Speyer School to the Board of Superintendents.

A complaint charging violations of the National Labor Relations Act was issued yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Regional Director of the National Labor Relations Board, against the Borden company and its subsidiary and affiliate, Willow Brook Dairy.

The visit to Finland of the prominent Nazi official Konstantin Hierl, Under-Secretary in the Labor Ministry, who was scheduled to lecture here tonight at University Hall on the system and the objects of compulsory labor in Germany, was canceled at the last minute.

On this the fourth day of training for the first Dodger squad, Manager Burleigh Grimes pitched a timehonored precedent into a cocked hat by staging a four-inning practice game without a single batting session having been held.

These orders were issued in the Northern New York area: 1st Lt. Clifford B. Rammer, Inf.-Res., R. D. 2, Sodus, N. Y., recently promoted, is reassigned to the 391st Infantry. The following Corps of Engineers Reserve officers are relieved from assignment to the 323d Engineers and are assigned as indicated:

Greater participation by Catholic college alumni and alumnae groups in Catholic efforts to help the American Negro was urged in resolutions adopted unanimously last night at a meeting of the Notre Dame Club of New York at the Centre Association, 120 Central Park South.
Inaugurating a movement which has as its aim an organization of State-wide scope, Conneoticut sportsmen have formed the Fairfield County League of Sportsmen's Clubs.

The British Imperial Airways' four-engined, long-range flying boat Caledonia achieved her second striking record within a fortnight by flying nonstop from Alexandria, Egypt, to Southampton today, thus building up stage by stage a basis for a safe, regular North Atlantic service.

Six movie producing and distributing companies failed in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today to obtain a reversal of a decision that they were "in conspiracy" in "blacklisting" exhibitors showing double features.

For weeks the rumor has been gathering force in Spanish Morocco, according to a French journalist who has just returned from there, that France, under the pretext of maintaining order, harbors the intention of attacking what is in reality General Francisco Franco's Spanish Insurgent base.

Edward T. Asplundh, assistant vice president of the Columbia chemical division of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, was elected a director to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Edward Pitcairn.

The Red Sox list of holdouts was reduced to mix today when. Jimmy Foxx, sluggoing first baseman, came to terms with Manager Joe Cronin at the Sarasota, Fla., training camp. Foxx rejected the first contract because, he claimed, it called for a $5,000 salary cut. He is believed to have accepted last season's terms, said to be about $22,000.

" Love Is News" will go on view this morning at the Roxy, with Tyrone Power, Loretta Young, Don Ameche and Slim Summerville in the principal roles.... "The Great O'Malley" opens this morning at the Strand. Pat O'Brien, Sybil Jason, Humphrey Bogart, Frieda Inescort and Ann Sheridan are in the cast.

Jerome Strauss brought about a triple tie for first place in the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline billiard championship by defeating Howard Bergman, 200 to 163 in 22 innings at the Capitol Health Center last night.

The government's fourth shipment of gold, which was started last night on its way from the United States Assay office, Old Slip and South Street, to the Federal vaults at Fort Knox, Ky., brought the total to be sent from here to date to $510,000,000.

On this fourth of March, 1937, in millions of homes, the thoughts of American families are reverting to the March 4 of another year. That day in 1933 represented the death of one era and the birth of another.

The United States Trust Company of New York declared an extra dividend of $10 a share and the regular quarterly dividend of $15 a share. The extra dividend takes the place of that usually paid in July of each year.

Mrs. Lawrence J. Mead and Mrs. Louis G. Smith have formed a partnership to be known as Mead Smith and have opened a real estate office at 654 Madison Av. Nathan Adler has moved his real estate offices to 489 Fifth Av.

Many subscriptions have been received for the bridge party and photographic exhibit which will be held this afternoon in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York. Mrs. Walter Kobbe heads the executive committee for the party.
A Zagreb couple returning from a heliday in Berlin reported that their only child had been taken from them there and sent by special airplane to a leper colony in the Mediterranean.

In approving the flotation of the German funding bonds issued in payment of interest due American creditors on older German bonds that are subject to the German transfer moratorium, the United States Securities and Exchange Commission announced, "for the protection of the investing public," that Germany had "unrecorded" obligations amounting to 5,000,000,000 reichsmarks as of June 30, 1935.

Plans for using funds of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for new upland communities and dwellings to replace existing homes along the nation's river bottoms that are flooded every few years, were announced today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Federal lending agency.

Dr. Leo I. Mishkin of 275 Central Park West, specialist, died of heart disease yesterday morning in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 51 years old and was senior clinician and assistant pediatrician of the Mount Sinai Hospital out-patient department, associate pediatrician of the Jewish Maternity and Beth Israel Hospitals.

THE OLIVE TREE AND OTHER ESSAYS, by Aldous Huxley. (Harper, $2.75.) A collection of Mr. Huxley's most recent essays. THE YEARS OF MASTERY, 1705-08, Volume 5 of Marlborough, His Life and Times, by Winston S. Churchill. (Scribner, $4.50.) The fifth volume of a major work.

Consumer demand for proper identification of fabrics can be handled effectively through labeling only if advertising, label and the statements of salespeople agree, according to Harold Brightman, general merchandise manager of L. Bamberger Co.,

The need for drama and pageantry in peace times to equal that of the drums and bugles of war was stressed yesterday by speakers at a peace conference of 400 church workers called by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick,
The Securities and Exchange Commission heard today that Harrison Williams, utility man, took $5,000,000 in cash from formation of the Shenandoah Corporation, a holding company, in 1929.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday reached the highest level since Dec. 23 last, with a total of $7,109,623,000 for twentytwo leading cities, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The figures,

The Rev. William H. Bridge, educator and former rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, Boonton, N. J., died on Wednesday night in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 51 years old. Before his illness he had lived at 8 East Fifteenth Street.
Miss Marcella Arnold, "Miss Los Angeles" of 1926, was killed instantly in a movie automobile accident here last night.
First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler, in charge of traffic regulation, announced yesterday additional modifications of the new traffic regulations.
' Bank night" and other giveaway schemes employed by movie theatres were attacked yesterday by Paul Moss,

The President's preference for " ought to" as a substitute for "must" should be respected. The lexicon supports his request. The general verb " ought," according to the New English Dictionary, is used strictly of moral obligation but also with various weaker shades of meaning expressing what is " befitting, " proper, correct, advisable or naturally " expected." The word "must,"

The entire Lebanon Valley plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation shut down today over a wage disagreement. Representatives of the Committee for Industrial Organization dedared that all employes of the mechanical departments went on strike, demanding an agreement similar to that signed by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

Lucie B. Alcott, in 400 Park Av.; Ann Jones and Marlan Quinn, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., in 100 W. 59th St.; Charles A. Hall, through Sharp Nassoit Corp., in 155 E. 47th St.: Frances Marsh Shaskin, in 151 E. 19th St.; Wm A. White Sons, broker.

Formation of the Cancer Council, to bring together the fields of cancer education, therapy and research and to serve as a liaison agent between the outstanding authorities in the cancer field and the lay public through the medium of the press and radio, was announced yesterday by Dr. Clarence C. Little, managing director of the American Society for the Control of Cancer.

Britain will spend more on her "contemptible little army" in the coming financial year than at any time since 1922, when normal military expenses were swollen by the costs of demobilization and the winding up of the World War.
Partisans of so-called company unions massed their forces tonight for a show-down with John L. Lewis for leadership of the 540,000 workers in the nation's steel mills.

In "Out of Sight," tried out at the Gate Theatre tonight, the authors, Leslie and Sewell Stokes, have set out to show the effects of prison life on three different types of men sentenced to long terms, two of whom are a solicitor for embezzlement and a minor civil servant for betraying State secrets.

Explanations of the new rule requiring that transactions in rights to subscribe in business hours be made on the floor of the Exchange, with the exception of Pennsylvania Railroad Company rights, were forthcoming in New York Stock Exchange circles yesterday.

A resolution of the New Jersey Democratic State Committee requesting United States Senator-elect William H. Smathers to retain his seat in the State Senate was adopted at the Democratic Victory Dinners here tonight and at others throughout the State.

Business activity for the Pittsburgh district rose from 126.3 per cent of the 1923-25 average in the week ended Feb. 20 to 126.9 last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

The Privy Council is now considering the proposals agreed upon by the British and Japanese Governments for final settlement of the perpetual leasehold question which, in Kobe and Yokohama, has long been a source of friction between foreigners and the Japanese authorities.

William J. B. Macaulay, 49-yearold Irish Free State Minister at the Vatican, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia to discuss with Mrs. Genevieve Garvan Brady, widow of Nicholas F. Brady, their forthcoming marriage in the late Spring.

After a turbulent meeting, and by the relatively close vote of about 7 to 5, the New York County Lawyers Association went on record last night in opposition to President Roosevelt's proposals for reform of the Supreme Court and the Federal judiciary.
In one of the longest wrestling matches of the Winter, Jim McMillen, ex-Illinois football star, threw Robert Bruns of Berlin last night to win the feature bout at the Hippodrome.
Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, said today, during a lapse in the investigation of the Van Sweringen railway system,

Despite the difference in names, Park and Fourth Avenues are physically and legally one street, Justice Samuel I. Rosenman held yesterday in enjoining the Seyopp Corporation from operating a retail liquor store at 2 Park Avenue.

William A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, announced advances yesterday of $3 to $8 a ton in steel prices, effective April 1, by all subsidiaries in order to meet steadily increasing costs of production.
As foreshadowed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 21, the government has decided to ship gold to forestall any difficulty in maintaining Japanese exchange.

Protesting because the Spring holidays will not be allowed this year, the student body of 400 girls of Asheville Normal and Teachers College went on a sitdown strike at noon today in the college chapel.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -The German Embassy protested officially today against the attacks on Adolf Hitler and the Nazi government made yesterday in New York by Mayor La Guardia. The protest brought a quick comment from Secretary Hull that he regretted the use of language by any American citizen calculated to offend a friendly power.

ANY fight fan who wants to know how the various heavyweight muddles are going to be cleared up should consult his attorneys. He may not get an immediate answer, but, at least, it's the sensible place to start asking. Who else could even guess at a solution?

Seven records were broken three American, three national intercollegiate and one "noteworthy" American-at the Yale-Springfield swimming meet tonight in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium, all in the short or twenty-yard pool. Yale won, 57 to 18, for its 162d straight dual meet triumph.
The marriage of Miss Dorothy Day, daughter of Mrs. E. McCormack Day of East Hampton, L. I., and Irving M. Day of Greenwich, to Timothy F. Crowley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy F. Crowley

Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today urging enactment of a law fixing an eight-hour day and forty-eight-hour week for all women employed in hotels and restaurants in the State.

Franca Somigli, star of Italian opera at La Scala in Milan, arrived yesterday on the Conte di Savoia, enthusiastic over her three weeks' engagement in Puccini's operas at the Metropolitan Opera. She will make her debut here as Cio-Cio-San in "Madama Butterfly" on Monday night.

Frank Tisdale, 72 years of age, retired superintendent of schools of Watertown, N. Y., where he served for thirty years, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack while he and his wife were visiting his daughter and son-in-law, Dr. Walter Tiudeau, here.

The purchase of $200,000 New York World's Fair bonds by three railroads was announced yesterday by Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the transportation division in sale drive. This increased the transportation group's total to $1,800,000.

KINGS BURELLI, LUIGI (Aug. 2, 1935). Gross assets, $15,704; net, $13,440. To wife, Bice Burelli. Chief assets, cash and real estate, $15,704. Vincent A. Bochicchio, attorney, 184 Bleecker St., Manhattan.

Improved financial and industrial conditions in the Soviet Union were interpreted tonight from the trade figures for 1936, announced today. They showed an increase of industrial exports, although the favorable balance of trade was the lowest in years.

While the Committee for Industrial Organization's steel drive is entering the second phase of its campaign. preliminary plans were discussed today among C. I. O. leaders for an early organization drive among the nation's 1,250,000 textile workers.

Herbert Morrison and his Laborite forces held their positions so well during today's conflict at the municipal polls that his retention of power in the London County Council for another three years seems assured.
Paul Mellon's Drinmore Lad, one of the nine American-owned eligibles for the Grand National at Aintree, March 19, today was listed as a doubtful starter following the

With the approach of the Eastern racing season the stewards of the Jockey Club met yesterday and cleared the way for the opening of the metropolitan campaign April 15. During their meeting they granted licenses to ninety-one trainers and twenty-one jockeys.

More than 20,000 employees in body plants of the Briggs Manufacturing Company and the Murray Corporation of America returned to their jobs here today atfer sit-down strikes had ended. They evacuated occupied plants last night and this morning.

A boycott demonstration as a "restatement of the grievances against Nazism on the occasion of the fourth anniversary of the accession of Hitler to power," to be held at Madison Square Garden Monday, was announced yesterday by the Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and the Jewish Labor Committee at a luncheon of the council at the Hotel Commodore.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 3: COLONEL Walthall, H. L., Adjutant General's Dept., 1 month and 23 days' leave, March 7.

WASHINGTON, March 4.-The rift between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee on Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, measurably widened today when it was revealed that warnings had been sent to affiliates throughout the country by the American Federation of Labor that it would not "tolerate" the extension of support to any rival organization.
Master and Journeymen barbers from the seventy-five union shops in this community were "next" this afternoon in all of the fifteen or more non-union shops.
Dr. Andrew Fay Currier died here today after an illness of six months at the age of 80.

Substantial improvement in the business of the International Harvester Company in 1936 is revealed in the annual report to be released today by Sydney G. McAllister, president. Noting that the company's fiscal year had' been changed to end on Oct. 31 instead of Dec. 31, the report states that net profits last year were $29,760,000, compared with $19,618,238 for 1935.
The Insurgents attacked in another sector of the Madrid front last night, along the Escorial road northwest of this city from El Pardo to El Plantio north of Las Rozas.

Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature urging enactment of a measure fixing an eight-hour day and a forty-eighthour week for all women employed in hotels and restaurants. In the evening he spoke at a Democratic "victory dinner" here.

Eighty-four nurses, sixty-one of them young women and twentythree young men, received diplomas at the sixty-fourth annual graduation exercises of the Bellevue School of Nursing at 8:30 o'clock last night at the nurses home auditorium, 426 East Twenty-sixth Street.

Archibald MacLeish has completed a poetic radio drama called "The Fall of the City." The theme is "The terror that stands at the shoulder of our time." Farrar Rinehart will publish the drama in book form some time this Spring.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Horace N. Stevens of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary V. Stevens, to Dr. Merton L. Griswold Jr., also of Plainfield, son of Dr. and Mrs. Merton L. Griswold of Uxbridge, Mass.

Five ringleaders were executed by troops and 100 others were arrested as the government suppressed a "tea-cup" revolt in the town of Xalatlaco, north of the capital, it was reported today by the newspaper Ultimas Noticias.
