Mrs. Louise Knoblock Jackson, 47, wife of William T. Jackson, a retired New York broker and former resident of Brooklyn, was found dead in the front seat of her automobile in the garage on the Jackson estate, Lake Avenue, soon after 1 P. M. today.

Twenty-two seniors and ten juniors at Princeton University were elected to Phi Beta Kappa at the midwinter elections, it was announced today by Professor Whitney J. Oates, secretary of the Princeton chapter of the society, which now has forty undergraduate members.

Twentyone determined British seaman ended today a week's "stay-in" strike against carrying nitrates to Spanish Insurgents, choosing fines and loss of their berths on the freighter Linaria to transporting its cargo.

Last evening, on the anniversary of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S first inauguration, Democrats in many sections of the country met for the purpose of celebrating his victory in 1936 and of acclaiming the gains achieved during his first four years as President.

The Baltimore Orioles tonight defeated the New York Rovers by a score of 6 to 2. In less than two minutes the Rovers scored a goal, but the Orioles then tallied four times before the period ended to clinch the game.

Miss Betty Cooke and Mrs. Toby Barrett of the English Wolfe-Noel squash racquets team today defeated Mrs. Ian McKechnie and the Hon. Anne LyttonMilbanke to win the national doubles championship on the Sleepy Hollow Club courts, 8-15, 15-12, 15-13, 15-6.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the System as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important items in the System reached a new high or low figure for the year.
The Union Dime Savings Bank, as plaintiff, took over at auction yesterday the six buildings occupying the block front on the east side of Madison Avenue between 130th and 131st Streets.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Condition Trading in steer hinds and ribs and lamb was good. Fresh pork cuts moved fair slow and veal cuts only fair. The lamb market continued to advance.

With at least three persons dead and fifteen injured in a four-alarm fire early yesterday morning that swept two tenement houses at 137 and 139 Suffolk Street, on the lower East Side, authorities pushed investigations yesterday into the circumstances surrounding the blaze.

Lady Astor was the center of a sharp tilt today in the House of Commons. She started it by saying that a recent meeting in her constituency, at Plymouth, addressed by James Maxton, Laborite, had been "an absolute flop."

Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L. I., defending champion; James H. Van Alen of New York, and William C. Wright, Philadelphia, kept the seeded ranks intact by joining Lord Aberdare of London in the semifinal round of the forty-sixth annual American amateur court tennis singles championship at the Racquet Club today.

Ten months of hearings on the Securities and Exchange Commission's charges that C. C. Wright and nine others manipulated the stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., came to an end yesterday.

Peggy Garcia was released from the Women's House of Detention last night after she had posted bail of $1,000 to assure her appearance in General Sessions to answer a bigamy charge resulting from her recently dismissed $500,000 breach of promise suit against David Rubinoff, violinist.

Revised gas rates, which will save about $630,000 a year for consumers in Manhattan, the Bronx and part of Queens, were filed with the Public Service Commission yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York. The new rates become effective next Thursday.
Bronx properties changing hands in the deals reported yesterday covered a wide area of the western section of the borough, and several of the transactions involved wellknown operators.

Mayor Irene E. Armstrong, the housewife-executive who defied the Governor when he attempted to oust her, resigned today. Her husband took over the post he held until Dec. 10, when he resigned, saying he feared he would be susended by Dave Sholtz, then Governor. The City Commission named his wife to succeed him.

A revival of activity in the leading clubs of New York, after precipitous declines in their rosters during the depression, is reflected in the 1937 edition of Club Members of New York, published today. About 50,000 club memberships, with residential addresses, are included in the volume of 415 pages.

Documentary evidence that tear gas and machine gun sales representatives of the Federal Laboratories, Inc., received with delight news of impending strikes and subsequent disorders, and a letter suggesting the writer thought President Roosevelt should be the object of a "restraining order" because he stopped strikes and injured business were put into the record today as the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage went into the affairs of one of the largest manufacturers of tear gas.

Profit-taking brought about an irregular decline in the stock market yesterday. Some of the steel, copper and motor shares were down 1 to 3 points, but on the average the set-back amounted to less than one-third of the gain made in Wednesday's spectacular market.

C. P. Blackwell, dean of the School of Agriculture of Oklahoma Agricultural and Mechanical College, died today. He was 50 years old. A former Professor of Agronomy at Clemson College in South Carolina, he joined the faculty here in 1928.
In the Supreme Court of the United States William Clarke Morris of New York City was admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had:
Charging that $60,000,000 of the company's bonds secured by a mortgage held by the bank are in default, the Chase National Bank of New York

Tonight is the night Mr. Pemberton is opening "Now You've Done It," the comedy about politics by Mary Coyle Chase. Scheduled for late February, it was twice postponed, on the last occasion by the illness of John Alexander, since replaced in the cast by Walter N. Greaza. The company also includes Evelyn Varden, Margaret Perry and Barbara Robbins. Henry Miller's is the theatre and the hour 8:30.
The United States linear Washington, arriving today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh, will bring William C. Bullitt, Ambassador to France; Colonel and Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt,

Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" received its seventh presentation of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The music drama was again performed before a sold-out house and did not fail to arouse the same intense enthusiasm which prevailed at its previous interpretations during the Winter.

What is believed to be the first exhibition of American paintings and prints ever to be sent to Bermuda is being prepared for shipment next Wednesday on the Queen of Bermuda. Under the auspices of the Bermuda Trade Development Board, the exhibition will be shown at Hamilton from March 14 to April 3, during the Easter holidays when Bermuda is thronged with tourists.

Scientists associated with the drug and chemical industry were urged last night by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. to devise from the three great fundamentals-government, capital and labor-that long-sought formula for a better understanding and greater happiness, contentment and prosperity for the people of the country.

Estate and residential purchases in various parts of Westchester County were reported by brokers yesterday. Mrs. Henry Fox has sold her estate at 50 Haywood Road, Pelham Manor, with a brick Colonial house containing thirteen rooms and four baths, to James B. Thorpe for occupancy. The property was held at $50,000, according to Chauncey B. Griffen. broker.

The Hunter College Dance Group, in collaboration with the college. Choral Society and Orchestra, will present a program of music and original dances this evening and tomorrow evening at 8:30 in the Little Theatre of the Bronx Buildings of Hunter College, Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue.

Weakness in the pound sterling and the French frane, which reduced both currencies to the cheapest prices since last November, accompanied yesterday renewed rumors in the foreign-exchange markets here and abroad of French monetary difficulties.
Bill Dickey, baseball's ace catcher, tonight became the highest salaried backstop in the business when he signed a contract after a day of conferences with Manager Joe McCarthy.
New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from William A. Greer to Walter N. Frank of Marcus Co. and from the late Jacob W. Gutman to Richard Davis of George E. Price Co.
The Conservation Department assured Northern New York fishermen today that construction of trails along the Salmon River would not deplete the stream's trout supply. On the contrary,

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard, declared today that American universities must prepare to present to the country through the press and radio frequent accounts of their "trusteeship" of scholarship by "accurate and interesting statements of what they are accomplishing."
The eleventh annual convention of the alumnae of the College of New Rochelle, comprising more than 2,000 women, will be held in Brescia Hall, on campus, tomorrow and Saturday.
The Supreme Court denied today an application for a writ of certiorari to review a resolution of the City Commission of Bayonne authorizing construction of a ship-to-rail terminal to cost $5,000,000.

Probability of a compromise developed today on a bill to put parole from all State correctional institutions under the State system, The proposed changes came at a public hearing before the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.

The election campaign ending Nov. 3 cost the political parties and organizations taking part in it more than $23,000,000, according to a report made to the Senate today by the special committee investigating campaign expenditures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am beginning my fourth year as an investigator for home relief in the Harlem area, so it was with great interest that I read the recent article, "Jobs for Negroes Lagging, ERB Finds;"
The forthcoming fusion of the two great rival labor unions in Spain to solidify support behind the government was announced tonight.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, who recently placed first in a civil service examination for general medical superintendent in the Hospitals Department, received that post yesterday from Hospitals Commissioner S. S. Goldwater.

Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada declined $4,738,025 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. Deposits by chartered banks were down by $1,636,947.

Fear that cotton-textile mills will follow the example of the steel industry and increase wages brought in a heavy volume of buying to the cotton gray-cloth market yesterday and forced an advance in prices.

George A. Tilzer, Assistant District Attorney of the Bronx, declared yesterday after an investigation that the death of 15-monthsold Gordon Keith Jr. Wednesday morning in Fordham Hospital was "apparently not suspicious," but that the case was "still open."

The marriage of Miss Marjorie French, daughter of Mrs. Arthur E. French of this place and the late Mr. French, to Hamilton LeRoy Shields of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Howard H. Shields, took place this afternoon in the Ripley Chapel here. The Rev. Howard J. Childley performed the ceremony.

Judge Alfred C. Baldwin in Superior Court found today that Eugene E. Hinkle of Westport is "sane and capable of managing his affairs," in a decision which criticized members of Mr. Hinkle's family for seeking to commit him as an "insane person."

An insight into the informal bookkeeping methods of a man for whom million-dollar incomes were common, and $3,000,000 or $4,000,000 earnings a year were not unusual, was furnished today while executors of the Cyrus H. K. Curtis estate continued their resistance to the Federal Government's attempt to collect an additional $1,000,000 of income taxes.
The annual report of the Ohio Bell Telephone Company, controlled by the American Telephone Telegraph Company, for 1936 was issued yesterday.

The stock markets here today were quiet, but firm, following the strong tendency in Wall Street yesterday. British funds drooped slightly in dull trading. Continental European bonds did not change substantially, but South American issues became firmer.

A deal in the garment center area featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday when the Greenwich Savings Bank sold to an investing client of Adolph Bangser, attorney, the sixteen-story building at 241-45 West Thirty-sixth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
The Court of Assizes today gave a former Sing Sing inmate, Francesco Ruggero, thirty years to think up a better way of introducing gang methods into Italy.

Dr. Aldo Castellani, to whom Mussolini and the King of Italy gave credit for keeping the Italian Army in Ethiopia in good health, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia to resume his work at Louisiana State UniversitY, where he is Professor of Tropical Medicine.

The National Research Council will sponsor a tour of leading European research laboratories, starting on May 14, and has invited 100 executives and bankers to make the trip, Maurice Holland, director of the division of engineering and industrial research, announced yesterday.
A painting by Corot, "Le Chevrier Charmant sa Chevre avec la Flute" brought $7,700 last night at an auction of European and American paintings at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.
Warren Irvin of the International Labor Office in Geneva, Switzerland, was here today arranging for the preparatory textile conference in Washington on April 2. He called on William McLaurine,
Arsen Nikolov, Macedonian terrorist, who admits having killed seven men, was sentenced today to death by hanging by a Belgrade special court instituted by the dictatorship.
Deputy Chief Inspector William A. Coleman, retired police official, died yesterday morning at his home, 138 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 62. He was well known as a traffic expert.

The marriage of Mrs. Emma Dexter Greve of Port Chester and Captain Paul A. Raymond of Greenwich has been announced. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Dexter. The ceremony took place at Peekskill, N. Y. on Feb. 20.
Smiling Dick Metz of Chicago sailed around a windy golf course today in 63 strokes to forge to the front of the Hollywood open field.
Twenty-one members of the crew of the Greek tanker Loukia tonight were believed drowned as their vessel struck a mine and sank off Capo de Creus, easternmost point of the Spanish mainland.
President Roosevelt tonight put support for his plan to make over the Supreme Court squarely on the basis of party loyalty and responsibility.
Benton S. Oppenheimer, former judge, author and civic leader, died at his home here early today of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

William A. Barber, chairman of the board of the Childs Company, announced withdrawal of a plan to allow five executives to buy 23,331 common shares at $1 a share over seven years, subject to certain restrictions, before the plan came to a vote at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

5th Av., 2,174, s. w. cor. 133d St., 25x107; A. Askanas and another, executors of Mathias Strasburger, to Vig Realty Corp., 225 W. 34th St. ($25). 93d St., s. s., 150 ft. w. of 1st Av., 25x 100.8; Carrie Reinhardt to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; mtg. $7,000 ($8.50).

Miss Anna M. Spottiswoode, daughter of Mrs. William J. Spottiswoode of this city, has completed plans for her wedding to Clifford C. Macauley, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Macauley, also of Orange. The ceremony will take place April 3 in St. John's church, Orange. The Rev. Thomas W. Cunningham, assistant rector, will officiate.

Madison Square Garden will press its claim on Heavyweight Boxing Champion Jim Braddock for a title bout against Max Schmeling by charging him with "anticipatory breach of contract," it was learned yesterday.
Edwin Jessop Marshall, stockman and last of the West's great cattle lords, died at a hospital today from complications resulting from his age. He was 76.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. M'Cready Sykes of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia M'Cready Sykes, to Jean-Louis Terry of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hopkins Terry of Paris.

Domestic gas appliance sales of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company are running at record high levels, Clifford E. Paige, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting. Sales of gas appliances in January and February, he said, were from 40 to 45 per cent ahead of sales in the corresponding period in 1936.
A blue-eyed baby girl, about five months old, was found today in the first-floor hallway of 201 Garfield Avenue, Jersey City, by a resident of the house.

Richard Deming, construction engineer and first vice president of the American Surety Company, died today of complications following an operation. His age was 73. He was preparing to return to his home in Short Hills, N. J., when stricken.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 3 unless specified: At San Diego: Memphis, March 4; Rail. Ranger. San Diego to Balboa: New York, Wyoming. At San Pedro: Utah, March 4; Pennsylvania.
The most powerful aircraft engine in the world, in actual production, is now being turned out at the plant of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation at Paterson, N. J., it was disclosed yesterday.

The question of admitting testimony about church doctrine into the hearing of a suit involving rival claims to church property caused spirited discussion before Vice Chancellor Francis B. Davis in Camden Chancery Court today.

Lumber production increased last week when a decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to ??0.1 from 75.3. It was 72.3 for the week ended Feb. 29, 1936. Shipments and orders also in??reased, according to the reports ??ired specially to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the regional associations.
Widespread and growing opposition to the proposed Lindbergh Anniversary New York to Paris air race, sponsored by the French Government, is being manifested here.

TODAY-New England: Cloudy, occasional rain and slightly warmer, with thawing temperatures over all New England except rain, probably preceded by snow and warmer over north. New York State: Cloudy, occasional rain and slightly warmer; thawing temperatures continuing over all of State. Pennsylvania: Cloudy, occasional rain and continued mild, with thawing temperatures over entire State. New Jersey: Cloudy, occasional rain and continued mild over entire State.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Vomlehn of Fanwood of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Helen Vomlehn, to Alfred Ashton Rich, son of Mrs. George Rich of Westfield, and the late Mr. Rich.
Thirteen miners were killed today in a revolver battle at Metlaoui with gendarmes and soldiers who had been called to put down disorders in a mine. Twelve other miners were seriously wounded.

Edward C. Johnson, Securities and Exchange Commission trial examiner in the W. E. Hutton Co. case, will present on Monday to the commission in Washington the request of David W. Peck of counsel for Mr. Hutton to move the hearings from Washington to New York.

With the calibre of the opposition not quite so powerful and their own play considerably improved, the Giants today finally got around to winning their first game of the exhibition season. They defeated the Fortuna Sporting Club, amateur champion of Havana, by 7 to 2.

Carl K. Withers, State Commisioner of Banking and Insurance, urged today passage by the New Jersey Legislature of a bill under which State banks, trust companies and savings institutions would be "revised, recodified and consolidated."

Licenses for export of arms, munitions and implements of war were issued to the number of 382 and to the value of $3,746,553.72 in February, State Department figurs showed today, These figures are slightly less than in the previous two months.
Miss Caroline T. Burkham, former president of the Industrial Educational Association for Southern Mountaineers, died yesterday at her apartment, 995 Fifth Avenue, after a week's illness.

Walter P. Chrysler Jr. entertained with a supper party last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Moore 3d, Mr. and Mrs. Christian B. Hewitt, Mr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Marston,
Thomas F. McMahon, State Director of Labor, announced at 2:20 o'clock this morning that the three-day strike of 2,000 Rhode Island truck drivers had been settled.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Robinson Jr. of Hatboro, Pa., formerly of Summit, N. J., who are visiting at the home of their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Robinson, in Weymouth Heights, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Robinson, to Ernest F. Mudge of New York.

Eduard Santos, publisher of the newspaper E1 Tiempo, in a speech tonight outlining his plans as a candidate for the Liberty party's Presidential nomination, stressed the need of a working majority in Congress.

The changes that Governor LEHMAN has recommended in the State Unemployment Insurance Law are necessary in the interests both of simplification and of fairness. At present the law covers only " non-manual" laborers earning $2,600 a year or less and all "manual" laborers. This involves several difficulties.
Commander John William Konkola of the Finnish naval training frigate Suomen Joutsen called on Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday and received an official welcome from him.

The continued operation of merchant ships for at least ten days was guaranteed yesterday when Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey granted an extension of a restraining order against John J. Daly, Shipping Commissioner, in the enforcement of provisions of the Copeland Safety at Sea Act.
Proudly demonstrating his ability to walk a few paces without danger of tiring his healing legs, Pope Pius greeted several Cardinals today.
B. F. Avery Sons Company have arranged for the sale to F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., of $1,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent notes and 36,500 shares of $25 par value preferred stock.
Final settlement on Monday of General Motors strike issues with the United Automobile Workers of America was described as "possible" by a corporation official tonight.
John Joseph Hughes Jr., New Yorker who shot an 82-year-old German in the street for apparently no reason, will be placed for a time In an asylum for observation before trial.

Egyptian authorities strove tonight for a peaceful settlement of a Coptic monks' sit-down strike despite an appeal from Patriarch Yoannes XIX to dislodge them from within the massive walls of their desert monastery.

Hailing the victory of franklinn D. Roosevelt at last year's election as an even greater. political achievement than that of Thomas Jefferson when, for his second term, he received 163 of the 117 votes in the electoral college, Governor Lehman was the principal speaker at the "Victory Dinner" tonight at the Albany County Democratic Organization.

The demand for hogs was less active today, while offerings were about in line with trade expectations; the market was steady to 10 cents lower. The top declined 5 cents to $10.40, with the day's average off 5 cents at $10.20. Most of the sales were at $10 to $10.30.
Colonel and Mrs. S. L. Slover of Norfolk, Va., who are among many planning parties for the Bal Musette dinner dance on Saturday night at the Surf Club, will have about thirty guests.

Rudolph Degener, retired securities broker well known in society of this city and chief police officer of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children from 1918 to 1925, died of heart disease last Monday on his coconut plantation at Tobago, near Trinidad,
Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the right would be offered on Monday to holders of $502,361,900 of 3 per cent Treasury notes maturing on April 15 to exchange their notes for bonds.

The premiere of the high school operetta "The Headless Horseman," based on "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow," by Washington Irving, will be presented tomorrow and Saturday evenings in the auditorium of the Bronxville school.

Sales of the F. W. Woolworth Company in the first two months of this year aggregated $38,408,292, or 6.7 per cent more than in the corresponding period last year, when they totaled $35,998,877. Sales in February totaled $19,758,264, against $19,014,284 in February, 1936, a gain of 3.9 per cent.

Artur Rodzinski, who made his second Thursday appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, again arranged an interesting and well-organized program and conducted in a fashion that gave evident pleasure to the large assembly.

Davidson Av., 2,344 (11-3198). 2,344 Davidson Av. Corp. To Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; extends mtg. to Mar. 2, 1947. at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent $135,000 Hughes Av., 1,997-1,999 (11-3068), Jerlan Realty Corp. to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 1 Madison Av.; installments, 5 per cent $185,000

Parachute spinnakers will be used on the Atlantic Class sloops this year. That was decided last night at the annual meeting of the Atlantic Class Association, held in the clubhouse of the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty fourth Street.

The Lee Higginson Corporation will offer today $3,000,000 of Dallas Joint Stock Land Bank 3 per cent farm loan bonds, due in 1944, at 101 and accured interest, to yield more than 2.48 per cent to the optional date and 3 per cent thereafter.
Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the right would be offered on Monday to holders of $502,361,900 of 3 per cent Treasury notes maturing on April 15 to exchange their notes for bonds.

The premiere of the high school operetta "The Headless Horseman," based on "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow," by Washington Irving, will be presented tomorrow and Saturday evenings in the auditorium of the Bronxville school.

Sales of the F. W. Woolworth Company in the first two months of this year aggregated $38,408,292, or 6.7 per cent more than in the corresponding period last year, when they totaled $35,998,877. Sales in February totaled $19,758,264, against $19,014,284 in February, 1936, a gain of 3.9 per cent.

Artur Rodzinski, who made his second Thursday appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, again arranged an interesting and well-organized program and conducted in a fashion that gave evident pleasure to the large assembly.

Davidson Av., 2,344 (11-3198). 2,344 Davidson Av. Corp. To Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; extends mtg. to Mar. 2, 1947. at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent $135,000 Hughes Av., 1,997-1,999 (11-3068), Jerlan Realty Corp. to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 1 Madison Av.; installments, 5 per cent $185,000
The Coast Guard announced the following orders today for week ended March 3: Captain H. D. Rinkley, (retired) died at Seattle, Wash. Lt. Com. B. C. Wilcox, the Tahoes, assigned Seattle Division.

Authorization for the Federal Trade Commission to investigate the alleged activities of public utilities in seeking to influence public opinion against municipal or public ownership of power plants was sought in resolutions offered today in both houses of Congress.

Erwin M. Jennings, former head of Erwin M. Jennings, Inc., and former chairman of the Westport (Conn.) Board of Finance, died yesterday in the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary following a mastoid operation. His age was 72.

Play started last night on the courts of the Harvard Club in the national Class C squash tennis championship, with A. K. Marckwald of Short Hills defeating W. Oertley, Yale Club, in an upset, 15-8, 5-15 and 15-7, in the second round. Marckwald was not included in the seeded list, while Oertley had been ranked No. 3.

Leo J. Flynn, attorney-examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, died yesterday. He was 57 years old. Mr. Flynn, who was with the I. C. C. for a quarter of a century, wrote the report on which Congress based present truck and bus regulations.

Sixty - three prints representing the best work of forty-six living French artists, in the opinion of Jules Lieure, vice president of the Association of French Engravers, will be put on exhibition today at the Maison Francaise, 411 West 117th Street.

The Lee Higginson Corporation will offer today $3,000,000 of Dallas Joint Stock Land Bank 3 per cent farm loan bonds, due in 1944, at 101 and accured interest, to yield more than 2.48 per cent to the optional date and 3 per cent thereafter.

The marriage of Miss Marian C. Inglis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Inglis of Cleveland, to Douglas S. Gibbs of New York, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Vivan A. Peterson, rector of St. James' Episcopal Church.

While the metropolitan district was enjoying a touch of Spring-like warmth yesterday, snowfalls visited the upper stretches of New York State, Vermont and New Hampshire, assuring another favorable week-end for skiing.

Private engineering construction awards this week gained 47 per cent over the same period of last year, but dropped 72 per cent from last week's total, according to Engineering News Record. The drop from last week is accounted for by the Pennsylvania Railroad's electrification program award of that week.
Opponents of any revival of the NRA idea were urged by Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland today to seek passage of the bill he and Representative John E. Miller of

Twelve charitable institutions will share about $2,000,000 under the will of Mrs. Emma W. Schoonmaker, wife of Jacob H. Schoonmaker, retired member of Butler Brothers, wholesalers of general merchandise, which was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
The International non-intervention committee today abandoned the Saturday midnight deadline for placing a cordon of ships and land observers about Spain.
George W. Norris of Nebraska began his thirty-fifth year in Congress today by expressing faith in national progress, but impatience "because the pace is not faster."

Dr. Frank H. Clark, a practicing physician and surgeon in Brooklyn for half a century and one of the group which founded Bushwick Hospital, died on Wednesday night in the Prospect Heights Hospital. He was 75 years old and resided at 758 Putnam Avenue.

Manufactures of airplanes in the United States during 1936 increased 78 per cent over 1935, and the production of light planes of the private-owner type gained by 66 per cent, the Bureau of Air Commerce of the Department of Commerce announced today.
An afternoon "stayout" strike of high school pupils in this Crow's Nest Pass mining town brought quick reprisals from the School Board today.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, continuing its investigation of the financing of the vast system of railways and other properties included in the so-called Van Sweringen empire, charged today that prior to the negotiations by the Van Sweringens of a $39,500,000 loan in 1930, officers and directors of banks participating in the loan had been privileged by J. P. Morgan Co.,

The net operating income of 144 Class I railroads in January was $38,436,679, compared with $35,728,532 in January, 1936, the Association of American Railroads and the Interstate Commerce Commission reported yesterday. Combined gross earnings amounted to $331,684,689, against $299,058,328.
The one-story taxpayer at 342 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Michel's Restaurant, which owns the adjoining buildings.

Detroit's Red Wings took a hard-fought 2-1 decision from the Rangers before 12,000 spectators tonight to come within two points of clinching the season's leadership of the National Hockey League's American Group.

Leading stocks reacted and prices closed irregularly lower; steel, copper and motor shares off 1 to 3 points; turnover, 2,725,830 shares. United States Government bonds steady and dull; other issues irregular; transactions, $17,143,800.

On motion of William Power Maloney, Assistant United States Attorney, Federal Judge John C. Knox dismissed yesterday an indictment against four of nineteen defendants on trial for mail fraud and conspiracy in the sale of stock of the Public Service Holding Corporation.

Plans for dwellings, tenement houses, stores, a garage and a variety of other operations were filed yesterday in the city. Owners also submitted plans for numerous alternations to structures in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

Mrs. May Sargent Rice, wife of William Acker Rice of this city, died in New Haven Hospital today after a week's illness. Mrs. Rice was a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Sargent. Her father was the founder of Sargent Co.,

Predicting the adoption of President Roosevelt's proposal for reforming the United States Supreme Court, General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA Administrator, termed it the fourth great battle of the New Deal. The first three were in the elections of 1932, 1934 and 1936, General Johnson declared.

Dartmouth defeated Brown in hockey, 8-5, tonight, after taking a 5-0 lead in the initial period. Brown, playing its last game, came back to dominate the second period with two goals by Darling and the rivals played on even terms through a desperately fought third session.
Legalized betting on horse races in Texas suffered a major blow in the Legislature today and both friends and opponents said it apparently was headed for the discard.

As the site for a group of sixstory apartment houses, sixty lots comprising the block bounded by Exeter and Fleet Streets, Baldwin and Stafford Avenues, Forest Hills, Queens, have been purchased by the Charlotte Realty and Construction Corporation from the Bankers Trust Company.
A six-man jury in Municipal Court returned a sealed verdict against the New York Telephone Company yesterday in a $3.85 suit over the accuracy of timing devices for longdistance calls.

Mrs. Victoria Redwood and the man she says told her he knew who ordered her husband, Norman Redwood, murdered will meet each other face to face this week for a showdown on discrepancies in their stories, it was announced yesterday by John J. Breslin, Prosecutor of Bergen County.
A slight increase in the general level of wholesale prices was recorded in the week ended on Feb. 27, but the sharp upward movement slackened somewhat, the Bureau of Labor statistics announced today.

Although some of the large buyers have already placed substantial orders for men's Fall staple suits, the new lines will not be officially opened until around the first of next month, according to reports here yesterday. At the present time manufacturers are preparing their samples and figuring their costs, making every effort to keep price advances down.

The thirty-five-bell carillon which Alfred University Alumni are giving the school as a memorial to President Emeritus Boothe C. Davis and Mrs. Davis will be dedicated at the 101st commencement in June.
E. G. Buckland, president of the Railroad Credit Corporation, said yesterday the corporation would make on March 15 a liquidating distribution of 1 per cent amounting to $735,407.

The six-day bicycle race continued apace at Madison Square Garden last night, with the indefatigable riders still grinding their weary way around the glaring pine saucer. With competition for first place running high, the athletes contributed a goodly share of entertainment for the benefit of the onlookers.

The thirty-five-bell carillon which Alfred University Alumni are giving the school as a memorial to President Emeritus Boothe C. Davis and Mrs. Davis will be dedicated at the 101st commencement in June.
E. G. Buckland, president of the Railroad Credit Corporation, said yesterday the corporation would make on March 15 a liquidating distribution of 1 per cent amounting to $735,407.

The six-day bicycle race continued apace at Madison Square Garden last night, with the indefatigable riders still grinding their weary way around the glaring pine saucer. With competition for first place running high, the athletes contributed a goodly share of entertainment for the benefit of the onlookers.

An investing syndicate headed by Bennett Milnor, vice-president of the Harmon National Real Estate Corporation, bought the business property at 18 and 20 Washington Street, southeast corner of William Street, East Orange, N. J. The property,

Spectators who saw the national A. A. U. senior indoor track and field .championships in Madison Square Garden last Saturday night voted Tommy Deckard's world record-breaking 3,000-meter steeplechase race as the meet's most meritorious performance.
A decisive development appeared near today in the tug-of-war between the Federal Government and the States over the financing of relief.

Supreme Court Justice CharlesC. Lockwood in Brooklyn, who fought unsuccessfully for compulsory accident insurance laws when he was a State Assemblyman sixteen years ago, renewed his plea yesterday, a destitute widow won an empty victory in his court.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 3:

Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant State Attorney General, announced yesterday the arrest in Los Angeles, Calif., of David Walton, alleged stock swindler, for whom detectives in the Bureau of Securities have searched for more than two years.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ordered today a withdrawal of a ruling yesterday in which it refused to modify a decision of Jan. 16, 1936, that six large motion picture producing and distributing companies were violating the antitrust laws by refusing to furnish films to exhibitors who showed "double features."

Sir Charles and Lady Sykes of London arrived yesterday from California and are at the Ritz-Carlton before going to Canada. Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hutchinson of 720 Park Avenue are sailing today on the Conte di Savoia to visit their son,

Announcement has been made by Mrs. George H. Kuper of 610 Park Avenue and Redding, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen D. Kuper, to John E. Barrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Barrett, also of this city and New Canaan, Conn.

Governor E. D. Rivers of Georgia in a letter to Governor Nelson G. Kraschel of Iowa said today that a bill in the Iowa Legislature to place a tax of 5 cents a pound on lard substitutes "discriminates against the farmers of our State."

Somebody in Toledo who once cheated the government sent a two-cent stamp to the Treasury today to relieve his conscience. The stamp was duly credited to the "Conscience Fund," which received $170 during the day.
The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company had before it today demands for a 20 per cent wage increase to apply to more than 8,000 of its Pittsburgh workers.

W. A. Davis, seeded sixth, of the Cornell Club, gained the second round of the Metropolitan Class C squash racquets tournament at the Downtown A. C. yesterday by subduing M. S. Gaffney, Princeton Club, 15-5, 15-10, 15-9, in an opening-round test.
Pennsylvania bituminous coal operators and State authorities urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to remove a freight-rate differential on coal.

Four freight ships will be added to the New York-South African service this month to handle he unusually heavy volume of freight which has been coming to the market in the last ten days, it was announced last night.

The New York Hospital Society eventually will receive $127,736 from the estate of Miss Katherine Grace M Snyder of 1 East Fifty-seventh Street, who died Jan. 13, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. She left a net estate of $352,706.

Apparently unmoved by President Roosevelt's appeal for party loyalty in his Victory Dinner speech last night, Democratic opponents of his proposal to remake the Supreme Court made plans today to take the issue to the country and to show the people the "innate wickedness" of the scheme.
Ego, owned by Miss Maria Deal, came from behind in the stretch to win the O'Keefe Cup at Montagu Park race track today. Ego was the favorite. The cup was presented by Lady Clifford.
The test of the government communique announcing new measures to strengthen the financial position of the French treasury follows:
Russell Forbes, Purchase Commissioner, denied yesterday that idleness among prisoners at Sing Sing was the result of a drastic curtailment of New York City's purchases of prison-made commodities.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a membership for $125,000. The last previous deal was consummated at $119,000 on Feb. 13.

The glorification of burlesque, which has been furthered of late hereabouts by certain academic citizens and others, has had its inevitable repercussions this season in the field of night club entertainment.

Apropos of current discussion of wildlife restoration throughout the nation, Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the United States Biological Survey, stresses the constant need for research, "a constant search after facts and yet more facts."
The Brooklyn College of Pharmacy five triumphed over Temple College of Pharmacy, 39-22, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Pharmacy League game at home last night.
At the Democratic victory dinner they had, among other things, terrapin soup croute au chaud farci, artichokes chatelaine, oranges gateau parfait and coupe

A law partner of the personal attorney of Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey was retained yesterday to defend Martin Schlossman, one of the persons accused of kidnapping Paul H. Wendel in the plot alleged to have been inspired by Governor Hoffman's lifelong friend, Ellis H. Parker Sr., chief of the Burlington County (N. J.) detectives.

The steel inspector who was assigned to examine the apartment house at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, which collapsed last June 19, killing eighteen workmen, admitted yesterday in the Bronx County Court he did not investigate the reason for installing girders in the roof tier capable of supporting a load equal to that on the vestibule tier.

ONCE we get started, it will be pretty hard to find anything favorable to say of Malcolm Muggeridge's book on Samuel Butler: "The Earnest Atheist" (Putnam, $2.75). So here, at the beginning, is an honest tribute. Mr. Muggeridge writes extremely well. He pitches into his victim with a skill both wonderful and furious.

Benjamin Thaw, for many years in the diplomatic service before his retirement two years ago, died late yesterday at the Medical Center from heart trouble. He was 48 years old. He had been ill about three weeks.
Professor J. Leo O'Gorman, head of the education department at Holy Cross College and former Superintendent of Schools in Revere, Mass., died suddenly yesterday at his home here. He was 56 years old.
Aided by favorable weather, retail trade here continued active this week. Gains ranging up to 10 per cent or more over the comparative 1936 period were reported by department store executives.

BERUEN, ALEXANDER JAY (Feb. 25). Estate, $20.000. To Evelyn L. Bruen and Constance L. J. Bruen, daughters, executrices; Edward F. L. Bruen and Alexander L. J. Bruen Jr., sons, executors, all of 19 E. 83d St., residue equally.

SENIOR STENOGRAPHIC REPORTER, $2,300 a year, Securities and Exchange Commission, New York, N. Y. Applications must be on file with the manager, Second United States Civil Service District, Federal Building, Christopher St., New York, N. Y.. not later than March 19.

Stockholders of the Monsanto Chemical Company will vote at their annual meeting in St. Louis on March 23 on a proposal to increase its capital stock from 1,250,000 authorized shares, all common stock, to 2,000,000 shares, including 1,725,000 common and 275,000 preferred, all of no par value.
Negotiations over settlement of Mexico's foreign debt, which were regarded as virtually concluded, have struck a snag which may upset the settlement.

Following is the text of Governor Lehman's radio address tonight urging ratification of the child labor amendment: I am glad to accept the invitation of the New York Joint Committee for Ratification of the Child Labor Amendment to present to the people of the State my views on the amendment. I do so as one who became intensely interested in the problem of child labor many years before I assumed public office.

The special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case handed up a superseding indictment yesterday against Louis Luckman, who was indicted recently for perjury. The new indictment adds a new count also charging perjury.

Stockholders of the Cities Service Company at a special meeting in Dover, Del., on March 16, will vote on a proposal to approve the offer of compromise and settlement of the suit brought by six holders owning 840 shares of stock against Henry L. Doherty, Cities Service and affiliated companies and ten of Mr. Doherty's fellow directors.

Tomorrow is the twenty-fifth anniversary of the death of Frederick Keppel, and in memory- the Keppel Galleries, 71 East Fiftyseventh Street, which he founded, has arranged an exhibition called "The Golden-Age of Engraving"the title given to Mr. Keppel's book of criticism and personal reminiscence, published in 1910.
Colby men students threatened today a "sit-down" invasion of a social room in which they said they had been forbidden to continue quiet chats with co-eds of their choice.
PATROLMEN--John W. Mooney, Traffic Precinct B. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 24, 1906. Frederick Ganss, office of the Property Clerk, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 16, 1909.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
The Spanish Insurgent regime today accused France of fomenting disturbances in Spanish Morocco in order to force a pretext for invading the territory held by General Francisco Franco's armies.
More than 7,000 shirt and collar workers in Albany, Troy, Cohoes and Kingston today were awarded a 73 per cent wage increase retroactive to March 1.

Representatives of fifteen families who lost their homes and belongings in the tenement fire Thursday morning at 137-39 Suffolk Street, started a sit-down strike yesterday at the Emergency Relief Bureau, 43 Bleecker Street.

In a statement issued at the end of tonight's meeting, the Fascist Grand Council revealed that the net loss in Italy's fiscal reserve from the beginning of the Italo-Ethiopian campaign to Feb. 20 of this year amounted to about 2,750,000,000 lire (the lira was quoted in New York yesterday at 5.26 1/2 cents).
William R. Tremper, District Superintendent of Schools of Northern Dutchess County, died yesterday of heart disease in Red Hook Township at the age of 71.
The preliminary report of the General Electric Company for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $43,947,000, or $1.52 a share, after providing $300,000 estimated surtax on undivided profits.

Federal Land Banks during the last six months sold more farms than they took over and realized a net reduction in their farm land holdings for the first time since the depression, it was announced today by the Farm Credit Administration.

More than 750 old tenements will be repaired and brought into compliance with the Multiple Dwellings Law under legislation adopted by the Legislature last January, Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, said yesterday.
A handful of Yellow cab drivers went on strike this morning, starting a movement which spread rapidly and had a development in an order by leaders tonight for all cabs to leave the streets.

Enrico Venturi, 140 1/2 pounds, of Italy, and Frank Wallace, 135, of Cleveland, fought a draw in their ten-round feature bout on the benefit program for Gene Pope's Italian Newspaper Club at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 3,500 was present.

Mr. and Mrs. Ewald H. Schniewind of Greenwich, Conn., gave a luncheon yesterday in the ladies' annex of the Metropolitan Club for Princess Daria (Dolly) Obolensky and Hans George Spitzer, who will be married next Friday in the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour, this city.
The Middle Atlantic Association of the Amateur Athletic Union announced today that it would conduct the track and field meet. at Hershev March 12-13.

The Yale freshmen quintet today defeated the Princeton cubs, 39-33, in a hard-fought game. The lead changed hands several times during the first half, but the Yale cub five forged ahead in the second. Meyerholz of the visitors was high scorer with 11 points. Captain Tom Ericsson of Yale led his team with nine.

Park Av. (11-2899), n .w cor Ittner P., 102x90; 4,077 Park Av. Corp. to Harlem Savings Bank; $26,000. 158th St. (10-2655), a s, 113 ft w of Union Av., 50xl00; Hyman Winick to Chase National Bank, at 3 to 4% per cent; $36,000. Cambreling Av. (11-3090), s e cor 189th St., 99x74; Brookhaven Trading Corp. to Workmen's Sick and Death Benefit Fund, 714 Seneca Av., Brooklyn, 5 per cent; $94.500.

Miss Jane Elizabeth Van Cott, daughter of Mrs. Lincoln Van Cott of 160 Henry Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Van Cott, was married yesterday afternoon to Hardwick Stires, son of the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, and Mrs. Stires.

The establishment in the United States of center for political, financial and economic studies for the youth of all the American republics, so that the future leaders of this hemisphere would have personal friendships and a common technical basis for international relations, was proposed yesterday by Dr. Rafael Belaunde, Peruvian 'Minister to Mexico.

Additional changes in the new Traffic Code, permitting left turns on red lights by cars going-north or south on Eighth Avenue, were announced yesterday by Deputy Po lice Commissioner Harold- Fowler, Similar modifications, allowing left turns on Madison and Fifth Avenues, Broadway and Riverside Drive, were announced previously.
Now that it has come to applying non-intervention to Spain in detail, the job is, proving even more difficult than expected.

Timothy Patrick Murphy, for many years a lecturer on socialism and atheism, died on Thursday at him home, 157 Vermlyea Avenue. He was 63 years old. Born in Ireland, Mr. Murphy had served in India in the British Army before coming to this country.

Stocks closed at highest level of movement, steel and rail shares gaining 1 to-4 points; turnover, 2,827,180 shares. United States Government bonds lower, convertible issues up, other groups irregular; transactions, $16,510,000.
Herbert Grant Stockwell, writer and founder of a Philadelphia firm of accountants, died here last night from complications growing out of a mastoid infection. He was 70 years old.
The World premiere of "The Head-less Horseman," a new American school operetta, was held tonight at the Bronxville High School auditorium, presented by students of the Bronxville school.
Nothing that has happened in the United States this year interests Europe as much as the passage by the Senate of the Pittmax neutrality resolution.

A warning voted by the county executive committee of the American Legion that the charter of the 307th Infantry Post "is at stake" brought a protest yesterday from the post that it had been "tried without a hearing" in contravention of the principles of "true Americanism."

The House passed the $526,555,000 Naval Supply Bill today after rejecting by a vote of 66 to 81 an amendment which would have requested President Roosevelt to call a conference to halt the "mad naval race."

The Committee for Industrial Organization's first request for recognition in a Trenton plant was refused today by F. E. Schulter, president of the Thermoid Rubber Company, who announced at the same time any one using threats to force his employes to join a union would be prosecuted.
Mrs. Elizabeth Foster Tucker, widow of William Austin Tucker, one of the organizers and former senior partner of the brokerage firm of Tucker, Anthony Co., died Thursday at her home, 399 Park Avenue.

Stanley Galowin of the City Athletic Club defended his Eastern Squash Racquets Association, Group 1, championship by defeating Albert E. Watt of the Jackson Heights Squash Club in the final at the New York Athletic Club yesterday, 15-7, 15-9, 16-18. 15-11.

A first book of "photocrimes," in which a mystery is presented in a series of snapshots and readers are invited to find the guilty man after a study of the pictures, has been brought out here by Hillman-Curl. The title is "Photocrimes," and the volume is the work of Mileson Horton and Thomas Pembroke This series is popular in England.

Secretary Ickes announced today a Public Works Administration allotment of $175,000 to the Quartermaster Corps of the War Department for additions to accommodations at Fort Hamilton and Governors Island.

Grain prices on the Board of Trade here rose sharply today on fairly general buying induced by the strained financial and political situation abroad, heavy buying of cash wheat by importing countries and the strength in commodities in general.
Authority to sell $7,500,000 of equipment-trust certificates, Series I, was sought today by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad from the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Miss Innes Gordon Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Stewart of Kensington, GreatNeck, L. I., entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for her cousin, Miss Constance Stewart Herbert, and Harrison Cochran Bettes, whose engagement was announced recently.

Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L. I., the defending champion, and James H. Van Alen of Westbury, L. I., runner-up last year, again won the right today to face each other in the final round of the American amateur court tennis championship.

Alfredo Salmaggi and his company presented the first of a series of three week-end operatic productions at popular prices last night at the Hippodrome. The opera, Verdi's "Rigoletto," attracted an assemblage of 5,000 persons.

The orchestra of the Institute of Musical Art will give a concert tonight at the Juilliard School of Music. Willem Willeke will conduct. Rossini's "Barber of Seville" will be the production this afternoon at the Hippodrome.

MEN'S SINGLES, CLASS A First Round Stephen Hartshorn, Central, defeated Elliott MacRae, New York, 15-9, 15-5; Donald C. Vaughan Jr., Garden City. defeated James McK. Rose, New York, 15-11, 15-1; Gilbert Carpenter, Westport, defeated Conrad Lavin, Jamaica, 15-12,

The Seth Low College basketball team concluded its season with a smashing 50-20 victory over the Nassau Hofstra five, at the Columbia University gymnasium last night. The Seth Low junior varsity routed the Hofstra jayvees by 26--10 in a preliminary game.

Philip Grossel, one of the defendants in the restaurant racket trial, told yesterday of trying to hide $29,000 in cash from Sam Krantz, who took over the racket for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer five weeks after Jules Martin had been murdered on an up-State visit to murdered on an up-State visit to "the Dutchman" with $21,000.

A tribute to German methods in radio broadcasting, with emphasis on German "kultur," was paid by Dr. Walther Funk, head of the Reich Press Deapartment, at the opening of the International Radio Conference at the Adlon Hotel here today.

Woodrow Wilson High School or Weehawken defeated Rutherford, 49-30, and Ridgefield Park downed Englewood, 34-31, to advance to the final in Group 3 of Division 1 in the New Jersey State interscholastic basketball tournament tonight.
A contract on a midtown business property provided the item of leading interest in Manhattan real estate activity yesterday.
Mrs. Alice Hawley, 45 years old, whose husband, J. B. Hawley, editor of the magazine Interior Decoration, died a month ago today, was found dead in bed this noon at her home, 19 Circle Drive.
Paul J. Kern, vice president of the National Lawyers Guild, condemned yesterday the opposition of the NewYork County Lawyers Association to President Roosevelt's plan to enlarge the Supreme Court.

Bleachers and grandstands at the Poinciana diamond were filled with spectators for the twenty-seventh annual society baseball game, played there this afternoon for the benefit of the Palm Beach police pension fund. Milton W. Holden was'

The Rev. Dr. John A. MacKay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, tonight accused the Catholic hierarch of Spain, the Archbishop of Toledo, of initiating any class or anti-clerical feeling that might exist today in Spain.

The dashing young King of Iraq, Emir Ghazi Ibn Feisal, has always nursed an ambition to attend a New York cocktail party, and he will have his wish if he carries out his plan to visit the United States next year.

President Roosevelt had as his overnight guest Premier William Mackenzie King of Canada. During the day he received from Secretary Ickes and other officials a request for additional funds for road building and sanitation projects in the Virgin Islands.

Broadway, 886-888, 6-story loft and store building, 45.8x1231; Irving Trust Co. against Nineteenth Street and Broadway Corp.; due, $142.513; to plaintiff for $20,000. By DAVID B. KUNSTLER 114th St., 62 E., 5-story tenement and store, 25x100.11 parcel 1; due, $17,745, taxes, , $150; and 114th St., 64 E.,5-story tenement and store, 25x100.11, parcel 2: due, $17,828, taxes, , $150; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Harry Sammet; to plaintiff for $1,000 each.

The six-story apartment house at 2,525 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, containing sixty suites, has been acquired by the Housing Holding Corporation, which paid cash above a first mortgage of $185,000 in a deal negotiated with the State Mortgage Commission and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company as trustee. The mortgage was extended for five years. The Midwood Management Corporation acted as broker and L. J. G. A. Shapiro represented the buyer.

The Connecticut State College Women's basketball team, paced by the sharp shooting Miss Julia Case, easily defeated New York University, 22 to 13, yesterday on the Evangeline House court. It was the second victory of the campaign for the visitors.

Miss Leila Delano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Delano of this city and Barrytown-on-Hudson, and a cousin of President Roosevelt, was married yesterday afternoon to Arthur Willing Patterson in the Church of the Incarnation.

The investigation by the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce of the part played by J. P. Morgan Co. in the financing of the Van Sweringen network of railroads and other properties was suspended today. and probably will not be resumed for three or four weeks, during which time the committee will be in recess.
Four teams were eliminated today in the first round of Stockton Cup curling competition at the Country Club. Twenty teams were entered in the contests, with finals to be held Sunday.

Out of the bewildering maze of men's and women's singles and doubles, as well as mixed doubles matches, in both the Class A and B divisions of the fifth annual metropolitan badminton championships at the 165th Regiment Armory, emerged only one notable early round contest last night.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 969,000 bales, against 929,000 a week ago, 920,000 two weeks ago, 806,000 three weeks ago and 747,000 a year ago; of which American 415,000 bales, against 410,000 a week ago, 415,000 two weeks ago, 399,000 three weeks ago and 392 a year ago.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in February totaled $26,070,426,220, a decline of 11.9 per cent from the preceding month, but a gain of 8.2 per cent over the turnover in February, 1936.

The period from April 18 to 24 has been designated by Cardinal Hayes for the annual appeal of New York Catholic Charities for funds to b carry on the organization's work in the archdiocese in 1937, it was announced yesterday by Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, executive director of the charitable group.

With the outcome hinging on the result of the heavyweight bout, Herb-Pickett gave Yale a 19-11 triumph over Harvard's matmen tonight by throwing Bill Glendinning with a cradle hold in 4 minutes 32 seconds. Yale took five of the eight bouts.
The Cambridge Farmers Club, one of f the few such still in existence in this State, celebrated its fiftieth anniversary today.

With the end in sight, the field in the six-day bicycle race thrilled a crowd of enthusiastic fans with steady jamming at Madison Square Garden last night. A gathering of 10,000 persons, the largest turnout since the race got under way on Sunday night, sat in on the evening activities, and saw the tireless athletes maintain an unending battlee for the lead position. Postmaster General Farley was one of the onlookers.
Adrian Rosley, motion-picture actor and formerly on the New York stage, died at a hospital here today of a heart ailment. He was 47 years old.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, met a setback today from Massachusetts leaders of his own organization in reply to his call for a war to the finish against attempts of the C. I. O. to organize the boot and shoe industry of this State.
A 900-year-old Chinese incense burner was stolen today from property occupied here a century ago by Joseph Bonaparte, brother of Napoleon.
BRUETSCHER, WILLIAM (Oct. 19. 1933). Gross assets, $16,872; net, $15,739. To Marjorie Bruetscher, widow. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $11,086. Sydney S. Jalkut, attorney, 275 Madison Av.

The decision taken by the French Government to permit the Bank of France to buy gold at the current market rate and to remove restrictions on the freedom of gold movements becomes clearer in the light of the last fortnight's frequent conversations between Paris and London.

Harvey Dow Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company and chairman of the American committee of German "standstill" creditors, returned yesterday on the United States liner Washington from conferences in Berlin and London at which the agreement for "freezing" more than 1,000,000,000 marks of short-term credits owed by- Germany to foreign banks had been renewed one year for the seventh time.

Dr. Cornelius Doremus Van Wagenen, an ear and throat specialist died yesterday in Harbor Hospital after a short illness. Dr. Van Wagenen, the son of the late Cornelius Doremus and Susan Anderson Van Wagenen, was 71 years old and a member of an old New York family.

Three men who on Feb. 25, pleaded guilty to a plot to manufacture and circulate $50,000 in counterfeit $10 Federal Reserve notes were sentenced yesterday by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in the Federal Court in Brooklyn, to eight years each in a Federal penitentiary.

Peddie School of Hightstown, N. J., paid tribute to one of the leading sports figures in its alumni ranks last night when Larry Kelley, Yale's colorful football end and star athlete, received the John D. Plant Cup at the Peddie Alumni Association's annual dinner at the Hotel McAlpin.
George P. Richter, former Assemblyman, died yesterday at his home, 42-27 Westmoreland Street, Little Neck, Queens, after a year's illness. Mr. Richter was born in New York seventy-five years ago.

With the publication today of the air estimates calling for the expenditure of [Pound]82,500,000, the minimum cost of Britain's army, navy and air force for the financial year 1937-38 stood revealed tonight at the colossal sum of [Pound]277,800,000.

The Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets played outstanding hockey tonight to take a 2-goal lead, but faltered in the final period and allowed the New York Rovers to tie the score at 3-3 in an Eastern Amateur League Bil game. Neither team could break the deadlock in an overtime period.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Czechoslovakia was described last night at a dinner of the AmericanCzechoslovak Chamber of Commerce at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel as an island of democracy and a force for peace in a Central Europe beset by rival warlike ideologies.

Finding that prevailing poultry loading rates at New York City were "unreasonable," Secretary Wallace prescribed today a maximum charge of $41 a car for the service. This is $11 under the present rate.

Two instances in which the interests of holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates had been well safeguarded were described yesterday at a public hearing of the joint legislative committee that is studying the guaranteed mortgage situation. The hearing was at the Bar

The stock markets here were quiet today at the end of the account, except international issues, which were affected by profit-taking. British funds eased, while German bonds gained and French bonds were strong.

Under the influence of favorable weather conditions, consumers started Spring buying in earnest this week, sending retail sales to a new high for the year, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Directors of the Allis Chalmers Manufacturing Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share. Last year the company paid dividends aggregating $1.50 a share, beginning with a 25-cent payment on June 30, when dividends were resumed after four years without dividends.

Stockholders of the United Electric Coal Companies will vote in Chicago on March 25 on a plan to change the authorized capital stock from 730 shares of 7 per cent $100 par preferred and 535,000 10-par common shares to the same amount of preferred and 750,000 common shares of $5 par value.

At the annual meeting on March 17 stockholders of the General Cable Corporation will be asked to authorize the redemption of all outstanding 5 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds of the corporation at 105 and accured interest.

The 1,403 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $46,571,646,225 par value as of March 1, had a total market value of $45,007,329,915, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Feb. 1,

Homer Saint-Gaudens, American sculptor, and Mrs. Saint-Gaudens; Harrison Williams, financier; H. M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, and Mrs. Warner are among the passengers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte di Savola.

The Zeppelin Hindenburg will make eighteen round trips across the North Atlantic this year, eight more than were scheduled in 1936, it was announced yesterday by Edward S. Farley, president of the American Zeppelin Transport Corportion, general agents for the Hindenburg in the United States.
Lusty batting was displayed by the touring Marylebone Cricket Club players today when they started a two-day encounter with a Victorian country team.

Dick Metz of Chicago, who shattered the course record with a seven-under-par 63 on the second round, coasted to victory today in the seventy-two-hole Hollywood open golf tournament. Metz took $700 of the $3,000 purse, the same amount he won in the recent Thomasville (Ga.) open.

Arthur D. WVhiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was the guest speaker at the annual dinner of the reporting staff of the mercantile agency at the Hotel Astor last night. The dinner also marked
A severe break in the franc and the prospect of higher wage costs in the domestic textile industry brought general buying and another sharp rise in prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday.

In honor of the Spring, Brock Pemberton, the sage of Times Square, offers Mary Coyle Chase's "Now You've Done It," which opened at Henry Miller's last evening. Mrs. Chase is a Denver newspaper woman. Under another title her play was first produced by the Denver Federal Theatre Project last December.
The three openings scheduled for today are: "Nancy Steele Is Missing," with Victor McLagien Walter Connolly, Peter Lorre and June

Cramn's Reports, Inc., estimated today that automobile production for the current week would total 126,975 units, compared with 111,915 cars and trucks turned out last week and 91,705 in the corresponding week of 1936.

A group or the daughters or Newport army, navy and marine officers, who constitute the Tau Omicron Phi sorority, presented at the Viking this afternoon "Ensembles in Fashion" for the benefit of the Navy Relief Fund.
Chief Justice R. A. E. Greenshields decided that a man who plays Cupid for a consideration is doing the world a real service and is entitled to his fee as matchmaker.

The marriage of Miss Mary Louise Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mills Wheeler of Fairfield, to Frank Carley Hunt Jr., son of Mrs. Herbert D. Smith of New Canaan and Frank Carley Hunt of Bridgeport, took place this afternoon at St. George's Episcopal

Herbert Morrison, virile Labor party leader, today was swept back into control of London's municipal government for another three years with his majority in the County Council increased from 14 to 26.

Notifiction of registration under the Public Utility Holding Act of 1935, covering the issue of 153,034 shares of $1 par value common stock, was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the Great Lakes Utilities Company of Philadelphia.

The Hun School hockey team closed the season tonight in Baker Rink with its ninth victory out of eleven starts, defeating the Highland High School, 3-2. Bill Garrison opened the scoring for Highland in 9:01 of the first period and Parry made it one more on a pass from Dyroff in 3:02 of the second.

Winning three bouts by default, the Pennsylvania boxing team scored a 5-3 victory over Princeton in the university gymnasium tonight. Four of the five bouts were settled by the verdict of Referee Arthur Donovan.

The preliminary report of the Western Union Telegraph Company, Inc., for the year ended Dec. 31 reveals a net income of $7,199,120, or $6.89 a share on the 1,045,279 shares of common stock outstanding. This is compared to a net income of $5,258,078, or $5.03 a common share in 1935.

Otto Best, retired railroad and munitions executive, died yesterday morning of heart disease at St. Vincent's Hospital after a short illness Mr. Best, who was 70 years old, lived at 1,461 University Avenue, the Bronx.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We are hearing a great deal about the "American way" of life. Thousands of billboards are impressing our people with the advantages of .the American economic system with joyful, happy pictures of far from typical American families. Perhaps it is meant as a goal

All embassies here were placed on bread rations yesterday. Last night each of us had half a roll for dinner at the United States Embassy. The past week's frost retarded early vegetable crops, and there is an abnormal scarcity of fresh garden produce at the moment.

A five-hour session of the House of Commons today was devoted exclusively to the defense of aged and work-worn horses and their protection from exportation for exploitation in other countries not so friendly to animals.
These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: So much of Paragraph 10, Special Orders 41, Feb. 19, 1937, pertaining to 1st Lt. Charles P. lender. Inf.-Res. as reads:

A United Automobile Workers of America "ultimatum" on its demand for sole bargaining rights for 67,000 Chrysler Corporation employes prolonged a conference betWeen union and company officials for nearly two hours today before it recessed until Monday.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market is steadier, chiefly in sympathy with the stronger tone which has developed in the foreign markets.
Peru will witness a "double sunset" June 8. It will be brought about by the longest eclipse of the sun in 1,200 years, which at one point will have a totality of 7 minutes 4 seconds.
A program presupposing unusual endurance, intelligence and technical skill on the part of its executant was put forward by Katherine Ruth Heyman at her piano recital in Town Hall last night.
Eighteenthcentury gold snuff boxes and jewelry were stolen this afternoon from the Cognacq-Jay Museum.

New bond financing this week amounted to only $11,555,000, the smallest volume for such a period since the week ended on Nov. 6 last year, when only $450,000 in new loans was placed. Last week the total was $18,615,000 and a year ago this week it was $131,488,000.
Demanding "shorter hours" and "better studying conditions," about 100 of the 200 boys enrolled in technical courses at the Bayonne High School went on a "stay-out" strike this morning.

The Federal Trade Commission made public today trade practice rules proposed by the American Brush Manufacturers Association of Philadelphia, said to represent more than 80 per cent of the toilet brush manufacturing business in the United States, and set March 23 as the date for oral hearings by persons wishing to speak on the proposals.

The team-of-four crown of the Eastern Bridge Championships was won yesterday by Waldemar K. von Zedtwitz, S. Garton Churchill, Charles Lochridge and A. Mitchell Barnes with a whirlwind finish to their two-day, eighty-board final.

Rose A. Keane has purchased a plot on Fox Run and Howard D. Dabney a plot on Lake Drive, at Candlewood Isle, Conn. The General Motors Building at 1,775 Broadway earned a net profit, before interest and depreciation, of $396,280 in 1936 as compared with $388,077 in the previous year, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc. The building is reported as 85 per cent rented.
Captain Thomas Harding, of Engine 64, died March 3. Funeral will take place from premises, 1,467 Beach Av., Bronx, at 10:30 A. M., Saturday, March 6. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was split sharply into two distinct categories, namely, high-grade investments and convertible corporate issues, which displayed highly conflicting price trends.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Campbell Watt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Frederick Watt, to William Washington Smith, son of Mrs. William Washington Smith of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Smith, took place yesterday

There was a sharp letdown today in the stiff breeze which for nearly a week has been churning the deep blue waters of the Gulf but this only served to give Bill Terry an idea for stirring up a little wind on his own account.

Cotton mill activity declined last week when the seasonal trend was upward and the adjusted index dropped more than six points. The figure now is 131.0 as against 137.4 in the preceding week and 103.4 for the week ended Feb. 29, 1936.

Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's employee representatives' leaders mobilized a defense of their reorganized collective bargaining plan tonight in the face of William Green's refusal to join their campaign against John L. Lewis's steel union.

The volume of round-lot sales on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Feb. 6 was 15,689480 shares, compared with 13,108,170 shares for the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Air Pilot Sam, big pointer owned by L. D. Johnson of Evansville, Ind., captured the 1937 bird dog championship today in a run-off race as surprising as any in the forty-two-year history of the national field trials.
British Ministers, engrossed. in their colossal rearmament campaign, have deliberately said as -little as possible about the League of Nations in recent weeks.

Eighteen members of the faculty of Harvard Law School, acting as individuals, have just signed a "round-robin" protest against the proposals for changes in the Federal judicial system, particularly in the Supreme Court.

The American Legation and Consulate in Addis Ababa will be closed and diplomatic and consular representation of the United States in Ethiopia terminated on March 31, the State Department announced today.
The State Banking Department announced today its approval of a certificate of reduction of capital stock of the New York Produce Exchange Safe Deposit and Storage Company of New York.

The board of stewards of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association put everything in order for the opening of the hunt and steeplechase season by granting licenses to riders and trainers yesterday. Certificates were approved for ten amateur riders and four jockeys, along with the applications of eleven trainers.
Fifty New York labor leaders will leave tomorrow for Washington to attend, as delegates from the American Labor party, the convention of Labor's Non-Partisan League on Monday.

A "sit-down" strike at the bottom of Lake Superior, carried out by a lone diver, was chalked up tonight as successful. Tony Dimo was engaged yesterday to examine the mouth of the intake pipe connected with the Port Arthur waterworks system, thirty feet below the surface.
The Bell System announced yesterday a net gain of 92,200 telephones on its lines in February, compared with a gain of 95,600 stations in January and with one of 66,400 in February, 1936.

Rosa Pauly, soprano of the Vienna and Prague State Operas, will sing the title role in the concert production of Strauss's opera, "Elektra," scheduled by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of its guest conductor, Arthur Rodzinski, for March 18, 19 and 21 at Carnegie Hall, it was announced yesterday.

Five former directors of the Pelham National Bank, closed since 1933, have offered $75,000 to settle a suit alleging mismanagement brought against them by Edward Loughman, Federal receiver for the bank.

The Bencrest Realty Co, Inc., Herman Epstein, vice president, gave a mortgage for $125,000, due according to the bond, to Investors Syndicate on 265 Northern AV. This is a building loan. The T-D Construction Corp., Max Wilson. president, bought the n. e. corner of and Charles Sts. from the Emigrant Bank giving back in part payment a purchase-money mortgage for $18.119. The bank also advanced as a builddemand. The indicated consideration was $18,500.
Right Wing group predicts victory in the general elections Sunday. The Leftists refused today-to make forecasts.

Playing sub-par golf, Miss Patty Berg, Minneapolis ace and medalist, and Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., golf queen of the Carolinas, won their semi-final matches today in the Florida East Coast women's championship.

Twelve thousand German fans forgot all about Nazi racial theories tonight and thunderously applauded the Belgian Negro boxer. Al Baker, even though he lost a twelveround fight to Gustave Eder of Germany.

Having decreed with grim determination some time ago that the Dodgers no longer would be "the daffiness boys," Manager Burleigh Grimes announced today his proposed remedy for some of the odd base-running and fielding that are alleged to have stirred laughter even on Mount Olympus.

A reform of the Communist party to introduce democracy and secret, direct voting for lower officials of the party was announced tonight at the conclusion of a secret session of the central committee of the party, which had been in session in the Kremlin for ten days.

Richie Ling, once leading man for Lillian Russell, Fritzie Scheff and Christie MacDonald, and asuccessful actor on Broadway for almost fifty years, was found dead of heart disease in bed at the Lambs Club, where he lived, yesterday morning. Mr. Ling was born

The National Tube Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, announced price increases today, graduated from $3 to $10 a ton for tubular products, effective immediately. The rise was attributed to higher costs of raw materials and wage increases.
