New York City was named today 1936 winner of the grand prize in the National Traffic Safety Contest conducted annually by the National Safety Council. It was cited as "the city which, in the opinion of the judges, came nearest to doing for safety the maximum that can be done practically."

A notable canine achievement was officially recognized yesterday at the offices of the American Kennel Club. In the presence of a large gathering of dog fanciers, Champion Vigow of Romanoff, famed borzoi owned by Louis J. Murr of Spring Valley, N. Y., was honored as the American-bred dog having won the greatest number of variety group classes at American dog shows during 1936.

The board of trustees of Mount Holyoke College moved tonight to write finis, as far as it is concerned, to the controversy over the-election of a man as president of this century-old women's institution.

Opposition to President Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization was expressed yesterday in a statement issued by Henry Winters, executive secretary of the Bronx Borough Taxpayers League, Inc., on behalf of the league.
Mrs. Marie Schmeder and the man she mysteriously shot in the back as they flew together at 1,300 feet were reconciled tonight in the District Attorney's office.

Governor Lehman signed today the Twomey bill, reappropriating approximately $15,000,000 of unexpended funds to prevent payless paydays for employes of contractors on State work and for legislative committee aides. The measure, which also includes a large sum for reimbursement of localities for relief expenditures, was passed in advance of the regular budget lest such payments be held up by any possible deadlock on the budget.

Evidence of perjury, extortion and labor racketeering in New York developed during the course of the investigation into the murder of Norman Redwood was turned over yesterday by John J. Breslin Jr., Prosecutor of Bergen County, N. J., to District Attorney William C. Dodge.

Three alarms of fire were sounded early this morning as the Meyer London Matzoth Bakery, described as one of the oldest and largest in the city, housed in a building at 494 Grand Street, was threatened with destruction.

The visit of the Finnish naval training ship Suomen Joutsen to New York harbor is a symbol of the strengthening of the ties between Finland and the United States, Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, declared yesterday afternoon in a radio address from Washington.

John Scott awards for 1937 were presented by the City of Philadelphia tonight to Dr. W. D. Coolidge and Dr. Irving Langmuir, director and associate director of the General Electric Company's research laboratory in Schenectady, and to Dr. Evarts A. Graham, Professor of Surgery at the Washington University Medical School in St. Louis.

The Kansas City Power and Light Company reported yesterday for 1936, a net income of $4,710,405, which, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, amortization and dividend requirements on the $6 first preferred stock, was equal to $8.51 a share on the 525,000 shares of common stock outstanding. This compared with a net of $3,627,867, or $6.45 a share in 1935.
Some indication of the assistance British volunteers have been giving the Valencia-Madrid Government in Spain was revealed tonight by the British Communist party headquarters here.

This city's steel strike, which Bethlehem Steel Corporation officials described yesterday as a "misunderstanding" over terms of a recent wage increase, spread today to the ore concentrator plant where 250 workmen walked out.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: If the results of the National track and field championships at the Garden last Saturday are any criterion, America has little to fear in the next Olympic Games, for, according to the poll conducted by the A. A. U. asking spectators

The Rev. Dr. Henry B. Master is the only man ever to be at the same time Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America and president of the western section of the Alliance of the Reformed Church throughout the world holding the Presbyterian system.

Retail businesses continued yesterday to demand store space in a widespread area of the city. Numbered among the firms leasing new quarters were food merchants tailors, cigar manufacturers and dealers and shoe and dry goods retailers. The list follows:

The engagement was announced today of Miss Betsy Bell Smith, daughter of Mrs. Dudley Robbins Smith of this city, to Lawrence Mills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Hunt Mills of Portland, Ore., and grandson of Bishop

For the release and cancellation of all claims to $4.20 in accumulated dividends, to and including Dec. 1, 1936, stockholders of the General Alloys Company have authorized the directors to make the following offer to holders of the company's Class A preferred stock:
Turpentine steady, 41/2c: no sales; receipts. 43 barrels; shipments, 70 barrels; stock, 24,246 barrels. Resin quiet; no sales; receipts, 380; shipments, 902; stock, 56.839.
William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington to spend two weeks here on private business and to report to the State Department.

Acting in accord with a recent amendment to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange which gave the committee on quotations and commissions greater powers in approving partnership arrangements, it reported yesterday to the membership that on March 18 the committee would consider four changes in firms, including a new partnership.

The Confessional Synod and the Protestant Bishops of Bavaria and Wuerttemberg informed the government, and announced publicly, that they would boycott any church elections in which such a general political mobilization of all church-taxpayers occurred as it did in 1933.
Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission contended today that there was, $420,000,000 of "water" or "inflated values" in the 1929 market price of stocks controlled by Harrison Williams.

A wage increase of about 50 per cent was won today by Western Union Telegraph boys here. They called off their "run-around" strike when J. N. Armstrong, Chicago superintendent, raised their commission rates to a level by which the average boy will earn at least 30 cents an hour.
Dean Clarence W. Mendell of Yale College tonight unexpectedly announced that he would retire at the end of the college year in June. He has held the post since 1926.

The unbeaten Scarborough School basketball team extended its winning streak to sixteen straight yesterday when it routed Mount St. Michael High School, 47-19, on the victors' floor in Westchester. Ben Zajac and Lloyd Cornell, with 13 and 10 points, respectively, starred for Scarborough, which held a commanding lead of 24-5 at the intermission.
The possibility of another maritime strike over refusal of seamen to carry government-issued continuous discharge books appeared eliminated today.
Movements or vessels follow, all dates are March 4 unless specified: Ponta Del Gada to Trieste, March 5: Charleston, McDougal. At Charlotte, March 5: Lapwing, Teal, Wright.

R. J. Magor has retired as president of the Magor Car Corporation and A. Van Hassel, formerly vice president, has been named to succeed him. Mr. Magor will continue as chairman of the board. L. C. Haigh, formerly secretary, was elected vice president. J. W. Leis,

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had approved tentatively part of the rules of trade practice adopted by the perfume and cosmetic industry at a conference in New York in November and would hold a final hearing on March 23 at the commission's headquarters here.

Charges for bond discount and for abandonment of property helped the Southern Pacific Company to avoid accruals under the Federal surtax on undistributed net income in 1936, according to the annual report, issued yesterday.

Exposed to a public hearing tonight, the proposed charter to reorganize the government of Westchester County was viewed in a favorable light' by most of the thirty men and women who expressed their views, speaking as individuals or representatives of civic organizations and societies.

Money in circulation at the end of February amounted to $6,399,309,454, the Treasury announced today. This was an increase of $50,638,213 over the total as of Jan. 31 and of $553,349,786 over April 29, 1936. The average per capital circulation was $49.59, compared with $49.23 on Jan. 31 and $45.63 a year ago.

A farewell service for the Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, American Methodist missionary, on the eve of his return .to India will be held Tuesday evening in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, with Dr. Jones as the speaker. This will be under the

A tea was given by Miss Jane Robb Murdoch yesterday at the Pierre for a group of young women working with her on arrangements for a concert to be held on March. 15 to augment the scholarship fund of the Nightingale-Bamford School.

Our readers do not need to be reminded that, in discussion of the business situation, this is an age of " index numbers." Judgment is often based on comparison of the weekly or monthly statistical averages, say of prices or of industrial production, with other periods--1932. for instance, or 1929.
Trading In lamb was not quite as active as earlier this week. Steer hinds and ribs continued in good demand however and some slaughter houses were completely sold un to current kill.

Pla. In the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League reaches its climax tonight at Squadron A Armory in Manhattan and Squadron C in Brooklyn, where the first of the play-off games for the Squadran A Challenge Cup are to be held.

A foul shot by Don Pitman in the last two minutes of play enabled the Brooklyn Polytech quintet to halt Drexel, 35--34, at Odd Fellows Hall last night. Bill Waller led the victors' attack with 12 points. In a preliminary the Polytech jayvees turned back Dwight School, 37-19.

The "Bal Musette," most elaborate of the dinner dances of the season, will be held tomorrow night at the Surf Club, the patio of which is to be transformed into a replica of the Place du Terte, a French square in the Montmartre district.

The New York Telephone Company is anxious to eliminate its monthly.charge of 10 cents for the use. of handset telephones, according to a letter received by Mayor La Guardia yesterday from James L. Kilpatrick, president of the company.

Acosta settled today two differences with the law and was a free man again after spending a week in jail for failure to answer a non-support complaint by his wife, Mrs. Helen Acosta of Rockville Center. He had been committed to jail in default of bail the second time within a week.

Ground was broken yesterday by Mayor La Guardia for a new $1,022,000 school in Harlem, the first one to be erected in that congested area since 1925. It will have special the classrooms for cripples and children with heart trouble, and will have facilities for adult activities.

With the proposal to ratify the Federal child labor amendment in jeopardy, largely because of opposition among Democratic members of the Assembly, where a ratification resolution, already adopted by the Senate, will come up for a vote next Tuesday, Governor Lehman tonight carried his fight for the amendment to the people in a radio appeal.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed registrar of the capital stock of the Covered Wagon Company, consisting of 45,000 shares of class A stock of $20 par each and 500,000 shares of no par common.

The week's Department of Commerce report on gold imports, which covers the period of Feb. 20 to 26, inclusive, again discloses a wide discrepancy between actual gold imports and imports affecting the monetary gold stocks as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank.

Seventy-two lots, having a frontage on Queens Boulevard of 140 feet and frontages on both sides of Junction Boulevard of about 700 feet near Nassau Boulevard, Queens, were sold to a client of Moffatt Sanford. The sellers were Samuel Cohen and Celia Gershuny. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., made the sale through L. V. Kerr.

Searchers tonight found the battered body of 4-year-old Beverly Ann Page of Claremont, N. H., a victim, State's Attorney Albion Parker said, "of death by violence Parker said, "of death by violence and an attempted criminal attack."

A statement was filed today with South Trimble, clerk of the House, by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's National Union for Social Justice showing contributions of $723,847 and expenditures of $630,928 in last Fall's political campaign.

James W. Slaght of 345 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, who for more than thirty-five years was a member of the staffs of The New York Herald and The World, died at Trinity Hospital, Brooklyn, on Thursday at the age of 74.

Mrs. Gertrude Schuyler Vandef Poel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Oakley Vander Poel of 117 East Seventy-second Street, and member of an old New York family, will be married on March 18 to Lloyd Hilton Smith of 23 East Seventy-third Street, a broker.

Domenico Cimarosa's "The Clandestine Marriage," sung in English, received its second presentation of the current season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House before a large audience. Ettore Panizza conducted.

Charles Fechheimer of the City Athletic Club reached the final of the national Class B squash tennis championship by upsetting John A. Schwarz of the home club, 17-15, 15-12,. 15-7, at the Crescent Athlectic Club in Brooklyn last night.

Irving I. Weissman, Passaic lawyer, was ordered disbarred by the New Jersey Supreme Court today on the ground his treatment of a client demonstrated "an entire absence of the moral and ethical fitness required for the practice of law."

A tear gas and machine-gun sales agent for Federal Laboratories, Inc., was complimented by a superior officer for his sales efforts after he reported that he had "shot and killed a Communist" in demonstrating the efficacy of "Federal" weapons to the San Francisco police, according to letters introduced at the hearing today of the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage.

The boyhood home of John Hay, wartime secretary to Abraham Lincoln and creator of rustic ballads, has been sold for taxes. The dwelling, dilapidated from neglect, went to Adam P. Buckert for $30. Buckert has arranged to restore it to habitable condition.

Serious disorders at the Metlaoui mine in Southern Tunisia yesterday were followed by new riots today at another mine at Mdilla. Four men were killed in today's clash and thirteen were killed and twenty injured yesterday.

Net income for 1936 of the United States Rubber Company and subsidiaries, according to its annual report, was $10,172,484, after provisions for all taxes (including undistributed profits taxes on subsidiaries) and a provision for fluctuation of raw material prices of S700.000.

Red Robert Rolfe, sprightly third baseman from the Penacook, N. H., woodlands, today came into the Yankee fold, thereby reducing the number of unsigned players to what might be called the "big three."

Paul Hartnek, Creighton University football star, the only defending champion to return to competition, scored a surprising upset tonight by defeating Lem Franklin, Cleveland Negro, to retain heavyweight honors in the finals of the Chicago Golden Gloves competition.

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch delivered an explanation of Yugoslavia's foreign relations in Parliament yesterday. He reiterated that the principles of the nation's foreign policy were based on the maintenance of peace and a respect for Yugoslavia's present frontiers.

Formation through legislation of mortgage banks is urged again by the State Mortgage Commission in its report for 1936. The report, which was made public yesterday, holds that these banks would supply real estate capital and at the same time protect investors in "guaranteed" realty certificates.

John Rogerson Montgomery Sr., former president of the Illinois and Chicago Bar Associations and member of the law firm of Montgomery, Hart, Pritchard Herriott, died today in his home in Hubbard Woods, a suburb, after an illness of three months. He would have been 71

Marlene Dietrich, German film actress, asked today to become a citizen of the United States. Appearing unexpectedly in the naturalization department of the Federal court, she made out her first papers and the oath of allegiance.

THOMAS MANN, in his pre-Hitler Nobel Prize address, remarked by way of preface that he was a writer and not a speaker, adding that " improvisation was a violation of esthetic econ" omy "-or perhaps it was "artistic " economy. Doubtless His Honor the

The whole structure of the Prestdent's argument for his Supreme Court plan rests on the premise that this country is faced by a " crisis " so acute that it cannot wait upon the adoption of a constitutional amendment to' give the Government whatever wise and necessary authority it may need.

William A. Simonson, senior vice president and director of the National City Bank of New York, died today at a Palm Beach hotel, where he and his wife had been spending the Winter. Death was attributed to a heart attack. Mr. Simonson

F. J. Dillon, an aide of President William Green of the American Federation of Labor, asserted in Common Pleas Court today that the Committee for Industrial Organization would ultimately "destroy the trade union movement in America."

The Republic Steel Corporation announced today it "stands for the open-shop principle" and at the same time called a meeting in Cleveland Monday and Tuesday of employee representatives of all its plants to discuss rate adjustments in recently announced wage increases.

ABOUT this time of year the athletes in the major league training, camps are not the only ones who warm up. The holdouts on the sidelines and the magnates in their offices warm up too. In fact, they reach the melting point, approaching it from opposite directions. One gives in a little bit and the other gives out a little more.

After a small fire, the sixth in the last month, was discovered last night in the Bushwick High School, Irving Avenue and Woodbine Street, Brooklyn, policemen surrounded the building in the hope of trapping the culprit, and the 500 night students were summoned into the main auditorium where a detective, mounting the stage, appealed to them for help.

Persons close to Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady confirmed reports current last night that she would be married at 8 o'clock this morning in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola to William J. Babington Macaulay, Irish Free State Minister to the Vatican. The ceremony will be
Cornell University today ordered its athletic figures-coaches, trainers and players-to discontinue visits to preparatory and high schools unless they are graduates of those schools.

Prices of hogs generally showed little change here today, with the top and average prices unchanged at $10.40 and $10.20 a hundred weight, respectively. Most sales were at $10 to $10.30 with light lights quoted at $9.10 to $10.05; light weights, $9.65 to $10.40; medium weights, $10.10 to $10.40; heavy weights, $9.75 to $10.40; packing sows, $9.35 to $10, and pigs, $7.85 to $9.60.

Persistent alarms and reports of an impending Putsch have at last induced Budapest newspapers to make guarded allusions to the scare. What is afoot, however, is not preparations for a Putsch but a reported political conspiracy under German influences and with German financial backing to get control of the State machinery.

Miss Ruth Chapin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Chapin of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church to Francis Johnston Gerhard of South Orange, N. J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Gerhard.

Five shows will be along next week, giving the local theatre what is likely to be the Spring's final flurry of excitement. Monday evening will usher "Storm Over Patsy," the James Bridie-Bruno Frank. play, into the Guild Theatre.

Frank C. Whitmore, dean of the School of Chemistry and Physics of Pennsylvania State College, received the William H. Nichols Gold Medal last night at a dinner given jointly by the New York section of the American Chemical Society and the Society of Chemical Industry in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

William Lyon Mackenzie King, Premier of Canada, arrived in Washington today and went to the White House, where he and President Roosevelt dined and spent the evening together in privacy. Mr. King spent the night at the White House. He will go to the Canadian Legation for the week-end.

Speculation on the outcome of the Grand National Chase ran into confusion today when H. L. Thomas's Royal Mail, favorite for the Aintree classic, ran third in the Worcester Park Chase of three miles and 180 yards.

The thirty-fourth annual Public Schools Athletic League indoor track and field championships will be staged at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn tonight. The meet, which will get under way at 8 o'clock, will see twenty-two schools represented.

Proclaiming once more that the monetary agreement concluded last September with the United States and Great Britain remains the basis of its policy, the French Cabinet announced today measures which it is hoped will restore confidence and turn the flow of gold back toward France.

Despite the vigorous and concerted campaign of Conservative and Liberal candidates, Labor increased its majority in Thursday's election for the London County Council from 14 to 26 in a body of 124 members.
Wyoming Seminary of Kingston, Pa., led thirteen other teams at the end of the first day's competition in the second annual Lehigh University scholastic wrestling championships.
Miss Ada Mackenzie of Toronto, former Bermuda titleholder, defeated Miss Dorothy Jones, promising
The Canadian curling title was wrested from Manitoba today by Cliff Manahan's Edmonton Royals, a newly assembled unit guided by the skip who won the MacDonald's Brier Tankard in 1933.

If President Roosevelt succeeds in his determination to alter the structure of the Federal courts, the Supreme Court will "be merely an errand boy of any political party that is in power in Washington,"
William H. Hurley, 91, and Mrs. Phoebe Drysdale, 79, both of Dover, were married on Wednesday, it was announced today.
The Archbishop of Canterbury and the Duke of Norfolk today were appointed official censors of all news films to be taken inside Westminster Abbey during the coronation of King George VI.

The Board of Estimate took the first step toward construction of a crosstown Brooklyn highway leading to the World's Fair site in Flushing yesterday when it approved plans for the acquisition of land valued at $2,000,000 for the artery.

Registering its twelfth triumph of the season, the St. John's University quintet turned back a revamped Providence College five, 44 to 37, in their annual game in the DeGray Gymnasium last night. It was the last home appearance of the season for the victors.
Paul Dean had his longest workout on the mound today since last Aug. 24, when he started against Pittsburgh. Paul threw. 112
Dr. Ernst Krieck, an enthusiastic supporter of the National Socialist idea, has been appointed rector of Heidelberg University. He will succeed Dr. Wilhelm Groh.
The Argentine Government signed today a new reciprocal trade treaty with Italy, which is expected to double Argentina's exports to that country.

Our old friends, the heiress and the newspaper man, are back again this time in a furiously unimportant farce called "Love Is News." at the Roxy. Having met them so often before, we can calculate almost to the last decibel point how loudly they will scream at each other, how cutely they will fight, how frantically they will discover their love.

The French franc fell heavily yesterday in the foreign exchange market as official support was withdrawn in connection with the announcement in Paris by Premier Lion Blum of changes in the monetary policy, including the restoration of free dealings in gold.

New State and municipal financ-' ing scheduled for next week totals $6,629,663, to be represented by thirty-five municipalities. The revised total for this week is $4,736,000. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $35,248,641.

Mrs. Anna Van Sciver, 45 years old, of 223 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn, was fatally injured about 5 P. M. yesterday when struck by a bus of the New York Omnibus Company at Broadway and Twentysecond Street. She died in St. Vincent's Hospital.

Ben Tuthill, theatre manager, and once press agent for Lillian Russell, Marie Tempest and DeWolf Hopper, died on Thursday of apoplexy at his home, 540 East Fifteenth Street. He was 76 years old and...

Federal Judge William Clark compared the Jersey City police today with Adolf Hitler. The comment came in a hearing on an application by the American Civil Liberties Union and members of two labor unions for an injunction to restrain the Jersey City police from interfering with picketing.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 27 amounted to 696,727 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 18,157 cars, or 2.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 23,858 cars, or 3.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 92,396 cars, or 15.3 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Miss Norma Taubele, runner-up to Mrs. John Van Ryn last year, was eliminated from the national indoor tennis championships yesterday as four new finalists were qualified in the men's and women's singles at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
Construction will soon begin on the new United States legation here. The structure will cost $250,000.
The City College swimming team closed its season with a 46-to-29 triumph over Johns Hopkins last night at the C. C. N. Y. pool. The summaries:

Jerome Strauss went into undisputed possession of first place in the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline billiard tournament last night when he defeated Anthony La Via, 200 to 111, in twenty-three nings, at the Capitol Health Center.
Mrs. Mary Hull Flint, music critic and lecturer on fine arts and science, died yesterday at her home at 320 West Eighty-third Street after a ten-day illness. Her age was 90.

A statement urging the Assembly to ratify the child labor amendment, signed by a group of ministers and rabbis of the New York City area, was made public yesterday by Roswell P. Barnes, chairman of the Commission on Social Action of the New York State Council of Churches.

An official expression of regret over the remarks on Adolf Hitler made by Mayor La Guardia of New York was tendered to the German Government on behalf of the United States Government today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

The number of employes on the payroll of the Federal Government on Jan. 31 showed a decrease of 1,301 since the beginning of the year, the eivil Service Commission announced today. The total at that date was 829,794 civil employes, of whom 647,200 were employed in the regular agencies.

Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada-For 1936: Total assurance premiums of $96,924,789, compared with $100,240,383 in 1935; total income was $164,083,596, against $153,406,765; excess of income over disbursements, $60,698,728, compared with $47,230,869. As of close last year, total
Mrs. Gabrielle Greeley Clendenin, only daughter of Horace Greeley, editor of The New York Tribune, died here today.

The increasing difficulties of the German food situation are emphasized anew by a survey published in the Koelnische Zeitung, according to which Germany must import this year no less than 3,500,000 tons of grain and fodder and another 500,000 tons of high protein feeds.

The Association of National Advertisers yesterday issued a group of nine charts, giving the norm or average rate base by which the unit rate of newspapers in a given section of the country can be compared. For example, the normal national 10,000-line rate for a newspaper of 12,000 circulation in Wisconsin is 51/2 cents, according to the chart for that section.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, seventime winner of the women's tennis title both at Wimbledon and at Forest Hills since 192, has granted the Twentieth-Century-Fox Film Corporation- an option on her services for motion picture work, it was learned yesterday.
In the Supreme Court of the United States Edgar R. Kraetzer, Philip Levy and William A. Seidl of New York City were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

The arrest in Balboa, C. Z., of another of the group of men wanted in connection with the kidnapping of Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr., on July 10, 1933, was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine. The man, who

The joint Maryland State and District of Columbia Federation of Labor will be the first State labor unit to visit reprisals on the Committee for Industrial Organization by barring local C. I. O. delegates from the coming federation convention, it was indicated here today.
Exports of American aeronautical products in 1936 were valued at $23,055,761, compared to $14,290,843 in 1935 and $17,548,181 in 1934, the Department of . Commerce announced today.

A charge that Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, the Chase National Bank and a "subservient board of directors" have "conspired to carry out a program of financial ruin" upon the Utilities Power and Light Corporation is contained in a bill filed today in Federal District Court here by Harley L Clarke, deposed head of the utility concern.

First-round play in the national Class C squash tennis championship was completed at the Harvard Club yesterday, with the match between W. Jennings of the Columbia University Club and E. A. Mays Jr., Harvard Club, providing a competitive highlight.

Colonel James Henry Hayes of New York, representing the Colombian Dollar Bond Protective Committee, said today at the termination of hearings before the Securities and Exchange Commission that his registrants were ready to furnish any and all information required in order that about $165,000,000 in certificates of deposit might be exchanged for a like amount of defaulted bonds of the republic and some of its departments and municipalities.

Miss Elspeth Davies has been elected president of the Undergraduate Association of Barnard College for 1937-38, with Miss Jean Allison as treasurer and Miss Deborah Allen secretary. Miss Sofia Simmonds was elected chairman of Honor Board.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday that it had applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to intervene in the hearings in the reorganization of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad. The bank is trustee of

The New York Central Railroad plans to issue about $55,000,000 of 31/4 per cent convertible bonds due in 1952, F. E. Williamson, president, announced yesterday in a letter to stockholders. The bonds will be offered at par to stockholders of record of March 16.

Fundamental Investors, Inc.-As of March 4, assets, at market value, had advanced to more than $10,900,000; undistributed earned surplus for dividends and other purposes for first two months of this year increased to $386,000; unrealized appreciation of investments was $1,971,747; and shares outstanding totaled 413,589, against 366,209 at close of 1936.

Scammel St., 34, 27x95; Elsie Jagodnik and Abraham Margulis to Benjamin Cohen, 314 Madison St.; mtg., $11,000. East Broadway, n. w. cor. Montgomery St., 23x105; Philip Blum to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp.; consideration, $1,000, foreclosure.

Music Education Conference of the New York University School of Education, 9:30 A. M. Speakers: Dr. Walter Damrosch, Mrs. August Belmont, Dr. Ernest G. Hesser, Dr. Marshall S. Brown, Professor Herman H. Horne, Vernon Smith, Dr. George Gartlan, Dr. Karl Gehrkens, Marion Flagg, M. Claude Rosenberry.

The following editorial comments on President Roosevelt's address on court revision were sent by telegraph to The Times from papers regarded as Democratic, although many designated themselves as "independent Democratic" or "independent."

Although little news of any account is now coming from Addis Ababa, it is the general belief that the full story of the attack on the natives following the attempt on the life of the Viceroy, Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, has vet to be told.
The bulk of new construction projected yesterday in the city consisted of plans for dwellings in Queens. Several home plans also were submitted in Brooklyn.

More than 200 Class A stockholders crowded yesterday into Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey's court room and won permission for themselves and others in their class to intervene in the reorganization procedings of the Roxy Theatres Corporation, although they were advised that their cause, legally and practically, seemed hopeless.
Sermons in observance of the middie of Lent will be preached tomorow in the ritualistic churches.

The engagement of Miss Mildred Davis, daughter of Mrs. John H. Davis of this place and the late Mr. Davis, to Alfred J. de Greck Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. de Greck, also of Rockville Centre, has been announced by her mother.

THERE were fewer entries in the Eastern tournament, just concluded, than there were last year. That was to be expected, perhaps, since tournaments have been generally smaller in all sections of the country. .

A film, "The Liberation of Malaga," made by the Luce Institute [Italy's semiofficial news-reel institute] was withdrawn from circulation today because it showed too many Italian soldiers, officers and army trucks in Malaga, Spanish city recently taken by the Rebels. s.

Regional gains of 12 to 31 per cent in farm receipts in January, this year, compared with January, 1936, were reported today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. The receipts include sales of principal farm products and government payments.

One of the finest of plants for the house or conservatory is clivia, a distinctive member of the amaryllis family. The large, brightly colored flowers last for a long time; the foliage is evergreen, thus making the plant attractive at all seasons of the year, and its culture is simple, making success in handling it almost a certainty.

About 90 per cent of the money paid into the Metropolitan Restaurant and Cafeteria Association was turned over to Jules Martin and Sam Krantz, Phillip Grossel, secretary of the association and a defendant, testified at the restaurant racket trial yesterday.

THIS new study of Whitman might almost be bound with Mr. Masters's recent biography of Vachel Lindsay. Together they represent a distinguished contemporary's plea for Americanism in poetry and criticism, with an account of its comparative success and failure.

The commercial treaty signed by Cuba and Great Britain Feb. 19 will not become effective from the date of signature, as provided in the signatory protocol, but will await ratification by the Senate, according to interpretation of a statement issued following a Cabinet meeting this afternoon.
Joseph J. McCann, a broker of Montclair, was stricken with a heart attack while a passenger on a terminal-bound Erie railroad train this morning and died within a few minutes. He was 65 years old.
No sit-down strike is going to cause unpleasantness between the seventy-five employes of the Gud-Fit Shoe Company and Joseph Moskowitz, their boss.

An agreement has been concluded with the Japanese Government whereby real property valued at $3,000,000 held under perpetual leaseholds in Japan from the time extraterritoriality obtained there will be converted to American ownership on April 1, 1942.

The rising trend of world cotton prices under way during the last two weeks gained momentum yesterday and quotations on the Cotton Exchange made new high records for the eleventh successive session. The March of the old crop sold above 14 cents a pound while new crops advanced above 13 cents under the most active trading in several years.
Mrs. Helen Townley of 22 Erie Street, a member of an old family here and active in Democratic politics in Elizabeth for many years, died last night at her home following a short illness.

The thirteen-year fight for the Federal child labor amendment, giving Congress "power to limit, regulate and prohibit the labor of persons under 18 years of age," will reach a critical stage this week when the lower house of the New York State Legislature passes upon it.

SANDHILLS RACE COURSE, N. C. THERE is one sure sign of Spring in the South. It comes early; definitely in March; maybe in late February. The traveler on a North-South highway is surprised to see loom in the distance what appears to be an old-time race course, minus the country-style grandstand.

THE dedication reads: "To those lovers of classical music who find their appreciation dimmed by being regimented in uncomfortable seats while listening to good program." The dedicator is known as Continental Concerts. certs.

Last among the great overseas trading nations, Canada is rearming. With a foreign commerce greater than that of Japan and a territory greater than that of the United States, this Dominion has remained probably the most lightly defended country of her importance in the world.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Fred M. Stein of 60 East Sixty-seventh Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cecilia Borg Stein, to W. Arthur Cullman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Cullman Jr. of this city and Stamford, Conn.

SINCE the United States Coast Guard's ice patrol was established nearly twenty-five years ago, after the wreck of the Titanic, not one life has been lost through ice collision and not one ship has met the Titanic's fate.
Syracuse and Cornell's boxing teams ended their dual meet season today with the Orange scoring a 6-to-2 victory. Two stirring bouts featured the match. Carl Sorenson, brilliant

Snapping back into winning stride, the Lehigh University wrestling team concluded its dual meet season tonight with a 21-15 victory over Navy. Trailing, 15-8, with three bouts to go, the Engineers, badly crippled with injuries, crashed through to win all three and top the Midshipmen.

APROPOSAL that broadcasting licenses issued by the Federal Communications Commission be increased from six months to five years has been made in a bill introduced in the House by Representative C. Arthur Anderson of Missouri. i.
President Mary E. Woolley of Mount Holyoke College and several faculty members will discuss changing ideas in Europe at the annual Alumnae College beginning June 14.

Girls in the Home Economics Department of the School of Education of New York University will give a "model" low-cost dinner for their parents tomorrow night in the Education Building, 41 West Fourth Street.

A CURIOUS dream gave Maurice Baring the title for his new book, which Alfred A. Knopf will publish on March 15. Mr. Baring dreamed that be crossed the River Styx and was asked to declare the literary baggage with which he had traveled during his life, but only those things of which he had made a permanent record, either in his memory or in his notebooks.

Phillips Andover, by staging a fast at tack, backed up by a stubborn defense, won a surprising victory on the basketball court from its ancient rival, Phillips Exeter, in the Thompson gymnasium today. The score was 49 to 33.

Many additional subscribers have been announced by Mrs. Henry L. Sherman and Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, co-chairmen of the executive committee, for the recital by Lotte Lehmann of the Metropolitan Opera, which will take place this afternoon at the Town Hall for the benefit of the philanthropic and educational work of the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

The East Stroudsburg State Teachers College girls' basket ball team defeated New York University today by 19-9. The N. Y. U. girls led at the and of the half, 9-5, but were unable to score after the intermission, while the home squad tallied 14 points.
This weekend marks the first anniversary of an event that may prove to have been the turning point in Great Britain's relations with Nazi Germany.

Argentina will send its American-built dreadnoughts Rivadavia and Moreno to England for King George VI's coronation. She will also be represented at the coronation ceremonies by a large special mission, headed by Dr. Tomas A. Le Breton, Ambassador to Paris. Dr. Le Breton was formerly Ambassador to Washington.

Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation--For 1936: Net income after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes, amortization and other charges $1,857,836, equal, after dividends on old 6 per cent preferred and new 4 per cent cumulative preferred stocks, to 97 cents each on 1,500,000 common shares, against $1,930,897, or $1 a common share, in 1935.

The New York Rovers defeated Hershey, 3 to 2, in an overtime game in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight. Lloyd Ailsby's shot from Kilby MacDonald's pass won the game a minute and 41 seconds before the game ended. The victory kept Hershey out of first place, the team being tied for the lead with Atlantic City.

The third annual session of the Model Senate Association will be held here next Friday and Saturday, with delegates from more than thirty Eastern colleges expected to participate in the two days of plenary sessions and committee meetings.
Beginning a year's celebration of its fiftieth anniversary, the Baldwin School this week entertained many of its alumnae in connection with announcement of plans for the observance.
Staffed by a faculty of only three, the Bureau of Customs now operates, in its School of Instruction with an enrollment of 8,500, the largest of the thirty-odd government schools in Washington.

Congressional tax experts said today that revenue legislation probably would be delayed until June. Speaking privately, they gave two major reasons for holding off a measure to continue the so-called nuisance taxes:

Members of the Manhattanville Alumnae Association will hold their final Lenten sewing meeting on Wednesday at the home of Mrs. George H. Bradford, 308. Work on the communion garments for poor children, begun West Eighty-first Street in the classes; will be completed during the annual three-day alumnae retreat, which will open at Manhattanville, College of the Sacred Heart on March 17.

MORE and more the 36,753 Cub Packs, Scout Troops and Scout Ships of the nation are vying to make their indoor meeting places attractive and useful reflections of scouting. Wherever possible the Scouts use existing facilities for their headquarters, and Troops are discouraged from building special homes. There is a growing trend for the institutions that sponsor Troops to provide for Scout meeting rooms when planning new buildings.
Miss Dorothy Downey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Downey of suburban Radnor, was married this evening to Herman Edward Werner of Latrobe.

The Helvetia Maennerchor, conducted by Edward E. Bechtel, gave a concert in the Town Hall last night under the auspices of the Swiss Benevolent Society of New York. Ruth Kelley, violinist, and Oscar Ziegler, pianist, were the assistant artists. A large and appreciative audience attended.

Townspeople of Huntington at the annual town meeting decided that the only way to keep children out of mischief on the streets at night and to inculcate a due respect for the authority of their elders was to revive an old by-law establishing a curfew hour.
The Worcester police have invoked the aid of the Federal Government to checkmate the activities of a new "racket" which has been turning their official hair gray.

A 9-year-old schoolboy was questioned for an hour tonight by State's Attorney Albion Parker after a chum, 5, had asserted that the older boy struck Beverly Ann Page, aged 4, with a brick and rolled her into a shallow mill stream, where she was found dead yesterday. .
BERLIN.--How thoroughly military an affair Labor Service has become German fathers and mothers first realize when their sons return on holiday leave.

The contract for union recognition signed this week in the red brick and stone building here which Andrew Carnegie built to symbolize his dominion over steel marked a turning point in the relations between organized labor and American industry.
THE record of one day in the life of a married woman in her early thirties, "Time at Her Heels" is no stream-of-consciousness affair.

With the coming of Spring, geology classes at Middlebury College are getting out hammers and notebooks in preparation for the several field trips taken annually into the Adirondacks and Green Mountains.

The sit-down strike of the student body of Asheville Normal and Teachers College was virtually ended after three days this afternoon when the president of the college and members of the faculty agreed to the demands of a group of more than four hundred girls.

Ranging alongside the favorite at the top of the stretch, the filly Columbiana smashed onward today to score one of the most telling victories a thoroughbred of her sex ever has brought off in a famous American stake race.

The underlying characteristics of the bond market remained unchanged yesterday in the two-hour trading period on the New York Stock Exchange. Two distinct price trends predominated, the higher-grade investments again seeking lower levels, while speculative interest in the convertible industrial and railrod-loans forced many of those issues into new high ground.

AT its final concert of the season March 30, the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, Inc., under Antonia Brico, will offer Horatio Parker's "Hora Novissima" and the "Rhapsody" and "Academic Festival" overture of Brahms. Four choral societies, of which Miss Brico is the director, will participate in the concert.

Twelfth Annual Communion Breakfast of the Order of Seville, Hotel Astor, 9 A. M., following 8 A. M. service at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Speakers: Senator A. Harry Moore, Martin Conboy, Judge Robert V. Kinkead, L. O. Head, Alexis C. V. Barinque, James O'Toole.
Fifty years in prison, the heaviest Federal Narcotics Law violation sentence on record, stunned Louis Ginsberg, 53, today.

Many of the great field trial dogs of the United States will compete at the annual meeting of the English Setter Club of America, which will start on Monday morning, April 5, at the famous course at Medford, N. J., to continue through the week.

TWO men traveled through the cotton belt a year ago and didn't like what they saw. They talked to sharecroppers who worked all year for $200, most of it in "furnish" from the planter's commissary--cornbread, molasses and sowbelly. y.
With an attendance of 225 couples, the annual midwinter promenade of the sophomore, junior, and senior students of Russell Sage College took place last night in the Hendrick Hudson Hotel.
RAYON is to find new use in the manufacture of tires. P. W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear. Tire and Rubber Company, said last week.
A performance of choral and instrumental works of Johann Sebastian Bach will be given in the Princeton University Chapel next Sunday as the 1937 memorial to Elizabeth Milbank Anderson.
A hunt for first editions of the Harry Castleman boys' books has been undertaken by V. Valta Parma, curator of the rare book room of the Library of Congress.

Increases in operating costs for buildings have discounted any improvement in gross income resulting from recent gains in occupancy, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared yesterday.

The Philadelphia combination of Neil Sullivan and Roy Coffin emerged from a hard-fought first-round battle today in the fifth annual national doubles squash racquets championship favored to retain their title.

Although most gardeners raise dahlias from roots, they can be grown from seed to full bloom within a few months. Few fanciers seem to realize that dahlias from seed bloom only about two weeks later than tubers planted in the usual way.

IF the Oxford Dictionary definition of "classic" is accepted, Bernard Shaw's comedy "Can dida," which Katharine Cornell revives in the Empire Theatre at the matinee on Wednesday, has passed into this category in the twoscore and one years that have passed since its first performance in the Theatre Royal, South Shields, England, on March 30, 1895.
Although an injury-riddled Cornell basketball team battled gallantly tonight, it dropped its tenth straight Eastern Intercollegiate League game to Yale, 39 to 31.

Music Hall of the Air symphony orchestra, with Dr. Howard Hanson of the University of Rochester as guest conductor, presents the music of contemporary American composers. Edwina Eustis, contralto, and Jan Peerce, tenor, are soloists: WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M.

Assured of the Eastern Athletic Club League title, the Penn A. C. basketball team registered its thirteenth straight circuit triumph by defeating the New York Athletic Club, 39 to 22, at the Winged Foot gymnasium last night.

FOR at least six months of the year transcontinental motorists, unless they are adventurous, usually take the southern route to the West Coast-from Dallas or San Antonio to El Paso, and thence through Southern New Mexico and Arizona to their destination which, in nine cases out of ten, is Southern California. a.

The Rev. Edward J. Higgins, founder of the Catholic War Veterans, Inc., made public yesterday the names of priests in thirteen diocese in the country who have been appointed members of the National Chaplains Board of the organization.

Despite the numerous court decisions on the subject of stock dividends, none as yet rendered presents an authoritative standard by which the taxability of various forms of stock dividends is definitely determinable.

Rounding out a "decade of progress," Yale College, in the opinion of Dean Clarence W. Mendell, is now destined to enter upon "one of those longer periods of absorption and consolidation, less thrilling than the times of stress and change, but more genuinely academic in spirit."

KEY WEST, Fla. HERE'S Dreamers' Heaven: Paradise for slug-a-beds, for truants from reality, a loafers' Arcadia. Southernmost city of the United States, 375 miles farther south than Cairo, Egypt. Egypt.

The marriage of Miss Lily Hindley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Hindley of this city, and John Stuart Smart Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Stuart Smart of Maplewood, N. J., took place here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church.

Coming from behind in the last period, a combination Princeton junior varsity and freshman hockey tem defeated the Manhattan Arrows in Baker Rink today, 6-5. Bob Cooke, former Yale star, led the scoring with a goal each period for the visitors, while Bob Bordley, who counted the winning marker at 15:07 of the final frame, led the Nassau sextet with two goals and an assist.

An exodus of nurses from New York, Brooklyn and Queens hospitals tomorrow and Tuesday beard some resemblance to those bitter doses about which they warn their wards, "You won't like this, but it'll be good for you!" Because both the wry medicine and the temporary desertion of alcohol rubs, pulse checking and pillow patting is intended ultimately to benefit the patient.

Glen Dawson, the Oklahoman who ran for Uncle Same in the last two Olympics, has ended his sixteenyear career on the cinders. Dawson came back to the University of Oklahoma, scene of his collegiate triumphs, today to visit his former coach, John Jacobs, and other old friends.

Verdi's "La Traviata" enjoyed a smooth and consistently well-sung presentation at the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon. The performance was given extra interest by the fact that the three principal roles were all in new hands. Bidu Sayao, the Brazilian soprano, was entrusted with the Violetta and Charles Kullmann and John Brown-lee were heard here for the first time in the roles of the younger and the elder Germont.

THIS is an age of purposeful (though often hectic) concentration; and books of leisurely reminiscence and reflection are few. Really good books of this kind are fewer still, of course. "Caravansery and Conversation" is really good.

Harvard's freshman and junior varsity hockey teams submerged their Yale rivals before 1,000 spectators at the Boston Garden this afternoon. After the Crimson first-year team had battled its way to a 5-to-2 triumph over the Eli yearlings, the Harvard Jayvees blanked the Blue scrubs, 5 to 0.

As trustee for the Chesapeake Corporation ten-year 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds due in 1944 and the twenty-year 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds due in 1947, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York has notified the New York Stock Exchange of two conversions.
GEORGE MACAULAY TREVELYAN is England's dean of historians. He is accustomed to finding his way through masses of material and nothing that he writes is written
Sam Abraham, 46-year-old Syrian who "socked" a customer who came into his Detroit meat shop and passed a slurring remark about the late King George V, is no longer a man without a country.
William Ayres Gray Jr., an engineer with offices in Manhattan, died suddenly yesterday at his home here following a heart attack. His age was 42.

Based on the theme, "Reducing the Economic Waste of Poor Education," some 3,000 persons interested in secondary school education from nine States will assemble at New York University next Friday and Saturday for the Thirteenth Annual Junior High School Conference, conducted by the University's School of Education at Washington Square East.

A college campus romance in which the principals--Bobby Wilson, 1935 all-American quarterback, and Miss Betty Bailey--rode to fame with the Southern Methodist University Mustangs will culminate in their marriage here April 14.

The Peddie basketball team clinched the Eastern Private Schools League championship by defeating the Trinity quintet, 42-25, at- the losers' court yesterday. It was the ninth straight circuit triumph and the sixteenth in a row for the Peddie five.
Princeton's varsity swimming team defeated Pennsylvania in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet at Hutchinson pool today, 49-26.
MANHATTAN BASCH, ROSE RICE (Jan. 30). Estate. $3,000. To Julia Rice Meyers and Hattie Schwartz. sisters, since deceased; two minor bequests. Elsa Rice Meyers Herst. niece. executrix, 107 W. 96th St.

Fordham University, generally regarded as an educational institution for men, at present has an enrollment of 1,961 women students in its various departments, according to a report made public yesterday.

Riza Shah signed today a decree granting American companies the privilege of developing oil concessions in eastern districts of Iran. Negotiations on the concessions were concluded in January and ratified by the Parliament Feb. 5.

Establishment of an international police force and an "equity tribunal" is the "best insurance policy" for the maintenance of world peace, Lord Davies, founder of the New Commonwealth Society, an international peace organization, declared yesterday before 150 members of the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

One significant result of the recent period of "indigestion" in the market for new bond issues and the accompanying downward readjustment in values has been the transition from a "sellers" to a "buyers" market, according to investment bankers.

With Spring trade activity moving rapidly toward peak levels as the result of the early Easter season, all of the major branches of business registered some of the sharpest gains of the year last week. Retail sales were far ahead of the volume in the corresponding period last year as the surge of buying gained momentum in all sections of the country.

BERNSTEIN--GOLDSMITH--Mr. and Mrs. Milton M. Goldsmith announce the marriage of their daughter. Janet E., to Mr. Arthur H. Bernstein, son of Mrs. Sarah and the late Mr. Jacob Bernstein, on Sunday, Feb. 28.
Daniel McCormack, former national president of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, Board of Erin, and president of the Tyrone Society, died Wednesday at his home, 6,529 Greenway Avenue.

Mr. and Mrs. Paulding Fosdick were hosts for dinner tonight at Casa Alexado Miss Margaret Stewart, T. Chesley Richardson, Charles G. West and Robert Sherwin, their house guests, were among those attending.

SYDNEY, Australia. JAPANESE who operate the fleet of luggers which visits Australian waters for pearl shell defy discomforts and danger, but they appear indifferent to pain and unmoved by the risks they run.

Dr. William T. Hornaday, who retired as the first director of the New York Zoological Park in 1926 after thirty years' service and who since had devoted himself to the protection of wild life, largely through his writings and efforts as head of the Permanent Wild Life Protection Fund, died tonight at his home, the Anchorage, in West North Street, this city.

Recently prominent business men in New York and Boston were asked to give opinions on the talents and abilities of the perfect secretary. Their answers revealed that the prime qualifications of the model secretary are sevenfold.

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under the direction of Artur Rodzinski, gave its regular popular students' concert last night at Carnegie Hall. A large audience heard a program which consisted of Handel's "Water Music Suite," Dohnanyi's "Variations on a Nursery Air" for orchestra and piano obbligato, with Arthur Loesser as the soloist.

Essex Troop's two-year reign as New Jersey low-goal polo champion came to an end tonight when the local riders fell before the Red Bank Polo Club, 8 1/2 to 7 1/2, in a first-round elimination match that required a sudden-death play-off at the loser's armory.

Four singers will make their Philadelphia debuts in Puccini's "La Boheme," which the Metropolitan Opera Association will present at the Academy of Music next Tuesday night as the fifth of its six performances in this season's local series.

Dr. Leslie Frank Mulford, Professor of Surgery at Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia, died of a heart attack today while at the wheel of his automobile. He ws 53 years old. last year, had been on sick leave. Surviving are his widow and a brother, Dr. Alfred Mulford, also of Philadelphia.
Catholics seeking the reopening of their long-closed churches today sought to reinforce their demands through a campaign of "passive resistance."
Penn State defeated Pitt, 24 to 21, in an Eastern Conference basketball game tonight. It was the first victory of the Lions over the Panthers since 1932.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Weissman of 115 Central Park West and Woodmere, L. I., of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Betty Weissman, to Herbert G. -Small of this city and Detroit, son of Mrs.

A measure providing for the licensing of all trade schools in New York State, with the Department of Education as a supervising power, has been favorably reported by both the Senate and the Assembly. This bill, introduced early in the legislative session by Senator A. S. Feld, had the support of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, which adopted a resolution of endorsement at its last convention.
Minnesota won a half share of the 1936-37 Big Ten basketball championship tonight, coming from behind to defeat Chicago, 33 to 23, in the final game of the season for both teams.

Mis Muriel Hammond Goodenough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude E. Goodenough of this place, was married to Richard Carleton DeWitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. DeWitt, also of Scarsdale, this evening in the Hitchcock Memorial Church here.

The strong New York University fencing team defeated Cornell easily today, 21-6. The visitors won seven bouts in the foils, eight in the and found the losers strong in the saber, but won 6-3. George Detmold was the only Cornell duelist to win more than one bout, and he defeated Soroka in the foils and Kirschner and Garlin in the saber.

At noon on Feb. 5, a month ago last Friday, President Roosevelt sent to Congress his message asking power to appoint six justices to the Supreme Court if those now over seventy did not retire. Thereby he brought to an abrupt close the era of political tranquillity that had followed his re-election.

The Soviet cotton crop last year beat all records, totaling about 750,000 metric tons, 50 per cent higher than the 1935 crop. The 1936 total was 100,000 tons above the appointed maximum for the second Five-Year Plan, which ends next December and is thus overcompleted in four years.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today she hated guns, but carried one when she motored alone. Lecturing on "A Day in the White House," she was escorted in New Orleans by two armed city detectives, assigned by her hosts but not at her request.

A life-size pen and ink portrait of Dr. Thomas G. Masaryk, first President of Czechoslovakia, presented two weeks ago by the 87-year-old statesman to Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia University as a memento of war-time association, was turned over by the latter yesterday to the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

Furniture, tapestries, rugs, objects of art and tableware, the property of Edward Michael of Buffalo, Mrs. Henri Vibert of this city and other owners, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Miss Elise Minshall Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wilson Robinson of Overbrook, has selected April 9 as the date for her wedding to Leighton Howe McIlvaine, son of Charles Lee McIlvaine of Bryn Mawr.

Word has been received here of the marriage in London on Feb. 13 of Miss Eugenie Lee Levy, daughter of Mrs. Charles Levy of 30 East Chester Road, New Rochelle, and the late Mr. Levy, to John Deane Palter of London.

Two constitutional amendments regulating interstate commerce appeared today to have been defeated in a nationwide poll. Majorities in all six of Australia's States opposed a proposal to change the interstate free trade provision

Members of the women's English squash racquets team were victorious in the invitation mixed doubles, which opened at the Merion Cricket Club today. This was the first appearance of the British stars in the PhiladelPhia district.

Applications for this Summer's Citizens Military Training Camps received thus far at the Second Corps Area headquarters of the army at Governors Island total 4,000, it was announced yesterday by Colonel George H. Baird, cavalry, on the staff of Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the area.

Mexico has embarked on a policy of getting control of her own vast natural resources as quickly as possible. The production and marketing of Mexico's raw materials heretofore has been largely in the hands of foreign concerns and hundreds of millions of dollars in the money of American and British nationals are invested in them.

As members of the Elizabeth Rodman Voorhees Chapel Choir, forty-five alumnae of New Jersey College for Women will return to the campus tomorrow. at their own request, to join with the student chapel choir in singing a program from the repertory of the choir from 1927 to 1937.

The Boerse was weak at the opening today but showed resistance and scattered buoyancy at the close. Heavy industrials weakened somewhat on realization selling, Vereinigtestahl and Mansfeld each losing 1/2 point. Potashes were slightly weaker, Wintershall losing 1 1/2 points.

A preopening of the exhibition of humor in literature at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League will be held the night of March 15. Many dinners will be given before the event. The exhibition will include specimens of humorous writings in all ages and countries, among which. will be many first editions, original comic prints and early copies of humorous magazines.

Perspiring drama critics puffed across the stage of the Apollo Theater here today in a program of acrobatic dances for the entertainment of an audience of chorus girls, comedians and other stage folk.

Alphonse Gaulin, who from 1926 to 1929 was American Consul General in Paris, died in St. Vincent's Hospital at 12:20 P. M. yesterday, half an hour after he had been taken in an ambulance from the Mills Hotel, 160 Bleecker Street. Mr. Gaulin had suffered from a stomach ailment, and the cause of death was given as an intestinal hemorrhage.

Playing its last game of the season, the Blair quintet defeated the Horace Mann School for Boys in an Eastern Private Schools League game today, 30-27. The losers started off fast to lead at the end of the first quarter, but Blair came back strongly to hold a 17-14 advantage at half-time.

For the fourth consecutive year, Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L. I., won the national amateur court tennis singles championship today by outdriving James H. Van Alen of Westbury, L. I., in the final at the Racquet Club. The score was 6-3, 6-2, 6-4. The match lasted an hour and a half.

The amateur hunts racing season under the jurisdiction of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association will get under way at Pinehurst, N. C., Saturday with the meeting of the Sandhills Steeplechase and Racing Association.

"Ladees an' gentlem'n! Bat'ries for today's game: For Brooklyn, Grimes pitch, Phelps catch." Some time this year the foregoing announcement may come booming from the loud-speaker at Ebbets Field and that despite the new Dodger pilot's recent terse remark, "I'm not going any place pitching."

Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius Jr., of 21 East Seventy-ninth Street, will arrive from California Tuesday on the Santa Rosa. Lord and Lady Marchamley of Hatherleigh, Devon, accompanied by Commander and Mrs. Geoffrey Duveen of London, have arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Catcher Frank Hayes clouted three home runs to lead the sixteen-hit bombardment which produced an 8-2 victory for the Philadelphia Athletics over the Necaxa club today. It was the third straight triumph for the Macks in the Mexican exhibition series.

The New York Stock Exchange's committee on foreign business adopted yesterday a new rule providing minimum salaries for international arbitrageurs employed by Exchange houses and discouraging competitors from hiring such clerks away from each other.

A large advance sale of tickets has been reported for the annual all-star show and fashion revue of the Israel Orphan Asylum to be held the evening of March 20 in Madison Square Garden. Proceeds of the event will go toward the maintenance of the institution's homes at 274-282 Second Street and in Far Rockaway.
QUASI-MIRACLES would have to be performed by any one determined, to cover, with original documents, the whole Panorama of man's sport as chronicled in art.

In the frigid setting of University Field, Columbia staged a dress rehearsal today for the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships next Saturday by winning the third annual Polar Bear meet from Princeton and Penn. But the Arctic Lions cut it pretty fine.

OUT of plans, at present nebulous, may arise a nation-wide movement for the resurrection of the legitimate theatre. The potentialities of the movement are as obvious as its need. In vast areas of the country the theatre of yesterday has ceased to exist.

There is a banner across one of the main traffic arteries in this city, the first time in history such a decoration has been observed. It notifies natives and tourists alike that this is the permanent training ground of "the world champion Yankees," and it points the direction to Huggins Field.

IN an epidemic of remakes, the screen has turned to the successes of the past for material. Virtually every studio has rifled its files seeking yarns made prior to 1930 which did gratifying business at the box office.

The New York State Executive Committee of the Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., announced tonight it would request from National Democratic Chairman Farley ('a voice in selection of Democratic candidates for office." Meeting to plan a membership drive, the organization went on record demanding that the Democratic party "recognize" the group.

The spectacular accomplishments of "Sandow" Roosevelt, "Magician" Lehman, "Gypsy Rose Lee Guardia" and other political figures were revealed, in satirical song, dance and dialogue against the setting of the Political Midway at the World's Fair, to 1,200 public officials, politicians and other prominent guests at the annual stunt dinner of the Inner Circle last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A list of sixty-five students at the Stevens Institute of Technology here who did "consistently excellent" work in the first term of the current college year was made public today by Dean Franklin De Ronde Furman.
Thomas J. O'Grady, former Alderman from the Fourteenth Ward and former State Representative, died early yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital of heart disease. His age was 43.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Tappan of this city, formerly of Forest Hills, L, I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Tappan, to William Jennings Harmon:3d of Birmingham, Ala.

The eighth annual Spring card party to be held for the benefit of the blind men and women under the care of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor next Saturday at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, will be one of the largest of the early Spring benefits. About 400 tables will be in play. Miss Madeleine W. Smith is chairman.

Undefeated in league competition, the De Witt Clinton High School quintet progressed to the semi-final round of the P. S. A. L. city championship race by outscoring Abraham Lincoln High School, 45-19, at the Textile High School gymnasium yesterday.

Plots in Candlewood Isle, at Candlewood Lake, Conn. have been purchased by Everett L. Booth and Worth B. Perry. Twenty new log cabins have Just been completed at Mountain Lakes, Smallwood, N. Y. Twenty eight cabins were sold during February, according to A. N. Smallwood, developer. A rustic addition to the Lake Hill Lodge there has been completed.
Featured by six stakes, the richest of them the $5,000 Tropical Special, the twenty-four-day meeting of the Gables Racing Association will get under way tomorrow at Tropical Park in Florida.

A fashion show enlisting young women of society will be one of the features of the Children's Village benefit to be held at Arnold Constable Co. on March 16 and 17. Mrs. William R. K. Taylor Jr. heads the committee of manikins, members of which will model in various departments of the store, wearing gowns they have selected.

NOT far from the age where Mr. Pitkin says life begins, Lois Wilson, after twenty-two years in motion pictures, is reminiscent of a sunny September afternoon, bright with the afterglow of a pleasant Summer and briskly anticipating approaching Autumn.

The scholarship fund of the Katharine Gibbs School will be aided by a joint concert- to be given by the Glee Clubs of Princeton University and the school next Friday night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

For the first time this season a delegation from the League of Women Voters will attend sessions of the Women's Day Court at 425 Sixth Avenue on Thursday. Magistrate Anna M. Kross will be the sitting jurist, hearing cases concerned with offenses against the vice laws.

A PLAN to double existing rapid-transit facilities between Manhattan and Northern New Jersey, made public last week by the Port of New York Authority, has aroused great interest on both sides of the Hudson River.
Ambassador Davies, with his 20-year-old daughter Emlen, and his nephew-secretary, J. D. Shamm, had just returned from an eight days' tour of the industrial region. of Donetz in Southeastern Ukraine.

Turpentine quiet, 41 1/2 cents; no sales; receipts, 104 barrels; shipments, 161 barrels; stock, 24,189 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 371; receipts, 381; shipments, 400; stock, 56,820. Quote: B. $8.10; D, $8.35-$8.40; E, $8.70$8.80; F, G and H, $9.10-$9.20; I and K, $9.10-9.20; M, $9.10-$9.20; N, $9.10-$9.25; WG, $9.35-$9.45; WW, $11; X, $11.50. .

The sit-down strike of the twentyfive representatives of the survivors of the tenement fire at 137-39 Suffolk Street, which began Friday afternoon at the district office of the Emergency Relief Bureau, 43 Bleecker Street, was abandoned temporarily about 1 P. M. yesterday.

FROM the South Seas comes a report that the celebrated Falcon Island will soon disappear again. This member of the Tongan group periodically emerges out of the blue-green waters of the South Pacific, looks around. so to speak, and then goes back to Davy Jones's locker. er.

The Dartmouth hockey team conquered the Princeton sextet, 4-3, in an overtime contest witnessed by 1,500 persons in Baker Rink tonight. The defeat sent the Tigers to the bottom of the International Intercollegiate League as both teams concluded their seasons.
Coffee from Jimma, Sidamo and Harrar was recently put on sale in Italy and is the first Ethiopian agricultural product to appear on the Italian market.

Plans for a drive in support of the Wagner-Steagall housing bill will be formulated Tuesday at City Hall at the New York Conference on Slum Clearance and Low-Rent Housing of the National Public Housing Conference.
Plans were filed in the Building Department in Brooklyn yesterday for a fifty-seven family apartment house, costing $225,000, by M. N. Weinstein, architect.

PARIS. ERNEST BLOCH'S Sacred Service was given recently in the Temple Rue de la Victoire under the direction of the composer. Two choral societies, the Amicitia and the Mizmor, collaborated with the orchestra of the Concerts Colonne in the first Paris hearing of Mr. Bloch's work. .
WHEN she isn't digging into musty archives for material on the people she writes about, Clemence Dane may usually be found rearranging furniture, wherever she may be.

The final two operatic offerings at popular prices by Alfredo Salmaggi and his company yesterday at the Hippodrome attracted large audiences. In the afternoon, the performance of "The Barber of Seville" was given before an audience of 3,500 persons, and in the evening, "La Tosca" had a capacity audience of 5,200.
ROME THE Italians are a land-hungry people, for whom the possession of a plot of ground represents the height of human aspiration. And land in the Italian East Africa Empire is crying for men:

THE "indoor intercollegiates" are just ahead and that brings up a little matter of record. Whenever a record falls in an indoor or outdoor track and field meet there comes to mind those tall stories the revered elders tell of the great athletes of old days.

Mrs. Carlisle Norwood 4th heads a group of young women who will act as manikins in a fashion show to be known as the "Prophecy of Spring," which will be held on March 18 in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club.

The Montreal Maroons kept their grip on second place in the International Group of the National Hockey League tonight with a third-period attack that defeated the New York Americans, 4-3, and shoved Red Dutton's men out of the league play-offs.

Although he has not made up his mind whether he will prefer art or writing as a career, 12-year-old Carl Limbacher Jr., editor and publisher of The Scarsdale Eagle News, feels his success in this dual capacity has something of the prophetic about it.

The annual Spring bridge and tea of the New York-Long Island Chapter of the College of St. Elizabeth Alumnae Association will be held April 17 at Sherry's. Miss Kathryn I. Fee is general chairman of the party, which will aid the scholarship fund.

A windowless four-story warehouse and office building is under construction at 117-119 West Twenty-first Street. Designed by Theodore R. Feinberg, architect, for Maurice R. Spear, the building is expected to be leased by the Hershey Chocolate Company.

One of Norway's premier skiers, 20-year-old Miss Turid Jesperson, gave a breath-taking performance today in annexing the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's women's downhill championship, the first held in the fourteen-year history of the organization.

HAMILTON, Bermuda.- Added interest will be given to the social and sporting activities of Bermuda during the coming week with the arrival tomorrow of the German naval training ship Schleswig Holstein, which is to remain in port until March 15.

Concrete will be poured this week for the foundation of a high-speed rod and bar mill at the Bethlehem Steel Company's plant at Sparrows Point, Md. This mill will be additional to new facilities there for cold-reduction of tin plate.

Former State Senator Charles O. Bailey of Byfield, Mass., died in the Anna Jaques Hospital here yesterday at the age of 74. He was a Selectman in Newbury for four terms and three times was chairman of the board.

Information that the Securities and Exchange Commission is studying and may announce soon a rule limiting the trading privileges of Stock Exchange firms which carry commission accounts has revived in Wall Street discussion of the fundamental differences between its conception of a security market and that of official Washington.

In his annual message to the Legislature, Governor LEHMAN reviewed the record of the State Milk Control Law and recommended that the question whether it should be extended, permitted to lapse, or repealed at once, be made the subject of a legislative inquiry.

Mr. and Mrs. Horace N. Stevens of Plainfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Victoria Stevens, to Dr. Merton L. Griswold Jr. also of Plainfield, son of Dr. and Mrs. Merton L. Griswold of Uxbridge, Mass.
Two events will herald the formal opening of the sesqui-centennial year at Franklin and Marshall College, which was founded on March 10, 1787.
IT was Virginia Woolf who delivered that challenge in one of her numerous attacks on realism in the novel, but Miss Barnes has gone beyond Mrs Woolf's practice of her own theory.

A diamond reported to weigh 93 carats, found by a Negro laborer 100 miles in the jungle, has precipitated a rush, said wireless advices received here today. Stampeding fortune seekers were said to have found one 18-carat stone and several smaller ones.

Mrs. Silas M. R. Giddings is chairman of manikins for the Easter fashion show, to be presented under the auspices of the School Settlement Association of Brooklyn, on the afternoon of March 19 at The Towers, Brooklyn. Mrs. Tremper Longman is general chairman of the benefit. Mrs. Walter Scott Robinson is president of the association.

The United States has been able so far to retain its leading position in the Argentine market 'despite discrimination in this government's distribution of official exchange and despite the subsidizing of German trade through a compensation marks arrangement.

This week ushers in a historic era for the Girl Scouts of America, dedicated to the commemoration of a portentous, polite little tea party in Savannah, Ga., a quarter of a century ago. Out of that hospitable gesture by Juliette Gordon Low to a dozen of her small friends grew the 16,145 troops and the 4,366 Brownie "packs" of junior members that make up the Girl Scout organization of the present.

Seventeen young men, most of them college students, will sail from Boston the second week of July on a two-year world cruise which will include, among other things, scientific investigation of the report that many of the smaller islands of the East Indies are actually from twenty to fifty miles off the locations fixed for them on the map.
