Fifteen upper-classmen of the Collegiate School will have roles in the eleventh annual presentation by the school's dramatic club, to be given Friday evening at the BarbizonPlaza. Proceeds from the production, "Curtain's Going Up," a comedy, will go to the fund for a new school library.

Massanutten Academy and Trenton High School battled to a tie in the seventeenth annual Rutgers University scholastic swimming meet today, each capturing one of the relay events as the thrilling program closed.

Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Glosser of Westmont, Pa., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Freda Rebecca Glosser, to Dr. William Herrick Bernstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Bernstein of this city.

The stock market moved higher on every day last week but one, Thursday, when profit-taking occasioned a minor setback. The vigor of the advance lifted THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks by 4.90 points on the week, the best showing of any week since that ended on June 9, 1934.

More than 11,500 students are expected to enroll this Summer at Columbia University, to pursue 1,057 courses from furniture appreciation, table service, table manners and the teaching of badminton to the theory of functions of a real variable and the morphology and biology of tumors.

No more emphatic answer has been given to Great Britain's rearmament program than that voted Tuesday by the Fascist Grand Council. Italy thereby declared its determination to intensify its war preparations and its endeavors to become independent of foreign raw materials at "even the "total sacrifice, if necessary, of all "civil requirements."

Every gardener knows the importance of getting completed now all tasks which can be done before the planting season begins. One of these jobs is the pruning of flowering shrubs-a class of plants all too often neglected, with the result that they yield but a small part of the beauty they should add to the garden.

Browallia, or Amethyst, is a dependable annual-producing flower of the trill blue so generally desired by gardeners. Less well known, it has many of the characteristics of its popular relative, the petunia, and like the petunia produces masses of flowers.

The aggregate net revenues of the four chief railways in Great Britain was [Pound]35,731,000, or [Pound]9,252,000 below the figure for 1929, according to the publication "Facts About British Railways."

For the third time in five days police bullets brought down a criminal suspect in Brooklyn yesterday. On Monday Mayor La Guardia at City Hall told 613 rookies, "If a crook tries to pull a gun on you, be fast on the draw and pull the trigger first."
Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Ambassador, will return to London at the beginning of next week after a brief visit in Germany. He will be received by King George on Thursday.

Dr. John L. Tildsley, retiring Assistant Superintendent of Schools, told the High School Teachers Association yesterday it was time for the organization "to emerge from its status as a glorified labor union and become first and foremost an association for the advancement of education."

More than 500 persons attended the Junior Promenade Of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a supper dance, held last night in the Imperial Ballroom of the Hotel Statler. College girls from leading institutions of the East, guests of M.
Shooting surely and scoring easily, the Harvard varsity basketball team overwhelmed a scrappy team from Brown today, 53 to 28. The Harvard yearlings defeated the Brown cubs, 45 to 40. .

A year ago Boston was caught napping by a series of heavy snow storms. Lacking sufficient snowremoval equipment, the city suffered from blockaded streets and impeded traffic, which caused merchants to rise in their wrath and denounce the city administration for its negligence.

The program of the concert given yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall by the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conductor, and Rudolph Serkin, pianist, was devoted to Mozart and Beethoven, and included remarkable performances by Serkin of two piano concertos by these masters, the first being Mozart's concerto in C major, No. 21, and the second the Beethoven "Emperor."

The Newtown High School basketball team, beaten twice by Jamaica during the regular campaign, conquered the Red and Blue, 30 to 21, yesterday in a play-off for the Queens P. S. A. L. championship on the Grover Cleveland High court in Ridgewood.
At least thirty Canadian mining properties will be equipped with mills or will have old mills reopened in the coming year, according to a survey of the mining industry made this week.

Miklos Szabo of Hungary, making his final appearance on an American track before returning to his homeland next week, made short work of a field of New England distance runners by taking the special two-mile tonight in 9 minutes 27.6 seconds.

Mrs. Daniel Moore Bates of this place, formerly of Cambridge, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Theodora Hastings Bates, to Arthur Duncan Moir of Saranac Lake, N. Y., and New York City.

WITH the approach of Spring reception of European and African 49-meter wave band stations closing down before 5 P. M., Eastern standard time, is unlikely because of the lengthening of daylight hours along these "night" wave-paths.
Alabamans will determine on next Wednesday which of the State's sixty-seven counties are to permit the legal sale of liquor.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury of Philadelphia and Palm Beach were and Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Wood Casa Robert Jr. of Washington were art, guests of honor at a dinner given by Mrs. J. Hunter Barton and Alfred I. Barton at the Surf Club tonight.
A close victory in the final event, the 200-yard relay, gave Exeter Academy's swimmers a 38-28 victory over Andover today. One meet record was broken and another was equaled.

French shipping was tied up in port here early today as maritime workers resumed their strike after once abandoning their occupation of docked vessels and removing their barricade of tugs across the Channel.

A tropical harvest of West Indian vegetables is being displayed in the foreign marts of New York, and especially in the stalls of vendors who operate in the city-owned Park Avenue Market. They are selling at extremely low prices, and many of them are adequate substitutes for staple foods that are now on the scarcity list.

The need for revival of some control over hours and wages and working conditions of labor has been put forward by President Roosevelt as one of the greatest reasons for his desire to "remake" the Supreme

A new taxpayer building recently completed by the Metropolitan Realty Holding Company, Isidor Wolfe, president, has just been opened at 603-611 Central Avenue, near Harrison Street, East Orange, N. J.

Joseph Stalin, you must understand, is building Russia--making men out of mice and putting courage, backbone and unity into a people that have been slaves for centuries. That is Stalin's job which Lenin set for him and while Leon Trotsky talks about world revolution Stalin is trying to do his job.
Agreements reached by manufacturers of automobile parts with the United Automobile Workers of America, affiliate of the Committe for Industrial Organization, ended three sit-down strikes here today.

Miss Elsie R. Lawson of 11 East Sixty-eighth Street gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Miss Patricia Preston of Boston, who is her house guest. Others present were the Misses Elizabeth Rice, Edith Beale, Elizabeth and Margaret Sillcocks, Lorabel Hutchins, Edith and Ethel Prosser, Frances Berry, Joan and Fanny-Jane Smith, Barbara Burke and Renee Van N. Schanck.

William D. Hart, a mechanical engineer for many years with the Crocker-Wheeler Company in East Orange, died today, following a stroke, at the age of 67. Mr. Hart was active in athletics in his youth as an amateur boxer and a cyclist.

The annual benefit of the Brooklyn Home for Consumptives, to be held April 19 at The Towers, Brooklyn, will have for its theme the romance and beauty of the sea. Alan Villiers, explorer and author, will give a lecture, illustrated by motion pictures, in which the story of his square rigged ship, the Joseph Conrad, will be depicted.

By staging a powerful and pulse-throbbing spurt in the final hour, the Belgian cyclists, Jean Aerts and Omer Debruycker, captured the sixty-second international six-day bicycle race which came to an end in Madison Square Garden last night.

Funeral services for William A. Simonson, senior vice president and member of the board of the National City Bank of New York, will be held tomorrow at 2 P. M. at All Angels' Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street. Burial will be in Evergreen Cemetery, Elizabeth, N. J.

Amherst's swimming team kept its undefeated record intact today, defeating Williams by 58-19 in Pratt Pool in the final dual meet of the season. The victors showed tremendous power in sweeping every first place to defeat their highly rated rivals.
Several incidents in the past two days show that terrorism, hitherto confined mostly to the north of Palestine, is spreading to the south.

French financial developments and implications of the loan that France is to float were considered today by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau in two conferences, first with Georges Bonnet, the French Ambassador, and later with V. A. L. Mallet, counselor of the British Embassy.

One of the distinctive features in the Rockville Center model home, now being built at North Village Avenue near Allen Road, Rockville Center, L. I., states Louis W. Capone, executive director of the Rockville Center Building and Industrial Exposition, is the construction of most of the windows on the two stories at the corners of the house, with each window facing on two sides of the structure.

Sophomore Joe Cottone, with 15 points to his credit, led the Dartmouth basketball team to a 46-37 victory over Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest tonight before a capacity crowd of 3,000 persons in the Alumni Gymnasium.

Winning the final two bouts, the Syracuse wrestling team turned back Columbia, 21-11, yesterday in the Lions' gymnasium. In the other varsity encounter of the day, the Blue's fencing team defeated Pennsylvania, 20 to 7.

The Assembly Judiciary Committee has voted 13 to 1 against the Zimmerman bill which would repeal the Ives Teachers' Oath Law, thereby killing it. Assemblyman Fite, a professor at Vassar College and a Republican, was the only member to urge that the bill be reported out.

Seven philanthropic organizations aided by the Generosity Thrift Shop at 1,237 Third Avenue will benefit from a "Dawn to Dusk" fashion revue to be held during a special luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria on April 15.

A temporary Student Union building for Rutgers University will be created by the conversion of the two-story residence of Professor Robert C. H. Heck into an activities center for undergraduates, President Robert C. Clothier announced today.

ONE of the oldest of mankind's dishes--the pancake--finds a special place for itself on the Lenten menu. Once it was merely a griddle cake or flapjack or flannel cake in this country. But travelers, foreign chefs and immigration have introduced variations ranging from the delicate French crepe Suzette to the Russian blini.

The Savage School girls' basketball team vanquished the Nassau Collegiate Center squad, 33-12, at the victors' court yesterday. The winners had a 16-1 advantage at half time, and the triumph was their eighth straight and their ninth in ten starts this campaign.

Canon T. Guy Rogers, rector of the ancient parish of St. Martin's in Birmingham, England, and chaplain to the King, arrived here yesterday on the Hamburg American liner Hansa at the invitation of the Rev. W. Russell Bowie,

During the recent hearing at Albany on the child labor amendment the most potent reason why it should never become a part of the Federal Constitution came from the Attorney General of the United States. The following excerpt is from his statement:

To-the Drama Editor: One of the most ill-considered bills is H. R. 30, introduced by my colleague, Representative Dickstein. Ostensibly, its purpose is to protect American actors, vocal musicians, operatic singers, solo dancers, solo instrumentalists and orchestra conductors.

The Navy Department's recent inability to obtain bids for steel and copper has served to focus attention on the government's huge expenditures under contracts, and on how a relatively short delay in procuring supplies affects a construction program employing thousands of persons besides those in industry.

ONE disappointment that vexes and perplexes many an American--especially if he chances to be from the Middle West--is the refusal of Europeans to remain true to type. True, that is, to the types he knows and loves in vaudeville and light comedy; true to the types in Wodehouse and Galsworthy; and those classic types, the chill, unapproachable Briton, the effervescent Frenchman and the conspiratorial Italian, so dear to the heavy reader of light fiction.

IT is always heartening to be able to report that a new novelist, exposed by an initial success to the dangers of applause, has resisted in his second novel the temptation to repeat that success; that he has blazed a trail in a new direction, has set himself a larger task-that he has, in a word, continued to grow as an artist. One can say this unreservedly of Samuel Rogers.

The engagement of Miss Mary Park Heuser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Charles Heuser of this city, to A. Frederick Nielsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian F. Nielsen, also of New York, has been announced by her parents.
FOR some thirteen months it has been this way and that with E. Schwartz's plans for the play called "La Femme en Fleur," but now it seems to be really on the way.
PARTY LEADER: When the Polish liner Pilsudski sailed up New York Harbor seventeen months ago on her maiden voyage, she carried an official delegation bearing

With gains in five of its components, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended Feb. 27 advanced to 107.3, a new high for this year. It was 104.3 for the previous week, and 92.0 for the week ended Feb. 29, 1936.
United States Senator-elect William H. Smathers of this city has altered his plans to be sworn in Tuesday in Washington and instead will continue in the State Senate for at least two weeks more.

Migration of German-Jewish agricultural workers to South America Is generally welcomed by almost all South American countries, according to Dr. Bruno Weil, a Berlin lawyer and vice president of the Jewish Centralverein, who arrived here last week after a tour-month trip to South America.

Plans for the reorganization of the Prudence Bonds Corporation "by which stockholders of the old company might benefit at the expense of the first mortgage bondholders" are opposed by the members of the Prudence Bondholders' Protective Association, Special Master James C. Moore was told in a letter from Kadel, Van Kirk Trencher, attorneys for the association.

Police today warned persons who picked up coins on the highway outside Georgetown last night that the coins were counterfeit. Two men, who were arrested on charges of passing counterfeit money, flung the coins away as they sought to evade capture.

The Federal Power Commission has set March 18 for a hearing on an application by the Montana-Dakota Utilities Company of Minneapolis for permission to borrow $750,000 from the Northwestern Bank and Trust Company of Minneapolis and a like amount from the First National Bank and Trust Company of Minneapolis.

Jonathan Brewster Bingham, son of former United States Senator Hiram Bingham, and Richard Moore of New York City, both former Yale Daily News editors, today argued, as rival lawyers, the case of Hood vs. Guaranty Trust Company of New York City at the Yale Law School.

A counter attack against President Roosevelt's appeal at the Democrats' Victory Dinner for support of his proposal for reorganization of the Federal judiciary began today, with Senators Burke and Copeland, both Democrats, as spokesmen. Senator Burke took the offensive in a radio speech tonight, describing the Supreme Court as a defender of the rights of the individual.
Harvard's great swimming team easily defeated Navy, 60 to 15, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet today. The Crimson won both relays and was first in six of seven individual events.

Henry A. Wallace, Secretery of Agriculture, speaking yesterday afternoon before the Consumers Emergency Council in the Hotel Pennsylvania, asked that "thought" be given to the use of "bargaining power" lest "more harm than good be done."

The Jade Petroleum Corporation of Dover, Del., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed issue of 1,500,000 shares of $1 Class A convertible preferred stock and 3,000,000 shares of no-par value Class B stock.

Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said tonight that income tax collections this year might reach $4,800,000,000. Mr. Helvering recalled that returns from the fiscal year ending in June, 1933, when he took office, totaled $1,600,000,000. Last year the collections were about $4,000,000.000. 00.
A brilliant second-half rally by Syracuse tonight brought a 44-to-32 victory over Colgate tonight.
Three of the eight seeded players were eliminated in the second round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class C championship on the Downtown A. C. courts yesterday.
Two miners were killed at a bootleg coal hole operation at Seltzer City this afternoon when a clamp on their "buggy" broke as they were being lowered into the pit and they fell 150 feet.

Feeling "bored" and endeavoring to escape unnoticed through a veranda window from a beauty queen's champagne party aboard the Paris as the liner neared Plymouth from New York early this morning, Frank O. Vosper, noted 37-year-old British playwright and actor, fell sheer down the vessel's side into the sea and was drowned, it is believed. He was nearsighted.

The New York Central Railroad has reduced its outstanding debt $68,695,738 in four years. In its application filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to issue $54,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/4 per cent convertible bonds, the railroad revealed that on Dec. 31, 1932, its funded debt and notes payable in the hands of the public amounted to $1,108,807,952 and that on Dec. 31, 1936, it had been cut to $1,040,112,214.

In crinolines and lace mitts, with snoods on their hair and ivory fans in their hands after the fashion of fifty years ago, members of the Lincoln Circle, Ladies of the Grand Army of the Republic, swished and bustled their way into the Elks Club at Jersey City last night to celebrate the golden jubilee of their group.
The 156 members of the second class of the United States Military Academy, West Point, paid a visit to the Hayden Planetarium yesterday afternoon. The officer in charge was Captain C. D. Eddleman.

The stay-in strike idea among monks threatened today to spread to a second monastery. Disgruntled brothers at a retreat on the Red Sea watched anxiously the progress of a "sit-down" by Coptic monks at Deir-el-Moharrak, reported relenting a little in their demands.

MEMBERS of the Seven O'Klockers Klub, a group of 125 Philadelphians who commute 180 miles daily on the round trip to and from their New York offices, convened recently and reviewed the year's activities, which included covering 54,000 miles. The extent of this mileage suggests the question: Is the commuter a traveler?

Nineteen New York University seniors have been elected to Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary scholarship fraternity, it was announced yesterday by Dean Irving H. Berg of the University College of Arts and Pure Science at University Heights. The students honored are:

ALTHOUGH there have already been two commercial productions this week that have enjoyed considerable success, the real focus of theatrical interest has been at Oxford, and what London is discussing is "The Rawlings Lady Macbeth,"

Whatever might be lacking in the way of public information as to President Roosevelt's intention regarding his court proposals and his determination to press them in Congress to the practical exclusion of all else until they are adopted was supplied this week by Mr. Roosevelt himself. .
Miss Rebecca May Hagy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Emerson Hagy of Germantown, was married this afternoon to George Albert Weber Bisbee of Bristol.
ENGLAND produced in the last half of the nineteenth century a remarkable group of travelers who faced dangers and hardships with as much fortitude as any of-her earlier wayfarers.
An observer inquiring into the state of mind of the Corn Belt over President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposal will find, first, the evidence of very decided hostility.

More than 2,000 young journalists, representing publications in elementary, junior and senior high schools as well as private, parochial and normal schools throughout the nation, will gather in New York this week to participate in the thirteenth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association. The three-day convention will open Thursday at Columbia University.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 4. REAR ADMIRALS Richardson, J. O., commander destroyers, Scouting Force, to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C., as assistant to chief of Naval Operations, June 7.

IN effect this study is actually a handbook on English poetry during the nineteenth century, so that the title is slightly misleading. The central figure is indeed Tennyson, but he is a pivot, as it were, Professor Weygandt first going back from Tennyson to establish the general Victorian debt to Wordsworth and the Romantic heritage, and to treat of Landor and the Georgian aftermath.

In addition to their regular program, the members of the New York Athletic Club held a two-man team race over the Traverse Island traps yesterday. Gross scores figured in the team event. The winning combination was made up of E. J. Schaeffler and Z. Rogers, who had a score of 100-96-196.

Members of the Manor Club here will present the English comedy,. "Passing Brompton Road," by Jevan Brandon-Thomas, on Friday and Saturday evenings at the club house. Merritt E. Tompkins is the director. Members of the cast include Daphne Williams, William L. Russell, Mary Fowler, Trevor Hodges, Kitty Hodges, Richard Kemble, Irving Lyon, Mary Ewing and Helen Kingsley.

The value of the estate of Jacob W. Gimbel has risen to about $1,000,000, it was revealed today when Judge John F. O'Connel approved distribution of $38,000 in securities to the three heirs in Cook County Court.

An intelligent person is more likely to measure up to accepted standards of morality than a stupid one, Dr. Clara Frances Chassell declared in a study, "Morality and Intelligence," made public yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University.
The HispanoCanadian Institute for ?? Transfusion, which will ?? and civilian hospitals in Loyalist

The Chicago Great Western Railway is inquiring for one lightweight and one heavy locomotive of the 2-8-0 type, according to Railway Age. The St. Louis Southwestern Railway will build two 4-8-4 locomotives in its shops. The Seaboard Air Line Railway is inquiring for ten locomotive tenders, the Missouri-Kansas-Texas

The Stuyvesant High School fencing team scored a surprising 9-0 triumph over Textile yesterday at the Washington Irving gymnasium for its second victory in Division 1 of the P. S. A. L. tournament, which opened last week.
Penn Hall's long string of swimming victories was broken tonight when it lost to the mermaids of Posse School of Phyhical Education, Boston, 31--26.

Six programs in special subjects, including three courses not before given, will feature the Summer session of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Professor Edwin S. Burdell, chairman of the new Summer session committee, stated today.

ACCORDING to our records, it is nearly five years since the last regular issue of Brunswick gold-labeled records was released. Since then occasional batches of singles have seen the light, but outside of the popular department the name had almost become something belonging to the past.

Many gentians do well in a rock wall. Gentiana ornata is exquisite when established in such surroundings, though it does not do itself justice the first year of its bloom. The blue trumpets are about halfway in color between the sapphire G. sino-ornata and the Cambridgeblue Farrer's, Gentian, though much smaller in size, as befits the smaller plant.
The Harvard hockey team defeated Yale tonight, 5 to 0, and brought to a brilliant close the finest season it has had since 1921.
AARONSON--Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Aaronson announce the birth of Elaine's brother on March 6, 1937. ABRAHAM--Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Abraham announce the birth of a son March 6. at Park West Hospital.

Mrs. Herbert Swift Carter Jr. gave a reception today at her home for parents of the pupils of the Harvey School here. "House to Rent-Furnished," translated from the French by Thomas Graham of the French Department of the school, and "The Ghost of Jerry Bundler,"
Opposition to the Wadsworth proposal to require reports from and publicity on labor unions was-voted yesterday by the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union.

Contending that numerous delays encountered in getting merchandise through customs in the last two years are due to an insufficient staff in the customs service, importer yesterday launched a determined effort to persuade Congress to appropriate at least $21,000,000 for the revenue collection division in the coming fiscal years. The sum is $850,000 greater than the budget estimate.

A field that is still uncrowded for the properly trained college woman is statistical work, according to a survey made recently at Hunter College by the Department of Mathematics under the direction of Professor J. Hobart Bushey.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles McAllen of this place have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter,

The Greenwich Travel Club will be entertained by a lecture at the Masonic Temple Friday afternoon when A. H. Wilson of Boston will speak on "Hoop Skirt and Horse-Car Days," illustrated with stereopticon slides showing fashions of the past.

The sixty-eighth annual luncheon of the Brooklyn Woman's Club, of which Mrs. Thomas Henry McClintock is president, will be held on April 7 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. S. Earle Saylor is chairman and Mrs. Frederick W. Burbank is co-chairman. Mrs. Joseph J. Kerby will head the reception committee.

Forty-five undergraduates and alumnae of New York University were elected to four honorary societies in the university's School of Education and Commerce, Accounts and Finance at Washington Square East, it was announced at the university yesterday.

A card party for the benefit of the Washington Heights Day Nursery will be held the afternoon of March 15 at the Pennsylvania Hotel. The nursery at 350 West 145th Street cares for children under 6 years of age whose mothers are employed during the day.

Passage of the Dickstein bill providing for the exclusion of foreign artists from appearances in the United States was scored yesterday by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, as being "one of the most disastrous things that could ever happen to opera in this country."

The Royal Military College defeated West Point tonight, 4 to 1, in the fourteenth annual hockey meeting of the two leading military schools. The victory kept the Canadians' record in this international play intact with only one tie to mar a perfect string.

Miss Jane Reynolds Shepard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ellison Shepard of East Orange, was married yesterday to Frederick Fast of East Orange, son of Mrs. Alvina Fast of New York, both formerly of Hackensack.
The proposed Bayonne port terminal, a $4,252,000 Public Works Administration project, which has been delayed a year and a half, became the subject of new litigation today.

Lehigh evened its basketball series with Lafayette by scoring at the Memorial Gymnasium today, 33--26. Lafayette won last Saturday. Lehigh gained an early 10-0 advantage and led at half-time by 20--9.
The Bolsheviki now admit and seriously criticize grave fundamental defects in the elaborate plans of 1936 to double the population within twenty-five years.

The Department of Music at Cornell University yesterday announced that a performance of Beethoven's Passion Oratorio, "The Mount of Olives," will be given on Good Friday, March 26, in Bailey Hall of the university.
While miners' riots in Tunisia today exacted a further death toll among those injured Thursday and Friday, Armand Guillon, French Governor of the Tunis Protectorate, conferred with Premier Leon Blum.

Immediately following the increase of steel wages the United States Steel Corporation announces an increase in steel prices, effective April 1, "necessary to cover increased cost of production due to labor advances." The corporation explains that the basic labor rate with the latest increase is 42 per cent higher than that prevailing in 1926.
Columbia's hope of ending Pennsylvania's Eastern Intercollegiate League winning streak was blasted tonight as the Red and Blue gained a 28-20 victory at the Palestra before a crowd of 6,000 fans.
ABOUT history Mr. Miller feels pretty much as Lily Langtry did--that it is better to let bygones be bygones.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

TWO years ago Dr. W. M. Stanley of the Rockefeller Institute made the sensational discovery that the mosaic virus of the tobacco plant can be crystallized. And the crystals can induce the mosaic disease in healthy tobacco plants.

Federal scientists have found a new use for the sweet potato, one of the most important crops of the South. After two years of chemical research and one of commercial production, they believe that the production of sweet potato starch offers Southern farmers another important industry, particularly in sections that produce large yields of sweet potatoes at low cost.

Miss Carol Marion, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Marion of Shippan Point, Stamford, will be married to Edwin Brightman, son of Professor Charles L. Brightman and, Mrs. Brightman of Syracuse, N. Y., at the bride-elect's home on the afternoon of April 3. The Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham will officiate.

The combined glee clubs of Vassar and Princeton, totaling almost 100 voices, tonight sang a concert version of Rameau's 200-yearold opera, "Castor and Pollux." The performance was given in the Students Building.

WHEN Alexander Graham Bell was born, March 3, ninety years ago, the Western World was almost as lacking in intercommunication as ancient China. Towns, cities and States were in touch with one another only through slow young postal systems.

A four-day little theatre tournament will be conducted by the Westchester Drama Association at the County Center here, on April 20 to 24, it was announced today by Mrs. Gertrude Hammill, secretary of the association.

Navy today won the pentagonal fencing meet held in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium of Yale University, scoring 64 points in epee, saber and foils bouts. The Eli team finished second with 61, and Army third with 55. Princeton took fourth with 50 1/2 and Harvard fifth with 38 1/2.

Organized opposition to the appointment of Dr. Roswell G. Ham of Yale as Mount Holyoke's first male president ended today when the Alumnae Council unanimously adopted a resolution saying that "nothing can be accomplished by further discussion of the presidency."

The Queens link in the municipal subway system, now open as far as Kew Gardens and soon to be extended to Jamaica, is opening new territory for intensive development with small homes and apartments, points out Leonard S. Gans, head of the realty firm bearing his name.

George Wyckoff Garretson of 92-64 217th Street, Queens Village, Queens, an assistant treasurer of the Bank of New York and Trust Company, died yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens, following an operation. His age was 60.

Students at home from schools and colleges for the Spring recess. will attend the Spring Middle Holiday Dance of Long Island, which will be held on April 1 at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. An entertainment will be presented during the supper hour.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Elvin Blauvelt of this city and Franklin Lake, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Blauvelt, to Andrew W. Patten Jr., son of Mrs. Andrew Patten of Carbondale, Pa., and the late Mr. Patten.
AN invitation of the Cuban Government has been accepted by the United States to attend a North American radio parley with Mexican and Canadian radio officials, March 15 to 22, at Havana. a.

ROME. THE first absolute novelty of the Rome opera season was Adriano Lualdi's ballet, "Lumawig e la Saetta" (Lumawig and the Dart), at first ?? "Fantasia Negra," set to a scenario in two senes conceived by the composer's son, Maner Lualdi. .

The steel worker who receives the "average" pay of 73 cents an hour and is working 48 hours a week will have his weekly pay check increased from $34.44 to $49.80 under tonight's increase announced by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, in his first "fireside chat" with the radio audience since his re-election, will be heard on Tuesday from 10:30 to 11 P. M., Eastern standard time, from the Diplomatic Reception Room of the White House. .

John L. Lewis's union drive in steel spread today to the aluminum industry. The biggest unit of the Aluminum Workers Union, at the New Kensington plant of the Aluminum Company of America, broke away from the American Federation of Labor to follow the banner of industrial unionism.

THE news of the re-engagement as artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera Association offered Mr. Johnson for two more seasons, and the probable extension of the Metropolitan season next Winter, is a very heartening sign that the Metropolitan Opera Association has passed the crisis in its affairs occasioned by the panic of 1929, and that it is looking toward a resumption of its activities on a scale commensurate with its history and traditions.

FOR almost 500 years the peasants of Korichane, a Yugoslav village 5,000 feet above sea level on Maglic Mountain in Western Bosnia, have been fighting for the ownership of the woodland surrounding their homes. Originally granted to the Korichaners by the Sultan Mohammed II, the property is now claimed by the Yugoslav Government.

Colgate University students have gone on record as favoring a general activities tax to finance publications, concert and lecture series, dramatics, work of the Christian Association and allied campus projects.

New England Power Association common shares, no par value; 6 per cent cumulative preferred shares, $100 par value, and $2 cumulative preferred shares, no par value, have been admitted to listing by the New York Curb Exchange.

John Llewellyn Lewis, born in Iowa in 1880, the son of a Welsh miner, went down into the mines at the age of 12 and emerged, self-educated, to become president of the United Mine Workers and an outstanding spokesman for American labor.

The Dollar liner President Coolidge, outbound for the Orient with 678 passengers aboard, rammed the oil tanker Frank H. Buck in a dense fog today almost underneath the great span of the Golden Gate bridge.

FOR the twelfth annual exhibition of engravings, woodcuts and etchings of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, the Knoedler Galleries have assembled a veritable museum show of prints no lover of the medium will want to miss (through March 27).

Belts give promise of being a most important detail in the Spring fashion picture--excellent backgrounds for them are supplied by the dress and coat ensembles and by the dressmaker suits. Young women who have to make their Winter clothes look fresh until the first warm days of Spring know that a smart new belt can make an old dress take new lease on life.
Count Louis de Courten, who served the Vatican as military commander for nearly fifty years, died today at the age of 102.

While sales of those clothing chains which advanced prices slackened somewhat last week, the reaction was not taken seriously, because of the heavy buying which consumers had done in the previous week to beat the rise. On the previous Friday and Saturday customers had thronged the stores and sales were unusually heavy.
A junior in a New York City high school of more than 3,000 pupils recently wished to look up some definitions in an unabridged dictionary.

Members of the Colgate Club of Nassau and Suffolk Counties have arranged a concert, featuring the Colgate Glee Club, to be given next Saturday night in the auditorium of the South Side High School here.
THE members of the Scriveners Club, says one of the more frivolous characters in "Death Comes on Friday," are a bunch of literary cats.

BECKER--Rebecca, beloved mother of Louis and Irving Becker, on March 4. BELKNAP--Carman Runyon. Suddenly, on March 4, Carman Runyon Belknap. son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Belknap, 6,516 Fountain Av., Hollywood, Calif.

Retail merchants throughout the country are anticipating the full force of a Spring buying wave, "without recent parallel," within the next week or ten days, according to a survey of the Easter trade outlook, issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of traffic, announced another modification of the new traffic code yesterday. Left turns on red lights are to be permitted on Broadway and Seventh Avenue from Thirty-fifth to Forty-first Street, inclusive. The changes are designed to prevent the piling up of traffic.

The University Club of Stamford outscored the Columbus Council K. of C. quintet, 44-41, in an extra-period contest at the Columbus Club, Brooklyn, last night. The Eastern Athletic Club League rivals were tied, 39-39, at the end of the regular playing time.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, which on Friday received demands for a 20 per cent wage increase for more than 8,000 employes of its Pittsburgh plants and a threat of a strike unless the demands were met by Tuesday, announced yesterday a revision of its wage and salary adjustment plan.

Mrs. A. Harris Gaines and Miss Elizabeth C. Lane are among a group of younger members of society serving with Mrs. William Garland Heeks in behalf of the bassinet dinner dance for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, which will be held on April 2 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador.

SIX March-April programs comprising the music of Johann Sebastian Bach will be broad cast by the WABC nationwide network featuring the Westminster Choir, directed by Dr. John Finley Williamson. Carl Weinrich organist, will play throughout the series.

The Savage School basketball team defeated Cooper Union, 36-23, at the victor's gymnasium yesterday. Martin Friedman and Bob Berlin each scored 10 points for Savage, which was ahead at the half, 15 to 13. Jim Lang tallied 10 points for Cooper Union.

An entertainment unique in the history of the old Seventh Regiment will be given under the auspices of the First Company of that organization on March 20 at the regimental armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, to raise funds for the relief of families left destitute by the Midwestern floods.

When in a Washington Summer seventy-one years ago the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution was written by Congress there was not the remotest public suggestion that the "due-process" clause would be used some day to protect private business against State laws.

Columbia College will observe the second anniversary of the invasion of its once strictly male varsity show by the mezzo-sopranos when the curtain rises Wednesday night on Seymour Nadler's musical review, "Some of the People," scheduled for a three-night stand at the Riverside-Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street.

Dr. Gertrude M. Hirst of the Greek and Latin Department of Barnard College, has been promoted from associate professor to professor, it has been announced by the trustees of Barnard College. Professor Hirst has been at Barnard for thirty-six years.

John J. Breslin Jr., Bergen County Prosecutor investigating the murder of R. Norman Redwood, sandhog union leader, temporarily turned his attention yesterday from the intricate interstate union set-up in which he believes the assassination plot was hatched to the search for the gunmen.
Philadelphia Methodists attacked President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposal today as "executive seizure of the safeguards of American government."

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Palmer Ten Eyck of Lawrence Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edna, Marian Ten Eyck, to Alan Thompson, son of County Judge Lloyd Thompson and Mrs. Thompson of Springfield Road.

Miss Frances Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hall Myers of this city, has chosen April 26 as the date for her marriage to Lawrence Cremin Gaynor, son of Arthur C. Gaynor of Stratford, and the late Mrs. Gaynor. The ceremony will take place in St. Augustine's Church.
Plans for expansion of its transportation affiliates east of Chicago by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad were revealed today in the filing of an application by Safeway Lines, Inc.,

The largest customs force ever engaged in a smuggling raid here closed a carefully laid net on the Brooklyn waterfront early yesterday and seized 600 tins of prepared smoking opium on the Bank Line motor freighter Taybank from Shanghai.
Simon Kramer, founder and honorary president of Botoschaine, the first Rumanian Sick and Benevolent Society organized in New York, died today in his home here. He was 76 years old.
BRUSSELS. It now seems probable that Belgium's nascent Fascist movement has passed the peak of its influence. But foreign backing,

Dr. Herman Renkoff, 34 years old, of 957 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, was sentenced to thirty days in the workhouse yesterday in Special Sessions where on Feb. 23 he pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud an insurance company through issuing fraudulent accident medical certificates.

The Philadelphia Flower Show will be held in the Commercial Museum, Thirty-fourth Street below Spruce Street, opening at 1 o'clock tomorrow afternoon and continuing through the week. On Sunday next it will be open also, from noon on.

Allan Henry Hoover, son of former President Hoover, and Miss Margaret Coberly, socially prominent in Los Angeles, applied for a marriage license today. They are to be married March 17 at the home of Miss Coberly's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Bayley Coberly. Mr. and Mrs. Hoover will be present.

The porcelains, bronzes, damasks, furniture, tapestries, rugs and other decorations sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries realized $19,732.50. They were part of a two-day sale which opened Friday and brought altogether $31,597.50.

The Bermuda ladies' golf championship at Riddells Bay today was won by Miss Ada Mackenzie of Toronto. After a hard fight that went to the twentieth hole, she beat Miss Katherine Sylvester of New York, 1 up, before a large gallery.

Demands upon the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company that the United Rubber Workers of America be recognized as sole collective-bargaining agency, and for unqualified abolition of the existing conference plan of employee representation, were voted late today at a mass meeting of nearly 4,000 union members. This action blasted hopes for immediate reopening of the Firestone factories, where 10,000 are idle.

MR. READ, both as lecturer and writer on art, has an enviable record of distinguished achievement. He has been Watson Gordon Professor of Fine Arts in the University of Edinburgh, Assistant Keeper, Victoria and Albert Museum, and is now editor of The Burlington Magazine of art.

The War Department awarded the Soldier's Medal today to Private William D. Eubank of Eleventh Field Artillery Brigade, Schofield Barracks, Hawaii, for heroism in saving a fellow soldier from death by electric shock.

Seventy-five couples attended the freshman dance of Barnard College in Barnard Hall last evening. Miss Antonia Holding was chairman of the dance committee, which included the Misses Margaret Boyle, Caroline Duncombe, Elizabeth Harpel, Florence Kotzian and Evelyn Healy.

The government again today issued communiques designed to allay public anxiety regarding the reported political conspiracy under German influence, intimating that all measures had been taken for the preservation of order.

With the franc dropping rapidly lower and with a large section of his People's Front adherents protesting his surrender and even calling for his resignation, Premier Leon Blum asked tonight for national support for a financial program that in many ways is the antithesis of all underlying principles of the People's Front regime.
Garbage accumulated on doorsteps, slippery streets went unsanded, housewives complained, but sixty municipal ash and garbage collectors merely sat today.

The plight of six large industrial States was laid before President Roosevelt today by their Governors, anxious lest projected cuts in employment by the Works Progress Administration should outpace re-employment by private industry and leave the States with a burden of relief needs too heavy for them to bear.

China's oldest family, that of Confucius, which makes the House of Windsor seem like upstarts and moderns, will furnish this country's official representative to the coronation of King George VI of Britain next May.

Distinguished art patrons and critics from throughout the East, along with hundreds of other invited guests, crowded the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts tonight to attend a comprehensive exhibit of the sculptures of Malvina Hoffman.

In France imponderable economic and financial considerations have caught up with the social program of the Popular Front government of Premier Blum and there has resulted a determined effort by Paris to peg the franc. The purpose is, of course, to prevent the franc going a great deal lower.

Dr. George Everson, who retired in 1926 after forty-five years of medical practice in Brooklyn, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack, after a long illness of a complication of ailments, at his residence, 80 Cranberry Street, Brooklyn. He was 79 years old.
PATROLMEN--John M. Parchen, from 40th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad Manhattan, for duty with Midtown Squad. for duty with Midtown Squad.

United Drug, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1936 a net profit of $2,065,475 after depreciation, interest, Federal and foreign income taxes, undistributed profits taxes, loss on guaranteed leases, flood losses and other charges. The profit equals $1.47 each on 1,400,560 shares of $5-par capital stock and compares with $1,504,517, or $1.07 a share, earned in 1935.

An illustrated lecture entitled "Building a Highway 100 Feet Below the Ocean's Surface" will be given by Charles Carswell, superintendent of the George Washington Bridge, tonight at the clubhouse of the Girls Service League, 138 East Nineteenth Street. Mr. Carswell will speak of the midtown tunnel and the many problems of transportation which confront the Port of New York Authority.
Highway improvements estimated to cost at least $2,500,000 in Brooklyn are among the projects planned for the present year by President Raymond V. Ingersoll of that borough.

Miss Cecilia Colledge, successor to Miss .Sonja Henie as the women's world figure skating champion, arrives in New York tomorrow on the Queen Mary and will spend a few days here en route to Ottawa and Toronto, where she will give exhibitions in the leading Canadian carnivals.

Wellesley students are preparing for the American premiere on March 20 of a ballet pantomime first presented in Vienna 176 years ago. The ballet, known as "Don Juan or the Libertine Destroyed" at the time of its English production in 1785, has been called the first modern ballet.

The Hamilton College choir of fifty-three undergraduates, which is about to make its twelfth annual metropolitan concert tour, is a product of its conductor, Professor Paul A. Fancher, who, from material gathered each year at the opening of the college, welds together, by constant practice, a chorus which has won the praise of many critics.

GENEVA. MANLEY O. HUDSON, American member of the World Court bench who is soon to take up his duties at The Hague, brings to the tribunal much that is new, while his election marks a significant change in the history of the institution.
Dr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Crane have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Louise Crane, to Morgan Sargent, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Leslie Sargent of Quincy, Mass.
The marriage of Mrs. Hollyday Sothoron Compton to John Laughlin Swope Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Swope of Roland Park, took place here today in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

Helene Madison of Seattle, former world's and Olympic swimming champion, was married here today to Luther C. Melver, builder of the Great Rock Island Dam here. The couple came here from Seattle by automobile late this afternoon for the ceremony. ny.

Prices of wheat advanced more than a cent a bushel in early trading today on the Board of Trade as the result of general commission-house buying and short covering induced by strength in Liverpool and Buenos Aires and on reports indicating that Germany might be forced to import substantially more wheat than recently estimated.
It was a great day for Gilbert Carpenter as the fifth annual metropolitan badminton - championships moved into the final stages at the 165th Regiment Armory in a twelve-hour session yesterday.

The President Hotel, twelve-story fireproof structure built in 1926 on Albany Avenue and the Boardwalk at a cost of $4,000,000, is to be sold on a mortgage foreclosure on March 18, it was announced today by William H. Albright, the receiver. The sale is to be conducted at the hotel at noon by Allen B. Endicott Jr., Atlantic City attorney, as a Federal court master.

Carl K. Withers, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, today was appointed trustee of the Security Mortgage and Title Insurance Company of Passaic and its subsidiary, the Gladmar Company, a real estate holding unit. The appointment was made by Vivian M. Lewis, vice chancellor.

Mrs. Mildred E. Agness, 35-year-old estranged wife who has conducted a sit-down strike for back alimony in her husband's shop since Wednesday, was stricken with hysteria this afternoon and taken to the Municipal Hospital by order of a physician.

HIGH in the hills that give this city its name, and overlooking the fertile valley through which the muddy Missouri River twines, motor travelers later this year will find a beautiful monument in an equally beautiful setting on the site where more than a century ago Merriwether Lewis and William Clark "held peaceful parley with the Otoe and Missouri Indians."
Dartmouth defeated Columbia, 53-22, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet today, winning seven events and setting new Dartmouth and Spaulding Pool records in the 400-yard relay.

Experts of the Securities and Exchange Commission studied today the problem of equitable carrying charges for investment trusts. In virtually every company examined by the commission this question of the carrying charges or "load" was stressed, particularly in view of the fact that some companies voluntarily have reduced these charges by as much as 50 per cent.

Three persons, one a senior at the New Jersey College for Women, met death early today in a head-on collision of automobiles at the intersection of the Milltown Road and Route S-28 in East Brunswick Township.

Renewing a rivalry of long standing, Lawrenceville set back a fighting Hill quintet today, 17 to 14, in a close, slow-scoring contest. Frank Browne, sharp - shooting Laurentian left forward, starred on the attack with 6 points.

Public opinion in Belgium is becoming increasingly apprehensive lest the diplomatic stalemate in Western Europe should furnish Chancellor Hitler with a pretext for a new manoeuvre that might make the position of the Belgian Government even more difficult than it has been since his violation of the Treaty of Locarno.

Old-age assistance grants from State and Federal sources are not wanted in the institutions for care of the aged which are privately conducted in New York. A note of compassion has been dominant in conferences held through the Winter as a result of the proposed extension of security benefits to inmates of institutions.

With an all-day conference at the Central Branch, interspersed by songs of peace written for the occasion, business girls' clubs of the Brooklyn and New York units of the Y. W. C. A. are participating today in a nation-wide observance of a peace program which opened on Tuesday, their tenth anniversary.
Two women and four children were killed when the Spanish Insurgent cruiser Canarias shelled and captured the steamer Galdames, advices reaching Bayonne said today. day.

The Freiheit Singing Society presented the folk opera, "Bunt mit a Statchke," or "Strike and Revolt," at the Venice Theatre last night before a capacity audience. A portion of the work was presented last year in New York. The opera consists of Yiddish folksongs, arranged in such a manner as to present a narrative.

With all aboard except one poisoned by fish and nearly helpless, the American schooner yacht Yankee arrived at Pitcairn Island early in February, according to a letter just received hero from Chief Magistrate Richard Edgar Christian, descendant of Fletcher Christian, leader of the Bounty mutineers.
Airlines operated by American companies here and abroad carried 1,147,969 passengers and 8,350,010 pounds of express during 1936, the Bureau of Air Commerce reports.

CONCORD, N. H. AS Winter wanes and the longer days become noticeable, the nature lover will find many things of interest in Northern New England. Photographers will find the clear morning light exceptionally good for pictures. ctures.

Two world outboard motor boat speed records fell today before drivers taking part in the third annual Bradenton regatta. Streaking over the Manatee River in the first heat of Class B. Frank Davis of Kansas City was clocked at 49.157 miles an hour.

ALTHOUGH the sun on an aver age is 92,897,416 miles away, radio engineers believe they have studied the sunspots so accurately that their antics and effects on short waves can be fore, cast almost as well as the weather. eather.
PINEHURST, N. C.--Preparations have been completed for the Sandhills Steepleheld on the Barber estate course on Midland Road, midway between Pinehurst and Southern Pines, on Saturday.

The Teatro d'Arte directed by Commendatore Giuseppe Sterni, after several weeks playing in suburban towns and productions over the radio, returns this afternoon and evening to Vanderbilt Theatre. Its offering will be an Italian translation of D. Angel Guimera's Catalan tragedy, "Feudalismo," via a Spanish translation by Jose Echegaray.

Miss Margaret Youle Royall, daughter of Mrs. Maud F. Royall of this town, will be wed on Friday to Edwin Burns Hinck, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Hinck of Montclair. The ceremony will take place at the Royall home.

The Siberian Singers, a male choir of ten members under the direction of Nicholas Vasilieff will present a concert in the Phi Beta Kappa Memorial Hall of the College of William and Mary tomorrow at 8 P. M. The choir has made several tours of the country and has appeared at many colleges and universities.
An Olympic steeplechase star, Joe McCluskey of New York, beat a fast field tonight in the Governor's Mile, feature event of the University of Maryland-Fifth Regiment indoor track and field meet.

The financial measures the French Government was forced to adopt to pave the way for the new armament loan completely overshadow in German eyes the loan itself and its purpose, for these measures are hailed here as the complete collapse of the Socialist experiment initiated by Premier Leon Blum and his People's Front.

Henry E. Judkins, former hotel owner here and in Los Angeles, died today at the age of 83. A native of this city, he was employed for nineteen years by the Maine Central Railroad and was credited with inventing the electric stop signal for trains in 1885.
A DISTINCT departure from his earlier work is evident in the exhibition this week of recent paintings by Robert Philipp at the Grand Central (Fifth Avenue) Galleries.

FLYING a transport plane on instruments without ever leaving the ground, and flying a a radio beam course as the "ship" pivots on its base in the hangar is the novel experience being undertaken by 250 pilots of American Airlines.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--The annual corsage presentation ceremonies will be held on the Boardwalk on Palm Sunday.

While it would be too much to say that the new Italian armament program was received with indifference in England, there is no sign of it having ruffled the composure of any responsible persons in British political, naval or military quarters.

AN original note in the modern room is the decorative floor screen. Among the new examples may be found varied designs and unusual materials and textures, ranging from cloth and wood to glass and metal, each with its own effectiveness.

In reporting yesterday the earnings of the United States Rubber Company for 1936, the news story related that earnings were equivalent to $3.31 a share on the common stock, but the headline erroueously stated them as 90 cents a share.

The Union College dramatic organization, The Mountebanks, under the direction of two representatives of the Broadway theatre, is making its final preparations for the presentation of Maxwell Anderson's "Winterset."

Yale's hard-riding polo team scored a 9 1/2-to-7 1/2 victory over the Harvard trio in a fast match at the Commonwealth Armory tonight. The game was close throughout and not until the last period did the Blue have more than a one-goal lead.

BERGER--BAUM--Mr. and Mrs. A. Henry Baum of 24 Lenox Av., Mount Vernon, N. Y., announce the engagement of their daughter, Natalie, to Mr. Meyer Berger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Berger, also of Mount Vernon.

Advances of $2 a ton were announced yesterday in prices of pig iron at all important centers, putting the price at the highest level since early 1924 for some grades and since late 1923 for others. The iron makers had announced increases of $1 a ton only a few days ago.

Through eyes weakened by the Arctic Winter, a missionary Bishop tonight looked over the trim new plane in-which he soon will fly back to the frozen North. For when his eyes recover, Bishop Pierre Falaize expects to resume the life of an Arctic churchman in the Far Northwest:
Discussing the President's speech on his court proposal, ex-Governor Ely said today: "The President knew eighteen months age that the Supreme Court had declared unconstitutional his program.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie today set April 17 for a hearing on the conflicting refunding plans proposed for Asbury Park's bonded debt of $10,735,000. He granted to Asbury Park and to the State Municipal Finance Commission each a rule to show cause returnable on that date.

The Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships, the one meet in the year where individuals are subordinated to the team race and the mad chase for points, will arrive with all its color and glamour on Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

Brooklyn Prep wound up its Private School Hockey League campaign undefeated by vanquishing the La Salle Military Academy sextet, 1 to 0, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday. Frank Deegan tallied the only goal of the contest in 1:17 of the second period.

First Division, the surprise of the current indoor polo season, had ?? more upset to offer to the campaign last night, defeating the ?? A team in the latter's armory to the first of the play-offs for the Metropolitan League championship
Michael A. Connor, 140-18 Cherry Avenue, Flushing, died in Flushing Hospital early yesterday morning from complications after several operations. His age was 40.

IT is the dance in education which rises to claim the lion's share of attention this week. The first of several items of activity in this amazingly energetic field has to do with the announcement of a three-day dance conference to be held at Teachers College, Columbia University, on April 19, 20 and 21.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 5: Lieutenant Colonels Fletcher, R. H. Jr., Inf., Ft. Humphreys, D. C., to retirement. Lovell, G. E. Jr., Air Corps, Barksdale Field, La., to Panama Canal Dep't., to ?? from New York about May 4.
Breezing Along, a 6-year-old son of Whiskaway, carried Mrs. F. S. Harris's silks to an easy victory over the mile and seventy yards of the featured Hanover Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

WITH college registration again on the increase after the depression slump and with new youth problems created by the economic upheaval of the past seven years it is more and more evident that higher education in America is in for a period of change and experiment. Although schools of educational thought are numerous there is a sharp line of cleavage between those who believe in an intellectual discipline which gives all qualified students certain fundamental

A lively debate on the topic of "Democracy Versus Dictatorship" at the first regional conference of the New England Student Federation of the Catholic Association for International Peace closed at Albertus Magnus College today with the passage of this resolution, proposed by Miss Katherine Bergin of Albertus Magnus:

Federal Judge William H. Holly ordered today the present management of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation continued and appointed James L. Houghteling, investment banker, as a special investigator to examine operations of the holding company.

BETWEEN his first book of short stories, "A Young Man in a Hurry." and this, Mr. Beachcroft's art has undergone a change. He has always written very accurately of the English working people. But his early stories were gently ironic studies of the many contradictions in ordinary human life. e.

AS the patriotic Scotsman shouted from the gallery: "Whaur's your Wullie Shakespeare now?" He's in the rougish hands of George Jean Nathan, who has taken one jigger of Romeo and Juliet," two jigger of "Othello,"

The Senate page boys, who leap to the finger-snapping of the ninetysix members, like Senator Reynolds of North Carolina best. The athletic legislator, whose office walls are lined with boxing gloves and footballs, received their vote in an informal poll.
Army outplayed Cornell's strong indoor polo team in the cadet riding hall today to win its thirty. second consecutive victory, 15-6.

AT last Alfred Hitchcock is deserting London as a background for his films. In "A Shilling for Candles," which he has adapted from a novel by Josephine Tey, he will do for the English countryside and its South Coast towns what he has already done for the capital.

Not since the days of the World War have conditions now existing in the machine tool industry been duplicated, builders and dealers said yesterday in commenting on the fact that at least eight months' time is now required on deliveries of many special types of machine tools.
Thirteen Coast Guard stations were ordered decommissioned today in a six-months program designed to bring greater efficiency to the lifesaving service.
A daughter, their third, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Floy Forrester Johnston of LeRoy, N. Y., formerly of New York and Tenafly, N. J., on Thursday at the Jerome Hospital here.

At the Chester Congregational Church this afternoon Miss Barbara White Bates, daughter of Hamilton C. Bates, banker and manufacturer, and Mrs. Bates of Chester, became the bride of Donald Webster Crowther of Hartford.

Great Britain's rearmament program does not impress responsible German opinion as constituting a menace to Anglo-German relations, and if those relations appear to be undergoing a temporary diplomatic crisis, the reasons for such tension must be sought elsewhere than in the field of armaments.
The old bogey, the report card, has been fixed up to eliminate a traditional sore spot in the home and class room and bring teacher. pupil and parents into closer cooperation.
More than usual interest is attached by New Jersey anglers to the fate of the bill now pending in the State Legislature to prohibit the snaring and jigging of striped bass.
The Nazi press pridefully recalled tonight Chancellor Adolf Hitler's thunderbolt a year ago when he sent troops into the Rhineland in denunciation of the Locarno Treaty.

Of the economists, business men and professors who will exchange ideas on. economic conditions in Germany at International House this afternoon, one of the youngest participants will be Miss Alma Luckau, a graduate student from Germany, who is doing research work on the Versailles treaty.

The widespread interest aroused by Governor Lehman's plea for a better State system of land-title registration gives promise that amendment of the so-called Torrens Law will be accomplished at the current session of the State Legislature.

BOONVILLE, Mo. MOTORISTS traveling through Central Missouri on United States Highway 40 find their route directs them along the main business street of this historic old river-port town, now a city of some 4,600 residents. ents.
A contract for 141 model R-1820-49 geared cyclone airplane engines at a cost of $1,099,729.50 was awarded by the War Department today to the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of Paterson, N. J.

BEGUN as a hobby a score of years ago, the McKee Jungle Garden at Vero Beach, Fla., has cost so far more than $100,000, and is now considered the most nearly complete assemblage of woods and flora to be found in one spot.

Protests signed recently by 10,000 educators against the retirement by Teachers College, Columbia University, of Professor William Heard Kilpatrick at the age of 65 have raised the question: What is the best age for retirement of college teachers? At the request of THE NEW YORK TIMES, six educators, most of them professors or administrators in colleges of education, have answered the question.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David J. Peterson of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vida Dolores Peterson, to Alfred Spurdle Jr., son of Alfred Spurdle of Rutherford and the late Mrs. Mary Stuart Spurdle.
ON a rainy morning forty-four years ago a young nurse was led by a child through the squalor of an East Side tenement to the bedside of a woman giving birth to a baby.
The first in the series of four symphony concerts for March was presented last night under the direction of David Mannes at the Metropolitan Museum of Art before an audience of 4,500 persons.

Realization that New York's 1939 exposition is to be a real world's fair, backed by all the resources of the metropolis, which dawned slowly on San Francisco, has led to a revision of the plans for this city's Golden Gate International Exposition.

Pointing out that in recent months much importance has been accorded certain new elements which are being increasingly used in the manufacture of toilet preparation, the Board of Standards of the Toilet Goods Association, Inc., has sent questionnaires to manufacturers regarding the use and effect of vitamins, particularly Vitamin D, the new Vitamin F, hormones and the use of ultra-violet ray irradiation in the manufacture of toilet preparations.

AT 52 years of age Francois Mauriac is one of the two outstanding Catholic novelists of France, the other being Georges Bernanos. His first four novels were comparative failures, but with the publication of "Le Baiser aux Lepreux" he achieved a promising measure of success.

IN view of the adoption by New York last week of an ordinance restricting the total number of taxicabs to a maximum of 17,858, there is interest in the way the City of London met its traffic congestion problem in 1663, when Charles II was King, also by restriction.

Temporarily, parliamentary red tape is functioning as an effectual gag on official utterances by dominant organizations of women on the President's plan for revision of the Supreme Court. Yet individually within the memberships the velocity-and sometimes ferocity-of the discussions and arguments have seldom attained such whirlwind proportions throughout the country.

Recent announcements from builders and development syndicates indicate that a larger volume of construction work, the majority of which will be for homes, will be seen this season along the New Jersey shore than 'was the case last year.

Penn State's boxers overwhelmed Army tonight, 7 to 1, scoring their seventh straight victory of the season. The Cadets gained their only point of the meet in the first bout when Clarence Bess outboxed Alex Sopchak.
Frank Parker of New York and Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France are the new national indoor tennis champions.

MIAMI Fla.--Today's attraction for a large percentage of the greatest Miami colony. within recent years will be the start of the South's oldest golf classic, the annual. Miami international. four-ball matches which, under a revised. schedule, will continue through tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday, with a strong field of professional players contending for prizes totaling $4,000.
A NEW "radio opera" entitled "Weg in den Nebel" (Path in the Mist) was recently broadcast for the first time by the Munich radio.

An overnight sit-down strike staged at the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, by thirty-four models, including three men, ended yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock. The models called off the strike with the understanding that the directors of the league would meet their representatives in conference tomorrow morning at 8 o'clock to discuss their demands for higher pay and recognition of the models' union.

Commenting on the Farbstein bill now in the Legislature, the committee on taxation and public revenue of the Merchants Association of New York states that, "the proposed form of tax exemption is a crude attempt to deal with the complicated problem involved in the housing situation."

Trading in foreign exchanges quieted down yesterday, with only minor fluctuations in the various currencies in relation to the dollar. The French franc, which attracted attention on the preceding day by falling more than 11 points to the lowest price since the devaluation of the dollar in 1933, closed unchanged yesterday at 4.53 cents.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 3, aggregated $10,873,000,000, or 22 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days, and 15 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Germany's entry into world markets as a seller of war materials has been confirmed by the Business Research Institute, which, surveying world trade in war materials, writes, though only in a footnote:

Funeral services for Mrs. Gabrielle Greeley Clendenin, daughter of Horace Greeley, founder of The New York Tribune, who died here yesterday at the age of 79, will be held tomorrow at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin at 11 A. M.
Spinning many a colorful yarn of seafaring days along the Delaware Bay, Captain Jim Bartlett sits eagerly awaiting the fulfillment of a dream carried for fifty years deep within his heart.

For the first time in its history New York City will become the bowling mecca of the nation this week, when, starting on Wednesday, some 20,000 keglers from 31 States will converge upon the 212th Coast Artillery Armory for the thirty-seventh annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress.

New Castle officials were perfecting today a town employment service in the hope it might reduce expenditures on home relief during 1937. Robert B. Stewart, town supervisor, said $23,000 is included in the current budget for home relief, but substantially less may be spent.

The officers and men of the cruiser Indianapolis, which carried President Roosevelt to South America, have contributed $500 extra to the Red Cross instead of spending the money on a gift for the President, it was learned today through correspondence made public by the Navy Department.

Like most nations of Europe, the Netherlands is rearming, but the Dutch can truly say that they are rearming only for their own protection, and if there is only one possible enemy in Europe against whom they need to be armed, that is not their fault.

The Almoners, of which Mrs. Sydney Lane is president, will hold a monthly meeting tomorrow at Sherry's. Miss Phoebe F. Scott, guest speaker, will discuss the vocational analysis of the Quballah. A business meeting will follow the lecture,
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ensign Rockwell today announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Louise Rockwell, to Henry James Forsyth, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Forsyth of Buffalo.
Mrs. Dan Macdougald knew today for the first time that she was not the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilmer Speed Adams of Louisville but the child of Mr. and Mrs. Fontaine Talbot Fox.

Discussing the problem of low-cost housing, Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declares that the proper way to make adequate housing available for the lowest-income class is to provide funds at low interest rates to rehabilitate existing housing and, where necessary, a budget-income subsidy instead of a capital-grant subsidy for the tenants to enable them to pay economic rents.

St Benedict's Prep School tonight won their seventh consecutive State title in the sixteenth annual track and field championships held under the victors' auspices at the 113th Infantry Regiment Armory. St. Benedict's scored 42 points, beating Lawrenceville, which had 24, and Peddle School, which came in third with 22.

Led by Joe Morningstar and Len Havens, who tallied with 12 and 10 points, respectively, the Wesleyan basketball team gained a tie with Amherst for the Little Three title by routing Williams, 44 to 29, tonight in the last game of the season.

The Fordham University Glee Club, under the direction of Dr. Frederic Joslyn, will give its annual recital in Town Hall on Tuesday night. The chorus of seventy-five male voices will present a varied program of eighteen vocal selections, and there will be an added feature of several numbers by a two-piano team.

State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews has requested the Real Estate Board of New York, the Brooklyn Real Estate Board and owners and operators of apartment houses generally to conduct an educational campaign against the overloading of dumbwaiters with garbage. Richard J.

The New York City pair of Harry Fishbein and Louis Bernard captured early today the Goldman Cup pair title of the Eastern bridge championships at the Hotel Commodore in a close finish with three other teams.
Nine recommendations embodying ideals for organs of student government were suggested yesterday by about fifty representatives of thirteen colleges in the metropolitan area meeting at City College.

Sales and operating revenue of the Republic Steel Corporation and subsidiaries in 1936 amounted to $219,900,387, the highest in the company's history, according to the pamphlet report issued yesterday. Net sales were $218,317,399, compared with $136,164,554 in 1935.

Miss Doris B. Draper, daughter of Mrs. Mary Childs Draper of 61 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, has selected June 26 for her marriage to Charles Edgar Rogers 3d. son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Rogers, also of Brooklyn.

Silas Kimball died in Flushing Hospital yesterday morning of a fractured hip which he received on Feb. 27 when he slipped on a rug in the home of his daughter, Mrs. Emma Zeigler, 33-12 209th Street, Bayside, with whom he lived. His age was 89.

Several young women are aiding Mrs. Henry Burchell and members of the executive committee in their plans for a dinner dance and entertainment to be known as "Capri Night," in behalf of La Margherita Society, which will take place April 8 in the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton.

The National Socialist press attacks on Mayor La Guardia have now spread not only to a general campaign against the United States and Americans, but Julius Streicher's Frankische Tageszeitung of Nuremberg appears with a personal attack on prominent American Jews.

An annual carnival in southern districts of Russia heralding the advent of Spring will be reproduced here on Tuesday night in La Maisonnette Russe of the St. Regis. The main ceremonial for this fete dates to the sixteenth century, when the wine-growers of South Russia presented a huge bottle of wine to the Czar each Spring. ther feature.

The Rudolph Wurlitzer Company, music house, planned refinancing steps today after approval by stockholders of a ten-for-one split in common stock. The present 50,000 shares of $100 par value will be replaced by 500,000 shares of $10 value but will not alter the status of 7 per cent preferred stock.

The war cries of the Lenni Lenapes had not been silenced over the council fires of the Delawares when Waling Jacobse Van Winkle left his Knickerbocker friends in New Amsterdam, moved to what is now Rutherford, and founded the real estate firm that two and one-half centuries later is being carried on by his descendants.

Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow: Tomorrow Lambert Company, com. (50cQ). United Fruit, com. (75cQ).

A satirical musical revue entitled "Don't Look Now," which is to be presented for three performances on April 1, 2 and 3 at the Pauline Edwards Theatre of the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, will be the annual Spring production of the Dramatic Society at the college.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence A. Clough of Englewood have issued invitations to the marriage of their daughter, Miss Sally Naugle Clough, and Philip Weiting Banker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Banker of Johnstown, N. Y. The ceremony will take place on March 27, in the First Presbyterian Church.

The Yale swimming team won a triangular meet in the Payne Whitney pool tonight, scoring 55 points to 24 for the New York Boys Club and 18 for Rider College of Trenton, N. J. The scores with points taken as in three dual meets were Yale 57, Rider 14; Yale 54, Boys Club 21; Boys Club 44, Rider 33.

If Spain were isolated from the rest of Europe, if weapons and troops so- generously supplied by over-armed powers were withdrawn and the Spaniards were left to slaughter each other in their own less efficient manner, the bloodshed would be reduced to the more moderate proportions befitting a technically backward country, but the future of Spain would continue to be doubtful.
