Members of the Alumnae Association of Brentwood Academy will give a bridge party and tea on April 3 at the Delmonico to augment the school's gymnasium fund. Miss Dorothy Nealis, president of the association, is honorary chairman, and Miss Isadel Browne Nolan general chairman.
Mrs. Ellery Sedgwick, wife of the editor of The Atlantic Monthly, died today at her home after a long illness. She was 64 years old.
Some of the craft union leaders hostile to John L. Lewis hinted tonight that they might use a boycott as a weapon in their conflict with his Committee for Industrial Organization.

Announcement has been made by Edwin Arthur Shewan of 888 Park Avenue of- the engagement of his daughter, Miss Anne Barbara Shewan, to George Ide Malcom 2d, also of this city, son of Julian Malcom of Benham House, Woodbury, Conn.

Today Carroll Club--Lenten lecture, the Rev. George D. Bull, speaker on "The Problem of Man," 4:30 P. MI., clubhouse. Carroll Club (Outdoor Club)--Snowshoeing, skiing and skating group to Great Barrington, 7:45 A. M.

IN this excellent little book Professor Hans Kohn makes an attempt to give a rational explanation of an irrational world. Is this the end of an insane world or the beginning of a new civilization? The popular view is to look for economic reasons.
Back home after an extended road tour, the New York Rangers will swing into action against. their arch foes, the Boston Bruins, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

A new film - appreciation series, designed for the layman and illustrating certain major phases of motion-picture technique, will be presented by the Film and Sprockets Society of City College on five evenings between March 19 and May 14 at the Pauline Edwards Theatre, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.
Australia's first frog farms are now being started at Burwood and Orange, near here, with consignments of specially bred giant frogs brought by freighter from the port of New Orleans.

Wholesale buying activity increased in a number of departments last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Reorder volume corroborated retailers' reports of satisfactory consumer response, and indicated a decided trend toward better merchandise. . The report continues:
President Lewis of Lafayette College has laid before the officials of the New York World's Fair a plan for a comprehensive university and college exhibit.

Five years ago on March 12 Ivar Kreuger of Sweden, known as the match king and savior of nations, went to a Paris gunsmith's, bought a small weapon, returned to his apartment, wrote three notes and shot himself through the heart.

United Air Line officials announced today that an investigation had revealed that a radio microphone had lodged between the control column and seat rail and caused the crash of a Los Angeles-San Francisco plane Feb. 9 with the loss of eleven lives.

In a ceremony at which neither relatives nor lay friends were present, Mrs. Genevieve Garvan Brady, widow of Nicholas F. Brady, utilities financier, was married at 8 A. M. yesterday to William J. Babington Macaulay, Irish Free State Minister to the Vatican.

Victorious geisha and relieved teahouse owners prepared tonight to celebrate the end of the singing and dancing girls' strike. Welcoming parties were arranged along the city's gay white way for the return of the 300 gayly clad entertainers who secluded themselves in a mountaintop temple for eight days and won recognition of their geisha guild.

The International Tin Committee has fixed the production quota for the second quarter of this year at 100 per cent of standard tonnages, unchanged from the quota for the first three months. Owing to the rearmament races now going on and the recovery movement in the United States and other countries,
The sensational Seabiscuit won the $10,000 added San Juan Capistrano handicap today as Santa Anita Park closed the most successful race meeting in the history of the West.

The conference of six State Governors with the President at the White House today on proposals to cut down the amount of Federal relief aid to the States has drawn attention sharply to the future relief policy of the administration.

An increase in wages, effective on Tuesday, for all employes of the, United States Metals Refining Company was announced today at the company's plant here. The base rate for workers paid by the hour is to be increased from 45 to 53! cents.
Major Gen. Sir Frederick Maurice, President of the British Legion, denied in a speech here that loyalty of the ex-service men is divided between King George VI and the Duke of Windsor.

Two weeks of investigation into the murder of Norman Redwood has failed to disclose the identity of his slayer, but it has focused interest on craft unionism in an industry which is particularly susceptible to shakedowns by racketeering labor leaders.
Leaders of both parties were watching today the response to Governor Lehman's radio address last night urging ratification of the child labor amendment to the Federal Constitution.

University of Pittsburgh faculty members have traveled 85,000 miles during the last nine years to "carry education" to 1,729 students at one extension center of the university, according to C. Stanton Belfour, assistant director of the Extension Division.

Word has reached New York From Moscow and London simultaneously confirming the arrest, on the charge of "Trotskyism and counter-revolution," of Professor Joseph Lieberberg, Jewish scholar and authority, who for the last three years was president of the autonomous Jewish region in the Soviet Far East known as Biro-Bidian.

Professor Cesare Frugoni, who was sent to Addis Ababa by air to attend those wounded in the recent attempt on the life of Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, Viceroy of Ethiopia, has returned to Rome reporting that all his patients are now out of danger and doing well.

An intersectional debate between Manhattan College and St. Mary's College of California, sister institutions from the East and West Coasts, respectively, has been arranged for March 31 by John P. Moore, president of Manhattan's debating society.

A THREE choir festival, to be sponsored by Congregation Emanu-El and its choir committee, will be held March 19 and 20, at Temple Emanu-El. The festival, devoted to "Early Ritual, Gothic and American Music, Old and New," will be directed by Lazare Saminsky.

Engineers of the Department of Sanitation are working on plans for a mechanical loader which will reduce injuries to employes, Mayor LaGuardia announced yesterday. He said the search for safer devices was being pressed at his own suggestion, which was contained in a letter to William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation.

Peace legislation, war perils and recent developments concerning both will occupy the attention of speakers and audience at the second annual Institute on International Problems to be conducted for organizations of women in the metropolitan area on Saturday, under auspices of the Foreign Policy Association.

The first of three lectures on "Literary Personalities of Europe and America" will be held on Wednesday at the home of Mrs. William H. Moore, 4 East Fiftyfourth Street, when Eleanor Markell will speak on "The Theatre reflects the Changing Life of the Times."

MORDECAI MANUEL NOAH, who was born in 1785 and died in 1851, was one of the first Jews to take an active part in the life of the young American Republic, as distinct from the earlier Jewish patriots who had helped in the Republic's establishment.

Reginald Stewart, founder and conductor of the Promenade Symphony Concerts in Toronto, gave his first New York piano recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His pianism possessed the musicianly qualities which might be expected from an artist who has played so prominent a part in the cultural life of the Dominion in recent years.

Savings and loan accounts of 1,357,373 persons were insured up to $5,000 each by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation as of Feb. 15, it reported yesterday. The total represented a gain of 427,262 over the like date in 1936. Institutions protecting the savings of their members rose from 1,160 to 1,632 in the year and insured assets advanced from $706,033,234 to $1,217,760,429.

Major Walter H. Wells, in command of the First Battalion, Eighteenth Infantry, at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, for the last two and a half years, has been transferred to Louisville, Ky., for duty with the organized reserves, according to War Department orders made public last week.

Clicking off goals steadily with crisp hitting and fine teamwork, Princeton's varsity polo trio overwhelmed the Wilkes-Barre Whips tonight, 18 1/2 to 5 1/2. It was a fast game in all periods, but the superiority of Princeton was pronounced.
DETROIT. DIE castings are widely used for automotive parts not only for decorative purposes but also for structural service.

The Wyckoff Drawn Steel Company announced a price advance of $7 a ton on cold drawn steel, carbon and alloy steel, effective today. The new prices were reported $2.90 per hundred pounds for carbon and $3.60 for alloy steel, at Pittsburgh.

Dr. Lehnich, president of the Reich film department, sounded a note of warning yesterday that the output of the German film industry had seriously decreased during the last four years-the years of National Socialist power.

Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary scholastic society, elected to membership twelve students of New Jersey College for Women today. They were named by the New Jersey College for Women section of the Rutgers Chapter, Alpha of New Jersey, of the Phi Beta Kappa Society.

FREDERIKA--This evening at the Imperial Theatre. A special performance on behalf of the Stage Relief Fund. HELEN HOWE--This evening at the Little Theatre. Two mono-dramas: "Manana" and "The Lesser Breed."
The St. Joseph's College basketball team of Brooklyn vanquished the College of Mt. St. Vincent team 14 to 11, in a closely-contested game on the latter school's Riverdale campus yesterday.

Mark Lawrence Requa, Republican National Committeeman in California from 1932 to 1936, a dominant figure in national Republican circles and one of the outstanding political and civic leaders of California, died today at St. Vincent's Hospital here. He was 71 years of age.

Because of the popularity of the Federal Music Project's Mozart-Haydn chamber music programs at the PWA Theatre of Music, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street, Chalmers Clifton, the project's city director, has announced that the concert would be extended indefinitely. Last night was originally scheduled as the close of the series.

The Long Island University A. A. quintet, composed of the probable 1937-38 Blackbird varsity, met unexpected opposition before downing the Crescent A. C., 37-34, in the quarter-final round of the metropolitan A. A. U. basketball championship at Union Temple in Brooklyn yesterday.

RETAIL trade reached the largest volume of the year last week as early Easter buying put in an appearance. About the best reports were received from the Middle West, where sales gains of 25 per cent and even better were mentioned. The South was coming close to these figures, followed by the East.
WASHINGTON. REORGANIZATION of the Bureau of Air Commerce, which took place last week, was foreseen in some quarters four years ago. ears ago.

NOT since passenger travel by air ceased to be an occasional adventure and became a scheduled operation, less than a decade ago, has there been so much evidence of expansion of airways, extension of services and world-wide interest in air transport as during the past few weeks.

A short time before Morton D. Whitford left for Miami, Fla., for a month's rest in an effort to improve his health he wrote a brief, factual obituary of himself. That was about five weeks ago. He died in Miami early today after a heart attack at the age of 69.

A monograph explaining the mysteries of numbers and numerals, edited by David Eugene Smith and Jekuthiel Ginsburg, has been issued by Teachers College, Columbia University. Professor William D. Reeve of the Mathematics Department-writes that this is the first in a series of studies on various phases of mathematics education.

Miss Margaret MacKenzie Treadway and Miss Margaret Schieffelin Pardee head a group of debutantes who will act as manikins in the fashion revue entitled "A Century's Looking Glass in Fashion" to be given during the luncheon hour on March 30 in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's for the benefit of the West Side Thrift Shop.
Improved demand in the United States accounted for an appreciable increase in Cuba's tobacco export trade in January, the tobacco division of the Department of Commerce reported today.

Mr. and Mrs. Adolph A. Weinman of Forest Hills have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Jane Weinman, to Dr. Freeman Brooks of this city, son of Mrs. Walter F. Brooks of Chicago and the late Mr. Brooks.

Motion pictures and lantern slides of Stratford Hall, birthplace of Robert E. Lee on the Potomac River, will be shown Wednesday afternoon in the garden of the Ambassador under the auspices of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation, which is restoring the Colonial mansion and plantation of General Lee.
Rudolph Reimer of 2 Montague Terrace, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaret-Clare Reimer, to Charles Francis Petit of Los Angeles.
PALM BEACH, Fla.--None of the usual pre-Easter lull appears on this week's program here. Concerts, lectures, sports tourneys and numerous social events are scheduled for the resort.

To Dr. Walter Guyton Cady, Foss Professor of Physics at Wesleyan University, has been awarded the Duddell Medal for 1936 by the Physical Society of 'London. He is the second American to ever be thus honored.

THE question is: Will time cast the same halo of romance over the names of John Dillinger. Baby Face Nelson and other present-day terrorists that now attaches to the bad men of the wild and lanuginous West of half and three-quarters of a century ago?
With the revival of "Heartbreak House" next week, and with Ann Harding's "Candida" an established success, Mr. Shaw will again be well represented on the London stage.

THAT a camera adds much to the thrills of hunting and fishing was amply demon strated in prize-winning photographs shown recently at the National Sportsmen's Show at Grand Central Palace. The trout jumping to the lure, a covey of quail rising from the brush, a young deer in flight-these and other camera highlights of sports afield won recognition in the contest.

SCIENTISTS, physicians and meteorologists have taken their places in the new scheme of aircraft operations and the outlook bids fair to materialize the dreams of a few years ago with flights at extreme altitudes and meteoric speeds as a regular part of long-distance operations.
Cecile Sorel, famous actress of the Comedie Francaise and the Paris music balls, was seriously ill in a hospital today. Her condition was described as "very disquieting" by attending physicians.

ALTHOUGH the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers of America, Inc., (known to the trade as the "Hays office") has acquired a largish personnel and maintains active branches both here and on the Coast, it is still essentially one man.

Mr. and Mrs. Barney Jaffin of this city, formerly of Mount Vernon, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nicki Jaffin, to Irving J. Galpeer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Galpeer, also of New York.

The C. I. O. drive to organize thousands of textile, shoe, rubber and jewelry workers in New England, with a goal of wage increases, shorter hours and better working conditions, moved forward today with the union's leaders ignoring an olive branch extended by officials of the American Federation of Labor.

Samuel Earle Heller, president and general manager of the Connecticut Plumbing Supply Company, and active in the affairs of the Jewish community, died Thursday at the Stamford Hospital. His age was 38.

American shipyards were building 225 vessels of 282,186 gross tons on March 1, according to a report published yesterday by the American Bureau of Shipping. This represents an increase of eighty-nine ships and 116,306 tons over the corresponding period a year ago.

Laughing and shouting, Egypt's 17-year-old boy King, Farouk, went skiing and sledding over heavy snow today to begin his three-month holiday. Soon to become ruler of Egypt's 15,000,000 people. now governed by a regency, the boy King was joined in play under a brilliant sun by four sisters.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the gala supper dance in aid of the Union Settlement, which will be held the night of March 15 in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Miss Ellen S. Marvin heads the group that has arranged the benefit.

Sharply advancing prices of raw materials may narrow profit margins for some makers of nationally trademarked merchandise, but at the same time are likely to improve their competitive relation with private and unbranded goods, according to merchandising comment here yesterday.

Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the Progressive City Committee, which supported President Roosevelt for re-election last year, announced that a special meeting of the executive committee of the organization will be held in Albany Wednesday to take action on President Roosevelt's court reform proposal.

A message from Governor Lehman praising the annual pageant and "mass lesson in philanthropy" to be held next Sunday at the Roxy Theatre under the auspices of the Women's Division of the Federation for the support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies was made public yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Mary Ann McFarland, daughter of Colonel Earl McFarland, U.S.A., and Mrs. McFarland of Governors Island, N. Y., to Lieutenant Hamilton Austin Twitchell, U.S.A., also of Governors Island, took place there yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Cornelius the Centurion.

A code of safety regulations intended for incorporation in architects' specifications for construction work has been drawn up by Samuel R. Bishop, chairman of the committee on health and safety of the American Institute of Architects.
There is hardly a dull line in the stenographic report of the late Moscow treason trial, now being distributed by the ties.

A NON-SUBSCRIPTION performance of "Tristan und Isolde"; the debut of Franca Somigli, Iyric soprano; the return to the company of Gladys Swarthout and Charles Hackett, and the season's first performances of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly' and "La Boheme" and Thomas's "Mignon," will be features of the twelfth week, last but two, of the Metropolitan Opera season.
Prospective freshmen at Williams College will be required hereafter to submit a detailed health history prior to their admission.

Nicasio Osmena, just arrived here from the Philippines for a vacation, told today how the islands' gold boom brought an American almost $3,000,000 for mining stock given him to cancel a $500 debt. Osmena is the son of Vice President Sergio Osmena of the Philippine Commonwealth.

NIAGARA FALLS. THE Falls at Niagara, which generally put on a spectacular show for Winter visitors, supplied thrills for spectators a few days ago when the largest ice movement since 1908 was recorded, huge cakes going over the cataract and jamming into high "mountains."

Mrs. Ella O'Gorman Stanton of this city, and her daughter, Mrs. Thomas J. O'Brien are sponsors for a bridge and fashion show, to be held the evening of March 16 at the Hotel Commodore, for the benefit of work being done by the Rev.

An almost iceless and snowless Winter is making the motor boat fitting-out season a topsy-turvy affair. Balmy Saturday afternoons and Sundays in February meant that canvas covers were removed far earlier than normal, ports and hatches were opened for airing, and calluses are already sprouting on many a skipper's hands from scrubing, sanding-down and painting.

The Long Island University Club's rugby team opened its season yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park with a 24-0 triumph over the Pilgrims' Rugby Club. In much better condition than their opponents, the winners set a fast pace from the start and scored practically at will, while the losers were never a serious threat.

Wilson College will entertain many prominent educators on May 21 and 22 when Paul Swain Havens will be inaugurated as president of the college. A conference on "Looking Forward in Education" will be held on May 21, at which the speakers will be Miss Mary Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College;
The Dartmouth College English Department will try an innovation next Fall, and as a result the general "major" for students in that subject will be a thing of the past.
The junior auxiliary of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, Yonkers, is now making arrangements for the annual Butterfly Ball dinner dance to be held on the night of April 9 at the Ritz-Carlton.
The justices of Special Sessions has made public the annual report of the work of their court during 1936, showing disposition of 25,360 cases, of which 11,894 resulted in guilty pleas.

ARTURO TOSCANINI, called the "perfectionist" among orchestra leaders, having accepted an invitation to conduct ten American radio concerts, has caused the broadcasters to cut another niche of triumph in their shield of glory, for they feel they are responsible for inducing the distinguished Italian maestro to return to America. rica.

Many prominent educators and psychologists contribute to the first issue of a new educational journal, to be the organ of the Association of Consulting Psychologists, which made its appearance yesterday.

As 1937 nears the end of its first quarter, I the upward climb of the cost of living continues, giving indications that the year will witness a further advance along a line of march that has followed an ascending path since June, 1933.

The return of world prosperity and the consequent increase in trade and travel have brought boom times to Britain's shipbuilding industry. Hordes of workers have returned to the yards and shipbuilding shares have skyrocketed.
BOSKOOP, in the Netherlands, will keep open house for a fortnight, beginning March 24, in honor of the fields of flowers for which it is renowned. ed.

Charles Foster Talbott, a member of one of Maryland's oldest families, died today of a heart attack while sitting at the wheel of an automobile in the salesrooms of the Talbott Motor Company, which he headed. He was 59 years old.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. STEPS are being taken to transform St. Augustine into a laboratory of history by restoring and preserving ancient evidence that goes back to aboriginal Indian days. Planned on a thoroughly scientific basis, the project has vast possibilities, for the community was founded two centuries before the Revolutionary War, and is therefore the oldest in the United States. s.

IT may be true that, as Mr. George Steer says in the introduction to his book, its title will disappoint many," inasmuch as neither Italy's supreme leader nor even the Italian Army figures much in this volume.

ALTHOUGH it is scarcely early enough to strike a trial balance, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is convinced, from the evidences of financial success indicated thus far in the progress of its Norma Shearer-Leslie Howard Romeo and Juliet," that the way is now open for further cinema production of Shakespeare.

Twenty-one villages in Westchester County will go to the polls on March 16 to elect Mayors, trustees and other officials. Having special charters, Ossining elects in December, Peekskill on the first Tuesday in April and Port Chester on the fourth Tuesday in April.

Encouraged by Springlike weather, Detroiters turned out in large numbers today for the opening of the twenty-second annual all-breed show of the Detroit Kennel Club at Convention Hall. The exhibition drew a fine entry of 946 with fifty-three breeds represented.
The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, declared last night that Catholics

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo, in a formal statement distributed yesterday among members, of New York Printing Pressmen's Union 2, insisted that Andrew R. Armstrong, for many years president of the local, had agreed to the election of officers which will be held tomorrow.

No case that is' not disingenuous can be made out for the President's proposal for packing the Supreme Court. While that proposal has the undeclared aim of making the court subservient, not enough attention has been drawn to the fact that it would not even achieve its declared aim in the process.

The Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., announced today a 5 per cent wage increase, effective next Monday, and Wellesley B. Cooper, superintendent of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, Inc., said he would confer with representatives of the Committee for Industrial Organization Wednesday on their request for a 15 per cent pay increase.

T. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, announced yesterday the Hayden Planetarium would send an expedition to Peru to observe the Solar eclipse on June 8. The point of observation would be near Lima, he said.

Three weeks after its incorporation into General Francisco Franco's territory Malaga has its life under this regime quite well organized. Street cars not only are running again but are repainted in Insurgent colors--two horizontal red stripes separated by a gold stripe.
By a preliminary vote of almost ten to one, the Bar Association of President Roosevelt's home State recorded opposition today to his Supreme Court reorganization plan.

Transatlantic shipping tonight was warned in the daily naval hydrographic broadcast that forty-two icebergs and great areas of field ice had been sighted 150 to 200 miles from the steamer lane now in use.

Miss Margaret Brownell, daughter of Mrs. Isaac Anthony Brownell of 2 Riverview Terrace and the late Mr. Brownell of London, was married to Knight Ames, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Ames of Milton, Mass., yesterday afternoon in St. Stephen's Church, West Sixty-ninth Street.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Feb. 20 totaled 287,574,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 1,416,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 1,518,000 in stocks of domestic crude, but a decline of 102,000 in stocks of foreign crude.
Daniel Hugh Roney, former village trustee for three terms and former Assistant Police Justice of the village, died today in his home here after a long illness.

Harry Balsamo of Harlem outpointed Jackie Aldare of Williamsburg in the feature eight-round contest before 2,500 fans at the Ridgewood Grove last night. The victor scaled 161 3/4 pounds, six less than Aldare.

The New York City World's Fair of 1939 will influence architecture as no previous fairs have influenced it and may result in the houses of the new cities being built upon stilts above grassy plots and beds of flowers, John T. Briggs, secretary of the New York Society of Architects, said yesterday.

Nebraska retained the Big Six Conference indoor track and field championship tonight by scoring a record-breaking total of 50 points. The previous mark of 46 points was set by the Cornhuskers last year.

SUFFERERS from insomnia may profit from a discovery reported by Ilico of The British Weekly. A distinguished physician has suggested to him that the re-reading of old novels is of peculiar efficacy for the man who cannot sleep.
Thirteen seniors and nine juniors have been elected to Phi Beta Kappa at Amherst College. The men are:

The projected drive for unionization of the entire textile industry by the Committee for Industrial Organization will probably launch another buying wave similar to that which took place before the National Industrial Recovery Act was inaugurated, according to opinions here yesterday.

AMONG the one-man shows of the week is an exhibition of oils by Sol Wilson at the Babcock Galleries (through March 13). Mr. Wilson likes to paint in large patterns, canvases with space filling designs such as his "Breakwater"; or the "Squall" or "Granite," with the huge blocks of stone presenting him with natural forms.

Mrs. Georgette Gerard-Varet Hyde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Gerard-Varet of Semur, Cote d'Or, France, will be married to Harris Fahnestock of 15 East Sixty-sixth Street and Eastover, Lenox, Mass., it has been announced here. It is expected that the wedding will take place near the end of this month. h.
A group of owners and management agents of dwellings having assessed valuations of less than $50,000 each is being formed within its owners' division, the Real Estate Board of New York announces.
In emulation of President Roosevelt, his predecessor at Albany, Governor Lehman of New York has often taken his administrative fights by radio directly to the people.

PSYCHOLOGISTS say that practically all truly happy persons have hobbies. There is the little California foothill town of Sierra Madre whose hobby is the encouragement of hobbies. The person without a hobby is considered perhaps a little queer in Sierra Madre. Madre.
The Glee Club of the New York Athletic Club, of which Edward J. McNamara is chairman, will give a concert this afternoon at 4 o'clock at the organization's Travers Island home.

Lawrenceville's poloists easily defeated a Yale junior varsity trio, 21 1/2 to 6 1/2, today on the indoor field of the 112th Field Artillery. Goals by Hayward and Rose gave the Larentians a first-period lead which was never' threatened during the entire game.

An exhibition of corn products, showing how they are developed from the time of the seed in the ground to the last process of manufacture, is on view at the New York Botanical Garden, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Marian Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Young of Star Lake, N. Y., was married here yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church to William Bolling Taylor, son of Mrs. John Sterling Taylor of Richmond, Va., and the late Mr. Taylor.

The annual Princeton junior promenade will be held here on the evenings of March 19 and 20, it has been announced by William K. Coors, class of '38, of Golden, Col., chairman of the junior prom committee. Dancing in the university gymnasium will last from 10 until 4 the first night and from 9:30 to 12:30 the second evening.

What has the League of Nations been doing amid all the disturbing events of these days in Europe? Great Britain has taken the unprecedented decision to spend in peace time $7,500,000,000 on armaments of which $2,000,000,000 will be borrowed.
Two thatch-roofed homes are being erected at Lake Mohawk, in Sparta, N. J., for John R. English of East Orange and Willard L. Hults of Milburn by the Arthur D. Crane Company.
A fire roared through a lonely little home here today, taking the lives of three of Mr. and Mrs. George Washington Farnham's four young children. Squirrels were blamed for starting the blaze.
John Ellis Martineau, federal District Judge and former Governor of Arkansas, died today of influenza, complicated by a heart ailment. He was 63 years old.

IN the age-old struggle to share in the benefits of education, what has been humorously alluded to as "the weaker sex" has shown a capacity for heroism and sacrifice that might well be envied by the dominant male.
TO the great disappointment of this reader, who found its first one hundred pages irresistible. Robert Graves's satire on the predacious becomes in time, and, finally, in sum, tedious.

Miss Dorothy Remsen Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Remsen Johnson of The Towers, Brooklyn, was married yesterday at 12:30 P. M. to Roland von Goeben, son of Mrs. Herman Behr of this city and the late Carl K. von Goeben.

Breaking from the traditionally conservative educational methods of the South, the University of Georgia, "oldest State-chartered university in America," today announced a course employing the newest thing in modern educational techniques.

The Glee Club of the New York Athletic Club, of which Edward J. McNamara is chairman, will give a concert this afternoon at 4 o'clock at the organization's Travers Island home.

An exhibition of corn products, showing how they are developed from the time of the seed in the ground to the last process of manufacture, is on view at the New York Botanical Garden, it was announced yesterday.

College students are rapidly becoming captains of commerce. Today 73,232 of them are enrolled in campus cooperatives doing an annual business of close to $3,000,000, according to figures just compiled by the Cooperative League of the U. S. A. Most of this development has taken place during the last four years.

Approval of the experiment conducted at the Speyer School to develop new teaching techniques for gifted and dull-normal children was voiced yesterday by three members of the school system, who agreed that problems of the exceptional pupil need serious consideration.

Dr. Jeremiah D. M. Ford, chairman of the Department of Romance Languages at Harvard University and fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, was announced today as recipient of the Laetare Medal, bestowed annually since 1883 by the University of Notre Dame upon an outstanding member of the Catholic laity.

THE motor car of the immediate future is not likely to introduce radical changes in design, W. J. Davidson, technical director of the General Motors Corporation, told members of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States at their recent convention here. n here.
THE day will come," wrote Ludwig II of Bavaria to Wagner in 1866, "when the world will grasp the deep significance and importance of our indissoluble bond."
William H. Milne, Albany and Schenectady stock broker, was found guilty today of first and second degree grand larceny.
With Chicago's first major taxicab strike in its second day, union leaders and officials of the Yellow Cab Company and the Checker Taxi Company were striving tonight to make peace.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa.--Gold, copper and other treasures lying at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of the Cape of Good Hope will be salvaged. The Italian Sorima Company, responsible for the salvage of the liner Egypt which sank off the Brittany coast with $5,000,000 worth of bullion trapped in massive steel safes, will tackle the job.

SPRING in New York means ski time in the Canadian Rockies. After one has practiced stemming on country-club bunkers, gone by snow train to week-end slopes, made holiday in the Adirondacks or Laurentians;

President Lazaro Cardenas made effective by official decree tonight his promise to cattlemen last year that the agrarian program would not hurt their interests. He altered the agrarian code so as to make cattle ranches ranging in size from about 750 to 123,500 acres not subject to expropriation by the government for twenty-five years, under certain conditions.

SO extensive and well chosen is the group of lithographs now displayed (for a period of two months) in Room 316 at the Public Library, that it gives one a very good idea of Fantin-Latour's creative work in this medium.

NEARLY a score of paintings by Thomas Eakins may be seen until the end of this month at the Kleemann Galleries. That is an event so unusual that further comment hardly seems needed. Perhaps, however, it is well to quote from the foreword which Walter Pach has supplied, and to underscore his judgments. ts.

Miss Katherine M. White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Stockton White of Malpas, Devon, has completed plans for her wedding on April 16 to Lawrence Illoway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Illoway of Chestnut Hill.

Concluding one of the finest seasons enjoyed by a school athlete in years, Leslie MacMitchell, George Washington star, added the 1,000-yard crown to his long list of victories at the thirty-fourth annual Public Schools Athletic League senior high indoor track and field championships at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night.

College students are rapidly becoming captains of commerce. Today 73,232 of them are enrolled in campus cooperatives doing an annual business of close to $3,000,000, according to figures just compiled by the Cooperative League of the U. S. A. Most of this development has taken place during the last four years.

Approval of the experiment conducted at the Speyer School to develop new teaching techniques for gifted and dull-normal children was voiced yesterday by three members of the school system, who agreed that problems of the exceptional pupil need serious consideration.

Dr. Jeremiah D. M. Ford, chairman of the Department of Romance Languages at Harvard University and fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, was announced today as recipient of the Laetare Medal, bestowed annually since 1883 by the University of Notre Dame upon an outstanding member of the Catholic laity.

THE motor car of the immediate future is not likely to introduce radical changes in design, W. J. Davidson, technical director of the General Motors Corporation, told members of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States at their recent convention here. n here.

Selling and renting activity in many residential areas-of Westchester County is reported by brokers as showing a decided upward tendency and the scarcity of mediumpriced homes in many localities, Plans either for purchase or to lease, is expected to stimulate building operations early in the Spring.

Miss Silvia R. White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris White of a the Fifth Avenue Hotel, will be married at noon today at the home of her parents to Justin R. Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Wolf of Omaha, Neb. The ceremony will be performed by Dr. Leo Jung of the Jewish Center.

Miss Marie Frugone will be hostess at a tea to be given Wednesday in the auditorium of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, 285 Schermerhorn Street, for members of the women's committee that is working for the success of the dance to be given by the Italian-American committee of the bureau on May 15 at the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island.
Cuba still reigned supreme in baseball affairs today when for the fourth time since the start of this Havana training campaign the Giants tumbled inelegantly to defeat.

STORM OVER PATSY--Tomorrow evening at the Guild Theatre. Being James Bridie's adaptation of Bruno Frank's "Sturm im Wasserglass," being, further, the Theatre Guild's fifth local show of the season In the cast are Sara Allgood, Roger Livesey, Ian McLean (all of the London company), Claudia Morgan, Brenda Forbes, J. W. Austin, Leo G. Carroll, Louis Hector, John Hoysradt, Valerie Cossart and Francis Pierlot.

Mrs. Herbert Parsons will give a tea tomorrow at her home, 1,049 Park Avenue, for a group of members of the Womens Field Army of the American Society for the Control of Cancer that is planning a card party to be held March 16 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis in behalf of the organization.

The annual Smith College Sup per Dance was held simultaneously last night in twenty-eight campus houses. It was attended by 1,250 students, representing the four classes, with their escorts. Much of the charm of Supper Dance dates back to 1891, when the first Spring dance was held on the campus, preceding the Harvard Glee Club concert.
A pay increase for miners in the Lake Superior district was announced today by the Oliver Iron Mining Company, United States Steel Corporation subsidiary, and several independent mining companies.

TUCKED away in a dark block of West Fifty-fourth Street, New York's night court, noisy and crowded in its depressing old building, is one of the sights of the town, one of the most famous courts in the world. It has been called the busiest. st.

Diana Wynyard, British actress, was ill today of an infection caused by grease paint entering a scratch on her face. Although her condition is not serious, it was announced her play, "Hearts Content," will be withdrawn after tonight.

Little Archie San Romani of the Emporia State Teachers College raced to a brilliant and unexpected triumph over Glenn Cunningham, king of American milers, tonight in the Bankers' Mile, feature event of the Chicago Relays, before a capacity crowd of 8,000 in the International Amphitheatre.

For the first time since Thomas Walter added the two modern wings to the National Capitol and linked them with a cast-iron dome, about threequarters of a century-ago, there is a good chance that Congress will correct the historic building's esthetic defects.

LAST year the Postoffice Department received more than 200 proposals for commemorative stamps. Suggestions continue to pour in, reflecting the current interest in philately. It has been proposed to honor Father's Day, Santa Claus, the 100th anniversary of American baseball, the inauguration of streamline train service,

With Georges Bonnet, the French Ambassador, as guest of honor, Philadelphia Museum of Art will open on March 20 ten new French galleries to house its treasures of French art of the eighteenth to twentieth centuries, it was announced today by J. Stogdell Stokes, president of the Pennsylvania Museum.

Warner Brothers, Inc., motion-picture producers, who recently bought 311 and 313 West Forty-fourth Street, adjoining the ten-story Warner Brothers Building, have added to their holdings by purchasing the five-story apartment house at 309 West Forty-fourth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

Champions in eight classes were crowned today as Lehigh University's second annual prep school title wrestling meet was concluded in Taylor Gymnasium. Wyoming Seminary of Kingston, Pa., took four of the individual championships to clinch the team title with a total of 23 points, eight more than its closest rival, Mercersburg Academy.
Secretary Hull's apology to Germany for Mayor La Guardia's remarks about Adolf Hitler was criticized here today by the Rev. Dr. Harry F. Ward, chairman of the American League against War and Fascism.
TEN years ago a group of mutineers turned their backs on Second Avenue-the Broadway of the lower East Side--and fixed their eyes on a playhouse to be consecrated to social plays for workers.

After holding possession of two plants of the Chevrolet Motor Company here for more than three hours last night, about 600 members of the United Automobile Workers of America evacuated the buildings early today.
Manchukuo, a Japanese experiment in imperialism-was five years old last week. The Japanese Army created it and controls it as Japan's "life line," It is fair now to ask: Is the experiment paying?

THIS is a strange and at the same time interesting book because of the sharp contrasts in subject-matter and in the personality of the author. The first section has to do with Mr. Gubsky's school days and young manhood in Russia during the late imperial days; the second with his struggle against poverty in England.

Plans for the Coronation Dinner Dance to be given at the BellevueStratford Hotel on April 9 by the Junior League are now rapidly taking form under the management of members of the executive committee.

Rioting and other prison troubles are caused not only by overcrowding but also because prisons are too big, according to Father John P. McCaffrey, Roman Catholic chaplain at Sing Sing, in an article published in the current issue of The Commonweal, at Catholic publication.

Mrs. Samuel A. Lewisohn and Mrs. J. Culbert Palmer Jr. head a group of women in charge of the arrangements for a reception to be held the afternoon of March 22 at the preview of the retrospective exhibition of twenty Degas masterpieces at the Durand-Ruel Galleries for the benefit of the Public Education Association.

One of the fine old estates in Great Neck, L. I., adjacent to the Sound, has been purchased by the developing firm of Levitt Sons for immediate improvement as a high-class residential community similar in type to the Levitt development at Manhasset known as Strathmore-at-Manhasset.

Cambridge, training for the annual boat race with Oxford on the Thames March 24, today rowed a full-course trial from Mortlake to Putney, the opposite direction to that in which the race will be rowed, in 18 minutes 45 seconds.
An artist now does not have to wait to be grown up to obtain a national, or even an international, showing of his work. This week two major exhibitions of youngsters' art are in progress in New York.
Fifty thousand Texans in the Tenth Congressional District may be the first to express themselves by ballot on President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court.

The heavy movement of vessels and cargoes to and from Pacific Coast terminals which has followed the strike has been accompanied by a rise in freight rates approaching but probably not yet equalling comparative freights offered by other world markets.

Dr. Ellice McDonald, director of the Biochemical Research Foundation of the Franklin Institute, in a report published in the current issue of The Franklin Institute Journal, asserts that "the jealousies and antagonisms of the cancer research workers in this country have delayed the cure of cancer many, many years."

Plans were announced today for a testimonial dinner for former Senator Pepper on March 16 in celebration of his seventieth birthday and the fiftieth year of his graduation from the University of Pennsylvania.

Andre Jessurun, 147 3/4, Bronx welterweight, conquered Willie Eley, 143, Harlem, in the feature tenround bout before 1,500 persons at the Rockland Palace last night. Eley waged a game and uphill struggle but was unable to cope with Jessurun's powerful rights.
Cornelius Van H. Engert, United States Minister Resident and Consul General at Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, left there today for Jibuti, French Somaliland, en route to the United States.

Secretary Woodring and Major Gen. Markham, chief of Army Engineers, will confer in Hartford, Conn., on Monday with Governors Cross of Connecticut, Aiken of Vermont, Hurley of Massachusetts and Murphy of New Hampshire in an effort to facilitate an agreement between the States to permit the beginning of construction of a reservoir system for flood control in the Connecticut River Valley. .

Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., champion of the Carolinas, registered her third major tournament victory of the Southern season by defeating Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis in an extra-hole final for the Florida East Coast championship on St. Augustine links today.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand. MANAM, great volcano of the Western Pacific, is stirring again. From far at sea captains of passing liners have seen great flames leap from its crest, and the warning rumbling of the mountain shows that mighty forces are in play. On the island itself little attention is paid to these periodic signs, now given after fifteen years of quiescence. "Manam is talking," the people say, and continue with their tasks. s.
A new course, "The Consumer in Modern Society," is being given at Barnard College with the aim to providing students with an opportunity to learn the position of women in the modern world.
The annual luncheon of the United Neighborhood' Houses will be held next Saturday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. "Preparedness for Peace" will be discussed by Senator Gerald P. Nye.

WITH a record-breaking Winter travel season nearing its peak, American rail roads are rushing orders for millions of dollars of unusual new passenger equipment and hurrying the rebuilding programs that will convert hundreds of old-style but still useful coaches into modernized, air-conditioned and roomy cars that compare favorably with the latest design in appointments and comfort.
Wild Bill Hickok "was quick on the draw," John B. Edwards, 92, said today as he recalled his arrest by the famous frontiersman.

Heretofore a non-union bulwark, Detroit the past two weeks has been engulfed by a tidal wave of sit-downs as an aftermath of the General Motors strike, in which the United Automobile Workers won a partial victory.
Strikers who caused the closing of the Lebanon plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation carried their fight to the corporation's larger Steelton mills tonight.
A GIANT natural hole on the side of Monte Sano, overlooking Huntsville, first settled town of North Alabama, soon may become one of the chief spots of interest to visitors in this part of the South.

President CONANT' of Harvard University in his annual report touches first upon the widespread interest in the reports of the Conference of Arts and Sciences held during the Tercentenary Celebration, finding in that interest conclusive evidence (if any were needed) that this country prizes the "triumphs of the mind" for their own sake as well as for their utility.

While corporation profits increased about 50 per cent in 1936 and a similar gain is indicated for the current quarter, the balance of the year should see some reduction in this percentage rise, according to opinions expressed here yesterday. Inability to pass along the full extent of the raw material and labor cost increases to consumers will force companies to absorb such rises, it was said.

THE YELLOW CAT" is that rare thing, a story for younger children--its popularity will be greatest with readers from 8 to 11--which has genuine style and real charm of atmosphere. "When," the story begins, "the Yellow Cat was a small kitten the color of marmalade, it occurred to nobody that he might have an exciting life."

In preparation for the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Pittsburgh, beginning. Oct. 18, R. L. McKallip, president of the Pittsburgh Real Estate Board, which, will act as host to the delegates, has appointed the following committee:

At the First Congregational Church this noon Miss Theresa Mallary Turner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Harvey Turner of this town, was married to James Gardner Stevens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gardner Stevens of Monterey.

The first of a series of events to celebrate the silver jubilee anniversary of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing will be a luncheon to be given by the New York jubilee committee of the organization on March 18 at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Conditions created by the recent excessive floods in the Ohio River Valley have demonstrated, according to Frederick M. Babcock, chief of the FHA underwriting section, the value of the Federal Housing Administration's risk rating method in respect to location in its mortgage lending practice.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday its opposition to the proposed Health Insurance Law on the ground that it would increase the "menace of governmental competition, particularly in a field now adequately and ethically served by private enterprise."
The current international arms race may be said to have begun on land and in the air in March, 1935, with Germany's reintroduction of compulsory military service.

Having received invitations from twenty-two members, Egypt has formally applied for admittance to the League of Nations. In her application she expressed her sincere desire to participate in international cooperation.
What will this country do about the overseas naval construction program? Will the declared American policy of a navy second to none be maintained?

LITTLETON, N. H.-The Hochgebirge Challenge Cup ski races to be held today on the Richard Taft race course on Cannon Mountain, Franconia Notch, highlights a late-season calendar of Winter sports events in New Hampshire and the North country. The meet features the first woman's championship down-hill races in the East. e East.

Holding the upper hand virtually all the way, the New York A. C. trio vanquished Winmont Farms, 8 to 5, at Squadron C Armory last night and qualified for the play-off final in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League at Squadron A Armory next Saturday evening.

Mrs. Warren Pearl, wife of Major Pearl of the American Consulate, gave a party at her home in Eaton Square this week to meet La Argentinita, Lydia Sokolova, Anton Dolin, Mar kova and other ballet dancers who will appear before Queen Mary at a matinee in aid of the National Council of Girls' Clubs.
Women students of the University of Pennsylvania who are adept with the brush and the drawing pencil are preparing for their fourth annual art exhibition, to be held in Sergeant Hall on the campus.

Edgar Thomason, president of the Piedmont Northern Railway and the Durham Southern Railway, died here today. The 69-year-old railway executive had been critically ill since Feb. 22 when he suffered a stroke in his office.
William P. Given, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Cresson Given of New York City and New Hope, Pa., has been elected president of the Dramatic Association at the Connecticut School.

The two awards given this municipality of 41,000 by the National Safety Council for being the largest city in the country without a fatal traffic accident in 1936 and for having the lowest traffic accident record for municipalities between 25,000 and 50,000 population were acknowledged today by Mayor Joseph Stilz.

A survey by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts shows, according to the organization, that manufacturers who had left the State are returning and that many new industries have been established here.

In his defense of his Supreme Court plan on Thursday evening, President ROOSEVELT said that those who place their confidence in his Administration have been reassured by the criticism his proposal has received:

Doing its best scoring in the final period, Connecticut State College defeated the Upsala girls' basketball team today, 34-18. The visitors forged ahead in the second period to lead, 14-9, at the half. Miss Blanche Johnson of Upsala was the leading scorer.

Editor, American Rose Annual In the forthcoming issue of the American Rose Annual more than 200 new or recently introduced rose varieties will be described for the first time. That figure indi cates how general is the interest in "the queen of flowers," which, season after season, holds her old courtiers and wins new ones.
MARCUS--Walter. Mr. and Mrs. Max Marcus announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Walter, to be held Saturday, March 13, at the Ahavath of Israel of East Midwood, Avenue K and East 29th St., Brooklyn.

The work of the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor will be aided by a bridge party to be held the afternoon of March 20 at the Commodore. Depending entirely upon voluntary contributions, the sisters, whose headquarters are at 342 East Sixty-ninth Street, have for twenty-one years helped the destitute sick in their homes, often supplying their patients with food, clothing and other necessities.

Decorative gourd-growing has faithful practitioners. Gourd growers will meet to discuss their hobby on March 17 in Horticultural Hall, R. C. A. Building, at 3:30 P. M. Speakers are to be Professor E. W. Sinnott of Barnard College and George L. Fisher, chairman of the garden center committee of the Maplewood (N. J.) Civic Association.
The El Pardo sector, northwest of Madrid, was the scene of heavy fighting tonight, as the Insurgents made their third attack in twenty-four hours in the Madrid area.

The Budget Committee of the House of Representatives voted the budget yesterday without an amendment. This action, indicating a withdrawal of opposition to the government's policies and assuring a peaceful termination of the session, so pleased Premier Senjuro Hayashi that he summoned reporters and for the first time gave them an unstudied talk on the situation.

Disregarding the protest of Harry Green, attorney for Ellis H. Parker Sr. and his son, Ellis H. Parker Jr. Jury Commissioner James Kerney Jr. proceeded to draw a jury panel for the April term in Federal district court today.

Keen interest is developing among Westchester taxpayers over the week-end as to what action the Board of Supervisors will take when it. meets tomorrow to vote upon the new Westchester charter plan drafted by Supervisor Bert C. McCulloch of Mamaroneck and a special committee.
In the nearly seven years that Clarence E. Watters has been music director at Trinity College, the glee club has been making definite progress toward becoming one of the leading New England clubs.
The Rt. Rev. George Horsfall Frodsham, Vicar of Halifax since 1920 and formerly Bishop of North Queensland, Australia, died here today. He was 73 years old.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday Mount Hope Retreat, Baltimore, Md., of the Rev. Thomas J. Keenan, who was pastor of the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Tuxedo Park, N. Y., from 1910 until illness compelled his retirement in 1920.

While the majority of the German newspapers are still digesting the Pittman neutrality resolution just passed by the United States Senate, some, including the Hamburger Fremdenblatt and the Frankfurter Zeitung, welcome the American measure from the idealistic and theoretical viewpoints.

Miss Eleanor Outhouse, 29-year-old daughter of Arthur J. Outhouse, a Croton Falls farmer, was found dead about 5:25 this afternoon beside. the southbound tracks of the Harlem Division, New York Central Railroad, about five miles north of here.
The death of Captain Ramon Torres, noted Spanish aviator, amateur bullfighter and popular sportsman, was reported tonight in dispatches from Gerona.

Members of the New York Society of the Descendants of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence held their annual dinner last night at Sherry's. Kenneth Chorley gave a talk with motion pictures during the evening on "Colonial Williamsburg."

IMPROVED port facilities and modern highways are attracting an increasing number of tourists to Santo Domingo. Big passenger liners, which formerly had to lay at anchor off shore now dock right at the quay side in Ciudad Trujillo, capital city of the Dominican Republic. blic.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Burnett Woodruff of Flushing of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Virginia Woodruff, to Richard Jones Mead of Forest Hills, Queens, son of Mrs. E. Jones Mead of Binghamton, N. Y.
The body of Serge Zolotoohin, Russian newspaper man and adventurer, was found in the sea today at the mouth of the River Exe. His empty yacht Rona was stranded near by.

In view of an agreement by Thomas Leeming Co., Inc., 101 West Thirty-first Street, New York, to discontinue some allegedly misrepresentative claims for "Baume Analgesique" or "Baume Bengue," the Federal Trade Commission has closed its case charging unfair trade practices.

The public reaction in France, apart from that in Parliament and the press, to the government's financial proposals may be best summed up as favor assure stable currency and 4 per cent on invested money.

On the heels of the Academy award to Luise Rainer for the best performance of 1936, Metro-GoldwynMayer has negotiated a new contract with the Viennese star by which she no longer will be concerned with options.

Madrid commenced the fifth month of its siege quietly today. There is a tenseness in the air these days, however, for everybody knows General Francisco Franco is preparing for a Spring drive that will exceed in strength and determination anything he has yet tried.
Deaths exceeded births in New York State in January, Dr. J. V. DePorte, Director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Department of Health, announced today.

Thomas Clyde, son of the late William P. Clyde, steamship owner, who died in 1923, died here Friday morning of coronary thrombosis. He was 70 years old. Mr. Clyde had lived in Washington since 1926, making his home at the Wardman Park Hotel. He was a bachelor and had no immediate relatives here.
Adopting a plan first suggested fifteen years ago, congregations of St. Philip's and St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Churches have voted to merge, it was announced today.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,899,251,000. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

Cash expenditures for additions and improvements to properties of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and subsidiaries in 1936 amounted to $16,193,549, according to the annual report, signed by Charles M. Schwab, chairman, and Eugene G. Grace, president. The estimated cost of completing the construction authorized and in progress at the end of the year is $38,118,800.

Having defined the term of press agent and agreed upon qualifications for membership, the newlyformed New York Theatrical Press Agents yesterday ratified a constitution at a five-hour meeting at the Hotel Algonquin.

Skiing for all they were worth, an Austrian, a Frenchman and a Swiss raced down in the Arlberg-Kandahar contest here today and finished the distance-2.3 miles-within less than two seconds of each other.

This week-end produced more violence than any since the Arab general strike ended last October. Palestine is gravely apprehensive. The Hebrew press draws parallels with the events leading to last year's strike. The Palestine Post asks:

The positively liberal orientation given by the Government to its financial policy caused a sudden turn on the Bourse last week, where prices hardened sharply on Thursday when it was Larned financial measures were being studied.
The New York Americans snapped another Detroit winning streak tonight, defeating the National League hockey champions, 3 to 1 before 10,850 spectators. It was the Red Wings'

Bobby Wilsoni of Washington, D. C., will make his first start in the St. Nicholas Palace when he tackles Paulie Walker, veteran welterweight from Trenton, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the midtown club tonight.

Raymond Moley, one of the members of the original Roosevelt "brain trust," split definitely with the Roosevelt administration yesterday over the President's Supreme Court proposal. Mr. Moley, now editor of News-Week, has been lukewarm toward some aspects of the New Deal for several years.

The marriage in SagHarbor, L. I., on Saturday afternoon of Mrs. Ethel K. Gaffney of Laurelton, Queens, to L. Eugene Decker, Jamaica lawyer and former Assemblyman, has been announced. The ceremony was performed in the Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Sidney H. Barrett.

A goal by Woodrow (Porky) Dumart in the closing minutes of the game enabled the Boston Bruins to defeat the New York Rangers in Madison Square Garden last night. Dumart's counter was the sole tally scored during the battle, and was a shocking blow, indeed, to the Blue Shirt forces.

Preservation of Pittsfield's famous Bulfinch Church seems assured with its acceptance, as a gift from the Berkshire County Savings Bank, by Mrs. Elisabeth C. T. Miller of Friendship Farm, Windsor, formerly of Cleveland.
Striking maritime workers abandoned today their blockade of this port and evacuated occupied vessels after negotiations to end the strike had taken a favorable turn.

Dozens of sightless men and women chatted together or listened to the radio tonight, carrying the nation's first sit-down stirke of the blind into its second week. Since the tolling of a bell last Monday morning none of the 107 employes of the Pennsylvania Association for the Blind has done any work.

Officials of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers of America adjourned a six-hour conference tonight without result in the deadlock which has closed the Firestone factories and made 10,000 employes idle. Negotiations are to be resumed at 10 A. M. tomorrow.
The need of most Christians in New York City is for a sanctuary, the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, chaplain of the Sons of the American Revolution, said yesterday afternoon that Americans should mind their own business about Europe. He condemned public officials "who go out of their way to stir up as much trouble as they can."
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt delivered her first Texas lecture in a tour of the Southwest today and left here for Fort Worth with her son, Elliott, in whose home she will visit.

The outstanding movements in the United States balance of international payments in 1936 were the net inflow of gold, which, inclusive of earmarking operations, aggregated $1,030,000,000, and the closely related inward movement of shortterm and long-term capital funds, which amounted to $1,141,000,000," Amos E. Taylor, assistant chief of the Finance Division of the Department of Commerce, said in a statement today.

Financial comment on Great Britain's deficit of [Pound]19,000,000 in its foreign trade balance for 1936 is, generally speaking, favorable. There is some fear that as the defense program gets into full operation the adverse trade balance may tend to widen, because rearmament involves larger imports of essential raw materials and impedes exports, owing to the preoccupation of manufacturers executing government orders and their consequent neglect of foreign customers.

Pope Pius XI, in a simple ceremony in his private apartments, today blessed the Golden Rose he will bestow on Queen Elena of Italy to commemorate the fortieth anniversary of her marriage to King Victor Emmanuel.

Plans for a new probationary training school for rookie firemen at the Fire College in Long Island City are under way, it was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott. He said that the three-platoon system, which eventually will add more than 4,000 men to the department, made additional training facilities necessary.
A marigold with a delicate fragrance, David Burpee's new "Crown of Gold," makes its formal debut at the annual Philadelphia Flower Show, which opens tomorrow at the Commercial Museum.

Edward Fagan, 34 years old, of 163 Stanley Avenue, was brought to court today on the complaint of his wife, Mary, who charged he returned home at 2 o'clock this morning with a demand for 50 cents and would not let her sleep because she refused him the loan.

William W. Prager, assistant general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission in charge of the legal division of the New York regional office, announced yesterday that he had resigned, effective March 15. He will resume private practice with the firm of Spiro Felstiner, which again will become Spiro, Felstiner Prager. His successor has not been chosen.
It is now learned that the British invitation to Haile Selassie to send a representative to the coronation of King George resulted in demonstrations against the British consulate at Messina, Sicily.

The diverse opinions expressed on public questions recently, notably on flood control and the Supreme Court, were compared with the confusion at the Tower of Babel by the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner in the sermon last evening at the Broadway Temple Methodist Church. at 174th Street.

A subscription of $100,000 by the Pullman Company and five purchases of $50,000 each head the list of subscribers to New York World's Fair 4 per cent debentures, announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the fair's volunteer bond sales committee.

Mothers voted for, the first time.. today in this nominally dictatorial country. They cast their ballots in communal elections that began without incident in two regions. The voting, giving the populace avoice in government, will continpe in other regions until March 28.
Marshal Italo Balbo prepared today for the climax of his career as Governor of Libya, the arrival of Premier Benito Mussolini Thursday to inspect his North African domain.

Favorable reaction to the history and appreciation of music courses offered by the WPA Federal Music Project has led to the addition of the West End Community Center, 251 West 100th Street, to the list of music centers served by WPA teachers.

Both of the proposed amendments ot the Constitution were decisively rejected in the election yesterday. Of the 3,978,000 votes cast, the 2,857,000 ballots counted show that the marketing amendment was defeated in all the States while the aviation amendment was approved only in Victoria and Queensland, although the Commonwealth vote shows an affirmative majority.

Museum and group shows are chiefly conspicuous by their absence from the lists of exhibitions opening this week, leaving the field largely free for one-man shows, of which more than a score are on the calendar.

Declaring that no member of Congress dared any longer to oppose openly a government housing program, Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, urged yesterday that slum tenants organize to cooperate with labor in demanding housing reform.

More than 150 civic and religious leaders throughout the State have signed a letter, made public yesterday, addressed to the members of the Assembly by the Joint Committee for Ratification of the Child Labor Amendment urging the legislators to vote for ratification.

Harry F. Wolf of Montclair, national champions and Winged Foot star, won .the New Jersey State squash tennis championship for the 15-0, 15-7, 10-15, 9-15, 15-12. Wolf set a terrific pace to take a close match from Philip T. Moore of the Columbia University Club in the final at the Short Hills Club, seventh time today, when he took the first two games.

The population of this peaceful French town on the border of Catalonia was terrified at 6 A. M. today by a violent explosion. There was a scramble for cellar shelters by those who thought Rebel airplanes had mistaken Cerbere for Portbou, a Catalonian village on the other side of the border.

Judge and Mrs. Walter Mason Pickett of this city announced today the engagement of their daughter, Louisa Marcena, to John Irville Waterman of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irville Dennet Waterman of New Haven and South Weymouth, Mass.
The regular monthly meeting of the New York State Safe Deposit Association will be held in the Hotel Pennsylvania on Wednesday at 6 P. M. Dinner will be followed by an open forum.

Mrs. Ann Redfield Finlay died yesterday in her home here of a heart ailment at the age of 70. She was a member of the North Riding Chapter, D. A. R.; the Woman's Club of Great Neck, and the Founders and Patriots of New York City.

The stock markets here were able to congratulate themselves this week on their successful surmounting of - a difficult settlement in the account. Although the markets recovered well from the deep depression that resuited from the government's plan for financing a [Pound]1,500,000,000 expenditure for defense in the next five years, substantial differences had to be met on account day.

Coast Guard crews continued the search tonight for the twenty-eight-foot fishing boat Sunbeam with four persons aboard, which has been missing since 6 A. M. yesterday. Cutters, airplanes and other craft joined in the search.

The 1,173-ton British freighter Springwear, bound from England to Spanish ports, was halted in the Straits of Gibraltar tonight by Spanish Insurgent armed trawlers and ordered to proceed to Ceuta, Spanish Morocco. Her master refused to comply and steamed rapidly for Gibraltar.

Many people are "forever estranged from the Christian faith because they have been hurt by those who are 'supposed to represent it," the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
It is argued by the President and those who support his proposal for adding six justices to the Supreme Court that it is essential to liberalize the interpretations of the court.
A 60-year-old citrus grove tender married here last night a high school student, aged 15, and both described their romance as "love at first sight."

An exhibition series of home-andhome games between the top two teams in the Eastern Amateur Hoclkey League and the best pair in the Quebec Hockey Association of the Montreal Senior Group will be held in Atlantic City and Toronto next month.

Mrs. Hilda Kristina Lascari, a sculptor who won a gold medal from the National Academy of Design in 1926, leaped or fell to her death yesterday afternoon from the eleventhfloor solarium of the French Hospital at 326 West Thirtieth Street. Hospital attendants discovered the body in a courtyard at the rear of the building.

Dr. William Alanson White, psychiatrist and physician, an authority on mental ailments and for the last thirty-four years superintendent of St. Elizabeth's Hospital here, died of pneumonia this morning at the hospital after a short illness. He was in his sixty-eighth year.

The three minimum wage bills now pending in the Legislature were the subject of a symposium conducted over the air from Station WOR last night, when Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, minority leader, defended the Steingut-Fischel bill and Senator Thomas C. Desmond urged the Desmond Brownell bill.

Several hundred persons of an audience of 1,800 in the Capitol Theatre, 73 Newark Avenue, were thrown into a short-lived panic today when some one in the balcony yelled "fire" after a heavy fire extinguisher had fallen from the wall with a crash.

A secret law, which science has been unable to fathom, unites all human endeavor, passing it on from generation to generation, the Rev. Z. N. Corbe said yesterday at the United Lutheran Church of the Transfiguration, 74 West 126th Street.

Lard supplies are so large that short selling of futures has been encouraged for several weeks. The advance in cotton and cottonseed oil in the last few days, however, brought about a covering movement on the part of shorts and a little new speculative buying.

An unseeded entrant, Gilbert Carpenter of Westport, last night ended the three-year reign of Kenneth J. Ridgway of Garden City as metropolitan badminton champion when the Connecticut star downed the defending champion in the Class A men's singles final.

An oil sketch of Omai, reputed to be the first native from the Pacific Islands ever seen in England, painted soon after 1774 by Sir Joshua Reynolds, has been presented to Yale University by the Associates in Fine Arts at Yale, it was announced today by Dean Everett V. Meeks of the Yale School of the Fine Arts.

Richard H. Higgins, banker, died yesterday at his home, 470 Park Avenue. Mr. Higgins, who was 67 years old, had been ill for only a short time. At his death he was a member of the board of directors of the Manufacturers Trust Company, a position he had held since the bank of which he was formerly first vice president, the Chatham Phenix National Bank and Trust Company, merged with the Manufacturers Trust.

It is regarded of here as most certain that the effect of the law establishing an embargo on United States exports of raw materials to belligerents will be to incite all governments to build up stocks. thus accentuating the present price boom.

James A. Whiting, 40, a World War veteran and restaurant owner of Ossining, died on Friday in a veterans' hospital in Washington, D. C. He was a brother of Fire Chief Leonard Whiting of Ossining. He joined the 165th Infantry Regiment in the World War and saw action at Verdun and Chateau-Thierry.

Aided by the masterful -performances of its versatile captain, Warren Chivers the Dartmouth Outing Club today made a sweep of the honors as the seventh annual invitation Hochgebirge Challenge Cup two-day skiing competition, one of the oldest of its kind in the country, came to an end.

An automobile pursued by motorcycle policemen crashed into another car today, killing one person and injuring four others. Unable to stop, the patrolmen and their motorcycle piled into the wreckage of the two automobiles.

Norwalk declared a holiday today to welcome its newest resident, Lily Pons, French soprano of the Metropolitan Opera. It was "Lily Pons Day," and several thousand townspeople crowded a local theatre to see Mayor Frank Stack present the keys of the city to Miss Pons.

Eleven Federal agencies awarded sixty contracts valued-at $2,005i929 under the Public Contracts Act in -the week ended on March- 4, the Departmecrt of Labor has announced. Slightly more than one-fourth f the total went to contractors in New York State.

Mrs. Joseph B. Whitehead gave a dinner tonight at the Patio, at which her guests were Colonel and Mrs. Harold A. Braman, Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Logan, Mr. and Mrs. George Stevenson Fenton, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Huntley, Mr. and Mrs. William Hall, Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Hasler and Mrs. Edward Plaut.

Mrs. Ian McKechnie of the invading British team and Charles Francis Gummey Jr., Racquet Club, today captured the invitation mixed doubles squash racquets honors by defeating Lady Katherine Cairns, also of England, and George. (Pat) Thornton, Merion, on the courts of the Merion Club, 10-15, 15--6, 17-14, 15-10.
District Attorney Buron Fitts, prosecutor of many noted cases, was shot from ambush and wounded in the arm tonight as he left his ranch home near suburban Monrovia alone in an automobile.

PWA expenditures in New York State have passed the $250,000,000 mark, State Director Arthur. S. Tuttle announced yesterday after reviewing accounts of payments to municipalities for contractors on the 500 PWA projects under way or completed throughout the State.

The appointment of Victor J. Freeze as general freight traffic manager of the International Mercantile Marine Company was announced yesterday by Basil Harris, vice president in charge of traffic. Mr. Freeze will succeed Frank A. Ryan, who died on Feb. 23.
The Giants put on the pressure today and, feeling that their Cuban tormentors had something coming to them, they let them have it all in one blast.

Patricia, 17-month-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Doyle of 52 Ashburton Avenue, was reported recovering today in Yonkers General Hospital from the effects of swallowing a disinfectant last night while her parents were away.
Another child victim of "upsidedown stomach"--diaphragmatic hernia--is in St. Vincent's Hospital and has an excellent chance to live following two operations, it was learned yesterday.

James Brickell, a Columbia University student, recorded the top score today in Class B of the dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club. After driving along at the tiller of his boat Loon all Winter, he went out this afternoon with Miss Allegra Knapp as crew and they piled up 104 points in six races, to 101 for Howard McMichael in his Ordeal.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday that the differences between the Committee for Industrial Organization and the A. F. of L. are of tactics and ultimate direction rather than of vertical or horizontal groupings of membership.

With a shortage of supplies in leading wheat countries, combined with heavy exports from producing to consuming countries and a more widespread bullish feeling in the trade, the markets are attracting more attention, although the trade is not broadening to any extent.

Rabbi William Margolis, chairman of the National Social Justice Commission of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America and leader of the Congregation Ohab Zedek in New York City, described charges that the Jewish people had arrogated to themselves the title of "God's Chosen Race" as a "stupid myth."
Leonard Romagna Jr., sailing Jenny, and 0. H. Chalkley, in Popover, were winners in today's regatta of the Manhassett Bay dinghy fleet, held in a cold, puffy northwest breeze.
The fifteen-ton sailing yacht Hoho, manned by three Norwegian former naval captains, Thorstein Schyberg, Birgen Brhyn and Tomas Ostmoeen, arrived here today from Tahiti.
