WHEN Max Addled-a-bit Baer left for England last week the report along the waterfront was that he went aboard ship in disguise to foil the Madison Square Garden bailiffs who were there to "have the law onto him." His disguise was not described. Maybe he was dressed like a prizefighter.

There is an uneasier conscience in the world today than there was before Christ, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said in his sermon yesterday morning in the James Memorial Chapel of the seminary, 121st Street and Broadway.

The word "ain't" is not necessarily an incorrect usage but merely a colloquialism, according. to Professor Harold H. Bender, chairman of the Department of Oriental Languages and Literatures of Princeton University and an authority upon the origin, history and relationships of words, who has traced the expression back as far as the independence of the United States.

With 19,000 persons expected to attend, the final round of the Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight. A program comprising twenty bouts will mark the end of the tourney, which has ben running for more than a month under the auspices of The Daily News A. A.

There was no rest for the Dodgers on this bright and warm Sabbath. Manager Burleigh Grimes had fifty players in uniform when today's exercises opened at 10:30 and before the end exactly forty had participated in an eight-inning ball game.

A total of 23,613 personas received advice on health problems during 1935 and 1936 from the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, according to a report covering the two years made public yesterday.

Dr. Arthur R. Mandel of 43 West Eighty-eighth Street, New York, for many years Professor of Pathology at New York University and attending physician and consulting pathologist to St. Vincent's Hospital, New York, died suddenly of a heart attack this afternoon while showing a friend over his new Summer place at Mahopac Mines.

Mrs. Adelaide C. Lawrence, president and general manager of the Claypool Hotel here, died today. Born in Ogdensburg, N. Y., Mrs. Lawrence was married early in life to Henry W. Lawrence, who operated a hotel in Moore's Junction, N. Y. They came to Indianapolis forty years ago Mr. Lawrence died eleven years ago.
Dr. John Arnold Rockwell, former medical adviser at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, tonight gave college men a rule by which to tell whether they were in love.
Both voluntary euthanasia and birth control were approved today by Dr. E. W. Barnes, Bishop of Birmingham, in a sermon at Oxford University.

Macombs Rd., 1,515 (11-2872-2800-2797-3173 and 9-2450); also Grant Av., 1,254; also Creston Av., 2,435; also 176th St., 176 E.; also Weeks Av., 1,790; also Macombs Rd., 1,479 and 1,491; A. V. J. Realty Corp. to Jacob R. Schiff, 575 Park Av.; $63,250.

Columbia's chances for victory in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday will hinge on the showing the Lions make in- the sprints and in the field events. It is in the field events that much of the strength of' the intercollegiate talent rests.

Star bowlers scheduled for early action in the American Bowling Congress tournament began gathering in New York last night. The competition will be held on the twenty-eight new alleys at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory, Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue.
The German wholesale price index on Feb. 24 was 105.8, against 105.5 on Feb. 17. The cost of living index for February was 124.8, compared with 124.5 in January.

The authorities at Orizaba in the State of Veracruz forbade anti-religious demonstrations scheduled for today. The Orizaba correspondent of the newspaper Universal reports churches in San Jose and San Miguel have been ordered placed in charge of local Catholics by the Secretary of Finance here.
A report showing that city dwellers in the lower income groups are taxed more heavily than residents of rural areas was made public last night by the Twentieth Century Fund.
The greatest saints at times felt as if God had "let them down," the Rev. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

The first anniversary of Germany's repudiation of Locarno and her armed reoccupation of the demilitarized Rhineland zone is chiefly commemorated in the. German press today by critical observations on the present outlook for Western European security.

Lou Gehrig, the New York Yankees' iron man first-baseman and at serious member of the hold-out brigade, returned here last night after a flying trip from Hollywood, where he had signed a movie contract. Gehrig was met at the Newark Airport by his wife.

Difficulties in forecasting the future course of commodity prices are increasing. The index of wholesale prices compiled by The Times of London shows a rise of approximately 17 1/2 per cent in the last year and a rise of 38 per cent from the low level of June, 1932.

Aetna Insurance Co. (Hartford, Conn.), com., 3 P. M. Ainsworth Manufacturing Corp., com. Canada Packers, Ltd., corn., 9 A. M. Cincinnati Union Stock Yards Co., com., 2 P. M. Coca-Cola Bottling Corp., A and B. Deisel-Wemmer Gilbert Corp., corn., 2 P. M. First National Bank Trust Co., Montclair, N. J., 8 P. M. Greenwich Water Gas System, 6% pf.. 2 P. M. Group Corp.. 6% Pf.. 3:30 P. M.

A longterm program of Federal public works to take up the lag from private industry was advanced by a group of sixteen members of the House in a settlement issued today as their answer to the unemployment problem.

An all-day trip along the Jarama River and Toledo fronts, during which Aranjuez was bombed while we were there, and an exciting night ride back to. Madrid with Insurgent bombers overhead served to give your correspondent an excellent idea of war conditions outside Madrid yesterday.

The Egyptian Government in efforts to end a two months' "stay-in" strike of Coptic monks, threatened today to strom their desert monastery. The Minister of Justice told the monks they must agree by Tuesday noon to admit an investigating

While passing the wine today at the communion service in the First Methodist Episcopal Church, John Zulauf, 78-year-old Somerset County Surrogate and president of the church's board of trustees, fell to the floor from a heart attack. He died a few minutes later in an auteroom.
Joseph Stalin has declared war on "bureaucracy" within the Communist party. That is the meaning of the discussions and decisions at the recent session of party leaders.

Alf Helton, veteran actor, died Saturday at his Forest Hills home after an illness of six weeks. He was 78 years old. Mr. Helton's last appearance was with Helen Hayes in "Victoria Regina," but he was forced to retire from the cast when he became ill.

Fulton's 650 Townsend Club members have contributed to a $200 fund to give the revolving old-age pension plan a tryout. Selection of the club members who will be charged with the task of spending $200 a month will be made about a fortnight hence, after some remodeling of the original Townsend plan is completed.

Sherman W. Finger, veteran member of the University of Minnesota coaching staff, died today. His age was 53. He was a Professor of Physical Education at the university and formerly was track coach. He came to Minnesota in 1924 as head track coach and also served as freshman football coach -for two seasons.

Samuel Rosoff announced yesterday that the followers of the late Norman Redwood in Local 102 of the International Union of Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers had called off their strike on the Sixth Avenue subway and the Wards Island sewer.
German industry has been quiet this week. Severe weather caused an abnormally sharp setback in the outdoor branches, but steel, non-ferrours metals and machine manufacturing have continued active.

In 1925 Dr. WILLIAM T. HORNADAY in his "Wild-Animal Round-Up" said that "honestly" he was glad that he would not be alive to see "the tattered remnants" of picturesque America as they would appear in fifty years.

Re-enter the Theatre Guild tonight, bringing to its own house in Fifty-second Street its fifth local offering of the season. "Storm Over Patsy" is the play, adapted by James Bridie from Bruno Frank's "Sturm im Wasserglass." Sara Allgood,

Frank and Max Bogner and W??mina Beck gave to Kas-Pen Builders, Inc., on 443 W. 47th St., a second mortgage for $6,000, at 6 per cent, subject to a first mortgage for $10,000. A mortgage for $11,400 on 71 W. 100th St. was assigned by Mildred Odell. Thomas to Louisa A. Ockers.
Two women were killed and seven other persons were injured in separate automobile accidents here early this morning.

C. W. Phellis set the pace for the New York A. C. gunners at Travers Island yesterday. Despite the handicap of a high wind, the Clasa A entrant finished with 94 out of 100 targets for the high scratch laurels.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimatedhere at 86 per cent of capacity, up 1 point in the week. The rate is not so significant for the future as usual because of notable developments in the week involving wages and prices.

Lionel A. Stahl of Brookville, L. I., an associate of J. W. Seligman Co., bankers, 54 Wall Street, died yesterday in the Neurological Institute of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 168th Street and Broadway, after a few weeks' illness at the age of 44.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 91.1, which compares with 90.9 a week before, 91 two weeks before, 90.7 three weeks before and 90.4 four weeks before.

Violin solos by Roman Totenberg were a special feature of last night's opera concert at the Metropolitan Opera House, which was attended by a capacity audience. An elaborate series of excerpts from "The Bartered Bride," given in costume, formed the entire second half of the bill.

A passenger and a member or the crew of the Italian liner Rex, which left New York Feb. 27, were killed in a storm off the Azores, The Associated Press reported last night in a dispatch from Genoa, Italy. In addition, other sources of information, including a radiogram received in New York, said that a number of persons aboard the liner had been injured.
The Agrarians, baseball champions of Mexico, downed the Philadelphia Athletics in an exhibition game today, 2 to 1. Romo Chavez, diminutive righthander, held the Mackmen to five hits.

The supreme tragedy of today is the lowering of human standards to a point where the fine things of life are reduced, the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson said In a sermon yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-EI, Fifth Avenue at Sixtyfifth Street. Dr. Goldenson deplored the state of the modern mind that rejects all that is sacred for the things that are essentially secular.

Representatives of fifteen nations, including the United States, gathered today in Geneva for the opening tomorrow of discussions of the distribution of sources of raw materials, a question held vital for world peace.

Last week's advance on the Stock Exchange, which carried the averages to the highest of this year to date--51/2 points above the previous week's closing and less than 2 points under the period's high mark of last November-was response to tangible events.
Communists failed to obtain more than 7 per cent of the total vote in local elections today in Loiret Department to replace two deceased General Council members.

Strikers at the Lebanon plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation voted unanimously at a mass meeting today to demand that the company recognize the Committee for Industrial Organization as the bargaining agency for members of the C. I. O. and pay a minimum wage of $5 a day.

John Francis Brice of Brice House, Bristol, Pa., a son of the late United States Senator Calvin S. Brice of Ohio, died Saturday evening in the Frankford Hospital, Philadelphia, after a brief illness, at the age of 59.

Young women, members of the Lakeview Players, formerly known as the Junior Branch Players, who have long been interested in the work of the New York Women's League for Animals, will take part in three one-act plays to be presented by the players Thursday night and Saturday afternoon at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street, for the benefit of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals.
The triumph of Herbert Morrison and his Labor organization in the London County Council election has brought a flutter of encouragement to the Labor party in the nation after long years of adversity.

Grand Concourse (11-2841), s w cor Elliot Pl., 100x126: Allenhurst Holding Corp. to Mutual Equities, Inc., 156 2d Av. Chatterton Av. (14-3807), n w cor of Castle Hill Av., 180x103; Antonio Marinaccio to Gli-Sol Realty Corp., 391 E. 149th St.: mtg., $250,100.

Representative Emanuel V. Celler of Brooklyn threatened yesterday' to complain to the United States Department of Justice about the activities of the National Association.. of Retail Druggists in supporting the Tydings-Miller PriceMaintenance Bill now before Congress.

A delegation of six, representing the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations, will leave for Albany this afternoon to voice the opposition of this organization, which represents virtually all of New York City's 36,000 teachers, to four bills affecting State educational legislation.

Exports of semi-finished and finished iron and steel products from the United States in January increased 49 per cent in value and 56 per cent in quantity over January, 1936, the Department of Commerce announced in preliminary figures today.

The Yankee brigade on the shores of Tampa Bay was mustered to its maximum of men under contract tonight as Field Marshal Joe McCarthy laid plans for a final week of drilling before sending the outfit into its first action of the 1937 campaign next Saturday.
A bill designed to repeal the Ives Teachers' Oath Law has been killed in the Assembly education committee, Harry L. Averill, committee chairman, said tonight.

The West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, scene of innumerable net classics, has been selected as the site of the Davis Cup'North American Zone final which will be played on Saturday, May 29, Sunday, May 30, and Monday, May 31.

Plans for a complete reorganization of the Columbia University School of Pharmacy, including a four-year course of study, higher standards of admission, a closer tie-up between the school and the University and introduction of academic subjects into the curriculum, were disclosed yesterday by Dr. Charles W. Ballard, Professor of Material Medica.

A majority of members of the Indian Congress party favor forming Ministries in the Indian provinces where the party obtained a majority in recent elections, according to the views of subordinate Congress organizations.

The Duke of Windsor has decided to bring Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson to this country to live after their marriage and is "considering most favorably" for their home the Cloisters, the castle-like country residence of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner A. Parker near Brooklandville, Md., just outside Baltimore, The Philadelphia Record says in a copyrighted story. Mrs. Simpson is a native of Baltimore.

With a fist fight and a near-riot supplying extra pyrotechnics to an exciting game, the Long Island University A. A. defeated Union Temple, 28 to 23, at the Hippodrome yesterday and rode into the. final round of the Metropolitan A. .A. U. basketball championship.

114th St., south side, 361 ft. east of Lenox Av., 17.8x101; Samuel Ortega to James Ivory, 52 W. 114th St.; mortgage, $7,000 (50 cents). Greene St., 68-68 1/2, 30x100, one-half interest; Dora Marks to Diana Furman, 2,185 Bolton St.. Bronx: mortgage, $10,000.

A thousand "angels" and disciples of Father Divine scattered for cover at 10:30 o'clock last night when a section of the plaster- ceiling in an auditorium at 20 West 115th Street, known as "Heaven No. 1," fell during a meeting in which the cult leader's followers were singing and attesting their faith in him.
An overflow crowd of 2,000 was treated to a brilliant three-hour exhibition at the first annual Westchester figureskating. carnival in the Playland Ice Casino tonight.

Apparently the New York Rovers have lost none of their charm since falling from grace. Making their first local appearance since becoming "outlawed," the Red Shirts were greeted yesterday by a crowd of 13,364 fans, who cheered them wildly.

The annual ball under the auspices of L'Union Alsacienne will take place next Saturday night in the main ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania. The event, which will mark the sixty-sixth anniversary of the founding of the organization, will be held under the honorary chairmanship of Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General at New York.

The Very Rev. Edward J. Walsh, president of St. John's University, emphasized the need for additional Catholic action yesterday in an address to 1,200 members of Columbus Council, K. of C., at a communion breakfast held in Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

Gaining their third consecutive victory by defeating the West Side Club, 8 1/2-11/2, the players of the Marshall Chess Club held first place in the annual championship tournament of the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday.

Walter Hagen, veteran professional, has been appointed captain of the 1937 United States Ryder Cup golf team, George R. Jacobus, president of the Professional Golfers' Assoc'ation, announced yesterday through The Associated Press from his Winter headquarters at Sarasota, Fla.

A new string quartet by Hindemith, No. 14, Opus 32, was played for the first time in New York at the concert given for the benefit of the Composers Fund by the League of Composers last night in Town Hall. Bohuslav Ma??tinu's string quintet with piano was also heard for the first time here, and Eva Gautier sang groups of modern songs in various languages and by suitably contrasted composers.

Cautiously astronomers suggest the sun is experiencing, or is about to experience, its most violent eruptions since the turn of the century. Sun spots are increasing steadily, both in number and size.

The radio direction finder developed by Pan American Airways on its routes across the Caribbean Sea and the Pacific Ocean is to be made available to all airlines, it was announced yesterday by Vincent Elendix, president of the Bendix Aviaation Corporation.

Harlen Henderson, 32 years old, and his wife, Mary, 30, were found dead of suffocation by gas at their home at Benjamin Avenue and Green Street here today. Their dog also was smothered. Coroner Eugene J. Mullen of Middlesex County said death was accidental.
The finalists in last year's classic came through successfully in the first round of the annual Miami international four-ball golf matches at the Miami Country Club today.

A collection of first editions of Catholic Bibles printed in this country prior to 1860, which is considered to be the most complete in existence, is now being catalogued at Georgetown University and will shortly be placed on public exhibition for the first time, it was disclosed here yesterday.

Artur Rodzinski completed his second week at the head of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The first half of the program contained compositions that he had directed some days before--Handel's "Water Music Suite" and Dohnanyi's Variations on a Nursery Air for orchestra and piano obbligato with Arthur Loesser as the soloist.

Funeral services for Dr. William T. Hornaday, first director of the New York Zoological Park and noted naturalist and protector of wild life, who died at the age of 82 in his home here last night, will be held on Tuesday at 11:30 A. M. in the First Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. George Stewart. Burial, which will be private, will take place in Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich.

Jean Aerts and Omer Debruycker of Belgium, who won the six-day bicycle race which ended in Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, were feted at a dinner given in their honor at the Unione Sportiva Italiana, New York's largest Italian cycling club, last night.

With the Most Rev. John T. McNicholas, Archbishop of Cincinnati, presiding, a solemn high military mass was held yesterday morning in honor of the Feast of St. Thomas Aquinas, patron saint of Catholic youth and education, at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Work on the development of the housing and slum rehabilitation program for this city, which was announced recently by the Citizens Housing Council, will begin immediately, according to a statement yesterday by Harold S. Buttenheim, chairman of the council.
Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Tollefsen of 946 President Street, Brooklyn, gave a large reception and tea yesterday afternoon at their home in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Spalding.

Many members of the Miami Beach colony and some from Palm Beach attended this afternoon the first horse show to be held on Miami Beach in sixteen years. It was sponsored by the Flamingo Polo Club in connection with the club's annual gymkhana.

For the first time in two years an open season on beaver has been declared in New York. A recent survey disclosed that there were sufficient numbers of the animals in several counties and accordingly the Conservation Department has declared that beaver may be trapped this year.

Little Miss Helene Rains of the Women's Swimming Association of New York joined the ranks of the titleholders yesterday by capturing the junior national A. A. U. 300yard indoor medley championship for women in record time, to feature the meet held in the seventyfive-foot W. S. A. pool.

Charles (Lady) Baldwin, old-time professional baseball pitcher, died today at his home here. He was 79 years old. Baldwin pitched the Detroit National League team to Detroit's first world 'championship in 1887.

Former basketball players at Columbia University have presented a new cup for competition in the Eastern Intercollegiate League to be known as the Claus D. Benson Memorial Trophy, it was announced yesterday by William MacRossie, chairman of Columbia's alumni basketball committee.

Republican women from all sections of New York State will be here tomorrow and Tuesday for the annual legislative conference of the Republican Educational League, of which Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, vice chairman of the Republican State committee, is chairman.

Delegates from twenty-one steel mills in the Beaver Valley district registered approval in suburban Ambridge today of President Roosevelt's proposal to revamp the Supreme Court and assailed William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.
E. N. Bisso's 4-year-old gelding, Whipwill, going in his best form, won the mile and a sixteenth Roses Warrington House purse that topped the program at the Fair Grounds today.
Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Chinese generalissimo, will receive a warm welcome in Japan when she passes through on her way to the United States soon, it was indicated today.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Goldman, Sachs Co.; White, Weld Co., and Wellington Co. will offer today at $98.50 a share a new issue of 100,000 shares of Spiegel, Inc., $4.50 cumulative preferred stock without par value.
The Leipzig Spring Fair, which marked the Initiation of Germany's new export drive, closes tomorrow with what the German press characterizes as "very satisfactory results."

The Reich will have no difficulty in paying for the imports of cereals and fodder. According to the Nazi press service, three-quarters of that import already is arranged for, which means that the Reich has the necessary exchange to pay for it.

The City Commission will meet tomorrow for tentative adoption of the 1937 budget, on the basis of which the amount to be raised by taxation for all purposes here has been estimated by city fiscal officers at $36,991,426.
The Italian Navy is considerably more powerful than indicated in the British official "fleets," according to Hector Bywater, naval correspondent of The Daily Telegraph.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday its support of Mayor La Guardia and William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, in their efforts to remove pushcart markets from the city streets and to establish the peddlers in enclosed areas.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Well, well! So at our Fair we are to have a "building dedicated to religious freedom" from which "propaganda is to be spread." To this may be added a "chamber of horrors" in which are to be placed images of those we do not like.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Matthew S. Reeves of Garden City, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Reeves, to Delevan Shields Mussey of Pittsburgh, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Mussey of Chicago.

Dr. and Mrs. Dudley Crawford Hughes gave a dinner last night in the Bowman Room of the Biltmore. Among their guests were-Dr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Pheiffer, Dr. Cecil H. Fletcher and Mrs. C. E, Murphy.

Figures made public yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute disclosed that employment in the steel industry increased by 11,000 workers in January, bringing the total with jobs at the end of that month to 548.000.

Three per cent dollar funding bonds of the Konversionskasse fur Deutsche Auslandsschulden (Conversion Office for German Foreign Debts), in the authorized amount of $65,000,000 will be offered formally today to United States holders of coupons of approximately 120 issues of German dollar obligations in satisfaction of overdue interest for the period from July 1, 1934, to Dec. 31, 1936.

The Black Hawks retained a slim mathematical chance of reaching the Stanley Cup' play-offs tonight by battling to a 2-2 overtime tie with Toronto in one of the fastest National Hockey League games seen here this season.

More than 700 men and women leaders of Jewish organizations on Long Island attended yesterday the eighth annual convention of the Long Island branch of the United Synagogue of America in the Jamaica Jewish Center. Dr. Harry L. Bisnoff, who presided at the three sessions of the convention, was reelected president of the chapter.

Alf Engen of Salt Lake City, ski-jumping champion of the United States, today won the Canadian crown before 4,000 spectators. At Mount Norquay, Engen made two leaps, soaring 194 feet on his first and 208 on his second.

Governor LEHMAN'S final radio plea for ratification of the child labor amendment was as persuasive in substance as it was temperate and conciliatory in tone. He began by pointing out that the amendment is neither radical nor partisan. It was passed by a two-thirds vote of each house during a Republican Administration.

John J. Curtin, special counsel for the Transit Commission, who recently was accused by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr. of "picking out of thin air" figures tending to discredit their $436,000,000 transit unification plan, struck back yesterday, charging that they were carrying on "a campaign of deception trying to fool the people."

Four fellowships are again being offered for young writers by the Breadloaf Writers' Conference of Middlebury College for the 1937 session from Aug. 18 to Sept. 1, Theodore Morrison of Harvard, director of the conference, has announced.

The stock feasible to market here, which was undecided the greater part of this week, turned suddenly strong late on Friday upon the announcement that the government will permit the paymeat to stockholders of excess dividends that had been impounded In the gold discount bank under a law of 1934.

Reports of hunger riots and warlike preparations of disaffected generals in far inland Szechwan Province were coupled here tonight with the revelation that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek had left secretly for the interior.

A nation-wide search for Mrs. Helen K. Harper, 33 years old, on a forgery indictment charging a shortage of about $50,000 in the accounts of a lumber company that employed her, was revealed yesterday.

The sixth and final opera of the Wagner matinee cycle will be "The Flying Dutchman," and it will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday, March 18. The cast will be headed by Kirsten Flagstad, Doris Doe, Rene Maison, Friedrich Schorr, Emanuel List and Hans Clemens, with Artur Bodanzky conducting.
St. Mary's Celtics rallied in the second half to gain a 2-2 tie with the Brookhattan Soccer Club before 4,000 fans at Starlight Park yesterday.

Pieretto Bianco, scenic director of the Scala Opera House in Milan and former scenic artist. of the Metropolitan Opera in New York, died yesterday. He was 60 years old. He is survived by his widow, the former Miss Mildred Turner of San Francisco, now a music teacher in Boston. She is en route to Italy.

Edouard Herriot, Mayor of Lyon and President of the Chamber of Deputies, is suffering from acute bronchitis with a high fever. He will be unable to take part in the opening of the Lyon Fair and will be forced to cancel other official engagements.

A supreme decree recently created a Section of Propaganda, Publications and Culture in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to encourage tourist traffic and by means of the radio, motion pictures and publications make Peru known abroad.

Aside from being an interesting melodrama, "Nancy Steele Is Missing," the new Twentieth CenturyFox film at the Rivoli, represents as glib a double-cross of the Hays code as the screen has executed this year.

The Spanish Cabinet has just weathered a storm from which Premier Francisco Largo Caballero emerges as the strong man. There has been no crisis in the ordinary sense, for no Cabinet member resigned. Yet there were serious differences and part of the press openly attacked Mr. Largo Caballero.
Because of the suppression of private trading in foreign securities and the government's unexpected decision concerning dividends, this week's stock market developed abnormally.

The five-story red brick dwelling with American basement and elevator at 6 East Sixty-ninth Street, near Fifth Avenue, has been sold by Thomas M. Peters to a buyer for occupancy. Occupying a lot 25 by 100 feet adjoining the home of Ogden Mills, the building is assessed at $105,000.

I am in the midst of a dust storm. The conductor tells me it is the first bad dust storm of 1937, and one of the worst he has seen in two years. Through the car window I can see telegraph poles, some twenty feet from the roadbed.

Tammany's Assembly district leaders, who make up its executive committee, are considering a proposal to elect an acting leader of Tammany to serve during the city campaign, it was learned yesterday. A meeting of the executive committee to put this proposal into effect will be sought about the first week in April.

With William H. Gallagher's Rudie as the probable favorite in the featured Pan American Handicap, the second meeting of the Gables Racing Association will get under way tomorrow at Tropical Park. Eleven are named for the sprint, one of six stakes during the twenty-fourday session which will continue until April 3.

Cotton prices scored one of the largest advances in years last week, reaching the highest levels touched since pre-depression times. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active months advanced 85 to 105 points in the week, following a rise of 16 to 47 points the week previous. Trading volume was the largest in many months.

Miss Silvia White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris White of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, was married to Justin Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Wolf of Omaha, Neb., yesterday noon in the Washington Square Room of the hotel. Dr. Leo Jung officiated.

Of all European capitals London has probably changed the most in the past year. This applies to the physical aspect, to the quickening of business and social activity and, above all, to the state of mind.
In an address the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street, yesterday morning, Mr. Jacques Kayser, professor at the Ecole des Hautes Etudes Internationales,

The 1937 oil burner sales drive will get under way in Philadelphia next Monday, when the Fourteenth National Oil Burner and Air-Conditioning Exposition opens at Convention Hall. Practically all companies have sharply expanded their advertising budgets this year and expect to mark up new sales records.

The French wholesale price index again increased slightly on Feb. 27 to 517, compared with 516 in the previous week and 514 on Feb. 13. As in the previous week, the rise was due solely to imports of industrial materials.

The body of Alphonse Gaulin, former Amierican Consul General in Paris, remained at the Morgue yesterday with no word from his wife and daughters, who are abroad, or from relatives in Woonsocket, R. I., his. home city.
Continuing his advocacy of a union of churches, John D. Rockefeller Jr. suggested this evening that the eleven Protestant churches of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown form a cooperative church center.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. May of 103 East Eighty-fourth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elsie Wise May, to Albert Philip Gross, son of Mrs. Edward Gross of the Hyde Park Hotel, 25 East Seventy-seventh Street, and New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mr. Gross.

The Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, suggested in his sermon yesterday morning that "the shabby results and sorry failures we make of our religion are largely due to lack of what the artist calls technique." Dr. Merrill further said:

While some of the 184 officers and crew of the Finnish naval training frigate Suomen Joutsen spent the day sightseeing here yesterday, or paying official or personal calls, a crowd estimated at between 5,000 and 10,000 persons visited the ship, which is docked at the foot of Thirty-fifth Street in the North River.
Mr. and Mrs. Sosthenes Behn will return from Europe on the Bremen today and will be at the Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Wallace Orr of the Pierre have sailed for Bermuda, to remain until June 15.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, ruled 'today that employable widows who have been dropped from the WPA rolls and who are not receiving Social Security benefits shall be restored to their jobs at once.
Dr. Leon Felderman, a captain in the Medical Corps in France during the World War, has been cited for the St. Mihiel Medal and has been made a member of the Societe Plastique et Morphologi of Paris.

Officials of the United Automobile Workers of America prepared to resume collective bargaining conferences with General Motors, Chrysler and the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporations tomorrow as week-end settlements of sit-down strikes called 2,500 workmen back to three Detroit parts plants.

In a sour moment The Cleveland Plain Dealer permits itself to say that in two months the lower house of the Ohio Legislature "has accomplished "about as much useful legislative busi"ness as can be carried in the left eye "of a gentleman with a squint."

Legislators returning to the capital tonight were prepared for a final showdown on ratification of the Child Labor Amendment on Tuesday, when the Kleinfeld resolution will come up for a vote in the Assembly.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the granting, of an application of the New England Power Association to acquire in the open market from time to time not to exceed 85,022 shares of Class A stock of the International HydroElectric System, to meet obligations under expiring option warrants.

A record of mortgage obligation payments by Home Owners Loan Corporation borrowers, described by Charles A. Jones, general manager, as "a memorial to the essential honesty, the bulldog tenacity, the recuperative powers of the average American citizen," was made publie today by the corporation.

The recommendations of the majority of the Nye Munitions Committee that the government set up a Council of American Shipbuilders were characterized by the National Council of American Shipbuilders, as economically unsound, a menace to peace and detrimental to the best interests of the navy.

Reports of the condition of all Federal Reserve member banks at the end of 1936 show, according to the Federal Reserve Bulletin made public today, that the outstanding developments of the year were a considerable growth, for the first time since 1929,- in commercial borrowings from banks,
With students throughout the country preparing to hold their annual peace strike next month, the Teachers Union announced yesterday that it had urged Dr. John S. Roberts,

Rideau Co., Inc., the Oregon Trail Memorial Assn., George Schatt and Distillers Factors, Inc., in 1,775 Broadway; Gardiner Advertising Co., in 9 Rockefeller Plaza; Charles F. Noyes Co., broker. Charles H. Kaplan, printing plates, in 22 W. 21st St.; Gate of Hope, Inc., in 1, 422 St. Nicholas Av.; Creative Productive Ideas, Inc., and Academy of Display, Inc., advertising, in 8 E. 41st St.: Byrne Bowman, Inc.. broker.
The Bzooklyn College tennis team will engage in eleven dual encounters this season, according to the schedule released by Louis R. Oshins, business manager of athletics, yesterday.

The Dutch are unable to appreciate President Roosevelt's judiciary reform, because the fullest independence of judges is one of the leading principles of the Dutch Constitution and of the inveterate Dutch sense of justice and freedom.

Dizzy Dean is all through with baseball-and this word comes from Mrs. Dizzy Dean. Only $50,000 written on a contract will draw Dizzy back to his old stand with the St. Louis Cardinals, Mrs. Dean told newspaper men who name here for an interview.

Militant opposition to communism was urged by Senator A. Harry Moore of New Jersey at the twelfth annual communion breakfast of the Order of Seville yesterday at the Hotel Astor. Members of the organization, composed of Catholic employes of the American Railway Express Company in the New York area,
Men may boast of some vices, but they never brag of hypocrisy, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday morning at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The seizure on Saturday by the customs officials in Brooklyn of $200,000 worth of smoking opium from Shanghai is dramatic evidence that the United States also is threatened by "the opium menace in the Far East."

General elections for a new Chamber of Deputies and half the Senate were held today throughout Chile without any major clashes. The results are not known officially but the impression prevails that the Right Wing parties, consisting of the Conservative,

Soy bean trading here was irregular last week. There were buying orders for cash and futures on weak spots and profit-taking by holders of futures on price advances. The May position closed at $1.433/8 a bushel, a net advance of 1/8 cent over the previous week's finish, while the July closed at $1.503/4, unchanged.

Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Scudder of The Orchards, in suburban Sherborn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hilda Chapin Scudder, to James Higginson Manning, son of Wayland Manning and the late Mrs. Manning.

Absent two years from Broadway, Helen Howe came to the Little Theatre last evening for a single performance, bringing with -her those "Characters and Caricatures" that prove her again an able and amiable monologist.
Marshall Eldredge of East Weymouth, Mass., scored 2,119 points to place first in the two-day outboard motor boat regatta which ended today.
The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin told a radio audience today that-"we are very near a national crisis"-the "passing of a nation."

Austrian monarchists celebrated today the union of all factions at a meeting in Vienna. The principal speaker was Count von Mirbach, who was described as Archduke Otto's aidede-camp, who recently came to Vienna from the pretender's home in Steenockerzeel, Belgium, to unite the factions.

An offring of $502,361,900 in 21/2 percent Treasury bonds due in 1935 and callable in 1949 was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau on a strictly exchange basis for an equal amount of 3 per cent notes maturing April 15. None will be sold for cash.

The decisions of the Council of Ministers on Brithday put an end to the uncertainty which had reigned for a fortnight and had caused heaviness on the Bourse in the week. For several months the Blum government had declared its chief concern was to bring boarded and exported capital back into circulation. Hitherto this effort had failed.

Major Gen. Sir Ronald Lane, distinguished soldier and sportsman, who fought through three African campaigns--the Zulu in 1879, the Egyptian in 1882 and the Boar War, being mentioned in dispatches on each occasion--died here today at the age of 90.
Men may boast of some vices, but they never brag of hypocrisy, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday morning at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

A Turkish tobacco stalk, grown from a seed the size of a grain of sand to a six-foot giant within four months, is one of the results of successful experimentation with chemical nutrients for plants cultured in pure sand in the botanical laboratories of Columbia University.
The recent attack by Mayor La Guardia on Adolf Hitler and the Nazi government was approved yesterday at an all-day interstate conferece of the Non-Sectatian AntiNazi League in the Hotel Astor.

Neil Sullivan and Roy Coffin of Philadelphia won their sixth straight national squash racquets doubles title tonight. The Pennsylvania champions conquered Andrew C. Ingraham and Teroy Weir of Cleveland, 17-15, 15-14, 15-6. in the final.

PIERREPONT B. NOYES was a Community's child, a result of an experiment of eugenics. His parents were intensely religious people who hoped to be perfect. They were attempting to establish social conditions under which sin could be eliminated. They had decided that the main causes behind sin were the desires of men for women, money and power.

Dan O'Mahoney and Chief Little Wolf will come to grips in the feature wrestling exhibition at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory tonight. O'Mahoney, former claimant to the world's heavyweight championship, is eager to wrestle his way back to his one-time eminence in the division.

Large blocks of railroad, real estate and foreign bonds featured the announcements last week of securities called for redemption before maturity. Notices were more numerous than in the preceding week, but, except -for some small municipal and foreign additions to the list for March, they were for bonds to be retired in future months.

Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin gave a tea yesterday at her home, 6 East Eigthy-second Street, for her daughter, Miss Judith Hamlin, whose marriage to Charles Percy Frederick North, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick North of Rougham Hall, Norfolk, England, will take place here Thursday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church.

American voting machines may help record the results of Soviet Russia's first nation-wide elections, an authoritative source said today. The elections will be those for Deputies of the Supreme Council, which will be the Soviet Parliament under Russia's new Constitution, and for lesser provincial and village officials.

Counting confidently on time as an ally, the supporters of President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan have laid out a schedule for an aggressive nation-wide fight to press the advantage which they strongly feel that the President's Victory Dinner address has given them.

The bock beer season will open officially on Monday, March 15, in New York City and many States east of the Mississippi, it was announced yesterday by Rudolph J. Schaefer, president of the Brewers Board of Trade. He said, however, that this year there would be no bock beer goat "beauty contest" like those staged -last year and in 1934.

All opposition parties held meetwings tonight to protest against the reported Nazi plot to seize power in Hungary. "No corporal or pocket Hitler is going to introduce the sway of the un-Christian swastika over us," dedared Deputy Makray, a Monarchist, to an enthusiastic mass meeting in Szeged.

There is no reason to attach any particular significance to the large expansion of [Pound]5,887,000 in the Bank of England's circulation in the last week. This compares with an increase of f4,147,000 in the corresponding week last year, and this year's more rapid rise is doubtless due to the greater activity in trade.

The approach of a tense competition, in which housewife will be pitted against housewife, recipe against recipe, while sports commentators describe to an eager audience the breaking of each egg, the sifting of each cup of flour, was heralded yesterday in a communication-from the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries.
It is more than a little sad in this issue between Mr. ROOSEVELT and the Supreme Court to find people harking

Lotte Lehmann, the Metropolitan dramatic soprano, gave a recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon for the benefit of the educational and philanthropic work of the New York Society for Ethical Culture. At this, her second appearance on the local concert-platform this season, the popular vocalist again was greeted by a capacity audience.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Recent Trends in the Orient," S. L. Joshi. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Social Security and Public Relief," James J. Wadsworth.
Scotland Yard officials today were confronted by a mass of conflicting testimony in their efforts to solve the disappearance at sea of Frank Vosper, British actor and dramatist.

One fireman was killed, another's leg was broken, and six were overcome by smoke or slightly injured in fighting an extremely smoky, stubborn fire which raged for five hours early yesterday morning at 81 Prospect Street, Brooklyn.

Regarding the future course of European rates for long-term loans, the Dutch hesitate to give an outspoken opinion because much depends on developments in each country. Nevertheless, the view gained ground here that rearmament, coupled with the rally in commodity prices and the general agricultural and industrial recovery and possible expansion of world trade, tends to stiffen long-term rates.
Taxicabs were all but unobtainable in Chicago tonight as drivers strove during the third day of their strike to perfect the newly founded Midwest Taxi Drivers Union.

Christian fraternity as exemplified in the "democracy of the communion rail" is the only solution of the social and economic problems of the day, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University. of America, Washington, D. C., declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's cathedral.

To Miss Anne H. Fuller of Milton, Mass., has been awarded the Margaret E. Maltby Fellowship of $1,500 by the American Association of University Women, according to word received at the Radcliffe Graduate School. Miss Fuller, a Radcliffe graduate, will sail April 18 for Syria, where she will study a Syrian Moslem peasant village in the Lebanon region.

Paul Bekker, music critic and author of many internationally known books on music, died early yesterday at his home, 43 West Seventy-fifth street, after a long illness. Death was due to a heart ailment. Mr. Bekker was 54 years old. He is survived by his widow and four children, living in New York, Basel and Berlin.

An advance of 24 per cent in food imports in January more than accounted for a 15 per cent increase in the combined foodstuffs export and import trade of the United States in that month, according to preliminary figures just made public by the Department of Commerce.

Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, recommended yesterday the establishment of a clearing house for crutches, wheel chairs, medical appliances and the names of all needy persons in the State who have suffered from paralysis or similar diseases.

Peter J. Smith of 2,797 Marion Avenue, Bronx, who retired in 1931 as a statistician at the custom house, this city, died yesterday morning in the Union Hospital, Bronx, of a heart ailment with complications. He was born in New York seventy-five years ago.

Rising prices featured the livestock markets here last week, the best steers selling at $15 a hundredweight, the highest price of the season, while lambs touched $11.75, the highest level for a March since 1929. Decreased receipts and increased buying power were said to be. responsible for the strong markets.

E. J. Lever, field director for the Atlantic Coast division of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, said tonight that leaders of the Lewis Committee for Industrial Organization planned to seek negotiations soon for contracts with the Crucible Steel Company that would be "identical to the one reached with Carnegie-Illinois."
MY FATHER'S HOUSE: AN ONEIDA BOYHOOD, by Pierrepont B. Noyes. (Farrar Rinehart, $3.50.) The autobiography of a son of the founder of the Oneida Community.

Pennsylvania added two victories to its string in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League last week and now needs only a triumph over Princeton in its final game on Saturday to finish its circuit season unbeaten and tie the record made by Columbia last Winter when the Lions won all twelve contests.

The First Division poloists of Brooklynwere defeated by the 112th Field Artillery unit of Red Bank, 101/2 to 5 1/2 today at the Red Bank Armory. In another game, Winmont Farms a won from the Red Bank Polo Club, 11 to 8.

A week-length celebration of West Orange's seventy-fifth anniversary opened here today with services in all churches and a concert by the West Orange Symphony Orchestra. The concert, which was attended by nearly 1,500 persons, was held in the West Orange High School auditorium under the direction of Jennings Butterfield. The guest soloist was Wolf Persinger, New York violinist.

The failure of the many branches of the Christian church to unite into one great church is not the obstacle to the forward march of Christianity that many people would have us believe, the Rev. J. V. Moldenhawer, minister of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The proposal of the Bergenfield Townsend Club to conduct a Townsend recovery-plan experiment here as an example for the metropolitan area, gained the support today of the Mayor, officials of the bank and leading merchants. The "pensioner" is to be selected regardless of age.

Coats and suits were foremost In wholesale apparel activity last week, although order and reorder business was brisk in all lines. Fleece-coated sport and casual suits, fleece coats and mannish suits were called for in volume, and interest increased in dressy coats.
Criticism of the Board of Aldermen for failing to obey a mandate of the voters by delaying reorganization of county offices was expressed yesterday by officials of the City Fusion party.

Two Americans were dropped from the board of directors of Dominion Stores, Ltd., at the annual meeting today. Plans were announced for taking the stock off the New York Stock Exchange and listing it on the Montreal Exchange so as to bolster Canadian interests in the company.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins expressed confidence last night that the new strikes in automobile plants of the Chrysler and other companies in Detroit would be settled amicably and without much difficulty.

Net profit of the American Tobacco Company and subsidiaries for 1936 amounted to $20,183,821, after all expenses, charges, depreciation and taxes excluding $57,602 net appropriation for taxes in prior years, equivalent after preferred dividends to $3.70 a share on 4,593,912 Class B and common shares.

An order to "cease and desist" from unfair methods of competition in the sale of flavoring extracts has been entered by the Federal Trade Commission against the National Kream Company, Inc., 360 Furman Street, Brooklyn, the commission announced today.

John Spellman, 27 years old, known to the police as "Shirts," was shot and killed about 4:30 A. M. yesterday in the Clarendon Restaurant, 1,145 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Only two other customers were in the establishment at the time.

Exports of Canadian lumber to the United States have resulted in a shortage of lumber in many parts of the Dominion and an increase in price of from $5 to $10 per thousand feet in Ottawa, lumber merchants said here today.
Some statistics pertaining to the activities of fishermen and hunters during the past year have been announced by Frank T. Bell, Commissioner of Fisheries, Department of Commerce.

A WPA engineer, acting as a supervisor on a sewer project in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, was accused yesterday of having operated a payroll racket which included the payment of $2 bonuses to workers for taking afternoons off.

The National Labor Relations Board will begin hearings at 45 Broadway this morning on charges that the Grace Line has been discriminating against its sea-going personnel in violation of collective bargaining provisions of the Federal law. Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick.

Miss Pauline Raymond, 18 years old, was seriously injured early today when she fell or jumped, according to the police, from a window of the top floor of the six-story house occupied by her family at 7 East Eighty-ninth Street.

Gilmore D. Clarke of New York City, designer of the Hutchinson River and Mount Vernon Parkways, said this afternoon in a Trowbridge lecture at the Yale Art School that the Merritt Highway in this State was extravagant in construction and antique in design.
Columbia's flotilla of nine crews worked out yesterday on the Harlem River as the Blue completed the transference of its rowing activities from Morningside Heights to Baker Field.

MANHATTAN CALLAHAN, ROSE (Dec. 23). Estate, $25,879. To Mary A. Callahan, sister, 332 E. 123d St.. executrix, residue; three specific bequests. GLUCK, DAVID L. (Jan. 24). Estate, less than $10,000. To Mark Wise, 15 Leo Pl.. Newark, N. J., Louis M. Hart, 14 Flint Av., Larchmont, N. Y., brothers-inlaw; Henry Gluck, brother, 29 Leo Pl.;

The Spanish motorship Mar Cantabrico, which gained notoriety when she sailed from New York Jan. 6 with airplanes and other munitions and supplies for the Madrid Government, tonight lies at the bottom of the bay of Biscay.

The Oratorio Society of New York will present "St. Matthew's Passion" by Bach in the Gothic nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Tuesday evening, May 11, it was announced yesterday by Bishop Manning.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Red Star Sightseeing Line, Inc., today to operate round-trip sightseeing and pleasure tours from Brooklyn to points in New Jersey, New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania.
It was officially announced tonight that the coronation year had begun with a rise in the number of foreign visitors to Great Britain.
Paulie Walker of Trenton, N. J., beat Bobby Wilson of Washington last night before 2,500 spectators in the feature bout at St. Nicholas Palace.
Francois Arago, one of the directors of the Petit Parisien, died at his home here today at the age. of 75. He entered the diplomatic service as a young man but' left it in 1903 to enter Parliament.

Of the $74,948,202 allotted by the Public Works Administration to non-Federal hospitals, $16,574,843, the largest amount for any State, went for construction in New York, $14,095,540 of it in the City of- New York.

As a present to Chancellor Adolf Hitler on his forty-eighth birthday, April 20, the Reich Postal Department will issue new stamps bearing his portrait. 'The stamps are now being prepared in all the usual denominations.

The United States Circuit Court set aside yesterday the conviction last November of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter for violating the Sherman Anti-trust Law in New York's $10,000,000-a-year-rabbit fur dressing trade.

Stephen A. Ruddy, leader of the Sixteenth Assembly District, has been asked by James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, to look after organization matters during the latter's absence in Florida. Mr. Dooling's request, made last Saturday, followed talks between the Tammany leader and a majority of the members of the Tammany executive committee.

The engagement of Miss Evelyn Beryl Blenheim, daughter of Mrs. William J. Blenheim of this city and the late Mr. Blenheim, to Edward Marsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Capron Marsh, also of East Orange, has been announced by Mrs. Blenheim.

Continued reports filtering through from Africa concerning scenes of horror in Addis Ababa when the Itallans took reprisals for the recent attempt to assassinate- Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, their Viceroy for East Africa, are beginning to stir up public opinion here. Today these reports received some official corroboration from Viscount Cranborne, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, in the House of Commons.

About 2,000 Journeyman members of the Printing Pressmen's and Assistants Union No. 2 took part yesterday in an election of officers under the supervision of a committee appointed by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo.

James A. Farrell Jr., president of the American South African Line, announced yesterday that the company had completed arrangements to purchase the freighter Challenger from the Sun Shipbuilding Company of Chester, Pa.

Three Long Island University basketball players gained places on the all-metropolitan team that was picked yesterday by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association. They were Jules Bender, Art Hillhouse and Ben Kramer.

Miss Ruth B. Cavanagh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Stewart Cavanagh of Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to George Le Blanc Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Le Blanc of 125 East Seventy-second Street, which will take place the morning of April 15 in the Church of the Holy Innocents in Brooklyn.
Young Sylvanus Apps of the Toronto Maple Leafs is just a point behind Detroit's sharpshooting Larry Aurie in the race for scoring leadership of the National Hockey League.
Allegheny County, Pa., will come into the market on March 27 with an offering of $5,500,000 of road, bridge, park, tunnel and building improvement bonds, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Margaret Gaulin, widow of Alphonse Gaulin, American Consul General in Paris from 1926 to 1929, arrived here early yesterday from her home at 629 Clarke Place, Wellmount, Montreal, and claimed her husband's body.
The Albemarle County grand jury at an unannounced session late today indicted Dr. R. G. Miller, Charlottesville dentist, on a charge of murder in the death of Cleo Sprouse on March 1.

The American Federation of Labor is about to undertake a drive to organize workers in the steel fabrication plants of the nation in opposition to the Committee for Industrial Organization, it was announced tonight by President William Green.

Because another Monday has passed without bringing a decision by the Supreme Court on the legality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act, it need not be assumed that the procedure in this case is in any way exceptional.

Bronx apartment properties furnished a major share of the activity in New York realty sales reported by brokers yesterday. Among the houses figuring in the day's trading was the six-story building at 1,307 Washington Avenue, which was purchased by the Eskar Realty Corporation from Arthur F. Danziger through Siviglia Giordano, brokers.

Deputy Controller Milton Solomon conferred yesterday with a committee of the National Association of Physically Disabled on the possibilities of having the city establish recreation centers with therapeutic pools in each of the five boroughs.
Dr. John F. Roderer, a physician who began practice in North Philadelphia fifty-three years ago, died at his home here last night at the age of 79.
Dr. Jesse Feiring Williams, Professor of Education at Teachers College, proposed a course in social dancing in the public school curriculum in a radio speech yesterday on "Health Activities."

The twentieth century jumped into existence overnight for Denver Arbogast, 14-year-old hero of a West Virginia blizzard, whose brief life had been as elemental as the red clay of his mountain home until yesterday, when he arrived in New York to attend a radio dramatization of his bravery.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was uneven, fair to slow. Steer beef sold strong to higher and the lamb market was higher. Some of the major cuts of pork were higher and the others mostly steady.
With the conclusion of this year's Town Hall endowment series tomorrow evening the management made public yesterday the artists who will appear in this series next season.

King George II, who is visiting Crete, created a surprise today when, with Premier John Metaxas, he visited Eleutherios Venizelos's grave, where Cretans had raised a great memorial to their celebrated compatriot.

The failure of undercarriages and their accessories such as brakes, wheels and tires was responsible for 25 per cent of the airline accidents in the last six months, a report made public today by the Bureau of Air Commerce indicated. Pilot and personnel error was blamed for 37.5 per cent of the accidents. The report included all airline planes, whether they carried passengers or passengers and mail or mail and express only.

The Louisville Refining Company filed. injunction proceedings and a $50,000 damage suit in Circuit Court today against twenty-eight former employes now picketing the plant. Judge Churchill Humphrey set a hearing for Wednesday.

While suggesting that the National Labor Relations Board should delay hearings under the Wagner act pending decision by the Supreme Court on its constitutionality, Federal Judge William Clark indicated today he would dismiss a restraint against board hearings, obtained by the Condenser Corporation of America, of South Plainfield.

Felix M. Warburg announced last night at a meeting of the board of trustees of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at the Hotel Plaza that Lawrence Marx had been elected President of the federation.

An adjustment of Japanese-American trade relations whereby Japan will buy more cotton from the United States on reciprocal terms is one of the aims of the Japanese trade mission that will visit the United States in May, headed by Chokyuro Kadono, noted industrialist.
Maureen Orcutt Crews, a leading golf player for a decade, filed suit today to divorce John D. Crews, bond broker. Mental-cruelty was charged.
Assemblyman Julian Thruston of Las Vegas introduced today an amendment to the divorce statutes reducing the residence requirement to thirty days.

Thomas D. Flynn, hard-hitting Princeton Club representative, defeated Charles Fechheimer Jr. of the City A. C. yesterday at the Crescent Athletic Club to capture the National Class B squash tennis championship.

The United Stockyards Corporation announced today the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering new issues of $1,700,000 of 4 1/4 per cent collateral trust bonds due in 1951, 130,000 shares of convertible preferred stock and 65,875 shares of no-par common stock.

The Cardinals had two more stiff practice sessions in hot, sultry weather today and the infield formation appeared about set. At any rate, the way affairs shape up now Johnny Mize will be at first base, Leo Durocher at short and Don Gutteridge at third.
The Rev. Charles Anderson Austin, pastor emeritus of the College Hill Presbyterian Church, died at his home here today at the age of 69. He received his education here and at Williams College.
Engagement of Princess Dolores of Bourbon, niece of the pretender to the French throne, to Prince Auguste Czartoryski of the Lithuanian house was announced tonight.

Nellie Gutowski, 20 years old, who was suspected of many early-morning restaurant holdups on the upper West Side, suddenly pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Bohan in General Sessions to third-degree robbery.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Palmer Ten Eyck of Lawrence Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edna Marian Ten Eyck, to Alan Thompson, son of Judge and Mrs. Lloyd Thompson of this place.

The Australian Federal Government, like our own, is a Government of limited and enumerated powers, subject to a Constitution. If it wishes to expand those powers it must submit a constitutional amendment.

The participation of Catholic school children in missionary work through contributions to Rome has increased materially in the last three years, the Rev. Joseph Rossenbach of Pittsburgh, national director of the Association of the Holy Childhood, said yesterday.

Deputy Fire Commissioner Francis X. Giaccone reserved decision yesterday on departmental charges against Captain Louis Goldschnelder of Engine Company 76, and Fireman Thomas McLoughlin of that company.

In line with his own opinion handed down last January, Federal Judge Mack entered yesterday a decree permanently enjoining the Electric Bond and Share Company and twelve of its affiliates from violating provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
Hogs sold generally 5 to 10 cents higher today with the better grade showing the most strength, due to smaller receipts and somewhat higher prices for fresh pork loins.
A Federal grant of $50,734.73 to New York State to help finance its Unemployment Insurance Law was announced today by the Social Security Board.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, comprising the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx, received more than $500,000 above the quota requested for flood relief, it was announced with the closing of the drive yesterday.

Charles Kroner, 56 years old, a WPA carpenter, of.2,916 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested yesterday on a charge of homicide in the death of Thomas E. Storey, 40, an iron worker, of 140B Edgewater Camp, Throgs Neck, the Bronx.

The National City Bank, as special agent, has notified holders of State of Minas Geraes (Brazil) 6 1/2 per cent external sinking fund gold bonds due in 1958 and external gold loan 6 1/2 per cent Series A bonds due in 1959, that funds have been received for the payment of March 1, 1937, coupons at the rate of 25 per cent of their face amount.

Viscount Swinton, the 52-year-old Air Secretary, who is officially declared to be suffering from "a tired heart," is to take a month's rest. During his absence "general supervision" over the work of the Air Ministry will be maintained by Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for the Coordination of Defense.

With the last pair of week-end games against Havana's dexterous professionals showing a marked and decided improvement, the Giants.today swung briskly into their third and final week of training here, which now has for its immediate objective the two clashes with the Cardinals next Saturday and Sunday.

How right was the Frenchman who said that everything is relative is beautifully illustrated by the present state of public and Congressional interest in the broad plan to reorganize the government which was submitted by the President a few weeks ago;
Net profit of the Johns-Manville Corporation and subsidiary companies amounted to $4,373,707 in 1936 after deducting provision for depreciation, depletion, obsolescence and Federal taxes.
Sit-down strikes would be outlawed in this State under a bill introduced tonight by Assemblyman Wadsworth, Livingston Republican.
Myer Friendly, the father of Edwin S. Friendly, business manager of The New York Sun, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

Manhattan BARNES, FRANCES M. (June 1, 1936). Gross assets, $81,321; net, $75,528. To James McCormack, nephew, $3,000; Jay Elms, friend, $1,000; Earl Bryant Barnes, son, three-fourths residue; Jeanette L. Ebersole, niece, one-fourth residue; several other bequests.
Bangor defeated Cliftonville, 4-3, and Was Newry Town shut out Distillery, 3-0, today in Belfast Cup soccer matches.

Many entertained at the first annual police pension fund ball tonight at the Colony Club. Half the proceeds will swell receipts from last week's baseball game and donations from individuals of which Edward T. Stotesbury and Ralph Beaver Strassburger are in charge.
The Borden Company and its subsidiaries in 1936 earned $7,921,489, or 3.3 per cent of sales, after depreciation, expenses, interest, estimated Federal and other income taxes and other charges.
For the first time in the short annals of ski racing the same man and the same woman have won in the same season the Arlberg-Kandahar classic as well as the International Ski Federation's races.

In an attempt to promote temperance, the State Liquor Authority is preparing a series of phonograph records on the subject for use on electrically transcribed radio programs throughout the State, according to the annual report of the Authority to be submitted today to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

Thomas D. Thacher, former chairman of the New York Charter Revision Committee, received yesterday afternoon in his office at 120 Broadway the Grand Street Boys Association Gold Medal "for outstanding and unselfish service to the City of New York for 1936."
Pan American Airways will extend its regular weekly Pacific air mail service from Manila to Macao and Hongkong, China, on April 21, the Postoffice Department formally announced today.
The sixth and final meeting of the year between the New York Rangers and the New York Americans will take place at Madison Square Garden tonight.

A review of the Alabama Unemployment Insurance Law, an adjunct of the Federal Social Security program, was tentatively granted today by the Supreme Court, which remained silent, however, on the application for a rehearing on the New York State Unemployment Insurance Act, automatically upheld by a four-to-four vote on Nov. 23.
The Rev. Joseph Heatly Dulles, librarian emeritus at Princeton Theological Seminary, died today at his home here, 27 Boudinot Street, following a long illness. He was 83 years old.

Nathan R. Reibel resents being called "Shylock" in his capacity as receiver for a Westfield taxi company or otherwise, and today tried to prove that any one who calls him that is guilty of contempt of court.

Landlords of the cotton South were warned today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration that any reduction in the economic status of their tenants would be met with cancellation of benefit payments otherwise due them under the soil conservation program.

The Board of Superintendents recommended yesterday the appointment of eighty-nine additional teachers to be taken from the License No. 1 eligible list. The recommendation will be acted upon at the Board of Education meeting tomorrow afternoon.
The Danish Premier, Theodor A. M. Stauning, addressing Swedish University students at Lund this evening on the northern defensive combination which has been discussed in the Scandinavian press, said.

The board of directors of the Bank for International Settlements at its monthly meeting here today elected Sir Otto Niemeyer, a director of the Bank of England, to fill for three years the new post that it is creating-chairman of the board.
Dr. Walter James Clarke, who had practiced medicine in New York from 1889 until 1933, died suddenly last night of a coronary thrombosis at his home, 1,035 Park Avenue, at the age of 72.

Another temporary armistice was reached tonight in Flint's recurring labor war when 13,200 men were ordered to return to work in two General Motors plants tomorrow morning after a day of idleness caused by sit-down strikes in.Chevrolet plant No. 4, and two departments of Fisher Body plant No. 1.

George M. Cohan Jr., 22 years old, of 993 Fifth Avenue, described by the police as the son of the veteran actor and playwright, was charged at the East Sixty-seventh Street police station last night with driving while intoxicated, with making an improper turn and with third-degree assault.

171st St. (11-2911), n. s., 176 ft. w. of 3d Av., 70x134; Sylvia Bachrach to Raugel Realty Corp., 1,821 Mohegan Av.; mtg., $120,800. Valentine Av., 2,084 (11-3144), Peter A. Quinn, referee, to Jerome Wile, 490 West End Av.

The employes of the Waterbury Steel Ball Company, a subsidiary of the Federal Bearing Company of Poughkeepsie, were on a sitdown strike tonight in an attempt to get a general increase of 10 cents an hour and time and one-half for all work over forty hours a week.
A complete control plan to insure non-intervention in Spain was unanimously approved tonight by the delegations of the twenty-seven nations represented on the International NonIntervention Committee.

The Brooklyn Prep basketball team vanquished McBurney School, 38-27, on the losers' court yesterday. The victors led at half-time, 19-12. Jack Padden of McBurney tallied 13 points for high-scoring honors.

Lena Langstroth, 16 years old, of 94-10 Case Street, Elmhurst, Queens, was found dead today of a fracture of the skull beside the tracks of the Reading Railroad, about 400 yards from the West Trenton station.
Jewell Dorsett, an odds-on choice from the Lone Star Stable, registered an easy triumph over five rivals in the five-and-a-half-furlong dash for 3-year-olds at the Fair Grounds today.

The Port of New York Authority has emerged from the depreession years with its underlying principles unaltered and its finances "In flourishing condition," according to the sixteenth annual report, submitted last night to the Governors and Legislatures of New York and New Jersey.

The two-story building containing five stores and offices at 159-161 Newark Avenue, corner of Barrow Street, Jersey City, has been sold by the Baltimore Company, Joseph F. Reilly, president, to 161 Newark Avenue, Inc., for investment.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 6, unless specified: At Pichilinque Bay: Cushing, Perkins. At San Diego; Gannet, Kanawha, Richmond.

Clergymen differed today on the suggestion of John D. Rockefeller Jr. that eleven churches of Tarrytown, North Tarrytown and Pocantico Hills unite in a cooperative movement, with weaker churches absorbed by the stronger.

Subscription books for the Treasury's offering of 2 1/2 per cent bonds of 1949-53 which were opened today will- be closed on Wednesday night, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.
Coach Lou Little, back from a two-month vacation in the Bahamas, announced yesterday that Spring football practice at Columbia will get under way either Thursday or Friday.

James Walter Keveny, long active in the citrus fruit industry and president of J. W. Keveny, Inc., wholesale fruit firm in the Wallabout Market, Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 160 East Fortyeighth Street, Manhattan, after a long illness. His age was 60.

Jim McMillen, former University of Illinois gridiron star, threw Frank Sexton of California in 1:09:03 in the feature match at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw McMillen triumph with a body hold.

President Roosevelt received assurances today that he could rely on the almost solid support of organized labor, and a large segment of agriculture for his plan to reorganize the judiciary, and particularly that part providing remaking of the Supreme Court with a more "liberal" personnel.

An unusually worded statement refusing to permit withdrawals of bonds deposited with it was made public yesterday by the committee for St. Louis-San Francisco Railway prior-lien bonds headed by John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company. The statement said that withdrawals would be permitted only in case of "dire need."

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: PATENTS 3773--Albert E. Dieterich v. Sol S. Leaf. Argued by Albert E. Dieterich, pro se, no oral argument for appellee.
Appointments The following probationary patrolmen are hereby appointed patrolmen, their conduct and capacity while on probation having been satisfactory:
Turpentine firm at 383/4c; sales, 48 barrels; receipts, 53 barrels; shipments, 1,157 barrels; stock, 23,085 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 298; receipts, 543; shipments, 2,768; stock, 54,595.
Negotiations for the conclusion of a new Locarno treaty are now likely to be resumed shortly.

Advertising campaigns to announce a new "age" for one whisky and the introduction of a lower price brand of another were made known here yesterday. One year and three months before the time the new government regulation requiring straight whiskies to be at lease two years old goes into effect, Hiram Walker Sons are bringing out their Ten High straight whisky two years old.
United States MECHANICAL ENGINEER (DIESEL DESIGN), $3,800 year; associate mechanical engineer (Diesel design), $3,200; assistant mechanical engineer (Diesel: design), $2,600; Navy Department.

Still clinging to his theory that Norman Redwood, leader of a sandhogs' union, was murdered by hired gunmen, John J. Breslin Jr., prosecutor of Bergen County, N. J., said yesterday that he expected important developments in the case within the next few hours.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. S. Lord of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Lord, to Russell Hall of Boston and South Windham, Me., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Russell Hall of Melrose Highlands, Mass.

Creation of an educational center consisting of a group of school buildings and an experimental laboratory for teachers on the site of the Parental School in Queens was voted last Wednesday by the Board of Superintendents, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

All issues of United States Government-securities fell sharply in trading in the bond section of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The net declines ranged from 1-32 to 12-32 point and most issues went to their lowest prices for the current year.
Two more bombs were discovered here today, making a total of five in forty-eight hours picked up in the Franco-Catalonian border district.

The annual report of the Southwestern Gas and Electric Company for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $1,805,892 after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal income taxes, preferred dividend requirements and other charges.
With a shower and the threat of real rain, which later was fulfilled, Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers and near-Dodgers today were deprived of what was to have been their initial batting practice.

Dart.mouth's Indians assured themselves of at least a tie for second place. in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by defeating Cornell's basketeers in a bitterly fought overtime contest tonight, 52-49.
With the assistance of a battery of four featured players, the Theatre Guild has put on "Storm Over Patsy," which opened at the Guild Theatre last evening.
Colonel and Mrs. William H. Wynne Finch, who were at the Savoy-Plaza, have departed for Tucson, Ariz. Mr. and Mrs. Ridley Watts have gone from Mayfair House to Useppa Island, Fla.

The dress trade continued to show improvement last week, with considerable order and reorder business in all lines, according to the report issued yesterday by the research and statistical division of the joint board of the Dress and Waistmakers' Union.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Robert M. Blair-Smith and Samuel Vigotsky of New York City were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: The Chief Justice announced the following orders of the court:
