Finance Minister Vincent Auriol will present to Parliament for discussion tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock a bill authorizing issuance of a new national defense loan in sterling and dollars as well as in francs.

A jury hearing charges of first degree manslaughter against Mrs. Alisa Shephard, 39 years old, wife of Stephen Adam Shephard of Bronxville, oil company executive, could not agree at 10:15 o'clock last night in Bronx County Court and was discharged by Judge James Barrett. Mrs. Shephard's bail was continued pending a new trial.

More than 200 Rumanian university professors in a stormy meeting tonight threatened to strike in protest against proposed legislation that would require them to assume responsibility for the "political education" of students.

The Democratically controlled House of Assembly passed tonight two Republican-backed Senate bills giving municipalities another month in which to adopt budgets and permitting them to omit inclusion this year of 35 per cent of the floating debt. The vote was 55 to 0.
Industrial Rayon Corporation capital stock installment subscription receipts, on which the first installment has been paid, will be admitted to the list of the New York Stock Exchange today.

Enactment of State statutes patterned on the Federal RobinsonPatman act curbing price discrimination should be held up until a sufficient fund of experience with the Federal law is available for the guidance of Legislatures, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., said yesterday if an address at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Courtesies of the naval and military services were exchanged yesterday between groups of American and Finnish army and navy officers aboard the Finnish naval training frigate Suomen Joutsen, moored at Pier 75, foot of West Thirtyfifth Street.
Monday, March 8. First day. Weather raining for first two races, cloudy for third, fourth and fifth, showery thereafter; track sloppy.

Having paraded yesterday at Rockefeller Center before a group of fashion editors, manikins representing New York merchants will take to the air at Newark today for an aerial Easter parade from coast to coast over the route of American Airlines.

An application for a certificate of reasonable doubt by Edward J. O'Connor, 38 years old, former attorney and head of the O'Connor Civil Service, Inc., 53 Park Row, Manhattan, was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel in the Queens Supreme Court.

Mike Best, known to the police as former chief of a rich gambling syndicate but now reduced to operating floating craps games in Yorkville, was shot in the chest last evening in Fifty-third Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue in a quarrel over a betting debt.

For the first time in Italy's parliamentary history all the Deputies were received simultaneously by King Victor Emmanuel in the royal palace today, so that they could express their joy personally to the sovereign on the birth of his grandson,. Victor Emmanuel.

A one-man show of Lovis Corinth's work will be held at the Westermann Galleries beginning April 20. The exhibition will include twenty oils and a number of water colors, drawings and etchings. It has been arranged by Thomas Corinth, son of the artist.

R. S. Rothschild upset thirdseeded H. P. Cole in an extended match to furnish the highlight of the third round of the annual Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class C championship at the Downtown A. C. yesterday.
Miss Adele Justine Lay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Oscar Lay of this place, has chosen the afternoon of March 27 for her marriage to John G. Earl, son of Mrs. John C. Earl, also of Montclair.
Emil Hurja, the right-hand man of Chairman Farley in the Democratic National Committee, said tonight that he would resign within sixty days to return to private business.

The Spanish freighter Mar Cantabrico, sunk yesterday in the Bay of Biscay, won a dramatic race with Congress in January to sail from Brooklyn with her war supplies before a neutrality bill could be rushed through barring such shipments.

More than 700 letters had been received up to yesterday evening in Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall commenting on his suggestion that a bust of Adolf Hitler be the central figure in a chamber of horrors at the New York World's Fair.

Mrs. Humphrey Wagar of Atlanta, Ga., and Miss Ruth Sherman of New York won the women's pair event for the Wainwright Cup in the final event of the Eastern bridge championships at the Hotel Commodore yesterday afternoon.

Trailing by 170-137 in the thirtythird inning, Howard Bergman rallied to defeat Leicester Fisher in the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline billiard championship at the Capitol Health Center last night and go into a tie for first place with Jerome Strauss with four triumphs in five games.

A committee of the Independent System employes' representatives, speaking for the 3,960 employes of the operating division of the cityowned subway line, visited City Hall yesterday and protested against the failure of the Board of Transportation to enter into collective bargaining with the employes in accordance with the policy enunciated by Mayor La Guardia.

Speakers before the Committee of One Hundred at the clubhouse meeting tomorrow night will be Albert Edward Wiggam, author of "New Decalogue of Science," and Representative Samuel B. Pettingill of Indiana.

Miss Hedessa Cordley, 40 years old, of Sycamore Ledge, Pecksland Road, Greenwich, Conn., told Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer in Supreme Court yesterday that she had advanced $168,596 to her husband, Christopher M. Cordley, president of Cordley Hayes, Inc., refrigeration experts, after their marriage on Dec. 18, 1928.

A neutralization pact for the Philippine Islands will be considered soon by the United States Government, former Governor Paul V. McNutt, new High Commissioner to the Philippines; said last night in a speech at the fifty-second annual dinner of the Ohio Society of New York, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The routine of Yankee training camp life was shadowed by gloom today when misfortune overtook Monte Pearson, right-handed pitcher whose flinging last year aided no little in bringing the American League pennant to New York.

Automobile production lincreased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 130.7, the highest point since the week of Aug. 22, 1936. It was 128.5 for the previous week, and 92.1 for the week ended March 7, 1936.

Eight colleges named a total of thirty-four boxers for the Eastern Intercollegiate championships at Syracuse University next Friday and Saturday. The entrants were tabulated and first-round pairings arranged at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
The newly organized New York Theatrical Press Agents are to be congratulated on their happy choice of a name.

The field for the Columbian mile took more definite shape yesterday when Luigi Beccali of Italy, the Olympic champion of 1932, who is improving with every indoor start, entered the feature race of the Knights of Columbus games a week from tomorrow at Madison Square Garden.
Spring styles were dramatized at a fashion revue at Hearn's in Fourteenth Street last night, directed by Miss Elsa Maxwelt Dancing manikins and comedy features marked the program.

Mrs. Walter Duncan entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. Among her guests were Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Mrs. H. Bradley Martin, Mrs. Griswold Thompson and Miss Marjorie Duncan.
The wire-haired terrier of doubtful lineage which was supposed to act as judge of his rightful master in court tonight did not have to make that decision.

The spot price for copper was set at 16 1/4 cents a pound in the domestic market yesterday, the highest price since March, 1930, and a gain of 1 1/4 cents over Saturday. Except for the periods from January, 1929, to March, 1930, inclusive, and that of March and April, 1923, the price of copper has not been so high since October, 1920.

The New York County grand jury handed upa second degree grand larceny indictment yesterday against William Watson, 24 years old, a plumber, who gave the West Thirtyfourth Street Branch of the Y. M. C. A. as his address, in the alleged theft of $175 last Feb. 11 from Jacob Lasky of 765 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx.

American housewives bought more dollars' worth of food, better grades and brands, and more "entertainment" foods and demanded more service in 1936 than at any time since 1931, according to the annual survey issued yesterday by The Progressive Grocer.

The Republican revolt against the renomination of Mayor La Guardia on that party ticket grew yesterday. Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens disclosed that he was considering running against the Mayor in the Republican primary as a result of many requests for him to become a candidate.

Three judges of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, after a five-hour hearing today, reserved decision on a petition of William A. Brady of New York, theatrical producer, seeking permission to appeal from the Federal District Court's ruling approving the reorganization plan of the Baldwin Locomotive works.

Brig. Gen. Frank Merrill Caldwell, U. S. A., retired, died in an army hospital here today. He was 71 years old. Surviving are his widow, the former Mary. Hay, and three daughters, Mrs. Frederick Beach of Hartford, Conn.;

A group of Yale undergraduates today started a "Roosevelt for King" club under the slogan "Crown America First." Following a long series of assertions, including "Whereas, Franklin Delano Roosevelt controls the executive and legislative and is soon to control the judiciary, and has provided a succession of heirs unto the third generation," the club adopted a resolution providing:

The role taken by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in drawing the battle line with John L. Lewis was criticized here today by Norman Thomas, who was Socialist candidate for the Presidency.
The Assembly passed tonight and sent to Governor Lehman the bill continuing for another year, beginning July 1, the moratorium on foreclosure of mortgages where interest and taxes have been paid.
Miss Mary Jane Fletcher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Fletcher of West Hartford, has chosen March 27 for her marriage to Clarence M. Ingraham, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Morton Ingraham of Bristol.

Edgar Allen, theatrical booking agent, and the Rev. Robert L. Hector, who conducts the Spiritualist Church of Universal Brotherhood at 245 West Seventy-second Street, were arrested on charges of grand larceny yesterday after a former member of the Police Department allegedly had paid them $300 for reinstatement in the department.

Colonel Sothenes Behn, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company who was in Spain during the first five months of the civil war, returned yesterday-from Paris on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. He said that the thirteen-story telephone building in Madrid gave sanctuary at times to as many as 600 women and children.

Winthrop Erasmus Phelps, retired New York real estate broker, died today at Fairview Hospital at the age of 86. He was born at Stockbridge, the son of the the Rev. Winthrop H. Phelps, minister of the Monterey Congregational Church from 1856 to 1861.

A tropical electrical storm and the Tropical Park race meeting began at almost the same moment today, with the result that the sheets of rain prevented any one from seeing the running positions in the first events of the twenty-four-day meeting.

The program announced by the Blum Government for stabilizing the franc and repatriating capital is remarkable in several ways. Reversing an almost universal tendency, it seeks to cure France's monetary ills by reducing, instead of increasing, governmental restrictions.
Directors of the Tilo Roofings Company, Inc., voted yesterday to increase the regular quarterly dividend on the common stock from 12 1/2 to 25 cents a share,

A plan of reorganization for the Munson Steamship Line, which was submitted on Feb. 2 to Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe for his approval, has been approved by a large group of creditors, Cecil P. Stewart, chairman of the general reorganization committee, reported to the court yesterday.

Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here dipped fractionally in early trading today in sympathy with a rather sharp decline in Liverpool, but there was no material pressure on the market, and later reports of dust storms in parts of Western Nebraska and Kansas and Eastern Colorado started a buying movement which swept the new-crop futures up nearly 2 cents a bushel from the low points.

A sit-down strike of maintenance employes of the Hospital for Joint Diseases who barricaded themselves in the kitchen and laundry of the institution at Madison Avenue and 124th Street all day yesterday and last night, ended temporarily with a truce early this morning.

President Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization program was the subject of debate in the Senate tonight. Senator Desmond, Republican, of Orange, introduced a resolution urging the Senate to adjourn out of respect to the seventh anniversary of the death of former President and Chief Justice Taft.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a hearing in the case of the Golden Conqueror Mines, Inc., of Manitou, Col., relative to charges of untrue statements and omissions of fact in the prospectus, had been called in the office of the commission at Denver for March 15.
The Sullivan County Bar Association adopted unanimously today at a special meeting a resolution disapproving any legislation affecting the membership of the Supreme Court.

Considerable activity in office space rentals in the financial district was shown in the business leases reported yesterday. Among them were two leases to American representatives of foreign organizations and one for additional space to the Peruvian Consulate. The list in detail follows:

Following last week's rise of $5 a bale, profit-taking developed on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the early losses ran to about $2 a bale in some months. A sharp recovery, however, left the list with net looses of 13 to 18 points.

Orders have gone forth from the Kremlin that the Communist party organization must democratize itself. This is a step toward the democratization of the Soviet State which will come to pass next Winter when the new Soviet Parliament under the new Constitution is elected by direct, universal and secret ballot.

The House Judiciary Committee sought today to find out whether the American housewife is a good bargain buyer. Itself divided, the committee summoned experts of the Federal Trade Commission to appear before it tomorrow.
The Insurgents unexpectedly launched a heavy attack on the Guadalajara front, northeast of Madrid, at dawn today. Late this afternoon fighting was still going on.

Stockholders of the Gamewell Company voted in Boston yesterday in favor of eliminating the consolidated earned deficit resulting from operations of its subsidiaries from the time of their acquisition until May 31, 1936, the close of the last fiscal year.

Bids for 3,000,000 pounds of copper in varying lots will be opened by the Navy Department Wednesday. They are for copper ingot, grade A, for navy yards, as follows: Portsmouth, N. H., 500,000 pounds; Brooklyn, 300,000 pounds; Philadelphia, 400,000 pounds; Washington, D. C., 600,000 pounds, and Norfolk, 200,000 pounds.

Max Eastman has edited and compiled the most complete, impartial and intelligent film history of the Russian revolution thus far shown. His "Tsar to Lenin," now at the Filmarte, is an important work, neither hymn of hate nor paean of praise.

Stockholders of the National Can Company voted yesterday to merge the company with the McKeesport Tin Plate Company. A new company called the McKeesport Tin Plate Corporation is to be formed and will exchange its $10 par stock on the basis of two shares for each outstanding share of McKeesport or National.
Carroll Pierce, president of the Citizens National Bank of Alexandria, Va., and former Mayor of that city, died at his home there yesterday after a long illness at the age of 64.

Flying Officer David Llewellyn, who has been hampered by weather, faulty machinery and physical exhaustion on his several unsuccessful attempts to lower the London-Cape Town record, returned to the airport here today, recalling still another obstacle during his recent flight.

Edward S. Whitney of Montclair, N. J., a director of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, and Mrs. Helen K. Buffum of suburban Cleveland Heights, obtained a marriage license here today from Cuyahoga County Probate Court. Mr.

Cornell's mysterious benefactor who signs himself "L. H. Anon" has made another gift to the university, President Farrand revealed today. As in two previous cases, it is in the form of a cashier's check.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, denied yesterday that he had intended to link John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, with "red propagandist" activities, as indicated by THE NEW YORK TIMES and other newspapers in reporting a speech by Mr. Woll at the Center Association of Catholic Men on Sunday.

Anthony Eden spoke tonight at Aberdeen, addressing a Scottish audience for the first time since he became Foreign Secretary. Much interest at tached to this speech because the last three public addresses Mr. Eden had made since, so to speak, attaining his full flower, had been, in a measure, progressive.
A warning to "keep your eyes on the road to liberty," mailed to District Attorney Buron Fitts two hours before he was shot and wounded from ambush last night, came to light today.

The steel industry's operations are scheduled at 87.3 per cent of theoretical capacity for this week, according to returns filed with the American Iron and Steel Institute. This is a gain of 1.5 points, or 1.75 per cent, from the previous week. The new rate is the highest recorded since the first half of October, 1929.
Miss Lucy Estelle Doheny, granddaughter of the late Edward L. Doheny, prominent oil man, and Waldeman Van Cott Niven, an attorney, today filed their notice of intention to marry.
A. Massey (Matt) Berry of Edmonton, Alta., has won the Trans-Canada Trophy for his service to aviation during 1936, the Department of National Defense announced today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John T. Haviland of 710 Lawrence Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Haviland, to Charles A. Whitney Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Whitney of Boston.

Julius W. Stoll, president and founder of the German Publishing Company of Rochester, died this morning in his home. He was 91 years old and had been publishing German newspapers in Rochester since 1882.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Weary Investigator," whose letter criticizing the granting of relief to domestics in Harlem appeared in THE TIMES, evidently-did not tire herself by putting into practice the Emergency Relief Bureau's policy covering the very subject she writes about.

Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth is one of a large group of well-known members of society serving on the patroness committee for the annual International Skating Carnival to be held the nights of March 27, 29 and 31 at Madison Square Garden.
With a red baggage wagon carrying her trunks, Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson left Cannes today in the automobile in which she had arrived three months ago.
Helen Wills Moody of tennis fame is due at Twentieth Century-Fox this week to make tests for what both the studio and Mrs. Moody hope will develop into a screen career.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission contended today that parent companies in the Harrison Williams Utilities empire of 1929 "ran up" their stocks for the purpose of floating new issues.

Appearing in Japanese costume, Baroness Shidvue Ishimoto, Japanese feminist, addressed a large audience at the Greenwich High School auditorium this evening in a program under the auspices of the Greenwich Committee for Maternal Health.

Morenz led the Canadiens to victory in the Stanley Cup series of 1924, 1930 and 1931 and in every year from the time he joined the "Flying Frenchmen," as the team is called, they reached the National Hockey League play-offs.

The groundwork was laid today by the Machen Memorial Committee for its campaign to raise $1,000,000 for the building and endowment of Westminster Theological Seminary in memory of the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, Presbyterian Fundamentalist leader.
A crystal stream tinkled in the lounge of the new ballroom at the Astor last night and furnished a harmonious background to an experts' discussion of a highly controversial matter.

Stockholders of the National Contrainer Corporation approved yesterday a plan to transfer assets to a new Delaware company of the same name with an authorized capital of 750,000 shares of $1 par value. The present company's 162,770 shares will be exchanged, share for share, for stock in the new company.

The opening gun of what apparently is to be a campaign to encourage anti-Semitism in the United States was fired today when the government news service picked up and distributed to all German newspapers an item in the Angriff presenting Benjamin Franklin in the role of an anti-Semite.

Dan O'Mahoney of Ireland, former claimant to the world's wrestling heavyweight championship. last night threw Chief Little Wolf of Trinidad, Col., in the feature bout of a show at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.
The German Government protests semi-officially in the Diplomatische Korrespondenz at being linked with internal disturbances in Hungary. The Foreign Office organ says:

Choice of a Republican Assembly nominee as a candidate for election to the post left vacant by the death of Assemblyman Richard B. Smith was put over tonight until noon Wednesday by the nominating convention of the Onondaga County Republican Committee.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Gulf States Steel Company has been called for April 6 in Wilmington, Del., to act upon the proposed sale of the assets of the Republic Steel Corporation and dissolution of the Gulf States Steel Company.
Howie Morenz, star center of the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League and rated one of the greatest hockey players of all time, died of a heart ailment tonight.
Howie Morenz was really a native of Mitchell, twelve miles from Stratford. He played with Stratford's junior team for several years and gained most of his amateur prominence here.

New York City's biggest amateur boxing tournament of the year, the Golden Gloves finals, held the stage at Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd of 20,000 fight lovers Jammed the arena to the limit, the survivors of an original field of 7,453 aspiring mittwielders vied for the championships in the various classes from the flyweight to the heavyweight.

The funeral of Mrs. Gabrielle Greeley Clendenin, daughter of Horace Greeley, founder of The New York Tribune, was held here today in the Church of St. Mary the.Virgin. She died on Friday at her home here.

Amendments which would bring the proposed new Westchester County charter in line with a few of the changes recommended at a public hearing Friday night were offered today by the Board of Supervisors' Committee on Reorganization of County Government.

A new departure in China policy, which will respect China's claim for equality and cease to arouse British suspicions, was foreshadowed today in Foreign Minister Naotake Sato's first speech before the House of Peers.

Man should be ambidextrous, Mrs. Claude Greneker contended yesterday in exhibiting an invention, known as "Fingertips," which will enable a man to lather his face, stimulate his scalp, manicure his nails, brush his eyebrows and put drops in his eyes without "picking anything up or putting anything down."
Katherine Bacon, pianist, and Harrington Van Hoesen, baritone, will appear in a joint recital tonight for the Musicians' Club at the Plaza.

C. Ray Phillips and Henry T. Bush, receivers of the MissouriKansas Pipe Line Company, filed today in Chancery Court an answer asking dismissal of a bill sought by Ralph B. Mayo to have 54,930 shares of common stock of the company delivered to him under an agreement which he said was made on Aug. 1, 1931. By the contract, Mr.

The establishment of a gold-buying price by the Bank of France, together with a generally favorable reaction to the French Government's plans for a defense loan payable in dollars, gave strong support yesterday to the faltering franc. The exchange rallied 33/8 points to 4.563/8 cents and closed at its best price for the day. The discount on ninety-day franc futures declined 23/4 points to 81/4 points below the spot rate.

J. W. Andrews, president of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, yesterday said at the annual meeting in Jersey City that earnings in 1937 probably would be less than in 1936 because of the higher cost of leaf tobacco.
Detective Edward Powers of Chicago, here on police business, asked two Detroit policemen to show him a sit-down strike today, so he would have "something to tell the boys" back home.

An agreement reached out of court as to which of the finders of $3,970 in cash and a savings bank book should share the reward was approved yesterday by Supreme. Court Justice Edward Riegelmann in Brooklyn.
While the United States continues to be the largest purchaser of Nicaraguan products, Germany's purchases on the barter system are increasing rapidly.

Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board, said yesterday in an address at the fourth annual convention of the Mortgage Conference of New York that programs for subsidized public housing were predicated on the "fallacy" that persons in the lowest income group should live in brand new houses.

Although its principal figure will be celebrating quietly at her Westport, Conn., home, the seventieth birthday of Lillian Wald tomorrow will be the occasion for radio broadcasts and parties throughout the city.
Thought is plowing wrinkles in the brows of the Indian werowances of Union Square. Leader DOOLING'S long illness seems likely to prevent his taking an active part in the coming municipal campaign.

Indictments charging perjury against Joseph Roshia and Mrs. Roshia, parents, and Joseph Roshia Jr., brother of ??eona Roshia Backus, were returned today by the grand jury. The girl was married recently at the age of 12 to Stanley S. Backus, 19.

Chicago's metropolitan horse-racing season of 157 days will open at Aurora May 1. Under the line-up adopted today by the Illinois Racing Commission, Aurora will operate for nineteen days, closing May 22 with its $15,000-added Illinois Derby as the farewell feature.

After a two-day search, in which three airplanes and as many picket boats were employed, the Coast Guard last night tentatively abandoned its search for the 28-foot fishing boat Sunbeam, missing from this port since Saturday afternoon with four persons on board.

The claims of the Neponsit Property Owners Association, Inc., against the city for waterfront property acquired by the city for a public beach between Jacob Riis Park and Beach Second Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens, were reduced yesterday to one-tenth of the $495,450 they had sought to recover.
The Daily Mirror announced the death at Burnham Market, Norfolk, of George Skeet, described as Britain's most wonderful father, at the age of 103--on the eve of his wife's thirtieth birthday.

Wallace G. Garland, honor graduate of Yale University, who is on trial in the Federal court accused of mail fraud growing out of the sale of stock of corporations built around patents on an "electric eye" system of traffic control, resumed the witness stand yesterday in his own defense.
Federal Judge William Clark signed today an order finally confirming a plan for reorganization of the Cuba Railway Company under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law.

So that the first championship tournament of the American Bowling Congress ever to be held in New York may get off to an auspicious start it has been arranged for outstanding stars of the game to take the alleys when the competition opens tomorrow night at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

A communique issued this evening by the Italian Line announces that one member of the crew of the Rex was killed and twenty passengers were injured during the Atlantic crossing of the liner, which arrived at Naples Saturday.

Deaths caused by vehicular accidents in this city during the week ended Sunday were only half as many as in the corresponding week a year ago, although the total of accidents and persons injured increased, it was reported - yesterday by -Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on March 3 shows increases for the week of $43,000,000 in total loans and investments and $56,000,000 in time deposits, and decreases of $137,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $158,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, $151,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $120,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Mischa Levitzki, Manuel Quiroga and the Perol String Quartet were the guest artists at the season's fifth concert of the Beethoven Association in the Town Hall last night. Lawrence Tibbett was scheduled to sing but did not appear.

THE STONE FIELD, by Martha Ostenso. (Dodd, Mead, $2.50.) A novel about a woman in love. AFTERMATH: A SUPPLEMENT TO "THE GOLDEN BOUGH," by Sir James George Frazer. (Macmillan, $3.) Fresh information on some of the subjects discussed in "The Golden Bough."

Announcement has been' made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis Salant of 35 East Eighty-fourth Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen L. Salant, to Myron S. Isaacs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Isaacs of this city and Croton-onthe-Hudson.

Miss Nella Webb, astrologer, told the hairdressers and beauty shop owners in convention yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania that, according to the stars, the world would be more conscious of beauty during the next six years.
The League of Nations committee for study of the raw material problem opened its sessions today, Secretary General Joseph A. C. Avenol explaining its task.
Standard Oil of Ohio announced today wage increases totaling about $300,000 annually for 4,000 employes.

The 6 per cent convertible collateral notes of the New York Central Railroad, which are to be called for redemption on June 1, resisted selling pressure on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and climbed higher after a minor reaction.

The first robin was reported in the metropolitan area yesterday; four of them, in fact, and by an expert. David H. W. Benson, who has been a State game protector in Far Rockaway for twenty-five years, said he had seen the quartet on a grass bank of the Long Island Motor Parkway near Roslyn, L. I., in the afternoon.
Dr. Charles F. Halstead, who had practiced medicine here for more than thirty years, died of a heart attack in his home here tonight. He was 65 years old.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: The Board of Officers appointed by paragraph 2, Special Orders 17, this headquarters, Jan. 21, 1933, pertaining to appointment of Board of Officers for the State of New Jersey, is hereby dissolved.

Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant dismissed yesterday a count charging concealment of bankruptcy assets in an indictment on which Jacob J. Lesser, New York attorney who was once a candidate for appointment to the Federal bench, is being tried, but declined to dismiss another count charging that Lesser took part in a conspiracy to conceal assets.

A blue-ribbon jury was chosen yesterday before County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn to re-try Martin Schlossman and Harry Weiss on the indictments charging them with participating in the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel in a plot to compel him to "confess" the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.
The Rare Book Department of the Scribner Book Store has just issued a large octavo catalogue, "Fifty Books, Manuscripts, Music," in black cloth boards with fifty-one full-page illustrations.

Running the Mount Norquay downhill course in 2 minutes 26 4-5 seconds-an approximate average speed of forty miles an hour-Pierre Francioli of the Swiss universities team today won the closing event of the Canadian ski tournament.

Hugh Lewis, for many years general manager and secretary of the Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company, member of one of the largest insurance groups in the world, died in Birkenhead today at the age of 72.
Slight earthquake shocks were felt late last night and early today in Ohio, Kentucky, Indiana, Michigan, West Virginia, Illinois, Wisconsin and Ontario, according to The Associated Press.

In the presence of government officials, Congressmen and members of the diplomatic corps among whom were no representatives of the Italian and German Embassies, Mayor La Guardia and Dr. Charles A. Beard, historian, spoke tonight at two crowded meetings marking the first of the Bronson Cutting Memorial lectures, sponsored by the Senator's mother, Mrs. W. Bayard Cutting.
An advisory committee on training schools for socially maladjusted children has been appointed by the Children's Bureau of the Labor Department.

A charge was made today before the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage that one of its investigators represented himself as a private detective to gather information against the William J. Burns International Detective Agency.
Picket lines were extended today by striking members of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers to include two more mills, Fedden Brothers in Shillington and the Reading Full-Fashioned plant.

The U. A. W. A., whose officers and representatives Chrysler Corporation has been dealing with for some time, insisted today on a yes or no answer to the union's demand for the sole right to represent all our employes, whether union members or not.

John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, refused tonight to go through a picket line of sit-down striking waiters, waitresses, cooks and bus boys at the Willard Hotel to address a meeting of Labor's Non-partisan League in the ballroom.
Last year for the first time since 1917 the death rate and incidence of new cases of tuberculosis rose sharply in New York. If Dr. HAVEN EMERSON is right, the city's rulers must accept the blame.

President Roosevelt conferred with representatives of farmers' organizations, received from John L. Lewis and Major George L. Berry a pledge of labor's support in his fight for reorganization of the judiciary, and worked on the radio address he will deliver tomorrow night.

2d Av., s. w. cor. of 32d St., 24.8x100; Cornelia Van A. Chapin to Everett F. Britz, 1-749 Concourse, Bronx ($15). 74th St., 30 E., 20x102.2; Michael Mazzola to Yale University, consideration $1,000; foreclosure.

ADDIS--Emerson W., suddenly, March 7, 1937,.at Brewster, N. Y., husband of Magdalene A. Dodge, son of Esther Lobdell Addis, brother of Marjorie and Alexander L. Addis and Barbara Addis Moore. Services at the Addis home, 53 Prospect St., Brewster, Tuesday, March 9, at 3 P. M. Interment Milltown Rural Cemetery.

Leaving 300 men to sit down in one of the plants, members of the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, went on strike at the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company today.

Tonnage of open hearth and Bessemer steel ingots produced in February was greater than in any previous February in the history of the country, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The average weekly output was the highest recorded since August, 1929.

A syndicate headed by Irving Feldman bought the one-story taxpayer on a plot 100 by 100 feet at Forty-first Street and Queens Boulevard, Queens, from Butt, Gilliam McVay, Inc. The property was held at $125,000 and was sold for cash over a first mortgage.

The studio of George de Forest Brush, painter, was destroyed by fire here yesterday. It contained paintings and drawings and other objects having a total estimated value of about $200,000, not covered by insurance.
General Gonzalo queipo de Llano, in an Insurgent broadcast from Seville, declared today that the famous Spanish painter Ignazio Zuloaga had been sentenced to death Sunday in government-held Bilbao.
The "gold coast" area of South Florida is under "stop gambling" orders from Governor Cone at the height of the Winter tourist season.
The stock market generally was off today, except for unusual activity in the rubbers and metals. British funds declined sharply, but, foreign bonds improved, where offered, in sluggish trading.

The Fascist Grand Council early today announced its approval of the work of Fascist corporations and its endorsement of the activities of the Fascist party under the secretaryship of Lieut. Col. Achille Starace.

Holding the first of three open meetings for members, the nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that Charles R. Gay had been "suggested" for renomination as president of the Exchange.

Eugene W. James, who retired in June, 1935, after twenty 'years 'as a compositor on THE NEW YORK TIMES, died Sunday at the age of 73 at his home, 43-63 167th Street, Flushing, Queens. His widow, son and daughter, survive.

Isadore Rauch, 39 years old, a roofer, of 94-45 166th Street, Jamaica, Queens, believed to be the first automobile owner convicted of being equally guilty with his employe in a motor vehicle accident, was sentenced to an indefinite term in the penitentiary yesterday by Judge Colden in Queens County Court.

Production of zinc in the United States in Feburary was 38,010 tons, against 40,025 tons in January and 36,228 tons in February, 1936, the American Zinc Institute reports. Shipments in February were 47,591 tons, against 50,638 tons in January and 39,918 tons a year ago.

Operations last year of the Wheeling Steel Corporation and subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $4,115,387 after depreciation, depletion, interest, Federal income taxes, strike expenses and other deductions.

Work on the new America's Cup yacht Ranger, building at the Bath Iron Works in Bath, Me., for Harold S. Vanderbilt, is going on according to schedule, and the racer may be launched on April 15, the date planned when the lead for her keel was laid.

Torrential rain halted the second round of the annual Miami international four ball golf matches, with the morning eighteen holes being completed in three of the four contests. Play will be resumed tomorrow.

The Music Education League made public yesterday its schedule of auditions for this season. The contests conducted by the league will begin on Thursday evening with auditions for junior pianists in Steinway Hall.

The refusal of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia to grant a preliminary injunction to restrain Secretary Ickes as PWA Administrator from allocating funds to the City of St. Louis for a $30,000,000 memorial to Thomas Jefferson was affirmed by the United States Court of Appeals today.
Passengers due to arrive this morning on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary include John D. Reilly, Robert Hague, Sir Thomas Brocklebank, A. Z. Gardiner, F. G. Wood, Harold Macmillan, C. H. M.

Ahner Edelman, i 200 W. 86th st. from Mortimer S. Gordon; M. Morgenthau-Seixas Co., Inc,. broker. Edwin L. Dahlberg, in 269 W. 72d St. C. F. Loughead, in 140 W. 58th st.; R. M. Manson, in 420 Riverside Dr.; G. Gomers, in 144 W. 86th St.;
Mrs. Marie Marquard, wife of Admiral Edward Jay Marquard, commanding the American Yangtze patrol, died early this morning in Hankow of pneumonia.

Sir Albert Kitson, geologist, died today at Beaconsfield. He was 69 years old. The important discoveries of Sir Albert included the black and brown coal fields and oil-shale deposits in Nigeria; the manganese, diamond and bauxite fields on the Gold Coast; the glacial and fossil beds in Victoria, Tasmania and on the Gold Coast.

The United States Maritime Commission, charged with adjusting fortytwo ocean mail contracts between now and June 30, must mark time until the President appoints two and possibly three new commissioners.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated March 6: COLONELS Pipes, H. F., Med. Corp., one month leave, May 11. Pistol, W. B., Judge Advocate General's Department, Boston, Mass., to home and await retirement.
John L. (Paddy) Driscoll, former Northwestern University star and for years a standout in professional football, signed a contract today to coach Marquette University's football team.
Dion Clayton Calthrop, dramatist, novelist, artist and grandson of Dion Boucicault, Irish actor and playwright, died at the age of 58 at his home, Chiedeock, near Bridport In Dorset.

The joint committee of the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen, which convened yesterday at City Hall to receive suggestions on meeting the shortage of low-cost housing, heard a proposal for a Rehabilitation Corporation that would use government funds to bring oldlaw tenements into compliance with the Multiple Dwelling Law, and thus check evictions and the vacating of property.

The Princeton University honor roll for the first term of the academic year, announced today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the -university, lists 548 students, or nearly a quarter of the undergraduate body. Of these, 86 men gained first general group and 462 a second general group.

The Burchill bill which would give the Public Service Commission authority to order municipal utility systems to limit rates to cost of service, was debated sharply today at a public hearing before the Senate Public Service Committee.
Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, and Cardinal O'Connell, Archbishop of Boston, will leave here tomorrow. Cardinal Hayes and his party will sail for Miami on the New Northland in the morning.
Friends and foes of the Federal child labor amendment, beginning to gather here tonight, were tensely awaiting the showdown in the Assembly tomorrow on the Kleinfeld resolution for ratification.
Miss Lois Adeline Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell S. Wise of this city, will be married to Harrison Gray Otis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Gray Otis of Rutherford, on April 3.

Federal intervention in Matto Grosso has been decreed by President Getulio Vargas. Captain Manoel da Silva Pires of the army, who has been named Federal Commissioner for the State, arrived by airplane at Cuyaba today to take charge.

Insurance in force with the Manufacturers Mutual Fire Insurance Company and associated companies at the end of 1936 totaled $2,642,162,348, representing a gain of about $155,000,000, or 6.23 per cent over 1935. The total was distributed among 2,177 risks, the greatest number ever insured by the group, according to the annual report to policyholders.

For the first time since the Workers Alliance began a campaign of sit-down strikes in district offices of the Emergency Relief Bureau, officials of the city relief agency decided last night to ask the police to eject the demonstrators from an ERB office. The police refused, however, to act on the complaint.

Despite continuous stormy weather over- the North Atlantic, which has delayed incoming ships, the North German Lloyd liner Bremen arrived on time yesterday, docking at 2:30 P. M. at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street.

Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S. C., set the pace for a strong field today in the qualifying round of the annual Belleview Biltmore women's golf championship. She annexed the medal by turning in a card of 40, 40-80, one over par.

A reception will be given for Mr. and Mrs. Philip Cowen on March 21, in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage, by their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Leon M. Solis-Cohen at their residence, 81 Colonial Place, New Rochelle, N. Y.

Despite continuous stormy weather over- the North Atlantic, which has delayed incoming ships, the North German Lloyd liner Bremen arrived on time yesterday, docking at 2:30 P. M. at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street.

A reception will be given for Mr. and Mrs. Philip Cowen on March 21, in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage, by their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Leon M. Solis-Cohen at their residence, 81 Colonial Place, New Rochelle, N. Y.

The Middle Atlantic A. A. U. indoor track championships, scheduled to be held at Hershey, Pa., Friday and Saturday, were called off today. Frank Percival, secretary-treasurer of the Middle Atlantic A. A. U., said the National A. A. U. withdrew its sanction for the meet after a visit to Hershey by Daniel Ferris, national secretary-treasurer.

On Saturday night, April 10, "Red, Hot and Blue!" will call it a Broadway run-and, by ordinary standards, a successful one. (It arrived at the Alvin on Oct. 29.) From here it will jump directly to the Grand Opera House, Chicago, opening there on Tuesday night, April 13, with hopes of an engagement extending well into the Summer.

It appears that horse racing is being carried along a wide wave of prosperity, but there is a mild complaint in this corner. The form followers and railbirds who can identify a horse all the way across a track by the gait of the animal probably will sniff contemptuously at the suggestion, but what this casual racegoer would like to see would be a standout horse on the turf.

When the Fifth Avenue Bank sold to Eugene Payor the house at 28 Grove St. for a stated consideration of $20,000, the bank took back in part payment a purchasemoney mortgage for $17,500, due five years hence at 4 per cent, with $85 paid off quarterly.

About 350 longshoremen and clerks of the Merchants and Miners Transportation Company walked out in South Boston, Charlestown and Providence today, but the line ended the strike five hours later by signing an agreement according full recognition to the locals of the International Longshoremen's Association.

Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S. C., set the pace for a strong field today in the qualifying round of the annual Belleview Biltmore women's golf championship. She annexed the medal by turning in a card of 40, 40-80, one over par.

EVEN the most stolid of families is, when regarded in the proper light and at theproper time, a pretty animated affair. For sooner or later the offspring, male and female, begin to collect stamps. And even sooner than that they begin to fight with one another.

Part of the costs of an appeal by which Abraham Finkel, cafeteria owner, sought to escape a jail term for giving "evasive answers" to a grand jury were borne by the Metropolitan Restaurant and Cafeteria Association, it was testified yesterday at the restaurant racket trial.
The police halted a heavy, zigzagging road roller today, took the driver to the station house on a charge of drunken driving, and went back after the roller.

Postmaster General James A. Farley predicted today that "the people will support the President in any program he undertakes." Addressing Alabama Democrats at a "victory luncheon," Mr. Farley made no specific mention of the President's Supreme Court proposal or of other pending matters. He said he expected to discuss the court proposal in an address tomorrow at Chapel Hill, N. C.

Business failures in the United States for the week ended March 4, numbered 174, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 166 for the fiveday week ended Feb. 25, and with 201 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Less than eight hours after the battered body of Mrs. Esther Bartnofsky, 75 years old, was found in the bedroom of her son's home at 1,733 West Fifth Street, in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn, yesterday, the police arrested Mrs. Bessie Bartnofsky, 45, her daughterin-law, and charged her with the murder.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, trustee under the prior lien mortgage of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company dated July 1, 1916, has notified the New York Stock Exchange of the release from the lien of $4,467,000 Fort Worth Rio Grande Railway Company first mortgage bonds due in 1928, 29,283 shares of capital stock in the same company and $780,347 of the same company's 6 per cent demand notes.

A battle on the part of counsel for one against a proposal to remove from Vermont for psychiatric examination two boys alleged to be involved in the drowning of little Beverly Ann Page caused indefinite postponement today of a court hearing scheduled for tomorrow.

Brig. Gen. Henry G. Learnard, U.S.A., retired, the first officer of the China Relief Expedition in 1900 to scale the walls of Peking and a veteran of the Philippine Insurrection and the World War, died in Walter Reed General Hospital last night at the age of 69.
A series of sit-down strikes tonight hampered operations at the Goodrich factory here and were reported by United Rubber Workers of America sources to be spreading through the plant.
Yale tonight defeated Springfield College at boxing, 6 to 2. Four bouts were defaulted by Springfield and one by the Elis. Ott Miller of Yale scored in the 155-pound class by a technical knock-out.

Every household chore but dishwashing was performed last night by sixteen girls in the Home Economics Department of New York University's School of Education when they prepared dinner for their parents at the Education Building, Forty-one West Fourth Street.

The Long Island University A. A., a varsity-freshman combination, caught the train for Denver last night, winning the Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball title and a free ride to the national championships in the Colorado capital. But the Blackbirds had to go into overtime to do it.

The unquestioned victory of the parties supporting the government in yesterday's general elections has closed a period of six months of political uncertainties, it is admitted by a majority of newspapers today.
The most drastic wave of sit-down strikes that the automobile industry has experienced in one day hit Detroit today in the midst of collective bargaining conferences.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today,, dated March 5: COMMANDERS Byrnes, J. C., Washington, D. C., to the Idaho as executive officer, about March 31. Crutchfield, J. A.. Washington, D. C., to the San Francisco as executive officer in March.
That Italy foiled a plan of Austrian monarchists to place Archduke Otto on the Austrian throne was suggested tonight by Virginio Gayda in the Giornale d'Italia.

A pair of American-owned jumpers, J. B. Snow's Delachance and Robert Lehman's Didoric, both well backed, today were quoted at 100 to 7 each in the call-over for the Grand National steeplechase March 19 at Aintree.

The United States Government on Saturday refused to approve a request of Vincent Auriol, the French Minister of Finance, that this government agree to the appointment of some bank in New York to act as agents in this country for the payment of coupons of the $1,000,000,000 French defense loan in cases where payment is requested in dollars.

Shakespeare Av., 11,272 (9-2506); Khyber Realties, Inc., to Cecilia J. Karl, 3,067 Sedgwick Av.; 5 years, 5 per cent; $10,000. Perry Av. (12-3346 and 11-3198), e. s., 220 ft. n. of 205th St., 125X100; also Grand av., n. e. cor. of Evelyn Pl., 100x100; Brandon Holding Corp. to Abraham Tabachnick, executor, 1,160 Cromwell Av.; installments, 5 per cent; $12,000.

What is believed to be an ancient temple of the Kings of the Mixtecan Indians, who most archaeologists think predate the Aztecs, has been discovered by Dr. Alfonso Caso at Tilantongo, near the Monte Alban ruins in the State of Oaxaca.

Seventy workers in the Hy-Grade Dress Company here staged a sitdown strike this morning in the landlord's office because the loft in which they were supposed to work was too cold for comfortslightly above 50 degrees.
Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe got a pay rise today and a recommendation City for further increases when North St Himsworth -Township is able to pay.

Both buyers' arrivals and mail orders and reorders increased in the women's apparel and accessory markets here yesterday, reflecting the headway made by pre-Easter trade in practically all sections of the country last week. Buyers sought to expedite deliveries on coats and suits, which have now reached the peak output period.

The special election today in San Francisco on the proposed charter amendment to authorize the city to issue $50,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance municipal distribution of electricity has drawn widespread interest in utility circles here.

National Public Housing Conference, City Hall, 10:30 A. M. Speakers; Mayor La Guardia, Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, B. M. Pettit, Captain Richard L. Reins, Jonah J. Goldstein. Afternoon session, 2. Speakers: Fannie Hurst, Langdon W. Post, Ira S. Robbins, Captain Reiss.

An attempt by three armed men to stage a hold-up in the New Deal Democratic Club, 3,033 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, was frustrated last night by a woman member of the club who locked them in the clubroom while they were herding sixty-five others into a corner.

The Rev. Dr. John H. Lathrop, chairman of the Brooklyn Committee, for Christian German Refugees, appealed yesterday to his fellow-clergymen to "present the actual story of German persecution" to their congregations.

Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" was performed last night, for the first time this season, in the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance was not of a high order, though it included a debut which had certain features of interest in the appearance of Franca Somigli in the title part.

Mrs. Arline Bennet Schley of 1,340 Second Avenue, New York, asked Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief today to declare her wealthy father-in-law, Henry Spaulding Schley, a cousin of Admiral Winfield Scott Schley of Spanish-American War fame, a mental incompetent.

Endowment Deputy Chief Henry L. Finch has endowed a bed at the Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled, for the benefit of crippled children of members of the Uniformed Force of this Department, as a memorial to his parents. Application for the use of this bed should be made, in writing, to the Fire Chief and Commissioner, whereupon the necessary arrangements will be made.
Farm leaders from a dozen States endorsed crop insurance before a Senate committee today, although several committee members and witnesses said that such legislation might be held unconstitutional.

Republican women from all parts of the State gathered at the Capital today for a two-day conference, at which they will discuss party affairs and leading legislative topics such as child labor, minimum wage legislation, State finances and education. County party leaders and members of the Republican State Committee are in attendance.

The Canadian Pacific Railway issued today a preliminary statement of its combined operations for 1936, showing $6,029,184 transferred to the profit-and-loss account. This was $3,197,100 more than the balance for 1935.

Cars and trucks of the General Motors Corporation sold to dealers in the United States in February numbered 49,674, compared with 70,901 in the preceding month and 116,762 in February, 1936, Alfred P. Sloan Jr. reported yesterday.

Market reacted in final hour and closed generally lower, with Chrysler shares weakest on strike news; turnover, 3,175,170 shares. United States Government issues lower, corporate and foreign bonds irregular; transactions, $16,924,600.

Plans for a block of fourteen sixstory apartments in Forest Hills, Queens, to cost $1,755,000 were filed yesterday by the Farmers Estates Corporation. The same corporation recently filed specifications for a number of multi-family structures in the vicinity. Plans also were filed for twenty-eight one-family houses in Whitestone, ten in St. Albans and for several extensive alterations in Manhattan. The list follows:

The management of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Lebanon plant announced today it had sent "all the facts" in the strike of its 2,500 men to James F. Dewey, United States Conciliation Commissioner.
Miss Yoshiko Tokudaiji reversed the usual custom of presents for the bride and planned today to distribute 1,500,000 classical Japanese fans as her wedding present to the people of Kyoto.

Brig. Gen. John Colt Beaumont United States Marine Corps, and Mrs. Helen F. Tucker of Washington, D. C., obtained a marriage license at the Municipal Building yesterday. They plan to marry here on April 3 in the Church of the Transfiguration.

The marriage of Miss Margaret W. Dorrance, daughter of Mrs. John T. Dorrance of Woodcrest, Radnor, and of the late Dr. Dorrance, to George Strawbridge, sonof John Strawbridge of Chestnut Hill and the late Mrs. Strawbridge,

The special election today in San Francisco on the proposed charter amendment to authorize the city to issue $50,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance municipal distribution of electricity has drawn widespread interest in utility circles here.

National Public Housing Conference, City Hall, 10:30 A. M. Speakers; Mayor La Guardia, Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, B. M. Pettit, Captain Richard L. Reins, Jonah J. Goldstein. Afternoon session, 2. Speakers: Fannie Hurst, Langdon W. Post, Ira S. Robbins, Captain Reiss.

An attempt by three armed men to stage a hold-up in the New Deal Democratic Club, 3,033 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, was frustrated last night by a woman member of the club who locked them in the clubroom while they were herding sixty-five others into a corner.

The real story behind the seizure of the Spanish motorship Mar Cantabrico came out here today from diplomatic sources that long had been expecting some such development as occurred-yesterday in the Bay of Biscay. From the vry day the freighter left New York the Spanish Insurgents were aware of her every movement and her fate was sealed.

Mary Pickford, accompanied by her niece, Gwynne Pickford, arrived here today on the Berengaria. She will go to London to remain two weeks and then will go on a motor trip on the Continent, visiting Paris, Cannes and Italian cities. She will return to the United States during the first half of May.
Receipts of hogs were somewhat above trade expectations today and prices generally declined 10 to 15 cents; with light weights off as much as 25 cents at times. The demand for the latter was slow.

In their last competition before meeting the Yale Freshmen Harvard's Cubs defeated the Dean Academy five, 31 to 21, in the new indoor athletic building today. The game was loosely played throughout. Harvard led, 6 to 5,

New York will become the host tonight to the greatest gathering of bowlers ever assembled at one spot when the doors of the 212th Coast Artillery Armory are thrown open for the thirty-seventh annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress.
In. chill tunnels far below the Loop and the Chicago River tonight fifty motormen of the Chicago Tunnel Company continued a sit-down strike begun in the afternoon.

Jascha Heifetz, internationally famous violinist, almost lost two instruments insured for $150,000 and got "the shock of my life" today. He walked out of a Dundee station restaurant, leaving behind a Stradivarius, purchased with the first money he earned on the American concert stage, and a Joseph Guarnerius, a present from his father.

Commodity futures generally were firm in trading on the local markets yesterday. Advances were registered by coffee, world sugar, hide, silk, copper, tin, lead, zinc, cottonseed oil and wool top futures. Cocoa and domestic sugar contracts lost ground. Rubber futures were irregular. On the cash market all the grains, cotton, tins, lead and butter advanced, but cocoa, raw sugar, silk and lard declined.

A. T. Partridge's Conte, a son of Reigh Count who was left at the post in his last appearance at Hialeah Park, upset calculations at Tropical Park today when he easily won the Angelfish Purse, mile and a sixteenth headliner of an eightrace card.
Robert Louis Stevenson's "Ebb Tide," which was brought to the silent screen in 1922, was announced by Paramount today under the title "With the Tide" as tone of its two color films for the season.

Henry Grady, American member of the League of Nations committee studying the access to raw materials, stressed today that "discrimination in all international economic as well as commercial matters" was the chief evil to be overcome.

Ed Meske, 218, Akron, Ohio, and Gino Garibaldi, 218, St. Louis, wrestled to a draw in the feature match before 1,000 persons- at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Both men fell out of the ring and were counted out. The time was 35 minutes.

Ranger, the new America's Cup yacht being built for Harold S. Vanderbilt as the prospective defender to meet T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II in the international match starting off Newport on July 31, is to have a real rival for that honor.

Miss Emily Barnes of 435 West. 119th Street, a teacher in the sixth grade .of the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack while being taken to the Columbia Presbyterian Medical

Joseph A. Frick tried to figure out today how he can comply with German laws and still enjoy a $3,000 estate to which he is heir. An aunt willed him a flourishing Bavarian inn and 6,000 marks in cash, but German export laws forbid removal of cash from the Reich, Frick said.

Senator Logan of Kentucky put before the Senate today letters denying a statement he submitted to that body a few days ago that the Kentucky Utilities Company was responsible for solicitation of telegrams against the Roosevelt court plan.

Harry Danziger and R. Weinstock, American members of the Manhattan String Quartet, were obliged to change their names for program purposes to Deninger and Winstone at the instance of the management of Konzerthaus, where the quartet gave their first Vienna concert tonight. The players' names,

Reversing its previous position in view of recent Supreme Court rulings, the Court of Appeals today upheld the State Fair Trade Law, which it had declared unconstitutional on Jan. 7, 1936. The court divided 5 to 1.

Last Thursday I described in detail certain economic problems which every one admits now face the nation. For the many messages which have come to me after that speech, and which it is physically impossible to answer individually, I take this means of saying "Thank you."
Governor Hoffman rebuked the New Jersey League of Women Voters today for what he declared to be a "rare and unusual attempt" to misrepresent his position with regard to the sitdown strike.

Governor Hoffman signed today two bills passed by the Legislature, extending for one month from Thursday the period within which municipal budgets for 1937 must be adopted and suspending for this year the provision of the new Budget. Act requiring inclusion in 1937 budgets 35 per cent of the floating debt.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week set another high record, averaging 3,298,800 barrels a day, compared with 3,296,100 the week before and an average daily output of 3,294,200 barrels for the four weeks ended on March 6, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Speedy disposition of a case before the National Labor Relations Board was hailed yesterday as one of the most encouraging developments in the complex relations of marine labor and marine employers since the end of the maritime strike.

Orders were issued last night for the arrest of a former henchman of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in connection with the murder of Norman Redwood, sandhog union leader, at Teaneck, N. J., on Feb. 19.

MANHATTAN BROWNELL, GEORGE F. (April 15, 1934). Gross assets, $1,638,715; net. $1,593,261. To Anne Abbott Brownell, widow, onefourth residue outright, life estate in onefourth residue and contingent interest In one-fourth residue; George A. Brownell, son, $10,000, life estate in $50,000, threeeighths residue outright and remainder in one-eighth residue: Abbott F. Brownell,

Luitweiler, Kellogg Co. have notified the New York Stock Exchange of a proposal to dissolve their partnership, effective March 15. On the same date the firm of Bendix, Luitweiler Co. will be formed, including Ludwig Bendix, J. C. Luitweiler, Cornelius Lipsky and Henry D. Talvot as general partners and Karl T. Frederick and Joseph Zawadski as limited partners.

In complimenting a jury in General Sessions yesterday for convicting a liquor salesman of third-degree assault in an attack that led to the death of a young lawyer of a cerebral hemorrhage, Judge George L. Donnellan said:
Columbia moved into a tie with Harvard and Yale for third place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League last night by defeating the Crimson, 38-25, in the Worningside Heights gymnasium.

Holders of common stock of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation approved yesterday a reduction in capital of $1,800,000 through the retirement of 120,000 common shares of no-par value which had been held in the treasury.

The War Departmeht today released the following orders, dated March 8: COLONELS Green, J. A., C. A. C., relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps. Ft. Sam Houston, Texas. May 31, and assigned to office of the Chief of Coast Artillery, Washington, D. C.

The magnificent Second symphony of Sibelius, considered cryptic and uncomfortably harsh and dour a few years ago, is now a surefire item of orchestral programs. It was the principal feature of the instrumental part of the concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, with Lawrence Tibbett as assisting soloist, last night in Carnegie Hall.

Buddy Hirsch's Columbiana broke the American speed record for fillies over a mile and a quarter by running the distance in 2:014-5 in the Widener Challenge Cup handicap at Hialeah Park Saturday, a search of the records by The Associated Press disclosed yesterday.

With higher labor and material costs emphasizing the need for greater sales volume, "everything depends upon advertising in the coming year," because it is the driving force to bring additional volume, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of Boston in the Hotel Statler, Boston.

The WPA Federal Music Project and Art Projects will formally open the Music-Art Center, 1 West 123d Street, this afternoon. Due to the large registration in the centers already functioning in Harlem, it was found necessary to establish a school where both music and art classes would be available to children and adults.

France today discarded her famous floating jail-the prison ship La Martiniere, which has carried more than 10,000 convicts to Devil's Island since 1921. The ship, turned over to a commeroial shipping concern by the government, henceforth will carry bananas, sugar and rum.

Some of the best known stars of indoor polo will take part in tonight's benefit "Evening of Polo" at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn, the games having been arranged as a benefit for the American Legion Mountain Camp Endowment Fund.

Stockholders of A. M. Castle Co. approved yesterday in Chicago an increase in authorized common stock from 120,000 to 300,000 shares of $10 par value, and the issuance of two new shares for each present share.

John P. Frey, vice president of the American Federation of Labor and foe of the John L. Lewis industrial union forces, arrived here tonight and met secretly with employee representatives of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

His usually magic putter failed Gene Sarazen of Brookfield Center, Conn., today, causing him and Jimmy Hines of Garden'City, L.I., his partner, to be eliminated in the second round of the annual international fourball matches. They lost to Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., and Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., 4 and 3, over the 36-hole route, the same score by which Sarazen and Hines lost to Picard and Revolta in last, year's final.

Dr. Lauge Koch, Arctic explorer, today lost a libel suit against nine Danish and two German geological scientists who in a pamphlet had criticized his scientific work, Geology of Greenland, in words that Dr. Koch found insulting to his honor. He asked 2,000 kroner damages, but after several months of hearings the high court found for the defendants with costs.

The report of the sinking of the Mar Cantabrico in the Bay of Biscay by a Spanish Rebel cruiser was cited today by Congressional advocates of the "cash-and-carry" policy for American trade with belligerents as a perfect example of the merits of their program.

The House of Representatives today de-. feated, 109 to 84, a bill to repeal Georgia's 22-year-old prohibition law. The Vote, on a bill by Representative Williani Hastings of Fulton (Atlanta) County, came after two days of debate.

The "puller-in," an institution for a century in the retail clothing trade contiguous to the Bowery, but declining in recent years, was publicly disowned yesterday in the Tombs Court by an organization of his former employers. Hyman Bleunberg, attorney for the East Side Merchants Association, denounced the persuasive puller-in as a detriment to trade.

The House Immigration Committee completed today its hearings on the Dickstein Bill to restrict entry of alien stage performers to this country, but a final vote on the question of reporting or tabling the proposal will not be taken before next week, Representative Dickstein of New York, chairman, announced.

Turpentine firm, 39c: sales, 120 barrels; receipts, 68 barrels; shipments, 25 barrels; stock, 23,128 barrels. Rosin, firm: sales, 553 barrels: receipts, 331 barrels; shipments, 228 barrels; stock, 54,698 barrels. Quote: B, $8.10; D, $8.40; E, $8.80: F. $9.20: G to N, $9.25; WG, $9.45; WW, $11; X. $11.50.

P. D. O'Brien of the Brown University Club, No: 7, only seeded player to see action, subdued P. B. Diesroth of the Squash Club, 15-10, 15-10, 9-15, 15-4, yesterday at the Downtown A. C. to gain the round of sixteen in the metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship.

Sammy Richardson of the Achilles Club of Toronto, the British Empire sprint and broad jump champion, will be among the starters in the 60-yard dash in the New York Chapter, K. of C., meet at Madison Square Garden on St. Patrick's Night, it was announced yesterday.

A brilliant rally in the closing frames gave Joseph R. Johann, defending champion, a 200-146 triumph in twenty-six innings over Howard Bergman in the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline championship at the Capitol Health Center last night.
Memories of the romance of the late Archduke Leopold Ferdinand of Austria with a commoner were recalled today with the filing of suit by his former wife for $200 monthly allowance.

Miss Judith Hamlin, daughter of Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin of New York and East Hampton, L. I., and by Charles Percy Frederick North, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick North of Rougham Hall, Norfolk, England, whose marriage will take place tomorrow afternoon, were guests of honor at a large supper dance given by a group of their friends last night at L'Aperitif Restaurant.

After a debate of more than three hours the Assembly late this afternoon overwhelmingly defeated the Kleinfeld resolution for ratification of the child labor amendment to the Federal Constitution. The vote was 102 to 42.

Testimony that fifty revolvers were "borrowed" from the Wilmington headquarters of the Delaware State Police and shipped to Hopewell, Va., for possible use in a textile strike in May, 1934, was introduced today. as the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage concluded its inquiry into the William J. Burns International Detective Agency.

Members of the Italian Historical Society will give a reception and dinner next Wednesday in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Olivia Rossetti Agresti, European commentator now on a tour of this country. Dancing in the Crystal Garden will follow the address by. Mrs. Agresti. The event is under the patronage of Fulvio Suvich, Italfan Ambassador, and Mrs. Suvich.

The "Big Four" houses of the packing industry today announced wage increases which bring basic rates of pay for employes on hourly or piece work payrolls to the highest point in history. The announcement, made in Chicago by Swift Co., Armour Co.. Wilson Co. and the Cudahy

Straits tin was advanced 31/4 cents in the spot market yesterday to a new high mark of 63 1/4 cents, a level exceeded only in eighteen of the twenty-two months between November, 1925, and August, 1927, inclusive, and during the World War.

It is instructive in these days of Federal insistence that the States of the Union cannot solve their mutual problems to find an interstate body right at our front door quietly and efficiently solving all the problems which come within its scope and prospering in the process. The annual report of the Port of New York Authority just submitted to the Governors and Legislatures

Continuing his splendid play, Frank Iannicelli of the New York A. C., head of the seeded list, defeated A. D. Weekes Jr., Harvard Club representative, 15-7, 15-9, at the Harvard Club yesterday to gain the semi-final round in the national Class C squash tennis championship competition.

Retail food costs declined during the five weeks ended Feb. 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics index standing at 84.5 on that date, as compared with 84.6 on Jan. 12 and 80.6 on Feb. 11, 1936. The index is based on the three-year average 1923-'25.

The House completed general debate today on the Guffey-Vinson Coal Bill, setting up Federal regulation for the bituminous industry as a substitute for the law invalidated by the Supreme Court last April. A vote is expected on Thursday.
Disposing of an estate estimated by attorneys at about $100,000, the will of Lottie Blair Parker, author of "Way Down East," was filed for probate here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell.

Larry Kelley tonight duplicated on the basketball court his football and baseball- superman exploits. With thirty-six secondss remaining he tossed the longest basket of an evenly fought Yale Penn State game, tying the score, and then, with only six seconds left; he shot the basket that won for the Elis, 33 to 31.

While the military champions of Germany and France arm with mutual distrust, their skiing champions show another conception of rivalry. Yesterday, after Rudi Cranz of Germany had surprised every one by nosing out Emile Allais of France, the world champion, in the first heat of the Arlberg-Kandahar

Victory for the so-called "New Deal" group in the New York Printing Pressmen's Union, No. 2, was revealed yesterday with the announcement of the results in the balloting of members of the union on Monday. The opposition carried off four of the five offices.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 573--Highland Farms Dairy, Inc., and Luther W. High, appits. V. J. P. Agnew, chairman, etc al., Argument continued for appeilees concluded for applts. concluded for applts.

The influence of higher education has been missing from the closing stages of the national A. A. U. basketball tournament for several years now. But several college teams mean to do something about it in this year's competition, which starts Sunday.

The Rev. Robert L. Hector of the Spiritualist Church of Universal Brotherhood in West Seventysecond Street and Edgar Allen, a theatrical booking agent, staying at the Hotel Edison, were held in $1,000 bail each by Magistrate Dreyer in the Felony Court yesterday on a grand larceny charge, to which they pleaded not guilty.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ended today its study of Harrison Williams's public utilities empire with evidence intended to show that the Shenandoah Corporation had huge actual and book losses in the stock market crash

Mrs. James Truslow Adams of London and Sheffield House, Southport, Conn., is at the New Weston. Mrs. Andrew McClean Parker of 14 East Sixtieth Street is in Charleston, S. C., for the rest of the month. Mr. and Mrs. William Wallace Kellett of Philadelphia are at the Biltmore.

Several hundred union carpenters, bricklayers, plasterers, electricians and metal workers declared a "holiday" today to picket two non-union building jobs. Edward Finney, president of the Building Trades Council, said that more than 600 union craftsmen reported for picket duty at a building being built for a meat packing concern and at a new school building.

Mrs. Ruth Morgenthau Naumburg obtained a divorce today from George W. Naumburg, retired New York banker. Mrs. Naumburg, sister of Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, took residence in Reno early in February.

The American people last November gave President Roosevelt no mandate to curb the Supreme Court, Dr. Glenn Frank, former University of Wisconsin president, told 1,000 members of the New York Credit Men's Association last night at the organization's annual dinner at the Waldorf Astoria.

The traditional method of saluting the flag will be retained in the public schools of this city as the preferred and officially endorsed method of pledging allegiance. Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, made clear yesterday.
Colonel John E. Munroe, who was on duty s in the office of the Chief of Ordnance of the army, died in Walter 8 Reed Hospital yesterday at the age of 56.

The Pittsburgh Steel Company of Pittsburgh filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 41,900 shares of $100-par 5 1/2 per cent prior preferred stock, 104,750 shares of Class A 5 per cent preferred stock and 104,750 shares of no-par value common stock to be issued under a plan of capital readjustment.

A tea was given yesterday in the Louis XVI suite of the St. Regis by Mrs. G. Clinton Fogwell for members of the Women's Field Army of the American Society for the Control of Cancer. A film entitled "Fight Cancer with Knowledge" was shown by Dr. Arthur H. Estabrooke. Mrs. Marjorie B.
Mrs. Helen Berroyer, one of four persons convicted of mail fraud in an attempted baby hoax, will leave tomorrow for Alderson, W. Va., to begin a five-year prison term.

Declaring that while loyalty to party is essential, the welfare of the Nation is preeminent, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, addressed a students' nonpartisan organization at the University of North Carolina this afternoon on the Roosevelt plan to reorganize the Supreme Court.
New Yorkdrawn plans for refinancing and modernizing Seattle's municipallyowned street railway system were rejected today by the voters of Seattle on a referendum from the City Council.

Pay increases ranging from $10 to $80 a month for the operating personnel on thirty-six vessels operated on the five government-owned steamship lines were announced today by the Maritime Commission as in effect since March 1 for officers and since Feb. 3 for unlicensed personnel.
Two noted women dog mushers barked commands to their teams today which will be pitted against those of eleven crack men mushers in the big three-day Ice Carnival Derby, starting Friday.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City: General Conditions Trading in steer hinds and ribs and veal hindsaddles was fair.
