Lamb moved slowly at recent advance and fresh pork cuts sold unevenly. Kosher beef and veal opened barely steady; lamb steady.

The New Friends of Music, Inc., will present a cycle of sixteen music and lieder concerts devoted to the major works of Mozart, Schubert and Schumann for its second season, 1937-38, at the Town Hall, it was announced yesterday.

The powerful Montreal Maroons regained second place in the National Hockey League's International Division tonight by whipping the Canadiens, 4 to 1, in the next to last intracity clash of the regular season. The victory broke the Maroons' tie with the idle Toronto Maple Leafs and placed them only 7 points behind the Canadiens, group leaders.

El Puma, 3-year-old distance horse owned by D. J. Sullivan 3d galloped in a winner in the feature race, the Little America claiming purse, at Epsom Downsi day. A Ladies' Day crowd of around 6,000 cheered the veteran campaigner, one of the favorites.
Dr. Paul Elmer More, educator, critic and editor, died today at his home here, 59 Battle Road, after a long illness' He was 72 years old and had lived in Princeton for the last twenty-one years.

Four men on trial for mail fraud and conspiracy, based on allegations that they falsely promised to help victims get back investments from defunct corporations, heard a former employee testify against 'them yesterday before Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell and a jury.

The Lerner Stores Corporation and subsidiaries yesterday reported for the year ended on Jan. 31 last a net profit of $2,181,510 after depreciation and provision for Federal income and excess profit taxes and $110,018 for surtax on undistributed income.

Authority to negotiate with labor representatives until a solution is reached on the employee pension problem was given today by the Association of American Railroads to its Committee of Seven at a meeting here of about 100 railroad executives.

Violence, accompanied by gun fire, flared this afternoon in the fifth day of Chicago's taxicab strike as drivers for the Yellow Cab and Checker Taxi Companies fought back for the first time at company efforts to break the strike. No one was hurt,

Margaret Plass Wilbur, 15-yearold bride, who was recently found guilty of juvenile delinquency, was ordered to separate from her husband today by Judge J. Gordon Flannery in the Children's Court. He placed her on probation for two years.

After investigating for several days charges of criminal negligence against Joseph Rizzo, 18 years old, of 45-09 162d Street, Flushing, Queens, in connection with the death of Mrs. Elizabeth Clark, 56, of 146-25 Cherry Avenue, Flushing,
British troops poured into Northwest India tonight to put down a revolt reportedly led

Trading in real properties in the Bronx reported by brokers yesterday was featured by the sale of a number of apartments, investors and operators being equally represented in the day's activity. Several vacant building plots also changed hands, and leases on several entire business buildings were closed.

A marked revival in European demand for cash wheat and reports of dry weather and duststorms in the Southwest sent prices up around 1 1/2 cents a bushel at the extreme today on the Board of Trade here. The May sold at a new high price for the current movement.

The Tunisian labor troubles, which have provoked riots costing a score of lives, have been settled by a compromise between the employers and the labor unions. The sit-down strikers were evacuating the phosphate mines today and work will be resumed tomorrow morning..

President Anastasio Somoza fixed the exchange rate today at two cordobas for one dollar and announced that speculators would be severely punished. Speculators had taken advantage of the slow shipments of coffee and other exports and the cordoba fell to three to one dollar.

MANHATTAN BUTLER, WILLIAM H. (Feb. 12). Estate, more than $20,000. To Gladys V. Butler, daughter, Cas-Alta, 1 Dialle Machiavell, Florence, R 3, Italy, residue; Florence Vivian Butler-Burke, niece, executrix, 2 Via Tornabuoni, Florence, Italy, $10,000. R. Wayland-Smith, Riverside, Conn., and Joseph T. Van Loan, 400 E. 57th St., executors.
The United Automobile Workers' statement of reasons why it is asking sole bargaining rights in Chrysler plants was as follows:

Engaging in his first serious pitching workout since last October when he was gently waved out of the box in the sixth game of theworld series, Lefty Vernon Gomez was something of a mild sensation today at Huggins Field, where the Yankees went through another brisk workout.

An nouncement of the liquidation of thirty-two receiverships of national banks in February was made today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of Currency. This made 603 receiverships closed or restored to solvency since the banking holiday of March, 1933, when the Roosevelt administration took office.

With solemn deference to those students of the American theatre who might be interested in midnineteenth century play forms, the Federal Theatre Project let itself go last evening in a whirl of red plush and bombast and put on at Daly's Sixty-third Street Theatre a trio of museum pieces, interlarded with a couple of olios, which fetched up broadly in the "hiss-thevillain" class.

MEN OF MATHEMATICS: The Lives and Achievements of the Great Mathematicians from Zeno to Poincare, by E. T. Bell. (Simon Schuster, $5.) For the general reader. THE FASCIST: HIS STATE AND, HIS MIND, by E. B. Ashton. (Morrow, $2.50.) An abstract study of Fascism.
Under ideal rowing conditions, Cambridge University's crew rowed today from Hammersmith Bridge to the Putney Bridge just two seconds over the record of 7 minutes 18 seconds.

After Monday's sharp setback, prices on the Cotton Exchange resumed their upward movement yesterday. Trade and commissionhouse buying lifted the list nearly $2 a bale, net gains of 19 to 23 points being reported for the day. May sold at 13 3/4 cents a pound, while all months ended the session above the 13-cent level, with the spot position above 14 cents, the highest close of the season.

Plans whereby Chevrolet, leader of the industry for seven years out of the last ten, expects to achieve its second consecutive million-car year in 1937 were unfolded to some 300 dealers, sales managers and salesmen yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, by H. L. Horton, Atlantic Coast regional manager, and P. R. Letts, New York zone manager.

Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Ambassador, will leave Berlin tomorrow to resume his post in London, it is understood here. The greatest interest is being shown in his return because the diplomatic exchanges that will undoubtedly take place soon after his arrival are expected to indicate whether the present German policy for Great Britain will continue.

President Roosevelt appointed Joseph P. Kennedy as chairman and named four other permanent members of the Maritime Com- Vi mission. Tonight he broadcast to the nation a speech on his proposals for reorganization of the Federal judiciary.

MARIE BASHKRTSEFF is a name known to most readers. But do many know more than the mere name? Marie .Bashkirtseff died over fifty years ago. Her famous journal, which even the eminently respectable W. E. Gladstone thought a work of "true genius,' was first published in an American edition in 1889.- In the interval much has happened to. rob the author of her fame: the talented and ambitious girl.

These orders were issued in the Northern New York Reserve Area: The following Reserve officers recently promoted are assigned as indicated: 390TH INFANTRY--lst Lt. Frank C. Dellecese,. Inf.-Res., 317 Pleasant St., Utica,N. Y. 392D INFANTRY--1st Lt. Louis J. Klinge, Inf.-Res., 36 Euclid Ay., Jamestown, N. Y.

Here is something that should prove good news for the batters in the National League this year not toiling under the banner of the Giants. Carl Hubbell, master moundsman of the circuit, is not perfecting a new delivery to add to his already extensive repertoire, which includes his famous screwball and an equally baffling curve.

Walter Peter Steffen, judge of the Cook County Superior Court, former head football coach of Carnegie Tech and one of the greatest football stars ever developed at the University of Chicago, died tonight in his home here. He was 51.

Mayor La Guardia signed the Haas ordinance yesterday, limiting the number of taxicabs in the city to the number already licensed. The Mayor approved strongly of the measure, since he has advocated limitation of taxicabs since 1920. Introduced by Alderman Lew I.

A stunned hockey world yesterday mourned the death of one of its greatest players. The news that Howie Morenz had succumbed suddenly to a heart attack in Montreal left his friends and admirers almost incredulous.
Tomorrow is the anniversary of the blizzard of 1888, celebrated in local song and story, As the years roll by the song grows more

Villa Toradale, the Tokeneke home of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Ellsworth, who were visiting in Pasadena, Calif., was wrecked by vandals, a police inquiry revealed today. Some one went through the house with an axe and smashed pianos, paintipgs, antiques and other valuable furnishings. The police estimated the damage at $25,000.
This afternoon, for the first time since the season of 1924-25, Broadway will see Katharine Cornell as Candida in Mr. Shaw's play of that name.

The Transamerica Corporation reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net profit of $25,016,200 after all deductions. This was equal to $1.08 a share on 23,181,568 shares of stock. It compared with $20,319,276, or 87% cents a share, in 1935.

Plans for an eleven-story apartment house for Jerome Avenue in the Bronx to cost,$500,000, and for an extension to the Goelet Park Avenue store building on the west side of the avenue between Fiftythird and Fifty-fourth Streets, to provide for a theater. were filed yesterday.

A fair value of $125 a share has been placed on the $5 dividend noncallable preferred stock of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company by a committee appointed by the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court to appraise the issue.

The hold-out troubles of the Senators ended today with the signing of Pitcher Buck Newsom. Newsom came to camp yesterday to dicker personally with Owner Clark Griffith. He reportedly took a $2,000 salary slash and signed for around $9,000.

Netherlanders see a harbinger of returning prosperity in the opening here today of the thirty-sixth Netherlands Spring Industries Fair with an unprecedented number of participants, 1,779 against 1,645 last year.
Arturo Godoy, the free-swinging heavyweight from Chile, and Maurice Strickland of New Zealand will clash in the star bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome tonilght.

Edward Johnson's contract as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association has been 'extended for two years covering the seasons 1937-38, 1938-39, as was exclusively published in last Thursday's TIMES.
Flechtseim, formerly one of the leading art dealers and critics of Germany, died here today at the. age of 60. He had been living in London for more than two years.

Mayor La Guardia told the National Public Housing Conference at an all-day session at City Hall yesterday that progress was being made toward a solution of the lowcost housing problem. Addressing 500 members of sixty-five organizations represented at the conference on slum clearance and low-rent public housing, Mr. La Guardia said:
Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the transfer of three lieutenants and seven sergeants from the Bathgate Avenue Station, in the Bronx, to other precincts.

Measures which would have the effect of writing into State law provisions of the National Labor Relations Act were praised by representatives of organized labor today at a public hearing and opposed by spokesmen for employers and civic groups.

Mrs. Helen Kerruish Buffum, widow of Frederic D. Buffum of Cleveland, was married to Edward .S. Whitney of Montclair, N. J., today in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. Walter. R. Breed officited in the presence. of relatives and friends, including Mr. Whitney's daughters,

Representatives of stockholders, bondholders and other interested parties in the reorganization of the New York, New 'Haven Hartford Railroad suggested today in United States District Court here that Henry B. Sawyer of Boston be named the third trustee, succeeding Professor Winthrop M. Daniels, who resigned recently owing to ill health. Howard S. Palmer.

William S. Murray, Republican State Chairman, voiced a plea for better human relationships between employer and employee to Republican women leaders here today, as Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, vice chairman, assailed President Roosevelt for his court revision program.

Award of engineering contracts totaling $1,088,998 were announced by the War Department today as follows Merritt Dredging Company of Charleston, S. C., for dredging Wappo Creek, waterway- from Charleston to Beaufort, S. C. $12,427.

The anti-Semitic "Prophecy" attributed to Benjamin Franklin and distributed in Germany within the last few days by the government news service was identified on publication here yesterday as a document that made its appearance here in 1934 and was investigated for several months by Professor Charles A. Beard, one of the foremost historians of this country. He pronounced it "a barefaced forgery."

While Manager Burleigh Grimes today directed his fifty athletes in a long-delayed batting practice and otherwise put them through preliminary paces, two statements suddenly flew from other directions.
Iona Prep defeated Power Memorial Academy, 22 to 16, at the Manhattan College gymnasium last night to reach the final of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Asqneiation Basketball tournament.

Continuing what the union terms its "mopping up" campaign against buildings which have refused to enter into contracts or have failed to abide by existing agreements, the Building Service Employes Union called strikes yesterday in ten apartment houses on the West Side.

Supporters of the Child Labor Amendment to the Federal Constitution renewed today their fight, begun more than a decade ago, to have Connecticut join the States which have ratified it. A large crowd gathered in the House for a public hearing on the proposal before the Federal Relations Committee of the General Assembly.

Two private dwellings on the East Side of Manhattan and several properties on the upper West Side were reported yesterday as having passed into new hands. In the first change of ownership in sixty-six years, the four-story residence at 128 East Sixty-first Street was acquired by a new syndicate represented by the Raymond P. Quinn Company.

Mr. and Mrs. Terence Kenyon of London, who are at the Surf Club, entertained there today for Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hill, Lady Dudley, Miss Diana Fishwick and Captain Macintosh, all of London. Bontet de Monvel, the French painter and illustrator, and Grover Loening, were guests of C. Alan Hudson Jr. of New York at the
The 1937 sailing of the Normandie, France's greatest ship, for New York with 500 passengers may have to be canceled or delayed by yet another strike.

Meeting of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, Community House, Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, 10:30 A. M. "The Supreme Court and the Constitution of the United States," Morris L. Ernst, Judge Clarence J. Shearn.

Laura E. Richards recently spent her eighty-eighth birthday correcting the proofs of a book she has written for children. Mrs. Richards is the daughter of Julia Ward Howe. Her new book is a story of a trip to England that Henry Richards, her husband, made alone.at the age of 9.

The stock market here today was steady and generally quiet. Although rubber shares continued active, they were affected by profit-taking. Gilt-edge issues, after fresh selling, staged a recovery and were better at the close. Foreign bonds were idle for the most part.
Upsets overtook two of the leading lights. in the tournament when first-round matches of the Belleview Biltmore women's golf championship were held today.
John Turablan, Avis F. Pearson, in 138 E. 39th St.; John Rosenfeld, in 300 W. 23d St.; Gertrude Raeburn, in 301 W. 24th St.; Hans W. Astheimer, in 365 W. 20th St.; James N. Wells' Sons, Inc., broker.

Joseph Schwartz, president of the First National Bank of Plymouth and former Representative in the State Assembly, died at his home in Plymouth this afternoon of a , heart attack. He was 76 years old.

Frank Hanson of the Columbia University Club was carried to the maximum of five games by Lester A. Strasser of the City A. C. last night as the national amateur squash tennis championship started on the courts of the New York A. C.

The conciliatory address of NAOTAKE SATC-his first as Foreign Ministerbefore the House of Peers on Monday was unusually significant and encouraging. Frankly confessing the failure of the militarists' "positive" policy China, he indicated the purposes of the Government more precisely than is customary in such official pronouncements of good intentions.

Frank Gillmore, president of the Actors Equity Association, has resigned from the advisory board of the American National Theatre and Academy, he disclosed yesterday. The press of other duties, he said, was chiefly responsible for his withdrawal from the academy, which holds a Federal charter and which has announced extensive. plans for the World's Fair here in 1939.

Plans for new structures and alterations filed with -the Manhattan Department of Buildings last month involved a total estimated expenditure. of nearly $7,900,000 Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings, reported yesterday.

Again the French seem to be taking possession of our local season. And French art promises to figure still more prominently in weeks to come. The big Manet retrospective, for instance, opens at Wildenstein's March 18; the Degas exhibition at Durand-Ruel's, organized for the benefit of the Public Education Association of New York, March 23.

A carnival, traditional in southern districts of Russia and heralding the advent of Spring, was reproduced last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis. Ceremonials dating back to the sixteenth century are observed at this annual fete which precedes the Russian Lenten season.

Wallace G.Garland, former honor student at Yale's Sheffield Scientific School, testified yesterday in Federal court at his trial for mail fraud that he never had promised investors that stock of the Public Service Holding Corporation would pay cash dividends'or be listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

A thief operating with skill and simplicity stole jewelry valued at $12,000 from the room of Mrs. Lucy Wright, a well-to-do widow, of Dallas, Texas, at the Hotel Plaza Monday night. The theft was not reported to the police until yesterday.

What he hopes will be the last word in his controversy with Chairman Maltbie of the New York Public Service Commission over New York City power rates was spoken today by Chairman Frank R. McNinch of the Federal Power Commission.

Edward J. Horn, a director of the A. C. Horn Company, 4342 Tenth Street, Long Island City, Queens, manufacturers of paints, varnishes and other products, died on Saturday of a heart ailment in Miami, Fla., after an illness of several months.

Robert P. Galloway,a lawyer, bought some old law books in Buffalo and found Grover Cleveland's signature in them, Roscoe Martin, president of the First National Bank of Forestville and a collector of Cleveland documents, examined the signature and reported that it appeared to be authentic.

Robert D. Kahn, architect and chairman of the committee working on the "theme" of the World's Fair of 1939, will describe the art and architecture of the exposition plan at a meeting of the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, tonight.

A proposal that all cotton yard goods be labeled to specify in percentages approximately the amount of expected shrinkage was placed before the trade practice division of the Federal Trade Commission yesterday at a hearing here, according to The Associated Press.

Business failures declined in the retail and manufacturing divisions, but increased in the wholesale group in the week ended March 4, in comparison with the figures for the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:
Steel production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 115.9 from 115.8. It was 73.8 for the week ended March 7, 1936.

Judge Ezra T. Carter late today denied a motion for a third trial for Edith Maxwell, twice convicted on charges of murdering her father. Judge Carter held that sufficient evidence had been introduced in the second trial to sustain the jury's verdict of second-degree murder, under which the 22-year-old former school teacher was sentenced to twenty years in prison.

Tenders will be considered on March 17 by offiicals of Erie County, N. Y., for a new issue of $3,250,000 of- parkway improvement, tax revenue and emergency relief bonds, to be dated March 1, 1937, and maturing March 1, 1938 to 1947. Bidders have been asked to name .a rate. of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.

Hearing on a complaint filed by Federal investigators against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company for alleged violation of .the RobinsonPatman Fair Trade Act was opened here today by W. C. Reeves, an examiner for the Federal Trade Commission.

The Scarborough School basketball team; undefeated in seventeen games this season, outscored the Columbia University freshmen, 30-20, at the losers' court yesterday. The victors led throughout but held a scant 12-11 margin at halftime.

Thomas Butler Van Alstyne, former president of the Van Alstyne Motor Corporation, at one time the largest distributor of Hupmobiles, died suddenly at 8 o'clock yesterday morning of a heart attack at his home, 17 East Eighty-ninth Street. He was 57 years old.

The Connecticut House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill which would provide a penalty of either death or life imprisonment for a kidnapper in case a an kidnapped person dies. Imposition of the penalty would be at the discretion of the court.

President Roosevelt's proposed reorganization of the United States Supreme Court is "not only wise but necessary," from the viewpoint of relieving congestion in that court, Samuel Untermyer, New York lawyer, who is here on vacation, declared today.

A two-day birthday celebration for Miss Lillian D. Wald, who will be 70 years old today, was begun last night with a program of tributes from her "disciples" of twenty-five to fifty years ago broadcast from Station WHN.

Miss Elizabeth Benziger of Diamond Tail Bar Ranch, on Big Laramie River, in Wyoming, was married to Robert Carter Nicholas Townsend of New York this afternoon in the chancel of the Cathedral of the Immaculate
Eight-year-old Zenka, winner of three straight before- failing in her latest starts, got back into a winning stride today in accounting for the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds.
Mr. and Mrs. G. Huntington Hartford 2d gave a dinner tonight at their home for 'Miss Vivian Dixon and T. Dennie Boardman, whose engagement was recently announced.

In accordance with plans of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation for simplifying its corporate structure, stockholders of the Cincinnati, Newport and Covington Light and Traction Company, a subsidiary, voted today to dissolve the company.

John B. Breunig has been appointed art director of Needham, Louis Brorby, Inc., Chicago advertising agency, to succeed E. Willis Jones, who has resigned, effective April 1, to establish his own advertising art directing service. Mr. Breunig has been associate art director.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are March 8, unless specified: Mare Island Yard to Pearl Harbor: Dent. Rathburne, Waters, Talbot. Algiers to Trieste, March 9: Charleston, McDougal. Acushnet, Indianhead to Washington, March 9. Antares, San Diego to Balboa. Arctic, Samoa to Pearl Harbor Yard. Brazos, san Pedro to San Diego, March 9. Bridge, San Francisco to San Diego.

Play started in the first round of the Westchester County open class high school invitation basketball tournament at the County Center tonight with eight schools competing. Scarborough defeated Leake and Watts of New Rochelle, 34-22.
The resumption of traffic in the Panama Canal following settlement of the seamen's strikes in the United States is reaching its peak.

The German demand for iron ore is so great that its export from Sweden is being maintained during the Winter. When iron ore is stocked on the docks in cold weather it freezes into blocks, and for this reason it is not generally exported in the Winter because dynamite blasting is a costly process and greatly increases the price.

Unanimous vote the Court of Appeals today upheld the provisions of the Multiple-Dwelling Law which require that specific changes shall be made in old tenement houses erected prior to 1901 in New York City. The case decided was that of the appeal of John B. Adamec of the Bronx against Langdon W. Post, as Tenement House Commissioner.

Payment of $10,000 a week salary to the three Warner brothers collectively did not constitute a waste of the assets of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., Judge John P. Nields ruled today in United States District Court here.

Miss Katherine Sylvester of the Green Meadow Golf Club, Harrison, N. Y., scored an 83, despite a 9 at the fifth hole, to capture medal honors in the qualifying round of the annual Belmont Manor women's championship today. Miss S. P. Powell of Vancouver was second with an 89. Match play is to start tomorrow.

Plans for a two-weeks' campaign to raise $500,000 to enlarge and modernize the Mercy Hospital here were announced tonight at a dinner given by the directors for about 200 newspaper men at the Hempstead Country Club.

Three Cabinet Ministers-Ramsay MacDonald, aged 70; Viscount Hailsham, 65, and Viscount Halifax, 55--are expected to retire with Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin when he leaves office after the coronation in May. Mr. Baldwin's plan to retire has been common knowledge for some time.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Quieen Mary, leaving today for Europe, includes several prominent persons, many of whom are going to see the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree on March 19.

The Right Wing press says today that the triumph of the government parties in Sunday's general elections marks the re-establishment of democratic principles because they had been menaced for many months by Socialist propaganda.

Miss LILLIAN WALD, the seventlein anniversary of whose birth will be widely celebrated today, has put an American city street among the famous streets of this continent. It boasts no great buildings and has no outstanding beauty. It was once called "Rough" Street and was " dug out" to provide fill for the Battery.

The midtown section led in the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday. Among the firms making business leases were a watch company, dress manufacturers and millinery firms. The list follows:

Three golfers from the Boston district carried off chief honors in today's qualifying round of the seventh annual seniors' championship. Seward M. Paterson of Boston, playing in Class A, the minimum age for which is 55 years. and Sam Hutchinson of Lynn, Mass., in Class C, the oldest group, tied at 84 for gross honors, and whichever loses in the play-off will win the gross laurels in his class.

The Canadian Pacific Railway reported for 1936 a net income of $6,029,184, or 4 cents a share on common stock, against $2,832,083, or 2.06 per cent on 4 per cent noncumulative preferred stock in 1935.

Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, New York, told the Advertising Club of Boston today that business was facing the greatest era of mass production in world history. In the evening, speaking before 300 members of the Boston Credit Bureau, Inc., he described "the nine old men of credit" and their part in handling the great increase in credit responsibilities, resulting from increased distribution.

A plea to reconsider the rule disqualifying a winner of the Good Hands championship, leading juvenile equestrian title, from future participation in the event has been made to leading horse-show officials by Leigh J. Sessions, first vice president of the Metropolitan Equestrian Club of New York, it was made known yesterday.
The National Safety Council said today that New York City formed a "solid front" against traffic accidents to gain its prestige as the prize safety city of 1936.

A termination of the sit-down strike in which more than 1,700 men, women and children had established themselves in twentyeight of the forty-five district offices of the Emergency Relief Bureau was announced from the headquarters of the Workers Alliance, 101 West Twenty-eighth Street, shortly after 3 A. M. today.

With all sails set and heeling slightly under a fresh northwest breeze, the Suomen Joutsen, Finnish naval training frigate, dipped her ensign yesterday in a graceful farewell to New York, which had been her host since last Thursday.
The Prussian Civil Service Appeals Court has ruled that German civil servants who cannot stand up to their wives in an argument shall be dismissed from the service.

Fred E. Fuller, cutlery manufacturer of 1,282 East Fifth Street, Brooklyn, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with Mrs. Fuller after attracting public attention as the American business man who was questioned at the British Industries Fair by members of the royal family.

William Watson, 24 years old, who gave his occupation as a plumber, pleaded not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to a grand larceny indictment charging the theft of $175 from Jacob Lasky of 765 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx. Judge Streit remanded him to the Tombs in default of bail to await trial.

The village of Briarcliff Manor was ordered today by J. Addison Young, official referee of the Supreme Court, to pay $46,403.26 and interest since 1926, to the Scarborough Properties Corporation for street and other improvements. Frank A. Vanderlip, banker, is president of the company.

Exhausted and worn, J. G. Le Van, American psychologist and explorer, reached Georgetown today, ending almost a month's struggle to find his way out of the desolate grassy savannas after superstitious porters, frightened by his scientific research, had deserted him.

When Joseph: P. Kennedy resigned the chairmanship of the Securities and Exchange Commission, after something more than a year of service in a pioneer eral field, his official and public ing. was close to 100 per cent. Probably no other New Deal administrator had received and earned such golden opinions.

Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson arrived today at her new retreat, the 400-year-old turreted Chateau de Cande, for an indefinite stay. Accompanied by her Riviera hosts, Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Rogers, Mrs. Simpson drove up to the chateau in the front seat of a low-slung sedan. Mrs. Charles E.
Cheeknipping cold harassed Frank Peterlin today but he was too hot under the collar to quit the nation's only "stuck in the mud" strike.

The Spanish Embassy made public tonight a cablegram received from the President of the Basque autonomous government in response to its inquiries as to the accuracy of an Associated Press dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning that Ignazio Zuloaga, Spanish painter, had been sentenced to death at Bilbao.

Deaths Announced Fireman 1st Grade Michael J. Mulvey of Eng. 207 died March 7 in the discharge of duty, while operating at fire at 81 Prospect St., Brooklyn. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 574 Lexington Av., Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M., Thursday, March 11, 1937. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

With Winter apparently about to give up the struggle for existence and Spring technically only two weeks away, Wall Street discussion of the five-day week has revived. So far this year the matter has not been referred officially to the governing committee of the New York

Testimony that Jules Martin, the gangster, hoped to sell his automo biles and taxicabs made out of used parts to Russia if he could merge an American Federation of Labor union with a "Communist" one was put in the record at the restaurant racket trial yesterday.

An unusual series of weather phenomena between 2 and 3 P. M. yesterday brought brilliant sunshine, blinding snow and a loud thunderclap. The oddities were explained by Dr. James H. Kimball, chief of the local Weather Bureau.

"When history is wrote and rewrote," said The McGuinness last night, "Greenpoint is going to have its share of the credit." The audience, members of the Greenpoint People's Regular Democratic Organization, Fifteenth Assembly District, Peter J. McGuinness, leader, nodded in agreement.

Alfredo Salmaggi, director of the Hippodrome Opera Company, yesterday announced a contest for two original one-act operas, one in English and the other in Italian, based on twentieth-century librettos. The winning works will be presented by the company after it opens its season on April 16 at the Hippodrome.

Official sources late tonight reported government forces were resisting stubbornly two Italian divisions in fierce night-fighting south of Alaminos, less than sixty-five miles northeast of Madrid. They asserted the divisions were commanded by an Italian general named Pozzi.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Current discussions show a misunderstanding in regard to the so-called legal tender decisions in 1869 and 1870. The Supreme Court never decided that Congress could not issue fiat money if it were foolish enough to do so. Its original decision was that Congress could not make depreciated: paper noney legal tender for pre-contracted debts.

Yesterday's snow flurries were only a stage setting to cover the retreat of Winter, according to evidence submitted last night at the fashion review in the BergdorfGoodman salon, where every sign insisted that it's Spring-and an epochal season. A parade of nearly 300 Parisian and American originals heralded the eventual exit of the "tangle-toe" long formal gown.

Isaac H. Smith, former register of deeds in Westchester County, died at his home here today of a heart attack after an illness of four days. He was 71 years old. Born at Indian Lake in Putnam County, he received his education here.

Representative Barry of Queens County, L. I., introduced a bill today which would permit a two-cent postal rate throughout all five boroughs of New York City. The same rate would prevail in all other municipalities having more than one postal district.

Articles made by handicapped patients at Bellevue and City Hospitals and by refugee women of the Near East will be sold at Booth 303 at the annual Flower Show to be held in Grand Central Palace March 15 to 20. The sale will be sponsored by the Bellevue Hospital

Stocks closed irregular, some groups higher, tobacco shares weak; turnover, 2,387,670 shares. United States Government bonds lower in heavier trading, corporate and foreign issues mixed; transactions, $19,348,800.

PAUL ELMER MORE was one of the American essayists who sometimes seemed, in this age of controversial criticism, to belong to another era. approach to his subject was calm and contemplative. Like JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL, he wrote mostly on literary personalities of the past, always with broad perspective; analyzing not only their style and manner of thought but their philosophy of life,

A sharp increase in the export of metals which go into the making of war munitions was reported today for January by the Department of Commerce. Copper exports in January totaled $4,768,785 in value, a gain of $2,252,998 over January, 1936.

As a child of 5 Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was sent away in disgrace from a French convent because she had falsely asserted she had swallowed a penny to attract attention. Mrs. Roosevelt recalled this and other incidents of her childhood in her memoirs, beginning in the current issue of The Ladies Home Journal.

Organization drives which will seek to enroll a large segment of the 2,250,000 workers in the textile and oil and refining industries will e started soon under the auspices of the Committee for Industrial Organization, it was announced today by John L. Lewis,
The Pennsylvania Railroad's plan to acquire a trucking company which operates thirty lines in six States and make it a feeder service was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

In a second appeal within six days for popular support for his plan to reorganize the Federal judiciary, President Roosevelt tonight sought to assure millions of Americans gathered around their radios that in this new project he was seeking only to protect them from the usurpations of a Supreme Court which had left its place at the scales of justice to set itself up as a "superlegislature."

Miss Ann Mitchell entertained with a luncheon yesterday at the Trouville for Princess Daria (Dolly) Obolensky, whose marriage to Hans George Spitzer will take place on Friday. The other guests were Mrs.

About 1,200 Irishmen are fighting in Spain, according to estimates made here. Nearly 1,000 are with the Insurgents in the neighborhood of Caceres under General Owen O'Duffy, leader of the Irish Fascist party.

Covering $42,000,000 of sinking fund external conversion loan bonds bearing 4 per cent interest due on March 15, 1972, the Argentine Republic filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The World War will be regarded as "child's play" in comparison with "the terrible and ghastly conflagration" toward which European nations are drifting, in the opinion of Lord Davies, founder of the New Commonwealth Society.

Following the assertion of George U. Harvey that he was considering, running in the Republican primary for the nomination for Mayor against Mayor La Guardia, the City Fusion party started a movement yesterday to nominate an independent Democrat for Borough President of Queens on the Fusion ticket.
The first rum to be produced at the Federal Government's. distilleries at St. Croix, Virgin Islands, will be placed on sale to consumers here on April 15, it was announced yesterday.

Jacques Webber of the Bloomsburg Silk Mill was appointed chairman of a committee of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., to serve with a committee of the Textile Converters Association in discussing the standardization of trade practices, it was announced yesterday following the annual meeting of the board of the federation.

The first commercial round-the-world air ticket. was sold today to S. David Winship, a Manila business man formerly of Lewiston, Me. His fare was estimated at $2,308.33, although the rate between Hongkong and Manila has not been set.

Drastic legislation to control the adulteration, branding and advertisement of foods, drugs and cosmetics in interstate and foreign commerce was passed by the Senate this afternoon. The bill, which Senator Copeland, chairman of the Committee on Commerce, said had been redrafted to meet objections voiced recently by the President, passed unanimously. It now goes to the House, where early action is expected.

By JAMES R. MURPHY White Plains Road, w. s. 231 st. 30x80; Bronx Savings Bank against 4,139 White Plains Road, Inc.; due, $12,727; taxes, , $357; to plaintiff for $11,000. By HENRY WALTEMADE St. Anns Av., 745, w. a. 156th St., 26.6x 93.5 1/4 by irreg.; 4-story tenement; Harlem Savings Bank against Eljulo Corp.; due, $10,448; taxes, , $87; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Two experts testified yesterday afternoon in the Bronx County Court, where six men are on trial for second-degree manslaughter as a result of the Bronx building collapse last June 19, described the steel which supported the tower as being full of cement-filled holes and as bearing a load far in excess of the maximum allowed by the Building Code.

J. Randolph Marshall, president of the Farrell Silver Plating Company of 424 Sixth Avenue, New York, died at his home here today of pneumonia after a week's illness at the age of 45. His widow, Catherine;

The dollar volume of furniture orders booked in January ran 48 per cent ahead of those for the corresponding month last year, according to the monthly report of Seidman Seidman, accountant specialists in that industry.

The board of the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company's employes' plan of representation voted today to dissolve the organization to clear the way for collective bargaining demands of the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union.

During today's debate in the Chamber of Deputies, Mrs. Leon Blum, wife of the Premier, who always attends important debates, was involved in an incident that caused several minutes' disturbance in the visitors' gallery.

Columbia University's swimming team defeated N. Y. U., Rider College and St. Francis in a. quadrangular meet last night in the Miorningside pool. The Lions rolled up 53 points to 45 for Rider, 36 for N. Y. U. and 33 for St. Francis.
Harry Brunette, 25-year-old bank robber, described by J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as "the toughest criminal I've seen,"

Property in Quebec Province used for the purposes of Communist propaganda would be padlocked, as are places used for illegal purposes, under a law which Premier Duplessis is laying before the Legislative Assembly.

The Yale Roosevelt-for-King Club laid plans today for the coronation of King Franklin I, enrolled 200 members and decided, after receiving a flood of telegrams from colleges all over the country, to form a United States league of clubs and to grant charters to clubs in Columbia and New York Universities.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here affirmed a lower court decision yesterday which refused to restrain the Manufacturers Trust Company from servicing the twelfth and thirteenth series of bonds issued by Prudence Bonds, Inc.

We now have a demonstration of what the Wagner Labor Relations Act means to Mr. LEWIS'S C. I. O. Here, apparently, was a statute completely forgotten when the sit-down strike was in progress in the plants of the General Motors Corporation only a few weeks ago. No attempt whatever was then made by the C. I. O. to invoke the Wagner act in order to establish
The intercollegiate basketball season in Madison Square Garden will come to a close tonight with the twelfth double-header of the campaign at the arena. An all-metropolitan card will be presented,

Certain German Christian extremists are reported to have requested Chancellor Hitler through Hanns Kerrl, Reich Minister for Church Affairs, to order a plebiscite on the question, "Do you as a German desire a confessionless German national church?" Mr. Kerrl, it is asserted, rejected the proposal.

Eldward T. Duval of Orlando, Fla. owner of $76,852 of the comrnon stock of La France Industries, Petitioned the Federal district court here today to direct J. Harris. Warthman, trustee of the corporation, to file suit against two banking houses in New York to recover $2,389,000 cash and 110,843 shares of La France stock from them.

Albert Kircher, whose farmhouse is situated in Folsom but whose henhouse is in Hammonton, wants to know who's going to pay for damage to a flock of his chickens. Although an attack by stray dogs occurred on the Hammonton side of the boundary, he sent a bill for $50 to Folsom.

Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn dismissed yesterday a suit for $250,000 damages and an injunction brought by the Good-Will Court, Inc., against A. L. Alexander and four other defendants for using the expression "Good-Will Court" in a commercial radio ,program.
121st St., 21 W., 21x101; Esther Rosenbaum to Agatha Clarke, 265 W. 123d St.; mtg., $10,000 ($5.50). Mount Morris Park W., 20x100; same to Moses Meller and wife, 7 Mount Morris Park W. ($2.50)

George R. James, former member of the Federal Reserve Board at Washington, died here today at the age of 70 years. The financier and merchant had been in ill health since January, 1936, when he resigned from the Reserve Board after years of service.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 6: COMMANDERS Kirkpatrick, R. D., Naval Examining Board, to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C. Howard, J. V., Med. Corps., Puget Sound, Wash., to receiving ship at San Francisco. Montgomery, L. C., Dental Corps, the Oklahoma, to the Tennessee.

Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday that he had reached an agreement with Colonel Brehon B. Somervell, WPA administrator, under which the full contingent of 170,000 WPA worker in this city could continue work until June 30, the end of the fiscal year.

The value of cotton, wool, silk and rayon consumed by American mills last year -was $1,058,200,000, the largest reported since 1929, according to figures compiled by the Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., and issued for today.

Paul D. Cravath, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association; Edward Johnson, the general manager, and Edward Ziegler, assistant general manager, will be honored by the Metropolitan Opera Club at a dinner tonight at its club rooms in the Metropolitan Opera House Building.

The 1937 Bawl Street Journal Committee of the Bond Club of New York, headed by George J. Gillies, has issued an appeal to members of the club for material for the 1937 edition. It has announced abandonment of the policy of giving prizes to contributors, the only reward for contributors now being "the pleasure of seeing one's handiwork in print."

William Lucius Churchill, an inventor, mechanical engineer and industrial economist, died of pneumonia late yesterday at is home, 52 Ogden Avenue. He was 66 years old. He served many manufacturing, corporations in perfeeting ef ficiency systems.

George M. Cohan Jr., 23 years old, of 993 Fifth Avenue, son of the actor-producer, was arraigned yesterday before Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schuman Jr., in,Homicide Court, on charges of assault, driving while intoxicated and making an improper turn. His case was continued until March 31 and $1,000 bail was fixed.

Maxie Berger of. the Bronx and Irish Eddie Brink of Scranton, Pa., lightweights, battled eight rounds to a draw in the feature bout at the New York Coliseurn last night. A crowd of 14,273, a record for the arena, was announced as the paid attendance.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey refused yesterday to extend the preliminary injunction he granted on Feb. 19 restraining United States Shipping Commissioner John J. Daly from enforcing provisions of the Copeland Safety-at-Sea Act, which calls for the issuance of continuous discharge books to American seamen.

The twenty-four hour strike of 112 waiters, waitresses, cooks and bellboys in the Willard Hotel was ended tonight by an agreement made in the office of Assistant Secretary McGrady. The strikers returned to work at once.

Miss Maye Doris Link, daughter of Mrs. George Link of this city and the late Mr.- Link, was married last night in the chapel of Riverside Church to Charles Winthrop Cayten, also of New York, formerly of Hawthorne, N. Y., by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick.
John W. Roberts, regarded as among the leading customs experts. of the United States, was appointed supervising customs agent at. New York City today by Secretary Morgenthau.

Army and navy experts hold that the United States is in a better position than any other nation to engage in war without calling for outside assistance. Soviet Russia rapidly is attaining a similar strategic position, their opinion.

The virtual completion of the liquidation of its interest in the National Freight Company at a loss of nearly $4,000,000 was disclosed in the report of the Pennroad Corporation for 1936 issued yesterday. The corporation was formed by the Pennsylvania Railroad interests to carry on activities outside the railroad field, but it maintains a separate corporate identity.

Air Reduction Co., Inc., corn., 9:15 A. M. American Products Co. pf. Atlantic Steel Co. com., 10:30 A. M. Atlas Thrift Plan Corp. pf., 9 P. M. Bancohio Corp. com. Canada Life Assurance Co. (Toronto, Ont.) corn., 12 M. Central National Bank (Richmond), 4:30 P. M. Chicago Title Trust Co. com.

The two-story business building at 69-10 Roosevelt Avenue, Woodside, Queens, has been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to an investor who will occupy a part of the building. George C. Johnson Jr. negotiated the deal.

Pirate gold on Cocos Island, vainly sought for more than 100 years by many expeditions, was the inducement held out by Harry G. Smith in promoting the Cocos Island Adventure Club, Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall, head of the Bureau of Securities. asserted yesterday, after the arrest of Smith on a charge of grand larceny.

Three of the live gunmen who held up Barney's clothing store on lower Seventh Avenue on Jan. 2, getting $700 in money and $1,500 in checks, entered. guilty pleas before Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably less than the preceding week. The total was also well below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The Assembly has passed the bill extending for one more year the moratorium on foreclosure of mortgages where interest and taxes have been paid. The measure now goes to Governor LEHMAN for his signature. Undoubtedly the extension was needed. The Governor himself urged it in his annual message.

President Roosevelt today named Joseph P. Kennedy of New York chairman and four other members of the permanent United States Maritime Commission, which has been functioning for almost nine months on a temporary basis.

The House Judiciary, Committee today favorably reported the TydingsMiller. bill; which would amend the. Sherman 'Anti-Trust Act to remove all doubt concerning the legality of contracts made under State laws which fix minimum prices of trademarked or branded articles.

Representatives of mothers of soldiers who lost their lives in the World War appealed to Congress today to provide compensation for those whose war risk insurance expires this year and next. Mrs. H. B. Blake. of Philadelphia, national president of the American Gold Star Mothers,
A former Mayor of suburban Highland Park and eight other men without previous criminal records were ordered to prison today by a municipal judge, who convicted them of a Black Legion murder plot.

Mrs. Dorothy Burgoyne Wilmot-Johnson received a divorce at Carson City March 1 from Captain Lewis Wilmot-Johnson, it was revealed today. She charged cruelty. They were married July 31, 1930, and have one child.
A crowded public hearing before the Senate Education Committee today heard nurses from all parts of the State clash on measures for new license regulations.

A spirited closing bid by the Rangers enabled the blue-jerseyed sextet to defeat the Americans in the sixth and final meeting of the season between the New York sextets at Madison Square Garden last night. In a thrilling, see-saw contest that entertained a crowd of 10,000 fans, Lester Patrick's skaters registered a, 7-to-5 triumph over the game crew piloted by Red Dutton.

Miss Cecilia Colledge of London and Felix Kaspar of Vienna, the new world figure-skating champions, arrived on the Queen Mary yesterday en route to Ottawa and Toronto, where they will be featured in the annual Canadian club carnivals this week-end and next.

All, apparently, is not quietalong the Beaverkill. And the cause for the lack of customary- conversation at this time of year regarding trout has been due to the presence of a wildcat at the Beaverkill Trout Club. Not so long ago the wildcat was taken alive by Charlie Tood, who appears to be an expert in these matters.
Many parties were given yesterday in conjunction with the luncheon and fashion show in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Longacre Nursing Center of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse
Eleven buildings, including the seven-story Lamborn Building at 87-9 Pine Street, and five vacant parcels were involved in the twelve auction sales held yesterday in Manhattan.

Paul H. Wendel took the witnessstand in Kings County Court yesterday and for the second time within a month told a jury his version of how he was abducted and tortured into "confessing" the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

Miss Angela Heckscher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maurice Heckscher of By-the-Way, Strafford, has chosen April 24 as the date for her marriage to Arthur- Richard Niessen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Niessen of Rydal.

Evidence was introduced today at the resumption of the hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission charging W. E. Hutton Co. with manipulation, that a specialist on the New York Stock Exchange who was "short" of Atlas Tack Corporation stock, had been advised late in 1935 to "cover his short position."

Continued firmness of the French franc following the favorable reaction to the French Government's plans for a defense loan carried the price of that currency here yesterday to 4.57 1/8 cents, a gain of 3/4 point on the day.
Strikers held full control of Chrysler plants in Detroit, even barring company executives for a time. Conferences on the issue of sole bargaining power continued, with no progress made.

Mrs. Wallis Simpson has been a good influence in raising the standards of American beauty, Miss Gail Aronton, editor of Beauty Culture, said yesterday at a crowded session of the convention for beauty shop owners at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Ellis L. Phillips, president of the Long Island Lighting Company, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting that the company's net income for 1936 was $2,076,177, against $2,411,489 in 1935. After payment of dividends on the 6 per cent and 7 per cent cumulative preferred stocks, he added, the balance applicable to the common stock was $478,190, or 16 cents a share. In 1935 this balance was 27 cents.

President Juan Demostenes Arosemena has again -announced his determination to repress promptly and severely any subversive attempts against his government, in a letter addressed to the coalition of the National Revolutionary, Conservative and National Liberal parties.

United States Government bonds declined again yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. On a turnover of $8,088,800, the heaviest since July 15 last year, the Treasury loans lost from 1-32 to 20-32 point. Their weakness affected the market for high-grade corporate bonds, which continued to drift moderately lower in light trading.

Five white bandits, at least two of them armed, raided a pawnshop at 218 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, in a section mostly Negro, at 9:05 A. M. yesterday and escaped with jewelry valued at between $10,000 and $25,000 and $500 in cash.

L. S. Buckmaster, president of Firestone local, United Rubber Workers of America, announced tonight that negotiations had collapsed between the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the union in a labor dispute which closed the Firestone plants last week, making 10,000 employes idle.

The Cabinet today authorized Dr. Wilhelm Frick, the Minister of the Interior, to take counter-reprisals against foreign nationals and their property in Germany in cases where foreign countries have adopted measures against German nationals or their property.

A reservoir of original material for future historians on the transportation of the American Expeditionary Forces in France has been given to the New York Public Library by Colonel William J. Wilgus, deputy director general of transportation of the A. E. F.
Following is the text of the opinion of Judge Irving Lehman deciding that old-law tenements must be made to conform to present standards:

Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, honorary chairman of the semi-centennial committee of the Jewish Theological Seminary, speaking yesterday afternoon before the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, said that the spir itual values of Judaism were being revived and the belief in the selfsufficiency of the individual disappearing.

BOWLERS are all right. As a rule, they keep pretty well under cover. It is alleged that Mayor Fiorello La Guardia not only tolerates bowling in his bailiwick but will aid and abet the keglers to the extent of rolling the first ball down a fresh-laid alley in the 212th Coast Artillery Armory tonight to start the big bowling championship, congress, jamboree or whatever may be the nroner designation.

Miss Mary Osborn, Polak of 825 Park Avenue has chosen March 17 as the date for her marriage to Donald Mitchell Oenslager, stage scenic designer of this city. The ceremony will take place in the roof garden of the Pierre. The Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan,

Esther Rosenbaum sold to Agatha Clarke the house at 21 West 121st St. for a consideration shown as $5,500 over the first mortgage of $10,000, taking back a purchase money mortgage for $3,000 payable $40 a month at 5 per cent. This new mortgage was assigned to Moses Meller and his wife.

Marked increases in new cases of diphtheria, measles, scarlet fever and whooping cough' were reported for the week ended last Saturday, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, revealed in his weekly health survey of the city.

Although most opposition leaders could not refrain from criticizing the government for its overnight change of financial policy, the Chamber of Deputies voted tonight almost unanimously for the necessary modifications in existing laws to permit the issuance on Thursday, of the French

Apparently suffering from an overdose of a sedative, Miss Bea Gottlieb, 31-year-old professional golfer, was found unconscious last night in her apartment at 72-34 Austin Street, Forest Hills, shortly after a jury had acquitted a man she accused of assaulting her.

Amelia Earhart piloted her "flying laboratory" through preliminary tests today for her flight around the the world. Within a few days, as soon as the weather looks right and all landing preparations have been completed, Miss Earhart will take off from Oakland in her $80,000 transport plane for the first leg of the proejected zigzag trip above and below the Equator.
The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company yesterday declared a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, the first dividend to be declared since the payment of 50 cents a share on July 1, 1931.
Kid Chocolate, former world featherweight champion, gained a draw with Bernie Friedkin of Brownsville last night in the fea- N ture eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn.

The first through "snow train" from New York to the Laurentians of Canada will leave Friday night from the Grand Central Terminal with some 300 passengers, the New York Central and Delaware Hudson Railroads announced yesterday.

A northbound subway train roaring into the Fifty-first Street station of the Lexington Avenue line at 3:32 P. M. yesterday ended the life of Colonel Frank Browne Keech, former large-scale operator in the stock market, who twelve days ago was indicted for the burning of his mansion at Tuxedo Park on Feb. 26, 1932.

Leaders of national Scouting, naturalists, representatives of outdoor organizations, associates in the wild life conservation movement which he founded and former associates and assistants from the New York Zoological Park were present in the First Presbyterian

The matter of the Italian and German Ministers who attended the Fascist Iron Guard demonstration before the burial of two members who had been killed while fighting with the Spanish Rebels ended today with the triumph of the Fascist powers and what is generally considered humiliation for Premier Tatarescu of Rumania.
Richard F. Davis's unanimous election as captain of next Winter's Fordham basketball team was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager John F. Coffey. Davis was the team's high scorer with 142 points.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court was asked yesterday, to decide whether a single creditor of any of the German companies whose obligations here are now in default can attach all the funds sent here to satisfy creditors in the United States.

The Legislative Council of Jamaica at the opening of its Spring session heard a speech by the Governor outlining the financial position of the colony. The Governor estimates that for the financial year ending in March, 1937, the deficit will be [Pound]38,000.
Edwin Burrage Child, noted portrait and landscape painter, died here today. Mr. Child had painted the portraits of some of the leading political figures of recent years. His age was 68.

The League Committee on Raw Materials today agreed that all questions concerning the distribution and transfer of colonial territories were outside its competence and that it had to do only with the distribution of raw materials.

Hearings before the Securities and Exchange Commission in the case of W. E. Hutton Co., charged by the government with having "rigged the market" in Atlas Tack Corporation shares, moved forward slowly today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest your editorial "Tuberculosis Gaining Again." I heartily endorse everything that Dr. Haven Emerson says in his plea for more special hospitals with sufficient number of beds to accommodate the thousands of consumptives waiting to be admitted into the relatively few hospitals now at our disposal.

Resale of a large housing property in Yorkville was announced yesterday when a syndicate bought the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 225-227 East Seventy-ninth Street from Frederick Brown, who had acquired it from the builder.

Offering will be made to the public today by an underwriting group of sixty-nine members, headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., of a new issue of $130,000,000 of Philadelphia Electric Company 3 1/2 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds, due on March 1, 1967.
The National Consumers League's board of directors has adopted a resolution approving President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan. The board said in a statement:

The Assembly approved today the bill of Miss Jane Todd, Republican member from Westchester, designed to bar "hasty marriages." The measure, which went through the lower house by a vote of 101 to 1, would require a seventy-twohour interval between issuance of a marriage license and performance of the ceremony.

Deploring the State Assembly vote by which the child labor amendment was defeated, Mayor La Guardia suggested yesterday that the Legislature authorize immediate referendum on the proposition to show whether or not public sentiment favored it.

The dollar volume of sales of the National Biscuit Company for the first two months of this year were ahead of the 1936 period, with sweet goods showing the largest percentage gain, Edward Crossmore, executive vice president

Mario Chamlee, Metropolitan Opera tenor, will be the guest artist at the dinner which the president and board of directors of the New York World Fair will give for members of the Consulate Corps in New York tonight at the Metropolitan Club.

Crashing suddenly to earth in the midst of a group of workmen, the thirty-five-foot boom of a traveling crane instantly killed three WPA laborers and seriously injured a project foreman today at the Philadelphia Navy Yard.

Frank Iannicelli, New York Athletic Club star, and A. H. Marckwald of the Short Hills Club yesterday advanced to the final round of the national Class C squash tennis championship as a result of their victories on the Harvard Club courts.

Sharp advances in cut-rate retail liquor prices were among the initial effects here yesterday of the decision of the State Court of Appeals on Tuesday, holding the Feld-Crawford Resale Price Maintenance Law constitutional.

A clause recommended for use by textile converters on sales contracts for all rayon finished goods was announced yesterday by the Textile Converters Association. The clause is similar to that agreed on with a committee of the National Rayon Weavers Association for purchase contracts on rayon griege goods.
Tributes continued to flow into Montreal tonight for Howie Morenz, dynamic center of the Canadiens, whose sudden death Monday night stunned fans and players of the National Hockey League.

Federal farm experts said today that the "three-horse team" which appeared in President Roosevelt's latest speeches is seldom seen nowadays. Such teams pulled old-fashioned plows and occasionally heavy milk, ice cream and beer wagons of a generation ago. But it is an "uncommon hitch" these days, the experts said.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a public school in Morris Avenue, the Bronx, to cost $540,000.
The Turahen bill, which would bar the manufacture or sale of household appliances by gas and electric companies was debated today in a publie hearing before the Assembly Public Service Committee.

The Rutgers basketball team scored its thirteenth victory in a season of fourteen games by downing the Princeton quintet, 43-34, before 2,000 fans in the losers' gymnasium tonight. The Princeton court men, playing their last home game of a year which has seen but six Nassau triumphs, were outclassed from the very first whistle.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition for Extension HYMAN STRUM AND DAVID MARK, trading as S. M. Dairy, 122 Dyckman St. Voluntary proceedings for an extension of composition under Section 74 of the Bankruptcy Laws-Liabilities, $5,973; assets, $1,940. Petitions Filed-Against BIRGE, GRANDBOIS PRESS. INC.. 333 Hudson St. Involuntary by Alling Corey Co. for $500 Miller Wright Paper Co., $500; Henry Lindmeyer Sons, $200.

The case against Chang Soo Lee, Korean house man accused of attempting to murder Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves with poison, was submitted to the jury at 4:12 o'clock this afternoon. At midnight the jury had still failed to reach an agreement and was sent to a hotel for the night.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, communicated yesterday with Dr. Stephen S. Wise of the American Committee of Religious Rights and Minorities agreeing to confer with the committee about its suggestion that a temple of religious and civil liberty be erected by the fair corporation as a part of the international exposition here in 1939 and 1940.

There has been "an alarming decline" in the forces organized to stamp out religion in Soviet Russia, the newspaper Izvestia, organ of the government, asserted today. It asserted the resulting situation was "intolerable."

J. Alexander Sloan, automobile racing promoter and at one time manager of some noted drivers, died today. He was 57 years old. A native of Pittsburgh, Mr. Sloan starred in football at Ohio Wesleyan University and then coached at Central High School in St. Paul.

Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems, daughter of Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff, gave a large luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Princess Daria (Dolly) Obolensky, daughter of Prince and Princess Alexis Obolnsky, whose marriage to Hans George Spitzer will take place tomorrow in the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour.

Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Ambassador, returned to London on a German airliner this evening. It is authoritatively understood he brings no reply to the British memorandum on the subject of a Western European pact but that he has instructions under which he will be able to engage in preliminary discussions that may lead to a reply.

New appointments and transfers in the diplomatic service were decided upon today by President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull at a luncheon conference in the White House. Usually well-informed circles belived that the changes would affeet Poland in the near future,

The art and architecture of the New York World's Fair will emphasize the contributions of the machine in making beauty useful and easily available to the average man, Robert D. Kohn, chairman of the Committee on Theme of the World's Fair, said last night in an address at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park.

Mrs. Nathaniel P. Hill of New York and Mrs. William Coxe Wright of Hill Top House, Devon, will be matrons of honor at the marriage of their sister, Miss Margaret Winifred Dorrance, daughter of Mrs. John Thompson Dorrance of Woodcrest, Radnor, and the late Dr. Dorrance, to George Strawbridge, son of John Strawbridge of Chestnut Hill and the late Mrs. Strawbridge, on March 29.

The filing of the will of Sarah Maria Talmadge for probate disclosed today that the New Haven woman had disinherited her nearest relatives, Norma, Constance and Natalie Talmadge of motion-picture fame.

This community and the whole of Rockland County was aroused today as sponsors of two mass meetings, one to oppose President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan and the other to favor it, made last-minute preparations for the rallies, both of which are to be held here tomorrow night.

Miss Sylvia Wheeler, a member of one of the early families of this community, died this morning in the North Country Community Hospital following an operation. She was 69 years old and had lived her entire life in Glen Cove. Born in the Cottage Row section, she was a daughter of the late Henry A. and Ann Elizabeth Merritt Wheeler. Her father owned almost all of the business area,

A performance, very effective, of Miaskovsky's Sixth symphony, played for the first time by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, opened the concert given by that body under the direction of Artur Rodzinski last night in Carnegie Hall.

Upon the advice of his physician, who reported that he was near collapse from overwork and nervous exhaustion, Noel Coward decided yesterday to cancel the remainder of his engagements here in his popular series of one-act plays, "Tonight at Eight-Thirty," in which he had been appearing with Gertrude Lawrence at the National Theatre.

Broadway (13-3405), n. w. cor. of 232d St., 114x117; 149-05-07 Northern Boulevard Corp. to 1,738 Crotona Park Co., Inc., 1,738 Crotona Park E.; mort., $86,500. Whitlock Av., (10-2730), e. s. 119 n. of Leggett Av., 101x51: Van Kannel Building Corp. to Van Kannell Revolving Door Co., 101 Park Av.

The list of the Italian liner Roma, due today from Mediterranean ports, includes: W. H. Eaton, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Bach and Miss Judith Bach, Dr. and Mrs. John W. Langdale, and Charles H. Phelps Sr.

The bodies of Mrs. Margaret Averill Ramsey, 55 years old, and her daughter, Alice Dean, 20, a former dancer, will be consigned to paupers' graves next Tuesday, when the Missing Persons Bureau's jurisdiction over them in the Bellevue morgue ends, it was said yesterday by Detective Daniel McCann.

With subscriptions and commitments for the 4 per cent debentures of the New York World's Fair of 1939 totaling more than $19,000,000, the fair's bond sales committee has broken practically every record established in connection with the retail distribution of securities in New York City and the United States, it was said by the committee yesterday.

The biggest stunt of the convention for beauty shop owners at the Hotel Pennsylvania was staged yesterday afternoon and five women and one man fainted. The man was in the worst condition of all. The stunt consisted of three nose operations done in the manner of vaudeville turns.

Henry Kohl, president and founder of the National Grocery Company, a New Jersey chain retail system with about 800 stores, died at 8 A. M. yesterday in his suite at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

The Kingsboro Mortgage Corporation has made a first mortgage temporary building loan of $180,000 on the six-story apartment now under construction on the northwest corner of Nostrand Av. and Erasmus St., Brooklyn, on a plot 140 by 142 feet, by the Beach Property Corp., Harry Lefrak, president.
The William Wrigley Jr. Company of Chicago, chewing-gum makers, in 1936 earned its largest profit since 1931, the annual report issued tonight disclosed.

The American Citizens League, Inc., was chartered at the Secretary of State's office here today for the announced purpose of aiding persons 40 years old or over to obtain steady, remunerative employment. The organization hopes to change the attitude of employers toward workers in that age group.

The annual cost of government of all political subdivisions in the United States increased from less than $3,000,000,000 in 1913 to about $15,500,000,000 in 1936, the First National Bank of Boston declares in its current news letter.
The Radio City Music Hall today will receive England's first Technicolor film, "Wings. of the Morning," produced by New World, a subsidiary of Twentieth CenturyFox. Annabella, the French star,

ALLIGER-Minnie H., on Wednesday, March 10, beloved daughter of the late Catherine Jane and John, sister of the late Frederick T. and Burnham. Survived by her beloved sister, Harriette A. Wyatt and her devoted nephews, Frederic A. Wyatt and J. Austin Wyatt. Funeral Friday, March 12. at 2:30 P. M., Chapel of Carr Son, Kingston, N. Y. Interment Montrepose Cemetery, Kingston, N. Y.

President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and other distinguished well-wishers paid tribute to Lillian D. Wald yesterday as the founder of the Henry Street Settlement celebrated her seventieth birthday at her home on Combo Road, Westport, Conn.

The American Artists Congress announces its first national membership exhibition to be held from April 16 to April 29. Instead of a single showing, concentrating work by the national membership of more than 600 painters, sculptors and graphic artists, there will be exhibitions in several major cities based on regional divisions.

The quarter-final-round matches in the Belleview Biltmore women's golf championship today furnished two additional surprises when the 1936 titleholder and leading 1937 tournament winner, Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., and Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, six times winner of the United States championship, were eliminated.

The following film programs, which will be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 8: REAR ADMIRALS Cluverius, W. T., commander of Base Force, to duty as commandant of the Fourth Naval District and commandant of the Navy Yard, Philadelphia, Pa., about June 7.

Attorneys for the Chrysler Corporation filed a petition in the Wayne County Circuit Court today, asking an injunction to compel sit-down strikers to evacuate its eight occupied plants in this county and to cease interference with production. The bill of complaint charges conspiracy.

More than 2,000 scholastic journalists will gather today on Morninside Heights to participate in a three-day convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association. The convention will open at 1:30 o'clock in McMillin Theatre, Columbia University.

Withholding its fire for the second half, New York University came on with relentless drive toward the close of its traditional basketball struggle with City College at Madison Square Garden last night before a gathering of 7,500 and won, going away, 38 to 32.

Charles M. Schwab, steel official, received 6,250 shares of stock of the Automatic Signal Company when he became a director in July, 1929, Wallace G. Garland, former Yale honor student, who organized that concern, testified yesterday in Federal court during his trial for alleged mail fraud.

Mr. and Mrs. E. S. Stackhouse of Greenwich, Conn., gave a luncheon at the Surf Club today for Mr. and Mrs. Charles Criqui of Buffalo, Mrs. C. F. Loose of New York and Mrs. C. Leonard O'Connor of Cortland, N. Y. Mr. and Mrs. F. Lowry Wall were hosts to a large group of friends at a tea dance at the Surf Club today.

The House voted today to authorize the Treasury to grant further extensions of time for the filing of returns on "windfall" taxes levied in 1936. The resolution was sent immediately to the Senate so that Congressional action can be completed before March 15, which would otherwise be the final date for filing such returns.

Several hundred railroad presidents, engineers and leading industrialists met here today as the guest of William A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, for the dedication of the brunorizing furnace in the rail mill of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, the largest subsidiary of United States Steel.

Fears that military influences on Japanese policy may lead to war or armament competition on too vast a scale for Japan's strength are voiced in a questionnaire that Yukio Ozaki, former Minister of Justice, has submitted to Premier Senjuro Hayashi.

The Museum of the City of New York has become the owner. of one of the most extensive private collections of New York theatre material in the country through the gift of the Garrison P. Sherwood collection of some 200,000 items.
The statement of Attorney General Cummings before the Senate Judiciary Committee on President Roosevelt's plan for reorganization of the Federal judiciary was as follows:

Consumption of gasoline in the United States in 1936 was approximately 19,565,922,000 gallons, an increase of 1,849,111,000 gallons, or 10.4 per cent, over the 1935 consumption, according to the American Petroleum Institute. There were reductions in only three States: Nebraska, where consumption last year was 230,951,000 gallons,

Miss Cornell and her associates have bestowed an admirable performance on an admirable play. Bernard Shaw wrote it and labeled it "Candida" a great many years ago. In 1924 Miss Cornell appeared in one of its most memorable rerivals.

Mrs. Simonds Duryea gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 1 Sutton Place, for Miss. Judith Hamlin, daughter of Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin of New York and East Hampton, L. I., whose marriage to Charles Percy Frederick North,

Two draft horses ran wild, dragging a heavy produce wagon through the crowded streets of the Washington Market district yesterday evening, wrecking a parked automobile, grazing a crowded cross-town bus and killing their driver.

Miss Eleanor Ball, daughter of William Watts Ball of Charleston, S. C., and Mrs. Fay Witte Ball, was married today to Philip HewittMyring, an English journalist. After a civil ceremony in the Town Hall another service was performed by the chaplain of the English Church of St. Hugh. Mr.

A public hearing will be sought in Albany if the Westchester County Board of Supervisors does not accept changes in the county charter plan recommended by the Westchester County League of Women Voters, it was announced today by Mrs. Kenneth M. Gould, chairman of the league's committee on government reorganization.
Large purchases of foreign wheat by the Reich from sources other than Argentina was indicated today with one Embassy reporting a big shipment of wheat had arrived recently from India.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading improved for lamb carcasses and fresh pork cuts. Steer hinds and ribs moved good and veal only fair. Steer hind and rib prices continued strong. Veal held about steady and lamb sold higher. Fresh pork cuts were uneven.
