Early trading in kosher meats indicated veal and lamb to be steady to weak. beef steady to $1 lower.
Led by Harry F. Wolf, the field in the national amateur squash tennis championship moved into the round of sixteen last night on the courts of the New York Athletic Club.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 9 unless specified: At San Diego: Brazos, Pike. Pichilinque Bay to San Diego: Cushing, Perkins. Acushnet, Indian Head to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, March 10. Cassin, Yorktown, to Charleston.

Benjamin F. Johnston of Rye, N. Y., president of United Sugar Companies, died suddenly yesterday in Hongkong, China, according to word received here from his widow, Mrs. Agnes Sherwood Johnston, with whom he started last November on a leisurely trip around the world. A son, Sherwood, of Los Mochis Mexico also sur??es.
Mrs. William H. Andrews, chairman of the Greenwich House Health Committee, entertained with a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 53 East Sixty-sixth Street, for the other members of her group.

Dr. F. E. Wright and Hamilton Wright, astronomers of the Carnegie Institution's observatory at Mount Wilson, Calif., are photographing the moon on glass globes instead of flat photographic plates. The globes are coated with photographic emulsion and pictures of the moon are projected on them.

Many contracts for commercial space in the Fifth Avenue district were included in the long list of business leases reported by brokers yesterday. The list follows: Fleischman Rosenfeld, Dominion Buyers, Inc., Leon Sebulsky, Chaminade Velours. Inc., Jean Marvel Dress Shops, Inc.,

A news correspondent in Nanking, China, reports that pirated editions of Henry L. Stimson's "The Far Eastern Crisis," published here by Harper, are enjoying a heavy sale through China, where the absence of copyright laws makes such unauthorized editions possible.

The three-story business structure on a plot 20 by 80 at 500 Fifth Avenue, corner of Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold to Eva Blinder, who will open a groundfloor store. The property is assessed at $39,000.

Under the headline "Enemy in Meteorological Station," the newspaper Izvestia reported today from -Archangel that one plane had crashed and another had been forced down because a radio station at Lechukom sent out false weather reports.

William Curley, managing editor of The New York Evening Journal, and the former Miss Mary Grace of Santa Monica, Calif., were on a brief wedding trip today after being married at the ranch of William Randolph Hearst here yester. day.

The three-family dwelling at 17 Hancock Av., Jersey City Heights, N. J., has been sold for occupancy of one of the apartments to E. Zier. Meta Wormke was the seller. J. I. Kislak, Inc., negotiated the deal. The latter also sold the four-story flat at 583 Park Av., West New York, for the Hudson Trust Co. to Anna Budka for investment.
The Westfield Polo Club surprised tonight by defeating the 112th Field Artillery of Red Bank, 12 to 10 1/2, in the semi-finals of the New Jersey low-goal tournament at the Essex Troop Armory.

The Boston Bees' rookies opened the intra-squad competition today by taking advantage of two second-inning errors and pushing over the tally that gave them a 1-0 victory over the regulars before a crowd of 7,500.

General approval of rules to control "daylight trading" was voted yesterday by the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange, and the business conduct committee was instructed to draw up a definitive rule.

As pickets spent a quiet day about their fires at the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today, about 1,500 office employes joined the 10,000 production workers in idleness when they found the office picketed.

The American General Corporation yesterday called for redemption on June 1 at 101 1/2 and accrued interest its outstanding 5 per cent debentures due in 1947, originally issued by the International Securities Corporation of America and assumed by American General.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn announced yesterday the settlement of condemnation proceedings in connection with the construction of the Fourteenth Street-Eastern District subway.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., March 11. 1937: SERGEANTS-18th Division, Detective Districts indicated, designated as acting lieutenants: George E. Lenihan James T. Doyle.. 8 PATROLMEN-Dennis V. Donovan, from 14th Division to 7th Precinct, assignment to duty in plain clothes discontinued.

Howard Jackson, 43 years old, employed by the Flatiron Window Cleaning Company of 1,658 Broadway, failed yesterday morning to use his safety belt in cleaning windows on the eleventh floor of a twelve-story apartment building at 325 West End Avenue.

The Council of Polish Organizations in the United States of America denied yesterday that Poland was forcing Jews to emigrate. It declared the present emigration of about 80,000 Polish Jews annually was normal.

The executive committee of the Progressive State Committee adopted a resolution today, after a meeting presided over by Maurice P. Davidson, "whole-heartedly" supporting President Roosevelt's judiciary program.
The Music-Art Center at 1 West 123d Street, one of the projects the Federal arts program of the WPA and the first building of its kind to be established by the government, was opened yesterday.

Shipments of all types of hosiery in January amounted to 9,845,400 dozen pairs, an increase of 1,358,467 dozen pairs, or 16 per cent over the figure for the corresponding month of last year, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reported yesterday.

After drifting about two miles aboard a small raft on the Harlem River last evening, three boys were picked up by the crew of a police launch opposite 177th Street, about two and a half hours from the time they put out at a point off Dyckman Street.

That much was learned yesterday from both principals engaged in the salary squabble, in which the world champion Yankees find themselves minus the services of their slugging first baseman and captain.
The Municipal Civil Service Commission ordered a promotion examination yesterday to fill the post of Chief Medical Examiner, vacant since the death of Dr. Charles Norris in 1935.

The annual Spring Savings Conference of the savings division of the American Bankers Association will open today in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. It will bring together from all parts of the country bankers concerned with savings problems and will include a forum on school savings. It will continue through tomorrow afternoon.

The entire force of the Pacific Railway struck today. It is reported the men on other government lines may strike in sympathy. The strikers include office workers, dock workers, coal miners and chauffeurs of the railway trucking department.

The marriage of Mrs. Marie Dorsey Smith to Horatio King Gray took place yesterday at the home of Mr. Gray's mother, Mrs. Percy R. Gray of 12 Clark Street, Brooklyn. The Rev. J. Stanley Durkee of the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, performed the ceremony.

Republicans and Democrats nominated Frank J. Costello and William Disque today for member of the Assembly from the Third Onondaga district to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Assemblyman Richard B. Smith.

Lou Gehrig's long holdout has proved a boon to one member of the Yankees, if it has pleased no one else. The beneficiary is Ellsworth (Babe) Dahlgren, a likable young fellow who was purchased with the intention of using him as a stop-gap at first base.

Only one past winner of the annual seniors' golf championship remained in the running after the first round of match play today. He was R. W. Smith of Greensburg, Pa., who had the double satisfaction of continuing in the title hunt and also putting out one of the players who tied for low gross in the qualifying round.

Apartment rentals reported yesterday by brokers included a penthouse of twelve rooms and five baths, which was taken by Allan Gerdau in 55 East Seventy-second Street, through Byrne Bowman, Inc., in conjunction with Douglas Gibbons Co.
Christopher St. John Sprigg, held to be one of Great Britain's most promising young authors, is reported to have been killed fighting with the Spanish Government's international brigade.

Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen, president of the BrooklynVisitingNurse Association, will give an outline of the association's history this afternoon at an organization tea meeting of the Auxiliary of the Bay Ridge Substation at the home of Mrs. Horace Gledhill, 225 Eightythird Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. J.

There are subtle minds in Downing Street, if sometimes they are misunderstood by cruder persons unable to dance on cobwebs. In December Sir ERIC DRUMMOND, British Ambassador in Rome, told Count CIANO, Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs, that the establishing of a British Consulate General at Addis Ababa in place of a British Legation meant not only the de facto recognition of Italian sovereignty in Abyssinia but the de facto retraction of Abyssinian sovereignty.

After receiving a report yesterday from Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, showing that 3 per cent of the city's employes were paying out $900,000 a year in garnishments, Mayor La Guardia said he would name a credit consultant in the Finance Department to protect employes against unscrupulous lenders.

Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Reeves of Brompton Road have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Reeves, to Delevan Shields Mussey of Pittsburgh. Miss Reeves was graduated from Ashley Hall, Charleston, S. C., and from the College of William and Mary. Mr. Mussey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Mussey

The Department of Commerce reported today that exports of confectionery from the United States in 1936 totaled 14,842,755 pounds, valued at $2,394,686. This was the largest volume for a year since 1930, when 16,545,000 pounds, valued at $8,086,000, were shipped.

Miss Mina M. Bruere, assistant secretary of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company in charge of the women's department, and a former president, 1928-30, of the Association of Bank Women, died yesterday in the Doctors Hospital, after a brief illness. She resided at 10 Mitchell Place and was treasurer of the cooperative group owning the building.

The three-story garden apartment house at 33-54 Seventy-first Street, on the northwest corner of Hayes Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Loomis J. Grossman from the Rocklyn Realty Corporation, representing the Brooklyn Diocese of the Catholic Church. Harry A. Levine was the broker.

Aladar Retek, a defendant union official in the restaurant racket trial, testified yesterday that he appointed three men employed by Jules Martin; the gangster, to count the votes at a union election held in December, 1932.

The Brooklyn Museum has bought a copy of Goya's "Los Caprichos," printed in 1790 as an advance proof for -the painter, it was announced yesterday by Philip N. Youtz, director, at a meeting of the governing committee.

A sit-down strike won wage increases today for 140 men and women employes of the Pardee Matawan Tile Company. They effected a settlement providing 5 cents an hour increase for the men and 3 cents for the women, effective March 16, and an additional 2 cents for both, effective April 16.
A net income of $4,352,563 in 1936 was reported yesterday by the American Sugar Refining Company and its domestic and Cuban constituent companies, after taxes, including $10,500

Esmond Romilly, Winston Churchill's 18-year-old nephew, and Miss Jessica Freeman-Mitford, his 19-year-old sweetheart, the daughter of Lord Redesdale, have returned here from Bilbao, Spain, and announced their intention of going to the United States to start a beet-root plantation at Palm Beach, Fla.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court appointed Henry B. Sawyer of Boston the third trustee today of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, which is undergoing reorganization.

The split between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization widened today when it was learned that a movement was on foot to have President William Green call a special convention in order to read out of the federation all unions affiliated with the C. I. O.

John Van Ess of Princeton was reelected today president of the American Whig and Cliosophic Societies, oldest political and debating organizations in the country. James H. Cleveland of Cincinnati was re-elected president of the combined halls. Meeting separately,

The man who designed the steel structure for the fifty-six-story skyscraper at 500 Fifth Avenue, the Salmon Tower Building on Fortysecond Street and other famous buildings testified yesterday in the Bronx County Court that the plans for the six-story apartment house at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South were "defective."

James J. McGowan of 88-33 212th Place, Queens Village, Queens, a clerk in the Department of Hospitals, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack while seated in a barber's chair near his home. He was 58 years old and had been emplayed by the city for forty years. Two brothers, Martin R. and John P. McGowan, survive.
Mrs. Velma Swanston Howard, Swedish-American writer and translator, died yesterday at the New York Polyclinic Hospital from the effects of a paralytic stroke suffeed on Feb. 18. She was 69 years old.

The oftplagued British Broadcasting Corporation landed in more trouble today when it broadcast the skit, "Money With Menaces." The script called for a telephone number and some one filled in a real one-Wimbledon 3922.

Although both sextets already have clinched play-off positions, New York Rangers and the Detroit Red Wings expect a banner turnout at Madison Square Garden tonight when the teams will meet for the last time in a regularly scheduled encounter.

Hanns Kerrl, Reich Church Minister; who has attempted for the last four weeks to establish full State control of the church contrary to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's plan, has been punished by being practically stripped of all his authority.

The entry of Glenn Cunningham, premier United States miler, for the featured mile event of the Maple Leaf indoor track and field games Friday night was received today by meet officials. Cunningham will oppose Archie San Romani, his chief rival on American boards this season;

M. B. Gordon, vice president and general manager of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, and Burdette S. Wright, vice president of the Curtiss-Wright Company, were elected directors of the last-named company yesterday. Guy W.
Flames swept through the Danish freighter Laila, today, exploding the nitrate in her cargo, threatening lives and endangering waterfront property in Charlestown.

THE LETTERS OF FANNY BRAWNE TO FANNY KEATS, 1820-1824, edited by Fred Edgcumbe. (Oxford University Press, $3.) Containing thirty-one hitherto unpublished letters. AGED 26: A PLAY ABOUT JOHN KEATS, by Anne Crawford Flexner. (Oxford. $1.50.)

Morris Av. (11-3170), e. s., 106 s. of 182d St., 132x110; 2,200 Morris Av. Realty Corp. to Investors Syndicate. 250 Park Av.; 1 year, 6 per cent; building loan; $200,000. Clinton Av. (11-2949), s. w. cor. of 176th St., 57x100; Helger Realty Corp. to Ida Strongin, 2,075 Creston Av.; installments; 6 per cent: $12.000.

The election of David A. Rosoff as president and chairman of the board of the Amtorg Trading Corportion, American trading agency for the Soviet Union, was announced here yesterday. Mr. Rosoff succeeds Ivan V. Boyeff, who will return to the Soviet Union soon to take up a directing position in the People's Commissariat of Light Industry.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Warren Newkirk of Old Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shirley Newkirk, to John Hamilton Tyson 2d of Millbrook, Greenwich, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Hamilton Tyson of Riverside, Conn.

Although the stock market here continued quiet today, it showed a general tendency toward firmness. Giltedge issues, after maintaining the advances they made yesterday, fell off slightly at the close of the session. Among the foreign bonds Japanese loans were strong.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during January have been announced by the Department of Commerce; they are here compared with those of the preceding month and with January, 1936.

Chester A. Bishop of the Downtown Athletic Club, seeded No. 1 in the metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship, advanced into the quarter-final round of the event yesterday when he defeated E. W. Curtin of the Union Club on the D. A. C. courts. Bishop won, 18-16, 15-13, 13-15, 17-15.

Support was in evidence in most all sections of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. On a somewhat slower trading pace, improvement was shown among the high grade investments and also the secondary and convertible corporate loans.

When the first Red. Cross appeal was made for the flood sufferers, the minimum goal for the nation was put at $2,000,000 and that of the New York Chapter (comprising Manhattan and the Bronx) at $300,000.

Former Justice Jeremiah T. Wahoney, president of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, last night granted official sanction to the Pan-American "Olympic games" to be held from June 30 to July 3 at the Pan-American Exposition at Dallas, Texas, according to The Associated Press.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has consented to the withdrawal of the following registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933:

Mrs. Jeremiah Van Brunt of 21 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn, opened her home yesterday for a tea and musical, held under the auspices of the Brooklyn branch of the Vassar Alumnae Association, of which Miss Katharine Ross is president.

Mrs. Ruth Manierre Delafield, 38 years old, a former president of the Junior League here and former wife of Lewis L. Delafied Jr., counsel for the Triborough Bridge Authority, was taken to the Neurological Institute in the Medical Center yesterday afternoon,

The Interstate Commerce Commission granted today permission to the Railroad Credit Corporation and the Southern Pacific Railroad to intervene in the reorganization of the St. Louis Southwestern Railroad, otherwise known as the Cotton Belt.

Calm amid a barrage of questions laid down by opponents, Attorney General Cummings opened today the administration's drive in Congress for passage of President Roosevelt's bill to reorganize the Federal courts, urging before the Senate Judiciary Committee that it was necessary to restore the governmental machinery to its proper balance.
The New York Stock Exchange's committee on stock list reported yesterday listing of the following securities:

Mrs. Florence Majestic, 41 years old, who conducts a camp-stool Spiritual Church of Sunshine in an apartment at 1,477 Lexington Avenue, pleaded guilty in Felony Court yesterday to a charge of defrauding a servant girl of $195 to be invested in a funeral parlor business in Brooklyn. Mrs. Majestic, who is the mother of five children, was released in $2,500 bail for a hearing next Thursday
Walter Carpenter of Hamden, one of four persons injured in a collision yesterday between a bus and an automobile, died today at the hospital here.
Two Cuban seamen were dead, two were missing and eleven were saved today after the molasses tanker Hopper 62, crippled by heavy seas, had piled up on a reef ten miles west of Havana.

The four directors of the MissouriKansas Pipe Line Company (Mokan) to which the common stockholders are entitled were elected today without contest before Albert L. Massey, master appointed by Chancellor Josiah 0. Wolcott.

Lou Gehrig, baseball's No. 1 fisherman, was back at his home in New Rochelle yesterday, but there wasn't a fishing trip in the offing. Not that the premier first baseman had not planned at least one expedition, sitting in the stern of a streamlined cruiser hooking a sailfish or two, but it just couldn't be done this year, Gehrig said.
Annual Spring Savings Conference of the American Bankers Association begins at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at 9:45 A. M. and continues tomorrow.
Aldo Spoldi, scheduled to box Henry Armstrong at the Garden tomorrow night, was granted a week's postponement by the State Athletic Commission yesterday because of an injured hand.

It is becoming more and more clear, as the President's argument proceeds, that his real quarrel is not with the Supreme Court but with the Federal system. To be sure, the dominant theme of his radio address on Tuesday evening was an argument that the court " has been acting not as a judicial body, but as a policy-making body ";

More than twenty States are considering passage of laws "harassing advertising in one way or the other," according to the Advertising Federation of America yesterday. Some of the bills introduced in various State Legislatures form a national pattern, "indicating that organizations of broad scope are behind these proposals," the federation said.

Dr. Beverley R. Tucker of Richmond described in The Virginia Medical Monthly today the "progressive regression at the rate of a year or so every few months" of a woman of 61 to a state similar to that at birth.

The foreign exchange market resumed yesterday its outward signs of calm and order as the various exchange controls set to work to restore the stability of rates that had been temporarily broken by the monetary developments in France.

Arturo Godoy, Chilean heavyweight, unbeaten since his arrival in this country, was forced to travel at top speed to maintain that record last night at the Hippodrome, and in the end he had to be content with a draw in his ten-round feature bout with Maurice Strickland, a newcomer from New Zealand.
A heart attack at the threshold of prison today killed Samuel Whittaker, accused of wife murder, who had said that "May God strike me dead before I get to my cell if I am guilty."

An echo from the wreck here last October of the Spanish steamer Cristobal Colon was heard yesterday when Malcolm Hollis, Bermudian, was charged in St. George's Police Court with stealing a quantity of silverware and silver dishes from the ship.
To a crowded Chamber, Premier Koloman Daranyi replied today to interpellations concerning Nazi conspiracies in Hungary by asserting the general alarm was "political hysteria."

COOTE, ALBERT E. (Dec. 28, 1933). Gross assets, $18,704; net a deficit. Lewis C. Grover, attorney, 16 Court St., Brooklyn. CRILLEY. HANNAH (Oct. 20, 1936). Gross assets, $4,630; net, $3,607. To St. Ignatius Loyola Church and the Corporation of the Roman Catholic Clergymen of Maryland, $200 each; Dorothy F. Ducey, sister-in law, residue; eight varying bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $4,595. Roger S. Brassel, attorney, 20 Pine St.

The continued scramble abroad for the raw materials of munitions raised the export price of copper here 60 points yesterday to 17.47 1/2 cents a pound, c. I. f., European base ports, the highest level recorded since 1929.

Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson passed her first day quietly at the ancient Chateau de Cande, in the Touraine chateau country. She ventured out of doors to explore the extensive estate, but was driven back by a heavy shower.

President Roosevelt discussed changes in the diplomatic corps with Secretary Hull, stated at his press conference that he had discussed the St. Lawrence waterway with Premier King of Canada during the latter's visit to the White House last week, and prepared to depart tomorrow for Warm Springs, Ga.

R. R. Stewart, Eton and Magdalen, who replaced D. R. B. Mynors at No. 3 in the Oxford crew last Friday, today was awarded his Blue. Both Oxford and Cambridge, training for their annual clash on the Thames March 24, took out new shells today.

Gerald F. Morrow, yeast buyer for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, who testified that his organization purchased 5,000,000 pounds of yeast annually at an average price of 14 cents a pound, was the principal witness yesterday at the continuation of the hearing on the Federal Trade Commission's complaint charging Standard Brands, Inc.,

The English women's Wolfe-Noel squash racquets team sailed on the Queen Mary yesterday minus the international trophy they brought over six weeks ago, but with a good supply of our tournament honors in their possession.

Unable to obtain a six-day p?? for a sound truck, the Women National Committee for Hands ?? the Supreme Court made ?? yesterday a letter to Mayor ?? Guardia asking "immediate assur ance that your administration not opposed to public discussion ??. the Supreme Court."

Captain Wellington M. White, master of the S. S. Florida and commodore of the Peninsula Occidental Line, died last night of pneumonia. His age was 78. Captain White, a native of Belfast, Me., went to sea at 16. Once he owned a steamship line on Florida's West Coast and later was master of the P. O. Line's Flagler and Cuba, plying between Havana and Florida.

Frank L. Burns, president of the Burns Holding Corporation at 165 Broadway and formerly one of the leading coal operators of the United States, died on Monday at Miami, Fla. He was 51 years old. His home was at Plandome. L. I.

The Fischel bill to provide permanent licenses for teachers after three years of substitute service was opposed yesterday afternoon by a majority of the 200 delegates to a special meeting of the High School Teachers Association of New York City at the Hotel Commodore.
Mayor La Guardia plans to ask the Board of Estimate to increase clothing and rent allowances to home relief families, it was learned yesterday at City Hall.

Lagomar was the setting tonight for a dinner to which Mrs. Henry R. Rea was hostess in honor of Mr. and Mrs. J. Denniston Lyon of New York, her house guests, and Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, also of New York.
A new plan which promised a happy ending to the long-contested Warner-Quinlan Company's reorganization proceedings was submitted by the debtor yesterday to Federal Judge Murray Hulbert.

The Federal Power Commission postponed today until May 11 the hearing scheduled for March 17 on the application of the Niagara Falls Power Company for an amendment of its license for Project No. 16 to provide for the use of 275 cubic feet a second of water through the project.
Merle Vandenbush, Anthony Rera and George Rera will be placed on trial tomorrow before County Judge Gerald Nolan and a jury, District Attorney Walter A. Ferris announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Schuyler Cammann of Lindenmere, Merrick, L. I., have announced the engagement of their only daughter, Miss Katharine Schuyler Cammann, to Howard Schiller Lipson, son of Mrs. William F. Wall of this city and Scarsdale, and of the late Howard S. Lipson.

One of the most improved fencers of the season, Miss Madeline Dalton of the home club, captured the women's metropolitan fencing championship at the Salle d'Armes Vince last night. Miss Dorothy Locke, victor last year, and Miss Marion Lloyd, former national champion, did not compete.
The police have discovered that John Hughes of New York, who is held here on a murder charge, had been posing in Berlin as a Bavarian prince.

Gerrit Smith Miller, grandson of Gerrit Smith, Abolitionist and philanthropist, died at his home here today. He was 92 years old. Mr. Miller's health had falied since the burning of his home, built by his great-grandfather, Peter Smith, in 1803. The house burned March 2. 1936.

Fourteen properties in Manhattan were sold at auction yesterday, and the sale of a fifteenth was adjourned for ninety days. The list follows: By DANIEL GREENWALD 66th St., 61 E., seven-story building, 20x100.5; Manhattan Co., successor trustee,

Asinari Charles (Feb. 24). Estate, more than $10,000. To Helene Asinari, sister, residue. Louis J. de Milhau, Glen Head, L. I., executor. CHARLES, HARRY H. (March 12). Estate, more than $10,000. To Jane Barbour Charles, daughter, executrix, 355 Riverside Drive residue.

Following a sharp disagreement with his colleagues, Sir Henry Gullett, Trade Treaty Minister, resigned today. Prime Minister J. A. Lyons refused to discuss the reasons for the clash, saying they were private, but it is understood the differences concerned negotiations for a Canadian trade treaty which were interrupted by the departure of W. D. Euler, Canadian Trade Minister, for Ottawa last week.

Payment of pensions to widows of war veterans not having service-connected disabilities and to veterans on the basis of need rather than of disability was criticized today before the House Committee on World War Veteran Legislation by Commander Donald A. Hobart of the American Veterans Association.
The Maine House of Representatives, listening to arguments that the State's "weather vane" role in national election years yielded in publicity "hundreds of thousands of dollars,"
Eduardo I. Montoulieu, Secretary of the Treasury, presented his resignation today, according to an announcement by Dr. Juan Remos, Secretary of State.
The Hitler Cabinet made public today a decree that in effect makes all foreigners and their possessions in Germany hostages for the good behavior of their native lands.

Jacob A. Livingston, former Kings County leader, told a Brooklyn audience last night that he was more interested in saving the nation than he was the city and promised that "a real 100 per cent Republican" would be put forward in the primaries for the Mayoralty nomination next Fall.

The Argentine newspapers have been giving much space to the projected reform of the United States Supreme Court. Today they turned attention to the mote in their own eye and discovered that Argentine civil courts were clogged up with more than 150,000 cases awaiting decisions.

Public subscription to the new government loan, which began on March 4 and will continue until March 18, has been so extensive that the total amount of the loan has been raised from 500,000,000 to 700,000,000 marks.

A small band of pickets shivered for several hours at the gates of the strike-closed Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant today, then withdrew. The entire plant was shut down almost a week ago by a dispute over wages and hours.

Kin Fu Ki, 32-year-old Korean Buddhist priest, who is 7 feet 9 inches tall and weighs 303 pounds, plans a trip to the United States to challenge American giants to an eating contest. When reminded that Robert Wadlow of Alton, Ill., is 8 feet 5 inches tall, the priest retorted:

The Marine Midland Trust Company, trustee for Symington-Gould Corporation, Gould Coupler Corporation first mortgage convertible income bonds of 1956, has notified the Stock Exchange that from Dec. 15, 1936, to March 8, 1937, bonds of this issue aggregating $414,200 were converted or redeemed and retired against which 34,516 2-3 shares of special 10-cent par value stock of the Symington-Gould Corportion were withdrawn from the collateral account.

Alabama swept its "bone-dry" statutes of twenty-two years aside today as its larger cities gave majorities for repeal in a county option election. Twenty-three of the State's sixtyseven counties gave repeal majorities in unofficial tabulations of the option elections.

Rollin M. Clark, First Deputy Superintendent of the StateDepartment of Insurance, has resigned to join the Continental Assurance Company and the Continental Casualty Company of Chicago, it was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, superintendent. His resignation will be effective on April 30.

Counting more consistently than his rival, especially in the late frames, Jerome Strauss won the national amateurClass B 18.2 balkline billiard crown last night by defeating Joseph R. Johann, the defending champion, 200 to 153 in thirty-five innings, at the Capitol Health Center.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Palmer Loening, who have been on a trip to Toronto, Canada, are expected to return tomorrow to their home here to greet William L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada, who arrived Tuesday from Washington on a surprise visit to the Loenings only to find that they had left last Saturday for Toronto.

There was a greater-than-seasonal increase in department store sales between January and February, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The index of sales has shown a gradual rise in the last few months. For February the adjusted index, which allows for seasonal variations, was 95 on the basis of 100 for the 1923-25 average, compared with 93 in January, 92 in December and 83 in February, 1936.

strike today closed the twelve-story building of Crowley, Milner Co., one of Detroit's largest department stores, while several thousand customers were inside. It caused the greatest tie-up of more than a score of unrelated commercial strikes called in this area within two weeks.

"Fortified by the splendid dry air of the Bronx," which he said acts as an antidote for the atmosphere of legislative halls, James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, yesterday accepted "unreservedly" an invitation

Kings County Judge John J. Fitzgerald yesterday sentenced John J. Keough, 31 years old, of 39 Charles Street, Brooklyn, to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing during the week of April 19 for shooting James Heaney, proprietor of a speakeasy at 96 Flatbush Avenue Extension.

The Curb Exchange has admitted to unlisted trading the new common stock, $1 par value, of the United States Radiator Corporation in substitution for the old common stock, no par value. The 7 per cent preferred stock, $100 par value, has been removed from dealings.

David Bernstein, J. Robert Rubin and Louis B. Mayer on Feb. 25 exercised options to buy 13,890 shares each of the stock of Loew's, Inc., at $35 a share, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission which was made public by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

The Philippine Commonwealth must obtain its full independence from the United States soon and should not be required to wait until 1945 if it is to have adequate opportunity to develop economic strength and economic freedom, President Manuel L. Quezon said today.
Electric power production decreased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index receded to 107.8 from 109.7. It was 97.1 for the week ended March 7, 1936.

TWENTY years from now the graybeards among the spectators at ice. hockey games will be looking at some twinkling star on skates and saying: "Yes, he's a good boy, but you ought to have seen Howie Morenz in the old days." And the remarks will be as right as rain.

Captain John Penny, United States Life Saving Service, retired, who aided in scores of rescues on the eastern shore of Long Island during his 42-year career, died here yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 82.

Leaders of the two chief factions of American labor forces expressed tonight before the annual Woman Congress divergent opinions of the cause of the split in their ranks. The congress was conducted under the auspices of The Chicago Tribune.

The German Olympic Committee's final report, published today, indicates the report on admissions issued by the committee when the games closed was exaggerated. The committee now reports 3,800,000 tickets sold or given away. The first figure was 4,500,000.

The Works Progress Administration in this city will operate on a budget of $16,000,000 a month between now and June 30, the end of its fiscal year, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, announced yesterday.

Informal conversations concerning a trade treaty with Great Britain are continuing, Secretary Roper said today in answer to a question at his press conference. He added that the matter of the Anglo-American trade agreement was receiving "very close and intelligent study."

Receiving a fifty-gun salute Premier Benito Mussolini left Gaeta, Italy, this afternoon for Tobruk, Italian North Africa, aboard the cruiser Pola. He was accompanied by Alessandro Lessona, Minister of Colonies; Dino Alfieri, Minister of Press and Propaganda;

Conversion of $7,912,500 of New York Central convertible collateral 6 per cent notes of 1944 into capital stock of the company was indicated in a statement issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Dr. William Harding Longley, Professor of Biology at Goucher College and director of the marine laboratory of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, died tonight in Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was 56 years old.
Harrison Durant, formerly financial adviser of Thomas A. Edison, at his home in Cynwyd today, confirmed reports from England that his daughter, Phyllis Durant, 23, met death while yachting there.

Samuel. S. Leibowitz, criminal lawyer, testified yesterday at the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping trial that District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn had assured him that Martin Schlossman, one of the defendants on trial, would be permitted to plead guilty to second degree assault for signing a waiver of immunity and describing his role in the case before a Kings County grand jury.

Yale's new Roosevelt-forOnly King Club is spreading like the as a proverbial wildfire. Princeton Jest behaves handsomely in the matter by organizing a chapter of its own, instead of wondering aloud if Yale got the idea from Princeton's sensational Veterans of Future Wars.

The Japanese Army, headed by its commander-in-chief, Emperor Hirohito, today celebrated its annual festival of remembrance, the anniversary of the battle of Mukden in 1905, most brilliant and significant triumph of Japanese arms on land.

Despite unfavorable conditions caused by strikes and floods, sales of twenty-five chain-store organizations in February totaled $167,054,274, an increase of $18,767,965, or 12.6 per cent over the volume in the corresponding period last year, according to the monthly compilation released yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.
The recent advance in prices attracted a fairly liberal movement of hogs from the country today and receipts for the second successive day exceeded trade estimates.

Charles Clay, 40 years old, who is facing life imprisonment as a habitual criminal, created a scene in Judge Koenig's part of General Sessions yesterday as he was about to go on trial for carrying a pistol.

The compositions of Rosy Wertheim and Dr. Paul Amadeus Pisk were featured last night in the Composers' Forum - Laboratory, sponsoring contemporary American music, at the WPA Theatre of Music, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street.
Rainbow, the America's Cup defender of 1934, which will be brought out by her new owner, Chandler Hovey of Boston, in the defense competition the coming Summer, will have no hull change.
Lawrence Marx, president of Cohn-Hall-Marx, who recently returned from an air trip through South America, will address a luncheon meeting of cotton goods interests at the Arkwright Club on Tuesday.

General Francisco Franco's Insurgent troops operating against Madrid from the northeast consolidated today ground won in a twelve-mile advance in the Guadalajara sector. At the same time they reported that other forces had pushed back government troops in the Jarama zone, southeast of Madrid.

A seven-man sit-down strike outside the office of William S. Menden, president of the B. M. T., was ended less than two hours after it started yesterday, when ten special officers of the company pushed the sit-downers into an elevator and out of the building at 385 Flatbush Avenue Extension, Brooklyn.

The Standard Oil Company (N. J.), a New Jersey corporation which is the holding company for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, a Delaware corporation, was assessed $75,000,000 on its registered office in Linden, N. J., in a surprise ruling today by the Union County Board of Taxation.

At exactly 8:56 o'clock last night, Mayor La Guardia strode to the foul line of Alley No. 14, made a sweeping underhand whirl, and sent a sixteen-pound ball whizzing down the shiny surface toward a triangle of ten pins.

Officers of the Shippers Conference of Greater New York were elected yesterday at the conference's monthly meeting in the Woolworth Building. In all cases incumbent officers were returned to their posts as follows:

The indications are for mostly cloudy weather, with slowly rising temperature, today and for cloudy weather, with little change in temperature, tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.
Shipments of finished steel products in February by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation amounted to 1,133,724 tons, compared with 1,149,918 in January and 676,315 in February, 1936.

Two park workers who have insisted with Jim Curran, editor of The Star, that Northern Ontario's timber wolves will not attack a man, took to trees today to escape the Sault's wolf pack, which escaped from their pen at Bellevue Park after hurling themselves against the doors and tearing a hinge from the post.

The Times of London expresses belief editorially that President Roosevelt's radio speech last night will carry popular appeal but not "placate" opposition to his court proposal. "These arguments are likely to appeal to a large section of the public," says the editorial.

Fully convinced that he is the master of James J. Braddock and seeking to protect his rights to a world heavyweight championship meeting, Max Schmeling yesterday weighed in with an offer to the present holder of the crown, proposing a title contest in Berlin next Summer.

Fines totaling more than $269 were paid yesterday in Manhattan and Bronx Magistrates Courts by 267 persons found guilty of smoking or spitting in the subways. All of those who appeared in court received summonses Monday and yesterday as the Health Department continued its drive to end this nuisance.

As the Giants' training activities swung today into the closing stages of the Havana chapter, one question seemed to perplex the assembled experts more than any other. The question concerns Colonel Bill Terry himself-"Why is the Giant boss, who so stoutly and vehemently declared last Fall that he would never play again, training harder this Spring than he has in several years?"

More money to buy books, more space for readers and staff, and provision for retiring faithful workers are some of the difficulties confronting the New York Public Library, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Immediate repeal of the city's 2 per cent sales tax and reduction of the 3 per cent tax on utility companies and the gross receipts tax on other businesses were asked in a resolution adopted yesterday by the New York Board of Trade at its March luncheon meeting in the Hotel Commodore.

The War Department released the following orders today dated March 9: COLONELS Noble, W. H., Q. M. C., 21 days leave, March 10. Cole, O. R., Infantry, San Francisco, Calif., to Fort McDowell, Calif., July 1. Severson, C. F., Infantry, Panama, to University of California, Los Angeles, Calif. Noble, W. H., Q. M. C., Atlanta, Ga., to retirement.
The Federal Communications Commission ordered today that automatic radio alarm devices must be Installed by July 10 on all' cargo. ships of 5,500 tons or over under the American flag.
The field for the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree, March 19, was reduced to thirty-three today when twelve jumpers, three of them Americanowned, were listed among the final non-acceptors.

The resignation of Joseph B. Weaver as chief of the Marine Inspection and Navigation Bureau, to be effective Friday, was announced today by Secretary Roper. H. L. Seward of Yale University, former bureau consulting engineer on construction, is being considered for the post, the secretary said.

The Eastern railroads serving New York Harbor petitioned the Federal District Court yesterday to restrain the Interstate Commerce Commission from carrying out an order, effective April 15, which would require them to increase their storage and handling rates in railroad-controlled warehouses.

Members of the Aldermanic committee appointed to investigate a shortage of policemen held their first meeting at City Hall yesterday. Alderman John Cashmore, who introduced the resolution for an investigation of the police after his Flatbush home had been robbed, was made chairman of the committee.

Dr. Israel I. Bernstein of 237 West Seventy-fourth Street died Tuesday of a heart attack in Miami Beach, Fla., while on a vacation. His widow, Anna J. Bernstein, and a brother, Leon B. Bernstein, survive. Dr. Bernstein, who was born in Russia fifty-six years ago,

The Peddle School five, which previously had clinched the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League title, closed its campaign undefeated by overpowering Irving School, 49-29, at Hightstown, N. J., yesterday. The triumph gave Peddle a record of seventeen victories, ten of which came in league play.

Mrs. Anna Sheehan, 27 years old, mother of three children, of 445 West Forty-eighth Street, was acquitted early this morning of firstdegree manslaughter in connection with the death of her husband, Joseph Sheehan, an elevator starter. The jury returned a verdict at 12:20 A. M. Mrs. Sheehan collapsed in a chair at the counsel's table, buried her head in folded arms and wept.

A Spanish Insurgent armed trawler made a daring attack within sight of the French coast today upon a Spanish Government freighter, and the French Navy took quick action "to force respect for French territorial waters."

Republican local leaders are said to be generally opposed to the renomination of Mayor LA GUARDIA, but as yet many of them hem and qualify. They don't know "where they are at." They don't want to be too premature and positive. Mr. KENNETH SIMPSON, leader of New York County, says guardedly that "it might be foolish in some ways to renominate LA GUARDIA."

President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposals were debated yesterday by two leaders of the legal profession at a forum under the auspices of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations in the community house of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Virginia J., who found a mile a little too far in her previous start, held on long enough at the same distance today to defeat five other 3-year-olds in the allowance race which topped the Fair Grounds program.

The eighth and final performance of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" for the current season was given yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The usual enthusiastic capacity assemblage was in evidence.

An engineering college student five days a week, draughtsman's helper after classes, shoe salesman on Saturdays, bank watchman on Sundays, Howard R. Booth, 23 years old, took on today the additional job of Borough Councilman.

A mortgage for $8,500 held by Helena Hoops from the 389 Grand St. Corp., Michael Valenzano president, on the southwest corner of Grand and Suffolks Sts. was extended to March 15, 1944, at 4 per cent. William E. Hart assigned to the St. Andrew's Society a $4.000 interest in a $20,000 mortgage on 34 Catharine St., and the Title Guarantee and Trust Co. assigned to the society its $12,000 interest in the same mortgage.

Completely modernized throughout and restocked with new merchandise for Spring, the HearnsBronx store at 150th Street, at Third Avenue, which was recently acquired by Hearn Department Stores, Inc., was opened for public inspection last night.

The average cost per family for all types of housing, land exclude in New York City during 1936 was $3,605, with a total of 33,921 families provided for, according to News Opinion, publication of the Building Trades Employers Association. The averages were computed from the United States Department of Labor building permit statistics.

A decree tomorrow morning will open subscriptions to a loan of 10,500,000,000 francs for French national defense. The interest rate is expected to be 4 per cent. This loan will be different from any other ever issued in this country in that it will be subscribable and repayable in francs, dollars or pounds.

Following the defeat in the Assembly yesterday of the proposal to ratify the Child Labor Amendment to the Federal Constitution, the Republican party in this State today took a stand against the exploitation of children in industry in an alternative measure, introduced by Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat of New York City, a stanch supporter of the proposed Federal amendment on the two occasions when ratification has been before the Assembly for action.

A LONG overdue book on Japan has been written by Dr. Freda Utley, an English economist. The title, "Japan's Feet of Clay" (Norton, $3.75), is an almost humorous understatement of the author's point. Dr. Utley has gone behind the charm and the cherry blossoms to find facts, and has turned up with an indictment.

The New Haven Railroad announced last night that a special "snow train" will leave Grand Central Terminal tomorrow night for the snowy slopes of the Mount Mansfield-Smugglers Notch Region of Stowe, Vt.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Feb. 27 totaled 288,121,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Many persons entertained guests at tea yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador, after the presentation of motion pictures and slides of Stratford Hall, birthplace of General Robert E. Lee on the Potomac River.

Union leaders negotiating with officials of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company for pay increases for 8,000 employes of the East Pittsburgh plant announced today that the company had granted a six-cent-an-hour average advance to 1,500 workers in the lower pay brackets, staving off a threatened strike.

Offering of 77,380 shares of $5 par value common stock of the Allied Kid Company at $18 a share will be made today by a syndicate headed by Jackson Curtis, Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc., and Mitchum, Tully Co.

Juvenal Marchisio was appointed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to serve for thirty days on the Domestic Relations Court. Mr. Marchisio is 34 years old and lives at 535 Eighty-Fifth Street, Brooklyn. He is a graduate of Fordham Law School, and also has studied law in Genoa, Italy.

The Hershey Bears went into first place in the Eastern Ice Hockey League tonight by tying the New York Rovers, 1 to 1, in an overtime game. Two minutes before the regulation playing time ended, Hershey shot the puck to the edge of the New York net and it rebounded.

Stocks closed irregularly higher; rail, motor, rubber and steel shares featured; tobacco and traction group weakened; turnover, 2,823,660 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly lower, convertible rail and industrial issues higher; transactions, $14,650,200.

The Federal Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, 1936, of $1,607,383, compared to a net of $1,344,465 for the preceding fiscal year.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Murray D. Welch of New York City was admitted to practice 'today and the following proceedings were had: 562-United States, petr., v. Harry J. Madigan. Argued for both.

Lewis M. Haupt, professor and engineering consultant, died today at his home in Cynwyd at the age of 92. Born in Gettysburg, he was the son of General Herman Haupt, scientist and railroad builder. Following undergraduate work at Harvard University he attended and was graduated from West Point in 1867.
John McCormack, Irish tenor, was the soloist tonight in the fourth concertina series given at the Mosque Theatre here under the auspices of L. Bamberger Co.

Three indictments charging nine individuals with cheating on wages or payroll padding on WPA projects were handed up in Federal court yesterday after a four-month inquiry by WPA investigators and the Attorney General's office.

In sympathy with an advance of 5 cents a bushel in wheat and new high records for copper and rubber and strong outside markets generally, prices on the Cotton Exchange rose about $1.50 a bale yesterday and ended with gains of 17 to 19 points. Both spot and contract quotations touched the highest figures since June, 1930, under aggressive foreign buying and urgent price fixing by domestic mills.

The New York Curb Exchange's board of governors has approved transfer of the regular membership of the late Karl W. Corby to W. W. Spaid of W. B. Hibbs Co. and that of the late Lee Ulman to Eugene J. Sweeney, in care of Reynolds, Fish Co.

The resignation of Finance Minister Gustavo Ross late last night came as a bombshell in political circles, where the importance of the unexpected withdrawal of the most prominent figure of the Right Wing parties was not concealed.

One interesting development in the debate over the new Federal judiciary proposals was the President's defense in his "Fireside Chat" last night against charges that he would pack the Supreme Court. He denied the intention.

Earl Averill, the Cleveland Indians' center-fielder holdout, revealed tonight that he had attempted, without success, to negotiate a deal for himself with the Detroit Tigers, the Boston Red Sox and the Chicago White Sox.

Turpentine firm, 41c; sales, 12 barrels; receipts, 33 barrels; shipments, 414 barrels; stock, 22,747 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 309; receipts, 286; shipments, 2,689; stock, 52,295. Quote: B, $8.15: D. $8.45; E, $8.90; F. $9.25; G, $9.30; H, $9.32 1/2; I, K, M, N, $9.35; WG, $9.60;. WW $10.75; X $11.50.

General and Mrs. Robert Lee Bullard will give a luncheon on Sunday at the Plaza. Mrs. Dwight Davis has arrived from Washington and is at the Ritz Tower. Mr. and Mrs. Laurence 'Boocock of 1,088 Park Avenue will sail on Saturday for California.
Nathaniel Paschall, an investment specialist, died yesterday of a heart attack in his apartment in the Hotel George Washington, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street. His age was 54.

In recognition of his diplomatic work during the period of strained AngloItalian relations preceding the gentlemen's agreement, King Victor Emmanuel has conferred on Dino Grandi, Ambassador to London, the title of count.

Yale's varsity swimmers easily defeated Princeton, 56 to 19, tonight in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet, stretching their list of consecutive intercollegiate vicstories in thirteen years to 163. Only one record was broken, the 150yard back-stroke mark in which Connie Mittendorf lowered the Yale standard of 1:41.4, created last year by Norris Hoyt, to 1:40.4.

The need for governmental regulation of trading over the counter decreases to the extent that selfregulation of the over-the-counter market is practiced, Sherlock Davis, assistant director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said last night at a dinner given for Oliver J. Troster, retiring president of the Security Dealers Association, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A registration statement was filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 by Hearst Magazines, Inc., of New York for issuance of $13,000,000 of debentures of 1937. The price to the public, interest rate, underwriters and underwriting discounts are to be furnished by amendment to the statement.

The appearance of college girls in the chorus of the Columbia Varsity show to take their place in the spotlight formerly occupied by bewigged men prancing awkwardly in tights drew a shower of hoots and pennies last night and one banana that left a slippery blotch on the stage.

Prices of wheat advanced sharply today on the crest of a world-wide buying movement which lifted all delivseries in Chicago, Winnipeg, Buenos Aires and Rotterdam and July in Liverpool to new high levels for the season.

Shipping men are awaiting with interest the reopening today of the months-old dispute between insurgent maritime workers and Federal authorities who seek to place continuous discharge books into effect against the seamen's will. It is expected that Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey will formally sign this morning an order implementing his decision, issued on Tuesday, denying to seamen further relief against the Federal law.

At a moment when the British Government is anxious to avoid public discussion of Anglo-American problems an unofficial parliamentary group sailed today on the liner Berengaria, ostensibly to discover what the United States thinks of the British Empire.

A potentially sweeping governmental control of all business in Alberta is indicated in two bills filed in the Provincial House by Premier William Aberhart and made public today. One bill gives the Cabinet licensing authority over business, with the power to refuse to grant or renew a license to any person or business operating in the Province.

After trailing for three quarters of the game, the NewYorkAthletic Club trio, consisting of Tom Bradley Jr., Major C. E. Davis and Johnny Pflug, came from behind in the final chukker to defeat the Optimists, 9 to 8 1/2, at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night in a benefit game for the American Legion Mountain Camp Endowment Fund.
The liner Normandie will sail for New York tomorrow, which means that the Cabinet of Premier Leon Blum has been able to settle yet another strike.

Columbia had a large number of veterans on hand yesterday as the Lions opened their Spring football training in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. Thirty-five aspirants worked under the direction of Coach Lou Little, who appeared to be in excellent condition following his two months' vacation in the Bahamas.

A possible bridge over which the opposing neutrality views of various members of Congress might travel to agreement is being constructed in the form of a two-year limitation on the projected legislation, it was learned today.

Negotiations for a new agreement in the bituminous coal industry were resumed yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore by representatives of the United Mine Workers and operators of the Appalachian area. Indications were that, while some progress was being made, final agreement was not likely for some time. The old contract expires March 31 and may have to be extended to permit continuance of negotiations.
An epidemic of sit-down strikes broke out in Chicago today as a peace pact ended the sit-down which for two days paralyzed the sixty-two miles of freight tunnels beneath the Loop business district.

Gordon Dexter of Boston died here today. The body will be sent to Boston on the steamship New Northland, leaving tomorrow. Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES. BOSTON, March 10.-Gordon Dexter, who died today in Nassau, was a leading business man, club man and yachtsman. He was 72 years old.

Captain William G. Du Bose, assistant chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair in the Navy Department, was appointed chief constructor and chief of that bureau today, with the rank of rear admiral, effective next Tuesday, and for a period of four years.

Major Gen. Samuel Hof, retired, former chief of ordnance of the army, died in Walter Reed General Hospital today at the age of 66. Born in Boscobel, Wis., he was graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1894 and was commissioned in the cavalry. He was assigned to ordnance in 1898.

Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., and Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., former P. G. A. titleholder, continued their victorious march toward their third successive title in the annual Miami international four-ball golf matches at the Miami Country Club today.
The possibility of Senate ratification of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence waterway treaty at the present session of Congress was discussed at the conference between President Roosevelt and Premier King

Picturing the 1939 World's Fair as an aid to the Port of New York and a stimulus to foreign commerce and international cooperation, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, made this theme the keynote last night of the annual Port of New York dinner of the Foreign Commerce Club at the Hotel Astor.

Jimmy Ward, star right-winger of the Montreal Maroons in the National Hockey League, was seriously ill tonight of what was officially announced as influenza. Tonight Manager Tommy Gorman of the Maroons said considerable improvement in Ward's condition had been observed during the day and evening.

In a $2,500,000 transaction, reported to be one of the largest New York realty exchanges in several years, the New York Protestant Episcopal Public School acquired as an investment yesterday the twenty-story apartment building under construction at the south corner of Riverside Drive and Seventy-third Street.

The Republic Steel Corporation announced today a vacation plan for its 35,000 employes in Northern plants and a 10-cent-an-hour wage increase for employes not benefited by the wage increase announced last week for common labor.

Governor Lehman spent some time with his advisers scrutinizing bills which the Legislature is sending down to him. The Senate passed two Feld bills designed to protect associate superintendents of schools in New York City.

Tonight's first-night is that of the postponed "Arms for Venus," arriving at 8:45 o'clock at that John Golden Theatre which was recently known as the Masque. It is Randolph Carter's comic interpretation of life at Nero's court, derived from Petronius's "The Widow of Ephesus"

Charging that the union was getting the "run-around" from realty interests on the question of reopening of existing agreements, James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32 B of the Building Service Employes Union, threatened yesterday to call a strike of 14,000 workers in 1,000 buildings in the garment and fur districts.

The recital given by Myra Hess, the English pianist, at Town Hall last night brought the seventh endowment series of that institution to a brilliant conclusion. The audience was so large that seats had to be provided on the stage to accommodate the overflow.
Governor Lehman led in a tribute paid tonight to George R. Fearon, former Republican leader in the Senate, at a testimonial dinner given in his honor and attended by 450 friends.

Residences in Mount Vernon, Scarsdale and other sections of Westchester figured in the realty deals reported from that county yesterday. Pease Elliman, as agents for the New York State Teachers Retirement System, in cooperation with Harry Levy sold to Mrs.

The eighth annual Easter Catholic high school invitation basketball tournament of the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, will be held at the Columbus Club March 21 to 28, it was announced yesterday.

Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will open a brief Spring engagement of five days at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning on April 9. After its engagement the ensemble will sail for London, where it will participate in the coronation festivities.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty approved yesterday a final accounting of a successor trustee in the estate of James Gordon Bennett Sr., who died on June 1, 1872. Mr. Bennett, who was the founder and publisher of The New York Herald, in his will created a trust the principal of which was to be shared by his grandchildren.

President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court was warmly debated tonight before the fourth annual Woman Congress. Thousands of leaders of women's activities, including representatives from thirty-eight States, attended the congress.

Favorite players who collected only once in eight races the previous day came in for more rough treatment again today at Tropical Park. The Cordoba Handicap, one-mile Class C event, saw the talent still winnerless when Miss A. Doris's Ridge Mor, the one depended upon, failed by a half length to match the effort put forth by Robert L. Gerry's Chancer.

The number of unemployed in Germany at the end of February was 1,611,000 against 2,515,000 for the same period of 1936, or a decrease of 904,000. The monthly statistics showed a decrease of 243,000 since the end of last month.

Thanks to the efforts of American producers to maintain a domestic price level below that of the London market, which reflects the European scramble for copper and other "war-scare" metals, the United States Navy yesterday was able to place 2,400,000 pounds of the 3,000,000 pounds sought at prices ranging from a shade below 16 1/4 to a fraction under 16 1/2 cents a pound.
The preliminary statement, given out by the Commerce Department, of the large items making up this country's foreign trade balance in 1936, is in line with previous information.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday additional changes in the new traffic code, permitting motorists to make left turns on the red light at the following intersections on Lexington Avenue:

The Official Gazette announced today an increase in import duties on vegetable oils entering Cuba. Experts said this would benefit United States refiners of the crude product and United States shipping interests.

Mrs. Clara Kapp Lichtenstein, widow of Paul Lichtenstein, banker, and mother of Alfred F. Lichtenstein of 770 Park Avenue, died here yesterday at the age of 86. She was born in this city, a daughter of Dr. Friedrich Kapp, a German Revolutionary of 1848.

The committee on securities of the New York Stock Exchange has ruled that all of the German nonReich bonds, matured coupons and interest claims on which will be paid in the new 3 per cent funding bonds of the Conversion Office for German Foreign Debts, shall be ex coupon or interest claims tomorrow.
Mrs. Frederick T. Fleitmmnn gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Gustav Stresemann, widow of Dr. Stresemann, noted German Foreign Minister.

While a small army of carpenters prepared the track in the basement at Madison Square Garden, heats were tentatively drawn for the sixteenth annual track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. there on Saturday.

The State of California invited yesterday tenders for two new issues of securities, aggregating $5,580,540. Bids will be considered today for an issue of $2,580,540 of registered warrants of the State, the proceeds from which will be used to replenish the revolving fund from which general fund the State expenses are paid.

Progressive education projects such as nut-bread baking to teach boys arithmetic were criticized tonight by taxpayers who want the grammar schools of this village to return to the old-fashioned methods of teaching the "three R's" and other fundamentals.

The Board of Education has approved the following appointments and transfers of teachers and others in various branches of the school system: APPOINTMENTS Industrial and Vocational High Schools Daniel J. Carey, McKee Vocational High. Harry Hirsch, Brooklyn High School for Specialty Trades.

The steel industry, faced with the problem of underwriting $200,000,000 a year in increased labor cost, has announced immediate price rises on substantially all commodities with the exception of tin plate, Iron Age says this week.

The 742 member banks of the Federal Reserve in the New York Reserve District had in 1936 average net profits equal to 8.9 per cent of their capital funds after charge-offs and recoveries, according to a report of average operating ratios of the banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Miss Jean Berger, executive director of Manhattan Council of the Camp Fire Girls, and director of that organization's camps near Arden, died yesterday at the Fitch Sanitarium, after an illness of several weeks. Her age was 40.

Directors of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association declared a semi-annual dividend of $2 a share, payable $1 each on March 31 and June 30, and voted to add $900,000 to surplus, increasing it to $35,000,000. Directors of the Bank of America, an affiliated State bank, declared a regular quarterly dividend of 41 2-3 cents a share.

While a small army of carpenters prepared the track in the basement at Madison Square Garden, heats were tentatively drawn for the sixteenth annual track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. there on Saturday.

The State of California invited yesterday tenders for two new issues of securities, aggregating $5,580,540. Bids will be considered today for an issue of $2,580,540 of registered warrants of the State, the proceeds from which will be used to replenish the revolving fund from which general fund the State expenses are paid.

Progressive education projects such as nut-bread baking to teach boys arithmetic were criticized tonight by taxpayers who want the grammar schools of this village to return to the old-fashioned methods of teaching the "three R's" and other fundamentals.

The three-second rule in the foul lane, elimination of the center tap, and interpretation of what constitutes a block were the chief points of discussion at the clinic held by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon with more than 100 of the leading college and school coaches in the East attending.

Murray Baron, New York City chairman of the Socialist party, made public yesterday a letter to Mayor La Guardia, asking him to reveal whether his attitude toward Mussolini and Italian fascism was the same as his recently expressed attitude toward Hitlerism in Germany.

The Schenley Distillers Corporation and subsidiaries had in 1936 a consolidated net profit of $8,227,796 after all taxes and charges and before dividends on the company's preferred stock. according to the annual report

Yesterday, for the first time since training began ten days ago, Burleigh Grimes turned his eager batswingers loose against a flock of well-conditioned pitchers and it was assumed that after today's session the hitters all would be happy.

Frank De Vivio, 11 years old, of 1,973 Arthur Avenue, the Bronx, was killed yesterday afternoon at Monterey Avenue and 178th Street, the Bronx, when he fell from the back of a truck on which he was stealing a ride. At Fordham Hospital, where he was taken in an ambulance, it was said he had died of a fractured skull.

Dr. Percy Lonsdale McAll, a member of the London Missionary Society in China for thirty-seven years, died today at Edinburgh. His age was 66. After studying at Cambridge and Edinburgh University he went to China in 1898 and served the first twenty years in medical work at Wuchang and Hankow, doing many translations of medical textbooks. He retired in 1934.

The Argentine authorities are maintaining a close guard over a large shipment of munitions from Paraguay that has arrived here consigned to Poland. The shipment consists of 430 cases of rifles and machine-guns, and knocked-down tanks with a total weight of sixty tons.
Louis Allen Abramson, architect, yesterday announced plans for a new building for Ben Marden's Riviera, at Fort Lee, N. J., which was destroyed by fire last November.

Leaders of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's employee representatives refused today to join hands with the American Federation of Labor in a war on John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization.

Plans for ten school building projects to be financed out of the city's capital outlay budget at a cost of $1,906,000 were approved yesterday by the Board of Education. The plans call for the general construction of Public School 117, the Bronx, at $704,000; addition to 169, Brooklyn, $260,000, and Public School 253, Brooklyn, $550,000.

The Athletics won a game and lost a pitcher temporarily today. Alvin Benton injured his hand while the Macks were trouncing the Mexican Agrarians with a 25-hit barrage, 18 to 1. Benton injured a ligament in his hand in fielding a hard grounder in the second inning.

Harry F. Sinclair was made today chairman of the board of the new $55,000,000 Richfield Corporation when the directors held their first official meeting. Charles S. Jones was elected president of the corportion, William C. McDuffie,
The Assembly of the California Legislature today adopted, 45 to 28, a resolution designed to pardon Thomas J. Mooney, convicted of the 1916 Preparedness Day bombing in San Francisco.

Mrs. Joseph A. Grazier will give a tea tomorrow at her home, 1,060 Park Avenue, for members of the volunteer committee aiding the board of managers of the New York Diet Kitchen Association in the annual Spring sale at the Nearly New Shop for the benefit of the association.

Retail-package deliveries increased 10 per cent for the week ended March 6 over the comparative 1936 period, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The rise shows an improvement over the gain for the previous week, which was 7 per cent.

Negotiations between the United States and Great Britain providing for reciprocal aviation services in connection with the proposed joint transatlantic operation by Pan American Airways and Imperial Airways of Great Britain have reached a deadlock.

Herbert H. Schell, president of Sidney Blumenthal Co., said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that business should improve in virtually all of the com pany's lines this year and that the upholstery business gave promise of some pick-up despite curtail ment owing to the strikes in theautomotive industry.

More in a spirit of sadness than resentment, the organization Democrats of Rockland County gathered 200 strong in the Jewish Community Center here tonight to support the President's court program and to deplore with almost eloquent restraint what they termed the defection of the RocklandCounty "Liberty Leaguers."

"The woman in red," who lured John Dillinger to his death, pleaded today from her exile in Rumania for re-entry to the United States. Writing from the Balkan town of Timisoara, where she is known as Dona Anna Cumpanasi, Mrs. Anna Sage asked a Chicago attorney to take the necessarylegal steps to expedite her return.

Officials said today that the State Department soon would initiate a policy of giving advance information to American producers con cerning foreign products on which tariff concessions are to be considered.

Bus ness activity in the Pittsburgh district last week, after allowance for usual seasonal swings, was 125.4 per cent of the 1923-25 average, ac cording to the Bureau of BusinessResearch, University of Pittsburgh.

Buster Boy, out only once since last September and then fifth in -a field of eight, surprised the form players at the Fair G bunds today by leading more highly regarded rivals in the featured sixfurlong dash for players.

In an uncensored letter received in Paris from Madrid today, mailed March 6, one of the best observers of the situation in Madrid writes: "things are gradually approaching a climax, and we had better prepare for the worst. As things are going now, the fall of Madridsooner or later appears inevitable.

A six-way deadlock for first place resulted in the final round-robin of the fifth annual invitation foils tournament for the Greco Trophy at the Greco Fencing Academy last night. Because of the late hour the fence-off was deferred until Tuesday night.

Mrs. Eliza Smith Pindell, widow of Henry M. Pindell, and president of The Peoria Journal-Transcript, Inc., died at her home here last night after a short illness. For years Mrs. Pindell had been a leader in civic,charitable and religious work.

A bill to fix minimum wages for men in the Province of Ontario, sponsored by the Minister of Public Welfare and the Attorney General, has been introduced in the Legislature at Toronto. This move brings into the foreground a "constitutional crisis" in another North American nation, presenting some aspects wholly different from the Supreme Court controversy in theUnited States.

"Bats in the Belfrey," a comedy by Diana Morgan and Robert McDermot, revolves around Lilian Braithwaite, who, as Aunt Miranda, descends uninvited on her rector brothers' unruly household and assumes with the charming unscrupulousness ofa foster hen control of his chicks.

Net income of the railroads in 1936 reached an aggregate which was the highest for any year since 1930, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported yesterday. The total was $169,900,578, which was in contrast with a net loss of $1,374, 094 in 1935 and with larger losses in 1934 and 1933. Net income in 1931 was $134,762,000 and in 1930 itwas $523,907,000.

The Republic Steel Corporation's new $3, 000,000 strip mill here was opened today with an inspection trip by the corporation's officials and citizens of Niles. It adjoins the present works and will utilize hot strip fromRepublic's Warren mills.

Secretary Morgenthau late today, at the request of the Mexican Government and with the approval of the President directed collectors of customs to refuse entry into the United States of shipments of gold from Mexico unless the shipment in each case is accompanied by a certificate showing that it may lawfully be exported from Mexico.

A free-for-all fist fight unparalleled in the Belgian Senate's recent history held up its proceedings for an hour this afternoon when a Rexist Senator, Count Xavier de?? Grunne, slapped the face of a Liberal colleague, Mr. Catteau, duringdiscussion of an election project.

The Whitney Museum of American Art will open to the public on Tuesday an exhibition of paintings and prints by Cleveland artists. This is the third of a series of regional exhibitions of contemporary American paintings and prints to be held by the Whitney Museum, the other exhibitions having presented works by Chicago and Philadelphia artists.

The British Government has been reminded officially and otherwise in the past few days that the United States is suffering almost as acutely as Ger many, Italy and other "have-not" nations from the soaring prices of important raw materials producedwithin the British Empire.

181st St. (11-3083) n. w. cor. Crotona Av.. 150x67; 681 E. 181st St. Corp. to Hashaf Realty Corp., 1,705 Andrews Av.; mort. $135,000. Beach Av. (15-3899) s. e. cor. Archer St., 50x92; John S. O'Leary to Taybeach Real ty Corp., 384 E. 149 St.; mort. $68,600. 227th St. (17-4828) s. s. 133 ft. w. of Lowerre Pl., 66x100; New York State Teachers' Retirement System to Lillian Edenbaum, 2,113 E. 38th St., Brooklyn;mort. $68,000.

While major sit-down interest centers in the automobile industry, Detroit's epidemic of strikes or other labor disputes today increased to eighteen concerns, besides affiliates. The official list of business places where difficulties exist changed hourly, but late this evening the list of those where sit-down strikes or other labor disputes were in progress stood as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: One exceedingly important fact stands out in the final paragraph of your editorial "'Hobby' Study." It is that a liberal education means very little to a man fifteen or twenty years after graduation from college. We should surely like to know how to prevent people from continuing theirchildhood until advanced ages.

The effect of the depression on education was detailed today in a sta tistical summary issued by the Office of Education, which said the total income for education, public and private, from kindergarten through college, decreased 22.6 per cent in the 1933-34 period, as compared with 1929-30.

The stock markets today generally were firm, the only feature in an otherwise quiet session being activity among the commodity shares. Gilt-edge issues were satisfactory and, among the foreign loans, Japanese bondsImproved.

Fred L. Merritt, 63 years old, clerk of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors since 1912, was killed late this afternoon when an automobile in which he was riding left Route 121 at Cross River, in thetown of Lewisboro, and hit a tree.
