The protective committee for Warren Brothers Company 5 1/2 per cent notes due on March 1 and convertible 6 per cent debentures due in 1941 reported yesterday that it had received powers of attorney from holders of about $2,000,000 ofthese securities.

The most promising week-end of skiing for metropolitan devotees this unusual Winter looms for tomorrow and Sunday as the general run of snow reports and trail con ditions in the "Northlands" rangefrom good to excellent.

With higher faxes, rising cost for materials and increased labor rates threatening to wipe out or sharply reduce their profits, manufacturers in the popular price dress field met at the Hotel Governor Clinton last night to work out a program tomeet the present situation.

Applications for passports to proceed to Spain to do relief work in the civil war areas will continue to be refused, Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today in a formal statement evidently intended to clarify an important aspect of the neutrality policy the administration is trying to work out in con formity with the expressed wishesof Congress.
After establishing new high prices for the last seven years quotations on the Cotton Exchange developed irregularity yesterday and ended 2points higher to 10 points lower.

An investigation of the Emergency Relief Bureau and other relief agencies by the Board of Aldermen was foreshadowed yesterday when members of the Aldermanic Rules Committee voted unanimously to report out the resolution introduced by Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley, Bronx Democrat, calling forthe inquiry.

A demand for dwellings and apartment houses was evident yesterday in realty deals in the upper West Side and Harlem sections. The five-story residence on a lot 23 by 76.1 feet at 303 West Seventysixth Street was sold by the Wood, Dolson Company for Charles M.Cannon. It is assessed at $24.000.

The Hudson's Bay Company today announced a net profit for the year ended on Jan. 31; last, of [Pound]226,695 ($1,106,860 in current ex change rates at Montreal), after allowing [Pound]150,000 ($732,375) for depreciation.

J. Edgar Hoover's Federal agents may, like the Canadian Mounties, always get their man, but they do not always pierce the center of the target. Secretary Perkins informed the world today that the G-men finished fourth in the national midwinter. team pistol championship at Tampa yesterday.

Professor Irving Fisher, who teaches economics at Yale, was challenged yesterday in Federal Court as to his expertness in mat ters of finance, after he had testified as a witness for Wallace G. Garland, former honor student at that university, who, with others, is accused of swindling the public, in cluding the professor, of between$3,000,000 and $5,000,000.

For the first time since he became ill in December, Pope Plus today presided over an imposing meeting, attended by twenty-six Cardinals representing the three congregations Propagation of the Faith, Extraordinary Ecclesiastical Affairs andthe Oriental Church.

The sixth and last of the Young People's Concerts by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Ernest Schelling, will be presented tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock at CarnegieHall.

Howie Morenz, the great hockey player who died Monday, was buried today amid the sorrow of sportdom. Ten thousand persons massed for the last service at the Forum, filling row on row the seats of the great ice arena where Morenz and the Canadiens had swept on to gether to mutual triumph in hisNational Hockey League years.

Three women who depicted Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania as the boss of a commercialized vice ring recanted their testimony yesterday in affidavits filed with Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook as the basis of a motion fora new trial.

"S" pins, the highest award of the Smith College Athletic Association, were given to six seniors today at student assembly. A special posthumous senior award also was made, and two juniors received certificates.

Twenty more candidates for the Princeton baseball team reported to Coach Bill Clarke today as regular daily practice began in the university field cage. The new diamond aspirants, who joined the batterymen that have been working out for the past ten days, included twelve infielders and eight outfielders.

Continued rapid expansion of the credit of local banks was disclosed in the condition statement for the week ended on Wednesday of reporting member banks of the Fed eral Reserve in New York City,issued yesterday.

Real estate operators were the principals in several of the deals for properties in that borough reported yesterday. In two of the transfers apartment houses which were assets of title and mortgage companies in liquidation or rehabilitation passed from the hands of the State Superintendent of Insur ance and the State Mortgage Commission.
Hundreds of persons waited in line over a long period yesterday morning to inspect the HearnsBronx store at 150th Street and Third Avenue, which was recently acquired by Hearn DepartmentStores, Inc.

Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the United States Biological Survey, reduces the entire philosophy of the waterfowl program to a concise statement. "First," he says, "we must have marshes and waters on which waterfowl may breed, feed and rest. Second, we must have breeding stocks of birds to use thesemarshes."

Seven stars are entered in the 1,000-yard run, which is expected to be one of the features of the eighteenth annual indoor track and field meet of the New York Chapter, K. of C., that is to be held in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night.

Antonio Sangroniz, chief of the Diplomatic Cabinet at Insurgent general headquarters, has not received replies to the protest sent by the Franco government to the signatories of the Algeciras agreement regarding agitation among the Moors in the Spanish protec torate zone, allegedly directed fromFrench Morocco.
Jerome G. Farquhar, oil man and an official in several companies, died in his sleep at the Schenley Hotelearly today. He was 55.

The Mead Corporation of Chillicothe, Ohio, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for bonds and stocks, more than $4,500,000 of proceeds from which will be used for expansion, for plant and equipment and forworking capital.
Chairman William P. Connery Jr. of the House Labor Committee told the Rules Committee today that a radio monopoly existed and that his proposal for an inquiry should be takenup on the floor.
Henry Fonda, who recently completed "Slim" for Warners, was reloaned to the brothers today by Walter Wanger for a second picture, "That Certain Woman," a remake of "The Trespasser."

The Senate Audit Committee recommended today that $150,000 be given to an Interstate Commerce Subcommittee to continue its in quiry into railroad financing. This is one of the largest investigativeappropriations on record.

The second explosion in six months tore through McBeth mine tonight, killing at least two men. Rescue workers said they held little hope for seventeen trapped behind coal falls two and three-quarter milesfrom the drift mouth.
Lumber production increased less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index receded to 78.8 from 80.1. It was 77.9 for the week ended March 7, 1936.

Secretary Morgenthau said today in discussing the closing of the books on the conversion of the April maturity of $502,361,000 of Treasury notes into 2 1/2 per cent thirteen-sev enteen-year bonds, that telegraphic reports indicated that exchanges had exceeded 85 per cent of the to tal of the outstanding notes. Late mail subscriptions have not yet been tabulated and it is expected that about 90 per cent of the noteswill be converted.
Prince Alexander of Thurn and Taxis, Duke of Castel Duino, died here tonight. He was 56 years old. His second wife, the former Helen Holbrook-Walker of Detroit, was athis bedside.

Producers of limburger cheese decided today to take a forty-fiveday holiday to let consumers of that product nibble through the huge surplus on hand. About 100 delegates from forty factories in Green County approved a plan to produce no limburger from March15 to May 1.

MANHATTAN GIEBLER, FRED J. (Nov. 29, 1936). Gross assets, $4,561; net, $3,099. To Clifford L. Giebler and Florence G. Davis, children, equally. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $2,689. Herman B.Schell attorney 270 Broadway.

A resumption of the decline in bond values forced many among the high-grade issues to new low levels for the year and longer yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Almost all groups partici pated in the downward trend in the third most active session of the year. Total transactions reached $22,045,500, compared with $14,650,200 on Wednesday.

The Westchester interscholastic invitation high school basketball tourney entered the final round tonight as Scarborough Prep downed Harrison, 52-23, and Pelham defeated the Raymond Riordon Academv of Highland. 25-23.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey signed an order yesterday which vacated a previous order restraining United States Shipping Com missioner John J. Daly from enforcing the Federal law in regard to continuous discharge books forseamen.
Full Fire Department honors were accorded Fireman Michael J. Mulvey, killed in action, at funeral services conducted yesterday at St. John the Baptist Church, Willoughby and Lewis Avenues, Brooklyn.

Leaders of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's employes' representation plan seeking to establish a stronger body to combat the forces of John L. Lewis, argued most today about cutting loose from the company and creating a selfsupporting organization.

Dull is the word for "Arms for Venus," which was put on at the Golden last evening. If that salute sounds abusive, this column can only report that for the last .two hours it has been toying witheuphemisms.

Mrs. Park Mason Woolley entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Savoy Room of the Savoy Plaza. Among her guests were Mrs. Charles G. Kerley, Mrs. Owen Locke, Mrs. J. Addison Woolley, Mrs. Ralph Campbell, Mrs. Jared G. Baldwin, Mrs. Alfred Nathan Jr., Mrs. John C. Hays, Mrs. Charles A. Wimpfheimer, the Misses Nellie Hatfield, Edith Leggett and Lillian Allen.

Mrs. George E. Parkinson gave a tea yesterday on the Terrace Court of the Waldorf-Astoria for members of the committee arranging the tea dance to be given to morrow at the Madison by the Young Woman's Republican Clubof New York.

Marse Joe McCarthy sent his athletes through their first practice game of the 1937 training campaign at Huggins Field today and after nine innings declared himself highly satisfied with the age-old experiment. Incidentally, more than 2,000 tourists and natives enjoyed the spectacle as the regulars treated the Yannigans to an 8-to-0 shellacking with a bombardment of extrabase blows that held two home runs.

A wage increase for the 2,000 employes of Johnson Johnson, surgical supplies manufacturers of this city and Chicago, was announced today after a meeting of the board of directors. A 10 per cent increase for hourly workers and a 5 per cent increase for piece workers will become effective nextMonday.

We have been hearing whisperings that there is something in the atmosphere of Britain particularly flattering to color photography, a climatic affinity which may impel all Hollywood producers to film their technicolor efforts there. Itmay be rumor or it may be true.

Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Gordon, belived to be the longest-married couple on Long Island, observed their seventy-first wedding anniversary today at their home here. Mr. Gordon is 90 years old and his wife is one year his senior. Relatives andfriends visited them today.

9th St., 16 W., 22.2x93.11: Natalie Finn Hunsicker and Frederick W. Finn to Eugenie Lee Finn, 16 W. 9th St. ($22). Mott St., 228, 26.3x93.1; Hyman J. Reit to Metropolitan Savings Bank; considera tion $1,000, foreclosure. 89th St.. 330 W., 20x100.8 1/2; Morton Pep per to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp.;consideration $1,000. foreclosure.

During the week ended March 10 member bank reserve balances increased by $89,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves rose from increases of $41,000,000 in gold stock and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency and decreases of $31,000,000 in money incirculation,

Looking like a symphony in blue, Mrs. Wallis Simpson this morning received the press in the library of the Chateau de Cande to tell them --that she feels sorry over the Spanish situation. She avoided all questions bearing on her marriageand the Duke of Windsor.

The ratio of gold reserve to note circulation and deposit liabilities was 54.90 per cent, against 54.75 a week ago and 71.59 a year ago. The legal minimum is 35 per cent. The highest figure, 80.87 per cent, wasreported on Dec. 20, 1934.

An initial step in removing the Standard Gas and Electric Company from reorganization proceedings under Section 77B of the National Bankruptcy Act is expected soon with the submission of a recapitalization plan to the courts. Bernard W. Lynch, president of the company, said yesterday that Standard is making continued progress on the recapitalization plan, and "as soon as it completely developed, security holders will beadvised."
About 2,000,000 residents of Western Honan Province have been stricken, the China International Famine Relief Commission reported today, by a famine that has created "3,000 square miles ofsilence."

John A. Hunnewell, president of the Lowell Electric Light Corpora tion since 1928, died here today. He was 59 years old. A native of Scarboro, Me., and graduate of Bates College, Mr. Hunnewell had been connected with the company for more than thirty-five years. He was formerly president of the Lowell Gas Light Company.

Coming from behind-with a pair of third-period goals, the Montreal Maroons took a tighter grip on second place in the international section of the National Hockey League tonight by downing the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 2. The victory, third in a row for the Maroons, shattered the Leafs' four-game unbeaten streak and sent the Montreal club four points infront of their Toronto rivals.

A pair of claimants to the world featherweight championship will trade punches with each other tonight, when Henry Armstrong of Los Angeles tackles Mike Belloise, sharp-hitting battler from the Bronx. Belloise is recognized aschampion in New York.

Four men who were alleged to have defrauded contractors, concessionaires and others of a total of $54,424 in a fake bridge-building project pleaded not guilty before Magistrate Dreyer in the Felony Court yesterday on a grand larcenycharge.

Men on the staff of The Pitt Panther, monthly humorous magazine of the University of Pittsburgh, have gone on a sort of sit-down strike. They appear at Panther headquarters in the cathedral of learning, but by common consentare doint no work.

Miss Elizabeth Sullavan, 50 years old, of Glens Falls, N. Y., who had been registered as a guest at the Hotel Commodore since March 1, was found dead in her nineteenthfloor room last night. Her death was due to submersion in a bathtub.

Three coaches followed Oxford during the Dark Blues' morning workout today and at a mid-day conference it was decided that D. M. de R. Winser, last year's coach, should replace J. S. Lewes, president of the crew, at No. 2.
Governor Hurley refused today to reinstate former members of the Boston police force who went on strike in 1919. In a brief statement, after a conference with their representatives, he said:

Consents from holders of approximately 78 percent of the stock of the General Stockyards Corporation to the sale of substantially all of its portfolio to the United Stockyards Corporation have been received by its board of directors,the company reported yesterday.

The question of providing for early complete independence of the Philippine Commonwealth is expected to be discussed with President Manuel L. Quezon in the course of his official visit here, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today, indicating, however, that the administration has as yet had no official indica tion of what the Philippine President may desire in that regard.

Secretary Perkins chose a unique method of asking for a conference today when she made public a letter to James H. Rand Jr., president of the Remington Rand Company, with whom her department has been unable to get in communication for several weeks.
Miss Dorothy Paget's Golden Miller, the winner in 1934, today became the favorite for the Grand National Steeplechase to be run at AintreeMarch 19.
The Commissariat of Defense announced today the death in the Far East of Jan Latzis, one of the most noted and trusted corps commanders in the Soviet Union. He was40 years old.

In his testimony today before the Senate Judiciary Committee on President Roosevelt's proposed plan for reorganizing the Federal judiciary, Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, said, in part: When a situation exists in the Supreme Court which the President feels he cannot continue to ignore, it is to the Congress that he may properly bring the problem.

Professor Bernard Fay, history professor at the College de France, Paris, advertised as a specialist on America, declared before the Academy for the Rights of Nations here today that the United States is in danger of sinking into communism and is likewise facing an economic catastrophe of "inconceivable magnitude."
President Roosevelt's proposal to increase the membership of the Supreme Court has been disapproved by a vote of more than 6 to 1 in a referendum taken among members ofthe American Bar Association.

Launched with an appeal by President Albert Lebrun over the radio tonight, the first half of the French national defense and restoration loan will be opened for subscription tomorrow morning. Already its complete success seems assured.
Italy informed Belgium today that she would guarantee Belgium against aggression by any other nation without requiring the Brus sels government to give a similarguarantee to Rome.
The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today the registration of Parmer Co. of New York as brokers or dealers in over-thecounter transactions.

Contracts for engineering construction awarded this week showed a gain of 28 per cent over last week, reaching a total of $41, 088,000. The awards in the same period of last year, however, were 16 per cent higher, according toThe Engineering News-Record.
The theft of enormously valuable religious treasures from Todaiji Temple caused a sensation todayt hroughout the Japanese Empire.

David Abercrombie, 35 years old, son of the co-founder of Abercrombie Fitch, died in a hospital today from a ruptured intestine suf fered when he was kicked by a horse. He was injured Monday on his "dude ranch," forty miles southeast of Jackson, Wyo.; was brought to Idaho Falls by plane and then toPocatello in an ambulance.

Last week the ratio was 36.50 per cent; two weeks ago, 39.10, The highest ratio of the year to date was 42 per cent, on Jan. 21; the lowest was 31.70, on Jan. 7. The highest for 1936 was 43.40, on Oct. 22; the ratio of 23.10 on Dec.31 was the lowest.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. The reserve ratio for the New York bank also reacheda new low figure for the year.

The executive committee of the Merchants Association of New York voted yesterday to oppose Governor Lehman's proposal for a $60,000,000 State bond issue to finance capital construction and improvements during the next five years as threatening future taxpayers with "a heavycumulative burden."

A bid of $13,000 a share for stock of the San Francisco Bank, San Francisco, tops a survey by the journal, The American Banker, of bank-share quotations in this country. Apparently no stock was offered in the market for no"asked" price was reported.

President Roosevelt heard David Lasser present the demands of the Workers Alliance of America for increased relief appropriations and expenditures; discussed com modity prices and the labor situation with Chairman Eccles of the Federal Reserve Board; conferred with Secretary Ickes on PWA projects, and received the credentials of the new Cuban Am bassador, before departing forWarm Springs, Ga.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended March 11 were announced today: Drum, Col. A. B., Puget Sound, Wash., to Marine Barracks, Pearl Harbor, T. H., sailing from San Francisco about June 19. Miller, Lt. Col. L. H., Quantico, Va., to Parris Island, S. C. Schmidt, Lt. Col. H., San Francisco, Calif., to Fleet Marine Force, San Diego, Calif.,about May 25.

Cold storage holdings of fishery products in the United States on Feb. 15 were 54 per cent greater than a year ago and 62 per cent greater than the five-year average, the Department of Commerce reportedtoday.

A locomotive engineer rushing over the rails in darkness at sixty miles an hour sees the block signal turn red sixty seconds before he reaches the point of danger-ample time to stop a heavy passenger train. But the man behind the wheel of an automobile must act sometimes in one second, sometimes in five seconds, to avoid somethingblack that suddenly looms in the night.

Among the apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday was one for the seventeen-room triplex penthouse in 1,133 Fifth Avenue by Sir William Wiseman of Kuhn, Loeb Co. Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., were the brokers. Other apartment rentals were: Bernard B. Kolby. in 118 W. 48th St.; Gertrude Morrison, 164 W. 48th St.; Fred erick Kolmetz, in 61 W. 51st St.; Frances K. Carter, in 43 W. 52d St.; Horn Burke,brokers.

The marriage of Miss Judith Hamlin, daughter of Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin of 6 East Eighty-second Street and East Hampton, L. I., and the late Mr. Hamlin, to Charles Percy Frederick North, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick North of Rougham Hall, Norfolk, England, took place yesterday afternoon in the CentralPresbyterian Church.
Miss Rhoda Rosenson daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Rosenson of 142 West Eighty-seventh Street, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert A. Newburger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Newburger of thiscity.

Earl Averill, top-ranking hitter of the Indians, rejected today a 1937 salary offer of $15,000 and remained a holdout, he said, to insist on not less than $16,000. The outfielder, whose .378 batting average gave him second place in the American League last year, said C. C. Slapnicka, business man ager, made the $15,000 offer at atwo-hour conference.

The "indelible national gratitude" of Cuba for the help of the United States, "in hours of need hardly less dangerous than those in which this nation bravely contributed with the blood of its sons to crown the labor independence," was expressed today by Dr. Pedro Martinez Fraga, the new Cuban Ambassador, in presenting his credentials to PresidentRoosevelt.

Mrs. Harry Bartlett, known on the vaudeville stage for many years as Gracie May, died yesterday in the South Side Hospital, Bay Shore, L. I., at the age of 73. Mrs. Bart lett, whose husband died in 1933, was a member of the team of Bartlett and May.

Chinese business men here are assisting in the promotion of a corporation, registered in Nanking and capitalized at $10,000,000 (silver), for organiz ing rice production throughoutSouth and Central China.

The efforts of some of the banks with large excess reserves to obtain a higher rate on "sales" of these funds to their less well supplied neighbors seemed yesterday to be meeting with some slight success. It was reported that deals in Federal funds had been made at 1/4 per cent, compared with the prevailing rateof 1/8 per cent.

80th St., 136 E.; 4-story house, 18.4x102.2; Greenwich Savings Bank against William C. Etzrodt; due, $55,218; to plaintiff for $50,000. By JAMES R. MURPHY 145th St., 304 W.; 5-story tenement and store. 25.6x99.11: Franklin Savings Bank against 304 W. 145th St. Corp.; due, $17, 819; taxes, , $425; to plaintiff for $15,000.

Offering will be made today by means of a prospectus of 27,900 shares of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of the Sunray Oil Corporation by a group composed of Russell Maguire Co., Inc.; Ericson, Nichols Robbins, Inc., and Edgerton, Riley Wal ter. The stock will be priced at $50a share.

Miss Josephine Roche, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, praised John L. Lewis and Sidney Hillman as exponents of a "new type of labor statesmanship" in a talk tonight before 150 members and guests of the Newark Junior Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Lewis is the head of the Committee for Industrial Organiza tion and Mr. Hillman is the head of the Amalgamated ClothingWorkers of America.

The Physical Culture Shoe Company will open a store at 57-18 Myrtle Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, tomorrow, and three others next week, the latter at 605 Central Ave nue, East Orange, N. J.; 4,508 Thirteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, and 2,151 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

A $500 grant is available for persons completing a study in race relations during 1937-1938, the John Anisfield Award Committee announces. Projects may be either of an academic research nature or the outgrowth of practical experience in the field of race relations.

The joint legislative committee investigating the milk problem received an additional week, to March 22, today to make its report to the Legislature. The measure was voted in the two houses over the protests of Republicans against what they termed unnecessary delay.

Nurses in city hospitals will go on an eight-hour day schedule on July 1 under the terms of the bill, introduced by Alderman James A. Burke of Queens, which Mayor La Guardia signed at City Hall yesterday. A large group of nurses in uniform attended the statutory hearing on the bill and thanked theMayor for signing it.

More than 300 members and guests of the Committee of One Hundred made the trip to Cocolobo Cay Clubhouse for today's seventh annual outing, which was under the direction of Commodore Jerome A.Turrell.
Profit-taking was general in most of the commodity futures yesterday following the recent well-sustained upward movements. Prices closed at, or near, the lows for the dayin active trading.

Frank Leroy Erskine, a former executive of the W. L. Douglas Shoe Company, died at his home here today. He was 63 years old. Mr. Erskine was formerly chairman of the Brockton Republican committee, a member of the Common Council, the City PlanningBoard and the school committee.
The Coast Guard said early today it had been requested to search for a small cabin launch on which Sir Charles Ross, British inventor, and three friends left Pass-a-Grille last Saturday forKey West.

Land has been bought for a Catholic chapel for Yale undergraduates and construction work will begin in June. This announcement was made today by the Rev. T. Law rason Riggs, chaplain of the YaleCatholic Club.

Study of the problem of secondary distribution of listed securities is being undertaken by a special committee of the New York Stock Ex change, which is to report its findings to the governing committee. The body's task is to coordinate and develop the policies and rules of the various standing commit tees in so far as they relate to sec ondary distribution and to trading in listed securities off the floor ofthe Exchange.
High government authorities, charging 30,000 Italian soldiers were driving toward Madrid with the Insurgent army in Guadalajara, accused Italy tonight of waging an "undeclaredwar" on Spain.

Louis Goldwater, a guard attached to the Bronx County Sheriff's office and formerly head keeper at the Bronx County Jail, died on Tuesday at the Morrisania Hospital, the Bronx, after a short illness. His age was 61. He lived at 1,317 WestFarms Road, the Bronx.

Arriving here from the Eucharistic Congress at Manila, where he represented 6,000,000 Catholics of Yugoslavia, Archbishop Nicholas M. Dobrecic, primate of Serbia, said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Biltmore, he was glad the depression in this country was over and that "American people are asgenerous as ever."
Mrs. J. Joseph McHugh of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Mc Hugh, to Dr. Vincent P. McNally, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. McNally of Ardmore.

Jose Fogenero, 119 1/2, of Puerto Rico, outpointed Georgie Holmes, 121 1/4, of Lynn, Mass., in the feature eight-round bout before 2,000 spectators at the Star Casino last night. Fogenero had little trouble in keeping Holmes at bay while scoring repeatedly with a fast attack.

Professor Marcus Nadler of New York University, assistant director of the Institute of International Finance, said yesterday in an address at the annual Spring Savings Conference of the American Bank ers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria that he did not believe there were good grounds for the generally held fears of a sharp break in highgrade bonds.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the transfer of the membership of the late Charles Hayden to Herbert G. Bell of Hayden, Stone Co. Balloting on the proposed transfer of the membership of the late Michael F. Brady to Edward Goldenis scheduled for March 25.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired an important life-size Renaissance marble figure by the Venetian sculptor, Tullio Lombardo (about 1455-1532). So difficult is it to obtain large examples of Renaissance sculpture today that American museums rarely have opportunity to acquire such a work as the figure of Adam, to be placed on view at the Metropolitan this morning.

Purchase of a plot for improvement with an apartment house featured real property activity on Washington Heights yesterday. As a site for immediate improvement with a six-story elevator building, the plot 87 by 86 feet at the southwest corner of West 187th Street and Overlook Terrace was sold by Gertrude S. Levy to the Rolein Realty Corporation, builders. Nehring Brothers,

MANHATTAN CULLEN, JOSEPH P. (Dec. 15). Estate, less than $2,000. To Viola Cullen, widow, executrix, 10 Monroe St., residue. CUSHMAN, WILLIAM RITTER (May 2). Estate, about $400. To Dorothy W. Cush man, widow, executrix, 325 W. 22d St.,residue.

Colonel Harris H. Walker, a sales representative in the national advertising department of THE NEW YORK TIMES, veteran of two wars, and well known in advertising circles, died of a heart attack yester day at his home, 35-28 210th Street,Bayside, L. I. He was 61 years old.
Entry blanks for the twenty-ninth annual interscholastic track and field meet of New York University have been sent to 400 public and private schools in New York, NewJersey, Pennsylvania,

An expansion of the facilities of the Better Business Bureau and the Advertising Federation of America and the creation of a $1,000,000 fund to wipe out unfair advertising practices were suggested yesterday by H. J. Kenner, president of the Better Business Bureau of New York, in an address before the Chicago Federated Advertising Club.

Chang Soo Lee was convicted of second degree assault on two counts at 11:42 o'clock this morning, nineteen and one-half hours after the jury had received the case. The jury had passed the night atthe Hotel Roger Smith here.

Bos ton's Bruins ruined Chicago's "All American" hockey party tonight, slapping a 6-2 defeat on the Black Hawks, who used five American-born rookies in the final Chicago game of the National Hockey League season. The game was played as Frank Caller, league president, considered a protest from Jack Adams of Detroit and Lester Patrick of the Rangers over use of the new players.

After deliberating only fifty-three minutes, a Kings County blue-ribbon jury yesterday found Martin Schlossman and Harry Weiss guilty of kidnapping Paul H. Wendel in a plot to compel him to "confess" the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

Estimating that more than 4,000,000 persons between the ages of 16 and 25 were unemployed, Dr. Homer P. Rainey, president of Bucknell University and director of the American Youth Commission, advocated here today the establishment of a nation-wide employment service foryouth.

The vast reserves to be set up under the Federal Social Security Act should be used to finance lowrent housing and wipe out slums, Stanley M. Isaacs, president of the United Neighborhood Houses, suggested yesterday at a meeting of the housing section of the Welfare Council, held in the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twentysecond Street.
Applications to list the following securities have been received by the Stock Exchange's committee on stock list and may be acted uponat its next meeting:

A letter from President Roosevelt extending his "hearty felicitations" to the Girl Scouts on their twenty fifth anniversary, to be celebrated today, was made public yesterday. In his letter, addressed to Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, chairman of the organization's board of directors, the Presidentsaid:

Dick Shikat, 230, of Germany, for mer world's wrestling champion, threw Jim McMillen, 220, of Chicago in the feature bout of the weekly show before 4,000 persons last night at the New York Hippodroce.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Evitts Coulbourne of Germantown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kitty Lou Coulbourne, to Robert Henry Schneider, son of Mrs. Jacob Matthew Schneider of LosAngeles.

Bank clearings of the principal cities throughout the nation totaled $5,950,467,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, against $6,015,502, 000 in the same period a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represented a loss of 1.1 per cent and was attributed principally to the only decline (New York)which was reported.

Both sides rested today in the legal battle to determine whether the Fundamentalist majority in the Collingswood (N. J.) Presbyterian Church or the West Jersey Presbytery of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America is entitled to thechurch property.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Steer hinds and ribs and most of the fresh pork cuts were in fair demand. Veal and lamb moved only fair. Steer beef sold strong to higher and some lamb cuts werehigher. Other classes were unchanged.

Richard Goldsticker defeated Sey mour Prince, 150 to 132, in fiftyseven innings and Bruno Klerings halted Edward S. Knapp Sr., 150 to 114, in twenty-four frames in the metropolitan Class C 18.2 balkline championship at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night.

A slap at Olympic officials with too great a "yen for world tours" and a plea for less "absurd" treatment of athletes was delivered today by Lorrin Andrews, new chairman ofthe A. A. U. rules committee.

The Presidents Club of Manhattan College is holding a smoker in the college gymnasium tonight in honor of the track and field squad, which will defend its team title at the I. C. A. A. A. A. indoor cham pionships at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

Frederick H. Stinchfield, president of the American Bar Association, in an address tonight, asserted President Roosevelt "wants a legislative form of government and not a constitutional type of control."

Announcement has been made by Mrs. C. E. Hogg of Point Pleasant, W. Va., of the marriage of her daughter, Miss Nancy Hogg, to Donald Rowley Coe, son of Mrs. Margaret Coe of this place. Themarriage took place on Nov. 7,1936.

The general level of wholesale prices was unchanged in the week ended on March 6, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, stayed at 86.1. Ayear previously it was 79.7.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, EN ROUTE TO WARM SPRINGS, March 11.-Leaving to his lieutenants the battle for his proposals for reorganization of the judiciary, President Roosevelt was headed south tonight for a vacation of ten days or two weeks at the sanitarium for sufferers from infantileparalysis which he founded.

The estate of the late T. A. Dorgan ("Tad") on the northeast corner of Grace Avenue and Seventh Street, Great Neck, has been sold for development to Samuel Leider, Jamaica builder. The parcel has a frontage of 141 feet on Grace Avenue and 285 feet on Barstow Road. It consists of 40,185square feet.

Record performances are anticipated in the sixteenth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. indoor track and field championships to be held in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, when representatives of twenty-five colleges willmake bids for honors.

Freight cars loaded with 180,000 tons of scrap iron stood in Atlantic ports yesterday awaiting cargo space in vessels bound for Europe and the Far East, clogging railroad yards to a point where Boston traffic executives raised "holding" charges and most Eastern carriers placed an embargo on further ship ments of scrap Iron for export untilthe congestion had been eased.
This week's New Republic has a special sup plement dealing with the rOLe of the newspapersin the last Presidential

Jorge Gonzalez, prominent leader of the Chilean -Nazi movement, who was chosen a Deputy in the recent elections, declared today that the movement would continue to grow unchecked, exercising its new polit ical rights in Congress until the present form of government is radically changed more in accordance with modern ideals of social justice.

Mrs. Helen Fuller Potter, widow of the Rev. Dr. Eliphalet Nott Potter, died yesterday at her home, 28 East Seventieth Street, at the age of 88. Mrs. Potter's husband was once president of Hobart College and Union College and was a broth er of the Right Rev. Henry CodmanPotter, eminent Episcopal Bishop.

Judge Norfleet R. Sledge of Senatobia, Miss., died tonight from apoplexy in his hotel room. Judge Sledge was a chancellor at Como, Miss., for twelve years and resigned to aid in the last campaign of Senator Pat Harrison of Mississippi.

Orders taken in February by the Baldwin Locomotive Works and subsidiary companies, including the Midvale Company, amounted to $3,331,742, compared with $3,600,301 for February, 1936, it was announced today.
W. Graham Browne, actor, producer and husband of Marie Tempest, the actress, died today of double pneumonia at his home in Hampstead at the ageof 67.

Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice were hosts to seventy tonight for dinner and dancing at Palmerial in celebration of the birthday of Mrs. Rice's son, George D. Widener, who, with Mrs. WidenerDixon, is visiting them.

Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Foster of Waterbury have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Myrtle Eva Foster, to Homer Stone Kelsey, son of the Rev. and Mrs. David Stone Kelsey of Middletown, Conn.

Supreme Court justices were asked in arguments today to determine whether George W. Norris, a grocer of North Platte, Neb., cleared himself of perjury when he recanted certain testimony after his name was brought forward in 1930 as a candidate against Senator George W. Norris. The court took thecase under advisement.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed agent of Powdrell Alexander, Inc., to accept subscriptions to $5 par common stock. The subscription price is $10 a share and the privilege of subscribing terminates at 3 P. M. March 25. J. A. Sisto of J. A. Sisto Co. has been elected a director of theDavega Stores Corporation.

New York, we fear, is frequently a city of passers-by on the other side. When trouble is in the wind the honest citizen, not necessarily a Caspar Milque toast either, is often a bit too quick to dismiss the disturbance as a " movie stunt" or to find some other readyexcuse for non-interference.
The Social Security Board paid today the first eight of 314,000 claims it expects this year for Federal oldage benefits. Seven came from wage-earners who reached the retirement age of 65 this year
Paul N. Coulcher, the dominant figure in Local 16 of the Waiters Union, took the witness stand late yesterday in the restaurant racket trial to defend himself againstcharges of extortion.

Fines exceeding 50,000,000 lire were imposed today on a group of twenty-eight bankers and brokers, including fourteen foreigners, all of whom were rounded up in Milan yesterday by financial police. The men were charged with speculating in foreign exchange, which isa very serious offense in Italy.

The sudden shipment to Russia of 3,000, 000 pounds of adapted alfalfa seed, said to be badly needed in this country for successful operation of the soil conservation program, led some AAA officials today to look with favor on legislation designed to prevent export of "essentialproducts."

Meeting for the first time under its new constitution, the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations showed signs yesterday of disunity as epithets such as "chiseler," "Queen of Sheba" and "temperamental prima donna" were hurledback and forth.
Formation of the Greater New York Hotel Sales Managers Asso ciation, headed by Hugh J. Connor, business manager of the Hotel Roosevelt, was announced hereyesterday.

President Lazaro Cardenas arrived safely today at Oaxaca, capital of the Southern State of that name, after a special train on which he was supposed to be traveling was wrecked late last night between this city and the near-by town ofPuebla.

Major C. E. (Stub) Davis, veteran of many polo campaigns both indoors and out, has been named as the first recipient of the Judge James D. Moore Trophy for being the outstanding player of the Metropolitan Indoor League during thepresent season.
Twelve-year-old Peter Alfred Constantine Maria Salm lost in the Court of Appeals today his effort to escape payment of a $1,727,022 tax on the estate of his grandfather, ColonelHenry H. Rogers.

Miss Emmy Lou Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Richard Parker of Greenwich, has com pleted arrangements for her marriage to Norman Shannon Illges, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Illges of Columbus, Ga. The ceremony will take place in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, NewYork, on April 8.

The Giants made another heroic effort today to bring down the pick of Havana's professional baseball talent when they battled a Cuban all-star team for twelve innings. But the best they could get out of the long struggle, which was played under a gray sky and a steady spatter ofrain, was a 1-all tie.

Thirty elementary school principals, recently ousted as evening school teachers, filed an application yesterday, which will be heard by Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo today, for an order directing the E. Board of Education to reinstatethem.
Captain Walter Glndwr Owen, former army officer and stock broker, died on Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He would havebeen 71 years old next Monday.

Being a successful mediator in a labor dispute was just part of a day's work today for Raymond Zimmerman, reporter for The Daily Home News here. Mr. Zimmerman not only covered the story for his paper but brought about a settlement of the strike while on his assignment.

The list of the French liner Ile de France, sailing tonight for Havre, includes Abbe Ernest Dimmet, Mr. and Mrs. Hubert R. Knickerbocker, Lucien Rollin and Mme. Rollin, Mme. Erica Morini, Baron and Baroness Georges Pacquement. Marcel Dutey-Harispe, Miss Cornelia Chapin, Mrs. Gordon Taylor, Mrs. Hobart Rawson, the Most Rev. Nicholas Dobrecic, the Rev. J. P. O'Mahoney, the Rev. Daniel A. O'Connor and the Rev. J. F. Moisant, Augusto Chotin and Clifford Fischer.

The seventh in the series of Mozart-Haydn concerts will be presented tonight at the WPA Theatre of Music. An international folksong recital will be given by Marie Radamsky at the recently organized ConcertLeague.
Babe Ruth viewed the coming major league baseball races from a bunker along the St. Albans golf course yesterday and predicted the Yankees and Cardinals would winby at least a mashie shot.
Plans for a detailed study of all important phases of the raw material question except the political side were made today by the League of Nations committee dealing with thesubject.

Recommendations for a survey and governmental encouragement of consumer cooperatives in the United States were made to President Roosevelt by the committee he sent abroad last Summer to study cooperatives in Europe, it became known today when its report wasmade public.

Clarence Addison Dykstra, city manager of Cincinnati, has been chosen by the executive committee of the University of Wisconsin Board of Regents to succeed Dr. Glenn Frank as president of theuniversity, it became known today.

King Peter, the 12-year-old sovereign of Yuogslavia, is ill with what is said to be a bad case of influenza. His mother, Queen Marie, who had been in England since January after placing her second son, Prince Tomislav, 9 years old, in a school there, has left London to bewith Peter.
Alexander Granowsky, founder of the Moscow Yiddish State Theatre, died here today at the age of 47 years.

A statement tending to alleviate Chinese fears of Japan was made by Kenji Kodama, former president of the Yokohama Specie Bank, when he left for Shanghai today with a Japanese business group to attend the first annual meeting of the Japan-China Trade Society, which was promoted to finance joint industrial enterprises.

The National Academy of Design has awarded fifteen cash prizes totaling $4,375 and three medals for works of art in its 112th annual exhibition, which will be opened to the public tomorrow at 215 WestFifty-seventh Street.

Declaring that Britain was determined to protect her possessions in every part of the world and keep her trade routes open on all the seven seas, Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, told the House of Commons today that his government does not care how many warships the United States might build.

Two hundred and twenty-two young women from Stephens College, Columbia, Mo.. arrived in the city yesterday on the college's biannual visit to New York City and the East. They were joined here by forty other students who arrived onWednesday.

John A. Spinney, retired sporting goods merchant, who was one of the orga??rs of the old Federal and United States Baseball Leagues, died today after a brief illness. He was 83 years old. Mr. Spinney also was one of the founders of the K. I. O. league. He served as business manager of the Covington and Kansas City clubs of the FederalLeague.

Miss Frances E. White, a member of one of Brooklyn's oldest and most distinguished families, died yesterday at the Brooklyn Hospital after an illness of several months. Miss White lived until her death in the old family mansion at 2 Pierre pont Place, Brooklyn, in which she had made her home since its construction in 1857. Her age was89.
A perfect day for golf brought out the largest galleries of the season today to watch the semi-final matches of the Belleview Biltmore women'schampionship.

The delivery to the German Government of an American oral complaint against attacks on the United States appearing in the German press has been delayed, as Ambassador William E. Dodd was unable to obtain an interview with Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foregn Minister, today.

Testimony given before the La Follette Senate subcommittee investigating alleged subversive activities in labor disputes today disclosed that Governor Hoffman of New Jersey had favorably recommended the chief of the Sherwood DetectiveAgency of New York to the R. C.

Two thousand school journalists, ranging in age from 8 to 20 and representing schools throughout the nation, took over Morningside Heights yesterday for three days to swap newspaper experiences, smooth over technical difficulties and take pointers from leading newspaper men at the thirteenth annual convention of theColumbiaScholastic Press Association.

Leslie Reade's new play, "His Excellency," which comments satirically upon the methods of international diplomacy, had its first per formance tonight at the Playhouse. Mr. Reade's comedy of diplomatic manners unravels to the credit of the Soviet Commissariat for ForeignAffairs.

Jacob A. Livingston, former Brooklyn Republican leader, who announced on Wednesday night his opposition to a Republican renomination for Mayor La Guardia, said yesterday that there were several prominent Republicans under consideration for the party Mayoralty designation. He said a city-wide movement already had been started to name "a real 100 per cent Republican."

Hoe Av., 1,310-1,316, 5-story brick tene ment. 100x100: New York State Teachers Retirement System against Pomeroy Hold ing Corp.; due, $151,611; to plaintiff for $1,000. By JAMES R. MURPHY Wheeler Av., 1,260, 30x100; Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. against Minnie Cohen; due, $10,500, taxes, , $900; to plaintifffor $5,000.

While local merchants here were inclined yesterday to sympathize with the stand of the New York Board of Trade that the 2 per cent city sales tax should be removed, several leading executives frankly said they did not see any alternative at present that would aid cityfinances and provide relief funds.
French cruisers were dispatched today to guard the ship lanes in the Mediterranean between Marseilles and North Africa following the recent bombing of the French ship Djebel Anatar in thatarea.
The thirty-seventh annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress moved through its second day yesterday and now has only amere. fifty-four days left.
Another Pacific air line, the trade route of nearly 7,000 miles from San Francisco to New Zealand, will be started this week in a survey flight, Pan American Airways disclosed yesterday.
The Princeton chapter of the "Roosevelt-for-King" Club col lapsed tonight, turned the movement over "to the people of the United States" and gave a brevetto Yale for originating the idea.

Mr. and Mrs. Franklyn L. Hutton, who have been at Youngs Island, S. C., are returning today to the Waldorf-Astoria. Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff and the latter's daughter, Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems,will leave on Monday for Florida.
J. S. Cullinan, Houston, Texas, capitalist and oil enterprise founder, died today of pneumonia. Hewas 76 years old.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union and its New York affiliates, representing 150,000 members, subscribed for $100,000 in World's Fair debenture bonds after a meeting at 3 West Sixteenth Street attended by Mr. Whalen and Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor. This is the largest sum taken so far by a labor group. Subscriptionsnow total $19,162,000.

For the first time since last September, the State will enter the long-term bond market on March 24, when Morris S. Tr maine, State Controller, will receive sealed bids at noon at his office here for an issue of $15,000, 000 of New York State bonds, the proceeds to be applied to the elimination of grade crossings.

New light on the recent plenary session of the Communist party leaders was thrown by a speech of Andre A. Zhdanoff, who-has been the Leningrad party secretary since Sergei Kiroff was assassinated in December, 1934. The speech was publishedin today's newspapers.

An astonishing new field gun, combining the best fighting qualities of the heavy plunging-fire howitzer and the lighter shrapnel-flinging eighteen pounder, is to replace both these notable weapons in the BritishArmy.

Conditions in Germany are better today than they were before Hitler came into office, and no danger of an economic or political collapse exists, Vaso Trivanovitch, chief of the department of international relations of the National IndustrialConference Board, said yesterday.

Over the objections of attorneys for Standard Brands, Inc., respondents in an action by the Federal Trade Commission charging violation of the Robinson-Patman Act Edward J. Dent, general manager for the bakery division of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, yesterday testified that his company made an average profit of 3-10 cent a pound on bread retailed by thecompany.
Composing room forces struck tonight in two Miami newspaper plants, and one group returned to work after a temporary wage scale increase had been granted pendingfinal settlement.

Edward L. Stanley of Lansdowne, Pa., and Frank B. Conklin of Great Neck, L. I., were today chosen as permanent president and secretary of the senior class at Williams College. Stanley, the present president of the senior class, has been a member of the football, basketball and baseballteams for three years.

The fifth shipment of gold from the United States Assay Office, Old Slip and South Street, to the Federal vaults at Fort Knox, Ky., was taken to a special train at Pennsylvania Station last night in sixty-four truckloads, all heavily guarded.
John M. Zook, treasurer and secretary of the former firm of Hoopes Townsend, nut and bolt manufacturers, died at his home here lastnight at the age of 94 years.

With buyers endeavoring to cover the bulk of their Fall needs in men's wear suitings and topcoatings, trading in wool goods moved sharply upward this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Boston awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,000,000 of short-term notes to a banking group composed of the First Boston Corporation, Brown, Harriman Co., Inc., and Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., on a 1.22 per cent interest basis,plus a premium of $88.

Vast armies of hungry crows, described as the largest in the country, raided Oklahoma's freshly planted fields today as embattled farmers pleaded for dynamite bombs to repel the attack. Game wardens, who have blasted as many as 50,000 crows from theirroosts at a single crack,

The boisterous reception which even the official German press gives Max Schmeling's offer to James J. Braddock for a world heavyweight championship fight in Germany leaves not the slightest doubt that the German champion has the National Socialist regime behind him. Just whence the money really is coming that Promoter Walter Roth enburg is ready to put up remainsa mystery.

Net profit of the St. Joseph Lead Company for the first quarter of 1937 will exceed that for the final quarter of 1936, C. H. Crane, president, said at the annual meetingof stockholders here yesterday.

Cincinnati Street Railway - For 1936: Net income, after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal income taxes, , $367,905, equal to 77 cents a share on the capital stock. This compares to a net of $212,528, or 45 cents ashare in 1935.

The second in a series of three dances being given by students of the Scudder School will be held tonight at the Ritz-Carlton. Proceeds will be devoted to the school's community chest fund, for which teas and bridge parties are also held during the year.

Students of empire affairs incline to the belief that the Imperial Conference called to meet in London May 14 will regard foreign affairs and defense as by far the most important of the three heads of the agenda that Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin disclosed in the House of Commonstoday.

Mrs. Dexter Fales of 178 East Seventieth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ellen Dexter Fales, to David Arms Lomasney of this city, son of Mrs. William Herbert Heywood of Toledo, Ohio, and the late LeonardLomasney.

Opposition to President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposals is expressed in a letter sent to mem bers of the New York State Legis lature by Richmond Pearson Hobson, president of the Constitutional Democracy Association, 590 Madison Avenue. The letter asked that the legislators help defeat the measure through collective action by the Legislature and by letters ofprotest to members of Congress.
New Jersey and New York golfers will figure in the finals of three divisions tomorrow in the seventeenth annual seniors' golf championship as a result of victoriesday.

A. M. Castle Co. new common stock, $10 par value, has been admitted to unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange. Two new shares are being issued for each old share, in accordance witha notice to shareholders on Feb. 28.
Premier Mussolini, aboard the heavy cruiser Pola, witnessed a series of exercises by the First and Second Naval Squadrons off the coast of Libyatoday, it was announced tonight.

The Guffey-Vinson Coal Bill, to regulate the bituminous industry through price-fixing, was passed by the House today without a record vote. Last-minute Republican attempts failed to force a roll-call upon the question of placing under civil service all employes of the Federal Coal Commission which would beset up.

Reflecting widespread price advances. The Annalist, weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose 3.7 points to 143.1 on Tuesday from 139.4 (revised) the Tuesday previous. The index is now the highest since Nov. 4, 1929. Theadvance was led by the metals.
The net profit of the National Dairy Products Corporation in 1936 was $13,282,028, after deducting interest, taxes and all charges, it reported yesterday.
Retail prices in February advanced for the eighth consecutive month, gaining 0.7 per cent over January, according to the Fair child retail price index issued yesterday.
The ranks of baseball's $50,000-a-year hold-outs remained unbroken today when Dizzy Dean, like Lou Gehrig, refused to cometo terms with his boss.

Miss Nora Colleen Cooper, daughter of Mrs. Harry Noel Leist of Chicago, was married here yesterday morning in the Church of the Ascension to Nicholas Barry Hekma, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Hekma of Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Frederick W. Cooper. Only the two families and a few friendswere present at the ceremony.

Liquor retailers adhering to the Feld- Crawford act regulations against sales below producers' suggested retail price levels said yes terday that distillers had promised a drop of $5 a case on bonded whiskies in the next few weeks. The reduction, they pledged, will be passed on directly to consumers and will mean a cut of 20 cents or morea pint.

The bull market in wheat on the Board of Trade came to a rather abrupt end today, a fractional advance at the opening being followed by commission-house selling and the close was at net losses of 5/8 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel, with the new crop months showing the most weakness, re versing their action of the previousday.
Willard K. Rice made his exit from the national amateur squash tennis championship at the New York A. C. last night, marking the first casualty in the ranks of theseeded group.

Postmaster General Farley was made "playing manager of the Supreme Court nine" tonight when, the Legislative Correspondents' Association staged its annual show lampooning the politically prominent in the State and nation. President Roosevelt was depicted as a "third termer" who packed the court witha "secret six."

Speaking at a dinner at the Harlem Y. M. C. A., 180 West 135th Street, Miss Pearl Buck told a group of 180 persons assembled to launch a drive by the New York Urban League for 10,000 new mem bers, that Negroes in this country had the advantage of "knowingwhat they want."

Robert H. Henshaw, retired custom house broker, died last night at his home here. He was born in New York 76 years ago. Prior to retirement in 1930 he was a member of the brokerage firm of George Henshaw Sons, 1 Broadway, New York, for forty years.
John L. Lewis's union, the United MineWorkers of America,

Charles V. Bob, mining engineer and promoter, is accused of breaking an agreement to share the stock of three corporations organized to develop and exploit an oil-finding machine in a suit for an accounting filed in Supreme Court yester day by Louis Silverman. The alleged agreement was made in 1927 beforeBob's financial bubble burst.
King George and Queen Elizabeth received the heads of diplomatic missions and their wives at Buckingham Palace this afternoon andentertained them at tea.

Gardiner's Island, the first English settlement in the territory that became New York State and the burial place of some of Captain Kidd's pirate treasure, will be sold at public auction and may pass out of the hands of the family that hasheld it since 1639.

The Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act became law in New York State in May of 1935. It contained two chief provisions. Section 1 declared a contract to be legal which provided that a buyer of a commodity bearing the label, trade-mark, brand or name of the pro ducer would not resell that commodity except at the price stipulated by theseller.

The Mellon Securities Corporation announced yesterday the election of Hugh D. MacBain as vice president in charge of the sales and trading department. Mr. MacBain was manager of the institutionaldivision of Shields Co.

With approving nods from nine matronly women who failed to get husbands as advertised, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson imposed a two-year prison sentence yesterday on William Steffens, 59-year old "lonely hearts specialist" whodid not make good.

A strike of news stand clerks in stations of the city-operated Independent Subway System, called at 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning, spread to nearly all of the system's stations yesterday afternoon after starting in the Forty-second Streetstation.

WHILE waiting for the Detroit Red Wings to pop out on the ice last night, M'sieu Lestairre Patrick was still talking about the Ranger-American skating fiesta of Tuesday evening. The players on both sides admitted that it was the craziest encounter in which they had participated since their amateur days on open ponds.

Spiros C. Pappas, cafeteria owner who testified in the restaurant racket trial, lost a suit yesterday for an injunction restraining Local 302 of the Cafeteria Employes Union from picketing his place at 121 East Twenty-third Street. Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman said that Pappas had failed to comply with the provisions of the AntiInjunction Law.

Dr. Tyler Dennett, president of Williams College, told alumni at the annual banquet here that the undergraduate body was not truly representative of the American people nor of the youth of America because of the influx of "nice boys" from thehigher class of preparatory schools.

Mrs. Elizabeth Singer Lancaster, prominent socially in New York, today filed a divorce suit against Herbert D. Lancaster of New York. They were married in New York City on Nov. 11, 1926, and have two children, John Singer, 9 years old, and Mary Jane, 6 years old. Mrs.Lancaster charges cruelty.

The Councillor of Culture of the Catalan Generalidad, Antoni M. Sbert, has advised the Catalan Committee of New York that an important lot of books has been dispatched from Barcelona forthe New York Public Library.

Acting without authorization from their organization, the Building Service Employes Union, elevator operators in some fifteen buildings in the garment and fur district staged a brief strike demonstration at the noon hour yesterday, causing much confusion and compelling hundreds to use the stairways orkeen out of the buildings.

Revenues of Greyhound Corporation omnibuses in the East declined 16.5 per cent following the reduction of fares by the railroads on June 1, according to the pamphlet report of the corporation for last year which was made public yesterday.

C. P. McDonald, advertising executive, died yesterday at Miami Beach, Fla., according to an announcement here last night by his concern, Ruthrauff Ryan of 405 Lexington Avenue. Mr. McDonald had been with the company threeyears.

The Democratic National Commit tee reported today that it took in $174,005 in the first two months of the year and spent $349,025. The Republican National Commit tee cut down its deficit by around $57,000, receiving $100,415 and disbursing $42,979.

Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, declared here tonight that only international cooperation can prevent another world war, and warned that it probably would come out of circumstances entirely different from those that caused the conflictof 1914.

At 10 o'clock this morning Van Lingle Mungo ended his holdout by agreeing to terms in a conference with John Gorman, Dodgers' business manager, and at 1:30 was on the mound as the first pitcher in the second of a pair of nine-inning practice games, allowing six hitsand one run in two innings.

Dr. Julius Miltz, 45-year-old East Side physician, was found guilty in Special Sessions late yesterday aft ernoon of conspiracy and petit lar ceny in a fake accident indemnity claim. Justices Perlman and Flood voted for his conviction, but Jus tice Walling dissented. Dr. Miltzrefused to testify.

The action yesterday by the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange ih giving general ap proval of rules to control "daylight trading" by members on that Exchange is interpreted here as virtually closing the first move in the broad program of the Securities and Exchange Commission con tained in its report to Congress on the advisability and feasibility of the segretation of the functions ofdealer and broker.

The concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, must rank, because of the material,of the program and the quality of the performances, among the most brilliant exhibitions that this distinguished instrumental body has given in this city.
Arthur F. Kaufhold, vice president and cashier of the Pennsylvania Exchange Bank of New York, died today at his home here inhis forty-seventh year.

Details of a share transfer affecting the estate of the late George S. Pomeroy were contained in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Allied Stores Corporation, made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
Through bus service on Fifty seventh Street, from river to river, will be started by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company on Monday, it was announced yesterday.

Officials of the Department of Agriculture said today that burley-to bacco growers were busy planting a near-record acreage, with no prospect of State compacts or new Federal legislation to control production this year.

The army's favorite dogma that Japan exists in a state of emergency, fac ing a national crisis, was con troverted by Foreign Minister Naotake Sato yesterday in another ex position of the principles on which he believes Japan's foreign policyshould be conducted.

Manhattan Alterations 181st St., 854 W.; to 6-story tenement; the New York Savings Bank, 81 8th Av., own er: Thomas O. Raad, architect; cost, $20,000. 97th St., 158 W.; to 3-story dwelling, store and baths; Jewish Women's Club, Inc. 131 W. 86th St., owner; Leon and Lionel Levy. architects; cost, $15,000. 63d St., 303 E.; to 5-story tenement; Gil green Corp., premises; owner; S. WalkerKatz, architect; cost, $4,000.

Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada decreased $1,875,145 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement of the bank, issued today. In the same time deposits of chartered banks increased$2,275,702.

Disbursements by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during February totaled only $17,091,482, according to a report made today by the corporation covering its operations from its establishment in February,1932, to Feb. 28, 1937.

Obscene and unrepeatable criticism of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York, published in the official German press in connection with his address to the Women's Division of the American Jewish Con gress on March 3, has been made the subject of "emphatic comment" to the German Government, Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today.
A group of Coptic monks on a stay-in strike at a desert monastery apparently won their demands today with Patriarch Yohannes agreeing to ask their abbot to resign andpermit them to elect a new one.

Nothing can disguise the fact that the action of the New York Assembly is a serious setback for the child labor amendment. As twenty-eight States have already endorsed the proposal, it is true that only eight more are needed out of the remaining twenty to makeratification complete.

John J. Davis, dismissed as a Works Progress Administration foreman in Newark, N. J., when he announced his candidacy for the City Commission, got his job back today without any attempt at a sitdown demonstration before WPAAdministrator Harry L. Hopkins.

H. L. Gates of 43 West Seventy third Street, newspaper writer and editor and the author of fifty-two novels, died yesterday morning of peritonitis at St. Clare's Hospital, 415 West Fifty-first Street. Mr. Gates recently had been operatedon for a stomach ailment.

Marking the anniversary of his fiftieth year with Balch, Price Co., retail furs, Fulton Street, Brooklyn, a reception was held yesterday for Garret L. Demarest, treasurer, by officers, directors and employes of the store. Mr. Demarest joined the store in 1887 at theage of 17, as assistant bookkeeper.

Gerald I. Carper, an engineer with the General Electric Company here and past president of the Producers Council of New England, died last night at the Waban Community Clubhouse during a bowling match.He was in his thirty-sixth year.

Stone-throwing and other disturbances at the Reading full-fashioned hosiery mill today caused suspension of operations at the plant, the twentieth affected by the generalhosiery strike begun on March 1.

The fourteenth annual Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association tournament will open in Syracuse University's Archbold Gymnasium tomorrow night, with the defending team champions from Penn State heavy favorites to win their third straight title and their seventh inthe history of the organization.

A vacant plot of 40,000 square feet at the foot of Danforth Avenue, near the new Roosevelt Stadium, in Jersey City, has been leased to Babsell, Inc. The deal was negotiated by D. E. C. Somers, Inc. through the Cafiero Realty Company. John D. Craven was theattorney for the lessor.

A Town Hall audience of members of the League for Political Education demonstrated its hostil ity to President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposals yesterday, booing and hissing a proponent of judiciary change and applauding acritic of the plan.

Movement of hogs to leading Western markets today fell below trade expectations and with a better demand prices were steady to 10 cents higher. Both the top and the average moved up 5 cents, the former being $10.25 a hundredweight, while the averageprice paid by packers was $10.05.

Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., report the sale of two properties in Greenwich and New Canaan, Conn., which formed parts of large estates. Twenty acres of the former Parker estate on Oeonoke Ridge, New Canaan, with a large Colonial residence and out buildings, were sold for the New York Trust Company as trustee. About seven acres of the land was immediately resold to Susan DwightBliss, an adjoining property owner.

WE ARE NOT ALONE, by James Hilton. (Little, Brown, $2.) A novel of an English doctor in a cathedral town. DUSK OF EMPIRE, by Wythe Williams. (Scribner, $3.) A foreign news correspondent for twentyfive years writes of his observations.

Merle Vandenbush pleaded guilty to first degree robbery today in the Westchester County Court, thus admitting he participated in the armed hold-up of the Northern Westchester Bank of Katonah on Feb. 25, exactly two weeks ago. Guilty pleas also were entered by Anthony Rera, who entered the bank with Vandenbush, and George Rera, who waited in an automobile a mile away. The three were trapped at Armonk less than a half hourafter the $17.600 robbery.
Representative Samuel Dickstein, Democrat, of New York, told the House Rules Committee today that 100 foreign spies were at work in the United States seeking "to foment a Fascist plot."

Empty Bottle, making his first appearance since trailing the big field that contested in the Hialeah Inaugural Handicap, turned up in top form and won the Orange Blossom Special, six furlong dash that occupied the honored position ontoday's program at Tropical Park.

The North American Light and Power Company of Wilmington, Del., one of the larger subsidiaries of the North American Company, and the Illinois Traction Company of Northport, Me., which controls subsid iaries in Illinois and Iowa and is a subsidiary of the North American Light and Power Company, have registered under the Public Utility Act of 1935, the Securities and Ex change Commission announced today.

Harry Kelley, right-hander and main stay of the Philadelphia Athletics' pitching staff, left tonight for New Braunfels, Texas, to finish his training with the Minneapolis club. He will rejoin the Athletics April20.

A Town Hall audience of members of the League for Political Education demonstrated its hostil ity to President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposals yesterday, booing and hissing a proponent of judiciary change and applauding acritic of the plan.

Movement of hogs to leading Western markets today fell below trade expectations and with a better demand prices were steady to 10 cents higher. Both the top and the average moved up 5 cents, the former being $10.25 a hundredweight, while the averageprice paid by packers was $10.05.

Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., report the sale of two properties in Greenwich and New Canaan, Conn., which formed parts of large estates. Twenty acres of the former Parker estate on Oeonoke Ridge, New Canaan, with a large Colonial residence and out buildings, were sold for the New York Trust Company as trustee. About seven acres of the land was immediately resold to Susan DwightBliss, an adjoining property owner.

The North American Light and Power Company of Wilmington, Del., one of the larger subsidiaries of the North American Company, and the Illinois Traction Company of Northport, Me., which controls subsid iaries in Illinois and Iowa and is a subsidiary of the North American Light and Power Company, have registered under the Public Utility Act of 1935, the Securities and Ex change Commission announced today.

Harry Kelley, right-hander and main stay of the Philadelphia Athletics' pitching staff, left tonight for New Braunfels, Texas, to finish his training with the Minneapolis club. He will rejoin the Athletics April20.

Assistant Attorney General Robert H. Jackson, appearing as the second administration witness in support of President Roosevelt's plan to re organize the Federal judiciary, told the Senate Judiciary Committee to day that Congress had the responsibility of providing for proper functioning of the Supreme Court.
Mrs. Frances M. Hoppe, mother of William F. Hoppe, billiard champion, died yesterday at her son's home, 425 West Fifty-seventh Street, after a long illness, at theage of 69.
Gimbel Bros., Inc., at a trustee's sale before Henry C. Frey, referee, yesterday purchased the James Butler Grocery Company's ware house at Nelson Avenue and SchoolStreet, Long Island City.

With the opening day for the New York racing season a little more than a month away, the State Racing Commission approved the dates petitioned for by the New York racing associations at a meeting held yesterday. The officials also announced that trials of the Australian barrier would be permitted.

A large part of the commercial leasing activity reported by brokers yesterday involved contracts for entire floors, and the millinery in dustry furnished the majority of the firms concerned. The list follows:

The third presentation of the current season of Massenet's "Manon" was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, with new principals. Rene Maison, who earlier in the season was unable to sing Des Grieux because of illness, essayedthe role.

The Wisconsin Power and Light Company is the first public utility to comply with Electric Plant Instruction No. 2 of the uniform system of accounts of the Federal Power Commission under which all utility companies must file a study of the original cost of their electric property within two years of Jan. 1, 1937, thecommission announced today.

S. A. Warner Baltazzi, chairman of the arrangements committee, an nounced today that the fourth running of the Aiken point-to-point race had been set for March 25, and that the entry list would beclosed next Wednesday.

A taxpayers' suit to void the special referendum on the city manager form of government last November was started here today in what city officials believe is an attempt to bring about another referendumthis year.
Hornell's City Council protested to Federal officials in Washington today against plans for the establishment of a CCC of Negroes nearhere.
James E. Bambrick, president of the importing firm, the Industries Shipping Agents and Brokers Company of New York, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home here.He was 45 years old.

Premier Senjuro Hayashi moved today into his new specially built offi cial residence, described by its architects as "assassinationproof." The $28,000 "house of secrets" is honeycombed with subterranean passages, secret exits, mysterious doors and disappearing floors and has a number of bombproof rooms with floors and wallsimpervious to bullets.

The House Judiciary Committee is "being asked to act on 'loss leader' selling in order to assist a nation-wide price-fixing program, in which both the Patman Act and the Tydings Miller Price-Maintenance Bill are two steps and State price-controllegislation a third step,"

Mrs. Catherine McKeon Dorsey, long a friend of Mary Pickford, died on Tuesday of a heart attack at the home of her sister, Mrs. Rose Post, at 44 Little Plains Road, Southampton, L. I. Mrs. Dorsey, who lived at 231 West Twenty-first Street, was 73 years old and a native of Ireland.

Members of the local unit of the United Rubber Workers of America, affiliated with C. I. O. and employed in the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company plant, went on strike today after announcing that the company had refused their demand for sole collective bargainingrights for all production workers.

Judge Edmund C. Faulkner is determined there will be no more thievery in the solemn precincts of the city court room where he presides. From a drawer in his desk, five feet from the door leading to police headquarters, his eight-dollar fountain pen was stolen.

Bancroft Hills, president of the Baltimore Transit Company, announced yesterday that the hourly wage rate of employes will be in creased 3 cents an hour, equivalent to approximately a 5 per cent in crease. A 5 per cent increase for all weekly payroll employes of thecompany also was announced.
Memorial High School of West New York was eliminated from the Group 4 New Jersey State basketball tournament tonight when a powerful Morristown High quintetprevailed, 30-23.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Theodore S. Jaffin of New York was admitted to practice today and the following proceed ings were had: 285-United States, ex relations, Girard Trust Co., trustee, , petr., v. Commis sioner of Internal Revenue. Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing submitted for the petitioner.

All very uncertain is the status of the Theatre Guild's sixth New York production for this season. It has been supposed that it would be Sidney Howard's "The Ghost of Yankee Doodle," but admittedly there has been difficulty in finding the four stars or featured players it requires.

Persecution of W. F. Hutton Co. of New York, brokerage house, was charged before the Securities and Exchange Commission today by David W. Peck, counsel for the brokers. The firm is accused of manipulating the market in Atlas Tack Corporation stock by boosting it from 9 5/8 to 30 and then "back ing off" and permitting the stockto fall back to around 15.

The education committee of the Massachusettes Legislature voted today to recommend repeal of the Teacher's Oath Law, which requires teachers in public and private schools to swear allegiance to theConstitution.
