Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Bochicchio of this place and South Orange, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosetta Felice Bochicchio, to Sydney B. White ofEast Orange.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 9: COMMANDERS. Roberts, L. J., Med. Corps, Washington, D. C., to instruction at the Mayo Foundation, Rochester, Minn., in May.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Feb. 28 showed that the ratio of gold reserve to notes in circulation had declined from 136.26 per cent on Feb. 15 to 134.99 per cent. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities slipped from 92.70per cent to 92.63 per cent.

School Savings Forum of the American Bankers Association, Waldorf Astoria Hotel, 10 A. M. Luncheon session 12:15 P. M. Afternoon sessions 2 P. M. and 3:30 P. M. American Museum of Natural Histary, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West, 10:30 A. M. "The North Atlantic Fisherman," John R.Saunders.

Stockholders of the Atlas Corporation have been asked by the board of directors to advise the board whether they are "in principle favorable to some fair, reasonable and limited profit sharing system for compensation of management, substituting in whole or part for fixed salaries, provided such plan is first submitted to stockholdersfor approval."
Chester A. Bishop, seeded No. 1 in the sixth annual metropolitan squash racquets Class C championship, came to the end of his trail in that event yesterday at theDowntown Athletic Club.
Chester A. Bishop, seeded No. 1 in the sixth annual metropolitan squash racquets Class C championship, came to the end of his trail in that event yesterday at theDowntown Athletic Club.

Fighting off a desperate lastperiod burst, the Detroit Red Wings turned back the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night, 4 to 2. The winners, taking advantage of every break in the fast, well-played battle, thus clinched first place in the American groupof the National Hockey League.

The marriage of Miss Florence T. Cohen, daughter of Mrs. E. Toplon Cohen of 235 West Seventy-sixth Street and the late Bernard Cohen, to Theodore Ruderman of Mamaro neck, N. Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Ruderman of Middle town, Conn., took place last nightat the Oliver Cromwell Hotel.
A registration statement covering the issuance of $30,000,000 of debentures due in 1942 has been filed by the Commercial Credit Company of Baltimore, under the Securities Actof 1933. Interest rate,

Samuel Goldwyn mane Known today that he holds contracts with Barbara O'Neil and Rita Johnson. Miss O'Neil, a member of Katharine Hepburn's "Jane Eyre" troupe, was brought to the Coast a few weeks ago for tests and will replace Mary Astor in "Stella Dallas" in the role played by Alice Joyce in the original.
Married men not only seem to live longer than single men, they actually do, according to a state ment yesterday by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life InsuranceCompany.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert signed an order yesterday requiring Mrs. Elise Hammond, wife of Harris Hammond, industrialist, to show cause on March 26 why she should not be perpetually restrained from claiming ownership to more than 300 articles of art and furnish ings against which a lien had beenplaced as property of her husband.

Miss Elizabeth Van Cortlandt Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Mahon Smith of this city, has chosen April 9 for her wedding to William Gard ner Mundy, son of Norris Have meyer Mundy of New York, former ly of Chicago, and the late Mrs.Mundy.

United States Government bonds declined sharply yesterday in the heaviest trading on the New York Stock Exchange in more than six teen -years. Declines ranged from 4-32 to 25-32 point and forced vir tually all of these issues to new lowlevels for the year.

Charging that discrimination was being practiced against certain Democratic officeholders who were not recommended by their depart ment heads for salary restorations, Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan sought yesterday to have the Board of Estimate lay down a blanket policy covering payrestorations to all city employes.
Miss Jacque line de Neuflize was married to Baron Jean de Watteville-Berck heim in the American Cathedral Church on Wednesday. Dean Frederick W. Beckman officiated.

Commissioner Langdon W. Post of the Tenement House Department said yesterday that residents in the four-story tenement at 72 South Eighth Street in the Williamsburg area of Brooklyn, which has been posted- as non-fireproof, would not be evicted until the department hadfound new quarters for them.

The Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, called a "Cathe dral of Service" when it was built at a cost of $1;250,000, has filed an assignment with the County Clerk for the benefit of its creditors in insolvency proceedings under theState Debtor and Creditor Law.

Harry Schreier, a public account ant in this city for forty years and an official in several real estate and other corporations, died yester day at his home, 370 Riverside Drive. He was 78 years old. Mr. Schreier was a partner in Schreier Hertz of 250 West Fiftyseventh Street, accountants;

At the completion of all preliminaries and most of the semi-finals in the fourteenth annual Eastern inter collegiate boxing championships in the Archbold Gymnasium tonight, the current competition had devel oped into what is virtually a dual meet between Penn State, the de fending titleholder, and Syracuse,last year's runner-up

President Roosevelt has settled a dispute between two small boys in Granton, N. Y., with the information that he has milked a cow, although he is only an amateur, "and is now considerably out of practice."

Mrs. Dorothy S. Underhill of Westport, Conn., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Cornelius Sullivan of Corning, N. Y., was married to Samuel Lytton Scott of 22 East Sixty-ninth Street, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Samuel Scott of New York and St. Louis, yesterday after noon in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Hackensack Water Company of Weehawken, N. J., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $13,600,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series A, due April 1, 1967, and 61,500 shares of $25 par value common stock. The interest rate and redemption provisions of the bonds and the prices of the bonds and stock will be supplied by amendment.

A report that Germany would boy cott the New York World's Fair of 1939 because of Mayor La Guardia's recent anti-Nazi remarks was dis credited yesterday at the offices of the World's Fair Corporation in theEmpire State Building.
Jeno Hubay, noted violinist and composer, died today of heart disease. He was 78 years old. His bestknown work was the opera "Anna Karenina."

Road-building equipment and ma trial valued at $100,000 for the three bridges to be erected by the United States as its contribution in Nicaragua toward the Inter-Ameri can Highway arrived today. United States engineers will be in chargeof erecting the bridges.

Allan Tolmich of Wayne Uni versity established a new meet and Notre Dame gymnasium record of 7.1 second tonight in the 65-yard low hurdle preliminaries of the Central Intercollegiate Conferenceindoor track meet.

The office of the Nazi party's for eign press chief, Dr. Ernst (Putzi) Hanfstaengl, has been liquidated, according to The Daily Telegraph's Berlin correspondent. The where about of Dr. Hanfstaengl is a mys tery. Some reports say he is in Spain and others maintain he is inBritain.

The annual report of the Euro pean Electric Corporation, Ltd., of Canada for 1936 shows a net income of $1,191,617 after all deductions, in cluding $93,569 loss on sale of se curities, compared with $2,190,052 for 1935, including $86,945 loss on sale of securities and $30,744 profit or reacquiring $603,000 of debentures.

John R. Powers, former New York State Republican Assembly man and president of the Rochester Street Signal Company, died at his home here tonight. He was 57. A native of Naples, N. Y., Mr.Powers came to Rochester in 1893.

The Wo men's Christian Temperance Union reported today that a survey con ducted through Salvation Army of ficers showed that intoxication had increased since repeal in all except three of 119 cities in forty-oneStates.

Reports of scattered rains in parts of Kansas, while largely in the eastern half of the State, where moisture is least needed, had a depressing effect on the wheat market on the Board of Trade here today, and while the close was on a moderate rally, the losses were 1 1/4 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel,with the July leading the decline.

New State and municipal financ ing scheduled for next week to tals $42,787,475, seventy-three is suing authorities being represented. The revised total for this week is only $8,629,663, and the weekly average for the year to date $32,586,744.

Sit-down strikes in mercantile establishments in Detroit today increased in number instead of diminishing, although three were adjusted to the satisfaction of both employers and employes. The list tonight includes everything from laundries and cigar shops to a department store andpacking house.

Miss Bar bara Rosemary Woodworth, daugh ter of Mrs. Charlton Eugene Battle, became the bride here this after noon of Rene Robert Salembier Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rene Robert Salembier of Englewood, N. J. The ceremony, attended by only the im mediate families, was performed by the Rev. Thomas Garrity in St. Clement's Church. A reception followed at the Charlesgate Hotel.

Paul Evans Green, civil engineer, died today at the age of 57. In 1934 he was ap pointed chief engineer in Illinois of the CWA and a consultant to the National Resources Board. In 1918 and 1919 he was district engineer for the United States Housing Bureau.

Emil Klein, banker, died here early today at his home of a heart attack. He was in his seventy third year. Mr. Klein had been with the Irv ing Trust Company of New York for many years and was a vice president on his retirement on Oct.31, 1933.
The depths of the MacBeth mine hold nine dead men tonight, while the bodies of nine others killed in the State's worst mine disaster in adecade rested in a funeral home.

Weekly cotton statistics are as fol lows: British stocks, 941,000 bales, against 969,000 a week ago, 929,000 two weeks ago, 920,000 three weeks ago and 735,000 a year ago; of which American 391,000 bales, against 415,000 a week ago, 410,000 two weeks ago, 415,000 three weeksago and 382,000 a year ago.

The return of Benny Fields to the Hollywood Restaurant on Wednes day evening was the signal for such a turnout of big-time performers, song-writers, scribblers of this and data and just plain hangers-on as is seldom seen these days east of the Sierra Nevadas. And Mr. Fields acknowledged the tribute

Barring changes of mind over the week-end, just two entertainments withdraw from Broadway after this evening's performances, they being "Stage Door" and "Fulton of Oak Falls." The first will have had 169 performances at the Music Box, and it is due to tour for at leastsixteen weeks next - season.

Mid-Pacific islands and govern ment ships hurried preparations to day to speed Amelia Earhart on her world flight. The flier announced that she would take off here at 5 P. M. (8 P. M. Eastern standard time), Sunday or Monday, weatherpermitting.

James V. Martin, inventor and aviation pioneer, filed suit yester day for $25,000,000 against the Manufacturers Aircraft Association, Inc., Pan American Airways, Inc., and other aircraft organizations, al leging that they conspired to keep him out of the industry in New York State in violation of the Donnelly Anti-Trust Act.
The sentiment of the New Jersey Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs re garding various pending fish and game legislation is expressed in abulletin now being circulated.

New con firmation came today of the impor tance of Italian aid on the Rebel side in the Spanish civil war. Two Italian captives, Major Luciano An tonio d'Inino and Lieutenant Achille Sacchi, made such revealing and apparently well-founded statements that they have been rushed to Va lencia for questioning by high government officials .
There is plenty of trouble ahead for the Italian administration in Addis Ababa, according to information reaching here tonight through reliable channels.

The Brooklyn Polytech quintet ended its campaign with a 33-29 tri umph at the expense of Pratt In stitute at Odd Fellows Hall last night. The success marked the fourteenth in nineteen games for Poly, which showed the way at thehalf, 15-10.

Following Thursday's announcement that C. I. O. officials would support their movement to negotiate a union contract with the Consolidated Edison Company, spokesmen for the 650 employes of the Hudson Avenue (Brooklyn) Edison plant met yesterday with the plant management.

Edward T. Pape, who wrote the largest annual volume of business for the Prudential Insurance Com pany, died today. His age was 83. Born in London, Mr. Pape came to the United States in 1882, and immediately joined the Prudential company in Orange, N. J. He was superintendent in Orange, Pater son, N. J., Wilkes-Barre, Pa., Bal timore and Hagerstown, Md., andChicago.

Mrs. George H. Bostwick's Fugi tive, one of the best timber toppers in the country, will rule favorite in the field of four that will face the starter tomorrow for the third run ning of the Sandhills Cup race. This will be the feature of the Sandhills Steeplechase and RacingAssociation meeting,

The United States protest against the German press attacks on Mayor Fiorello La Guardia of New York, and on the United States generally and Ameri can women particularly, was de livered by Ambassador William E. Dodd to Foreign Minister Constan tin von Neurath late this afternoon.

The deep concern shown in price levels, particularly with respect to non-ferrous metals, by the govern ments of Great Britain and the United States, appears to have had a sobering effect on the markets.

The 112th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design opened in the galleries. of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty seventh Street, with a private view last night and beginning to day the work there assembled will be shown to the public until April13.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Rail way was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to assume obligation and liability for $13,800,000 of its equipment trust 2 1/4 per cent certificates of 1937 to be issued by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York and sold to the Prudential Insurance Companyof America.

Trailing by 7-5 at the close of the first half, the Hunter College sextet turned back the Brooklyn College women's basketball team, 16-13, at the Girls Industrial High School court in Brooklyn last night. Miss Helen Gilligan and Miss Mar garet Dunning each scored eightmarkers for the winners:

Shortly after the body of Abra ham Ball, 77 years old, a retired leather merchant, of 575 Riverside Drive, was found last night beside the New York Central Railroad tracks below Riverside Drive Park at 141st Street, Bernard Ball, 35, a son, of 282 Northern Avenue, was at the West 152d Street police station reporting his father missing.

Edi tions of newspapers containing news of lotteries or winners of sweepstakes prizes not only must be barred from the mails in accord ance with Section 601 of the Postal Laws and Regulations, but shall not be distributed by other means. such as train, automobile or car rier, according to a ruling by Karl A. Crowley, Postoffice Department solicitor, transmitted to THE NEW YORK TIMES through Albert Goldman, Postmaster of New York City.

Paul N. Coulcher, dominant fig ure in Local 16 of the Waiters Union, and one of the eight defend ants of the restaurant racket trial, shouldered the responsibility yes terday for the activities of hisunion.

Two books that have frequently been announced for publication but have been delayed are now definite ly on publishers' lists for this sea son. They are "The Years," the new novel by Virginia Woolf that Harcourt, Brace will bring out, and "Present Indicative," by Noel Cow ard, which is to be published thisSpring by Doubleday, Doran.

Irving Weisglass, president of the United States Cabinet Bed Com pany, gave a party yesterday after noon for some 500 employes to cele brate the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the business and announced a 10 per cent rise insalaries.

The American Music League will present a concert of Spanish music tomorrow night at the Concert League. The concert is for the benefit of the Spanish Loyalists. Lolita Cabrera Gainsborg, pianist, will give a recital tomorrow after noon at the Columbia UniversityClub.

THE muscle-men and the speedy steppers of the I. C. 4-A group will be running and jumping and throwing things about in what they call "the indoor intercollegiates" at Madison Square Garden this evening. This isn't quite like the other athletic meets of the indoor season where the furious fun lies in the rivalry of individual stars at various distancesor in certain field events.

United States District Judge George H. Moore today ordered Guy A. Thomp son, trustee of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, to file suit against the estate of the late O. P. Van Swerin gen and four directors of the rail road to recover "large losses" in the railroad's purchase of its own stock through a subsidiary severalyears ago.
The German Government today communicated to the British Foreign Office its views on a new Rhineland pact to take the place of the defunct Treatyof Locarno.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, told more than 2,000 Dem ocrats here tonight that the real fear of the opponents of President Roosevelt's plan of reorganizing the judiciary was that the Supreme Court "will cease to be packed withnominees of the old order."

For the second time in the seven teen-year history of the Pinehurst seniors' golf championship, R. W. Smith of Greenburg, Pa., wears the crown. Playing In the title final today, Smith routed M. R. Brown of Rutherford, N. J., 6 and 5, aftergetting away to a fast start.

Members of the Strykers Lane Community Center Junior Auxiliary will give their annual barn dance tonight at the center gymnasium for the benefit of the boys' Sum mer camp at Palisades Park. Charles E. Tilton is chairman of thecommittee in charge.
Mayor La Guardia clashed with other members of the Board of Estimate yesterday over his effort to get the board's approval

Time was when Captain Patrick Tayleur, who has sailed the seven seas for nearly seventy years and has walked across three Continents besides, was not happy unless he was on the move, meeting people and listening to them remark in wonder upon his likeness to Mark Twain.

Miss Margaret youle Royall, daughter of Mrs. Maudeva KilGour Royall, was married here tonight at the home of her mother to Edwin; Burns Hinck of Montclatr, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Hinck.

Thieves escaped early yesterday morning after stealing more than $20,000 in furs from the establish ment of S. Arnow, furrier, of 2,328 Broadway, between Eighty-fourth and Eighty-fifth Streets. Fifteen years ago, Mr. Arnow said, he was robbed of $20,000 in the same ground-floor store. Only about $3,000 of yesterday's loot was insured, he said.

In an effort to ease the tin situation for United States and other consumers who are without home supplies, the International Tin Committee today suddenly raised the tin export quota by 10 per cent to 110 per cent of standard tonnages for the secondquarter of this year.

Hearing on the plan of reorgan ization for the Bush Terminal Company and the Bush Terminal Build ings Company was continued yes terday before Judge Robert A. Inch in the Federal court in Brooklyn. At the close of the day's session the hearing was adjourned againuntil next Friday.

A frac tured ankle removed Larry Aurie, the National Hockey League's lead ing scorer, to the sidelines tonight. The champion Detroit Red Wings, shorn of their best offensive weapon, have ten days in which to revamp their attack before hockey's world series, the league championship and Stanley Cup play-offs, open hereMarch 23.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday additional exceptions to the "no-turn-on-red-light" traffic regulations. Left turns on red lights will be permitted along the Sunrise Highway in Queens at Eighty-fourth, 101st, 117th,

Paul D. O'Brien of the Brown University Club and Bailey B. Scott, Short Hills, will meet this afternoon at the Downtown Athletic Club in the final of the Metropoli tan Class C squash racquets cham pionship. Both won their semi final matches last night in sternfive-game matches.

Sir Hubert Wilkins, ex plorer, outlined to directors of the Canadian Geographical Society to day his plans for a submarine expe dition to the North Pole and asked them to associate the society withthe project.

Miss Katharine Allen of 169 East Seventy-eighth Street and Richard S. Russell of this city and Boston, obtained a marriage license yester day at the Municipal Building. The marriage will take place in the nearfuture.

Trading in round lots on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges in the week ended on Feb. 13, in which there were only five trading days, was less than in the preceding week, the Securities and ExchangeCommission reported today.

Miss Catherine Mackey, daughter of Mr. and-Mrs. Wallace- Bradley Mackey of Upper Montclair,. N. J., was married yesterday to Charles Augustus Rittler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Rittler of Baltimore. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Randolph- Ray in theChurch of the Transfiguration.
P. A. Staples, president of the Hershey Corporation, challenged yesterday statements by Earl D. Babst, chairman of the American Sugar Refining Company, in his recent annual report to stockholders.

This Summer will see the fruition of the most intensive period of engi neering research for passenger car improvement in the history of American railroading, Victor R. Willoughby, general mechanical en gineer of the American Car and Foundry Company, said last night before the New York Chapter of the Railroad and Locomotive Historical Society in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninthStreet.

Diplomatic London chuckled today over a little jingle of four lines which has its significant bearing on Italo-German and Anglo-German relations. Under the caption "Raw Material" it ap peared anonymously in the current issue of The New Statesman andNation as follows:

New tests designed to bring out the physical ability of applicants for the Fire Department were agreed on yesterday-by members of the Municipal Civil Service Com mission and Fire Department officials.

Retail trade here turned some what spotty on several days this week, due to vagaries of the weather and to the approaching in come tax payment date, but with pre-Easter buying satisfactory to day a gain of 10 per cent for theweek was foreseen.

Week-end and carry-over influences overshad owed business on the stock markets today, and conditions generally were quiet. Gilt-edge issues weak ened, although Germans were strong among the foreign. Inter nationals worked downward at the opening, with United States Steel sagging, although InternationalNickel stood its ground.

A protest against the manner in which the New York County Law yers Association declared against President Roosevelt's plan to reor ganize the United States Supreme Court was made yesterday by Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, in a letter to Charles Evans Hughes Jr., itspresident.

United States Department of Agriouiture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was fair to slow. Most elasses were steady to strong with some sales higher. Strictly choice and prime steer hindquarters and cuts were scarce and some fair sized lots heavyweights were moved out of freezers;

E. E. Hall is vith Poor's Publish ing Company in Boston. Broadway-Barclay, Inc., first mortgage bonds are now ready for exchange for Broadway-Barclay Of fice Building first mortgage bondsat the Empire Trust Company.

Viscomte Rene de Montozon Brachet, 55 years old, travel lec turer and author, plunged forty-five feet from the stern boat deck of the French liner Ile de France an hour and fifteen minutes before he was scheduled to sail for his homeland aboard the liner last night and was rescued from the Hudson River by the crew of the tugboat Howard C. Moore, at the foot of West Fortyeighth Street, at few minutes later.

Carl M. Snyder, through Walter McMee kan Management Corp., residence at 35 Ox ford Road, White Plains, Westchester; Ranald W. Brewster, at 5 Gilbert Pl., White Plains; V. Floyd Self, for Marvin Building Co., Inc., in 89 Broadway, White Plains: Alfred L. Helwith, in 69 Walworth Av., Scarsdale; B. E. Farley, in 88 Mercer Av., Hartsdale; Roy S. Breese, in 22 Downer Av.. Scarsdale; Prince Ripley, Inc., Broker.

Russia's gold reserve now amounts to over $7,000,000,000 and is second only to that of the United States, according to john F. Chapman, foreign editor of Business Week, who is in Russia and who maintains in an article

Italy has withdrawn from the League of Nations, Ethiopia re mains seated, and Franco's claims to govern the Republic of Spain have been set aside. Such are the results of the opening session of the Assembly of the New England Model League of Nations, meetingin Sanders Theatre today.

Settlement of the strike in ef fect since Jan. 21 at the Perennial Dye and Print Works of West War wick was announced late today by Thomas F. McMahon, State direc tor of labor, who said the strikerswould return to work Monday.

Miss Lily Pons, the opera star, was dis closed today as the only woman in Connecticut holding a gold badge signifying that she is an inspector of the State Motor Vehicle Department. Commissioner Michael A.

Ward's Automotive Reports, Inc., today es timated the week's output of the automobile plants at 103,649 cars and trucks, compared with last week's estimated production of 127, 134 and 93,216 in the like week of 1936. It attributed the decline tothe Chrysler strike.
Fishermen found the body of Mrs. E. M. Ashworth, a Winter visitor from Hoosick Falls, N. Y., in Boca Ciega Bay today. Mrs. Ashworth disappeared from her Pass-a-Grille beach home early yesterday.

Walter I. Sherman, 52 years old, of 52 Fern Street, Floral Park, L. I., former cashier of the First National Bank there, who pleaded guilty to misapplication of $1,300 of the bank's funds, received a suspended sentence yesterday from Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, in the Federalcourt in Brooklyn.

At least twenty witnesses will ap pear before the Bergen County, N. J., grand jury early next week in the Redwood murder case, it was said yesterday by persons associat ed with John J. Breslin Jr., BergenCounty Prosecutor.

Traders in the shares of the Atlas Tack Corporation, including Elmer David (Del) Baker of the Detroit Tigers of the American League, were called as witnesses today by the Securities and Exchange Commis sion in a continuation of the gov ernment's effort to show that W. E. Hutton Co., New York brokers, manipulated these securities be tween November, 1935, and February, 1936.

American Museum of Natural His tory, 10:30 A. M., "With Arctic Nomads," Arnold H. Haverlee. Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Paint ing in Germany, England and France," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "Types of XVI Century Painting (Survey of Collections)," Edith R.Abbot, 2 P. M.;

Our country is facing a momentous issue vitally affecting our national welfare. With such an issue, all will agree that it is the duty of a public servant to give it the most earnest consideration and determine for himself the right position to take for thewelfare of his country.

Downing Street, the nerve center of the British Empire, is a dead-end street, strangely quiet in the London twilight. On one side is a short row of pleasant eigh teenth century brick houses beginningwith No. 10.

Employes of J. P. Morgan Co: are receiving a payment of additional compensation in recog nition of recent increased and overtime work. The bonus is being given to those who have been working overtime, due to the rush of business connected with the large number of divi dend declarations and other ac tivities. While the distribution is not general, it is understood that most of the employes will sharein it.

Justice Peyton Gordon, in United States District Court, today sen tenced Dr. Francis E. Townsend, elderly sponsor of old-age pensions, to pay a $100 fine and serve thirty days in jail for contempt of the House of Representatives. Justice Gordon overruled a motion for anew trial.

Two buildings in the Murray Hill section changed hands in deals an nounced yesterday and will under go extensive altering for residen tial purposes. They occupy abut ting plots and will be held for investment.

William H. Alfring, president of the Aeolian American Corporation, largest piano manufacturing con cern in the world and an officer or director of many other companies in the musical instrument field, killed himself here tonight by jump ing in front of a New York Central passenger train. Mr. Alfring was 52 years old and lived at 28 Wal worth Avenue, Scarsdale, an adjoining community.

A group of men selected the fash ions which were worn by manikins and judged at a style revue staged yesterday afternoon by Miss Elsa Maxwell in the Little Theatre at learns in Fourteenth Street. This was the closing event of a week's series of fashion parties given by Miss Maxwell at the de partment store, and the theatre wascrowded with women.

Mrs. Elizabeth A. Cuff, mother of Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff of Hempstead, died at her home here today of a heart ailment. She was 81 years old. Justice Cuff, who was presiding in Supreme Court in Brooklyn, ad journed his court yesterday when he was notified his mother's condition had become worse.

The Seaboard Terminal and Refrigera tion Company of Jersey City filed suit today in the Federal court here for an injunction to restarin the Interstate Commerce Commission from enforcing an order directing the Erie Railroad to reduce from $196,337 to $108,724 the annual ren tal paid to the Seaboard for a fourstory freight station built by it.

Celebrating the twenty-fifth anni versary of the founding in this country of the Girl Scouts, Mrs. Benjamin Harrison; widow of the former President of the United States, was the guest of honor yes terday afternoon at a reception and tea in the national headquarters,570 Lexington Avenue.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Ap peals the following proceedings were had today: PATENTS 3784--Ex parte Hugo A. Bertram, Argued. 3795-Rudolph A. Hagen vs. William Cords. Submitted on brief of applt. Arguedfor appellee.

The West ern Electric Company, manufactur ers of telephone equipment, today increased wages of 12,000 hourly workers at the Hawthorne plant in Cicero by an average of 10 per cent,totaling about $1,800,000 a year.

Hog receipts fell materially short of trade expectations today. Light weights, which have been declining rather sharply of late, advanced rapidly, and with a better demand priceswere 25 to 50 cents higher.

Junior high school teachers, meeting last night at the New York University School of Education in the opening session of the thirteenth annual Junior High School Confer ence, were told that they have "too little recognition of their own po tential power" and were urged to put their school program effectively before the public.

To the Editor of the New York Times: The committee of the Board of Esti mate to consider the housing of low-in come groups is faced with a problem of many aspects: social, economic, fi nancial, city-planning and architectural. Because we have emphasized the social aspects and neglected the others we facea serious crisis.

The death of Herbert Scoville, an attorney, of 37 East Sixty-eighth Street, on Thursday at his villa in Cintra, Portugal, was made known here yesterday. Mr. Scoville, the son of Mrs. Nathaniel ChurchScoville, was 58 years old.

With the three teams which have turned in the fastest times this sea son in the same mile race, there will be eleven relay tests in the Knights of Columbus. track and field carnival at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday, it was announced by Frank Brennan yesterday.

John L. Lewis bought a new house here today, and his trouble with Mrs. Bernice Flemming Holland threatened to break out all over again. This is because the labor leader's new house is so old, and Mrs. Holland does not like Mr. Lewis's principles-or sit-downstrikes.

Sixty-three school papers were picked from a list of about 950 publications entered this year in the Columbia Scholastic Press As sociation's annual contest and designated yesterday for high honor by a committee of thirty teacher advisers, who placed them on nine mythical "All-Columbian" staffs in recognition of individual excellence in one of seven branches of journalism.
Passion Sunday will be observed tomorrow. A week from tomor row will be Palm Sunday and two weeks from tomorrow Easter. Oratorios will be sung in manychurches.

A jury in the Bronx County Court was said to have established a record for speed in that borough when after seven minutes' deliberation yesterday it returned a verdict of guilty against Hyman Fogel, 36 years old, of 1,429 Charlotte Street, the Bronx, who was charged with first degree burglary.
The deadline for filing Federal income tax returns is midnight next Monday. Officials warned yesterday that failure to file on or before Monday will result inpenalties.

Members of the United States Ambulance Service with the French Army, under the late Colonel Percy L. Jones, and other Americans who served with the French Ambulance Corps, will form an organization to renew old acquaintances of the World War at a meeting on Monday at 4 P. M. at the Hotel

Three big independent steel companies in creased wages for 38,900 employes in the Pittsburgh district today. One of them, Spang, Chalfant Co., Inc., agreed on a contract with the John L. Lewis Steel WorkersOrganizing Committee.

Robert Meriman of California, commander of the Abraham Lin coln Brigade in the Leftist Gov ernment's international forces, was sent to a hospital at Murcia with a critical bullet wound inthe shoulder today.

The first 5,000,000,000-franc slice of the French defense loan was much over subscribed today. From early morn ing on there was a rush in all Paris banks and reports from the provinces indicate similar eager ness to subscribe. SomeParis banks were actually forced to turn cus tomers away long before closingtime.
E. N. Bisso's Whipowill again won at long odds today when he led six veteran campaigners over a mile and a sixteenth at the Fair Grounds. Paying $20.80 for $2 in the mutuels,

Traveling from work to his home in Brooklyn at 7:15 o'clock last night, Murray L. Garfinkel, a clerk for a woolen goods firm, saw a roll of papers, secured by a rubber band, lying on the floor of the subway train.

Electric refrigerator sales of the Stewart-Warner Corporation from Oct. 1, 1936, which is considered the beginning of the season in produc tion, to Feb. 28 this year were 89 per cent larger than a year earlier,the company announced yesterday.
A jam in scrap-iron traffic, attrib uted partly to Europe's rearma ment demand, prompted the Asso ciation of American Railroads to apply stringent regulations todayto shipments of the metal.

The seventh of the Mozart-Haydn concerts, sponsored by the WPA Federal Music Project, last night at the project's Theatre of Music, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street, had as guest artists the reunited piano team of Lee Pattison and Guy Maier, and Louis Persinger, violinist.

Manhattan COHN, HENRY L. (Jan. 27). Estate, less than $2,000. To Renee Van Holland, sis ter, 395 Riverside Dr., residue; several specific bequests. Morris Well, 315 River side Dr., executor. CUNNINGHAM, RICHARD H. (Feb. 24). Estate, less than $10,000. To Lillian V. Andrews, executor, 55 Tieman Pl., residue.

Mrs. Seymour H. Knox of East Aurora, N. Y., wife of the polo player, won the feature event, the mothers' race, at the annual sports day of the Aiken Preparatory School this afternoon. Mrs. Dean Bedford ofNew York was second.

An early rising young student from Hartford, Conn., is "waking" his way through college here. He is "Gilman, the slumber snapper," as he modestly proclaims himself in his neatly typed campus notices,otherwise Bernard Gilman.
Henry Armstrong, the Los Angeles featherweight, lived up to all the sensational advance notices sent out about him when he knocked out Mike Belloise at Madison SquareGarden last night.
A large volume of building plans was filed yesterday in four bor oughs of the city and included a total expenditure of nearly $2,000,000 in Brooklyn alone.

Gabriele d'Annunzio, Italy's poet hero, observed his seventy-fourth birthday today, chuckling over re ports that he had contemplated suicide. He appeared briefly at the window of his library to acknowledge gun salutes from the foredeck of the destroyer Puglia, erected as amonument on the estate.
John J. "One Play" O'Brien, 31, assist ant football and track coach at Notre Dame University, was killed early today when his automobile crashed into a railway viaductpillar.

Illinois, leading contender for the Big Ten wrestling title, led in qualifiers for the conference meet tonight, placing six in the semi finals and a seventh in the finals. Only two Illini wrestlers, however, had to participate in first-roundmatches, as the others drew byes.

The Hon. Caryl Baring and his daughter, Miss Leonora Baring, who have been traveling for sev eral weeks on the ,Pacific Coast and in Mexico, will return here on Monday and will be at the Pierre for a fortnight before sailing fortheir home in England.

Blindness proved no handicap to Robert Allman, 18-year-old Univer sity of Pennsylvania sophomore, in the thirty-third Eastern Intercolle giate Wrestling Association cham pionships at Lehigh University to day, for he scored two impressive triumphs to qualify for tomorrow's118-pound final.

After establishing another new high price yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange developed irregu larity and ended 2 points higher to 6 points lower. Reactions in sev eral outside markets and reports of active profit-taking abroad brought about wider price movements overa range of $1 a bali.

It cannot be said that the Metro politan has been particularly fortu nate this season with its Puccini. The performance last night did not do justice to the first "Boheme" of the season. The works of the Ital ian repertory deserve better treatment.

MANHATTAN ABEEL, ALFRED H. (Nov. 26, 1936). Gross assets, $6,108; net, $4,479. ToRachel H. Campbell, half-sister, $2,500. one other bequest. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $2,906. Patterson Brinckerhoff, attorneys, 11 Broadway.

After the election there was some lighthearted talk of Maine and Vermont seceding from the Union. Or, at least, it was suggested that the United States might issue passports to travelers pressed by necessity to enter those un reconstructed remnants of Old Dealdominion.

The Department of Commerce said today that February manufacturing production had been maintained at a high level "despite the retarding influences" of labor disputes and the crimp in business activity as aresult of the flood.
Oxford rowed its first trial over the race course from Putney to Mortlake today in 22 minutes 35 seconds in its train ing for the annual race with Cambridge March 24.
Union and employee representatives on a joint bargaining committee re jected today an offer of Westing house Electric and Manufacturing Company to raise minimum hourlywares 8 cents for day workers.

Michael Burke, organizer and owner of the Rex Distilling Com pany of Boston and Marlboro, died yesterday at his home here. He was 84 years old. Mr. Burke was a director of the People's National Bank of Marl boro, a trustee of the Marlboro Sav ings Bank and a member of thePublic Library Board in Marlboro.

The wer man reply to the British note of last November inviting suggestions for the framing of a Western Euro pean peace pact reached the British Foreign Office this evening by air plane from Sir Eric Phipps, the British Ambassador to Germany, to whom it had been delivered thismorning in Berlin.

An after-season performance of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House on the evening of March 30 at 7:45 o'clock. It has been arranged by the GermanAmerican Charities.

A return to simple principles and avoidance of "unnatural banking profits" was urged yesterday by Lindsay Bradford, President of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, before the annual Spring savings conference of the Savings Division of the American Bankers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria.

The junior show of Barnard Col lege, "It Doesn't Happen Here," was presented last night in Brinck erhoff Theatre, Milbank Hall. A group of skits featured college life as seen by Lewis Carroll, Eugene O'Neill, H. G. Wells, William Randolph Hearst and H. B. Warner.
Cardinal Hayes arrived home early last evening from Nassau, coming by train from Miami. He appeared to be in excellent health and good spirits as he alighted from the train at PennsylvaniaStation.
Industrial building plans for New York State submitted during Febru ary were the greatest in thirteen years, State Industrial Commission er Elmer F. Andrews reported today.

Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN--John E. Prince, 103d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed May 29, 1911. Transfers and Assignments SERGEANT---John J. Burns, from 18th Precinct to 5th Division, assigned to duty as supervisor of plain clothes patrolmen.

John Fish Goodrich, film and maga zine writer, died today after an ab dominal operation. His age was 50. One of his magazine stories, "Crack Up," is being filmed. Mr. Goodrich was born in Dela van, Wis., the son of Alonzo C. and Mary L. Goodrich. He was edu cated at Keokuk High School, Iowa State College, Cornell and ChicagoUniversities.

An almost unanimous preference for the discretionary features of the McReynolds neutrality resolution over the mandatory Pittman reso lution passed by the Senate was expressed in the House of Repre sentatives today as it began its gen eral debate on the substitute its own Foreign Affairs Committee hasoffered to the Senate measure.
John L. Kregg and his wife, both Ameri cans of New York, were severely injured this afternoon on the Cen tral Highway outside Havana when their automobile crashed into atree.

The New Rochelle Water Com pany met the demands of the City Council here today in connection with a rate dispute -which began more than five years ago. It is now expected the city will withdraw itssuit to condemn the company.

Waging a successful attack through two fence-offs after a three-way tie for first place had re suited in the final round robin, Ralph E. Marson, New York Ath letic Club, won the national junior saber championship at the fourth annual competition in the auxiliary gymnasium of Columbia Universitylast night.

Authority to call a general strike, affecting all members of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union throughout Manhattan, was given to James J. Bambrick last night in a resolution adopted unani mously at a meeting of more than 1,000 members of the union at the Center Hotel, 108 West Forty-thirdStreet.
Joseph Jackson has placed a first mort gage of $130,000 at 5 per cent for five years with a savings bank covering the six-story apartment at 160B 117th St.,Rockaway Park, Queens.

Elisio Ballerini, commercial counselor of the Italian Embassy, entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room fo the Plaza. His guests were Mr. and Mrs. Raoul Grenade, Mr. and Mrs. Wather Becker, Mr. and Mrs. Jean Appert, Mr. and Mrs. Generoso Pope, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Burke, the Misses Genevieve and Sily McLean, Miss Marta Abba, Miss Betty Leon, Muzaffer Yesim, Toyoji Inouye, Ugo Martabito and Paulo Hasslocher.
Governor General Lord Tweedsmuir and Lady Tweedsmuir will visit Washington at the end of this month on the invitation ofPresident and Mrs. Roosevelt.

Failure of the New York Central Rail road to include provision for a sink ing fund in its proposal to issue $54,000,000 of bonds brought an in quiry today from Director Sweet of the Interstate Commerce Commis sion's Bureau of Finance as to thereasons for its omission.

The second series of wool auctions closed today. Offerings at today's session totaled 9,431 bales, including 2,50 from South America, of which 8,996 were sold. The series ended with a cheerful tone, competition beingspirited and prices firm.

The flotation of $130,000,000 of 8 1/2 per cent bonds of Philadelphia Electric Company lifted the volume of new bond financing this week to $135,594,250, compared with only $11,555,000 put on the market last week. This week a year ago $119, 227,000 in bonds was placed on themarket.
Seaplanes, canoes and launches were pressed into service today in a search for the Lufthansa mail plane Dalix, which crashed near here. All four aboard are believed to have been killed.

With total sales for the country ranging from 15 to 30 per cent above the volume in the correspond ing period last year, retail distribu tion this week reached peak levels for the year in most of the key cities, according to the review is sued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The British Government appointed one or its leading experts on naval affairs, Sir Robert Craigie, Under-Secretary of the Foreign Office, to be Ambas sador to Tokyo in the general re shuffle that has followed the trans fer of Sir Eric Phipps from Berlin to Paris and Sir Neville Meyrick Henderson from Buenos Aires toBerlin.

Reginald E. Dunne, who has a long record as a pickpocket, was indicted by the Federal grand jury yesterday for failure to pay income tax on a taxable income for 1934 estimated at $81,488.94. It was alleged he made a gross income of $90,542.78 that year, mainly as acard player.

Motor boats with engines installed which were exported from the United States in 1936 were valued at $705, 500, compared to a value of $705,996 for 1936 shipments, the Departmentof Commerce reported today.

Special Referee John P. Cohalan announced yesterday that he had completed his report on charges filed by the Bar Association against J. Richard Davis, attorney for the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Fleg enheimer and that it would be for warded to the Appellate Division along with a transcript of testimony taken in the proceeding. It is expected that the report will befiled Monday or Tuesday.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson today or dered striking truck drivers and teamsters of the municipal Depart ment of Public Works to return to their jobs tomorrow morning or be dismissed. He had threatened ear lier to operate the city's trucks under police guard.

Frederic Frazier, chairman of the board of the General Baking Corpo ration, was the final witness ex amined yesterday at the Federal Trade Commission's hearing into the complaint against Standard Brands, Inc., for alleged violation of price discrimination regulationsof the Robinson-Patman Act.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Boxing seems to be going to seed rapidly, what with fighters jumping contracts, refusing to defend their titles against worthy opponents and with crowns being declared forfeited or champions being named by vari ous boxing commissions without benefit of a blow struck or even aglove drawn on.

Mrs. Louise Marie collapsed from hunger just outside Mayor La Guardian's office in City Hall yes terday after she had gone there to complain about being dropped from the rolls of the Emergency ReliefBureau.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is re flected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State,now offered by dealers:

Edward K. White of Belmont, Mass., was elected captain of the Dartmouth swimming team at a meeting of the lettermen today. White, one of the East's outstand ing breast-stroke men, has been defeated only twice this Winter.

1st Lt. David Heller, Med.-Res., 318 Atkins A.V., Brooklyn, N. Y., unassigned, is or dered to active duty for a period of six months, effective March 12. He will pro ceed to headquarters, Binghamton District, CCC, Binghamton, N. Y., for assignment in connection with CCC activities. Lt. Heller will rank from March 12. 1st Lt. Milbert D. Dunlap, Engr.-Res., will proceed from CCC Co. 1277, Camp S-81(N.Y.).

Local fishermen went on a strike today in protest against a decline this week in the price paid for shad by dealers. A. L. Dixon, spokesman for the fishermen, said that no boats would go out untilthe price rose.
The Metropolitan Opera Associa tion has begun an intensive cam paign to rid itself of the sidewalk ticket speculators who ply their trade in front of the. theatre, itbecame known last night.

Miss Grace Sanderson, daughter of Mrs. Imogene Sanderson of this place, was married this evening to Benjamin B. Rice, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian A. Rice of Scarsdale, in the Church of St. James the Less. The Rev. Alan R. Chalmers officiated. The ceremony was fol lowed by a reception at the Sanderson home.

The strike of 300 clerks that closed all of the 115 news stands in the city-owned Independent Sub way System for nearly two days was effected late yesterday after noon through the good offices of Commissioner Frank X. Sullivan ofthe Board of Transportation.

The State Banking Department announced to day the filing with it of a verified certificate of conversion of $12,380 of preferred stock into common stock of the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York, reducing authorized preferred stock from $10,000,000, consisting of 500,000 shares, par value $20 a share, to $9,987,620, consisting of 499,381shares.

The testimony given before the Senate committee in behalf of the President's Supreme Court plan has raised one inescapable question. If the situnation is as alarming as the Government's witnesses say it is--if it is true, as Attorney General CUMMINGS says, that the court has been "encroaching

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, suffered a frac tured left collar bone while skiing yesterday at Calais, Vt. He was making a turn with Mrs. Conant when one ski broke through the crust of the snow and he pitchedforward on his shoulder.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent addresses of Mr. Roosevelt at his Victory Dinner, and later over-the radio to the pub lic in general, seem to be based upon diametrically opposed theories.

Cotton mill activity increased last week, at a time when a decline is seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced 5 1/2 points. The figure now is 136.5, as against 131.0 in the preceding week and 102.0 for theweek ended March 7, 1936.
Invitations have been issued by Mrs. Harry D. Egbert of this place for the wedding of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Egbert, to John Wal lace, son of Mr. and .Mrs. ChesterWallace, also of Westfield.

While the dollar value of retail sales in 1936 was 22.8 per cent be low the 1929 level, the volume of goods sold was only 3.9 per cent less, according to a study made by the National, Industrial Conference Board, the results of which wereannounced yesterday.

Automotive linage in newspapers will make a poor showing this year, if the current wave of strikes in the motor field keeps up, according to comment here yesterday. Just as the various divisions of-General Motors reinstated copy in newspapers throughout the country,

Stockholders of the Utah Apex Min ing Company voted here today to merge with the Utah Delaware Mining Company to form the Na tional Tunnel and Mines Company for operation of copper, lead andzinc mines in Utah and California.

General Francisco Franco's Span ish Insurgent forces now have reached open country in their thrust on Madrid from the north east. During the night they estab lished advanced posts beyond To rija, within about six and a half miles of Guadalajara. They have now debouched from the hills into the plains, where their mechanized forces and cavalry can be employedto full advantage.

Desperate and hungry for food, 300 Insurgents, their women and chil dren-besieged in a mountain sanc tuary for months-failed today in an attempt to raid a government food depot. Two government troopers were wounded in the fighting as theybeat back the Insurgents.

The 10,000-ton oil tanker Montana of the Wilhelmsen Line of Tons berg, Norway, in charge of Captain Haakon Skar, was refloated at high tide at 7:59 o'clock last night, an hour and a half after it went aground in the channel about 400feet off shore from Gulfport, S. I.

Fears that Westchester County residents might get "mining fever" and start turning up their front and back yards in search of feldspar or other valuable deposits were ex pressed here today in a suit over mineral rights in a residential zonein North Castle.

President Roosevelt's judiciary reorganization proposals were de bated in the Senate, with Senator Wheeler quoting statements made by President Roosevelt in 1933 that appointment of additional judges would not solve the prob lem of judicial efficiency, and Senator Norris advocating both legislative and constitutional remedies.
David Lloyd George, Great Britain's World War Prime Minister, angrily attacked the government today for neglecting the "weakest link" inits war defenses, its "food front."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 10: REAR ADMIRALS Anderson, W. S., Washington, D. C., to duty as commander of Cruiser Division 4, scouting force. Wainwright, J. D., Washington, D. C., to duty as commander of Battleship Division 3, battle force. CAPTAIN Baldwin, F., Newport, R. I., to Bureau of Supplies and Accounts, Washington, D. C.

Miss Marion Natalie Newfield, daughter of Albert Newfield and the late Mrs. Newfield of this city, became the bride today of Bernard John Grad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Grad of Newark. The cere mony was performed at the Tumble brook Country Club, Bloomfield, Conn, at noon by Rabbi AbrahamJ. Feldman.

The Inter national Non-Intervention Commit tee today constituted an "interna tional board for non-intervention in Spain." This new body will in the future be responsible for adminis tering the scheme of observation ofSpanish frontiers.

A reversal in the trend of unemployment during the Winter months has been disclosed by the Canadian Minis ter of Labor. Normally there is an increase from month to month dur ing the Winter season, but for the first time since the depression that condition has been reversed and the families on relief in February decreased 17 per cent under thefigures for January.

Lawson Little of San Francisco, former United States and British amateur champion and present Canadian open titleholder, shot an eagle 3 on the thirty-sixth hole as he andhis partner, Tony Manero of Salem.
The eight demands made by the United Auto mobile Workers of America when it began nation-wide strikes against the General Motors Corporation and the final settlement of them folllow:

Augustus Phelps Dunham, 28, of 39 East Fifty-first Street, New York City, was killed here this afternoon when his automobile skidded into an embankment on Wahackme Road and overturned. Witnesses said that the car was traveling downhill at high speed,with the horn pealing.
The Census Bureau announced today that cottonseed crushed in the seven-month period from Aug. 1 to Feb. 28 totaled 3,780,419 tons, compared with 3,283,214 in the sameperiod a year ago.

The annual report of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $447,758 after taxes and charges, including adjustment bond interest, against a net loss of $488,224 in the preceding year.

Joe Brown, former International League infielder, was named manager of the Rome Club in the Canadian American League today. Brown played eleven years in the International League with Reading, Newark, Syracuse, Buffalo and Toronto. He managed the Springfield (Mo.) Cardinals in the Western League in1936.
Tomorrow will be Harvard and Yale Day here, with the Crimson and Elis meeting in two important Win ter sports, swimming and basketball.

The forty-fourth anniversary of the founding of the Waldorf was celebrated last night at a dinner, entertainment and dance. The festivities opened with a dinner party in the Jade and Basildon Rooms of the Waldorf Astoria, with Lucius Boomer, presi dent of the Hotel Waldorf-AstoriaCorporation, as host.

Mayor La Guardia made a fast trip yesterday from Albany to his office. in City Hall, covering the 149 miles in three hours. Driven by John Peluso, his regular chauffeur, and accompanied by Lester Stone, his secretary, the Mayor left Albany at 10:05 A. M. and arrived at City Hall at 1:05P. M.

Charles S. Payson has been elect ed a director of the American Roll ing Mill Company, George M. Verity, chairman of the board, an nounced yesterday. Mr. Payson, who is in the finance and manage ment business at 120 Wall Street, and publisher of The Commentator, is a director of the Rustless IronCorporation of Baltimore.

Allen Ward Nagle, an actor, died of pneumonia yesterday at the Hos pital for Ruptured and Crippled, 321 East Forty-second Street. His home was the Hotel Flanders, 135 West Forty-seventh Street. He was44 years old.

President Kyosti Kallio's first Cabinet was formed tonight under the Premiership of Aimo Cajander, a Liberal. It is noteworthy because it marks the Socialists' return in strength to the government after ten years of absence, the latter years because of former President Pehr Evind Svinhufvud's antagonistic attitude toward them.

The purchase of $100,000 World's Fair debenture bonds by the Ladies Garment Workers Union is the more valued because it is labor's "handsel" (that is, "earnest money," or the first gift, or a gift of good omen) for the Fair. By this sign does labor handsel this great enterprise and so strengthenthe promise of its success.

The third annual conference of the Model Senate Association opened here today, with more than 100 dele gates from Eastern colleges attend ing. The need for trained men in the government was stressed by Professor DeWitt Clinton Poole, director of the Princeton School of Public and International Affairs, who was the principal speaker atthe dinner tonight at Princeton Inn.

Those Americans who nave a passion ate desire to know what their favorite authors eat for breakfast need not be vexed by the austere remarks of M. FERNAND VANDEREM in Candide. He is speaking of French writers who con sent to be interviewed to gratify thecuriosity of their public.
The Chief, the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway's best train be tween Chicago and Los Angeles, is to become a lightweight, stream lined unit, S. T. Bledsoe, president,announced yesterday.

Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco, who surprised the golfing world in 1934 when she went through to the last round of the United States women's championship on her first try, today demonstrated that her game is of top caliber when she fired sub-par golf in the final of the Belleview Biltmore champion ship to beat Miss Helen Dettweilerof Washington, 5 and 4.

Lawrence Tibbett, baritone of the Metropolitan Opera Association, was acclaimed by an audience at the Academy of Music this after noon when he appeared as soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting. Mr. Tibbett sang Mahler's "Songs of a Wayfarer" on the firstpart of the program.

Mrs. Julia Anna Toler de Pey ster, widow of Colonel Johnston Livingston de Peyster, died Thurs day at her home in Ridgefield, Conn., at the age of 91.- Mrs. de Peyster was the daughter of the late William Edward and Anna Lind Smith Toler. She was a mem ber of the National Society of Colonial Dames.

Lou Ambers will defend his light weight championship of the world against Tony Canzoneri on May 7, instead of on April 2, as originally planned. The postponement was agreed on yesterday when Sammy Goldman, Canzoneri's manager, re quested more time for his fighterto get into shape.

Charles Beetham, Ohio State's great foot racer, ran second to Mel Trutt, In diana sophomore, tonight in their qualifying heat for the 880-yard final of the Western Conference indoor title track meet, then was hustled to a hospital to receive medical attention for a heavy cold.

James G. Moore, special master, has filed a report on the general plan for the first-mortgage col lateral trust bonds, eighteenth se ries, of the Prudence Bonds Cor portion, totaling about $53,000,000. His report sustains the objections of the General Committee for Prudence Securities to the com pany's proposals, John R. Walsh, secretary of the committee, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Scottish Mary, after a rest since Feb. 16, when she was a galloping winner at Hialeah, returned to action fresh and fit today at Tropical Park and easily annexed the fea tured South Wind purse of six furlongs.

When Dr. JOHN L. TILDSLEY wakes this morning he will find himself 70 years of age, for he was born on the 13th of March in the year 1867. It was of a Wednesday and in Pitts burgh, but he barely escaped being born a Canadian, his parents having moved to Ontario but two months afterhis birth.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 6 amounted to 734, 127 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Many parties will be given at the "Davy Jones Locker" gala dinner dance tomorrow night at the Surf Club. Mr. and Mrs. Byron S. Miller of New York will be among those hav ing large dinner groups for the dance. Others entertaining include Mr. and Mrs. Ritner Walling of Philadelphia and Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Breyer Jr. of Philadelphia.

An audience of 6,000 persons at the County Center tonight heard Nelson Eddy in a concert which marks the end of the current series presented by Mrs. Julian Olney. It was the largest paid audience ever assembled at the County Center,according to estimate.

The strike movement spread from in dustrial districts here to Loop sky scrapers today. More than 9,000 men and women, including waitresses, candy makers, cab drivers, clerks, peanut baggers, stenographers, tailors, truckers,factory hands,

More than 14,000,000 persons will attend conventions in the United States and Canada during 1937, according to a survey just completed by World Convention Dates, monthly publication in the convention-hotel field. Their expenditures, conservatively estimated,

Officials of the Chrysler Corporation, who were forced to establish temporary exec utive offices in a downtown office building after being put out of their own offices in one of the corpora tion plants now held by sit-down strikers, revealed today that they could not make up payrolls for back pay due up to the time of thestrike.

St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn showed the most strength yester day in the Columbia University pool as qualifying heats for the Athletic Association of Private Schools swimming championships reducedthe large entry.

RELIGIOUS TRADITION AND MYTHS,by Erwin R. Goodenough. (Yale Uni versity Press, $1.50.) Dr. Good enough opens with the statement that the world's intellectuals are in an unstable and untenable position.

Lutheran Bishops and the Confessional Synods, representing probably 90 per cent of the orthodox Protes tants, today published a proclama tion advising that the existing Ger man Protestant Church be split into two distinct religious bodies-one primarily Christian and the otherprimarily Nationalist.
John Weigan, 21, sat in a cell today trying to think up a new twist for a sit-down strike which would bring a reconciliation with hiswife, Elizabeth, 20.

Earl Averill, Indians' outfielder, announced tonight that he would sign tomorrow one of two 1937 con tracts offered him by Alva Bradley, club president, and leave Sunday for the Tribe's New Orleans train ing camp. The holdout ended when Bradley informed Averill he could take his choice between a straight $16,000 salary and a $15,000 contract with a $2,000 bonus clause.

Harold Brooks, director of Brooks Brothers, New York clothing mer chants, died today of heart disease at his home here. Mr. Brooks, who was 52 years old, had been retired from active participation in the af fairs of his concern for several years and had interested himself in managing his large apple orchard inNova Scotia.

The Yugoslav National Bank issued regulations considerably re ducing exports to Germany during March and April with the object of reducing the German frozen debt from approximately $8,000,000 to$6,000,000.

Commodity futures were irregular on the local markets yesterday. Profit-taking appeared in silk, world sugar, coffee, zinc and cottonseed oil futures, while rubber, copper, fin, hide, cocoa, domestic sugar andwool top futures advanced.

Three Democratic Senators, David I. Walsh of Massachusetts, Edward R. Burke of Nebraska and Royal S. Copeland of New York, joined here last night in an attack on President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganizethe United States Supreme Court.

Sales of multi-family buildings in Manhattan yesterday included a deal for the five-story walk-up at 17 to 23 Post Avenue, just north of Dyckman Street, which was bought by Morris Luskin, operator, from aclient of Morris and Samuel Meyers,

Without a record vote the House has passed the Guffey-Vinson Coal Bill. The original Guffey Coal Act was de clared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court a year ago. The court's decision applied particularly to the wages .andhours regulations.

On the eve of launching the annual Spring exhibition campaign here, the Yankee training camp to day was heartened by good news from the front office. Joe DiMaggio, sensational young Coast outfielder who made good with such emphasis last year in his first term as amajor leaguer, signed a contract.

Dr. Alice Ida Bernheim; daughter of Mrs. Isaac J. Bernheim and the late Mr. Bernheim, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother, 31 West Eighty-fifth Street, to Dr. Abraham Penner, sonof Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Penner.
A month and a day after General Motors Corporation employes went back to work, company officials and union representatives tonight reached a final agreement on the strike settlement.
Joe Lordi of the home club gained the remaining bracket in the quar ter final round of the national am ateur squash tennis championship yesterday at the New York AthleticClub.

Stephen Fuguet, a tool manufactur er and former banker, died of a heart attack in Jacksonville, Fla., today as he was returning to his home in Devon, near here. He was 60 years old. Mr. Fuguet became president of the Dallett company, maker of pneumatic tools, in 1923 when he resigned his membership in the investment banking house ofC. C. Harrison Jr. Co.

Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. was summoned before the local laws committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday to explain his policy on licensing peddlers for street pushcart markets.

Regulation of the house trailer, which is a "rapidly developing prob lem" because 75,000 trailers will be purchased this year, bringing to 375,000 the number used for homes, was asked yesterday by Assembly man Harold C. Ostertag, chairman of the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Coopera tion, at the opening of a nine-State regional conference on highwaysafety.

The stocks net estate of Colonel Edward H. R. Green, calculated to be $42,348, 500, would fall more than $2,000, 000 short of meeting all the inheri tance tax claims, according to a schedule filed in the Supreme Court today by William McCraw, Attorney General of Texas.

Patrick J. Delaney, a lawyer and for many years a member of the Cambridge City Council, died early today at his home in Cambridge at the age of 53. Mr. Delaney was called the "stormy petrel" of Cambridge pol itics. He studied law at nights whileconducting a small grocery store.

Allen Throop, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Com mission, and other officials of the Washington and New York offices are to attend a farewell dinner for William W. Prager, assistant gen eral counsel in charge of the legal enforcement staff of the New York office, on Monday night at Robert'sRestaurant.

Frank Iannicelli, young New York Athletic Club star, yesterday won the national Class C squash tennis championship when he defeated A. K. Marckwald, a pupil of his broth er Tommy at the Short Hills Club, in three straight games on the Har vard Club courts. The score was15-5, 15-11, 15-9.

The Salle D'Armes Vince trio of the Misses Marion Lloyd, Madeline Dalton and Maria Cerra handed the New York University women's fencing team its initial setback in four starts this season by a 9-0 count at the winners' strips lastnight.

In the Su preme Court of the United States the fol lowing proceedings were had today: Original; State of Texas, complainant, v. State of New York, et al. Motion for leave to file bill of complaint submittedfor the complainant.

Secretary Perkins was informed today that James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., would confer with her here Thurs day on renewal of negotiations with the Office Equipment Workers Council, whose Remington Randworkers went on strike last May.

Blair Academy's powerful swim ming team romped off with the New Jersey prep school swimming championship at the Newark Ath letic Club pool tonight by compiling a point total of 68. The Lawrence ville natators were second with 35and Hun School was third with 24.

Manager Bill Terry of the Giants, who ever since L?? has been spin ning around like a pinwheel in his attitude toward his own playing ac tivities for this year, came up with another decision today when he stated he would retain his presentplayer status until May 15.

The bituminous industry's wage conference shifted suddenly from the Hotel Biltmore to the Engineers Club, ,29 West Thirty-ninth Street, after John L. Lewis and other rep resentatives of the United Mine Workers learned that the fu migators union was picketing thehotel.
Quite without reference to the new president of the University of Wisconsin, one recalls that his predecessor,GLENN FRANK,

Assignments of claims and notes made for the purpose of institut ing lawsuits were declared illegal by the Appellate Division in a four-to-one decision handed down yesterday in a test case brought by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. at the request of the New YorkCounty Lawyers Association.

A new suit has been entered against Floyd B. Odlum, president, and other directors of the Atlas Corporation, charging that they wasted the assets of a subsidiary. This development was disclosed yesterday when those named as the defendants filed a motion in Supreme Court to have the complaint dismissed.

The State rested its case at noon yesterday against six defendants in Bronx County Court who are charged with second-degree man slaughter as a result of the collapse of the apartment building at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South in which eighteen workmen werekilled last June 19.

Mrs. Isabel Blumen stein of this town, died of a heart attack last night, two weeks after the death of Otto Schymik, tax collector, whom she succeeded on Tuesday. She was 34 years old. Mrs. Blumenstein was deputytax collector here for fifteen years.

According to The Daily Ex press, the Duke of Windsor is considering writing his memoirs in a non-political and non-con troversial vein covering the pe riod from 1900 to 1930. Publica tion plane, The Express says, al ready have been fully discussed and the Duke has sent to Lon don for personal papers and photographs taken on many tours.

Follow ing is the text of the compact made today between General Motors and the C. I. O. Union: [Agreement entered into this.. day of March, 1937, between Gen eral Motors Corporation, herein after referred to as the corporation and the International Union.
An increase of 1.8 per cent in employment and of 2.1 per cent in payrolls was noted in factories of the State from the middle of January to the middle ofFebruary, Elmer F. Andrews.
Appoint ment of Thomas A. Murray of New York City as a member of the State Board of Housing was an nounced today by Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, with the approval of Governor Lehman.

The New York Rovers sub dued the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 6-3, tonight in an Eastern Ama teur Hockey League game. The Rovers scored three goals before the Sea Gulls managed to tally near the end of the middle period. New York promptly came back with another goal, and thelast period was split, 2 and 2.

As an aftermath of last year's in ternal strife in the International Seamen's Union, the "new deal" faction in the Marine Firemen, Oil ers and Water Tenders Union insti tuted suit yesterday in the Supreme Court to make their union com pletely autonomous. If they are successful it was indicated they would sever existing relations with the American Federation of Labor and join the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Mrs. Nellie Fairchild of 1,809 Al bemarle Road, Brooklyn, died in a hospital here early today of injuries suffered in an automobile accident yesterday. She was a passenger on a world tour of the Canadian Pa cific liner Empress of Britain. Mrs. Fairchild was the widow of Marcus D. Fairchild, who died in1923.

A drive to raise $750,000 to pro vide retirement annuities for fac ulty members of Phillips Andover Academy was begun last night at a dinner under the auspices of the New York Alumni Association of the academy at the Hotel Roosevelt. About 600 alumni attended.

Governor Gordon Browning of Tennessee will visit this city next week to complete details of a debt reorganization program for the State prepared by Norman S. Taber Co., consultants on municipalfinance.

FELIX RIESENBERG has had an exciting life, and of the three autobiographies under con sideration today his will probably appeal to the largest number of readers. In almost any com pany, for that matter, it would stand out, for the author has not only a good story to tell but anunusual knack for telling it.

Samuel Krulewitch, retired build er and former Republican politi cian, died last night of heart dis ease at his home, 200 West Eighty sixth Street. He was 66 years old. He had been a builder and real es tate operator on the West Side and elsewhere in Manhattan for fortyyears.

Members of the New York Police Department Holy Name Society from branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond will attend in a body the 8 A. M. mass tomorrow in St. Patrick's Cathedral and re ceive Holy Communion. The cele brant of the mass will be CardinalHayes.

Commercial life is greatly disturbed by the registration here of the "Civil Service Association," a cooperative body which includes about 5,500 civil servants and government railway workers. Its plans are said to encompass cooperative stores, insurance and other services. Thecapital is reported to be $8,000,000.

Samuel Krulewitch, retired build er and former Republican politi cian, died last night of heart dis ease at his home, 200 West Eighty sixth Street. He was 66 years old. He had been a builder and real es tate operator on the West Side and elsewhere in Manhattan for fortyyears.
