Its plans are said to encompass cooperative stores, insurance and other services. Thecapital is reported to be $8,000,000.

Department stores here received several notifications yesterday from drug and cosmetic manufacturers of the establishment of suggested minimum retail prices under the provisions of the Feld-Crawford Resale Price Maintenance Law.

Three properties in the Park Slope section changed hands in trades in Brooklyn real estate, brokers reported yesterday. J. A. Rosenthal purchased for in vestment from the estate of Henry Kern, in the first sale of the prop erty in forty-five years, the five family apartment at 78 Seventh Avenue, on the corner of Berkeley Place.

The list of the Grace Line motorship Santa Barbara, leaving today for Ecuador, Peru and Chile, includes: Mr. and Mrs. Cyril von Baumann, Carl de Muralt, Miss Barbara Fischer, M. J. Tobin, Mrs. Edith L. Strongman, Robert Turner, Mr. and Mrs. Earl B. B. Tussing, B. M. Meador, H. C. Bickel, Mr. and Mrs. James W. Richards and Fred Newberry.

Members of the Board of Esti mate who met at City Hall yester day to consider the $278,394,140 cap ital outlay budget for 1937 were be sieged with requests from taxpay ers for subway extensions, schoolsand hospital facilities.
Glenn Cunningham got back on the win ning side of the mile-running ledger tonight by taking the Eaton Mile, feature of the annual Maple Leaf indoor track meet, in the slow timeof 4:18.2.

Mayor La Guardia has failed thus far.to find a sponsor in the Legislature for his bill which would permit New York City to build a municipal power plant, designed for use as a "yard stick" to bring about a reductionin electric rates.

The International Paper and Power Company filed today with the Secu rities and Exchange Commission an application under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 for a hearing on a plan of recapitalization.

A lively demand for store space by retail businesses featured the brokers' reports of leasing activity yesterday. Chain store concerns took space for new units on theWest Side and in Long Island City.

The City College wrestling team gained the metropolitan title by defeating Brooklyn College, 24 to 10, on the latter's mats last night. Abe Luft of the losers sustained his first defeat of the campaign when he bowed to Henry Wittenberg of the Lavender in 2:09 on time advantage in the 175-pound test.
Charles Widor, former director of the American Conservatory of Music at Fontainebleau, died today at the age of 93. He was a composer of symphonies, concertos and othermusical works.

Stocks closed firmer at lower levels after early heaviness; utility shares weak; turnover, 2,289,940 shares. United States Government bonds weak in heaviest trading since 1920; other issues lower; transactions, $35,199,200.

Keglers from the Pastime A. C. of Syracuse sent the tenpins flying with amazing consistency to sweep into the lead in the five-man team division as competitors in the thirty seventh annual American Bowling Congress entered the fourth day of maple crashing in the refur bished 212th Coast Artillery Armoryearly today.

Deaths Announced Fireman first grade George F. Blair of Engine 26 died March 10. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 116-46 222d St., St. Albans, Queens, at 2 P. M. Satur day, March 13. Interment at Cedar GroveCemetery, Flushing, Queens.

The League of Nations committee for the study of raw materials adjourned to June 21 after arranging to continue its inquiry meanwhile, and adopting Its report. This report begins by Stressing that it is not the committee's function "to discuss the distribution of territories whence raw materials are drawn."

Three Western Conference records were bettered and another tied as Michigan's swimmers set the pace in the qualifying rounds of the twenty-seventh annual cham pionships today. The Wolverines placed fourteen in the finals tomorrow night.

As part of refinancing to reduce the funded debt and fixed inter est of the Pittsburgh Coke and Iron Company, Hemphill, Noyes Co. and associates offered yesterday for the company $3,000,000 of con vertible first mortgage 4 1/2% per cent Series A bonds due in 1952, at 101; 15,000 shares of $5 no-par preferred stock, at $98.50, and 40,000 shares of no-par common stock, at $11 ashare.

Premier Benito Mussolini, on his first visit. to Libya in ten years, ar rived late today at this sun-baked city, that scene. of one of the most daring adventurs in United States history. He came here from Tobruk, where he was officially welcomed to Ital ian North Africa by Marshal ItaloBalbo, Governor of Libya.
The Portland Evening Express: says a group of New England busi ness interests, including some from Maine, have purchased virtual control of the Maine Central Railroad.

Mrs. Ida Goepp Pierson, for forty years a Presbyterian missionary in Japan, died at her home here today in her seventy-fifth year. Born in Easton, she was grad uated in 1883 from Normal College, now Hunter College, in New York and then entered the missionaryfield. She began tb teach in St.

The most mobile fleet in the history of the British Empire was envisaged in naval quarters tonight in the light of Sir Samuel Hoare's restatement of British naval policy in the Houseof Commons yesterday.

The Brooklyn club today nipped the career of a budding politician but insured itself the services of an excellent first baseman when that sterling young Bronx Demo crat, J. Aloysius Hassett, better known as Buddy, signed his contract.

Princess Daria Obolensky, daugh ter of Prince and Princess Alexis Obolensky of this city and a mem ber of one of the oldest houses of the former Russian nobility, was married yesterday afternoon to Hans George Spitzer of this city in the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour, Madison Avenueand 121st Street.

With her chance for survival still "very slight," a tiny girl baby, be lived one of the smallest ever born here, was still clinging to life last night in her glass-enclosed crib at the Park East Hospital, 112 EastEighty-third Street.

With the giant Zeppelin Hindenburg proceed ing at full speed, Colonel Ernst Udet, Germany's crack stunt flier, alighted several times on the air ship's substructure with his Focke Wulf plane today while thousands cheered up and down the countryside.

President Roosevelt arrived at his "other home" here at 9:30 o'clock this morning by special train rom Washington and slipped at once into a life of easy informality far different from that of the WhiteHouse.

Prelinary reports from Class I rail roads which normally account for more than 80 per cent of the operat ing revenues of such carriers show operating revenues for February to taling $259,228,638, compared with $244,509,004 for the same month last year and $341,232,821 for the same period of 1930, the Association ofAmerican Railroads reported today.

The Commercial Bulletin will say to morrow: "There is a better tone in the wool market again this week, chiefly in the pulled and scoured wool section of the market, but allholders of wool are more confident.

The city's housing project at 124 East Third Street, constructed with Federal funds and opened more than a year ago, has been 150 per cent successful, Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, told a group on a tour of slum areas yesterday. The tour was under the auspices of the City Affairs Committee.

The sophomore class of the University Heights center of New York University held its annual dance at the Hotel Astor last night. Approximately 125 couples attended. Invited guests included Dean and Mrs. Irving H. Berg of the University College of Arts and Pure Science,
Notre Dame's high-powered basketball team defeated the University of De troit, 36-18, tonight to close its season with a record of twenty victories in twenty-three starts.

Reporting the largest earnings in ten years and a new high record for gross income, the Phillips Petroleum Company showed yester day for 1936 a net profit of $17,875, 489 after Federal income taxes, in terest, intangible development costs, depletion, lease amortization, depre ciation, retirement and othercharges.
The body of Mrs. Hale Holden Jr., a prominent member of Main Line so ciety, was found hanging from a hook on the door of a bathroom of her home in Haverford this evening.

Brown, Tufts and Yale led the qualifiers into the finals of the New England intercollegiate wrestling championships at the Payne Whit ney Gynasium tonight. Brown University, the defending titleholder, sent six men into thefinals.

James A. Reed, former Democratic Senator from Missouri, who cam paigned last year against President Roosevelt, described the President's Supreme Court revision proposal as "tyranny" in a Civic Club speechtoday.
A Bronx transaction was reported by Pease Eliman, Inc., who sold for the New York 'State Teachers' Retirement System the five-story apartment house for thirty-twofamilies at 654 East 227th Street.

Frank Gonzalez and Italo Orio of the New York A. C. annexed met ropolitan junior wrestling cham pionships at the Vassa Castle Hall in the Bronx last night. Gonzalez won the 158-pound title, while Oriotook the 191-pound crown.

Dr. Frederick Julius Gaenslen, or thopedic surgeon, died--here last night. He was 59 years old. Dr. Frederick Julius Gaenslen was born in Milwaukee in 1877, the son of Julius and Mathilda Hummel Gaenslen. He was graduated from Wisconsin University in 1899, got his medical degree at Johns Hop kins in 1903 and studied for oneyear at Harvard.
Bodies of three men and two wo men, fatally burned in a truck auto crash, lay in Orange County mortuaries today. The two vehi cles crashed late yesterday at Sycamore Grove in Santa Ana Canyon.

Beginning Tuesday the Board of Transportation will confer with representatives of each of ten clas sifications of workers on the city's Independent Subway System, in an effort to reach agreement on a new set of wage scales and a readjust ment of working hours and conditions.
Alfred P. (Fish) Murrah, 33 years old, who rode into Oklahoma City on a box car eighteen years ago, became the youngest Federaljudge today.
North China is watching with in tense interest and some hope the renewal of Japanese overtures to Nanking and the friendlier utterances in Tokyo.

Mr. and Mrs. Vincent S. Mulford entertained with a dinner tonight at the Everglades Club for Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Durell of New York who arrived today from Nassau to be their overnight guests at Brazilian Court.

Mrs. J. West Roosevelt and her granddaughter, Mrs. Robert J. Bulkley Jr., will leave today for Charleston, S.C. They expect to return early next month.

Columbia and Cornell brought their basketball seasons to a close last night with the Lions defeating the Ithacans, 50--37, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. By its victory the Blue moved into a tie with Yale for third place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

The new quarters of the New York University Division of General Education at 20 Washington Square North will be opened with informal exercises on Friday evening, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University announced yesterday.
EDELSTEIN, SADIE (March 6). Estate, less than $10,000. To Alex Edelstein, husband, executor, 455 W. 34th St., residue; Esther Margowitz, New Rochelle, $3,000.

Another in their series of yachting parties will be given tomorrow by Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Spaulding of Greenwich, Conn., aboard their yacht Content. They will go with their guests to the Surf Club for the cocktail party Mr. and Mrs. Ross Beason of New York are giving there.

A maddened ox narrowly missed Premier Benito Mussolini with its horns today as it broke loose from its cart during a procession in the village of Luigi Razza. A crowd of colonists, gathered to welcome the Premier on his tour of Italy's North African dominions, was thrown into brief panic.

IT'S a long way from here to Liverpool, and fifteen minutes more to Aintree, but the mind wanders now and then, and this is Grand National Week all the way from Land's End to John o' Groat's, which pretty much covers the length of the British Isles.

The further rise in the price of wheat this week has been brought on largely by speculation. Heavy arrivals of Argentine wheat in Europe usually have a depressing effect at this time of the year, but the .Continental European demand has been strongly maintained, Germany being a particularly large buyer, while British millers, who hitherto had been holding off, again have entered the market with big orders.

The Daily Pennsylvanian, student newspaper at the University of Pennsylvania, in a copyrighted dispatch tonight from Washington states that a group of Senators and Representatives commended its editorial attacking the satirical "Roosevelt for King" movement, originating at Yale College, as in bad taste and disrespectful to the President and his family.

Newsprint production by Canadian mills in February was 275,532 tons, compared with 287,691 in the longer month of January and 221,569 tons in February, 1936. Canada's output in the first two months of 1937 increased by 25 per cent from that for January and February of last year.

Very much in the manner of their Dutch predecessors here, who often passed the Sabbath in a game of skittles on the bowling green, the current crop of keglers devoted their day of rest to the fifth session of the thirty-seventh annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress yesterday.

Dr. Herman Jarecky of 151 West Eighty-sixth Street, a specialist in diseases of the ear and throat, died yesterday in the New York Hospital after a short illness. He was one of the founders of the Sydenham Hospital and for many years had been an attending surgeon and a consulting otolaryngologist on its staff.

Harlem isn't Harlem any more. Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio gave that opinion yesterday upon finding that there was not a prisoner to face him and that it was possible for justice to take a holiday in Harlem court.

Reversing the custom of having outstanding business women address them at special functions, business women of the city today start a five-day program of visits to repretentative women at their work. The program is sponsored by the New York League of Business and Professional Women in observance of National Business Women's Week.

Expressing the hope that the city will proceed with the project without delay, the West Side Association of Commerce announced yesterday its approval of the plan of the Department of Public Markets for a group of wholesale meat buildings on Gansevoort Farmers Square in the Fourteenth Street section of the West Side.
The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed by Artur Rodzinski, presented an all-Russian program at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon twenty-four hours after the Boston Symphony had done likewise.

Lyndon G. Tuthill of New Suffolk, Southold Town Republican leader, died last night at the Eastern Long Island Hospital, Greenport, L. I., at the age of 34. Descendant of an old Long Island family, Mr. Tuthill was vice president of the First National Bank of Cutchogue, L. I., and managing director of Goldsmith Tuthill.

Holders of oats futures took advantage of the few upturns in prices to sell all that buyers would take here early last week. Later, when other grains broke, oats buyers were less anxious for supplies and, with increased selling pressure, prices weakened and the May delivery, after a range of 3 1/2 cents, closed at 46 5/8 cents a bushel, a net decline of 1/8 cent for the week.

Giving a superb exhibition of ski technique, the 22-year-old Austrian ace, Miss Elfriede (Micky) Pembauer, .ran away with the three titles at stake in the annual women's Canadian skiing championships today.

Man's worst sin is "the spirit of selfish independence," the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Episcopal Church, 174th Street and Broadway, said in his sermon last night. Dr. Reisner sought the opinions of newspaper editors, reporters, lawyers, business men and others regarding the worst sin today.

Announcement was made here today by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marshall Price of the Coconut Grove colony, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louisa Bryan Price, to Roger Sherman Robinson of New Haven, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hollister Robinson of that city. The wedding will take place here in June.

Miss Analia Morosini, last surviving child of Giovanni Morosini Sr., who fought with the Italian patriot Garibaldi and who made more than $10,000,000 with Jay Gould, died yesterday morning at her home, 635 Riverside Drive, of heart disease. She was born on Staten Island seventy-one years ago.

Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 88 per cent of capacity, up 2 points in the week. Some operating schedules prepared before the opening of the week were revised upward.

Entering on the last official week of Winter, the art world finds no let-up in pace. Some thirty exhibitions are on the calendar, three of the museums taking the lead with important and diverse events scheduled.

Eight passengers rescued from the blazing British freighter Silverlarch paid an unscheduled visit to Honolulu tonight, arriving on an American man-of-war that picked them up in a heavy sea yesterday after a high-speed run.

The University of Pennsylvania basketball team, undefeated champion of the Eastern Intercollegiate League, was the only quintet to place two men on the all-league five which will be released simultaneously tomorrow morning by the sports editors of the seven "Ivy League" daily newspapers.
The setback administered to Rebel forces on the Guadalajara front during the last three days has assumed large proportions, according to official reports received here.

The securities markets here this week were quiet. Main interest on the Boerse was the buying up of foreign securities by the Reichsbank, but there was some irregular speculation in dollar loans as a result of the Conversion Office's issue of 3 per cent funding bonds against interest coupons not transferred.
The government is to protect adequately the conflicting interests involved, the sugar program now before Congress must be- passed, Secretary Wallace declared in a statement today.
At a dinner today given in honor of Premier Milan Hodza by the association of Czech journalists, the Premier outlined the progress of his reconciliation measures with the German minority.

Soy bean futures here had a range of 2 cents last week with a lighter volume of business. At the close, May beans were $1.53 1/2 a bushel, a gain of 1/8 cent over the previous week, while the July position finished at $1.50, a net decline of 1/4 cent.

Discovery of gold gems and vessels hidden by the Prince of Megiddo fourteen centuries before the birth of Christ when invaders threatened his stronghold was announced today by the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago after receipt of a cablegram by Dr. John A. Wilson, director of the institute, from Gordon Loud, director of the institute's Megiddo expedition.

Charles M. Higgins, formerly a vice president and director of the Standard Oil Company of New York, died Saturday at the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-sixth Street and Park Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 80 years old.
Charles A. Ellis, manager of famous opera stars and the first manager of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, died today at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, where he had been making his home. He was 81 years old.

A milk price war in New York City, which will reduce the cost of milk to consumers by 2 or 3 cents a quart, was predicted tonight at the Capitol in the event that the State's present price-fixing law is dropped on March 31.

Two months ago, following the decision of the Supreme Court upholding the Ashurst-Sumners act, a committee of the American Bar Association, Dr. NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER and others urged that the child labor problem could be dealt with by the same type of legislation as that used in the case of prison-made goods.

The many charitable projects of the Near East Foundation will be aided by a card party and tea to be held April 8 in the Garden of the Ambassador. Miss Beatrice A. Gordon-Smith heads the group in charge of the arrangements for the benefit.

Marse Joe McCarthy tossed three of his young right-hand pitchers against as many of Bill McKechnie's today at Waterfront Park and before a crowd of slightly more than 2,000 the Yanks romped off with their second straight triumph over the Bees. The final count was 8 to 1.

Sympathetic observers watch with quickened hearts the resurgence and mounting moral grandeur of the Republican party in this State and these diggings. In the State it has been liberalized. In this town it is ascending

The Society of St. Vincent de Paul in the Diocese of Brooklyn dis avowed yesterday the statement presented to the governing board of the ERB on Saturday by Robert P. Lane executive director of the Welfare Council, who told the board that the Brooklyn society and nine other welfare organizations had endorsed the declaration. The state.

The Manchester (N. H.) Union takes pride in calling attention to the fact that while 45,000,000 Americans are out of the reach of library service, this will stir only academic interest in New Hampshire, for despite its small population (and in some measure because of it) the State has 3,570 volumes per thousand of population.

When I heard the wood thrush singing, Song so tender, sweet and clear; When I heard the cardinal calling As he called of yesteryear, "Heart," I said, "why beat so loudly? Bird song cannot bring him here." But it did-- It brought him here.

Some attention has been paid over the week-end to the twelve-page German note on the possibilities of framing a substitute for the lapsed Locarno treaty and to the Italian coordinate note of almost equal length.

Charlie Hutter, the Olympic swimmer who led Harvard's team to victory over Yale on Saturday night when the Elis' long string of triumphs extending over thirteen seasons was snapped, finished in first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League individual scoring.

A field goal in the final 30 seconds of an overtime period gave the Mohawks of Amsterdam, N. Y., a 34-to-33 victory over a quintet from Cowley, Wyo., and provided a thrilling opening for the men's national A. A. U. basketball championship tournament today.
Alwyn Ball Jr., real estate operator and religious leader in New York, died suddenly this afternoon from a heart attack in his home here, 74 Eastwood Street. He was in his seventy-eighth year.

Congregation Shaare Zedek, 212 West Ninety-third Street, began a week of celebration of its 100th anniversary last night with a rededication of its temple. Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, asked that the congregation continue the active support it has given in the past to the seminary, which has trained its rabbinate for the past thirty-five years.

An earthquake at 7:50 A. M. today sent Taltal's population scurrying into the streets in a panic. There were no casualties, but a number of buildings were damaged and several walls collapsed. Communications with the interior were interrupted.
Andre Gide's "Return from the U. S. S. R.," a record of his impressions and observations during a trip he made through Soviet Russia, is announced by Alfred A. Knopf for publication in late April.

Six hundred employes of the Bigelow-Sanford carpet mills voted today to reject the company's wage and hour agreement, advanced last week. The employes authorized Francis Benware, organizer of Local 2,337, United Textile Workers of America, a C. I. 0. unit, to carry their request to company officials tomorrow.

Today is the last day for the filing of federal income tax returns. Returns accompanied by at least one-fourth of the amount due must be in the offices of the collectors of internal revenue not later than midnight. Failure to file on time will result in penalties.

The week's stock market opened more active and slightly firmer with the main interest in textiles, chemicals and commercial banks. Thereafter trading turned dull and irregular, a situation aggravated by difficulties of a minor bank in Duesseldorf.

Tribute was paid yesterday to Dr. Stephen S. Wise on the occasion of his sixty-third birthday, which comes on Wednesday, and the fifteenth anniversary of his founding of the Jewish Institute of Religion. The institute marked both events with a luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

Mrs. Nellie Irene Bates Fairbanks, wife of Wilson L. Fairbanks, editor of telegraph news of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died here this afternoon at her home, 125 Pennington Avenue, after a long illness, at the age of 72.

Offering will be made today by R. K. Webster Co., Inc., of a refunding issue of $1,067,000 of sevenyear, optional three years, 3 per cent bonds of the San Antonio Joint Stock Land Bank of San Antonio, Texas, at 101 1/2, to yield approximately 2.50 per cent.

Sport's Peerless Pride, setter dog owned and handled by Louis M. Bobbitt of Winston-Salem, N. C., captured the quail championship of the amateur field trial clubs of America today at Camp Lee, near here. Pride ran a brilliant two-hour heat, scoring five finds, to top a record-breaking field of forty-nine dogs.

Miss Isabel Livingston Fountain, daughter of Mrs. Livingston Fountain of 1,000 Park Avenue and Quogue, L. I., and the late Mr. Fountain, has completed plans for her marriage to George Frederick Brackett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Brackett of Ridgewood, N. J., and Lewisfield Plantation, Oakley, S. C., which will take place the afternoon of April 24 in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Cupid's arrows flew thick and fast into the ranks of airline stewardesses during the last week and proved so effective that six from one company alone decided to give up the skyways for love.

DAVOS, Switzerland, March 14.A new name burst into the world's skiing firmament today. It is a local lad's and, from its English sound, stamps him as a predestined winner. The name is Beat Ruedi, yes Beat, and it is not a nickname.
A fire of unknown origin completely destroyed the quartermaster's storehouse at the Corozal army post last night. The loss was estimated over $75,000. The post fire fighters,
David H. Clark, Los Angeles attorney who has been missing for several weeks, telephoned his wife in Los Angeles today and apparently settled his immediate financial difficulties.

Mayor Clare W. H. Bangs, public utility baiter, who has been behind jail bars since July 6, 1936, for contempt of court, declared today that he was "not giving up the fight for municipal electricity," although he had ordered that 684 private and commercial consumers be disconnected from the municipal power plant.

Richard Van Dine, recording secretary and archivist of the American Society of Magicians and an enthusiastic amateur magician for nearly half a century, died yesterday at his home, 230 Union Street, Jersey City, after an illness of eleven days. He had been active until recently, and had expected to celebrate his ninety-third birthday tomorrow.

With the murder of three Jews in Northern Palestine early this morning in addition to the killing of two Jewish shepherds by Arabs yesterday a most critical situation has been created here. The Jews in the Valley of Jezreel are beginning to lose faith in the government's ability to protect them.

Christianity preaches that life is a human drama which must fulfill itself in a moral victory, Canon T. Guy Rogers, rector of St. Martin's Church, Birmingham, England, said in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Excellent order and reorder activity in ready-to-wear and accessories was reported in the wholesale market here last week, as preEaster consumer buying increased. In the dress market, ensembles of all types moved actively, and there was a good demand for sheer afternoon dresses, formals, bridal and graduation types.

The Rev. Ellis B. Burgess, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, dedicated the new St. John's Lutheran Church of Merrick today. The church has been organized as a religious body for twenty years.

With a fine easterly breeze under an overcast sky, twenty-four sailing dinghies were out today in the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Arthur Knapp and Dick Hill shivered out top scores in Classes B and X through six races.

Turning back the Modern Chess Club by the score of 6 1/2-3 1/2 in the fifth round at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club, the Marshall team gained its fourth consecutive victory to retain the lead in the annual championship competition of the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday.

The work of the women's field army of the American Society for the Control of Cancer will benefit by a card party to be held under the auspices of the organization tomorrow afternoon in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. Mrs. Herbert Parsons is chairman of the event and Mrs. James M. D. Worrall vice chairman.

Despite favorable conditions in tramp steamer trade, the merchant marines of the world are not showing satisfactory earnings commensurate with their possibilities, according to a statement made yesterday by Paul Broszio, German shipping expert of Hamburg, after a survey in Continental ports and Great Britain.

Following a strong German Government protest against the Yugoslav National Bank's proposal to reduce exports to Germany by 50 per cent until the end of April in order to reduce the steadily accumulating frozen credits in Germany, the Yugoslav Government decided today to make no reduction at present.
The German official broadcast from Berlin reported yesterday in a Salamanca dispatch the retreat of the Spanish Rebels on the Guadalajara front. The broadcast follows:

Molinard, Inc., has been formed to distribute Molinard French perfumes in this country. Edmond Grunig, who was vice president and general sales manager of Pierre Amouroux, Inc., which formerly handled the products here, will have a similar position with the new organization.

Country holders of cash corn took advantage here last week of the sharp upturn in prices to make fair sales for shipment to consuming markets. There were times when prices receded with wheat, and then rallied with the latter grain.

The possibility of a strike of the operating employes of the city's Independent Subway System in the near future troubled city officials last night as union leaders issued a call for a mass meeting to discuss recent refusals by Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Transportation to heed their demands for collective bargaining rights.
The board of directors of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company will be asked this week to endorse a $137,000,000 reorganization plan for the company, it was announced today.

Charles A. Munn was a dinner host tonight at his villa, Amado. Later in the evening motion pictures were shown. His guests were Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Alger Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Waterbury, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer, Mrs. Vincent

A mob of 500 persons led by the son of an ex-communicated Coptic priest attempted tonight to force an entrance into the Coptic Patriarch Yohannes's home. The mob broke down doors and smashed windows before police dispersed them.

A snowfall of from three to four inches was expected by this morning in the New York area, but in the city most of it melted as it touched the streets. With Spring less than a week away (it begins at 7:45 P. M., Saturday), the snow appeared to be the last gasp of an indecisive Winter.

President Conant of Harvard Univarsity, in a letter to Senator Walsh, Democrat, and to Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, today endorsed their opposition to President Roosevelt's plan for changing the Supreme Court.

Pastors of neighboring churches joined with the pastor and members of the First Presbyterian Church yesterday at a Church Fellowship Luncheon at the Hotel Brevoort. The pastor, the Rev. J. Valdemar Moldenhawer, presided.

The arrival tomorrow of Rickard J. Sandler, Swedish Foreign Minister, in response to an invitation by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden will be watched with the keenest interest because of belief here that the visit marks a new effort by Britain for closer cooperation with the group of smaller Western European governments.

ALEXANDER-Louisa G. (nee Heltler) in her seventy-seventh year, widow of Henry Alexander, on Saturday, March 13, 1937. Reposing at Jacob Herrlich Sons' Yorkville Memorial Chapel, 332 East 86th. Services Tuesday afternoon at 2 o'clock. Interment Lutheran Cemetery.
There were rival public meetings in Spring Valley, N. Y., the other night about Mr. ROOSEVELT'S court plans. Our staff correspondent said
A life-sized, three-quarter length portrait of the Duke of Windsor will be placed on exhibition today in the Colonel's reception room of the 107th Infantry Armory, 643 Park Avenue.

Christian Belle, in 15 E. 61st St., through Pease Elliman, Inc.; Mrs. E. B. Kilbert in 19 E. 72d St. through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.; John O'H. Anderson in 103 E. 86th St.; Mrs. L. J. Barnhart in 230 E. 73d St, from Bing Bing; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.

Fe Alf last night presented a program of dances at the Guild Theatre before an audience of good size and warm appreciation. This was her first New York appearance since her debut two years ago, and in it she revealed again that she is a young dancer of marked potentialities.
The Federal Social Security Act is described as "one of the most significant measures ever passed by Congress" in the 1937 Social Work Year Book, issued yesterday by the Russell Sage Foundation.

Albert Goldman, New York postmaster, has accepted the chairmanship of the Federal Employes Division of the Commerce and Industry Committee to solicit contributions for the Salvation Army, it was announced yesterday by Chalmers Wood, executive chairman of the city-wide campaign.

Confirmation of big-scale Italo-German military action in Spain was received here without surprise or dismay. Indeed, the Pravda and Izvestia editorials on the subject today might be almost said to contain a note of satisfaction, because the news fully verifies what the Russians have known from the outset about the Spanish "civil war" which Izvestia now calls "the Italo-German war against Spain."

Charles W. Phellis, Class A gunner, won the majority of the prizes over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He scored in six events. He began in the regular event at 100 targets and captured the high scratch cup with a card of 97. In the doubles he took the scratch trophy with a card of 27 out of a possible 30 targets, and in the handicap doubles

"The communism of a perfect home, rather than the communism of armed force, is necessary to preserve our democracy," the Rev. Dr. Robert Russell Wicks, dean of the Chapel, Princeton University, declared yesterday morning in Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Christianity is the tie required to bind together the varied segments of disintegrated modern society, Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, presi dent of Colgate-Rochester Divinity School, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Dick Durrance of Dartmouth College added the national amateur slalom championship today to his downhill ski crown. Through points piled up yesterday in winning the downhill, Durrance was declared champion also of the Sun Valley international open, in which forty-four of the nation's leading professional and amateur ski riders competed.

The sit-down strike carries within itself the seed of self-destruction "like all other methods of concourse by force," the Rev. Leon M. Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th Street, the Bronx, said yesterday morning in his sermon.

A similar phenomenon to that recorded in March, 1925, is making itself visible over the entire length of the Peruvian coast line. During the last few days the shores have been littered with dead fish and sea birds, principally cormorants.

As did thousands of other citizens, President Roosevelt devoted most of his time today to making out his Federal income tax return. He insists on preparing his own, always, and today was even without the help of a disbursing officer usually assigned by the Treasury.

More than 200 employes, mostly girls, of four H. L. Green Company 5-cent-to-$1 chain stores continued their sit-down strikes yesterday after spending the night in the establishments. They said they would remain there until ordered out by the Department Store Employes Union, Local 1250, the strike organization.

Albert Burton Strange of 136 East Seventy-ninth Street, president of the Read Lovatt Manufacturing Company, 95 Madison Avenue, silk throwsters, died yesterday at his country home in Bernardsville, N. J., of a stroke which he suffered on Friday. He was 66 years old, a son of the late William Strange, former head of the firm of his name in Paterson, N. J., who was one of the largest silk manufacturers of his day.

Mr. and Mrs. William H. Davis gave a luncheon yesterday at their home, 130 East Seventy-fourth Street, and took their guests to the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. The guests were Mr. and Mrs. David Franklin Houston, Judge and Mrs. John F. O'Brien, Mr. and Mrs. Merrel P. Callway, Mrs. H. M. Andrews and Jose De Creeft.

The American Bar Association, analysing the 16,132 to 2,563 vote of its members against "an increase in the number of justices of the Supreme Court," reported today the plan was disapproved in every State, the District of Columbia and the territories.
Under the stimulus of military expenditure, Japan's heavy industries have expanded by several hundred per cent in the past five years, according to statistics given by the newspaper Chugai Shogyo.

Twenty-five thousand men and women of Irish extraction marched today, in a driving snowstorm, in Newark's second annual St. Patrick's Day parade. Police estimated that more than 100,000 spectators viewed the parade on Broad Street, between Lincoln Park and New Street, and on New and Washington Streets.

Business transacted by the United States Steel Corporation and all its subsidiaries in 1936 amounted to $1,089,229,007, compared with $758,893,126 during 1935, a gain of 43.5 per cent, according to Myron C. Taylor, chairman, in the corporation's pamphlet report, which will be issued today.

Big Ten basketball mentors here to attend the National Basketball Coaches Association meeting voted tonight to abandon the center jump. The rule will go into effect at the start of the 1937-38 Conference campaign.

The quality of one's friends determines the quality of one's enemies, the Rev. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning. "In friendship with Christ," he said, "we must give and we'll find genuineness."
The champion Detroit Red Wings, playing without the injured Larry Aurie, the National Hockey League's high scorer, defeated the Boston Bruins, 2 to 1, before 9,500 spectators

Stocks lower on the week, with widest declines since August; turnover, 14,544,940 shares. United States Government issues weak in largest weekly turnover since September, 1934; other bonds irregularly lower; transactions, $118,002,300.

Briggus Princess, Airedale terrier, owned by Hinson Stiles of White Plains, N. Y., and handled by Tom Gately of Hempstead, L. I., won the special for best in show at the close of the twenty-first annual exhibition of the Western Reserve Kennel Club tonight. The judge was J. Macy Willets of New York City.

A strike call, effective this morning, was issued yesterday to 5,000 workers in twenty-five cash-andcarry laundries and 1,000 neighborhood stores in Brooklyn by the Laundry Workers Union, Local 280, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.
Striving to emulate their elders, a group of Broadway's younger thespians (all Equity members ranging in age from 7 to 16) have formed an organization called "Footlight Juniors." As a tribute to

Representative Caroline O'Day of New York entertained at tea this afternoon in honor of Mrs. Warren Delano Robbins, who was special assistant to the American delegation to the recent Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace at Buenos Aires. Mrs. O'Day was the ranking member of the delegation from the People's Mandate Committee which flew to Buenos Aires to present a petition to the conference.

"Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm," the last of a series under the auspieces of the Children's Welfare Foundation of 325 East Thirtyeighth Street, will be given on Saturday afternoon in the BarbizonPlaza Theatre. It will be performed by the Clare Tree Major Players.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

The Chilean Government has decided to experiment in the Chilean leper colony on Easter Island, in the Southern Pacific, with a new serum discovered by Dr. Dostal of Vienna, according to an announcement made today by Dr. Atilio Machiavello.
Ralph Flanagan of Miami and Miss Katherine Rawls of Fort Lauderdale bettered three United States long course free style swimming records in the Miami Biltmore pool today.

The Bourse at the beginning of the week had a sharp rise in the rentes and French securities in general, caused by reversal of the government on its policy. Irregularity, however, developed at the end of the week and renters, in particular sagged. Early strength, therefore, was purely of a speculative character.

About 100 members of Masonic lodges attended a holy communion and buffet breakfast yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer, Fourth Avenue and Pacific Street, Brooklyn. The rector. the Rev. Dr.

One of the major obstacles in the way of obtaining knowledge that might materially reduce the 150,000 annual deaths from cancer in the United States is the "painful inadequacy" of the financial resources available for research.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 10 as the average for 1926, was 92.9, which compares with 91.1 a week before, 90.9 two weeks before, 91 three weeks before and 90.7 four weeks before.
Apart from the effect of French liquidation, the stock markets here have been influenced powerfully by the wild movements of commodities, especially base metals.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Marjorie Simonds Duryea of New York and Willett House, Southampton, L.I., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Robinson Simonds of New York and Southampton, to Andrew Cameron Pearson, son of Mrs. Andrew C. Pearson of 202 Riverside Drive and the late Mr. Pearson.

Without one in a hundred Rumanians having the faintest inkling of the situation, Dowager Queen Marie -of Rumania has been lying dangerously ill since Friday as the result of poisoning. Her condition tonight was considered extremely grave as her heart was weakening.

Selling of lard futures here by speculators and hedging by packers made it easy last week to buy lard for future delivery and at the same time resulted in easing of prices. Trade at times was liberal and more general.

Cotton prices fluctuated over a wide range last week, with the general trend upward in continuation of the broad advance that began three weeks ago. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange registered last week net advances of 15 to 36 points, following advances of 85 to 105 points in the previous week.

It would be interesting to report that today's practice game, in which the first all-regular line-up defeated a second team, 10-3, in four and one-half innings, had revealed the identities of the Dodgers who will face the Giants at Ebbets Field on opening day.

The little bloc in Congress primarily responsible for the legislative experiments in neutrality enacted in the past two years has virtually abandoned hope of obtaining, for the present, the full degree of mandatory action that it believes should be laid down for the President to keep the United States out of war.

Mr. and Mrs. John Austin Amory of Toyfarm in Needham, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Violet Amory, to William Farnsworth Loomis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Lee Loomis of Tuxedo Park. N. Y.

A program of choral and instrumental works of Johann Sebastian Bach was presented this afternoon in Milbank memorial choir of the Princeton chapel as the university's 1937 memorial to Mrs. Elizabeth Milbank Anderson.

Miss Eunice Weinberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry G. Weinberg, was married to Herbert B. Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Levine, this afternoon at the Race Brook country club by the Rev. Edgar Siskin.

The Briggs Manufacturing Company, which makes bodies for the Chrysler Corporation, announced today that 19,400 of its 33,750 employes had been forced out of work be cause of the curtailment of its production due to the Chrysler strike.

Schools that teach religion are doing more to preserve the spirit of the Constitution of the United States than any other agency, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America, Washington, D. C., declared yesterday in his final Lenten sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Formation of the Citizens Crime Commission of the State of New York, Inc., to study and publicize methods of detecting, apprehending, prosecuting and punishing or reforming criminals was announced yesterday.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday that $150,000 of the police relief fund would be set aside to assist policemen in buying their uniforms, which have risen in price. He said that it was "only a step" from using the fund to keep the men in financial difficulties out of the hands of unscrupulous money lenders.

The National Retail Credit Association reported today average increases in collections and credit sales of 5 per cent and 7.8 per cent, respectively, in fifty-four cities in February. The gains were approximately the same as those for the same month last year.

Net earnings of the Western Electric Company and subsidiaries for 1936 were $18,698,049 after all charges, compared with earnings of $2,620,279 in 1935 and losses aggregating more than $34,100,000 for the three preceding years, according to the annual report, released today.

The City Council, when it meets Tuesday night, will announce the gift to this city of a twelve-acre park from Mr. and Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt and other members of the Pratt family. It will be named Harriet Barnes Pratt Park in honor of Mrs. Pratt, who not only supervised the landscaping but planted many of the bulbs and shrubs herself. Mrs. Pratt, who is chairman

Robert D. Burke, '38, of New York has been elected captain of the Princeton University hockey team for next Winter, Coach Richard Vaughan announced today. Burke succeeds John T. Bissell, '38, of Canton. Mass.

Offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. of a new issue of 100,000 shares of Walgreen Company $4.50 cumulative preferred stock, with common stock purchase warrants attached. The stock will be priced at $101.50 a share and accrued interest.

A long-range program of Federal aid to education, calling for the expenditure of $500,000,000 annually, was proposed yesterday by the American Federation of Teachers, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

The annual procession of guilds connected with the parish of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, took place at the morning service yesterday. More than 400 persons, representing all the activities of the parish, participated in the procession, each guild preceded by-its standards.

Active trading and a wide and irregular range of prices featured the livestock market here last week. Receipts of hogs and sheep were lighter than the previous week, largely because of mixed weather conditions throughout the leading shipping regions, while the run of cattle was slightly in excess of last week.
Further evidence that the Japanese Army is liquidating one chapter of its military adventures on Chinese territory was seen by Chinese authorities and foreign residents here today.

Contracts for supplies involving $5,999,351 were let by twelve government agencies in the week ended on March 11 under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has announced.
The liberty restored to gold dealings will permit hoarders to sell the metal to the Bank of France and obtain funds either for subscribing to the new government loan or for other purposes.

Former Alderman John J. Campbell died yesterday at his home, 1,136-A Sterling Place, Brooklyn, at the age of 47. Mr. Campbell had been a member of the Board of Aldermen continuously from 1921 to 1935, representing the Forty-third Aldermanic District, Brooklyn. In 1935 he decided not to seek re-election because of ill health.
Arthur Henry John Walsh, third Baron Or mathwaite, former Master of Caremonies to Kings Edward VII and George V, is dead at Ealing at the age of 77.
Federal Reserve officials announced today that the Reserve System's open-market committee would meet tomorrow for its annual election of an executive committee.

-Universal plans three films starring Deanna Durbin before the end of the season, following the 14year-old singer's success in the recent "Three Smart Girls." The first, "120 Men and One Girl," is ready for production, with Leopold Stokowski contributing.

A forty-passenger super-airliner, larger than the giant Clipper ships flying the Pacific, is nearing completion at the Douglas plant in Santa Monica. The largest transport now operating in America carries only twenty-one passengers.

Labor standards and economic relations in general throughout the world are threatened by the struggle for textile markets, and, therefore, a "common program of international cooperation and national action to promote the orderly development of the textile industry" is needed.
Jay St., 47. 22.3x87.6; George Norton to Guaranty Trust Co.; consideration, $10,000, foreclosure. Columbia St.. 96, 25x100; Morris Winkler to Central Savings Bank; mortgage, $17,400, held by bank.

As part of the silver anniversary being celebrated this year by the New York State Grand Lodge, Sons of Italy in America, a site for a proposed orphanage and home for the aged, to be constructed by the State organization, was dedicated here today.

Several firemen suffered injuries or were affected by smoke early today as a three-alarm fire raged for four hours through the Carlisle Block in downtown Springfield. Officials described the blaze as "the city's greatest in years."

Upsetting the Brooklyn Hispanos by 3-0 yesterday at Starlight Park, the New York Americans took the Eastern championship final of the U. S. F. A. cup competition by the margin of one goal. In the first game of the home-and-home series, total goals to decide, the Hispanos established a lead of 2-0 at Hawthorne Field on Saturday.

In last week's movement of the commodity markets and the security markets, a somewhat striking contrast was presented. Chiefly because of the emphatic advance in steel and iron prices, the weekly "Fisher commodity index" rose from 91.1 per cent of the 1926 average to 92.9; it compared with 87.9 in the last week of December.

The great air armament programs of Europe make the plans for America's own air defense seem puny in comparison, according to William R. Enyart, secretary of the contest board of the National Aeronautical Association.
The Treasury reported today that distilled liquor imports totaled 1,280,400 gallons in January, compared with 2,498,199 gallons in December and 775,805 gallons in January, 1936.

Playing before a gathering of 20,000, one of the largest baseball crowds ever seen in this quaint metropolis of the Antilles, the Giants closed out their Cuban training expedition today by squaring accounts with the Cardinals and winning a ten-inning struggle by a score of 5 to 4.
A storm covering nearly one-third of the 2,400 miles between here and Honolulu today forced postponement of Amelia Earhart's take-off on her projected 27,000-mile world flight.

Phillip S. Nutt, president of the Philadelphia Dancing Association and also president of the American Society of Teachers of Dancing, and thirty members of the Philadelphia group were greeted yesterday by Roderick C. Grant, president of the New York society, at its March meeting in the Hotel Astor.

On a small scale comparable with the ratio between Britain and the United States the eastern counties here are having an experience similar to the States bordering on the Mississippi River in recent floods.

The sit-down strike at the Frank Seder department store ended tonight. M. Herbert Syme, counsel for Mayor S. Davis Wilson's labor board, said that representatives of the store and of the employes signed an agreement. Arbitration had been continuous since 147 employes began the strike Thursday.

In a 50,000-word decision handed down today, the National Labor Relations Board ruled that Remington Rand, Inc., had engaged in wholesale violations of the National Labor Relations Act and had resorted to "ruthless" methods in breaking the strike of its 6,000 employes, which began on May 26, 1936.

The New York Council of the American Youth Congress protested yesterday afternoon against the recently organized drive by the Police and Tenement House Departments aimed at so-called "cellarr clubs." The clubs have been characterized by the officials of the two departments as "a menace to the morals of youth and a breeding place of crime."
The various cancer organizations have been telling us that the one way to combat cancer is to consult a physician when a persistent sore or lump appears. On its face it is good advice.

Comment here on the controversy raging around the United States judiciary is, on the whole, favorable to President Roosevelt, who, it is felt, has gained rather than lost support as the result of his recent radio speeches.

The Duke and Duchess of Marlborough will arrive at the WaldorfAstoria today from Palm Beach, accompanied by Colonel and Mrs. Louis Jacques Baisan. They will sail next Wednesday. Lord and Lady Ashburton, who have been travelling in the West, will leave Chandler, Ariz., today and will arrive at the Pierre on Thursday.

An increase in the cost of living of 4.4 per cent since February, 1936, was reported yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. Increases were noted in the cost of each of the major divisions of the budget, except in food prices.

The St. Mary's Celtics, playing For the first time at their new field, Bay Ridge Stadium, defeated the Paterson Caledonians 3 to 0 before 1,500 fans yesterday in an American Soccer League fixture. St. Mary's led, 1-0, at half-time. Credit for two of the goals went to McEwan, while the third was put into his own net by McKay.
A second place in the slalom today, added to her previous victory in the downhill event, gave Miss Clarita Heath of California first place in the twoday combined women's Austrian skiing competition.

The New York Rovers' chances of getting into the play-offs of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League were rendered very slim indeed yesterday afternoon when the local skaters finished on the short end of a 2-1 count after a hectic battle with Hershey at Madison Square Garden.

Artificial stimulation is combining with the natural forces of recovery to produce exceptionally vigorous business activity both abroad and here, says Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, in the current business bulletin of that bank.

The historic old Presbyterian Church on Moss Hill Road, founded in 1858, was burned today for lack of water to fight the flames. Captain Fred Higbee, a member of the congregation, discovered the fire shortly after Sunday school classes were dismissed.

Formal transformation of the congregation of Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, as an ecclesiastical body, into the Hanson Place Central Methodist Episcopal Church, was effected in six minutes at the morning service yesterday.

Three months of a new reign have made it clear to Britain that what its critics termed the smart international set-the fashionable group denounced by the Archbishop of Canterbury-is no longer welcomed by the British court.

Truth, justice and peace formed the central theme of the annual historical pageant and mass religious school lesson in philanthropy at the Roxy Theatre yesterday morning, in which more than 5,000 children from fifty-seven Jewish religious schools in Manhattan and the Bronx participated.

Emil K. Ellis, general counsel of the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, said yesterday in a statement that the Postoffice Department's ruling forbidding transportation of newspapers containing news of lotteries and winners of prizes "is to be commended if for no other reason than to demonstrate the futility of its enforcement."
It took Columbia sixteen years to win the indoor track and field championship of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. and now that the Lions are on top they have every intention of staying there.

Arnold Wiltz, an artist who had lived here since coming from Germany in 1913, died today of pneumonia in the Kingston Hospital, where his widow is seriously ill of heart disease. He was born in Berlin on June 18, 1889.

More than a hundred persons attended funeral services yesterday for Colonel Harris H. Walker, sales representative of the national advertising department of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Bayside, L. I. The Rev. Richard W. Trapnell, the rector, officiated.

Employes of the National Radiator Corporation's plant here who are members of a newly formed union affiliated with John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization adopted resolutions today asking the Legislature to impeach Governor Hoffman.

A committee for Philadelphia ana Reading Coal and Iron Company 5 per cent sinking-fund bonds due in 1973 has been formed. George W. Morris, chairman of the Beneficial Savings Fund Society, is chairman of the committee.

The Ludin Realty Company, Inc., gave to St. John's Guild a mortgage for $2,500, due three years hence at 5 1/2 per cent, on 259 West Thirty-fourth Street. And the Seebat Trading Corporation assigned to St. John's Guild on this parcel a mortgage for $12,500.

197th St. (12-3249), S. W. cor. of Claflin Av., 100x100; Jessie A. Back to 2,807 Claflin Av. Corp., 165 B'way; mtge., $121,400. Morris Av. (14-3778), e. s., 185 ft. s. of 172d St. 90x100: Adrian P. Burke, trustee, to Isaac Stern, 250 W. 104th St.: mtge., $84,500.
Clare Boothe, author of the current Broadway show "The Women," was guest of honor yesterday at the annual party held by the Authors' League Fund at the New Merry-Go-Round, 49 East Fiftyfourth Street.

John Bradley Cumings of Mount Kisco, N. Y., who served with the Headquarters Company, Twentysixth Division, A. E. F., during the war, died of a cerebral hemorrhage early yesterday at the Medical Center. He was 39 years old.

The completion of a "Social and Economic History of the World War" in- 152 volumes, was announced yesterday by Dr. James T. Shotwell as director of the division of economics and history of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

The University Fencers Club team of Miguel and Jose de Capriles and Warren Dow won the national foils team championship at the Fencers Club yesterday, replacing the Fencers Club as titleholder. Winners of the crown for six straight years, the 1936 champions let their title go by default.
The change in policy decided by the French Government last week in an effort to tempt hoarded and exported capital back into home circulation had the expected results.
Financial London's reception of the French defense loan has been entirely favorable. Other measures being taken to rehabilitate French credit also have received virtually unqualified approval.
Owing to complaints about the dirty and tattered condition of the majority of one-sol notes now in circulation, the Central Reserve Bank announced today that they are gradually being withdrawn.

Frank Garrett Shattuck, founder of Frank G. Shattuck Company, operators of the chain of Schrafft stores and restaurants and chairman of its board of directors, died late Saturday night of pneumonia at his home in the Hotel Pierre, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street. He would have been 77 years old on April 2.

Spurning a plea by an American Federation of Labor organizer, 800 employes of the Electric Storage Battery Company, after three and a half hours of heated debate, voted today to leave the federation and join the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, an affiliate of the John L. Lewis Committee for Industrial Organization.

Any member of Equity having a claim against that organization and attempting to enforce it by a suit at law will be liable to disciplinary action and perhaps a fine, it is announced in the March issue of Equity Magazine, published today.

A two-week celebration of the 200th anniversary of the founding of Masonry in New York State closed last night with special services in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street.

Speaking in German, with members of the United Brother Lodge, a German-American organization, in the congregation, the Rev. Dr. Fridolin Emil Oberlander urged avoidance of the prejudice prevalent abroad, in his sermon yesterday morning at St. John's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street.

Kuhn, Loeb Co., the National City Bank and Kidder, Peabody Co. announced yesterday that there has been drawn for redemption for the sinking fund on April 1, at par, $203,300 of 8 per cent secured bonds, due on April 1, 1951, and $118,800 of 8 per cent secured bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1952, of the Czechoslovak State Loan of 1922.

The French wholesale price index on March 6 stood at 524, compared with 517 and 516, respectively, in the previous two weeks. The index for native products, which had fallen from 541 on Feb. 13 to 538 on Feb. 20 and 27, rose to 542 for March 6.

The regular weekly shoot of the North Jersey Gun Club of Fairfield was held in a snowstorm today. W. M. Frederick was high gun in both events. High handicap honors in the first fifty went to W. H. Hine, with E. E. Bradley second. L. S. Rothwell third and A. F. Streelman fourth.

New Jersey sportsmen who count themselves among the State's fishermen and hunters are more fortunate than some of their antecedents of twenty or thirty years ago, George C. Warren Jr., president of the State's Fish and Game Commission, reasoned on Saturday.
The only performance of "Parsifal" will take place at the Metropolitan Opera House as a special matinee on Good Friday, March 26, during the closing week of the season.

The bondholders' protective committee for the Bush Terminal Buildings Company first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds, headed by George E. Warren, announced yesterday that it had adopted the plan of reorganization of the Bush Terminal Company and the Bush Terminal Buildings Company proposed by a preferred stockholders' protective committee.

The engagement of Miss Bettina ThurberBarrett, daughter of Thomas A. Barrett of this city and the late Mrs. Barrett, to John William Chapman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard G. Chapman of Syracuse, was announced yesterday at a party given by Miss Barrett's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Baldwin of South Orange, at the Baldwin home.

In an effort to force settlement of the strike of city ash and garbage collection employes, public works officials sent hundreds of newly hired collectors over the routes today; while police broke up allegedly disorderly picketing and arrested forty persons.

The unexplained and unannounced dismissal by the Department of Commerce of the National Committee on Safety at Sea was revealed yesterday when Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the committee, made public a letter addressed by him to Secretary Roper, asking why the group had been disbanded "in so abrupt a manner without so much as an explanation."

Still Alarm and High Diver, running as an entry for Mr. and Mrs. Francis' C. Dunn, finished one, two in the mile and a sixteenth allowance race that featured the charity program at the Fair Grounds today. Still Alarm had the feather of 98 pounds and was ridden by Charley Hanauer.

Weather and crop conditions were the governing factors in the world's wheat markets during last week. Prices in United States markets were advanced early in the week on short covering and speculative buying due to reports indicating that the crops were not doing so well as they should be.

Miss Edith Day, 52 years old, was killed today in a fall from a third-floor window at her home at the Willis Apartments, 216 Second Avenue. Her body, clad in night attire, was found by the janitor, John Jobswender. Miss Day was dead on arrival at Fitkin Memorial Hospital, Neptune.

Home prices of copper, brass and zinc bars, sheets and similar items again have been raised. The trade press treats the advance in non-ferrous metals as speculative and emphasizes producers' warnings:

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dudley Chapin of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Shepard Chapin, to James Stanfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Jordan Stanfield of New York and Madison, Conn.

Argentina's grain exports for 1937 have been considerably larger than for the same period of last year, the Statistics Bureau of the Ministry of Agriculture ,announced today. From Jan. 1 to March 12, the principal grain exports amounted to 2,084,714 tons of wheat, 2,091,244 tons of corn and 553,252 tons of flax.
The administration has adopted an attitude of paternal aloofness toward the Virgin Islands "Prohibition Emancipation Festival," set for about April 1.

Purchases of $47,000 by the Hotel Biltmore and $25,000 by Best Co., Inc., headed a list of subscribers to the New York World's Fair debentures announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the volunteer bond sales committee.

A warning to the American people that unless the cost of government is curtailed their taxes soon will exceed Great Britain's was given by John C. Gebhart, director of the National Economy League, in a study appearing in the league's publication, Watch Dog, made public today.

Several Russian sable skins valued in all at $25,000 were taken yesterday by a thief, who threw a stone through a window of the I. J. Fox fur shop on Fifth Avenue, near Thirty-sixth Street. The theft was timed so that neither policemen nor store watchman were on hand.

After completing preparations yesterday for a conference to be held this afternoon with officials of the General Electric Company on wage and working conditions affecting the company's 60,000 employes.

The protective committee for the 7 per cent and 6 per cent preferred stocks of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company has written authorizations from holders of 40 per cent of the stock and has received deposits amounting to 8 per cent, Carter H. Harrison Jr., head of the committee, announced today.
A buffet supper and musical was given at the Milbrook Country Club here tonight for 100 members and guests. Mrs. William Iselin was chairman of the committee.
At least three persons were drowned, many were injured and thousands of dollars of damage was done today during a storm which whipped the French coast for forty-eight hours.

The General Steel Castings Corporation announced today a wage increase of 8 cents an hour and adoption of a forty-hour week, effective tomorrow. Notices were posted at the company's Eddystone plant, near Chester, which employs 3,000 men, saying night workers would get an additional 5 per cent raise.
President Lazaro Cardenas declared today that Mexican Catholics have "complete liberty to go to church" in the first statement on the churchState question in more than a year.

O. H. Chalkley's Popover and Leonard Romagna's Jenny won the chief honors in the Manhasset Bay dinghy regatta today. Sixteen boats, twelve of them in Class D, raced in a light, steady northeast breeze that made fine racing conditions.
Rumanian soldiers with fixed bayonets were posted in front of many Masonic lodges in Bucharest today while the government and the Rumanian Orthodox Church joined forces to suppress Masonry.

CEDRIC BELFRAGE is a very young Englishman, remarkably bitter. At least he claims to be bitter, and knowing, and cynical. He tells in his "Away From It All; An Escapologist's Notebook" (Simon Schuster, $3), a book that is both annoying and interesting, of his efforts to escape "seeing the facts of life."

Premier Benito Mussolini visited both Bengazi and Luigi Razza today on his North African tour. He received a tremendous welcome from the 45,000 inhabitants of Bengazi, where Italians first landed in 1911 at the beginning of the ItaloTurkish War.

Pope Plus suffered a short period of prostration this morning, but his physicians said it could in no way be called a heart attack. The 79-year-old Pontiff, who recently appeared to be recovering partially from serious illness, was stricken at 10:30 A. M., it was disclosed.
Edith Gruen. lamp shades, in 145 E. 57th St.; Columbia Concerts Corp., Michael Keane. Inc., and The Musician. a publication, in 113 W. 57th St.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.

Twenty-fourth International Flower Show of the Horticultural Society of New York and the New York Florists Club opens at the Grand Central Palace at 2 P. M. and continues all week. Open daily, 10 A. M. to 10:30 P. M. League of Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "British and American Democracy," Arthur E. Bestor.

Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the world champion Yankees, arrived here tonight determined that he will sacrifice the club's chances for another American League pennant rather than let his holdouts dictate to him on the salary question, or have a dissatisfied player on his expensive club.

Don Shaw of Tamworth won the 1937 New England sled dog championship today, mushing his team of Siberian huskies over the eighteen-mile third and final run in 2 hours, 25 minutes 'and 32 seconds. He won all three heats, with a total elapsed time of 7:27:28 for the sixty-two miles.

Last night's opera concert at the Metropolitan was heard by a capacity audience. Features of the event included an aria from Romano Romani's opera, "Fedra," sung by Rosa Ponselle, with the composer conducting; excerpts from the fourth act of "Rigoletto," and the song, "Deep River," in a special setting.

The question of possible discrimination by the big broadcasting companies on the side of the President and his supporters entered the five-weekold fight over the President's court reorganization plan today.

Honorary degrees will be conferred upon three foreign scholars by the University of Pennsylvania at a convocation in the University Museum on Friday night. The convocation will be held in conjunction with the international symposium on early man, which the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia will conduct this week in celebration of its 125th anniversary.

Waging a gallant uphill struggle, the Maroons of Montreal humbled the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night, 6 to 4. The Northern forces, trailing from the middle of the first chap ter, staged a mighty closing rush to rob the American skaters of what looked like a certain triumph.

Charles Seaback defeated Leo Lewis, 40 to 36, in 51 innings in a professional three-cushion tournament match at McGirr's Academy last night. Lewis had a high run of 6 one more than Seaback's best effort.

A home for Russell, 5 years old, was provided yesterday by the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association. Russell's foster parents, whose names, in accordance with the association's rules, were not disclosed, interviewed four other wards of the committee before they selected him.

The setting of a new modern scoring record by Walter Foertsch, Cornell sharpshooter, was the most interesting development of the past week as the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League completed its season, with Penn succeeding Columbia as the champion.

Society women, teamsters, bricklayers, gardeners and- lighting experts were busy yesterday afternoon putting the finishing touches on the exhibits in the twenty-fourth International Flower Show, which will be opened at 2 P. M. today in the Grand Central Palace.
Cuba signed a new commercial treaty with Chile yesterday, in line with the policy of the present government to negotiate commercial pacts wherever possible to push the island's products.

About thirty enduring and experienced horses and riders will start Friday in the four-and-a-halfmile test of luck, strength and skill known as the Grand National Steeplechase. Approximately 100,000 persons will gather at the Aintree course to watch the running of what is considered the world's most difficult jumping race, while the rest of the world will stay up late or rise early to hear the result.

The Mississippi Valley Trust Company of St. Louis and the Chase National Bank of New York have been permitted by the Interstate Commerce Commission in a ruling filed in District Court to intervene in reorganization of the St. Louis-Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway.
Suddenly and rather surprisingly, in view of the excellent reception accorded "Candida" last week, Katharine Cornell announces that she -will end her New York season on Saturday night, April 10.

Works by German composers occupied the attention of the Madrigal Singers, under Lehman Engel, at the fourth concert in a series devoted to rarely performed choral works, given at the WPA Theatre of Music yesterday afternoon before an appreciative audience.
Representatives of organized labor and "Big Steel" will tomorrow begin negotiations for a work contract assuring the men of the mills a new all-time high-wage rate.

Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, last night canceled at the last moment an engagement to speak before a mass meeting sponsored by the Filipino Community of Greater New York in the auditorium of International House, 500 Riverside Drive.

British steel output in February amounted to 995,900 tons, against 998,900 in the preceding month and 938,500 in February, 1936. On a daily average basis, however, last month's production was higher than in January.

The Italian administration of Ethiopia and authorities of British Somaliland today reached an agreement opening the British ports of Seila and Berbera, on the Gulf of Aden, to goods destined for Ethiopia.

The Red Bank Polo Club defeated the Squadron A trio of New York today at the Red Bank Armory, 11 to 6 1/2. Squadron A was spotted one goal but was overtaken by the Red Bank riders in the second period, the first half ending at 5 1/2 to 5. The visitors were outplayed in the second half.

Dr. Alfred Douglas Flinn, since 1922 director of the Engineering Foundation, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, and formerly deputy chief engineer of the Board of Water Supply of the City of New York, died here this morning in the Heathcote Inn of heart disease, after a long illness, at the age of 67. Until he moved to Scarsdale a few months ago, he had lived in the Park Hill section of Yonkers for twenty-five years.

A number of new laws relating to the military duties of Turkish citizens have been prepared and submitted to the Kamutay [Grand National Assembly] for approval. Having established the principle that every male and female between the ages of 18 and 65 shall give unconditional service for the defense of the country, the laws define the work which citizens will be called upon to perform.

Clarence Addison Dykstra, city manager of Cincinnati, told the executive committee of the board of regents of the University of Wisconsin today, in a conference here, that he would accept the presidency of the university.

George Koverly, heavyweight wrestler, will tackle Hank Barber, former Dartmouth athlete, in the main attraction at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory tonight. They will grapple to a finish. Barber was named as an opponent for Koverly when Steve (Crusher) Casey suffered a leg injury.

Mrs. Joseph Tatnall Lea of East Orange has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann Bulkley Lea, to Ralph D. Osborne Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Osborne of Llewellyn Park, West Orange.

The fact that dried fruit sales in the last fifteen years have lagged considerably behind distribution of fresh and canned fruit is making producers of these types conscious of the need for a cooperative advertising campaign.

The marriage of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, United States Navy, a central figure in the 1931 Massie assault case in Hawaii, to Miss Florence K. Storms was announced today by the bride's sister. The marriage occurred a week ago in Seattle, said Miss Marie Storms.

Although the government of Panama has requested the extradition of Edward W. Eaton, a Negro messman on the U. S. S Wright, for the alleged murder of Arcueda Carbonell, a Colombian woman, in this city, his trial by court-martial will begin at Coco Solo tomorrow.

Sixty women and children, who described themselves as the wives and sons and daughters of thirtythree discharged B. M. T. bus drivers, picketed the Hotel Bossert, Montague and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday.

In the eighteenth century, when the curious rubbed beeswax and glass and made them attract bits of paper, and the sparks that could be drawn from a Leyden jar were talked about as we talk of the cosmic rays, the word" scientist" was unknown.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on March 10 at 85, compared with 82.3 a fortnight before. 81.5 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before thesuspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,949,281,000. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows.

Bishop William T. Manning officiated at confirmation services yesterday afternoon at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street. Thirty candidates knelt at the altar and received the sacrament of the "laying on of hands." The Rev. G. P. T. Sargent, rector, read the order of confirmation.

Emergency tax collections in New York City for 1936 amounted to nearly $12,000,000 more than the authorized relief expenditures payable from these taxes, it was said in a report made by the Committee on Taxation and Public Revenue of the Merchants Association of New York.

If President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the United States Supreme Court should go through, no self-respecting lawyer could accept appointment, former Supreme Court Justice Clarenoe J. Shearn, president of the Bar Association of the City of New York, declared last night.
The appointment of Sir Robert Leslie Craigie as Ambassador to Japan may lead to a new effort by the chief naval powers to reach a limitations agreement, said leading Japanese newspapers tonight.
