The Central Executive Committee by a brief decree today restored citizenship rights to thousands of persons previously deprived of their rights because of social position or ownership of property.

The "will to die" of Helen Wills Love, convicted slayer of her husband, tonight started her toward the fourth day of a deep coma, which physicians believe was self-induced to thwart a prison sentence.

Miles Sweeney, area director of the C. I. O., said today at a mass meeting that the organization planned to extend a strike at the Lebanon plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to other plants of the company at Bethlehem, Johnstown, Steelton and Sparrows Point, Md. He did not fix a date.
A series of orchestral programs known as "Continental Concerts" began at the Hotel Plaza last night. Macklin Marrow directed an ensemble of thirty-five musicians in a variety of ingratiating works.

Employes of the Atha works of the Crucible Steel Company at Harrison, N. J., received Charter 1289 from the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers of North America, a C. I. 0. affiliate, at a mass meeting this afternoon in the Workmen's Circle here.

Dr. Rollin Hills, 53 years old, of 231 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was found dead at the wheel of his parked automobile in front of 7,201 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, shortly before last midnight, by detectives who had been searching for him since he was reported missing at noon by his wife, Mrs. Charlotte Hills.

In the wake of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field games, Coach Peter L. Waters of Manhattan announced that he would send the Green's full strength into the two-mile relay at the Knights of Columbus meet in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night.

The old game of party politics has split this usually staid borough of 6,000 into two confused and-at present-deadlocked camps. To the amusement of some of Manville's taxpayers and the. indignation of the majority, the borough, with the exception of its Republican Mayor, who is vacationing in Florida, is vainly attempting to carry on its governmental functions with two complete sets of borough officials.

The imminence of the coronation, to be followed by the retirement of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and a shake-up in the Cabinet, combines with domestic shocks lately experienced to give more than conversational interest to the theme that is continually cropping up.

Bob Feller, the Cleveland Indians' prize rookie pitcher, worked for one inning today as the Indians defeated the New Orleans Pelicans, 11 to 0. Feller pitched the first frame and retired three men in order, striking out the last one.

C. S. Swayne, a landscape gardener from Toronto, became yesterday the first man to be robbed of an automobile trailer in this city, so far as certain usually keen memories could recall. It was first reported that the trailer was a luxurious one, equipped not merely with the usual facilities, but with a rock garden as well.

Brooklyn Republican supporters of Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday to meet the challenge of Jacob A. Livingston, former county leader, who is opposed to the renomination of the Mayor and has declared that there will be another candidate in the party primary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Because I have not had access during the past two weeks to the current issues of THE TIMES, I have seen only today Herbert C. Pell's letter published on Feb. 23 last. His sincerity and

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,949,281,000. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows.

Bishop William T. Manning officiated at confirmation services yesterday afternoon at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street. Thirty candidates knelt at the altar and received the sacrament of the "laying on of hands." The Rev. G. P. T. Sargent, rector, read the order of confirmation.

Emergency tax collections in New York City for 1936 amounted to nearly $12,000,000 more than the authorized relief expenditures payable from these taxes, it was said in a report made by the Committee on Taxation and Public Revenue of the Merchants Association of New York.

If President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the United States Supreme Court should go through, no self-respecting lawyer could accept appointment, former Supreme Court Justice Clarenoe J. Shearn, president of the Bar Association of the City of New York, declared last night.
The appointment of Sir Robert Leslie Craigie as Ambassador to Japan may lead to a new effort by the chief naval powers to reach a limitations agreement, said leading Japanese newspapers tonight.

By unanimous vote the Assembly passed tonight the bill of Assemblyman Brownell, New York Republican, authorizing New York City to issue $19,000,000 in corporate stock and serial bonds to finance the construction of a new Criminal Courts Building and an Appellate Division Building.

Joseph Thompson Van Loan, a general partner of the Stock Exchange firm of Pouch Co., 1 Wall Street, died on Sunday at the New York Hospital of a heart attack at the age of 62. He lived at 400 East Fifty-seventh Street.
An order for 500,000 pounds of lake copper for delivery to the Washington Navy Yard was awarded today to the Calumet and Hecla Consolidated Copper Company, 25 Broadway, New York.

The National Labor Relations Board is not to be blamed if it has used 50,000 words to condemn the labor policies of the Remington Rand Company after months of silence about the sit-down strikes in Michigan. Partisanship is imposed on the board by the very law which created it. This law, the Wagner act, empowers the board to intervene in any labor dispute "affecting commerce," but to intervene only in behalf of labor.

The marriage of Mrs. Lorraine Manville to Cornelius Dresselhuys of London will take place this afternoon in Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The ceremony will be performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman. Only members of the two families will be present.

John Thomas Winsett, the biggest question mark on the 1937 Brooklyn roster, is going to be taught how to use those long legs of his in starting his pursuit of fly balls and in circling the bases in a manner befitting a major league player.
Charles Carol Dana, freight traffic manager of the Santa Fe Railroad and Industrial Commissioner of Chicago, 1913 to 1916, died today at the Chicago Memorial Hospital. He was 68 years old.

The Department Store Employes Union took possession of another unit of the H. L. Green Company chain yesterday, bringing to five the number of stores in which sitdown strikers sang, danced, ate and slept while customers vainly sought admittance.

Myles Pickering, who retired from active service with the Salvation Army in 1934 with the rank of lieutenant colonel after some years as district officer for the Southern territory in charge of men's social work, died here yesterday in St. John's Riverside Hospital of a stroke suffered a few hours before.

The reduction in passenger fares made by the railroads on June 1 not only affected the traffic of independent omnibus companies but also the traffic of omnibus companies controlled by railways, the report of the Maine Central Railroad for 1936 discloses.

The selection of first and second all-league teams and the awarding of individual certificates and the team championship trophy marked the annual dinner of the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League at the Hotel Astor last night. Dan Meenan, former Columbia University basketball coach, was the guest speaker, with M. P. Durkee of Irving School also making an address. C. Walter Olson, Irving headmaster, was toastmaster.

The new traffic regulations of the city were further modified yesterday when it was announced that more turns against red lights would be permitted. These turns will be allowed at the following intersections in Manhattan:

Contracts establishing minimum retail prices under the Feld-Crawford resale price maintenance law for cigarettes and cigar brands were signed here yesterday. Little or no action developed in other lines, however, with executives of leading stores here reporting no additional resale contracts or notifications under the provisions of the law.

The city of Atlantic City, N. J., will spend $100,000 this year in advertising, of which $65,000 will go to newspapers. Metrooplitan papers, generally, in the Eastern half of the country, will be used with a supplementary campaign in outdoor sports and quality magazines.

The InterAmerican Radio Conference got under way here this afternoon at the Department of Education. Delegates from the United States, Canada, Mexico and Cuba will draw up a preliminary outline for a unified program to be presented by the American nations at the World Radio Conference at Cairo, Egypt: next February.
Legislation fixing prices of hotel rooms and meals during the approaching season of the international exhibition in Paris will be rushed through Parliament this week, it was announced today.
Germany's shortage of meats and fats was made more noticeable today with the announcement in Frankfort, the hot dog's home town, that fish sausage had been introduced on the market.
Funeral services for the Rev. Dr. John J. Donlan, who was pastor of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, Court and Congress Streets, Brooklyn, were held at the church yesterday morning.
Mrs. Dorothy Snell, formerly assistant buyer in the upholstery deapartment for Lord Taylor, has been appointed buyer of negligees for the store, it was announced yesterday.

Moroland's second reigning Sultan wore his crown today, which put him on an even basis with his rival, whose coronation was held almost two months ago. Ombra Amilbangsa was crowned Sultan of Sulu Sunday before a crowd estimated at 10,000 in a colorful ceremony on the Jolo High School campus.

The formation of a committte for refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds of 1973 of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company, headed by N. E. Waldman, was announced yesterday. The other members of the commission are James J. Kann, president of the Amera Securities Corporation, and Norman Johnson, a lawyer.

Head Coach Harvey Harman and his assistants greeted forty University of Pennsylvania football candidates at the training house today. This was the start of Spring training, but owing to snow and rain that covered River Field it was decided to stay indoors until Thursday.

Offering of 75,000 shares of stock in the Bender Body Company of Cleveland will be made today by William J. Mericka Co. and the Carlton M. Higbie Corporation, underwriters, and the First Cleveland Corporation, subunderwriter. The offering price is $12.50 a share.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today advocated higher Federal income and profits taxes if necessary to sustain the relief load, balance the budget and reduce the public debt as private debt expands. He added that "only by this process can monetary inflation be prevented."

On his own application: PATROLMAN-Otto P. Heubner, Traffic Precinct B. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 12, 1912. Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-George B. Regan, from 34th Precinct to 18th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur. Lawrence F. Kraemer, 5th Precinct to Traffic B.
Edwin J. King, American vice consul in Dublin, has reported to the Department of Commerce that the market for automobiles in the Irish Free State in the last half of 1936 was the best in six years.

Stockholders' representatives and the central committee of the Reichsbank will meet tomorrow for the first time since the Reichsbank was stripped of its technical independence and placed under Chancellor Adolf Hitler's direct authority as the National Socialist Government's central financial organ.

In answer to a letter from Howard S. Cullman of New York to Secretary Roper asking why a subcommittee on safety at sea of the Accident Prevention Conference of the Department of Commerce had been dismissed, Labert St. Clair, director of the conference, said today that one reason was to get rid of Mr. Cullman.

Mrs. Anna Van Reypen Green, organizing regent of Bergen Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, is dead at her Winter home, St. Petersburg, Fla., it was learned by friends here today. Mrs. Green, who was in her ninetieth year, was born in the old Van Reypen homestead here on the street that for 250 years bore her family's name.

Sales of cloth for men's clothing were about 20 per cent greater in January than in December, including an average of about 210,000 yards a week to government agencies, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers reported yesterday. January was the fourth consecutive month of high sales, the group said.

Plans were filed yesterday in Queens for a group of eight sixstory apartment houses in Forest Hills, to cost $1,410,000, and in the Bronx for a $250,000 apartment and a $120,000 business building. Other plans filed in the various boroughs included specification for a number of one-family dwellings. The list follows:

The bill of Assemblyman Moffat, Republican, of New York City to ban the sale in this State of any merchandise produced in whole or in part by child labor will be pressed to final passage in the Assembly as promptly as the rules permit.

With party lines split, the Senate passed tonight, 12 to 8, the Democratic Assembly's bill to make $12, 660,000 available for relief. Senators Clee of Essex, Van Winkle of Bergen and Burling of Camden, Republicans, joined with nine Democrats in support of the bill, while Senator Dolan, Sussex Democrat, voted with seven Republicans against it.

John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight champion from Phoenix, Ariz., punched out a decisive tenround decision over the veteran Hans Birkie of Berkeley, Calif., before 3,000 persons tonight. Lewis weighed 182 1/2 pounds and Birkie 196.

The University of Pennsylvania, undefeated in its spectacular twelvegame drive to the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship, placed two men on the 1937 all-star team picked for The Associated Press by the seven coaches. Franny Murray, clever quarterback on Penn's football team and ace guard of the cage squad, and Roy Menzel, tall center, were selected for the first team.
The country's college basketball coaches started out today to give the men who officiate at their games a going over, but wound up by assuming the blame for their whistleblowing troubles.

The annual Spring sale of clothing and household articles in behalf of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will be held Thursday at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue. Members of the benefit committee headed by Mrs. Joseph A. Grazier are making an appeal for articles of clothing and furnishings suitable for resale.

Constitutionality of the $4,000,000 PWA harbor improvement project at Bayonne, N. J., was attacked in a suit for injunction filed against Administrator Ickes in United States District Court today by a group as taxpayers of that city.

Members of the committee on arrangements for the dinner dance to be given on April 13 in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, were guests at a tea given yesterday by Mrs. Clyde R. Place at her home at 333 East Fiftyseventh Street.

Members of the junior committee, of which Miss Alma Nicoll was chairman, participated in the amateur waltz contest which was part of the entertainment program of the supper dance held last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Union Settlement.
American investors in the British Government's bond issue floated in New York in 1917 learned today why the gold clause in this particular contract had afforded them no protection.

The semiannual report of the administration of the North American Bond Trust for the six months ended Feb. 28, issued yesterday, showed that the market value of bonds held in the portfolio exceeded cost by $551,280.
An increase of more than 33 per cent in Federal income tax collections over last year was predicted shortly before midnight by the collectors of internal revenue in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

Fleeting is the word for leadership in the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress championships. Pace-setters continued to fall in the sixth session of maplecrashing in the old 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday.
Three players are deadlocked at the head of the scoring parade, according to official National Hockey League statistics issued tonight, as the teams swing into the last week of the schedule.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Rosemary Maloney, daughter of Mrs. Josiah Van Kirk Thompson of Pittsburgh, to Donald McLoughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett McLoughlin of New York, for the morning of April 5 in St. Paul's Cathedral, Pittsburgh.

In the flickering light of hurricane lanterns hundreds of farmers tonight were shoveling blue clay into the cracks in the elevated banks of the River Ouse, which, swollen by storms, seemed likely at any moment to gush over the fenland and inundate 250 square miles of the richest farmland in Britain.

The will of Colonel Frank Browne Keech, 71-year-old stockbroker who committed suicide by jumping in front of a Lexington Avenue subway train on March 9, was filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, with the estate formally valued at "more than $1,000,000." The document was drawn on March 1.

Requirements for effective prevention of frauds through securities in Canada to be achieved in close cooperation with the United States were agreed on, it was announced today, at a conference of Dominion and Provincial officials here aided by representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. Contrary to expectations,

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 88.9 per cent of theoretical capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, the highest level attained since September, 1929, when the monthly average was 90.44 per cent of capacity.
The impression that a lesson has been taught to the army by the nation-wide opposition it aroused during the recent political crisis is confirmed by incidents in the House of Peers.

That the sit-down strike is illegal confiscation of property, and one-way contracts between employers and employes are violative of the guarantee of equal protection offered to citizens under the law, are probably the views of the American majority. Nevertheless,

Harry F. Wolf of the New York A. C. and Philip Moore of the Columbia University Club reached the final round of the national amateur squash tennis championship yesterday at the New York A. C. They will play for the title tomorrow afternoon at 5:30.

The fancy of Arthur Hopkins is reported to have been caught by "Second Helping," the comedy by "David Carey" (David Egan), which was tested three Summers ago under the title of "Fair Exchange." That event took place at Caldwell, N. J., under the auspices of Martin Berkeley and Paul Groll -a light comedy about a New England family.
Madrid is doomed, and its fall will be an irremediable blow to the Leftist forces, Generalissimo Francisco Franco said in an interview at his Insurgent headquarters here today.

General Carlos Pasos, a member of the House of Deputies as well as an agriculturist and industrialist, is bringing cows from the United States to establish a high-class dairy. Silos have been constructed and American methods of operation instituted.

Circuit Court Judge Allan Campbell issued a mandatory injunction today-ordering John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization; Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America; other union officials and organizers, and all the sit-down strikers, to evacuate the eight Chrysler plants they seized a week ago today, by 9 o'clock Wednesday morning.

Amelia Earhart today postponed the start of her 27,000-mile globe girdling flight until tomorrow because of a storm at sea. The aviatrix reached her decision after consulting a weather map following Pan American's postponement of two scheduled flights.

Dowager Queen Marie is suffering from "a gastric complication" following influenza, but is now "out of danger," according to a physicians' bulletin made available to foreign correspondents following twenty-four hours of rigid suppression of all news of her illness.

A plan to have the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra make a post-season tour to Mexico and Cuba next May is being worked out, it became known last night. The proposal originated in the ranks of the orchestra and has won the spontaneous support of the members of the ensemble who are working hardest to bring the program to fulfillment.
E. C. Olson has joined the Chicago office of Frank Presbrey Company as account executive. He was formerly with the Chicago office of Erwin Wasey Co.
The Canadian National Railways reported today railway operating revenues in 1936 of $186,610,489, operating expenses of $171,477,690 and net revenue of $15,132,799.

George K. Van Deusen, organist and choirmaster of St. Paul's Episcopal Church and organist of the Temple Society of Concord for many years, died last night at a hospital here. He was 59 years old. Mr. Van Deusen had been in charge of the musical service at St. Paul's for thirty-five years.
Governor Earle signed a bill tonight creating an additional Common Pleas Court in Philadelphia. and appointed Judge Curtis Bok as its president judge. Judge Bok now is on the Orphan's Court Bench.

Forty-two Princeton freshman and sophomore football candidates worked out for nearly an hour on snow-covered University Field today as Head Coach Fritz Crisler launched his annual Spring training drive.
A period of intense political activity began today as a result of the pubiication of definite figures on the general election held March 7, in which Rightist parties gained a victory.

Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, announced yesterday that the city relief agency had saved $10,984,779 by reductions in its administrative budget since August, 1935.

Barring a training mishap or unexpected strong financial support for another horse, Miss Dorothy Paget's Golden Miller will go to the post on Friday favored to win the ninety-ninth running of the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree.
Taking at random a couple or big cities, like Calcutta, India,. and New York, N. Y., it is no trouble at all to show that they are remarkably

The National Steel Corporation and subsidiaries report for 1936 a consolidated net profit of $12,541,842 after all deductions, including $629,307 surtax on undistributed profits, equal to $5.80 a share of capital stock, compared with $11,136,452, or $5.16 a share, in 1935.

Secretary WALLACE'S statement defending the proposal to place an excise tax of 3/4 of a cent a pound on raw sugar contains some admirable economic reasoning. It is seldom that statesmen advocating measures deal directly with abstract economic principles. Secretary WALLACE has done so, and comes off with flying colors.

John M. McCauley of Brooklyn has bought from Mrs. William Carroll Wilson of Montclair a property fronting 390 feet on the North Shrewsbury River and having an average depth of 550 feet at Fair Haven, N. J.

William Hude Neilson Voss, socially prominent and formerly active in the development of real estate on Long Island, died suddenly at his home here yesterday. He was 62 years old. Mr. Voss retired from business several years ago.

Summoned to the Brooklyn approach to Manhattan Bridge at about 3 A. M. yesterday, the police of the Butler Street station found a self-styled Federal agent completing the job of dragging a Chinese "prisoner" across the span.

A meeting to protest anti-Nazi utterances in this country was called last night at the New York Turn Hall, Eighty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, by Kurt Mertig, an active organizer of pro-Nazi forces in this city.

A book that David Garnett has described as a "veritable Mme. Tussaud's of the vulgar language from the fifteenth century to the present day," will be published here by Macmillan next week. It is Eric Patridge's new "Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English," which contains 40,000 entries.
Argument on a motion for a new trial for Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, scheduled for today before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, will probably be postponed, it was indicated yesterday.

Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, advocated a national labor policy today in an address before the American Industrial Development Council at the headquarters of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

The following tribute by Owen D. Young was sent yesterday from St. Augustine, Fla., to the widow of Dr. Elihu Thomson: "The sad news of the death of your husband has just reached me and I send to you and the other members of your family my deepest sympathies.

Future historians will chuckle at the Congress that voted a neutrality resolution to keep the United States out of war and appropriated $1,000,000,000 for a defense establishment to use if it got into war, Representative Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois told the House today during the general debate on the McReynolds neutrality resolution.

MARK BENNEY'S "Angels in Undress" (Random House, $2.50) is published as the autobiography of a youthful English criminal. I say "published as" for reasons that will presently become clear. It is excellent and adult reading. Mark Benney is the son of a London prostitute. As a child he consorted with Wide People-panders, thieves, con men, fences, queenies, gamblers, drunks and jailbirds-people who get along without working as the respectable world understands work.

A consolidated net profit of $15,099,291 is reported for 1936 by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries, equivalent to $5.66 a share on combined 2,666,315 shares of preferred and common stock, which share equally in all distributions in excess of $3.50 a share annually.
The Coast Guard cutter Mojave raced tonight to help the freighter Malachace, which, having lost its propeller, was being battered by high waves in the Gulf of Mexico.

William H. Walker, president of the board of Trustees of the Flushing Hospital and Dispensary for the last twenty-two years and a member of the board for twentyeight years, retired from the presidency last night to have more time to study art. Mr. Walker, who is 66 years old, classifies himself as a student of color. He lives at 144-85 Sanford Avenue, Flushing.
Brown Bomber Joe Louis will show his fistic wares in London this Summer if Brig. Gen. Alfred Cecil Critchley's promotorial plans materialize.

Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury, and the estate of his brother, R. B. Mellon. will be enriched by income tax refunds of $390,289.39 as a result of a decision here today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company and the Corning Glass Works have formed the Pittsburgh-Corning Corporation to specialize in the production of glass for construction purposes, it was announced yesterday by Harry S. Wherrett, president of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, and Amory Houghton, head of the Corning Glass Works.

The expected switching of liquor accounts, which had attracted so much attention in the advertising field in the last week, definitely developed yesterday, when one large distiller officially announced a new agency and reports indicated the selection of a new agency by another important liquor company.
Prices of hogs generally showed today little change from the close of last week, although off-quality light weights were regarded as showing a decline of 5 to 10 cents.

H. E. Enger's 4-year-old Zoic, one of the most improved horses in Winter racing, scampered off with the Fort Dallas Handicap, which attracted a small but select field of sprinters at Tropical Park today.

A Spanish Loyalist victory north of Guadalajara is prominently proclaimed in the Soviet press. Izvestia announces on its front page in four-column headlines: "Defeat of second and third divisions of the Italian Army; Italian casualties approximately 5,000; government successes in Jarama section."

Miss Helen Pauline Schwartz, daughter of Mrs. John M. Schwartz of 88 Morningside Drive and the late Mr. Schwartz, was married to Dr. Frederick Andrews Kiehle of Portland, Ore., yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Domestic stocks of refined copper decreased 4,349 tons last month, according to the Copper Institute, while stocks of blister copper rose 583 tons, making a net decline of 3,766 tons in copper stocks.

Dr. William Lowe Bryan, president of Indiana University, gave his resignation to the board of trustees of the university today. George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., president of the board of trustees, said the board had accepted the resignation and that Dr. Bryan had been named president emeritus of the university.

Two Rollins College students were killed and two others and a professor seriously injured near here today when an automobile carrying the undefeated fencing team to scheduled matches with Northern schools swerved from the Richmond Petersburg highway, hit a telephone pole and burned. Rollins College is at Winter Park, Fla.

The Rev. Robert W. Hill, formerly an official of the State Board of Charities, died last night at the age of 92. He was national chaplain of the G. A. R. in 1926 and 1927. He was the oldest living Moderator of the Presbyterian Synod of Oregon, in which State he was ordained in 1878.

Samuel W. Wheelock, a salesman for the Borne-Scrymser Company, oil manufacturers, 17 Battery Place, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday in his apartment at the Hotel Roosevelt. A native of Stamford, Conn., he had been employed by the company for fifty years. His age was 66.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee in a brief conference today laid before the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation six pages of rules and regulations designed to govern working conditions of its members and to provide for arbitration of disputes.

In a long and interesting match that featured the second session of play in the Bermuda tennis championships today, Robert Murray, the Canadian who was runner-up for the men's title here last year, defeated Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., 5-7, 9-7, 6-4.

Amid scenes of wild disorder, policemen with drawn pistols routed strikers who had barricaded themselves yesterday in different rooms of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital in an eight-hour sit-down staged by 132 employes of the institution.

Moriz Rosenthal gave his last New York recital of the season at the Town Hall last night. This was Mr. Rosenthal's third Town Hall appearance this year, and an audience of generous proportions and frequent responsiveness turned out despite the bad weather to hear the distinguished. venerable pianist.

Legislation accepting on behalf of the United States Andrew W. Mellon's art collection and approving Mr. Mellon's offer to build in Washington a $10,000,000 National Gallery of Art to house the collection was virtually completed late this afternoon when the Senate, with a few dissenting votes, passed the bill.

Rising costs of commodities and labor are leading to price rises that are passed on to the consumer and should result also in higher values for real estate, according to Truman S. Mersereau, executive secretary of the New York Real Estate Securities Exchange, Inc.

The only two seeded college teams in the tournament drove into the third round of the National A. A. U. basketball championship with conyincing triumphs tonight. Long Island University of Brooklyn dazzled a crowd of 4,000 with sensational goal shooting in beating the extra-tall West Texas Teachers, 38 to 30. The Central Missouri Teachers,

The names of eight more candidates for the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange were suggested yesterday to the nominating committee in the second of its open meetings, held preparatory to the announcement of an official slate.
If the Social Security Board approves the application of John W. Rothfus, 65-year-old gas worker, he will show a 200 per cent profit on a $2.10 investment.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that the prospective increase in the company's business, visible now, was "most likely" to continue during 1937 and into 1938, and gave promise of more than overcoming rate reductions and any increase in the cost of raw materials that may enter into operating expenses.

The third step in the program of refunding the dollar debt of the Argentine Republic, involving the offering, scheduled for Thursday, of $42,000,000 of refunding 4 per cent bonds of the Republic due on March 15, 1972, has been postponed, at least until next month, because of the uncertain market conditions, it was disclosed yesterday. Morgan, Stanley Co., Inc.,

A 10 per cent gain in attendance for 1936, plu a $10,000,000 advance in production costs and an increase of 2,334 new theatres is reported in the 1937 edition of the Film Daily Year Book, published yesterday.

Members of the Broadway Association, and officials of the city administration celebrated yesterday the extension of the Fifty-seventh Street crosstown bus route from river to river, with a luncheon at the Castleholm Restaurant, 344 West Fifty-seventh Street.
The British Government is no longer worried by the delays in the production of new airplanes, Sir Philip Sassoon, Under-Secretary for Air, indicated to the House of Commons today.

Mrs. Katherine Carroll Beale, widow of John Wheeler Beale of Washington, D. C., died at her home there on Sunday after a brief illness, according to an announcement here last night. A daughter of the late Major General Samuel Sprigg Carroll, U. S. A.,

Hints by Senator King of Utah that the big broadcasting companies, in allotment of facilities, might be aiding President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the judiciary, including the Supreme Court, were denied by representatives of the major networks yesterday.

Close upon its complaints against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and the Biddle Purchasing Company, the Federal Trade Commission started today a third proceeding against chain stores under the brokerage clause of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act.

Showing the first increase over January in more than ten years, bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding at the end of February increased $13,880,480 over those outstanding at the end of January and amounted to $401,107,760, according to the report issued yesterday by the Acceptance Analysis Unit of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Governor Lehman announced tonight reappointment of the Saratoga Springs Authority with Pierrepont B. Noyes of Oneida as chairman. The other members are Frederick H. Ecker and Morton L. Schwartz of New York City, Dr. L. Whittington Gorham of Albany, Jerome D. Barnum of Syracuse, Carl R. Comstock of Saratoga Springs and Edward H. Butler of Buffalo.

A protest to Washington against tactics of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of Paterson, granting of a Federal court order allowing picketing in Jersey City and a sitdown strike by 900 girls in a cigar factory were developments today on the Newark labor front.

Alexander Kelberine, who gave a piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall, is an uncommonly equipped and serious pianist, indeed, a formidable one. He played a program that asked unusual things of the performer, and consisted principally of more or less elaborate transcriptions.
More than 200,000 employee of General Motors Corporation will receive a 40 per cent increase in accident and health benefits under the corporation's group insurance plan, at no added cost to them.
Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott warned twenty of his officers yesterday against excessive familiarity with their men, as he promoted the twenty to higher ranks in the department.

Application to release Price Brothers Co., Ltd., newsprint manufacturer, from bankruptcy, probably will be made in the courts here on next Thursday or Friday. Reorganization of the company is virtually complete.

Mrs. Harold W. Dodds, wife of the president of Princeton University, heads the list of twenty-five patronesses for the junior promenade, to be held in the university gymnasium on Friday evening, William K. Coors, '38, of Golden, Col., chairman of the promenade committee, announced today.

German art and theatre critics, who had been forbidden to criticize by a Propaganda Ministry decree in December, were directed today to resume criticism, but from the standpoint that what is National Socialist is good and what is not National Socialist is bad.

William Shakespeare, Equity's best friend over a lot of Broadway years, has paid dividends again, it was disclosed yesterday. On Saturday, the day when by tradition "the ghost walks" in the theatre, a 10 per cent salary rise greeted the entire cast of "King Richard II"--a reward for their "splendid cooperation," a notice on the backstage call board said.

Andre Jessurun, Bronx welterweight, won a close decision from Bobby. Pacho, California Mexican, in a bruising eight-round bout that featured the weekly boxing program at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

The thirteenth and penultimate week of the Metropolitan Opera season began last night with a performance of "Aida." Arthur Carron, the young British tenor, substituted on short notice in the role of Radames for Giovanni Martinelli, who was indisposed.

Hearings in the so-called "Kenyon case," scheduled to start here on Friday at 10 A. M., will mark the first important move by the Securities and Exchange Commission in its campaign to regulate over-the-counter trading. DonaldP. Kenyon, Charles R. Kenyon and Norman E. Dizer have been summoned to appear before John F. Davidson, trial examiner, on allegations of misrepresentation and other irregularities in their handling of the affairs of seven companies.

A round of conferences designed to solidify the already close cultural and economic relationship between Britain and Sweden began today when Rickard J. Sandler, Swedish Foreign Minister, conferred with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the first talk of a four-day series being held while Mr. Sandler is an official guest here.

Willis J. Ballinger, whose office with the Securities and Exchange Commission was abolished on March 1, was today appointed a special economic adviser to the Federal Trade Commission. Attaches of the F. T. C.

There's one player in the Browns' camp about whom Manager Rogers Hornsby won't trust his own judgment. It's Hornsby himself, Donald Barnes, Browns' president, said today. And so, at the Rajah's request, three other "old heads" will be the "jury" in his case.
Although an official decision has not yet been made, it is expected that the Eiffel Tower, which has been so long a landmark of Paris, will be demolished within the next two years.

Jeanne Cagney, sister of James Cagney, motion-picture actor, and Daisy Finfer were joint winners in the annual Herman Ridder German contest held by the German department of Hunter College on Friday night, it was announced yesterday.

Edward P. Kimball, who was senior organist of the Salt Lake City Tabernacle for more than twenty years, died today at his home here. He had been organist for the Latter Day Saints Chapel here for the last four years. Mr. Kimball was 55 years old and a composer of hymns and music for the organ. His playing had been heard by millions of listeners to broadcasts.

The Senate Appropriations Committee approved the $1,500,000,000 Treasury-Postoffice Appropriations bill today. Outlays totaling $3,207,396 were added to the measure, which already has passed the House.

W. E. Snyder's Brophy, a steadygoing son of Justice F., won his third straight race and his fourth in five starts in defeating six other $1,500 players in the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds today.

In spite of leaden skies which showered cold rain and sleet upon them as they went to the Grand Central Palace, more than 25,000 lovers of horticultural beauty thronged yesterday to the opening of the twenty-fourth international flower show.

The Propaganda Ministry today took cognizance of rumors surrounding the mysterious absence from Germany since Feb. 10 of Dr. Ernst F. S. Hanfstaengl, chief of the Nazi party's Foreign Press Bureau, and a graduate of Harvard University.
Publishing houses, statistical agencies and investment counsel organizations figured prominently in the commercial rentals reported yesterday in the midtown and downtown office districts.
Victoria won the Sheffield Shield, premier Australian cricket competition, defeatSouth Australia by nine wickets in the final match of the tournament today.

Remington Rand, Inc., announced yesterday from its office, 315 Fourth Avenue, that it would not comply with the order of the National Labor Relations Board requiring it to reinstate 4,000 employes said to have lost their jobs in the recent strike in the company's plants, but would fight the order in the Federal Courts.

The annual report of the General Reinsurance Corporation and subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net profit of $1,001,143, equal to $5 a share to be allocated to 200,000 General Reinsurance Corporation shares, compared with $805,104, or $4.02 a share, earned in 1935. The figures are without regard to gains or losses on the sale and maturity of assets and changes in equities in reserves, Edgar H. Boles, president, says in the report.

Joseph E. Davies, United States Ambassador to Russia, is accused of libeling a former business associate and failing to carry out an agreement for the division of profits of a promotional venture, in a suit filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Fred A. Landeck of 50 West Fifty-eighth Street.
Colonel Jacob Ruppert got his first glimpse of his Yankee ball team in a workout that was squeezed in before a rainstorm at Huggins Field today, and was duly impressed.

The Canadian freighter Aristo of the Ocean Dominion Line, which struck a sharp reef about two miles northeast of North Rock about 4 o'clock this afternoon, was pulled off four hours later by a salvage tug from St. George's. It is believed part of her cargo may be saved.

A "humanized" report card, placing more emphasis upon the child as an individual and less upon his mark in arithmetic or spelling, will be introduced in the city schools next Fall, Dr. John K. Bolen, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, disclosed yesterday.

With strike difficulties flaring up again in the automobile industry, production dropped off sharply last week when an increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index slumped to 98.2 from 130.3 (revised). It was 97.2 for the week ended March 14, 1936.
New Yorkers may not have had the best of weather yesterday, but at least they had variety. Nearly every form of precipitation occurred--rain, snow, sleet and fog.

Frank J. Higgins of 244 Woodside Avenue, a lawyer, who was president of the Hudson Casualty Insurance Company of New Jersey, 19211931, died yesterday in the Hotel Auditorium, Denver, Col., according to word received here tonight.

Bleak skies and income-tax payments may have combined to make yesterday gloomy Monday for some. But the weather man could scarcely have provided a more effective contrast than the brief blanket of snow which ushered visitors into the blaze of living color playing over the four acres of the Flower Show. It may have been Winter in the rest of the city, but it was Spring at the Grand Central Palace.

Bronze plaques, for cities that made the greatest progress in traffic safety in 1936, were presented last night to the Mayors of the cities in six classifications at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The presentations were made by Dr. C. H. Watson, president of the National Safety Council, as the culmination of its fifth annual traffic safety contest.

Samuel M. Washabaugh, assistant superintendent of the Pennsylvania Industrial School at Huntington, took exception today to Warden Lewis E. Lawes's contention that a newspaper boy's profession is virtually a school for crime.

With its accustomed pomp and pageantry the drawing for the Irish Hospitals Grand National Sweepstakes started at the Mansion House today. The motif of the ceremonies was wealth and the joys and luxuries it brings.

You printed a letter from Harold Riegelman, and I received at the same time a pamphlet from the Housing Authority. It is very unfortunate that people who are interested in what they think is reform feel that they must depend on exaggeration to carry their points. You will remember just before our entrance into the World War the propaganda against Germany with the stories of the atrocities perpetrated by the Germans.

The State of Missouri probably will be in the market on March 30 with a new issue of $3,000,000 of building bonds, according to advices received here yesterday from Jefferson City. The bonds will be dated April 1, 1937, and mature serially frnm April, 1940 to 1944.
Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that no loot had been obtained by a thief who early on Sunday tossed a stone through a window of the I. J. Fox fur shop at 393 Fifth Avenue.

The threatened strike of about 14,000 building service employes in hundreds of buildings in the garment and fur area appeared to have been averted yesterday as a result of a conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania of representatives of the Building Service Employes Union and the Midtown and Penn-Zone realty owners' associations.

Viscount Cecil of Chelwood demanded today that the League of Nations immediately investigate the accuracy of "the grave accusations" made by the Spanish Leftist Government of "a veritable invasion of its territory" by Italian and other foreign troops.
A card party in behalf of the missionary work of the Rev. Francis Powers in China will be held this afternoon in the East Ballroom of the Commodore.

Aided by a run of 58, Seymour Prince vanquished Carl Graff, 150 to 87, in 12 innings in a metropolitain Class C 18.2 balkline championship match at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night. Edward S. Knapp Sr. conquered Raoul Stasse, 150 to 83, in 32 frames in another encounter.

The pamphlet report of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $5,170,907 after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed profits, equivalent to $8.38 a share on the 617,161 shares of capital stock outstanding at the end of the year.

The Bank of New York and Trust Company has been. appointed registrar for 150,000 shares of $1 par common stock of the Burd Piston Ring Company. The New York Curb Exchange firm of C. R. Foshko Co. has been formed with offices at 2 Rector Street.

Although prefacing his statement by saying that "no law can smother art," Paul Whiteman, orchestra conductor, today urged the House Immigration Committee to report favorably the Dickstein bill to restrict the entrance of alien stage artists into this country.

Dissolution yesterday of the Curb Exchange firm of M. D. Fox Co. is announced, together with the simultaneous formation of C. R. Foshko Co., with offices at Gilligan, Goldberg Co. Partners of the new concern are Charles Rubin Foshko, formerly a partner of M. D. Fox Co.; Harry Foshko and Henry Gelobter, formerly with Gilligan, Goldberg Co.
Cold and rain today kept President Roosevelt from a projected tour of the Georgia countryside and inspection of a resettlement project and a camp of the Civilian Conservation Corps near here.

A sports program including everything from football to a 1,400-mile marathon race will be staged as a part of the Pan-American Exposition to be held at Dallas, Texas, it was announced here yesterday by George P. Marshall, Washington sportsman and director of sports and special events for the exposition, The Associated Press reports.

Submission of a constitutional amendment clarifying Congress's power to enact social and economic legislation, or perhaps restricting operations of the Supreme Court, moved further into the realm of possibility today, but whether as a corollary or a substitute for President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Federal judiciary was still the question.
Maurice Evans, British actor, star of "Richard II," said yesterday afternoon that workers in the theatre of this country had "ganged up" on their own industry and made experiment almost impossible.

The marriage of Miss Cornelia Harsell Drake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gaston Drake of Miami, to James Lawson Karrick Jr. of Washington and Stockbridge, Mass., took place today in Trinity Episcopal Church here.

Lord Aberdare, chairman of Britain's Council on Physical Fitness for Defense, returned from the United States today with the observation that "the average American probably is more fit than the Englishman" because of athletic training in schools.

Brig. Gen. Charles Leonard Phillips, U. S. A. (retired), died here today. His age was 80. He served in both the SpanishAmerican and World Wars. His commands included Fort Dade in Florida, the Key West barracks, Fort McKinley in Maine and the Fifty-second Field Artillery, Camp Wadsworth, Spartanburg, S. C.
Mr. and Mrs. George Higginson have come from Brookline, Mass., to the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Dwight F. Davis, after a stay at the Ritz Tower, has returned to her home in Washington.

The pamphlet report of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $36,865,526 after all deductions, equal, after preferred dividends, to $2.39 each on 14,584,025 common shares. This compares with $26,086,527, or $1.65 a share, earned in 1935.
The man who gave $146,000 to found fourteen scholarships for the study of engineering at Union College and his lawyer, who suggested the gift, were honored in a simple ceremony here today.

Business on the stock markets here today was restricted by budget uncertainties and the traditionally quiet tone of the new three-week account which covers the Easter holidays. Giltedge issues recorded losses and foreign bonds, with the exception of Rumanian issues, also lacked support. Internationals were bright, although United States Steel and nickels weakened after a firm opening.

Union workers affiliated with John L. Lewis's C. I. O. claimed their first major victory in the oil industry tonight with settlement of a projected strike of 1,300 Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation employes.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, opens today an exhibition composed of oils, water-colors and prints by Cleveland artists. It is scheduled to continue for one month. This is the third chapter in a series of regional shows initiated by the Whitney Museum several seasons ago, the two previous events having presented the work of artists living in or near Philadelphia and Chicago.

Services for Miss Ada Davenport Fuller, for forty years a reporter of women's activities on The Jersey Journal, were held here this afternoon in the B. A. Waters funeral chapel, 48 Brinckerhoff Street. Miss Fuller died Saturday morning at her home, 11 Emory Street.
Police Judge William R. Bell ordered noparking signs changed today after F. L. Wagner, successfully defended parking in front of a sign which read: No Parking From 8 A. M. to 12 P. M."

Mrs. Helen Mercer Rendell, wife of Harry M. Rendell of Yonkers, who was prominent as a social worker and in welfare circles, died today in her home. She was born in Binghamton more than sixty years ago.
East Side residential properties continue to figure-in transfers of Manhattan real estate. Two dwellings in that locality were reported yesterday by brokers am having changed hands.
Meat costs are rising and, with the exception of poultry, are all higher than a year ago, the Consumers Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets reported yesterday.

Who is more fitted to act as mediator between the German race and all its Slavonic neighbors on the East than precisely the Germans in Czechoslovakia? They would then not represent a wedge thrust in between us and Germany but a bond uniting us.
Editorials in Moscow newspapers are devoted to the burning question of today in this country-the new electoral system. As is often the case here these editorials contain interesting news.

George Koverly of Hollywood scored a surprising victory over Hank Barber, tossing the Cambridge wrestler with a body slam in 16 minutes 52 seconds in the feature bout last night at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory before 3,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Hayward A. Hibberd of Maplewood, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Haddow Hibberd, to Edward Remington Nichols Douglass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Payson Stone Douglass of Llewellyn Park, West Orange. N. J.
A French child marriage took place today at Maisoncelle, near here, when Desire Demagny, 18 years old, was wed to Miss Gisele Fauquemberge, 15.

Ground was broken today for the $650,000 public administration center on the University of Chicago campus. The structure, which is to be completed in 1938, will house fourteen autonomous associations of public officials.

Ernie Nevers, former All-America fullback at Stanford University, resigned today as head football coach at Lafayette College to become backfield coach at the University of Iowa. The resignation is effective April 1.

Justin Callahan, Columbia University undergraduate, became the new metropolitan 220-yard breaststroke champion last night when he decisively defeated Wallace Spence, the defending titleholder, in the St. George Dragon Club pool.

Dick Shikat, 229, Philadelphia, pinned Frank Sexton, 230, California, after 44 minutes and 48 seconds of desultory wrestling in the main event at the New York Coliseum last night. Three back drops in succession brought Sexton to the mat in the feature, which was watched by a crowd of 2,000.

The convention for the protection of migratory birds and game mammals between the United States and Mexico became effective today when ratifications were exchanged by Secretary Hull and Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador.

Properties near the World's Fair site in Flushing figured in several of the deals on Long Island reported yesterday. A portion of one is to be improved with taxpayers and the balance with apartment dwellings. Another has been bought for investment.

United Air Lines Transport Corporation had a net income in 1936 of $367,282 after expenses, maintenance, depreciation, taxes including surtax on undistributed profits of $22,000, and other deductions.

The 200 miles of documents relating to the World War (culled from other documentary files that would reach the full length of the western front) and the 152 volumes of its social and economic history as written by collaborators of highest competence under the chief editorship of Dr. JAMES T. SHOTWELL, lead to the conclusion of the whole matter in his words:

One of the features of the Knights of Columbus track meet at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night will be the attempt of Glenn Cunningham to take the Columbian Mile in what may be his last indoor test.

John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, told a wildly cheering crowd of 20,000 at an anti-Nazi mass meeting in Madison Square Garden last night that industrial democracy was the best guarantee against fascism in the United States.

Wallace Groves, chairman of the Phoenix Securities Corporation and the Certain-Teed Products Corporation, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the SloaneBlabon Corporation, a subsidiary of Certain-Teed Products and a large manufacturer of linoleum.

Death Announced Fireman 1st Grade Joseph L. Monaco of Engine 231 died March 14. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 32 Russell P., Brooklyn, at 9:45 A. M., Wednesday March 17. Interment at St. John's Cemetery, Queens.

Stocks eased and closed lower in slowest trading since March 1; turnover, 1,766,740 shares. United, States Government bonds active and generally lower, other issues irregularly lower; transactions, $15,597,300.
The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today filed in the Senate a preliminary report of its investigation of railroad financing in the United States.
Mrs.Rhoda Lewisohn obtained a divorce here today from Frederick Lewisohn of New York on the ground of cruelty. They were married on Dec. 24, 1907.

Initial steps in the formation of a local club composed of men who drove ambulances of other vehicles with the French Army during the World War were taken yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Vanderbilt attended by a score of these former drivers.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on March 10 shows increases for the week of $83,000,000 in total loans and investments, $148,000,000 in demand depositsadjusted, $39,000,000 in government deposits and $71,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and decreases of $20,000,000 in time deposits, $72,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $38,000,000 in balances with domestic banks.

Roswell Magill, acting Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that reports from Federal Reserve Banks indicate that $483,910,000 of 3 per cent Treasury notes of series B, 1937, of which $502,361,900 were issued, have been exchanged for 2 1/2 per cent Treasury bonds of the 1949-1953 series.

The Senate amended and passed the bill to accept from Andrew Mellon the gift of an art gallery and art treasures, approved an appropriation of $150,000 to continue the investigation of railroad financing and received a preliminary report of the Investigating Committee; received a report on the TreasuryPostoffice Appropriations Bill and adjourned at 4:56 P. M. until noon Wednesday.
Cool breezes blew across the sunny Southland and a blustery rain sent delegates scampering as the biennium of the American Association of University Women opened here today.

Prices of wheat in the world markets rose sharply today on a keen demand for cash grain from importing countries. There was comparatively little opposition to the advance. Closing trades were around the top prices of the day.

Manufacturers in conference tonight agreed on a court application tomorrow for an injunction against sit-down strikers in one of the three largest mills affected by the general hosiery strike here, which began March 1.

Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords, and Lady Marley; Viscountess Castlerosse, Sir Norman Watson, Dewitt Untermeyer and Frederick H. Prince Jr. are among the passengers arriving today from Europe on the French liner Normandie.

The rivalry between Garret A. Hobart of Paterson, N. J., and Vincent K. Hilton of Dayton, Ohio, was renewed today in the qualifying round of the Bellview amateur golf championship. In the tournament held here last month to decide the championship of the Belleair Country Club. Hilton defeated Hobart in the final, but today Hobart filed his challenge by duplicating Hilton's score of 77 to become co-medalist.

After a brief debate the Assembly passed tonight the bill, favored by Governor Lehman, permitting juries to recommend life imprisonment for accessories in felony murder cases. It now goes to the Governor.

Spain, through her Ambassador, Dr. Fernando de Los Rios, presented to the State Department tonight a note appealing to this country to take cognizance of the invasion of Spain by troops of other nations.

Miss Matilda Goetz of 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl J. Goetz of Kansas City, Mo., was married to Albert Richard Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Johnson of Kew Gardens, Queens, on Saturday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, the rector.

A new issue of $2,500,000 of fifteen-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures of the Memphis Commercial Appeal Company will be offered today by a banking group headed by Field, Richards Shepard and Robinson, Webster Gibson. The debentures will be priced at 101 and interest.
Governor Lehman made reappointments to various bodies and sent a special message to the Legislature recommending "moderate" appropriations for eradication of Bang's disease and mastitis among cows.
Several Democratic county officers have been successful in recent suits, brought against the city, for the money withheld from them in the form of pay-cuts, it became known yesterday.

Stimulated by record high domestic mill consumption, prices on the Cotton Exchange surged forward again yesterday to close with gains of 22 to 31 points. May rose to 14 1/4 cents a pound and under urgent buying the last half hour, July changed hands at 14 cents, the best levels since June, 1930.

The Supreme Court today postponed decision on any of the Wagner National Labor.Relations Act cases for at least two weeks more. Another decision day passed without reference to this issue. After handing down one opinion and a number of the customary formal orders, the justices left the bench until March 29.

Indoor football practice at Manhattan was inaugurated yesterday, a squad of more than fifty candidates reporting to Coach Chick Meehan in the gymnasium for a brief conditioning drill. It is planned to hold several more indoor sessions before the Easter holidays. After the vacation period two weeks of outdoor work are planned.

Good-luck lightning, at odds of approximately 6,000 to 1, yesterday struck 484 Americans who drew horses in the drawing of the $14, 000,000 Irish Hospital Sweepstakes at Dublin, which will be decided on the running of the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree, England, on Friday.

Felix Pagenstecher, a prominent paper merchant, whose family had been connected with the paper manufacturing industry in Germany and in this country for many generations, died yesterday of a brain tumor at his apartment in the Hotel White, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. He was 56 years old.

A HISTORY OF AMERICAN POLITICAL THOUGHT: From the Civil War to the World War, by Edward R. Lewis. (Macmillan, $5.) THE LASTING ELEMENTS OF INDIVIDUALISM, by William Ernest Hocking. (Yale, $2.) A scholarly study of individualism.

While the value of exports from the United States in January increased to $221,550,000 from the $198,564,000 for January, 1936, exports to European countries declined to $88,677,000 from $92,051,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Turpentine firm at 38 1/2c; sales, 58 barrels; receipts, 81 barrels; shipments, 1,034 barrels; stock, 21,723 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 283 barrels; receipts, 393 barrels; shipments, 1,204 barrels; stock, 51,053 barrels.

The trend among bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was toward definitely lower levels. The decline in United States Government obligations was irregular, but the volume of transactions rose. Nevertheless no severe pressure was discerned, such as characterized the market for Federal securities on last Friday.

Original musical scores written by young school children were the chief center of interest yesterday at the opening session of New York's second Music Education Week, held at the Midtown Community Center, 93 Park Avenue.
A. P. Zavenyagin was named First Assistant Commissar of Heavy Industry today. He succeeds Gregory Piatakoff, who was executed in February with twelve other Russians after being convicted of treason.

Dwight A. Walker, second vice president and associate actuary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, was found dead in the kitchen of his apartment at 716 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, near Beverly Road, at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning. He was 55 years old.

The following is the text of the address delivered last night by John L. Lewis before the anti-Nazi mass meeting of the American Jewish Congress and the Jewish Labor Committee at Mddison quare Garden:

A declaration covering the issuance of a 4 per cent promissory note for $450,000, due serially to July 1, 1941, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Amarillo Gas Company and the Southwestern Development Company, the parent concern, both of them registered holding companies.

What was regarded at Insurgent headquarters here as a decisive battle was reported raging on the Guadalajara front northeast of Madrid. The worst weather of the whole Winter had prevailed ever since the big Insurgent offensive against Guadalajara began last Monday.
Hearings will start tomorrow before the Interstate Commerce Commission on the reorganization of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway, better known as the Cotton Belt.

Maintenance of New York City's $500,000,000 water supply is an essential governmental function of the metropolis, and consequently the Federal Government cannot lay an inoome tax upon the salary of the Chief Engineer of the Bureau of Water Supply, the Supreme Court ruled today in a seven-to-two opinion.
Those critics, like KIPLING, who insist that Americans are a lawless people, may find support in the current issue of the Social Work Year Book of
Exports of the Argentine Republic in January and February increased 99.7 per cent over those in the same period of last year, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

The American Committee for Christian German Refugees announced yesterday at its office, 287 Fourth Avenue, that a group of fifty German Protestants was on its way from Europe to Colombia to settle there and that similar groups would follow if funds could be raised and provisions be made with Colombia or other countries.

Park Tilford, Inc., rights and Kingdom of Norway thirty-five-year 5 per cent sinking fund external loan gold bonds due in 1963 have been suspended from dealings by the New York Stock Exchange. The latter have been called for redemption.

More than 200 members of the Winter colony were guests of Mr. and Mrs. Ross Beason of New York at a tea dance and musical given at the Surf Club this afternoon. Assisting were Mrs. J. Hunter Barton, Mrs. Dewitt Page, Mrs. F. Lowry Wall, Mrs. George Gale Foster, Mrs. Irving J. Reuter, Mrs. C. Chandler Ross and Mrs. Frank B. Shutts.

Amid considerable gnashing of teeth and here and there a real display of bad temper the New York Giants succeeded today in returning to their native soil after three weeks of intensive training in Havana looking not only like superbly conditioned athletes but something that had just emerged from a washwringer.

The Canadian National Railways have ordered 100 refrigerator cars and 200 automobile cars from the Pullman Standard Car Manufacturing Company according to the magazine, Steel. The company also is inquiring for fifty passenger cars.

The Rev. Michael A. Sullivan, rector of St. Augustine's Catholic Church in this city, died in Misericordia Hospital today after a brief illness. He was 51 years old. Father Sullivan was born in Law-rence, Mass.,

The legal machinery of the Federal and State Governments will be invoked against the pro-Nazi German-American League and its leaders, according to an announcement yesterday by Major Julius Hochfelder, counsel for the anti-Nazi German-American League for Culture.

Even those rare ancients who remember the March blizzard of '88 but shut up about it because they have no more heroic memories than of sticking close to the fire, had painful hours Sunday. Those wretched little persistent flakes were ominous. The big, fat, good-natured flakes that soon get tired would have been of happier omen. Fortunately, rain intervened in time.
Less spry, but mentally alert, Mrs. Mary N. Rice, the nation's "oldest mother," celebrated her 105th birthday anniversary today. She proudly held a birthday greeting from President Roosevelt:

A Federal grand jury today brought an indictment charging sale of a narcotic against a man booked as Harry Peltz, 39, of New York, described by an Assistant United States Attorney as "the largest distributor of drugs arrested in New England."

Pope Pius XI plans to bless Easter Sunday throngs from the loggia of St. Peter's. The Pontiff, apparently unaffected by his brief prostration yesterday, arranged today to hear Cardinal Pacelli recite pontifical mass from the San Sebastian Chapel within St. Peter's and later to give his benediction from the famous balcony.

There is every confidence here that the second slice of the French national defense loan, which will be issued tomorrow morning, will be as easily subscribed as the first part, totaling 5,000,000,000 francs, was last Friday. Before the banks closed that day more than 8,000,000,000 francs' worth had been asked for, without taking into account applications made in the country districts.
Net profit of $172,768 in 1936 was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange and subsidiaries in their annual report, in contrast to a net loss of $209,326 for 1935.

The first conference between the General Electric Company and the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, a C.I.O. organization, seeking adjustment of union demands on a company-wide scale, instead of by plants, was held yesterday at the company's offices, 570 Lexington Avenue.

There is every confidence here that the second slice of the French national defense loan, which will be issued tomorrow morning, will be as easily subscribed as the first part, totaling 5,000,000,000 francs, was last Friday. Before the banks closed that day more than 8,000,000,000 francs' worth had been asked for, without taking into account applications made in the country districts.
Net profit of $172,768 in 1936 was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange and subsidiaries in their annual report, in contrast to a net loss of $209,326 for 1935.

The first conference between the General Electric Company and the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, a C.I.O. organization, seeking adjustment of union demands on a company-wide scale, instead of by plants, was held yesterday at the company's offices, 570 Lexington Avenue.
Leon Trotsky has withdrawn his libel suit against the Arbeideren, the leading Communist newspaper in Norway, his Oslo solicitor announced today.

Major Frederic McLaughlin, owner of the Chicago Black Hawks, who hopes soon to present a hockey team composed entirely of American-born players, will experiment with that idea at Madison Square Garden tonight, when his charges will skate out against the New York Rangers for the last time this season.

The unwillingness of some peasants to give up their lands for agrarian distribution led to a riot in which twelve persons were killed, including four women and two soldiers, and several were injured on a ranch in the vicinity of Ixtlahuaca in the State of Mexico.
New York State Troopers on road patrol duty will get a special course next month in "kindly correction."

Business failures in the United States totaled 170 for the week ended March.11, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 174 the week before and 222 for the corresponding week last year.

More than 200 members of the Winter colony were guests of Mr. and Mrs. Ross Beason of New York at a tea dance and musical given at the Surf Club this afternoon. Assisting were Mrs. J. Hunter Barton, Mrs. Dewitt Page, Mrs. F. Lowry Wall, Mrs. George Gale Foster, Mrs. Irving J. Reuter, Mrs. C. Chandler Ross and Mrs. Frank B. Shutts.

Amid considerable gnashing of teeth and here and there a real display of bad temper the New York Giants succeeded today in returning to their native soil after three weeks of intensive training in Havana looking not only like superbly conditioned athletes but something that had just emerged from a washwringer.

The War Department intends to establish an air base at Tacoma, Wash. A large airport has been offered to the government by Pierce County, which acquired the site at a cost of more than $539,000, General Malin Craig, chief of staff, told the House Appropriations subcommittee today when he appealed for sympathetic treatment of the department's request for more funds.

William Oelschlager of Woodside, L. I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Lillian, to Charles A. Sprague, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles H. Sprague of Bridgeport. Miss Oelschlager is a graduate of the Bergen School for Girls in New Jersey.

Service on seven miles of Interborough subway in the Bronx and upper Manhattan was halted or delayed more than two and a half hours yesterday by the breaking of a thirty-six-inch water main at Southern Boulevard and 140th Street, the Bronx.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 13: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Kraus, W. F. (Maj.), Air Corps, General Staff Corps, six days' leave, March 28. Ballard, R. H. (Maj.). Air Corps, 2 months and 15 days' leave, April 27. McDowell, R. M.. Med. Corps, Brooklyn, N. Y., to Hawaiian Dept., to sail Aug. 4.

The Metropolitan Opera will present "La Boheme" at the Academy of Music tonight in concluding its Brooklyn season. The cast will be headed by Franca Somigli, Stella Andreva, Charles Kullmann and John Brownlee. Gennaro Papi will conduct.
While two Negroes were appearing in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday their accuser, William Pescatore of 72 Ellison Street, Paterson, N. J., probably was catching up on his sleep.
The Transport Workers Lodge, militant union seeking to organize the B. M. T., the Interborough and the Independent Subway Systems, figured in developments affecting two of the systems yesterday.

With increasing pressure from the members of the Tammany clubs for the election of a new leader to prepare for the Mayoralty campaign, supporters of Representative Christopher D. Sullivan claimed for him yesterday a majority of the votes of the Tammany executive committee and indicated an intention to move in the near future for a meeting of the committee to elect a leader in place of James J. Dooling.
The six-story building at 675 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of Fifty-third Street, was transferred in a deed recorded yesterday to John T. Javasile of 1,120 Theriot Avenue, the Bronx.

The Chrysler Corporation files its bill of complaint against the International Union, United Automobile Workers of America, and upward of 100 named individuals, seeking relief from -a sit-down strike.

Harry A. McNichol, contractor and former athlete, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in West Philadelphia. He was 50 years old. Formerly one of the country's outstanding basketball players, Mr. McNichol was a member of the championship team of 1908 at the University of Pennsylvania and was captain in 1910, his senior year.

The writing of new life insurance last month was 7.5 per cent more than in February of last year, bringing the total for the first two months of 1937 to 2.9 per cent over the total for the same period of 1936, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.

Mrs. Susan Niles of 189-32 Fortyfourth Avenue, Flushing, who had been a Salvation Army worker for nearly half a century, died Sunday evening in an automobile while she and her daughter, Mrs. Samuel J. Maginnis, were on their way to a Salvation Army meeting in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

The Democratic organizations of the five boroughs received a setback yesterday in their fight to prevent the use of proportional representation in the election of City Councilmen this Fall, as provided in the new charter, when Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church handed down a decision declaring the method completely constitutional.

Directors of the Pfeiffer Brewing Company have notified shareholders of their decision to offer 39,041.2 shares of the company's stock for subscription by shareholders at $9.50 a share, according to a letter filed yesterday with the New York Stock Exchange. The communication emphasizes that this offering will not be made unless the registration statement to be filed with the Securities Exchange Commission is approved.

Edwin V. Hellawell, receiver of the First National Bank of Hempstead, L. I., obtained yesterday an order from Supreme Court Justice Peter P. Smith in Brooklyn requiring creditors of the bank to show cause in Nassau County Supreme Court on March 25 why he should not be permitted to accept $75,000 in collective settlement of a $1,710,000 suit against the former directors and officers of the bank.

Miss Mary E. Kennedy of 523-A Hancock Street, Brooklyn, was formally sworn in yesterday as secretary to Police Commissioner Valentine. Mr. Valentine officiated at the ceremony, attended by his chief inspector and the ranking officials of the department.

Police raided the headquarters of an alleged Fascist espionage ring today. They said they discovered plans to create disorders in the Catalan capital. Several army officers were reported among numerous persons arrested.
Representative Dickstein of New York told the House today that there were practically no Communists along the East River from Chatham Square to East Houston Street, the district he represents.

IT was a mistake to bring up the case of Horse vs. Man in any running debate. It led to too many complications. Volunteers bobbed up in all directions, taking sides with great enthusiasm, not to say fury. There were men who ridiculed the idea that anybody on foot could hope to keep up with a horse that wasn't hitched to a post.

Prospects are increasing for exploratory conversations before long between the United States and Japan looking to the negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement. It would be the first arranged in the Far East under Secretary Hull's program.

With a program that started before dawn and continued until midnight, business women paid calls yesterday on ten outstanding women executives and professionals and watched them at their work, as the first of a series of events scheduled for National Business Women's Week.
While pressure for delivery of Easter merchandise on order continued in the wholesale markets here yesterday, late reorder volume was somewhat under expectations.

The current traffic safety campaign of the Police Department bore its first dividends in several weeks with a reduction of the automobile death rate last week and week-end, it was announced yesterday from the office of First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.

The circus rushed the season by a month and came to town yesterday. Traditional harbinger of Spring to this city, the men, women and animals of Cole Brothers and Clyde Beatty Circus arrived at the Baltimore Ohio Railroad freight yards at Eleventh Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street at 2 P. M., one day behind a snowstorm.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Sunday at his home in Augusta, Ga., of Colonel Abram Levy, who served overseas in the World War and for a time commanded Camp Oglethorpe, Ga. He was 62 years old.

Leaders in science, education and industry thronged the First Unitarian Church here this afternoon when funeral services were conducted for Professor Elihu Thomson, inventor in the electrical field, who died Saturday at his Swampscott home.
