A district conference will be held by the American Trade Association Executives, with the cooperation of theTrade Association Executives, in New York City next Tuesday afternoon and evening, it was announced here yesterday.
Dr. B. B. Moeur, the country physician who rose from relative obsecurity to serve two terms as Arizona's depression-time Governor, died at his home here today. He was 67 years old.
Scoring five points out of a possible seven, Reuben Fine of New York, famous American chess master, today emerged as winner of first prize in an international tournament at the Moscow Chess Club.

Because of rumors that Kirsten Flagstad intends to retire at the end of the current Metropolitan Opera season, her manager made public yesterday the Norwegian soprano's engagements for the next eighteen months.

Rear Admiral Richmond Pearson Hobson, one of the naval heroes of the Spanish-American War, died of heart disease at his home, 1,435 Lexington Avenue, between Ninetythird and Ninety-fourth Streets, at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning. He was 66 years old.

Alleging that the Dock Department's plans for development of North Beach Airport, Queens, would result in a waste of money, Elmer H. Holmes, president of Air Terminal Properties, Inc., yesterday obtained an order from Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo directing the Sinking Fund Commission to show cause why they should not be enjoined from appropriating any funds to carry it out.

A funeral service for Charles Melbourne Higgins, formerly a vice president and director of the Standard Oil Company of New York, will be held at 10:30 A. M. today at St. James Episcopal Church, Seventy-first Street and Madison Avenue.

The chances of an American victory in the Grand National Steeplechase on Friday depends largely on Robert Lehman's Didoric and J. B. Snow's Delachance, in the opinion of the experts who back their selections with money.

A reduction in the weight and fineness of Colombia's gold peso, changing it from the equivalent of one-fifth of the old British pound sterling to a ratio of 1.75 pesos to the United States dollar, is provided in a bill presented yesterday to the Congress here by the Minister of Finance. The proposed value has been the exchange rate since May, 1936.

A banking syndicate headed by E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $638,000 of refunding and highway bonds of Rensselaer County, N. Y., on a bid of 100.41 for the securities as 2.90s.

With actual, as opposed to theoretical, control of Spain's frontiers and seacoast still ineffective because of delays in putting control officers at their stations, a non-intervention subcommittee went ahead today with measures of more extensive pacification.

Joseph A. Maynard, Collector of the Port, announced today that customs men had handled 12,750,535 pounds of wool in the last week. Of that amount, he said, 8,639,573 pounds entered the port and 3,554,134 pounds were withdrawn from bonded warehouses for consumption and 556,828 pounds for transportation.

Cholera has broken out among 50,000 pilgrims who gathered in the Coimbatore district for a festival amid thick forests. All went well till the last day, when cases of cholera were reported. The disease then attacked a party from Mysore State and before morning five persons, including four women, all belonging to one family, were dead.

Quick resales were reported yesterday for many of the thirty properties recently acquired by Orpington Estates, Inc., A. Simon, president, from the New York Protestant Episcopal Public School in a trade by which the Episcopal group acquired the twenty-storyl apartment building under construction at 5 Riverside Drive.

There is never a closed season on open letters to the editor. Here are two relating to subjects of current interest. From Joseph Bandes, secretary of the Association of Sportsmen's Clubs of Greater New York and Long Island:
Funeral services for Frank L. Chadwick, former clerk of Supreme Court in Brooklyn, were held last night at the Fairchild Chapel, 86 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn.

Income tax collections of $381,512,457 between March 1 and March 15 were reported today by the Internal Revenue Bureau. This compared with $281,758,032 for the corresponding period last year, a gain of $99,754,425, or about 35 per cent.
It was not mine to know you face to face; And yet I know you in your charming grace Of Grecian art and blue Italian skies; And in the poet's song that never dies.

Chief Little Wolf, 220, of Colorado, threw Ed Meske, 218, of Akron, Ohio, in 34 minutes with a body spread in the feature wrestling event at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 2,000.

The Bolivian Government issued a decree today canceling the Standard Oil Company's concession and confiscating its vast holdings. The decree charges Standard Oil with defrauding the Bolivian Government by exporting petroleum without paying royalties due the government under the concession.

Another record fell to Oxford today when the Dark Blues rowed from Barnes Bridge to Hammersmith Bridge in 7 minutes 42 seconds. The best previous mark was 7 minutes 45 seconds, made by Oxford in 1933.
The California Senate today vote down, 34-5, a resolution to grant a legislative pardon to Thomas J. Mooney, convicted of murder in the 1916 San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing.

There may be a combination division of the fifty-foot. and twelvemeter one-design sloops in the Handicap Class on Long Island Sound next Summer, making the biggest fleet of such large craft that ever has been assembled in the group.

Under aggressive buying for both foreign and domestic account, the upward movement on the Cotton Exchange was accelerated yesterday. All months rose to new high levels for the last six years, July advancing $2 a bale from its low figure of the morning, and the list closed with a net gain of 9 to 24 points.

For the first time in months steel manufacturers responded to Navy advertisements, thirteen different organizations bidding for parts of the 25,000,000 pounds needed for construction of destroyers and submarines in navy yards.

Savings Banks were among the sellers of business and housing properties reported yesterday. Some of the deals were resales. The Bank for Savings sold to Third Avenue Stores, Inc., a syndicate formed by Webb Knapp, Inc., the one-story taxpayer contraining eight stores and a fourstory apartment house at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

More than 500 members of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York were told at their annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night that they were the chief losers from strikes in the motor car factories. George E.

In a speech before a general stockholders' meeting of the Reichsbank, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, its president and the Minister of Economics, recounted pridefully today how the Reichsbank had financed the Third Reich's might and accomplishments and had confounded "false foreign prophets who had predicted the collapse of German economy long ago."

Toronto Skating Club officials announced tonight a sell-out crowd of more than 14,000 would witness the opening performance of the club's "coronation" ice carnival in the Maple Leaf Gardens tomorrow night.
Dr. Otto Wick of San Antonio, Texas, has won the first prize of $500 in the Lake Placid Club's choral composition contest. Dr. Wick is a former conductor of the New York Liederkranz.

Rio de Janeiro, Brazil's capital, also known as the Federal District, lost its autonomy today, when President Getulio Vargas signed a decree placing it under Federal jurisdiction, appointing the Acting Mayor, the Rev. Olympio de Mello, a priest, as interventor, and suspending the Board of Aldermen for one year.

John E. Coyle of R. C. Williams Co., Inc., was elected president of the Amalgamated Hotel and Restaurant Supply Credit Association, Inc., at the annual meeting and dinner at the Hotel Astor last night. Other officers are Joseph G.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-Daniel N. Tierney, from 6th Precinct to 19th Division, office of the Chief Inspector, assigned to duty with Safety Bureau. Assignment to desk duty discontinued. James E. Donnelly, from 1st Division, to 6th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.

Spirited contests in four villages-Babylon, Patchogue, Lindenhurst and Sag Harbor-featured the annual elections in Suffolk County tonight. Seven Mayors and twentysix village trustees in all were chosen.

A trade development program in which manufacturers and retailers will cooperate to increase the sales volume of carpets and rugs this year was outlined at the annual dinner of the Floor Coverings Advertising Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,372,850 barrels, a new high mark and a gain of 74,050 barrels over the previous week. The figure is compared to Bureau of Mines calculations of 3,159,000 barrels daily for March by the American Petroleum Institute.
Steel ingot production increased' more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index has advanced to 118.1 from 115.9 and compares with 77.5 for the week ended March 14, 1936.

Optimistic about "ultimate settlement" of Mexico's foreign debt and the debt of the Mexican railways, George Rublee, who, as the representative of the international bankers' committee, has been negotiating for a resumption of payments with the Mexican authorities, announced today that he would depart for New York on Wednesday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Catherine Lewerth, daughter of Mrs. Daniel Lewerth of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. Lewerth, to Lloyd Vincent Almirall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Juan A. Almirall of Brooklyn and Cragsmoor, N. Y.

Approximately 50,000 of New York's descendants of the Emerald Isle are scheduled to march up Fifth Avenue this afternoon in what they hope to make the largest and most colorful St. Patrick's Day parade in the history of the city.
Mrs. Francisca B. Benavides, wife of the President of Peru, Oscar Benavides, arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Maria to place two of her three children in schools.

Hosinger Bode, Inc., have arranged a permanent first mortgage loan of $225,000 for the Elbert Realty Corporation. Morris Strominger, secretary, on the six-story, eighty-two-family apartment house under construction at Elmhurst. Queens, on the south side of Elbertson St.. 150 feet east of Britton AV., on a plot 230 by 100 feet.

The German conception of a new Locarno agreement that would effectively banish war along the Franco-German frontier-as explained at some length in the Reich government's memorandum to Britain-indicates it was dictated by implications of a military nature no less than political considerations.

The first of a series of conferences between committees representing employes of the Independent Subway System and officials of the Board of Transportation took place yesterday at the offices of the board, 250 Hudson Street.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild, which provided funds last year for a new cyclorama for the Metropolitan Opera House, announced yesterday at its annual meeting at the Hotel Pierre that it would provide $10,000 for a Metropolitan endowment fund.
The Republican party organization in Hempstead, headed by Supervisor A. Holly Patterson, went down to defeat today in the Hempstead village election.

After inspecting two of the city's nineteen new Fire Department pumpers at the north end of the Municipal Building yesterday, Fire Commissioner McElligott said he was well pleased with the new equipment, which was built according to the city's specifications.

Edwards Rogers, champion, defeated Louis Brooks, challenger, 127-117, in the first of their threeblock match for the national amateur pocket billiard title at the Strand Academy last night. The block went twenty-one innings, with Brooks making a high run of 29, while Rogers had an unfinished cluster of 24.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels announced yesterday that the city would appeal the decision of Supreme Court Justice James T. Hallinan in Brooklyn, who granted a refund of $10,528.19 to former Kings County Sheriff Frank J. Quayle, who sued for the return of pay cuts.

Launching of two Spring beer campaigns was announced yesterda. The Beverwyck Breweries, Albany, producers of Beverwyck beer and Irish Cream ale, announced a greatly increased newspaper campaign in seventy New York, New England, New Jersey and selected Southern papers.

The Winter of 1936-37 will come to an end at 7:45 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Saturday, March 20. At that moment the earth will have reached the point in its orbit where its axis is at right angles to a line from the sun. Thus, the sun will then be directly over a point on the Equator.
Three players who had the confidence to couple Sequoia and Immersal in the daily double left Oaklawn Park $1,230.30 richer today.

Spokesmen for the nation's railroads and for the twenty-one standard railway unions tonight signed a voluntary agreement covering pensions to be paid to 1,500,000 railway employes after Congress enacts legislation to validate the arrangement.
A "Tyrolean wedding" with peasant costumes and music was a feature of a Spring fashion show yesterday at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Snowdrifts resulting in stalled automobiles did not hamper the interest in the elections in the four villages of Orange County where there were contests for Mayor and Trustees, but in the remaining nine villages, where candidates were unopposed, few voters ventured to the polls on account of the weather.

A summons was issued yesterday by Magistrate Adolph Stern requiring the appearance in Yorkville Court on March 29 of Fritz Kuhn national leader of the GermanAmerican League, which has repeatedly declared its mission of spreading the Nazi philosophy in the United States.

Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers took time off from baseball for track practice today. Instead of racing out around the field and gathering for the normal ball and glove exercise to start the workout, the entire group of fifty players was -lined up in left field like a company of soldiers at inspection.

Bernhard K. Schaefer gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Florence Ruperti, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justus Ruperti, and Allan Gerdau, whose marriage will take place in May.

The Democratic party made extensive gains in the village elections in Rockland County today, winning in Piermont, where the issue had been control by the Democratic organization, and returning West Haverstraw, Democratic National Chairman James Farley's home territory, to the Democratic ranks for the first time in several years.

After being locked up overnight in default of bail, eighteen union employes of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, who staged a sit-down strike in the institution, were arraigned with the president of their local yesterday before Magistrate Rudich in Flatbush Court and held for trial in Special Sessions.

Shareholders of the Western Auto Supply Company have authorized a recapitalization plan to become effective on March 24, according to a report by the company to the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Announcement has been made of the marriage in Reno, Nev., on March 10 of Mrs. Barbara Barry Owen de Davila, daughter of Paul Barry Owen of 425 East Eightysixth Street and Mrs. Raymond J. Funkhouser of Rye, N. Y., to Wilho H. Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Anderson of Cedar Knolls. N. J.

A national labor policy designed to minimize the probability of strikes is being formulated, it was learned today, and its presentation to Congress awaits the outcome of the fight over revision of the Federal judiciary system.

Trading in commodity futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday was of record-breaking proportions, and for the first time in the history of the Exchange the ticker ran from two to three minutes late.
The Ladies Auxiliary of the Fresh Air and Convalescent Home of St. Vincent de Paul, Spring Valley, N. Y., will hold its annual card party on Saturday afternoon in the ballroom of the Hotel Plaza.

Plans for the issuance of additional shares of common stock and the retirement of $1,000,000 of capital notes now held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were announced yesterday by the Empire Trust Company. Directors have called a special meeting of shareholders for March 29 to authorize the increase in capital.

Despite the fact that Merle Vandenbush was described by his attorney in Westchester County Court today as not being "inherently vicious," County Judge Gerald Nolan recalled the desperado's numerous crimes and sentenced him to a Sing Sing prison term of fortyfive to seventy years.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City: General Conditions Lamb trading was slow, though active enough to move a moderate kill at higher prices. Lamb cuts were strong to sharply higher. Other classes were little changed. Kosher lamb opened stronger and other kosher meats about steady under a slow trade.

Brooklyn provided the leading construction project in the city yesterday with plans for an eightyfour-family apartment house on Ocean Parkway to be erected at a cost of $260,000. Details of this project and others follow:

Boris Smolar, Jewish Telegraphic Agency correspondent, who on March 12 was ordered to leave Germany within three days, has received permission for an indefinite stay in Berlin through the intervention of United States consular representatives. Final decision in the case will be made in a fortnight by the secret police.
Gabriel Signoret, one of the foremost actors of the French stage, died this morning after an operation at the age of 59. Mr. Signoret was as successful
Mrs. Virginia Nesbitt Gamble, wife of State Assemblyman Ralph A. Gamble, died of a heart ailment this afternoon at her home here. She was 55 years old.
Death today stilled the notes of one-half of Linton's widely known musical duo. The singing mouse that had been giving concerts with a canary died from some unknown cause.
Paris will get one more World's Fair out of its Eiffel Tower and then will tear it down. It was built

At her home on Via Del Lago, Mrs. William Randolph Hearst entertained tonight with a dinner. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Paulding Fosdick, Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Shearson, Mrs. Henry R. Rea, Mrs. Margaret Emerson, Mrs. John Hay Whitney, Mrs. John Baragwanath, Mrs. Frederick McLaughlin, Captain Alastair Mackintosh, Bernard Boutet de Monvel, T. Chestley Richardson, William Taylor and Colonel Owen Hill Kenan.

In a long and brilliant seminal engagement Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, Conn., defeated Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France, the 1935-36 champion, by 12-10, 4-6, 8-6, to annex the feature match today in the Bermuda title tennis tournament.

Ireland's General Owen O'Duffy wanted to know whether Spain's civil war was a private fight or whether anybody could get into it. Tomorrow is St. Patrick's Day, but for many weeks there has been a great deal of wearing ' o' the green" hereabouts by two battalions of tall, broad-shouldered Irishmen.
The Free Synagogue announced last night a campaign to raise $300,000 for the construction of a new house of worship on a site adjacent to its present building at 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

Mulberry St.. 131, 40x25; Elwood Mildeberger and wife to Gennaro Montanimo, 131 Mulberry St. ($5). E. 4th St., s. e. cor. Lewis St., 100x51.5: Metropolitan Savings Bank to 400 East Fourth St.. Inc., 400 E. 4th St. ($50). Av. C. 73-75, 36.4 1/2x90; Union Square Savings Bank to Mary E. Wood, 147 4th Av., care of Wm. N. Webb ($11).
A petition for probate of the will of Thomas Clyde, son of a founder of the Clyde-Mallory Steamship Lines, disclosed today that he left an estate of approximately $1,500,000.

Dr. and Mrs. O. Paul Humpstone of 327 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Elizabeth Humpstone, to James B. Gardiner of New York, son of Harry Gardiner of Amsterdam, N. Y.

Four persons are known to be dead, ten are gravely wounded and 300 less seriously injured as a result of rioting that broke out about 9 o'clock last evening in the workingclass Paris suburb of Clichy and lasted until after midnight.

With more than 6,000 sit-downers in eight Chrysler automobile plants heavily armed with clubs, wrenches and missiles of all kinds, prepared to defy the injunction ordering them to leave by 9:30 o'clock tomorrow morning, this city of 1,700,000 persons was threatened tonight with something in the nature of a citywide general strike.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress, urged yesterday that members of the Far Rockaway Chapter of Hadassah cooperate in building up membership in the congress to strengthen its influence with the British Government, which is soon to receive, he said, a report from the Royal Palestine Commission.

Harold J. Brown of the Baltusrol Club, Short Hills, N. J., won his first-round match in the Belleview amateur championship today, defeating the Belleair Country Club titleholder, Vincent K. Hilton by 1 up.

Dr. Loretta Bender, head of the Psychiatric Ward at Bellevue Hospital, Mrs. Harriet Ayer Seymour, Ruth Collins and Dr. Willem van de Well will appear in the Forum, "Music Therapy," this afternoon at the Midtown Community Music Center.
The yacht Yankee Girl, on which Mr. and Mrs. John Archbold of New York are making a honeymoon cruise, ran aground near Castle Island light early Monday morning.

The Havana-trained Giants engaged in their first contest of the year on their native soil today and forthwith came up with a highly gratifying performance. They walloped the Bees, 8 to 6, with Melvin Ott exploding a home run and sundry others hammering the ball for a total of twelve hits.

Dr. Foster Kennedy, neurologist, 52 years old, of 14 Sutton Square, was found not guilty yesterday at a hearing before Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in traffic court on a charge of having passed a red light on Jan. 18.

Horace N. Dougherty of 841 Park Place, Brooklyn, resigned yesterday as foreman and as a member of the special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case, giving as his reason that he is now over 70 years old.

Omission of the Duke of Windsor's name from the message on the civil list, which King George VI sent to Parliament today, was the first official intimation that there would be no State pension for the royal-exile.
William Minot, Boston lawyer, trustee and clubman, died yesterday at his home here of complications following an attack of pneumonia. He was 51 years old.

A verdict that corresponds in English legal terms to death by misadventure and that is described tonight in France as a finding of "voluntary accident" has been returned by the magistrate who investigated the circumstances surrounding the death of the British actor and playwright, Frank O. Vosper, aboard the liner Paris en route to Southamption March 6.
Scoring ranged from a new low to a new high as more teams joined the parade into the third round of the men's national A. A. U. basketball championship today.

THIS LIFE I'VE LOVED, by Isobel Field. (Longmans, Green, $3.) Mrs. Field's autobiography is much concerned with her stepfather, Robert Louis Stevenson. A LAMP ON THE PLAINS, by Paul Horgan. (Harper, $2.50.) A novel of New Mexico

Current assets of the Erie Railroad Company at the close of 1936 amounted to $20,832,593, including $9,140,480 in cash, compared with $16,651,616 and $6,546,174, respectively, a year before, while current liabilities were $30,806,929, against $31,306,855, it is shown in the annual report for 1936 issued yesterday.

The six-family apartment house at 47-49 Forty-sixth Street, Sunny side, Queens, has been purchased for cash over a new first mortgage of $16,000 by the Norman Lila Estates, Samuel Horowits, president. T. Nicholson Scoble was the broker in the deal.
The Philadelphia Electric Company reported today, for 1936, operating revenues of $66,648,371, an increase of $2,854,262, or 4.5 per cent, over the revenues for 1935.

The need for enlarging the work of the Brooklyn Juvenile Protective Association was emphasized yesterday at the luncheon at the Hotel Bossert to start the organization's first budget appeal for $30,000.

A. L. Burbank of A. L. Burbank Co., Ltd., head of the Marine Division of the New York World's Fair bond sales committee, estimated yesterday that the influx of foreign visitors during the seven months of the exposition would more than treble the annual normal tourist business of the Port of New York.

Plaintiffs bid in seven properties in Manhattan at auction sales yesterday. The list included two sevenstory apartment houses at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 129th Street in Harlem. The results of the forced sales follow:

Federal Judge William Bondy reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for Radio-Keith-Orpheum, Inc., for authority to pay off $600,000 in first lien secured notes and thus save the corporation the 4 per cent interest payment.
District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan refused yesterday to surrender Paul H. Wendel to the Mercer County authorities

United States Government bonds again were pressed upon the market at declining prices in yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The Treasury 2 1/2s of 1953-49, a new block of which had been issued only the day before, dropped to 9930-32, a new low, since their first issuance last December.

The cost of compensation and medical care for injured WPA workers during the first eighteen months of the Works Progress Administration program was $10,000,000, or $70,000,000 less than the cost of insuring the workers through private companies, it was disclosed yesterday at the close of a two-day conference of State safety consultants of the WPA at the Hotel Edison.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16.-J. A. Robert Quinn, the red-headed president of the Boston Bees, was peering through the grandstand screen as his hired help went through a practice session this morning when he let out a yelp as a player in the field made a grand catch.

The Ocean Dominion Line American-built, Norwegian-owned freighter Aristo, 1,821 tons gross, which struck a reef in a thick mist at 4 P. M. yesterday eight miles north of St. George, Bermuda, sank at 2 A. M. today a mile and a half northeast of the island when a towline of the salvage tug John S. Darrell snapped.
Great Britain's new heavyweight champion, Tommy Farr, sprang a surprise today when he announced he probably would not meet Max Baer, former world titleholder, on April 15 as scheduled.

The Texas Company, which sells gasoline, oil and other products through more than 40,000 stations in the United States, was charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with violation of the Clayton AntiTrust Act and the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Four members of the English Parliament, Lord Phillimore, the Earl of Mansfield, Mackinnon Raikes, and A. R. Wise, are among the passengers due to arrive today from England on the Cunard liner Berengaria.
Henry A. Roemer, president of the Pittsburgh Steer, Sharon Steel and Niles Rolling Mills Companies, is to become chairman of the board of directors of the Empire Sheet and Tin Plate Company.

Expenditure of $300,000,000 in the next thirteen years for building a system of super-highways, four to eight lanes wide, was urged today by Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, State Superintendent of Public Works, in his annual report to the Legislature.
The thud of Postmaster John N. Kirchner's single hand stamp imprinted the postmark "St. Patrick, Mo., March 17," on the last of a mountain of collectors' mail tonight.
Syracuse and Buffalo bowlers walked off today with all the major honors of the 1937 New York State women's tourney.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 15: COLONEL Murchison, W. G., Adjutant General's Dept., to retirement. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Reddy, J. J., Med. Corps, promoted to colonel.

Lord and Lady Marley of London, who arrived on the Normandie, are at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. and Mrs. De Forest Grant have returned to 960 Fifth Avenue after passing the Winter at the Boca Raton Club in Florida.

After almost two hours of debate the Board of Aldermen voted yesterday to investigate the administration of relief by all public agencies in this city. The vote was 57 to 2, with two members not voting.

Ernest Angell of New York and James Caffrey of Boston, regional administrators of the Securities and Exchange Commission, are to participate in the conference of the Eastern group of the National Association of Securities Commissioners.

More than 250 members of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs served as store executives, hostesses and saleswomen today at the third annual celebration of New Jersey Club Woman Day at Hahne's Department Store here.

The Fashion Novelty Corporation, curtain manufacturers, have purl chased a plot of about 18,000 square feet on Thirty-eighth Street, off the Bergen Turnpike, North Bergen, N. J., from the Bonanno Construction Company. A one-story brick building is being erected on the site. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
Dr. Willard L. Thorp of New York, director of economic research of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., cited "war business without the business of war" as a principal cause of recent economic gains.

The hotel strike which began at the Statler late yesterday and spread to three other leading hotels here today as the employers and workers tried to beat each other to the punch in calling lock-outs and sit-downs, was settled tonight after an all-day conference called by Governor Frank Murphy.

A mortgage for $2,650,000 on the nineteen-story apartment house on the southwest corner of Amsterdam Av. and 86th St.. held by the trustees under a reorganization plan of New York Title and Mortgage Co. investments from Paloma Estates, Inc., Edward M. Krulevltch, president, has been extended to July 31, 1941.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated March 13: CAPTAINS Nichols, N. L., Headquarters Third Naval District, to command the Wyoming. Payne, S. S., the Dobbin, to Oahu, T. H., June 5, as Inspector of Ordnance in charge Naval Ammunition Depot.

The wife of a $17-a-week Greek dishwasher here and a Long Branch, N. J., widow were among the seven American winners of the $31,021 residue prizes of the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes drawn in Dublin Yesterday.
Stormy weather was largely responsible for a light vote cast in the elections today In the three villages in Putnam County-Brewster, Cold Spring and Nelsonville.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that the Independent city subway extension to 169th Street and Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, would be opened about April 24 and that Queens express service would start at the same time.
George B. Jermyn, a leader in the financial and business world of Northeastern Pennsylvania for forty years, died today at the family home here, after an illness of four months. He was 74 years old.

Although the rain which has plagued President Roosevelt since the second day of his visit here was not in evidence today a slight chill in the air canceled plans for inspection of the Pine Valley Settlement Project and the camp of the Civilian Conservation Corps at Chipley, a few miles away.

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized listing of $50,000,000 Great Northern Railway Company general mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, Series I, due in 1967; 880,036 shares of General Printing Ink Corporation common stock, $1 par value; 15,437 additional shares of Remington Rand, Inc., common stock, $1 par value.
Harvard University will offer a special onemonth business course in July, through which about 100 executives may get a taste of school days again.

Stocks closed generally higher, rail and liquor shares strongest; turnover, 1,750,150 shares, third slowest trading of year. United States Government loan weakened and closed lower, other bonds irregular; transactions, $19,286,500.

Miss Mary Isabella Stuart Brown, daughter of Mrs. Harold McCleave Brown of 157 East Eighty-first Street and the late Mr. Brown, will be married on June 5 to Bradford Willet Stiles, son of Mrs. Francis W. T. Stiles of 122 East Seventyfirst Street, and the late Mr. Stiles.

On the day on which the American State Department, following its policy of strictest neutrality, refused Sidney Franklin permission to accompany me to Spain as a war correspondent, fearing he might engage in bull-fighting, 12,000 Italian troops were landed at Malaga and More Cadiz.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest the article by Louis Stark in THE NEW YORK TIMES relative to the decision of the National Labor Relations Board in the Remington Rand case.
The Chrysler Motors Corporation strike in Detroit caused the lay-off of 5,000 automobile parts workers today in Toledo, due to inability to make shipments.

Leonard Del Genio, Harlem welterweight, knocked out Eddie Reilly, the Bronx, in 1:17 of the last round in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 9,000 watched the Harlemite win with a left to the jaw.

Catholic, Protestant and Jewish speakers joined last night in celebrating the 100th anniversary of Congregation Shaare Zedek, at the synagogue, 212 West Ninety-third Street. President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman sent letters of felioitation to the congregation which was founded in 1837.
The year 1936 witnessed the "virtual completion of the 'reflation' of the money supply," the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its annual report, which is being made public today.

United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies is leaving Moscow-somewhat unexpectedly-within the next two weeks for Washington. During his eight weeks here Mr. Davies has done more serious investigating than the rest of the diplomatic corps in a year.
The Court of Appeals held today that the New York City sales tax applied to the showing of motionpicture films within the city.
Mayor Wilson announced tonight settlement of the five-day strike of city garbage and ash wagon drivers, affecting more than 1,000 men.

In the greatest triumphal procession Libya has ever witnessed in modern times, Premier Benito Mussolini entered the city of Tripoli this evening on a white charger amid wild manifestations of enthusiasm from more than 100,000 persons.

Rodman Morgan, '37, of Philadelphia, captured the Princeton University squash racquets championship today on the university courts by defeating David S. Speer, '38, of Bronxville, N. Y., in straight games. 15-11, 15-5, 15-10.

Business failures in the retail group totaled ninety-one in the week ended March 11, which compared with 101 in the previous week and 144 in the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

James Riely Gordon, architect and member of many civic committees in this field for the last thirty years, died yesterday at his residence, 159 Corlies Avenue, Pelham Heights, N. Y., after an illness of two weeks. He was 74 years old.

While Republican chiefs in the Legislature remained hopeful that they would be able to bring about passage in both the Senate and Assembly of the Nunan-Moffat bill to prevent the sale in this State of any merchandise from other States wholly or in part the product of child labor, there were indications today of pressure being brought to bear on Democratic members of the Senate to oppose the measure.

In sending this Saint Patrick's Day greeting through the North American. Newspaper Alliance to Irishmen and friends of Ireland in other lands, I pray that they may continue to enjoy the blessings of peace and be spared the misery that war brings in its train.

Chairman Robert L. Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee expressed the belief today that no new taxes would be needed this year. He added that as a result of a talk last week with President Roosevelt, none would be requested unless receipts fell below expectations or appropriations exceeded budget estimates.

After an absence of nearly three months, the five United States Army officers and members of their families who accompanied them to Chile to participate in the celebration of the 400th anniversary of the founding of the city of Valparaiso returned to this city yesterday.

The nearer to the front lines that one g es the more impressive does the government's success against the Italians fighting as Spanish Rebels appear. This correspondent has just returned from Trijueque, which the Loyalists wrested from Italian hands three days ago.

Mayor La Guardia took issue yesterday with Alderman James A. Burke of Queens on the Alderman's demand for an investigation of what he considered unreasonable and discriminatory requirements of education and age for civil service positions. .

Dr. William C. Miller, Chief Veterinary of the New York City Health Department for the last twenty-three years, died early Monday morning at Misericordia Hospital after a brief illness. He was 57 years old.

At a meeting of the Women's Self-Government Association of Cornell University, Miss Janet E. Dempster of Schenectady was elected president of the association for the academic year 1936-37. This is the highest elective office open to women on the campus. Miss Dempster is a junior in the College of Home Economics.

The police began a search yesterday to recover twenty negotiable $1,000 Dominion of Canada bonds, which disappeared from the coat pocket of a Wall Street messenger while he was being jostled in an elevator of a building where he was to deliver them.

A $45,000,000 refunding and expansion program will be acted upon by stockholders of the American Rolling Mill Company at their annual meeting in Middletown, Ohio, on April 15, with stockholders of record on March 2 entitled to vote.

W. W. Norton reports considerable advance interest in "Mathematics and the Million," by Lancelot Hogben, which he will publish on March 25. This book was the surprise hit of the British publishing season last Fall, outselling--according to Mr. Norton-all titles on both fiction and non-fiction lists.
For the first time the Japanese authorities have prevented a reputable foreign journalist, long a resident in this country, from returning to Japan.
For the first time since the American Bowling Congress championships started in the 212th Coast Artillery Armory last Wednesday there were no changes among the divisional leaders yesterday.

More than half of the original members of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion, American volunteers aiding the Spanish Government, have been stricken from the ranks by death or wounds, Miss Mildred Rackley, assistant director of an American ambulance unit, said today.

John J. O'Brien Jr. of Rockville Center, L. I., was elected captain of the Columbia basketball team for next season, it was announced yesterday by: Manager John Northcott. The captain-elect is now in the junior class and was an outstanding performer at forward for the Lions in the past season.

A poll of attorneys in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey resulted in 1,423 votes favoring President Roosevelt's proposals to change the Federal judiciary and 1,350 votes in opposition, the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut announced yesterday.

Because of the glittering nature of other public questions not much attention has been paid to the President's establishment of the permanent Maritime Commission by sending to the Senate the names of his choices as Commissioners.

The statement that people who "wanted the movies purified seem to be staying away from clean classics in droves" was made today by E. L. Kuykendall of Columbus, Miss., president of the MotionPicture Theaters Owners of America.

A working committee of the AllIndia Congress tonight recommended, after several days' discussion here, acceptance of ministerial office in provinces where the party commands a majority, provided "the leader of the party in the Legislature is satisfied and is able to state publicly that as long as he and his Cabinet act within the Constitution the Governor will not use his special powers of interference or set aside the advice of the Minsisters."

Warren Dow of the Salle Santelli, member of the 1936 Olympic team, captured the Greco trophy for the second straight year by winning all of his bouts in the fence-off yesterday at the Greco Fencing Academy.
Students of London University demonstrating against Nazism completely spoiled today what had been intended by Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop as an impressive demonstration of German friendship.

In defiance of Governor Hoffman's ban on sit-down strikes and his warning that all the resources of the State would be used to foil such measures, strikers in Newark and in Clifton resorted to sit-down tactics yesterday, unmolested by State authorities.
Miss Rowean Turner wanted to know what a caterpillar ate, and the outcome of her casual experiment is that she now claims "Skeezix," brown and fuzzy, as a trained pet.
The budget of the Canadian National Railways for 1937, tabled in the House of Commons today by Transport Minister Howe, shows contemplated expenditures of $65,721,000.
The faculty and student body of the Columbia Law School have taken conflicting stands on the question of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposals, it was learned yesterday.

A merger of the Crown Willamette Paper Company and the Crown Zellerbach Corporation was voted at meetings of shareholders yesterday. The plan will become effective upon the filing of the necessary documents in Nevada and Delaware within a few days, representatives of the two companies announced.
The call which President ROOSEVELT made, soon after his arrival in Warm Springs, upon Mr. GEORGE FOSTER PEABODY had a significance beyond that of a friendly, neighborly visit.

By a vote of 1,614,096 to 22,068, stockholders of the Cities Service Company, at a special meeting here, which lasted from 2:30 to 8 P. M., approved Henry L. Doherty's offer of compromise and settlement of the suit brought by six persons owning 840 shares of stock against Mr. Doherty, Cities Service and affiliated companies and directors of the Cities Service Company.

America's professional golf legion, with the exception of sixteen stars who are exempt, will shoot it out on or before May 4 in qualifying rounds for 100 places in the annual P. G. A. title tournament at the Pittsburgh Field Club May 24-30.
Prices of wheat in the foreign markets continued on the upgrade today, with Liverpool and Buenos Aires and the deferred deliveries at Winnipeg advancing to new high levels for the season.
In the only upset featuring the elections of twenty-one villages of Westchester County today, the Democrats won control of the village board of Irvington while retaining control of North Tarrytown.

Construction work started in February in thirty-seven eastern States totaled $188,590,800, as compared with $140,419,100 for February of last year and $242,844,000 for January of this year, according to statistics made public yesterday by the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By CAFE PRE CAT, formerly 112 W. 48th St.-Liabilities, $11,561; no assets except real estate and insurance. The members of the firm are Sam Benrubi and Joseph Garcia.

Manufacturers of oil burners were urged here today to "assist the refiners in producing an adequate supply of fuel oil at a fair price" by reducing the number of grades now demanded for tank-wagon delivery.
The rose and the carnation, perennial favorites with lovers of horticultural beauty, were the featured flowers at the flower show yesterday.

The first appointments in the reorganization of the State Department of Social Welfare to take over the TERA before July 1 were announced yesterday by Commissioner David C. Adie after the monthly meeting of the Board of Social Welfare at the State Building.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee, will be prepared tomorrow to deliver Gulf States Steel Company first (closed) mortgage sinking fund 4 1/2 per cent bonds due Oct. 15, 1961, in definitive form in exchange for outstanding temporary bonds.

The National Child Labor Committee notified leaders of the Legislature yesterday of its opposition to the Moffatt-Nunan Child Labor Bill. A telegram appealed to the Legislature not to pass the bill, which "by giving a false sense of achievement will make it more difficult to secure protection for children in other States."
The Italian Minister has requested the Costa Rican Government to prosecute Francisco Marin Canas, editor of the Repertorio Americano, local weekly with a wide circulation in Latin America.
Lady Rothermere, wife of the proprietor of The London Daily Mail, died at their villa, Digibanson, at Mougins near here, tonight. Death was caused by cancer of the stomach.

Aurel Toma, 120, Bucharest bantam, scored a technical knockout victory over Jimmy Martin, 123,4 East Side, after 1:30 in the fifth round of the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

J Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, announced today that the board would proceed immediately to file a petition in the Circuit Court of Appeals to enforce its order against Remington Rand, Inc.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Voltter of 1 West Eighty-first Street have announced the engagement of their duaghter, Miss Ruth Doris Voltter, to Marvin J. Silberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Silberman of Hartford, Conn.

Greon H. Hackworth of Kentucky, legal adviser of the State Department, was appointed by President Roosevelt today a member of the Permanent Court of Arbitration at The Hague, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Elihu Root.
Jess Poulson of Mott, Texas, drilling superintendent for an oil company, died in a hospital here today after having been shot in the right forearm with an Indian arrow.
A proposal for a sweeping legislative investigation of life insurance companies produced a series of lively exchanges here today at a public hearing conducted by the Senate Insurance Committee.

Fox St. (10-2707), w. s., 200 ft. s. of 156th St., 100x100; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp., trustee, to Babsy Realty Corp., 725 Fox St.; mtg., $132,450. Burke Av. (16-4598), n. e. cor. Holland Av., 100x150: Louis Richman, referee, to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp., trustee.

A suit to recover $140,237 from Lee, Higgnson Co. on the ground that they had misrepresented the assets and earnings of Kreuger Toll Co. and the International Match Company was filed yesterday in Supreme Court.
Justice McReynolds of the Supreme Court told a small fraternity audience tonight that the "evidence of good sportsmanship" was to accept the outcome of a "fair tribunal."

In his very instructive statement on the steps necessary to prevent a price inflation, Chairman ECCLES of the Federal Reserve Board speaks in favor of three main policies: increased production, "easy money," and a budget balanced by increased taxes.

William G. Woolfolk, president of the Detroit City Gas Company, announced yesterday that "because of market conditions the Detroit City Gas Company had decided not to proceed at this time with the financing contemplated by the registration statement in respect to $31,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, 4 per cent series due in 1957, and $5,000,000 of 4 per cent serial notes due on Feb. 1, 1938 to 1947, which was filed on Feb. 1.

Examination The dates for the examination for promotion to the rank of Deputy Chief in this department have been set by the Municipal Civil Service Commission, as March 30 and March 31, 1937. Each candidate is to appear on each of the two days.

Notifications covering the largest number of products to be placed under the provisions of the FeldCrawford Resale Price Maintenance Law since the act was declared constitutional last week by the State Court of Appeals were received yesterday by leading stores.

These orders were issued in the Northern New York Reserve Area: The following Ordnance Reserve officers are relieved from their present assignments and are assigned as indicated: 15th Ordnance Company, Buffalo, N.Y.-Captain Clair C. McElheny, 15 Grand Blvd.. Binghamton, N. Y.; 1st Lieut.

The Yankees ran head-on into the Cardinals and a bit of wintry weather today without ending their succession of victories in the Citrus Belt. Before a gathering of 3,236 shivering fans at City Island Park, the world champions tamed the Gas House Gang from St. Louis for their third straight exhibition triumph. The score was 5 to 2.

Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, the tall girl professional star from Fort Worth, Texas, who was afforded a special invitation to participate in the first annual women's invitation tournament at the Highland Park Club, led a field of thirty of the outstanding women golfers of America in the qualifying round today. She returned a score of 73, one above par for the course.

Activity in rubber shares as a result of the remarkable rise in the price of the commodity was the feature of an otherwise quiet stock market here today. Gilt-edge issues attracted little interest and the closing levels of yesterday were maintained.

A proposal to rehabilitate the Consolidated Textile Company through issuance of common stock with a face value up to $1,500,000, underwritten in Wall Street instead of by private sources, was made yesterday before Peter B. Olney Jr., official referee, in the Federal Building.

Dealings in the common stock of the Pierce Petroleum Corporation were suspended yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The action followed conclusion of the committee on stock list, after consultation with officers of Pierce Petroleum, that the assets of the company, which is in liquidation, were completely out of line with the market's valuation of them.

Charles B. Kirkland, former advertising manager of the Conde Nast publications and father of Muriel Kirkland, the actress, died here of a heart ailment late yesterday at his home, 58 Castle Place. He was 67 years old. A funeral service was held this afternoon at the Ferncliff Mausoleum, Greenburgh.
The Rev. Dr. William Henry Young, a Baptist minister in the South for more than forty years, died on Sunday at the home of his daughter, Miss Eleanor Young, 472 Gramatan Avenue.

Gorge A. O'Brien, a Philadelphia newspaper man, died of pneumonia early today in the Graduate Hospital after a week's illness. He was 54. Born and educated in Trenton; N. J., he served as a reporter, telegraph editor and city editor of papers there before coming to this city. He was with The Inquirer at the time of his death.

Sir Austen Chamberlain, one of the principal architects of the Treaty of Locarno and probably the most widely respected of the British elder statesmen, died of an apoplectic seizure this evening in his home in South Kensington. He was 73 years old.

Thirty-one persons, including three physicians and ten Brooklyn housewives, who participated in a plot to defraud insurance companies through false proofs of claims, received suspended sentences and were placed on probation for three years yesterday by County Judge George W. Martin in Brooklyn. They pleaded guilty last Jan. 21.

Frank Borzage's first production at Metro will be Katharine Brush's "Mannequin," which will be retitled "Three Rooms in Heaven." The script is being written for Joan Crawford and Spencer Tracy, and production is expected to start late next month.
To Yale and Cornell has fallen the opening match of the year's intercollegiate indoor polo championship, according to the draw made yesterday by officials of the Indoor Polo Association.

HERE at last we seem to have a reliable book on life in Haiti-a work with sobriety, scholarship, patience, skepticism and all the other earmarks of trustworthiness. It is by Melville J. Herskovits, Professor of Anthropology in Northwestern University. It is called "Life in a Haitian Valley" (Knopf, $4).

The Social Security Board said today that 25,000,000 salaried and wageearning persons had been entered in the files of the Bureau of Federal Old-Age Benefits out of the 26,000,000 eligible for old age benefits.
Mrs. Elizabeth W. Pickert died today. She once was character actress in a New York stock company managed in the early 1900's by her husband, the late Willis A. Pickert. She was 72 years old.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 15, unless specified: At Pearl Harbor: Dent, Rathburne, Talbot. Waters. At Mare Island: Vega, Whitney. Sydney to Suva, F. l.: Preston, Smith. Babbitt, Balboa to Cristobal, March 16. Brant, San Diego to Wilson Cove, March 16. Bridge, San Diego to San Pedro, March 16. Chaumont, at Cristobal. Cassin, Charleston to Jacksonville.

The Canadiens clinched first place in the National Hockey League's international division and the Maroons virtually clinched the runnerup position tonight when they battled to a 1-1 tie in the final intracity clash of the regular season.
The Chicago Black Hawks signalized their last visit of the National League hockey season to this city by handing the New York Rangers a 4-to-3 defeat at Madison Square Garden last night.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that F. Ad. Richter Co., Inc., of Brooklyn, and Humphrey's Homeopathic Company of New York City had entered into stipulations with the commission "to end certain unfair representations in the sale of their products."
W. Forbes Morgan, secretary of the Democratic National Committee, was formally elected president of the Distilled Spirits Institute, Inc., at a meeting of the board of directors here today.
The municipality today placed a memorial tablet on the house in a side street here where Adolf Hitler had a room from the Spring of 1912 to the Summer of 1914, when he joined the German Army.
The Connecticut Senate and House Committees on Federal Relations, meeting jointly, voted 8 to 6 today to recommend that Connecticut ratify the child labor amendment to the Federal Constitution.

The Arnold Constable Corporation and wholly owned subsidiary reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 a net profit of $387,066 after depreciation, Federal income and undistributedprofits taxes and other deductions.

Two of the foremost yacht skippers on Long Island Sound are to have a part in the America's Cup defense next Summer. They are Cornelius Shields and Arthur Knapp Jr. Ten days ago it was learned that Harold S. Vanderbilt had invited Knapp to be one of the afterguard of the new Ranger.

Prospect Av., 1,419-1,421, 5-story tenement and stores, 56.8x39.3x147.11 by irreg.; Central Savings Bank in the City of New York against E. G. Realty Holding Co.; due, $44,102; taxes, , $831; to plaintiff for $2,000.

Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, has decided to include more Richard Strauss's "Elektra" than he had planned at the concerts of tomorrow, Friday and Sunday. Seventy minutes of the opera will be presented in concert form.
Representatives of the various arts and crafts of the theatre are trying to formulate plans for a revival of interest in the legitimate drama, both here and on the road.

France during the past four days has proved her financial solidity by oversubscribing the first part of the 10,500,000,000-franc loan for national defense. Last Friday her citizens poured 5,000,000,000 francs into the State coffers. Today 3,000,000,000 more francs were added.
Mr. and Mrs. Seton Henry of Pen Ryn, Andalusia, Pa., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Josephine Drexel Henry, to Joseph Wharton Lippincott Jr.
Voters of Randolph County will have an opportunity tomorrow to express their opinion on President Roosevelt's Federal court Program.

MANHATTAN FEIGENBAUM, DORIAN (Jan 2, 1937). Gross assets, $18,317; net, $13,303. To Yaffa Feigenbaum, widow, residue. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $14,207. Gallert, Hilborn Raphael, attorneys. 521 5th Av.

Dropping down into a more suitable spot after apparently having been outmatched in four previous outings this Winter, Mrs. E. A. Rotelli's brown filly Woof easily captured top honors in the Atlantis Class C Handicap, a six-furlong event that headed today's program at Tropical Park.

What is believed to be the most comprehensive exhibition ever held in this country depicting the development of photography, from its birth to its present maturity, was opened last night at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, and will be on view to the public from today through April 18.

Florence Ullman Breslav, a minority stockholder of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company, won a victory today in the Court of Appeals in her battle to prevent the company from acting to amend its charter so as to make the preferred stock (now not redeemable) subject to redemption at the option of the company at $105 a share.

Colonel General Hermann Goering startled his nation-wide radio audience today at a ceremony celebrating the second anniversary of the re-establishment of universal military service by a cryptic but scarcely to be misunderstood reference to the terrible vengeance that would be visited upon any one attempting to take Chancellor Adolf Hitler's life and upon the sympathizers and supporters of a possible assassin.

In the old grist mill on the Eldridge estate nine persons cast ballots today in the annual election of this village. When the polls were closed by Mrs. Anna Rusden, Village Clerk, it was announced that Mrs. Roswell Eldridge, whose property comprises 90 per cent of the village, had been elected Mayor for her sixth term. She is the only woman Mayor in Nassau County.
The end of the price-fixing features of the Milk Control Law will be recommended by the joint legislative committee which investigated the milk problem. Senator George F. Rogers,
Featuring observance of St. Patrick's Day tomorrow will be a water-sports program in the swimming pool at the Surf Club at noon, followed by a fashion show during the luncheon hour.
Governor Lehman spent a busy day on routine affairs and in the evening attended a dinner at the Fort Orange Club given by Lieutenant Governor Bray for the Senate.

Tear gas and clubs were used by the police here today to disperse an infuriated mob bent on attacking the Brazilian Central Railway station. A collision in the station yards between two trains, in which a score of passengers were hurt and two cars were wrecked, angered a crowd of several hundreds, who charged the station.

In an outburst from the witness stand, Paul N. Coulcher, one of the defendant union officials in the restaurant racket trial, accused Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey yesterday of having sought to "brutalize, crucify and lynch" him through motives of "rotten vengeance."
Howard S. Slater, general manager, said today that a brief sit-down strike in the Cohoes Rolling Mill had ended and the 300 employes were back at work.
Colonel Hugh J. Gallagher, retired, died at Walter Reed Hospital early today in his seventy-sixth year. He was born in Ontario.

The quota for the production of rubber in rubber-producing countries were raised today from 76 to 90 per cent of normal capacity by the International Rubber Regulation Committee in an effort to build up the depleted stocks in the United States, Great Britain and other countries and alter the condition that recently has led to sharp price rises.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Irene Cooper Emerson of East Orange, N. J., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Cooper of Los Angeles and London, England, to Charles Egerton Allcock, son of Mrs. Charles Egerton Allcock of Newark, N. J., and the late Mr. Allcock.

The German press was silent today on the latest repercussion of the "La Guardia incident" after an early edition of the Angriff demanded intervention by President Roosevelt because of "insults" to Germany.
Miss Margaret Schieffelin Pardee gave a tea yesterday in the Gold Room of Sherry's for members of a debutante committee, of which she and Miss Margaret Mackenzie Treadway are chairmen.

Commenting on reports from Washington that the Postoffice Department would bar from the mails any newspapers that published results of the drawing of the Irish Sweepstakes, James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney in charge of gambling prosecutions in New York County, expressed the view yesterday that the Federal Government lacks the power to do this.

The major track and field season will come to a rousing climax in Madison Square Garden tonight when the Knights of Columbus stage their eighteenth annual carnival before a St. Patrick's Day crowd of more than 15,000.
Within a short time Germany will be able to export artificial wool and artificial rubber, Colonel Fritz Loeb of the Raw Materials Department of the Four-Year Plan organization announced today.

The city's mortality rate in maternity cases for the first ten weeks of this year is 10 per cent below the rate for the corresponding period in the last two years, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday in his weekly health survey. Eighty-four deaths, as against 94 in 1936 and 95 in 1935, cut the death rate to 4.4 from 4.9 for both 1936 and 1935.

The Guaranty Trust Company, as trustee for Chesapeake Corporation ten-year 5 per cent convertible collateral-trust bonds due in 1944, has notified the Stock Exchange of the conversion of $7,000 of the bonds and the resulting withdrawal of 140 shares of Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company common stock from the pledged collateral.

A wide variety of units and businesses were represented in the reports of commercial space taken as received from brokers yesterday. Firms in the garment industry and in subsidiary lines were principals in many of the contracts, as were dealers and manufacturers of electrical and radio goods.

Stockholders of the American Bank Note Company yesterday approved a motion for a board of directors of not more than nineteen nor less than nine members and ratified a new set of by-laws. Loyall A. Osborne retired as a director.

Mayor La Guardia was asked to remove Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post for subemitting an allegedly false affidavit, in a resolution adopted unanimously last night at a meeting of the Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners, Inc., at the Bronx County Court House.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "European Decorative Arts," General Tour, 11 A. M.; "Types of Painting," Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M.; "Introduction to the Language of Painting," Roberta M. Fansler, 4 P. M.; "Gothic Architecture: Ornament and Tracery" (Mathews Lecture): Leopold Arnaud, 4 P. M.

Rules governing the employment of foreign representatives by New York Stock Exchange houses were issued yesterday by the market's committee on foreign business. Such representatives are subject to all the rules of the committee on customers' men as well as the committee on foreign business.

A Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Copeland today approved a proposal to relax the continuous discharge book provisions of the Copeland Safety-at-Sea Act. The proposal, which has passed the House, would permit seamen to deposit their continuous discharge books with the Department of Commerce rather than to carry them on their persons.

Details of the world's championship pocket billiard - tournament, which will bring the twelve leading players of this country together, starting March 29, at Ponzi's Academy, were announced yesterday by the-Sportsmen's Tournaments, Inc., an organization of professional billiard players formed for the express purpose of conducting this event.
The National Collegiate Basketball Coaches Association hung a discount tag on skyscraping centers today for a year at least.

There is only one "leader " in Nazi Germany, but there are many conflicting policies. Even in the censorship of the press there is no single authority that tells the newspapers and magazines what they may or may not print.

The French liner Normandie arrived yesterday with 421 passengers after a two-and-a-half-month lay-up at Havre for overhauling, during which she was equipped with two new propellers that are believed to have increased her speed.
The Indians made it three in a row today over the New Orleans Pelicans in a game called after eight innings. The score was 14 to 3, the reason for the premature end.

Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for almost twenty years and one of New York City's leading authorities on real estate investments and trends, died from a heart ailment early yesterday at his home, 185 Manhasset Woods Road, Munsey Park, L. I. He was 85 years old.

Holders of General Motors Corporation common and preferred stock for the first quarter of 1937 numbered 358,080, compared with 342,384 for the fourth quarter of 1936 and with 353,186 for the first quarter of last year.

It is forty-five years since AUSTEN CHAMBERLAIN entered Parliament, where his maiden speech won from Mr. GLADSTONE such praise as drew iron tears down JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN'S cheek. He rose rapidly on his own merits.

The sit-down strikes in Michigan clearly reveal the dangers of a situation in which power is exercised without responsibility. The United Automobile Workers Union has attempted to use the seizure of the Chrysler Corporation's property as a means of compelling the company to come to terms with it.
The story of "This for Remembrance," presented at the Embassy Theatre tonight in a translation by Ralph Neale from the German of Rudolf Urbantschitsch, is dismissed by the critics as improbable.

Representatives of the H. L. Green Company and of the sit-down strikers who control five of the company's stores adjourned a fourhour conference last night, with both sides confident that progress had been made toward settlement of the strike.
Secretary Swanson today ordered a special board of inquiry to convene at Portsmouth, N. H., tomorrow to investigate reported irregularities in the conduct of the naval prison there.
Reinald Werrenrath's recital at Carnegie Hall last night, his first public appearance here in several seasons, departed from the conventional procedure.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced today at a wage conference with employes that its 8,000 workers in the Pittsburgh district would receive nearly $1,000,000 in bonuses during March.

A large "delegation" of ancient men, including eleven casts of skulls of a newly-found prehistoric race of cannibals who feasted on their neighbors in Central Java some 25,000 years ago, will be the honored "guests" at the international symposium on early man, to be opened here tomorrow morning under the auspices of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.

The twentieth exhibition at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee opens today with the first floor occupied by sculpture and the other three floors taken up by paintings. The newly opening show lives up to the standard which the gallery has set during its first year, both in the quality and diversity of the works exhibited.

Eight veterans of the World War, including one holder of the Congressional Medal of Honor, gave to fellowmembers of the House of Representatives today their views on current legislative efforts to keep this country out of another conflict.

Mrs. Lorraine Manville, daughter of Mrs. Thomas F. Manville of this city and the late Mr. Manville, was married to Cornelius W. Dresselhuys of London yesterday afternoon in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Three flights across the Pacific may start tomorrow. The Pan American Clipper has a pioneering hop to New Zealand scheduled, the Hawaii Clipper hopes to head for Manila and Miss Amelia Earhart said she would take off on her world flight.

United States PRINCIPAL SOCIAL SCIENCE ANALYST, $5,600 a year; senior social science analyst, $4,600; social science analyst, $3,800; associate social science analyst, $3,200. Applications must be on file not later than April 19 if received from States other than those named below;

J. T. Loree, vice president of the Delaware Hudson Company, estimated yesterday that the net income of the holding company for 1936, exclusive of its interest in the Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation and the Hudson Coal

Herbert Morris Johnson, vice president and general manager of the Civic Opera Company in the period when opera in Chicago outgrew the old auditorium and was installed in the new $20,000,000 Civic Opera House by Samuel Insull, died tonight in the Alexian Brothers Hospital.

It is a long time since the SpanishAmerican War, and few will remember the adulation with which RICHMOND PEARSON HOBSON was received on his return to this country from a Spanish prison after trying to bottle up the enemy fleet in Santiago harbor by sinking the old collier Merrimac across the channel.

It is a pretty safe guess now that "Jane Eyre" will form the Theatre Guild's sixth show of the season of 1936-37, but that it still won't be seen locally until next Fall. If all this sounds complicated, the Guild has done it before-in the case of "Arms and the Man," also a holdover.

A. J. McCarthy, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, announced yesterday that Captain Robert A. Smith, master of the Panama Pacific liner California, and Captain William B. Oakley, master of the United States liner President Roosevelt, would exchange commands today when the Roosevelt leaves for Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg.

Unlisted trading privileges in the nopar value common stock of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and in the $1 par value common stock of the Studebaker Corporation were sought by the Philadelphia Stock Exchange at a public hearing today before an examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Two one-act operas, one in its world premiere, will be presented by students of the Curtis Institute of Music at a special benefit performance on Sunday evening, April 11, at the New Amsterdam Theatre, it was announced yesterday. Fritz Reiner will conduct both works.

Miss Bettina Bever Baldwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest E. Baldwin of this city, has announced the plans for her wedding to James G. Batterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Batterson of Hartford, which will take place on April 3.

Moscow Is cheerful these days for a variety of reasons. Japanese Foreign Minister Naotake Sato's recent speech, although not commented on in the newspapers here, produced a favorable impression despite his reference to the Communist International-regarded here partly as lipservice to Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany.

Scientific testimony proffered here today by Dr. Irving Lorge of Columbia University in an address to the American Association of University Women leaned heavily toward defense of the members of the Supreme Court before the bar of public opinion. His analytic diacourse on the mental capabilities of adults attacked as a fallacy the theory that minds grow lame and halt after twenty.

Remarking that he believed a plan for rehabilitation of the Fidelity Union Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company proposed by a group of stockholders could be made workable, Vice Chancellor M. L. Berry today adjourned a hearing on the plan to April 13.

MANHATTAN ARNOLD, MARY (Jan. 1). Estate, $2.900. to Gustav Otto, brother-in-law, executor, 11 Abingdon Sq., residue. CARPENTER, HENRY A. (March 5). Estate, more than $10,000. To Harold E. Carpenter, brother, 538 Westchester Av., Port Chester, N. Y., library;

East Missouri Power Company-For 1936: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, $42,370, against $18,491 in 1935; operating revenues, $173,884, an increase of $14,905, or 17.5 per cent over 1935.

The New York campaign of the United Palestine Appeal to raise $1,700,000 toward the national goal of $4,500,000 for the settlement of Jews in Palestine was opened yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

Total advertising linage in newspapers for February advanced 12.9 per cent over the corresponding month of last year, according to Media Records. The largest gain was made in classified, which moved up 17.5 per cent, while general or national linage advanced 17.2 per cent.
With the Senate in recess, the Judiciary Committee heard William Green and Justin Miller in support of President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan.

The number of buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week and in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the past week the arrivals numbered 788 as against 838 in the previous week and 856 in the same period last year.
Daily retail sales in February were about 16 per cent above those of February, 1936, and about 4 per cent higher than in January of this year, the American Retail Federation announced today.

War Minister Alfred Duff Cooper aroused laughter and cheers in the House of Commons this afternoon when he gave further details of his scheme for attracting army recruits-"kidding kids into the army," as some say.

A Princeton 300-yard medley relay trio shattered the pool record recently established by Harvard, swimming to a 3:00.4 performance in an exhibition which featured the third annual Columbia University water carnival in the Light Blue's tank last night.

Stuyvesant Park was pictured as a miniature dust bowl in the heart of New York during an argument before the Appellate Division yesterday on Park Commissioner Moses's appeal from a lower court decision enjoining him from constructing children's playgrounds there.

The cost to the railroads of pensions under the law which it now appears will be repealed, was estimated at about $60,000,000. Under the agreement reached by the managements and the unions, initial costs would be cut from 3 1/2 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent of payrolls.
Prices of wheat continued on the upgrade to-day with all deliveries in the foreign markets and the deferred futures in the domestic markets selling at a new high level for the season and since 1929.

Thomas (Red) Burke, who was brought to Brooklyn Tuesday from the Canal Zone by-two Bronx detectives, admitted yesterday to Bronx District Attorney Samuel J. Foley that he guarded Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr., when. the latter was held at a Hoboken apartment last July, following his kidnapping.

Sir James Currie, an educator and expert in tropical agriculture, died at Cambridge today. His age was 68. His manifold activities included the development of cotton growing in the Sudan. He also trained English munition workers during the war.
Their villa on Sea Breeze Avenue was the setting tonight for a spaghetti dinner given by Prince and Princess Balthasar Odescalchi for Mr. and Mrs. Charlton Yarnall.

Georgia became today the lone State in which the Tennessee Valley Authority, the government's great power plant, can increase its sale of electricity. The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals gave the Authority a free hand to sell electricity in Georgia, voiding an order of the Eastern Tennessee District Court in so far as Georgia was concerned.

Members of the New York Athletic Club are already looking ahead to warm Summer days and enjoyable off-shore expeditions. A fishing forum, at which Henry W. Ryan presided, was held the other evening by the club's anglers to discuss plans for the approaching fishing season.

If ideas were plays "Cross-Town" might be one. This is taking the hopeful point of view; it is not intended to be encouraging. Joseph O. Kesselring, who is down in the records as author of "There's Wisdom in Women," is now writing a satire about a thick-headed racketeer who makes a career of plagiarism until he discovers that he is a legitimate author.

The five-story apartment house, measuring 51 by 106 feet, at 1,052 Teller Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Irving O. Freedman. A fraternal organization represented by Joseph Rosenzweig, attorney, was the seller.

The contributions which the Irish have made to this country, and the contributions which this country has made to Ireland were discussed last night t the twenty-fifth annual dinner of the St. Patrick's Society of Queens, held at the Biltmore Hotel.

The New York University girls' basketball team crushed the Hunter College squad, 35-15, at the loser's court last night. The Violet, led by Miss Doris Palmer, who tallied 19 points, showed the way by 17-6 at the close of the first half.

Players from the metropolitan area filled a number of the twenty places open today in the 36-hole qualifying round of the third annual national amateur-professional best ball match play championship for a purse of $3,000.

Reports were circulated here today that the action of Bolivia in issuing a confiscatory decree against the Standard Oil Company of Bolivia, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, was the prelude to a wave of confiscatory measures against United States capital throughout South America.

Japan will decline to adhere to the London naval pact or give assurance that she will limit the calibers of the guns on her new capital ships to fourteen inches, according to inspired statements in the press.

Brig. Gen. A. G. M. Critchley, sports promoter, said tonight Tom Farr's "holdout" from a Max Baer heavyweight fight has ended and that the new British champion may go to New York to meet Bob Pastor if he gets by Baer.

Members of the younger set will act as ushers and distribute programs at the performance of three one-act plays by the Lighthouse Players, one of the enterprises of the New York Association for the Blind, tonight and tomorrow night at the Lighthouse Little Theatre, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler appears faced with a hesitant but widespread revolt of extremist National Socialist functionaries against a compromising policy in dealing with the Protestant Church.

Final registration figures for the Spring semester, released yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, indicated that 25,202 men and women had enrolled at all branches of the college.

Massing at two points in the Loop, more than 200 striking taxicab drivers wrecked cabs, slugged strikebreakers and battled police squads up and down crowded streets today while thousands of persons watched the riots from office windows.

Mrs. Alan H. Robinson, former president of the Rose Sirovich Relief Society, received a testimonial yesterday from her associates on the board of directors of the organization, which she served as president for the last two years. The presentation was made after a luncheon in Essex House, 160 Central Park South.

The Ramapo Valley polo team, consisting of Peter Rose, John Brabson and W. D. Wood, upset the Squadron A trio of W. B. Devereaux, Walter Phillips and Major F. A. Vietor, 9 to 8 1/2, in a Sherman Memorial game at Squadron A Armory last night.

The West Side Hospital and Dispensary will be the beneficiary of a card party and fashion show on Saturday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Some of those active in arrangements are Mrs. William W. Downey, who heads the executive committee; Mrs. Arthur Ansley,
