An unusually high tide marooned about twenty-five firemen and six pieces of apparatus about 10 o'clock last night on the narrow strip of sand called Plumb Island, between Sheepshead Bay and Marine Pirk, Brooklyn, and prospects were that they would stay there until 4 or 5 o'clock this morning.
The center-jump was officially legislated out of basketball today, but the "three-second" rule held its page in the rule book.

More than 3,000 persons, including 1,100 members of the 165th Infantry (Old Sixty-ninth) attended a pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning in honor of the saint whose name the edifice bears.

The forthright, ground-breaking statement recently issued by Chairman Eccles of the Federal Reserve Board has better served to focus the attention of the government and the public on the inflationary situation than any move that has been made.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of March 16, 1937, upon the eligible list of holders of license as junior clerical assistant in day high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

Stockholders of the B. F. Avery Sons Company approved yesterday changing the present common stock of no-par value into a like number of shares of $5 par value and authorized the issuance of 36,500 shares of $25 par value 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock with warrants and $1,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent notes.

A warning to the oil-burner industry to guard against the possibility of prohibitive taxes on fuel oil was voiced by Baird H. Markham of New York, director of the American Petroleum Industries Committee, in an address here today in connection with the National OilBurner and Air-Conditioning Exposition.

The $20,000 Wood Memorial, leading local prep race for the Kentucky Derby, will be run on May 1, according to an announcement yesterday from John J. Kane, assistant secretary of the Metropolitan Jockey Club, which will open the racing season at Jamaica on April 15. The Wood is the test of a mile and seventy yards, which in other years has pointed out the Derby winner.

NEWHALL-THOMAS--On March 15, 1937, in Cleveland, Ohio, by the Rev. William H. Beynon, Campbell Newhall of Cleveland, formerly of Philadelphia, to Margaret Elizabeth Thomas, daughter of Mrs. Daniel J. Thomas of Philadelphia, Pa.

Geneva is preparing to test the defenses against air raids. The Swiss authorities ruled some time ago that the whole country, including the city where the League of Nations has its headquarters, must be ready by April 1 to darken cities when sirens sound.

Charges, which opposing counsel immediately termed an "intemperate attack," were made yesterday against Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy, by Samuel Zirn, attorney for a creditor of Orpheum Circuit, Inc., and holders of 3,000 shares of preferred stock of that company. The hearing was adjourned until today.
John H. Abbot, 63, well-to-do retired railroad man, who has decided he has "lived alone long enough," today awaited replies to an advertisement for a "50-50 wife."

Stocks irregular, with rail shares higher and industrial group lower; turnover, 2,116,880 shares. United States Government bonds at new low levels, corporate and foreign issues irregular; transactions, $23,490,200.
Johnny McHale, Brooklyn welterweight, battled to a draw with Vince Pimpinella, also of Brooklyn, in the eight-round feature bout of the card last night at the Mecca Arena before 2,000 fans.

An audience of Irishmen and descendants of Irishmen who listened tonight to greetings from President Roosevelt also heard an attack on the President and his policies which came as a distinct surprise on the program of the Charitable Irish Society of Boston, celebrating at a dinner the 200th anniversary of its founding.
Queen Elizabeth today approved designs for the richly embroidered gown, a completely British-made product, which she will wear to the coronation in Westminster Abbey May 12.

Mayor La Guardia was the guest of honor of the American Association for the Recognition of the Irish Republic last night at its seventeenth annual St. Patrick's night reception and dance at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Miss Barbara Kaley of this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Kaley, has selected April 3 for her marriage to Edwin Cuyler Treat, also of Summit, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Erastus B. Treat of New York.

Joseph Knitzer, talented young violinist from Detroit, gave a recital in the Town Hall last night. This was Mr. Knitzer's second appearance. as recitalist in that auditorium, where he was heard two seasons ago as a winner of a Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation award. Since then, he appeared as
Pelham Parkway S., 1,500, 277.5x40.5x irreg.; Edgar N. Sidman against Eastchester Holding Corp., due, $63,737, taxes, , $7,993; to plaintiff for $50,000.

Thousands of tons of scrap iron, which shipping officials said were consigned to foreign ports, tonight were loaded into the holds of vessels here in an effort to reduce the strain on railroads and break a railroad embargo.

A real fighting finish developed out of the St. Patrick's Day Handicap, mile and a sixteenth feature today at Tropical Park. Three of the five starters came down to the wire heads apart and the two horses that delayed the start nine and a half minutes with their fractious antics settled the issue.
IMMORTAL FRANZ, by Zsolt Harsanyi. (Stokes $2.50) A novel based on the lfie of Franz Lizst. GALLOWS HILL, by Frances Winwar (Holt, $2.50.) A novel or witchcraft and persecution in Salem.

Calling upon manufacturers and distributers to cooperate, the National Better Business Bureau, Inc., is launching a campaign to revive interest in the "Name the Woods" code for the designation of furniture woods, it was announced here yesterday.

Six bead dealers and two corporations they managed in 1934 were accused yesterday in the first indictment of its kind ever returned in the United States of using a revenue law as an instrument for fraud against the government.

Turpentine firm, 38 1/2c; sales 22 barrels; receipts 27 barrels; no shipments; stock 21,422 barrels. Resin firm; sales 261; receipts 225; shipments 1,726; stock 48,549. Quote: B, $8.15; D, $8.45; E, $8.90; F. $9.30; G, $9.47 1/2; H. I. K. $9.55; M. N, $9.60; WG, $9.80; WW, $11.00; X, $11.50.

The annual report of the North American Company for 1936, -vhich is being sent to stockholders today, shows a consolidated net income of $16,743,621, after all deductions, including preferred dividends of subsidiaries, compared with $13,431,472 in 1935.

Outfooting thirty-one rivals from the rise of the barrier, Mrs. C. B. Robinson's Marmaduke Jinks scored an unexpected victory today in the mile of the Lincolnshire Handicap, first major stake of the new flat-racing season.
The St. Patrick's Day Parade yesterday lasted fifteen minutes longer than last year and there were about 10,000 more marchers. They totaled 50,000 and required three hours and a quarter to pass.

The re-creation of the post of Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Air, the appropriatino of $12,414,000 for immediate spending on airway aids, air safety and the expansion of the weather service and the lifting of some restrictions on air mail contractors instituted by the present administration were among the recommendations put before the Senate today by its Commerce Committee, of which Senator Copeland is chairman.

Following is Governor Murphy's statement, issued today at the opening of his law-and-order conference: There is probably no need for stating at length the conditions that exist in Detroit and to a less extent in other communities in the State. Public officials and, I

Proposals for changes in the Federal housing program now under consideration in Congress, and plans by which realty interests throughout the country would take a large share in the work of protesting neighborhoods from deterioration, were presented by officials of the National Association of Real Estate Boards at the first meeting of the newly formed New York chapter of the association yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore.
The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for March 15 showed the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation to have risen from 134.99 per cent on Feb. 28 to 135.34 per cent.

There is serious danger that the city's extensive public works program, now being carried on with the aid of Federal funds, may result in a population shift to suburban communities, leaving the heavy bill to be borne by a diminished number of taxpayers, Controller Frank J. Taylor declared last night at the eighty-eighth annual dinner of the St. Patrick Society of Brooklyn at the Hotel Commodore.

Award to Alfred J. Talley, New York attorney, of Gonzaga University's De Smet medal in recognition of outstanding contribution to the Catholic Church by a layman was announced last night by the Rev. Leo J. Robinson, rector of the university.

Miss Mary L. Gibbons, who was appointed Tuesday deputy commissioner of the State Department of Social Welfare in charge of New York City, began her new duties yesterday at her office in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.
After selling at new high levels again yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange developed irregularity and ended 1-point higher to 12 points lower.

Mrs. Pauline Einhorn Coblens, a daughter of the late Rabbi David Einhorn, one of the leaders of Reform Judaism in the United States, died on Tuesday of pneumonia at her home, 315 West Ninety-eighth Street, after two weeks of illness. Mrs. Coblens was long active in Jewish charitable work here.
Mrs. Ethel White, wife of Dr. Alexander D. White of 131 Lake Drive, died this morning in Daytona Beach, Fla., at the age of 55, after several years of poor health.

Speaking on French and British rearmament at a luncheon of the British Chamber of Commerce here yesterday, Premier Leon Blum declared France, like Great Britain, was arming but with a resolve never to take the initiative in war.

Temple defeated Rutgers in a post-season game for the benefit of the Scarlet crew before 2,500 fans tonight, 43 to 27. It was the home team's second defeat in fourteen games, the first having been sustained at the hands of New York University by a single point.

Today is the 100th anniversary of the birth of Grover Cleveland, twice President of the United States. The centenary will be widely observed. One of the most important celebrations of the day will occur at New York University, where a bust of Cleveland will be unveiled for the Hall of Fame.
The Central National Bank of Cleveland and H. R. Harris, as trustee for bondholders, today purchased at Sheriff's sale the former plant of the Newton Steel Company at Newton Falls for $302,000.
The War Department released the following orders today dated March 16: COLONEL Harris, C. T., Jr., Ordnance Dept., Washington, D. C., to Watertown Arsenal, Mass., May 1.

A bill to bar loss-leader sales was introduced today by Senator Jacob H. Livingston of Brooklyn. "My bill is not antagonistic but is supplementary to the Feld-Crawford act, the constitutionality of which was sustained recently by the Court of Appeals in this State," said Senator Livingston.

The old master finished his season last night the way he started it ten weeks ago--with a smashing victory. Glenn Cunningham won the Columbian Mile at the Knights of Columbus games in Madison Square Garden in the second fastest indoor time ever recorded, 4:08.7, a picayune three-tenths of a second off his own world mark.

The sixteenth annual Seamen's Book Week will be held in New York from April 5 to 12, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Langdon Marvin of 40 East Seventysixth Street, a member of the New York Committee of the American Merchant Marine Library Association, under whose auspices the book drive is to be held.

Phil Stong has written his first long novel, and his first novel with a historical theme, drawing a major part of the material from the memoirs of his grandfather, George Crawford Duffield, who settled in Iowa in 1857 and lived there until 1909. Linwood Farm, where Mr.

Testimony that Edward Flore, general president of the international union to which locals involved in the restaurant racket trial belong, had avoided appearance as a witness was put in the record yesterday by attorneys for the defense.

Willie Thomas, Dartmouth's great scoring basketball forward, was elected captain of the five today, succeeding Harold Parachini. At the same time the athletic council announced the awarding of varsity letters in basketball and swimming, as well as freshman numerals in hockey.
The senior dance in the holiday series directed by Mrs. Huntington Tappin will be held tomorrow night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

President Federico Paez signed today a contract with the Foundation Company of New York for the construction of 900 miles of roads in various parts of the country. The contract on a cost plus basis aggregates $3,000,000. It will be financed in part by a tax of 50 centavos a gallon on gasoline.

Hockey fans will get their last glimpse this season of the Americans tonight at Madison Square Garden, when Red Dutton's team will meet the Chicago Black Hawks. Following this game, the Americans will wind up their season at Montreal Saturday night in a game against the Maroons.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 16 unless specified: Acushnet, Norfolk to Washington Yard, via Potomac River points. Babbitt Cristobal to sea. Brant, at San Diego. Bridge, at San Pedro. Gold Star, at Shanghai, March 17. Heron, at Cavite.

Leasing of stores continued to be the feature of brokers' reports of commercial renting yesterday, several contracts with chain-store firms appearing on the list. A number of investment and brokerage concerns took space on upper floors, and two penthouse units were rented for business purposes. The list follows:

A license was issued yesterday at the court house in West Palm Beach for the marriage of Mrs. Paula M. Graham, widow of George S. Graham, formerly District Attorney of Philadelphia, and Jules S. Vatable, broker. Both are from Islip, L. I., and New York.
Tom Curran vanquished Julius Goldman, 75-73, in 14 innings in the Class A pocket billiard tournament at Jack Doyle's Broadway Academy last night. Curran had an unfinished run of 21 to Goldman's 19.

A genuinely moving and dramatic performance of Bach's "Passion According to St. John" was given by the Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross conductor, with the assistance of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra and various solo players and singers last night in Carnegie Hall.
As part of a movement to build up his "democratic" reputation, King George VI today drove several miles through South London, where he owns large roperties, as the Duke of Cornwall.

The State Board of Housing, in its annual report, took issue today with Governor Lehman on the question of a State bond issue to aid municipal housing authorities in fostering large-scale construction programs.

Ralph H. Tapscott, formerly vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., was elected president at a meeting of its board of trustees yesterday. He succeeds Frank W. Smith, who will retire at the end of June under the company's age limit of seventy years.
Six matches have been arranged for the St. John's University golf team this Spring, starting on April 8, according to the schedule announced yesterday by the athletic office.

The Federal Farm Land Bank of Springfield, serving New England, New York and New Jersey, closed 1936 in the strongest financial position in its history, E. H. Thomson. president, told more than 300 Farm Loan officials here today to celebrate the bank's twentieth anniversary.

Alexander Jerome McAllister, president of Central American Mines, INc., anda director of Compania Minera Salvadorens Divisadero, died at San Miguel yesterday. He was stricken with a heart attack when about to board an airplane to come to this city.

With a range of incidents that extended from hysteria on the part of women workers to the overwhelming of private guards whose presence had provoked a hunger strike, the sit-down of 5-and-10cent-store employes in the city spread yesterday to two stores of the F. W. Woolworth Co. chain, at 34 West Fourteenth Street, Manhattan, and at 22 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Balsan and the latter's son, the Duke of Marlborough, are sailing today for France on the French liner Normandie. Other passengers include Admiral Sir Hugh Watson, Viscountess Doris Castlerosse, Count and Countess Alfred Potocki, Francois Richepin and Mme. Richepin, Pierre Lyautey, Michel Fokine, Liam O'Flaherty, Mallory Browne, Cornelis T. M. Van Dongen, Mile.
Losing only one bout in eleven, the women's foils team of the Salle d'Armes Vince easily took the national team championship at the Fencers Club last night.

For the second straight day, leaders in the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress championships remained undisturbed by keglers who rounded out the eighth session of maple crashing in the revamped 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday.
Vital Benguiat, a well-known dealer in oriental ??ugs, other rare textiles and art objects, died of a heart attack yesterday in his apartment in the Hotel Great Northern.

Possible reform of the anti-trust laws to check collusive bidding and to prevent other abuses was indicated today by Attorney General Cummings as a result of a study made of alleged collusive bidding in the construction industry.

As a protest against "Fascists" who they declare were responsible for Tuesday night's rioting at Clichy, which involved the death of five workers and the wounding and injury of more than 300 policemen and civilians, there will be a halfday strike today of the 1,000,000 workers affiliated with General Confederation of Labor in the Paris district.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed a rise of 8 per cent for the week ended March 13, over the comparative 1936 week, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.

The sit-down strike was denounced in the Senate today as a breeder of industrial disorder and a harbinger of political chaos and possible Fascist revolution. Three Senators, two Democrats and a New Deal Republican, joined in the denunciation, which came without warning in midafternoon.
The prospects for new ship construction in the United States are good, W. H. Beal, chairman of the New York Shipbuilding Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

Senator Hayden said today that an investigation into the amount of "bootleg" printing being done by government departments had been started. The Joint Congressional Committee on Printing has demanded from all government agencies information on their use of reproducing machines, he stated.

Germany's export drive was able to register relative success for February. Although the total exports, amounting to 405,800,000 marks, decreased 2 per cent compared with January, nevertheless the exports per working day showed a slight increase over January and rose 9 per cent above February last year.
Evaluation of feminine higher education absorbed two sessions of the tenth biennial of the American Association of University Women here today.

A New Jersey branch of the Peck Peck Fifth Avenue shop opened yesterday in East Orange with a showing of Spring styles. More than 1,500 persons gathered in the pastel interior of the shop, which is at 596 Central Avenue.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had closed its case against Distillers Company, Ltd., Linden, N. J. The commission had charged misuse of 'the word "distillers" in the company's name. Investigation proved, the announcement said, the company produced gin by a process of rectification whereby tax-paid alcohol is redistilled over juniper berries and other aromatics.
Following is the text of the address which President Roosevelt telephoned from Warm Springs tonight to the St. Patrick Day dinners here and in Savannah:

Robert F. Wellman, also Mrs. Elsie C. Lewis, in 67 Park Av.; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., brokers. J. Phares O'Kelley Jr.; Lillian P. Draper and Syrena H. Stackpole; Peter N. Morrison, Dr. Robert F. Pitts, Henry T. Rawlings, John F. Dolan, Mrs. Jean Willing, Mrs. Agnes M. Angell, Mrs. Alexandra G.

Jerome (Dizzy) Dean said today he was through with baseball for 1937 at least, had placed his Bradenton home on the market and would head north tomorrow to consider one of several business connections.

Baron Robert Silvercruys, first Belgian Minister to Canada, is expected tomorrow from Ottawa and will be at the Ambassador. Mrs. Laurence J. Webster is arriving today from Holderness, Vt., and will join her sister, Mrs. Lansing C. Holden, at 14 East Sixtieth Street.

A cessation in the war of vituperation between Mayor La Guardia of New York and the German Government and press was asked by Secretary of State Hull today after Dr. Hans Luther, the German Ambassador, by direction of his Foreign Office, had again protested the Mayor's attacks on Adolf Hitler, this time in his speech at the mass meeting in New York last Monday night.

Declaring that Irish immigrants to this country had given their "undying allegiance to the laws and processes of the United States," former -Governor Alfred E. Smith told a cheering gathering at the 153d anniversary dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick at the Hotel Astor last night that the Constitution was the "civil Bible" of the nation.

The dike holding flood waters from 25?? square miles of farming country in East Anglia burst tonight an?? millions of tons of water are no?? sweeping across fens four mil?? from the cathedral city of Ely.

Representatives of employee groups of the B. M. T. were notified yesterday by William S. Menden, president of the company, that the directors have decided that it is "not necessary" to hold a new election to choose delegates or spokesmen for the workers.

In the second stay-in strike this week at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, 555 Prospect Place, at the corner of Classon Avenue, sixtythree employes were discharged yesterday and thirty-nine of them arrested on disorderly conduct charges and ejected from the hospital.

In addition to worrying about straight trade-mark legislation, requiring registration in States, national advertisers are now concerned about the move to tack trade-mark riders onto various State fair-trade laws.
Secretary Swanson has approved the insertion of advertisements in newspapers printed in shipbuilding areas calling for bids for construction of a 35,000-ton battleship.

The ancient man who dwelled in a limestone cave in the Holy Land 60,000 to 100,000 years ago, only a short distance away from the traditional site of the Garden of Eden in the valley of the Tigris and the Euphrates, was identified here today by Sir Arthur Keith, world renowned pre-historian, as the ancestor of modern man, the nearest scientific approximation to the biblical Adam.

Montgomery Ward Co. reported yesterday for the year ended on Jan. 31 net profit of $20,198,914, equal to $4.12 a share on its common stock outstanding before the issuance of more shares in January. The profit was the largest in the company's history. In the preceding year the net profit was $13,527,310, or $2.65 a common share.

Five seniors, fifteen juniors and sixteen sophomores in Harvard College with high honor records have received awards of Detur prize books. Each year these awards are made to students who in the previous year made Group 1 of the rank list in studies for the first time.

The sit-down strikers who are defying the law and mocking the courts in Michigan insist that they are doing only what the Chrysler company itself has done. The Wagner National Labor Relations Act forbids employers to indulge in "unfair labor practices." The strikers insist that the company has violated the Wagner act.
Ralph E. Forbes of Milton, Mass., lawyer and brother of W. Cameron Forbes, former Governor General of the Philippines, died in a hospital here last night. He was 70 years old.

ADLER-Isaac J., in his eighty-fourth year. Services Central Funeral Chapel, 109 West 87th St., Thursday, March 18, at 2 P. M. ALEXANDER--Louis, beloved husband of the late Clara Levy Alexander, dear father of Joseph M., Rita Hoffman and Mildred Rosenthal. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West 79th St., New York, Friday, March 19, 10 A. M.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a summary of thirty registration statements filed recently under the Securities Act of 1933, including one covering certificates of deposit for $14,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent twenty-year gold debentures due in 1947 and $36,000,000 of thirty-year gold debentures due in 1959 of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation by the committee for the protection of holders of gold debentures of that corporation.

Louis H. Pink, State. Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday the appointment of Thomas J. Cullen as First Deputy Superintendent to succeed Rollin M. Clark, resigned. Mr. Cullen has been deputy in charge of the office of the department in Albany and will remain in that city.

(First two in each qualify for semi-finals.) First Heat-Won by Ben Johnson, Columbia: Bob Rodenkirchen, New York A. C., second; Joseph F. Kelly, Boston College, third; Palmer Hughes, Penn, fourth. Time--0:06.4
A new American conquest of the air began today with Amelia Earhart launching her 27,000-mile world flight in the wake of two huge Clipper planes speeding toward the Orient and the South Seas.

Film programs, which will be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as particularly suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Robert T. Jones Jr., sportsman and retired world's champion golfer, was 35 years old today. The cake and birthday candlesand the dinner with his wife and three children-will have to wait until tomorrow, for Bobby was en route home from an Eastern business trim.

The Buick Motor Company delivered 5,418 cars at retail in the United States during the first ten days of March, the highest rate since 1926 and 1927. It is compared to 3,237 in the same period last year and to 1,791 in the first ten days of February, 1937, Harlow H. Curtice, president and general manager, said yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today in connection with its study of investment trusts that on Friday a public hearing would be held on the fixed trusts and special investment plans sponsored by Trans-Continent Shares Corporation of Philadelphia, formerly Bank and Insurance Shares, Inc.

The All-Indian Congress Committee met again today to decide whether to accept Ministerial offices in the six provinces where the party gained a majority in the elections. Despite a sharp division of opinion over the wording of the committee's resolution in favor of accepting office it is anticipated it will be adopted without alteration tomorrow.

A 30,000watt commercial television broadcasting station, which it was said would be the world's most powerful thus far, was announced in an order today by the French Ministry of Posts, Telegraphs and Telephones from La Materiel Telephonique Licensee, a company of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation of New York.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation reported yesterday a net profit of $7,924,126 after all deductions for the fifty-two weeks ended on Dec. 26, 1936, equivalent after dividends paid on the preferred shares in the year to $3.55 a share on common shares outstanding at the year end.
An arbitration award providing for a 20 per cent reduction in the prices of haircuts and shaves in the midtown area was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo.

The sales brokers committee of the Real Estate Board of New York will hold a luncheon meeting today in the Town Hall Clarke G. Dailey, president of the board. will be the chief speaker. Lawrence B. Elliman, chairman of the committee, will preside.

Massenet's opera, "Manon," was presented for the fourth time of the current season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. A large audience enthusiastically greeted the performance which was marked by one substitution in the cast. Sydney Rayner sang the role of Des Grieux in place of Richard Crooks, who was unable to appear because of illness.

Henry De Rees, real estate owner, editor of a magazine, Taxes, published in Hackensack, N. J., and the collector of delinquent taxes in Bergen County, was killed yesterday morning when he either fell or jumped from a tenth-floor room of the Hotel McAlpin. He was 59 years old.
A demonstration exhibit of musical-instruments made by the WPA Federal Music Project will be presented today at the Midtown Community Music Center, 93 Park Avenue. The exhibit is a feature
The sit-down strike of employes of the Pacific Slipper Company at Clifton went into its its third day today, with the management and the Clifton police joining the strikers in a "donothing" policy.

Payments on open-credit accounts of department stores were made at a slightly higher rate during January, 1937, than during the previous December and January, according to the Bureau of Foreign and Domestio Commerce. The collection rates on these accounts were 47.4 per cent for January this year, and 46.9 per cent for January and 47 per cent for December last year.

The House today passed the Schulte bill to restrict the habitual commuting of aliens to American border industrial communities despite a State Department protest that It might embarrass the administration's "good-neighbor" policy with Canada.

In the hope of ending clashes between Arabs and Jews in Palestine negotiations have been going on in Paris for some time between Arab and Zionist representatives, it was revealed today. The negotiations have been conducted with the utmost secrecy.

Miss Margaret Coberly and Allan Henry Hoover, younger son of former President and Mrs. Herbert Clark Hoover, were married today at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Bayley Coberly. The bridegroom's parents attended. Dr. D. Charles Gardner, chaplain emeritus of Stanford University, read the Episcopalian marriage service.
All British universities have received invitations to participate in the bicentenary celebration of Goettingen University, but none has as yet accepted.

Twenty-two years of "bone dry" prohibition formally ended today in Alabama when Governor Bibb Graves signed a proclamation declaring in effect the Alabama Beverage Control Act, providing a system of State liquor stores in twenty-four counties which returned majorities favoring repeal in a State-wide local option election March 10.
Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief approved today an offer of five former directors of the Pelham National Bank, now closed, to pay $75,000 to depositors if a damage suit against them is dropped.

Making good its avowal to take court action, the National Labor Relations Board petitioned the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday to enforce its order requiring Remington Rand, Inc., to reinstate 4,000 employes who allegedly lost their jobs in strikes in the company's plants.

Miss Tatiana Popova of this city, formerly of Switzerland, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Popoff, was married to Dr. Gordon Pollock, son of Dr. Isaac Pollock of Jersey City and the late Mrs. Anna Gordon Pollock, yesterday in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building by Deputy City Clerk Thomas Barry.
The House of Commons paid tribute this afternoon to Sir Austen Chamberlain. Leaders stressed his loyalty, honesty, chivairy, studied courtesy and unfailing belief in democratic institutions.
The quiet citizens-and the Boston Bees-of this area were left in a daze after the New York Giants had passed this way, heading for Orlando and points farther North.

In a speech here today in which aggressiveness and expressions of a desire for peace strove for mastery, Premier Benito Mussolini told 100,000 wildly cheering followers that the sanctions imposed upon Italy by the League of Nations during the Ethiopian War had not been forgotten.
A Museum of American Philanthropy in France will be opened soon at Blerancourt, near the Soissons battle area, it was announced yesterday by the French Government Tourist Bureau here.

Carter Goodrich, American International Labor Office Commissioner, left today to attend the international textile conference in Washington April 4. He was chosen as one of the government delegates to represent the I. L. O. at the conference.

MOST of the men still alive who have, in one criminal fashion or another, attained an actual numerical rating as public enemies are now the responsibility of James A. Johnston. Al Capone is in his care, and Harvey Bailey and George (Machine Gun) Kelly, and some two hundred more. They live behind tool-steel doors in single

The old Haviland Manor house at the corner of Haviland Lane and North Street, White Plains, has been sold to Arthur Sutherland, New York lawyer, who has assembled about three acres there and will alter the residence for his own occupancy. Mervin M. Krepps was the broker.

The Surf Club was the scene of a St. Patrick's water sports program and a fashion show. The largest of the luncheon parties was that given by Mrs. J. W. McColl of Toronto, who entertained her house guests, Mrs. Fred C. Koch of Wichita Kan., and Mrs. Harold Crane of Toronto and large number of women friends from the beach colony.

The momentum attained by the steel industry has scarcely been checked by the recent price advances, according to The Iron Age, which says that although new buying at the higher prices has not reached a substantial volume yet there have been heavy specifications against first-quarter contracts, resulting in larger backlogs at mills.

Representatives of the United Mine Workers and bituminous operators continued their wage conference yesterday. At the end of another long session they said they had not been able to reach an understanding for a new agreement. The existing agreement expires April 1.

As 6,000 sit-down strikers defied a court order to evacuate eight Chrysler automobile plants, and from 30,000 to 50,000 pickets cheered them on in noisy demonstrations outside the plants, Governor Frank Murphy issued a warning today that the State might have to use force to restore respect for the courts and other public authorities, to protect both personal and property rights and to uphold the structure of organized society.

St. Patrick High of Kankakee, Ill., came from behind to defeat Central Catholic of Fort Wayne, Ind., 26 to 24, tonight in the opening game of the national Catholic interscholastic basketball tournament at Loyola University.

Lawrence Tibbett, American baritone, will make his first appearance in the opera houses of Europe when he sings during the coronation season at Covent Garden in London, it was announced yesterday. He will make his debut as Scarpia in "Tosca."

Mrs. Alfreda Mitchell Bingham sued for a divorce today. from Hiram Bingham, Senator from Connecticut in 1924-33. She charged mental cruelty. Mrs. Bingham said she and her husband separated in 1932 after he had for four years increasingly become "cold and indifferent" and assumed "an attitude of superiority."

When the New York Legislature made race-horse betting legal at tracks in 1934 it inferentially held that bookmaking no longer was considered an evil, it was argued in the Westchester County Court today by Frank A. Saporito, counsel for Anthony Ross Rubicco, an alleged bookmaker.

Freak blooms from all over the globe, including plants that inspire worship, growths that resemble stones and horticultural oddities that grow underground, won for the Brooklyn Botanic Garden three prizes yesterday at the International Flower Show.

County Judge Peter J. Brancato in Brooklyn accepted yesterday a plea of guilty of second degree assault from Mrs. Theresa Giordano, 45 years old, and then directed a jury to acquit her husband, Andrew, of a second degree manslaughter charge on which they both had been indicted.
A total of 1,966 nominations have been made for the twenty- four stake events during the August meeting at Saratoga, it was revealed yesterday following the closing of the entries on Monday.

The weekly report of the United States -Weather Bureau follows: In the Western wheat belt Winter wheat will benefit decidedly from the precipitation of the week, especially in the Southwestern plains. In Kansas the crop generally covers the ground in the eastern half, and is showing well in drill rows elsewhere, except in the extreme west. In Oklahoma, progress and

William Dillon, a Negro, 32 years old, of 303 West 122d Street, driver of a Department of Sanitation truck which fatally injured John H. Hodgson, 55, of 137 West Fortyseventh Street at Seventh Avenue and 131st Street on March 8, was found not guilty yesterday of a charge of homicide before Magistrate Henry H. Curran in Homicide Court. He was found guilty,
Eugene T. Warner, a retired insurance executive and formerly active in civic affairs in Brooklyn, died on Tuesday night at his home, 239 Washington Avenue, of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

Five members of an unofficial mission from the House of Lords and the House of Commons, sent over by the Imperial Policy Group, arrived from London yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to study political, social and labor conditions in the United States. The visitors said they expected to see Secretary of State Cordell Hull and possibly President Roosevelt.

182d St. (11-3195), s. e. cor. of Grand Av., 125x100: 38 W. 182d St. Corp. to Harle Properties Corp., 332 E. 149th St. Leland Av. (14-3756), w. s., 281 ft. s. of Gleason Av., 50x100; Margaret Mulcahy to Soccaroso Trigani. 1,156 Leland Av.
The Continental Export and Import Corporation, capitalized at $300,000, fully paid in, has just been organized to increase trade between the United States and Germany, it was announced yesterday.

From bullet wounds he received during an attempted hold-up in his grocery store at 443 Jerome Street, near Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, on Tuesday at 9 P. M., Berle Wolkowits, 64 years old, died yesterday at 2 A. M. in Trinity Hospital, Brooklyn.

Jacob Hurwitz, 31 years old, confessed leader of a gang alleged to have defrauded insurance companies of hundreds of thousands of dollars in fake accident indemnity claims, completed his testimony yesterday as the first State witness in the General Sessions trial of Henry Steinberg, 31, a lawyer, on a grand larceny indictment.
Sales of apartment and other residential properties in various parts of Long Island were reported yesterday. Woodside, Jamaica, Manhasset and Hempstead realty figured in the transactions.
In the outstanding match today in the Bermuda tennis championship Robert Murray of Montreal defeated Charles Harris of West Palm Beach, Fla., 6-3, 6-8, 6-4, 6-1. to reach the final round.
Captain Carlos Bean, retired, died suddenly at his home here yesterday, the Navy Department announced today. His age was 56. He was born at Kilgore, Texas. His widow,
Noyes Dwight Clark, retired real estate dealer, financier and civil engineer, died of a heart attack at his apartment in the Hotel Taft this morning.

Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy come to the Capitol's screen this morning in a Metro-GoldwynMayer adaptation of the Rida Johnson Young operetta "Maytime." Headed by John Barrymore, the supporting cast includes Tom Brown, Lynne Carver, Rafaela Ottiano, Herman Bing and Guy Bates Post.

President Roosevelt "got even" tonight with St. Patrick for helping to steal the show at the President's wedding thirty-two years ago. The President took the center of the stage at two Irish dinners with a speech telephoned from here.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers won yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,250,000 of parkway improvement, tax revenue and emergency relief bonds of Erie County, N. Y., on a bid of 100.0777 for 2.90s.
Injunctive powers of Michigan's courts over labor disputes would be limited and picketing legalized under a bill before the Legislature today.
Magistrate Lester Clayton ruled today that dissemination of information on contraceptives was in "the public good."
Diverse results for February were reported yesterday by railroads, the Southern Pacific reporting increased and the Erie decreased returns. Their statements follow:

Fear of a political crisis in France as an aftermath of the riots in Clichy renewed the selling pressure against the franc in the foreign exchange market yesterday. In spite of vigorous support from the official control the French currency fell to 4.58 1/4 cents and closed at 4.58 7-16 cents, off 15-16 point from the previous day.

Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands has consented to officiate at the launching of the new transatlantic liner Nieuw Amsterdam on April 10 and will name the ship with the traditional bottle of champagne broken across the bow, it was announced yesterday by the Hqlland-America Line. F. R.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months through February issued yesterday, shows a net income of $24,910,933 after depreciation, interest, subsidiary preferred dividends, taxes and other charges.

The Akron Employers Association, to which the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company was the main contributor, spent $21,000 out of its $36,000 income in 1936 for industrial spies and undercover men, it was testified today before the La Follette Senate subcommittee investigating subversive activities in labor disputes.
Properties in Connecticut reported yesterday as having changed hands included the former estate of Dr. Freeman Ward on Westover Road in Stamford.
Southern Boulevard, 2,363 (11-3114); Leonard Schack to Samuel Schack, 451 West End Av.; due on demand, 6 per cent; $16,626.
In springlike weather and warm sunshine Ireland kept the festival of the patron saint with no abatement of its traditional fervor and national enthusiasm.

Jonas Lie, president of the National Academy, will be one of the exhibiting members of the Society of Independent Artists when the annual exhibition opens on April 2 at the Grand Central Palace. He is the second well-known member of the academy to join the society this season, John Taylor Arms having recently become a member of the board of directors.

Following is the text of the agreement signed tonight between the Carnegie-lllinois Steel Corporation and four other subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation, and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee:

Colonel Philip Cartaret Hill Primrose, Lieutenant Governor of Alberta, died today at the age of 73. Joining the Northwest Mounted Police soon after his graduation from the Royal Military College at Kingston, Ont., Mr. Primrose served through the days of the prairie development and later in the far northwest.

Offering will be made today by Evans, Stillman Co.; Harris, Hall Co., Inc., and Dominick Dominick of a new issue of $4,290,000 of 2 1/4 per cent equipment trust certificates of the New York Central Railroad. The certificates,
The Reichsbank's statement as of March 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:
Students at Columbia University Law School are for Mr. ROOSEVELT'S judiciary reforms by something like 5 to 4. The members of

Physicians are still undecided tonight whether to operate on Dowager Queen Marie of Rumania, who is suffering from gastric hemorrhages. The Queen, attendants indicated, had rallied from a morning set-back and partial paralysis, noted Monday, had diminished.

The excellent physical condition that the Giants attained during their three-week stay in Havana began to pay dividends today as Colonel Bill Terry's men polished off Bucky Harris's Senators with almost ridiculous ease and by a score of 6 to 0.
Finishing near the nineteenth green, Eugene F. Thomas, Baltimore golfer, won the flag tournament today. H. B. Peabody of Detroit, 225 yards in front of the nineteenth tee, was second.

Stockholders of the General Cable Corporation at their annual meeting here yesterday approved the issuance of about $12,000,000 of new first-mortgage bonds and the retirement of $11,477,000 of 5 1/2 per cent Series A and B first-mortgage bonds.

A report submitted yesterday to Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, by Captain H. L. Peckham, assistant in charge of operations, disclosed that $108,377,946 was expended by the WPA in this city in the six months ending last Dec. 31 on construction, highway, repair and park projects.

Allen J. Johnson, a director of the Anthracite Industries Laboratory at Primos, Pa., has been appointed a member of the committee on correlation of research of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, it was announced yesterday.

A new horsemanship trophy for riders not over 19 will be offered at the third Metroplitan Equestrian Club horse show on March 27, it was announced yesterday. The prize is the Metropolitan Equestrain Club Horsemanship Challenge Trophy and must be won three times to be retired.
A mystery of the ocean, involving the disappearance from a thirty-foot yacht in mid-Atlantic of a man and woman who had "hitchhiked" a ride to the South Seas, confronted Barbados police today.

A state of labor peace which is expected to appeal to automobile and other industries in the United States is in the making here through the efforts of Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario. If his efforts cause a new movement of American industries into Ontario soon, it will be no surprise to the Premier, who is hoping for just that thing.
The Carolina Crest Hotel on North Carolina Avenue, Atlantic City, has been bought by Harry L. Fairbairn, veteran hotel man and lessee of the hotel since July, 1932.

Washington St., n. e. cor. Charlton St., 71x63; John Bradley, Inc., to John F. and Patrick F. Bradley, 63 75th St., Brooklyn. 121st St., 414 W., 118x101; Imft Realties, Inc., to Stanely Properties, Inc., 551 5th Av.; mtg. $196.000 ($17).

The Federal Alcohol Administration sharply warned distillers, rectifiers, importers and wholesalers of distilled spirits today that advertisements claiming for their liquors results beneficial to health were forbidden under Federal regulations.

CERMAK, MARY (Feb. 28). Estate, $13,399. To fourteen legatees varying bequests: Anna Janson, 1,378 York Av., executrix, household and personal effects. BOWMAN, LIZZIE I. (Feb. 13). Estate, less than $5,000. To Wilbur C. Held and Eugene H. Held, executor, brothers, 47 W. 94th St., one-half residue each; three specific bequests.
Mayor La Guardia will pull a switch at 11 o'clock Saturday morning which will discharge dynamite under the 227-foot chimney at Floyd Bennett Airport in Brooklyn and raze the structure.

Major Edwin Webb Moore, former head of a concern which supplied a large part of the special type of wire used by the American army for telephone communication on the battlefields of the World War, died Tuesday at his residence, the Hotel Bedford, of a heart attack. His age was 56.
The committee on hours and wages of the retailers' platform commission of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will meet on Monday in the offices of the association, it was learned yesterday.

American women must study the mood of the nation and do everything in their power to sweep away sit-down strikes, which, if allowed to continue, "can only end in revolution, dictatorship or the overthrow of the government," Miss Charlotte Aycrigg of Ridgewood, N. J., president general of the National Society of the Daughters of the Revolution, declared yesterday.

Speaker Bankhead left the Speaker's chair today to deliver a eulogy of the late Rear Admiral Richmond P. Hobson, hero of the sinking of the Merrimac in Santiago Harbor during the Spanish-American War.

Rather belatedly-and as though the discontinuance of a nineteenyear-old practice was as naughtcomes word that Walter Hampden has decided to give up his accustomed dual role of actor-manager and that henceforth he will just work as an actor for other folk.

Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis conscore an easy victory and advance to the semi-final round of Aiken's first annual women's invitation golf tournament. The young star eliminated Mrs. E. Warren Beard of Boston, 7 and 5.

Former associates in the financial field and executives of the Standard Oil Company of New York attended funeral services for the late Charles M. Higgins, a vice president and director of that company, yesterday at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.
Electric power output increased last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 107.9 from 107.8 It was 97.8 for the week ended March 14, 1936.

The two-story store and warehouse at 4,014-18 Third Avenue, between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets, Brooklyn, has been bought for occupancy by the Fanti Export Company, Inc. Situated on a plot 40 by 95, the property is near the Bush Terminal Building.
Ignace Jan Paderewski is gravely ill with influenza in his Swiss home at Morges. He is 76 years old, and his doctors are anxious.

"It's all in the feet," was Burleigh Grimes's remark when he announced several days ago that a track coach would be attached to the camp to teach his Dodgers how to run. Boss Burleigh's statement is true, with some qualifications.

Allan Potts, member of the 1932 and 1936 American Olympic teams, and Eddie Quimby, representing the Texaco Skating Club, captured the 10,000-meter team race, feature event of the annual carnival of the Brooklyn Figure Skating Club, before 1,200 persons at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The time of the winners, who compiled a total of 35 points, was 23:35.2.
Long Island University of Brooklyn advanced into the quarter-finals of the National A. A. U. championship basketball tournament tonight by defeating New Mexico Normal in the-third round, 43 to 39.
Raleigh Shaver, the tall rancher whom children all over the country know as "Santa Claus" because of his generous giving for thirty-one Christmases, died today in a St. Joseph hospital.

The marriage of Theodore Rousseau, a vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company and president of the American Club of Paris, and Princess Albert de Broglie, the former Nicole Xantho, was celebrated here today in the Church of Ste. Therese de 1'Enfant Jesus with the strictest privacy because of the recent death of the bride's father.

Secretary Wallace gave official confirmation today of administration fears that the nation may be on its' way toward another business boom and ensuing collapse such as rocked the economic structure beginning with 1929. At the same time he gave the impression that the administration, at the proper time, would seek new powers to head off such a development.
Meeting of the New York City League of Women Voters, 151 East Fiftieth Street, 10:30 A. M. "The Marriage Law of Our State," Dr. Sidney Goldstein.

The Securities and Exchange Commission acted in Federal court here yesterday to smash an enterprise engaged in selling the stock of the American Consolidated Tin Mines Corporation, described in the complaint a; a "paper" corporation with skimp mining property.

Readers of legislative and Congressional proceedings are pretty well acquainted with the iniquities of the press. Bills to put a hook into the jaw of this leviathan turn up rather frequently, only to be turned down by marble-hearted committees.

T. Jefferson Coolidge of Boston, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, was elected a director of the New York Central Railroad yesterday. This was in accordance with the company's custom of having a New England representative on its board. Mr. Coolidge succeeds the late Gordon Abbott.

The New York division of the Pennsylvania Railroad, with headquarters in Jersey City, won first place in Group A of the superintendents' divisions for the best safety record in 1936, it was announced yesterday.

More than 2,500 persons attended yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral a funeral service for Frank Garrett Shattuck, chairman of the board of directors of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, operator of Schrafft's restaurants and candy stores.

Humbling a strong Irish squad, 4-1, today, Wales captured international soccer honors for the seventh time since the full series of games was inaugurated in 1883. Twenty-five thousand spectators saw a one-sided encounter in which the victors were. on top practically all the time.

The Irving Trust Company has been appointed trustee under a lease and agreement securing $2,380,000 par value of equipment trust certificates of the Union Railroad Company. R. C. Gunnell has been appointed an assistant trust officer of the Bankers Trust Company.

Greater coordination of the varyous phases of management is necessary during the recovery period to develop efficiency in manufacturning and selling, it was agreed by speakers representing different industries at a meeting of the Socity for the Advancement of Management at Rockefeller Center last night. Walter K. Porzer, general

The number of policy holders as well as the amounts of written and earned premiums and new business of the New York State Insurance Fund reached record figures last year, Charles G. Smith, manager, reported yesterday.

The law committee of the Board of Education will recommend at the board's meeting on March 24 that the board disapprove a legislative bill that would give permanent tenure to associate superintendents after ten years' service.

The twelve-story loft building at 33-43 East 33d St.. 115 1/2 feet of frontage, was sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. to the 33 East 33d St. Corp., Max Rosenfeld, president, for a consideration shown as $550,000, the buyer giving back a purchase money mortgage for $450.000, payable ten years hence at 5 per cent, and to be amortized $4,500 semi-annually beginning April 1, 1938.

Keeshin Transcontinental Freight Lines, Inc., in which Lehman Brothers hold 40 per cent of the common stock, was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to enter the New England Trucking field through the purchase of Seaboard Freight Lines, Inc., which, with three subsidiaries, operates freight lines into five New England States going as far north as Bangor.

The annual luncheon meeting of the New Jersey Society, Daughters of Colonial Wars, was held at the Old Barracks here today. Mrs. J. W. Flickinger of South Orange, Mrs. John D. Schoeffel of Dunkirk, N. Y.; Mrs. A. L. Stillwell of Somerville and Mrs. Alfred G. Mayor of Princeton were chosen as delegates to the national meeting in Washington on April 17.

Miss Mary Osborn Polak of 825 Fifth Avenue, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. John Osborn Polak, was married yesterday afternoon in the roof garden of the Pierre to Donald Mitchell Oenslager of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Oenslager Jr. of Harrisburg, Pa.
Mr. and Mrs. John Franklin Davies of Aldcroft, near Baltimore, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annette Davies, to Raymond Francis Momonier of New York.
California Packing Corporation 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $50 par value, has been admitted to the list by the New York Stock Exchange.

The Senate passed and sent to conference the Treasury-Postoffice Appropriation Bill, debated sit-down strikes, received the Commerce Committee's report of air safety, and adjourned at 3:18 P. M. until noon Friday.

A series of announcements made yesterday by officials at Columbia University revealed that Professor Franz Schrader has been named head of the university's Department of Zoology, while Professor Joseph F. Ritt has become acting head of the Department of Mathematics.

It is the Music Box Theatre which will receive "Young Madame Conti" on March 31. Constance Cummings, who will star in the play, and her husband, Benn W. Levy, who has collaborated on the adaptation, will arrive here from London next week.

Bates Fabrics, Inc., a newlyformed corporation which will be the sole distributors of the Bates Manufacturing Company's bedspreads and other products, will establish headquarters at 80 Worth Street early in April. H. D. Ruhm

Five of the largest producing units of the $2,000,000,000 United States Steel Corporation signed contracts tonight with union followers of John L. Lewis setting up machinery designed to insure industrial peace among their 160,000 workers for at least a year.

Professor Irving Fisher, Yale economist, became the target of both defense and prosecution yesterday when attorneys summed up in the trial of Wallace G. Garland and Arnold C. Mason, graduates of Yale, who with eleven other persons are accused of mail fraud in the sale of stock of the Public Service Holding Corporation.
The Soviet Fine Arts Commissariat approved today the idea of the American conductor, Vladimir Shavitch, for carrying grand opera to the masses without great expense or loss of quality.

The Cornell-Pennsylvania Luncheon Club, Inc., with a membership composed of alumni of the two universities who are employed in the downtown financial district, was opened yesterday with a luncheon at the club headquarters, William and Beaver Streets.

Advancing in the upper bracket of the Belleview amateur golf championship, the second round of which was played today, Robert E. Barbour of Paterson, N. J., and F. H. Gouverneur of Rochester, N. Y., entered the Semi-finals.
MODERN REPRODUCTION CO., INC., 347 Madison Av.-By Defiance Sales Corp., for $273: Eugene Dietzgen Co., Inc. $532: Charles Bruning Co., Inc., $232.

A birthday brother of St. Patrick won his race with stork and snowdrifts today to be born in Leonard Hospital here. The youngster arrived just twenty minutes after his mother, Mrs. D. S. Corlew of Stephentown, reached the hospital, following a six-hour, twenty-threemile trip through drifted highways.

Samuel Robinson, president of the American Stores Company since its formation in 1917, announced his retirement today at the annual meeting of stockholders. He said he felt that he had served in the office long enough.

The City Club attacked the Board of Aldermen again yesterday in an effort to force adoption of the new Building Code, which is being held in committee. The club's latest onslaught was in connection with an exchange of letters between Alderman Edward J. Sullivan, chairman of the committee on buildings, and Richard S. Childs, president of the club.

Political analogies, always risky, are never more so than in French politics. Tuesday's fatal rioting in a Communist section of Paris recalls the much more bloody riots of Feb. 6, 1934, which seemed for a moment to bring France to the verge of revolution.

A FrancoGerman understanding regarding exploitation of the French African Cameroons is reported here. Although no official statement has been made, it is reported that the German Foreign Office and the French Ministry of Colonies view the plan approvingly.

Favored to gain a place in the Scottish Football Cup final at Hampden Park April 24, Aberdeen defeated the Hamilton Academicals, 2-1, in their fourth-round match today. Celtic and Motherwell battled to a 4-4 draw.
United States Government bonds were depressed further in price yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in a turnover somewhat larger than that of Tuesday.

Younger members of the American Bar Association are agreed with their elders in opposing President Roosevelt's plan to revise the Supreme Court, according to an announcement today at the association headquarters here.

Heavy rains which swamped all England in the last few days spent considerable of their violence in this vicinity, assuring heavy going over the Aintree country both for tomorrow's opening program and for the ninety-ninth running of the Grand National Steeplechase on Friday.

Ann Harding announced today she would withdraw from the revival of George Bernard Shaw's play "Candida" April 1 in order to accompany her husband, Werner Janssen, the symphony orchestra conductor, on a tour of the Continent. She arranged with her friend, Diana Wynyard, to take her place.

East Side properties from the Corlears Hook section up to East 123d Street figured in many of the deals in Manhattan real estate reported yesterday. Three parcels on the upper West Side also changed hands.

Members of the Union Temple quintet, which captured twenty out of twenty-two games during the regular campaign and third place in the Metropolitan A. A. U. championship tournament, were honored at a dinner tendered by Henry C. Jacobs, chairman of the basketball committee, at the Temple House last night.

Rubber shares made further advances in a generally quiet but firm stock market here today. Gilt-edge issues improved slightly. Among the foreign securities, French loans declined. International issues did well as a group; United States Steel shares were well supported but International Nickel securities were irregular.

Vincent Richards, former Davis Cup player and national doubles champion with William Tilden, will appear in singles and doubles at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night on the program that will feature the first meeting between Tilden and Fred Perry of Great Britain.

Additional notifications of the maintenance of resale prices on liquors and several proprietary drug preparations under the provisions of the Feld-Crawford act were received by stores here yesterday. The liquors comprised an imported champagne, rum, cognac and Scotch whisky.

St. Patrick's Day in the camp of the Yankees was celebrated with a snappy drill that proceeded with routine smoothness. The absence of a scuffle against National League opposition gave Joe McCarthy a chance to appraise the work of his flingers in the three games which have already gone into history and the Yankee pilot frankly declared himself satisfied.
Stockholders of Safeway Stores, Inc., meeting yesterday in Baltimore, approved a financing plan, with about 60 per cent of the outstanding stock represented.

Contradicting the testimony, of prosecution experts, six defense experts testified yesterday in the Bronx County Court before Judge Lester W. Patterson that two 10inch I-beams were intended to bolster the roof tier of the building at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, which collapsed last June 19, killing eighteen workmen.

The House Rivers and Harbors. Committee debated a proposal today that $40,000,000 be spent for stream purification purposes. Representative Joseph L. Pfeifer, New York Democrat, told the committee that New York's World's Fair might be affected unless immediate action was taken to make the fund available.

Ordered In accordance with an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Jan. 29, 1937, John J. Shea, who was dismissed from the force on Nov. 30, 1935, be and is reinstated to the position of first grade patrolman, and assigned to the 41st Precinct.
With first place in the Eastern division already in their possession, the Philadelphia Ramblers defeated the New Haven Eagles, 4 to 2, tonight in an International-American League hockey game.

Mercantile Credit Corporation Public offering of 300,000 shares of $1-par value capital stock of the Mercantile Credit Corporation of New Orleans will be made today by Eli T. Watson Co., Inc., at $3.75 a share, out of 650,000 shares covered by a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A former actress and journalist, known as Miss Madeleine de Fontange, shot and wounded Count Charles de Chambrun, French diplomat, in the Gare du Nord tonight as he was about to enter the train, with his wife, for Brussels.

The neutrality bills now before Congress are not supported by the League of Nations Association, Inc., 8 West Fortieth Street, Clark M. Eichelberger, national director of the association, said yesterday. He added, however, that the McReynolds bill was to be preferred to the Pittman bill.
Champions come and go, but Marry Wolf came in with the depression and it looks as if it will take another one to get him out.

Net profit of $3,483,602 made in 1936 by the National Supply Company of Delaware and subsidiaries, including Spang, Chalfant Co., Inc., was the best in seven years, according to their annual report, issued yesterday.
A physician's gruesome description of the wounds on the body of a murdered Negro woman, related yesterday from the witness stand in Kings County Court, caused one of the jurors to collapse.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that a protest had been filed with the United States Maritime Commission against the threat of limiting the time of free storage of commodities on New York piers to ten days.
Eagle Pass, the Valdina Farm's star colt, won the feature race, the Galveston handicap, from a field of fast-stepping 3-year-olds at Epsom Downs today.

It is reported from authoritative sources in Berlin that Chancellor Adolf Hitler, during the lengthy talk he had Monday with King Christian of Denmark, suggested the conclusion of a pact of non-aggression.

Strategic experts on naval and military factors in the Far East refuse to regard seriously renewed conjectures as to the availability of the northeast passage from Russia to the Maritime Provinces of Eastern Siberia as a channel through which the Soviet Government could send naval vessels and so maintain an important fleet at Vladivostok in event of another Far Eastern war.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in the Morristown Hospital, Morristown, N. J., of George J. Little, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of W. E. Burnet Co., 11 Wall Street. Mr. Little, who
A shillalah freshly cut from a blackthorn tree in County Cork was presented to Speaker Bankhead for a gavel today by Representative O'Connor, Democrat, of New York.

The Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., instituted a suit in Supreme Court yesterday for $50,000 against the Rosenthal Kalman Company, Inc., charging that the latter had violated an agreement designed to prevent style "pirating."

Intense feeling has been aroused in financial quarters in London at what is belived to be an attempt by the British Government to further President Roosevel's policy of keeping "hot money" out of the United States by again tightening the unofficial embargo on foreign lending, which under the Treasury's guidance recently had been made easier.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today permitted the name of William E. Hutton 2d to be linked with the alleged manipulation of Atlas Tack Corporation stock in 1935.
Governor Lehman signed today the Quinn bill permitting juries to recommend life imprisonment in trials of felony murder cases. He attended the dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick here.
Charles Zeek, president of the Jefferson Township Board of Education and an employee of the United States Arsenal at Picatinny, was arrested today on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the township.

Dr. Ernst F. S. Hanfstaengl, Harvard-educated former head of the Foreign Press Bureau here, early today expressed surprise that the world had been hunting him for days. Reached by telephone at his hotel in Zurich, Switzerland, he said:

William J. Falk will give a lecture-recital on "Parsifal" this afternoon at the Sherman Square Studio. The eighth in the series of MozartHaydn concerts will be given tomorrow night at the WPA Theatre of Music. The fourth in the series of popular Thursday evening concerts will be presented tonight in the same auditorium.
The Treasury contended tonight that the taxes proposed to finance a new railroad pension system are too low.

The marriage of Miss Helmi Felsberg, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John Felsberg of West Englewood, N. J., to Major Marius B. Greene of Brooklyn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John K. Greene of Stockbridge, Mass., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Riverside Church. The Rev. Dr. C. Ivar Hellstrom performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at Sherry's.

Miss Venetia Anne Dormer, third daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Dormer of Hove, Sussex, was married at St. Mary's Church, Chelsea, today to Frank R. Kelley, only son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Kelley of Brooklyn. Mgr. Valentine Elwes,

Mrs. Willard S. Brown entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Duncan Sterling, Mrs. John E. Berwind, Mrs. Charles E. Pettinos, Mrs. Cecil Barret and Mrs. Hoppin Pool.

Efforts of twenty-seven European nations to isolate the Spanish civil war appeared to be in jeopardy tonight as Great Britain moved to investigate reports that Italy had permitted "volunteers" to land in Spain.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in the Morristown Hospital, Morristown, N. J., of George J. Little, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of W. E. Burnet Co., 11 Wall Street. Mr. Little, who

About 250 members of Local 251, the Brooklyn unit of the National Federation of Postoffice Clerks, went on record unanimously yesterday afternoon for the enactment of the Mead bill, now pending in Congress, which provides for an increase in pay for postoffice employes.

Thirteen thousand persons, filling every seat in Maple Leaf Gardens, saw tonight's opening performance of the Toronto Skating Club's thirteenth annual carnival. Felix Kaspar of Vienna, world figure skating champion, received a tremendous ovation. Pretty Miss Cecilia Colledge of London, world women's titleholder, was just as popular with the huge crowd.
Rapid extension of the ticker system carrying quotations of the New York Curb Exchange were announced by that market yesterday, when Kanss City and St. Louis were added to the list.
The Treasury contended tonight that the taxes proposed to finance a new railroad pension system are too low.

The marriage of Miss Helmi Felsberg, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John Felsberg of West Englewood, N. J., to Major Marius B. Greene of Brooklyn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John K. Greene of Stockbridge, Mass., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Riverside Church. The Rev. Dr. C. Ivar Hellstrom performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at Sherry's.

Miss Venetia Anne Dormer, third daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Dormer of Hove, Sussex, was married at St. Mary's Church, Chelsea, today to Frank R. Kelley, only son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Kelley of Brooklyn. Mgr. Valentine Elwes,

Mrs. Willard S. Brown entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Duncan Sterling, Mrs. John E. Berwind, Mrs. Charles E. Pettinos, Mrs. Cecil Barret and Mrs. Hoppin Pool.

Efforts of twenty-seven European nations to isolate the Spanish civil war appeared to be in jeopardy tonight as Great Britain moved to investigate reports that Italy had permitted "volunteers" to land in Spain.

Members of the Manhattan Chapter of the Reserve Officers Association were told at a luncheon meeting at the Columbia University Club yesterday that the increased range and power of aircraft threaten soon to nullify the protection now afforded to the United States by the flanking oceans. Colonel Frank P.

Gordon C. Repzer, 18 years old, a student at Brooklyn Technical High School, was accidentally killed by carbon monoxide fumes last night while repairing an automobile in a garage owned by his parents at 220 Sixteenth Street, Brooklyn.

The 175 "slow readers" who were enrolled last February in the Speyer School's seven "Binet classes" by the Board of Education and Teachers College have proved in a little more than a year that enterprise can partly make up for the lack of reading ability.

Efforts to settle the wage dispute involving thousands of building service employes in the garment and fur districts were resumed yesterday at a conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania. James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union; Larry Mayer of the Midtown Realty Association and Leon Spear of the PennZone group were among those present.
Gordon Browning, Governor of Tennessee, discussed yesterday at a luncheon of the Municipal Bond Club here the development of the Tennessee Valley by the Federal Government. This development,
Senator Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan proposed today that control of all interstate natural gas pipe-line companies be vested in a Federal commission.

About 250 members of Local 251, the Brooklyn unit of the National Federation of Postoffice Clerks, went on record unanimously yesterday afternoon for the enactment of the Mead bill, now pending in Congress, which provides for an increase in pay for postoffice employes.

Thirteen thousand persons, filling every seat in Maple Leaf Gardens, saw tonight's opening performance of the Toronto Skating Club's thirteenth annual carnival. Felix Kaspar of Vienna, world figure skating champion, received a tremendous ovation. Pretty Miss Cecilia Colledge of London, world women's titleholder, was just as popular with the huge crowd.
Rapid extension of the ticker system carrying quotations of the New York Curb Exchange were announced by that market yesterday, when Kanss City and St. Louis were added to the list.
Mrs. Emma Frances Fisher Porter, the widow of George F. Porter, an electrical engineer, died on Monday at her home, 145 East Fifty-fourth Street, after a brief illness. A native of Philadelphia

Frank A. Hoey, foreign manager for the Pillsbury Flour Mills with an office at 21 West Street, died yesterday at his home, 3,530 Riverdale-on-Hudson, at the age of 51. A month ago he underwent an operation for a gastric ailment.

The Appellate Division, Third Department, authorized the State today to appeal a decision in favor of the Electrick Bond and Share Company involving $104,274 in stock-transfer stamps. This amount plus interest, was awarded by the State Court of Claims.

The voluntary agreement covering pensions, arrived at between the nation's railroads and the twenty-one standard railway unions, is an important victory for collective bargaining. It settles a controversy which goes back to 1934, when Congress passed the first Railway Pension Act.
Oxford today devoted its first outing to trying starts from stakeboats as training continued for the OxfordCambridge crew race next Wednesday. The Dark Blues were impressive in each effort.
Sitdown strikers at the Rosedale Knitting Company's plant in Laureldale were ordered today by Judge Paul N. Schaeffer to show cause why an injunction should not be issued ousting them from the mill.

The confirmation of the five-man board of the Maritime Commission, whose nominations were sent to the Senate Commerce Committee a week ago by President Roosevelt, will be postponed for at least a week.
Prices of hogs advanced 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight today because the receipts were smaller than expected. Arrivals were 12,000 head, the smallest for a Wednesday since September.
Scientific advice on the treatment of ailing snakes was given by radio yesterday to a ship hundreds of miles at sea by Harold J. O'Connell, vice president of the Staten Island Zoological Society.

Assurances from the Department of State that two men from the staff of the committee for reciprocity information, which works on reciprocal trade treaties, will be in constant attendance at the World Two-Way Trade Fair here May 10 to 22, were received by the fair directors at a special meeting yesterday. In addition,
Friends of Governor Lehman learned today that he is determined to veto the pending Republican bill which would outlaw the sale of child labor products in this State.

An hour after the Hawaiian Clipper, with a record mail and express shipment and seven passengers, had cleared the Alameda, Calif., base, we received clearance for our departure on the first leg of our 7,000mile survey flight to far-off New Zealand.
Many reservations have been made for the "Prophecy of Spring" fashion show and tea, this afternoon in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

Opponents of President Roosevelt's plan for reorganizing the Federal judiciary renewed their efforts today to obtain the views of Supreme Court justices, following Justice McReynolds's speech last night in which he called for "fairness" toward the court in the present controversy.
The great smokestack jutting smokelessly from the Dodge Brothers plant looked down solemnly tonight on this island-like suburb of Detroit and an acute state of civic jitters.

Edward Rogers, defending titleholder, pulled further away from Louis Brooks by taking the second of their three-block encounter for the national amateur pocket billiard title, 135-17, at the Strand Academy last night.
Arrangements have been made for sale of a New York Curb Exchange membership at $32,500, a gain of $500 over the last previous sale.

So many Federal, State and city detectives had been lurking near his home at 69 MacDougal Street for four days that Eddie Capobianco, 36 years old, who has been arrested many times and has served two sentences, decided he must be wanted again.

Walter Doyle, writer of popular songs, and his widowed mother, Mrs. Thomas K. Doyle, are on a sit-down strike tonight against an order obtained by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to evict them from their home at 710 Sixth Street.

The Hershey sextet took a 4-point lead in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight by defeating the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 6-4, in a rough game. Nineteen penalties were called, two of them five-minute majors, for fighting, and at one time all the Hershey and Sea Gull players were slugging on the ice.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 15: REAR ADMIRAL Brinser, H. L., Comdr. Cruiser Division 4, to duty as president of Board of Inspection and Survey, Navy Department, Washington, D. C., about June 7.

Earnings of the United Fruit Company in 1936 were the best in several years because of general improved business conditions and consequent betterment in purchasing power, Francis R. Hart, president, said at the annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday.
The Shooter, a consistent performer at Santa Anita, where he won his last two starts for the Millsdale Stable, signalized his Fair Grounds debut by winning the six-furlong feature today.

"Big Jim" Tobin, 1 year old, and the only Irishman present yesterday morning at the Salvation Army's St. Patrick's Day party at its Cherry Street Settlement, was not the least bit interested in honoring Erin's patron saint. He slept through the whole program.

This week's decline in United States Government bonds, culminating in yesterday's sharp reaction, caused a variety of conjecture as to its cause and meaning. Early this present year or in the closing weeks of 1936, practically all of these bonds had reached the highest price of their history; declines

Frederick H. Bedford Jr., Harrison K. McCann and James Henry Hayes resigned yesterday as members of the Bondholders Committee for Republic of Colombia and the Independent Bondholders Committee for Republic of Colombia, and Hayes, Nottingham Combs resigned as counsel for the committees, it was announced by Lawrence E. de S. Hoover, executive secretary of the committee.
