Two large-swastikas, the emblem of Nazi Germany, were found painted in- black enamel last night on the doors of the Congregation Ahavath Chesed.synagogue at 7,902 Fifteenth. Avenue in the Bath Beach 'area of Brooklyn. Four smaller symbols in chalk were marked on side doors of the building.

The real estate tax and debt limistation bill, known as the RogersRapp bill, now before the State Legislature, is receiving the hearty support of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce. It provides that the real estate rate for all local tax purposes other than funded debt service cannot be more than 1 3/4 per cent of the assessed valuation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I should like to question the reasoning implied in your leading editorial "Labor and the Law." The Wagner act is there condemned because it empowers the National Labor Relations Board "to intervene only in behalf of labor."

Although Majorca, under joint Italian and Rebel occupation, is sealed against the emanation of news, the writer has come into possession of copies of official documents and private letters-the originals of which he has seen-relating to a public execution recalling Inquisition days.
Juries will be permitted to recommend life imprisonment for accomplices in felony murder cases under the Quinn bill signed today by Governor Lehman.

"Big Jim" Tobin, 1 year old, and the only Irishman present yesterday morning at the Salvation Army's St. Patrick's Day party at its Cherry Street Settlement, was not the least bit interested in honoring Erin's patron saint. He slept through the whole program.

Frederick H. Bedford Jr., Harrison K. McCann and James Henry Hayes resigned yesterday as members of the Bondholders Committee for Republic of Colombia and the Independent Bondholders Committee for Republic of Colombia, and Hayes, Nottingham Combs resigned as counsel for the committees, it was announced by Lawrence E. de S. Hoover, executive secretary of the committee.

Two large-swastikas, the emblem of Nazi Germany, were found painted in- black enamel last night on the doors of the Congregation Ahavath Chesed.synagogue at 7,902 Fifteenth. Avenue in the Bath Beach 'area of Brooklyn. Four smaller symbols in chalk were marked on side doors of the building.

It provides that the real estate rate for all local tax purposes other than funded debt service cannot be more than 1 3/4 per cent of the assessed valuation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I should like to question the reasoning implied in your leading editorial "Labor and the Law." The Wagner act is there condemned because it empowers the National Labor Relations Board "to intervene only in behalf of labor."

Although Majorca, under joint Italian and Rebel occupation, is sealed against the emanation of news, the writer has come into possession of copies of official documents and private letters-the originals of which he has seen-relating to a public execution recalling Inquisition days.
Juries will be permitted to recommend life imprisonment for accomplices in felony murder cases under the Quinn bill signed today by Governor Lehman.

Henry C. Omme died at the Northern Westchester Hospital last night. His age was 76. He was former business agent for a carpenters' union in Northern Westchester County, former chief of the Mount Kisco Fire Department and a charter member of the Mount Kisco Lodge of the Elks.

Continued small receipts of hogs met with an active demand and prices advanced 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight, with some good quality underweights regarded as 15 to 25 cents higher. The top price advanced 5 cents to $10.40.

Boston Rd., 1,351-53, 2-story brick stores, 36.6x136.6, 37.1x128.6; Harlem Savings Bank against Harry Crane; due. $18,156; taxes, , $307; to plaintiff for $1,000. Sagamore St., n. e. cor. Birchall Av., 119.10x51.4, 106.5x45.6; Ernest T. Stehlby against B. V. Holding Corp.; due, $11,037; taxes, , $2,977; to plaintiff for $5,000.

Expansion by several firms featured the business leases reported yesterday. James McCutcheon Co., Fifth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, leased for their executive offices a floor of $3,000 square feet in the adjoining building at 10 East Forty-ninth Street.

Domestic stocks of refined copper, excluding consumers' stocks at their plants or warehouses, at the end of February have been revised to 136,121 tons by the Copper Institute, making the total decline in that month 6,253 tons.

Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. C. Douglass Green, who will leave on Monday with her husband for Tucson, Ariz. The other guests were Mrs. V. Fisher Kuser and Mrs. du Pignac Thompson.

METROPOLITAN BEVERAGE, INC., 412 W. 48th St., by Piel Bros., for $402; Kings Brewery Co., Inc., $330; Fidelio Brewery, Inc., $454. Petitions Filed-By IRVING BRUCKMAN, musician, 500 W. 147th St.-Liabilities $1,261; no assets except insurance.

Martha Harris, 18-year-old student in the London School, was a short distance from the structure when the explosion came. Here is her account of the scene: "I was in the home economy building about sixty yards from the school when I heard a terrible roar. The earth shook and brick and glass came showering down.
Newark police, seeking the body of a "murdered woman," today called off dragging the Barge Canal, satisfied that the "mystery" which stirred this Wayne County village for four days was all a mistake.

Attorneys for the Chrysler Corporation appeared before Circuit Judge Allan Campbell in chambers today, preparatory to asking for another court order looking toward the legal eviction of the 6,000 sit-down strikers who have held possession of eight of its plants here since a week ago Monday.

Sheriff's deputies, accompanied by William C. Bitting, president of the Rosedale Knitting Mills in Laureldale, served individual notices of injunction proceedings today on 168 sit-down strikers at the plant.

Robert Dougherty of Overbrook, Pa., was elected captain of the University of Pennsylvania five for 1938 at a testimonial dinner to the Eastern Intercollegiate League champions at the Ritz-Carlton tonight. Dougherty has played forward the last two seasons. He also is a football halfback.
The second medical unit organized by the American Friends of Spanish Democracy sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie. The unit is headed by Dr. John Jacob Posner, New York surgeon.

There is a lack of adequate personnel in the public health field to meet increasing demands for this type of service, Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University, told representatives of public health nursing agencies yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Roosevelt.

A petition to have Henry Spaulding Schley declared mentally incompetent so a committee could be appointed to manage his estate was dismissed today by Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief on the ground venue was improperly laid in the Ninth Judicial District.
Traversing a wide-swinging are, the Pan American Clipper crossed the eastern quadrant of the Pacific Ocean last night on the first leg of a survey flight for a new aerial trade route to New Zealand.
The Bank of Canada increased its gold holdings about $3,500,000 in the week ended yesterday, according to a statement issued today.
Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" was presented for the second time this season at the Metropolitan last night. Because of the indisposition of Franca Somigli, the title role was sung by Susanne Fisher.

Side by side in Wednesday's news were reports of two conferences-one of archaeologists looking backward and comparing views on the age of man on the earth, the other of scientists interested in lengthening the intellectual life of the individual.
A bill to continue the State's milk advertising program for another year with an appropriation of $400,000 was introduced today in the Legislature by Assemblyman Hallowell of Yates, Republican.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading In fresh pork cuts was fair. Other classes moved only fair to slow with the exception of a few miscellaneous cuts which were in good demand.
George Rayner, civil engineer and surveyor, who was formally active in civic and business affairs in Yonkers, died last night at his home here at the age of 77.
The thirty-three probable starters in tomorrow's Grand National, with ages, weights, jockeys, owners and odds:

It is nearly 100 years since Captain Becher swallowed the water of the brook which has borne his name from that day, but the Aintree course, over which the Grand National will be run tomorrow, remains substantially the same as when Lottery won the first running in 1839.
Sweden's Foreign Minister, Rickard J. Sandler, left for Paris today after a visit that has done much to strengthen British influence over the democratic kingdoms of Northern Europe.

Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson leaped back into the headlines today when the King's Proctor, Sir Thomas Barnes, took sudden action in connection with the historic decree nisi granted by a divorce court at Ipswich last October.

PRIZE-WINNERS among run-of-the-mill books are hardly more rare than genuinely good books among prize-winners. Jenny Ballou's "Spanish Prelude" ($2.50), chosen for the second in the series of Houghton Mifflin Fellowship Awards, is a notable exception to the rule of better-than-average. It is something of a work of art.

Construction activity during the week shows a gain over the same period of 1936 of 6 per cent in the total and 62 per cent in the volume awarded for private work, according to The Engineering NewsRecord. The figures for the week are: Total, $34,569,000; private, $17,925,000; public, $16,644,000.
The sit-down by remote control that has interfered considerably with the training preparations of the world champion Yankees suffered one important defection today.

Charles Lee Cooke, ceremonial officer of the State Department for many years, died here today in his seventy-second year. Secretary Hull, at a press conference and in a formal statement, expressed "great personal sadness" over Mr. Cooke's death.

The reproach is frequently made abroad that the Soviet regime does not allow criticism of its prominent personalities. If that is true, the newspaper Izvestia, government organ, has never heard of it, because today it takes a resounding crack at Vice Commissar of Agriculture Demchenko under the caption, "Demchenko's Ridiculous Order."

William H. Ludlow, cashier of the Tax Department in Richmond Borough and a Republican district leader -for more than fifty years, died Wednesday night at his home in Fort Wadsworth, S. I., after a vear's illness. He was 80 years old.

A plan for reorganization of the Rochester lines of the New York state Railway drafted by United states Judge Frederick H. Bryant of Syracuse was distributed today for study by attorneys involved in the eight-year receivership litigation.

By the signing of a treaty with Mexico this week, the United States now has further authority over migratory birds while they are in this country and is to provide protection for species that are not covered by the Canadian treaty.

One of the most thrilling and dramatic performances that the writer has been privileged to hear in thirteen years of music in New York was given last night in Carnegie Hall, when Artur Rodzinski, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and a fine cast of singers, headed by Rosa Pauly of the Vienna Opera, who then made her American debut, gave most of Richard Strauss's "Elektra" in concert form.

Responding to the pleas of residents of the Rockaways and of the North Bronx for extensions of the Independent City Subway to those sections. the Board of Estimate voted in executive session yesterday to add $16,000,000 for subways to the 1937 capital outlay budget.

Strange things are happening in this 1937 Dodger training campstrange, at least, to an observer who for a dozen years has watched the changing heroes of Flatbush limbering muscles and sharpening batting eyes for many a weary campaign that never brought a pennant.

A group of explorers, educators and others, under the chairmanship of F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, have completed plans to bring Mrs. Martin Johnson, widow of the explorer, to New York for her first public appearance here on the evening of March 29 at Carnegie Hall.

Avery M. Hoadley, former Madison County Assemblyman, died at his home here today at the age of 73. An active Republican in Madison County for twenty-five years, he was Assemblyman for two terms, 1900-02; a Supervisor of the town of Hamilton, N. Y., for eighteen years, and chairman of the Board of Supervisors of Madison County for five years.

One of the outstanding events of our early Spring season opened with a private view yesterday afternoon at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. It is a large retrospective loan exhibition of paintings by Edouard Manet, and is being held for the benefit of the French Hospital and the Lisa Day Nursery.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has invited Admiral Richard E. Byrd to speak with her from the White House on April 6, when they will participate in starting a nationwide No-Foreign-War Crusade.

Asserting that the Bolivian Government's contentions were without substantial merit. Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, announced last night that title to the Bolivian concession, held through a subsidiary company and recently canceled by the government, would be defended.

Moving up fast in the stretch, E. Milner's Yellow Metal won her third straight race in defeating seven other cheap players in the mile and an eighth of the Covington purse, feature at the Fair Grounds today.

A lusty triple by a rookie flychaser gave the Yankees a victory over the Reds at Waterfront Park today and enabled the world champions to stretch their string of citrus belt conquests to four straight. The score was 3 to 1 at the end of a tight game witnessed by 2,759 fans.

Carloadings to date in March of the Erie Railroad are running about 23 per cent ahead of March last year, according to C. E. Denney, president. Mr. Denney explained that the comparatively poor showing of his road in February was due to the falling off in coal shipments because of the Ohio Valley floods.

Three thousand men worked in the ruins of the $125,000 London Consolidated High School this morning under the glare of searchlights and gas flares, trying to find the bodies of school children and teachers still buried under the ruins of the building that collapsed yesterday afternoon after an explosion, with a loss estimated as at least 500 lives.

Marcus Tullius Reynolds, Albany architect, died today in the Albany Hospital after a week's illness. His age was 67. He was taken to the hospital a few days before he was to have sailed for Rome to address the American Academy of Architects on city planning, a subject with which he was most familiar.

A group of houses in Jackson Heights accommodating seventytwo families changed hands yesterday when David S. Meister bought the twelve three-story buildings at 71-02 to 71-20 Thirty-fourth Avenue, 34-05 Seventy-first Street, 34-60 Seventy-second Street, 33-53 Seventieth Street, 70-05 Thirty-fourth Avenue, 35-23 Seventy-seventh Street and 35-29 Seventy-second Street.

Sales of two homes in White Plains were reported yesterday by Dusenbury Roberts, brokers. A six-room home on Hazelton Drive, at Helen Avenue, was bought by Elizabeth B. Bevan from the Prudential Insurance Company, and a six-room house at 98 Overlook Road was purchased by Lena Waldorf.

A jury that deliberated eleven and a half hours brought in a verdict yesterday clearing Jacob J. Lesser, New York attorney, who was once a candidate for appointment to the Federal bench, of charges that he advised a former client to engage in a bankruptcy racket.

A spectacular one-handed toss from the side by Tom Searby, with seventy seconds to play, enabled the St. Augustine's High School quintet of Brooklyn to carry off the city C. H. S. A. A. championship last night by topping Iona Prep of New Rochelle, 20 to 19, in the De Gray gymnasium, Brooklyn.
Daniel J. Sweeney, assistant headmaster of Suffield Academy and a member of its faculty for twenty-four years, died today of a heart ailment. He was 57 years old.

In a book published today by Longmans, Green Co., under the title "A Foreigner Looks at the TVA," Odette Keun, the author, says that one of the most intelligent and far-reaching social experiments of modern times is going on here in the United States.

Dr. Marie L. Bauer, who practiced medicine in this city for nearly fifty years, died today in her seventy-fifth year. Apparently in good health, she held office hours as usual this morning and was stricken during the afternoon.

Willis H. Booth, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company and honorary president of the International Chamber of Commerce, and Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, were the recipients yesterday of the Order of the North Star, First Class, at the Royal Swedish Consulate General, 630 Fifth Avenue. The order carries the rank of Knight.

Mrs. E. B. Carpenter's fleet 4year-old, Empty Bottle, continued his winning ways today at Tropical Park when he defeated four other speedy sprinters in the six furlongs of the Palm Island Handicap, a Class B event for 3-year-olds and upward.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
Detroit's champion Red Wings today dominated the National Hockey League's all-star team, picked annually for The Canadian Press by hockey writers in the six league cities.

Upholding for the second time the Constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Act, the United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals here today reversed the decision of Federal Judge Charles A. Boynton of El Paso, Texas, who had held the act unconstitutional and had permanently enjoined the Labor Relations Board from enforcing the act against the El Paso Electric Company.

River Mist, a chestnut mare owned and ridden by Miss Dolly Von Stade, Westbury, L. I., won the hunter championship at the Aiken Horse Show today. Reserve honors went to Arnold, a chestnut gelding ridden by Harry Webb, the property of D. W. Bostwick, also of Westbury.

Many dinner parties were given last night at the final dinner dance of the season in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. In Mr. and Mrs. F. N. Lawrence White's party were Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Grant, Mr. and Mrs. Burrows Freeman, Mr. and Mrs. Percy Owen, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Davis, Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Burke Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Carlos D. Kelly and Mr. and Mrs. Van Vechten Burger.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: 1st Lt. William H. Johnson, Engr.-Res., Sept. 20

Governor James V. Allred declared martial law tonight at the vicinity of the New London school disaster after ordering troops to proceed there. He instructed officers to call out available troops at Tyler and Longview and take charge of the situation. About 200 National Guardsmen were available. The Governor issued the order after he was informed that thousands of sightseers were rushing to New London.

Chicago's striking taxi men were warned today by police that their Midwest Taxi Drivers Union would be "broken up" if violence such as marked yesterday's demonstrations in Loop streets occurred again.

The rich oil lands in this East Texas region are perfectly flat-so flat that as far as the eye can see there is no rise of more than fifteen or twenty feet. The only objects dotting the smooth expanse of sparsely grassed black earth are oil derricks-thousands of them sprinkled as close together as 100 feet.

The Bureau of Customs of the Treasury Department will hold a hearing on April 12 on a demand of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association that each piece of imported lumber be marked to indicate its foreign origin, the association announced today.

Turpentine firm, 38 3/4c; sales, 15 barrels; receipts, 21 barrels; shipments, 230 barrels; stock, 21,213 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 396; receipts, 304; shipments. 434; stock, 48,419. Quote: B, $8.15; D, $8.45; E, $8.90; F, $9.32 1/2; G, 39.47 1/2; H. I. K. $9.55; M. $9.60; N, $9.65; WG. $9.80; WW. X, $11.

James O'Brien, head porter for forty-nine years at Representative Allen T. Treadway's Red Lion Inn at Stockbridge, left personal property of $50,000 and real estate of $4,000, according to a bond filed today in Berkshire Probate Court.

George Bain Wightman, retired stock broker, died on Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla., after a short illness. He was 78 years old and lived on Nassau Road, Great Neck, L. I. Mr. Wightman retired in 1933 when the Stock Exchange firm of Wightman, Williams Co., which he formed in 1930, was dissovled.

At a hearing before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe in the Munson Steamship Line reorganization proceeding Captain Sidney Morgan Henry, its general manager, testified yesterday that the company's assets for 1936 aggregated $9,169,675. This included $6,596,861 invested in subsidiary companies.

A technical argument in a New Castle zoning case before Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis developed into a discussion of spring and trout fishing today and ended with the justice making a tentative engagement to visit the property on April 3 and take along his fishing paraphernalia.

The list of the Italian liner Rex sailing today for Mediterranean ports includes Luigi Petrucci, Miss Maria Petrucci, Countess de Salverte, Count and Countess Robert Jean de Vogue, W. F. Goulding, Mr. and Mrs. P. V. G. Mitchell, Dr. and Mrs. Howard K. Gray, Mrs. Burke Roche, Mgr. James B.

Guilty pleas to second-degree murder, on which they may be sentenced to life imprisonment, were entered in General Sessions yesterday by Walter Seymour, 20 years old, of 1,524 First Avenue, a parolee from Elmira Reformatory, and Harry J. Martin, 20,

The body of an unidentified woman washed onto the shore of Maxwellton, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Maxwell in the Red Springs colony on Long Island Sound this morning. Jacob Risso, an employe of the estate, found the body and notified Glen Cove police.

One of the most important victories of the Committee for Industrial Organization in New Jersey was achieved today with the signing of a closed-shop agreement between the Suitcase, Bag and Portfolio Makers Union and the Belber Bag and Trunk Company of Woodbury.
Kid Chocolate, former world featherweight champion, knocked out Joey Woods of Jersey City in 2:26 of the first round of their scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Star Casino last night.
With Bob Feller, Willis Hudlin and Ivy Paul Andrews on the mound, the Indians handed the New Orleans Pelicans their fourth consecutive exhibition defeat today, 7 to 0.

Under the auspices of the Gilbert K. Chesterton Memorial Committee of the Catholic Writers Guild, part of the proceeds of tonight's performance of "The Eternal Road" at the Manhattan Opera House will be for the benefit of the Gilbert K. Chesterton Memorial Committee in America.

In connection with the latest "La Guardia incident" a section of the German press has settled down to the thesis that the United States Government must be induced to pass a law prohibiting "attacks on the heads of foreign States."

While weather conditions have not been of the best, pre-Easter trade has been building up to a peak, which is expected to be reached tomorrow or early next week. Locally, sales. volume this week has been maintained at about the previous 10 per cent rate of gain, although merchants commented that many customers were not rushing their apparel purchases because of the earlier date of Easter.

Albert C. Benninger, United States Marshal, died yesterday at his home, 72-26 Seventy-second Place, Glendale, Queens, after an illness of several months. Mr. Benninger was 52 years old and had been prominent in Democratic politics in Queens for the last twenty-five years.

A six-mile stretch of sodiumvapor and incandescent safety lighting, the longest of its kind in Connecticut, will be opened formally tomorrow night. It extends along the Boston Post Road from the New York State line to the Stamford town line.

European statesmen are "thinking peace" and, while unable to predict what will happen eventually, are unanimous in the belief that "no war is imminent," Anne O'Hare McCormick, journalist, told members of the League for Political Education yesterday in Town Hall.

Alarmed over the growing misapprehension of foreign corporations concerning what they believe to be their tax liabilities for funds on deposit here, the State administration plans to amend the allocation formula to assure these corporations of freedom from taxation except where their capital actually is employed in business in this State.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $70,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $1,450,000,000, the highest figure since the increase in reserve requirements that went into effect on March 1.

The warning of the Federal Alcohol Administration to distillers yesterday about advertising-copy claims was another "headache" for agencies handling liquor accounts. If all the restrictions now surrounding liquor copy are observed-and it is likely they will be-many liquor advertising campaigns may become "very innocuous," according to comment.

Dr. George Herbert Sherwood, honorary director of the American Museum of Natural History, died of a heart attack last night on the second floor of the museum after attending a dinner in the museum restaurant to Peter Freuchen, Danish explorer of the Arctic. Dr.

The Senate Committee on Appropriations voted today to report - the Naval Appropriation Bill to the Senate. The bill, which carries $522,847,808, is $3,707,620 less than the total carried in the bill as it passed the House.

Robert Hume-Gibbons, a dealer in rare books and a former actor, died on Tuesday at the York Hospital of a heart ailment. He lived at the Hotel Wellington. Born in England, Mr. Hume-Gibbons lived for a time as a child near the home of Charles Dickens, who was a friend of his father.

The unbeaten St. John's University freshman fencing team closed its campaign yesterday by subduing the New York University cubs, 5-4, at the De Gray gymnasium for its seventh victory of the season. Murray Kornfeld of the Vincentians captured. three bouts to bring his season's total to twenty in as many starts.

Initial public financing for the Air Devices Corporation of Chicago will be done today with the offering by J. A. Sisto Co. of 300,000 shares of the company's $1 par value common stock at $3.75 a share. The net proceeds, estimated at $600,000, will provide additional resources to meet present obligations and demands of the air-conditioning market.

A dinner in honor of Louis Rittenberg on the occasion of his appointment as editor of the American Hebrew was given last night at the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. Dr. Elias Lieberman, principal of Jefferson High School, was chairman, and Rabbi Isaac Landman, toastmaster.
Mrs. Ernest Fahnestock will give a luncheon on Tuesday at her home, 954 Fifth Avenue, for Mrs. Georgette Gerard-Varet Hyde, whose marriage to Harris Fahnestock will take place later this month.

At a time when the Administration is eager to obtain the adoption of the President's plan to increase the membership of the Supreme Court a series of reports are coming out of Washington which describe the Government as lacking power to deal with several immediate problems.

Usually the time of Winter when skiers store their equipment and recall pleasant experiences on rolling slopes and wooded trails, this week-end surprisingly enough presents an entirely different picture.
Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index advanced to 80.4 from 78.8 in the previous week, comparing with 78.7 for the week ended March 14, 1936.

James J. Braddock, heavyweight boxing champion, has purchased the two-story eight-room dwelling at the southeast corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, North Bergen, N. J., from Matthew Heine. The house is situated on a plot 50 by 100 feet, near the County Park and Boulevard East. A. J. H.
Sam Breadon, president of the St. Louis Cardinals, early today said that Dizzy Dean had wired him he had signed his contract and would report for Spring training today.

Urging Federal legislation to regulate the provisions of bond contracts, Louis S. Posner, a member of the New York State Mortgage Commission, says in the March issue of The Yale Law Journal that his study of legal literature concerning the position of corporate trustees under bond indentures leads him to the conclusion that the investing public is inadequately protected by present contracts, court decisions and financial practices.

Independence of the Philippines by 1938 or 1939, without waiting for the date of 1946 as set forth in the organic act, was proposed today by President Manuel Quezon. It was recognized as a possibility in a joint statement made by Mr. Quezon and Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State.

Government forces, with anti-Fascist Italians in the van, swept forward again on the Guadalajara front today and recaptured the important town of Brihuega, on the Tajuna River, fifty-two miles northeast of Madrid, from Rebel divisions that lost more than 100 prisoners and a large quantity of war material.

As a sequel to the decline in United States Government securities and the uncertainties that it has stirred up in the money market, leading dealers in bankers' acceptances yesterday advanced yield rates on bills by one-sixteenth to three-sixteenths of 1 per cent, lifting them to the highest levels since March. 1934.

Charging that Communists completely dominate relief administration in his home borough, Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens said yesterday that he would present affidavits to the Aldermanic committee investigating relief to bear out his contention.

In another strong encyclical against communism running to 13,000 words, Pope Pius today called on all States "to prevent within their territory the ravages of the antiGod campaign, which shakes society to its very foundations."

Miriam Hopkins and Clark Gable have been chosen for the roles of Scarlett O'Hara and Rhett Butler, respectively, in Selznick International's film edition of "Gone With the Wind," and Leslie Howard and Janet Gaynor have been named as Ashley Wilkes and Melanie, it was learned yesterday from a source close to the producer, David O. Selznick.

Albert Vande Weghe, Olympic back-stroke star and captain of the Princeton freshman swimming team, has been awarded a major six inch "P" for establishing a new national intercollegiate 150-yard back-stroke record this Winter, it was announced tonight by Professor Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the University Council on Athletics.

A Colonial house of ten rooms and three baths on a plot with 200 feet of frontage on Cove Road, Lucas Point. Old Greenwich, Conn., has been sold by Helen Case White to Stuart C. Whiteside. The deal was negotiated by Dusenbury Roberts, Thomas N. Cooke and Harry C. Frost, brokers.

The defense in the restaurant racket case expected to rest today, after which Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey will begin rebuttal testimony, which may take a day and a half. All the defendants except the two lawyers, Abraham Cohen, who was counsel to the Metropolitan Restaurant and Cafeteria Association,

The Rev. Lawrence Hosie, pastor of the Judson Memorial Baptist Church on Washington Square, was elected president of the Ministers Union of America, Local 1, New York City, yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting held in the Presbyterian Labor Temple, Second Avenue and Fourteenth Street.

Before going into the whys and the wherefores, dull things at best, let this enthusiastic bulletin be entered into the departmental record: "Maytime," which opened yesterday at the Capitol and cannot avoid continuing for weeks, is the most entrancing operetta the screen has given us.

Scoring one of the major surprises of the tournament thus far, the fiveman team of the Malone Elks, Lodge 1,303, Purple unit, of Malone, N. Y., early this morning turned in the best score of the ninth session of the American Bowling Congress at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

The levels reached by United States Government bonds on Wednesday were sufficiently low to induce substantial institutional buying, and a brisk rally developed in those issues yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Seven alleged "Trotskyist counter-revolutionists" were brought to trial today at Novosibirsk, Siberia, charged with criminal responsibility in the deliberate planning of a school fire in which many children were burned to death.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elisabeth Carleton Hubbard, daughter of Mrs. William Brewster Hubbard of this place and Portsmouth, N. H., to A. Ten Eyck Lansing 3d, son of Mrs. Stuart Douglas Lansing of Watertown, N. Y.

The creative thinking of young architects is dominant in projects so far scheduled for the 1939 World's Fair, according to a progress report given yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, at a luncheon in the Downtown Athletic Club.

Columbia Academy of Dubuque, Iowa, advanced to the second round of the national Catholic interscholastic basketball tournament at Loyola University today with a 34-to-29 victory over St. Mary's of Anderson, Ind., runner-up for the 1936 title.

The Rev. Dr. John Campbell, rector for the last forty years of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Mediator, Kingsbridge Avenue and 231st Street, the Bronx, died early yesterday at the rectory, 260 West 231st Street, of a heart attack. His age was 70.
Mrs. Lucy Fitch Perkins, author and illustrator of children's books, notably the "Twins Series," died suddenly of a heart attack today in her Winter home at Flint Ridge, Calif. She was 71 years old.
Garret A. Hobart, Arcola Country Club, and F. H. Gouverneur, Rochester, will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of the Belleview amateur golf championship tomorrow.

The alphabet has taken on a living form atop a sunny hill at the government's research center here. Throwing technicalities to the wind, this lettered flesh-and-blood consists of litters of puppies which scientists have evolved by crossbreeding Hungarian and domestic dogs.

Nearly a third of the children of school age of this little town and the surrounding countryside in the heart of the rich East Texas oil fields were killed yester-day when a gas explosion brought their big, modern schoolhouse crashing down upon their heads.

Operation of all maintenance departments of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, which has been disrupted twice this week by sit-down strikes by members of Local 171 of the Hospital Workers Union, returned to normal yesterday as volunteer workers and student nurses temporarily filled the positions of sixtythree dismissed union employes.

In a report filed in Supreme Court yesterday, Official Referee Jacob Marks recommended a $300,000 reduction in the assessed valuation of the land occupied by the Rialto Theatre in Times Square for 1935 and 1936. Testimony offered at a hearing which he conducted indicated that the value of the land in 1935 was $2,525,000 and in 1936, $2,400,000, he said.

Resolutions approving fair trade contracts under the Feld-Crawford resale price maintenance law and calling for the appointment of a committee to study the problems involved in a model resale contract were adopted yesterday at a meeting of publishers held under the auspices of the National Association of Book Publishers in the McGrawHill Building. Stanley M. Rinehart, Jr., president of the association, presided.

The present New York State Unemployment Insurance Law covers all "manual" workers, but only those "non-manual" workers earning $2,600 a year or less. A few weeks ago Governor LEHMAN recommended that the law be amended to cover every employe at whatever form of work he is engaged, or at whatever salary,

Senator Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that there would be no legislation for increased taxes in this session of Congress. He had in mind the recent statement by Marriner S. Eccles, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, that increased taxes should be imposed if such a step were necessary to balance the budget.

Miss Phyllis Ames, daughter of Mrs. D. Abbott Ames of Wayland and Richard Ames, has selected June 12 as the date for her marriage to Archibald Cox, son of Mrs. Archibald Cox of Plainfield, N. J. The ceremony will be performed in the First Parish Church of Wayland by the Rev. John M. Foglesong, the minister. A reception will follow at the home of the bride-elect's mother.

Creation of an "Eternal Village," where certain types of criminals and mental detectives could be sent and from which there would be no return, was proposed yesterday by Dr. E. J. Humphreys in an address at the twenty-second annual Conference of Children's Agents at the Hotel McAlpin.

"New York Advancing," the book on city affairs published by Mayor La Guardia last Summer, went through its first printing two months ago and is now in a second, it was said yesterday by Miss Rebecca B. Rankin, editor.

Most commodity futures were firm yesterday in fairly active trading in the local markets. Rubber and coffee futures advanced, while copper, tin, lead, zinc, sugar and wool top futures held firm. Silk, cocoa, hide and cottonseed oil futures were easier.

World economic activity continued to expand during February, according to the monthly review of foreign conditions in the current issue of The Annalist. Industrial operations showed further gains outside the United States. Prices continued to advance as growing arms programs promised increased demand.

A warning that unless President Roosevelt is successful in his attempt at changing court interpretations of the Constitution the people, by amendment, might "sweep the Supreme Court out of the constitutional picture" was sounded before the Senate Judiciary Committee today by Thomas Francis Konop, dean of the Law School of Notre Dame University.

The disaster in New London, Texas, yesterday, was the worst school calamity in recorded history. In a fire and panic at the Lake View School at Collinwood, Ohio, near Cleveland, on March 4, 1908, 174 children and two teachers lost their lives.

Miss Betty Schwartz, 21 years old, of 305 Milwaukee Street, Pittsburgh, Pa., died in Bellevue Hospital at 3:50 o'clock yesterday afternoon from injuries received an hour earlier when she jumped in front of a B. M. T. subway train at Fourteenth Street and First Avenue.

St. John's College at Annapolis, Md., founded as King William's School in 1696 and next to Harvard and William and Mary said to be the oldest collegiate institution in the country, has been dropped from the accredited list of colleges by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, it was revealed yesterday by Frank H. Bowles, secretary of that body's commission on higher institutions.

Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, Conn., who virtually won the woman's Bermuda tennis championship Tuesday when she defeated Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France in the semi-finals, found Mrs. Frederick McBride of Boston an easy opponent today in the title round.

Fanny Todd Mitchell Leonidoff, play wright and scenario writer, ob trained a second divorce from Leon Leonidoff, ballet master at Radio City in New York, at Yerington Nev., last night, it was learned here today. She charged menta cruelty.

MANHATTAN BURKHARDT, OSCAR IVES (April 6, 1936). Gross assets, $109,167; net, $97,603. To Sheridan M. Knight, life estate in $20,000; John C. and Julius W. Burkhardt, nephews, one-half residue each. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $69.165. David W. Kahn, attorney, 120 Broadway.
Mrs. Catherine B. Horan, prominent in Democratic politics and Catholic welfare work here for many years, died today at her home following a short illness.

Sale of The Providence NewsTribune, a Democratic newspaper, by Senator Peter G. Gerry is indicated by recent filing of incorporation papers with Secretary of State Louis W. Cappelli by Walter E. O'Hara, managing director of the Narragansett Park race track at Pawtucket, his wife and his lawyer, Raymond J. McMahon.

The United States Treasury notified yesterday depositary banks in this Federal Reserve district that it had called for repayment on Monday of $36,372,550, consisting of the entire amount on deposit to its account for book-credit subscriptions to the Treasury 2 3/4 per cent bonds, dated Sept. 15, 1936, and due on Sept. 15, 1959.

Abraham Schindel resigned today as vice president, treasurer and general manager of the Kresge deapartment store, with which he had been associated since 1929. Previously he had been vice president and general superintendent of the L. Bamberger Co. store.

A resolution asking the Federal Trade Commission to delay acceptance or promulgation of the fair trade practice rules for the toilet goods industry was adopted yesterday at a meeting of the Toilet Goods Association held at the Hotel Biltmore.

President Roosevelt used the dedication of a school for the Negro children of Warm Springs today as a forum and the low wages of the South as a text for a lecture on the need of increasing the purchasing power of the nation by regarding the problem as "a national picture."

Senator Julius S. Berg, Democrat, of the Bronx, introduced again today two bills designed to permit the State or municipalities to conduct lotteries and following the lines of similar proposals which failed in past sessions.

Miss Pauline Raymond, 18-yearold daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan S. Raymond, who plunged from her bedroom window on the fourth floor of the Raymond house at 7 East Eighty-ninth Street on March 9, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital of a fractured skull and internal injuries suffered in the fall. Miss Raymond had been ill for some time before the incident.

A message recommending legislation to make the Civilian Conservation Corps a permanent agency is planned by President Roosevelt, according to a letter received today by Representative Citron of Connecticut from Robert Fechner, director.
Foreign Affairs for April reprints the article which Mr. ELIHU ROOT wrote for its first number in September, 1922. It was called "A Requisite "for the Success of Popular Diplo"macy."
Philip Everhardt Armstrong, Seattle newspaper man and a storm center in The Seattle Post-Intelligencer strike last year, died tonight of a heart attack at the age of 47.

Miss Elizabeth Tilden Sabin of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dwight Sabin, was married to Robert G. Ingersoll Brown of New York and Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., yesterday morning at the Municipal Building by Deputy City Clerk Thomas J. Barry. A reception and wedding breakfast were held at the Blackstone after the ceremony.
Rear Admiral Richmond Pearson Hobson, Spanish-American War hero, was buried with full naval honors this afternoon at Arlington National Cemetery.

Stockholders of the American Steel Foundries yesterday approved an increase in the authorized common stock from 1,000,000 to 1,250,000 shares and to reduce the authorized preferred stock from 218,982 to 57,650 shares.
The Baltimore Orioles defeated the New York Rovers, 3 to 1, tonight in a game without a penalty, and took undisputed possession of second place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League.

The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation reported yesterday for 1936 a net income of $25,323,834 after all deductions, equal to $11.44 a share on 2,214,099 common shares, com paring with $21,701,275, or $8.71 a share on the common stock after preferred dividend requirements, in 1935.

Forty Brazilians were freed today by the security tribunal because of lack of evidence on charges growing out of the Leftist revolt in November, 1935. The tribunal also refused to imprison twenty-six Integralistas accused by Bahia police of fomenting disorders in that State.

A tentative agreement to end the strike of Remington Rand, Inc., employes which began last Spring was drawn up today in the office of Secretary Perkins, where James H. Rand Jr. had his first meeting with union leaders since their requests for such a conference before the strike began.

Charles H. Cook, president of the, American Rolling Mills Company, has been elected a director of the' Rustless Iron anal Steel Corporation. Charles J. Alfke has been elected a director and a vice president of the Hackensack Water Company.

The consolidated net profit of the National Cash Register Company and its subsidiaries last year amounted to $2,865,341 after depreciation, provision for income taxes and $4,373 provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings, it was reported yesterday.

Capturing five of the six events, the New York University women's swimming team defeated Hunter College 33 to 20, in the Bronx pool of the latter school yesterday. Miss Constance Hanf and Miss Constance Diemling led the way for the Violet, each accounting for two first places.
Mayor La Guardia of New York City leased the former Paul Grout estate at Asharoken Beach today and will move here this Summer with his wife and two children.
Price Brothers Co., Ltd., newsprint manufacturers, have been freed of bankruptcy through payment of all debts, Gordon W. Scott, trustee in bankruptcy, announced today.

Golden Miller, a four-time previous starter and winner in 1934, Ego and Royal Mail ruled favorites for the historic Grand National tomorrow as an estimated throng of 400,000 persons converged here tonight to see the racing classic.

March 16, the last day of New York Central Railroad's deferred conversion offer, saw a heavy rush to exchange convertible collateral 6 per cent bonds due in 1944 into capital stock. Face value of $7,029,100 was converted into 175,727 shares of capital stock, leaving $24,771,400 of the former and 5,871,089 shares of the latter listed as of the close of business March 16,
The patio of the Fontane was the setting tonight for a dinner and dance given by Mrs. Winston Guest in honor of her house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Hitt and Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Clarke.

Manufacturers of popular price dresses, at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the headquarters of the Dress Returns Bureau, Inc., approved a plan to "rubber stamp" all future orders, which are to be subject to the fair trade practices rules and regulations of the bureau.

Bids for $100,000,000 in Treasury bills dated March 24 were asked today by Acting Secretary of the Treasury Magill. The bills will provide additional cash for the government, which will retire about $50,000,000 of bills on March 24.

The New York Stock Exchange membership of Thomas C. Eastman has been transferred to Thomas P. Fowler. McKeesport Tin Plate Corporation $10 par common stock is to be admitted to the list today, when McKeesport Tin Plate Company capital stock, no par value, will be suspended from dealings.
The Cole Brothers and Clyde Beatty brought their circus to the Hippodrome yesterday for a first performance that thrilled young children and the grown-ups they had brought with them.

Holders of common stock of the Interlake Iron Corporation of record of March 25 will receive rights to purchase new 4 per cent convertible debentures of the company at the rate of $500 of debentures for each 100 common shares held, the company announced yesterday. The rights will ??ire on April 15.

The marriage of Mrs. Gertrude Schuyler Vander Poel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Oakley Vander Poel of 117 East Seventy-second Street, to Lloyd Hilton Smith, son of Mrs. Roland H. Smith of Merion, Pa., and the late Mr. Smith, took place yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Charles Shannon, lithographer and painter, died today after a long illness at the age of 73. He won a place apart among his contemporaries because his work, although scrupulously pictorial in form, was inspired by literature rather than life.

SPANISH PRELUDE, by Jenny Ballou.. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50.) A novel of Spain before the present war. LEON BLUM: FROM POET TO PREMIER, by Richard. L. Stokes. (Coward-McCann, $3.) Said to be the first biography of Blum ever written.
James B. Overton, Professor of Plant Physiology at the University of Wisconsin, died at his home early today of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

The New York Americans bade adieu to local fans last night by administering a sound trouncing to the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. In their final home game of the National Hockey League season the spangled skaters entertained a crowd of 5,000 with a 9-to-4 victory.

Three bills, which originated with the Citizens Union and propose to make the magistrates' courts, Special Sessions and the Domestic Relations Courts in New York City starting points for career men, were introduced today by Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Orange.

Unanimously elected to succeed Dr. Meta Glass, Dean Margaret Morriss of Pembroke College at Brown University took her place here today as president of the American Association of University Women. She held no office during the administration just concluded, but was a member of the committee on membership and standards.

The demands of railroad labor for increased pay were discussed informally at the monthly meeting here yesterday of the Eastern Railroad Presidents' Conference. The demands were filed by the railway unions on most of the individual lines on March 4.

Leo R. Sack, retiring United States Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the Republic of Costa Rica, has been appointed vice president in charge of public relations of the Schenley Products Company and its affiliated companies, it was announced yesterday.

Patrick Byrnes, business agent of Local 27 of the Bricklayers, Masons and Plasterers Union of Tarrytown, died tonight in a cell at North Castle Township's police headquarters here, a few hours after he had been arrested on a charge of drunken driving.

Frank Thomas Eldridge, a foreman at the office of the Appraiser of Customs, United States Custom Service, 201 Varick Street, died of a heart attack on Wednesday night at his home, 75-18 Ninety-fifth Avenue, Ozone Park, Queens.
Dr. Charles C. Duryee, one of the founders of the New York State Conference of Mayors and twice Mayor of this city, died tonight. He was 78 years old.

Harassed to a point where its whole population is pretty tired of the word "sit-down," this city moved decisively today to break the grip of the series of strikes which up until now seemed likely to continue indefinitely.

A birdie deuce on the fifth extra hole enabled the defending titleholders, Gene Sarazen of Brook??eld Center, Conn., and Mal Reynolds of Jacksonville, to win their first-round match in the third annual national amateur-pro best-ball match play championship at the St. Augusine links today.

John Cox, member representing Devonshire Parish, gave notice in the House of Assembly today that next Tuesday he would move for a message to be sent to Lieut. Gen. Sir Reginald Hildyard, Governor, saying the House "views with concern the delay in the inauguration of air service between Bermuda and, New York."

Approval of the State Mortgage Banking Bill, introduced by Senator Lazarus Joseph and Assemblyman Carl Pack, has been voted by the New York Building Congress, Thomas S. Holden, president, announced yesterday. The proposed legislation would permit the incorporation of privately owned mortgage banks, which would be placed under the supervision of the State Banking Department.

Because of a wise Federal Mediation Law, railway executives and employes have just adjusted their pension differences and made mutual agreements under that law, among them a labor promise not to strike until mediatory processes have been exhausted.

Slithering around the throng-packed course in his silver and blue Mickey Mouse, C. Mulford Scull of Ventnor City, N. J., captured all three heats of the Class A outboard event as many of America's leading enthusiasts competed in the opening program of the twenty-fourth annual Biscayne Bay regatta today.

An agreement between Judge magazine and the Cartoonists Guild of America is expected to be signed at 10:30 A. M. today in the offices of Monte Bourjaily, publisher, at 16 East Forty-eighth Street, according to a statement last night by Ned Hilton, president of the Guild.

April has picked up another show, the Jean Ferguson Black comedy called "Penny Wise" which Juliana Morgan recently acquired. Kenneth MacKenna will play the male lead, perhaps with June Walker in the leading feminine role, and the whole matter will be under the direction of Arthur Sircom, who staged the first production of the play at Locust Valley in the Summer of 1935.

Amelia Earhart brought her huge "flying laboratory" roaring into Honolulu with a transpacific speed mark today and retired to a Waikiki Beach residence to await better flying weather for the next leg of her flight around the world, a 1,532-mile adventure to tiny Howland Island.

The stock markets here continued quiet but firm today. Gilt-edge issues made a good recovery. In the foreign section, German and French loans weakened. Transatlantic issues were dull and United States Steel and nickels were off.

The Harvard Club topped the Yale Club, 8-6, in their annual invitation squash tennis match at the Yale Club courts yesterday. In the No. 1 singles encounter F. B. Ryan Jr. of the losers vanquished W. K. Wright. 5-10, 10-6, 10-4.

Holders of 747,739 shares, or more than 98 per cent, of the second preferred stock of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company have deposited their stock for exchange into the new $5 convertible preferred stock and common stock under the terms of the plan for the rearrangement of capitalization, the company announced yesterday.

Harold Jacobi, chairman of the Greater New York Campaign of the United Palestine Appeal which is seeking to raise $1,700,000 for settlement in Palestine of Jews of Poland, Germany and other lands, announced yesterday the formation of a trades council of business leaders.

The Harris Trust and Savings Bank obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,080,000 of refunding bonds of Madison County, Iowa, on a bid of 100.629 for 2 1/2s. The bonds will mature serially from 1938 to 1946.

A somewhat unbalanced young woman's unrequited love for Premier Benito Mussolini is now thought by police to have caused yesterday's drama in the Gare du Nord when the ex-actress-writer Magda de Fontanges shot and wounded Count Charles de Chambrun, former French Ambassador to Rome.

Four of the world's largest ocean liners, the Normandie, the Europa, the Rex and the Berengaria, stood almost side by side for a short while yesterday at piers on the North River between Forty-sixth and Fiftieth Streets.

Congratulations are certainly in order to AMELIA EARHART, ranking woman flier of the United States, if not of the world, on completion of the first and longest over-water leg of her globecircling journey-that from Oakland to Honolulu-in 15 hours 40 minutes.

Carroll B. Merriman of Topeka, Kan., banker and a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corpora- the tion, said last night at a gathering of insurance executives and salesmen of New York and Northern New Jersey that "no business on earth so important to mankind or so large in totals" had come through the depression "with such clean hands" as had life insurance companies.
The Arab attacks on Jews in Palestine continue to increase. Early this morning a bomb exploded in the hands of an Arab near the Jewish quarter in Kerem, seriously injuring him and three Arab workmen.
Edwin Cubby of Little Falls, N. J., and MacArthur Manchester of Granville today were elected varsity managers of wrestling and swimming, respectively, at Syracuse University.

Scrolls honoring twenty men for their "leadership in making a better world for better business women" were presented last night at a dinner of the New York League of Business and Professional Women at the Biltmore. Mrs. William Brown Meloney, editor of the Sunday magazine of The Herald Tribune, read the citations which accompanied each award.

Holders of more than the requisite two-thirds of the stock of Paramount Pictures, Inc., have assented to the issuance of $15,000,000 of new 3 1/4 per cent convertible bonds in exchange for an equal amount of 6 per cent debentures. About $12,500,000 of the debentures was deposited under the exchange plan up to the close of business on March 9, when the offer ended.

The names of 533 couples who are expected to attend the annual promenade of the junior class of Princeton University tomorrow evening were announced today by William K. Coors of Golden, Col., chairman of the class of '38 promenade committee. Five hundred "stags" are expected to attend.

Blonde Miss Barbara Bourne, unheralded entry from New York. will match her accurate short game against red-haired Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis tomorrow in the eighteen-hole final of the women's inaugural Aiken golf tournament.

Settlements through banks in the United States in the week ended on Wednesday, last, advanced to the highest level in twelve weeks, or since Dec. 23, 1936, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., covering the twenty-two leading cities.
The Massachusetts House of Representatives late today passed and sent to the Senate by a 120-to-112 vote a measure to repeal the Teachers' Oath Law.

Gordon Dean was today appointed by Attorney General Cummings to become special executive assistant to the Attorney General, effective April 1, to succeed Henry Suydam, who will join the editorial staff of The Newark Evening News.

W. C. Shaw, 61-year-old superintendent of the Consolidated School at New London, whose son, Sam, 17, was in the building when explosion and fire leveled it, said tonight he was standing about fifty feet away from the structure at the time.
Charles H. Miller, 55 years old, a former Circuit Court judge of Benton, Ill., plunged to his death tonight from the twenty-second floor of an apartment building in which he lived with his family.

Lehigh New England The Lehigh New England Railroad Company, controlled by the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, reported yesterday for 1936 a net income of $397,860 after taxes and charges, equal to $2.92 a share on the 136,000 shares of $50 par value capital stock.

New York gardens of the past and the future, depicting an experimental garden in the days when the Dutch East India Company ventured upon the futile project of growing tropical spices here and skyscraper apartments made beautiful with growing plants, were a center of interest yesterday at the Flower Show.

Speaking before the sales brokers committee of the Real Estate Board of New York City yesterday at the Town Hall, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the board, declared that real estate commission-cutting was an "evil of the depression" which would cure itself because "business is becoming more normal." John H. Potter of Potter,

The state of perplexity regarding the markets went unrelieved yesterday. The fact that two members of the Cabinet issued statements on the general subject of rapid price rises, following that of the Reserve Board's chairman made earlier in the week, served to heighten the nervousness felt in trading circles.

Following is the official Vatican abstract of Pope Pius's encyclical on atheistic communism, including the salient points textually: The encyclical, divided into chapters and numbered paragraphs, begins by pointing out the serious danger to which all nations are exposed by the inroads of communism.
Young persons numbering 4,012 obtained new jobs in private industry during February, Dr. Mary H. S. Hayes, Director of Guidance and Placement of the National Youth Administration, said today.

Three California seamen who were among those on strike here recently at the Dollar Line pier, were sentenced to terms of fifteen to sixteen years in State's Prison today by Judge Robert V. Kinkead in Common Pleas Court as a result of their conviction last Tuesday on charges of assault and robbery.

Clarence Addison Dykstra, City Manager of Cincinnati, was appointed president of the University of Wisconsin today at the end of a clash on the board of regents reminiscent of the fight which accompanied the dismissal of Dr. Glenn Frank two months ago.

Gari Shelton, pianist, will give a recital this afternoon at the Town Hall. The Neighborhood Music School will give its monthly concert at 5 P. M. today. Clarence Adler, pianist, and Michel Piastro, violinist, will present a sonata recital tonight at the Washington Irving High School.
The Senate was in recess but its Judiciary Committee questioned Dean Leon Green of Northwestern University and Dean Thomas F. Konop of Notre Dame on the judiciary reorganization program.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 16: REAR ADMIRAL Land, E. S., Chief Constructor of the Navy and Chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C., to home and relieved from all active duty, March 15.

An investing syndicate headed by Samuel Fagenson bought the two five-story apartment houses at 3,154-56 Grand Concourse, occupying the block front from 205th to 206th Streets, the Bronx. The buildings have a frontage of 193 feet and contain seventy-four apartments. They were sold through Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc.

Coincident with the announcement by Sidney Hillman yesterday that the C. I. O. would launch its unionization drive in the textile field today, gray cloth mills and commission houses took steps to protect themselves against shutdowns by eliminating the "damage" provision in the standard cottontextile sales note.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 17: MAJOR GENERAL Brigham, C. E., Chief of the Chemical Warfare Service, seven days' leave, March 29. COLONELS Mitchell, H. D., Adjutant General's Department, three days' extension of leave. Lawson, L. L., F. A., Hawaii, to 13th F. A. Brigade. Fort Bragg. N. C.

Employes of nine Pittsburgh restaurants of the Thompson national system, seven in the downtown district, Walked out near midnight in what leaders said was a strike for wage increases and improved working conditions.

A major problem of present-day industry is "to get mass production and mass consumption to match," dealers attending the National OilBurner and Air Conditioning Exposition were told today by Dr. Herbert W. Hess, Professor of Marketing at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania.
The Giants continued to sweep through Florida like a young hurricane today as they lambasted the Cardinals, 12-4, for their third straight triumph since crossing the Gulf from Havana.

Wool goods prices strengthened this week, following the heavy buying recently, and some manufacturers withdrew their lines, having sold about all of the goods their current wool holdings will allow, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Wallace G. Garland, former honor student at Yale University, who became known as "The Wizard" because he developed patents on an "electric eye" system for traffic guidance, winning the approval and support of Professor Irving Fisher, economist; Arnold C. Mason, also a Yale graduate; eleven other persons and three corporations, were found guilty last night in Federal court on forty-three counts of mail fraud and conspiracy.
Only one of the Supreme Court justices has said anything that might bear on the great controversy,

Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, told the House of Commons today that it would be "a matter of very great regret to all of us if any one of the naval powers started building guns bigger than fourteen inches or battleships bigger than 35.000 tons."

The Connecticut House of Representatives, for the third time since 1925. killed the Child Labor Amendment today. By a vote of 174 to 83, the lower branch accepted an adverse minority committee report on two bills proposing ratification.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission today charged that W. E. Hutton Co. "unlawfully" paid a "bonus" to a customers' man for alleged manipulation of Atlas Tack Corporation stock in 1935.

The drive of the Committee for Industrial Organization to unionize 1,250,000 textile workers will be officially started today, Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and chairman of the Textile Workers Organization Committee, announced yesterday.

By an overwhelming vote of 374 to 12 the House passed today the McReynolds discretionary neutrality resolution, sending it to the Senate as a substitute for the Pittman mandatory legislation already adopted by that body.

Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener. Inc., was the broker in the recent sale of the five-story tenement at 1,659 York Av. Daniel W. Lave has removed his real estate offices to 724 5th Av. Kidder Fitzpatrick have placed for the Ludin Realty Co. a first mortgage $20,000 on the six-story store and lost building at 213 W. 40th St., which occupies a plot 25 by 98.8 feet.

Albert W. Kraft of North Haven was elected today president of the United Illuminating Company by the directors. He succeeded James English of this city, one of the founders of the company and its president since 1900. Mr. Kraft joined the company in 1900 as an office boy.

President Roosevelt tonight called the Red Cross, of which he is honorary head, and all government agencies to help in the disastrous explosion in New London, Texas. At the same time, the President issued a statement which read:

Mrs. John Frederick Stanyer of this city and Sea Girt, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Hilary Vincent Stanyer, to William Georgi Rodgers, son of Mrs. Georgi Rodgers of Elizabeth, N. J., and Earle Vincent Rodgers of Cranford, N. J.

New England cotton manufacturers tonight announced 10 per cent wage increases for more than a third of the section's 90,000 cotton textile workers. The announcement of the manufacturers, made independently in New England's many mill centers, came on the eve of the scheduled drive by John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization to unionize the textile industry.

Miss Polly Luke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Luke of Braemar, this place, was married here tonight at the home of her parents to John Calvin Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Calvin Graham of 1,070 Park Avenue, New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. C. Kenneth Ackerman, rector of Christ Church.

Van S. Merle-Smith, former president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound and owner of the international twelvemeter sloop Seven Seas, will be the representative of the New York Yacht Club on board T. O. M. Sopwith's challenger during the America's Cup match off Newport starting on July 31.

With President Roosevelt leading in offering homage to the memory of a predecessor, the 100th anniversary of the birth of Grover Cleveland was observed yesterday with commendation of Cleveland's courage.and his principles as beacons for guidance in present difficulties and examples for all Presidents to follow.

Eighteen men convicted of taking part in the "Bloody Sunday" rioting at Altona July 17. 1932, were sentenced tonight to prison terms ranging from two and one-half to ten years. Their trial lasted eight days.

Spokesmen for the State Housing Board here today took exception to a construction placed upon the annual report of the board that it advocated favorable action on a $100,000,000 bond issue for housing purposes in preference to ratification of Governor Lehman's proposed $60,000,

Charging infringement of the front cover of Life magazine, Time, Inc., its publishers, obtained a temporary restraining order yesterday in Federal court against the Hollywood Restaurant, the A. and U. Restaurant Corporation and two individuals. A suit for a permanent injunction is pending.
Clara Taplin of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, has been elected president of the Smith College Student Government Association.

Deals involving housing properties covered a wide area in Manhattan yesterday. The activity included several sales in Harlem. The five-story tenement house at 356 West Forty-first Street, held in one family for more than thirty years. was sold by Josephine Kenny to the 558 Ninth Avenue Corporation.

The annual fund campaign Of the Catholic Charities, with this year's objective set at $1,372,000, was be gun yesterday with a warning by, the general Chairman, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, that unless big business voluntarily increases its private contributions to charity, eventually it wilt pay double the amount in taxes.
An unidentified passenger on a train bound for Saskatoon today tackled two desperadoes who had overcome their police escort, knocked one out and prevented their escape.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The dissenting opinions of Justices Roberts and Brandeis in the Brush income tax case open up several interesting questions. First, whether income for similar services can properly be taxed against a government employee with the same weight and effect as against a private employe.

Josephine Johnson, who received the Pulitzer Prize in fiction for her novel "Now in November," will have a new novel, called "Jordanstown," published by Simon Schuster on March 30. Two weeks before publication 8,000 copies have been sold.
Eastern Group of the National Association of Securities Commissioners open forum on "Problems in Securities Regulation," Hotel Pennsylvania, 10 A. M.

A bill of complaint was filed in the district court of the District of Columbia today by the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking to enjoin Automatic Guns, Inc., of Washington, D. C., and William Ray Baldwin of Elk Hills.

Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Chief City Magistrate, added an amendment yesterday to the new Traffic Code, under which defendants in certain traffic cases may plead guilty and pay fines either personally or through a representative.

Lionel Fink, former production manager for the Milton Alexander Company, and Wilfred Doner, former account man there, have formed the agency of Fink Doner here. They will release a national campaign for the Hygenos Laboratories of Detroit late this Spring.
Indianapolis was left without any newspapers tonight for at least twenty-four hours when 300 members of the International Typographical Union went on strike for higher wages.

The annual dance of the Horace Mann Alumni Association, including graduates and members of the senior classes of the boys' school in Riverdale and the girls' school on 120th Street, will be held tonight at the Plaza.

Henry Armstrong, the heavy-hitting featherweight from Los Angeles, will face a severe test tonight when he opposes Aldo Spoldi, holder of the lightweight championship of Italy, in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden.

The American Red Cross mobilized swiftly tonight to take charge of relief operations at the scene of the New London, Texas, school disaster. Albert Evans, Mid-west disaster relief director, left here with two aides to assume command of operations at the scene.

The sixteen-room and six-bath duplex cooperative apartment at 1 Beekman Place has been leased from Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, by George U. Vetleson, through Douglas Gibbons Co. and Douglas. L. Elliman Co., brokers.

The City-Wide Tenants Council, speaking in behalf of "upward of 10,000 families" living in the city's slums, has petitioned Governor Lehman to veto the Crawford-Moffat Sprinkler Bill permitting the substitution of sprinkler systems for fire-retarding in the hallways of old-law tenements.

Weedon's Island, a 420acre tract bordered by Tampa Bay, has been purchased by J. O. Paine of Newark, N. J. Mr. Paine said that the island would be turned into a huge botanical garden, with docks on the waterfront and a series of canals. The property is within the northern limits of St. Petersburg.

A furother advance in wholesale prices in the week ended on March 13 was announced today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average, rose to 87.2. In the previous week it was 86.1 and on March 14, 1936, it was 79.2.

A furother advance in wholesale prices in the week ended on March 13 was announced today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average, rose to 87.2. In the previous week it was 86.1 and on March 14, 1936, it was 79.2.

Trial Results Fireman 1st grade Francis X. Loughran, Engine 245. Charge 1: Assaulting a police officer. Guilty. Fined three days' pay. Charge 2: Committed an act for which he was arrested. Charge dismissed. Charge 3: Conduct tending to bring discredit on Fire Department. Charge dismissed. Charge 4: Suffering from effects of alcohol, drug or compound. Guilty. Fined two days' pay.

The latest in the series of Anglo-Italian pinpricks that are preventing the restoration of the friendliness implied in the Anglo-Italian agreement of January was supplied today by the Rev. Dr. Edward Gordon Selwyn, Dean of Winchester.
A bill was introduced today by Representative Emanuel Celler of New York, to repeal the provision in a law of 1886 requiring dealers in oleomargarine to take out Federal licenses.

MANHATTAN BUHLER, SUSANNA (March 14). Estate, more than $10,000. To Lina S. Krauer, niece, Kempten Witzikon, Canton Zurich, Switzerland, $3,000; Jacob Vontobel, nephew, Belinhof Wald, Canton Zurich, Switzerland, $2,000; Anna Fehr, sister, Wackerlin-Stiftung, Uetikon, Switzerland, $1.500 and one-half residue: Babette P.

Edward Rogers successfully defended his national amateur pocket billiard title by defeating the challenger, Louis Brooks, 113-65, in thirteen innings in their final block at the Strand Academy last night. Rogers won the match by 375-199.

The early morning hours. today found this town of 8,000 inhabitants, nine miles from the scene of yesterday's school explosion tragedy at New London, still wide awake, but it was a stunned, tearful awakeness.

The elusive ghost of the original "Columbus" who discovered America for the Indians and was the very first man to set foot on this vast continent stirred up a lively discussion here today among the scientists participating in the international symposium on early man held this week under the auspices of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia in celebration of the 125th anniversary of its founding.
PATROLMEN-Anselm J. Cramer, from 6th Precinct to 14th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur. David X. Oakley, 14th Division, assignment changed from chauffeur to duty in plain clothes.

Ellis A. Gimbel Jr., executive head of Gimbel Brothers' New York store, announced yesterday that Alexander Fish has been named buyer of the housewares, majorappliance and toy departments in the basement store. Max Sass, formerly in charge, has resigned.

Lumber shippers have been notiflied by carrier members of the Intercoastal Steamship Freight Assoelation that rates on lumber will be increased in April from $13 to $14 a thousand feet, it was revealed Yesterday.

Until barber shops concerned are served copies of the arbitration award approved Wednesday by Supreme Court Justice Cotillo, Local No. 1 of the Journeymen Barbers International Union of America will not press for the new- prices fixed in the award, it was said yesterday.

Stratford Av. (14-3744), e s, 516 ft s of Westchester Av., 100x100; Bessie Handler to Philrem Realty Corp., 152 W. 42d St., mtge. $93,000. Belmont Av. (11-3081), w s, 145 ft n of 180th St., 50x81; Charles Prati to Chapra Realty Corp., 2,115 Belmont Av:

Miss Marjorie Van Schaick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Van Schaick of Southport, has completed plans for her wedding. She will be married to the Rev. Sewall Emerson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Kendall Emerson of New York, on April 8 in Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport.

Premier Benito Mussolini made a new bid tonight for the loyalty and affection of Italy's Mohammedan subjects, promising them that the Fascist regime soon would adopt laws "to prove to you how greatly it is interested in improving your destiny."

The Delaware House of Represenatives rejected unanimously today the bill of Representative W. R. Ringler that would have levied a $50 annual tax on bachelors over 30, the proceeds to support the Florence Crittenton Home in Wilmington, a home for unmarried mothers.

No material reduction in the prices of bonded whisky can be expected for some time, the Distilled Spirits Institute said today through its chairman, Owsley Brown of Louisville. Mr. Brown's statement to the press, made in response to published reports of an imminent price slash, follows:

New construction projected yesterday in Manhattan included plans for a school in Harlem to cost $753,000, a trucking and storage building in Renwick Street and a garage on Tenth Avenue. Architects also submitted plans fer numerous alterations. Filing also was heavy in Brooklyn and Queens.

That the decline in government securities recently and the firmer tone in the money market were not due to any immediate tightening of the supply of money in the hands of the banks was plainly shown in this week's Federal Reserve statistics.

Dr. George Edward Maurer, veteran of two wars and physician to the late Will Rogers as well as to many New York families of prominence, died of pneumonia on Wednesday night at the Wickersham Hospital after an illness of about twelve days. He was 70 years old.

Marse Joe McCarthy, wearing a light gray suit and a wide smile, was taking his ease in his inn. He looked like a contented man and there was reason for it. He was the manager of the world champions, the great Yankee ball club that was bulging over with talent.
The news that Tommy Bridges, dependable right-hander, may be in a hospital when the season starts revived rumors today that the Tigers were angling for Wes Ferrell, pitching star of the Red Sox.

During the week ended March 17 member-bank reserve balances increased $81,000,000. Additions to memberbank reserves arose from an increase of $31,000,000 in gold stock and a decrease of $99,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal

Rising temperatures and a lull in a forty-eight-hour storm today cheered up-State New Yorkers digging out from under the heaviest snowfall of the year. At least eight deaths were attributed to the storm.

7th Av., South, 101 (70 Grove St.) 16.4x93.3; M. Hallanan Realty Corp. to Rismore Holding Corp., 271 Madison Av., care of J. Helman; mortgage, $30,000 ($15). 10th Av. n w cor 19th St., 46x100; Carl G. A. Schumann to George C. and F. Franklyn Stratford, Glen Ridge, N. J., right, title and interest ($6).

After a day of virtual siege warfare between sixty sit-down strikers and about thirty non-striking employes in the F. W. Woolworth 5 and 10 cent store at 32 West Fourteenth Street, the police cleared the store early last evening and arrested fifty-six strikers and three union officials who refused to leave.
