A further reaction occurred in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday in sympathy with the weakness in the stock market. The statement by Secretary Wallace that the recent rise in prices would probably increase cotton acreage more than had been originally intended also was a factor.
The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended March 17 were announced today: Baker, Lt. Cmdr. L. H., the Samuel D. Ingraham, to the Itasca, as executive officer.

A former Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company employee in Gadsden, Ala., told the La Follette subcommittee investigating labor espionage today that an employee in the personnel department formed a mob comprising Goodyear employes and others

At the Hotel Astor this afternoon Equity members will. select six members of a nominating committee who, with three others named by the Equity Council, will later choose the regular ticket of officers and councilors to be submitted at the annual meeting of the association in the late Spring.

The final performance of the special Wagner matinee cycle was given yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera House. The opera was "The Flying Dutchman." Kirsten Flagstad, rapturously applauded and also cheered, was the Senta;

The engagement of $1,755,000 of gold abroad for shipment here, $560,000 in England and $1,195,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Reserve Bank announced the arrival yesterday of $140,700 of gold from England.

Arrangements have been made for sale of a New York Curb Exchange membership at $32,500, unchanged from the last sale. The Curb has admitted to listing New York City Omnibus Corporation ten-year warrants to buy capital stock at $17.50 a share on or before March 1, 1947.

Westchester Av. (14-3740), s e cor of Elder Av., 100x100; Westeld Realty Corp. to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 1 Madison Av.; extends mtg. to Aug. 1, 1942, at 5 per cent; $75,000. Wallace Av., 2-572-2,574 (16-4439); Marglan Realty Corp. to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 1 Madison Av.; extends mtg. to Aug. 1, 1941, at 5 per cent? $112,450.

The first extension to the original street plan of old San Juan proper in more than 200 years is now under way. It will add 200 feet to the south end of Cruz Street and permit the diversion of motor traffic from the congested retail and office section.
The "Prophecy of Spring" fashion show and tea attracted many yesterday to the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

5th Av.. 73, n e cor 15th St.. 11-story building; Seamen's Bank for Savings against Kasa Realty Co.; due, $268.699; to plaintiff for $100,000 46th St., 155 E., 4-story dwelling; trustees of St. Patrick's Cathedral against Cashel Development Corp.; due, $54,087; to plaintiff for $10,000.

With the opening of the season's major events set for tomorrow night on two fronts, the officials of the Indoor Polo Association yesterday announced plans for the remainder of the championship play which is to carry through to the campaign's close with the EastWest matches of April 7 and 10.

Miss Louise St. Leger Vance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William McClellan Vance of this city, formerely of Princeton, N. J., was martried to Laurence Stallings of New York, writer and newsreel editor, last evening at the home of her parents, 410 East Fifty-seventh Street. The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony.

The Health Department announced yesterday it had a sufficient supply of Type l pneumonia serum to take care of all demands. Dr. William Best, Deputy Health Commissioner, said the threatened shortage was ended when the Health Department obtained a shipment from a commercial drug company. Another shipment is expected today.

Obeying the order for a strike, issued last night by their local syndicates as a "protest against Fascist provocation" in the Clichy riots and half-heartedly approved by the General Labor Confederation in Paris, workers stayed at home this morning or gathered in small groups at their plants to discuss the situation.
Superintendent W. C. Shaw theorized tonight that, although he had detected none in the building, an accumulation of gas caused the school disaster which killed hundreds of children.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended March 18 were announced today: Breckenridge, Major Gen. J. C., Department of Pacific, San Francisco, Calif., to duty as commanding general, Marine Barracks, Quantico. Va., June 30.

Crushing power carried the Denver Safeways to a decisive triumph over Long Island University in the first quarter-final game of the National A. A. U. basketball tournament tonight. The score was 49 to 26. Approximately 6,000 spectators jammed City Auditorium.

"I have never seen anything like it since I came out of the trenches in France," said the Rev. C. W. Holmes, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Overton, which he turned into an emergency hospital to treat the injured children from the New London school explosion.

The centenary of Mount Holyoke College, South Hadley, Mass., which occurs in May, was celebrated at a luncheon in London today. About 200 alumnae and friends of the college and supporters of the cause of education throughout the world gathered to honor its founder, Mary Lyon, and its retiring president, Dr. Mary Emma Woolley.
Stocks reactionary, closing with widest declines since October; turnover, 2,276,920 shares. United States Government bonds rallied and closed higher, other issues lower; transactions, $19,513,700.

7 :37 1/2 P. M.-Amelia Earhart and three men companions took off for Honolulu at Oakland, Calif., Airport. 8:40 P. M.-Overtook Pan American Clipper, which had left Alameda, Calif., at 4:19 P. M., on 7,000-mile pioneering trip to New Zealand.

Members of the Miami Beach colony were hosts this afternoon to groups of friends aboard their yachts to watch the outboard motor boat races marking the opening of the twenty-fourth annual Biscayne Bay regatta, which will continue tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Eldon Bisbee in his letter to THE TIMES holds out no hope that any of the suggested changes in the present system can "save us from future business depressions, which, regardless of complex contributing causes, result from acquisitiveness stimulated by the strife implicit in the capitalistic order * * * those inherent weaknesses must continue to produce their inevitable consequences."

In sympathy with the weakness in the outside markets here and a decline in Liverpool and Alexandria, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back another $1 a bale yesterday to end with losses of 19 to 23 points.

About 400 employes of Beth Israel Hospital, Stuyvesant Park East, Brooklyn, have received pay increases under an agreement signed yesterday by David Podell, president of the Beth Israel Hospital Association, with the Association of Hospital and Medical Professionals, Local 20094. The following increases were allowed:
The Continental Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, acquired yesterday at auction on a bid of $50,000 the twelve-story Hotel Monterey, at the northeast corner of Broadway and Ninety-fourth Street.

Mayor La Guardia's Committee on City Planning issued a pamphlet yesterday containing a collection of modern nursery rhymes intended to inform children about the planning of a large city. Mrs. Anna Shepard compiled the booklet for the use of children in the lower grades of public schools.

Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, replied yesterday to the criticism by Borough President Lyons of the Bronx because the Tenement House Department had ordered four families out of an apartment house at 72 South Eighth Street. Brooklyn.

Gathering in annual and special meeting in Baltimore on March 30, shareholders of the Commercial Credit Company will be asked to amend the certificate of incorporation to increase the authorized preferred stock to $50,000,000 par value, including the $12,230,200 of 41/4 per cent cumulative convertible preferred outstanding on Feb. 25, which would be considered one series of the new authorization.

Department store trade in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 7.8 per cent for the thirteen shopping days from March 1 to 15 over the comparative 1936 period, according to figures issued -yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. New York and Brooklyn stores alone had a gain of 8.5 per cent in sales, while Northern New Jersey establishments reported an increase of 4.3 -per cent.

Paul W. Reifsnider, at 115 Battle Av., from Shipmates, Inc.; Caroline J. Clark, at 30 Mamaroneck Road, from Board of Education of White Plains; Laurence D. McGonigal, at 72 Waller Av., from Miss Agnes Blakely; Dusenbury Roberts, brokers.

Until today most people here accepted as a matter of course that President Eamon de Valera would have a sweeping victory in the general election in June and that former President William Cosgrave's party would only return to the Dail Eireann a remnant of its former self.

The following information was obtained from a usually unreliable source and cannot be guaranteed. Under the rules of the SEC (Securities and Exchange Commission, also known as the BWS, or Bugaboo of Wall Street) no stock in this story is offered for sale.

A hard-hitting Princeton indoor polo team concluded its home season tonight with an 11-9 1/2 triumph over the strong Lawrenceville School trio. Tonight's victory gave the Nassau unit a 2-1 edge in its Winter series with the school boys.

A conflict between the anti-price fixing provisions of the Federal Trade Commission Act and the fair trade laws of New York and other States which permit selling-price agreements under some conditions was cited today by the Seagram-Distillers Corporation and Seagram-Distillers Corporation of Massachusetts in answer to a complaint of the Federal Trade Commission.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $29,310,425, to be represented by one State and fifty-five municipalities, compared with the revised total of $43,787,475 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $42,695,915.

Retail businesses seeking store space furnished many of the principals concerned in the commercial leases reported by brokers yesterday. The Liggett Drug Company took the store and basement in the new building being constructed on the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street by the Aymar Johnson estate, which has owned the land for more than 105 years.
The Duke of Windsor and "the woman I love," Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, found virtually the last obstacle removed today from the path toward their wedding in the coming Spring.

A memorial service for Eleutherios Venizelos, who was seven times Premier of Greece, will be held tomorrow at 12:30 P. M., at St. Eleutherios Church, 315 West Twenty-fourth Street, in commemoration of the first anniversary of his death.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Salesmen in slaughter houses found fresh pork business good. Demand in wholesale markets, however, was only fair. Trading in steer hinds and ribs was fair to slow.

Sister Camilla Broden, Mother Superior of St. Vincent's Infant Asylum for the last seven years, died today in St. Mary's Hospital, Milwaukee. Her age was 68. Before she became Mother Superior at St. Vincent's, Sister Camilla had a similar position at St. Joseph's Hospital in Chicago for twenty years.
Atlantic Assets, Inc., sold to an investing client of David W. Frankel the six-story apartment house on a plot 131 by 100 feet at 1,040 Carroll Street, corner of Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

The "White List" of the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee is made public today. There are ninety-five titles included, the largest classifications being juveniles and religious books. This survey of approved books is issued every three months.

J. Harry Reth died at his home here yesterday at the age of 57. A native of Baltimore and a graduate of the Baltimore City College, he was associated with the George A. Fuller Company and later with the Thompson Starrett Company of New York.
Cram's Reports, Inc., today estimated the current week's automobile production at 99,013 cars and trucks, compared with 101,684 last week and 102,233 during the comparable week a year ago.

At most points there is little to choose between the two resolutions which the House and the Senate have now adopted as the new basis of American foreign policy. Both resolutions are aimed at achieving a "neutrality" which is more legalistic than real. Both rely on a " cash-and-carry" plan which would fortuitously favor maritime Powers and Powers heavily armed, at the expense of other Powers.

The property of Sarah C. Swenke, consisting of an old Colonial house, outbuildings and forty-seven acres on Riverbank Road, Stamford, Conn., was bought by Erard A. Matthiessen, New York architect, who intends to remodel the house for his own occupancy. The sale was arranged by Kenneth Ives Co.

Seventh Annual City-Wide Conference of Junior High Schools of New York City, Hotel Astor, 9:30 A. M. Luncheon 1 P. M. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Painting in Germany, England and France," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "Chinese Landscapes," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 2 P. M.;

The Rev. and Mrs. Abner F. Bowling of Verona, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Gertrude Bowling, to Norman Alexander Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Wilson of this city.

A surprise night attack has closed an important gap through which the Insurgents defending Oviedo had established precarious communications with the exterior and were effecting an evacuation. This is in the Naranco area, north of the city, where both government and Insurgent troops hold parts of a hill by that name.

To provide for expansion of its manufacturing facilities, the American Transformer Company has purchased a plot of more than an acre running from 273 to 201 Emmet Street, Newark, N. J., from Martin R. Everett, Inc.

Sole rights to commercial use of the words quinss, quints and quintuplets" are vested in the official guardians of the Dionne quintuplets by an act adopted in the House of Commons tonight. The measure, sponsored by Ross Gray, Ontario Liberal, received third reading and was sent to the Senate.

The Millimet Construction Company of Union City, N. J., today received a contract from the Treasury Department for the construction of six additional stories on the nine-story Federal Building on Vesey Street, in New York City, at a price of $2,100,000.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Gibbons of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Louise Gibbons, to Joseph D. Freney, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Freney of Philadelphia.

Stockholders of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation have been called to a special meeting at Richmond, Va., on April 7, to consider a plan providing for the exchange of present common stock on a one-for-two basis, the reduction in par value from $10 to $1 a share, and the raising of $2,600,000 of new capital through the sale of 988,971 shares of new common stock pro rata to present stockholders.

This is written at sea. Europe recedes into the distance and America is just over the horizon, hidden by the mountainous waves churned up by a March gale. Looking backward before the waves dissolve into the sharp outline of New York, some things stick out in the whirl of unassorted impressions printed on the mind during the hurried round from capital to capital.

The civil war in Spain is a death struggle between Christianity, as championed by the Spanish Insurgents, and anti-religion, as represented by the Madrid government, Hilaire Belloc and other speakers said last night at a symposium at Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Alumnae Association of Fordham University.

The Senate heard an impromptu debate between several members on the prevailing sit-down strikes, after Senators Morris Sheppard and Tom Connally of Texas had deplored the tragedy in New London, Texas, confirmed the nomination of William H. Hastie as a district court judge for the Virgin Islands, passed several minor bills and recessed at 4:41 P. M. until noon on Monday.

An eviction order obtained by the Home Owners Loan Corporation was carried out today and Walter Doyle, song writer, and his mother, Mrs. Gertrude Doyle, lost their sitdown strike against the Federal agency.

Miss Rosamond Frame of Auburndale, Mass., Mount Holyoke, '38, has been elected chairman of the Community for the coming academic year. Miss Jean Steadman, '38, of Passaic, N. J., was elected chairman of the judicial board.

With Mayor La Guardia indicating that he would veto the resolution calling for a relief investigation by the Board of Aldermen, the Board of Estimate appropriated $27,124,000 yesterday to finance relief for the next three months.

C. L. Croan's Zebar raced to his fourth consecutive victory in the featured Sunny Isles purse of one mile today at Tropical Park. The gelded son of The Scout, coupled with The Queen and closing at the lucrative odds of 6 to 1, withstood a long, grueling drive to win by half a length from the Medway Stable's lightly-weighted Jub Jub.

George R. Kirkpatrick, former faculty member of the Universities of Wisconsin, Kansas and Ohio, died suddenly at his home here yesterday. He is the father of George T. Kirkpatrick of New York. Death was ascribed to a heart attack.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company of Decatur, Ill., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 75,000 shares of no-par value $5 series cumulative preferred stock and 570,000 shares of $10 par value common stock of which 420,000 shares are outstanding in an exchange plan and to increase working capital.

Miss Hilda Chapin Seudder, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Locke Scudder of The Orchards in suburban Sherborn, was married here this afternoon to James Higginson Manning of New York, son of Wayland Manning of this city and the late Mrs. Manning, at the Commonwealth Avenue home of the bride's cousin Miss Elizabeth Marshall Garritt.

H. L. Thomas's Royal Mail raced to victory today in the ninety-ninth running of the Grand National steeplechase, overcoming thirty-two competitors while an estimated crowd of 400,000 headed by King George and Queen Elizabeth watched the world's hardest test for horses.

MANHATTAN ALBERT, YUNA (Feb. 13). Estate, less than $5,000. To Tauba Albert, 30 Liberty Av., Brooklyn, one-third residue; Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, 813 Howard Av., Brooklyn, twothirds residue; twelve specific bequests. Joseph Goldman, 153 Osborn St., Brooklyn.

Dr. Boyd Edwards, headmaster of Mercersburg Academy, has completed plans to turn Laucks Hall over to the younger boys of the school beginning next Fall. This is a departure from the tradition that boys should room in the dormitories of Mercersburg irrespective of age and according to the desire of the boy as to his room.

When the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Hopkins leave next Wednesday on the Queen Mary for South Africa, the clergyman, who is general secretary of the World's Sunday School Association, will represent 34,139,519 pupils and 3,145,895 teachers in the world's 369,510 Sunday schools.
Jack Colvin led the Denver Safeways to a 49-32 victory over the Hollywood Stars, Olympic tournament champions, in the national A. A. U. basketball semi-finals tonight.
Quickly following the example set by the German naval chiefs, the British Admiralty is forming a "suicide flotilla" of forty-knot speed boats carrying torpedoes.

Cotton mill activity held unchanged last week at a time when a slight decline is seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced one-half point to 139.9. In the preceding week the figure was 139.4 (revised) and for the week ended March 14, 1936, it was 103.0.

Gari Shelton, young American pianist, who has been heard here before, appeared in a recital yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. The recitalist's chief offerings were the Prelude and Fugue in D major, Bach-d'Albert, and Beethoven's "Appassionata" sonata.

R. Walton Moore and Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretaries of State, are two men who are prominently mentioned in connection with the post of Under-Secretary of State, an office which has been vacant since William Phillips was appointed Ambassador to Italy last Summer.
Funeral services for Charles Lee Cooke, ceremonial officer of the State Department, who died here yesterday, will be held tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock in the Speare Funeral Home.

Internal revenue collections for the first eight months of the 1937 fiscal year amounted to $2,309,709,976, an increase of $343,670,899 over the corresponding period last year, while for February the receipts were $237,826,183, an increase of $52,825,246 over February, 1936, it was announced today.

Trial Results Fireman First-Grade Anthony J. Rahmer, H. L. 146. Charge 1, neglect of duty (failed to respond on apparatus floor and accompany apparatus to an alarm for fire); guilty, sentence suspended. Charge 2, Ab sence without leave; guilty, reprimanded. Charge 3, disobedience of orders; guilty, sentence suspended.

Quite proud of their triumphant sweep through Florida which saw them flatten on successive days the Bees, Senators and Cardinals, the Giants today pulled into this resort town which for the next two weeks is to serve as their second training base of this most elaborate conditioning campaign.

Passengers leaving today for Southampton and Antwerp on board the Red Star liner Pennland include Miss Gladys Wells, Captain and Mrs. T. M. Richards, Mrs. H. G. Ingersoll, Captain J. W. Kimberlin, Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Potter and Dr. and Mrs. Henry D. Chapin.

The Los Angeles Gas and Electric Corporation and the Southern California Gas Company have filed with the California Railroad Commission an application for authority to permit the merger of the two companies into the Southern California Gas Company.

The body of a woman discovered Thursday night on a beach at Glen Cove, L. I., was identified yesterday afternoon by her brother as Mrs. Sadie C. Barrett, 42 years old, the wife of Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett.
The War Department issued the following orders today dated March 18: COLONELS Prosser, W. E., Signal Corps, Fort Sam Houston, Texas, to headquarters, Baltimore Md., Jun 30.

Mary J. Home sold 15 Bank St. to Joseph Warde Evans, for a consideration shown as $14,000, Mr. Evans then selling it to Morris A. Wainger for $16,000, who gave a purchase money mortgage for $12,000, due July 1, 1940, to John C. Robinson.

Nearly 3,500 youngsters, pupils in New York high schools and from schools in Westchester County and New Jersey, attended a special performance of Verdi's "Aida" yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.
The Public Service Commission refused today to approve the merger of the Metropolitan Edison Company with the Northern Pennsylvania Power Company. Both are subsidiaries of Associated Gas Electric.

Richard K. Mellon's Pittsburgh entries today walked away with the first half of the twenty-seventh annual Camden Horse Show, taking six firsts, three seconds, three thirds and a fourth in ten classes. Mrs. Simon T. Patterson, also of Pittsburgh, followed with seven ribbons, while Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby captured three.

While his recent suggestion for a $1,000,000 fund for self-regulation of advertising was in the nature of a "trial balloon," H. J. Kenner, president of the New York Better Business Bureau, said yesterday such voluntary regulation is "inevitable" unless the job is turned over to the government. He added that the plan would require "slow going," as it is not one which could be put into effect immediately.

General Count Felix von Bothmer, distinguished as the leader of the Southern Galician Army during the World War, died here today at the age of 85. During the Summer and Fall of 1916 he commanded the combined force of Germans and Austrians facing the brunt of Broussiloff's offensive.
Foreign markets for American products are listed in the current issue of Commerce Reports, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The Fordham Friars, dramatic organization of Fordham College, Manhattan division, and the Fordham School of Business Administration will offer tonight an original Passion play as their annual production this evening in Collins Auditorium on the Fordham campus.
Admiral Henry Edgar Grace, British gunnery expert and second son of England's most famous cricketer, Dr. W. G. Grace, died at Devonport today at the age of 61.

Henry H. Jenkins of Forest Hills, L. I., first mate of a transatlantic freighter, reached Niagara Falls today to see the fifth of the "seven wonders" of the world that he has viewed, and, paradoxically,' of all the seven, the nearest to his home.
At the annual meeting of the Standard Oil Company of Kentucky held in Louisville yesterday, A. M. Stephens was elected a director to succeed T. Q. McGoodwin, who resigned on July 1, last year.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court signed an order today allowing claims approximating $266,307,259 against the New Haven Railroad. The claims represent in part bonded obligations of the road, State taxes and bank loans.
District Attorney Joseph P. Molinari said today that Clyde Proctor, indicted for second-degree murder in connection with the death by shaking of a 15-month-old infant, would be arraigned tomorrow.

President MANUEL QUEZON'S suggestion "that the date of independence might be advanced to 1938 or 1939 "officially announced in Washington on Thursday-should help stimulate public interest in United States-Philippines relations.

Another of Gypsy Rose Lee's colleagues was signed today. She is Ada Leonard, whom RKO has hired for a specialty dance in "Mrs. America," featuring Helen Broderick, Victor Moore and Ann Shirley. Twentieth Century has Miss Lee under contract.
The Senate restored today to June 29, 1937, the deadline for charter of government-owned shipping lines now operated by private companies as agents.

The Milk Drivers Local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs has suffered a drop in membership from 5,000 to 1,200 as a result of the opposition of the Borden Farm Products Company to the union, according to testimony heard yesterday by Charles Wood, trial examiner for the Regional Labor Board, 45 Broadway.

Broadway's population will be increased next week by two plays: "Driftwood," a melodrama by Samuel J. Park, which will open Monday evening at the Longacre, and "Chalked Out," by Sing Sing's Warden Lawes and Jonathan Finn, due Thursday evening at the Morosco.

Asbury Park and Bloomfield High Schools will meet tomorrow night for the Group 4 basketball championship of New Jersey, by virtue of victories scored over Camden and Dickinson of Jersey City in the Rutgers gym tonight.

Bullish enthusiasm in the wheat market evaporated overnight when Liverpool failed to respond to the strong close in North America yesterday. Coupled with the development were reports that rain had fallen in the Southwest and West and a denial of the recent rumors that Argentina was to restrict exports.

The House Appropriations Committee reported the 1937-38 supply bill to. day carrying $121,222,000 for the State, Justice, Commerce and Labor Departments, an aggregate increase of $3,418,405 above those for the current fiscal year.

Fairfax H. Gouverneur of Rochester, N. Y., won the Belleview amateur golf championship today by defeating Garret A. Hobart, Paterson, N. J., 2 and 1. Both courses were utilized for the final thirty-six holes.

A bitter "showdown" fight between the William Green and John L. Lewis forces in Philadelphia labor took shape today with the sending of nearly 100 notices of suspension to delegates of the Committee for Industrial Organization to the Central Labor Union of Philadelphia and vicinity.

Mrs. Bijou Heron Miller, widow of Henry Miller, the actor, and mother of Gilbert Miller, theatrical producer of London and New York, died Thursday night in her apartment at the New Weston Hotel. She was stricken by paralysis last Friday. Her age was 75 years.

Jules Henri Venon, president of J. H. Venon, Inc., importers of Swedish glassware, of 104 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday at his home, 41 West Ninety-fourth Street, after a short illness. He was 64 years old.
Delegates of fifteen medical schools of the country participated in the dedication today of the new two-storied Theobald Smith Memorial Laboratory of the Albany Medical College.

Turpentine firm, 38 1/2@40c: sales, 20 barrels; receipts, 43 barrels; shipments, 1,166 barrels; stock, 20,090 barrels. Resin, firm; sales, 315: receipts, 228; shipments, 1,411; stock, 47,236. Quote: B, $8.15; D, $8.45-.50; E, $8.90; F, $9.30-.32 1/2; G. $9.45-.47 1/2; H. I, $9.55; K, $9.57 1/2; M, $9.62 1/2; N, $9.65; WG, $9.80; WW, X, $11.00.

Stocks closed irregular after rail shares rallied on freight decision; turnover, 1,741,170 shares. United States Government bonds weakened and closed lower; rail issues higher, other groups irregular; transactions, $18,286,800.

Retail distribution was less uniform this week, due to adverse weather conditions, sit-down strikes and the inroads on cash reserves as the result of income tax payments, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. While all of the leading cities reported an increase from the previous week's level, the rise was shortened to 2 to 6 per cent.

Increases in freight rates calculated to yield the nation's railroads an estimated $500,000 a year of additional revenues were approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to become effective at midnight.

Henry Armstrong battered Aldo spoldi, Italy's lightweight champion, into defeat in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The Pacific Coast Negro, who claims the world featherweight championship, easily outscored the game Italian to gain an undisputed decision.

Federal crop experts reported today that farmers had accepted the advice of Secretary Wallace to fill the nation's bins and granaries this year. Surveying farmers' planting plans, they saw indications of an 87 per cent increase in the acreage of Spring wheat that will be harvested next Fall. Lesser gains were foreseen for other major Spring crops.

The story of how four Federal agents, wearing old clothes, peddled eggs in Chinatown at the cheap price of 25 cents a dozen and gathered clues that led to four raids in which 2,500,000 pills of heroin were seized and eight Chinese arrested was divulged yesterday with the arraignment of the prisoners before United States Commissioner Isaac Platt.
Spring, premature signs of which have teased birds, flowers, gardeners and even fish for several months, will come to stay at 7:45 o'clock this evening, according to the calendar.

Reports of Communist party difficulties in the Ukraine were confirmed today with the disclosure that Paul Postisheff, secretary of the Kiev party committee, had been demoted. Mr. Postisheff, one of the topranking Bolsheviki and a candidate for the important Political Bureau, was made acting secretary of the Quibysheff (formerly Samara) provincial party committee.

Class 1, Model Hunters (to be shown in hand conformation and soundness only)First, Sen Satin, R. K. Mellon; second, Kylenahone, Mrs. S. T. Patterson; third, Knight Flight, R. K. Mellon; fourth, Steadfast. W. B. Ruthrauff.

James Roosevelt, administrative assistant to the President, declared here today that "cunning opponents" of the plan to reorganize the Supreme Court had attached themselves, in "the strategy of securing delay," to the group who favor a constitutional amendment.

Rules of trade practice proposed by the Carbon Dioxide Institute, Inc., of New York, in behalf of the carbon dioxide manufacturing industry, which makes annual sales of about $10,000,000, were announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to raise freight rates on a small group of commodities provided a favorable augury on the future of the railroads' petition for a general freight rate increase.

To protect local industry from dumping by foreign suppliers the Union of South Africa has adopted a new regulation under which it has authority to fix a minimum price below which no steel may be landed in the union, the Department of Commerce was informed today by Commercial Attache Samuel H. Day at Johannesburg.

Members of the New York Executive Council of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board voted yesterday to appoint a committee to confer with the Federal Trade Commission in Washington on Tuesday on the curbing of unfair garment returns, according to J. L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, who presided at the meeting.
Attorneys representing the respondents in the Securities and Exchange Commission's proceedings against Donald P. Kenyon and six others yesterday requested and obtained an adjournment for thirty days.

To commemorate the 125th anniversary of its founding, the Academy of Sciences in Philadelphia arranged an International Symposium on Early Man. The particularly Early Man who received most attention was the one who first settled America. It turns out that he was not so early.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, criticized last night certain teacher-training institutions which have made "big business" of their work, and urged that they return to the traditional course of training "master teachers" instead of "more teachers."

A Hall of Fame for East Central New York State is projected by the trustees of Hartwick College. Its new administration hall and chapel, for which $215,000 is now being raised, will be adorned with busts, paintings and tablets commemorating celebrities of the central section of the State.

The Congressional delegation of the State of Sonora today asked President Lazaro Cardenas to overrule the Supreme Court of that State which condemned five Mexicans to death for holding up and murdering the United States mining engineer, T. R. Sturtivant, some weeks ago.

Columbia Academy of Dubuque, Iowa, defeated the speedy St. Francis Mission Indian team of St. Francis, S. D., 43-31, today as the national Catholic interscholastic basketball tournament neared the quarterfinals.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 17: CAPTAINS Almy, E. D., Mare Island, Calif., to the Staff of the Commander of Battle Force as engineer officer, in May.

Coach William V. McCarthy yesterday took his New York University baseball squad out of doors for the first time this season. For the last four weeks the players have been drilling in the University Heights gymnasium.
Apparent proof that a prehistoric man, wandering in the jungles of pleistocene Alaska, speared a baby mammoth was en route today to the American Museum of Natural History, New York City.

Peking man, who lived in a cave near Peiping, China, from 100,000 to several hundred thousand years ago, was described today before the international symposium on early man, at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, as "perhaps the next to the last step traceable between anthropoids and man."
King Leopold of the Belgians will arrive Monday on what is ostensibly a private visit to London but is nevertheless a journey of great importance.

Another break in the ranks of the utility holding companies which are contesting the validity of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 occurred today when the American Light and Traction Company, a major member of the United Light and Power Company system, registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission after a conference between James M. Landis. chairman of the SEC. and Charles S. McCain, president of United Light and Power.

Followers of Father Divine, the Harlem evangelist, are planning to enter the field of education by establishing a private school on the elaborate 177-acre estate known as Greenkill Park, at Eddyville, Ulster County, where Max Schmeling trained for his fight against Jack. Sharkey in 1932.

The Board of Education yesterday filed plans for a new high school on Astor Avenue, the Bronx, to cost $2,000,000. The building, designed by W. C. Martin, architect, will occupy a site 190 by 421 feet, between Colden and Bronxwood Avenues.

Rarely has the speed of the present day news pictures service been more strikingly demonstrated than by that given by THE NEW YORK TIMES Wide World Photos in its photographic coverage of the school disaster in New London, Texas, on Thursday.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 13 amounted to 748,993 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 14,866 cars,

The large six-story apartment building at 10 Bowne Avenue, Flushing, Queens, on a plot 125 by 200 feet near Northern Boulevard, has been purchased by J. C. Berkwit of New York. The building is reported to be 100 per cent rented and has an annual rent roll of about $60,000, according to the new owner.

Arthur Meyerowitz of White Plains, one of the charter members of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, was the recipient of a letter this week from the Conservation Department which brought interesting news to him.

Jacob Baker, chairman of the President's commission of inquiry on cooperative enterprise in Europe, last night predicted that "cooperative enterprise will expand to considerable proportions in the United States in the next generation."

The Three Choir Festival, sponscored by Congregation Emanu-El and its choir committee, opened yesterday afternoon with a concert in the assembly hall of Temple Emanu-El, at which some twenty examples of noble choral music, illustrating the development of the art during the last seven centuries, were impressively set forth.

Cash over a first mortgage of $117,000, at 5 per cent for five years, was paid by Max Rosenfeld, operator, when he bought the five-and-a-half-story walk-up at 883 Fairmount Place, the Bronx, from a client of William Rosan. The house is on a plot 100 by 100 feet and contains fifty-one apartments. E. Wolf was the broker.

The Supreme Court of Canada declared invalid and canceled today a Canadian patent granted to the Samuel B. Smith Incubator Company of Cleveland, which enabled incubators to be constructed capable of hatching 10,000 to 60,000 eggs at one time.

Among the financial leaders who celebrate today the opening of the new Toronto Stock Exchange are many who can remember when charter members of the old Mining Exchange paid $35 to $40 for their seats in 1897 and when, not so many years later, interest had dropped to such a low ebb that $10 would have purchased a membership.

Radio played an important part in directing the flow of supplies and men to the scene of the New London school explosion. A small station, operated by Ted Hudson and opened in the Randolph Hotel here only twenty-four hours before the disaster, helped bereaved parents to locate the victims.

Stockholders approved today liquidation of the National Leather Company at its annual meeting here. The concern, a holding company incorporated under Maine laws, has as its principal assets the entire capital stock of the A. C. Lawrence Leather Company.

"The Golem," a French film, will have its American premiere today at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Harry Baur portrays the mad Emperor Rudolph II of Prague and Germaine Ausseyplays the feminine lead . . . The Central today will bring in "Navy Spy," featuring Conrad Nagel, Jack Doyle, Judith Allen and Eleanor Hunt.

Municipal MEDICAL INSPECTOR, Grade 1 (a), venereal diseases; (b) tuberculosis; (c) pediatrics (infant and child hygiene); (d) obstetrics (pre-natal care); (e) ophthalmology. Salary: $1,200 to, but not including, $1.800 per annum. or S5 per session when employed; maximum 3 1/2 hours per day; pension; fair sick leave. Ages: through 35, on April 1.

A month ago, shortly after the end of the first important sit-down strike in Michigan, the Police Department of this city announced the policy it would pursue in the event of local disturbances of this kind. It was said then that the police would aid in the ejection and arrest of sit-down strikers whenever formal complaint was made by the owner of the property in question.

The swallows of San Juan Capistrano Mission came back again today. Legend has it that these swallows, probably the most traveled of all feathered creatures, arrive at the mission promptly on March 19 (St. Joseph's Day), and depart just as promptly on Oct. 23 (San Juan Day).

Malaria is on the increase in both the North and South because of a combination of cheap automobiles, good roads and the multiplication of power dams and recreational lakes in malarious areas, according to Dr. L. L. Williams of the United States Public Health Service in Washington.

Miss Patty Berg, the Minneapolis schoolgirl, wound up her Southern campaign today by winning the Aiken invitational golf tournament in easy fashion for her fourth triumph of the Winter season. The sturdy redhead beat blonde Miss Barbara Bourne of New York, 6 and 4, in the eighteen-hole final round over the Highland Park course.

Columbus O'Donnell Iselin of New York and New Rochelle, retired banker and financier, left a net estate of $4,833,550, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The principal beneficiaries are members of his family.

Persons living in areas where natural gas is generated in the depths of the earth face the constant threat of a virtually odorless gas the presence of which cannot be detected until an explosive quantity has accumulated, a member of the American Gas Association, who has been connected with the industry for thirty-six years, said last night.

Central European mail is becoming a problem as a result of currency restrictions and sometimes of political events. Greek letters going abroad are usually opened by officials searching for foreign exchange.

Aroused by the heavy accumulations of scrap iron and steel by foreign interests in recent months, independent steel companies in the United States held a series of meetings this week to determine whether or not joint action should be taken to seek some means of preventing further heavy exports of scrap metal.

Adolph Hitler in a message to President Roosevelt today upon the Texas disaster said: "For the terrible New London catastrophe costing so many young lives I convey to Your Excellency my sincere condolence as well as that of the German people.

Mrs. Florence Majestic,. 41, head of the Spiritual Church of Sunshine at 1,477 Lexington Avenue, was at liberty in $2,500 bail yesterday on not guilty pleas in General Sessions on fraud charges, to one of which she entered a not guilty plea in the Felony Courf last week.
Jack Doyle, Broadway betting commissioner, installed the Yankees 4-to-5 favorites today to repeat their 1936 American League pennant victory this season as a result of Lou Gebrig's signing.
Gradually the vast unfinished caverns of the Pennsylvania Museum of Art are being completed and made thus to enlarge the facilities of this enterprising institution directed by Fiske Kimball.

Remington-Rand, Inc., increased its capitalization between Feb. 28 and March 11, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. On Feb. 28 there were 1,461,041 shares outstanding.

Testimony in the restaurant racket case was finished yesterday, after which the attorneys in the case conferred with Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and arranged a schedule for summing up which will put the case in the hands of the jury next Friday or Saturday.
The City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince, will give a concert tonight at the Bronx County Building.

By I. LINCOLN SEIDE Sedgwick Av., 3,866, 2-story brick dwelling, 50x114.10, irreg.; Railroad Federal Savings Bank and Loan Assn. against Antonio Zilli; due, $16,733; taxes, , $13; to plaintiff for $500.
The clergy of New York-Protestant, Catholic and Jewish-has been invited to the private showing next Tuesday of a painting which challenges the real Christianity of socalled Christian nations.

The heavier income tax payments, the vagaries of the weather and the recession in the bond and stock markets all contributed to hold down gains in retail trade this week, although increases over last year ranged around 8 per cent. Early Easter shopping is running somewhat under expectations, although a sharp increase in volume is expected today.

MANHATTAN HARTT. DELIA (Jan. 4, 1937). Gross assets, $3,094; net, $2,176. To Robert Bauerfeld, grandson, residue; three others $100 each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $3,094. Lawrence B. Spiess, attorney, 258 Broadway.

An estate of $274,981 was left by the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, Presbyterian Fundamentalist leader, according to an inventory filed today. Dr. Machen died on Jan. 1 in Bismarck, N. D. Most of his holdings were in stocks and bonds.

The creation of what amounts to a governmentdirected trust monopolizing German film production and distribution has been announced. Majority stock control of UFA, Germany's largest production concern, has been purchased by an anonymous group headed ostensibly by the Deutsche Bank und DiscontoGesellschaft.

The sympathy of the nation is centered today in the little Texas town of New London. The hearts of parents the world around are touched by the fate of the children who in the midst of life found at an end the schooling which their districts had done their best, it would seem, to provide for them.

Barclay St., 103, 19.11 1/4x61.5x irreg; Josephine E. Nostrand to 105 Barclay St., Inc., 105 Barclay St. (quitclaim). E. 3d St., 325, 20x96: Three Twenty-five East Third St., Inc. to Dry Dock Savings Institution; mtg., $5,500 held by bank.

A strike of shopmen and power-house employes of the Indiana Railroad left eleven towns in darkness tonight and stopped service on two divisions of the railroad's interurban system and the Anderson street car lines.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Stockholders of the Ruberoid Company at their annual meeting yesterday at South Bound Brook, N. J., voted to split the present nopar shares of capital stock three for one. To provide the additional shares the authorized capital stock of the company was increased to 1,000,000 shares.
The New York Rovers and the Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets waged tonight their battle for last place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League, with the victory in the game going to New York; 6-3.

Otto Williams, former major and minor league baseball player and scout, died here today of pneumonia. His age was 59. Williams came to Omaha after ending his playing career as an infielder seventeen years ago.
Jack Russell, American League veteran right-hand pitcher who has been working out with the Dodgers, may have been doing his Spring training with the club that will pay him his 1937 wages.

When American reviewers suggested that "Angels in Undress," a study of the London underworld, was "ghost-written," and that Mark Benney, the author, probably supplied only the facts, Random House, the American publishers, cabled Peter Davies, the English publisher, for additional information.

More than ninety delegates from forty women's colleges of the Northwestern States are attending the athletic conference at Vassar College, the second session of which was held today. Problems and activities of amateur athletics were discussed by special groups and speakers.

The Railroad Employes Personal Loan Company of New York has been authorized as a licensed lender at 385 Flatbush Avenue Extension, Brooklyn, the State Banking Department announced today. The company has $25,000 in liquid assets.

Miss Alice Gregg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hayes Gregg of this place, will be married on April 30 to Sidney Bartram Schou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Schou of Glen Ridge. The ceremony will be performed in St. Luke's Church by the Rev. Dr. Luke M. White. A large reception will follow at the Upper Montclair Women's Club.

Judge Robert A. Inch, in the Federal court in Brooklyn, tentatively approved yesterday the reorganization plan for the. Bush Terminal Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Bush Terminal Buildings Company, subject to modifications to the plan agreed upon by various interests in both companies after a hearing on March 12.

Charles Heywood, actor, singer and female impersonator of the last century, died last night at St. Michael's Hospital. He was 8?? years old. He retired twenty-five years ago from the stage and more recently as a teacher of voice culture.
Apartment houses in the Dyckman section, the upper West Side and Harlem proved attractive to buyers in Manhattan in deals announced yesterday.

Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-Andrew E. Langert, from 4th Division to 112th Precinct, assignment to duty in plain clothes discontinued. Edwin T. O'Keefe, from 4th Division to 80th Precinct, assignment to duty in plain clothes discontinued. Additional compensation of $240 ($220) per annum revoked.

Engineers found "a potential disaster" threat in Amelia Earhart's $80,000 flying laboratory today, but failed to deter her in preparing for one of the most dangerous phases of her projected aerial dash around the world.

The leading National Socialist party organ in Wuerttemberg, the Nazional Kurier, bitterly protests that a Protestant pastor confirming a Hitler Youth member Sunday employed the commandment "Thou shall not kill" and the religious motto, "Fight the good fight for thy faith."

Spanish Insurgent authorities have sequestrated all foreign securities held by Spaniards in occupied territory or temporarily resident abroad, according to information reaching the Bank of London and South America here today.

The Long Island Railroad's practice of charging more than 2 cents a mile on short hauls within the city was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of Brooklyn, which unanimously sustained the refusal of Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway in Brooklyn-to punish the railroad company for contempt of court.
Consumption of iron ore by furnaces in February totaled 4,443,306 tons, compared with 4,694,312 in the previous month, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today.

Despite a reduction in the rate paid by the city to private hospitals for the care of city patients, the hospitals affiliated with the Catholic Charities received an increase last year of $210,000 from patients as compared with the previous year, it was reported yesterday by the health division of the charities.

John Alvaro Smith, sixty-five years an attorney here, died today after a brief illness. During his career he served as Mayor of East Cleveland for two years, was a Cleveland Councilman and for several years was a member of the board of the Cleveland Public Library.

Frank Parker, America's secondranking star, won the Bermuda tennis championship today, defeating Robert Murray of Montreal, 6-1, 6-0, 6--2, in the final before the largest crowd on record in the Bermuda Tennis Stadium.

Washington awoke today to the full realization of the school disaster yesterday in New London, Texas. Both houses of Congress convened at noon, with heads bowed in sorrow as the chaplains offered prayers for the stricken families. In the Senate the tragedy was deplored by Senators Connally and Sheppard of Texas.

The Court of Appeals has reversed the judgment found against John Curley and dismissed the complaint of Mary S. Swanton, his former wife, who sued him for the support of a daughter, whose custody was awarded to the mother when the marriage was dissolved.

The Cartoonists of America and the magazine Judge signed a contract yesterday. Under the terms of the contract the magazine's management recognizes the Guild as the collective bargaining agency for the cartoonists and agrees that there shall be no discrimination against cartoonists for their Guild activity and establishes a minimum of $20 for "gag" drawings and $5 for "spots."

Union printers voted here tonight to return to work on the three Indianapolis newspapers, ending a twenty-four-hour strike which left this city without a local paper. The vote on returning to work was 207 to 18.

A duplex apartment of fourteen rooms in 955 Lexington Avenue has been leased by Frank C. Page, vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company. Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., were the brokers.
Meeting five of his usual rivals, W. Weber's Gay Dog showed the way home in the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds today for his second straight victory.
Tension of a railroad embargo on scrap iron to prevent shipments from blocking freight yards relaxed tonight at Boston as one ship sailed with 590 tons, and two others took on similar cargoes.

For the first time in the history of international expositions, chain stores of the nation will be represented with exhibits at the World's Fair here in 1939, officials of the fair announced here yesterday. The chains will exhibit their methods of distribution and operation in a distribution sector, which will be one of the eight main exhibit areas.

Operations of two Standard Oil companies last year resulted in favorable earnings. Net profit of the Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries amounted to $7,881,571 for 1936 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, depletion, interest and other deductions.

A brief sit-down strike of five schoolboys in neighboring Margate was ended today by hunger. A police radio car was parked near the Granville Avenue school while Patrolman Walter A. Eberding, the driver, was handling traffic.

Mr. and Mrs. William E. Shepherd entertained with a dinner las night at their home, 21 East Eighty second Street, later taking their guests to a dance at the Cour House Tennis Club, 206 East Sixty fifth Street.

Binghamton police were ordered today by City Judge William S. Richardson to break up "every policy racket in the city." The order came as police sought Michael (Policy Mike) Maione on a warrant charging possession and sale of lottery tickets.

The Board of Tax Appeals disclosed today that two New. York Stock Exchange member firms and ten individuals had been assessed for alleged income-tax deficiencies totaling $75,944, plus $18,986 in penalties, as transferees of the assets of the Consolidated Coppermines stock syndicate of New York.

Two members of a hold-up gang of six were shot and killed and another was wounded yesterday afternoon when one of them attempted to shoot it out with detectives of the Safe and Loft Squad, who captured all as they were fleeing from a $30,000 fur robbery at the establishment of Harry Bleiweis Son, 231 West Twenty-ninth Street.
The engagement of $11,494,000 of gold abroad for shipment here, $6,104,000 in England and $5,390,000 in Japan, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Last week's unusually large advance in steel prices called attention sharply to the general upward movement of prices; also to the diversity of influences which have contributed to that movement.

The actual cost of living has increased about 6 per cent in the past three years, according to an index compiled by the Labor Department. Dr. Isador Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, gave the House Appropriations Committee the figure at hearings on the Labor Department Supply Bill.

The eighth in the series of Mozart-Haydn concerts last night at the WPA Theatre of Music, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street, had as soloists Frances Blaisdell, flautist, and Lucy Lewis, harpist. The project's chamber orchestra was under the direction of Georges Barrere.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann have returned from Palm Beach, Fla., to their home at 4 East Eightieth Street. Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Kirkman of 43 East Sixty-eighth Street will give a dinner dance on April 17 at the Ritz-Carlton for Lefferts and Waring Strebeigh, sons of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Strebeigh.
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 943,000 bales, against 941,000 a week ago, 969,000 two weeks ago, 929,000 three weeks ago and 691,000 a year ago, of which American.

Federal Judge George A. Welsh assumed jurisdiction today in the Reading hosiery strike situation and issued an order here restraining the Rosedale Knitting Mills from making further attempts to oust sit-down strikers from its plant pending completion of a Federal court hearing.
Blinding dust swirled over parts of four Southwestern States tonight in clouds so dense that visibility sometimes dropped to zero. A couple here was lost for hours in the storm.

Governor Lehman announced today that he would send to the Senate for confirmation the nomination of Paul Livoti of Ridgewood, as a justice of the City Court. He is to fill the vacancy caused by the death of William B. Hazelwood.
After a lapse of several years, Mercersburg Academy regained the national interscholastic swimming championship before a big crowd at the Penn A. C. pool tonight.

President Manuel Quezon's recommendation for Philippine independence in 1938 or 1939 caused a have shock in insular business and political circles, despite previous indications in Washington that this was contemplated.

The New College team defeated the Hunter squad, 26-21, in a girls' basketball game at the latter's court yesterday. The victors led at the intermission, 17-5. Miss Hildegarde Gross of New College and Miss Doris Franck of Hunter each made 10 points.

Mrs. Alice du Pont, widow of Senator T. Coleman du Pont, died this afternoon at her home here after a long illness. She was 74 years old. Like her husband, who died more than six years ago, she was widely known for her philanthropic activities.

A semblance of peace returned to New Jersey's industrial communities tonight with the settlement of the sit-down strike of 600 women employes of the Waitt Bond Cigar factory here and no further sit-downs, walkouts or lockouts of consequence being reported.

A 16-year-old Brooklyn art student won first prize in the Bill of Rights poster competition under sponsorship of the American Civil Liberties Union, Corliss Lamont announced yesterday in behalf of the organization's board of directors.

Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant imposed sentences yesterday upon four men convicted last Thursday of conspiracy and concealing assets from a trustee in the bankruptcy of the Aetna Sportswear Company of Boston.

The Census Bureau credited the cotton spinning industry today with setting an all-time record for operation during February. On the statistical basis used to compare current figures with past years the bureau said the industry operated at 144.8 per cent of capacity.

Marion AV. (12-3286) w s, 526 ft n of Fordham Rd. 50x154: Marion B. Weinraub to Hergreen Holding Corp., 2,579 Marion Av. 175 St. (11-2953), n e s, 240 ft s e of Prospect Av., 150x194: Loeb Associates, Inc., to Bio Associates, Inc., 2,599 Davidson Av.

The five-man team division again provided the fireworks as keglers rounded out the tenth session of maple crashing in the thirtyseventh annual American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory early this morning.

"THE situation in which the Blum Ministry finds itself," said Dr. J. Salwyn Schapire in a recent issue of the magazine Events, "is unique in French politics. In the shuffle of Ministries that usually takes place, no sooner is one formed than plans are laid for its successor. But there is no successor to the Blum Ministry in sight.

John Neville, 35 years old, a former house-to-house hosiery peddler in Boston, who under the name of John Bruce Heath recently became financial backer of The Financial Observer, was held without bail yesterday morning by Magistrate Samuel Katz in the Tombs Court on a charge of being a fugitive from justice in Massachusetts.

Observing that the country had gone "technique-wild" in social work, Dr. James S. Plant, psychiatrist-director of the Essex County Juvenile Clinic, Newark, told welfare workerss yesterday their efforts were fruitless unless they changed to a more personal and individual relationship with their clients.
Two men regarded as important gangsters in racketeering operations in the garment industry were arrested yesterday by detectives attached to the staff of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.

The Mamaquarro Apartments, a four-story building for twenty-one families at the southwest corner of Mamaroneck Avenue and Quarropas Street, White Plains, was sold by J. N. Heeny to a syndicate formed by Henry Mandel.
President Roosevelt braved a chilly Spring rain today to drive twenty-five miles to dine at the farm and plantation of Cason J. Callaway at Blue Springs.

The merger of the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Standard Stock Exchange in 1934 into the third largest Exchange on this continent will be consummated physically tomorrow when a new $750,000 building will unite the two organizations in a single trading floor, also the third largest in North America.

The honorary degree of Doctor of Science was conferred upon three foreign scholars by the University of Pennsylvania at a convocation of the university council tonight held in connection with the symposium on early man here.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has amended the requirements under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 on financial statements in the instruction book to Form 23 for successor issuers.

The United States Consulate at Barcelona has Intervened to save the lives, if possible, of Bernard Marques Rullan, his wife, Catalaina Mayol, and two daughters, Maria Luisa and Catalaina, whose lives the prosecutor demanded before a military court at Soller, Majorca, for their republican ideas.
Mrs. Louise Thorne Ditmas Talmage died Thursday at her home, 104 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. She had lived in her home for fiftyone years. She was 54 years old.

With approximately 95 per cent of the total income derived by individuals from the bituminous coal mining industry paid out in the form of wages and salaries, dividends and interest are of small significance, according to information made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, which has just completed a study of the industry.

New York Stock Exchange members have been notified of proposed admissions to existing partnerships which will be considered April 1. Phillip W. Brown, Ogden Phipps and William Fenton Johnston would be admitted to Charles D. Barney Co. and Leo D. Tyrrell, Robert M. Williams Jr., John Strawbridge Jr. and James D. Winsor 3d would be admitted to Biddle, Whelen Co.

Lieutenant Richard Aldworth, superintendent of Newark Airport, left today for Washington to take up with Federal officials allegations of "grossly inaccurate" weather reports "issued by Floyd Bennett Field" in Brooklyn, it was announced by James W. Costello, chief city engineer.

After a stormy executive session of the Aldermanic buildings committee in City Hall yesterday Timothy J. Sullivan, majority leader, emerged as a peacemaker for the Aldermen warring over the city's new building code.
Governor Lehman signed today the bills continuing for another year the moratorium on mortgage foreclosures and fixing conditions designed to eliminate abuses in deficiency judgments.
The All-India Congress, by a vote of 127 to 70, last night authorized elected Congressmen to accept office in the new provincial Legislatures.

The Rev. Dr. James E. Holmes, director emeritus of the Methodist Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn, died there early yesterday of heart disease. He was 74 years old and lived at 862 Union Street, Brooklyn.

Philip Epitano, president of the E. and F. Construction Company, was held up this afternoon by two masked bandits, who escaped with a $2,787 payroll that he had just brought from a bank. The robbery took place in front of Mr. Epifano's office, at 78 Wells Street.

Colonel Francois de la Rocque, leader of the French Social party, warned Premier Lion Blum tonight that "tyrannical acts" against his party may arouse "Immense uprisings." It was followers of Colonel de la Rocque who battled Communists in suburban Clichy Tuesday night, when five persons were killed and about 300 injured.

Gloria Lee was just a night club singer, not a very good one either, until she became Galaxy's owner and met Steve Rowan. Galaxy was a horse and Steve Rowan was a trainer and a bit of a poet. He taught the ever-so-slightly tarnished beauty that a great-hearted thoroughbred was one of nature's noblest works.
Worried parents besieged school officials here tonight with requests to do something about the menace of gas pockets in the derrick-studded East Side residential oil field district.

Gene Sarazen, former United States and British open titleholder, and Mally Reynolds of Jacksonville, winners of the event in 1936, were defeated in the second round of the third annual national professional-amateur best-ball match play championship on the St. Augustine links today.

The statement made last night in the British House of Commons by Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, that an Italian vessel had landed an "unknown number of people" at Cadiz, Spain, on March 5, is prominently featured in today's Pravda, organ of the Russian Communist party.

Dizzy Dean formally signed his 1937 contract with the St. Louis Cardinals tonight after a stormy session with the management. The ace pitcher, who will receive a reported $25,000 for his services, first balked on a "good behavior" provision.

The Rev. Frank Hoffnagel Bigelow, headmaster of Rectory School at Pomfret, Conn., died last night while visiting his brother, Charles A. Bigelow, at Wilmington, Del., it was reported here early this morning by his widow, Mrs. Mabel Augusta Brittain Bigelow. His age was 63.

Jagged holes gaped in the glass doors of seven downtown shoe stores here j tonight after more than 100 police, under orders to restore the shops to their managements, ended sitdowns which had lasted eight to sixteen days.

More than $60,000 of New York World's Fair 4 per cent debentures has been subscribed by a group of the leading advertising agencies, according to an announcement yesterday by H. K. McCann, chairman of the advertising committee for the distribution of these debentures, and president of McCann-Erickson, Inc.
The Lehigh University chapter of Phi Beta Kappa has elected these fourteen seniors: Arts College-John D. Houck, Scranton: Sidney J. Lewis, Quakertown; Eugene H. Uhler, Bethlehem.

For fifteen residents of the metropolitan area March. 19, 1937, will be a day to remember. The three horses on which they held twelve tickets in the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes finished first, second and third in the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree, England, and with their victory brought undreamed of wealth.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation announced today it would construct a new sheet and strip mill at Clairton, Pa. The mill will be named the Irvin Works, for William A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, of which Carnegie-Illinois is a subsidiary.

Count Hideo Kodama, Minister of Communications, told the Diet today that the Japanese Government had allotted 90,000,000 yen (about $25,200,000) of the current budget for development of civil aviation.

Cornell alumnae from New York, Brooklyn and the suburbs, as well as delegates from Cornell clubs throughout the country, are expected to attend the annual reception and luncheon of the Cornell Women's Club to be held today at Essex House, Central Park South.

Joseph Virdone, 24 years old, a Brooklyn law student, has been arrested in London on a charge of stealing $3,000 from a Brooklyn receivership fund, it became known yesterday. The arrest was made at the request of William F. X. Geoghan. Kings County District Attorney.
Gardner Read, 24-year-old American composer, was announced yesterday as the winner of the first prize of $1,000 in the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society's contest for a major orchestral work.
Hogs were in slow demand and prices steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, a good part of the day's offerings selling in the late rounds at 5 to 10 cents decline.

Totaling 18 1/2 points to Hamilton's 8 1/2, the Columbia University fencers easily routed their hosts tonight. High scorers were Columbia's Kellerman and Wallis, both of whom won all three of their bouts.
Palm Sunday, which will be celebrated tomorrow in all churches, will be the occasion of many sermons advocating that the day be also "Peace Sunday." Faure's "The Palms" will be sung.
Pierre S. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., a director, of the General Motors Corporation, acquired 1,500 shares of the common stock of that corporation on Jan. 6 and sold 1,633 shares on Jan. 14,

The Soviet Film Trust today charged Sergius M. Eisenstein, well known director, with portraying. the Communist revolution unfavorably and picturing its opponents sympathetically in his new picture, "Bezhun Lug."
Florida Kingsley, actress, died today in the Southside Hospital here. Her age was 70. Since 1933 she had been living at the Percy Williams Home at East Islip.

A new highly sensitive seismograph that will record with greatly improved fidelity the tremors of the earth will be installed at Fordham University's seismic station In April, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. J. Joseph Lynch, Professor of Physics.

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana was accused of trying to stifle competition from the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company, which it controls, in a suit filed yesterday in Supreme Court by minority Pan American stockholders.

Harold Laski, Professor of Political Economy at London University, declared on his arrival yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan that the world was "the lunatic asylum of the planets," and said that the political relationships of Europe were "very similar to those of 1913."

A lawyer, his "runner" and a physician received suspended sentences in Special Sessions yesterday on charges growing out of the investigation by Bernard C. Botein, Assistant District Attorney at the head of the new Accident Fraud Bureau, of irregularities in suits and accident indemnity claims on insurance companies.

A luxuriant wild-flower garden, designed by women to inspire Americans to preserve wild plant life, was singled out yesterday at the Flower Show for the special award offered by the National Council of State Garden Clubs, Inc.
The proposed New York State Securities Commission now under consideration by a joint legislative committee was denounced here yesterday by John J. Bennett Jr., Attorney General of this State.

Brilhart Chapman, 38 years old, an interpretive dancer, shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday morning jumped or fell to his death from his room on the thirteenth floor of the Hotel Bromley, 31 West Seventy-first Street.
Led by Clarence (Buddy) Combs Jr., who scored fourteen goals, the Cornell University poloists rode roughshod over the Detroit All-Stars, 17--6 1/2, at the Coliseum tonight.

With the announcement that Gene Venzke would definitely start in the one-mile run, the New York A. C. squad yesterday became even more of a favorite than heretofore to retain the team title in the annual Metropolitan A. A. U. indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. George H. Miles of 345 East Fifty-seventh Street and Rumson, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Bramhall Miles, to Robert Shippee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl C. Shippee of The Grange; Red Bank, N. J.

Two young American stage designers and a Polish painter will collaborate with Choreographer George Balanchine in the American Ballet Ensemble's presentation of three Stravinsky ballets at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, April 27 and 28.

Frederic W. Goudy, the distinguished typographer, received last night from the hands of Miss Francis Perkins, Secretary of Labor, the Ulster-Irish Society's annual award for outstanding achievement by a person of Ulster-Irish descent.

One person was killed and six were seriously injured today when an explosion during the filming of a motion picture blasted away a wall of historic Himeji Castle, most highly prized surviving example of medieval Japanese castle architecture.

Theodore Fred Kuper, executive manager of the Board of Education, went on trial yesterday on charges of "unethical and reprehensible conduct" at an open hearing conducted by the board at 500 Park Avenue.
Pursuing its policy of expropriating national defense factories, the government tomorrow will announce the expropriation of the plants of some of France's most well-known airplane manufacturers.
The stock markets here were extremely quiet today and most sections displayed weakness. Gilt-edge issues, after early gains, turned downward. In the foreign loans, French and German bonds declined.

Grapplers from Oklahoma A. and M. became outstanding contenders for team honors tonight when they qualified six men for the semi-final round of the National Collegiate A. A. wrestling tournament in the Indiana University gymnasium.

Judge Allan Campbell in the Circuit Court here today signed an order directing Sheriff Thomas C. Wilcox of Wayne County to arrest the 6,000 sit-down strikers who have held possession of eight Chrysler automobile plants since a week ago Monday, on charges of contempt of court in violating the injunction issued by Judge Campbell ordering them to evacuate the plants by 9 A. M. last Wednesday.

Dr. and Mrs. William Turner Wootton of Hot Springs announced tonight that their daughter, Mrs. Martha Wootton Collings, would be married on Monday at their home to Colonel Lawrence Westbrook of Washington, chairman of the National WPA Advisory Board.

A semi-offcial statement issued tonight regarding German attacks on alleged false information published here declared 'that the Austrian Government was sorry for any erroneous dispatches published in Austrian papers, but added it was not the Austrian press but the German press that constantly printed items calculated to harm Austro-German relations.
The Textile Workers Organization Committee began its campaign officially yesterday to organize 1,250,000 employes in the textile industry under John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization.

The Spanish Loyalist army's information department issued this evening a copy of a message purported to have been sent by Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy to General Mancini. The original was said to have been found among five cases of documents captured yesterday at Brihuega, fifty-two miles northeast of Madrid on the Tajuna River.
A legislative investigation to determine the cause of the explosion that wrecked the New London school house was voted today by the House of Representatives.
Parties including members of the college set here for the Easter vacation will feature attendance on the "Sidewalks of New York" gala dinner dance at the Surf Club tomorrow night.

The future of the American merchant marine depends to a large extent on the relations between maritime workers and their employers, according to Paul Scharrenberg, legislative representative of the International Seamen's Union, who spoke yesterday at a luncheon of the New York Propeller Club at the Downtown Athletic Club.

The engagement of Miss Anne Mitchell, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Herbert Mitchell of Princeton and the late Mr. Mitchell, to John C. Dielhenn, son of Mrs. Clarence Arthur Dielhenn of Cleveland. Ohio, and the late Mr. Dielhenn, has been announced by her mother.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1936 a net profit of $1,643,977 after depreciation, amortization and other deductions, but before expenses of excess manufacturing and airport facilities, Federal taxes and minority interests.

The former Kaiser's great land holdings are threatened. The Deutsche Arbeiter Korrespondenz, organ of the German Labor Front, complains that the aristocracy still holds large estates aggregating 13,000,000 acres and demands that they be taken over under a State financing program and divided into small holdings.
Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, British High Commissioner, returned today from a vacation in England, having flown here from Alexandria, Egypt.

First-round games in the annual Manlius School invitation basketball tournament for teams coached by Manlius alumni and former faculty members were played in Dodge Gymnasium today. Lynbrook (L. I.) High conquered Chittenango, 48-14, and Holley High downed Frankfort, the winner of last year's tourney, 32 to 29.

Two more members of a gang of five gunmen who held up Barney's clothing establishment in lower Seventh Avenue on the night of Jan. 2 were sentenced to prison in General Sessions yesterday. They had pleaded guilty.

Lewis Bruner Scull, former Philadelphian, veteran hotel man here and member of the Morris Guards, died today at his home. He was 62 years old. For the last twenty-nine years Mr. Scull was connected with the Hotel Breakers here.

Conflicting views on President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the United States Supreme Court and on other proposals affecting the court will prevent any stand in the controversy by the American Civil Liberties Union, its board of directors decided yesterday.

McKeesport Tin Plate Corporation common stock, $10-par value, and New York City Omnibus Corporation capital stock, no par value, were admitted to the list yesterday. General Printing Ink Corporation common stock, $1 par value, will be admitted to the list today, when the old no-par value common stock will be suspended from dealings.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art comes within the definition of a charitable institution and is therefore exempt from the New York City sales tax, Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller decided in Supreme Court yesterday.

Winding up their tour of Australasia, the touring Marylebone Cricket Club players, vanquished three games to two in the tests with Australia, started a short series against New Zealand teams today. Three matches are scheduled and the Englishmen will leave for home early in April.

Those rounders who recall with nostalgic sighs their pre-repeal Harlem and the old Cotton Club, with its purple lights and fantastic bowers and its essential atmosphere of hey-hey frenzy, will be happy to know that the nearest thing to it since Harlem itself declined has been recaptured in the new revue which opened this week at the downtown (and more refined) Cotton Club.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: About two or three times a year the subject of Merkle's error in not touching second base in 1908 comes up in the newspapers and I am surprised at some of the stories related about this incident.
