The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market is a bit stronger again this week. There is better buying of piece goods reported from the New York market, especially in men's wear.

The price of lead was reduced 25 points yesterday by the two leading producers. The new price here is 7 cents a pound; at St. Louis it is 6.85 cents. On Tuesday and Wednesday, similar reductions were announced.

Westchester County is fair territory for any one who wants to dig for feldspar, gold, silver, iron or any other mineral that might be found on his property, no matter how strict the residential zoning laws of a municipality.

There is too much "shotgun education" in America, Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, declared last night in an address at the annual dinner of the New York Alumni Association of the college at the WaldorfAstoria.

Shareholders of the American Rolling Mill Company at a meeting on April 15, are to be asked to approve issue of approximately $45,000,000 of convertible preferred stock, according to a letter sent to them yesterday. W. E. Hutton Co. and Edward B. Smith Co.
Fluency and charm were present to an unusual degree in the superior playing heard from Adele Marcus at her piano recital in Town Hall last night.
GR0VER CLEVELAND'S likeness in picture and stone displays a rugged individual. Please note that the word

The Cabinet decreed today another series of laws, including the budget for the new fiscal year. According to an official announcement, the adoption of the budget is seemingly a rather incidental matter,

The annual report of the North American Light and Power Company for 1936, being mailed to stockholders today, shows a consolidtaed net income, after all charges and deductions of accumulated preferred dividends on subsidiary companies, of $478,877, compared with a consolidated net deficit of $135,654 for 1935.

Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee were told today that justices of the Supreme Court would not appear before them to state their views on President Roosevelt's plan to reorganize the Federal judiciary, but Senator Robinson announced that John H. Clarke, only living former member of that high tribunal, would deliver a radio speech on the subject Monday night.

A Taste Tour of Europe will be the feature of the Madison House Ball to be held tonight at the Plaza under the auspices of the Madison House Society, governing body of the settlement house which for the last forty years has served the residents of the Lower East Side.

Westchester County is fair territory for any one who wants to dig for feldspar, gold, silver, iron or any other mineral that might be found on his property, no matter how strict the residential zoning laws of a municipality.
A new hypothesis on the subject of gravitation was expounded here today by Dr. Conway Robinson, engineer, scientist and former co-worker with Charles Steinmetz.

More than 2,000 women attended the Easter fashion show, held under the auspices of the School Settlement Association of Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Mrs. Walter Scott Robinson is president of the association, and Mrs. Tremper Longman was chairman of the benefit.
Lady Greer, wife of Sir Arthur Greer, Lord Justice of Appeal, died today after an operation. She was the former Katherine Van Noorden of Orangebury, S. C.
Mrs. Charles A. Denneen of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary A. Denneen, to Dr. Cecil Early Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Early Hurt Johnson of Columbus, Ga.
Two lawyers were disbarred and three others, one of them a woman, were suspended from practice yesterday by unanimous decision of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

Resentment against the sit-down strike as a weapon in labor disputes welled up in both Houses of Congress today and produced a torrent of turbulent oratory in which the leaders of sit-down strikes were castigated, President Roosevelt's labor policies were sharply criticized and the attitude of industry toward labor was assailed as a factor in current unrest among the workers.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed upon the eligible list of holders of licenses for service in day high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated:
Formation of a new sales section for miscellaneous household appliances has been announced by D. C. Spooner Jr., manager of the General Electric household appliance division at Bridegport.

As workmen pulled debris from the London Consolidated School today a blackboard was exposed showing this in a scrawl: "Oil and natural gas are East Texas's greatest mineral blessings. Without them this school would not be here and none of us would be here learning our lessons."

Miss Doris Borden, daughter of General and Mrs. Howard S. Borden of 280 Park Avenue, has chosen May 14 as the date for her marriage to William Boardman Leonard, son of Mrs. William B. Leonard of Rumson, N. J., formerly of Albany, and the late Mr. Leonard. The ceremony will take place at Old Oaks, the Borden country place in Rumson, N. J.

The Real Estate Board of New York announced yesterday that it had approved a report of its mortgage committee advocating passage of the Joseph-Pack bills in the Legislature for the incorporation by the State of mortgage banks, privately owned but under the supervision of the State Banking Department.
"Awhile to Work," a philosophic comedy written and directed by Melchor G. Ferrer, '39, of New York, was enthusiastically received last night in Murray Theatre as the play opened a six-day run.

Something the Germans like to describe as "Homeric laughter" is ringing through the German press today at a revelation, which came out in London Wednesday, that the French and British Governments had had in their possession for the last six weeks a note from the Loyalist Spanish Government which was said to have offered them Spanish Morocco in return for military aid.

Holding an "open throttle" all the way except on the turns, S. Mortimer Auerbach of Miami and Atlantic City today sent his new Emancipator VI, which he launched only Wednesday, to a new world record for 135-cubic-inch hydroplanes today. He did 49.945 miles an hour in the first heat of the event at the twenty-fourth annual Biscayne Bay regatta.

The 51,000-ton liner Rex, the fifth largest ship in the world and flagship of the- .Italian Line, hit her West Forty-eighth Street pier yesterday afternoon while trying to move out of her slip against a strong up-river wind and a flood tide. No one was hurt.

In consideration of his work in the next five years and the expenditure of not less than $510,000, Waddill Catchings, director of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., has received an option to buy for $490,000 a 49 per cent share in a Warner Brothers subsidiary to be organized under his direction, according to a statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in testimony before the House Appropriations Committee, reiterated a recently expressed belief that European armament programs threaten a military catastrophe or an "almost inevitable" economic catastrophe "within a year or so" unless they are abandoned.
Mayor La Guardia intervened yesterday to end the sit-down strike disorders in stores operated here by the F. W. Woolworth Company and the H . L. Green Company.

Member round-lot trading for own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 20 amounted to 5,911,100 shares bought and sold, or 20.30 per cent of the total volume, compared with 5,791,303 shares, or 20.24 per cent, in the previous week, when there were only five trading days, according to the summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Secretary Perkins sought by personal efforts late last night and early this morning to resolve the deadlock in negotiations between the Chrysler Corporation and the strikers in its Detroit plants.
The police today raided the printing plant of the Communist organ Chase Operaria which was operated clandestinely with the aid of a powerful radio station, and arrested the staff.
Seminole, the first county to hold a Presidential preference primary for President Roosevelt in 1936, gave his Federal court reorganization plan a favorable vote today.
Prescott Bigelow has been elected a director of the Waldorf System, Inc., to succeed Arthur F. Ray. A. B. Hoppe, Adolph Radnitzer and Whitney S. Powers have been elected directors of Loft, Inc.

Milton Seymour Cohn, lawyer, died on Thursday night at his home, 575 Park Avenue, after a short illness. He was 40 years old. Mr. Cohn was admitted to the New York bar in 1918, and maintained offices at 60 Wall Street.

With championship matches scheduled for Squadron A and Squadron C Armories tonight, the officials of the Indoor Polo Association yesterday announced the addition of a new tourney to the title events which will bring the season to its close.

Mining developments in close succession have been responsible for the growth of the Standard Stock and Mining Exchange, now part of the Toronto Stock Exchange. The Rossland Rainy River enterprise in the closing years of the last century gave it its impetus, the Cobalt silver rush gave it prosperity and the Porcupine, Kirkland Lake, Quebec and Sudbury Basin discoveries gave it continental as well as Dominion importance.

Observing a tradition of the Feast of St. Joseph, patron saint of the Little Sisters of the Poor, an order founded in Brittany nearly a century ago, the Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of the Newark diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, donned a large white apron and helped serve the inmates of the order's home for the aged on South Eighth Street here today.

The Federal grand jury in Brooklyn handed to Judge Clarence G. Galston, in the United States District Court, yesterday an indictment charging William F. Marshall, former assistant cashier of the Kingsboro National Bank, 6,901 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, with embezzling $21,420 of the institution's funds.

At a meeting attended by several thousand employes of the I. R. T. Subway, held last night at the Hotel Center, 108 West Forty-third Street, it was resolved to send a telegram to Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the company, demanding a referendum on collective bargaining.

The resignation of Dr. Claude W. Munger as director of Grasslands Hospital was announced today by the Westchester County Depart. ment of Public Welfare. Dr. Munger, will leave May 15 and become director of St. Luke's Hospital in New York.

A number of country properties in Westchester and Putnam Counties and in Connecticut are reported sold by H. A. Veit, broker. Konrad Bercovici has sold five acres of his holdings at Lewisboro, Westchester, to Mrs. Ernest Landesmann.
Philip J. Eberhard, for fourteen years manager of the Bronx Branch of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company,- died yesterday afternoon at his home, 2,679 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx. Mr.

An Easter dawn service will take place on Sunday, March 28, at 7 A. M., on the steps of the Low Memorial Library, Columbia University. Arrangements have been made by the university committee and the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

The funeral for Dr. George H. Sherwood, honorary director of the American Museum of Natural History, who dropped dead of a heart attack in that institution Thursday night, will be held at 1:30 P. M. today at the Riverside Church. 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

The board of governors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today condemned sit-down strikes as interfering with the rights of others to work, and called upon the government for enforcement of the Law.
The cause of the explosion which wrecked the school here yesterday with huge loss of life may never be known. Formal inquiries, however, are already in progress or projected.
Stanley S. Holmes Village in Atlantio City, N. J., is the seventh Public Works Administration low-rent housing project to be completed, Administrator Harold L. Ickes said today.

New bond financing this week dwindled to $18,108,000 as a result of the postponement of a substantial volume of new loans eligible for marketing and compared with a total of $135,594,250 in new issues, featured by the flotation of $130,000,000 of Philadelphia Electric 3 1/2s, last week.
Ruter W. Springer, retired college professor and army chaplain and prominently identified with Boy Scout and Masonic activities, died here today after an illness of ten weeks. His age was 73.

The Seth Low Debate Council, representing Columl a University, defeated Dickinson College tonight in the affirmative side of the question: "Resolved, that Congress should be empowered to fix minimum wages and miximum hours for industry."
The decline in United States Government bonds was resumed yesterday over a broad front, eliminating, in most instances, most of the recovery made on Thursday.

Mrs. Nellie Rosenberg Meyer, a clerk in the advertising bookkeeping department of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died Thursday at the Park East Hospital after a short illness. Mrs. Meyer, who lived at 215 West Ninety-eighth Street, had been employed by THE TIMES since October, 1918. Her age was 38.

Colonel Jacob Ruppert tossed out the first ball at Plant Field today as the Yankees helped the Reds open their local exhibition stand, an inaugural that saw the world champions' winning streak tossed right into the discard.

Dr. Artur Rodzinski, guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, whose presentation of Strauss's "Elektra," at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night was acclaimed, will be honored this afternoon at the Ritz-Tower Hotel by the Polish Government.

It is too early for Republicans to commit themselves for or against endorsement of Mayor La Guardia, should the latter seek re-election, Chairman Kenneth F. Simpson of the New York County Republican Committee declared last night.

Rudolph Hecht, 56 years old, an investment broker said to be a nephew of the late Otto H. Kahn, was acquitted by a jury in General Sessions yesterday on a charge of grand larceny made by the Hunter Travel Bureau of East Orange,

Primrose House, Inc., of 400 Madison Avenue, New York dealers in cosmetics and toiletries, filed with the Federal Trade Commission today its answer to a complaint under the Robinson-Patman act in, which it denied discriminating between its customers, and also challenged the constitutionality of the act.

Miss Peggy Esberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Esberg, was married here tonight at the home of her parents to Henry Mosler Marx, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Marx of New York, Larchmont and Birmingham, Ala., by the Rev. Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott.

Miss Mary Adele Halsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Duffield Wrenn Halsey of this place, became the bride tonight of William Waverly Bell of Montclair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waverly James Bell of Bacon's Castle, Surrey County, Va. The ceremony. was performed in St. Luke's Church here by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Luke M. White. A. reception at the Halsey home followed.
Ruter W. Springer, retired college professor and army chaplain and prominently identified with Boy Scout and Masonic activities, died here today after an illness of ten weeks. His age was 73.

The Seth Low Debate Council, representing Columl a University, defeated Dickinson College tonight in the affirmative side of the question: "Resolved, that Congress should be empowered to fix minimum wages and miximum hours for industry."
The decline in United States Government bonds was resumed yesterday over a broad front, eliminating, in most instances, most of the recovery made on Thursday.

Many reservations have been made for the sixty-eighth annual luncheon on April 7 at the WaldorfAstoria of the Brooklyn Woman's Club, of which Mrs. Thomas Henry McClintock is president. A musicale will follow the luncheon, which is being arranged by Mrs. Joseph J. Kerby, Mrs. S. Earle Saylor and Mrs. Frederick W. Burbank.
James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, suggested tonight that sitdown strikes may be recognized ultimately as legal just as strikes have become legalized.

Union College students of fourteen fraternities were hosts last night and tonight to 250 young women guests at a series of house parties in celebration of the semiannual interfraternity week-end festivities, which open and close the Winter social season on the campus.

The Senior Dinner Dance for the Spring season organized by Miss Adeline King Robinson will take place on March 29 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Serving on the committee of sponsors, members of which will assist in receiving at the dance, are Mrs. James Lenox Banks Jr.,
Mrs. Vera L. Hayward of this borough has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Myra C. Hayward, to Fred W. Miebach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Miebach, also of Hawthorne.

Grief-stricken fathers and mothers of this great oil-producing countryside today buried most of the 400 children killed Thursday when the London Consolidated School was blown to dust by an explosion. Trucks, pick-up wagons and hearses bore the coffins over the unlit, winding roads from early morning to sundown. Seventy-five

Reports that the Argentine Grain Board was considering restricting exports of wheat as the result of fears of domestic scarcity turned North American markets sharply upward today, and while profit-taking caused a moderate recession from the best figures, closing trades in wheat futures on the Board of Trade were at net gains of 2 1/4 to 3 cents a bushel.
Members of the alumnae of the Katharine Gibbs School will give their annual Spring dance in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador on April 9 for the benefit of a scholarship fund.

THOUGH an evolutionary product, today falling little short of being a living thing in its powers of adaptability, the automobile does not make the adjustment from Winter to Spring without outside aid.

Motor-boat folks may rant and rave, argue and bicker with the sailormen most of the year in a natural but harmless sort of pride for their sport, but the record books ought to show, henceforth, at least one item of generosity and neighborliness. Girl Scouts are said to give out a bead for every good deed.

The Babbs Memorial School near this place, where thirty-seven children and parents died in a Christmas Eve fire in 1924, started a movement today to raise a relief fund in behalf of the New London school sufferers.

PROFESSOR VENTURI. whose most recent previous publication was the splendid catalogue raisonne of the oeuvre of Paul Cezanne. reports in this new work the completion of a historico-critical journey begun twenty-five years ago. This journey of research and appraisal was prompted, he tells us, by a desire to answer one "very simple question" Says Professor Venturi in his preface:

To the Art Editor: To clarify the position taken by the following artists' societies on the Mellon gift and the National Gallery of Art-the American Artists Congress, Inc., National Society of Mural Painters, An American Group, Inc.,
How about opening day? That's a question that many of New York's trout fishermen are beginning to turn over in their minds as they note the passing days on the calendar.

Two large signs, derisive of Jews, were painted across the facade of the orthodox synagogue Ahavas Achim at 175 Myrtle Avenue here early this morning. Lampblack was used to paint letters extending ten feet across the light-colored brick.
Walter Stillman, a member of the Board of Education for thirty years and many years its president, died at his home here this morning. He had been ill for several months. He was 69 years old.

Miss Josephine Hill, daughter of Commander Patrick Hill, U.S.N., and Mrs. Hill of this city, was married here this afternoon in St. Alban's Protestant Episcopal Church to Lieutenant Beverly Carter, U.S.N., son of Mrs. E. A. Carter of Washington and Jackson, Miss.

Mary Barry, brown mare owned by Mrs. Crompton Smith of Middleburg, was today adjudged the best of thirty-four hunters that galloped five miles across rolling country in three point-to-point races that furnished sport for a crowd of 2,000.

Three youths arrested as suspects in the strangling of Otto Schwecke, 50 years old, of Hamburg, Germany, an engineer for the Dollar Steamship Line, were held without bail for a hearing Thursday when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Leonard McGee in the Felony Court.

If any one still thinks Russians are not "different" he should read the piece in Izvestia of last Thursday by L. Sheinin, a prominent official in the Criminal Investigation Department, It is an incredible story which would make Dostoyevsky or Victor Hugo sick with envy.
The number of priests authorized to officiate has been variously fixed ??ocally in Mexico's States and terristories.

Twelve of this city's largest department and 5-and-10-cent stores were suddenly closed at 3:30 this afternoon and thousands of Easter shoppers and 5,000 employes were turned into the streets in a move to forestall what store owners said they feared might develop into a sitdown strike after a conference with officials of the Committee for Industrial Organization had ended in a deadlock.
Four American musicians who were beaten in Rome during the Ethiopian sanctions bitterness are to play Monday before the Rome Philharmonic Society.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lucas Forbes of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Catherine Forbes, to Thomas A. Hoctor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Hector, also of New Rochelle.
When the Locarno pact was signed in 1925, it was considered symbolic of a new era that not once in the negotiations had the words "allies" and "enemies" appeared.

QUEENS SPRUNG, JULIA (Nov. 18, 1936). Assets, $134,661 gross; $128,041 net. Stocks and bonds valued at $56,915 and $55,481 in cash and notes. To son, Harry J. Sprung, of 284 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, $1, "because I amply provided for him during my lifetime"; a son, Samuel Sprung, of 255 West 88th St., Manhattan, $20,681;

PALM BEACH, Fla.--With the Northern hegira only six weeks distant, members of the Town Council have been receiving the usual Spring flood of requests for the further beautification of Palm Beach during the Summer.

Miss Marguerite Ballantine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Ballantine, will give a tea on Tuesday at her home, 375 Park Avenue, for members of the dance committee for the Spring Dolphin Dance to be held March 31 in the ballroom of the Pierre.
In addition to the two cruisers already assigned to duty in Spanish waters the Netherland Government has instructed a submarine to cruise in the Strait of Gibraltar to protect Netherland ships.

An appeal to New York City Jews to raise the $1,860,000 set as their quota in the national campaign for $4,650,000 of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee for aid to overseas Jews was issued yesterday by the Greater New York honorary chairmen. They are Governor Lehman, Felix M. Warburg,

Frederic Burkhardt, assistant secretary of the Harlem Savings Bank of New York, in charge of the branch at 157th Street and Broadway, died here today at his home, 19 Ellsworth Avenue, of heart disease after an illness of several months at the age of 48.

Joseph M. Dillon, a patrolman attached to the 111th Precinct, Bayside, died suddenly early yesterday morning at his home, 199-02 Thirtysecond Avenue, Bayside. Earlier in the day he had returned home from a tour of duty.

Extending his winning streak to three straight and gaining much prestige as a candidate for the $5,000 added Tropical Special to be decided here closing day, H. W. Jackson's Par easily defeated five other ranking 3-year-olds in the one mile Royal Palm Handicap today.
Charles Dallas Reach, advertising man, has purchased a 150-year-old stone farmhouse and 70-acre farm at Erwina, Bucks County, Pa., from Dr. Collin Foulkrod of Phildelphia.

Announcement was made here of the death on Friday at his home in Hollidaysburg, Pa., of Alfred H. Bousfield, a former vice president of the Fairbanks Company, scale manufacturers, who had an office in New York from 1918 to 1924.

Declaring that sprinkler systems in hallways afford tenement dwellers inadequate protection against fire, the housing section of the Welfare Council of New York urged Governor Lehman, in a letter recently made public, to veto the Crawford Bill to permit the installation of such systems in hallways of

Dr. Harry F. Ward, Professor of Christian Ethics at the Union Theological Seminary and national chairman of the American League Against War and Fascism, opposed yesterday the Shepherd-Hill bill, now in Congress committee, on the ground that it would encourage fascism.

A witty Tokyo diplomat summed up his reaction to Foreign Minister Naotake Sato's "new - start in China" speech by saying a new start is not necessarily a new policy, nor does a change in method guarantee a change of heart. Yet a new start is implied in Mr. Sato's speech so different from the old it amounts to a new policy.
The Greenwich Woman's Club Gardeners will hold a meeting jointly with the Riverside Garden Club on Monday at the Masonic Temple. Mrs. Ethel A. S. Peckham will speak on "Iris in the Home Garden."

ST VALENTINE'S Day may be the time for American youths to court their sweethearts, but in Spezzano Albanese, Calabria, Palm Sunday -is the day. In this particular section of Southern Italy, however, that time is known as Daphne Sunday. On this day unattached young men and eligible bachelors are given the unusual opportunity to serenade their sweethearts in broad daylight.
The mortgage business is characterized as "unsafe and unsound" by the joint legislative committee investigating the business in this State. A report to the Legislature will be made tomorrow.

Fred A. Cauchois won the majority of the prizes at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. His most important victory was registered in the scratch shoot at 100 targets. He took the honors with a card of 99.
This town has hit upon a new wrinkle in economy. Instead of hiring printers to get out the annual town report, the selectmen furnished data and paper and left the job to the high school children.

While the hysteria generated by "sit-down strikes" versus "protection of property rights" and the "need of curbing activities of professional organizers to serve public convenience" may becloud the issues, the current epidemic of labor difficulties now manifest in the distribution field does not call for a "defeatist attitude" on the part of merchants, according to views expressed in retail circles here last week.

The present system of apartment renting in New York,. by which the majority of leases expire on a common date each year, is an inheritance from the period when construction of this type of housing was at its height,. John H. Meinke of Realty Associates Management, Inc.. told the apartment house

JON CORBINO is having two one-man shows in New York recent oils at the Macbeth Galleries , until April 5, and drawngs at the gallery of the Associated American Artists, 420 Madison Avenue, until March 23. Together these furnish a comprehensive report on this gifted artist's present Line of endeavor.

Former associates at the American Museum of Natural History, trustees, curators and friends attended funeral services for Dr. George Herbert Sherwood, honorary director of the museum, yesterday afternoon at Riverside Church, 122d Street and,Riverside Drive.

Completion of the first unit of the Chester Crest apartments at Fleetwood, between Mount Vernon and Bronxville, is announced for May 1. The project is one of the largest apartment-house operations that has been started in Westchester County for many years, the total cost being estimated at more than $1,500,000.

The four divisions of Rebels who attempted a drive on Madrid from the Northeast, reported to have been chiefly Italians, have been routed. For two days this army has fled in veritable panic before Spanish Leftist troops, which have been unable to make contact with them, despite a steady advance.

Eric Seelig, 158 1/2 European boxer, won on a technical knockout from Jackie Aldare, 166 1/4, Williamsburg, in 1:16 of the sixth session of the main bout of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove before 3,000 persons last night.

Brooklyn College and Hunter College defeated the girl fencers of the College of William and Mary today when the latter aggregation made its debut in intercollegiate competition. Both scores were 9 to 0.

The Naval Academy fencers closed their home schedule today with a double victory over Princeton, the varsity scoring by 17 1/2 to 9 1/2 and the plebes topping the visiting freshmen, 16 to 11. The local swordsmen will end their season in the intercollegiates at New York Friday and Saturday.

The engagement of Miss Mary Elizabeth McDonald, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milo F. McDonald of Rockville Center, L. I., to Raymond Joseph McCall, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John J. McCall of this city, has been announced by her parents.

SIAN, China.-Communism, has come to China to stay, in the opinion of Chou En-lai, vice chairman of the so-called "Chinese Soviet Government." "During the Sian crisis," he told the writer recently, "the gate of communism was opened and the Chinese Communist party had the opportunity to prove the falsity of many of the old charges against it. Now that the gate is wide, the Chinese Government can never close it."

Stuyvesant High School's strong fencing team continued as the unbeaten leader of Division 1 in the P. S. A. L. competition by scoring a decisive 7-2 success over Morris at the Washington Irving gymnasium yesterday morning. The triumph was the fourth for Stuyvesant.
The first performance of the figure-skating carnival at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service and the Carroll Club will be staged Saturday night.

Harold B. Butler, director of the International Labor Office, will arrive in New York tomorrow on the Queen Mary for the Conference of Textile Producing Nations that will open in Washington on April 2.

Whether the Mexican Government will amplify "collective" farming, Russian style, or resort to individual farming in connection with estates that are being divided among farm workers is likely to be decided by the government's succes or failure in the communal working of the Laguna cotton lands, seized this year from British owners.

A collection of 50,000 books for seamen has been set as the goal for the sixteenth annual Seamen's Book Week to be conducted by the American Merchant Marine Library Association in this city, April 5-12. A committee of thirty-two persons, under the chairmanship of C. H. C. Pearsall, president of the Columbian Steamship Company, will direct the collections, establishing receiving stations for the books at many centrally located places in the city.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -The coronation of King George VI in London in May will be celebrated in many parts of the British Empire. Plans have already been made for the ceremonies to be held in Bermuda, one of the oldest of the British overseas possessions.

The New York Women's League for Animals will be the beneficiary of a recital to be given by Elisabeth Rethberg and Friedrich Schorr of the Metropolitan Opera the afternoon of April 12 at the home of James Speyer, 1,058 Fifth Avenue. Both Miss Rethberg and Mr. Schorr have donated their services for the occasion.

Trenton High retained its national high school swimming championship in the Penn Athletic Club pool today, while three boys from Hibbing High of Minnesota turned in a new national scholastic 150-yard medley relay record and also finished second for team honors in the meet.

For more than a decade Chicago has been dissatisfied with the mechanism of its city government-the traditional Mayor-Council type. The Mayor is elected on a party ticket, together with certain other city officials. The Council, consisting of fifty Aldermen, is ostensibly elected on a nonpartisan ballot.

E. V. LUCAS is an ideal writer to fill in odd intervals and interludes between sessions with heavier and more verbose authors. He is to be recommended equally for the idle half hour or quarter hour, or for the peaceful evening spent by the fireside with armchair and slippers.

The Carolina Cup, which has become one of the most important fixtures in amateur racing will have its eighth running Saturday over the beautiful Springdale course at Camden, S. C. It promises to bring to the post one of the best fields that has ever contended for .the event.

The Oratorio Festival Society of Yonkers, numbering 100 voices, will sing "The Seven Last Words of Christ," by Dubois, on Tuesday evening at St. Andrew's Church here. Assisting artists will include Mme. Rose Manning, soprano soloist of St. Luke's Church, Philadelphia; Harry MacKnight, tenor soloist of the First Church, Christ Scientist, New York, and Harold Land, baritone

Hamilton House, an affiliate of the Henry Street Settlement founded by Miss Lillian D. Wald, will be the beneficiary of a theatre party the evening of April 15, for which the board of directors has taken over the performance of "Babes in Arms" at the Shubert Theatre. Mrs. Lester H. Weil is chairman of arrangements.

Included in the French rearmament plans of the immediate future are completion of border fortifications from Switzerland to the Flanders lowlands, creation of two more mechanized divisions, the manufacture of many new tanks, the addition

Governor James V. Allred today proclaimed tomorrow as a State day of mourning for the children who lost their lives in the New London school explosion. "This terrible tragedy," he said, "reached and horrified every home throughout the land.
HOBBYISTS who specialize in making architectural models are watching with great interest the building of a "miniature World's Fair" in the New York World's Fair offices in the Empire State Building.
Children in a gypsy camp here have collected $9 among themselves for the relief of victims of the New London schoolhouse disaster.

Dr. Franz Boas, anthropologist of Columbia University, challenged the wisdom yesterday of a "biological purge" and "sit-down reproductive strike" among ineffectual breeders recently advocated by a fellow-scidentist, Professor Earnest A. Hooton of Harvard, head of the American Society of Physical Anthropologists.

Real recovery in real estate, in the opinion of Robert H. Armstrong of the realty firm of Armstrong Armstrong and head of the New York Chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, is not likely to be fully realized until more funds are loaned than are being called in the mortgage market.

WITH South America beoming a year-round tourist mecca and with steamship service to its many ports steadily increasing, travelers are pushing into formerly inaccessible and strange outposts. The country's big cities offer metropolitan amusements, fine Spanish architecture, churches and art treasures, but there is much to be seen beyond the thickly populated centers. Mountain villages,

Miss Daisy Krey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Krey of 44 Palmetto Street, Brooklyn, will be married April 1 to Arthur Richardson. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Dr. Howard V. Ross in the Bushwick Methodist Episcopal Church.

With some of the ablest feminine speakers marshaled on either side, adherents and opponents of the Equal Rights Amendment are preparing to debate on protective legislation on three separate occasions this week.

The first lumber consignment from the Pacific Coast since the outbreak of the shipping strike more than five months ago recently arrived at Port Newark when four vessels brought in about 5,000,000 feet of Oregon fir.

Stocks eased slightly and closed irregular; turnover, 713,030 shares, second slowest trading for a Saturday this year. United States Government bonds contined to decline, reaching new low levels, other issues irregular; transactions, $10,960,000.

The War Department released the following orders today dated March 19: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Koehler, G. R., Inf., Ft. Slocum, N. Y., to Kansas City, Kan., for duty with organized reserves, May 1. McKnight, J. R., Med. Corps, promoted to Colonel.

Toscha Seidel, with Herbert Jaffe as pianist, gave a violin recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Seidel's program was a substantial one, and he gave evidence in performing it of his earnest atti tude toward masterpieces.

The Wholesale Dry Goods Institute is conducting a referendum among its members to determine their attitude to the Miller-Tydings Price Maintenance Bill now before Congress, it was learned here yesterday. The board of directors of the institute is reported to have gone on record in favor of the legislation but is awaiting an expression of opinion from its membership before making any public statement.

Japan's puppet territory of East Hopei has severed another of its few remaining bonds with China by launching a new currency system, aimed at driving out all the Chinese Government's national currency from the area.

FROM 150 to 200 glider pilots and a minimum of fifty gliders and sailplanes will be present at the eighth annual National Soaring Contest, Dr. Karl O. Lange, contest director, predicted last week as he made preliminary arrangements for the event. at Elmira. The meet, to be held from
Captain Archibald Pither, who demands his pipe Sunday and any other day, was notified today that he must pay a fine or go to jail for buying tobacco on Sunday.

Students and faculty of Wellesley College will unite Monday morning to pay homage to scholarship and to honor the sincerest among its devotees. The guest speaker will be Dr. George Lyman Kittredge, Harvard's professor emeritus of English Literature.

Cielito Lindo was the setting tonight for a dinner given by Mrs. James P. Donahue. Her house guests include Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Holmsen, Prince and Princess Chlodwig Hohenlohe-Schillingsfurst, who are on her yacht, Freedom; Sir Robert Throckmorton, James

ALBAUM--Rachel, wife of the late Tanchum Albaum and dear mother of Nathan, Sidney, Molly Friedman, Jennie Wiener, Ninette Gluck and Malna Burstone. Funeral Sunday, 10:30 A. M., from her late residence, 1,624 Carroll St., Brooklyn.

The Duke of Windsor is making preparations to travel southward from Enzesfeld Castle in the next few days, Assistant Director of Police Ludwig Weiser disclosed tonight. He. said the police were working on arrangements for an extended absence by the former King, who left his throne last year for the love of Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson.

Helmut Hirsch, officially described as a "Stateless Jew," has been sentenced to death by the People's Tribunal on charges of high treason and possessing explosives. The sentence was passed March 8 but was not announced until today. As is usual in such cases,

The Minister of Security, Baron Odo Neustaedter-Stuermer, has resigned, it is officially announced tonight, and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg himself is taking over the portfolio, with Vienna's police president, Michael Skubl, assisting him as State Secretary.

Completion of the organization of the City Fusion party in the Bronx by the appointment of leaders and co-leaders in each of the eight Assembly districts was announced yesterday by Everitt F. Britz, county chairman, at a meeting at the Concourse Plaza Hotel.

Communist activities are obviously increasing in the Third Reich. Perhaps the most startling evidence of this revival is the fact that promptly at 10 o'clock every night a secret radio station broadcasts Communist propaganda.

The Textile Workers Organization Committee of the C. I. O. announced today that early next week it would establish headquarters in Passaic to direct the organization of the thousands employed in the great textile area extending diagonally across the State from Paterson to the Trenton-Camden district. This is part of the national T. W. O. C. drive.

The six teams that survived the regular season of the National Hockey League, which comes to an end tonight, will embark on their several play-off series this week, with the Stanley Cup and the world championship as the big objective.
Jacob Gerling, prominent in Rochester's political arena for many years and an implacable foe of the voting machine, died at his home here today. He was 69 years old.

A series of teas is now being arranged for this Spring to foster interest in the MacDowell Colony for' creative artists in Peterborough, N. H. The first in the series will be given by Mrs. W. Bayard Cutting on Easter Tuesday, March 30, at her home, 24 East Seventy-second Street.

The marriage of Miss Katharine Allen of this city, daughter of the late Ethan Allen of New York and North Andover, Mass., to Richard Spofford Russell of Boston and New York, took place yesterday morning in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Federal, State and New York City governmental agencies will participate in the 1937 North American Homes Exposition in Madison Square Garden May 12 to 23, according to L. Porter Moore and Captain R. L. Purdon, directors of the show:

CHANGE OF HEART: On July 6, 1936, Mayor Clare W. H. Bangs of Huntington, Ind., went to jail for contempt of court. He had disobeyed an order to disconnect consumers from the municipal power plant. Last week he decided to permit the disconnection.
The members of the Footlight Juniors, founded by juveniles of the stage recently in imitation of The Lambs, probably will have their ice cream parties after all.

The new liberal arts curriculum which Brown University will introduce in September is expected to encourage independent achievement by high-ranking students under the university's revised honors plan, Professor William T. Hastings, adviser to honors students, said today.

A bus man's holiday landed Glenn Garren, a bus driver on the New York-Boston route, in jail here yesterday. Garren, according to the police, got in the driver's seat of Willard Parker Hospital ambulance which was parked outside Polyclinic Hospital on West Fiftieth Street.

SPRINGTIME in Scandinavia is a very beautiful season. Released from snow and the long dark nights of Winter, all nature seems to be in a hurry to grow and bloom as quickly as possible, to be ready for the long Summer days that are to come. Meanwhile the fjords of Norway, the farming lands of southern Sweden, Finland's 60,000 lakes,

Having no chairs for a sit-down, 150 girls and 25 stock boys staged a "fold-arms" strike today in four stores of the G. C. Murphy Company 5-and-10-cent chain, which operates 200 stores in Pennsylvania and the East.

Increased racial pride to the point of intolerance of others will be the result of the "dangerous tendency" of economic discrimination against the Negro, Dr. E. Franklin Frazier, Professor of Sociology at Howard University and director of the surveys by the Mayor's commission on Harlem, warned yesterday.

THREE years ago the city of Minneapolis went through what nearly amounted to a revolution. In fact, as Mr. Walker tells the story in this case study, an empire, already weakened by long-term economic forces, lost its grip when General Drivers Local 574-that is to say, the truck drivers-won their famous strikes.

Another name will be added to the list of scientists who have received the Mendel Medal, when Pere Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, paleontologist, receives the medal Monday night at a faculty dinner at Villanova College.

Chalmers Clifton, New York City director of the WPA Federal Music Project, has outlined the plans for the project's presentations of chamber operas at its new Theatre of Music, formerly the Gallo Theatre, at 254 West Fifty-fourth Street.

Thirty thoroughbred horses, including Equinox and Designate, two veterans of American race tracks, were endangered this afternoon when fire swept the main barn and stables on the George B. Widener estate in near by Whitemarsh.

Driggers Lady Mary, a pointer owned by Dr. B. F. Driggers of New Brunswick, N. J., took the spotlight today at the opening of the two-day Spring field trials of the Babylon Hunt Club held on the estate of Colonel Robert Guggenheim.

Facilities for industrial expansion in the Bronx will be materially improved, in the opinion of Roderick Stevens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade, with the construction of the proposed Bronx-Whitestone bridge, which will span the East River from the old Ferry

LISZT used to say one should always be careful about criticizing the music of nobility, because one could never tell who had written it. In the case of Count Franz Esterhazy's two-act comic opera "The Love Letter"which, after numerous delays and postponements, was produced recently at the Budapest Royal Opera against a background of glittering social manifestations-there is no need for such caution.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick WainConn., and Fishers Island, N. Y., announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Holcomb, to Frank Donald Stemp of Bournemouth, England, who is general manager of the Bermuda Railway Company. Miss Holcomb is the sister of Mrs. Pierre S. du Pont 3d of Wilmington, Del., the former Miss Jane Holcomb.

ALTHOUGH the authorities in the drama, music and art departments-not to forget that exclusive coterie devoted to the dance--enjoy pretending it is a normal aspect, we have been bothered by the hangdog look of the constant moviegoer these windy pre-Spring days.
A black flag, denoting a hunger strike, was hoisted over the American-financed Giesche mine near here today. Three thousand men were on strike, one-third of them underground.

Declaring that "education and poverty will not mix," Mayor La Guardia described the public schools yesterday as essential to the survival of democracy, and defended public expenditures to expand and improve education.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Charlotte Irving Noyes, daughter of Mrs. D. Grinnell Noyes of 1,120 Park Avenue and of C. Reinold Noyes of 53 East Sixty-sixth Street, to William Raymond Driver Jr., which will take place on the afternoon of April 9 in All Souls Unitarian Church.

CHARLES WILLIAMS, who is favorably known as a poet, dramatist and novelist, is also a competent literary critic, and in a recent address on modern poets and their work he has expressed some views that deserve attention. He believes that very few moments in English history have been so full of pure poetic energy as the present In the past it has often
NOT every program annotator can become, by conducting them, so familiar with the orchestral works he is explaining as Sir Donald Tovey, who conducts the orchestra in Edinburgh.

A large seminary to educate Mexican youths for the priesthood is to be established in buildings already obtained near Las Vegas, N. M., the National Catholic Welfare Conference announced today. The new institution is to be created and equipped by Catholic bishops of the United States. The Rev.

The annual Spring bridge party and tea of the New York-Long Island Chapter of the College of St. Elizabeth will be held at Sherry's on April 17. The proceeds will aid the scholarship fund. Miss Kathryn Fee is chairman of the benefit. Members of the various committees include Mrs. Edwin. Camson, Mrs. William Cashman, Mrs. Coleman Nichols, Mrs. Walter Kramer, Mrs. Vincent T. Reilly,

Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman of the State Mortgage Commission; William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, and Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, will speak at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Astor on Wednesday under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.

CONTINUING its series of exhibitions devoted to work done in various regions of America, the Whitney Museum now brings to the attention of the New York public a large group of paintings, water-colors and prints by Cleveland artists. This show will be current for a month.

Archie San Romani of the Emporia (Kan.) State Teachers College made another bid tonight to succeed Glenn Cunningham as America's ace miler by defeating Cunningham in the feature mile run of the fifth annual Butler relays. The time was a slow 4:21.4.

The Boerse was weak throughout the list today. German interest in the market remained almost completely inactive and the drop was attributed to foreign sales. Weakness was most noticeable in the heavy industrials, chemicals and other major groups involved in the armament and government construction booms.
A FEW close friends attended the funeral services of Charles A. Ellis, the first manager of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, last Wednesday in the Forest Hills Cemetery near Boston.

Although the native press is publishing the Britsh criticisms of Japan's refusal to define naval-gun calibers, the Diet and the larger newspapers ignore the subject. Admiral Mitsumasa Yonai, the Navy Minister, attended the session of the House of Representatives yesterday to answer questions, but the only ones asked referred to the navy's attitude during the Pakhoi and Chengtu incidents in China last year. The answers were given in camera.

The Child Study Association will hold a special program for fathers tomorrow evening at its headquarters, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street. A discussion of "Facts, Fads and Fallacies" will be held under the direction of Professor Lois Hayden Meek of Teachers College.

THE sixteenth International Exhibition of Water-Colors opened at the Art Institute of Chicago with a reception on Wednesday eve ning and will be current through May 16. The institute is contributing to the number of exhibitions circuited throughout the country. These groups are made up of selected subjects chosen from the important
Bloomfield won the Group 4 high school basketball championship of New Jersey by defeating Asbury Park, 30 to 24, before a capacity crowd of 3,600 in the Rutgers gym tonight.

Arturo Toscanini, the orchestra conductor, will celebrate his seventieth birthday here next Thursday by working out details for a radio orchestra under his three-year contract with the Radio Corporation of America. His concert series in the United States is scheduled to start in December.
THE theme of this romantic novel is the problem faced by a man and a girl in establishing a successful marriage with plenty of love to go on but with scarcely a point in common in their upbringing.

A phrase in Premier Benito Mussolini's speech Wednesday at Tripoli established very clearly the motives dictating Italy's policy not only in Europe but in Africa as well. Recalling the period of sanctions against Italy, he said:

School-wide elections have been held in thirty-five extracurricular organizations at Hunter College, it was announced yesterday. More than 150 girls will administer the affairs of department clubs, religious and athletic groups and class organizations during this semester.

The Rains Galleries will offer at auction on Wednesday evening prints from the collection of Mrs. Joseph Lilienthal. Included will be impressions of Rembrandt's portrait of Jan Lutmer, works of Frank W. Benson, Heitzelman, Blampied, Ernest Haskell, Frederick Briggs, Childe Hassam and others.

In the First Congregational Church on April 10, Miss Anne Benton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Benton of Pittsfield, will be married to William B. Hagyard, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Hagyard, also of Pittsfield. The Rev.

Miss Maude Beatrice Pfalzgraf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Pfalzgraf of this place, has chosen April 16 as the date of her marriage to Horace Darlington of Brookline, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hart Darlington, also of Maplewood. The ceremony will be performed here in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Francis H. Richey.

A group of women interested in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital will serve as patronesses for a dinner dance to be held in its behalf under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of the institution on April 13 in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. Mrs. Webster B.

Although graybeard professors harrumphed and class deans knit brows at Dickinson College yesterday, there came no denial of the discovery that gambling had once saved the college from an early death and enabled it to achieve the cloistered sobriety of which it is now proud.

Mrs. Evelyn Kennedy Oliphant, widow of Dr. Samuel Rutherford Oliphant of Mount Vernon, N. Y., died Friday at her sister's home at Lafayette, La., according to word received here yesterday by members of the Louisiana State Society in New York, of which she had been president for many years. Her age was 65.
Oil companies operating here and individuals throughout the nation rallied today to the relief of bereaved families in the New London disaster.

When the rugged State of Maine trembles, Harvard University wants to know something about it. It is establishing a seismograph station in the basement of the Portland home of Roger L. Arrington, at 211 Ocean Avenue, in that city.

With Holy Week at hand, the medieval brotherhoods of Seville are reviving the traditional processions which for centuries have been the most famous Holy Week ceremonies in Western Christendom. Nothing will be missing but the tourists.

After defying Governor Murphy to use the National Guard to eviet the 6,000 sit-down strikers occupying eight Chrysler plants here, Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, threatened tonight to call a strike Monday in all "organized" automobile plants in Detroit except General Motors' unless local authorities stop the forcible eviction of sit-downers in small atores and manufacturing plants.
Louis J. Drevers and his wife, Fern M. Drevers, of 40 Wall Street, New York City, asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to set aside a $47,013 income tax deficiency assessment for 1933.
IN comparing Canadian folkcrafts with those of our own Colonial times, the antiquarian who tours our neighboring country will note both similarities and differences.

The women whose figures are ample still should be able to wear a suit this Spring, since new girdles have been specially designed for wear with suits. Through new fabrics and the use of shaping done in the weaving, the girdles are dedared to confine the figure without binding it uncomfortably.

Exploiting the well-established theory that he who gets in the first blow invariably comes up with some sort of advantage, the Giants today put their condition par excellence on display for the edification of the Indians with telling effect.

For Senator COPELAND it must be said that he did his best to strengthen his Pure Food and Drug Bill to meet the President's objections, yet because of the powerful political and business interests by which he was opposed he fell far short of prescribing the kind of consumer protection that the original Tugwell bill was intended to afford.

FOR twenty years the Stracheys and the Guedal las have been summoning their eminent Victorians from oblivion. Into one compare hensive resurrection the Queen herself, the Prince Consort and the more conspicuous Prime Min isters of the period have been ushered by their gentlemen-biog raphers-in-waiting, and the pleas ures of paradise have been enhanced by a more mundane popularity in the United States.

Appearance of the fan dancer Sally Rand in a large St. Patrick's Day parade here evoked a protest today from Bishop Joseph Schrembs of the Cleveland Catholic Diocese. "I am deeply humiliated and ashamed that a parade to honor the patron saint of Ireland should have included an internationally known fan dancer whose performances on the stage have been so offensive to Catholics," The Catholic Universe Bulletin, official organ of the diocese, quoted the Bishop.

Speaking at the formal opening today of ten French galleries by the Pennsylvania Museum of Art, Georges Bonnet, the French Ambassador, appealed for the loan of "some of this artistic wealth collected here" for exhibition "even if only for a few weeks" in the Palace of Fine Arts during the Paris Exposition this year.

The trustees appointed to administer the $13,000,000 Series B-K mortgage certificate issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company have reported to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler that they believed they would be able to pay all certificate holders in full.

Nelson P. James, president of the James Rubber Company of Boston for the last ten years, died early today at the age of 48 at Phillips House following an operation. His home was in Newtonville. He began his career with the Firestone Tire and Rubber

Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Sauer of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor W. Sauer, to William C. Bagley Jr., son of Professor and Mrs. William C. Bagley of Teachers College, Columbia University, and Westport, Conn.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hosford Sutton of this place, announced tonight the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Margaret Sutton, to David Witman Mountford, son of Mrs. W. J. Mountford, also of Red Bank. The engagement was made known at a party at the Sutton residence.
The necessity for a State securities commission was declared here yesterday by Edward Weinfeld, counsel for the joint legislative committee that first met a month ago to consider the matter.

The former Cunard White Star liner Majestic, with a tonnage of 56,500, will soon sail from Southampton for Rosyth to become a training ship for 2,000 cadets. Captain William Binks will take the ship to the Clyde on what will probably be her last voyage.

THE bombshell that dropped into the bailiwicks of broad casting during the past week was tossed by Senator King of Utah. He hinted that the broadcasters were favoring the administration in allotting radio time to speakers discussing the pros and cons of President Roosevelt's proposal for reorganization of the judiciary and the Supreme Court.
The junior class of New York University's Washington Square College, Washington Square East, will hold its annual promenade next Saturday in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Plaza.
The capture of Brihuega on the Guadalajara front by the Spanish Loyalists received a big play in the Soviet press today as the second smashing blow to the "Italian expeditionary force."

The oldest electric trolley line in New England and the second oldest in the country will be permanently discontinued at 1 A. M. tomorrow, when the "Belt Line" trolley makes its final trip from Ansonia to Derby. Bus service will start at 7 A. M.

Having found that seniors often know little more than freshmen after completing a course and forget almost as rapidly as they learn, Skidmore College is giving to each of its students in the three upper classes review examinations in two of the five courses studied the previous year.

A transcript of secret hearings before the Senate Commerce Committee disclosed tonight that Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, accused a committee investigator of seeking to blame an innocent man for the

AMERICAN broadcasters will open their microphones early next Sunday morning to participate in Easter sunrise services. At 5 o'clock in the morning, Eastern standard time, the pontifical high mass in St. Peter's Cathedral, Rome, Italy, will be broadcast by the combined networks of WEAF-WJZ as far west as Chicago; also WABC's hook-up. Following the service, probably between 6 and 6:45 o'clock, the papal benediction is scheduled.

Elmira College students enjoyed a valuable educational experience today when radio station WESG in Elmira was turned over to them in entirety for the whole day from 7 o'clock in the morning until 7 in the evening.

Mr. and Mrs. Lovett L. Engley of 431 South Avenue will observe on Monday the sixty-fifth anniversary of their marriage. Mr. Engley, who was born in Ashland, Mass., celebrated on Tuesday the eighty-fifth anniversary of his birth. He has been a Mason for fifty years.

MANY years ago as a young actor on tour I made a journey across America. Film-making had hardly been born and I remember Los Angeles as a small haven in a fertile valley. What stayed with me most clearly, however, was the memory of the enormous grandeur of the Canadian scenery, the sweep of the pine forests, the huge teeth of the Rockies, reflected in the blue waters of mountain-rimmed lakes.

The skull of an ancient creature about 250,000 years old, which had the brain capacity of an ape and the teeth closely resembling those of a human being was presented today before the closing sessions of the International Symposium on Ancient Man, at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.

The extent to which the battle in Congress on the President's proposal affecting the Supreme Court may threaten adoption in the present session of comprehensive legislation covering the corporate trustee under indentures, protective committees in bond defaults and control of investment trusts is becoming a matter of considerable interest.
John F. Rolfe, publisher of The Hartford Times, died tonight at his home after an illness of two days. He was 57 years old. He was stricken Thursday evening with a heart attack.

Ben Ticknor, former all-American Harvard football center, and his partner, Richard Eckart of Englewood, N. J., were among the firstround victors in the doubles championship tournament of the American Paddle Tennis Association at the Fox Meadow Tennis Club today. Rain limited the day's program to four matches.

Five Duke University students from New York and vicinity had roles in the Duke Players' production of Mark Reed's "Petticoat Fever," presented on the campus last night. The production was directed by A. T. West.

Miss Lois Adeline Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russel S. Wise of this city, has' completed plans for her marriage 'on April '3 to Harrison Gray Otis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Gray Otis of Rutherford.
In the eight trading days ended yesterday noon values of United States Government long-term bonds underwent one of the sharpest downard readjustments in many years for a similar length of time

Many books and catalogs, covering thousands of plants suitable for rock gardens, have been published in England and the United States, but few of them make any mention of what evergreens and shrubs are advisable to use and how to use them.

The visits of vocational counselors at Wesleyan University have resuited in some fifty seniors receiving guidance in post commencement employment in business or industry. Last year, 55 per cent of the graduating class obtained Jobs in business, the remainder taking up graduate or other academic work.
Perkiomen School lost its final basketball game of the season today, bowing, 52 to 26, to a smoothworking championship outfit from Rutgers Prep, coached by Harry Rudy, former Perkiomen mentor.

Experience and maturity took precedence over collegiate fervor as the New York Rugby Club and the French Rugby Club turned back Long Island University and Princeton University, respectively, in a Rugby double-header at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday.

Thomas Conyngton of 174 Wildwood Avenue, co-founder, with his brother, Hugh R. Conyngton, of the Ronald Press of New York, which they operated from 1903 to 1920, died this morning at the home of his brother in Pasadena, Calif. His widow, the former Adelaide Brierly, also survives.

THE Copeland committee which investigated the crash near Kansas City in which Senator Bronson Cutting was killed has done a great deal more than turn in a report on the causes--as the committee members see them-of that accident. Senator Copeland made public his final report on the Senate floor last Wednesday. A study of it reveals,

A survey of the strike situation throughout the country, made by THE NEW YORK TIMES, emphasizes that Michigan, Illinois and Indiana constitute the major trouble-center. In the Detroit-Lansing area comparatively small groups of sitdown strikers have enforced idleness upon 90,500 workers in Chrysler, Hudson and Reo automobile plants.

A large subscription has been reported for the annual Easter card party and supper for the benefit' of the Catholic Young Women's Club the night of March 30 at Schrafft's in West Fifty-seventh Street. Miss Constance Armstrong is president of the organization.
The Misses Ruth Kieser and Marion Johnson gave a dinner party tonight at the Cherry Valley Club, before Miss Elsie Livingston Hepburn's holiday dance.

Miss Martha Elizabeth Dixon, who will be married on April 3 to Donald Adolph Korper of this place, has chosen as her matron of honor Mrs. Stirling W. Spafford of Wethersfield, and as her maid of honor Miss Charlotte Ann Korper, sister of the bridegroom.

A 35-year-old veteran, Charles Collins of Rye, turned in a fine performance today in defeating a field of younger contestants in the slalorn competition that marked the opening of the two-day tournament being sponsored by the Amateur Ski Club of New York and the Manchester (Vt.) Winter Sports Association.

Because the bearded students of Colgate's first psychology class, fifty years ago, studied for tests sitting on rail fences two Colgate upperclass men, John J. Head of Pittsfield. Mass., and Fred Van Horn Jr. of Westfield, N. J., pushed their way on skis over the snowy hills to one of the last rail fences near Hamilton for an examination review last week.

PERHAPS the most striking aspect of Great Britain's tremendous rearmament is the way it has been welcomed outside the Fascist countries. For Britain's growing power is looked upon as having far more than a national or imperial significance.

Count Jerzy Potocki, Polish Ambassador to the United States, decorated Dr. Arthur Rodzinski, guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, with the Polonia Restituta, highest order of merit of Poland apart from military honors, at a special ceremony yesterday in the Ritz Tower Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

Attacking the problem of the transition of the student from high school to college, difficult admittedly for both the student and the teacher, Yale has used both the psychological and educational approach and has achieved results from research and experience in both.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -Resort guests in the Poconos had had their first real taste of Winter sports during the past week, when 12 inches of snow blanketed the hills and trails of the mountains. Although no special program of entertainment was prepared, hundreds enjoyed the skiing and tobogganing. Many made special trips from the cities to enjoy the sports.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Lorillard, who have been at the Pierre, sailed yesterday to pass a fortnight in Nassau, Bahamas. They were accompanied by their son. L. Livingston Lorillard, and Francis E. House 3d. Constantin Fotitch, the Yugoslavian Minister, and Mrs. Fotitch have arrived at the Ritz-Carlton from Washington.
