Without being in the least cynical one may say that it is a necessity of the French temperament that there should be occasional bloodshed. For physical strife is a natural outcome of that passionate and obstinate division of this high-spirited, courageous people into Right and Left.
The Securities and Exchange Commission heard today that about 25 per cent of investors in the special investment plans of the Transcontinental Shares Corporation of Philadelphia, an investment trust,
Activity last week in the retirement of bonds before maturity was not visibly affected by the unsettlement of bond prices on the

Pickets barred company officials, including the president, C. L. Pierce, from admittance today to the shovel plant of Hubbard Co., where 800 men went on strike yesterday. Only two payroll clerks and two watchmen were allowed to pass through the picket line.

New fears were aroused among residents in the flooded fen district of the Isle of Ely, East Anglia, today when a crack forty yards long was discovered in the base of the east bank of the River Lark, a tributary of the Ouse.

Germany, like the rest of Europe, was interested this week in reports emanating from Washington that President Roosevelt was planning a new step, "pacification of the world through limitation of armaments and liberalization of world trade."
An audience of 3,500 persons last night attended the third free symphony concert in the series of four for the month of March under the direction of David Mannes at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Forty-two freshmen students sharing the Rodney dormitory on the University of Pennsylvania campus have been engaged since the opening of the academic year in September in an unusual program of living and study along self-government lines suggested by a senior dormitory adviser.

The smashing defeats which the enemy forces on the Guadalajara front have received and which were climaxed on Thursday with the recapture of Brihuega have removed to the indefinite future any possibility of Madrid's falling into Insurgent hands.

The Three Choir Festival, under the auspices of Congregation Emanu-El and devoted mainly to "early ritual, Gothic and old and new American music," came to a close yesterday morning in the synagogue proper of the temple. The third.and last session was part of the regular Saturday morning religious service.

Dr. Albert A. Lowenthal, specialist in mental diseases, died of a heart ailment yesterday in his home at 424 Melrose Street. He was 63 years old, a son of the late Dr. Louis Lowenthal, who was a physician in Chicago for fifty years.
The eighteenth annual show of the Cincinnati Kennel Club opened this morning in Music Hall with an entry of 635 dogs representing fiftyone breeds.

Opening of the- second annual New Jersey National Home Show yesterday in the 113th Infantry Armory, Newark, will bring an expansion of home-building and other residential activity in various parts of the State, and particularly within the metropolitan zone, according to officials of the Federal Housing Administration, who are cooperating in the program.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Salvage of Glen Head, L. I., today announced that their daughter, Miss Margaret Smith Salvage, would be married here on April 9 to James Potter Polk, son of Frank Lyon Polk, former Under-Secretary of State. and Mrs. Polk.

A new public high school in the Connecticut town of Hamden is completing a second year of experiment with an original marking system. The school is not just a new building; it is a new institution with a new staff and a new program. It has 1,250 students,

Chancellor John G. Bowman of the University of Pittsburgh called for an athletic policy against subsidization of athletes today following the resignation of W. Don Harrison as Pitt's athletic director.

Savings and loan associations now holding membership in the Federal Home Loan Bank System number 3,770 and have total assets of more than $3,300,000,000, as compared with 119 members and $217,000,000 in assets in December, 1932, according to Preston Delano, goververnor of the system.

Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Capps of Brooklyn and Bainbridge, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Dare Capps, to Paul Sanborn Batterson of Brooklyn Heights, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Samuel Batterson of Chicago.

Construction work on the $273,000,000 Delaware aqueduct project, designed to bring 540,000,000 gallons of water to New York City for its future needs, will be started Wednesday when Mayor La Guardia, in the presence of State and city officials, will fire the first blast of dynamite for sinking Shaft 3 at the town of Gardiner, in Ulster County.

General Miaja, commadner of the defenders of Madrid, announces that he has defeated Insurgent forces in the Guadalajara sector. He announces further that the Insurgents' forces consistd mostly of two Italina divisions, that all the prisoners took there were Italinas and that he saw few other opposing neighoborhood.

THE recent announcement of plans by Pan American Airways for establishing, possibly within six months, a passenger line from San Francisco via Honolulu to New Zealand foreshadows drastic revision in the habits of South Sea islanders who see in such plans the final collapse of their sublime detachment from the world.

MANHATTAN GOTTHELF, JENNIE L. (Feb. 21). Estate. less than $10,000. To Stanley A. Gotthelf, son, executor, 559 W. 186th St., two-thirds residue; Geoffrey M. Gotthelf, grandson, same address, one-third residue. DALY, ELLEN MARY (Feb. 5). Estate, more than $5,000. To Margaret Beaudin, sister, executrix, 228 W. 16th St., residue; John Daly. Dunmanway, Ireland, $1,000; Anna Carl, St. Paul's Hotel, 60th St. and Columbus Av., $1,000: seventeen minor bequests.

THE hour approaches midnight and the theatres of the Times Square district have sent their audiences swarming to the street. From the direction of Broadway and the thorough-fares that lead eastward from it come the commotion of restless traffic, the fulgurant blaze of electric signs and the glow of inviting doorways, through which the night clubs of New York are bidding their customers welcome.

The sudden development of the sit-down strike from endemic to epidemic followed the failure of Michigan authorities to enforce the eviction order against the General Motors strikers in Flint. This is chronologically a fact.

UNITED STATES JUNIOR SUPERVISOR OF GRAIN INSPECTION, $2,000 a year, Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Department of Agriculture, applications must be on file not later than the following dates-(a) April 12, 1937, if received from States other than those named in (b) below. (b) April 15, 1937, if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming.

THE fourth annual Bennington Festival will be held this year from July 2 to August 14 at Bennington, Vt., under the sponsorship of the Bennington School of the Dance, an autonomous unit of Bennington College, directed by Martha Hill and Mary Jo Shelley.

Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, and Mrs. Davis of this city, Stockbridge, Mass., and Washington, D. C., announced yesterday the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Christine Paschall Davis, to Robert W. Whiton Stuart of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. P. Whiton Stuart of Princeton, N. J.

The labor disputes of the nation echoed loudly last week in Washington, where the Supreme Court issue was dropping into the background as Congress debated the perils involved in the swift and contagious spread of sit-down strikes.

Arrangements have been completed for the Spring field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club to be given on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. April 1, 2 and 3, on the estate of R. R. M. Carpenter, owner of the noted Dilwyne Kennels of Chesapeake Bay does.

Speaking before the graduate students of the Department of Agricultural Economics and Farm Management of Cornell University last week, Charles M. Chuckrow, president of the Fred F. French Operators, Inc., declared that the real estate market of New York City was in the accumulation stage.

The banner of high scholarship for the first time within average memory flies over the men's fraternities at the University of Vermont as the result of relative fraternity computations based on the membership marks for the last semester.

Miss Margaret Woodworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur V. Woodworth of Boston, has completed plans for her marriage to Stuart Scott Jr., son of Mrs. Stuart Scott of 320 East Seventy-second Street and the late Mr. Scott, which will take place the afternoon of April 24 in the Emmanuel Church, Boston. The Very Rev. Henry Bradford Washburn and the Rev. Phillips E. Osgood will officiate.

Vassar students held their largest dancing party of the year tonight. More than a thousand persons, including escorts from many colleges, were present. Skits were presented between the dances, being scheduled under the title "Vassar as the Movies Would Do It."

The Treasury said today that international team work set a new record in world seizures of illicit narcotics this month. It reported that $500,000 worth of opium was taken by Treasury agents in New York harbor March 6 and that shortly afterward enforcement officers improved their operations "to the point where seizures were made by foreign police prior to shipment to this country."
ABOUT a dozen or more years ago I, dear diary, was entertaining away for dear life at a Summer retreat called Camp Topstone in Branchville, Conn. That was the Summer in which I died.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for April 8 on an application by the Illinois Power and Light Corporation of Monticello, Ill., a subsidiary of the North American Company, for an order authorizing it to charge against paid-in surplus resulting

To Teach Public Speaking Instruction in public speaking will be an added feature of the new class to be formed by the Realty Training Institute on Tuesday eve?? in the Engineers Society Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.
FLIERS SAIL FOR THE U. S.
" Dahlias are a man's flower," so the saying goes. Prime favorites among the women gardeners are the smaller-flowered dahlias that lend themselves well to indoor flower arrangements.

President Edward C. Elliott of Purdue University said today that "while sympathizing with Amelia Earhart in the unfortunate accident to her plane, we have faith in her ability and courage to continue the world trip."

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld the constitutionality of the Social Security Act, specifically its taxing provisions. The decision was unanimous in a three-judge tribunal composed of Senior Judge Rufus E. Foster and Associate Judges Samuel H. Sibley and Edwin R. Holmes.

United Air Lines officials announced tonight that Anatol Maren, 30, of San Francisco, had broken open an emergency exit window and leaped to death from one of their planes which left there at 7 o'clock tonight.

The Sunday Referee reported today that a suspected plot against the life of King George VI was being investigated by Scotland Yard following a raid on the room of an unnamed man where detectives found a throwing knife wrapped up with a map of the coronation route.

Child psychiatric patients at Bellevue Hospital, formerly regarded as "hopeless" cases, are gaining a new personality adjustment through school music activities, conducted by the Federal Music Project, Dr. Loretta Bender, head of the children's psychiatric ward, told educators last week.

HOLLYWOOD. CHARGES have been leveled on occasion that American interests use the screen for propaganda purposes. The accusations for the most part have been groundless or have been laid on such frail foundations as to be of no consequence.
THERE has been an amazing expansion of intercity bus travel. Last year 479,000,000 passengers journeyed by bus between cities in the United States, and today 29,000 intercity buses are in operation.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Whiteside of Westport, Conn., will give a dinner at the Pancoast Hotel tomorrow for their daughter, Miss Joan Dare Whiteside and the latter's friend, Miss Alice Bailey, who are here for the Easter holidays.

The second and last for this season of the Colony dances for debutantes of next Winter took place last night at the Ritz-Carlton. The party was attended by many young people who are at home for the Easter season.

At this stage of a Congressional session, members spend little time on the floor of either house. This year, more than ever before, practically all legislative activity is at a standstill awaiting action on President Roosevelt's court proposal. Thus an ordinary member of

Embarking on "the most novel experience of my life," Miss Helen Keller, whose life most people regard as a series of remarkable events, will leave New York on Thursday for Japan, where she will carry out a two months' speaking tour on behalf of the blind and the handicapped of the Orient.

DREAMY Key West ghostly city in the sea stirs sleepily, awaiting resurrection. Another year and a $3,600,000 causeway down the coral keys will bring the world to its door, end forever its slumbering isolation.

Visions of an orderly, regulated and perpetual calendar with an equal number of days in each quarter and fixed holidays give new inspiration to Miss Elisabeth Achelis as Easter approaches, for the movement which she is fostering for a revised twelve-months looks to the day when this festival will regularly occur on April 8, rather than be computed as the Sunday after the first full moon rises in Spring.
When President Lazaro Cardenas told foreign correspondents this week that there is "liberty" for religion in Mexico, he was doubtless sincere, if judgment is to be made on a comparative basis.

In behalf of the New York Osteopathic Clinic a Charity Ball will be held on April 26 at the WaldorfAstoria. A varied entertainment will be presented. The event has been arranged under the auspices of the Osteopathic Society of the City of New York and the Women's Auxiliary of that organization.

While the proposed Federal Sales Bill is an improvement upon the Uniform Sales Act, "in a number of particulars it needs amendment in the interest of accuracy, clarity and practical utility," a special committee of the Merchants Association of New York states in a report submitted to Congress recommending revisions in the new measure. The committee,

An extra mural division of Temple University has been established to carry educational opportunities to young men and women in localities not readily accessible to this city. The new division is designed to be a service unit which will bring the acedimic curricula of Temple's three undergraduate schools to educational centres which will be set up at strategic points in this and neighboring States.
Sit-down strikes continued to plague Chicago employers today, while new holes for peace in the taxicab drivers' walkout were raised by the union's attorney, Joseph M. Jacobs.

Dr. Clifford W. Sumner died at his home here last night after suffering a stroke. He was 62 years old. Born in Pownal, Vt., Dr. Sumner was graduated from Albany Medical College. Although a lifelong Democrat, was thrice elected to the Washington County Board of Supervisors from a normally Republican township.

The Young Men's Board of Trade of New York has adopted a resolution condemning President Roosevelt's proposals to reorganize the Supreme Court and to enlarge the personnel of the lower Federal courts, it was announced yesterday. The vote was 145 to 29.

Fourteen years ago Dr. Rafael Ernesto Lopez, then a twenty-sevenyear-old American-trained Venezuelan surgeon, was forced to flee Venezuela because of his efforts to free his native land from the dictatorship of the late Juan Vincente Gomez, at that time President of Venezuela.

The ship which crashed yesterday and terminated the attempt of Miss Amelia Earhart to fly around the world at its maximum practical circumference was one of the most complete thus far built in the United States. It was designed for

THIS is to be music and pageant year in Germany. Having exhausted athletics last year, the Reich has gone back to its old stand-by tourist attractions to fill out a program that is certainly elaborate enough to suit any one with a taste for melody or the history-come-to-life sort of thing.
Buddhist priests said prayers today for the souls of departed cats, dogs, monkeys, rabbits, goldfish and even singing crickets.

Final plans for Alumni Day at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on June 7, announced here today, call for a national conference on housing, at which the economic and social significance of housing, including new methods of design, new materials and the prospects of prefabrication, will be discussed.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey asked Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday to hold night sessions in the restaurant-racket trial during the coming week so that the tase might be given to the jury by Wednesday afternoon.

There are 103 nominations for the sixty-third Kentucky Derby, to be run May 8 at Churchill Downs, Louisville, according to an announcement from M. J. Winn, who restored the mile-and-a-quarter test to its former value of $50,000 added this year. The entries number one more than 1936, which was the smallest since 1922.

Members of the board of directors of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work, of which Mrs. Robert C. Ream is president, will hold their annual meeting tomorrow at the headquarters of the organization, 541 Madison Avenue, to complete plans for the first intensive membership drive of the organization in many years.

THIS is a miscellany of old and new Huxleyana of vatrying merit. It has one of his very best essays on one of the best of possible subjectsthe essay that Peter Davies, the publisher, used for his admirable edition of Haydon's "Autobiography and Memoirs" in 1926.
Fencers of the Riverdale Country Day School captured both the individual and team championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools yesterday on the strips of the Salle d'Armes Vince.

The three old-law tenement houses at 1,971-1,975 Second Avenue, between 101st and 102d Streets, owned by the Excelsior Savings Bank, have recently been remodeled by providing four suites of three rooms on each floor, all equipped with modern sanitary facilities, steam heat and electric refrigeration from plans by the architect, J. M.. Berlinger.
Mrs. Joseph F. Dempsey of 84 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, will open her home for the forty-sixth annual meeting of the Brooklyn Free Kindergarten Society on the afternoon of April 19.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla.-More than 50,000 persons are expected to attend the tenth annual Easter sunrise servce which will be held on the ocean front next Sunday.

Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth R. Cunningham of Pittsburgh and Williamsburg, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth, to John H. Peterson of this city, son of Mrs. William Remsen of New York and Monroe, Conn., and John L. Peterson of New York.
THE Academy of Sciences of Philadelphia, one of our oldest scientific institutions, celebrated its 125th anniversary last week by holding a congress of leading European and American anthropologists.

Several promising plays are now rehearsing and should soon prove to be bright additions to the London stage. Rehearsals have just started for Emlyn. Williams's "He Was Born Gay," wherein John Gielgud has been joined in the cast by Gwen Ffrangcon-Davies and Carol Goodner, with the author playing a small but important part in the last act.

The fifteen-story apartment house at 108-112 West Ninety-sixth Street, fronting 75 feet, near Columbus Avenue, will be sold at auction under foreclosure proceedings in the Vesey Street rooms tomorrow by Henry Brady.

THIS is Spain behind today's headlines before it was smashed under the gun-butts. It shows you Madrid with a King on the throne and the tide of desperation rising, when a few of today's Madrilenos were unborn and many of them were unkilled, when the thinkers talked and the workers waited, when young Spaniards got a friend up as a donkey and followed him down Alcala shouting: "Good-day. Mr. Minister,

A somewhat capricious Winter ended officially at 7:45 o'clock last night and along with the arrival of Spring new names sprang into the select circle of leaders in the thirty-seventh annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress during its eleventh session at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

The "supermen" who directed recent reforms in city government are not always inspired by the desire to save the taxpayer's money and to promote efficiency, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx declared last night at the thirteenth annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx, in the Hotel Commodore.
Irish casualties in the Spanish civil war total nine killed and three wounded. Seven of the nine men killed were fighting for the Madrid government in the international column.

The decision of the Supreme Court in the Brush case, in which the majority held exempt the salary of an engineer of the Bureau of Water Supply of New York City "necessarily contributes little toward certainty in approaching the. innumerable immunity problems" that the Internal Revenue Bureau must decide, Morrison Shaffroth, chief counsel for the bureau, told the tax committee of the American Bar Association today.

Revision of many State laws governing building and loan associations in the interest of standardizing such legislation nationally is vital to the construction and financing of new homes in the United States, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
More youths are attending agricultural colleges in the Middle West today than ever before, but authorities differ in their opinions as to the aims of students.

Virginio Gayda today denounces in the Giornale d'Italia the "system of chronic slander" against Italian policies and cites President Roosevelt's public references to fascism as an example of the campaign he says is being waged by democracies to create an atmosphere of hostility around Italy.

CONTINUING the good work so many wish might be extended to others of the restricted subscription series, Victor now puts into general circulation what in England was the first volume of the Sibelius Society sets. In chronological order of

Several charitable organizations and individuals came to the aid yesterday of 16-year-old Antoinette Atoria, who was arrested last Monday night in Brooklyn for begging, and as a result a new home probably will be found for the child and her family and a fund raised for their support.

With textile stocks at the lowest point in many years and, in some cases, on record, and with the industry at present operating at peak capacity, any prolonged shutdown of important producers from strikes would create a serious shortage of goods in primary channels, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

Navy, defending champion, again won premier honors by leading a field of fifteen teams in the regional small-bore rifle match today with a score of 1,397 out of a possible 1,500. George Washington University was second with 1,363 points.

Those who will serve as chairmen of the committee for the charitable organizations taking part in the twenty-third annual Rittenhouse flower market to be held in Ritten.house Square on May 20 will include Mrs. Henry S. Jeanes, Presbyterian Hospital, assisted by Mrs. Clarence Brinton; Mrs. Albin G.

More than 250 secondary school students from New Jersey, New York, Delaware, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia and New England States have been invited by Rutgers University to attend its Preparatory School week-end on April 30 and May 1, Stanley R. March, alumni field secretary, announced today.

Four new scholarships, valued at $800 each, have been established by Manhattan College. Announcement of the grants, which will cover full tuition for four years, was made yesterday by Alfred D. Donovan, registrar. The scholarships will be awarded on the basis of competitive examinations to be held in June at the college and various Christian Brothers secondary schools throughout the East.

Enforcement of the provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law and prohibition of rent increases to tenants of buildings which have been altered to comply with the law amounts to virtual confiscation of the properties, according to a recent letter of the Bronx Borough Taxpayers League to Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx.

Harry Vardon, generally regarded as one of the greatest of all golfers, died at his home in Totteridge, Hertfordshire, today of pleurisy at the age of 66. He had suffered from chest trouble for many years.

A cabaret dance will be given by the Junior Club of the Women's Town Improvement Association of Westport, Conn., on April 3 at the Shorehaven Golf Club, South Norwalk, for the benefit of the Emily B. Fuller Scholarship Fund.

After being knocked by one automobile into the path of another and then caught on the rear bumper of a taxicab and dragged 250 feet, Mary Kosowitz, 25 years old, of 760 Home Street, the Bronx, was taken to Morrisania Hospital last night with concussion of the brain and other injuries. Her condition is serious.

Another of Governor Lehman's program bills will have its day next week before the Assembly, where the Democrats are shy a majority and the Republicans, with one seat vacant at present, also are lacking one.

New light has been shed on the early middle ages by excavations at the former Church of St. Martin at Angers, France, it was revealed today by Professor George H. Forsyth Jr., '23, of the Department of Art and Archaeology of Princeton University.

John J. Breslin Jr., prosecutor in Bergen County, N. J., said yesterlay that the failure of the New Jersrey Legislature to pass an act extending the terms of grand juries would prevent him from submitting evidencee to the present Bergen County Grand Jury in connection with the murder of R. Norman Redwood, sand-hog union leader.

AS the Bohemian Crown is set with beautiful jewels, so the lands formerly belonging to it are studded with castles replete with memories of stirring historical events. Throughout Bohemia and Moravia these landmarks abound and lend peculiar distinction to the surrounding landscape. Slovakia too, for 1,000 years under the crown of St. Stephen. boasts many relics
THE Rand is an abbreviation of Witwatersrand, which is the Boer equivalent of the Ridge of White Waters, and it is hard to thing of a pleasanter sounding name.

Over the red clay roads of Georgia drives a little brown touring car with its top down. A big man in a loose gray suit is at the wheel. The car stops beside the first tee of the Warm Springs Foundation golf course while the big man chaffs a foursome about to drive off.

The 1924 play, "Fashion," was revived by the Studio Workshop Players of Greenwich tonight with a performance in the studio, known as The Barn, under the direction of Mrs. Mary Hill-Brown, who was assisted by Ralph Chamberlain. The settings were designed by Ronald Allwork, the lighting effects by Cleveland Webster and the costumes by Martha Van Prague. A large audience was present.

Disturbed over Spanish Loyalist sympathies expressed yesterday by General Carlos Hevia, a former President of Cuba, at a luncheon symposium on "The Spanish Crisis," Ogden H. Hammond, United States Ambassador to Spain from 1925 to 1929, arose in vigorous defense of the Insurgents.

Ridgaway Merryman, for many years active in the lumber trade and former president of the Baltimore lumber exchange, died suddenly yesterday at his home at the age of 77. He was born in Baltimore, the son of Joseph P. and Martha Gray Merryman.

Reconstruction of the brownstone house at 27 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, was started last week under a plan proposed by the Brooklyn Better Housing Committee to stimulate the use of many of Brooklyn's old homes by modernization.

J. P. Blanco, supervisor of English instruction in the Department of Education, is regarded as a strong contender for the appointment as Commissioner of Education, heading the Puerto Rican public school system.

Miss Dorothy Mae Glover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Glover of Williston Park, L. I., was married last night to Robert Stephen Bell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Bell of Bloomingburg, N. Y. The Rev. Talman Bookhout performed the ceremony in the East Williston Community Church.

Mrs. George Nelson of Englewood, N. J., entertained with a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for her son-in-law and daughter, Count and Countess Nikolai von Keller, who celebrated the first anniversary of their marriage. Among the other guests were Prince and Princess Cyril Toumansky, Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Luke, Ramon Verchovsky and Allan Luke of Roanoke, Va.
The Bucknell University men's debating teams will leave Tuesday on a Midwestern tour of 2,000 miles, in which they will meet representatives of sixteen colleges and universities.

Goaded by a barrage of muddy snowballs, mounted police this evening rode down on several hundred persons at the scene of a sit-down eviction, swung night sticks hard and often and injured several men. While the crowd shrank, huddling on doorsteps, more than 150 patrolmen and plainclothes men swept through the four-story plant of the Bernard Schwartz Tobacco Corporation, just across the street, closed a month by the strike.

The military inquiry into the explosion which destroyed the London Consolidated School Thursday with huge loss of life brought out as it got under way today that economy in the construction of the school may have been a factor in the disaster.

The war of words which has been proceeding between Nazis and their critics in this country has directed attention to Nazi activities in the United States. The chief Nazi organization in this country, the German-American League, is led by Fritz Kuhn, a chemist on leave from the Ford automobile works in Detroit.

MELODIOUS voices re-echo from the past and forgotten treasures are discovered anew when the magic needle whirls about on the round, black disk that has become an Aladdin's lamp for those who collect phonograph records as a hobby.

The marriage of Miss Rosemond O'Reilly, daughter of Mrs. Henry M. O'Reilly of this place, to Job Herbet Lippincott Jr., son of the former New Jersey Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, and Mrs. Lippincott of Short Hills, will take place at the bride-elect's home on March 29. The Rev. Michael J. Glennon, pastor of St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Churhc, Summit, will perform the ceremony, which will be followed by a reception.

With all but one of its components increasing, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended March 13 advanced to 106.9 from 106.7 (revised). It was 92.4 for the week ended March 14, 1936.

A busy season is expected in Nassau, British West Indies, where considerable activity including building and improvement of property, is reported as being under way. James E. McDonald of New York and Lake George, managing director of the British Colonial Hotel, announces a number of improvements and additions to the Henry. L. Doherty properties.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Verner F. Davis of West Orange, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vera A. Davis, to Miller Franklin Naylor, son of Dr. and Mrs. Wallace F. Naylor of Somerville, N. J.
Mrs. George Russell Talcott has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Mary Bell Archer, to John Aydelotte Mapp of Accomac and Richmond. The wedding will take place in June.
A number of the big intercoastal and round-the-world passenger liners are at last catching up with their schedules, which were so badly disrupted by the maritime strikes over the year-end.

The Crescent Athletic Club soccer team gained its twentieth consecutive victory of the season at Metropolitan Oval in Brooklyn yesterday, defeating the German-Hungarians, 3-2. The losers had a 2-0 lead at half-time.

History has become an increasingly popular subject with the students at Barnard College, due to the growing importance and complexity of international affairs, according to Charlotte T. Muret of the Barnard history department.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals refused today to permit William A. Brady of New York, theatrical producer, to appeal against the confirmation of the reorganization plan of the Baldwin Locomotive Works by the Federal District Court here on Feb. 4.
American sugar refiners asked Congress today to prohibit importation of refined sugar from Cuba by limiting the Cuban quota to the raw product.

Indications that diphtheria will be more prevalent this year than in the last six years has caused the Department of Health to launch an intensive immunization campaign in several sections of the city, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday.
Buoyant spirits and good health outweigh Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser's deep concern over the state of the nation as she brings to an end the first year of her second century.

When the privilege afforded business corporations of filing consolidated returns was abolished with the enactment of the Revenue Act of 1934, the Congress evidently intended that the Commissioner of Internal Revenue should continue to have the right to consolidate in whole or in part the accounts of affiliated or controlled business corporations.
A one-story garage will replace the two five-story tenement houses at 289-291 Tenth Avenue, the sale of which by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank was announced yesterday.

The newspaper Pravda's leading editorial today is a savage blast against the Communist party and government leaders in Southern regions, where the Spring sowing had reached only about 1,750,000 acres by March 15, as compared with 10,000,000 on the same date of last year.

Governor Earle's administration will propose next week that all Pennsylvania workers be given a five-day, forty-hour week. Bills have been prepared by the Department of Labor and Industry for presentation in the Legislature Monday.

To bridge the gap between the work of the individual departments at City College. a faculty committee has completed the first stage in a program of departmental cooperation by outlining the project in an exhibit in the Lincoln Corridor of the main building.

Justice Ferdinand Pecora of the Supreme Court of New York today injected the sit-down strike issue into the Senate Judiciary Committee's hearings on President Roosevelt's bill to reorganize the judiciary. Mr. Pecora urged the committee that it "never forget that sit-down strikes in defiance of law originated in the lofty seats of high finance before the technique was merely copied by working men and women."

LAST week it became evident that Easter trade must close with a decided rush if earlier forecasts of the increase over a year ago are to be approximated. Various sections of the country reported a definite lag in trade for the season and blamed it variously on unsettled weather conditions, strikes or threatened strikes and Federal income tax payments. For the country as a whole,

Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, delivered an address last week at the semi-centennial celebration of the Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway and 122d Street, urging the necessity of learning, "not only for religious leaders but for all who influence public opinion."
The debates in Congress over neutrality and other aspects of the country's foreign relations have served to turn much national attention outward, away from immediate domestic problems.
Mexican cavalry went into action today, and three men were killed and thirteen wounded as the Mexican Government pushed its campaign against banditry in the State of Jalisco.

If and when any Irish government has the temerity to end the sweepstakes, it will create something akin to a national crisis, since running sweeps has become one of the Free State's most important industries.

Juliette Gordon Low, dynamic daughter of this tranquil Southern city, has been dead for ten years and two months. But the expanding fame of her personality and her accomplishments, coupled with the current silver jubilee of the Girl Scouts, which organization she founded in America, lures a consistently regular quota of pilgrims to her old home on Lafayette Square here.
FLUSHED with the success of a Winter sports season that filled its hotels as in predepression days, Switzerland is preparing a varied program to keep tourists coming the rest of the year.

Committees for the Butterfly Ball dinner dance to be held on April 9 at the Ritz-Carlton are now meeting weekly to further arrangements for this party, which is given each Spring under the auspices of the junior auxiliary of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers, a hospital for the treatment of men, women and children afflicted with pulmonary tuberculosis.

" Let us have peace!" This exhortation, expressing a wistful longing not only for peace but for the progress that peace makes possible, typifies the dominant campus feeling as the University of Wisconsin anxiously awaits the arrival of its new president, Clarence Addison Dykstra, City Manager of Cincinnati.

Students at Connecticut College are assisting faculty research in several fields. In addition to the small independent projects in which they engage for honors, many help in the more comprehensive problems upon which the faculty are working.

SIX hundred miles from here a little band of New Zealanders has founded the newest dependency of Britain and the smallest colony in the empire. The colony is on Sunday Island, a fertile subtropical territory twenty miles in circumference, whose crest is 1,600 feet above the sea.

The Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania sailed at 2:20 P. M. yesterday for California via Cuba and Colon with. 480 passengers after being delayed at Pier 60, North River, for two hours and twenty minutes by a strike in the engine room department.

The robin has long fooled the public in his ro1e as a harbinger of Spring. As a matter of fact, he hangs around New York and vicinity all Winter, and throughout cold weather this fellow with the - red breast can be seen on Long Island and even in Connecticut.

The appropriation of about $12,500,000 annually as a subsidy to keep rents at or under the $6 per Room level as provided for in the Wagner-Steagall bill for low-rent housing, is called a definite departure from all former policies of making grants toward capital construction charges to achieve the $6 per month rate by H. I. Feldman, New York architect.

Seniors at the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance have chosen Professor William S. Schlauch as the most popular professor for the fourth successive year, it was announced yesterday as the result of the annual senior questionnaire conducted by The Violet, undergraduate yearbook. Professor Schlauch is a member of the Accounting Department.

Having seen its "New Deal" program blocked by its Supreme Court, Canada now is continuing the political paralled with affairs in the United States by debating the need of constitutional changes. Here, however,

Turpentine firm, 38 3/4c; sales, 65 barrels; receipts, 47 barrels; shipments, 30 barrels; stock, 20,107 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 342; receipts, 641; shipments. 378; stock, 47,499.
