Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 17 aggregated $10,927,000,000, or 21 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 7 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

A buying mood and a lively interest in the latest New York fashions was reported by a group of models who returned yesterday from a three week tour of the United States under the directions of Harold Heimerdinger, merchandise director of Carolyn Modes, Manhattan designers of women's clothes.

The marriage of Miss Corinne Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Stewart of this place, to Edward Clinton Wadsworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Clinton Wadsworth of Glen Rock, took place at noon today at the Stewart home. The Rev. Arthur M. Hughes, pastor of the West Side Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony.

The tapestries, carpets, period furniture and other decorations sold yesterday at the American Art Association realized $21,497, bringing the total for the two-day sale up to $35,289. The goods included property of the late Mrs. Hugh A. Murray, who was killed in an automobile crash in December, 1931, and whose husband, killed at the same time, was a member of the New York Stock Exchange; property of Mrs. Alfred

A voluntary petition in bankruptcy was filed in Federal Court yesterday by Roger Q. Williams, New York-to-Rome flier, who placed his liabilities at $4,979, and said he had no assets. Most of his debts were for legal services and rent.
RADIO performers corssed the finish line of Winter with comedians ahead in the race for popularity. At least that is what the latest survey conducted by telephone in thirty-three cities revelaed.

The Washington District Council of the powerful Federation of the Pacific announced tonight it would withdraw from the American Federation of Labor and join John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization.

Two new sweet-scented marigolds (one of which is said to have come from Tibet, though all knownmarigolds are of the New World), interesting new advances in zinnias, and the new showy early flowering dahlias-which may be had in bloom for Easter-all remind us of the importance of Mexico as the mother of many of our best garden plants.

BILOXI, Miss. WE have stopped for the night in a tall, white pillared mansion less than forty feet off the beach. At first we were a bit awed by the gleaming white corridors, wide enough to turn a ten-ton truck in, but we registered and followed the lady of the house up a wide staircase piled with flowered carpet; into a cavernous white room.

PERIL: "Isolation and neutrality are dangerous concepts if they blind us to the fundamental fact that modern war is as contagious as the plague and that war industries are as interdependent as peace industries."-Dr. James T. Shotwell.
Franchise tax laws, transfer tax laws and the laws of human nature, that same human nature which always has wanted as much as possible for as little as possible, are

Several hundred young women from colleges throughout the East were guests last night of Brown University students at the Brown Interfraternity Ball, which was held in the ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel here. It was the first interfraternity dance ever given here.
The year-old son of Mrs. Charlton Shell, young Spartanburg, S. C., widow, was found dead and his mother semi-conscious in the bathtub of a hotel room here late today.
Changes in the law governing the surtax on undistributed corporate earnings will be sought by the Merchants Association at this session of Congress.

Installation of sprinkler systems, provided in the Crawford bill now before Governor Lehman for signature, as an alternative for owners of old-law tenements to the fireretarding provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law, will enable many owners to comply with one section of the law, according to the Brooklyn Real Estate Board and the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities.

The demands of President Quezon of the Philippines, that the date of final independence for the islands be moved up from 1946 to 1938 or 1939, were laid before the President today by Paul V. McNutt, former Governor of Indiana, who will start next week to take up his duties as High Commissioner to the Philipappoint a special committee of expines.

THE pleasure lands of Centra Europe-Austria, above all whose scenic beauties the world is beginning to know well, then Czechoslovakia, in reality little behind Austria in this re spect but much less known because she has somehow become labeled "industrially properous but linguis tically unpronounceable,"

Disregarding Spring's official arrival, only a few hours off, Bernard Hansson of the Telemark Ski Club proclaimed today that a ski jump would be held tomorrow under "ideal" conditions. Hansson said more than a foot of snow covered the mountain ski course used by the club at nearby Rosendale.

IT is not without some apprehension that one opens a new volume by Leon Trotsky. He has written so many books! In connection with the recent trials in Moscow his views on the Soviet Union have received so much newspaper publicity that there would seem to be little that has remained unsaid.

SINCE the Little Theatre movement is, in the opinion of many observers, the last hope of the spoken drama, it is rather a pity that the production of an original play by a group of amateurs should be stopped by the murder of one of the principal players However, that is the situation that Mr.

ABOUT a week ago a large tour1st agency announced a coronation cruise aboard one of the big transatlantic ships. The sale of reservations began at 9 o'clock in the morning. By 4 o'clock that afternoon the ship was booked solid from waterline to A deck, with a waiting list of applicants ready to step in if cancellations occurred.

WHEN the traveler on returning from South America is asked the almost inevitable question. "What do the Latin Americans think of us?" he is at a loss. It makes a difference whether the questioner refers to the political ro business leaders. to the plain people or the wealthy. for as a matter of fact most people in Latin America think little

Five hundred former students and friends, through representatives, conveyed greetings and felicitations yesterday to Dr. I. David Cohen, principal of the Brooklyn Boys' Vocational School, at a testimonial luncheon at the Commodore Hotel, which marked his completion of twenty years of work in vocational guidance, a field in which he is a pioneer.

A group of enthusiastic young men, including several college graduates, will sail out of Boston Harbor some time in June, bound on a unique roundthe-world cruise. It will take them over twelve seas to five continents and to more than 150 ports.

The Archbishop of Canterbury feeling, as he said, that "some voice of remonstrance should publicly be raised in the name not of Christianity only but of the common instincts of humanity" in the House of Lords this week assailed the Italians for the recent massacres at Addis Ababa.

It will be a year next month since the Civilian Anti-Gas School at Falfield, Gloucestershire, received its first pupils. In that time more than 800 persons, physicians, members of the Red Cross Society, employes of local authorities, and so on, have taken a fortnight course in studying various noxious gases and the means of purifying affected clothing and districts.

A special performance of "Die Meistersinger," with Elisabeth Rethberg, Doris Doe, Rene Maison and Friedrich Schorr in the leading roles, the night of March 30 at the Metropolitan Opera House has been taken over to raise funds for the German American Charities, Inc.

The Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company has offered employes a week's vacation with pay this Summer in addition to a 10 per cent wage increase, according to Harold Griffiths, president of the local Federation of Carpet and Rug Hopes Workers.

In spite of an almost general rise in food costs, New York housewives will find in the market this week certain fresh products that have either stayed pegged at a reasonable level or have actually dropped in price.

Moscow. THIS promises to be a banner year for travel to the Soviet Union. Following the 40 per cent increase in tourists reported in 1936 by the American representatives of the travel company of the U.S.S.R., a further increase--this time 30 per cent-is looked for in 1937.

Intercollegiate sport picks up the thread of the oldest tradition it has in the world on Wednesday of this week when England sees the University Boat Race. On that day, over the famous stretch of the ancient Thames from Putney to Mortlake-four and a half miles-the eight-oared shells of Cambridge and Oxford race each other in their annual meeting.

OF the many myths and legends surrounding the artificial creation of life, none has been more enduring than that of the Golem, which originated in the tortured, twisted ghetto of medieval Prague. Its archaic charm has persisted for three hundred years or more, and even Gustav Meyrink, an authority on the lore of the period, says in his novel,

With aspirations to sing at the World's Fair of 1939, several hundred of the city's civil service employes have formed the City of New York Civil Service Choral Society, it was announced yesterday. Rehearsals, to be held at Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and East Sixteenth Street, will start next Tuesday evening.

American Steel Foundries, Chicago, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 217,083 shares of no-par value common stock and common stock purchase warrants.
AFTER the Prix Goncourt, three novel prizes, the Prix Femina, the Prix Renandot and the Prix Interallie, have been awarded respectively to Mme. Louise Hervieu M. Aragon and M. Rene Laporte.

The presence of the King and Queen as guests of the Earl and Countess of Derby at Aintree brought larger crowds than usual to see the Grand National. The Duke of Westminster's party numbered forty. Miss Dorothy Paget, owner of Golden Miller, brought twelve guests, Sir Malcolm McAlpine, Lord Melchett and the Earl of Lindsay also entertained parties.
The Mexican Federation of Educational Workers, "in the name of 50,000 Mexican school teachers," sent to the Governor of Texas a telegram in condolence of the school house disaster in his State.

The ethics of the sit-down strike, and its potentialities, are everywhere a cause of concern and debate. When workers take possession of a corporation's plants and offices and deny even the executives access to files and desks, the challenge to personal and property rights becomes a cause of alarm.

Wrestlers from Oklahoma A. and M. College captured four of the eight championships in the final round of the national collegiate wrestling tournament in the Indiana gymnasium tonight and appeared a certain winner of the team title.

An effort to remove the dangers of politics from the election to the leading campus office, the presidency of the Student Government Association, as carried out by the students at Pembroke College in Brown University, has resulted in a plan which has proved successful in two annual elections.

AMONG the many Hungarian artists visiting Italy nowadays one of the best equipped was Gyorgy Pasman, a young pianist from Budapest, heard at the Milan Conservatory. Pazman combines Magyar fire with a virtuoso mechanism that carries off his audiences, especially in Liszt. But he is a musician none the less. He was also appreciated in items of his teacher, Dohnanyi, and in a spirited piece of his own, styled "Ecstasy."

The New York University fencing team ended its dual meet -season with an impressive 21-6 victory over City College yesterday on its home strips at Washington Square. City, offering the victors unexpected resistance in the foils, was routed in the epee and saber.

Receipt of a telegram from the Hospital Conference of the City of New York endorsing the steps taken by the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn to end the recent sit-down strike there was announced yesterday by Max Abelman, secretary to Nathan S. Jonas, president of the Brooklyn institution.

Willoughby House, of which Mrs. William B. Greenman is president, will hold its annual meeting and an informal reception tomorrow night at the settlement, 97 Lawrence Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. Sanford Bates, executive director of the Boys Clubs of America, will speak on "Boy's Clubs-The Democratic Method."

ALL about the Theatre Guild, being chiefly notes of the future: 1. Maxwell Anderson, now automobiling around the South, has three plays in mind, one of them a comedy, all modern in theme and setting and all in verse.

Pi Alpha Chi, Syracuse University's "poor man's fraternity," this week celebrated its first anniversary. Founded by eleven juniors for students financially unable to join other Greek letter societies, Pi Alpha Chi in one year has recruitted thirty-seven members, acquired a house on the campus and attained the highest fraternity scholastic record ever held at Syracuse.

The heads of thirteen banks in this city, as well as several State and national financial officers, are among the 600 persons who thus far have made reservations for the convention cruise of the New York State Bankers Association to Bermuda next Memorial Day weekend, it was announced yesterday by Raymond N. Ball, president of the association.

To the Radio Editor: Of the many factors in the rapid pace of our modern civilization that contribute to ill health, probably unnecessary noise is one of the most serious. Great improvements have been made toward eliminating unnecessary street noises. But the noises in the closely packed dwellings of our cities are even more serious and far-reaching in their consequences.

LONDON.-In the most extensive work of reconstruction since the Great Fire, whole areas of friendly old London are taking on a new aspect. Already many of those once delightful backwaters off Piccadilly have disappeared to become mere automobile driveways to huge blocks of modern apartment houses.

The controversy between protectionists and foreign traders over the necessity for curtailing competitive imports of manufactured goods flared out again here last week after a six-month period of quiet. As a result, both sides began making plans for nation-wide appeals to consumers to support their respective standards.
West Point graduates in all parts of the country and in several foreign lands gathered at dinners last night to celebrate the 135th anniversary of the founding of the United States Military Academy.

A GLACIER tore loose from its moorings in Alaska recently and threatened to push a roadhouse and a section of a highway into oblivion. Few people who read of the occurrence knew what a glacier looked like.

The ten-story structure, known as the Park East Hospital at 112-114 East Eighty-third Street, on a plot 50.7 by 102.2 feet, will be sold at auction under foreclosure tomorrow in the Vesey Street rooms by Edwin J. McDonald.

The annual Spring bridge party of the Battle Pass Chapter, D. A. R., of which Mrs. George Monroe Aldrich is regent, will be held on April 3, in the Brooklyn Edison Building. Mrs. Fred E. Haskins is chairman of the bridge, which will aid the educational, patriotic and charitable work of the chapter.

Under the auspices of the executive board of the Brooklyn Home for Children, 141 South Third Street, Brooklyn, a benefit bridge will be held on the afternoon of April 7 at the Flatbush Reformed Protestant Dutch Church.

The Greenwich House Music School will be aided by a concert to be given by members of the Greenwhich String Orchestra, under the direction of Enrique Caroselli, tonight in the auditorium of Greenwich House, 37 Barrow Street. Persons well known in the social, musical and educational worlds are among the subscribers of the benefit.

President Roosevelt might well have restated this week his oft-repeated recovery slogan: "The only thing we have to fear is fear." His administrative officials, and probably he himself, were disturbed by the ghost of inflation which again came out of hiding and stalked across the national scene. Commodity prices were sky-rocketing.

Viewing native culture in America as "neither crude nor fragmentary," but "neglected," Professor Thomas Ritchie Adam of Occidental College, Los Angeles, warned yesterday that "an educational elite is very dangerous" and that leaders in adult education should start from the premise that "the people know what they want."

Now that the big Spring flower shows-with record-breaking attendance reported everywhere in the country-have drawn to a close, hundreds of thousands of amateur gardeners are turning again to the problems and the opportunities which await them at home.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee, unit of the Lewis C. I. O., began tonight a drive to organize the workers in the "Big Five" independent steel producers. Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, carried the fight to the heart of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation at a mass meeting in Bethlehem, Pa.

Young Morton Cooper was wild and ineffective, yielding four runs in the tenth inning to give the Senators an 8-4 victory over the Cardinals in an exhibition game today. The Columbus recruit issued two walks, hit a batter, made a wild pitch and permitted two hits to turn the close game into a rout.

IF the present trend continues, 1937 will be a record-breaking tourist year for France and this Summer Paris expects to welcome thousands of travelers from across the Atlantic. Advance hotel reservations for the months of May to September indicate as much; also reports from New York that the Summer bookings for North Atlantic sailings are encouraging."

Numerous sales of "electrical kitchens" as units for installations in new and remodeled houses in recent weeks has prompted the promotional committees of the Edison Electric Institute and the National Electrical Manufacturers' Association to revise plans for the current year. The committees,
IN "Saltwater Farm" Rober P. Tristram Cuffin, who has came before us with that rousting novel fo Maine ship building and skipper folk.

The unusual happened in the final judging of the eighteenth annual show of the Kennel Club of Atlantic City in the Auditorium tonight when Dr. Henry Jarrett of Chestnut Hill, Pa., awarded the highest honors to a toy dog.

The concept that there is a valuable source of usefulness in most mentally backward children and adults, which can and should be developed if society is to fulfill its duty to all its members, was discussed yesterday at a conference of more than 100 workers in the fields of medical, psychological, eductional and social service.

Two new high records for production of base metals in Canada were- established in December, according to official figures released this week. Production of nickel reached a record of 18,011,386 pounds, a gain of approximately 3,000,000 pounds, or about 20 per cent, over production in November.

Pope Pius XI, joyous for having been spared for still another Easter week, began today his Palm Sunday celebrations of Christ's triumphant entry into Jerusalem. Fresh palm leaves decorated every Roman balcony in commemoration of the day, and the Pope received the traditional Easter gift that has marked the opening of the festive season for almost 400 years.

FOR the seventh season artists of the Metropolitan Opera are reading the mail to discover what the unseen audience far outside the Golden Horseshoe thinks of them and the Saturday matinees, broadcast from coast to coast.

Two prominent Cleveland brothers, sons of a Lutheran minister, who moved to this city from Missouri in 1851, died early today. The brothers are the Rev. Paul F. Schwan, 86 years old, founder and pastor emeritus of St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church, and Judge George H. Schwan, 78 years old, lawyer here for fifty-eight years and formerly Common Pleas Court judge.

Five juniors were tapped this week for admission to the Rutgers chapter of Tau Beta Pi, national honorary engineering society. They are Benjamin Lazansky of Freehold, Thomas B. Woersching of Somerville, David J. Campbell of Highland Park, Dean Milliken of Wilmington, Del., and Willard Van Nostrand of Highland Park.

C. W. Phillips, Olympic gymnast from Temple University, was successful in his defense of two individual titles today at Dartmouth and added a third crown to his laurels in the annual Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League championships.

Plans for a new men's residence at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy are nearly complete, Dean Halford L. Hoskins stated today. It will be erected on land adjoining the site of the first dormitory, the George Grafton Wilson House, and will add twelve single rooms and two double suites to the housing facilities of the school. In addition, it will contain a large living room, recreation rooms and a typing room.

Gounod's "Faust" was offered for the third and last time of the current season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. An audience, which filled every available seat in the Broadway house and included rows of standees, heartily applauded the performance.

Governor Quinn will send to the Legislature Tuesday a set of acts increasing the size of the State Supreme Court from five to seven members. The measure would also abolish the Superior Court, substitute a circult court system,

IN the headquarters of four governments, within a fortnight, whenever I have put a question on some vital point of foreign policy, I have been shown or referred to a map. In Prague, discussing the prospects of war as they appear from that strategic capital.

Henry Ford said today that reports he had heard that he planned to shut down his plants in the event of a strike were "absolutely untrue." "I have heard reports that I said we would shut down for three years if necessary, in the event of a strike," Mr. Ford said in an authorized interview at his Winter home here.

The Dollar liner President Wilson due here on April 15 will be the first of the company's round-theworld vessels to come here since the entire fleet of more than a score of ships was brought to a halt by the maritime strike in December. The last world ship to dock in

WITH plans for the territorial series of stamps commemorating Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Hawaii and Alaska well advanced, the Postoffice Deapartment is now giving thought to another group of major interest to philatelists--a new series honoring each of the Presidents of the Okla. United States up to and including Calvin Coolidge, twenty-nine in all, though the ordinary denominations number only twenty-six.

Robert Crawford, baritone, was not in the best of vocal trim at his recital in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, and therefore, less successful in controlling his tones than at his appearance in the same auditorium last season. His work was sincere and conscientious and all his interpretations were carefully planned and earnestly projected.
Music Hall of the Air presents a symphony orchestra directed by Erno Rapee; soloists are Dana Suesse, pianist-composer, and Edwina Eustis, contralto: WJZ, 12:801:30 P. M.

Secretary Ickes announced today that only families unable to secure adequate housing in private dwellings would be admitted to Atlantic City's new low-cost housing project. Mr. Ickes announced regulations governing the selection of families for the Stanley Holmes slum-clearance project to accommodate 277 families. He said the average rent would be $17.18 a month and that already 1,121 families had applied for living quarters.

AS Spring advances, the low frequency end of the short wave spectrum is likely to become somewhat noisy, and listeners equipped with receivers which will tune very high frequenCies may be tempted to go "adventuring" now and then in the staticiless regions near 10 meters, where signals are few and far between.
In 1920 there were 643,630 registered Republican voters in New York City, 47 per cent of the city's total of voters. The Democratic registration was 531,167. John F. Hylan, a Democrat, was Mayor.

Both as exporter and producer of apples the United States leads the world, according to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. On an average, during the five-year period from 1931-35 American growers contributed 31 per cent of the world apple production of 500,000,000 bushels. Throughout the world, according to estimates of Federal experts, there are about 450,000,000 apple trees. One-fourth of these will be found in the United States.

Miss Amelia Earhart's round-the-world flight came to a sudden and sensational end here at dawn today. When speeding down the runway of Luke Field for Howland Island the right tire of the twin-engined plane blew out. The $80,000 "flying laboratory" swerved and turned almost completely around before coming to a grinding stop on its belly.

Contracts totaling nearly $2,000,000 for construction of the Thousand Islands international bridges across the St. Lawrence River were awarded today by the Thousand Island Bridge Authority. Winners of the contracts and amount of each follow:
AN Infallible sign of the approach of Spring is the increased activity in dealers' catalogues. So intense has the barrage become this season that the ambitious reader of them would find it

The civil war in Spain has caused the Library of Congress to suspend indefinitely its exploration of archives at Seville for source-material on American history, thus shutting off one of the important centers of research.

Discovery of a "false fireplace" by workmen wrecking an old house on the Wilmington-Xenia road lent renewed credence today to countless stories of days before the Civil War, when thousands of Negro slaves escaped into Canada over the "underground railroad." The "U. G.," as it often was called, was neither underground nor a railroad, but it did have "depots," such as the cubicle behind the fireplace in the ancient house near here.

An extensive progressive education experiment begun in this city a year ago has proved successful, and will continue five more years, according to Dr. John J. Loftus, assistant superintendent of schools in charge of the program.

Citing some of his reasons in favor of the Rogers-Rapp Bill, now before the Legislature, providing an amendment to the State Constitution to limit taxes on real estate and restrict the debt- incurring powers of municipalities, Herman A. Acker, president of the Real

A SYSTEMATIC discussion of Proust and Santayana in a single volume is very attractive fare; and it must therefore be said, not necessarily in disparagement of Dr. Ames's book but in justice to prospective readers, that its title and subtitle ought to have been Interchanged.

Frank A. Vanderlip, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, criticized the President's Supreme Court reorganization proposal at a fraternity banquet here last night. "If the three branches of our government are to be likened to three horses who must pull together, then it was never expected that one of the horses would jump on the seat

A suit for divorce was filed today against the Count of Covadonga, the former Prince of Asturias and heir to the Spanish throne, by his Cuban commoner wife, the former Edelmira Sampedro. She alleged voluntary and continuous desertion from March 28, 1936. She made no demand for alimony.

Exceeding any previous event of its kind in the size of the display area and the number of companies exhibiting; the Seventh Packaging Exposition will open on Tuesday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, under the sponsorship of the American Management Association. In connection with the exposition, which will close on Friday, there will be conferences and clinics on three days.
A few remarks by Senator ASHURST the other day set the mind to spinning fanciful pictures. We close our eyes and see members

A revamped team took international rugby honors to England today. Registering their third victory in the series, the Englishmen defeated Scotland, 6-3, for their first triumph north of the border since 1923 and retained the Calcutta Cup, fought for annually by the two countries.

Fletcher D. Mallin, dean of Lake County politicians and member of the Lake County Democratic Executive Committee for fifty-four years, died of pneumonia at his home here today. His age was 75. Until he retired ten years ago he had operated a lumber yard here.

After again expressing his determination to make Floyd Bennett Field the air mail terminus for New York, Mayor La Guardia pressed a button at 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning and set off a dynamite charge which brought down, like a mighty tree, a brick chimney near the seaplane ramp on the south edge of the field. More than 1,000 persons attended the ceremonies.

Seventy-one persons-most of them girls-who engaged in a sitdown strike at the Simplicity Pattern Company plant at Niles in violation of a court injunction were convicted of contempt late today by Circuit Judge Fremont Evans.
INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER has opened a new company branch in New York City, eighth in the metropolitan district, on the easterly block front of Eleventh Avenue from Forty-first to Fortysecond Street.

Miss Elizabeth Kompa, former national 220-yard back-stroke champion. captured the New York State A. A. U. women's 100-yard backstroke laurels in the feature event of an A. A. U. swimming meet last night at the Central Y. M. C. A. in Brooklyn.
As it checked in today. the vernal equinox didn't miss Clearwater and neither did the Phillies. For if Spring comes, can the Phils be far behind? One answer to that is, not more than six runs.

Mrs. Mary Higgs of Oldham, Lancashire, whose life was devoted to social work, particularly on behalf of friendless tramps, died yesterday at the age of 83. In the last honors list she was received into the Order of the British Empire.

The annual Easter party for one hundred of the children cared for by Silver Cross Day Nursery will be held on Thursday afternoon at the nursery, 247 East 117th Street, under the auspices of the junior auxiliary. Games and a treasure hunt, followed by a special holiday dinner will be features. Voluntary contributions of Easter bunnies,

The First Company of the old Seventh Regiment presented a gala entertainment last night in the regimental armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street as a means to raise funds for the relief of families left destitute by the Midwestern floods.

THIS unusual novel. unusual in the sense that it is unlike the run of serious contemporary junior novels, is the story, from the outside (not autobiographical , of a boy and young man touched with that unearthly quality of feeling and seeing that we call genus.

WHILE thousands of Margaret Mitchell's readers have been offering casting suggestions to Selznick International for the film version of "Gone With the Wind," David O. Selznick has been quietly selecting his own cast. Its principals have been chosen and they include Miriam Hopkins as Scarlett O'Hara, Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, Janet Gaynor as Melanie

DOWN here, beyond the farthest reaches of the subway, where Spring arrives early and the only sit-down strikes are those conducted in beach chairs and rolling chairs, events are moving rapidly toward the opening of a season which local seers and
Wage increases amounting to 10 per cent were granted to 7,500 workers in the Wilmerding and Swissvale plants by the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and Union Switch and Signal Company today.

The Wood Memorial, chief event at the Jamaica meeting which will open the metropolitan racing season, has an entry of fifty-three thoroughbreds, including Matey, winner of the Pimlico Futurity, who was not named for the Kentucky Derby. The mile-and-seventy-yard
IN his easay on child play Stevenson comments on the fact that a child's natural impulse is to act out the events of a story, when he "comes

Several charities will benefit by an Easter sale of blouses, hats and accessories to be held tomorrow at the Bargain Box, a permanent Thrift Shop at Third Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street. They include the Henry Street Settlement, the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, the New York Eye and Ear Hospital, Lincoln Hospital, the New York Infirmary for Women and Children and the Metropolitan Hospital.

THE Bethlehem Bach Choir will present its thirtieth Bach Festival Friday and Saturday, May 28 and 29, in the Packer Memorial Chapel of Lehigh University, Bethlehem, Pa. According to the yearly custom since the inception of the festivals, the choir will present the Mass in B minor in its complete form. Bruce Carey, director, also has selected six cantatas for performance, several of which are new at these events.

An entertainment to be known as a "Twilight Tea Dance" will be held April 7 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for the benefit of the West Sixty-third Street Community House, formerly the Riverside Day Nursery. The enterprises of the organization include a prekindergarten class for children from 2 to 5 years of age and classes in sewing, music, art and cooking.

Holders of stock of the Lion Oil Refining Company of record of March 26 will receive rights to subscribe to 4 1/2 per cent sinkingfund debentures due in 1952 and convertible until March 31, 1942, unless previously redeemed, the Curb Exchange has been notified.

Antiprice cutting provisions of the liquor industry's code under the old NRA, to which some distillers and liquor merchants have adhered, were cited as a defense against price-fixing charges of the Federal Trade Commission in answers filed today by Hiram Walker, Inc., and Gooderham Worts, Ltd., both of Detroit.

Something new in style revues the "Fashion-Show-Your-Own" has been arranged for the afternoon of April 8 at the Delmonico for the benefit of Irvington House Thrift Shop. The admission fee to the benefit will be a package of useful articles, clothing, books, bric-abrac or household furnishings suitable for resale later at the organization's shop at 716 Third Avenue.

THE American Bridge League conducts three special tournaments annually for those who have won its "master points" by winning other tournaments of the league. The masters' contests for individuals and for teams of four will take place at the Park Central Hotel the week of April 5.

Mail requisitions in the New York wholesale market were quite heavy in the beginning of last week, but declined considerably toward the end of the period, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers.
The non-intervention committee will meet Monday to consider further details of the international blockade to halt the flow of arms and volunteers to Spain.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wesley Cushman of Winnetka, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Curtis Cushman, to Stuart Wilder Wells Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Wilder Wells of Minneapolis and Wayzata, Minn.

Nineteen industrial workers and farmers, who have completed a sixmonth course in labor history, journalism, economics, public speaking, consumers' cooperation and drama, were graduated from Brookwood Labor College today. Tucker P. Smith, director of the college, presided at the fifteenth annual commencement exercises.

New York City is empowered to erect a new building covering two blocks, housing the criminal courts and a new city prison and replacing the present structures, under the terms of the Murray bill signed today by Governor Leh. an.

Since it's a long lane that has no turning, Gene Venzke won his first mile race of the season in his last indoor try last night as the onetime world-record holder glided to victory in the eight-furlong test that featured the annual Metropolitan A. A. U. championships at the 102d Engineers armory.

Members of the New York Alumnae Association of Rosemont College will give their annual bridge tea on April 3 in the Garden of the Ambassador to augment the building fund for a new chapel at the college.
A contract for 1,700,000 pesos more in munitions of war has just been made between the Spanish Embassy here and the Mexican Government. It was formally endorsed at a

Two hundred and fifty children and grown-ups brushed joyfully past specially deputized court officers today to the side of King, 4-year-old Belgian shepherd dog, when Justice of the Peace Hamilton Hicks acquitted the pet of a charge that he was vicious and had bitten an 8year-old boy on the playground of the King Street School during afternoon recess March 11.

Miss Annette Jeanne Bauer, daughter of Mrs. George Jackson Byrnes of 201 West Seventy-ninth Street, was married to Donald Kennedy Keith, son of Alexander J. Keith of Eau Claire, Wis., yesterday noon in St. Agnes Chapel by the Rev. Dr. William W. Bellinger, the vicar.
As a prelude to the intercollegiate fencing championships of next week-end, fifteen freshmen from six colleges competed for the Clemens Medals at the Fencers Club last night.

Eugene Deardorff of St. Louis, whose fate it seemed to be always a ruuner-up and never a champion, finally won the national amateur three-cushion billiard title tonight by defeating Al Primeau, the champion, in a challenge match.
Mrs. Elizabeth C. Buck of Green Spring Valley, Baltimore, and Major Lawrence I. J. Barrett, U. S. A., on luty with the students Reserve

The marriage of Miss Miriam Bodine Fielding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Trumbower Fielding of this city, to Robert Otto Bieling, son of Mrs. Frieda B. Bieling of Roselle, N. J., took place this afternoon in the First-Park Baptist Church here. The Rev. Dr. Walter J. Swaffield, former pastor of the Park Avenue Baptist Church, performed the ceremony.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Charles Mayer of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjory Mayer, to Henry Hewlett Tredwell Jr., son of Henry Hewelett Tredwell of Old Westbury, L I., and the late Mrs. Tredwell.

The National Grain Board published today a warning that it will be necessary to put an embargo on Argentine wheat exports if they continue at their present abnormal volume. The statement said the board had organized a new statistical bureau to keep in daily contact with the wheat market in preparation for a forcible curtailment of exports, probably in May, to protect the home market against a shortage.

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to the list Household Finance Corporation 5 per cent preferred stock, $100 par value; Texas Corporation capital stock subscription installment receipts (first installment paid), and General Printing Ink Corporation common stock, $1 par value.

THE coronation of King George VI on May 12 is the focal point of what promises to be the longest and most varied season of festivity that Great Britain, or any other nation for that matter, has ever known. England, Ireland, Scotland and Wales expect several million visitors from abroad between now and the middle of August. More than 250 events, besides

TOURISTS looking southward at this time of year should include in their itineraries visits to a number of the country's most beautiful showplaces-the gardens of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina and Virginia. In Alabama,
Mrs. Harold S. Brewster was elected president of the Junior League of Elizabeth at a meeting this week at the Elizabeth Town and Country Club.

CASSADAGA, Fla. THE metallic swish of an iron rabbit, the frenzied yipping of greyhounds, the pop of a signal pistol, and the sleek hounds flash like shadows around the track. A laughing, shouting grand stand swings to its feet. The decoy vanishes into a distant white splash.

The report of Blauner's, a deapartment store in Philadelphia, and its wholly owned subsidiary companies, for the year ended on Jan. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $328,507 after depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and $26,241 provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

The Federal Government is the largest printer and distributer of documents in the world, Mrs. Martha Coplin Leister, head of the department of public documents in the Philadelphia Free Library, told the New Jersey Library Association and the Philadelphia Library Club in the Hotel Claridge here today.
ALTHOUGH it only cost sixpence when it appeared in London in 1848, the small, paper-covered pamphlet named "A True Picture of Emigration, or Fourteen Years in the Interior of North America,"
The Holley High Quintet, coached by Karlton Davis Manlius '32, won the annual Manlius School invitation basketball tournament in Dodge Gymnasium today by defeating Lynbrook (L. I.) High, 39 to 31.

The Ladies' Auxiliary of the Catholio Seamen's Institute, of which Mrs. John R. Oulton is president, will give a benefit card party and dance on April 22 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Mrs. H. J. Oakman is chairman of the card committee and Miss Betty Corcoran, cochairman.
COHEN--BERLINER-Mr. and Mrs. Max Berliner announce the marriage of their daughter. Judith Josephine, to Mr. Arthur John Cohen, on Sunday, March 14, at Hotel Astor.

Strike news which fills the columns of the newspapers today is so dramatic in some of its aspects that those who run and read may have the notion that labor unions have penetrated every nook and cranny in the industrial edifice, and that the country is about to be unionized overnight.

Current rises in wholesale prices of raw leather and factory costs indicate higher prices for leather goods items within the next few months, the American Retail Federation pointed out yesterday in an analysis of statistics on leather stocks and prices.
Dr. Arthur J. Parker, a surgeon who had practiced in Brooklyn since 1921, died Friday at his residence, 190 Hancock Street, of a heart attack after an illness of three days. He was 40 years old.

A bridge and tea was given yesterday by the New York Chapter of the Trinity College Alumnae in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the building and endowment fund of the college, which is in Washington, D. C. The party was attended by many residents of suburban towns as well as a large number of New Yorkers.

Levitt Sons, builders, have established a testing laboratory, under the direction of Clarence A. Monroe, chief engineer of the company, to test various new products and building materials, with a view to using some of these materials in their new houses to be built on Long Island and in Westchester.

IT is my opinion that the theatre is on its way out of the morass of the depression through which it has been wading for the last seven years. But it is not making as good time or heading as surely for secure ground as it might or, I think, as it should.

GEORGE NIDEVER was a California pioneer who neither went for the gold rush nor succeeded in it. He was a genuine frontiersman, a hunter, explorer, coast pilot and rancher; and in the eventful years of the Eighteen Thirties, Forties and Fifties he took adventure calmly as a part of every day. Lured by gold,

THIS is going to be an early Summer in Europe. It will begin in May with the English coronation on one side of the Channel and the Paris Exposition on the other. As the coronation is expected to attract immense crowds from all over the world, the exposition might conceivably be regarded as a French bid to catch the coronation crowds on their way to and from London.

The Princeton Tiger, campus humor magazine, reopened its traditional hostilities with The Daily Princetonian this morning by inviting 1,700 persons, including students, women guests at the Junior Promenade and faculty members, to a cocktail party between the hours of 12 and 4 today in the offices of The Daily Princetonian.
UNLESS a miracle occurs, there will be nothing finer on the Spring theatre calendar than Katharine Cornell's revival of "Candida." As Mr. Walkley used to say, it is a marriage of the "superbities."

THE Eastman School of Music will hold its annual festival of American music in Rochester, N. Y., the last week of April. The plans include five evening performances, three of these in the Eastman Theatre and one in Kilbourn Theatre.

Lord and Lady Elton will arrive here tomorrow on board the liner Scythia on their first visit to this country from England. Lord Elton is coming at the invitation of the League for Political Education. He is a lecturer on modern history at Oxford University and the author of biographical works.

A routine test administered by Federal civil service executives to clerks employed in the United States Appraiser's Stores building brought a volume of criticism from importers and customs brokers here last week.

A new subject-inflation-came up for discussion in Washington last week. President Roosevelt had alluded to the topic in his "fireside chat" on the court when he said: "The dangers of 1929 are again becoming possible, not this week or month, perhaps, but within a year or two."

Two of the six-meter yachts built for the several international events in that class this year were launched yesterday. Briggs S. Cunningham's Lulu, designed by Sparkman Stephens, was put overboard at Nevins' yard in City Island, and Herman F. Whiton's Light Scout, designed by her owner, took the water at the A. E. Luders yard in stamford, Conn.

After having been forced to hold for several years thousands of properties which they took over at the height of the depression period, New York banks and financial institutions at last are finding themselves able to dispose of these holdings on favorable terms.

Those who sold gold and gold coins to the Bank of France prior to the new law setting a daily fixed price for the metal will be compensated for their losses by payment of the difference between the old price and the new, the Treasury announced today.

AS railroads, motor roads and river steamers penetrate into Africa's most secret places, attention turns to this new tourist country known, until recently, for the least characteristic of her characteristics.

THE final week of opera at the Metropolitan will feature the first and only performance of "Parsifal" this season. The opera will be given Friday afternoon, with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles.

The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, at Buenos Aires, was described as "an achievement of profound and lasting significance" by Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State in charge of Latin American affairs and one of the United States delegates to the conference, in an address today

Labor disturbances, unfavorable weather conditions and heavier income tax payments combined to check business activity to some extent last week in many sections of the country. While reports from some cities indicated that preEaster buying, particularly in apparel lines, was below retailers' expectations, sales figures generally were well ahead of the volume in the corresponding period of last year.

James Lafayette Hutchison, advertising manager of the United Drug Company and short-story writer and author of the novel, "One, Two, Three, Four," and "China Hand," died today at his home in Cambridge. His age was 47.

Business and political circles were puzzled today on reading in the morning newspapers the following official announcement: The office of the president of the Reichsbank directorate, Dr. Schacht, has expired under the Reichsbank law, and that of the president of the Reich Audit Office, Dr. Saemisch, because of attainment of the age limit.

Rivals for broadcasting facilities in the New York metropolitan area challenged before the Communications Commission today the Brooklyn Broadcasting Corporation's financial ability to own and operate Station WBBC.

MEXICO, D. F. ALTHOUGH some seventy-five miles of the Pan-American Highway between Laredo, Texas, and Mexico, D. F., remains unsurfaced, motorists from the United States are experiencing little difficulty in making the 775-mile drive.
Two men were arrested here today on manslaughter charges in connection with the death of Virgil Osterholt of Danbury, who was killed in an explosion and fire in a hat plant Jan. 13.
Formation of an organization to present grand opera in this city at popular prices was announced today, when the Franz Phillips Grand Opera Company applied for a charter.

Miss Dorothy Murray ?? daughter of Mrs. George A. Boomer of this city, became the bride of Henry Neal Karr, son of Mrs. Henry C. Karr of Bethesda, Md., in the Second Congregational Church here this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. John C. Walker officiated.

Upholding the negative of the resolution that "Extension of Consumer Cooperatives Is for the Best Interests of the Country," the College of New Rochelle will meet Boston College in a debate Monday evening, John Lane, coach of the New Rochelle council of debate, announced here today.

The committee on legislation of the Citizens Union announced yesterday that it had decided to urge the passage of Assemblyman Mercier's bill for a referendum on the proposed Child Labor Amendment at the Fall election. Earlier in the legislative session, the committee opposed this bill as a move to delay ratification, but rejection of the amendment by the Assembly, in its opinion, now makes a referendum desirable.

The marriage of Miss Doris Helen Symans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George K. Symans of Riverview Community, to Harold A. Mitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Mitchell of Jersey City, will take place next Saturday in the Pompton Plains Reformed Church. The Rev. Eugene H. Keator, the pastor, will perform the ceremony, which will be followed by a reception at Windbeam Lodge.

The Long Island Horticultural Society, meeting Tuesday at 8 P. M. at the State Institute of Agriculture in Farmingdale, will outline its program for the year and listen to discussions of horticultural problems. Long Islanders, members or not,

Lafayette College seniors will obtain an opportunity to adjust themselves to life after graduation at a series of voluntary conferences next month with faculty members and well-known business and professional men.

Miss Helen Lucille Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Guy Stevens of this place, will be married on April 10 to Harold Douglas Lindemann of Long Branch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Lindemann of Juneau, Wis. The Rev. Dr. Edward Dawson will perform the ceremony in the First Reformed Church, Passaic.

Two Summer courses in real estate appraisal will be given at Columbia University under the auspices of the School of Business of the university and the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

TWO decorous conventions of educa tors-thousands of school superintendents, college professors and teachers from all parts of the United States-broke out into a week's pandemonium of partisanship recently over the case of a quiet silver-haired professor who is being retired this year from Teachers College, Columbia University.

Following a two-day open hearing before a trial committee of the Board of Education on charges of official miscounduct, Theodore Fred Kuper, legal adviser and executive manager of the board, was vindicated yesterday of any wrongdoing, and a recommendation will be made that all charges be dismissed.

John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, and Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, conferred for nearly an hour today at the Labor Department over the sit-down strike situation in general and the Chrysler strike in particular.

DRIFTWOOD--Tomorrow evening at the Longacre Theatre. This is the Samuel J. Park melodrama which was due last week. In the cast are James Kirkwood, Katharine Warren, Clem 'Wilenchick, Geraldine Kay and Bertram Thorn.

There is an epidemic in Detroit. The town has become a laboratory for studying that phenomenon, the sit-down strike, in all its phases. A great city is besieged, but life goes on much as usual. That is, the ordinary vocations go on. But all the while there is concern as to where the next attack will fall.

Debutantes headed by Miss Patricia Emmet will act as guides at the retrospective exhibition of twenty Degas masterpieces which will open tomorrow afternoon with a private reception and preview at the Durand Ruel Gallery and will continue there until April 10 for the benefit of the Public Education Association. After the preview tomorrow the exhibition will be opened to the public.

The 1937 Mississippi River flood is history. The river waters which wrought such devastation in the upper stretches of the great stream are pouring into the Gulf of Mexico in orderly cadence. The river gauges are falling all along the line.

THE new-born foliage that has mantled Italy in pale greenery heralds the approach of Spring and its thousands of tourists. Italy is looking forward to a good tourist season-reckoning on the lessened international tension and on the noticeable economic recovery all over the world to cause a general resumption of the habit of traveling.

CHARLES BROWN, who was born in 1786, nine years before Keats, was the friend with whom that poet made a tour of Scotland, and with whom he lived for a year and a half before he left for italy to die. Naturally, therefore, there--are here no letters from Brown to keats, since the two were together.

The charities of the Catholic Church are described as "the Catholic Church in action in the social welfare field "the "bond of perfection" which "strengthens the weak, uplifts neg"lected and supernaturalizes the gifts "of all."

The junior committee of the Little Italy Neighborhood Association, of which Mrs. John O. Zimmerman is chairman, will hold a meeting on Wednesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. E. Jefferson Browder, 12 Clark Street, Brooklyn.

USUALLY it rests with the cook to give drama to the potato. But during the last several months the relatively light stock of this vegetable in storage and the resulting high prices have done this. Consumers -- accustomed

Squadron C's reign as the Eastern and national junior indoor polo titleholder came to an end last night as the Ridgewood Polo Club trio rallied superbly in the second half to achieve an 11-to-3 victory at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.
Strong batting by R. E. S. Wyatt featured the second day's play of the match between the Marylebone Cricket Club touring team and a combined Canterbury and Otago eleven today.

ST. LOUIS.-The St. Louis Board of Aldermen, dissatisfied with the air that this city breathes, has passed a law to alter the atmosphere. And by next Fall, if the predictions of Mayor Bernard D. Dickmann materialize, there will no longer be any poisonous sulphur

Nettie Bishop, 17 years old, sat down today in the automobile of Clare Welch, her former employer, at Drayton Plains. Miss Bishop got into the car as Mr. Welch was about to leave home this morning, and said that he owed her $8 wages and that she would sit there until he paid it.

The decision of the Bolivian Government for cancellation of the concession of a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey is based "on authentic conclusions in a suit started against the company about two years ago for fraud in connection with fiscal taxes and clandestine exploitation of petroleum," Guillermo Alborta, Consul General of Bolivia here, stated yesterday.

The recurrent upheaval over local relief, which has been going on for several years, has again manifested itself in a demand for an inquiry into the Emergency Relief Bureau which handles home relief cases for the city. It has been motivated this time by Joseph E. Kinsley, Bronx Democrat and member of the Board of Aldermen, who maintains that the bureau is wasteful.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Paragraph 6, Special Orders 56, dated March 10, 1937, relating to First Lieutenant Milbert D. Dunlap, Engrs.-Res., is revoked. So much of Paragraph 3, Special Orders 60. dated March 15, 1937, relating to First Lieutenant Irving Krakower. Med.-Res., as reads: "Now on active duty with CCC Co.
The swordsmen of the Fencers Club of New York defeated Army today in an engagement fought with foils, saber and epee by a score of 14 1/2 to 12 1/2.

Dr. B. F. Fackenthal Jr., president of the board of trustees of Franklin and Marshall College, announced today that he would build a library on the campus to cost about $250,000. A special meeting of the board of trustees, called to hear plans for the sesqui-centennial of the founding of the college next October, heard the announcement.

The dean's list discloses that 132 students, including seven from New York State, attained scholastic averages of 85 per cent or better during the first semester at Bates College. The New Yorkers were

OKLAHOMA'S tenth annual Easter sunrise services, de picting scenes on inspirational subjects, will be presented at 3:30 A. M. on Easter Sunday, March 28, in the natural amphitheatre on the mountainside in the Wichita National Forest, twenty-two miles northwest of Lawton, Okla.

Mrs. Maria Ferdinando of Jackson Heights, Queens, has announced the engagement and coming marriage of her daughter, Miss Rosina Ferdinando, to Louis Joseph Scaramelli Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Scaramelli of Rutherford, N. J.
S. Mortimer Auerbach, Atlantic City sportsman, made a record in the twenty-fourth annual Biscayne Bay regatta today that won't go into the books.

Frank Averill, 27, flying instructor. was teaching Don Farrell to loop at 3,500 feet today. The plane stalled momentarily upside down. When Farrell righted it, Averill was not aboard. Farrell, shocked, flew around a bit to pull himself together, then landed.

FRANCE'S announcement during the past week that Paris will have the most powerful television station in the world on the air by July stirred speculation in American radio circles whether or not this move augured an international television race comparable to the one now being run in superpower broadcasting.

Although the Board of Supervisors this week adopted a new charter for Westchester County, not all is harmony. Opposition has developed in the rural districts and is growing. On the theory that no real economies will be effected, the charter already is being called a financial Frankenstein.

Winning from her opponent, Miss Helen White, by means of a welldirected attack after twenty-three moves, Mrs. Adele Rivero, holder of the Hazel Allen Trophy, yesterday scored her fourth consecutive victory in the women's open championship tournament under the auspices of the National Chess Federation at the rooms of the Marshall Club.

LONDON-At the recent meeting of the Raw Materials Commission, called at Geneva under League auspieces, Sir Frederic Leith-Ross, the economic adviser of the British Government, is reported to have said that the transfer of colonial territory by Great Britain to any other power could not be contemplated.

A speech by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, justifying Stock Exchanges generally against the "widespread prejudice" and "great misunderstanding" which he said were prevalent, was a feature of a dinner held tonight by members of the Toronto

Catholic High of Joliet, Ill., joined Fenwick High of Chicago in the final round of the national Catholic interscholastic basketball tournament tonight by trouncing La Salle Institute of Philadelphia, 41 to 23.
Cornell closed its indoor track season tonight by running away from its Central New York rivals and scoring 81 points to 18 for Colgate and 17 for Syracuse.

Carrier pigeons have flown here from the besieged mountain shrine of Santa Maria de la Cabeza with word that its garrison of more than 1,000 is holding out in dungeon cellars after more than six months of self-imprisonment against the government.

The engagement of Miss Terese Ruth Semel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Sidney Semel of Richmond Hill, Queens, to Dr. Milton J. Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Meyer of Jamaica, has been announced by her parents.

Mrs. Laura Feller McCoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Feller of Kansas City, Mo., was married yesterday morning to Alfred W. Mellowes in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

Signs of increased consumer resistance to higher price levels are still lacking, retail executives said yesterday. They pointed out that as yet the price advance at retail over last year is only about 6 per cent, and that many consumers had received wage increases exceeding that amount. It is likely, however,

The highest average speed ever made in a day's run by any commercial vessel was established yesterday by the French liner Normandie, which left New York on Thursday, according to a message to the line here from Captain Pierre Thoreux, master of the ship.

THE annual exhibition of paintings by members has opened at the Salmagundi Club, bringing together pictures by many well-known New York artists. It is a large and colorful "little academy" show that overflows the main gallery into the hallway and lounge. It will be current till April 2 (visiting hours daily from 12:30 to 6 P. M.; Sunday, 2 to 6 P. M.).

Miss Mary Helen Estey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Howard Estey of 1,357 President Street, Brooklyn, and Keuka Park, N. Y., was married last night in the Baptist Church of the Redeemer, Brooklyn, to Arthur Lord Nash, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Douglas Nash of Sewickley, Pa., formerly of Flushing. The Rev. Quentin D. Lightner performed the ceremony.

Prime Minister King came back to Canada today expressing belief there should be more communication of views between the heads of the governments of Canada and the United States. He considered his recent talks with President Roosevelt "valuable," he said, adding:

The Cornell swordsmen bowed to the Columbia fencers, 15 1/2--11 1/2, in their last dual meet today. The New Yorkers won the match chiefly on their work in the epee, taking the event, 6 1/2--2 1/2, as Jacobs swept all three of his bouts.

WITH this third long Stuart novel, in every way the finest she has yet produced, Margaret Irwin has won a prominent place among the distinguished contemporary writers whose work is the rendering of strict historical data into dramatic narrative.

Three Americans have applied to the Governor in Council for permission to purchase Bermuda properties. Aymar Johnson of Newport, R. I., desires to buy one acre in Sandys Parish adjoining the water on Church Bay and the ocean.

With Johnny Reiser pacing a fast second-half attack, the New York Whirlwinds repulsed the New York Jewels, 34-25, in a benefit basketball game before 3,000 persons at the 106th Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night. Part of the proceeds will be donated to the American Jewish Congress.

Described by the committee in charge as the most successful show ever held here, both in attendance and in volume of sales, the twentyfourth annual International Flower Show, which opened in Grand Central Palace last Monday, closed last night. More than 30,000 persons

The increased cost of operating apartment houses in this city will have to be passed on to tenants in the form of higher rents, according to statements yesterday by officers of two leading real estate brokerage concerns.

Equipped with hatchets, pickaxes, cameras, field glasses and notebooks to aid them in their annual search for "signs of Spring," a group of Boy Scouts descended upon the Jersey shore early yesterday morning and walked into a hailstorm.

Taking closely contested matches today, the New York combination of Jimmy Hines of Garden City, L. I., and Mark J. Stuart of the Winged Foot Golf Club, and Henry Picard, Hershey, Pa., and Frank Ford, Charleston, S. C., reached the final in the third annual national professional - amateur best - ball championship on the St. Augustine links.

" THE historic seat of the Marquess of Lothian, Newbattie Abbey, near Dalkeith, Scotland, founded in the twelfth century, has been opened as a college for adult education, a counterpart of Ruskin College at Oxford.

Twenty-one pickets were arrested early yesterday evening in front of the F. W. Woolworth Company store at 34 West Fourteenth Street, bringing to 121 the number of persons taken into custody as a result of the sit-down strike there Wednesday and Thursday.

With the acquisition by the Biological Survey of fifty-five new wild-life refuges in 1936, and with another fifty now being established, mote than 2,000,000 acres have been set aside for sportsmen under th4 Federal program of wild-life restoration.
Something like 300,000 people will take part tomorrow, it is estimated, in the funeral of the five victims of the rioting that broke out in suburban Clichy Tuesday night.

OUT of the strife of the past year between capital and labor, and between two labor groups differing on methods of unionization, John L. Lewis has emerged as an outstanding figure. The unions composing his

The Rev. Dr. Charles Livingston Fry, a retired Lutheran clergyman who had held many church offices, died of a heart attack at the dinner table last night at his home in Germantown. He was 78 years old.

Henry G. Hilken, for many years head of A. Schumacher Co., shipping agents, and a leader in GermanAmerican circles in Eastern cities, died today at his home at the age of 89. He was a native of Bremen and came to the United States in 1867. Before the World War Schumacher Co. were agents here for the North German Lloyd steamship line.

Signing a waiver of extradition after assuming full responsibility for his peculations, John Neville, alias John Bruce Heath, former backer of The Financial Observer, 55 William Street, was surrendered yesterday afternoon by the authorities here to detectives from Boston.

A tea will be given by Mrs. I. Curtis Gary on April 7 in the garden of the Ambassador for members of the New York Browning Society, following the monthly meeting of the group's study class, the subject of which will be "Intellectual Renaissance."

Hampshire House, the thirtyseven-story apartment hotel now being completed at 150 Central Park South, will be ready for occupancy by Oct. 1, according to Roland F. Elliman, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co.

Members of the Catholic Cradle Guild of New Rochelle will hold their annual bridge and supper party on April 3 at the Wykagil Country Club here. The proceeds will be used to purchase material for layettes to be distributed among needy families in Westchester County.

An irregular plot of land on Creston Avenue, running diagonally through the block to Morris Avenue, between 181st and 182d Streets, the Bronx, was sold by Helen M. Quinn and Catherine Snee to Max Bernstein, who assigned his contract to the Bradbag Realty Corporation, Samuel A. Brody, president. The latter took title to the property on Thursday and intends to erect an apartment house there.

Miss Anne Cleve, daughter of Mrs. N. Harrison Cleve of 141 East Eighty-eighth Street, and William W. Cleve of Norfolk, Va., was married here to John Nicholas Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Drury W. Cooper of Montclair, N. J., yesterday in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, the rector.

Miss Carol Kirkpatrick, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. T. L. Kirkpatrick of Charlotte, N. C., was married to Haviland Smith of Bridgeport, son of Mrs. Helen Holbrook Smith of Royal Oak, Md., and Julian Pierce Smith of New York, today in the First Baptist Church here.

With no opposition and with only minor technical amendme??, the Ontario Government's bill to establish minimum wages, maximum hours and proper working conditions was passed by the Legislature last night and will soon become law. In a few weeks similar

After arriving here late last night the liner Aquitania left for New York today, carrying tourists who had told of hardships experienced at Montevideo. The ship anchored twenty miles offshore because of a heavy storm, it was said, and passengers were
Commenting on his purchase last week of the twelve-story loft building at -33 East Thirty-third Street, Max Rosenfeld reported "increasing activity" in the industrial buildings of that neighborhood.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Vita N. Kane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew J. Kane of 101 Central Park West, to Dr. Frederick M. Marek, also of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Marek of Vienna.

A "Centenial Anthem," written especially for Mount Holyoke College's 100th anniversary by Associate Professor Clara B. Tillinghast of the Department of Music, will be sung in Mary Lyon Chapel by the combined undergraduate choirs during the celebrations of May 7 and 8.
To the Music Editor: Upon reading the very interesting leader in the Sunday TIMES upon Wagner as a best-seller at the Metropolitan, I am inspired to ask a question.

The Montreal Maroons, running wild in the last two minutes of play, scored an 8-4 National Hockey League victory tonight over the lowly New York Americans to clinch the second-place play-off berth of the International group in the Stanley Cup merry-go-round.

The New York Athletic Club's junior poloists earned the right to represent Manhattan in the Eastern championships last night when they defeated Squadron A in the latter's armory, 7 1/2 to 7. That slim margin of victory rattled off the mallet of Tom Bradley with just 35 seconds left of one of the most exciting games the season has produced as yet.

Charging that thousands of tons of freight will be diverted from this port if the United States Maritime Commission's proposals to limit free storage time for imported merchandise on steamship piers to ten days are put into force, importers here yesterday scored the commission's suggestions as a discrimination against this district and its importers.

Members of the younger set attended a dinner dance this evening, sponsored by the Westchester Assembly at the Siwanoy Country Club here. The committee in charge included Mrs. Henry Doyle, chairman: Mrs. Andrew Wilson, Mrs. William Guthrie Packard, Mrs. Edmund C. Stanton, Mrs. Christopher Chenery, Mrs. Harvey McClintock, Mrs. William MacIntosh and Mrs. John Snyder.

The Department of Parks announced the completion of the new Police Department boat repair shop on Randalls Island yesterday. The opening of one new playground, a section of a redesigned and reconstructed playground, and two new recreation buildings also was announced.

While weather conditions have not been conducive to producing the very heavy increase in pre-Easter apparel and accessory trade that was anticipated earlier, the result will be to swell consumer demand next month, and one of the best April in recent years is now anticipated by retailers.

Manhattanville scored a 16-15 victory over St. Joseph's College of Brooklyn in a girls basketball game played yesterday at the loser's court. Trailing 9-5 at the half the home team spurted after the intermission but the early lead of the winners enabled them to gain a hard-fought triumph.

New England's intercollegiate rifle championship rested tonight on the tired shoulders of the Coast Guard Academy representatives, who found the targets for 1,340 points today to defeat eleven other universities.

The executive committee of Remington Rand, Inc., approved yesterday the tentative plan for settlement of the strike in the company's plants, which was drawn up by James H. Rand Jr. and American Federation of Labor officials in the office of Secretary of Labor Perkins last Thursday.

Twenty boys, this year's scholarship winners at the Burroughs Newsboys Foundation, Boston, arrived yesterday morning in New York on the steamship Acadia for the sixth annual visit to this city of the Foundation's Scholarship Club.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jacob S. Friedman of 115 Central Park West of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene A. Friedman, to Jerome H. Rose, son of Mrs. Pheenie Rose of Cleveland.

Remarking that a postponement would give "the parties time to cool off," Federal Judge George A. Welsh today delayed until Tuesday arguments in an important test case in which sit-down strikers are attempting to establish their right to remain in the plants of their employers without molestation until their labor differences are settled.

Estimating that an additional expenditure of $4 was made for home modernization purposes in New Jersey to every $1 obtained in FHA repair loans, Thomas E. Colleton, FHA director for that State, announces that practically $200,000,000 up to March 1 had been spent for the modernization and renovation of New Jersey homes.

A really good lawn requires, as a foundation, at least four inches of fairly rich, friable soil, and good drainage conditions. If the existing lawn is very poor it pays to plow or spade it up in the Spring and plant a green manure crop.

The appearance of booths in railroad stations and other places today is telling the world that the enlistment drive in the mobilization for war on cancer is under way. The Women's Field Army, a volunteer organization whose ammunition is education and whose warcry is "Fight Cancer With Knowledge" is on the march.

AARON-Mr. and Mrs. Irving Aaron announce the birth of a son, March 10. at Hunts Point Hospital. APFEL--Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin L., announce the birth of Barnet's sister, Rose Mary, March 16, Doctors Hospital.

Lou Gehrig arrived here this morning shortly after 9 o'clock. Three hours later the highest priced ball player in the major leagues was in uniform going through a brisk workout at Huggins Field. And at 3 o'clock he was

After months of bickering over designs for a Spanish-American War memorial statue for Summerfield Park, the WPA has withdrawn all sculptors from the project and will offer no additional designs, it has been announced by Village Clerk Richard X. O'Connell. He said a letter to that effect was received this week from Mrs. Audrey McMahon, assistant director of Federal Art Projects in the area.
An eminent New York educator, in forceful if unacademic phrases, has just admonished the American Association of University Women. "Don't be afraid to blow your own horn. You've got something; toot!"

THE first edition of "The Reserve Banks and the Money Market" was published in 1927; it reviewed with great exactness and clarity the experiences through which the system had passed during the thirteen or fourteen first years of its history.

Thomas H. Stallsmith, a resident of Los Angeles since 1916, during which time he was active in civic and political affairs, died here today at the home of his son, Weldon Stallsmith. Mr. Stallsmith was connected with the promotion of the Panama Pacific International Exposition, held in San Francisco in 1915.
Representative Dies of Texas proposed today a law requiring deportation of aliens who are spreading foreign propaganda in this country, he said, in preparation for another World War.

Local groups of the National Association of Credit Men have subscribed more than one-quarter of the fund of $400,000 which the organization is seeking for its development program, it was made known here yesterday at the association's headquarters. This progress has been made despite the fact that only about half of the 125 local affiliates have started their drives.
Italian officials today characterized a purchase reported telegram from Premier Benito Mussalini to Italian "legionnaires" on the Insurgent and a "poor trick."
The security and commodity markets, especially the former, were in a highly nervous state last week, more so than in the week before, Statements on the subject of "curbing speculation" made by

YOU got inside the earliest came era, which was not a "candid" but a capacious "camera obscura" 'or dark room. And Alfred Barr, who is something of a magician himself, has had a camera obscure built into the entrance gallery of the Museum of Modern Art as Exhibit A in the show assembled under the direction of Beaumont Newhall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whatever may be thought of the merits of the President's proposals for the transformation-of the Supreme Court, they have done one good thing. They have given the citizens of the United States as a subject for widespread debate a fundamental constitutional question in which they are all interested and which they are eagerly discussing.

Panair do Brazil, a subsidiary of Pan American Airways, inaugurated today a tri-weekly Rio de Janeiro-Bello Horizonte plane service covering the distance of 346 kilometers (approximately 215 miles) in seventy-five minutes.

The past week has brought increasing evidence of a concerted effort on the part of Administration leaders to persuade the country that the Federal Government needs greatly increased powers, at present, it is hinted, denied to it by the Supreme Court, if it can hope to deal effectively with a possible inflationary boom.

Dr. Wesley M. Coates, physicist and inventor, was killed by an electric shock shortly after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Crocker Research Laboratory of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center at 168th Street and Broadway, when he brushed against a high-tension electrical conductor while adjusting an X-ray machine.

DeWitt Clinton High School became the city basketball champion of the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday afternoon by defeating Seward Park High School, 35 to 22, in the final-round battle of the 1936-37 tournament at the 102d Engineers Armory. A crowd of 4,500 saw the Clinton five capture the city crown for the second time since 1933.

A "sell-out" performance for each night is indicated by advance subscriptions to the annual International Skating Carnival, which will be presented at Madison Square Garden on Saturday and on March 29 and 31. This ice festival, for

The Metropolitan Opera Association will conclude its Philadelphia series of six performances with Wagner's "Lohengrin" at the Academy of Music on Tuesday evening. "Lohengrin" has not been sung here for seven years.

City officials rode up and down Broad Street today in the first test of a new light-weight bus which Mayor S. Davis Wilson believes may make a 5-cent fare possible in Philadelphia. This type of singledeck bus has a capacity of twentyfive persons.

The Child Labor Amendment to the Federal Constitution, approved by only four States in 1937, appeared today to have slight prospect of full ratification this year, the Council of State Governments said today.

The Gross-Morton Corporation, which erected last year about 450 homes on its large tract at Bayside Hills, near Bayside, L. I., has opened an exhibit of materials and equipment in the basement of one of six new model homes just completed at Bell Boulevard and

Subscribers to the elaborate luncheon and fashion show entitled "Styles From Dawn to Dusk," which will be held on April 15 in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria, will be requested to bring donations of useful articles for resale at the Generosity Thrift Shop, beneficiary of the event.

PRODUCTION figures in industry show that we are emerging or, indeed, have emerged from the depression. One phase of this emergence will be increased production in books dealing with the problems implicit in the depression and

Their recent successful drive for new members will provide pertinent material for the institute on membership and publicity which the National Council of Jewish Women will conduct tomorrow at Essex House as the first of a number of similar conferences to be held in various sections of the country.
