Fred Perry of Great Britain, world's amateur champion for the past three years, will return to Madison Square Garden Wednesday evening to play William Tilden in the first formal singles match ever staged between them.
How a city whose people have rather tolerated gambling and vice generally can disregard the State laws prohibiting them without encouraging police graft has become a hot issue in San Francisco.

Little Johnny Kelley, unemployed Arlington florist, today stamped himself as the marathoner to beat in next month's Boston A. A. race, when he gained his fourth consecutive Medford Club twenty-mile race victory in the record time of 1 hour 52 minutes 59 2-5 seconds.

Salvatore Ossido, 26 years old, a barber and father of two small children, last night was charged formally with the murder of 9-yearold Einer Sporrer, who was hammered to death in the back room of his one-room barber shop at 293 Irving Avenue, in the Ridgewood section of Brooklyn, Friday afternoon. An autopsy report said she had been criminally assaulted after death.

We sit-down strikers in the Chrysler plants want to state our case directly to you. We want to state it as strongly and as vigorously as possible. And we want you to know that what we have to say is supported by more than 50,000 other Chrysler workers, more than 100,000 automobile workers in Detroit, 200,000 in Michigan and 300,000 in the United States.

After several eye specialists had pronounced a surgical cure impossible, complete vision was restored to a Long Island City schoolboy after three months of osteopathic treatment, according to a case history presented last night at the regular monthly meeting of the Osteopathic Society of the City of New York, held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Dr. Edward W. S.

FOR more than a century no organized hostile force has landed on the shores of the United States or crossed its land boundaries. Yet we have been invaded-dramatically, in disasters which were splashed across the front pages of our newspapers;
The Essex Troop polo team displayed a spirited attack tonight to defeat the Ponolo trio of Redbank, 18 to 14, in the main exhibition game at Essex Troop Armory.

Firm in the belief that economic disturbances presage a new era for the United States, Mrs. Olivia Rossetti Agresti, Italian economist, who sailed for home last week after a two-month tour which took her as far as the Pacific Coast, compared existing conditions here to the-status of Italy fifteen years ago. She also praised the leadership of American women.

Tiger Jack Fox, Spokane (Wash.) light-heavyweight, outpointed Jack Trammell of Youngstown, Ohio, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Rockland Palace last night. A crowd of 3,000 persons saw the fighting. The weights were 175 3/4 for Fox and 192 1/4 for Trammell.

No one here today envied Henry V. Colt, judge at the twenty-seventh annual Camden Horse Show, his position in the last class of the twoday show. Having passed out three blues each to Richard K. Mellon's Rector and Sen Satin yesterday and an additional blue to Rector in the Corinthian class today, he was up

Displaying superiority with all three weapons, Yale's fencers -defeated Harvard, 18-9, today. The Crimson pressed the Elis only in the epee bouts, Lester Mills defeating Yale's three leading duelers, Captain Randall, Grasson and Miller.

Thirteen awards were made last week for the best work submitted in thirteen different crafts at the second annual exhibition of the work of students at the Craft Students League of the Y. W. C. A. in the Squibb Art Galleries, 745 Fifth Avenue, which will continue through March 27.

The final performance of the evening "Ring" cycle given at special prices in the Metropolitan Opera House transpired last night before an audience which packed the theatre in spite of the fact that Kirsten Flagstad, being indisposed, could not sing as Bruennhilde.

THE California artist Millard Sheets is playing a return engagement (until April 3) at the Milch Galleries, watercolors, as in his last exhibition, being the medium. In less expert-hands these large. papers might seem empty, but so cleverly are they designed, such sweeping use does Sheets make of his wash and such excellent disposition does he

Dealing in Queens and adjacent parts of Long Island gave unmistakable evidence last week of a substantial upward trend in the suburban market. The influence of the forthcoming World's Fair upon realty activities was also indicated in the sale to a development syndicate of the former Hurlbut estate properties in Corona adjacent to the World's Fair grounds for $300,000.

Most manufacturers were cautious and displayed no haste last week in taking advantage of the resale price maintenance privileges of the Feld-Crawford law, and the action taken for the most part was in line with expectations, retail executives here reported yesterday. It was indicated that many producers are waiting to see what Congress will do with the Tydings-Miller bill, which would validate "fair trade" price agreements in interstate commerce.

Secretary Wallace complains that the government does not have sufficient power to effectively mitigate the wide swings of the business cycle. The declared purpose of the New Deal was to fix responsibility, and the failure to carry out that purpose may be a cause of some of the present difficulty.

The interval for reflection since passage of the cash-and-carry neutrality resolution by the Senate has led to a fairly optimistic view here of the effects of the new American policy upon Great Britain's power to purchase in United States markets in wartime those supplies of food and raw materials which probably would be as vital to her in a future war as they were in the last war.

Miss Shirley Ludlam Woodward, laughter of Mrs. Cedric Rainey Woodward of Old Greenwich, Conn., has completed the plans for her marriage to H. Fletcher Eggert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Eggert of 117 East Seventy-second street, which will take place here on April 24 in St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Journeys to scientific and industrial laboratories and plants in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts will be taken next week by students at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, accompanied by faculty members.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Forbes Perkins of Owl's Nest, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elsie Hooper Perkins, to William Sterling Youngman Jr. of Brookline.

American builders today are constructing the most livable homes that have been created for the occupancy of American families, declares Irwin S. Chanin of the Chanin Organization developers of the home community known as Green Acres fronting on Sunrise Highway at Valley Stream, L. I Livability, he explains, means not only structural beauty but soundness in taste and architecture.

The current controversy over progressive school policies in Roslyn, L. I., has been carried on with little reference to available records. These show that good standards in major subjects have been attained by pupils from the Roslyn schools as well as from progressive schools in general.
Winning five of the six events, the New York University women's swimming team defeated the Swarthmore representatives, 32 to 21, in the Evangeline House pool yesterday. It was the fourth
Annual communion breakfast of New Amsterdam Council, Knights of Columbus, Hotel Delmonico, 9 A. M. Speakers: The Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, William Griffin. the Rev. D. J. O'Koefe and John J. Mahoney.

Many protests against President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court have been received by the Women's National Committee for "Hands Off the Supreme Court" at its headquarters, 535 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

On the ground that "military training has no part in our public education system," Mrs. Henry S. Pascal, president of the United Parents Association, urged the Assembly committee on public education yesterday to reject the proposal of Assemblyman McLaughlin that boards of education be permitted to establish military training courses in the schools, in lieu of physical training, if the parents of 100 or more male children over 12 years old request it.

After identifying more than 100 birds, many of unusual varieties, Mrs. Raymond V. Ingersoll, wife of the Borough President of Brooklyn, arrived with three friends here today from Central America aboard the United Fruit steamship Castilla.

Superintendent CAMPBELL, in his address at the celebration of the thirtieth anniversary of the Riverdale Country School, quoted most aptly a remark of Judge CARDOZO (now Mr. Justice CARDOZO) in desideration of the peace of mind that must come to the builder of a mighty bridge:

Just as the Robinson-Patman law is believed to have been partly responsible for recent increases in national advertising, so will the various fair-trade laws being adopted by numerous States act as a stimulus to advertising campaigns by manufacturers of trade-marked goods, according to opinions here yesterday. In the first instance,

There was a constantly increasing volume of trading in the cotton market here last week, and this applied as well to futures as to spots. A growing speculative interest in the futures market was based on the strength of spots, the increasing activity in the manufactured goods market, the growing indications of inflation in all commodities, the rapidly expanding consumption of all growths of cotton end the fear of an outbreak of war in Europe.

Miss Sylvia Elaine Lavinsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Lavinsky of. West Orange, N. J., was married to Irwin J. Brainen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Brainen of Newark, N. J.. last night at the Essex House in Newark. The Rev. Dr. Leon S. Lang of Newark officiated. A reception and dinner followed the ceremony.

James W. Carkner was re-elected president of Loft, Inc., at the annual election of officers on Saturday. He reported to the directors that the recently instituted program of modernization of the Loft stores indicates sales gains in rehabilitated stores ranging from 20 to 60 per cent over comparative periods of last year.

On the Fish motion to recommit the McReynolds neutrality resolution to the Foreign Affairs Committee with instructions to report it back with an amendment making it unlawful "to export, or attempt to export, or cause to be exported" arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States "in time of peace, as well as in time of war," rejected, 118 to 274:

A general strike of all retail store employes in Providence, affecting between 10,000 and 12,000 workers, was voted here today at a mass meeting called this morning by leaders of the Committee for Industrial Organization as a result of the action of twelve stores, with whose owners the C. I. O. has been bargaining, in closing their establishments yesterday in what was described as a move to avert a sitdown strike.

A meeting of the Joint Committee on County Consolidation of the Municipal Assembly, to take immediate action on bills before it for reorganization of the 'county governments in New York City, was asked yesterday by Richard C. Patterson, Jr., chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, in a letter to Alderman Murray W. Stand, chairman of the committee.
A plea for more Jews who are Jews by faith and conviction rather than under protest and rebellion was made in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson at Temple Emanu-EI,
Artur Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra repeated at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon the performance in concert form of the greater part of Richard Strauss's "Elektra."

Controller Morris S. Tremaine made public today an analysis of the State's fiscal position in anticipation of a sale on Wednesday of an issue of $15,000,000 grade crossing elimination bonds. The Controller disclosed that, according to the present schedule of bond redemptions, more than $285,000,000 of the State's bonded debt

The cross is woven into the pattern of life itself; it is central in the world's supreme religion because it is central in the world's deepest experience, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of the Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, said yesterday morning in his sermon.

Contracts under the Walsh-Healey act calling for supplies totaling $4,411,204 were made by the government in the week ended on March 18, Secretary Perkins has announced. There were 109 contracts made during the week, covering textiles, metals, oil, cement, food supplies, rubber goods, automotive products and airplane accessories.
Mr. and Mrs. Philip Cowen and celebrated their fiftieth wedding anniversary this afternoon with "open house" here at the home of their daughter, Mrs. Leon M. SolisCohen, with whom they live.

The greatness of a nation lies in the number of its citizens who obey the unenforceable laws, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, of which he is the pastor.

The restaurant racket trial before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook will enter its tenth week today, with every prospect of a verdict before the end of the week. There remain only the summing up of the attorneys and the charge of Justice McCook before the jurors will begin deliberating on the mass of evidence. The summing up will begin today.

A vote of 96.4 per cent for the employes' representation plan as their collective bargaining agency was cast by employes of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation at the twentieth annual elections of employee representatives held in the past few days.

It was something like 10 o'clock last evening before the Rebel Arts Players raised the curtain of the Labor Stage to disclose the first performance of "The Brave and the Blind," Michael Blankfort's new play.
The present system of divided control over the air-mail lines of the country between the Interstate Commerce Commission

A goal in the final seconds of the second overtime period gave the Trenton Highlanders the Eastern amateur soccer championship yesterday and lifted them right into the final for the United States crown against the Western winners.

Midshipmen officers of the Naval Academy regiment from March 22 on through the academic year have been chosen. The commander of the regiment, or "five-striper," is Ralph Kissinger Jr. of Fairfield, Neb. The regimental sub-commander, "fourstriper," Richard P. Nicholson, is also a Nebraskan, his home being in Valentine.

Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel of New York entertained at dinner last evening in honor of Sir Bede Clifford, Governor of the Bahamas, and Lady Clifford, at their home, Caprice. Among their other guests were Baroness Von Moltke, Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Odman, Mr. and Mrs. Austin Gray, Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel 3d and Commander Hugh Longden.

Frederick Lawrence Stephens, in 280 Park Av. through Mayne Co., broker. Mrs. Elsie Gerard Lee. John Ward, Stanley S. Harris, in 321 E. 37th St.: Marie Rose Jobin, in 1,383 3d Av.; Edwin E. Tanzer, Inc.. broker. Abraham L. Zimmerman, Rudolph Cowen, Sidney S. Buchler, Joseph L. Miller, in W. 79th St.; through Bing Bing. Inc.
The concluding concert of the New Friends of Music season at the Town Hall late yesterday afternoon was one of the finest in the series of sixteen.
A series of fashion shows will be presented daily at 3:30 P. M. in the sixth-floor restaurant at R. H. Macy Co., Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway, beginning tomorrow and closing Thursday.
The American Ceramic Society opened its thirty-ninth annual meeting last night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. The meeting will continue all week.
The concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was for the benefit of the Rand School scholarship fund. A capacity house attended. The singers were Natalie Bodanya, Lucielle Browning,
Nationalist agitation for an independent Puerto Rico led to a serious riot this afternoon at Ponce, second city on the island. Seven or more persons were killed and more than fifty were injured.

Government troops continued their victorious advance in Guadalajara Province today, capturing Cogollor, on the road from Cifuentes and about eight miles from Almadrones, where the Rebels started their drive two weeks ago.

The projected series of Sunday performances of "The Eternal Road" began auspiciously yesterday afternoon. In attendance were 2,103 persons, the box-office statement showing $3,728. At an admission scale ranging from $1.10 to $2.75, the potential capacity is $4,519.

French prices rose again from March 6 to 13, chiefly because of advances in imported and native products. The general index stood at 533 on March 13, compared with 525 and 517, respectively, on March 6 and Feb. 27.

Final settlement of Mexico's funded and railroad debt depends on whether United States banking entities are prepared to make substantial loans to Mexico to assure continuance of the present tempo of Mexico's "revolutionary" land reform and social program.

With only the stipulation that it be used in the humanities section of the curriculum, a gift of $750,000 has been made anonymously to the California Institute of Technology. It will be used largely in the fields of literature, history, economics, foreign languages and philosophy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his testimony before the Senate committee Professor Corwin declared that the Supreme Court has become a "hybrid" body, performing both judicial and political functions. This may be admitted, at least for the sake of argument-though, as Charles Warren has shown, its record in the matter of nonpartisanship is remarkably and indeed amazingly high.

The French Navy will contribute only "mosquito" craft to the Spanish maritime control scheme, it became known today. Economy is believed to have dictated the decision not to use big naval units for patrol service.
The Rev. Dr. Douglas P. Birnie, who for many years was pastor of the Presbyterian Church at Rye, N. Y., died at his home here this afternoon after a long illness.
Buying activity in the wholesale dress market here last week centered on fill-in items, costume suits, sheer bridesmaid and graduation types, and sheer afternoon dresses for post-Easter selling.

Packing all the scoring into the third period, the New York Rangers and the Canadiens of Montreal brought the regular season of the National Hockey League to a close at Madison Square Garden last night, with the local sextet registering a 3-1 victory.
Austria, hemmed in by other nations, is developing a navy strong enough to control, with the aid of an air fleet, the Austrian part of the Danube River.

Edwin S. Stuart, former Mayor of Philadelphia and former Governor of Pennsylvania, the only man ever elected to both offices, died of a heart attack this afternoon at his home in Overbrook. He was in his eighty-fourth year.

Two hundred persons are dying of starvation daily in Chungking and its suburbs, it was estimated today, as the worst drought in a quarter century held most of Szechwan, China's most populous province, in its grip.
Italy's island of Pantelleria in the narrow passage between Sicily and Tunis, has been heavily fortified as a counterweight to Britain's base on Malta.

The Foreign Office will call the Japanese Consul General at Vladivostok, Siberia, to Tokyo, it became known today, for a consultation on the latest developments in what is termed Soviet persecution of Japanese residents there.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at Pineland, Fla., of Graham L. Wilson, a son of the late Mrs. George B. Wilson of Philadelphia, who owned a famous collection of orchids valued at $1,000,000.

A resolution urging the Legislature to pass the McElroy-Sullivan bill to set up codes for the service industries of the State along NRA lines was adopted last night at a mass meeting in Irving Plaza Hall, 15 Irving Place, held under the auspices of the Retail Cleaners and Dyers Association.

Dr. Jay Glover Eldridge of Moscow, Idaho, Professor of German language and literature at the University of Idaho, is the winner of the centennial hymn contest held this Winter by the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, it was announced yesterday.
Julian Tafsun, an executive of L. S. Tafsun, Inc., operators of shoe stores here and in Miami Beach and Tampa, Fla., died today in Miami Beach at the age of 38.

A shore front property consisting of an eighteen-room house, acre of land, swimming pool and pier in Wampage, Sands Point, L. I., was sold by Mrs. Pinna Gaston buyer represented by S. Hillen McSherry. J. Ralph Bloomer was the broker. The property formerly was owned by James H. R. Cromwell.

Eastern Blvd., 2,236 (14-3695): Arnold J. Malkan, referee, to Hamilton F. Dean, 214 E. 31st St. Eastern Blvd., 2.240 (14-3695); Vincent F. Morreale. referee, to Hamilton F. Dean, 214 E. 31st St. Theriot Av., 1,407 (15-3900); Adrian P. Burke, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp., 350 5th Av. 202d St. (12-3307), s. s., 343 ft. e. of Marion Av., 69x100; Harold Elfin to Sidbar Development Corp., Bronx.

Bicycles exported from the United States increased from 1,120, valued at $26,468 in 1935, to 2,322, valued at $61,530 in 1936, a gain of 51 per cent in number and 132 per cent in value, the Department of Commerce reported today.
A canal across Florida, by-product of an $18,000,000 Lake Okeechobee flood control project, today awaited only formal dedication exercises before being thrown open to water traffic.

Champion Wolvey Noel of Clairedale, Sealyham terrier owned by Mr. and Mrs. W. O. Penney of Riverhead, L. I., and handled by Leonard Brumby of Hicksville, L. I., received the special prize for the best in show as the eighteenth annual Cincinnati Kennel Club exhibition closed at the Music Hall tonight.

Red flowers and red flags in grouped masses or unfolding like scarlet ribbons along miles of streets marked the funeral in the Clichy district this afternoon of the five young men killed in Tuesday night's Communist rioting.

A blind woman who has earned a precarious living for many years. as a beggar on the cit. strocks told Magistrate Mark Rudich in Flatbush Court yesterday morning:: t!-she always carried more than $1,000 cash concealed in her garments because she did not trust the banks.

The defenders of the Grimes citadel here were blasted right back on their heels today by the spirited, not to say vicious, attack of the Dressen Reds. One gallant Dodger, in fact, was knocked out, an incident from which developed a considerable amount of acrimony between the two commanding officers.

Thousands of sea birds took possession of Howland Island's newly completed airplane runways today as the lonely mid-Pacific spot abandoned plans to receive Miss Amelia Earhart on her projected world flight.

Secret elections will be held on the vessels of the Merchants and Miners Transportation Company of Baltimore so that deck officers and licensed engineers may choose labor organizations to represent their respective interests in collective bargaining with the company, according to a decision announced today by the National Labor Relations Board.

In an encyclical marking his first direct intervention in the controversy between the National Socialist State and the Catholic Church Pope Pius tonight sternly warned the church's enemies that all attempts to replace the Christian faith with modern ideologies were doomed to swift defeat.

The first anniversary of the death of Eleutherios Venizelos, former Premier of Greece, who died in Paris during a self-imposed exile from his own country, was observed yesterday with a mass and other ceremonies at the St. Eleutherios Greek Orthodox Church, 359 West Twenty-fourth Street.

At the annual convention of Mr. COSGRAVE'S United Ireland party in Dublin Friday many delegates were present. Praiseworthy enthusiasm was manifested. Predictions were made that the General Election in June would be no walk-over for Mr. DE VALERA and the Fianna Fail.

An action in replevin and mandamus will be instituted this week against Mayor Clyde Potts of Morristown, in the name of the Board of Aldermen, to obtain warrants now held by the Mayor for the payment of salaries of the city attorney and the park superintendent whose appointments he vetoed, and to test his power of veto.

Fascism and communism were condemned yesterday afternoon by William H. Carmody, national head of the Knights of Columbus, on his annual visit to the Long Island Chapter. He spoke at a meeting of Grand Knights and delegates of sixty-eight councils at the Knights of Columbus Institute, 81 Hanson Place, Brooklyn.

Mrs. Elizabeth Krunchwitz, 46 years old, of 598 Ocean Avenue, Lakewood, N. J., dropped dead at Beth Israel Hospital tonight while on her way to visit a patient. Dr. Lewis E. Savel of the hospital staff said a tentative examination disclosed that a stroke was responsible.

Hyman Landau has purchased eight lots on the south side of Hillside Avenue, about 450 feet east of Broadway, in the Dyckman Street section of Manhattan, for improvement with a six-story elevator apartment house, to be ready for occupancy next Fall. The Arnold B. Bashein Company was the broker in the sale.
Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt of Oakland Farm, Newport, and this city are arriving here tomorrow on the Santa Lucia from Havana and will go to their Newport home.

Never since the days of Christ and the apostles has any religious group been as humanly defenseless as evangelical Protestantism seems to be at present, the Rev. William Ward Ayer, the pastor, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Alan Seymour was heard in a piano recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Mr. Seymour, who has appeared here in several events of the kind, had arranged a program which was led off by three Beethoven sonotas. These included,

Representatives of unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization assailed today the plan of Lewis G. Hines, American Federation of Labor organizer here, to "purge" the central labor union of C. I. 0. delegates, and prepared to carry their battle to the. State Federation of Labor meeting at Harrisburg on March 30.

After two weeks of listening to supporters of President Roosevelt's court reorganization program the Senate Judiciary Committee will resume its hearings tomorrow with opponents of the plan as witnesses.

High winds that hit the backs of the gunners were responsible for poor scores at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The high scratch gunner in the shoot at 100 singles was Harry Thoens, who had 94.
Matanuska Colony's new "work to eat" credit system, the management said in a report today, has raised and strengthened the colonists' morale and resulted in sharp increases in work.

The sit-down strikes which have recently broken out in the United States are a repetition of those experienced in France last Summer. In France judges often ordered evacuation of Factories, but the orders were rarely executed, and in most cases the employers were forced to meet the workmen's demands.

Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 89 per cent of capacity, up 1 point in a week and 3 points in two weeks. Output was at a rate of about 62,000,000 tons a year, comparing with production of 54,850,000 tons in 1929, the record year,

Mr. and Mrs. Jerome T. Shaw of Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Joan Shaw, to Robert Haydon Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haydon Jones of 10 Gramercy Park.

The decline in United States Government bonds is attributed here in part to talk of inflation and to social unrest, out fundamentally to the rise in prices and the prospect of dearer noney. The banks are inclined to criticize he failure to use the United States gold, which, they say,
Two eightyear-old girls rode in a shell-torn bus into Madrid in the darkness early today to tell of nine days in a wine cellar during the Insurgent occupation of Brihuega.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman P. Powell does not directly say so, but he indicates in a book to be published tomorrow that Professor Pitkin was thirty years out of the way when he set 40 as the age when life begins.
Paleontologists of the Smithsonian Institution are somewhat concerned over an apparent gap of about 60,000,000 years in the life story of insects.

While asserting that he did not believe dictatorship was imminent in the United States, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, minister of the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, pointed yesterday to the success of the sit-down strike technique in

Gold imports in February amounted to [Pound]41,716,688, exports to [Pound]17,281,823. Of the imports, [Pound]33,982,305 came from France, [Pound]4,623,908 from Africa, [Pound]1,757,943 from India, [Pound]394,940 from Australia, [Pound]408,242 from Holland, [Pound]91,887 from Belgium, [Pound]750,943 from Germany, [Pound]49,089 from Spain, [Pound]54,988 from Switzerland and the balance from other countries.

The Giants were still streaking along today like lightning on the loose as they once again bowled over the Indians with great thoroughness and a final score of 8 to 1. It gave the Terry forces their second straight triumph over the somewhat astonished and bewildered Clevelanders.
Dr. Willis G. Gregory, for forty-six years dean of the University of Buffalo School of Pharmacy, died of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home here last night.

Seventeen Princeton University units will engage in a total of 141 contests in seven sports this Spring, according to the schedules released today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics. The program for the eighth Spring sport, polo, is incomplete.

Specuative trade in soy beans on the Board of Trade has fallen off and processors also are giving the market less attention. The processors say consumptive requirements are lighter and some plants have shut down because of inability to operate profitably.
A spokesman for Scotland Yard asserted today that it knew nothing about reports that it was investigating a suspected plot against the life of King George VI.
CLINTON LAUNDRY SERVICE, INC., 230 E. 125th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $61,392 and assets of $68,850.

An appeal for Federal aid in the search for Joseph Retz Ramser, 35 years old, broker and former economics instructor at the University of Illinois, who disappeared Wednesday night, was decided upon today by anxious friends.

Greenwich society attended in large numbers this afternoon a preview and tea at the art galee of the Greenwich Library which marked the opening of the annual exhibition of the Greenwich Society of Architects. The hostesses were Mrs. William F. Dominick, Mrs. Philip Ives, Mrs. Joseph C. Bailey, Mrs. Alden Twachtman, Mrs. Phelps Barnum and Mrs. Cass Gilbert Jr.

Mitzi Green, former child actress and currently rehearsing in Manhattan for the Rogers-Hart "Babes in Arms," will return to Hollywood after the runs of the Broadway show to make "Love Below Freezing" for RKO-Radio.

The premium list of the Squadron A Spring Horse Show, scheduled for April 16 and 17, will be sent out to exhibitors today. A $500 hunter championship stake and a $500 open jumper stake are among the prizes for the thirty-three classes to be contested at the show.

Away to a commanding lead in the first period, the New York Rovers yesterday bade au revoir to their local public in victorious fashion, defeating the Montreal Victorias, 5 to 3, in the exhibition feature of an amateur hockey double-header in Madison Square Garden.

Fenwick High of Chicago, taking a quick lead in the opening period and then fighting off a great opposing rally in the final minutes, won the national Catholic interscholastic basketball championship tonight, defeating Catholic High of Joliet, Ill. 30 to 27.

The marriage of Miss Jane Cor nelia Goldenburgh, daughter of Mrs. David C. Goldenburgh of New York, formerly of Richmond, Va., Jand of the late Mr. Goldenburgh, to Spencer Dana Oettinger of 815 Park Avenue, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, 19 East Seventy-fourth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Isaac Landman. There were no bridal attendants. Joseph Oettinger was best man for his brother.
Chief Ernie Koy shook off the effects of a depressing day at Waterfront Park this afternoon just in time to give the Yankees a victory over the Bees in an extrainning skirmish.

Seth B. MacClinton, veteran Federal court reporter, who was president of the New York State Shorthand Reporters Association, died yesterday at his home in Massapequa, L. I., of pneumonia and heart disease, having never fully recovered from a heart attack suffered in 1935.

The desirability of promoting peace among the nations of the world by preserving a "sane balance" of national freedom and practical international cooperation is stressed by Secretary of State Hull in an exclusive interview which will appear in tomorrow morning's Daily Princetonian.
Reduction of city water rates to the figure that prevailed prior to Sept. 14, 1933, when the rates were increased 50 per cent, was recommended yesterday by the Merchants Association.

Carl J. Kress, who is believed to be the only yodeler in the United States with a written permit to indulge that type of vocalizing, soon will resume his trips to Orange Mountain and it will re-echo to his "O-lee-o-lay-eedee-e-e" with the official approval of the Essex County Park Commission.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 93.7, which compares with 92.9 a week before, 91.1 two weeks before, 90.9 three weeks before and 91 four weeks before.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society will extend its season for 1937-38 to twenty-eight weeks, it was announced yesterday. The current season is only twenty-four weeks. Thus four weeks will be added next year. The twenty-eightweek session will begin on Oct. 21 and end on May 1.

Norman Thomas, thrice Socialist candidate for President, speaking in Rutgers University's Kirkpatrick Chapel this morning, called on college students to concentrate upon learning the lessons of the past rather than upon preparing for economic gain.

The Central Information Bureau at Washington, which the BrownlowGulick-Merriam committee to reorganize the government would establish, "is a real menace to the legitimate flow of news to the public" and possibly would "amount to an intolerable inner censorship," Arthur Krock, head of the Washington bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, believes.

Despite the party platform demand for absolute independence and the accompanying threat of non-cooperation in the working of the new Constitution, the Indian Congress party last week took another momentous step toward cooperation.

It started with the customs inspector. Although he had been routed out at dawn to meet the early boat, he was not so much grumpy as gloomy as he ran a perfunctory hand through the bags of a traveler who brought back no souvenirs of Europe except those that are carried in the head.

A decree published today over the names of Joseph Stalin and Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff annulled the necessity for collectives and individual farmers to pay up their arrears of grain deliveries to the government.

WE stopped at the Dome and had a few drinks. There was a Ruasiaan there with a Fiench girl who looked like a travel poster and proved to-be just as banal. But the Russian"These lines have been missing from books published since 1929, when the expatriates started rushing home. Visits to Paris,

After a bad start giving their opponents a 1-0 lead in the first half, the Brooklyn Hispanos easily outplayed Baltimore in the second period at Hawthorne Field, Brooklyn, yesterday, to win by. 3 to 1 in an American Soccer League game witnessed by 1,500.
Edward P. Burrell, nationally known engineer especially in the astronomical field, died today at his home here after an illness of less than a week. His age was 65.

The engagement of Miss Rose Marie de Foix Edmunds, daughter of Mrs. Gustave A. Heckscher of Strafford, Pa., and the late Ralph Edmunds of this city, to B. Grosvenor Chapman, son of Mrs. George McM. Godley of Greenwich, Conn., and the late F. Burnham Chapman of Rye, N. Y., has been announced by her mother.

The latest list of purchasers of the debentures of the New York World's Fair included three of $25,000 each, it was announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the Fair's bond sales committee.

Brazil's foreign debt payment arrangement, entering its final phase in April, 1938, may be extended at its termination on conditions similar to those ruling in the present Aranha scheme, but under a revised schedule.

Miss Mary Ridder, daughter of Victor F. Ridder of 81 East Seventy-ninth Street, has selected April 17 for her marriage to Dr. Hans Hartmann of Munich, son of Adolf Hartmann of Hanover, Germany. The ceremony will be performed in the home of the prospective bride's father by the Rev. Hugh Diman of Portsmouth Priory School.

Cardinal Hayes was the central figure in "a procession of the Palms" and gave his blessing from the cathedral steps after the solemn mass yesterday marking Palm Sunday in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The cathedral, which seats 3,000, was so crowded that many stood throughout the two-hour liturgical service.

Stocks lower on week in less active trading; turnover, 10,364,890 shares. United States Government issues declined to new low levels, corporate and foreign bonds irregularly lower; transactions, $107,134,500.

The marriage of Mrs. Emily Reber Housel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Reber of Sunbury, Pa., to James Renwick Thomson of Chappaqua, N. y., took place this afternoon at the home of the bride in Scarborough. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward West of Ossining, N. Y., in the presence of relatives.

French foreign trade in February again was unfavorable. Imports rose to 3,681,000,000 francs, against 3,319,000,000 in January and 2,051,000,000 in February, 1936. Exports decreased to 1,695,000,000 francs, compared with 1,773,000,000 and 1,229,000,000, respectively.

Nebraska lawmakers "pointed with pride" today at the record of the nation's only one-house non-political State Legislature, which is well past the half-way mark in its work. Standing committees have virtually finished their part of the labor and the session's major issues are nearing final stages of action.

Jonn P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Division of the American Federation of Labor, today denied the possibility that local A. F. of L. groups in Detroit might participate in a general strike there.
The week beginning Thursday, April 1, will be "Conservation Week" under a proclamation issued today by Governor Lehman which said:

German manufacturers have made representations in official quarters that, in view of the dearness of imported materials and home-produced substitutes, it will be impossible to maintain prices for manufactured goods unchanged, as prescribed in General Goering's November decree.

President Anastosio Somoza appointed a commission today to regulate the prices of foodstuffs and merchandise. Dealers must post prices and those selling at higher than established prices will be subject to fines.
Charles A. McCloud, former Republican National Committeeman for Nebraska, died today of a stroke. His age was 77.

German industry is more active. It is noteworthy that, although industrial corporations have considerably reduced their old bank debts, their total short-term indebtedness again is increasing. Manufacturers, with more orders than they can fullfil, demand payments on account or credits from customers. This indicates that credit is getting tighter.
Characterizing England as "the most anti-Catholic State in the world," Hilaire Belloc yesterday attributed the violence of the recent quarrel between that country and Italy to a religious cause.
New London, Texas, is so small and new a place that it is not to be found in the United States Postal Guide, or in the big newspaper directory, or on the available maps.

Mrs. Harry W. Courter of Hollis, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elodie Courter, to Wayland Ayer Fry, son of Mr. Wilfred W. Fry and the late Mr. Fry of Camden, N. J., and Philadelphia. The announcement was made yesterday at a tea at the Courter residence.

Residents of the Great Ouse River fenlands, where the flood has been serious for a week, looked tonight for gradually better conditions barring heavy rains. Rain fell for a while tonight at historic Ely in the potential danger zone and the wind minimized the aid derived from opening the Denver sluices, but flood workers remained optimistic.

Housewives who submitted menus created around homely American dishes have won the six sectional prizes in the second national cookery contest under the auspices of the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries, it was announced yesterday afternoon, at the exposition headquarters, 247 Park Avenue.

The Grand Central School of Art released yesterday the first section of the report on its recent survey of students in art schools charging tuition. The survey was made with the cooperation of fourteen schools throughout the country and it was found that there are twice as many women as men in those schools.

Police radio patrol cars and repair crews of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity cooperated yesterday to trace and repair three small breaks in the Fire Department's high-pressure water system in lower Manhattan. The largest of the breaks was traced to Morris Street and Broadway, where the system was disabled for some hours for 200 feet around the break.

Repatriation of French funds is not proceeding at a rate to cause any embarrassment to the London market, and any future movement in that direction should have no serious influence on monetary conditions.

While sitting with several friends at a table in the rear of Honeymoon Lane, a "taxi" dance hall on the second floor of 711 Seventh Avenue, Alfred Rossi, 35 years old, of 48 East 107th Street, the manager of the ballroom, was shot and killed by an unidentified assailant at 1:35 o'clock this morning.
The State Legislature will be requested to create, establish and incorporate a borough to be called the Borough of Jersey Homesteads, Walter A. Simon, community manager, said this afternoon.

Seven New York and Brooklyn retail stores have entered into stipulations with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue "false and misleading advertising" in which they "improperly describe" materials of fabrics, and a number of other stores are following their example, the commission said today.
Moslem outlaws raided Hindu and Sikh rural populations beyond Bannu on the Waziristan frontier today, capturing nine Hindu tradesmen and one Hindu girl, British advices said tonight.
An upper level will be added to the new Henry Hudson Parkway Bridge over the Harlem River, Park Commissioner Robert Moses, sole member of the Henry Hudson Parkway Authority, announced yesterday.
Caution proved the undoing of Charles Pierson, president of the Ski Club Hochgebirge of Boston, as he finished one-tenth of a second behind Whit Katzenbach of New Canaan, Conn.,

Mr. and Mrs. Bryce Metcalf of Ardsley, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Metcalf's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Burnet Glover, to Fanshawe Lindsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Sinderen Lindsley of Lawrence, L. I.
The Brookhattans of the American Soccer League defeated the Irish Americans of Kearny, N. J., 5 to 4, in one of the most exciting games of the season before 2,500 fans at Starlight Park yesterday.
Prices of hogs here were on the upgrade last week, reaching $10.45 a hundredweight early on Friday. The late top, that day, however, was $10.30. In the previous week the best price paid was $10.50.

President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposals were debated last night at the Broadway Temple, Broadway and 174th Street, by Justice William Harman Black of the State Supreme Court and Frederick H. Wood, one of the attorneys who successfully argued the Schechter poultry case before the Supreme Court.

Calvary is the symbol of responsibility felt and discharged, the Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee, the new rector, said yesterday morning in his sermon at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

Rosedale Bob, lemon and white pointer owned by Samuel Faile of White Plains, N. Y., scored an impressive victory today in the Open All-Age Stake which climaxed the two-day field trials of the Babylon Hlunt Club on the estate of Colonel Robert Guggenheim.
The Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler deplored "name-calling" among nations in this sermon yesterday at the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.
The wholesale price index on March 10 stood at 106.1, against 106 on March 3. This recent rise in the index almost without a break is due to the advance in world market prices.

Members of the library committee of the New York Junior League, of which Mrs. O'Donnell Hoover is chairman, will give a luncheon tomorrow at their clubhouse for Miss Marta Abba. Later Miss Abba will visit the exhibition of Humor in Literature, which opened at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League last week.
Wilhelm Buenger, Supreme Court justice who presided over the Reichstag fire trial in 1933, died tonight. He retired as Senate President in the Supreme Court in April, 1936. He was 66 years old.

Mrs. William Jennings Weller of New York gave a luncheon at the Surf Club today in honor of Miss Martha Tinsley Bright and her fiance, John Hubbard Cheatham Jr., and members of their bridal party. Miss Bright and Mr. Cheatham will be married in Miami on Saturdav.

" Driftwood" will not have its scheduled premiere tonight at the Longacre. After five postponements, a record approached in modern times by "Jumbo" and "The Eternal Road," the Samuel J. Park melodrama yesterday was deferred once more.

Sinclair Lewis writes on writing in the Winter issue of The Colophon: A Quarterly for Bookmen, that is released today. His article is headed "Breaking Into Print" and is a story of his beginnings as a writer.
The French Government, pushing nationalization of arms factories, will take possession tomorrow of the Bleriot airplane plant at Suresnes and the Aeronautical Corporative Union plant at Begles.

ST. GEORGE OF WELDON, by Robert Rylee. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) A novel of a family in the deep South. THE PARADOXES OF MR. POND, by G. K. Chesterton. (Dodd, Mead, $2.) A final collection of mysteries settled by deduction, written by the master of this form.
Mrs. Marion Rendall, a member of the executive committee of the Girl Scouts Council of America, died today in Orthopedic Hospital, New York.

Stockholders of the Merchants and Farmers Bank at Bakersville have voted unanimously to consolidate with the Deposit and Savings Bank of North Wilkesboro, the Wautaugal County Bank at Boone and the Bank of Sparta. Some time ago,

To many Holy Week is just another week, marked if at all by the school holidays, which often coincide with the last days of Lent, and brightened by the homecoming of college boys and girls for the Easter vacation.

Arthur S. Vernay, the explorer, has just returned to New York with Mrs. Vernay after a 22,000mile flying trip from London to India, Siam, Java, Hongkong, Manila, Honolulu and San Francisco in seventeen days.

With export inquiry superimposed on a domestic demand not equaled in many years and orders consistently exceeding shipments, the situation in the steel industry resolves itself into a struggle by consumers to obtain deliveries and by producers to find means to make more tonnage, according to the magazine Steel.
John A. Clinchy, retired New York business man, died last night of heart disease at his home here at the age of 70.

The newly organized New York Theatrical Press Agents will choose their permanent officers on April 1 at the Hotel Algonquin, it was decided yesterday afternoon. Those to be chosen are a president, vice president, secretary, treasurer and five members of the board of governors.

Motorists passing through this village from the Northern State Parkway to points east on the Oyster Bay peninsula today found traffic in Roslyn Harbor jammed at the high stone walls that surround Willomere, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Curtis, where the first Spring blooms made a carpet on a hillside slope.

" Joy Will Come Back," Elizabeth Goudge's dramatization of the career of Fanny Burney, novelist and diarist, consisted of a rather dull portrayal in eight scenes of a halfcentury of life in which the chief character came into contact with such notables as Samuel Johnson Boswell and Thackeray.

After being favorably impressed by the success of the new defense loan, French opinion was painfully surprised by the Communist riot last Tuesday on the outskirts of Paris at Clichy. Political and financial circles maintained their sangfroid, however, and there was no panic on the Bourse, although the fall in French securities which began last week gained a considerable pace.
Palm Sunday yesterday ushered in an Italian stage version of the Passion Play to the Broadway Theatre, the house at Broadway and Fifty-third Street which generally shows Italian screen offerings.

Protests against the Roosevelt plan to alter the Supreme Court took form in two ways here today. Dean Harry A. Bigelow of the University of Chicago Law School and five of his associates issued a public statement announcing their opposition to the Roosevelt plan.

Accelerated by speculation, the rise in British commodity prices continues at a rapid pace. The leading indices of British prices now are at the highest levels since 1929 and are substantially above the average for last year.

A pair of bowlers from Rochester, N. Y., returned home last night thoroughly convinced that there is absolutely nothing to the superstition that 13 is an unlucky number. In fact, John Pelce and Mike Lombardo left the twelfth session of the American Bowling Congress at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory pretty much inclined to regard that figure as a good omen.

Horace G. Fetterolf died today in Jefferson Hospital after an operation. He was 74 years old. Born in Collegeville, he entered the real estate business in his youth and in 1901 founded the H. G. Fetterolf Company, a rug manufacturing concern, in Germantown.

The government of El Salvador is reported to have refused permission to General Emiliano Chamorro, former Conservative President of Nicaragua, to visit Dr. Leonardo Arguello, candidate for the Presidency of Nicaragua in the recent elections, who is now an exile in El Salvador.
Officials of two New York State colleges denied tonight a statement that the "reefer man" had invaded their campuses.

In two closely contested polo games today at the Red Bank Armory, the Winmont Farms trio, conceding the Essex Troop of Newark four goals, won by the score of 11 1/2 to 9, while Silverbrook defeated the 112th Field Artillery team, 8 1/2 to 6.

A combination to bring about the election of Dennis J. Mahon, former acting president of the Board of Aldermen, as leader of Tammany is being sought by members of the Tammany executive committee opposed to Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, it was learned yesterday.

Maitland F. Griggs of New York, a graduate of the class of '96, has given Yale University a fifteenth century polychrome relief of the Virgin and Child which has been added to the collection of Italian Renaissance art in the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, today telegraphed to all auto union locals in Detroit, except General Motors, ordering them to stand by in preparation for a general automobile strike in protest against last week's raids by the police on sit-down strikers in small cigar and packing plants and retail stores. He instructed them not to strike until he gave the order.

The acute weakness that suddenly afflicted United States Government bonds this week somewhat disconcerted the market here. It all seems, howaver, part of the policy that seeks to bring about a readjustment in prices, wages and costs involved in concessions to labor and the rise in commodities with as little injury as possible to business recovery.

A collection of about 150 Goya etchings, in the earliest published state from the original plates, has been lent for exhibition in the Treasure Room of the Princeton University Library by Albert E. McVitty, '98, of Princeton, it was announced today by Dr. James Thayer Gerould, librarian.

The wave of preparation throughout Europe against sudden air attack has reached the League of Nations Palace. Secretariat officials are now working on plans to black out the whole vast structure at the first alarm. One official explained that this is mainly a question of providing an emergency system and master switch to put out all lights in one second.

A campaign for nation-wide membership in the Presbyterian Fellowship for Social Action, which was organized in this State in 1934, was announced yesterday by its president, the Rev. John Paul Jones, of Union Church, Eightieth Street and Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn.
Bishop R. E. Campbell. representing Bishop William T. Manning, conducted the Palm Sunday services yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church,124 West Sixty-ninth Street.

Myron A. Lomasney has been admitted as a general partner in Knight Co., who have moved to 40 Wall Street. The First New Amsterdam Corporation has opened a trading department under the management of Lee D. Sherman, who has been elected a vice president.
William H. Stevens, a real estate operator in Newark, died last night in Presbyterian Hospital in Newark, following an operation performed three days ago. He was 51 years old and lived here.

The National Hockey League concluded its regular season last night and turned attention toward the post-season play-offs for the league championship and the Stanley Cup, historic emblem of the world professional championship.

Securities with estimated gross proceeds of $429,990,000 became fully effective during January, as compared with $698,408,000 in December, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Preferred stock issues aggregated $134,719,000, the largest amount for such issues registered in any month since the act became effective in July, 1933.

Members of the New York Board of Trade have been urged to resist racketeering in any form. The appeal was made in a letter from M. D. Griffith, executive vice, president of the organization, which was made public yesterday.
The departure of the Pan American Clipper for Kingman Reef, the next stop on our survey route to New Zealand, has been delayed until Tuesday to permit tests of our radio direction finder.

Nantucket Island, which recently threatened to secede from Massachusetts and join New York State in a complaint against utility rates, now has a battle among its Selectmen over the question of whether the town could run a night club.

The Cardinals came out of for their four-game losing streak today in a 5-to-2 victory over their American Association farm, Columbus. The pickings were not so easy, however, for St. Louis held only a one-run lead until Terry Moore rapped a homer with a mate aboard in the eighth.

The recent pronounced decline in British Government securities, as a result of which the yield basis has increased by at least one-fourth of 1 per cent, appears to be giving way to more stable conditions. Actually,

The independence of New York City's public school system is in jeopardy and a "body blow" to the welfare of the 36,000 teachers and 1,120,000 pupils is threatened, James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education, charged yesterday.
With a loss estimated at $250,000, Peny Bryn, the residence of Colonel Louis A. Watres, former Lieutenant Governor of Pennsylvania, was destroyed by fire this afternoon.

Admiral Spencer Victor Yorke De Horsey, who retired in 1911, died on the Isle of Wight today at the age of 73. He was a son of Admiral Sir Algernon De Horsey, who died in 1922 at the age of 95, and a grandson of Admiral Andrew Drew.

There were plenty of signs of Spring around New York yesterday, and not all of them were in the shop windows. The fact that any one who looked too persistently for the gentle season. was likely to get wind-burned did not keep many thousands from strolling along Fifth Avenue and the other promenades. Other parts of the country, however, were less fortunate.

A sharp upward movement of private placement activity by the United States Employment Service during February with 158,013 placements in private industry, a gain of 138.5 per cent over February, 1936, was reported today by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

New York causes as much sorrow to Christ as did ancient Jerusalem, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared in his sermon yesterday after he had dedicated a new set of chimes at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street. The chimes were given to the church by Mr. and Mrs. James H. Schmelzel in memory of their son. James H. Schmelzel Jr.

Warm sun and bright skies took President Roosevelt into the open most of today. He visited the camp of marines established here for his protection and again took a critic's part in a golf match between his aides here.

A plan for setting up the fellowships at a major university for the study of Christian-Jewish relations on the campus with a view to improving racial relations at the university was announced last night at a dinner of the Pi Lambda Phi

An antiCommunist world congress to be a held in the near future was an- h nounced today by Nils von Bahr, e Swedish Army reserve officer, who is secretary of a group representing twenty nationalities.

Don Bosco Institute, finalist last year, was eliminated by a speedy Brooklyn Prep quintet last night in one of the features of the first round in the eighth annual metropolitan Catholic High Schools invitation basketball tournament. Brooklyn Prep won, 27-19.

The defeat of the child labor amendment shows that education must be completely secularized if democracy is to continue, the Rev. Dr. Charles Francis Potter said yesterday morning in his sermon before the First Humanist Society of New York, at 113 West Fiftyseventh Street.

Representative John T. Bernard of Minnesota attacked yesterday the McReynolds neutrality resolution adopted by the House last week. He spoke at Mecca Temple at a meeting sponsored by the Italian Anti-Fascist Committee and attended by about 3,000 persons.

Indications that the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization would work together in unionizing New Jersey employes for the present, at least, were noted today in statements by State leaders of the two groups.

French and American art of the nineteenth century is very much to the fore in the exhibitions of the current week. "Masterpieces of French Painting, From Courbet to Seurat," is the title of the new attraction at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries.

The Vienna public today demonstrated its antipathy for Italians on the football grounds. The Austro-Italian international match was halted by the referee a quarter of an hour before the close of play owing to the violent conduct of the two teams.

The Catholic Youth Organization staged its first outdoor art exhibition yesterday. Like the larger outdoor exhibitions by the city's adult artists, it was held in Greenwich Village, but instead of sprawling all over Washington Square

When Rheims was under fire French peasants had to be driven from the plow-so callous had they grown to screaming shells. In New London, Texas, it must have been the same. Here is a vast pool from which 22,000 wells pump oil.

Miss Virginia Schwarte, 55 years old, a public school teacher for thirty-three years, killed herself yesterday morning by jumping from the window of her apartment on the thirteenth floor of 200 East Sixteenth Street. She had suffered a nervous Beakdown.
Albert Petersen, 55 years old, a chauffeur, of 65 East Eighty-second Street, was fatally injured by two automobiles at Park Avenue and Eighty-second Street yesterday.

On February's foreign trade return opinions here are divided. The pessimists point out that the pace of increase of export surpluses slackened, the February surplus, indeed, being the smallest since July, 1936. This development is not propitious from the point of view of imports and debt service.

A sit-down strike, despite Governor Hurley's stand against such demonstrations, will be called among 3,400 employes of more than thirty-four Greater Boston cleaning and dyeing firms Wednesday, if an employers' committee does not meet union demands at a conference tomorrow, Joseph Salerno, organizer of a new C. I. O. union in the industry, said today.

Federal aid in removing the obstacles to neighborhood self-development and community self-expression is suggested as the next step in the solution of the housing problem in a symposium in the April issue of The Junior League Magazine.
A north-northwest wind, bringing the hardest puffs of any Sunday of the entire Winter, limited the New Rochelle Class D dinghy fleet to four boats and one race today.
Sir James Jeans, Professor of Astronomy at the Royal Institution, will arrive this afternoon on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, accompanied by Lady Jeans.

Miss Dorothy Boxer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Boxer of Brooklyn, was married to Martin Cain of Atlanta, 'Ga., yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 3,004 Bedford Avenue, by the Rev. Maxwell Sachs of the Jewish Center of Brooklyn.

The spiritual triumph of Jesus celebrated on Palm Sunday has become an everlasting inspiration to the human race, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, said yesterday morning in his sermon. The church is at Lexingon Avenue and East Eightieth Street.

New York City "is filled with Palm Sunday Christians," the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said there yesterday morning. Such Christians he termed timid and fickle.

Ed Gisburne of the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. captured the Metropolitan A. A. U. junior 50yard free style swimming championship at the Park Central pool yesterday in the excellent time of 0:25. Anthony Steinhauser, unattached, finished inches behind Gisburne with Nat Cannon of Park Central third.
A new record in the consumption of copper in the United States is indicated for this year, according to Bertram B. Caddie, secretary of the Copper and Brass Research Association.

Scoring a record-tying 63. for the first half of the match, Henwr Picard of Hershey, Pa., and Frank Ford of Charleston, S. C., defeated the New York combination of Jimmy Hines and Mark J. Stuart, 4 and 3, in the 36-hole final of the third annual national professionalamateur best-ball match play championship today on St. Augustine Links.

Howard S. Cullman, who was vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea until it was dissolved a week ago, made public yesterday a letter to Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper in which Mr. Cullman defended his stand as a critic of the department's management of maritime affairs.
The end of the depression was formally acclaimed by organizers of the National Business Show, the first to be held here since 1931, tonight as they prepared for the opening tomorrow. The show,
Jack Rutherfurd of New York sent his Baby Juno roaring to victory today in a dogfight for the Wanamaker Trophy that featured the finish of the twenty-fourth annual Biscayne Bay regatta.
Non-striking employes or the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Mills and officials of the company reached an agreement here tonight on new wages and hours.

A "lost" Rembrandt painting, the "Juno" portrait that gathered dust in the cellar of a museum in Germany for more than thirty years, is to arrive here on the Queen Mary today to be exhibited for the first time in this country.

Winning in the semi-final round by 7-3 from the Scanthorn team of Brooklyn, the Marshall Chess Club notched its fifth consecutive victory in the annual inter-club series for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday.
Governor Lehman's $370,000,000 budget bill is due for passage in the Senate tomorrow night as the legislators renew their sessions.

Whether because this was Palm Sunday or the morning after the threat by the United Automobile Workers to call a general strike in the motor industry, the city halted its drive against sit-downs today.
The budgets of the city agencies concerned with the detection and guarding against crime, together with those for its prosecution and punishment, total more than $64,000,000 a year,

The Clarinet Ensemble of the Philharmonic - Symphony Society celebrated its tenth anniversary with a jubilee concert in Town Hall last night. Besides commemorating the inception of the ensemble, the concert was a benefit for the founding and maintenance of an instrument committee of that body.

Wheat prices throughout the world moved to new high levels last week and the markets had the most bullish sentiment that has existed this season. The finish was well toward the top of the week. There were sharp recessions, due largely to profit-taking on futures, but every show of weakness developed new buying which eventually carried prices upward more rapidly than they had declined.
Fire Captain Ernest Walah of Engine 8 of the Yonkers Fire Department was found dead in the fire house by fellow-firemen this morning. He was 46 years old.

Jacob J. A. de Haas, American representative of the New Zionist Organization, of which Vladimir Jabotinsky is president, died last night in Mount Sinai Hospital, where he had been a patient for several weeks.

The disastrous school explosion in Texas calls for an immediate examination of the safety of all public school buildings, the Rev. John Brett Langstaff, rector of St. Edmund's Protestant Episcopal Church, Morris Avenue and 177th Street, the Bronx, said in his sermon there yesterday morning.

The German labor service army is being expanded and early next month will call to the spade no less than 235,000 young men for six months' service, compared with the last contingent of 160,000 discharged today.

Dorothy Thompson's one-woman debate. on the President's Supreme Court proposals has been printed in pamphlet form by the League for Political Education. The pamphlet is called, "Our Constitutional Crisis: Two Views."
Ralph Flanagan of Miami clipped three and one-fifth seconds from Johnny Weissmuller's ten-year-old United States free-style swimming record for 500 yards over a twenty-yard course today.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday that the three-platoon system for firemen would be fully in effect in all boroughs four months before the deadline set by the referendum last Fall.

Two developments of the past week have served to focus fresh attention on the question of national finance. One of these is the decline in the price of Federal securities, a movement which may have raised in some quarters the question whether the Government's fiscal position has in any way taken a sudden turn for the worse.

The W. T. Grant Company and subsidiaries reported consolidated net earnings of $4,594,379 after all charges, including provision for Federal income taxes and $257,000 for undistributed-earnings tax, according to the annual report for the year ended on Jan. 31, issued today.

The fact that General Glatz of the Rumanian War Office, who is in charge of Rumanian rearmament, will accompany Premier George Tatarescu on his visit to Czechoslovakia tomorrow indicates that the scheme for unification of the Little Entente's armament will be carried a step further.

A resolution calling on Mayor Hague and the City Commission to protect free institutions from defacement by vandals and "Nazi sympathizers" was adopted today at a meeting under the auspices of the Hudson County Council of Jewish War Veterans.

An insanity defense was planned yesterday for Salvatore Ossido, the 26-year-old Brooklyn barber charged with the criminal assault and murder of 9-year-old Einer Sporrer, German-born parochial schoolgirl, in the back room of his barber shop Friday afternoon.

Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen, engineer-in-chief of the navy, disclosed today the development of a new high-pressure boiler at the Naval Experiment Station at Annapolis in experiments to improve the motive power and decrease the machinery weight in battleships.

Out of the industrial turmoil of Detroit has come a new word-" strikemaker." As vivid a term as the cognate "strike-breaker," it describes the individual sent across State lines by labor organizers to stir up trouble and sit down for pay in a plant where he has never worked.

Most of the sit-down strikers in the five F. W. Grand 5-10-and25 stores continued their occupation of the establishments yester.day, expecting an early settlement of the strike. A conference of representatives of the Department Store Employes Union, Local 1,250, the strike organization, will be held at City Hall with Mayor La Guardia today in an effort to bring about a settlement.

Former King Edward VIII, despite the abdication of his throne, is still one of the ten outstanding news figures in the world today, according to a poll made public yesterday by students of journalism in the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance of New York University at Washington Square East.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Henry Larned Keith Shaw of Albany and Guilderland, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter. Miss Elizabeth Burrill Shaw, to Archibald Carr, son of Mrs. Archibald Hamilton Rowan Carr of Edgebank, Deramore Park, Belfast, Ireland, and the late Mr. Carr.

Billboards throughout Germany carried glaring placards today urging the public to buy a special number of Julius Streicher's Stuermer, consisting of a fourteen-page article intended to demonstrate that the essence of Christianity is antiSemitism.

The government's national defense loan, with a foreign exchange guarantee, was a complete success, subscriptions reaching around 8,500,000,000 francs, or 500,000,000 more than the offering. All the bonds that were subscribed for will be allotted, because the government had the right to Issue up to 10,500,000,000 francs worth.

The Hospital Workers Union, Local 171, threatened yesterday to cripple further the services of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, 555 Prospect Place, where sit-down strikes were started last week. Moris Berlin, vice president of Local 171, asserted that hospital employes who had remained at their posts were prepared to act on the union's instructions.

A bulletin of the Central Reserve Bank says that, in keeping with the upward trend of foreign trade, the money market and banking activities in Peru showed greater expansion last year than in previous years. Deposits in November amounted to 226,000,000 soles, an increase of 20 per cent over November. 1935.

The projected visit of Mayor La Guardia of New York to Annapolis tomorrow in behalf of ratification by Maryland of the Federal child labor amendment was sharply criticized today by Harry O. Levin, legislative counsel for the American Bar Association.

John H. Vruwink, '38, of Albany, N. Y., varsity football end, has been elected captain of the Princeton University basketball team for next season, it was announced tonight by Coach Kenneth Fairman. Vruwink will succeed Fred D. Sauter of Chicago.

Germany's economic position promises to be solved either by an explosion leading to forcible territorial expansion or the reintegration of the country in the world economy, the Foreign Policy Association said today in a report prepared by J. C. de Wilde of its research staff.

An increase of almost 3,000,000 pounds in local lard stocks in the first two weeks of March led to hedging sales by packers here last week. There also was selling against receipts of cottonseed oil. Trade was spasmodic and on the whole lighter than in recent weeks.

Catholic and Protestant defenders of the traditional confessional school system suffered an overwhelming defeat in Saar-Pfalz and the neighboring Palatinate today. School registration showed 13,478 children of school age entered for the non-confessional National Socialist schools and only 268 for confessional schools.

A 10-year-old girl from Atlanta visited this spot today and suddenly found herself putting a flower in the President's buttonhole. She was Jacqueline Jones, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. K. Jones, and a niece of one of the newspaper men here with the President's party.

Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Domestic Relations Court declared his opposition to President's Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court yesterday, terming the plan an "unblushing program" under which the additional judges would be expected to "disregard their oath of office and ignore the Constitution."

The French pair, Emile Diot and Emile Ignat, won Chicago's thirty-seventh international six-day bicycle race tonight in the Chicago Stadium, finishing with a one-lap margin over Cor Wals and Alvaro Georgetti, and William (Torchy) Peden and Jules Audy.

The most extensive land, sea and air manoeuvres ever held by the British forces at Hongkong, lasting six days, were concluded this morning. A communique said the defenses were found adequate although the attacking forces, which included 1,000 British troops from Singapore, outnumbered the defenders.

The rise in prices of raw materials is considered here as justified by the increased outlets, and that is a consequence of the world-wide economic recovery and rearmament, but it certainly was accentuated by speculation. Nevertheless, it is difficult to prevent speculation by intervention of a monetary nature because, by trying to limit the extension of credit to speculators, there is the risk of depriving trade and industry of credit facilities which they need.

Despite favorable corporation reports, stocks here most of this week declined. Exceptions were commercial banks, which held well, and certain specialties, chief among which were Harburg Rubber, Bruderus Iron and West German Department Stores.
Settlement of the long tugboat strike has been announced, with tugboat union members receiving a 20 per cent wage increase and a 50 per cent reduction in working hours.

An increase of more than $6,000,000 in net working capital is reported today by the Canadian Pacific Railway Company in its fifty-sixth annual statement for 1936. Total assets increased about $14,000,000 in the year.

In a registered shoot at the North Jersey Gun Club today J. A. Seegar, a Class A marksman, won the high-over-all trophy with a card of 94. J. D. Rae and W. M. Frederick tied for second in Class A with B. M. Higglnson next.

A permanent international trade commission is advocated by Dr. Lewis L. Lorwin, economic adviser to the International Labor Office, writing in "The World Textile Conference," a book to be published today by the National Peace Conference.

All day meeting of the National Council of Jewish Women, Essex Souse, 10 A. M. Mrs. Leo Sulzberger will preside. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "The Americas Versus Old World Diplomacy," Edward Tomlinson.

An appeal for enlistments this week in the Women's Field Army of the American Society for the Control of Cancer was made public yesterday by the society. The appeal was signed by thirty-nine prominent women and physicians in all parts of the country.

The second of the series of "Continental Concerts" was presented at the Plaza last night. Macklin Marrow directed a small orchestra in works by Rossini, Wagner, Rimsky-Korsakoff, Mozart, Mendelssohn. Handel and Dvorak.

Testimony that the gas line serving the explosion-shattered London Consolidated School had been connected to a gas company pipe "without knoweldge or consent" of the company was heard by a military inquiry today while the funerals of the 455 child victims Proceeded.
Ogligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,670,199,500.

A matter of $50,000, among other things, stands in the way of a world's heavyweight title fight in Berlin in June. Max Schmeling, former holder of the crown, yesterday made a new offer to James J. Braddock of a flat guarantee of $350,000 for the latter to defend his championship against Schmeling in the German capital three months from now, and Joe Gould, Braddock's manager, countered with a demand for $400,000.
Connecticut's striped bass survey, which was conducted last year under the supervision of the State's Board of Fisheries and Game, will be continued, but on a broader scale, this season.

A motive for Anatole Maren's suicide plunge from an air transport over mountainous western Kern County presented a mystery tonight to authorities as they concluded a fruitless search for the San Francisco man's body.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Willcox of Cornell University, Ithaca, N. Y.. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Goodenow Willcox, to Alexander Wiley of New York.

Full support of the Committee for Industrial Organization was voted yesterday by New York Typographical Union No. 6, which includes 10,500 newspaper, book and job printers in this city. The action was taken by unanimous vote of 700 members at the union's regular monthly meeting at Stuyvesant High School.
New York State has turned to the airplane in its fight against "dendroctonus piceaperda," an Eastern spruce beetle that threatens to destroy the Adirondack forest preserve.

The Italian Teatro d'Arte gave Ibsen's "Ghosts," under the direction of Comm. Giuseppe Sterni at the Vanderbilt Theatre, yesterday afternoon and evening before a half-house followed by a full one. There were curtain calls after the third act and at the end.
Robert Armstrong, national union representative, declared today that interurban and electric power service in this area "will not be resumed until our demands have been met."

The scene of the Palestine crime wave shifted to the south today. Dov Zemel, chauffeur, of the Meshek Haotzar settlement, between Kfar Saba and Telmond, in Southern Palestine, was fired on from an Arab-owned orange grove near by. He is in a critical condition in Hadassah Hospital in Tel Aviv.

Eleven New York City boys were among the class of forty graduates who received diplomas today at the thirty-seventh annual commencement exercises of National Farm School, near here. Six of the New York group were prize winners. The graduates came from nine States.

Plans to unionize the 75,000 utility workers of the Consolidated Edison Company and its affiliates are being prepared jointly by the Brotherhood of Utility Workers and the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union, it was announced yesterday from the office of the last-named organization, 1,133 Broadway.
The official English abstract of the encyclical epistle from Pope Pius to German Bishops, including some textual excerpts, follows:

Frank G. Shattuck, founder and chairman of the board of directors of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, operators of Schrafft's restaurants and candy stores, who died on March 14, left most of his estate to his family.
