When his will was filed yesterday the estate was formally valued at "more than $30,000."

Winning exhibition. games in the Spring, it is true, never exactly won a pennant for a major league ball club in September. There have, in fact, been clubs such as the Yankees of a number of years ago who would lose these Spring jousts with alarming regularity only to come on at the start of the championship campaign and flatten all opposition.

Dr. Edwin A. Spies, a specialist in orthopedic surgery, who had been surgeon to the New York Yankees for the last three years, died suddenly here last night of a heart attack at his home, 252 Elderwood Avenue, at the age of 49. He had been suffering from a cardiac ailment since November.

The last of 1,188,000 cubic feet of structural concrete for the first eighteen units in the $12,500,000 PWA housing project in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn was poured yesterday, according to Romer Shawhan, project manager.

A suggestion that sex criminals be segregated and sterilized "if necessary" was advanced yesterday by County Judge George W. Martin in Brooklyn at the arraignment on a first-degree murder indictment of Salvatore Ossido, 26-year-old barber, accused of criminally assaulting and murdering 9-year-old Einer

A baby boy between two and three weeks old was left last night on the doorstep of Nicholas Turco, an unemployed barber, who has twelve children of his own and is expecting another child. Turco discovered the foundling about 8 o'clock as he entered his house at 588 Second Avenue.

Press reports from Shanghai admit that the Japanese trade mission, which is seeking to promote commerce with China, has found its efforts balked by the polite, but undisguised, refusal of Chinese to engage in economic cooperation until Japan's policy in North China is changed.
Police here today cleared two places of sitdown strikers, despite threats of a general strike call in event of such action.

Seville, Andalusia's capital, which normally has a population of something over 300,000, now has considerably more as a result of its military importance in the last eight months. Nevertheless, the city by no means resembles an armed camp. Uniformed men do not predominate in the streets.

Wellesley College paid tribute to the scholastic achievements of 148 undergraduates and five alumnae this morning at the annual Honors Day celebration. In an address before the assembled students and faculty Dr. George L. Kittredge, Professor Emeritus of English at Harvard, spoke on "Shakespeare and His Critics.

Five Canadian pulp and paper companies have announced that they will follow the lead of the International company in raising the price of newsprint to $50 a ton in 1938. It is expected that the whole industry will follow suit.

Play will be resumed tonight in the indoor polo championships at Squadron A Armory with the opening match of the high-goal competition for the new Granniss Cups. In this game Elbridge T. Gerry leads his Aknusti team into action against Billy Nicholls's Old Westbury side.

Stocks reactionary, closed with 1 to 6 points losses; turnover, 2,025,960 shares. United States Government bonds weakened to new low levels after early gains; corporate and foreign bonds lower; transactions, $18,749,000.

Mrs. Wayne Chatfield-Taylor and the Misses Adelaide and Rose Chatfield-Taylor have come from Washington to the Savoy-Plaza. Sir James and Lady Calder of London have arrived at the RitzCarlton after a trip in the South.

Merchants will increase their advertising linage in newspapers from 5 to 20 per cent above last year, according to a survey by Roy Ozanne merchandising counselor of The Merchandise Mart, Chicago. This will not necessarily mean increased advertising appropriations for retailers, but that a greater percentage of the budget will go into newspaper space.

Ferdinand Pecora, New York Supreme Court justice, defended last night President Roosevelt's proposal for a change in the United States Supreme Court as constitutional, necessary and in line with the New Deal philosophy of government approved by the voters in 1932, 1934 and 1936.

George Henry Minor, vice president and secretary of the Erie Railroad Company, died yesterday after an illness of several days. He was 70 years old and had been with the Erie Railroad since 1903. It was a natural development that George H. Minor should spend the major part of his business career with the Erie Railroad,

The new Pier 92. last of five piers built on the North River waterfront between Forty-fourth and Fifty-second Streets by the Department of Docks in the last ten years, will be occupied for the first time on Thursday when the Italian liner Saturnia arrives from Trieste with passengers and freight.
The nude body of Frank O. Vosper, who vanished recently from the French liner Paris, has been washed ashore near Eastbourne. An inquest will be held Wednesday.
The text of the speech delivered by John Hessin Clarke, former member of the United States Su preme Court, over a network o, the National Broadcasting Com pany, was as follows:
Carnegie Institution of Washington announced today the discovery, in a pyramid mound of the ancient Maya near Guatemala City, of the largest piece of jade ever found in the New World.
Former Governor and Mrs. Nathan L. Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Miller, to Francis T. Carmody, son of Mr. and Mrs. Terence F. Carmody of Watertown, Conn.

Joel McCrea today won from Samuel Goldwyn his release from the part of Terangi in the NordhoffHall "Hurricane," pointing out that his Caucasian features differ considerably from those of a South Sea native. After a conference with Director John Ford, Goldwyn switched McCrea to the romantic lead in "Dead End," with Sylvia Sidney and Humphrey Bogart.

Fred Perry of Great Britain followed William Tilden .into town yesterday morning to prepare for their match tomorrow evening al Madison Square Garden. Perry came on from Chattanooga, Tenn., accompanied by Ellsworth Vines and Bruce Barnes, and Tilden reached here from Dayton, Ohio. These four players and Vincent Richards will all appear on the Garden tennis program.

AS I was reading away in Ford Madox Ford's "Portraits From Life" (Houghton Mifflin, $3), I kept thinking of Mr. Ford himself-how one evening earlier this Winter (or last Winter, to be accurate and completely up to date) he had stood leaning -against our host's black piano and had talked in a slow, very wheezy voice about a sable wrap.

Harold B. Butler, director of the International Labor Office in Geneva, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to attend the Conference of Textile Producing Nations that will open in Washington April 2.

A radio in every classroom in the New York City public school system was advocated yesterday by Dr. Joseph M. Sheehan, Associate Superintendent of Schools. Through the use of the radio, Dr. Sheehan declared, school work could be made more exciting and vital for both pupils and teachers.

After a year of engineering examinations and metallurgical tests, a New York syndicate represented by a George A. Hool has taken over the San Marcos group of eleven gold claims five miles southeast of Wenden. Mr. Hool expects to have the property producing within a few months.

Queen Mary will wear her own crown at the coronation, it became known today. Detachable crossbars will be removed along with several State jewels, including the Kohinoor diamond, which will be in Queen Elizabeth's crown.
Sir Robert L. Craigie, former British Assistant Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, arrived yesterday from England on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Residents of the Fort Hill Road section of Greenburgh crowded into the court room of Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis today when trial began of a suit instituted by Mrs. Marion A. Ridgway to enjoin "Negroes" from living in the section.

Lord Elton, writer and leader in Great Britain's Labor party, will arrive today from London on the Cunard White Star liner 'Scythia, accompanied by Lady Elton. Others coming on the ship include Horace E. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. S. H. Armstrong, Mrs. Edna W. Curtis, Major J. H. Roberts, Arthur Butterfield and Mrs. H. G. Webber.

Mrs. Georgette Gerard - Varet Hyde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Gerard-Varet of Semur, Cote d'Or, France, and Harris Fahnestock of 15 East Sixty-sixth Street and Eastover, Lenox, Mass., obtained a marriage license yesterday in the Municipal Building. They will be married in this city next Tuesday.

The fourteenth and final week of the Metropolitan Opera season began last night with Puccini's "La Boheme." Bidu Sayao, who has given praiseworthy accounts of herself in the title roles of "Manon" and "Traviata," sang Mimi for the first time locally. She made a sympathetic, appealing figure.

Winding up training for Wednesday's race with Cambridge, the Oxford crew paddled in a cold wind to the Stork training ship today and attempted a start from the stakeboat. The Dark Blues got in 10 strokes in a quarter-minute and 18 in half a minute.
The opening shot was fired today in Madison Square Garden's legal campaign to compel Jim Braddock, heavyweight boxing champion, to fight Max Schmeling instead of Joe Louis.

Frederick William MacMonnies, American sculptor, died of pneumonia last night in the Doctors Hospital. He was 73 years old. Mr. MacMonnies had won honors with his sculptures in many of the capitals of the world. He is represlented by his works in the greatest museums of Europe and America. heroic monuments stand upon battlefields and in public places at home and abroad.

K. T. Keller, president of Chrysler Corporation, yesterday announced the appointment of Herman L. Weckler as vice president in charge of industrial relations. Mr. Weckler is now vice president and general manager of the DeSoto division.

Receipts of hogs today fell considerably below trade expectations, and, while demand was not brisk, prices here advanced 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight, the top of $10.50 being 5 cents above the close of last week and the highest since Jan. 12.

Joseph H. Nuelle, who has been connected with the New York, Ontario Western Railway since 1908, has submitted his resignation as president of that company to become president of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, financial circles disclosed yesterday. The change follows the acquisition of a large amount of the coal company's stock by a group headed by .the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation.

The building containing a theatre and thirteen stores on the block front on the south side of Roosevelt Avenue, between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Streets, Woodside, Queens, was sold by the Pensy Holding Corporation to an investing client of Edwards Co., brokers. It occupies a plot 224 by 178 feet.

It is reported in film circles that the new owners of UFA paid last week for all the concern's stock 29,000,000 marks. The total outstanding stock had a par value of 45,000,000 marks and stood at 74 on the Boerse.

One hundred and two men were arrested late today when police and Elbert T. Gallagher, Assistant District Attorney, raided an alleged bookmaking establishment over a furniture store at 63 Main Street. Horse race betting equipment, including elaborate electrical tabulators and a loud-speaker system, was dismantled and carted to police headquarters.
Franklyn Munnell, actor, died yesterday at the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital. Mr. Munnell, a native of Canonsburg, Pa., was 66 years old. He formerly lived at 316 West Fifty-sixth Street.
The French liner Normandie recaptured the record for the fastest eastward Atlantic crossing from the British Queen Mary, it was announced tonight.
Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch's foreign policy was subjected to a severe cross fire of criticism in the Senate today, after he had repeated the expos he delivered in the Chamber of Deputies last week.
A mother and four children perished early this morning when fire, apparently started by a defective oilburner, destroyed their two-story, frame dwelling at 73 Verity Lane in Baldwin Harbor.

Miles M. O'Brien, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the Homicide Bureau, made a report yesterday to District Attorney Dodge on the death of three persons in a fire that swept the tenements at 137 and 139 Suffolk Street in the early morning of March 4.

An extract from the log of the Empress Ann, of which Ben E1derd of Freeport, L. I., is captain, describes the fishing trip of a party of New Yorkers off the Florida coast during the week-end just past.

Buster Boy, owned by Miss L. C. White, won the fifth race, feature of the card, at the Fair Grounds today. The gray gelding, close up most of the way, assumed command in the stretch and was two lengths ahead of J. Baumbach's Windshield at the finish. The latter took the place award from Mrs. C. C. Winter's Always Blue.

Dr. John B. (Jock) Sutherland called threescore Pitt football candidates into the brisk Spring air for practice today and introduced two new assistant coaches. The men he chose to fill vacancies created by the exodus of aides to other schools were Alec Fox of Philadelphia, line coach at the University of Pennsylvania, and Edward Schultz, a Pittsburgh attorney.

A 33-year-old Negro odd-job man was arrested tonight and charged with the slaying of Mrs. Celia Kadesh, 60 years old, who was beaten to death in her bedroom in her apartment here last night. Her daughter, Bessie, 23, a University of Pennsylvania graduate, was critically injured.

Parents were warned last night not to insist always on the same standard of results from their children in their school work. Dr. Fritz Redl of Vienna, fellow in research of the Progressive Education Association, who issued the warning, said that parents should make allowances for outside influences.

Bernard A. Ottenberg of 50 West Fifty-fourth Street, who had been a real estate operator in this city for the last thirty years, died yesterday, in the Park East Hospital after a ten days' illness. A bachelor, he is survived by three sisters, Mrs. L. D. Bloch, Mrs. Charles Ehrlich and Mrs. Roy Foster.

Democratic and Republican office holders joined yesterday in pressing for the passage of legislation permitting the city to acquire the Rockaway Division of the Long Island Railroad and connect it with the Queens branch of the city's independent subway system.

John Hessin Clarke, only living former Justice of the Supreme Court, defended in a nation-wide radio address tonight the constitutionality of President Roosevelt's program for enlarging the court, but expressed no opinion on the wisdom of the proposal.

With fifty-three candidates reporting, Spring practice drills for the New York University football team began yesterday at Ohio Field. The sessions will be held every afternoon and are expected to continue for the next four weeks.

Thirteen thousand workers at the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation's Aliquippa works opened a drive today for a new general wage increase in the steel industry. Thirty-six leaders of the plant's company union voted unanimously to reopen wage negotiations with the corporation and the movement has the backing of the Committee and Industrial Organization chiefs.

That the sensational good luck of Mrs. Emil Denemark ended on closing day at Hialeah Park, when her favored Finance lost to Columbiana in the Widener Challenge Cup Handicap, was again demonstrated at Tropical Park today.

The comparative effects of moving pictures, appeals by mail, radio and posters in the development of women's activities were discussed yesterday at a meeting of 150 delegates of the National Council of Jewish Women at Essex House.
Pitt came through with a hardfought 35-29 victory over Temple in the play-off for the Eastern Intercollegiate Conference basketball championship at the Arena tonight before a crowd of 4,000 fans.

The Rev. Thomas J. McNichol, C. S. P., former rector of the Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd, 207th Street and Broadway, died yesterday in a hospital in Baltimore, where, for the last six years, he had been superior of the Paulist Preparatory Seminary. Father McNichol, who was born in Philadelphia sixty-six years ago, was ordained in 1897.

A new type of public nuisancethe "radio bug," who is a brother of the fire bug--telephoned a false report of a hold-up to police headquarters last night, apparently just for the fun of seeing radio cars whizz by.

Ethel and Otto Luening gave a joint recital at the Town Hall last night. Mrs. Luening is a soprano and Mr. Luening plays the flute. They were assisted at the piano by Willard Rhodes. The first half of the program was devoted to rarely heard classics and the second to first performances of contemporary Americans.

Reorganization of the bankrupt Abitibi Power and Paper Company is closer to realization now than any time since the company failed, Attorney General Arthur Roebuck told the Ontario Legislature today in introducing a bill affecting the company.

Sit-down strikers who have been occupying the Champion Shoe Manufacturing Company's plant at 104 Bleecker Street since March 11 will be ordered summarily evicted unless they can show a legal right to remain, Justice Julius Miller declared yesterday as he started trial of the first injunction suit involving the new labor strategy to reach the Supreme Court in Manhattan.
Members of the Service Club of St. Thomas Church have arranged a card party and tea for March 30 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of the Church Mission of Help.

Several sales and industrial leases in New Jersey were reported yesterday. In New Brunswick the estate of Frances Smith Johnson on Easton Avenue was sold to Charles F. Marden, a professor at Rutgers University. Joseph P.Day, Inc., the broker in the deal, also sold the following three properties In Bergen County:

Four world speedboat straightaway records fell and a new one was established in time trials over smooth Indian Creek today. The Black Imp III, a Cincinnati boat owned by Charles Schuler and driven by Dr. Robert H. Hermann, churned the measured mile twice for an average speed of 69.903 miles an hour in the test for 225-Class Hydroplanes.

Three bills aimed at preventing price cutting, now pending in the Legislature, were attacked today by William J. Wells, president of L. Bamberger Co., in a pamphlet asking members to defeat the measures.

More than four floors in the Empire State Building at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street have been leased to the Schenley Distillers Corporation and affiliated companies. Closing of contract for this large space was announced yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, as president of Empre State, Inc.

Frank E. Gannett, back today from a Washington visit, declared that several Senators told him the administration was beginning to "turn on the heat" in its fight for President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan.

Several ships, led by the Hamburg of the Hamburg-American Line, were racing last night to aid the stricken Norwegian freighter Bjerkli, which sent out distress signals early in the evening from a point about 400 miles south of Sable Island.
If the Boston Bees come anywhere near winning the National League pennant this season, it will be a great surprise to all concerned, beginning with the Boston Bees individually and collectively.

Large volume trading developed in synthetic gray goods toward the end of last week and a strengthening price tendency developed at the week-end, following the numerous wage increases announced, according to the market report of Nickel, Barrett, Lieberman Quinn, Inc., textile brokers. The price differential existing between buyer and seller narrowed considerably during the week, with some business taken and much more offered. However.

This, the world's smallest inhabited ocean island, located almost in the exact center of the Pacific Ocean, 3,000 miles from the mainland and 1,000 miles from Hawaii, is ready to take its place as a key port on the trans-ocean airways map. The first airplane ever to explore this quarter of the Pacific is expected to arrive here tomorrow.
The Western Beer Corporation, 2 Baltic Street, Brooklyn, will take over the distribution of Schlitzbeer in the metropolitan market April 1, it was announced yesterday.
The first American novel will shortly be republished by Columbia University Press. The title is, "The Power of Sympathy; or, The Triumph of Nature," and the book first appeared in January. 1789.

To speed up confirmation of Joseph P. Kennedy of New York, nominated by President Roosevelt to be chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, Senator Robinson today introduced a joint resolution which stipulates that ownership of shipyard stock by Mr. Kennedy "shall not be deemed to be in violation" of provisions of the Maritime Act.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Dietz of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Elizabeth Dietz, to Walter Bolles Davison of Hightstown, N. J.

Democrats of the Assembly dis. cussed in caucus today a bill which would set up a State Labor Relations Commission with the power to conduct elections in factories in the State and determine what unit, whether industrial or factory union, should be recognized in collective bargaining.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, proprietor of one of the country's largest racing strings, is the leading nominator for stakes at Saratoga next August, according to an announcement from the Saratoga Association yesterday.

Enraged to a fighting pitch by the rough tactics of his opponent, Danno O'Mahoney, former world heavyweight wrestling champion, suddenly unleashed a furious attack last night at Madison Square Garden and in practically no time at all had George Koverly's shoulders pnned firmly to the canvas.

Fritz Kuhn, national leader of the German American League, the center of the pro-Nazi movement in this country, accepted a summons here yesterday to appear in the Yorkville Magistrate's Court on March 29 at 10 A. M.

J. Dana Kafer, former Princeton University athlete and a member of the all-America football team in 1903, died of heart attack today at his home here. He was 57 years old. Recognized as one of the outstanding athletes of his day, Mr. Kafer was a member of the baseball and football teams while at Princeton University. He prepared at Lawrenceville School

A picture, characterized by officials as more than "cheering," of the operations in 1936 of 7,584 insured State banks which are not members of the Federal Reserve System was disclosed today by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. It showed net profits for these banks, before dividends, of $76,000,000, or about 7 1/2 per cent on their capital stock. This contrasted with a net loss of $5,000,000 in 1935.

In accord with a previous decision to adjust all grievances peaceably, representatives of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union met yesterday with spokesmen for the Realty Advisory Board in the Bar Association Building,

Like the Manet show at Wildenstein's, the group of oils and pastels by another great nineteenth century Frenchman, Degas, had been eagerly awaited. The Degas show, which is being held for the benefit of the Public Education Association, opened with a private view yesterday afternoon at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Military authors with ideas, political or otherwise, that they, wish to publish, must in the future obtain permission from their divisional commander, according to new army regulations effective from April 11.

The government troops' advance in the Guadalajara sector slowed down today, first because the enemy at last rallied their disordered forces near Padilla de Hita, twenty miles north of Guadalajara, and secondly because of extremely poor weather.

Proper sales accounting records, intelligently correlated to market research statistics, will eliminate many unsound sales and advertising practices, A. W. Ramsdell, sales consultant, declared yesterday in an address before the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York. Mr. Ramsdell divided the country into five territories, four of which were "aces" and the fifth a joker. The last one had the largest number of counties but the smallest percentage of retail sales.
Mrs. Olive Campbell Dick received a divorce today from Adolph M. Dick of New York on the ground of cruelty. There was a property settlement. They were married March 9, 1935.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School's quintet led the way into the quarter-finals of the eighth annual metropolitan Catholic high schools invitation basketball tournament by beating De La Salle Institute of Manhattan in a secondround battle at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus clubhouse in Brooklyn last night. Loughlin, which gained a first-round bye, won 40-29.

A syndicate headed by Isadore Lorber has purchased the two-story taxpayer at the northwest corner of 162d Street and Third Avenue, Bronx, for cash above a purchase-money mortgage of #53.500. The North Side Savings bank was the seller. Isidore Tankus was the attorney for the purchaser. Schim-mer, Kerner Feder were the brokers.
Four British yachtsmen arrived from England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with a mission that, if carried through, may mean a change in the size of the America's Cup yachts.

Britain's "flying Duchess," the 71-year-old Duchess of Bedford, was missing tonight on a solo flight. She left Woburn, in Bedfordshire, at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon in her Moth airplane to see the flooded Fenland area.
John J. O'Rourke, former newspaper man and of late assistant to the secretary of the Paterson Board of Education, died this morning at him home after an illness of several weeks. He was 67 years old.

Another possible legal obstacle to the trial of Ellis H. Parker, chief of Burlington County Detectives, and his son, Ellis H. Jr., on a charge of conspiracy in the alleged kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton lawyer, was removed today when Federal Judge William Clark overruled a demurrer to the indictment.

Passage of the Patterson-Stank Chain Store Tax Bill, which would impose a graduated tax of $1 to $500 on chain business . establishments in Pennsylvania, was urged by Governor Earle in a message to the Legislature tonight.

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at 16.80 cents a pound, c. i. f. European base ports. Export copper prices now are about 85 points below the high level of two weeks ago, but are still more than 50 points above the domestic level.

French luxuries will be displayed in the 1939 World's Fair, Charles Ritz, son of Cesar Ritz, who established the Ritz hotels, said yesterday in an interview at the RitzCarlton Hotel. Mr. Ritz, in fact, is here to see just how the French luxury trade can exhibit to best advantage.

Three Harvard Law School professors today declared that the President in making his proposals for an increase in the number of justices of the United States Supreme Court "would seem to be in a state of mind where more than the independence of the judiciary is at stake."

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was fair to slow. Lamb cuts were strong to higher and some fresh pork cuts moderately higher. Prices of other classes showed little change. Early trading in kosher meats was active and prices were steady to strong.

Harold W. Newman Jr. has resigned as vice president and general counsel of the Metropolitan Casualty Insurance Company to resume private practice. John Butler, at G. M.-P. Murphy Co., and Joseph Gassoun, at W. D. Yergason, were elected yesterday to associate membership in the New York Security Dealers Association.

Several measures are now pending at Albany, the passage of any one of which would impair the efficient and disinterested administration of New York City's school system. One of these measures is the Tenure Bill, introduced by A. SPENCER FELD, chairman of the Senate Education Committee.

President Roosevelt was initiated today as an honorary member of the Phi Beta Kappa society of the University of Georgia. The literary and debating society, which is 117 years old, has had as members Presidents Jackson, Polk, Buchanan and Tyler; Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederacy, and Napoleon III of France.

Pete Appleton of the Senators packed enough dynamite today to turn back the Red Sox, 4-1, in an exhibition game. Besides holding Boston to three hits in five innings, he whipped out a three-bagger in the fourth, tallying two runs. The score by innings:

Dr. Bess V. Cunningham, Associate Professor of Education at the University of Toledo, received the Parents Magazine Medal yesterday for the most helpful book written for parents in 1936. The presentation was made at a luncheon at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. The prize-winning book is "Family Behavior."

Madeleine la Ferriere, who used the stage name of Magda de Fontanges, told an investigating magistrate today she shot Count Charles de Chambrun, former Ambassador to Rome, because he revealed her friendship with "my Benito," meaning Premier Mussolini of Italy.

The major items in the sales at auction yesterday of eleven Manhattan properties were a fifteenstory apartment building at 106-12 West Ninety-sixth Street, the Park East Hospital Building at 112-14 East Eighty-third Street, and the three seven-story apartment and store buildings at 3,601-5 Broadway. The list follows:

The engagement of $8,570,000 gold abroad for shipment here--$7,450,000 in England and $1,120,000 in Belgium-was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the gold taken in Great Britain, $1,750,000 was obtained yesterday and $5,700,000 earlier. No imports of gold were received here yesterday.
President Roosevelt could call a halt to sit-down strikes, Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, asserted in the House today during a brief flare-up over the labor situation.
Following proceedings lasting several years, Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg finally succeeded in obtaining a declaration of nullity of his marriage by canonical courts.

Peter Barnett, 3 years old, only child of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Barnett, was burned to death in his crib early today in a fire which destroyed the Barnett home at Loantaka Way and kitchell Road in Harding Township near here.

Demands for a 20 per cent wage increase for railroad workers went to "all railroads in the United States" today, David B. Robertson, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Firemen and Enginemen, announced.

The two inside unions, representing the operating engineering staffs of the fifteen stations owned and operated by the National Broadcasting Company and the nine owned by the Columbia Broadcasting System, have completed arrangements with their managements under which the engineers of both networks will be working a five-day, forty-hour week on or before Sept. 1, it was disclosed yesterday.

Magistrate Gustave W. M. Wieboldt in Queens Traffic Court at Jamaica sent Nicholas Schwernforth, 30 years old, of 40-17 Astoria Boulevard, Astoria, to jail yesterday for.ten days for contempt of court. He said he believed it was the first time any magistrate had exercised such power since the Legislature conferred it last June.

My Dear Senator Wheeler: In response to your inquiries, I have the honor to present the following statement with respect to the work of the Supreme Court: 1. The Supreme Court is fully abreast of its work.

Thomas B. Austin, retired lumber and trim dealer, and a captain in the United States Army during the World War, died on Sunday at his home, 74 Eighty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, of influenza. He was 52 years old.

The motor trade outlook in the United Kingdom for 1937 is described as bright in a report today from Edward B. Lawson, American trade commissioner in London, made public by the Department of Commerce.

Jesse James, 185, California, pinned Gino Martinelli, 190, Italy, in the finish wrestling bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A back drop and shoulder lock, following his opponent's flying tackle, gave James victory in 34:38. It was a good exhibition and it pleased a crowd of 2,000.

Strikes were called today in two shoe factories while organization drives were pushed among 10,000 rubber workers and 3,400 cleaning and dye house employes in Greater Boston by affiliates of the Committee for industrial Organization.

The stock markets here opened the short week today in an atmosphere of quiet caution due to uncertainty about the United States and continental European markets. Giltedge issues were steady in small trading, while in the foreign bonds Brazilian issues declined on reports that Brazil would request a new extension of its foreign debt payment schedule. Transatlantic isSues were weak, with steels and nickels declining.

The Nashville (Tenn.) Carters knocked the seeded Topeka (Kan.) Sewells out of the girls' national A. A. U. basketball championship scramble tonight as seven other favorites advanced, three through byes. The Southerners took an early lead, increased it to 12-7 at the half and then spurted to a 19-16 victory after the favored Topekans had tied at 15-all.
Willem van Hoogstraten will be guest conductor of the WPA Federal Symphony Orchestra on Sunday evening at the WPA Theatre of Music.

Premier Benito Mussolini returned to Rome this afternoon after an eleven-day tour of Libya and went straight to the Palazzo Venezia to resume his work. Italian circles denied his trip had been curtailed one day by reason of international complications.

For once in their lives boys were concerned over the appearance of their smaller sisters, and they proudly ushered them to the platform of the Boys Club of New York at 287 East Tenth Street yesterday, where they made their bid for neighborhood fame in the Third Annual Little Sisters Beauty Contest.

The engagement of Miss Marjorie Elizabeth Campbell, daughter of Mrs. Alexander Carlyle Campbell of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Campbell, to Robert Lethbridge Foshay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Addison Youngs Foshay, also of Brooklyn, has been announced by her mother.

The Dartmouth College athletic council today released schedules for the Spring sports, including varsity baseball, track and lacrosse. These three teams will make Southern trips during Easter vacation. Freshman dates also were announced.

Mrs. H. Graves Terwilliger gave a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. Brian C. Curtis, who returned recently from California. The other guests included Mrs. James Breckenridge Curtis, Mrs. Ezra Winter, Mrs. Rollin Kirby, Mrs. Michael Gunn, Mrs. Gladys Trimmingham of Bermuda and Miss Eleanor Edson.

According to the Reuters correspondent at Valencia, the Spanish Government is about to inform the non-intervention committee here that it cannot admit control of the coasts of the Spanish Republic by nations that are openly intervening on behalf of the Insurgents against its. authority or to consent to ships flying the Spanish flag being visited by any one.

Colonel Lawrence Westbrook of Washington, D. C., member of the National WPA Advisory Board, and Mrs. Martha Wootton Collings of this city were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. William Turner Wootton. The Rev. Marion Boggs, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony.

Frank H. Robson, president of the Church League, with offices at 156 Fifth Avenue, New York City, died yesterday at the Elizabeth General Hospital. He underwent a major operation in November. His age was 72.

The Brooklyn Savings Bank sold to the Gotham Equities Corporation the four-story apartment house on a lot 26 by 100 feet at 910 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn. The buyer intends to alter the building into sixteen smaller suites. The Sterling Investing Corporation was the broker.
Arrangements were reported yesterday for the sale of a New York Stock Exchange membership for $110,000, a decline of $15,000 from the last previous transaction, on March 5.
Pensions for all widows in the Irish Free State are the aim of a new Widows and Orphans Amendment Bill now before the Dail.

For more than fifteen minutes yesterday afternoon Mrs. Elizabeth Maranz, a 33-year-old pianist, argued and struggled with a Negro assailant who struck her on the head with a hammer, threatened to kill her, then listened to her and finally, accepting $4 for sparing her life, fled.

On his own application: PATROLMAN-Arthur D. J. Primont, Traffic Precinct F, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 3, 1907. Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-James M. Dempsey, from 4th Precinct to Quartermaster's Department; Benjamin W. Greves, 74th Precinct, assigned to tours 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and 4 P. M. to 12 Midnight.

For many years a Broadway landmark, the William Harris Jr. offices will be moved this Friday from the Hudson Theatre, which Henry B. Harris built and which has always been associated with the family name. Mr. Harris does not yet know where his next headquarters will be and probably he won't decide immediately.

Peace seemed near in the chain store strike situation yesterday as the Department Store Employes Union conferred amicably with executives of the F. W. Woolworth Company and the H. L. Green Company. Sit-down strikers continued, however, to occupy five units in the Green chain.

Representative Robert Rich, Republican, of Pennsylvania denounced the administration fiscal policy in the House today, asserting that the President had "pulled the wool over the eyes of most of the members."

The police have set a close watch aboard the Finnish steamer Herackles, carrying seventy tons of war material, one tank, seven cannon, several heavy machine guns and shells at first believed intended for Spain.

United States Government bonds resumed their downward course yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange following only a brief respite at the opening, when prices were a shade firmer. Subsequent pressure, or rather lack of bids, however, forced values sharply lower, carrying five long-term issues to below parity at the close; four issues to the lowest levels since their issuance, and twenty-two to new low levels for 1937.

The demand for financing of mediumpriced homes throughout the nation has increased sharply, in some localities as much as 100 per cent, the presidents of the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks reported today at the opening of their semiannual conference with the Federal

Gilbert. F. Heublein, founder of the Heublein Hotel, died last night of arteriosclerosis. He was 87 years old. At his death he was president of G. F. Heublein Bro., dealers in liquors and condiments, distributors for the United States of A-1 Sauce, the Heublein Corporation of New York, a real estate organization, and G. F. Heublein, Inc., holding company for the other companies.

Shipments and earnings of the Hudson Motor Car Company last year were the largest for any year since 1929, according to the annual report issued yesterday by the company. Consolidated net earnings in 1936 amounted to $3,305,616 after all charges, including interest, depreciation, domestic and foreign income taxes, A. E. Barit, president and general manager, said.

James Robinson of Philadelphia outpointed Don Risko of New York, Catholic Youth Organization competitor, in the feature intercity heavyweight special contest at the amateur boxing show held at the New York Athletic Club last night.

Arthur L. Phillips, presiaent the Merchants and Newark Trust Company in Newark, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital at Orange after a long illness in his sixty-fifth year. His home was at 52 Curtis Street, Maplewood.
Sylvanus Apps, Toronto center who stepped into the shoes of the famed Joe Primeau last Fall, was named today as the outstanding rookie of the National Hockey League.

The International Union of Operating Engineers, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, sought the assistance of the courts yesterday in preventing invasion of its field by John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization.

One of Senator Huey P. Long's stringent election laws was ruled out today by the Louisiana Supreme Court, which said the statute opened the door "for the practice of the grossest kind of discrimination and unfairness."

William H. Bartlett, a former Director of Public Safety in Atlantic City, died in a private hospital here yesterday after a short illness. He was 76 years old. Born in this city, he went to Atlantic City in his youth to manage the ice business established in 1857 by his father, William Good Bartlett.

The Senate passed the Navy Appropriation Bill, agreed to consider tomorrow the bill for remodeling the front of the Capitol, delayed action on a resolution to declare Joseph D. Kennedy legally eligible for appointment to the Maritime Commission, and adjourned at 3:35 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

It is only in the small college that every student has a chance to compete for positions on the athletic teams, declared Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens, N. Y. U. football coach, tonight at the tenth annual block U Dinner in honor of 203 athletes at Union College.

The executive committee of the City Fusion party decided last night at the City Club to hold a meeting of officials of the party at the Hotel Astor on the evening of March 31. A difference of opinion developed as to whether Mayor La Guardia should be endorsed for reelction at this meeting, and it is likely that approval of the Mayor will go no further than endorsement of his administration.

With two Republicans and .nine Democrats giving the necessary eleven votes, the Senate tonight adopted the Assembly resolution proposing an amendment to the constitution to legalize pari-mutuel betting at race tracks. The resolution must be adopted by the Legislature next year and then approved by the voters at a referendum before becoming effective.

Sixty Pennsylvania football candidates engaged in their first outdoor practice today on River Field. The call was issued a week ago, but owing to the bad weather Coach Harvey Harman was only able to outline the work indoors.

Generous gifts toward the 1937 quota of $4,650,000 in behalf of Jews overseas menaced with "economic, cultural and social annihilation" were urged in an appeal mailed yesterday to 30,000 Jewish leaders throughout the United States and Canada, by Rabbi Jonah B. Wise as national co-chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee campaign.

Harold J. Walter, general manager of the Uxbridge Worsted Company, said today that a wage increase for 3,500 employes of the company's seven mills in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut would go into effect next Monday.- He said the amount had not yet been determined.

Berlin Catholic lay circles were inclined today to the belief that the papal denunciation of National Socialist procedure, as set forth in the encyclical delivered to Catholic congregations yesterday,

After voluntarily circulating and signingg a pledge of loyalty through :he factories and tanneries of the Endicott Johnson corporation, 19,)OO employes have forwarded the pledge to George F. Johnson, chairman of the board, who is in Florida.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lucius R. Eastman of Axonwold, Scarsdale, N. Y., formerly of Montclair, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Margaret Eastman Sortor, to Paul Cornell French of Amherst, Mass., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Howard D. French.

The defending champions, Mrs. A. W. Paine of the Colony Club and A. G. Thacher of the Harvard Club, were defeated in a four-game firstround match as a small, but select, field started after the Metropolitan mixed doubles squash racquets championship at the Brooklyn Heights Casino last night.
A bill designed to inform users of alcoholic beverages as to "what's in, the bottle" was put before the Legislature today.

Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday comprised properties in various sections of the borough. The purchasers in several of the transactions plan to alter old buildings to bring them up to modern standards.

Donald Pearson, 14 years old, was accidentally shot dead by a schoolmate in the woods on top of the Palisades here late this afternoon. He was rushed to the Englewood Hospital, but was beyond medical aid when he arrived.

Steel ingot production in the United States this week is scheduled at 89.6 per cent of capacity, a new high record for the current movement and the highest average since September, 1929, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

Members of the joint housing committee of the Board of Estimate and Board of Aldermen who assembled at City Hall yesterday for an executive session found their meeting invaded by about 100 tenants and landlords. Instead of going ahead with the executive session the committee decided to throw the doors open and hear the speakers.

There was disconcerting gossip in the House of Commons lobby tonight concerning the health of Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, who after the coronation is to succeed Stanley Baldwin as Prime Minister.

Villanova College presented the Mendel Medal tonight to Pere Teilhard de Chardin, discoverer of the "Peking Man." His was the seventh name added to a list of Catholic scientists who have given "practical demonstration of the fact that between true science and true religion there is no real conflict."

Dr. Henry J. Wolf, long a general practitioner of medicine here, who had done also extensive work in neurology and psychiatry, died yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. Dr. Wolf, who lived at the Hotel Peter Stuyvesant, 2 West Eighty-sixth Street, was 75 years old.
Counsel for Pierre S. du Pont asked Federal District Court today to order return of $54,439 in income taxes which Mr. du Pont paid the government in 1931 under protest.
Three men were under arrest yesterday in what the police alleged was an improved form of the old "money-making game" in which several persons were defrauded of about $200,000 in recent years.

Virtual termination of the Public Works Administration as a recovery force was predicted privately by officials of the agency today as a result of a new policy on grants imposed by President Roosevelt, requiring that Federal funds for financing projects be devoted only to labor taken from relief rolls.

Special emphasis is being placed by the New York Curb Exchange upon details of the plan for dissolution of the National Leather Company. In the past, because of failure to register shares held in brokerage houses and other oversights, shareholders of companies effecting similar plans have learned of them too late and have lost their rights. Accordingly,

Several large leases on Madison Avenue were among the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday. In the main, the leases reported covered a wide area of the city and represented a varied assortment of businesses. In 385 Madison Avenue, the L. C. Mayers Company, Inc., wholesale jewelers, leased a floor of 20,600 square feet for executive and buying offices. Holmes Douglas,

Polish holders of five issues of government bonds totaling nearly $100,000,000 and payable in United States dollars are to receive an offer of a new issue of 4 1/2 per cent bonds, payable in zlotys in twentyone years, in exchange for their holdings.

The Ragaz Holding Corporation appealed to Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo yesterday for an order staying the eviction of sixty-three tenants from the fifteenstory apartment house at 51 Riverside Drive on which the New York Life Insurance Company recently foreclosed its $385,000 mortgage. The request was taken under consideration.

The Naval Appropriation Bill, carrying a total of $512,847,808 for the fiscal year 1938. was passed by the Senate this afternoon exactly as it came from the Committee on Appropriations. The vote was 64 to 11,

Thirty-nine men and women who participated in a sit-down strike last Wednesday at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn received a hearing yesterday in Flatbush Court on charges of disorderly conduct and violation of Section 1910 of the Penal Code, which concerns the endangering of life by refusing to work.

Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L. I., a professional, established a new women's competitive record for the Forest Hills course today in winning the medal of the annual Augusta invitation match play golf tournament, with a 37. 39-76.
The 90-ton motorship Richard Campbell, completing her maiden voyage from Nassau to Bimini, Miami and return, ran aground on Great Bahama Bank, off the Island of Andros, Friday morning.

Mr. and Mrs. F. F. Blaisdell of Red Bank have announced the betrothal of their daughter, Miss Frances Blaisdell, to Alexander Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jan Williams of New York. The marriage will take place on April 20 in the clubhouse of the Beethoven Association in New York.

The failure of officials of Allegheny County, Pa., to receive a single all or none bid yesterday for an issue of $5,500,000 of its one-tothirty-year bonds was attributed in official quarters to the general uneasiness in banking circles over bond market conditions. A few optional bids for parts of the issue were submitted.

Abraham Cohen, lawyer-defendant in the restaurant racket trial, made his own plea to a Supreme Court jury last night. Cohen, on trial as counsel for the Metropolitan Restaurant and Cafeteria Association, had offered only the testimony of several character witnesses in the course of the trial before Justice Philip J. McCook.
Termination on March 31 of the price-fixing features of the present Milk Control Law was recommended to the Legislature tonight by its special investigating committee.

A baby daughter born in Fitkin Hospital here to Mr. and Mrs. R. N. Matthews of 568 Deal Parkway in near-by Allenhurst is the first female child born in the Matthews family in at least 100 years, according to the child's father and grandmother.
Contracts were awarded at the quartermaster depot today as follows: Invitation 205, Warrenton Woolen Mills, for 300 yards of Special material for officers' uniforms, at $4.50, $4.75 and $5.00, net.
Perry firemen, responding to a rural fire alarm, found themselves unable to fight the flames because no water was available, so they spent their time listening to a phonograph concert.

The concert given by the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall offered as a novelty the first American performance of the piano concerto of Vittorio Giannini, the young American-Italian composer of this city and brother of Miss Dusolina Giannini of the Metropolitan Opera Association. The piano part was admirably played by Miss Rosalyn Tureck.

A squad of fifty oarsmen reportto to Coach Allen Walz as Maihattan's sixth season of rowing was inaugurated yesterday. No time was wasted in starting work and four shells were launched from the Manhattan boat house on the Harlem River for a drill which lasted more than an hour.
Governor Lehman submitted to the Senate for confirmation the nomination of Paul Livoti of Queens as a member of the City Court of New York.

Strikes reduced automobile production further last week, at a time when a gain was seasonal, causing the adjusted index to decline to 93.3 from 98.1 (revised). It was 102.4 for the week ended March 21, 1936.

A dirt track race driver who had survived several crack-ups without injury was killed today when a gasoline truck was struck by a Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Lines train at an unprotected crossing in Pennsauken Township, near here.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, for the first time in its history, put in an appearance yesterday, acting as an aide to the court in proceedings in reorganisation under. Section ?? of the Bankruptcy Act.

For a time yesterday there was a rumor knocking about Wall Street that Europe, always disposed to interpret American news developments as sensationally as possible, had been responsible for much of the pressure on stocks and bonds in the last week. A check-up among firms with extensive European connections, however, gave a different picture.

Enraged when a 10-year-old boy came to his mother's defense in an argument over the loan of $100, a man listed by police as Anthony Dorki, 45 years old, of 10 Cypress Street, Springfield, Mass., threw the child through a closed fourth-story window and then jumped after him here tonight. The man was killed and the child critically injured.

Funeral services for United States Marshal Albert C. Benninger, Democratic leader of the Sixth Assembly District, Queens, were held yesterday at St. Pancras Catholic Church, Myrtle Avenue and Sixtyeighth Street, Glendale. He died last Thursday.
American Electric Securities Corporation-Gross income for 1936 was $323,961, against $170,799 in 1935. The more recent figure included

At the close of its third open meeting yesterday the nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange found itself with only one name suggested for the presidency, that of the incumbent, Charles R. Gay. The committee is accordingly virtually certain to renominate Mr. Gay on April 10, in which case reelection on May 12 will be all but assured.

Objection by Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes to increasing the size of the Supreme Court was flashed upon the Senate Judiciary Committee today by opponents of President Roosevelt's plan for judiciary reorganization,

Lower prices to consumers from manufacturers of branded goods "believed overpriced" under the Feld-Crawford law will be sought by a committee of the Consolidated Brooklyn Retail Pharmacists, Inc., it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors of the organization at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn. The association comprises 1,200 of 1,500 retail druggists in the borough, according to Percy Goldman, vice president, who made the announcement.

Captain Frederick J. Bennett, Atlantic Coast operating manager for the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 441 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, in his fifty-sixth year.

The Bermuda Athletic Association Rugby team defeated the Yale University fifteen, 4 to 0, today in the fifth annual tournament here. Fennessey made the only score of the game seventeen minutes after the start, when he drop-kicked a field goal from twenty-five yards out.

Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan today approved a settlement prepared by Carl K. Withers, State Banking Commissioner, whereby the Commercial Casualty Insurance Company of Newark agrees to pay $852,192 to the New Jersey Fidelity and Plate Glass Insurance Company, also of Newark.

Homer Martin, president, and Richard T. Frankensteen, Detroit organizational director for the United Auto mobile Workers of America, caused a stir at this afternoon's negotiations between the union and the Chrysler Corporation by producing documents which purported to be photostatic copies of records showing the company had maintained a "blacklist" to keep active union members out of its employ.

Boston Elevated Railway--February: Excess of cost of service over receipts, $120,410, against an excess of $83,606 in February, 1936. Eleven months to Feb. 28: Excess of cost over receipts, $1,873,590, against $2,276,481 in corresponding period a year before.

Hopes of vacationists for a mosquitoless millennium were dashed today by experts who are meeting here. Dr. L. L. Williams, senior malaria surgeon of the Public Health Service, said at a meeting of the Florida Anti-Mosquito Association:

The Keith-Albee-Orpheum Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1936 a net profit, after all charges, including $63,600 provision for surtax on undistributed profits, of $1,237,141, equal to $19.23 each on 64,304 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, on which arrears on Dec. 31 were $24.50 a share. In 1935 earnings were $403,073, or $6.26 a share earned on the preferred stock in 1935.
Chicago's largest current sit-down strike ended peacefully tonight when 800 employes heeded orders from the police to evacuate the Wilson-Jones Company plant.

Belgium's future, not only in Europe but as an African colonial power, depends to a large extent upon the result of the conversations begun here tonight by her King, Leopold III. It is now tacitly admitted in diplomatic circles that his so-called unofficial visit is a move of the first importance in the tactical manoeuvring among the great powers.

Completion of installation of the new radio apparatus at Fort Shafter, Hawaii, and in the Munitions Building here was celebrated today wtih an exchange of messages between Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the Hawaiian Department, and Major Gen. J. B. Allison, chief signal officer.

Colleen Moore, screen actress, arrived here today from Birmingham, Ala., to attend preliminary activities in connection with the exhibition of her $435,000 doll house at the Kresge department store for the benefit of the Hospital and Home for Crippled Children here and the New Jersey Orthopedic Hospital and Dispensary in Orange.
A total of $188,422,000 was bid for the two series of Treasury bills offered on March 19, the Treasury announced. Of this, $100,197,000 was accepted.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith has a trip to Europe under consideration, it became known yesterday. His plans contemplate visits to Paris and Rome, where it is expected that he will be received by Pope Pius XI. He will be accompanied by Mrs. Smith and friends.
By unanimouse vote the Assembly passed tonight the bill of Assemblyman Ehrlich, Buffalo Republican, sharpening the teeth of the Domestic Relations Law to guard against child marriages.

A General Sessions jury acquitted last night Henry Steinberg, 31 years old, an attorney, of 541 Hinsdale Street, Brooklyn, following his trial on a charge of grand larceny. The jury returned its verdict at 9:30 P. M., after five and a half hours of deliberation. The case against the defendant had resulted from the alleged changing of the date of an accident in an insurance claim.

Colonel Jake Ruppert dared the fates at Firemen's Field today and his Yankees paid the consequences. Warned last week in Tampa he was a jinx as a first-ball thrower, the Yankee owner nevertheless heaved the first ball for the game between his world champion outfit and the Newark Bears.
Governor Blanton Winship today accepted for the people of Puerto Rico two hydroelectric plants with a generating capacity of 9,000 horsepower from the Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration.

Following revocation today of 183 licenses of operators for "leaving the scene of accidents" during the first two months of the year, Charles A. Harnett, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, called upon the courts to take drastic action in dealing with "hit and run" drivers of automobiles.

For a fee and publicity, Ray Woods, professional diver, leaped from the San Francisco-Oakland Bridge this afternoon and broke his back. His wife and mother watched the plunge from a boat beneath the bridge, saw him flounder through the air when a gust of wind whipped his body, and then crashed to the water with a terrific splash.

The statement of Chief Justice HUGHES which was read to the Senate committee yesterday-a statement specifically approved by Justice BRANDEIS and Justice VAN DEVANTER, and generally in accord with the views of all other members of the Supreme Courtought definitely to dispose of one argument which has been advanced in behalf of the President's proposal.

Deep-seated objections by the government that indicate high hurdles stand in the way of the American-British reciprocal trade treaty envisaged by Secretary of State Cordell Hull were stated bluntly today by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin.

Prize awards in its fifteenth biennial exhibition of contemporary American oil paintings, which is to be opened to the public on Easter Sunday and to continue until May 9, were announced today by the Corcoran Gallery of Art.

A three-unit plant for the manufacture of automobile motors and axles will be constructed here this year by the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation, Marvin E. Coyle, general manager, announced today.

The world today needs another Goethe who can hold fast to his ideals of peace when war threatens, Herman A. Heydt, national president of the Goethe Society of America, said yesterday at memorial ceremonies held in Bryant Park to commemorate the 105th anniversary of the death of the poetauthor.

Various signs indicate a hardening in the attitude of the Western powers and others toward Italian policy following upon the cruel methods used by Marshal Rodolfo Graziani in Addis Ababa, the words and deeds of Premier Benito Mussolini in Libya last week and the landing of Italian troops in Spain notwithstanding the international agreement of Feb. 20 placing a ban on all volunteers.

Following is the text of the letter sent to Governor Murphy today by Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, stating the union's position in the Chrysler strike, especially on its demand for sole collective bargaining rights:

The new municipal stadium at Randalls Island will be the scene of the annual metropolitan collegiate track and field championships on Friday, April 30, it was learned yesterday. The games, which bring together the varsity athletes of Columbia, New York University, Manhattan, Fordham and City College in the full intercollegiate program, will be held in the early evening so that the athletes will not miss late classes.
Mrs. James McCosh Magie will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 930 Park Avenue, for members of the Cribside Social Service Committee of the Babies Hospital.

Up-State keglers continued their successful bombardment of the tenpins through the thirteenth session of maple crashing in the American Bowling Congress's thirty-seventh annual championships yesterday.

The Kings County grand jury, which has been investigating the charge by Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor last August that Brooklyn had the dirtiest streets in the city, handed up an indictment yesterday charging thirteen persons with extorting money for the removal of garbage and waste.
The community high school party was enlivened by some spiked punch, but the revelry had an aftermath today in the suspension of fourteen students.

The military inquiry into the New London school explosion which killed 455 children and teachers ended today with testimony of Dr. E. P. School of the University of Texas, an explosion expert, that in his opinion accumulated gas under the basement floor caused the blast.

The strike of 700 employes of the Malleable Iron Fittings Company of Branford was settled today and work will be resumed tomorrow. The company agreed to recognize the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin W'orkers for collective bargaining for its own members, but not for all employes, as the union demanded.

Cully A. Cobb, chief of the cotton section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, said today over the radio for the information of Southern cotton growers that a 14,000,000bale crop and 1932 prices were not unlikely next Fall if they permitted themselves to be influenced by cuRrent prices for the staple and increase their acreage by 15 per cent as indicated.

The division among Mexican farmers of more than 20,000 acres of land in Lower California belonging heretofore to the American Colorado River Land Company began today. Red flags flew near Mexicali, and government officials made speeches, while bands played as the peasants marched onto the land, which in the future will be worked on a communal basis.

Chairman Mansfield predicted today early approval by the House Rivers and Harbors Committee of a bill authorizing army engineers to spend about $25,000,000 on improvements to rivers and harbors throughout the nation.

Business failures in the United States totaled 193 for the week ended March 18, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 170 the week before and with 218 for the correspending week of 1936.
Spring is here, but it is greatly changed since the poet CHAUCER'S time. In his day when the sweet April showers had broken

Conflicting opinion between Mayor J. Tormos Diego and the insular police chief, Enrique de Orbeta, resulting in Mayor Tormos's first granting and then withdrawing at the last minute a permit for Nationalists to parade at Ponce, seems, by general opinion, to have been the cause of Sunday's street rioting and bloodshed.
The Navy Department awarded contracts today for 7,003,500 pounds of steel for submarine and destroyer construction. The cost will be $292.709.76.

Consumers have confidence in advertising endorsements given by middle-class women, but are skeptical of those obtained from society women or motion-picture stars, Mrs. Anna Steese Richardson, associate editor of the Woman's Home Companion, said last night in an address before the class in advertising sponsored by the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., at THE TIMES. In the course of her talk.

Mrs. George Horace Lorimer was appointed today to the chairmanship of women's activities for the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the drafting of the American Constitution, to be held at Convention Hall on April 30.

Miss Edith Moira Kavanagh, daughter of Mrs. Rupert MacMurrough Kavanagh of 1 Fifth Avenue and the late Mr. Kavanagh, will be married on the afternoon of April 3 to Joseph Andreae Mosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman O. Mosenthal of this city.
It won't count in the standings after April 20, but right now it must be recorded that Chuck Dressen and his rambunctious young Reds are pennant-winners against the Dodgers.

Charles B. Henderson of 280 Warren Street, Brooklyn, who died penniless in Kings County Hospital on Sunday, was identified yesterday as a former United States vice consul at Johannesburg, South Africa. The identification was made by James H. Gilvarry, an attorney, who was his landlord.
Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of the President, paid an informal visit yesterday afternoon to the park on the lower East Side that was named for her and opened in 1934.

Automobile accidents, deaths and injuries decreased last week and week-end as compared to the corresponding periods of last year, a report issued yesterday by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler showed. For the first time in some weeks the figures lessened in all categories.
Jacques Cavalier, director of higher education in France since 1926, died today of injuries suffered when he was struck by a motor-cycle yesterday. He was 67 years old.
A claim for payment of $69,000,000 was made by the Norwegian Government in a note transmitted today to the United States Department of State.

The marriage of democracy and capitalism has reached the stage when capitalism must suppress democracy or democracy must transform capitalism, Professor Harold J. Laski of the London School of Economics and Political Science declared last night in a debate with A. A. Berle at the New School for Social Research. The topic of the debate was "Has Democracy Vitality Today?"

Fordham's senior class conquered Team K of City College, 35-23, in a basketball game between the intramural champions of the two schools at the Fordham gymnasium yesterday. The contest was played with the elimination of the center tap except at the beginning of each half and the action appeared to be considerably faster.
William B. Redmond 2d, a 27-year-old Nashville Negro, made in Chancery Court today his protest against the refusal of educational officials to enroll him in the University of Tennessee.

John McIntosh, 21 years old, of 20-04 Steinway Street, Astoria, testified yesterday afternoon before Judge Downs and a jury in Queens County Court that he beat his father, Robert, 59, to death in their home last Dec. 12 in self-defense after his father had attacked his mother and him with a knife. McIntosh is on trial for murder in the second degree.

Addressing the annual meeting of the Virginia Farm Bureau tonight, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, made a bid for agrarian support of President Roosevelt's plan to clear the way for New Deal reforms by enlarging the Supreme Court.

A new plan of reorganization for the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation and its subsidiary, the Chesapeake Export Company, was filed today in Federal court here by a creditors' committee representing 700 creditors holding more than 25 per cent, or $622,000, in unsecured claims. Judge William H. Holly, who has had jurisdiction over the two companies since April, 1935, ordered copies of the plan sent to all claimants and stockholders and set a hearing for April 26.

After a ban on the plan had been voted by the City Council, the United Automobile Workers of America won tentative permission late tonight to hold a mass meeting of 100,000 to 200,000 workers tomorrow afternoon in Cadillac Square, the heart of Detroit.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on March 17, shows decreases for the week of $103,000,000 in total loans and investments, $108,000,000 in demand depositsadjusted and $19,000,000 in time deposits, and increases of $40,000,000 in government deposits, $44,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, $14,000,000 in deposits.credited to foreign banks, $58,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, and $85,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Following last week's decline of $3 a bale, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered $1 to $1.50 a bale at one time yesterday in response to a sharp upturn in foreign markets. Houses with foreign connections bought heavily, particularly in the new crop months, but weakness in the stock market here caused commission-house realizing which left the list with gains of 11 to 22 points.

Spencer Tunnell Jr. of New York had as luncheon guests at the Bath Club today Mrs. Dwight Anderson and Miss Marion Pewogel. Among those invited by Mrs. C. Tuthill Warren to a luncheon she will give at the Roney Plaza Hotel on Wednesday are Mrs. Theodore A. Lucchesi, New York;

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt does not mind riding on a day coach, she informed the Jackson reception committee today. The committee, arranging for Mrs. Roosevelt's appearance on a lecture tour here Wednesday, was disturbed when advised that the local train she would ride from Meridian to Jackson carried no Pullman.

The Westchester County Savings Bank sold to a client of Prince Ripley, Inc., broker, the four-family flat at 152 Chatterton Avenue, White Plains. The same broker sold for the Hartridge Estates, Inc., an acre in the Knollwood Manor section of Greenburgh. Edward F.. Warntje, the buyer, plans to erect a house for his own occupancy.

Plans to add ten stories to the existing six-story laundry and office building on the northwest side of the College of Physicians and Surgeons in the Columbia Medical Center at 165th to 168th Street, Broadway to Fort Washington Avenue, were filed yesterday. The addition will provide a number of laborastories for research purposes.

Whether an equal rights amendment to the Constitution would be the shortest way to greater freedom for women, or the rights would be lost in a maze of judicial interpretation, was argued yesterday afternoon by six leaders of four national women's organizations, in a symposium arranged by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

The quest for the Stanley Cup and its attendant honor, the professional hockey championship of the world, will start tonight. Six teams, the survivors of the regular National Hockey League season, which came to a close on Sunday night, will compete in the various rounds of play that eventually will produce the champion.

Forty-five hunger-striking miners, suffering from privation and exposure, were hoisted to the surface today by their self-entombed comrades at the Americanfinanced Giesche mine, near here. They were taken to a hospital.

The upward movement of the past year in prices and business activity, lately much accelerated, has occurred in England as in the United States. British prices have in fact risen more rapidly than ours, and talk of a possible "cyclical reaction" shortly ahead has been heard at London as well as at Washington. The London Economist,
After a stormy and at times exceedingly acrimonious debate the Senate shortly before midnight passed Governor Lehman's main budget bill by a vote of 46 to 4.

With retail attention concentrated on building up heavy pre-Easter trade this week, buying activity in the wholesale markets here yesterday was largely confined to fill-ins for quick delivery to near-by stores. Weather conditions and labor difficulties, however, cut the volume of late fill-ins below what was expected. However,

The American Federation of Actors will hold its annual election on May 6 at Union Church Hall, the following candidates having been chosen by a nominating committee for three-year terms: President, Rudy Vallee (incumbent); honorary president, Sophie Tucker; vice presidents, Joe Laurie Jr., Ben Bernie, Chick York and Harry Richman; executive secretary, Ralph Whitehead; treasurer, Charles Mosconi.

A pre-Easter parade of what should be worn by the well-dressed World's Fair building was opened yesterday afternoon at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street. Discreet use of color, simple lines, mural paintings, sculpture and landscaping were recommended by the fashion experts.

The hard lot of British Prime Ministers, who draw a lower salary than the Lord Chancellor and no more than some others of their Cabinet colleagues to whom they have given posts, is to be relieved by a bill the government is introducing in the House of Commons tomorrow.

A syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will offer today 35,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of $100 par value of the Broadway Department Store. Inc., at $100 a share. Other members of the group are the William R. Staats Company, the Pacific Company of California, Bateman, Eichler Co., Battson, Barnes Lester, Inc.; GriffithWagenseller Durst and Schwabacher Co.

The administration was accused in the House today by Representative Engel, Republican, of Michigan, of having abused the mail franking privilege and of having used $72,000,000 for "purely political propaganda."
To Report to Medical Chief The following ununiformed firemen shall be directed to report to the chief medical officer at these headquarters at 12 o'clock noon on date specified:

Reports that restrictions on exports of wheat by Argentina were simply a question of a short time had a drastic effect on the world's wheat markets today. Prices advanced as much as 5 3/8 cents a bushel at the extreme with Buenos Aires in the lead. A wild wave of speculative buying developed, both here and abroad, with Liverpool closing 3 3/8 to 4 3/8 cents higher.

Secretary Perkins continued today, but without success, her efforts to bring together for a conference John L. Lewis and Walter Chrysler. Mr. Chrysler was reported as insisting that the law restore to the Chrysler Corporation the property seized by sit-down strikers and as adhering to his refusal to confer until they had vacated the plants they occupy in defiance of the courts.

A city-wide, one-day strike against Providence retail stores ended early today when workers accepted a preferred agreement of store owners granting wage increases and recognition of the Committee for Industrial Organization as a bargaining agency for members only.

Mrs. Ethel Beach Wales, wife of James Albert Wales, president of the Wales Advertising Company, Inc., of 230 Park Avenue, this city, died on Sunday at her home, 1,738 Elm Street, Stratford, Conn., after a long illness. Born in Stratford, Mrs. Wales was the daughter of the late Frederick C. Beach, editor of The American Photographer, and the late Mrs. Margaret Gilbert Beach.

Colonel Charles Goff Thomson, widely known to tourists from all over the world, and superintendent of Yosemite National Park since 1929, died today in the Park Hospital from a heart attack. He was 54 years old.

The appointment of a special committee to investigate Nazi and Communist "propaganda" and organizations in this country was urged today by Representatives Schulte of Indiana and McCormack of Massachusetts before the House Rules Committee.

Supreme Court Justice Philip A. Brennan, sitting in the Second Judicial District in Brooklyn, held yesterday that the proportional representation system for voting on City Councilmen in the Fall election was unconstitutional.

The Montreal Maroons, riding their regular Season winning streak into the Stanley Cup play-offs, defeated the powerful Boston Bruins in the first battle of the second-place series tonight, 4-1. A crowd of 12,000 atched the contest in the Forum.

Announcement, has been made of the engagement of Miss Rita Agnes McKenna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McKenna of Pelham, N. Y., to Egbert Rollo Ferguson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Egbert R. Ferguson of Lakewood, Ohio.

All business-enterprises and civil authorities are being urged to create a civilian reserve which in case of war can immediately take the places of men called to the colors. The Labor Front's official organ contends that in the next war, even more than in the World War, all men able to bear arms will be sent to the front, irrespective of their positions or their "indispensability." The reserve,

The American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday reduced the price of lead 5 points to 6.95 cents a pound at New York. It is understood that the St. Joseph Lead Company, the other important producer of lead, does not intend to follow the decline.

The Spanish Embassy here let it be known tonight that the Valencia government was about to request the Secretary General of the League of Nations to summon the Council to meet in order to examine the problem arising from the presence in Spain of a fully constituted division of Italian troops.

An alleged hold-up man whose in tended victim snatched his pisto and knocked him out with the but? was held in $100,000 bail by Magis trate Anthony P. Savarese in Fel ony Court, Ridgewood, Queens, yesterday for the action of the grand jury.
Did the Chief Justice of the United States, in his letter to Senator Wheeler, render for himself and his brethren an advisory opinion on a constitutional question when he wrote:

Passenger traffic on the Interborough Rapid Transit System, including both subway and elevated divisions, totaled 80,531,457 in February, according to the monthly report of Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, filed yesterday with Judge Julian W. Mack in the Federal District Court.
The Senate today passed and sent to the House the Connally bill to extend the east front of the original part

United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies is successfully breaking all precedents of the Moscow diplomatic corps. Tonight he gave a dinner to Red army chiefs, only two or three of whom have ever accepted foreigners' invitations.
The professional brigade took advantage of rare golfing today in the first round of the North and South open tournament to give the famous Pinehurst course its worst lacing in many moons.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Current Events," H. V. Kaltenborn. Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eightysecond Street and Fifth Avenue.
