"The Egyptian Collection," General Tour, 11 A. M.; "Introduction to the Language of Painting," Roberta M. Fansler, 4 P. M.; "Gothic Architecture: Windows (Mathews Lecture)." Leopold Arnaud, 4 P. M.

A group of 168 members of the Actors Equity Association yesterday petitioned the Equity Council to hold an immediate referendum on the question of secret balloting. No date has been set for the referendum which now becomes mandatory. At last Friday's meeting of Equity a proposed

The Senate approved the bill authorizing remodeling of the east front of the Capitol, received a favorable report on the nomination of Joseph P. Kennedy to be chairman of the Maritime Commission, ratified the Fisheries Convention between the United States and Canada and adjourned at 2:50 P. M. until noon tomorrow. The Judiciary Committee heard Raymond Moley and Representative Lemke on the President's court plan.

Miss Rose Weld gave a tea yesterday at the Continental for members of the debutante committee and others active in the production, "Come Across," to be presented on April 9 at Mecca Temple by the Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard.

Kings County Judge George W. Martin granted yesterday a defense motion for a commission to inquire into the sanity of Salvatore Ossido, 26-year-old Brooklyn barber, under indictment for criminally assaulting and murdering 9-year-old Einer Sporrer.

Until the world actually disarms, the United States should maintain an army and navy so strong that she can command peace by forbidding any trespass on her rights, Colonel Edward M. House declares in an article in the April issue of The American Legion Monthly, which will be issued tomorrow.

Brushing aside every objection advanced by the La Guardia administration, Democratic members of the Senate, with some Republicans aiding, joined today in passing a series of bills affecting employment on the city's Independent subway, sponscored by Senator Julius S. Berg of the Bronx, which, opponents held, would imperil the five-cent fare.

Miss Mildred Davis, daughter of John M. Davis of 1,035 Fifth Avenue, has chosen the afternoon of April 6 as the date for her marriage to John B. Gates, son of Albert Oscar Gates of New Haven. The wedding will take place in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

Conklin, Ohio State left fielder wno went into the game in the sixth inning, accounted personally for Ohio State's second victory in two days over Washington and Lee today by hitting a triple in the eighth with the bases loaded and the score tied at 7-all. He came home himself on a passed ball to give the visitors an 11-to-7 victory.

The directors of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, 555 Prospect Place, declared in a statement yesterday that they would not reinstate the fifty-six discharged employes who took part in sit-down strikes that badly crippled services at the hospital last week. The directors also asserted that they would not deal with the Hospital Employes Union, Local 171, which has undertaken to represent the employes in collective bargaining.

Fireman 1st Grade George P. W. Zimmerman, Engine 271, died March 21. Funeral will take place from Funeral Parlor of August Herrlich, 68-59 Fresh Pond Rd., Glendale, Queens, at 11 A. M., Wednesday, March 24. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery. Funeral services will be held at 9 P. M., Tuesday, March 23.
Errors afield and inability to cash in on their greatest hitting spree to date tumbled the Reds to a 7-to-4 defeat today at the hands of the Red Sox in an exhibition game.

The Brooklyn Real Estate Board announced yesterday that it would support the bill to set up a State mortgage bank system, "provided some minor amendments are made." The measure now is before the State Legislature.

Ever since Virgil Geddes's "The Earth Between" was put on in the Village eight years ago many people have been expecting great things of him. They did not, for instance, expect "Native Ground," which was acted at the Venice last evening by the Experimental Theatre section of the WPA.

In the opener of the new Granniss Cups polo tournament Billy Nicholls's Old Westbury team got off to an early lead against Aknusti and withstood a wild third-period rally to win, 8 to 6 1/2, last night at the Squadron A Armory.

The Springfield Indians punched home a game-winning goal in the second period of an International-American Hockey League play-off with the Providence Reds tonight to win, 1-0, in the semifinal eastern division series before a capacity crowd.

The police announced today that Willi Seligmann, proprietor of the Seligmann banking house, had killed himself three days ago and that his bank had collapsed following the discovery of a shortage of 600,000 to 800,000 marks.

The St. John's University track team will engage in four dual meets during the coming outdoor season, it was announced yesterday. The Indian track and field men will oppose Rutgers University, Rhode Island State,

Newton H. Fairbanks, Republican member of the Ohio Legislature from Clark County and brother of the late Charles W. Fairbanks, who was Vice President of the United States under Theodore Roosevelt, died yesterday at his home in Springfield,

A general theory of church unity was endorsed by nine Protestant clergymen of Tarrytown, North Tarrytown and Pocantico Hills this afternoon, but they avoided acting specifically on a church consolidation plan advanced by John D. Rockefeller Jr. on March 7, when he spoke at a union Lenten service held in Christ Episcopal Church.

Dr. Hans Luther is to be replaced as German Ambassador to the United States by Dr. Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff, Acting Under-Secretary of the German Foreign Office. A request for approval of the appointment was received by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today through the United. States Embassy in Berlin. A favorable reply is being transmitted.

Miss M. Thayer Gibbons gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Doris Terhune to celebrate the latter's birthday. Other guests were Mrs. Ludlow Elliman, the Misses Alice Andre, Mary Schley, Lucy Hutchinson, Elizabeth Russell, Barbara Hoge, Elizabeth Alexandre and Suzanne Murray.

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. Harvey T. Deurer of Maplewood for the wedding of their daughter, Miss Cecile Marie Deurer, and Edward John Iverson, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. N. Iverson of Trvington.

Stockholders of the Tennessee Corporation at their annual meeting on April 22 will be asked to approve an issue of' convertible bonds, debentures or notes not to exceed $5,000,000, the proceeds from which would be used to refund the company's 6 per cent debentures, Series B and C, aggregating on March 16, last, $4,046,300, due on March 1, 1944, and callable on Sept. 1, 1937, at 103 1/2.

The Louisville Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday that, owing to the fact that it still was impossible to determine accurately the amount of damage sustained by the company during the recent floods, it had postponed taking any action on the common-stock dividends for the quarter ended on Feb. 28, 1937.

David E. Grange applied yesterday to the Supreme Court for an order enjoining insurgent elements in the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union, of which he contends he is the president, from disputing his authority or setting up their own machinery to collect dues and conduct union business.

Governor MURPHY expresses the hope that his conference today with Mr. JOHN L. LEWIS and Mr. WALTER CHRYSLER will result in an agreement which will make it unnecessary for the State of Michigan to enforce the law against the sit-down strikers in the Chrysler plants.

The General Foods Corporation had last year the largest sales since 1929 and the best earnings since 1931, according to C. M. Chester, chairman of the board, and Clarence Francis, president, in their remarks to shareholders and employes as contained in the pamphlet report, made public for today.

City boys with self-reliance, adaptability and "gumption" can become as proficient at farming as country boys, R. W. Stimson, Massachusetts State Supervisor for Agricultural Education, said yesterday at the annual conference at the Hotel Lincoln of executive officers, State directors and State supervisors of agriculture.

Organized as a timely foil for the present deluge of French painting, the exhibition of nineteenth century American art that opened this week in the Marie Sterner Gallery, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, proves to be an event of more than ordinary interest.

Several oil-company officials who recently instituted a lawsuit in behalf of the Pan-American Petroleum and Transport Company against the Standard Oil Companies of New Jersey and Indiana and others announced today that they would resign soon.

Stockholders of the National Gypsum Company at a meeting in Buffalo approved yesterday a split-up of the common stock, 2,500,000 shares of $1-par common stock being authorized to replace the present stock on the basis of four new shares for each Class A share and six new shares for each Class B share.
Ten years of litigation ended in the Court of Appeals today when the tribunal unanimously confirmed the title of the State to Jones Beach in Suffolk County.

Two bills to require financial reports by labor unions and bar sit-down strikes were assailed today by representatives of organized labor as designed to "destroy union labor" and as "forerunners of fascism." The measures are sponsored by Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth, Republican, of Livingston.
